title: Bridge
description: One of the many sad bridge stories of 1989 concerns the final of the Australian National Team Championship, played in Canberra, the capital, in February. It attracted an entry of 178 teams, far more than an equivalent American event would do, and there were players from New Zealand, Japan and the United States.

title: He Has Tyson On His Mind
description: THOSE on Donovan Ruddock's Christmas-card list got a personalized card this year.

title: For Dinkins, Pomp, Ceremony, Triumph And a Dream Realized
description: The walls of David N. Dinkins's borough president's office, once covered with photographs recounting his political career, are bare except for dozens of nails from which the pictures hung. They have been packed away until his new office at City Hall is prepared.

title: Army Doesn't Have to Compete With Marines;   Why We Need a Navy
description: To the Editor:

title: Students Must Get to School and Back Safely
description: To the Editor:

title: Calm Sought in Argentina
description: The Minister of Economy, Antonio Erman Gonzalez, tried Saturday to calm fears concerning a new economic policy to be announced this week as prices surged and Argentines faced the threat of hyperinflation.

title: ISRAELI OR DRIVER? HOW SIGNALS CROSS
description: United States officials in Panama who thought they had captured Mike Harari, an Israeli identified as a close associate of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, may have mistaken the Israeli's driver for Mr. Harari, Administration officials said today.

title: How to Rewire America
description: Dial a number and the video screen in your wall becomes a window into the place you are calling. You can see and converse with people on the other side, even slide documents through the window, via fax machine. All this could be possible once the country is wired with fiber-optic cable. But that will cost some $250 billion and won't happen for decades unless Washington decides it should be done sooner. If so, how? And who should pay? Unlike the copper wires of telephone or cable television, fiber-optic cable can carry vast flows of information, including high-quality video and audio signals. This hair-thin cable is a channel for pulses of laser light that carry information as a stream of numbers, giving transmission of higher quality than ordinary signals. Transmission can be two way, allowing interactive video as well as voice.

title: Exchange Chairman Aims to Polish Image Of Futures Industry: LEO MELAMED, Chicago Merc
description: In the world of commodity futures trading, Leo Melamed is widely considered to be the chief lobbyist, spokesman and public relations man - and an adept one at that. In 1990, Mr. Melamed, the chairman of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange's executive committee, will need all those qualities and others to restore his industry's tarnished image.

title: CNN Lawsuit On Vietnam
description: Turner Broadcasting System Inc. is suing the Bush Administration to be allowed to provide its Cable News Network to Vietnam.

title: How Ancients Improved On Their Natural Good Looks
description: The Israel Museum has opened an exhibition on a part of ancient life that is not often presented today - cosmetics and toiletries in use from ancient Egyptian times through the Roman Empire.

title: Bronx Man Killed on Subway As He Tries to Stop Robbery
description: A Bronx man was fatally shot Saturday night on the subway after trying to stop a man who had stolen a portable cassette player from his friend, the police said yesterday.

title: Economists Take Up The World's Problems
description: An ancient economics scoring rule is that a session is a failure when the size of the panel exceeds the size of the audience; by that measure, most of the sessions at the annual convention of the American Economic Association here were a success.

title: India Bars Filming of a Documentary on Calcutta
description: The Indian Government has withdrawn permission for the filming of the book ''The City of Joy'' on the ground that it would show Calcutta in too negative a light.

title: Morocco Pleads for Aid as Oil From Huge Spill Nears Coast
description: Morocco appealed for help today in its struggle to keep a 230-square-mile oil slick away from its coastline and to halt the spill that began when an Iranian tanker was damaged in an explosion nearly two weeks ago.

title: Ruling in Lincoln Savings Lawsuit
description: A Federal district judge in Arizona granted a Government motion on Friday to dismiss three counts in a lawsuit related to the Government's seizure of the insolvent Lincoln Savings and Loan Association in California.

title: A Melee Interrupts Testimony by Chun
description: Former President Chun Doo Hwan testified for the first time today about his repressive eight-year martial rule over South Korea, but he was cut short as a melee broke out in the National Assembly and walked out amid screams, curses and shoving.

title: TV Ads Are Spreading To Subways and Malls
description: There seems to be no escaping the long arm of Madison Avenue. Advertisers have now found a way to intrude electronically into people's lives while they browse in shopping malls or wait for buses or trains.

title: Steelers Top Oilers With 50-Yard Field Goal
description: Gary Anderson is the third-most accurate kicker in National Football League history. Today, he was No. 1 for the Pittsburgh Steelers.

title: Washington Talk;   For Bush in 1989, the Focus Was Foreign Policy
description: His friends always said George Bush would be a foreign-policy President, but even they didn't expect this.

title: Officer's Body Found; Husband Is Charged
description: A 26-year-old police officer was found dead in a ditch near the Long Island Expressway yesterday, the police said. The officer was found two hours after detectives arrested her husband in the shooting of a man he had found with her in a parked car, and the husband was also charged with killing her.

title: Firm's Chief Hopes Troubles Remain Behind: FREDERICK H. JOSEPH, Drexel Burnham
description: With Drexel Burnham Lambert's ''junk bond'' money machine sputtering, Frederick H. Joseph now faces the challenge of navigating the firm through what may be its toughest time in the market.

title: Spurrier Takes Florida Job
description: Steve Spurrier, who won the Heisman Trophy in 1966 as quarterback at the University of Florida, today returned to the school as head football coach after a scandal-plagued decade for the Gators that resulted in the ouster of his two predecessors.

title: Poet Who Jousted Soviets Loses to Burglars
description: A noted Ukrainian poet who has jousted with pre-glasnost Soviet officialdom at home ran into New York's criminal element Saturday night when a sheaf of her hand-written notes and poetry disappeared from the trunk of a parked car, the police said yesterday.

title: Therapy for Child Molesters: Many Doubt That It Works
description: When Westley Allan Dodd was arrested in November and charged with killing three young boys in this Columbia River community, his case provided critics of the legal system with a tragic demonstration of their argument that the law has failed to protect society from sex offenders.

title: President Quits At Midway Air
description: Midway Airlines Inc. announced Friday that Jeffrey H. Erickson had resigned as president and chief operating officer to pursue personal business.

title: Literary Critics Find Politics Everywhere
description: The questions seemed so simple and yet so all-encompassing that they defied any easy answers: ''Who's laughing now? Laughing at what? Who's laughing last?'' The question, the questioner continued, ''which was always a question of power,'' is: ''Why should we be laughing at all?''

title:
ON YOUR OWN;

When Training Hits Personal Heights
description: LEAD: IN health clubs throughout the metropolitan area, people are working out two-by-two, exorcising the demons of solitary exercise in favor of personal training.

title: Review/Dance;   An Ugly Duckling Parable In a Setting of Urban Frenzy
description: Loco 7 is the name of a train that journeys through time in New York City, into the 21st century. It is also the name of an ambitious multi-media piece by Federico Restrepo, a Colombian dancer and director now working in New York, which was performed by Mr. Restrepo's Puppets and Drummers company on Saturday night at La Mama Annex.

title: Battle Against Cocaine Traffic Is Languishing in South America
description: Despite some seemingly spectacular successes, the drug war in South America is not going well. Critics say the American military attack on Panama, justified in part as an anti-drug initiative, has only fragmented what is already a largely ineffective effort.

title: Against Heavy Odds, Treasury Secretary Makes Achievements: Nicholas F. Brady, Treasury Department
description: Nicholas F. Brady, a diffident, modest, well-born Wall Streeter of whom not much was expected when President Reagan made him Treasury Secretary in November 1988, tackled some of the most difficult problems of the American and world economy in 1989 and, against heavy odds, actually achieved some success.

title:
SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS: BOXING;

True Fighters
description: LEAD: THE filmmaker Spike Lee offers his definition of a great fighter: ''You have to be fearless. You have to have absolutely no fear and absolute belief in your talent and your commitment and go to all lengths to carry that out.''

title: Wings' Late Burst Sinks Devils, 6-4
description: The Devils led, 3-0, midway through the game tonight but sagged badly in the second half as they lost to the Detroit Red Wings, 6-4.

title: Prayer and Praise Honor New Mayor
description: In a soaring service of prayer and song, David N. Dinkins yesterday heard Archibishop Desmond M. Tutu, the Rev. Jesse Jackson and more than 1,000 New Yorkers wish him godspeed as he assumes the New York City mayoralty today.

title: Wheels On Cutting Edge
description: A new wheel for cyclists has bypassed conventional spoked designs in favor of aerodynamic blades.

title: Pilot of Helicopter Describes Ceausescu's Escape Attempt
description: Nicolae Ceausescu's brief and vain attempt to escape capture was described today by his helicopter pilot as a scrambled flight in which crew members were held at gunpoint and one of them sat in the Rumanian dictator's lap.

title: CAMBODIA ASSERTS U.S. GUERRILLA TIES
description: Prime Minister Hun Sen expressed concern today that Khmer Rouge forces were coordinating military operations and strategy with non-Communist guerrilla armies supported by the United States, and he said the Khmer Rouge had obtained weapons from the non-Communist factions.

title: Sizing Up Cuts to the Military Budget
description: The debate over how to cut the military budget has been complicated by a confusing array of numbers and budgetary terms.

title: A Legion of Volunteers Helps Elderly Keep Fit
description: As older Americans strive for healthier, more active lives, New York City is offering to help, by sharing its innovative fitness regimen tailored for men and women over age 60.

title: INSIDE
description: In Japan, Year of the Horse

title: European Leader Watches a Vision Transform Into Reality: JACQUES DELORS, European Commission
description: There is still a lot of the professor in Jacques Delors, the 64-year-old president of the European Commission, the European Community's excutive branch. But unlike most professors, Mr. Delors, who used to teach at France's elite Ecole Nationale d'Administration, has the opportunity so see much of his vision transformed into reality.

title: PANAMA OFFICIALS SPLIT ON NORIEGA
description: With the impasse over the fate of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega entering its second week, the new President of Panama and his Attorney General disagreed today over whether to file charges against the deposed strongman or leave the question of his prosecution to the United States.

title: The Freeze In Florida Aids Brazil
description: The icicles dripping off frozen Florida oranges on Christmas weekend warmed hearts in Brazil, the world's largest producer of frozen orange juice.

title: Industry Group Formed to Exploit Technology Developed by Military
description: American industry, battered by years of stiff foreign competition, has found a new ally in the technology wars: the multibillion-dollar military research program at Wright-Patterson Air Force Base.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 2-9

title: All Agree on Failure Of Our Drug Strategy
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Music;   Amato 'Barber' Mixes Tongues and Time Frames
description: The feisty Amato Opera, as intimate as the Metropolitan is grandiose, revels endearingly in the contrast. After its two little chandeliers rise to the ceiling before the current production of ''The Barber of Seville,'' a recording of the opera's overture is played on an antiquated sound system that, in the concluding crescendo, produces a thunderous roar of audio distortion. The live ''orchestra'' picks up: an upright piano whose mistuning is undoubtedly chronic and a pathetic band of a half dozen or so wind players.

title:
VOICES OF THE NEW GENERATION;

In the East Bloc, It's Lennon - Not Lenin
description: LEAD: My friends and I were not completely surprised the night the Berlin Wall came down. In 1979, we were students in Berlin, part of a Stanford University exchange program. We often crossed Checkpoint Charlie into East Berlin, and there we developed an intimate network of friends. Those ties convinced us that the days of the cold war were numbered.

title: 90's, in Poll: A Good Life Amid Old Ills
description: As Americans look to the year 2000, most of them anticipate a better life for themselves, but at the same time they foresee a worsening of many of the nation's social and economic problems, according to a new Gallup Poll.

title: American Journal;   '89 Glimpses: Cubs Fall, Mighty Oak Still Stands
description: It has been a year of hurricanes and housing scandals, but also of quieter tales of American people and places. Here are the last, or at least the latest, chapters from the journals of 1989:

title: From Miami to New York, Sharing Power in Schools
description: The school system here has been experimenting with democracy, shattering the wall between principals and teachers and allowing both to share power in running their schools.

title: Soviet Deputy Prime Minister Is Seeking A Safe Path Through a Time of Change: LEONID ABALKIN, Soviet Adviser
description: In the rapidly changing world of perestroika, Leonid Abalkin is not the only economist of influence. But he is apparently highly valued for his political flexibility and grace under pressure.

title: Crew Safe as Greek Freighter Sinks 800 Miles From Hawaii
description: A 600-foot Greek freighter loaded with scrap metal sank in the Pacific early today after her 28 crewmen gave up a two-day fight to pump seawater out of the hold, and abandoned ship, the Coast Guard said.

title: A Passion in the Desert
description: Alcide Chaisson, who is 69 years old and lives in a trailer near Crystalaire Airport, a small field northeast of Los Angeles, was charged Friday with obstructing a flight path. He said small planes buzzing his desert home drowned out his radio and he fought back by flashing sun into pilots' eyes with a 4-foot-square mirror. If convicted, he could get six months in jail and a $1,000 fine.

title: Business Scene;   Stock Buybacks Vs. Risky Outlays
description: FOR six years, American corporations have been buying their own stock in a big way. The original idea was to help protect the company from a takeover. But now the takeover threat is waning while the buybacks are as strong as ever. Clearly, they have taken on a life of their own, with important consequences for America's economy.

title: Devaluation In Poland
description: The National Bank of Poland is devaluing the Polish zloty by 32 percent, Polish media reported today.

title:
ON YOUR OWN;

Catch, Pull, Recover: Swimming for Fitness
description: LEAD: WITH the New Year come resolutions for following through on that exercise regimen you've always talked about. Swimming for fitness might be a place to start.

title: Markets Closed
description: All financial markets in the United States and most world markets will be closed today because of New Year's Day.

title: Islanders Win, 4-2
description: Pat LaFontaine scored three times, extending his goal-scoring streak to seven games, to lead the New York Islanders to a 4-2 victory over the Buffalo Sabres tonight.

title: No Ranger in Box Leads to Loss
description: The gaffe was monstrous, the price paid for it enormous. Afterward, Coach Roger Neilson's mistake, the one that made Pittsburgh's tying goal possible and its subsequent 5-4 victory almost inevitable, was explained, analyzed and rehashed again and again.

title: Steinberg Interviews Perles
description: George Perles, a controversial but successful coach on three levels, yesterday became the first of half a dozen finalists to be interviewed for the Jets' head-coaching job.

title: Jill Armel Marries Ens. Evan Dash
description: Jill Lynne Armel and Ens. Evan Dayan Dash were married yesterday at the Inter-Continental Hotel in New York by Rabbi Thomas Weiner. Mrs. Dash is the daughter of Marilyn W. Armel and Paul H. Armel, both of New York. Ensign Dash is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph F. Dash of New York.

title: Outdoors: Of Muzzleloaders and Mergansers
description: NOT long ago in Massachusetts, the beginning of a three-day primitive-firearms hunt for deer and the start of the second half of the state's waterfowl season coincided, plunging me into indecision.

title: Some Lincoln Investors Escape Loss in Collapse
description: The collapse of the Lincoln Savings and Loan Association produced an array of victims, from retired California investors who bought unsecured bonds to American taxpayers. But it also turns out that not all the investors in the failed institution were losers.

title: Clemson Coasts
description: Clemson's defense became West Virginia's nightmare in the Gator Bowl on Saturday night.

title: INQUIRY ON PRICES OF OIL HEAT URGED
description: As New England's coldest December on record shivered to a close, lawmakers and consumer advocates called for an investigation into heating-oil prices that have shot up with the mercury's fall.

title: Praying In The Year In Japan
description: A few seconds before midnight, the chief priest of a small hilltop sanctuary known as Sengen Shrine fidgeted in his scarlet robes and looked nervously at his watch while listening to the radio for the electronic beep signaling the arrival of the Year of the Horse.

title: Ortega Says Search Made U.S. Relations The Worst in Years
description: President Daniel Ortega Saavedra said today that the ransacking of the Nicaraguan Ambassador's residence in Panama by American troops on Friday has brought Nicaraguan-American relations to their deepest crisis in 10 years.

title: Deal for Hawaiian Airlines
description: A group headed by Peter V. Ueberroth, the former commissioner of baseball, and Thomas Talbot, a California entrepreneur, has bought control of Hawaiian Airlines for $37 million.

title: Poll Voters Won't Matter If Colorado Wins Tonight
description: The old, worn wooden stands that surrounded Bill Coleman did not appear as they will Monday night, when the painted faces arrive, the lights go on, the bands begin to play, the Orange Bowl comes alive, and a lifetime of memories, joyous or painful, will be compressed into 60 minutes of football.

title: Lisa Kuvin and Benjamin Schreier Wed
description: Lisa Rose Kuvin, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Sanford Kuvin of Palm Beach, Fla., and Jerusalem, was married yesterday at her parents' home in Palm Beach to Benjamin Myer Schreier, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard Schreier of Birmingham, Mich. Rabbi Leonid Feldman performed the ceremony.

title: Gifts to Neediest for Those Without Options
description: It is not necessary to visit New York City to evoke images of the deprivation in which so many live. Letters to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund draw a vivid portrait.

title: Longer Lives for Aging Cargo Ships
description: With demand outstripping capacity and freight rates rising, the new year might seem ripe for a flood of orders for new bulk-cargo ships - a flood reminiscent of those in the early 1970's and the early 1980's. But that will not be the case this time, many people in the industry say.

title: Correction
description: An article in Business Day on Saturday about economists' views of changes in Eastern Europe misidentified a Princeton University professor. He is Alan Blinder.

title: Mindless Macho in Panama
description: The Administration was right to apologize after American troops broke into the Nicaraguan Ambassador's residence in Panama. But President Bush is much too cavalier when he dismisses Friday's raid as a mere ''screw-up.'' Nor can the raid be pardoned, as he implies, just because the troops found a cache of weapons.

title: In a Land Without Abundance, Joy in the New Year Has Limits
description: The Soviet nation bid an ambivalent adieu to 1989 in midnight revels, joining President Mikhail S. Gorbachev in expressing regret over the ''bitterness'' of the withered economy while hailing the ''waves of revolutionary renewal'' that have tattered the Kremlin's Eastern European bloc.

title: A Year of Surprises Benefits European Stocks
description: In the world's stock markets, 1989 was a year of the unexpected.

title: Parking Rules for Holidays in 1990
description: The New York City Transportation Department has issued its parking-rule changes for 1990.

title: Angry Words Spark Kansas
description: An angry rebuke from Coach Roy Williams was all Kansas needed Saturday night to pull away from previously unbeaten Stanford and post an 83-61 victory in the final of the BMA Holiday Classic.

title: New Year, New Mayor and New Hopes
description: ''Personally I'm optimistic on everything,'' said 10-year-old Chris Park, pausing to contemplate the minting of a crisp new decade and a historic changeover at City Hall -New York's first new Mayor in his lifetime.

title: Town in Bulgaria Defies Order to Give Muslims Full Rights
description: Local Communist authorities in the Bulgarian town of Kardzhali have defied party orders to restore full civil rights to the Turkish minority, jeopardizing Government efforts to reassure the Muslim population.

title: Spain and Its Writers Celebrate A Long-Awaited Renaissance
description: The Nobel Prize in Literature that Camilo Jose Cela received this year has come at a time when the Spanish literary world is astir with what is being called ''the new Spanish narrative.''

title: Victor G. Trapasso, Real Estate Executive, 54
description: Victor G. Trapasso, the president and chief executive officer of the GT Realty and Management Company of Herndon, Va., died of cancer on Thursday at Alexandria Hospital in Alexandria, Va., where he lived. He was 54 years old.

title: Brother of Ceausescu Was Suspected as Spy
description: Nicolae Ceausescu's eldest brother, Marin, found hanged in a Viennese cellar on Thursday, may have played a role in espionage in Western Europe, Austria's Interior Minister has asserted.

title: DEALS
description: FOOTBALL

title: Tokyo Market: Now a Leader
description: At a time when bankers and economists speak of a global financial village, with the world's centers of finance closely linked and interdependent, the Tokyo stock market is increasingly going its own stable and buoyant way.

title: Soweto Journal;   To Be Black and a Police Officer: Perils and Pride
description: Fanyana Zwane was watching television with two of his sons one evening last August when two Soviet-made hand grenades smashed a window and exploded in their living room, seriously wounding 12-year-old Gabriel. The neighborhood in the black township of Soweto, where the Zwanes live, was shocked but not surprised.

title: At Colorado, Passer Grows Up on the Move
description: HE tugged at the Los Angeles Raiders cap snug atop his head and his eyes shifted as if he were anticipating a blitzing linebacker. Darian Hagan, a teen-ager laden with adult-like responsibility, was explaining in his own way how he became a man so hurriedly, so unexpectedly.

title: Do Special Sections Overwhelm Readers?
description: AT a number of American newspapers, it has become almost a fad to publish pullout news sections focused on a single topic.

title: The Opposition Stirs
description: ''For myself, as a Democrat, respectfully,'' quietly begins the best public speaker in American politics today, ''I think we have given an appropriate period of deference to the newly victorious President.''

title: Jackson Says Panama Took Focus Off China
description: The Rev. Jesse L. Jackson said yesterday that the attack on Panama had allowed the Bush Administration to deflect criticism of its secret diplomatic missions to China after the crackdown on demonstrations there.

title: Booksellers Rank the Best Markets
description: With retail book sales of more than $283 million a year, the New York metropolitan area remains the nation's largest book market.

title: Nicaragua Devaluation
description: The Government has devalued Nicaragua's currency for the 40th time this year and raised the price of gasoline and public transportation. The move by the Nicaraguan central bank brought the official exchange rate to 38,150 cordobas to a dollar. The previous rate was 36,330 cordobas. Friday's action raised urban and inter-city bus fares by 30 percent.

title: Question Box
description: Bear and Big Bowls

title: Scott Burton, Sculptor Whose Art Verged on Furniture, Is Dead at 50
description: Scott Burton, an American sculptor whose work balanced stubbornly and elegantly between art and furniture while evolving into a new kind of public sculpture, died of AIDS on Friday at Cabrini Medical Center in New York City. He was 50 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Books of The Times;   A Man of Bitter Prejudices, A Writer With Agile Wit
description: The Diary of H. L. Mencken

title: Returning Legislators Face Tough Demands in Albany
description: After a six-month break, their longest in 19 years, New York State lawmakers will gather here Wednesday to begin a new session. But, pressed with demands for greater spending and hemmed in by what appears to be a near-chronic budget deficit, few legislators seem particularly eager to return.

title: Satellites of Two Nations Sent Up In a Long-Delayed Titan Launch
description: A Titan 3 rocket carrying British and Japanese communications satellites roared into space tonight after nine postponements as the Martin Marietta Corporation entered the commercial launching business.

title: Blazing a Trail
description: IN the past few years - and increasingly so now that the Iron Curtain is being torn apart - East European athletes have streamed from their homelands for the West.

title: Holiday Today
description: Today is New Year's Day. Here are holiday schedules.

title: Together Separately for the Two Germanys;   'Deutschlandlied'
description: To the Editor:

title: Metro Matters;   Decade's Misery And Strengths Greet the Mayor
description: What a difference a decade makes.

title: An Israeli Paper Says Jews Were Released And Ceausescu Paid
description: Israel paid thousands of dollars in cash to Nicolae Ceausescu for every Rumanian Jew he allowed to emigrate for two decades, an Israeli newspaper reported.

title: Aquino Reorganizes Her Cabinet
description: President Corazon C. Aquino announced changes in her Cabinet today in the aftermath of the military mutiny against her Government earlier this month.

title: 1989 Postcards Range From Tragic to Bizarre
description: BETWEEN a riot and an earthquake, death and scandal, the games seemed a bit anticlimactic this year. But for one wandering sports columnist, 1989 did have its moments, from datelines as diverse as Trinidad and Paris.

title: Nunn Says U.S. Should Negotiate Deeper Cuts on Troops in Europe
description: Senator Sam Nunn, the leading Democratic figure on military issues on Capitol Hill, says the United States should seek deeper cuts in American and Soviet troop strength in Europe than the Bush Administration has proposed in arms negotiations.

title: OFFICERS SAY PARTY IN RUMANIA PLANS TO DISSOLVE ITSELF
description: Confronted by growing demands that the Communist Party dissolve itself, top officials of this country's old order say they will call a special congress to dismantle the disgraced party even before free elections are held in April.

title: Review/Television;   The Birth Rate Is Rising Sharply As Networks Court Baby Boomers
description: Know any unemployed adorable babies? Rush them over to central casting. Prime-time television has become obsessed with pregnant women and childbirth scenarios. In recent months, the phenomenon has been prominent on ABC's ''Thirtysomething,'' NBC's ''L.A. Law'' and ''Cheers,'' and CBS's ''Beauty and the Beast,'' in which, heaven help us, Mom was killed in the delivery room and the newborn was kidnapped. Parenthood, it seems, can have its downside.

title: Review/Pop;   A Certain Brand of Lambada
description: Anybody looking to decipher the Brazilian term lambada, which applies to a dance, music, cross-cultural sensibility and product of marketing hucksters, would have left Margareth Menezes's show at S.O.B.'s on Saturday night no more insightful than when he came in. Miss Menezes, who recently performed with David Byrne, the fan of third world music and singer, is being promoted as a lambada singer; in truth, she is a decent singer familiar with Afro-Brazilian music. The music she and her half American and half Latin band played was standard-issue Brazilian pop, but with less American fusion and more Caribbean influences - soca from Trinidad, compas from Haiti, zouk from Guadeloupe - thrown in to quicken it. There was a crossover dream fueling it all; even so, the lambada aspect was mostly chimerical.

title: Go Ahead. Eat That Potato Chip.
description: LEAD: New Year's Day is a time when many people resolve to lead better lives. In recent years, that has meant cutting out smoking, exercising more and eating fewer unhealthy foods. The first two, while not easy to do, are at least easy to understand. But which foods are unhealthy? The American Heart Association is glad you asked.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: INTERNATIONAL

title: Nancy Bauer Weds Michael Cooper
description: Nancy Fay Bauer and Michael Anthony Cooper, both candidates for Ph.D. degrees at Harvard University, she in philosophy and he in English, were married yesterday at the Memorial Church at Harvard by the Rev. Arthur O. F. Bauer, the bride's father, a Lutheran minister.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''It's nice to have a black Mayor, and it'd be even better if he could really do something about the crime and about the homeless. The best thing about New York is when people really want to get together and do something, people really do get together.''

title: Kinnock to Meet Gorbachev
description: Neil Kinnock, leader of the opposition Labor Party, will meet with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev in Moscow on Jan. 16, a party spokesman said today. No details of the visit were available, the spokesman said.

title: Army Doesn't Have to Compete With Marines
description: To the Editor:

title: Joyce Dinkins, a Quiet Lady Who Is No Longer a Private Person
description: Shortly before her 59th birthday last month, Joyce Dinkins found herself at the center of an outpouring of affection.

title: In Poland, Capitalism Brings Hope Tempered With Worry
description: At the stroke of midnight, Poland becomes the first Eastern European country to leap into the capitalist era.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE: FINANCIAL NEWSMAKERS OF 1989 - SIX WHO MADE THE HEADLINES IN AMERICA AND ABROAD;

Savings Executive Becomes the Center Of a Wide Criminal Investigation: CHARLES H. KEATING Jr., Lincoln Savings
description: LEAD: When he entered the savings and loan business in 1984, Charles H. Keating Jr., a successful Arizona land developer, seemed to personify the promise of the age of financial deregulation.

title: Knicks May Win Honor for Coach
description: With a third of the National Basketball Association season completed, the Knicks' 20-7 record is tops in the Eastern Conference and second-best over all in the 27-team league after the Los Angeles Lakers' 21-6.

title: Holiday Box
description: Because of holiday production requirements, The Times is printed today in two sections.

title: Display of Japanese Art
description: Fourteen pieces of Japanese artwork from the collection of the late John D. Rockefeller 3d, including paintings, screens and poem scrolls, will be on view for seven months beginning Jan. 18 at the Asia Society, 725 Park Avenue, at 70th Street. A major part of the show is a pair of folding screens in gold leaf, recently acquired by the museum, that date from the Edo Period (1615-1868). Hours are 11 A.M. to 6 P.M. Tuesdays to Saturdays and noon to 5 P.M. Sundays. Admission: $2 ($1 for students and the elderly). Information: 288-6400.

title: A College Super Bowl: The Ultimate Sellout
description: LEAD: For many college football fans, today's glut of bowl games will be one game too few, especially if they fail to produce a clear-cut national champion. It is apparently not enough to have several excellent teams, each winning a bowl game. There is growing pressure for one last playoff game, a college version of the Super Bowl, to produce an undisputed national champion.

title: William Scott, 76, a British Artist Devoted to Still Lifes and Figures
description: William Scott, a British artist acclaimed for his still life paintings and drawings, died of Alzheimer's disease on Thursday at his home outside Bath in Somerset, England. He was 76 years old.

title: Rams Upset Eagles, 21-7; Giants Next
description: The Los Angeles Rams made big pass plays today, two of them for touchdowns. They ran for 144 yards, including a 54-yard sprint by Greg Bell, which set up the clinching touchdown. Their offensive line and defensive gimmicks also contibuted mightily as they upset the Philadelphia Eagles, 21-7.

title: Together Separately for the Two Germanys
description: To the Editor:

title: A New Star For Studios Is Mexico
description: Hollywood's big names and big studios are increasingly being drawn to Mexico to make feature films and television movies.

title: Ruth Messinger, New Borough Chief, Weds Andrew Lachman, Schools Aide
description: Ruth W. Messinger, who is to be sworn in today as Manhattan Borough President, was married yesterday to Andrew Lachman, the special assistant to the superintendent of Community School District 2 in Manhattan. Rabbi Allan Miller officiated at the New York home of the bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Wilfred Wyler, who also have a home in Westport, Conn.

title: Mixed Reviews for Hong Kong's Cultural Center
description: The new Hong Kong Cultural Center stands on one of Hong Kong's finest waterfront sites, looking out over Victoria Harbor with its quaint wooden fishing junks and busy passenger ferries parading past the colony's glistening glass and metal skyscrapers. But the $77 million center, designed by a committee of government architects, has no windows. The only opening onto one of the most magnificent waterfront views in the world is a narrow slit of glass that runs up a wall of the low, angular pink-tiled building.

title: New Weapon Against Drugs: A Stamp Tax
description: LEAD: The continuing Congressional bluster over drug policy is rich in ideas on how to fight but not how to pay.

title: Some of the Casualties Meet Their Commander
description: Gregory Johnson's Purple Heart was pinned to his pillow, and a three-foot-high inflatable Santa stood near his bed.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: HORSE RACING

title: Mental Health Group Can't Buy Network Ads
description: To the Editor:

title: Shamir Dismisses Weizman From Israel's Government
description: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir today dismissed Science Minister Ezer Weizman from the Israeli Cabinet, saying the influential Labor Party minister had met with leaders of the Palestine Liberation Organization and given them advice on how to thwart a Government peace initiative.

title: A Proud Beginning to 1990
description: A new year, a new decade and, in New York, a new era begin today, with the swearing in of David N. Dinkins as New York's Mayor. The moment recalls a line from the old Christmas carol about ''the hopes and fears of all the years . . .''

title: Bushes Will Attend Funeral Of Brother-in-Law in Boston
description: President Bush and his wife, Barbara, will go to Boston on Tuesday for the funeral of their brother-in-law Alexander Ellis 2d, the White House said today.

title: Chief Justice Makes Plea for More Federal Judgeships to Help in Fight Against Drugs
description: Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist, in a year-end plea to Congress and the White House for additional Federal judgeships, warned yesterday that ''the war on drugs will fail if the judiciary is not given the judgeships necessary to do the job.''

title: Warm-Weather Sissies?
description: HURRYING through the tunnel at Veterans Stadium, the Los Angeles Rams' left guard, Tom Newberry, yelled, ''Warm-weather California sissies, huh?'' With a grin he disappeared into the locker room to calmly celebrate a 21-7 wild-card victory over the Philadelphia Eagles in a cold raw rain, which qualified the Rams to go against the Giants next Sunday at Giants Stadium in the Super Bowl XXIV tournament.

title: Democracy Means Staten Island Could Pull Out of New York City
description: To the Editor:

title: Dinkins Party: Populist Gala and Diversified Feast
description: At 2:10 P.M. a drumroll and the first tentative wheeze from the bagpipe band of Local 3 of the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers announced the arrival of Mayor David N. Dinkins and his wife, Joyce B. Dinkins, at the inaugural reception yesterday.

title: G. Douglas Hofe, 59, New Jersey Prosecutor
description: G. Douglas Hofe Jr., a former Deputy State Attorney General for New Jersey, died of cancer yesterday at his home in Morris Township, N.J. He was 59 years old and also lived in Orleans, Mass.

title:
WALL STREET OUTLOOK;

Dollar Fails to Heed Analysts' Predictions
description: LEAD: The dollar began 1989 on the offensive and ended it in a partial retreat. It consistently confounded economists, foreign exchange traders and the policy makers of the United States and its chief economic allies.

title: Powell Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $323,000 for the quarter and $1,583,000 for the year. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $286,000 and $221,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. The year-ago periods also included an extraordinary gain of $1,050,000, or 10 cents a share, from recognition of net operating loss carryforwards.

title: A Keyboard With a Difference
description: COMPUTER users rarely give much thought to their keyboards, yet they spend far more time in contact with the keys than with any other peripheral, with the possible exception of time spent making eye contact with the monitor.

title: A Tumultuous Year for 'Junk Bonds'
description: The turmoil in the ''junk bond'' market that began in the middle of last year shows no sign of easing soon.

title: Defective Offspring Of 'Alcoholic' Rats
description: MALE rats that consumed large amounts of alcohol before breeding sired male offspring that suffered from learning disabilities and low levels of the male sex hormone testosterone, scientists have reported.

title: For the Retarded, Independence in Real Jobs
description: Matthew R. Starr washes pots and pans in the Marriott Hotel here. For $3.60 an hour, 40 hours a week, he presides over three arm-deep steel sinks, one for washing, one for a regular rinse and one for an extra sanitizing rinse.

title: The Editorial Notebook;   Checking Out the 1990's
description: Programmed dreams. Individual flight platforms. Human hibernation. These are some of the innovations cited by Herman Kahn and Anthony Wiener as likely to occur before the year 2000. Their predictions, offered in 1967, were not at all bad. But even with 10 years to run they veer toward excessive optimism about technology and its blessings. Given the tenor of the 60's, that's not surprising.

title: 'Pumped Up' Auburn Stops Ohio State
description: Reggie Slack shrugged off a slow start to throw for three touchdowns and run for a fourth as Auburn held the Big Ten's top offense to 81 yards in the second half en route to a 31-14 victory today in the Hall of Fame Bowl.

title: Books of The Times;   Poet, Businessman, Mystic, Senator, Irishman
description: W. B. Yeats

title: Jane Dauber Wed To M. L. Lewittes
description: Jane Dauber, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Leonard G. Dauber of New York, was married yesterday at the Tavern on the Green to Michael Louis Lewittes, the son of Mr. and Mrs. David J. Lewittes of Poughkeepsie, N.Y. Rabbi Israel Silverstein, a grandfather of the bride, performed the ceremony.

title: 3 Jazz Musicians Given U.S. Arts Fellowships
description: Three jazz musicians and composers - George Russell, Cecil Taylor and Gerald Wilson - have been awarded fellowships by the National Endowment for the Arts. The fellowships, worth $20,000 each, have been awarded annually since 1982 for ''exceptional artistic merit in the field of jazz.'' A panel of jazz musicians and composers chose the winners.

title: The New 'Sooners'
description: Seers and prognosticators of all varieties are taking loose advantage of the calendar to proclaim that a ''new decade'' is ushering in a ''new world'' that will follow upon the deflation of Communist pretensions and the end of the Soviet empire.

title: Transit Lines Brace for Test Of $1.15 Fare
description: Fares in New York City increased to $1.15 yesterday for bus and subway riders, many of whom New Year's morning caught rumpled and bleary eyed, fumbling for the extra nickel and dime to get them home.

title: Atlantic Express Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After income tax benefits of $756,000 for the latest first quarter and $478,222 for year-ago period. The year-ago results included a one- time $675,000 payment from one of the company's suppliers.

title: Patterns
description: The 80's: Good Times

title: Correction
description: Because of a mechanical error, a front-page article in some copies yesterday about the treatment of child molesters omitted several words in a sentence about an approach to treatment used in many states. The passage should have read: The other approach tries to change behavior by shock therapy, drugs, hormone injections or, in extreme cases, chemical castration.

title: Three Names for S.E.C.
description: Three names, including that of Vince Dooley, the former Georgia football coach, keep surfacing as the search for a Southeastern Conference commissioner enters its final stages. The New Orleans Times-Picayune reported Sunday that Roy Kramer, the director of athletics at Vanderbilt; C. W. Ingram, the athletic director at Alabama, and Dooley, Georgia's athletic director, are considered the leading candidates.

title: A.&P. Invitation
description: The Great Atlantic and Pacific Tea Company, whose advertising agency review was announced on Thursday, has invited J. Walter Thompson and Laurence, Charles, Free & Lawson to compete for its account, advertising executives said. D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles/New York, the grocery chain's agency since 1986, resigned the account after the review was initiated. D.M.B.& B. said A.&P. billed $13 million.

title: Off-Balance Virginia Loses to Illinois
description: John Mackovic said the difference was rhythm.

title: Analysts See Lower Rates In First Half
description: Most credit market analysts predict that the gradual decline in interest rates that began last spring is likely to continue well into the first half of 1990. By summer or early fall, however, the bottom will have been reached and a firming trend will emerge, they say.

title: Upheaval in the East;   No Change in Albania, Party Leader Declares
description: Albania's leader, Ramiz Alia, said today that the uprisings that had ended Communist control in most of Eastern Europe would not affect his country, the region's last hard-line Communist state.

title: 10,000 in Hong Kong Rally for a Free China
description: About 10,000 people staged a noisy but peaceful demonstration today in support of democracy in China.

title: In Health Care, a Question of Quality: Cost-Control Efforts Raise Concerns
description: HAVE Government measures to control health care costs reduced the quality of care and increased death rates among the elderly?

title: Markets Closed
description: All financial markets in the United States and most world markets were closed yesterday because of New Year's Day.

title: For Many On Wall St., A Post-80's Hangover
description: For years Wall Street has been a beacon of wealth and glamour for talented young people willing to work punishing hours for mind-boggling pay. Today, as Wall Street shrinks back to life-size proportions, the game has shifted to making a living, not a killing.

title: Upheaval in the East: The Dossier;   Rumanian Finds His File: 12 Years of Being Watched
description: When Doru Pavaloiae, an economist, met an old classmate on Lipscani Street here at a time when Nicolae Ceausescu was still in power in Rumania, the two men talked, and in the conversation he let slip that he would like to leave the country.

title: Marine Sues Navy Over a Demotion
description: A former Marine sergeant who lost her assignment as a drill instructor after testifying that a lesbian colleague ''did a fine job'' has asked the Navy to award her back pay and to restore her good-service record.

title: Bitter Ending for Oilers As Steelers Move On
description: Coach Jerry Glanville invoked Abraham Lincoln to fire up his Oilers on Sunday, but Honest Abe never had to debate the Steelers' Chuck Noll in a playoff contest.

title: Review/Television;   Asian Troupers of the 40's Recall a West Coast Club
description: Home-grown exotica is on tonight's bill of ''The American Experience.'' ''Forbidden City, U.S.A.'' celebrates a Chinese-American nightclub that thrived in San Francisco during World War II. American servicemen jammed the place to watch Oriental dancers and singers doing the Occidental.

title: Reporter's Notebook;   Bush's New Winning Combination
description: Do you want to hear something really disgusting about the President of the United States?

title: End the Abuse of Legal Services
description: Unable to persuade Congress to kill the Legal Services Corporation, President Reagan called for its ''reform'' - meaning the correction of alleged abuses by lawyers representing the poor. He found people who agreed with him and made them directors of the corporation, which administers $300 million in grants to poverty law offices across the country. These ''reformers'' have become the program's main enemies, hostile and incompetent managers of one of the finest institutions to emerge from the War on Poverty.

title: Sock Shop Negotiations
description: Sock Shop International P.L.C. is negotiating with a potential partner to try to reopen its outlets in the United Staes, The Financial Times reported Friday. Sock Shop closed its 17 stores in New York last week, citing rent and security problems. Peter Moss, a director of the company, was quoted as saying the New York clothing market had slowed since the stores opened two years ago. He said negotiations with the potential partner should be concluded within two weeks. Sock Shop, which has 121 stores in Europe, is also discussing rent cuts, the paper said.

title: Steel Problems in China
description: Some Chinese companies have asked to cancel orders for imported steel products since a 21 percent devaluation of the currency this month, the China Daily said Saturday. But it quoted Zhu Desheng, director of the metals and materials department of the Ministry of Materials and Equipment, as saying the ministry would ''persuade'' importers not to cancel orders. The newspaper said many importers wanted to turn to domestically produced steel, but that domestic output was insufficient.

title: Conair Head Planning Strategy for Cuisinarts
description: Lee Rizzuto, the chairman of the Conair Corporation, has had his eye on Cuisinarts Inc., the famed maker of food processors, since 1986. But sales were booming, and Cuisinarts rejected Mr. Rizzuto's bid. Frustrated, Mr. Rizzuto started a subsidiary to make Conair kitchen appliances to extend his company's line of personal care products.

title: Bridge
description: A large number of players, including numerous experts, missed a chance for brilliant declarer play in six spades on the diagramed deal played in October in the Regional Championships in Stamford, Conn. It was reported by Allan Stauber of Wappingers Falls, N.Y., who had earlier won the Men's Pair title.

title: 19 Expelled U.S. Diplomats Leave Nicaragua for Miami
description: Nineteen of the 20 American diplomats who were ordered to leave Nicaragua in a reprisal for a military raid on the Nicaraguan Ambassador's residence in Panama departed today for Miami.

title: Vols' Victim No. 600 Is Arkansas, by 31-27
description: Chuck Webb put Tennessee into the 600-victory club today as the Volunteers defeated the Arkansas Razorbacks in the Cotton Bowl, 31-27.

title: 8 Works by Matisse Are Stolen in France
description: A burglar stole eight works by Henri Matisse valued at an estimated $12.5 million from the Matisse home on the Riviera, the police said today.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Below are the major economic indicators to be released this week.

title: For Actress in 'The Merchant,' Hatred of Portia Turns to Love
description: ''Portia had never been an attractive character to me,'' Geraldine James says. ''I didn't like her. I found her rather insufferable. I'd played Jessica, Shylock's daughter, about 10 years ago, and I thought the play was fairly horrible. So when Peter Hall first asked me if I was interested in playing Portia in 'The Merchant of Venice' with Dustin Hoffman as Shylock, I truly said, 'No.' I said, 'I really don't think she's a very nice character at all.' ''

title: Eight Hours of Bloodshed: New York Records 13 Slain
description: In less than eight hours Sunday night and early yesterday, 13 people were slain in New York City, the police said, as one year of bloodshed and homicide gave way to another with the blare of noisemakers and the crackle of gunfire.

title: Upheaval in the East: Warsaw;   Poland Raising Basic Prices Sharply
description: The Government deflated some of the nation's New Year gaiety today by announcing a series of hefty price increases on basic goods and services, a move that is part of a crash program to give Poland a more market-oriented economy.

title: Racing Against Time To Save Recordings Of Toscanini's Work
description: In a cluttered corner of the basement of the New York Public Library at Lincoln Center, Seth B. Winner, an audio engineer, threaded a reel of film through what is believed to be the world's only extant selenophone.

title: Helen Adams Masten, Librarian, 94
description: Helen Adams Masten, who read to children at the New York Public Library for nearly 38 years, died of congestive heart failure Sunday at Devon Manor, a retirement home in Devon, Pa. She was 94 years old and had lived in Pelham, N.Y., until two years ago.

title: After 37 Years, a Split
description: After 37 years together, the Leo Burnett Company and Harris Trust and Savings Bank have agreed to split up. Burnett and Harris Bank executives said that leaving the Chicago bank, whose billings are believed to be about $1 million, would enable Burnett to pursue larger financial services accounts.

title: Our Towns;   Where Changes In the U.S.S.R. Resonate Loudly
description: When he was a youngster growing up in Philadelphia, Roman Mirchuk listened intently as his father, Petro, almost every evening after dinner talked of the four bitter years he spent in Auschwitz.

title: Warring Shiite Rivals in Lebanon Accuse Each Other of Israeli Ties
description: Warring Shiite Muslim factions that are engaged in bitter clashes in southern Lebanon have accused each other of collaborating with a common enemy, Israel.

title: A Way Out of Welfare Via Foster-Mother Role
description: Fourteen mothers who were once on welfare have found $21,000-a-year jobs - as mothers. They are serving as foster parents to disabled children under a state program.

title: Phyllis Raphael, A Writer, Weds
description: Phyllis Raphael, a writer, and Dr. Robert Langs, a psychoanalyst, were married yesterday at their home in Manhattan by Rabbi Deborah antor.

title: Editor's Note;   Outcry Erupts at The Jerusalem Post Over New Publisher's Editorial Bent
description: Journalists at The Jerusalem Post, Israel's only English-language newspaper, have mounted a drive to oust the paper's publisher of eight months, saying he is trying to turn the liberal daily into a platform for right-wing views.

title: Football As First Fiddle
description: ''The trouble is,'' the college president says, cracking open a bag of walnuts with the telephone, ''we're neglecting football for education.''

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I stand before you today as the elected leader of the greatest city of a great nation, to which my ancestors were brought, chained and whipped in the hold of a slave ship. We have not finished the journey toward liberty and justice, but surely we have come a long way.''

title: Upheaval in the East: Prague;   Havel Tells Festive Czechoslovaks That Honesty Is Key to Recovery
description: President Vaclav Havel told the citizens of Czechoslovakia today that their Communist leaders had lied to them for 40 years, that their country was in a serious economic and environmental crisis, and that only a return to the values of honesty, decency and mutual respect could lead to recovery.

title: Ms. Meisel Weds Charles Heming
description: Barbara Krueger Meisel, an assistant manager for personal financial services at Brown Brothers Harriman & Company in New York, and Charles E. Heming of Scarsdale, N.Y., and Fayston, Vt., a partner in the New York law firm of Wormser, Kiely, Galef & Jacobs, were married yesterday. The ceremony was performed by Elizabeth Hyde, a justice of the peace, at her home in Waitsfield, Vt.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Central Paper Co., Newark, named David H. Berkowitz president and chief operating officer.

title: Crews Fight Oil Spill Off Morocco
description: Cleanup experts tried today to patch a crippled Iranian supertanker and protect the Moroccan coastline from 37 million gallons of spilled crude oil that formed a 108-square-mile slick on the Atlantic Ocean.

title: Volcanic Harbinger?
description: Subtle shifts in gravity at the Poas volcano in Costa Rica preceded the eruptions of ash clouds last April and May, suggesting that such changes could predict volcanic activity, scientists from the Open University in England have reported.

title: INSIDE
description: Let Me See. $3.45 From $10.... Are You in a Hurry?

title: Text of Dinkins Speech: 'We Are All Foot Soldiers on the March to Freedom'
description: Following is a transcript of Mayor David N. Dinkins's inaugural address yesterday, as recorded by The New York Times.

title: Designers Unite to Indulge Every Fashion Whim
description: At the dawn of a new season it is apparent that fashion choices have probably never been more diversified. From classic calm tailored clothes to frivolous glittery ones, the vast range of styles for spring offers something for every woman's taste. Fashion has been globalized to the point where identical trends turn up in all the major fashion centers, a sign not necessarily of designers' copying one another but of their being on the same wavelength, no matter where they live and work.

title: Technology Companies Dominate Active List
description: The Nasdaq over-the-counter market registered a healthy advance over the last year despite weakening in the fourth quarter.

title: Fiftysomething - and in Charge
description: LEAD: It has become a rite of national self-definition: focusing again and again on Americans born in explosive numbers after World War II - the baby boomers. Almost as much notice is taken of our senior citizens' awesome voting bloc, which can shift Congress tremulously around on who pays the medical and retirement bills.

title: Bioanalogics Inc reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
Computer Aid Is Sought for Pilots on Takeoffs
description: RESEARCHERS at the space agency are working on a new computer system that monitors airplane performance on takeoff, displaying the point at which an airplane will lift off and other crucial information that they hope could prevent a number of takeoff accidents.

title: Bond's Move on Breweries
description: Bell Resources Ltd. said today that it had priority over a banking syndicate to claim the assets of the Australian breweries of the Bond Corporation Holdings Ltd.

title: BEI Holdings Ltd reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After income of $224,000, or 2 cents a share, from discontinued operations. c-Net income and after a loss of $137,000 from discontinued operations and included an extraordinary gain of $1.7 million, or 19 cents a share, from utilization of net operating loss.

title: Census in the Age of Information Grows to Fill a Hunger It Created
description: The Federal Census Bureau, conceived 200 years ago as a national adding machine, has in the last decade evolved into something more: the engine of the multimillion-dollar information industry that is battling for the hearts and modems of American business.

title: DC-10 Bound for New York Makes Emergency Landing
description: An American Airlines DC-10 bound for New York City with 257 people aboard made an emergency landing early today at Baltimore-Washington International Airport after the pilot reported smoke in the cockpit, an airline spokeswoman said. Several passengers suffered scrapes or bruises using emergency chutes, but no serious injuries were reported.

title: Proclaiming A Decade Of Decency
description: GOOD Housekeeping, the magazine that declared that the liberated woman had been succeeded by the ''new traditionalist,'' is risking another look into the future, contending that the 1990's will be the ''decency decade.''

title: From Letter Writer to Starting Forward
description: In an era of high-powered recruiting that now encompasses the world, Nadav Henefeld of Israel took an unusual approach: he tried to sell himself as a prospective American college basketball player by writing letters and sending his statistics to a number of big-time schools.

title: Royal Family's Seal of Approval: Instant Status, but Boasting Is Prohibited
description: In Britain, pork sausage, fertilizer, shoes and other everyday goods can break into the rarefied realm of royalty. Part of the trick is getting noticed by the right people.

title: Careers;   'Open Door' For Women Managers
description: WOMEN have had a harder time moving higher in management than men, but there is now a growing trend toward an ''open door'' policy to help them. The open doors are provided by older women who already have arrived in senior management and are willing to offer advice.

title: Perles Reveals Little on Talk With the Jets
description: George Perles, Michigan State's head football coach, who was interviewed Sunday for the Jets' head coaching job, yesterday described the talks as ''informative.''

title: Guest Supply Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included $400,000 reserve established at year-end.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Wall Street Outlook

title: Continents In Motion: Patchwork Process
description: A REVOLUTION is taking place in attempts to understand how the continents were born and grew. Geologists once drew a simple picture of a single great land mass, assembled from earlier fragments, breaking into pieces 150 million years ago to form the continents of today. Now they say the process was much more complicated.

title: Many Florida Bathers Stung By Portuguese Men-of-War
description: Portuguese men-of-war have stung hundreds of beachgoers in recent days, from Palm Beach south to Miami Beach and Key Biscayne.

title: Old Fashion Foods Inc reports earnings for 13wks to Nov 25
description: b-Net income

title: Vipont Pharmaceutical Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After extraordinary credits of $199,000, or 2 cents a share, for the quarter and $1,224,500, or 20 cents a share, for the year.

title: Corneliu Bogdan, Leading Figure In Rumanian Uprising, Dies at 68
description: Corneliu Bogdan, the longtime Rumanian envoy to Washington who broke with the Ceausescu dictatorship and took a prominent place in the new revolutionary Government, died of a stroke yesterday in Bucharest, his family said. He was 68 years old.

title: Florida State's Passing Thwarts Nebraska, 41-17
description: Peter Tom Willis threw for 422 yards and 5 touchdowns as Florida State routed Nebraska in the Fiesta Bowl today, 41-17. The 422 yards and 5 touchdowns were both Fiesta Bowl records.

title: Aegean Sea Floor Yields Clues to Early Greek Traders
description: LEAD: JUST 65 feet below the sea off the northern coast of the tiny Greek island of Dokos, archeologists are digging for buried treasure: the 4,200-year-old remains of what they believe is the oldest shipwreck in the world.

title: Jordan to Restore Libya Ties, Official Says
description: Jordan will soon restore full diplomatic relations with Libya, a senior official said Sunday.

title: Snapple Drink Account Has Moved Once Again
description: The fast-moving Snapple Natural Beverage Company account has landed with Buckley/DeCerchio. Last at Taylor-Gordon, Aarons & Company, since 1986 the account has also been held by Rosenfeld, Sirowitz, Humphrey & Strauss and Margeotes Fertitta & Weiss, as well as by a defunct media buying service.

title: Reason and Law Reject Our Panama Invasion
description: To the Editor:

title: Democracy Means Staten Island Could Pull Out of New York City;   Americana at Its Best
description: To the Editor:

title: Winter Wheat Farmers Fear Second Year's Crop Failure
description: When Lawrence Weber looked out of his pickup truck over his wheat fields at just the right angle, he could see a delicate fuzz of green bristling up out of the black earth. And what he saw was reason enough for the frown that flashed across his countenance.

title: Takeover Stocks Fade As Top Money Makers
description: Speculative fervor about possible growth in overseas companies helped make several ''country funds'' the biggest winners on the New York Stock Exchange in 1989.

title: Lilly Dache, 97, Creator of Hats For the Fashion Set of Yesteryear
description: Lilly Dache, the milliner who flourished in this country in the decades when women selected their new hats before they chose their new clothes, died Sunday at a nursing home in Louvecienne, France. She was 97 years old.

title: Manila Views Coup's Impact
description: The recent unsuccessful coup attempt in the Philippines is likely to worsen inflation, put pressure on the currency and dampen foreign investment in the first half of 1990, Vicente Jayme, the Finance Secretary, said Friday.

title: Upheaval in the East: Security Police;   RUMANIA DISBANDS REBELLIOUS FORCE
description: The Securitate, Rumania's feared internal police force under Nicolae Ceausescu, has been disbanded, and its former chief was placed under arrest Sunday after his loyalty to the new revolutionary Government came under question.

title: Hope for Threatened Species Seen In Effort to Breed Captive Animals
description: LEAD: ALMOST weekly for nearly 10 years, Ulysses S. Seal has raised a long plastic pipe to his mouth and blown a tranquilizer dart into the flank of a caged Siberian tiger.

title: MSI Electronics Inc reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
Q&A
description: Jumping Beans

title: Business and Health;   Time to Confront Health-Care Issue
description: ADMINISTRATION officials, members of Congress and executives who buy or provide health care are girding for a broad debate on the future of the troubled medical system.

title: Into the Fire: How Past Mayors Started Their Administrations
description: Former New York City mayors tend to see the problems they confronted as worse than any other mayor's. But at least one, Abraham D. Beame, believes that David N. Dinkins faces the most serious problems.

title: Oliver Stone Is Ready to Move On From Vietnam
description: Oliver Stone's eyes were puffy from sleeplessness, and when he smiled, as he did frequently, his lips drooped with exhaustion. He had just stepped off ''the tube,'' as he called it - the Concorde from Paris, where he had visited the grave of Jim Morrison of the Doors and scouted locations for his next film, a celebration of the rock icon.

title: Comterm Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $855,000 for the quarter and 9 months. Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Patrick Kelly Dies; Made Name in Paris With Witty Fashion
description: Patrick Kelly, the American designer whose sexy, witty clothes attracted attention in Paris, died yesterday at the Hotel Dieu, a hospital near the Cathedral of Notre-Dame. The cause of death was bone marrow disease, Bjorn Amelan, his business partner, said.

title: After Long Wait, Help for Cleaning a Toxic Dump
description: Eight years after the Federal Government designated a mobile home park here for cleanup of toxic wastes, three companies and the town of Springfield have begun buying the mobile homes so their residents can relocate.

title: White House Says First Troops, 141 Soldiers, Have Left Panama
description: The White House announced today that the first United States combat troops sent for last month's invasion had left Panama. It expressed the hope that the remaining forces would leave ''as soon as possible,'' but offered no time frame.

title: Canon Settles U.S. Claim
description: Canon U.S.A. Inc. has agreed to pay $2.5 million to settle claims that it overcharged the Federal Government for copiers, the Justice Department said Friday.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;

Columbia Savings Gets Chairman
description: LEAD: Just a few weeks after Thomas Spiegel resigned as chairman of the Columbia Savings and Loan Association to help sort out problems with ''junk bond'' holdings, the savings institution has named his father, Abraham, to the post.

title: U.S. Vehicle Output Off
description: Domestic auto makers built 10,843,657 cars and light trucks in 1989, down 3.2 percent from 1988's output of 11,197,335, Ward's Automotive Reports said last week. Production last week was zero, with all domestic car plants closed for the holidays.

title: Prospects In Britain
description: The Chancellor of the Exchequer, John Major, said today that the outlook for Britain's overheated economy was good if high wage increases did not cripple the Government's anti-inflation strategy.

title: Argentina's Military Chiefs Warn of Anarchy
description: With Argentina tumbling again into a frenzy of runaway prices, shortages and general economic confusion, military leaders have warned that the country is approaching anarchy and admonished people to close ranks behind their democratic Government.

title: APL Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included net from discontinued operations of $1,674,000, or 45 cents a share. c-Included net of $163,000, or 4 cents a share, for the quarter and a net loss of $1,093,000 for the year, both from discontinued operations. Results for both periods included the operations of Fischbach Corp. and also reflected the reclassification to discontinued operations of the company's tissue paper products segment, which was sold in April 1989.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L.

title: Irvine Sensors Corp reports earnings for 12mo to Oct 1
Burping Through the 80's
description: To look back on this decade is to see the chimichanga, the burrito and the empanada. It is to see beef satays and salmon tartare and blackened redfish and Yukon gold potatoes and farm-grown mussels and sushi and free-range chickens. It is to see a nation with a fork in its mouth.

title: Scientists Dismiss Finding of 'Maleness' Gene
description: TWO years ago scientists thought they had found the gene that specifies that an embryo will develop into a male. But it now turns out to be a case of mistaken identity.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-13

title: Account
description: * Nature Organics Inc., to Rutkin Costello McCullam Whitley, with a budget of $1.2 million.

title: In Final Minutes, U.S.C. Scores Touchdown To Win, 17-10, Spoiling Schembechler's Exit
description: In his final game, Bo Schembechler refused to fade quietly into the landscape of old college football coaches. He joked and laughed tonight when the Rose Bowl was over, and then he walked away with a casual wave. But deep inside, where no one could see, there must have been a seeping anger.

title: Corporate Underwriting At Record Level in 1989
description: Corporate America sought a record amount of cash from the public markets in 1989, but the large underwritings brought little joy to Wall Street. A decline in new issues of common stock and troubles in the high-yield ''junk bond'' market had a devastating effect on two of the most profitable businesses for investment banks.

title: Quake Near Palm Springs
description: A small earthquake was felt near this desert resort early today, but there were no reports of damage or injury. The quake, measuring 3.1 on the Richter scale of ground motion, came at 4:54 A.M. Sunday in a remote area 24 miles southwest of here, said Bob Finn of the California Institute of Technology in Pasadena.

title: Computertime Network reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Upheaval in the East: Havel's Vision;   Excerpts From Speech By the Czech President
description: Following are excerpts from President Vaclav Havel's New Year's Day address, as translated by The New York Times:

title: Pittston and Miners in Accord To Resolve Bitter Coal Strike
description: With what a mediator called a ''win-win'' accord, the Pittston Company and leaders of its coal miners said today that they had resolved their brutal, nine-month strike in the hills of Appalachia.

title: Ethel F. Donaghue, 93, A Real-Estate Lawyer
description: Ethel F. Donaghue, one of the first women to practice law in Connecticut, died in her sleep Saturday at her home in West Hartford. She was 93 years old.

title: Beijing Journal;   On the Stifled Campuses, Faint Echoes of Dissent
description: At one of Beijing's elite universities not long ago, students were subjected to another of a series of propaganda films intended to insure the reindoctrination of China's future leaders along the correct Communist road.

title: Medical Examiners Are Vital to Control of AIDS
description: To the Editor:

title: Upheaval in the East;   Castro Remains Adamant
description: Fidel Castro said today that nothing would divert Cuba from socialism, indicating once again that his Government would not be swayed by the reforms sweeping Eastern Europe, the official Cuban press agency said. ''I am sure that we have all the political and moral factors to confront any type of problem and that nothing and no one will make our nation backtrack on the road of socialism,'' Mr. Castro said, according to the agency. The Cuban President spoke in a televised New Year's message that was monitored here.

title: Loan Pact Seen For Hungary
description: Hungary expects to complete a deal with the International Monetary Fund by mid-month that will unlock more than $1 billion of credit for the heavily indebted country, the official press agency said Friday.

title: Lackluster Colorado Leveled by Notre Dame
description: Less than six weeks after their collective sense of confidence appeared as damaged as their chance to win a second consecutive unofficial college football championship, the Fighting Irish of Notre Dame tonight ended Colorado's undefeated, untied season and may have produced a perfect ending of their own.

title: Wendy Anne Buynak Weds Stuart J. Frank
description: Wendy Anne Buynak, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Joseph Buynak of Bayville, L.I., was married yesterday to Stuart Jeffrey Frank, a son of Nina Frank of Brookville, L.I., and Benjamin Frank of Stowe, Vt. The Rev. Dr. Melvin Hawthorne, a Baptist minister, performed the ceremony at the Russian Tea Room in New York.

title: Fischbach Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a $14 million charge relating to contract claims and legal actions. c-After a gain of $10,433,000, or $2.67 a share, from an adjustment in accounting.

title: Success for Wisconsin
description: Barry Alvarez, the assistant head coach at Notre Dame, has tentatively agreed to become football coach at Wisconsin. After a 75-minute meeting with members of the Wisconsin Athletic Board yesterday, Pat Richter, the Badgers' athletic director, said he would leave immediately for Miami to meet with the 42-year-old Alvarez and make the appointment official.

title: David Dinkins and His Friends
description: David Dinkins took office just the way he ran for it - politely, quietly, and with a generosity of spirit. ''I intend to be the Mayor of all the people of New York,'' he said at his inauguration yesterday, standing on the steps of City Hall in the winter chill. The city's first black mayor offered no flashy promises or grandiose oratory. Instead he reached out to what he calls ''the gorgeous mosaic'' of his city, as if striving to encourage good feelings all around.

title: Gasoline Spill in Monongahela
description: A barge loaded with 100,000 gallons of gasoline hit a bridge and ruptured today, spilling about 10,000 gallons in the ice-choked Monongahela River.

title: Upheaval in the East: A Nation's Treasures;   Caught in the Cross-Fire, a Bucharest Museum Counts Its Casualties
description: The mythical hero Hercules grimaces in agony, a bullet hole through his heart, as he wrestles with a centaur in a 17th-century painting at the National Museum of Art.

title: Soviets Beat Rangers In Exhibition Contest
description: Their credentials were not exactly breathtaking: The Soviet Wings had finished fifth over the first half of their season in the Soviet National League. They had, on top of that, not won at all in their three previous exhibition games during their current tour of the National Hockey League.

title: 2 Inquiries on Dinkins Are Still Unresolved
description: Two investigations into Mayor David N. Dinkins's account of his dealings in the stock of the Inner City Broadcasting Corporation were pending yesterday as the Dinkins administration took office.

title: I.M.F. and World Bank Face New Task in Eastern Europe
description: The lamps were burning late in the afternoon of Christmas Day in the office of Eugenio F. Lari, director of East European operations for the World Bank, as he completed a report on a project to modernize the Hungarian banking system.

title: Back on the Ice
description: The Tri-City Americans of the Western Hockey League returned to the ice Sunday night after a one-game strike against the team's management, defeating the Portland (Ore.) Winter Hawks, 8-4, with five goals in the third period.

title: A Mosaic of Humanity Gathers Near City Hall
description: DeVore Van, an inauguration committee volunteer, walked into the Blue Room at City Hall yesterday and announced in a voice as strong as the Hudson River and filled as deep with pride: ''Clear a path. The Mayor is coming in.''

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Jan. 1, 1990:

title: Billy Crystal to Be Host Of Oscar Ceremonies
description: Billy Crystal will be the sole host of the 1990 Academy Awards telecast, the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences has announced.

title: Chess
description: Most chess openings that are put away on the shelf deserve their fate. They cannot spoil or get musty or deteriorate beyond the original failure that got them there. They are the well-forgotten mistakes.

title: New Deal for Ryan?
description: Buddy Ryan, the Philadelphia Eagles' coach, said yesterday that he expected to get a contract extension from the club owner, Norman Braman, and doubted that he would return without one.

title: Sanford Journal;   Death at 35 Breaks A Loving Silence
description: It was not until the eulogy by his sister Karen Coleman that the conspiracy of silence about the cause of Thomas E. Whigham's death from AIDS was broken. Family members had feared rejection and perhaps violence if his illness became known.

title: Counterattack Planned By Lawyers for Lincoln
description: Lawyers for Charles H. Keating Jr., who headed the bankrupt Lincoln Savings and Loan Association, plan to attack the Government's seizure of the institution.

title: New Decade, New World, New Strategy
description: Americans well understand what the historic changes in the Soviet bloc are doing to the Soviet Union's influence in the world. But do we understand the impact of this on America's influence? Unless we are prepared to develop and implement a new American strategy in international politics, we could well see our own influence decline in parallel with the Soviet Union's.

title: Role of Nuclear Power Is Disputed Despite Looming Energy Shortage
description: As the 1990's begin, the nuclear power industry and its most vocal critics agree that the United States faces a new energy shortage, but they remain at odds over the role that nuclear power should play in averting a crisis.

title: A Classic Mac's Many Possibilities
description: THE Christmas fruit basket last week contained an apple, or, rather, Apple. A Macintosh SE/30, to be exact.

title: Miami Puts Away Alabama Easily
description: Miami trounced Alabama tonight in the USF&G Sugar Bowl, and afterward, the winning coach, Dennis Erickson, put in a claim on college football's national championship for his team.

title: In New Haven And Yonkers, 2 New Leaders
description: The first black mayor of New Haven and a Yonkers official who came to represent defiance of court-ordered housing were sworn in as chief executives of their cities yesterday.

title: Upheaval in the East;   Bulgarian Communists Promise a Freer 1990
description: Bulgaria's Communist leaders pledged today that Bulgarians would ''taste the fruits of freedom'' this year.

title: To Make the Big Time of Science, Better Take Your Show on the Road
description: AT precisely 7:30 one evening, Dr. Stanley J. Opella sauntered into a packed lecture room at Memorial Union, a large, red stone building on the banks of Lake Mendota at the University of Wisconsin in Madison. The chemists and physicists who had gathered for a five-day meeting filled every chair and lined the sides and back of the room, pushing closer together as more and more scientists came in through a side door.

title: Market Place;   Why '89 Party Had So Few Winners
