description: For many an investor, living through 1989 was like having a miserable time at what should have been a great party. Whether 1990 is any better may depend on whether interest rates fall fast enough to offset declining profits.

title: Israelis Deadlocked Over the Dismissal of Weizman
description: The Israeli Government remained in a deadlock today over Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir's dismissal of the Labor Party's outspoken Cabinet Minister, Ezer Weizman, on Sunday.

title: 'Between the Years,' Religious Group Takes Time to Pray
description: There is a point between the end of the old year and the beginning of the new, when, in effect, time must stand still so that man can look back at what he has done and look ahead to what he must do.

title: Seoul to Allow Du Pont Plant
description: E.I. du Pont de Nemours & Company will be allowed to build a titanium dioxide plant in South Korea, ending a four-year dispute over pollution, Finance Ministry officials said Friday.

title: Market-Value Index Set Record During Year
description: With economic conditions becoming more treacherous and takeovers less trendy, the companies that simply did what they said they were going to do walked away last year as the big winners on the American Stock Exchange.

title: Innovations Help the Neediest
description: For most contributors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, making a donation simply entails writing a check. But some people and business enterprises come up with inventive ways of collecting funds. This year, selling teddy bears was one of them.

title: Temco Service Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Upheaval in the East: At the Wall;   100 Injured as Video Screen Falls On Revelers at Brandenburg Gate
description: A giant video screen collapsed onto a crowd early this morning and injured more than 100 people during wild New Year celebrations at the Berlin wall, the police said.

title: John Frank Wood, Lawyer, 81
description: John Frank Wood, a retired partner in the Manhattan law firm of Thacher Proffitt & Wood, died of a heart attack Thursday at his home in Buck Hill Falls, Pa. He also lived in Manhattan and was 81 years old.

title: Upheaval in the East: Bucharest;   NEW RULING GROUP IN RUMANIA TO VIE IN APRIL ELECTIONS
description: A leader of Rumania's provisional Government said today that the ruling group would put forward its own candidates in the free elections promised for April.

title: In 1989, Wall Street Was Not Easy Street
description: For many investors, living through 1989 was like having a rotten time at what should have been a great party.

title: Mayor Dinkins;   Dinkins Sworn In; Stresses Aid to Youth
description: Pledging to be ''the Mayor of all the people,'' David Norman Dinkins, a barber's son who built a political triumph, took the oath of office yesterday as the 106th Mayor of New York City in a simple and solemn ceremony on the steps of City Hall.

title: Oncogene Science Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Vast Cheating Forces Many in India to Retake Scholastic Test
description: Thousands of Indian students hoping to enter American colleges will have to retake the Graduate Record Examinations and English-language proficiency tests in January, because copies of the tests were widely sold before the tests were taken.

title: DeRose Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Open Housing Is Mired in Lawsuits Again
description: After 18 years of litigation and two landmark court rulings, New Jersey's Mount Laurel open-housing doctrine is embroiled in lawsuits again, this time over a law that allows suburbs to transfer their affordable-housing obligations to cities.

title: Light Schedule Of New Issues
description: The Treasury's schedule of issues in this holiday-shortened week is confined to today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills.

title: Reason and Law Reject Our Panama Invasion;   'Gringo Imperialism'
description: To the Editor:

title: Reason and Law Reject Our Panama Invasion;   Light From Europe
description: To the Editor:

title: By Design;   Standbys, Old and New
description: Fashions come and fashions go. But some styles never fail. What would a woman do, for instance, without her pearls, her black cashmere sweater and a pair of well-tailored black pants? For that matter, how can a wardrobe work without a good white shirt, jeans, a batch of T-shirts and a trench coat, too?

title: Panama's Predicament: Sorting Out the Military
description: The newly appointed military commander of Los Santos province had just been sworn in after promising loyalty to the new President, Guillermo Endara, and the civil authorities under him.

title: U.S. Approves Banknote Deal
description: The Justice Department said Friday that it had advised the International Banknote Company, the United States Banknote Company and Francois Charles Oberthur Group of Paris that it would not challenge a proposed three-way transaction among them.

title: Defying Fear, Group Marks the End of Slavery
description: With police standing guard outside, about 200 people at an annual celebration of the end of slavery in the South, today offered prayer, song and humor in the face of a rash of threats and mail bombs.

title: The Pride Decade
description: The 90's now, and before they are over we will know whether the United States will recover its pride in itself.

title: Reason and Law Reject Our Panama Invasion;   What of El Salvador?
description: To the Editor:

title: Giants Wary but Confident as Playoffs Near
description: The Giants gave their verdict today on the Los Angeles Rams, the team they will play Sunday at Giants Stadium in their first game in the National Football League playoffs.

title: Bridge
description: The two Player of the Year races of the Greater New York Bridge Association have never been closer than they were in 1989, with decisions coming Dec. 17, in the final hour of tournament action at the Winter Regional Championships.

title: $1 Billion Fund Set Up to Back Poland's Currency Program
description: The United States and 14 other industrialized countries, having promised to help Poland overhaul its currency, have established a $1 billion fund to support Warsaw's efforts to make its currency partly convertible into dollars and other hard currencies, the Treasury said today.

title: Image Bank Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $276,000 for the quarter and $494,000 for the year. c-Net income Image Bank went public during the summer of 1989. Operating results have been stated on a pro forma basis and reflected adjustments reducing officers' compensation to amounts prescribed in employment agreements and the company's executive bonus plan, effective August 1989.

title: Rude, Rash, Effective, Act-Up Shifts AIDS Policy
description: To many parishioners, the recent invasion of St. Patrick's Cathedral by dozens of angry AIDS protesters was an act of desecration. But to Christopher Hennelly, a former seminarian among those arrested inside the church, it was a prayer for self-preservation.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Saab Leaves Lord, Einstein
description: Saab-Scania of America Inc., the United States unit of the Swedish car maker, yesterday removed its account from Lord, Einstein, O'Neill & Partners. The agency, whose survival was assured when the automobile manufacturer first awarded it the $20 million to $25 million account, had won the business in April 1988.

title: KEY RATES
Fannie Mae Debentures
description: The Federal National Mortgage Association, known as Fannie Mae, plans to price $1.4 billion in debentures today equally divided between four-year and 10-year maturities.

title: H. E. Kershner, 98, A Longtime Worker In Children's Causes
description: Howard E. Kershner, a businessman and an outspoken conservative about politics and economics who retired 50 years ago to devote himself to relief causes for children, died of a pulmonary ailment on Monday at the Southland Lutheran Home in Norwalk, Calif. He was 98 years old and had lived for several years in La Jolla, Calif.

title: Wales All-Stars Led by Lemieux
description: The center Mario Lemieux and the defenseman Paul Coffey of the Penguins have been voted to the Wales Conference starting team for the 41st National Hockey League All-Star Game, to be played in Pittsburgh on Jan. 21.

title: St. John's Trounces Connecticut by 93-62
description: There was enough highlight material in the 40 minutes of basketball that St. John's played last night against Connecticut to show that the Redmen will be a team to reckon with during the Big East season.

title: CUOMO TO REQUEST $1.9 BILLION BOND TO BUY OPEN LAND
description: Moving to preserve New York's remaining open spaces, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo will propose the largest environmental bond issue in state history, totaling $1.9 billion, officials here said today.

title: Kawaguchi Journal;   Fellow Asians, Yes, but Where's the Fellowship?
description: The Mayor of this drab factory town north of Tokyo is upset that some people viewed recent statements of his as racist, especially his comment that with so many dark-skinned foreigners in town, Japanese were having trouble seeing them at night.

title: Oracle Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Israeli Sought in Panama May Have Been Alerted to U.S. Invasion
description: An Israeli reputed to be Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega's closest associate may have eluded capture on the night of the United States invasion because he was warned to flee nearly six hours before American troops swept into the capital, the deputy commander of Panama's new police force said today.

title: Let Marketplace Repair Our Crumbling Nation;   Use Municipal Bonds
description: To the Editor:

title: Worker Survives 150-Foot Fall
description: A 23-year-old construction worker survived a fall of 150 feet from the Queensboro Bridge yesterday, landing in a pile of soft rubbish, the police said. Kenneth Wolf, an ironworker from Patchogue, L.I., was in critical condition last night at the City Hospital Center in Elmhurst, with two broken legs, broken ankles and hip injuries, the police said. Mr. Wolf was a member of a work crew that was taking apart a scaffold under the bridge when he fell at 7:20 A.M. He landed in pile of debris on the Queens side of the bridge.

title: Let Marketplace Repair Our Crumbling Nation
description: To the Editor:

title: Gain in Home Affordability
description: A typical American family's ability to buy a median-priced home improved in November, but many first-time home buyers were still unable to afford starter houses, a trade group said today.

title: Montana Is M.V.P.
description: The San Francisco 49ers' Joe Montana, who finished 1989 with the best all-round passing year in National Football League history, has been named the league's most valuable player by The Associated Press in balloting by sportswriters.

title: Let Marketplace Repair Our Crumbling Nation;   Not With Pension Funds
description: To the Editor:

title: New Weapon in War on Insects: Hot Air
description: rrSeeking to avoid the use of toxic chemicals in eliminating indoor insect infestations, two California scientists have developed a method that relies solely on hot air.

title: Lisbon Premier Shuffles Unpopular Cabinet
description: Prime Minister Anibal Cavaco Silva replaced five ministers in his center-right Government today, two weeks after his Social Democratic Party suffered heavy losses in municipal elections.

title: Israelis Come to Terms On Weizman Dismissal
description: The Likud and Labor parties averted a breakup of their governing coalition today with a compromise under which Ezer Weizman, the independent-minded Labor Party Science Minister, would keep his post but be suspended from the Government's decision-making core.

title: Real Estate;   S.R.O. Hotel Razed; Long Fight Ended
description: FOR the first time in more than five years the owners of a single room occupancy hotel in New York City have demolished their property as a matter of right. The action ends a decade-long battle over the S.R.O. issue in City Hall, which led to protest demonstrations by advocates for the homeless and legal fights that stretched from New York to Albany to Washington.

title: Rights of the Turks Protested
description: Angry Bulgarians chanting anti-Turkish songs dating back to Ottoman rule demonstrated in this southern town today against a decision to grant religious rights to local Bulgarian Turks.

title: MICROWAVE COOKING
description: ON a cold day, nothing makes for a simpler, friendlier party than curry. Fortunately, it cooks quickly and well in a microwave oven. Serve with a large bowl of rice - the pilaf in Micro-Tip does well - and small bowls of selected accompaniments like raisins, sliced banana, grated coconut, chutney, yogurt and roasted unsalted nuts. A big green salad can finish off the meal. A slightly coarse red wine like an inexpensive zinfandel or Beaujolais with a little age, or beer, go well with curry.

title: None but the Homeless Stopped; None but the Homeless Helped;   Take It to St. Agnes
description: To the Editor:

title: None but the Homeless Stopped; None but the Homeless Helped
description: To the Editor:

title: Solomon Birnbaum, Scholar, 98
description: Solomon Birnbaum, a Jewish scholar credited with establishing the authenticity and age of the Dead Sea Scrolls, died here on Thursday. He was 98 years old.

title: The Goalie With No Nerves;   Meola's Calm Helps Keep U.S. in World Cup Play
description: Whether reclining in a chair in his living room here or positioning himself on a soccer field in some other part of the world, Tony Meola, the goalkeeper for the United States national team, is relaxed. His composure does not waver when he dives for a save in a World Cup qualifying match or reaches for a cookie in his kitchen before watching a National Football League game.

title: Rebels Report Gain in Ethiopia
description: Ethiopian rebels said today that they seized a third town in central Ethiopia in their drive southward toward Addis Ababa, the capital.

title: Meeting Sought On Nekoosa
description: The Georgia-Pacific Corporation said today that it had solicited enough approval by shareholders of the Great Northern Nekoosa Corporation to call a special meeting to consider replacing Nekoosa's board with nominees who support its takeover offer.

title: African Studies at Yale Continue to Thrive
description: To the Editor:

title: For Dinkins and Fernandez, First Day on Job Is Brisk;   Mayor Seeks Advice On Budget Problems And Welfare Chief
description: Mayor David N. Dinkins began his first real day on the job yesterday with a sunrise appearance on national television, an impromptu breakfast and walk with senior aides and meetings with friends and advisers on how to handle the simmering stew of a city he inherited Monday.

title: Alan Colby Green, 54, Cooper Union Official
description: Alan Colby Green, the executive vice president of the Cooper Union for the Advancement of Science and Art, died of a heart ailment on Friday at the Maho Bay campground in St. John, V.I., which he was visiting with his family. He was 54 years old and lived in Pelham, N.Y.

title: Reliance Is Buying Transamerica Unit
description: Reliance Group Holdings Inc. agreed to acquire the title insurance unit of the Transamerica Corporation for about $65 million. The acquisition of the Transamerica Title Insurance Company will add to Reliance's title insurance operations, primarily in the West and Midwest. Reliance operates the Commonwealth Land Title Insurance Company in Philadelphia, whose title revenues totaled about $375 million last year.

title: Anti-Bias Classes in Georgia
description: From racial strife to vandalism at religious schools to the exclusionary traditions of private social clubs, issues of bigotry are coming to Georgia's classrooms under a new education project.

title: Sakharov Memorial Service
description: A memorial service for Andrei D. Sakharov, the Soviet human rights champion, will be held at 3:45 P.M. tomorrow at the Celeste Bartos Forum of the New York Public Library, 42d Street entrance. The service is sponsored by the International League for Human Rights. Speakers will include Elie Wiesel, Robert Bernstein, Yuri Orlov and Jerome J. Shestack. Dr. Sakharov died in Moscow on Dec. 14.

title: Bangladesh Curtails Protests
description: The Government announced today that it was banning demonstrations outside Parliament, the site of several opposition rallies last year. The decision, which takes effect Wednesday, is apparently meant to thwart a demonstration when Parliament opens its session Thursday.

title: About New York;   Hey, Come On In, The Polar Bears Are Just Fiii-ine!
description: Approaching a wintry Coney Island by elevated subway, you are struck by a motionless Wonder Wheel, a lifeless Cyclone roller coaster. Alighting, you see boarded-up arcades, kiddie rides guarded by razor ribbon, frozen hints of faraway summer. It's 30 degrees and a bitter wind chews at the cheeks. What to do but go swimming? The Coney Island Polar Bear Club assembles this time of year for dips in the icy Atlantic. We had joined them for reasons ever more elusive as the moment of our plunge approached. We glanced tremulously around at the sundry folks with whom we had chosen to contract hypothermia.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: Restaurant Outlook

title: Market Place;   Payout Increases Slumped in 1989
description: THE end-of-the-year treat for shareholders of a dividend increase was less evident last year than at any time in nearly two decades.

title: Nicaraguan Candidate Hurt
description: The leading oppositon presidential candidate, Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, injured her knee in a fall today and plans to fly to Houston for surgery, a spokesman said. Mrs. Chamorro, the National Opposition Union candidate, hoped to return here by mid-January, said the spokesman, Luis Chavez. Elections are scheduled for Feb. 25.

title: Contemplating the Past, at 40 Going on 36
description: As of Wednesday I am no longer 30-something. Nor am I 40-odd; that will come next. Beginning Wednesday and for the rest of this year I am just plain smack-in-the-middle-of-your-life 40.

title: A Blue Cheese Made in Iowa With Gallic-Flavored Care
description: LEAD: UNLIKE the impersonal processing plants that are so often behind the quaint images of specialty food producers, the home of Maytag Dairy Farm, maker of Maytag blue cheese, is the real thing.

title: Study Says Ford Leads In Efficiency
description: A study of North American auto plants has concluded that the Ford Motor Company has better manufacturing efficiency than its Big Three rivals, giving it the best competitive position for the 1990's.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Predicting The Trends Of the 1990's
description: IF the 1980's witnessed the transformation of advertising agencies into diversified marketing/communications conglomerates, the 1990's will mark the continuing evolution in the advertising images that Americans will see and in the companies that will provide them.

title: Allegheny Selling Stake in Titanium
description: Allegheny International Inc. reached an agreement to sell its interest in the Titanium Metals Corporation of America to the Baroid Corporation. Allegheny said Baroid, based in Houston, would pay $50 million for about 30 percent of Titanium Metal's outstanding stock and for a $3.25 million note to be paid by the metal company. The deal will give Baroid, which supplies services and equipment for oil and gas well drilling, complete ownership of Titanium Metal.

title: Inflation Up in Sri Lanka
description: Sri Lanka's annual inflation rate rose marginally, to 15.1 percent, in December, from 15 percent in the period a year ago. The index rose 3.8 percent in December alone, up from a rise of 2.3 percent in November and 2 percent in December 1988.

title: With Rural Towns Vanishing, States Choose Which to Save
description: Since the 1950's half the people and most of the businesses have left the barren buttes and prairies of Sheridan County in central North Dakota. The county has no doctor, no hospital, no traffic light, no Greyhound bus service and more ghost towns than live ones.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Accounts
description: * Cadbury Schweppes, to Ammirati & Puris, for its Crush and Hires soft drinks, with an undetermined budget.

title: Genentech Seeks Approval for Drug
description: Genentech filed an application with the Food and Drug Administration seeking approval to sell gamma interferon to treat patients with chronic granulomatous disease. If approved, it would be the third drug created by genetic engineering to be sold by the biotechnology company, based in South San Francisco, Calif. The others are human growth hormone, for children suffering from dwarfism, and tissue plasminogen activator, for heart attack victims.

title: Bucharest Says Entire Politburo Ruled by Ceausescu Is in Custody
description: All members of the Rumanian Politburo commanded by Nicolae Ceausescu, the executed dictator, are in detention, a spokesman for the current Government declared today.

title: U.N. Takes Step Toward Global Climate Pact
description: After difficult negotiations, the nations of the world have laid the groundwork for an accord between rich and poor countries on protecting the atmosphere and encouraging ecologically sound development.

title: Barbara Miller Wed in Omaha
description: Barbara Ruth Miller, a Foreign Service officer, was married yesterday in Omaha to Dr. James H. Alleman, the director of the International Center for Telecommunications Management at the University of Nebraska at Omaha. Judge Samuel V. Cooper of the Douglas County Court in Omaha officiated at the home of the bride and bridegroom.

title: State of State: Proposals by the Dozen
description: The annual State of the State address, which Gov. Mario M. Cuomo will deliver here on Wednesday, is often described as a road map for the coming year, filled with gubernatorial directives and proposals. But it also has its share of dead ends.

title: RAC Income Fund reports earnings for As of Oct 31
description: Net income represented net assets. The company began operations on Dec. 30, 1988.

title: Good Fortune Prompts Gifts For Neediest
description: For some people, the way to celebrate good fortune - their own or that of others - is to give to those whom fortune has overlooked. Few occasions bring that generosity out more than a wedding, or the prospect of one.

title: Sort Out Your Chilies
description: To The Living Section:

title: Volcano Spews Plume In Largest Outburst Yet
description: Redoubt Volcano erupted again today in what scientists said appeared to be the largest outburst since the volcano emerged in December from a 25-year sleep.

title: R. Jess Brown, 77, Civil Rights Lawyer In Mississippi Cases
description: R. Jess Brown, a civil rights lawyer whose clients included James Meredith and a young black man who was lynched before he could be brought to trial on charges of raping a white woman, died of cancer on Sunday at Hinds General Hospital here. He was 77 years old and lived in Jackson.

title: Brief Trading Halt in Italy
description: Stockbrokers in various parts of Italy today suspended trading of shares for 20 minutes to protest the nation's slow pace in modernizing the securities business.

title: Local Military Contractors Cautiously Brace for Peace
description: As relations warm with the Soviet Union and talk grows in Washington of smaller defense budgets, military contractors in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut and communities dependent on military bases are girding themselves for what might become leaner times.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: PRO BASKETBALL

title: Alpha Microsystems reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 26
Phone Fraud: It's Still a Big Problem on Campus
description: With college students returning to campuses after the holiday break, long-distance telephone companies are continuing their nationwide crackdown on students who steal telephone services by using illegal credit card numbers and access codes.

title: Hurricanes Produce Convincing Victory
description: At halftime in the Sugar Bowl game here Monday night, the University of Miami, in a battle with the Crimson Tide of Alabama, was still No. 2 in the country. But as the second half wore down, the Hurricanes had become No. 1, especially in the hearts and minds of their fans at the Superdome.

title: And Now, The Last Word On Dieting: Don't Bother
description: AH, the Great Diet Paradox: If you diet long enough, you're not really dieting anymore.

title: A Deficit of $65 Million Is Seen in Connecticut
description: Budget officials said today that falling sales-tax revenues and rising welfare costs will leave Connecticut with a budget deficit of $65 million for the fiscal year ending June 30.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: EVERYONE in the food industry is talking about a return to homey cooking in the 1990's - call it bistro, traditional American, unfussy Italian, whatever - which started me thinking about offal, something I associate with home cooking in France. Offal, or variety meats, includes liver, kidney, tripe, tongue, brain, sweetbreads and other internal organs. Most commonly used are those of lamb, mutton, beef and veal.

title: A Top Officer At Shearson Steps Down
description: Jeffrey B. Lane, one of the top officials at Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc., has resigned from the firm he has worked for since 1969 to pursue business opportunities elsewhere.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Top Officer Resigns At Diversified Services
description: Barry E. Loughrane has resigned as chairman and chief executive of Diversified Agency Services, the division of the Omnicom Group that includes its direct marketing, financial advertising and other specialty communications companies. Bruce Crawford, president and chief executive of Omnicom, will take over as chief executive of Diversified Agency Services.

title: The Mosaic Thing
description: First there was the melting pot, but that seemed overly romantic. Then came patchwork quilt, a down-home image that Jesse Jackson has used over the years. Now the metaphor of the moment is gorgeous mosaic, Mayor David Dinkins's favorite description of New York City. ''I see New York as a gorgeous mosaic of race and religious faith, of national origin and sexual orientation,'' he said in his Inaugural Address on Monday, turning his oft-used campaign slogan into - a trademark, the equivalent of George Bush's ''kinder, gentler nation.''

title: INSIDE
description: A Stock Market Record:

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The state wants to keep every community it can. But when you have a declining population and tax base and have to keep the schools going and the highways going and the medical services and the nursing homes, it's going to be almost impossible to keep these communities alive.''

title: Celebrating 2 Ex-Knicks
description: As part of the celebration of the 20th anniversary of the first of the franchise's two National Basketball Association championships, the Knicks will retire Dick Barnett's number and honor Red Holzman, the coach of that team. The ceremonies will take place during halftime of the March 10 game against the Nets at Madison Square Garden.

title: Strike Leaves Deep Vein of Anger in Coal Country
description: There were no celebrations in the coal towns of Appalachia today, no banners unfurled, no outward signs of joy that there may soon be an end to one of the nation's longest and most bitter miners' strikes.

title: Union Pacific Agrees To Sell Real Estate
description: The Union Pacific Corporation said today that it had agreed to sell most of the assets of its Union Pacific Realty subsidiary to a California real estate investment firm for about $532 million.

title: U.S. Economy Stayed In Slump in December
description: The economy remained in a slump in December, although production levels rose and exports expanded, the nation's purchasing managers said in a monthly report.

title: WINE TALK
description: THERE is no dearth of experts ready to tell us what to drink. Most concentrate on what to buy for the next few weeks, with occasional tips on wines to lay down for the future. Would anyone dare suggest what we will be drinking for the next 10 years?

title: For Bavaro, Season Ends and Surgery Looms
description: When Mark Bavaro is healthy, he is probably the best tight end in pro football. But he is far from healthy now, and today Coach Bill Parcells of the Giants said Bavaro would be unable to play for the rest of the season.

title: LAWMAKER IS SEEN ACCEPTING $3,000
description: Jurors today watched a videotape that showed a State Senator who is charged with bribery and extortion accepting a $3,000 check from an undercover Federal agent.

title: Land Deal Is Described at Lincoln Hearing
description: A Tucson, Ariz., mortgage broker told a Federal District Court examining the Government takeover of the Lincoln Savings and Loan Association today that he had legally bought a parcel of land for $14 million, as a favor to an associate of Charles H. Keating Jr., even though he had no intention of taking possession of the property.

title: 30,123 Entries On Sale List
description: Savings institution regulators today printed what amounts to one of the largest real estate listings ever published.

title: Liberia's Leader Ousts Aide For Ignoring Hints of a Coup
description: The President of Liberia, Gen. Samuel K. Doe, dismissed his Interior Minister today for failing to heed a warning of an uprising by dissidents last week.

title: Prague Chief Visits Germanys
description: President Vaclav Havel of Czechoslovakia paid brief visits, laden with symbolism, to East and West Germany. It was the former dissident's first official foreign trip. Page A13.

title: Reagan Fighting a Subpoena
description: Former President Ronald Reagan moved today to stall attempts to subpoena him as a witness at the trial of his former national security adviser, John M. Poindexter, in the Iran-contra affair.

title: Chiron-Ortho Pact For Du Pont Unit
description: The Chiron Corporation and Ortho Diagnostic Systems Inc., a unit of Johnson & Johnson, said they had an agreement to buy most of the AIDS and hepatitis blood-screening business of E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company. The companies, which said last week that they were discussing the acquisition, did not disclose terms. The business will be combined with Ortho and Chiron's AIDS- and hepatitis-diagnosing business.

title: New Chief to Be Named at Federal Health Agency
description: Dr. William Roper, the top health adviser at the White House, will be named head of the Federal Centers for Disease Control, Federal officials said today.

title: CSX Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $1,000,000 for the quarter and income of $2,000,000, or 2 cents a share, for the year, both from discontinued operations, and the year also included a gain on disposal of discontinued operations of $23,000,000, or 23 cents a share. c-After a loss of $4,000,000 for the quarter and income of $5,000,000, or 3 cents a share, for the year, from discontinued operations and the year also included a gain of $180,000,000, or $1.23 a share, on disposal of discontinued operations.

title: For Dinkins and Fernandez, First Day on Job Is Brisk;   Chancellor Pays Visit To School That Uses Some Power Sharing
description: Joseph A. Fernandez took over as chancellor of New York City's schools yesterday with gestures that swiftly underscored his intention to reshape the troubled system: he visited a school in Brooklyn where teachers share leadership with the principal and he brought the president of the teachers union along for the tour.

title: Couple Enter Not Guilty Pleas To Missouri Murder Charges
description: A farm couple pleaded not guilty Tuesday to charges of slaying five transient workers to cover up a cattle-theft scheme in northwestern Missouri.

title: Tandem Expected To Show Computer
description: Tandem Computers Inc. is expected to introduce next Monday its first fault-tolerant computer based on the Unix operating system, analysts said. The company has scheduled a news conference for Monday for an announcement, but officials were unavailable to elaborate.

title: Economic Scene;   The Americans Are Coming
description: TO Jacques Delors, president of the European Commission, the case for discouraging European imports of American television programming is self-evident. ''Have we the right to exist, to perpetuate our traditions?'' he asked broadcasters meeting in Paris in October. They approved guidelines for 1992 limiting American programs to 50 percent of air time.

title: Poland's Brave Plunge
description: The Polish celebration of the new year has already ended. The crash program to propel the economy into capitalism has gone abruptly into effect, and that means pain. The price of heating fuel may jump by seven times. Other necessities will also cost much more. And hundreds of thousands of workers will soon be unemployed.

title: 70% Wage Increase Decreed in Lebanon, Fueling Rise in Tensions
description: Lebanon's already severe political and military tensions have been further strained by the prospect of widespread labor and economic upheaval.

title: For Epicurean Elite, Trouble in Paradise
description: GASTRONOME is the magazine of the Chaine des Rotisseurs, a food and wine society with about 7,000 members in this country and some 50,000 more worldwide. Gastronome articles read like this:

title: O'Toole's Group reports earnings for Year to Aug 31
description: Some year-ago figures have been restated. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: A Death in Border Clashes In a Muslim Soviet Republic
description: One death and two separate episodes of riot and ambush were reported today in the southern Soviet republic of Azerbaijan, with Tass, the Soviet press agency, describing ''barbarous'' actions and rising tensions along the Iranian border.

title: Stuffing, in Their Words
description: To The Living Section:

title: Nichols Research Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
U.S. Aid for Khmer Rouge Is Repugnant
description: To the Editor:

title: Vector Aeromotive Corp. reports earnings for Year to Aug 31
Earth Technology Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 24
Tranzonic Cos. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Included a gain of $701,500, or 19 cents a share, from the cumulative effect of prior periods of an accounting change for income taxes. c-Included income tax credit of $606,000, or 17 cents a share, because of change of accounting estimate.

title: Tap Transport Trust
description: To the Editor:

title: Don't Roll Back 'Roe'
description: LEAD: The public debate over abortion, already bitter, is likely to become even more so. Indeed, with state legislatures debating new restrictions made possible by the Supreme Court's decision in Webster v. Reproductive Health Services, consensus looks further away every day.

title: Booming Business: Drug Use Tests
description: As employers begin testing millions of transportation workers for drug use under Federal rules that took effect in December, the laboratories that conduct the tests say their business is surging.

title: The Fed Intervenes to Slow Dollar's Rise Against Yen
description: The dollar rose sharply yesterday, forcing the Federal Reserve to intervene by selling dollars several times to stem its rally against the Japanese yen.

title: Books of The Times;   A Vietnam Medic Heals His Own Hidden Wounds
description: Veteran's Day

title: Critic's Notebook;   Film Makers' Youth: Outsiders Looking In
description: In an interview with Martin Scorsese not long before ''The Last Temptation of Christ'' opened, I asked when he had first read the novel on which the film was based. The answer emerged 15 minutes later: he had heard about the book as a film student at New York University. But first his conversation took a revealing detour through his childhood in Little Italy, where he was an asthmatic boy who spent endless hours at movie theaters watching biblical epics in Cinemascope and even more time rooted in front of the family television set watching black-and-white reruns of ''The Red Shoes.'' It seemed he could not mention the university without recalling how foreign it had seemed to someone from what he called the ''feudal'' society of Little Italy, and he could not discuss his affection for film without describing his childhood as a boy who did not run and roughhouse as much as most.

title: I.R.A. Kills Ulster Cab Driver And Cites Paramilitary Link
description: I.R.A. bombers today killed a Belfast taxi driver taking his teen-age daughter to school and said he had been a Protestant paramilitary militant.

title: Andover Offers Tuition Prepayment
description: What is thought to be the first ''guaranteed tuition'' plan at the secondary school level has been announced by Phillips Academy at Andover, Mass.

title: 28 Invited to Train
description: Brent Goulet, dropped from the United States national soccer team last fall after a scoring slump, was among 28 players invited yesterday to report to the team's training camp when it regroups Friday to prepare for the World Cup.(AP)

title: Eligible Bachelors (And They Cook)
description: GREAT COOK: 43, together, tall, fit, attractive, divorced male professional with youthful outlook toward life in search of attractive, classy, fun-loving female . . .

title: Suns Snap the Knicks' Two Winning Streaks
description: The scoring, the shooting and the assists were down and the defense was spotty in the last four games for the Knicks, indications that their home-court supremacy and winning streak were in jeopardy.

title: Final Call in the Polls Is Clear: Miami Is No. 1
description: At the corner of San Amaro and Corniche, at the edge of the University of Miami campus, several hundred noisy people dressed in orange and green gathered this afternoon to surround a crystal football that rested behind the glass of a circular 7-foot case.

title: Assassination Attempt Reported by Prosecutor
description: The Camden County Prosecutor said today that two gunmen fired at him on Monday in what he described as an unsuccessful drug-related assassination attempt. He shot one of the assailants in the head, he said.

title: Reaction Mixed to Certification Plan
description: An agreement among seven Northeast states that will ease restrictions for teachers who want to cross state lines for a job is getting a mixed reaction from educators.

title: Apogee Enterprises reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 2
description: b-Included an after-tax charge of $1.9 million related to a performance guarantee for an independent contractor; the 9 months also included a charge of $1 million related to the sale of its solarium international subsidiary.

title: New Rival for Personal Computer
description: The personal computer, which has dominated the computer industry since the early 1980's, has a new competitor that could someday take away a significant share of the office market.

title: Bread, Up 38%, Gas, Up 100%, But Still the Poles Are Hopeful
description: The Government's economic program to move Poland toward capitalism went into full force today, and Poles were shaken but optimistic as bread prices jumped by 38 percent and coal prices for households by 600 percent.

title: Miniscribe, Citing Lawsuits, Makes Bankruptcy Filing
description: The Miniscribe Corporation, which makes disk drives for computers, said today that it had filed for protection under Chapter 11 of the Bankruptcy Code.

title: Correction
description: A chart on Monday showing New York City parking rules for 1990 misstated the date for Labor Day, when Sunday rules will be in effect. It is Sept. 3, not Sept. 12.

title: American Nursery Products reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Rise in Health Insurance Rates Levels Off
description: After several years of climbing steeply, increases in health insurance rates are leveling off in many parts of the country, according to executives of the Blue Cross and Blue Shield Association, the nation's largest health insurer.

title: Czechoslovak President Visits Wall and Buries It
description: Vaclav Havel, Czechoslovakia's dissident-turned-President, paid brief visits laden with symbolism to both Germanys today in his first trip abroad since becoming head of state on Friday.

title: Exxon Pipeline Spills Oil Into the Arthur Kill
description: A ruptured pipe from an Exxon refinery in Linden, N .J., leaked 5,000 gallons of heating oil into the Arthur Kill between Staten Island and New Jersey yesterday morning, the Coast Guard said.

title: Murdoch Hires Outsider To Run British Papers
description: To hear Rupert Murdoch tell it, the British portion of his publishing and television empire is consuming too much of his time, and Andrew Knight is just the man to do something about it.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A2-13

title: EATING WELL
description: BABY BOOMERS brought up on a steady diet of children's cereals in the 1960's and 70's must be struck by the commercials for adult cereals over the last two or three years. Unlike the commercials of their youth, which emphasized fun and tie-ins with television characters, adult cereals trumpet their fiber and dried fruits. They are all about health.

title: About Education
description: In a happy academic coalition, Fiorello H. La Guardia Community College in Long Island City, Queens, which admits all applicants, and highly selective Vassar College in Poughkeepsie, N.Y., have become what they describe as an academic ''odd couple.''

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;

West Coast Executive Promoted by Drexel
description: LEAD: Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. said yesterday that Allan Sher, who oversees the investment firm's West Coast operations, had been promoted to vice chairman.

title: Construction Outlays Up In November
description: Construction spending rose 1.5 percent in November, hitting a 10-month high, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: 2 Campeau Units Win Delay In Default on Bank Loans
description: The two American retail subsidiaries of the Campeau Corporation said yesterday that they had received a two-week reprieve from a threat by their bank lenders to declare $2.34 billion loans in default.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Addenda
description: * Hal Riney & Partners has moved its New York office to 100 East 42d Street, Manhattan.

title: Tale of Two Dictators
description: An American invasion finally dumped Gen. Manuel Noriega of Panama. Popular fury rid Rumania of the Ceausescus. Various means reach the end.

title: A.J. Ross Logistics reports earnings for Year to Aug 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary loss of $454,000. c-Net income The company said the loss for the year was attributable to unusual and nonrecurring items, including a reserve for an anticipated collective bargaining settlement, an inventory readjustment, taxes, penalties and interest, and an extraordinary loss related to an early extinguishment of debt.

title: Spy's Role in Soviet H-Bomb Now Discounted
description: Nuclear experts have concluded that the Soviet Union learned almost nothing of how to make the hydrogen bomb from the atom spy Klaus Fuchs and may have instead deduced the crucial secret by analyzing radioactive fallout from American nuclear blasts.

title: Governor O'Neill's Commuter War
description: Fares for Metro-North commuters went up 15 percent on New Year's Day - except for riders to and from Connecticut. At the last minute, Gov. William O'Neill vetoed any increase within Connecticut's boundaries. By blocking needed funds, he pandered to affluent Fairfield County commuters. In a gubernatorial election year, that's good politics but weak leadership.

title: Oxford Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 1
For Judaism's Remnant, Coup Is Mixed Blessing
description: For Rumania's fast-disappearing Jewish minority, the overthrow of Nicolae Ceausescu represents something of a mixed blessing.

title: Fitch Benches Carroll For Uninspired Effort
description: The Nets' starting lineup was so inept tonight, the game was lost almost from the moment it began. And it was an especially frustrating and embarrassing night for Joe Barry Carroll, the starting center.

title: To Lithuania: Stay Put
description: LEAD: The Lithuanian Communist Party, by breaking with Moscow, has raised the expectations of secessionist movements in Lithuania, the other Baltic republics and among each of the 104 ethnic nationalities in 12 other republics, 20 autonomous republics and 18 national districts that comprise the Soviet Union.

title: Labor Dispute in Louisiana Ends With Ecological Gain
description: The end of a long, bitter labor dispute against a major Louisiana chemical maker has left in its wake not just a new contract but a new toughness in the state's environmental movement.

title: The Pop Life
description: Among the innovations the 1980's brought to pop music were the rise of MTV, home videos, the compact disk and rap. But what comes next? The heads of three major record companies were invited to speculate on what the 90's might hold for pop music technologically, stylistically and in the techniques for breaking - record company parlance for commercially establishing - performers.

title: Vow by Schembechler
description: Bo Schembechler seemed more convinced than ever yesterday that Michigan could have beaten Southern Cal in the Rose Bowl were it not for a controversial penalty on a fake-punt run late in the game.

title: Crossman, LaFontaine Each Score Twice
description: The Islanders, who have spent most of the season in last place, began the second half of their schedule by vacating it.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Markets

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Bronx Councilman in Line For Top Post on Land Use
description: As the New York City Council begins assuming greater powers under a new charter, its leadership has hired staff members, raised salaries and shaken up its most important committess.

title: Material in 4 Bombs Was the Same, F.B.I. Finds
description: Bombs that killed a Federal judge and a Savannah lawyer last month as well as two others disarmed before exploding were made from the same material, a Federal Bureau of Investigation spokesman here said today.

title: Perles High on Jets' List
description: George Perles of Michigan State is the front-runner in the Jets' search for a new coach, several sources in the National Football League and in the college ranks said yesterday.

title: Treasury Securities Down Slightly
description: The credit markets opened the new year on a somewhat sour note yesterday, as prices of Treasury securities dipped slightly in light trading.

title: Karajan's Provocative Successor at Salzburg
description: ''Not all operas should be played. It is good to hear some unknown operas, but also good to forget some. There is no real reason to stage Wagner's 'Ring' now that Patrice Chereau has done it for our time at Bayreuth.''

title: Chicago Journal;   Famed Shopping Street Is Fighting for Survival
description: Maxwell Street has been called ''The Great Incubator of Capitalism.'' It has also been called a junkyard. Both descriptions fit.

title: METROPOLITAN DIARY
description: LUCIUS BOLEY is standing in the cafeteria line at the American Museum of Natural History. Ever-mindful of his low-cholesterol diet, Mr. Boley seeks the help of a young woman in front of him in making his choice. 'Is that meat or vegetable?'' he asks. ''I wouldn't know,'' she replies. ''I'm in fossils.''

title: Book Notes
description: Japanese Literature

title: Advice on Negotiating Legal Thickets of the Wine Business
description: WANT to open a winery in New York State? Want to teach or learn about New York wines? The New York Wine and Grape Foundation, expecting a burst of winery openings in the 1990's, has begun a publishing program designed to meet such information needs.

title: Review/Music;   Rap and Politics From Public Enemy
description: Public Enemy's show early on New Year's Day at the World was a mess of contradictions. The group, notorious because of its anti-Semitic statements, both in interviews and on its most recent single, ''Welcome to the Terrordome,'' allows inconsistencies to make its show politically incoherent. Group members pronounce anti-authoritarian slogans like the ambiguous ''fight the power'' while keeping a squad of stone-faced guards -dressed in military outfits, and the image of power - onstage. One minute they claim that all races and religions are ''in this mess together,'' the next they state that the choice is to be ''human or Caucasian.'' Great minds they're not.

title: New Wisconsin Coach
description: Barry Alvarez, an assistant for Notre Dame the last three seasons, took over yesterday as the head coach for Wisconsin.

title: Is This Justice Necessary?
description: Surely the United States can't really want custody of General Noriega. It's understandable, of course, that President Bush should pretend he does. Having sent the Army to unhorse a tinpot Caesar, he is obliged to huff and puff about having him handed over to Yankee justice.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Life Offers Discount For Running Old Ads
description: In its latest effort to tap the nostalgia boom, Life magazine is offering a discount to advertisers who run old ads next to new ones. Advertisers who pay the current price for a full-page ad get the adjacent page for an old ad at the rate in effect when the ad first ran. The vintage ad must be at least 10 years old, and advertisers are promised at least a 24.1 percent discount over a standard two-page spread.

title: Budget to Be a Week Late, White House Tells Congress
description: The Bush Administration has told the Democratic leadership in Congress that it cannot meet the statutory deadline for its 1991 budget and will submit it Jan. 29, a week late.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   People
description: * Ronald J. Benza and Steve Centrillo have been promoted to executive vice president and general manager, and senior vice president and management supervisor, respectively, of Bozell's Minneapolis office.

title: Panamanian Runs the Canal: A First
description: In the tumult surrounding the American military invasion of Panama and the overthrow of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, one historic watershed has passed without fanfare: For the first time in its 75-year history, the Panama Canal is now being run by a Panamanian.

title: In the Air Where the Martyrs Fell, A Question: Where To From Here?
description: In Palace Square, where the worst of the fighting had taken place, the people came slowly across the cobblestones, huddled against the cold, as if a long hibernation had just ended.

title: 20 Quit at The Jerusalem Post
description: The new publisher of The Jerusalem Post accepted the resignations today of 20 senior editors and longtime reporters who objected to what they called the publisher's moves to turn the liberal daily into a platform for right-wing views.

title: Evangelos Averoff, Ex-Official of Greece And a Politician, 79
description: Evangelos Averoff, a former Foreign Minister and former Defense Minister of Greece and a leading conservative politician, died of a heart attack in Apolloneion Hospital in Athens yesterday, an official at the Greek Mission to the United Nations said. He was 79 years old.

title: Orange Bowl Top Draw
description: NBC's telecast of Notre Dame's victory over Colorado in the Orange Bowl drew more than twice as many viewers as ABC's broadcast of Miami's victory over Alabama in the Sugar Bowl, according to overnight ratings released yesterday.

title: MacLeod Hopeful
description: John MacLeod, former coach of the Dallas Mavericks, said yesterday in Dallas that he was ''just waiting'' to hear back from the Sacramento Kings, who have reportedly narrowed their search for a new head coach to MacLeod and two others.

title: Lawrence Alloway Is Dead at 63; Art Historian, Curator and Critic
description: Lawrence Alloway, an English-born art critic, historian and curator who was one of the earliest European champions of postwar American art, died of cardiac arrest yesterday morning at his home in Manhattan. He was 63.

title: Chemicals Sprayed on Oil Slick Off Morocco to Safeguard Coastline
description: Helicopters sprayed chemical agents on a 100-square-mile oil slick and cleanup crews vacuumed some of the muck from the surface of the Atlantic Ocean today in efforts to protect Morocco's coastline.

title: Bush Picks a Panama Envoy And Sends Team There, Too
description: President Bush today announced the appointment of a veteran diplomat, Deane R. Hinton, as the new United States Ambassador to Panama.

title: Bank of Boston Acts to Offset Bad Property Loans
description: The Bank of Boston Corporation yesterday announced additional losses from its real estate lending but said it expected to break even in the fourth quarter as the losses were offset by profits from selling most of its credit card business to the Chase Manhattan Corporation and the restructuring of its pension fund.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Federal Bank, Greenville, S.C., named Michael A. Trimble, its chief financial officer, to the additional post of chief operating officer.

title: Vincent T. Malone, Stockbroker, 64
description: Vincent T. Malone, a retired senior vice president of the Manhattan stockbrokerage firm of Pershing & Company, died of cancer on Friday at his home in Monmouth Beach, N.J. He was 64 years old.

title: Ketema Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Comparable results are not available because the company began independent operations on Dec. 1, 1988.

title: Lessons
description: American grade schoolers can be forgiven if they occasionally confuse their classrooms with aviaries.

title: Burke Stands Out as Devils Get Back to Winning
description: The Devils rebounded from a loss to one of the worst teams in the National Hockey League with a victory tonight over the team with the best record in the league.

title: C.D.'s, Bank Funds Steady
description: Yields on certificates of deposit and money market accounts at commercial banks and savings institutions were mostly unchanged for the week ended yesterday.

title: Peru Inflation at 2,775.3%
description: Peru's inflation rate reached 2,775.3 percent in the last 12 months after consumer prices rose 33.8 percent in December, Government figures showed today. Last month's inflation was down from the 42.9 percent rate in December 1988.

title: Index for Jakarta Stocks
description: A new daily index to measure the Jakarta stock market will be issued starting Wednesday by BT Brokerage Asia, a unit of Bankers Trust New York. The Jakarta Stock Exchange's own index has been criticized as being imprecise. The base of the BT Jakarta index will be Jan. 4, 1988, and will use the adjusted weighted capital of all issued shares of listed companies, BT said today.

title: EASTERN CUTS FARE ON MANY ROUTES
description: Eastern Airlines yesterday introduced fares at up to 45 percent below the lowest discount fares in the industry.

title: FACING SENTENCING, REP. GARCIA QUITS
description: Representative Robert Garcia, one of the country's leading Hispanic politicians, resigned his House seat from the Bronx yesterday less than two weeks before he is to be sentenced on conspiracy and extortion convictions, and Assemblyman Jose R. Serrano emerged as the person most likely to replace him.

title: Felix Bloch, Still in Limbo
description: For several days last summer Felix Bloch, the suspended diplomat, was being tailed by the F.B.I. and the agents in turn were tailed by journalists and photographers - all on the streets of Washington and much of it on television news.

title: 2 Nuns, One From U.S., Are Slain By Gunmen in Nicaragua Ambush
description: Two Roman Catholic nuns, one of them American, were killed Monday night when their pickup truck was attacked on an isolated highway in this remote Atlantic Coast region by armed men who Government and church officials said were American-backed contras.

title: Dow Soars To 2,810.15, New Peak
description: Investors greeted the new year yesterday with a burst of enthusiam that catapulted the Dow Jones industrial average beyond 2,800 to its highest level ever.

title: Calculators Cleared For Students Taking Regents Math Tests
description: For the first time, students in New York State will be allowed to use calculators next year on their mathematics Regents examinations, a State Education Department official said today.

title: George B. Vest, Ex-Government Lawyer, 94
description: George B. Vest, general counsel of the Federal Reserve Board from 1945 until his retirement in 1957, died of liver cancer on Sunday at his home in Washington. He was 94 years old.

title: Price-Shaken Argentina Halts the Money Flow
description: As grocery store workers were busy doubling prices and pharmacies opened with nearly bare shelves, the Government of President Carlos Saul Menem undertook a new plan today to turn back inflation by making Argentina's currency a scarce commodity.

title: Rams Are Refusing to Be Left in the Cold
description: When John Robinson came in from the cold to lunch with local reporters today, he looked like a man braced for a rare but occasional afternoon chill. In a city of short sleeves and sunglasses, he wore a light sweater.

title: Midmonth Car Sales Down 21.3%
description: Sales of cars made in the United States continued to remain sluggish, falling 21.3 percent in mid-December from the comparable period a year earlier.

title: In Spain, It's Grand Ham Time
description: If anything unites the European continent it is the ubiquitous pig in all its culinary renderings. But it is hard to imagine the pig being more deeply rooted in folklore, tradition and gastronomy than it is in Spain.

title: BRIEFS
description: * American General Corp., Houston, a holding company, said it had completed the sale of its group life and health insurance operations to Associated Insurance Cos., Indianapolis. The price included $175 million in cash and a $10 million note.

title: Notre Dame Only Played 1 Bad Game
description: rrLou Holtz, who had a golf appointment later in the day, sounded very much the golfer devising some exotic handicap system as he tried to justify why Notre Dame should be rated the top college team in the country, instead of Miami, which is.

title: Royal Palm Beach Colony L.P. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: Share earnings represented earnings per partnership unit.

title: Drug Foe's Brother Is Killed in Quarrel With His Landlord
description: The brother of Maria Hernandez, the Brooklyn woman who had campaigned against drug dealers on her block and who was shot to death last August, was killed Monday in an argument with his landlord, the police said.

title: Japan's Luxury-Car Gains Pose New Threat to Rivals
description: Behind Japan's recent entry into the luxury car market lies a fundamental change in the way the Japanese producers manufacture cars, posing a new and costly challenge to Detroit and other rivals.

title: Fare Rises But Riders Keep Cool
description: On the first working day of the new year yesterday, most New Yorkers appeared to greet the transit fare increase with resignation, indifference and pockets filled with tokens bought at the old price.

title: Chrysler Shows Van Concept
description: The Chrysler Corporation today introduced a futuristic concept vehicle that combines a compact car and a mini-van.

title: Review/Opera;   With Dazzle and Hubbub, 'Turandot' at the Met
description: Franco Zeffirelli's extravagant staging of Puccini's ''Turandot'' generated considerable heat when the Metropolitan Opera unveiled it in 1987. Like most of the director's other recent productions, it seemed predicated on the notions that operagoers' eyes should get as thorough a workout as their ears, and that no expense should be spared in the pursuit of detail.

title: Alaskan Volcano Settles Down
description: Redoubt Volcano quieted down today after a violent outburst that sent ash and steam eight miles into the sky and caused some airlines to cancel flights.

title: City Cars Taken Away From School Officials
description: Bearing down on what he called wasteful spending, Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez yesterday took city cars away from 14 top-level Board of Education officials who, he said, were using them chiefly to get to and from work.

title: Group Halts Deal With L. J. Hooker
description: A $400 million offer to buy various real estate assets of the financially distressed L. J. Hooker Corporation has been withdrawn, according to an executive of the Shidler Investment Corporation, a Honolulu company that is part of the investment group involved in the deal. Ian Killips, a Shidler partner, said the LHJ Funding Company broke off negotiations because of Hooker's decision to sell the properties individually. The group preferred to buy the regional malls and office buildings as a package, he said.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE ECONOMY

title: Jerusalem Journal;   Who Needs Hebrew? More and More Palestinians
description: Like thousands of new immigrants, foreign diplomats and exchange students before them, Nabil Mushara, Mohammed Lafi and Issam Kassis spend four hours a week studying Hebrew for beginners.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Noriega will finally have his day in court, which is more than he gave the people of Panama.''

title: Coghlan Reconsiders
description: Just over a year after he retired from competition after suffering a hairline leg fracture and other injuries in an automobile accident, Eamonn Coghlan, the world-record holder in the indoor mile, announced that he was suspending part of his retirement, the part that takes place under a roof.

title: Study Says the Military Hurts Competitiveness
description: Although Pentagon contracts provide ''safe havens'' for American high-technology companies, the military's emphasis on low-volume, high-cost products has put those companies at a commercial disadvantage, especially in competition with Japanese manufacturers, a study sponsored by the Ford Foundation contends.

title: Close to Home
description: WE went to the animal hospital, my daughter and I, with the cat wrapped up in an old yellow comforter. ''It's all right,'' the cabdriver said when we choked up trying to give directions. ''I know how you feel.''

title: Assassination Attempt in Lebanon Fails
description: An attempt to assassinate Lebanon's chief of military police at a mountain resort near here was foiled today, but four soldiers and a civilian were killed.

title: Guggenheim Artworks Stolen From Italian Villa
description: Thieves raided an Italian villa that houses a collection belonging to the Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation, stealing four paintings and a piece of 18th-century furniture that have a total value of $115,000, the police said.

title: Corrections
description: A chart in Business Day on Saturday headed ''Tracking the Markets'' misstated the dividend yield on the Dow Jones industrials as of Friday and the difference between that yield and the interest on AAA corporate bonds. The Dow dividend yield was 3.6 percent and the resulting spread should have been 5.55 percent.

title: An Architect of Special Effects Builds for Himself
description: WHY is this house smiling?

title: Dr. Nathaniel Pier, 37; Treated AIDS Patients
description: Dr. Nathaniel H. Pier, an internist whose practice consisted largely of AIDS patients, died of acquired immune deficiency syndrome at Roosevelt Hospital. He was 37 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Noriega's Surrender: Overview;   NORIEGA GIVES HIMSELF UP TO U.S. MILITARY; IS FLOWN TO FLORIDA TO FACE DRUG CHARGES
description: President Bush announced tonight that Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega had surrendered to the United States military authorities in Panama, giving the President the final victory he had been seeking in the invasion of Panama.

title: Upheaval in the East: Government;   Council of National Salvation
description: Executive Committee

title: Anselm Kiefer to Receive Israeli Prize
description: The West German painter Anselm Kiefer is to receive the $100,000 Wolf Prize in the arts, the Wolf Foundation announced today.

title: Don't Let Privacy Be a Luxury for the Wealthy;   The Telephone Game
description: To the Editor:

title: Precious Metals Are Down While Crude Oil Prices Rise
description: Precious metal prices continued to fall yesterday, largely on the firmness of the dollar and the belief that the Federal Reserve will not reduce interest rates because of recent signs of economic improvement.

title: Peru, in Switch, Plans to Attend Drug Talks
description: Peru, which said it would boycott a drug summit meeting in Colombia next month to protest the United States attack on Panama, has reversed itself and will attend the conference, American and Peruvian officials said today.

title: Sematech Today: Cash Dispenser
description: Sematech, the Government-industry alliance formed two years ago to develop better ways of making computer chips, has been forced to become a financier as well as a coordinator of company research efforts.

title: Merrill Lynch Deal to Sell Canada Unit
description: Merrill Lynch & Company announced yesterday that it had agreed to sell its Canadian retail securities brokerage business to Wood Gundy Inc., a leading Canadian investment firm.

title: Hollywood Registers A Bonanza For 1989
description: Americans flocked to the movies in 1989, and spent more money at the box office than ever before. Seven films sold over $100 million worth of tickets each, the first time so many have achieved blockbuster status.

title: Upheaval in the East: Soviet Union;   Soviets Reinforcing Troops Along Iranian Border
description: The Soviet Government reinforced its troops along the Iranian border today in the face of continuing reports of destructive protests by Azerbaijani crowds demanding an open frontier.

title: Editor in Chief Named At Elle Decor Magazine
description: Louis Oliver Gropp has been named editor in chief of Elle Decor, a new magazine managed by Diamandis Communications, the American subsidiary of Hachette Publications, the French publishing house.

title: People
description: * Ralph McGill has joined the McDonald Group, Atlanta, as senior vice president and a creative partner.

title: Surveying the State of the Glass Makers' Art
description: LEAD: ''GLASS AMERICA 1990'' is the Heller Gallery's 11th national exhibition of American studio glass and the first major glass show of the 1990's. Over the years, Douglas and Michael Heller have pruned the number of invited glass artists, so that the exhibition now displays work they consider of the highest quality or most innovative.

title: Events: Gardening, Walks and Interiors
description: Exhibit Times Three, The Municipal Art Society, the Urban Center Galleries, 457 Madison Avenue at 51st Street; 212-935-3960.

title: Metro Matters;   New York Hopes, With Eloquence Or Otherwise
description: When David N. Dinkins was running for mayor of New York City last year, his largely lackluster style was sometimes judged against the electricity generated by the Rev. Jesse Jackson.

title: Arthur Gold, a Canadian Pianist Performing in a Duo, Dead at 72
description: Arthur Gold, a Canadian pianist who performed for nearly 40 years as part of a piano duo with Robert Fizdale, died of lung cancer yesterday at the Manhattan apartment he shared with Mr. Fizdale. He was 72 years old, and also had a home in Water Mill, N.Y.

title: Don't Let Privacy Be a Luxury for the Wealthy;   A Bigger Threat
description: To the Editor:

title: Syracuse Slips Past Pitt, 80-78
description: Stephen Thompson, who scored 24 points, converted a 3-point play with 5 seconds left as Syracuse rallied from 13 points down, then lost a 5-point lead before beating Pitt tonight, 80-78.

title: New Insights on Why Some Children Are Fat Offer Clues on Weight Loss
description: Experts are finally gaining insight into the genetic and chemical roots of childhood obesity and are trying to develop sensible programs for childhood weight loss.

title: Green Thumbs in Winter
description: WHEN green thumbs are blue with winter cold, the indoor sill is the garden location of choice. Take the scene at George and Virginie Elbert's Manhattan apartment, which is landscaped with more than 500 plants, give or take a pot or two. Windowsill space has been extended by tiers of shelves and movable tables, and every cranny is covered with vegetation.

title: John P. Devine, Bond Trader, 52
description: John P. Devine, a municipal-bond trader, died of leukemia on Tuesday at Overlook Hospital in Summit, N.J. He was 52 years old and lived in Short Hills, N.J.

title: Upheaval in the East: East Germany;   Leader Promises to Consult With Opposition
description: The interim Government of the Communist Prime Minister, Hans Modrow, promised today to keep political opponents better informed about national affairs and to consult pro-democracy forces before making important decisions.

title: New Gerber President Called Sound Manager
description: Alfred A. Piergallini today was named president and chief executive of the Gerber Products Company, succeeding David W. Johnson, who will take the top posts at the Campbell Soup Company.

title: Herbert Pollack, 84, a Physician, Teacher and Government Adviser
description: Dr. Herbert Pollack, a physician, educator and Government consultant, died of cardiac arrest Tuesday at George Washington University Hospital in Washington. He was 84 years old and lived in Manhattan before moving to Washington about 10 years ago.

title: Upheaval in the East;   Angola Meeting Next Week
description: A meeting of eight African leaders aimed at ending the 14-year Angolan civil war will be held Jan. 10, Angola announced today.

title: Tragedy and Loss Stir Some To Give to the Neediest Cases
description: Some gifts to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund break the heart, as much for the donors' situation as for that of the recipients.

title: Home Improvement
description: WHEN water freezes and expands inside pipes, itcan cause major damage requiring expensive repairs. Frequently, the pressure causes the pipes to burst or, at the least, to leak at the seams. And, because pipes usually freeze when and where coping with them is most difficult, preventing the problem is as important, if not more so, than knowing what to do if it occurs.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A.

title: Don't Let Privacy Be a Luxury for the Wealthy
description: To the Editor:

title: Upheaval in the East: Rumania;   Some Parties Want Elections Postponed
description: Some of Rumania's nascent political parties called today for a delay of national elections, now planned for April, because they said they could not get ready in time.

title: Jackson Calls for Reward in Racial Bombings
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson called on the Bush Administration on Tuesday to offer a reward for the capture of whoever is responsible for the bombings that killed a Federal judge and a civil rights lawyer in the South.

title: Murray S. Kaplan, Lawyer, 82
description: Murray S. Kaplan, a lawyer and textile executive, died of cancer Tuesday at his home in Palm Beach, Fla. He was 82 years old.

title: INSIDE
description: Federal AIDS Estimate Is Being Revised

title: Computer Chip Fails on Venus-Bound Craft
description: The space agency said today that a computer chip had failed on the Magellan spacecraft, but the defect will not endanger the $550 million mission to map the surface of cloud-shrouded Venus starting in August.

title: Oil Spill Cleanup Continues; Iranian Tanker Defects Cited
description: Seamen fought today to keep a huge oil slick from fouling the sensitive Atlantic coastline of Morocco as Dutch television reported that three sister ships of the tanker involved were recently seized for maintenance defects.

title: PERSONAL HEALTH
description: One of the best activities to brighten a dreary winter is cross-country skiing, which is suitable for nearly all ages and stages of physical ability.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article by The Associated Press in some copies yesterday about the killing of two Roman Catholic nuns gave an incorrect date for the collapse of the cease-fire in Nicaragua. It ended on Nov. 1.

title: Noriega's Surrender: Army;   For First Time, a Woman Leads G.I.'s in Combat
description: An Army woman led an attack against troops of the Panamanian Defense Forces last month, the first time a woman has commanded American soldiers in battle, Administration officials said today.

title: DAMAGES LIMITED FOR PAN AM SUITS
description: A Federal judge ruled yesterday that an international treaty bars punitive damages for the families of the 259 passengers and crew members who died in the bombing of Pan American Flight 103 in December 1988 over Lockerbie, Scotland.

title: Stiff Security for Militant as Gaza Trial Opens
description: A cleric who headed a militant Islamic group in the Israeli-occupied Gaza Strip went on trial there today amid tight security.

title: Lecture on the History Of a Black Community
description: Weeksville, a historic community in the Bedford-Stuyvesant section of Brooklyn, is to be the subject of a free lecture on Feb. 7 at 7:30 P.M. at Lehman College, Gillet Hall Auditorium, Goulden Avenue and Bedford Park Boulevard, in the Bedford Park section of the Bronx.

title: G.M. Displays the Impact, An Advanced Electric Car
description: The General Motors Corporation today displayed what it called the most advanced electrically powered car yet developed and said that it could be on the market as soon as the middle of the decade.

title: Alan Hale Jr., Who Was Skipper On 'Gilligan's Island,' Dies at 71
description: Alan Hale Jr., an actor who gained fame as the jolly Skipper in the television series ''Gilligan's Island,'' died of cancer of the thymus on Tuesday at St. Vincent's Medical Center in Los Angeles. He was 71 years old and lived in Hollywood.

title: J. Willcox Dunn, Former Publisher, 91
description: J. Willcox Dunn, a retired newspaper editor and publisher who actively opposed gambling, died Friday at a nursing home here. He was 91 years old.

title: News Summary
description: International A3-15

title: Review/Cabaret;   Songs for Grown-Ups, by Cy Coleman
description: In the literature of pop songs that celebrate sophisticated flirtation, the collaborations of the composer Cy Coleman and the lyricist Carolyn Leigh rank just below those of Cole Porter in their wit and mischievous eroticism. Songs like ''The Best Is Yet to Come,'' ''You Fascinate Me So,'' ''Witchcraft,'' and ''When in Rome'' combine slinky syncopated melodies and tongue-twisting double-entendres to portray a game of romantic hide-and-seek that almost always ends in a passionate embrace. As the narrator of ''You Fascinate Me So'' teases, ''You're like the finish of a novel that I finally have to take to bed.''

title: The Soviets' Terminal Crisis
description: The following article is adapted from the conclusion of a longer historical analysis to be published under the pseudonym ''Z'' in the winter issue of Daedalus, journal of the American Academy of Arts and Sciences. Daedalus is withholding the author's name from all parties at the author's request. (Although it is not The New York Times's usual practice to withhold an author's identity, it is honoring Daedalus's commitment.)

title: Dole Winning Applause For Labor Dept. Actions
description: With her help this week in reaching an agreement in the coal miners' strike in Appalachia, Secretary of Labor Elizabeth Dole has taken a step toward ending a bleak period for organized labor in its relations with the Government.

title: Atlantic City Mayor and 3 Others Are Indicted on Corruption Counts
description: A state grand jury today indicted the mayor of Atlantic City, James L. Usry, and three others on corruption charges in a wide-ranging investigation of influence peddling among government officials in the gaming resort.

title: A Dubious Reagan Achievement
description: Despite Ronald Reagan's pledge to shrink the bureaucracy, Federal employment rose in five of his eight years in the White House. When he left, the headcount was higher than at any time since World War II. So much for that promise.

title: Camping and Hiking Instruction in Cold Weather
description: If you have thought about extending your backpacking activities into cold weather, you might start by attending the Appalachian Mountain Club's Jan. 26-28 winter camping workshop at its Pinkham Notch lodge in the White Mountains in New Hampshire.

title: NBC to Link Broadcast To Cable TV
description: NBC said yesterday that it would begin coordinating the sale of advertising time on its broadcast and cable-television networks, a move that could enable advertisers, for the first time, to buy commercial packages that include the two media.

title: Burmese Government Ends Martial Law in Two Regions
description: The Burmese Government said it was ending martial law in parts of the troubled Mandalay and Sagaing regions starting today, a move seen by diplomats in Bangkok as an attempt to reassure the public before planned elections in May.

title: Scientist Raises Question: Is Tyrannosaurus Still Rex?
description: Generations of children have delighted in the scary lore that Tyrannosaurus rex was the largest and fiercest predator ever to walk the earth. A leading paleontologist has announced, however, that another family of dinosaurs every bit as large and ferocious flourished 30 million years before tyrannosaurs ever saw the light of day.

title: Upheaval in the East: Rumors;   Whispered No Longer, Hearsay Jolts Bucharest
description: Rumors and conspiracy theories, once the spice of this Balkan city's romantic reputation, have crept back to life here, spreading old-fashioned intrigue through the hotel lobbies and coffee shops.

title: Soviet Pressure Sidelines Mogilny
description: When the Buffalo Sabres were the hosts to Moscow Dynamo last night, they chose to leave Aleksandr Mogilny out of their lineup.

title: TRW, Motorola Develop New Chip
description: TRW Inc., of Cleveland, and Motorola Inc., of Schaumburg, Ill., have built a microprocessor chip with four million transistors as part of a Defense Department program to create very-high-speed semiconductors. It is intended for high-speed mathematical applications and can also repair itself.

title: Noriega's Surrender: Celebration;   As Word Spreads in Panama, Thousands Turn Out to Cheer
description: Jubilant street celebrations broke out tonight as the news spread in the capital that the country's deposed military ruler, Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, had voluntarily handed himself over to the United States authorities and would be tried in a United States court.

title: Pontiac Sees Gain in '90
description: The Pontiac division of the General Motors Corporation said today that it expected its domestic market share to rise in 1990 to as much as 7.5 percent from 7.2 percent last year. Pontiac's general manager, John Middlebrook, said an array of new vehicles should help spur sales.

title: Home Is Where the Job Is
