description: BATHED in the burnt-orange light of a fading day, a youthful-looking man with a beard is working at his computer on his deck, his dog at his feet. The message of the advertisement for American Telephone & Telegraph Company is clear: you can stay home in a beautiful setting and still pursue a career that will pay for the deck and the dog food.

title: Joseph Loftus, 82; Was Times Reporter And a Cabinet Aide
description: Joseph A. Loftus, for 25 years a reporter for The New York Times and then a special assistant for communications to Secretary of Labor George P. Shultz, died of heart disease yesterday at his home in Sarasota, Fla. He was 82 years old and had suffered a series of strokes.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about a turnaround in the health insurance business of Blue Cross and Blue Shield associations misstated 1987 financial results for the Independence Blue Cross Association in Philadelphia. It had a loss of $38 million.

title: Subcompact For Chrysler
description: The Chrysler Corporation has been talking with at least one Asian auto maker about a joint project to build a successor to its Omni-Horizon subcompacts, a company executive said. Chrysler Motors' president, Robert Lutz, said the nation's No. 3 auto maker was moving on two fronts to develop a new subcompact for the mid-1990's to succeed the Dodge and Plymouth models. The Omni and Horizon will go out of production early next month when Chrysler shuts down its Jefferson Avenue assembly plant in Detroit.

title: 150 May Be Dead in Crash Of Trains in South Pakistan
description: More than 150 people were feared killed in southern Pakistan early today when a passenger train rammed into a freight train in what the railroad police said could be the worst such accident in the country.

title: Noriega's Surrender;   Guerrillas in Colombia Kill 6 Policemen and 3 Civilians
description: In their first major attacks of the year, leftist guerrillas ambushed and killed six policemen on patrol and burned a city bus, killing three passengers and wounding 20, the police said today.

title: Family Demonstrates Northern Hospitality
description: To the Editor:

title: Talking Deals;   It's Slow Going In Eastern Europe
description: THE Samsonite Corporation, the world's biggest luggage producer, has been working on a deal for six months to make luggage in Hungary for sale in Western Europe. Production is already under way, even though details of a joint venture with a Government cooperative are far from complete.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a calculation error in editing, a table on Monday showing population shifts in the United States misstated percentage changes. A corrected version appears today on page D20.

title: Redmen Pursue Rivalries
description: St. John's, in an apparent reaction to criticism of its soft nonconference schedule, announced yesterday that it wanted to add games against Georgia Tech and Indiana to its 1990-91 basketball schedule and renew a home-and-home series with U.C.L.A. next season.

title: Coast Guard Says Oil Spill Off S.I. Exceeds 200,000 Gallons
description: The rupture of an underwater Exxon pipeline, far more serious than officials calculated on Tuesday, has allowed more than 200,000 gallons of heating oil to leak into the Arthur Kill between Staten Island and New Jersey. Environmentalists said the leak posed a significant danger to wildlife.

title: Upheaval in the East: Caucasus;   Azerbaijan: An Old Puzzle
description: The Azerbaijanis are a Turkic-speaking Shiite Muslim people who live on both sides of the Soviet-Iranian border, in territory that has been a battleground for peoples and tribes for centuries.

title: Japan Store Shuns Bloomingdale's Bid
description: The Tokyu Department Store of Japan said it had decided not to join in a proposed management buyout of the Bloomingdale's department store chain. The decision came late last year after a series of studies and contacts with Bloomingdale's, a Tokyu official said.

title: Review/Ballet;   So Much for 'Nutcracker'; Back to the Repertory
description: Too many sugarplums? The New York City Ballet resumed its repertory season on Tuesday night after having visibly overdosed on a month of ''Nutcrackers.''

title: Currents;   Wiltons, Axminsters And Less
description: FERNANDO MATEO'S flagship Carpet Fashions shop (111 Fourth Avenue, at 12th Street) built its reputation on a far-ranging stock of floor coverings. Now Mr. Mateo and Bill Seyler, vice president of the company, are venturing farther uptown, where about 8,000 samples are on display at a new store at 143 East 54th Street.

title: Storming Through the 80's
description: The latest telegrams were being delivered to the coach of the 1989 unofficial-but-pleased national college football champions, and a floral arrangement was on its way to Dennis Erickson's unfinished office.

title: A Correction: How the Population Has Shifted
description: Because of a calculation error in editing, a table on Monday showing population shifts in the United States Misstated percentage changes. This Corrected chart shows changes in the population of states and census regions, according to the Census Bureau. The 1989 column gives the estimated population as of July 1. The 1980 column gives the population according to the 1980 census.

title: Girl, 12, Is Raped, Burned and Stabbed
description: A 12-year-old girl was repeatedly raped, burned with a red-hot knife and stabbed with an icepick late Tuesday night during a five-hour attack by three teen-agers in a Harlem apartment, the police said yesterday.

title: Where Thomas Jefferson Went to Get Away From It All
description: THE archeologists have unearthed the foundation of a long-lost addition, an afterthought grafted on by an owner who just could not stop tinkering with his original design. The historians have read through reams of letters, uncovering a telling paragraph here, a helpful sentence there.

title: Noriega's Surrender: Indictments;   Drug Importing Charged
description: In the February 1988 indictment in Miami, Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega is charged with conspiracy, racketeering, importing drugs and traveling to further the conspiracy. It accuses him of these activities:

title: Noriega's Surrender: Change of Command;   PANAMANIAN QUITS AFTER TWO WEEKS
description: The newly appointed commander of Panama's security force resigned today, less than two weeks after the country's new civilian Government appointed him to head the remnants of the Panamanian Defense Forces.

title: Mafia Prosecutors Quitting As Strike Forces Disband
description: Nearly one-fourth of the Justice Department's organized crime prosecutors have resigned since Attorney General Dick Thornburgh announced plans to put their strike forces under the control of local United States attorneys.

title: Richard Steinhaus, 61, Lawyer and Lobbyist
description: Richard Z. Steinhaus, a lawyer and lobbyist, died of a heart attack on Dec. 25 at St. Thomas Hospital while on vacation in the United States Virgin Islands. He was 61 years old and lived in Loudonville, a suburb of Albany.

title: I.C.I. Markets Drug
description: Imperial Chemical Industries of London said its Stuart Pharmaceuticals unit had started marketing the anti-depressant drug Elavil. I.C.I. bought Elavil from a joint venture of Johnson & Johnson and Merck & Company on Tuesday in exchange for I.C.I.'s over-the-counter pharmaceutical business. Elavil has annual sales of at least $25 million, said I.C.I., which valued the deal at more than $450 million.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;

New Chief Takes Over At American Healthcare
description: LEAD: After struggling through almost two and a half years of bankruptcy, American Healthcare Management Inc. has completed its reorganization and installed new leadership.

title: Excerpts From Cuomo's Address: 'Journey Toward the Next Millennium'
description: Following are excerpts from the text of Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's State of the State address to the Legislature yesterday:

title: Noriega's Surrender: The Prosecution;   U.S. to Start Noriega Case With Miami Indictment
description: Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega is likely to be brought to a Federal court in Miami on Thursday in the first step in a long and uncertain legal journey as the United States tries to prosecute him on a variety of drug-related charges.

title: Bridge
description: In the final stages of major national championship events, a vast majority of the players are between the ages of 30 and 55. They have acquired the experience, in terms of technique, psychology and partnership adjustment, and they have not reached the point at which stamina begins to fail after hours of grinding concentration.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption yesterday about the inauguration of Andrew P. O'Rourke as Westchester County Executive misidentified the justice who administered the oath. He was Samuel G. Fredman.

title: President Appointed By Pacific Exchange
description: The Pacific Stock Exchange said yesterday that it had appointed Leopold Korins president, effective Jan. 22. Mr. Korins, who is currently managing director of Merrill Lynch Capital Markets, is also expected to be named chief executive officer by the exchange's board of governors on Jan. 25.

title: Bernard Stephens, 72, Ex-Newspaper Editor
description: Bernard Stephens, a retired editor of newspapers for labor unions, died of a heart attack yesterday at North Shore University Hospital in Manhasset, L.I. He was 72 years old and lived in Albertson, L.I.

title: Salvadoran Coffee Boycott Does Harm
description: To the Editor:

title: Jay Wells, 73, Founder Of Rental-TV Concern
description: Jay Wells, who founded Wells Television, which became the country's largest supplier of rental television sets to hotels and hospitals, died of a heart attack on Tuesday at his home in Scarsdale, N.Y. He was 73 years old.

title: Forecast of AIDS Cases Is Cut by 10%
description: Federal scientists have revised their estimates of new AIDS cases in the next three years, saying that while diagnoses will continue to rise sharply, the total number will be at least 10 percent fewer than previously predicted.

title: Rams Are Looking Ahead, Not Back at Easy Victory
description: All day, from the moment they arrived for practice until the sun began to fall in the late afternoon, the Los Angeles Rams were forced to remember the game they played almost two months ago on a warm Sunday at Anaheim Stadium.

title: Howard Helps North Carolina State Top Clemson
description: Brian Howard scored 29 points and Tom Gugliotta hit an 18-foot jumper with six seconds left tonight to lift North Carolina State to a 79-77 victory over Clemson in their Atlantic Coast Conference opener.

title: Group W Sports Gains
description: Group W Sports Marketing has contracted to sell advertising time on the Madison Square Garden Network, a cable television sports service. The Westinghouse Broadcasting Company division was formed last year to serve as advertising representative for regional cable sports networks. The MSG Network will maintain responsibility for its local ad sales effort in New York.

title: Joseph Magruder, 76, Ex-Business Executive
description: Joseph H. Magruder, a retired businessman, died of lung cancer on Saturday at his home in Venice, Fla. He was 76 years old and had lived for many years in Fairfield, Conn.

title: Rangers Actually Win A Game
description: It had been 27 days and 11 games, a brutal stretch of defeat and depression that had not produced a single triumph. The Rangers, then, were slightly rusty with the ceremony they were able to perform last night at Madison Square Garden in the wake of their 2-1 victory.

title: New Uranium Pollution Is Found In Wells at U.S. A-Plant in Ohio
description: Test wells drilled at the Federal Government's Fernald uranium processing plant show a new source of uranium contamination in an underground waterway.

title: Campbell Hires a Chief Executive
description: David W. Johnson, who led a sharp two-year turnaround at the Gerber Products Company, was named yesterday to become president, chief executive and a director of the Campbell Soup Company, one of the world's largest but most troubled food companies.

title: Soothing Wood That Gets Too Much Sun
description: LEAD: Furniture sitting in a sun-filled room is guaranteed to fade. The time it takes will vary, depending on the endurance of the wood's natural pigments, the original finish and its maintenance.

title: Real Videotape by Real Divorce Lawyer
description: A Hartford lawyer is helping unhappy spouses negotiate the legal complexities of what he calls the ''most powerful judicial institution in America,'' divorce court.

title: Currents;   New Urns That Look Old
description: IN the old, old days - 575 to 475 B.C. - these urns, amphoras and pitchers, decorated with sports, love or war scenes, would have been used to hold or serve oil, wine or water. Their 20th-century counterparts, imported from southern Italy, are the latest neo-archeological decorating accessory: reproductions of pieces from the J. Paul Getty Museum in Malibu, Calif.

title: Currents;   Furniture Designers' Rebirth
description: THE last decade has seen a renaissance of the craftsman, a generation of accomplished artists who feel at home combining traditional furniture techniques with contemporary design influences. ''New American Furniture: The Second Generation of Studio Furnituremakers,'' an exhibition that opened Dec. 8 at the Museum of Fine Arts in Boston, presents the work of 25 such craftsmen.

title: Low Water at Nuclear Plant
description: Low levels of cooling water entering the intake canal at the Oyster Creek nuclear station today forced the power plant to go into the first stage of its four-step emergency plan. The 650-megawatt plant continued to operate at full power, plant officials said.

title: Topics of The Times;   Digital Density
description: Los Angeles, which fancies itself America's trend-setter, may set yet another in 1992 when it becomes the nation's first city with three area codes. Pacific Bell has announced that parts of the sprawling metropolis will become a new 310 area, split off from the original 213 and the 818, which was itself split off five years ago.

title: Giants Could See Tricky Defenses
description: When a pro football defense faces a passing situation, it usually puts in a nickel defense with five defensive backs or a dime defense with six. It usually has three or four defensive linemen rush the passer (one may be a linebacker), and in addition one or more linebackers or defensive backs may blitz.

title: Surgery for Liut
description: Mike Liut, the Hartford Whalers' goaltender who was injured Dec. 20, underwent arthroscopic surgery to repair torn cartilage in his knee. . . . The Islanders assigned the defenseman Wayne McBean to Springfield of the American League yesterday. McBean appeared in five games for the Islanders since they recalled him from the Indians Dec. 19. (AP)

title: Money-Fund Yields Rise
description: Yields of tax-exempt and taxable money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report were up sharply for the week ended yesterday.

title: Ben Reifel, 83, Dies; Former Congressman
description: Ben Reifel, the first Sioux Indian elected to the United States House of Representatives, died of cancer on Tuesday at Sioux Valley Hospital in Sioux Falls. He was 83 years old.

title: Parent & Child
description: THE holiday season is barely over, yet many of the presents that children had so fervently demanded only a few weeks ago lie neglected in a corner of the room. So it is only natural that, at this time of the year, a great many parents find themselves worrying about whether their children have become spoiled.

title: City Council Increases Its Members' Stipends
description: Meeting for the first time under a new charter, the New York City Council quickly voted stipend raises yesterday for most of its members, totaling $113,900.

title: DINKINS WILL DELAY HIRING OF RECRUITS FOR POLICE FORCE
description: In his first major act as Mayor of New York, David N. Dinkins said yesterday that he would indefinitely delay hiring 1,848 police officers who were to have gone on the payroll on Jan. 16 as recruits at the Police Academy. He said he might also have to delay another class that was scheduled to start in June.

title: Topics of The Times;   Usage, Decimated
description: People irritated by the use of the verb ''aggravate'' to mean ''irritate'' had better prepare to have their irritation aggravated. The Manchester Guardian Weekly reports that a panel of language experts regularly consulted by the Random House Dictionary gives this usage its blessing. In 1969, a majority of the panel regarded it as a solecism. Now 71 percent accept it.

title: Ex-Bolivian Aide, A Drug Suspect, Is Denied Bond
description: A Federal magistrate refused bond today to a former Bolivian Government official brought to the United States to face drug charges.

title: Paul Corbin, 75, Dies; Robert Kennedy Aide
description: Paul Corbin, a political consultant who was an aide to Senator Robert F. Kennedy, died of cancer on Tuesday at his home in Alexandria, Va. He was 75 years old.

title: Books of The Times;   A Tale of Distressing Sunsets and Radiant Details
description: Picturing Will

title: China Faults Report on 2 Rebels
description: In a toughly worded statement, China today rejected as ''speculations pure and simple'' recent reports that the dissidents Fang Lizhi and Li Shuxian would be allowed to leave China soon.

title: Leonard Zahn, Stockbroker, 73
description: Leonard Zahn, a stockbroker and philanthropist, died of a heart attack on Tuesday at Good Samaritan Hospital in Palm Beach, Fla. He was 73 years old and had homes in Palm Beach and Kings Point, L.I.

title: CHIEF IS TO RESIGN, HANOI PARTY SAYS
description: The Vietnamese Communist Party Secretary General, Nguyen Van Linh, will resign at a coming party meeting, Vietnamese officials said today.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Bristol-Myers Squibb Co., New York, the pharmaceuticals company, appointed William T. Comer president of its Bristol-Myers Pharmaceutical Research unit and Bristol-Myers Squibb Licensing Group.

title: Centrust Plan With Ensign
description: A proposed merger of the troubled Centrust Bank with the Ensign Bank in New York was announced today in a plan to ward off regulators from the Miami-based savings and loan association.

title: Environmentalists and Ranchers Fight Pentagon Bid for More Land
description: Military officials told Congress today that they needed millions of additional acres of public land for bombing-run practice, electronic battlefield training and tank maneuvers.

title: Safecrackers Use Sleight of Hand
description: SCHILLIZZI'S hands are his work; he keeps his nails manicured and his fingers nimble with regular exercise. He is neither a pianist nor a masseur. He is a world champion safecracker.

title: Market Place;   Eastern Bloc Shift Worries Western Banks
description: The move away from Communism and toward market economies in Eastern Europe may be good news for the Europeans, but some Western bankers are getting nervous.

title: Trump, Settling Suit, Will Endorse Cards
description: Donald J. Trump has agreed to endorse a line of photographic business cards made by a small Georgia company he had sued for calling the product ''Trump Cards.''

title: Subway Voucher Policy Rescinded by T.A.
description: The Transit Authority reversed itself yesterday and rescinded an order that stopped riders over 65 years old from using subway tokens bought before Jan. 1 to obtain a free return-trip voucher, a transit spokesman said.

title: Bombs Disrupt Sudan Relief
description: Planes last month bombed and harassed rebel-held towns in southern Sudan, disrupting famine-relief operations, a United Nations official said today. The planes bombed seven towns 10 times, said the official, who spoke on condition that he not be identified.

title: Savings Agency Ordered to Sell Real Estate Fast
description: The new agency created to manage the huge savings and loan bailout was instructed today to sell the real estate it inherited from hundreds of insolvent institutions as quickly as possible. The directive from the Bush Administration raised concerns among bankers that the properties could be ''dumped'' in an already weakened real estate market.

title: D. R. Capello, 80, Official Who Led Jersey State Police
description: Dominick R. Capello, Superintendent of the New Jersey State Police from 1962 to 1964 and later a private detective, died on Sunday at Holy Name Hospital in Teaneck, N.J. He was 80 years old and lived in Hackensack, N.J.

title: Cuomo Defuses Protest And Still Makes a Point
description: A member of the ubiquitous AIDS protest group, Act-Up, disrupted Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's State of the State address today, presenting an opportunity that Mr. Cuomo converted into the most dramatic moment of his hourlong speech.

title: Chemotherapy Used On Ovarian Tumors Is Tied to Leukemia
description: Chemotherapy drugs that were long used to treat ovarian cancer may have sharply increased the risk of leukemia, researchers have found.

title: Policy in Latin America: 2 Standards
description: The killing of an American nun on a highway in a remote area of Nicaragua on New Year's Day highlights the differing standards Washington sometimes places on protecting American lives in Latin America.

title: Mr. Cuomo Dances on the Deficit
description: With the eloquence only he can muster, Gov. Mario Cuomo of New York used his State of the State message to present a generous menu of plans and programs, but left unclear how he would pay for it. Instead he called on the Federal Government to help, with money from the ''peace dividend.''

title: HEALTH INSURANCE FOR ALL CHILDREN IS URGED BY CUOMO
description: Presenting an election-year array of new programs, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo today proposed a universal health insurance program for children and an overhaul of the method that the state uses to distribute education aid.

title: Matt's Scooter Wins an Award
description: Matt's Scooter, who won more than $1.1 million in 30 starts in 1989, has been named Pacer of the Year in voting conducted today by the United States Harness Association.

title: Treasury Prices Drop for 2d Day
description: Prices of Treasury securities skidded for the second straight session yesterday, as dealers sold securities on signs that the economy may not be as weak as many had expected.

title: New-Home Sales Post 9.6% Rise
description: Sales of new homes surged 9.6 percent in November, the steepest gain in four months, the Government said today in a report that showed sharp gains in every region of the nation except the South.

title: Upheaval in the East: Bulgaria;   Party Leaders Hold Discussion in Sofia With Key Opponents
description: Communist Party leaders met today with opposition groups for the first time in discussions that could result in the formation of a transitional government until free elections are held.

title: Trustco Rebuffed By Albany Bank
description: The National Savings Bank of Albany said it had rejected an offer from the Trustco Bank Corporation of Schenectady, and that its board had adopted an anti-takeover plan and declared a dividend of one preferred share purchase right for each common share held on Jan. 17.

title: Noriega's Surrender: The President;   Text of Bush Announcement On the General's Surrender
description: Following is the text of President bush's statement last night on Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, as recorded by The New York Times through the facilities of ABC News:

title: Ballet Theater Steps Gingerly Into the Post-Baryshnikov Era
description: At the beginning of its 50th-anniversary year, American Ballet Theater has - after Mikhail Baryshnikov's unexpected departure in September - no artistic director. But it does have a strong-willed executive director in Jane Hermann, who is minding the store.

title: Peter Paul Muller, 72, Long Island Architect
description: Peter Paul Muller, an architect, died of cancer on Sunday at Southampton (L.I.) Hospital after a long illness. He was 72 years old and lived in Bridgehampton, L.I.

title: Charter Starter
description: The Charter amendments approved overwhelmingly by New York City voters in November impose a dizzying array of requirements and deadlines for restructuring city government. Putting aside his personal differences with many of the Charter changes, Mayor David Dinkins moved wisely this week to insure a smooth transition.

title: Daniel Moffat, Stockbroker, 78
description: Daniel Moffat, a retired stock broker, died of complications following open heart surgery Tuesday at New York University Hospital in Manhattan. He was 78 years old and lived in Queens Village, Queens.

title: New Gadgets and Vistas Welcome Citizen Koch
description: ''I don't care what anybody says: I won't give it up,'' Edward I. Koch once vowed, referring not to the Mayor's job but to his $475.49-a-month, rent-controlled one-bedroom apartment in Greenwich Village.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Upheaval in the East: Economy;   Rumanians Take Stock Of a Tattered Economy
description: As they grapple with ways of turning a revolution on the streets into a broader transformation, Rumanians face the bleak legacy of the broken economy left by the regime of Nicolae Ceausescu and his family.

title: Currents;   Artist Sees Hippo Bite Washer
description: LIFE-SIZE household items like pianos, cars, outboard motors, magazines and mantels are intrinsic to David Mach's artwork: overscale constructions that juxtapose seemingly disparate elements. One of his latest pieces, on view through Jan. 13 at the Barbara Toll Fine Arts gallery (146 Greene Street, between Prince and Houston Streets), glorifies a washing machine by placing it in the locked jaws of a fiberglass hippopotamus. The sculpture, titled ''Distant Drums,'' is $18,000.

title: Senate Is Urged to Stall Clean Air Measure
description: A business coalition including major oil, gas, automobile and chemical companies favors stalling early action on a Senate clean air bill, according to a memorandum describing a private strategy session.

title: Salvatore J. Licata, 50, An Educator on AIDS
description: Salvatore J. Licata, an AIDS educator with the New York City Health Department, died of AIDS-related illnesss on Tuesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 50 years old. In 1985, Mr. Licata helped found People With AIDS Newsline, a monthly newspaper written by and for people with AIDS. He also wrote articles for the newspaper.

title: Don't Let Privacy Be a Luxury for the Wealthy;   Violation of Law?
description: To the Editor:

title: Protecting Children: Health Plan for the Uninsured
description: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo outlined a plan today that would make New York the first state in the nation to subsidize health care for all its uninsured children.

title: Hospitals Start Transfer Plan In Emergencies
description: Facing an unprecedented crush of emergency cases in New York City, the Emergency Medical Service yesterday began for the first time to transfer seriously ill patients from emergency rooms to beds in other hospitals.

title: Upheaval in the East: Czechoslovakia;   A Casualty of Amnesty: A Plant Using Convicts
description: When President Vaclav Havel declared an amnesty for 20,000 prisoners on New Year's Day, he obviously was not thinking about what the effect would be on the country's biggest automobile factory.

title: Oscar Gass, 77, Dies; Economic Consultant
description: Oscar J. Gass, a retired economic consultant, died of respiratory and circulatory collapse Monday at Suburban Hospital in Bethesda, Md. He was 76 years old and lived in Washington.

title: A Deputy Police Head Will Join Philip Morris
description: Alice T. McGillion, First Deputy Commissioner of the New York City Police Department, has been appointed director of corporate communications at Philip Morris Companies, Inc., the company announced yesterday.

title: Accounts
description: * Mutual of America Life to Kaufman & Maraffi, with a budget of $2.5 million.

title: Currents;   Fitting New York Into Your Wallet
description: EVEN if he said so himself, John Tauranac, a New York writer and graphic designer, has ''built a better mousetrap.'' Mr. Tauranac, who designed the official Metropolitan Transportation Authority map 11 years ago, has produced new New York subway and bus maps in conjunction with the Transit Center, an alliance of mass-transit operators.

title: Man With AIDS Is Shot to Death By Friend, Who Commits Suicide
description: A close friend of a man dying of AIDS shot him to death in his hospital bed on Tuesday, then killed himself. Groups counseling people with AIDS expressed sympathy today both for the pain of the dying man and for what they said must have been the fear and loneliness of his friend.

title: Q&A
description: Shineless Brass Brackets

title: Big Rise in Blue Cross Rates Fought in New Jersey
description: A proposal by New Jersey Blue Cross and Blue Shield to increase premiums for 605,000 individual subscribers by an average of 33 percent is drawing strong opposition from organizations representing the elderly, women and minorities, who will bear most of the increase.

title: Corrections
description: The Sports of The Times column yesterday cited the result of the 1962 World Series incorrectly in some editions. The Yankees beat the San Francisco Giants.

title: Kentucky Job Brings A Cast of Characters
description: There is nothing like a college coaching vacancy to perk up the travel industry.

title: Disrupting Worship Was Wrong, but the Reasons Were Right
description: To the Editor:

title: Port Authority Planning for $6 Tolls by '93
description: Tolls for Port Authority bridges and tunnels would rise, to $6, in 1993, and the PATH fare would go up, to $1.50, if a long-range plan released this week becomes a reality.

title: Teen-Agers Who Won't Join When Drug Dealers Recruit
description: One recent Saturday afternoon on the South Side here, a 14-year-old boy received a telephone call from a gang leader. He was calling, he said, to recruit drug dealers. The boy, who did not know the gang leader, politely declined.

title: Knicks Set for Oakley's Return As He Says His Knee Is Better
description: At a time when the Knicks need his physical presence and rebounding the most, Charles Oakley should be back for the game tonight against the Atlanta Hawks at Madison Square Garden. The Hawks, with such huge players as Moses Malone, Kevin Willis, Antoine Carr and Jon Koncak, have one of the biggest and most physical front lines in the National Basketball Association.

title: New Coach, Old Faces Bring Hope to Devils
description: Despite minimal contributions from several newcomers who were expected to be important players, such as Vyacheslav Fetisov, success has overshadowed disappointment for the Devils in the first half of the National Hockey League season.

title: Tyson Says He Overcame Drinking Habit
description: Mike Tyson says he had a drinking habit that intensified after Robin Givens filed for divorce in October 1988, but that he has stopped drinking entirely.

title: Pena Wants To Be the Stopper
description: It wasn't a challenge and it wasn't a warning, but Alejandro Pena said yesterday that he wanted to become the right-handed stopper in the Mets' bullpen and not just the man who set the stage for John Franco to chalk up the saves that make relief pitchers rich and famous.

title: Resignation at Brown
description: John C. Parry, the Brown University athletic director, announced yesterday he would resign at the end of June, ending 11 years at the Ivy League school.

title: Walter Heldmann, 85, Staten Island Physician
description: Dr. Walter T. Heldmann, a physician, died of cancer on Monday at his home in Ward Hill, S.I. He was 85 years old.

title: OPEC Quota Rise Sought
description: Because of the high price of oil, OPEC should look at the possibility of increasing quotas when the group's oil ministers meet in March, the Kuwaiti oil minister, Sheik Ali Khalifa al-Sabah said today.

title: Topics of The Times;   Illegal Smoke
description: Nonsmoking New Yorkers reporting for jury duty are accustomed to plenty of exposure to secondary smoke as other jurors light up while waiting to be called. That was supposed to end on Monday, when New York's Clean Indoor Air Act took effect.

title: UAL Moves Up Meetings on Buyout
description: The UAL Corporation said today that it was accelerating talks with its nonunion workers over a possible employee buyout, but the parent of United Airlines will still miss a deadline set by a big shareholder for coming up with a plan.

title: Federal Express Sharing Contract
description: The Federal Express Corporation said it was one of five companies sharing a Defense Department contract valued at more than $700 million. Federal Express estimated its potential share of the $724 million contract at about 68 percent.

title: Phoenician Resort Goes To Cramer-Krasselt
description: The task of advertising the Phoenician Resort, a Scottsdale, Ariz., luxury hotel that was embroiled in the national savings and loan crisis, has fallen to the Phoenix office of Cramer-Krasselt, an agency based in Milwaukee. The account, which had been inactive, was put up for review in December, after the Federal Government seized the hotel, which is still in operation and is owned by the Lincoln Savings and Loan Association, the failed institution that was operated by Charles H. Keating Jr. The Phoenician, which opened in October 1988, is a Mediterranean-style 605-room resort that was built at the base of Camelback Mountain at a cost of $260 million.

title: Want to Coach Jets? Here Are Some Tips
description: What do you look for when you're trying to hire a new coach for the Jets? And if you want the job, how do you approach the interview?

title: Cooney's Common Denominator
description: On the late September day that Gerry Cooney's comeback on Jan. 15 against George Foreman was announced, Gil Clancy happened to bump into Bob Martin, the legendary Las Vegas oddsmaker. Clancy, the CBS boxing analyst who had once been the trainer for Emile Griffith, a five-time champion, as well as for Foreman, had decided to drape a white towel over his shoulder again and return to the gym as Cooney's trainer. Not that Clancy's presence swayed Martin's opinion.

title: Two Harbors Journal;   A Highway Is Viewed As Killer And Victim
description: From his living room window, Myron Vold can see a great many deer, a bald eagle's roost and an occasional red fox chasing a quail. He also sees a spectacular variety of traffic accidents on U.S. Highway 61, one of America's most beautiful and treacherous highways.

title: Top Contras Deny Killing Nuns, but Clergy Differs
description: A senior official of the American-backed contras emphatically denied today that the rebels played any part in an attack that killed two Roman Catholic nuns, one of them American, in northern Nicaragua on Monday night.

title: The Peabody, Ready or Not, Is Pushed to Go Out on Its Own
description: One of cultural Baltimore's favorite sons is in danger of becoming its fiscal orphan. The Peabody Conservatory, a source of civic pride since 1857, is suffering its biggest crisis since Johns Hopkins University rescued it from extinction 12 years ago.

title: Review/Television;   A Drama and a Documentary on A&E
description: The Arts & Entertainment Network, on cable television, is unusually active these days on the original-programming front. Tonight at 9 o'clock, the monthly ''American Playwrights Theater'' series continues in its one-act mode with Paul Zindel's ''Let Me Hear You Whisper.'' And this Sunday at 8 P.M., Michael Palin sets off on a seven-part travelogue called ''Around the World in 80 Days.'' The series, more or less retracing the route taken by the fictional Phileas Fogg a hundred years ago, is a co-production of the BBC and A&E.

title: Dow Slips by 0.42 as Stocks Close Mixed
description: Stocks ended narrowly mixed yesterday, as investors' fervor faded in the wake of Tuesday's strong advance. The Dow Jones industrial average, which moved decisively past 2,800 to set a record on Tuesday, slipped 0.42 yesterday to close at 2,809.73. But 887 issues rose in price on the New York Stock Exchange, outpacing the 724 declining ones.

title: Vote of Confidence
description: His teammate may be the great one, but when it comes to current popularity, not even Wayne Gretzky can hold a candle to Luc Robitaille.

title: Disrupting Worship Was Wrong, but the Reasons Were Right;   Like Operation Rescue
description: To the Editor:

title: First Lady Starts Radiation Therapy for Eyes
description: Barbara Bush yesterday began the first of 10 radiation treatments to her eyes to relieve the persistent double vision, discomfort and tears that she has suffered as part of a thyroid condition, the White House said.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Aetna Life and Casualty Co., Hartford, sued Massachusetts, challenging the state's 7.9 percent limit on automobile insurance premium increases for 1990.

title: The Z Document: 'Mr. X' in Our Time
description: ''The cold war is over; the free world won and the evil empire lost; let's pick a date for V-C Day and celebrate the history-ending victory over Communism.'' So say our triumphalists.

title: Hot-and-Cold Nets Losers Again
description: Tonight's Nets game would have been even more bizarre had the Nets won. As it was, New Jersey's 110-96 loss to the Milwaukee Bucks was loaded with unusual events. How weird was it? The Nets played a horrendous second quarter in which they scored only 10 points, committed 13 turnovers, and did not score for the first 4 minutes 56 seconds. Then in the third quarter, the same New Jersey team scored 39 points - a team-high for any quarter this season - shot 74 percent from the field, and erased an 18-point deficit to tie the game. Then in the fourth quarter, the Nets went cold again and scored just 19 points.

title: KEY RATES
Cocaine Tubes Tied to Vessel
description: More than 250 pounds of cocaine was stashed in two waterproof tubes attached to the underside of a Colombian ship, said police officers who seized the drug on Sunday and arrested four men who showed up in diving gear, apparently to retrieve the cache. The men were arrested on drug trafficking charges. Capt. Herschell Connell, head of the organized crime section of the sheriff's office, said the police were tipped off about the drugs.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;

HDM Mattingly Wins Myer-Grace Account
description: LEAD: HDM Mattingly, the Australian arm of HDM Worldwide, was relieved to learn yesterday that it had won the bulk of the $80 million advertising account of the Myer-Grace Brothers department store group. The agency will be responsible for merchandise marketing and day-to-day advertising at the Australian retailer.

title: Some Russians Reflect on Pluralism
description: The Soviet nation's cold and dreamy sense of imperviousness seemed especially pronounced on this moonlit night on the ice at Gorky Park, as skaters stopped to consider the fiery political events in Eastern Europe.

title: Dinkins Says He Favors Special Fund to Hire Police
description: Faced with fiscal problems that have forced him to delay hiring more than 1,800 police officers, Mayor David N. Dinkins said yesterday that he favors creating a special fund to help pay for the police, but he did not say how the money should be raised.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;

Accounts
description: LEAD: * Ben Hogan Co., to GSD&M.;

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I've been on this earth 50 years, and I've read a lot of suspense stories, but I've not heard anything as bizarre and troubling as this.''

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;

Addenda
description: LEAD: * Medicus Intercon International, the health-care advertising subsidiary of D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, has acquired Agence M.K., a French health-care ad agency with billings of $35 million.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Elsa Andresen Bledsoe, Contralto, 92
description: Elsa Andresen Bledsoe, a charter member of the Oratorio Society of New Jersey, died Tuesday at the Arnold Walter Nursing Home in Holmdel, N.J. She was 92 years old. Surviving are two daughters, Margery Owen Bostrom of Red Bank, N.J., and Elizabeth Owen Greene of Poughkeepsie, N.Y.; two stepdaughters, Dorothy Barber of Bridgewater, N.J., and Geraldine Slattery, of Bryn Mawr, Pa.; two stepsons, Harry Bledsoe of Avoca, Iowa, and George Bledsoe of Council Bluffs, Iowa; 11 grandchildren; 13 great-grandchildren, and 2 great-great-grandsons.

title: Inmates Set Up a Barricade In Jail Protest in Jersey City
description: About 25 inmates at the Hudson County Jail barricaded themselves in a dormitory yesterday and refused to leave, and other prisoners tossed debris from windows, jail officials said. No injuries were reported.

title: Two Resign At D.F. King
description: Two senior executives of D. F. King & Company, a firm that solicits proxies from investors in takeovers and other corporate contests, resigned yesterday, the firm said.

title: Jackson Hears Cheers Again
description: As Mark Jackson stepped out of the shower in the Knick dressing room last night with a huge contingent of reporters waiting at his locker, he turned to his teammate Eddie Lee Wilkins and said, ''Welcome back, Kotter.''

title: Car Sales Off 20.2% at End Of December
description: Despite a late surge in light-truck sales, American auto makers ended December and last year with total sales badly depressed and little confidence that the current salesroom incentives are enough to solve the problem.

title: MCI Mexican Link
description: The MCI Communications Corporation and Telefonos de Mexico S.A. signed an agreement to provide voice and other telecommunications services between the United States and Mexico. MCI, whose international division is based here, and Telefonos de Mexico said they expected to begin providing voice service early next week. Under the operating agreement, MCI will also provide to the Mexican company with training programs and technical expertise.

title: Economic Scene;   Business Cycle's New Stability
description: IS the business cycle dead? The United States economy has now completed seven straight years of expansion, the longest in its peacetime history. Most economists foresee no recession in 1990 or 1991, and 1992 will be another Presidential election year, when the odds tip strongly against recession. Japan, West Germany and most of the other capitalist countries of Europe and Asia are also on a long upward roll, with no end in sight. It is time to consider whether the capitalist system has experienced a fundamental change in its stability, as important in its own way as the decay of the Communist system.

title: Drexel Pays Fine for Fraud
description: Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. paid a $1.3 million fine today to the State of Illinois for securities fraud, an administrative penalty stemming from a highly publicized Wall Street corruption case.

title: Appeal Is Sought On Howard Beach
description: The New York State special prosecutor's office yesterday asked the state's highest court to review a ruling that threw out the riot convictions of three of the defendants in the 1986 racial attack in Howard Beach, Queens.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising
description: LEAD: AN urban landscape of freeways, palm trees and jumbled communities, Los Angeles confounds many because it lacks geographical focus.

title: Chancellor Vows to Take Charge Of Failing Schools in New York
description: Continuing to move aggressively in his first days in office, Joseph A. Fernandez, the New York City Schools Chancellor, said yesterday that he would take command of schools and school boards that do not measure up to his academic standards.

title: Suspect in Rochester Killings
description: The state police said tonight that they have a suspect in 14 slayings of women in the Rochester area in the last two years, but they refused to release any details of the investigation.

title: As Buyers Balk, Argentine Prices Dip
description: Faced with the refusal of customers to buy and assurances from the Government of President Carlos Saul Menem that he is serious about stabilizing the economy, many stores began to roll back prices today that had doubled and tripled over the holiday weekend.

title: Motorist Gets 13 Years In Violence With Van
description: A motorist who pleaded guilty to charges stemming from a rampage along a crowded downtown street last year was sentenced Wednesday to a minimum of 13 years in prison.

title: Truths Of the Pariahs
description: One day it may become respectable again, maybe even fashionable, to speak plain truths about some of the world's more important political realities.

title: Taxi Fare Increase Reflects Rise in Costs Only
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: Because of a transmission error, an article and a caption on Dec. 20 about an American entrepreneur in Zaire misidentified him. He is Elwyn Blattner.

title: 'Kinder, Gentler Noriega'
description: The 12-year-old who picked Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega to be her pen pal says she stands by the fallen dictator no matter what.

title: For Children
description: Shows, Nature, Museums

title: Panama in Disorder: The 1980's
description: March 1982: After the death in 1981 of the armed forces chief, Gen. Omar Torrijos Herrera, three senior officers - Col. Manuel Antonio Noriega, Col. Ruben Darlo Paredes and Col. Roberto Diaz Herrera - cut a deal to resolve ja power struggle. Paredes is promoted to general, takes over as armed forces chief and agrees to retire in August 1983, leaving Noriega to take over, with Diaz Herrera as second-in-command. Noriega promises jto deliver 1984 presidential election to Paredes.

title: Giants in Good Shape
description: Only the injured Brian Williams was absent today as the Giants practiced for the playoff game here Sunday against the Los Angeles Rams.

title: Wisconsin Doesn't Cut Family Off for Truancy
description: To the Editor:

title: Books of The Times;   Taking to the Highway, Fleeing the Inescapable
description: Escapes

title: Watts at Carnegie
description: The pianist Andre Watts is to be the soloist with the American Composers Orchestra in Edward MacDowell's Piano Concerto No. 2 at Carnegie Hall on Sunday at 3 P.M. Mr. Watts is replacing Emanuel Ax, who is ill. The program, which is to be conducted by Dennis Russell Davies, also includes the New York premiere of Chinary Ung's ''Inner Voices,'' the work that won the 1989 Grawemeyer Award, as well as Aaron Copland's Symphonic Ode and the New York premiere of Richard Danielpour's ''First Light.'' Tickets are $9 to $28. Information: 247-7800.

title: Litton Seeks Sale Of 3 Divisions
description: Litton Industries put up for sale three divisions that supply electrical and electronic interconnection products. The three divisions, which have combined annual sales of about $170 million and employ about 2,200 people, are: Advanced Circuitry and Inter-Pak Electronics, based in Springfield, Mo.; VEAM, based in Milan, Italy, with domestic operations in Watertown, Conn., and Winchester Electronics, based in Watertown.

title: The Editorial Notebook;   Moscow's New Deal Economics
description: Thinking about economic restructuring on the grand Soviet scale is a thrill for any economist. So it was with special eagerness that I approached a recent meeting with Abel Aganbegyan, the Soviet guru of perestroika.

title: No Johnson-Lewis Duel
description: Ed Futerman, the attorney for the suspended Canadian sprinter, Ben Johnson, said yesterday he had not been contacted about a possible match race against Carl Lewis in September.

title: Vatican Issues an Ultimatum And a General Takes a Walk
description: After 10 days of trying to persuade Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega to give himself up, the Vatican's envoy to Panama on Wednesday entered the spartan quarters that served as the deposed Panamanian dictator's temporary sanctuary and delivered an ultimatum: His refuge in the Vatican Embassy would expire at noon today.

title: 2d Man Slain in Case Of Murdered Agent
description: A man suspected of helping Costabile (Gus) Farace elude the authorities for more than eight months in the murder of a Federal drug agent was found shot to death in Brooklyn early Wednesday, slumped over the steering wheel of a car.

title: Diner's Journal
description: Financiers and Fritters

title: Conductors' Conference To Include Szell Tribute
description: The 1990 Annual Conference for Conductors is to take place today through Sunday at the Kellogg Center of the School of International Affairs at Columbia University, 420 West 118th Street. A major feature will be a retrospective of the career of George Szell, the music director of the Cleveland Orchestra for 24 years, until his death in 1970. Film clips will be shown, and panelists will include the conductor James Levine, the former mezzo-soprano Rise Stevens and the pianists Leon Fleisher and Gary Graffman.

title: Toyota Sales Forecast
description: The Toyota Motor Corporation said today that it expects to sell one million cars and trucks in the United States in 1990. Robert McCurry, executive vice president of the company's United States sales organization, said Toyota expects to sell 750,000 cars, 190,000 trucks and 60,000 of its Lexus luxury cars. The company sold about 945,000 cars and trucks in 1989.

title: Treasury Security Prices Mixed
description: Prices of Treasury securities ended narrowly mixed in fairly light trading yesterday, as market participants largely shrugged off developments in the foreign exchange, energy and equity markets.

title: History Lesson for Children: Listening to Radio Dramas
description: Children, it was once held, should be seen and not heard. The Museum of Broadcasting, 1 East 53d Street, takes a different tack: children should be heard but not seen. This is the stuff a new workshop, starting this weekend, is made of.

title: Review/Cabaret;   Lainie Kazan, a Torch-Song Diva With a Sense of Humor
description: ''I understood pain at a very young age: I've been a torch singer since the age of 4,'' Lainie Kazan joked while introducing her version of ''La Vie en Rose,'' Edith Piaf's signature song, at Rainbow and Stars (30 Rockefeller Plaza) on Wednesday evening. ''But I was never a little sparrow,'' she added. ''I was more like Big Bird.''

title: Laos Radio Calls '89 A Socialist 'Nightmare'
description: The official Laotian radio has said that 1989 was ''a nightmare year for socialism'' but that the ideology will prevail and citizens should rally around the Communist Party leadership.

title: NORIEGA ARRAIGNED IN MIAMI IN A DRUG-TRAFFICKING CASE; HE REFUSES TO ENTER A PLEA
description: Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, the fallen Panamanian leader who had vowed never to surrender to the United States, was arraigned on drug trafficking charges here today after giving himself up to American forces in Panama.

title: Zenith Ends Claim
description: The Zenith Data Systems Corporation, a unit of the Zenith Electronics Corporation, agreed to drop its protest against the award of a $706 million Air Force contract to the Unisys Corporation for desktop computer equipment, both companies said. The contract calls for Unisys, a computer manufacturer based here, to make equipment that combines two of the most widely used desktop operating systems - Unix and MS-DOS. Zenith Data Systems, based in Mount Prospect, Ill., held the Defense Department's two previous desktop computer contracts and had vigorously sought the latest contract.

title: Israel Is Criticized by Amnesty International
description: Amnesty International has issued a report asserting that the Israeli Government appears to have encouraged the killing of Palestinians in an effort to crush the uprising in the occupied territories.

title: Illinois Museum to End Exhibit of Indian Remains
description: A state museum has decided to shut down an exhibit featuring the exposed graves of 234 prehistoric American Indians because of ''heightened sensitivity to display of human remains,'' an official said.

title: From Apple Corps to WPA, It's Open House in Chelsea
description: The revival in Chelsea on Manhattan's Lower West Side is not so much Gothic as it is theatrical. The neighborhood, a center for New York show business in the 19th century, is dotted with small theaters of every description that, starting today, are proceeding to make a festival of themselves.

title: At La Salle, It Pays to Be Nice
description: When Lionel Simmons stops running so gracefully on the basketball court, perhaps he should run for political office.

title: Dollar Is Sharply lower As Bundesbank Intervenes
description: The dollar dropped precipitously yesterday as a result of unexpected intervention in the foreign exchange market by the West German central bank.

title: New State Treasurer Is Named by Florio
description: Governor-elect James J. Florio yesterday appointed his campaign manager, Doug Berman, as State Treasurer.

title: Dow Drops 13.65 Points, To 2,796.08
description: Stock prices fell broadly yesterday, depressed by caution before the Government's report today of employment data for December. The Dow Jones industrial average fell by 13.65 points to close at 2,796.08, just below the important 2,800 technical level.

title: 'Criminal Is Gone,' but Joy Is Fleeting in Land He Ruled
description: With Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega in American custody and out of the country, relieved Panamanians turned their attention today to the arduous process of repairing the damage he inflicted on the political, social and economic fabric of this nation of 2.3 million people during his six-year rule.

title: River in Pennsylvania Is Reopened After Spill
description: Navigation resumed along the entire Monongahela River today, three days after at least 61 barges broke free and crashed downstream. One spilled 10,000 gallons of gasoline.

title: Apple Expands Stock-Buying Plan
description: The board of Apple Computer Inc. approved the repurchase of up to 2.5 million more shares of its common stock. In August 1989, the company announced a plan for the repurchase of 2.5 million shares. ''We believe purchase of Apple shares represents good long-term value to our shareholders,'' said John Sculley, Apple's chairman and chief executive.

title: The Council Crashes on Takeoff
description: New York's ''new'' City Council, given real power in the just-approved City Charter, is off to a disappointing start. At its very first meeting under the new Charter this week, the Council sent the message that it likes the perks of power, but isn't yet too interested in the responsibility.

title: Husband of Slain Boston Woman Becomes a Suspect, Then a Suicide
description: From the first, the story seized the attention of the nation: a pregnant young woman dying of gunshot wounds while her husband, also shot, frantically called for help over his car phone; then the 17-day fight for life of their baby boy, delivered eight weeks premature.

title: U.S. Marshals Conferring on Overcrowded Prisons
description: Federal marshals in the Northeast and elsewhere are throwing mattresses on the floor for Federal prisoners and driving hundreds of miles a day in a hunt for empty jail beds as the authorities grapple with badly overcrowded prisons.

title: Lin Merger's Windfall: A Question of Fairness
description: It will be a good New Year for shareholders of Lin Broadcasting, who will profit from the company's merger deal with McCaw Cellular Communications. But it will be an extraordinary one for Lin's chairman, Donald A. Pels, as he sells his 1.3 million stock options to McCaw for about $200 million.

title: Fresh, Hot and Headed for Fame
description: FOR performers and visual artists, recognition can be immediate -as a newcomer makes a striking first impression in a debut. Or, after a period of anonymity, a more experienced professional may attract attention after finally having the opportunity to demonstrate originality. In a theater or concert hall, there can be an audible certification of that newness, with the sound of an audience rustling programs to find the name of a previously unknown and soon-to-be-memorable performer. Those shown here, as selected by seven New York Times critics, have recently achieved such a public awareness. There are more on pages C20 and C21.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;

People
description: LEAD: * James Dalthorp has been promoted to senior vice president and associate creative director at Ammirati & Puris. The agency also promoted Gary Derish to senior vice president and creative director of the direct marketing department, and Peggy Grenamyer to senior vice president and director of print services.

title: E.P.A. Rules On Emissions
description: The Environmental Protection Agency proposed regulations today to reduce hydrocarbon releases from cars and trucks when gasoline evaporates.

title: Paratrooper in Practice Fall Is Killed by Plane in Midair
description: A transport plane flew through a group of falling Army paratroopers at Fort Bragg on Wednesday, killing one soldier and injuring another, Army spokesmen said.

title: 200 at Manhattan Service Hail Sakharov as Hero
description: Some 200 admirers of the late Andrei D. Sakharov gathered yesterday at a memorial service in the New York Public Library at which leaders of the international struggle for human rights paid tribute to the physicist and Nobel Peace Prize winner. Dr. Sakharov, who was 68 years old, died Dec. 14 in Moscow.

title: Official Warns S.I. Oil Leak Threatens Crucial Bird Area
description: As efforts to clean up an oil leak of at least 200,000 gallons continued yesterday in the Arthur Kill, a New York State official warned that one of the most important feeding and nesting areas for rare birds on the East Coast would suffer major damage, unless the work was adequately performed.

title: Braniff Names A New Chief
description: The financially strapped Braniff Inc. said today that David Murchison had been named its chief executive.

title: Kings Lure Motta Out of Retirement
description: When Dick Motta retired as coach of the Dallas Mavericks in 1987 after 19 seasons of marking X's and O's with three National Basketball Association teams, he did so after a 55-27 record by the Mavericks and a first-place finish in the Midwest Division. Yesterday, the 58-year-old Motta was back as an N.B.A. coach, this time with a 7-20 team, the Sacramento Kings, who are last in the Pacific Division.

title: Rumania Averted Massacre By Executions, Official Says
description: A leading tactician of Rumania's Provisional Government said today that if Nicolae Ceausescu and his wife had not been swiftly executed last week the country might have endured ''a blood bath with hundreds of thousands of dead.''

title: Charles E. Arch, Manufacturer, 79
description: Charles E. Arch, founder and chairman of Blistex Inc., manufacturers of lip care products, died of heart disease Monday at Loyola University Medical Center in Maywood, Ill. He was 79 years old and lived in Oak Brook, Ill.

title: Ethics Panel Widens Inquiry on Senator Over Condominium
description: The Senate Ethics Committee has expanded its investigation of Senator Dave Durenberger to include a deal through which he was reimbursed for renting his Minneapolis condominium to himself, the Minnesota Republican said today.

title: Real Estate Sales Lure Investors
description: Attracted by the hope of bargains, real estate investors and prospective home buyers are jamming the phone lines of the Government agency that this week began selling billions of dollars' worth of properties owned by failed savings institutions.

title: Review/Dance;   Love at First Sight, in Both Classical and Ballroom Steps
description: The New York Theater Ballet, a small company directed by Diana Byer, resembles a chamber-music ensemble. Each of its members is a skilled performer and all work harmoniously together.

title: Dining Out: In and Near Chelsea
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication; restaurants mentioned in Diner's Journal do not have stars. Prices are current.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Zydeco by Fernest

title: Fresh, Hot and Headed for Fame, These Are the Faces to Watch;   Television
description: Now that Catherine has been murdered and Vincent has begun a prolonged period of mourning, CBS's ''Beauty and the Beast'' (Wednesdays at 8 P.M.) is gingerly grooming a new leading lady to flesh out the title. Exit Linda Hamilton. Enter JO ANDERSONas Diana Bennett, special-crimes investigator for the Manhattan District Attorney's office. Blond Catherine was all soft curves, physically and emotionally. Red-haired Diana is more angular, tougher, more independent. She even has - gulp - a live-in lover. Will she prove attractive to Vincent and, more crucially, the somewhat cultish fans of the series who are wary about anyone replacing their beloved Catherine? Even the show's producers profess that they haven't yet decided if Diana will add up to a meaningful relationship for the Beast. Problems, problems.

title: Checks, Large and Small, for Neediest Cases
description: With contributions to the 78th annual New York Times Neediest Cases Fund pouring in, one gift in particular stood out this week - a check for $50,000 from Grenville and Sandra Craig of Paris and Princeton, N.J.

title: Dinkins Fills Operations and Economic Posts
description: Mayor David N. Dinkins filled two more major positions in his administration yesterday, selecting as his director of operations a New York City school official whom he credited with helping to reduce the bureaucracy at the Board of Education. The Mayor also named an investment banker to head the city's economic-development effort.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Radio Deals By Evergreen
description: The Evergreen Media Corporation, a privately held radio company, agreed today to acquire a station and a statewide network in Texas for $58.5 million in cash and debt.

title: Countdown Starts for Flight Of Shuttle to Save Satellite
description: The space agency began the countdown today for the launching of the space shuttle Columbia on Monday on a 10-day satellite rescue mission.

title: C.F.T.C. Approves a Proposal to Restrict Dual Trading
description: The Commodity Futures Trading Commission today unanimously approved a proposed rule that would restrict dual trading on the nation's largest commodity markets, a first step toward the possible banning of the practice from all futures markets.

title: Keating, Unshaken, Takes Stand
description: For the first time since his Lincoln Savings and Loan Association was taken over by Federal regulators in April, Charles H. Keating Jr. took the stand in a crowded courtroom here today. He denied any wrongdoing and answered questions about his involvement in the institution.

title: H. E. Edgerton, 86, Dies; Invented Electronic Flash
description: Harold E. (Doc) Edgerton, professor emeritus of electrical measurements at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, whose invention of the electronic flash expanded the scope of photography, died yesterday after a heart attack at the institute faculty club, where he was having lunch. He was 86 years old and lived in Cambridge, Mass.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: COLLEGE BASKETBALL

title: Review/Art;   A Course in Portraiture by an Individualist With a Camera
description: In her eighth exhibition at Metro Pictures in 10 years, Cindy Sherman continues the relentless forward motion that has characterized her career from the beginning. In the past, Ms. Sherman's photographic fabrications, which almost invariably star herself, have been inspired by film noir, fashion and girlie magazine shots, children's fairy tales and, more recently, the messiest scenes from C-grade horror or disaster movies. (In these last works, the artist departed somewhat from her usual format, letting dolls and life-sized dummies play the leading roles.) The types of women, men, children, monsters and grotesques featured in these images - all products of Ms. Sherman's genius for makeup, costume, arrangement and acting -form a very long list. Equally long would be the lists of the genres of representation evoked, the moods and emotions pinpointed, the colors, textures and camera angles deployed. All have been orchestrated to make the viewer newly aware of the human appetite for images, while also laying bare any image's essential fiction.

title: Michaels to Coach
description: The eight-team International League of Football, which begins play in eight cities in Europe in April, began assigning head coaches to teams yesterday and Walt Michaels wound up as coach of the Helsinki team in Finland and Jack Elway as coach in London.

title: PRAGUE IS SEEKING NEW TRADE SYSTEM FOR THE EAST BLOC
description: Declaring the old Communist trading bloc a dead letter, Czechoslovakia's Government said today that it would propose the annulment of the group's previous trade agreements at a meeting of the Soviet-led organization next week.

title: KEY RATES
Old Knick Typecast As Fighter
description: In a charming new film called ''Sidewalk Stories,'' a couple of street artists are bickering over a prospective customer. As the argument intensifies, one hustler gets up from his chair. And gets up. And gets up. My goodness, it's Tom Hoover, all 6 feet 10 inches of him.

title: Restaurants
description: Distinguished Mexican food is not something that leaps to mind when describing the New York dining scene. It may have something to do with immigration patterns, or maybe the weather, but it just seems that Mexican cooks don't settle here in significant numbers to nurture a culinary community that could adequately demonstrate their diverse cuisine.

title: Science Has No Doubts on Theory of Evolution;   Not Darwin's Phrase
description: To the Editor:

title: With Official Permission, Change Stirs Mongolia
description: Less dramatically than in Berlin and less bloodily than in Bucharest, the winds of Communist change have swept across the Gobi Desert to stir up political life in the sparsely populated nation of Mongolia.

title: China's Coal Output Up
description: China announced today that its coal output for 1989 had exceeded a target of one billion tons, but said industries still remained short of the fuel. Output rose to 1.04 billion tons last year from 970 million tons in 1988, the official Economic Daily said.

title: Lithuanians Say Gorbachev Eases Off
description: In a sign that President Mikhail S. Gorbachev might be softening his vehement stand against the splintering of the Soviet Communist Party, Communist leaders in Lithuania said tonight that Mr. Gorbachev had strongly indicated that he would not try to force them to reverse their decision last month to break from Moscow.

title: Fresh, Hot and Headed for Fame, These Are the Faces to Watch;   Pop, Jazz and World Music
description: Shimmy-Disc Records, which is having a two-night showcase tonight and tomorrow at the Knitting Factory, 47 East Houston Street (219-3055), is a record label with an attitude somewhere between a shrug, a snarl and a chuckle. Its founder and house producer, Kramer, used to be the bassist in Shockabilly, a group that sped up and pulverized golden oldies and its own songs with maniacal exultancy. His label's roster treats popular music with the same affection, amusement and mockery, making albums that fall somewhere between sophomoric humor and savage re-invention.

title: President Wins Bipartisan Praise For Solution of Crisis Over Noriega
description: President Bush, who took the largest political gamble of his Administration by sending American troops into Panama last month, reaped the political rewards today as bipartisan praise poured in for the surrender of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega.

title: Man Is Charged In Fatal Attack On Bleecker St.
description: A 23-year-old Bronx man has been indicted on murder and robbery charges in what the police said was an unprovoked attack on a young advertising executive last month in the East Village, the Manhattan District Attorney said yesterday.

title: Honecker Free From House Arrest, But Could Still Face a Prison Term
description: Erich Honecker, the East German leader who was overthrown in the protests that shook the country late last year, has been freed from house detention but could still face jail.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: At the Movies
description: Biff the Bully

title: Pope Sees Thirst for Religion
description: Pope John Paul II said today that the current collapse of atheist systems in Eastern Europe showed the error of trying to exclude God from human life. He told a group of Italian pilgrims that mankind was living through ''exceptional times'' as the 20th century drew to a close. ''On one hand we are seeing the collapse of projects constructed by men with the explicit exclusion of all references to God, while on the other hand we are seeing a new hunger for the word of God,'' the Pope said.

title: Teachers to Go to Poland
description: The Peace Corps announced today that it would send its first contingent to Poland, 60 volunteers who will train English teachers there.

title: Court Detours Effort to Repair an L.I. Parkway Junction
description: No one ever liked the interchange between the Meadowbrook and Northern State Parkways, site of 130 accidents a year, six times the state average for similar spots. So two years ago, New York State began rebuilding the awkward junction of two of Long Island's most heavily traveled highways.

title: Devils Put Clamps on Gretzky
description: The Devils received offensive production from defensive specialists tonight and defeated the Los Angeles Kings, 4-2, at Byrne Meadowlands Arena to move into sole possession of first place in the Patrick Division.

title: Workers Say Moroccan Oil Spill Could Have Been Halted Sooner
description: Dutch salvage workers trying to clean up a huge Atlantic oil spill said today that the accident could have been controlled much faster if the Spanish or Moroccan authorities had allowed a crippled Iranian oil tanker into their coastal waters for repairs.

title: Operation Just Begun
description: President Bush can now fairly and proudly claim success for the military phase of his Panama policy. The surrender of Manuel Antonio Noriega to U.S. custody is a personal triumph for the President and a great relief to most Panamanians.

title: Michaels Stores Buyout Bid Ends
description: The leveraged buyout of Michaels Stores Inc., an Irving, Tex., retail chain, by MSI Holdings has ended because of financing problems related to the weakening ''junk bond'' market, the company said. Michaels Stores said it would take a fourth-quarter charge of $3 million to $5 million to cover expenses.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;

2 at Fisher-Price Share Duties of President
description: LEAD: Fisher-Price, the troubled toy division of the Quaker Oats Company, yesterday named two executives to take over the duties of its president, R. Bruce Sampsell, who resigned to become vice chairman and chief operating officer of the First Empire State Corporation, a banking company in Buffalo.

title: First Executive Deal Collapses
description: The First Executive Corporation said today that a deal to sell a subsidiary, the Executive Life Insurance Company of New York, had collapsed.

title: Money Fund Assets Fall
description: The assets of the nation's 469 money market mutual funds decreased by $955.0 million, to $365.04 billion, for the week ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. The assets of the 144 institutional funds increased by $625.7 million, to $88.23 billion. The assets of the 227 general-purpose funds were down $112.1 million, to $119.87 billion. The 98 broker-dealer funds decreased by $1.47 billion, to $156.94 billion, the institute said.

title: For the Record
description: Ambiguity of the Law

title: Review/Film;   Burning Books and Burying Scholars Alive
description: More than 2,000 years ago, a crafty Chinese feudal king put down a rebellion in his province, went on to conquer six neighboring kingdoms, and then gave himself the name Qin Shihuang, meaning First Emperor. Having established peace, the first Chinese Emperor maintained it ruthlessly, burning books that challenged his laws and burying alive 460 scholars who disagreed with him.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a report in the Business People column on Monday misstated the age of Frederick H. Joseph, chief executive of Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. He is 52 years old.

title: A Theatergoer Is Shot in the Knee While Watching 'Steel Magnolias'
description: In a strange night of high drama at the theater, a woman watching an Off Broadway performance on a Greenwich Village stage last night was shot, apparently when someone seated nearby dropped a pistol to the floor, sending a single stray bullet in her direction, the police said.

title: Fresh, Hot and Headed for Fame, These Are the Faces to Watch;   Classical Music
description: One would think that the major endeavors by so well loved a composer as Franz Schubert have all been heard by now. But in its quest to present the composer's complete works chronologically in a 10-year Schubertiade, the 92d Street Y has already made some significant introductions. An important addition to the canon - a concert version of Schubert's first complete theater work, ''DES TEUFELS LUSTSCHLOSS''(D. 84), in what is billed as its United States premiere - is to open the third annual installment of the series on Sunday at 3 P.M. at Hunter College, East 69th Street, between Park and Lexington Avenues.

title: Super Bowl Is 2 Victories Away, But Glory Isn't Players' Only Goal
description: The incentive for winning National Football League divisional playoff games this weekend is clear and concise for the participants.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday

title: Pop/Jazz;   Jazz Concerts Will Benefit An Ailing Innovator
description: The drummer Ed Blackwell is one of those musicians who radiate influence.

title: Science Has No Doubts on Theory of Evolution
description: To the Editor:

title: Auctions
description: Old Master Paintings

title: Edgewater Sugar Factory Is Now a Rental Complex
description: The opportunity to get a new luxury apartment in a rental complex is rare in the suburbs and older towns around New York City. Hardly any rental buildings have been built for several years, and most of the rental offerings have been made by investor-owners of condominiums.

title: What 'Permanent Congress'?
description: It is disturbing that so many Americans have fallen prey to the easy temptation of Congress-bashing. While some bashers attempt legitimately to hold Congress accountable for its obvious shortcomings, others illegitimately undermine it as an institution.

title: Red Cross Issues Emergency Plea For Blood in Some Regions of U.S.
description: The American Red Cross has issued emergency appeals for blood donations in some parts of the nation, pointing out that critical spot shortages were reported in Arizona, Florida, Georgia, Michigan, New Jersey, Pennsylvania and Virginia.

title: Gang-Logo Caps Inflame Crime Fighters in Boston
description: Crime fighters in this city's tougher neighborhoods, who have pledged to win their war in the 1990's, can claim a victory of sorts as the decade dawns.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;

New Diet Coke Spots
description: LEAD: On Sunday, Diet Coke will broadcast its latest television commercials aimed at drawing away drinkers of regular Pepsi. In the spots, prepared by Lintas, Jerry Hall, Chris Evert, Phylicia Rashad and Vanna White relate how they've decided to end a long attachment - to Pepsi - for Diet Coke.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Mark Murphy's Songs

title: For a Rumanian City, Revolt Wasn't Sudden
description: Small and grinding deprivations led the people of Brasov, Rumania, to take up arms against tyranny on the night of Dec. 22 in the revolution that toppled Nicolae Ceausescu.

title: Harlem Hospital Overflows With Patients
description: At the Harlem Hospital Center yesterday, some patients lay sleeping on parked emergency room stretchers; others were being treated in busy hallways.

title: In Manila, Coup Season Never Ends
description: LEAD: Six coups have been attempted against Corazon Aquino's administration since 1986 and each has been fiercer than the one before. Because the cashiered Col. Gregorio ''Gringo'' Honasan has figured in each of them, it is easy to see them as a progression, related to each other, and to see the Philippine drama as a struggle between would-be military juntas and democracy.

title: The Boat People and the Commonwealth
description: The sad story of Hong Kong's Vietnamese boat people gets sadder by the day. News that the refugees are now willing to risk violence to avoid repatriation only increases the urgency for a more humane global response.

title: Walesa Donates His Prize
description: Lech Walesa gave away his Nobel Peace Prize money today to help relieve the economic hardships facing the Polish people in 1990.

title: Rangers' High Hopes Undergo a Pounding
description: There had been for the Rangers, in the brief hours of euphoria produced by their first triumph in 12 games, talk of perhaps making a move. The stall that had become a full stop had ended.

title: Quaker State Plan
description: The Quaker State Corporation is offering a free warranty on engine parts of new cars lubricated by its oil for 10 years or 250,000 miles. Car owners must meet strict rules, including having an oil and filter change every four months or 4,000 miles using Quaker State oil. The warranty does not cover claims already covered by auto manufacturers' warranties, but it will pay for deductibles not covered by the auto makers' extended service contracts.

title: Simms's Pocket Inviting Target for Rams' Greene
description: Under the baseball cap and behind the dark glasses, Kevin Greene seemed lost in the crowd of players that walked off the field in the late-morning sunshine today. He stopped suddenly near the shade of a nearby tree, and then he smiled when someone asked him about Phil Simms.

title: James P. McDonald, Publicist, 73
description: James P. McDonald, a retired public relations executive, died on Dec. 27 at Englewood (N.J.) Hospital. He was 73 years old and lived in Tenafly, N.J.

title: Campeau Surrenders 29% Stake
description: Robert Campeau, the Canadian developer who borrowed heavily to buy two big American retailers and then brought them into severe financial straits, surrendered about $100 million worth of his own stock in his flagship company, the Campeau Corporation, yesterday to a Canadian bank when he defaulted on a loan to two of his private companies.

title: Fresh, Hot and Headed for Fame, These Are the Faces to Watch;   Art
