description: It may be that the dawning of a new year, makes an art dealer's fancy turn to thoughts of fresh, undiscovered talent. Whatever the reason, a number of debuts are under way this weekend, in galleries on 57th Street and in SoHo.

title: INSIDE
description: Drilling Delay Is Proposed

title: Editors' Note
description: Two articles in Business Day on Monday - about the stability of the Tokyo stock market and about the 1989 record of the world's stock markets - referred to the performance of the Japanese market. Their percentage figures appeared contradictory.

title: Church Says Noriega's Sole Guarantee Was for a Fair Trial in U.S.
description: The Vatican said today that Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega was given no special guarantees beyond the promise of a fair trial in the United States before he agreed to leave the papal embassy and surrender to American forces in Panama Wednesday night.

title: Pactel Will Reduce Work Force by 16%
description: The Pacific Telesis Group, the regional telephone and communications company based in San Francisco, said yesterday that it plans to eliminate 11,000 jobs, or 16 percent of its work force, in the next five years to cut costs.

title: Youth Held in Rape Of 12-Year-Old Girl
description: A 16-year-old youth was held on $50,000 bail yesterday after a prosecutor said the youth admitted being part of a group that raped, sodomized and tortured a girl, 12, in Harlem Tuesday night.

title: Bengals Deny Charges
description: Stanley Wilson, the former Bengals fullback who was suspended on the morning of the 1989 Super Bowl for snorting cocaine in his hotel room in Miami, says in the February issue of Penthouse magazine that he conspired to buy the drugs with his Cincinnati teammates Eddie Brown, Daryl Smith and Rickey Dixon.

title: Woman, 31, Dies From Severe Beating
description: A 31-year-old woman was found severely beaten in her apartment on the Upper West Side of Manhattan on Wednesday and died that night, the police said yesterday. There have been no arrests.

title: New President Of Lane Bryant
description: Cheryl Nido Turpin was named president this week of Lane Bryant, the 720-store division of the Limited Inc. Lane Bryant is the country's largest retailer of special-size women's apparel.

title: Fresh, Hot and Headed for Fame, These Are the Faces to Watch;   Film
description: When Dustin Hoffman plays an autistic savant or Daniel Day-Lewis a man with cerebral palsy who paints with his left foot, it is easy to praise the distance these men have come to create their roles. But when unknown actors disappear into their characters, it is easy to forget they are acting at all; who knows how far they have transformed themselves? And so while Mr. Day-Lewis receives deserved praise and awards - including the New York Film Critics Circle citation for best actor - for his portrayal of the disabled painter and writer Christy Brown in ''My Left Foot,'' HUGH O'CONOR, who plays Christy as a boy, is almost taken for granted.

title: U.S. Aide Hints at a Deal If the General Tells All
description: Federal prosecutors insisted today that they would prevail in a trial of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, but a senior Administration official said the Government would be prepared to discuss a negotiated settlement if the deposed Panamanian leader provided detailed information about international drug trafficking activities.

title:
THE LAW;

Minority Critic Stirs Debate on Minority Writing
description: LEAD: At some of the nation's leading law schools, a rancorous debate is being waged over a recent trend in scholarly writing by law professors who are minority members.

title: Gerhard Schroder, 79, Ex-Official And Founder of Bonn Party, Dies
description: Gerhard Schroder, a former Foreign Minister of West Germany and a co-founder of the Christian Democratic Union that has been in power for much of the post-World War II period, died of heart failure on Sunday at his home on the North Sea island of Sylt, his family said. He was 79 years old.

title: F.D.A. Begins Testing Milk
description: The Food and Drug Administration says it has begun testing retail milk supplies in 13 cities after an independent survey found samples in several areas tainted with potentially harmful drugs. The agency said Tuesday that while it was concerned that these unconfirmed findings might indicate ''violative drug residues in milk,'' it saw ''no public health threat associated with animal drug residues in milk'' at the levels reported by The Wall Street Journal last Friday.

title: U.S. Accused of Failing to Assail Rights Abuse
description: A human rights group accused the Bush Administration of failing to denounce abuses in 50 countries, including China, El Salvador and the Soviet Union.

title: U.S. Panel Calls for Delays In Offshore Drilling for Oil
description: Recommending choices to appease both environmentalists and the oil industry, a panel headed by Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan Jr. says more study is needed before oil companies drill off the coasts of California and Florida.

title: Review/Theater;   Scenes of Everyday Discord In One-Act Family Dramas
description: It is not so much a matter of taste as a taste of matter that creates problems for the chubby housewife whose name gives the title to ''Beth,'' one of the three plays in Steven Sater's ''Carbondale Dreams'' package of one-acters at the Judith Anderson Theater. The plays, presented two at a time, explore the tensions between family togetherness and individual yearnings.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A2-15

title: 2,000 Reported Slain in Sudan
description: Sudanese rebels said today that more than 2,000 people were killed in a central Sudanese town last week in what they termed a massacre by local militia forces recruited and armed by the Khartoum Government.

title: CREW CANNOT SUE MAIMED PROTESTER
description: A Federal district judge ruled Wednesday that a protester was not legally responsible for traumatizing the crew of a Navy weapons train that ran over and maimed him at a demonstration in 1987.

title: Bogota Journal;   Police Chief's Tough (Just Ask the Death Squads)
description: A visit to the ninth-floor office of Colombia's top police officer, Gen. Miguel Maza Marquez, underlines the adage that office decor speaks volumes about the occupant.

title: Fresh, Hot and Headed for Fame, These Are the Faces to Watch;   Theater
description: Anyone with a memory of the all-star film ''Grand Hotel'' should be surprised by the initial appearance of MICHAEL JETERin the Broadway musical of the same name. The role of Kringelein, the dying bookkeeper embarked on a final fling, was created in the film by the portly Lionel Barrymore. In contrast, Mr. Jeter is slight and unassuming. But by the end of the show, he completely possesses the role - and is a singing, dancing Kringelein.

title: Review/Film;   Growing Up In Argentina, Isolated And Naive
description: Civilization intrudes slowly and cruelly into the remote Argentine mountain setting for ''Veronico Cruz,'' a place so primitive that the mud hut in which the title character lives is wholly detached from any other signs of human society. Veronico is a young boy whose mother died in childbirth, and whose father left soon afterward to seek work in the city.

title: Review/Art;   Death, Myth and a Resistance to Conventions
description: Even if Gino De Dominicis is not as wild and wacky as some of his supporters believe, and even if his mixed-media work may not be a ''mix of sanctity and damnation'' that ''has not been seen in a European artist since the times of Rimbaud,'' as the critic Italo Tomassoni recently wrote in Flash Art, he is still an endearing, imaginative and occasionally inspired artist.

title: Insider Case Is Settled
description: A Federal judge in Manhattan yesterday approved a settlement between the Securities and Exchange Commission and a typesetting supervisor accused of illegally trading on confidential information from advance copies of Business Week magazine.

title: At Least 210 Die in Pakistan's Worst Rail Crash
description: Soldiers with acetylene torches cut into crushed railroad cars today searching for victims of Pakistan's worst train wreck, which officials said killed at least 210 people and injured 700.

title: Market Place;   Money Managers Lagged in 1989
description: Last year was a tough one for both investment advisers and mutual funds, with most of them failing to match the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index. But the investment advisers seem to have done better than the stock mutual funds, according to figures released yesterday.

title: New Jersey Blue Cross Wins Overall 24.6% Rise in Rates
description: New Jersey Blue Cross and Blue Shield today was granted an overall increase in rates of 24.6 percent, effective Feb. 15, for 605,000 subscribers. The insurer had sought a 33 percent increase.

title: Ground Round Leader Started on Wall Street
description: Michael P. O'Donnell, a 33-year-old executive who gave up a budding Wall Street career to return to his first love, the food service business, will become president and chief executive of Ground Round Inc., the restaurant chain announced yesterday.

title: Corrections
description: A table yesterday showing corrected figures for population shifts in the United States misstated the census region for Pennsylvania in some copies. It is the Middle Atlantic region. In addition the 1980 population total and percentage change for the Midwest were incorrect in some copies. The 1980 total was 58,868,000 and the increase was 2.2 percent.

title: DEALS
description: BASEBALL

title: Goldman, Kidder Head Loan Plan
description: New York State's loan program to improve and upgrade municipal sewer treatment systems will be managed by an underwriting team of Goldman, Sachs & Company and Kidder, Peabody & Company, Thomas C. Jorling, chairman of the State Environmental Facilities Corporation, announced yesterday.

title: California Is Investigating Doctor Who Whisked Newborn Onto TV
description: State regulators are investigating a doctor who speeded up delivery of a baby, put the infant in a Christmas stocking and dashed to a television studio next door to display her as the county's first newborn of the 1990's.

title: Delta Tells of Getting Threat But Says It Suspects a Hoax
description: Delta Air Lines said today that it had received a general threat against its trans-Atlantic operations but believed the warning was a hoax.

title: Baroque Concert
description: Donald Joyce will conduct a choir and a Baroque instruments orchestra in the Heinrich Schutz oratorio ''The Christmas Story'' tomorrow evening at 6:30 at St. John's in the Village Episcopal Church, 224 Waverly Place. Gregory Purnhagen will be the Evangelist in the performance. The program also includes Guillaume Dufay's ''Hostis Herodes,'' and a Handel Organ Concerto (Op. 4, No. 6), with Mr. Joyce as the organ soloist. Admission is free. Information: 243-6192.

title: Christie's Appointment
description: Emmanuel de Margerie, the Ambassador of France to the United States for five years through December and director general of the Museums of France from 1975 to 1977, has been appointed to the board of Christie's International and chairman of Christie's in Europe, a new position. Mr. de Margerie, who is 65 years old, will be based in Paris.

title: Gorbachev Postpones Meeting With Kinnock
description: Citing political events in the Soviet Union, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has postponed all his scheduled meetings with foreign politicians in January, a spokesman for Neil Kinnock, the British opposition leader, said today.

title: Review/Dance;   Chuma, Skura, O'Connor: Improvisers With a Plan
description: In a gracious program note for this year's Dance Chance performances at Dance Theater Workshop, Patsy Tarr, the producer and curator of the series for eight years, cautions future audiences not to underestimate the value of the experimental.

title: City Bar Association Long Enlightened
description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about new year's observances in Japan referred incorrectly to the calendar used in the West. It is the Gregorian calendar, based on the solar year.

title: In Texas, AIDS Struggle Is Also Matter of Money
description: As the AIDS epidemic rages in New York and California, Texas is struggling with a less noticed but no less destructive AIDS plague of its own.

title: Vladimir Ussachevsky, 78, Electronic Composer
description: Vladimir Ussachevsky, who composed the first piece of electronic music heard in concert in the United States and who went on to lead the pioneering Columbia-Princeton Electronic Music Center, died of a brain tumor yesterday at Calvary Hospital in the Bronx. He was 78 years old.

title: Business May Look Down, but Racing Fans Can Look Up
description: Thoroughbred racing begins a new season amid a mixed forecast: a year of poor business but wonderful racing.

title: Freedom For What?
description: ''You [Americans] have known freedom always,'' Jaroslav Baraban of Czechoslovakia told a New York Times reporter, Craig Whitney, in Wenceslas Square on New Year's Eve. ''But we have only known it for a month.''

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Dime Savings Bank of New York, Garden City, L.I., appointed David J. Totaro first senior vice president and director of marketing, and Jack L. Wagner first senior vice president, responsible for the bank's data processing activities.

title: Lawyers go to the Mat in a Battle Between Hulk Hogan and a 98-Pound Comedian
description: It seemed like the classic mismatch.

title: Edwin Shelley, 68, A Data Consultant And Systems Expert
description: Edwin F. Shelley, a management consultant and an inventor and engineer, died of a heart attack yesterday at New Rochelle (N.Y.) Hospital. He was 68 years old and lived in New Rochelle.

title: TV Weekend;   'After the War,' Mini-Series on 'Masterpiece Theater'
description: Something of an endangered species, the long-form mini-series returns to ''Masterpiece Theater'' on Sunday evening - on Channel 13 at 9 Channel 31 and 49 at 10 and Channel 21 at 11:30 - in Frederic Raphael's ''After the War.'' The 10-hour Granada Television production is to be presented in eight installments.

title: Islanders' Struggles Starting to Pay Off
description: The Islanders began their schedule with a luxury losers do not always enjoy: they were virtually ignored.

title: Science Has No Doubts on Theory of Evolution;   Dogs vs. Dogs
description: To the Editor:

title: Lebanese Shiite Rivals Step Up Fighting
description: Heavy fighting that has raged for nearly two weeks between rival Shiite Muslim factions in southern Lebanon gained intensity today as the combatants ignored an appeal from their spiritual leaders for an end to the bloodshed.

title: Jet Lands After an Engine Drops Off
description: One of three engines on a Northwest Airlines jet fell off the plane yesterday as it flew over northern Florida, but the pilots were able to land safely.

title: Our Towns;   Quiet Community Stirs When Feast Turns Violent
description: For 40 years, the Portuguese community in Naugatuck has celebrated St. Paio, a patron saint, and the celebration has evolved into the biggest social event of the year for the 6,000 Portuguese and Portuguese-Americans who make up 20 percent of the town's population.

title: Chinese at the U.N. Seeking to Keep Jobs
description: The union of United Nations civil servants has asked Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar to extend the contracts of several Chinese workers at the Secretariat who the union says have been asked to leave their jobs under ''pressure from the Chinese Government.''

title: Edward West, Retired Canon And Author, 80
description: The Rev. Dr. Edward Nason West, the retired Canon Sacrist of the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, where he was master of ceremonies for more than 40 years, died of pulmonary failure on Wednesday at St. Luke's Hospital in Manhattan. He was 80 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: I.M.F. Panel Picks Leader
description: The policy-making body of the International Monetary Fund Wednesday named Canada's Finance Minister, Michael Holcombe Wilson, to serve as chairman, setting the stage for a special meeting of the panel to work out an increase in I.M.F. financing.

title: 'Masaryk on the 100!'
description: To the Editor:

title: On Stage
description: On the Way

title: BRIEFS
description: * Asarco Inc., New York, a metals producer, sold its last operating coal mine, located in Peoria, Ill., to a group of former managers of the mine for $3 million.

title: Fiscal Quest For Cuomo
description: ''For everything there is a season and a time,'' Gov. Mario M. Cuomo said Wednesday in his State of the State address. ''This will be a time for renewed discipline in our spending.''

title: Surgery for Dravecky
description: Dave Dravecky, the former San Francisco Giants pitcher, underwent surgery for four and a half hours at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in New York yesterday to remove a tumor from his left arm.

title: Show on Black History
description: ''When the Colored Band Goes Marchin','' a one-man show combining autobiography and black history, is to be presented by John Patterson on weekends through Jan. 28 at the Castillo Cultural Center, 500 Greenwich Street. In the piece, Mr. Patterson draws upon his own writings and works by Frederick Douglass, Langston Hughes, W. E. B. DuBois, Alice Walker and others. Shows are Fridays and Saturdays at 8 P.M., and Sundays at 3 P.M. Tickets are $10. Information: 941-5800.

title: Surge in Oil Prices Falters As Gradual Decline Is Seen
description: After surging this week to one of its highest trading levels in four years, oil prices are likely to decline gradually before reaching a low point sometime in the spring, industry analysts said today.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption on Wednesday about the inauguration of Andrew P. O'Rourke as Westchester County Executive misidentified the justice who administered the oath. (The error was repeated in some copies yesterday in a correction in this space.) The justice was Samuel G. Fredman.

title: Giants Need New Script To Win
description: The Giants remember the horrible game they played eight weeks ago in a 31-10 loss to the Los Angeles Rams. They know they will have to be a different team Sunday when they meet the Rams at Giants Stadium in the National Football League playoffs.

title: Leonard Elliott, Actor, 84
description: Leonard Elliott, an actor and comedian who performed on the Broadway stage and in Manhattan nightclubs, died of cardiac arrest on Sunday in St. Vincent's Hospital. He was 84 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Seattle Journal;   Drug War Weapon: Manpower On Bikes
description: When Seattle police officers began riding 21-speed mountain bicycles into drug strongholds in bright yellow Gore-Tex raincoats, black nylon pants, fashionable helmets and oversized galoshes, the gang members giggled.

title: Alberto Lleras, Twice President In Colombia, 83
description: Alberto Lleras Camargo, twice President of Colombia and an architect of a 16-year coalition Government that reduced rural violence, died today after a long illness, a presidential spokesman said.

title: Fed Approval on Securities
description: The Federal Reserve Board said today that it had approved limited securities underwriting and dealing by three foreign banking companies that operate subsidiaries in the United States.

title: Judge Denies Bail to Woman Extradited on Drug Charges
description: A woman extradited from Austria will remain in jail without bond to face charges that she operated an international marijuana-smuggling ring, a Federal district judge has ruled.

title: Punished by Bucharest, City's Choice Was Revolt
description: The man described his day. He wakes. He goes to buy milk for his children. For the babies, there is no formula to buy. He goes to work. The bus line is long and slow. It is cold at work. There is no heat, no equipment for proper work. He finishes work and goes to buy something to eat. But there is no food to buy. The next day, it is the same. Thus did Victor Carauscu, a 28-year-old research engineer, describe the small and grinding deprivations that led him, on the night of Dec. 22, 1989, to take up arms against tyranny in the revolution that toppled Nicolae Ceausescu and his wife, Elena.

title: Washington at Work;   Lobbyist's Bitter Attack on Congressmen Reverberates From 60's to the 90's
description: Many people in Washington believe Marian Wright Edelman, the president of the Children's Defense Fund and an icon of sorts among many liberals, made a fundamental error when she bluntly accused two members of Congress of sabotaging a child care bill before adjournment late last year.

title: Fresh, Hot and Headed for Fame, These Are the Faces to Watch;   Dance
description: JEPPE MYDTSKOV,who was born in Copenhagen and received his dance training at the Royal Danish Ballet School, has proved to be just as distinctive as such earlier Danish recruits to the New York City Ballet as Peter Martins (now head of the company), Adam Luders and Ib Andersen.

title: Weighing The Differences Among Heaters
description: Another fad is taking hold in the business of keeping warm: ceramic electric heaters. Like the portable kerosene burners and quartz electric heaters that preceded them, ceramic heaters have a few advantages over older models. But they are also the subject of advertising and sales promotions that sometimes promise too much.

title: CONSUMER'S WORLD: Guidepost;   Credit Card Savings
description: With interest rates headed down, as they are now, holders of bank credit cards with payments based on a fixed rate of interest can save as much as $100 a year in fees by switching to cards with interest payments tied to a variable rate. The fixed rate charged on many bank cards has been holding at current levels for a few years - good for card holders while interest rates rise. But the bank prime rate was lowered twice in 1989 and may be lowered again soon. That means it is time to think about a change. Here are the estimated annual savings over the average fixed rate of 18.66 percent if the variable rate falls another half of a percentage point: $ Monthly Balance Savings At 16.5% Savings At 16% $2,000 $43.20 $53.20 1,000 21.60 26.60 500 11.40 13.90

title: Prosecutor Quits; Tale of Attack Was Hoax
description: New Jersey's most flamboyant prosecutor resigned today after his tale of a high-speed chase and shoot-out between him and men he described as drug dealers, terrorists or members of the Ku Klux Klan turned out to be a hoax.

title: OPEC's Output at 1989 High
description: OPEC's oil output reached a 1989 high of 23.6 million barrels a day throughout December and will probably remain strong in early 1990 despite a new production-cutting accord, oil industry, government and shipping sources said this week.

title: Residents Can Return To Gramercy Building
description: More than four months after they were forced to leave their homes, tenants of a Gramercy Park building that was coated with asbestos when a Consolidated Edison steam pipe exploded last summer can move back to their apartments beginning Jan. 15, the utility said yesterday.

title: Creation of Jobs Is Only Sluggish In Latest Report
description: New jobs were created at a markedly slower rate in December, but the nation's unemployment rate remained unchanged at 5.3 percent, completing a year of exceptional stability, the Labor Department reported today.

title: 'Beauty and the Beast' Is Canceled by CBS
description: CBS will cancel ''Beauty and the Beast'' after its broadcast on Jan. 24.

title: U.S. Sets Offer on Contra Aid
description: The United States is prepared to provide up to $3 million to an international commission to begin planning the voluntary relocation of contras to Nicaragua provided that democratic conditions exist there, the State Department said today.

title: Savings Data Are Revised
description: The nation's savings institutions lost $6.4 billion in deposits in October, rather than the $5.6 billion in outflows originally reported, the Office of Thrift Supervision said today.

title: Department Spent $224,000 In Effort to Unmask Informer
description: The Justice Department said today that it spent $224,000 on an attempt to identify the source of an unauthorized disclosure of a preliminary criminal investigation involving Representative William H. Gray 3d, Democrat of Pennsylvania.

title: M.T.A. Amplifier Ban Is Blocked by Judge
description: A Federal judge in Manhattan yesterday blocked the Metropolitan Transit Authority from enforcing a rule that bans musicians from using amplifiers in New York City subways.

title: Patents;   A Spaghetti Sipper and a Rodent Derby
description: This was an exceptionally rich week for patents on novelty inventions. From a spaghetti sipper to a new jump rope, patents were granted for simple devices offering a creative, often whimsical twist to things most people assume cannot be improved.

title: Alexis P. Fekula, Choral Conductor, 58
description: Alexis P. Fekula, an oil and gas consultant and choral conductor of Russian liturgical music, died of heart disease on Thursday in Boston. He was 58 years old and lived in Southport, Conn.

title: Citgo Stake May Be Resold
description: Venezuela, which recently agreed to buy the 50 percent of the Citgo Petroleum Corporation that it did not already own, will probably resell the stake, the Energy Minister, Celestino Armas, said today.

title: Upheaval in the East: Czechoslovakia - The Talk of Prague;   Glee for Communists: Havel Suffers a Miscue
description: The medieval squares and coffee houses of this city have come alive again with politics. But the heady talk has been more about what may have been President Vaclav Havel's first mistake than about the crimes and abuses of the Communists.

title: Less Delay Encountered On Real Estate Inquiries
description: Prospective buyers eventually encountered fewer delays today in telephone calls seeking to learn more about the thousands of single-family homes, apartments, office projects and other properties inherited by the Government from failed savings institutions and now being auctioned off.

title: The Noriega Case: Statement;   Transcript of Bush News Conference on Noriega and Panama
description: Following is a transcript of President Bush's news conference yesterday in Washington, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Bengals' Offensive Coach Interviewed by Steinberg
description: Dick Steinberg yesterday conducted his second interview to select the next head coach of the Jets and left little doubt what he is looking for: a motivating, teaching leader who can bring the often-troubled team together.

title: Eased Verdict Sought
description: Aaron Pryor, the former world junior welterweight champion, said in a motion filed Thursday in Hamilton County Municipal Court in Cincinnati that he should receive treatment for drug dependency instead of a conviction for possession of drug items.

title: COMPANY BRIEFS
description: * American Magnetics Corp., Los Angeles, said it would consider inquiries from various groups, including one organized by members of senior management, regarding the purchase of the company's card-reader and access control businesses.

title: TBS Allowed Vietnam Link
description: Turner Broadcasting System said Thursday that it had won its battle with the Bush Administration over providing its Cable News Network and a satellite receiving station to Vietnam.

title: Ernest T. Brainard, 99, Broker in Connecticut
description: Ernest T. Brainard, who apparently was the nation's oldest active stockbroker, died on Wednesday as he was getting ready to go work. He was 99 years old and lived in West Hartford.

title: The Noriega Case: Security;   U.S. IS SECRETIVE ON NORIEGA PRISON
description: Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega arrived in Miami guarded by dozens of police sharpshooters and bodyguards, part of an extraordinary security blanket that continued today as camouflaged military helicopters crisscrossed city skies while his lawyers conferred with their client at a secret location.

title: Portugal Turns Away Damaged Iran Tanker
description: A crippled Iranian tanker that spilled 19 million gallons of oil off the Moroccan coast was turned away today by Portugal, the third nation to deny the ship entry.

title: Upheaval in the East: Troops;   U.S. Says the Kremlin Seeks Deeper Cuts in European Forces
description: Soviet officials have informally suggested that Moscow is prepared to make deeper troop cuts than those it has previously proposed in the Vienna arms talks, Administration officials said today.

title: Japanese Insurance Concern Invests in American Express
description: The Nippon Life Insurance Company, the large Japanese insurer that already has a sizable stake in Shearson Lehman Hutton, the brokerage unit affiliated with the American Express Company, has agreed to make a $200 million investment in American Express itself.

title: Tree Devastation in Riverside Park Silences the Song of Birds
description: To the Editor:

title: Racial Manipulation in Boston
description: When Charles Stuart jumped off a bridge to his death in Boston Harbor Thursday, he apparently took with him the answers to one of the most bizarre murder mysteries in Boston's history. But his death is only the beginning of what is sure to be a period of soul-searching, even anger, in a city long torn by racial conflict.

title: Gertrude Simon Kosting, Health-Care Worker, 84
description: Gertrude Simon Kosting, a health-care worker and the president of the Huxley Institute of Connecticut, died of an embolism on Tuesday at Norwalk (Conn.) Hospital. She was 84 years old and lived in Weston, Conn.

title: CONSUMER'S WORLD: Coping;   With Stain-Resistant Carpets
description: These days, almost all American-made nylon carpets offer some sort of stain protection, which makes it easier than ever to remove spots. So, parties that chase the post-holiday blahs need no longer leave permanent reminders.

title: Maine Fights Nekoosa Bid
description: The Maine Attorney General asked a state judge today to block on antitrust grounds the Georgia-Pacific Corporation's $3.8 billion hostile bid for the Great Northern Nekoosa Corporation.

title: Richard H. Wels, 76, a Lawyer; Was an Expert on Family Law
description: Richard Hoffman Wels, a lawyer who was influential in the reform of New York State's divorce laws, died on Thursday at his home in Manhattan. He was 76 years old. Mr. Wels, an expert on family law, helped to modernize the state's matrimonial laws. For nearly 40 years, he was a leader of the New York State Bar Association and the American Bar Association.

title: Suffolk County Officer Held On Rape and Sodomy Counts
description: A 49-year-old Suffolk County police officer with 20 years on the force was arrested today on charges of raping and sodomizing a girl, the authorities said.

title: Noriega Can Get A Fair Trial
description: Since Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega turned himself over to U.S. authorities this week to face drug trafficking charges, two contradictory predictions have been made about his trial.

title: Bond Wins a Round In Fight Over Holdings
description: Alan Bond's flagship company, Bond Corporation Holdings Ltd., successfully withstood an attempt today to liquidate the Australian's brewing and media holdings, but it now faces new demands from United States creditors to repay $510 million immediately.

title: Pappy Mason's Mother Gets 10-Year Term
description: The mother of the drug dealer Howard (Pappy) Mason was sentenced yesterday to 10 years in prison for running her son's crack business while he was in jail.

title: Patents;   New Jump Rope Offers Greater Control
description: Priscilla Burton, a retired secretary in Providence, R.I., liked the aerobic exercise of jumping rope but wanted a rope she could swing more slowly and with less stress.

title: Dorsey Return Likely; Allegre Still Waiting
description: Since the National Football League season began four months ago, the Giants have added only eight players to their roster. On Saturday, the day before their first playoff game, they will probably add one and perhaps two or three.

title: The Noriega Case: Panama City;   Papal Envoy Asserts Psychology, Not Ultimatum, Swayed Noriega
description: The papal envoy to Panama, the pivotal figure in 10 days of tense negotiations that ended in Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega's surrender, insisted today that the general's departure from the Vatican mission resulted not from an ultimatum but from a precisely calibrated psychological campaign.

title: Gary Reasons' Head
description: The head is a strange instrument, an awesome thing, a thing of multiple utilities. It can be used to cogitate; it can be used to ruminate; the skeletal remnant can be a memory device - ''Alas, poor Yorick! I knew him, Horatio.'' And it can be used as a weapon - like being armed with your head.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Thursday about Mayor David N. Dinkins's decision to delay the hiring of 1,848 police officers misstated a campaign promise he made about subway crime. He pledged that by the end of his first term he would put an officer on every train every night, not in every car.

title: MGM/UA Sale Seen as Stalled
description: Jeffrey Barbakow, chairman of the MGM/UA Communications Company, has told company executives that efforts to sell the entertainment company are on hold, the trade publication Variety has reported, quoting unidentified sources.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A.

title: Inquiry at Clemson
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association will conduct an official investigation of the Clemson football program, the school said yesterday. A preliminary investigation uncovered 14 alleged rule violations, ranging from wrongful payments to illegal recruiting contacts, the school said.

title: Asahi Breweries Plans U.S. Plant
description: Asahi Breweries Ltd., the third-largest beer producer in Japan, said it plans to build a plant in the United States and produce its Super Dry beer, one of the company's largest exports. Asahi is planning to invest about 10 billion yen, or about $70 million at today's exchange rate, to build a plant near Denver in April, aiming to complete it by the end of 1991, said a company official who declined to be named.

title: What? Send Women to War?
description: Capt. Linda Bray led an attack in the Panama invasion, apparently the first time that a woman has commanded American forces in battle. But she was acting as a Military Police officer; women are still barred from combat roles in the armed forces. Since women like Captain Bray already serve with distinction in danger zones, isn't it time to allow them into combat too? A careful experiment could clarify a difficult issue.

title: Dehere Sparks Pirates Over St. Peter's by 76-57
description: Terry Dehere of Seton Hall played his high school basketball at St. Anthony in Jersey City, just a few minutes from St. Peter's College.

title: Treasury Securities Move Lower
description: Most Treasury securities prices declined yesterday as the fixed-income market shrugged off the smaller-than-expected rise in employment that the Government reported for December. The bond market also paid little notice to the strong rise in December factory orders.

title: Mortgage Rates Mixed
description: Fixed-rate home mortgages are averaging 9.83 percent, up from 9.78 percent last week, according to a national survey released today by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation. On one-year adjustable-rate mortgages, lenders were asking an average initial rate of 8.35 percent this week, down from 8.39 percent the week before.

title: Bridge
description: Happy players at the end of a pairs contest often report that they had a ''big game,'' meaning that they did very well. But to deserve the title ''Big Game'' with capital letters, one needs a score of 75% or better, which is very rare.

title: 'Legs Diamond' Suit Is Settled Out of Court
description: The choreographer Michael Shawn will receive $175,000 from the producers of the 1988 musical ''Legs Diamond'' in an out-of-court settlement of a suit in which he charged that the producers had dismissed him because he had tested positive for the AIDS virus.

title: Oil Prices Push Transportation Charges Up
description: The recent explosion in petroleum prices, especially diesel fuel, is raising transportation prices in a way not seen for a decade, economists and industry executives say. Airlines and trucking companies are imposing fuel surcharges or indexing their rates to fuel costs.

title: Tokyo Official Takes on Bastion of Sexism, and Loses
description: To the delight of traditionalists and the consternation of feminists, the first woman ever to be named chief spokeswoman for the Government of Japan was humbled today by one of the nation's most powerful remaining male strongholds, the world of sumo wrestling.

title: Hanoi Allows Hundreds to Go
description: Hundreds of Vietnamese who helped the Americans during the Vietnam War and who were punished for it after the Communist victory are on their way to the United States. Three jets brought the first 156 former re-education camp inmates and their families today to Bangkok from Ho Chi Minh City, formerly Saigon, and 151 more are expected on Saturday. Nearly 2,000 Vietnamese are scheduled to leave their homeland by March.

title: Knick Trainer Hurt
description: Mike Saunders, the Knicks' trainer the last 12 years, was hospitalized yesterday with multiple facial fractures and lacerations after his vehicle skidded on ice and struck a tree yesterday morning at the team's training center at the State University of New York campus in Purchase, team officials said. (AP)

title: Campeau Unit Trims Office Staff 14%
description: Federated Department Stores, a subsidiary of the financially troubled Campeau Corporation, said yesterday that it had eliminated 52 positions in its Cincinnati headquarters, or about 14 percent of its already reduced corporate staff.

title: Generic Drug Bribe Sentence
description: A former chemist for the Food and Drug Administration was sentenced today to 30 days in jail for taking $4,300 in bribes to influence the Government's approval of generic drugs.

title: Brooklyn Chorus Auditions
description: Open auditions for the Brooklyn Philharmonia Chorus are to be held on Tuesday at 7 P.M. at the First Presbyterian Church, 124 Henry Street, in Brooklyn Heights. Performances by the group, the oldest community chorus in Brooklyn, are scheduled for April and May in Brooklyn and Manhattan. Information: (718) 640-3028.

title: Patents;   A Raceway for Rodents That Is Escape-Free
description: For people looking for an alternative to raising horses and greyhound dogs, Robert L. Tottey of Ithaca, N.Y., has invented an ''escape-free rodent raceway.''

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, JANUARY 6, 1990
description: The Economy

title: Upheaval in the East: Funeral;   Simple 'Last Homage' to One Who Stood Against Ceausescu
description: Rumania's new leaders paid last respects today to Secretary of State Corneliu Bogdan, the first of their number to die since they took power two weeks ago.

title: Factory Orders Rise by 2.4% Led by Demand for Durables
description: Orders for manufactured goods rose 2.4 percent in November, reaching their second-highest level ever, the Commerce Department said today.

title: A New Air Force One
description: A new Air Force One jet will be delivered to President Bush on Sept. 30, almost two years late, largely because of efforts to make it resistant to a nuclear explosion, the Boeing Company said Thursday. Boeing, which has been building two modified 747 jumbo jets for the President's use, originally promised that a new Air Force One would be ready in November 1988. Progress on the planes was delayed by efforts to equip them with wiring that could withstand a nuclear blast, Boeing said.

title: About New York;   For Paraplegic, Acting in a Film Is the Easy Part
description: Kenneth Osborne has known grave disappointment. When he was 19 years old and a carefree college football player, his spine was severed in a car crash, leaving him paralyzed from the chest down. It was hell to adjust. But he did. ''That took some serious time,'' Mr. Osborne said.

title: Contributors to the Neediest Continue to Recall Holidays
description: The Christmas trees may be down and the decorations put away for another year, but the holiday season is not yet over. The Feast of the Epiphany, which for Western Christians marks the homage of the Three Kings, is celebrated tomorrow. And holiday themes continue to dominate the letters to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: Exxon 'Stonewalling' on Spill, New Jersey Aide Says
description: A spokesman for the New Jersey Attorney General's Office yesterday accused Exxon Corporation officials of ''stonewalling'' an investigation into the spill of at least 200,000 gallons of oil into the Arthur Kill.

title: Devils Bolster Checking Line, Trading Broten For Brooke
description: The last of the Colorado Rockies left the Devils yesterday when Aaron Broten was traded to the Minnesota North Stars for Bob Brooke.

title: Patents;   New Flea Repellant
description: Two researchers at the Elexis Corporation, a company in Miami that makes pulse monitors, have patented an electronic flea repelling device for household pets. The heart of the device, which is mounted on a pet's collar, is a transducer that sends out periodic ultrasonic pulses that do not bother a dog or cat but apparently are intolerable to fleas.

title: Books of The Times;   Two Memoirs of Changes in Journalism
description: How Many Words Do You Want?

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''What kind of crazy way is this to run a place? If they treat me this way and I'm the Chancellor, what is going on here?'' -Joseph A. Fernandez, New York City Schools Chancellor. [1:4.]

title: Pilots Had No Way of Knowing Jet Engine Fell Off, Experts Say
description: The pilots of a Northwest Airlines jetliner who flew for nearly 25 minutes on Thursday unaware that one of the plane's three engines had sheared off and plummeted 35,000 feet would have had no way of knowing what had happened, aviation experts said yesterday.

title: Review/Dance;   Evolution of Three Familiar Works
description: George Balanchine, perhaps more than other choreographers, liked to revise his ballets over the decades. Two that he reworked, ''Danses Cocertantes'' and ''Tchaikovsky Suite No. 3,'' shared the New York City Ballet's program with Peter Martins's recent ''Barber Violin Concerto'' on Thursday night at the New York State Theater.

title: Many Flee Liberia as Clash Destroys Towns, Envoys Say
description: Fighting between Liberian forces and rebels opposed to the West African country's leader, Gen. Samuel K. Doe, has devastated two towns in northeastern Liberia and sent thousands fleeing across the border, Western diplomats said today.

title: The Noriega Case: Intelligence Operations;   U.S. Worry: What Damage Can Noriega Do?
description: Even as the Bush Administration celebrates its success in capturing Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, intelligence experts have turned their attention to the question of how much damage or embarrassment General Noriega can cause the United States in his new role as criminal defendant.

title: 11 Kashmir Cities Get Curfew to Counter Militants
description: The authorities in the northern state of Kashmir have imposed an indefinite curfew in Srinagar, the capital, and 10 other cities after militants seeking independence threatened to disrupt the region, Government officials said today.

title: Councilman Asserts Minorities Dislike Education
description: The new chairman of the New York City Council's education committee -long known for his outspoken views -has asserted in an interview that, in contrast to ''children of European-born'' parents, ''there appears to be no liking of learning'' among black and Hispanic children.

title: In Boston, a Storm of Recriminations
description: A vicious round of finger-pointing began here today as prosecutors, the police and the news media began tracing the trail of faulty assumptions, disregarded suspicions, blunders and perhaps even lies that put the wrong man at the center of one of the most highly publicized and emotion-charged murder cases in the city's history.

title: Letter: On Abortion;   The Problem of Parental Notification
description: To the Editor: In 1977 and 1978 I was privileged to serve with an august group of people on the Governor's Commission on Alternatives to Abortion, headed by the then dean of the Fordham Law School, Joseph McLaughlin, who subsequently was named to the Federal bench. The conclusions of that study group were the basis for subsequent policies of Gov. Hugh Carey on abortion, which were upheld by the Legislature, and which continue in force today in New York State.

title: Joseph Anderson, 75, Ex-Military Attache
description: Jospeh Crook Anderson, a retired Army colonel and former military attache, died of leukemia Monday at his home in Bethesda, Md. He was 75 years old.

title: Elegy for an English Bike
description: My bicycle was stolen the other day. Or maybe I should say my friend was kidnapped on West 23d Street sometime between 7 P.M. and 10 P.M. She was a Raleigh three-speed, English, heavy, black and one of the most remarkable machines I've ever had. No effete, high-strung 10-speed from Italy or Japan was she. No, she was made of solid steel, rugged, not easy to carry, but a masterpiece. I feel a deep gloom without her.

title: Carmen Hill, Pitcher, 94
description: Carmen Hill, a former National League pitcher who compiled a 49-33 record in 10 major league seasons over 16 years, died on Monday in Indianapolis. He was 94 years old.

title: Nils Hansell, Sailing Promoter, 80
description: Nils Hansell, an amateur sailor best known as the originator of Operation Sail, an international maritime festival in New York City in 1964, died of pnuemonia last Saturday at the Princeton (N.J.) Medical Center. He was 80 years old and lived in Princeton.

title: Plea in Martin Case
description: A plea of not guilty was entered in Port Crane, N.Y., late Thursday for William Reedy, the Detroit bar owner who is accused of driving while intoxicated in the accident that killed Billy Martin of the Yankees on Christmas Day. Town Justice P. Murray Benjamin also granted a request by Gerald Mollen, the Broome County District Attorney, for a 60-day adjournment to present findings to a grand jury. (AP)

title: Gunn to Leave Transit Agency; Says System Is Now Acceptable
description: David L. Gunn, who embarked six years ago on what he called a ''suicide mission'' to turn around New York City's crumbling mass-transit system, announced his resignation yesterday as president of a now ''acceptable, but not perfect'' system.

title: BUSH DENIES MOVE FOR NORIEGA DEAL, BUT DOOR IS OPEN
description: President Bush today left open the door for Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega to try to arrange a reduction of the charges in his drug-trafficking case, but the President said he ''is not seeking a deal.''

title: Patents;   A Chain That Becomes As Rigid as a Bar
description: In a similar spirit, a Brooklyn inventor won a patent several weeks ago for what she called a ''chain bar.''

title: Upheaval in the East;   Poland to Cut Army Strength
description: Poland will reduce required military service from 2 years to 18 months this year and also cut manpower, Defense Minister Florian Siwicki said today.

title: 71 Ships Use Suez Canal
description: Seventy-one ships sailed through the Suez Canal today, the highest number in 12 years, earning Egypt $6 million in tolls, Canal Authority sources said. The record was set in 1978 when 95 ships passed through the canal in a single day, they said. A southbound convoy of 41 ships sailed through the 117-mile waterway from the Mediterranean to the Red Sea, including 9 oil tankers and 13 container ships. Thirty vessels, including eight tankers, sailed in the opposite direction.

title: Principal to Be Charged With Incompetence
description: New York City's new Schools Chancellor, Joseph A. Fernandez, said yesterday that he would file a charge of incompetence against the principal of a Brooklyn high school whom he removed from office over her handling of two disturbances by the school's students.

title: Alaskan Oil Spill Laid to Collapse of Regulation
description: A collapse of Government regulation of the oil tanker industry created conditions that led to the Alaska oil spill, a panel of scientists and oil industry experts concluded in a report released today by the state of Alaska.

title: Dinkins Seeks Spending Cuts From Agencies
description: Mayor David N. Dinkins, saying fiscal troubles may force trims in more city programs, told the heads of all city agencies yesterday to outline new spending cuts to help close a budget gap of up to $150 million for the rest of the fiscal year that ends June 30.

title: Upheaval in the East: Poland;   Warsaw's Economic Chief Opposes Weakening of Plan
description: Complaints that Poland's program of economic change is exacting too much pain are increasing, but the counry's Finance Minister insisted today that a severe economic program was the only way to reduce inflation and revive Poland's crumbling economy.

title: Carson Has a Team of His Own
description: At the age of 58, after making the playoffs 11 times as an assistant coach, Bud Carson will run his very own National Football League playoff team for the first time today.

title: Theodore I. Felner, 81, Former Textile Official
description: Theodore I. Felner, a retired executive of Burlington Industries and of Macy's New York, died of an embolism on Wednesday at his winter home in Pompano Beach, Fla. He was 81 years old and also had a residence in Manhattan.

title: Upheaval in the East;   Delay Appears Likely In Rumanian Election
description: Pressure mounted today from new and revived political parties, including the Liberals and the National Peasants Party, to postpone elections beyond the April date set by the provisional Government. Count Otto von Lambsdorff, head of West Germany's Free Democratic Party, said at a news conference here that in talks held with leaders of the new Rumanian political groups, all sought such a postponement.

title: Upheaval in the East: Rumania;   Ex-Dissidents Will Monitor Bucharest on Rights
description: A small group of former dissidents is setting up a committee to make sure that human rights are observed here as Rumania rids itself of the remnants of the Government of Nicolae Ceausescu.

title: Kwiatkowski Is Named Head Coach at Brown
description: The Hofstra football coach for the last nine years, Mickey Kwiatkowski, moved from Division III to the Ivy League yesterday when he was appointed head coach at Brown University, succeeding John Rosenberg, who resigned Dec. 4.

title: Anheuser-Busch
description: Anheuser-Busch Inc. said it plans to begin selling its new non-alcoholic brew, O'Doul's, around the country starting on Monday. The brewery said it has had strong initial sales in selected cities where the beer has been on shelves since March. Anheuser-Busch, the world's largest brewery, said O'Doul's would meet the desires of a growing segment of consumers who like the taste of beer but do not want the alcohol. Other breweries, including the Miller Brewing Company, have recently introduced non-alcoholic beers.

title: Upheaval in the East: Soviet Union;   PARTY CHIEF QUITS IN MUSLIM REPUBLIC
description: The Communist Party leader in a troubled region on the Soviet border with Iran has been forced to step down, the republic's Foreign Ministry said today.

title: Don't Encourage a China Hostile to Freedom;   Keep the Door Open
description: To the Editor:

title: News Summary
description: International 3-7

title: Why Milk Prices Are Soaring
description: Elsie the Cow, meet Adam Smith.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball

title: Missing Boy: Drug Trade Hits Again
description: The morning of Dec. 5, 12-year-old William Porter left his crowded railroad apartment on 132d Street in Harlem, walked down the dirty stairs, past the rotting sofa filled with garbage in the front of his building, and started off to school.

title: KEY RATES
For New York Area, 20 Lessons in Real Estate
description: There will not be any Greenwich mansions at Levittown prices in the Government's sale of 30,000 properties taken over from failed savings institutions. But a look yesterday at some of the 20 residential properties offered in New York, New Jersey and Connecticut showed housing for every pocketbook and life style and, maybe, a chance to save a few thousand dollars.

title: Review/Jazz;   Swan Songs From 1974 Still Strong
description: Among the eight selections that the Modern Jazz Quartet played in its first set on Tuesday evening at the Cafe Carlyle, Madison Avenue at East 76th Street, five were part of the group's concert at Avery Fisher Hall on Nov. 25, 1974 - ''Django,'' ''Softly as in the Morning Sunrise,'' ''True Blues,'' ''Skating in Central Park'' and ''Odds Against Tomorrow.''

title: Don't Encourage a China Hostile to Freedom
description: To the Editor:

title: Ian Horvath, Dancer, Dies at 46; A Founder of the Cleveland Ballet
description: Ian (Ernie) Horvath, producing director of the Jose Limon Dance Foundation, a founder of the Cleveland Ballet and a former soloist with the Joffrey Ballet and American Ballet Theater, died of AIDS yesterday at St. Vincent's Hospital in New York. Mr. Horvath was 46 years old.

title: The Noriega Case: Defense Strategy;   Noriega and Lawyers Meet for 2 Hours
description: Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega today plotted strategy with defense lawyers amid questions about the future of the defense team itself.

title: Travelers' Security Precautions
description: The holiday travel rush is over, but passenger security precautions know no season. Here is some advice for travelers from Christopher Grose, president of Control Risks Limited, an international security consultant whose United States headquarters is in Bethesda, Md.

title: Computer Brokerages Match Buyers, Sellers and Used Gear
description: Demand is growing for both used and new computers for the home and office, and an increasing number of purchases and sales are being made through computer brokerages.

title: Tandy Expects Earnings Decline
description: The Tandy Corporation, whose sales have been hit in a weaker domestic computer industry, said it expects to post lower earnings for its quarter that ended Dec. 31. The consumer electronics maker, which operates Radio Shack stores, said its profit for the second quarter would be lower than in the period a year ago, when it had earnings of $1.50 a share on sales of $1.4 billion.

title: Arlene D. Friehling, Hotelier, 59
description: Arlene Dinnerstein Friehling, a former owner of the Stevensville Country Club, a resort hotel in Swan Lake, N.Y., died of cancer on Wednesday at the Community General Hospital in Harris, N.Y. She was 59 years old and lived in Liberty, N.Y.

title: Premature on the 90's
description: To the Editor:

title: Amid an Average Bunch, No One Is Counted Out
description: The current college campaign composes a conundrum because there is no distinguishing the strong from the not so strong. They all seem average in ECAC Hockey and Hockey East, the two Eastern Division I leagues, which are beginning the second half of their seasons.

title: COURT OVERTURNS AWARD TO FAMILY IN SMOKING DEATH
description: A Federal appeals court yesterday threw out the first verdict ever requiring an American cigarette manufacturer to compensate the family of a smoker who died of cancer. But at the same time, the court, may have made it easier for smokers and their families to prevail in future lawsuits against tobacco companies.

title: Manila to Dismiss 126,000
description: The Government will dismiss 126,000 employees this month in an effort to weed out unqualified civil service workers who got their jobs through patronage, an official said today. The affected employees hold temporary positions received through the intercession of politicians, said Patricia Santo Tomas, head of the Civil Service Commission. Not included are employees without civil service eligibility but who have served for 10 years or more, she said.

title: Corrections
description: A headline on Thursday about an art theft at an Italian villa misstated the ownership of the four paintings and one piece of furniture that were stolen. They belong to the villa's owner, Giuseppe Panza di Biumo, not to the Solomon R. Guggenheim Foundation.

title: The Noriega Case: Television;   President Complains About TV's Use of Split Images
description: President Bush complained yesterday that by juxtaposing pictures of him in a jocular mood during a news conference last month and the arrival of the bodies of American soldiers killed in Panama, some television news organizations had made him appear insensitive to the deaths.

title: The 'Hounding' of Isabelle Adjani
description: In the dazzling sunlight filling a gilded hotel suite on Madison Avenue, Isabelle Adjani was recalling the bleak season two years ago when she went on French national television to prove that she was alive and well.

title: The Noriega Case: Public Opinion;   Panamanians Strongly Back U.S. Move
description: The Panamanian people overwhelmingly approve of the sending of United States troops to remove Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega from power, and they want them to stay for at least six more months, according to a poll taken in Panama that was made public last night by CBS News.

title: Your Money;   Are the Insurers Fiscally Strong?
description: The Pacific Standard Life Insurance Company, a carrier with $7 billion of insurance in force that had invested heavily in ''junk bonds'' and ''junk mortgages,'' was declared insolvent by the California Department of Insurance at the end of November. In the weeks since then, many financial advisers have asked whether the insolvency is an isolated event or whether other insurers are also at risk.

title: Award for Reagan
description: Former President Ronald Reagan will appear at the National Collegiate Athletic Association's annual honors dinner Monday night in Dallas to accept the Teddy Award, given annually for contributions or achievements in college sports. Several women on the N.C.A.A.'s award committee said they would stage a low-key protest of the event, citing what they termed Reagan's lack of support for women's sports.

title: Don't Encourage a China Hostile to Freedom;   Hasty, Furtive Move
description: To the Editor:

title: Right to Bear Arms
description: To the Editor:

title: Minnesota Senator Denies New Charges of Impropriety
description: Senator Dave Durenberger, who is already facing a Senate investigation of his financial dealings, today strongly denied new accusations of impropriety regarding the Government's reimbursement for his rental of a Minneapolis condiminum.

title: Peru's Inflation Is Owed To Lack of Restraints
description: To the Editor:

title: Bruce Jay Heim, 37, An Investment Banker
description: Bruce Jay Heim, an investment banker, died of complications of AIDS on Thursday at his home in Bernardsville, N.J. He was 37 years old.

title: Inside
description: Recriminations in Boston

title: A U.S.-Soviet Venture of a Gentler Kind
description: Susan Eisenhower, granddaughter of the President who led the United States in the early years of the cold war, and Roald Z. Sagdeyev, a former leader of the Soviet space program, announced today that they will marry in Moscow next month.

title: Wilfred B. Doner, Advertising Executive, 75
description: Wilfred B. Doner, founder of W. .B. Doner & Company, an advertising agency based in Detroit, died Thursday, apparently of a cerebral hemorrhage, at his home in Birmingham, Mich. He was 75 years old.

title: Paroled Killer Accused in Deaths Of 11 Women in Rochester Area
description: A convicted killer of two children was accused today of killing 11 women, most of them prostitutes, in a series of attacks that began here in March 1988, a year after his release from prison for the earlier slayings.

title: The Mayor's Signal: Blunt, but Brave
description: Score one for Mayor David Dinkins. In his first days in office he announced that he had delayed hiring the next class of New York City police recruits. The gesture, though blunt, was brave and important. Nobody wants fewer police officers. But neither does anyone want the city to stumble back into fiscal trouble. His action should reassure those worried about Mr. Dinkins's capacity to make tough decisions, and lets New Yorkers with raised expectations know that the city is in for difficult times.

title: Patents;   A Tape Measure With Digital Readout
description: The Kyoto Measuring Instruments Corporation, based in Kyoto, Japan, has invented a retractable tape measure with a digital readout. The device is said to be easier to use and to read than the standard tool, in which measurements are marked on the tape itself.

title: Duane C. Bogie, Television Producer, 67
description: Duane C. Bogie, a television producer who helped create the ''Hallmark Hall of Fame'' drama series, died of brain cancer Tuesday in Parkland Hospital in Dallas. He was 67 years old and had homes in Dallas and Litchfield, Conn.

title: Beliefs
description: When the baby boomers needed backyards, America got suburbia. When they protested, America got sit-ins and antiwar marches. When their hormones began to act up, America got the sexual revolution.

title: From Jewish Eden to Embarrassment
description: In 1823, James Fenimore Cooper described the Catskills in his novel ''The Pioneers'': ''You must have seen them on your left as you followed the river up from York, looking as blue as a piece of clear sky, and holding the clouds on their tops, as the smoke curls over the head of an Indian chief at the council fire.''

title: Grand Juries: Wasteful and Pointless
description: If a defendant pleads not guilty to a felony charge, the New York State Constitution provides that he cannot be tried for that charge unless he is indicted by a grand jury. The idea is sound: No one should be accused, arrested or required to answer a felony charge at trial if there is no evidence to support the charge.

title: Vacancy For A Czar
description: There is talk of creating a ''homeless czar.'' The position was mentioned to me by a well-connected Republican. He knows of my ambition to replace Dan Quayle on the ticket in 1992. ''Get yourself a czardom,'' he counseled. ''Like Bennett.''

title: Israeli Denies in TV Interview He Served as Noriega Adviser
description: The man identified by American officials as a top aide to Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega appeared on Israeli television tonight to deny that he had served as security adviser to the fallen Panamanian dictator.

title: Big Jackpot and Big Dreams: Lotto Fever Hits New York
description: When Zoriano Caballero picked up his newspaper yesterday, his eyes scanned the grim mug shot of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega. He focused on the prisoner identification plate the fallen Panamanian leader held to his chest: ''U.S. Marshal, Miami, FL 41586 004.''

title: Stocks Drop Broadly, With Dow Off 22.83
description: Stocks retreated broadly yesterday in continued moderate trading. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 22.83 points, to 2,773.25.

title: Keating Questioned By Judge
description: Federal District Judge Stanley Sporkin took charge of the questioning of Charles H. Keating Jr. today, and in almost five hours of intense inquiries the judge voiced deep concerns about accounting methods used by the Lincoln Savings and Loan Association and its parent, the American Continental Corporation.

title: Radio Show to Feature Works by Beckett
description: A memorial program honoring Samuel Beckett, who died on Dec. 22, is to be broadcast on WBAI-FM (99.5) on Sunday from 11:30 A.M. to 5:30 P.M.

title: Dakin Accord With Hallmark
description: Hallmark Cards Inc. and Dakin Inc. said today that they had reached an agreement in principle for Hallmark to acquire Dakin, a leading marketer of plush stuffed toys, for an undisclosed amount.

title: Welcome to New York City, Chancellor (but Please Hold)
description: One day this week, Joseph A. Fernandez noticed that his office windows were dirty. He called an engineer. Sorry, he was told, the engineers' contract stipulates that the windows are cleaned once a year.

title: Prison for Attack on Gay Man
description: Two teen-agers who admitted beating a West Hartford man in 1988 because he was a homosexual have each been given one-year prison sentences. Superior Court Judge Raymond R. Norko sentenced Lawrence Brush, 19, and James M. O'Brien, 17, on Thursday. Two other teen-agers involved in the West Hartford beating, Sean G. Burke and Marcos J. Perez, were sentenced last month for the beating death of another gay man, Richard F. Reihl. Judge Norko sentenced each to more than 35 years in prison.

title: Italy Devalues Lira by 3%
description: The Italian lira was devalued by 3 percent against other major European currencies late today, while its trading band within the European Monetary System was narrowed.

title: Review/Music;   Philharmonic In Concerto By Neikrug
description: For someone who has had genuinely mixed reactions to Zubin Metha's New York Philharmonic concerts over the years, Thursday evening's program at Avery Fisher Hall was an especially dispiriting event.

title: Katmandu Journal;   Some Room at the Top of the World
description: On Wednesday, when Dipendra Bir Bikram Shah Dev, a young man of 18, rode a fine carriage from temple to temple to mark his coming of age as Crown Prince, a lot else was going on in this city transformed almost beyond recognition in less than a decade.

title: 80 Days With Michael Palin, In Pursuit of Phileas Fogg
description: When Michael Palin agreed to circle the world in the company of a small television crew from the BBC, he knew the result would be no more a learned travelogue than the Jules Verne novel that inspired the journey.

title: Washington Talk;   Rationing In the Sky: U.S. Takes New Look
description: Even in this era of deregulation and free markets, rationing remains the Federal Government's preferred solution to some problems. While competition may be constrained, some social purpose is served, or so goes the theory, by limiting immigration, radio and television licenses - or the right to land and take off at airports where traffic is at full capacity.

title: Peter Carlsen, Writer, 43
description: Peter Carlsen, a writer and editor who specialized in design and architecture, was found dead, apparently a suicide, on Dec. 26 at his home in Manhattan. He was 43 years old.

title: Henry Luce 3d And Leila Hadley Exchange Vows
description: Leila Hadley and Henry Luce 3d were married yesterday at the Madison Avenue Presbyterian Church by the Rev. David H. C. Read.

title: Robert Sivard, 75, Former Art Director For the Government
description: Robert Sivard, a painter and illustrator whose sprightly canvases range from urban street scenes to the lives of famous painters and literary figures, died of a heart attack yesterday at his home in Washington. He was 75 years old.

title: One Constant: Winning
description: An air of edginess is evident among the San Francisco 49ers as the defending Super Bowl champions prepare for today's National Conference semifinal against the Minnesota Vikings at Candlestick Park. Actually, the edginess has been apparent for most of this season, a season of incessant role changes for this franchise, ranging from management to coaches to players.

title: Textbook Gold
description: HOLD THE OLD and the new textbooks in your hands and the difference is startling.

title: A CONDUCTOR COMMITTED TO NEW MUSIC - AND OLD
description: For most New York concert-goers, the name Dennis Russell Davies will evoke thoughts of new music, and new American music in particular. As co-founder and principal conductor of the American Composers Orchestra - which he will lead this afternoon at Carnegie Hall - and as the recently appointed music director of the Brooklyn Academy of Music and its Next Wave Festival, Mr. Davies has linked himself inextricably with 20th-century repertory that few other conductors will touch. What other conductor of international renown would direct a program such as the one Mr. Davies leads today, consisting of works by Chinary Ung, Ezra Laderman, Richard Danielpour and Aaron Copland?

title: Axie Gibbons Engaged to William E. Sutcliffe 3d
description: The engagement of Anne Thomas Gibbons to William Edward Sutcliffe 3d has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Anne T. Gibbons of Fairfield, Conn., and Maxfield S. Gibbons of Greenwich, Conn. Mr. Sutcliffe is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Sutcliffe Jr. of North Redington Beach, Fla. A 1990 wedding is planned.

title: Iran Rejects Iraqi Offer of Talks as a 'Deception'
description: Iran has dismissed an Iraqi proposal for reviving peace talks between the two countries as ''a new campaign of public deception,'' Iran's official press agency said today.

title: Correction
description: An article on Dec. 24 about Texaco Inc. misidentified the company's former chairman and the company's current chairman. They are John K. McKinley and Alfred C. DeCrane Jr.

title: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST: East Germany;   Berlin Communist Urges Troop Cuts
description: The head of East Germany's Communist Party proposed today that all NATO and Warsaw Pact forces quit both Germanys within a decade, adding spice to an already bitter political struggle shaping in East Germany.

title:
IN SHORT;

FICTION
description: LEAD:

title: Donna Ferdinand to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence Ferdinand of New Haven have announced the engagement of their daughter Donna M. Ferdinand to Lloyd M. Prezant, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Prezant of the Bronx. Ms. Ferdinand, who is 30 years old, works in the corporate safety office of the Southern New England Telephone Company in New Haven. Mr. Prezant, 37, is an audio and video engineer for NBC in New York.

title: Deauville
description: To the Editor: Recently returned from France where we spent a night in Deauville, at the Royal. Had been delighted to see your article on Deauville (Travel, July 23) shortly before we left. Armed with the article, my companion and I headed for the Bar du Soleil for dinner to discover that it is only open for lunch. We were able to have a fine dinner at Ciro's with excellent service even though we had no reservation.

title: Frederic Raphael: Seriousness Can Be Smuggled Onto TV
description: Beetle comes rushing into the room with the evening newspaper, displaying the banner headline: ''Ceausescu Toppled and Gone.'' Her proper name is Sylvia Betty, and she has been married to Frederic Raphael for 33 years. When she met him, she told him that Beetle was a family pet name and that he was to promise never to use it, but since his way of showing his love for things is to tell of their secrets, he has never called her anything else.

title:
THE JANUARY REPORT;

Made, Not Born
description: LEAD: AS CONCERN about the quality of American leadership in government and business mounts, colleges are reviving old forms of scholarship, packaging them with practical courses and serving up the result under a new rubric: leadership studies. Indeed, though something of a collegiate mutt, leadership is increasingly seen as a necessary adjunct to the standard college curriculum.

title: Lifestyle: Sunday Menu;   One-Dish Fish, Mediterranean Style
description: Throughout the Mediterranean region there is some version of the accompanying fish dish with potatoes and tomatoes. Most take much more time, usually calling for an initial cooking step, followed by baking.

title: FLASHCARD
description: VERMONT earned the most from public college and university tuition for the 1988-89 academic year, collecting an average of almost $5,500 per student. A large number of students at Vermont's public colleges are from another state and therefore pay the higher nonresident tuition. California charged the lowest average tuition - about $500 per year. - Research Associates of Washington, ''State Profiles: Financing Public Higher Education 1978 to 1989''

title: PERSPECTIVES: The 10-Year Housing Plan;   Issues for the 90's: Management and Costs
description: IN housing, New York City has changed horses in midstream. Mayor David N. Dinkins has come into office at about the halfway mark of the expensive, long-term municipal housing program begun by former Mayor Edward I. Koch in 1985.

title: Charlotte Fans Should Study Amazing Mets
description: They are booing the home team in Charlotte. Can you believe it? Until last year, they didn't even have a home team. Now they are yowling at it.

title: 1990's AUDIO: DAT AND DISH
description: The notion of decades sticks firmly in the mind. We speak of the 60's, or, more distantly, of the 20's and 30's as if they were sealed compartments. But time can't be tied up into parcels.

title: THE ULTIMATE DECISION
description: Andrew H. Malcolm's article ''The Ultimate Decision'' (Dec. 3) points out the critical need to educate and prepare the public for the day when each of us may stand in his shoes.

title: Savory Fried Bread Of New Mexico
description: WHETHER the visitor to New Mexico samples Spanish-American or American Indian fare, some form of simple native bread is likely to be offered with the meal. The most ubiquitous forms are Indian fry bread, served at Indian pueblos or cultural centers, and sopaipillas - the puffed pillowlike breads served in most of the Spanish-American cafes and Mexican restaurants.

title: SPECIAL SECTION: Science Under Scrutiny;   Home work
description: His name is Mr. Wizard, a.k.a. Don Herbert, and he has worked science magic on television for 38 years. His formula may clash with curriculum. But there are some basics: Choose subjects that appeal to children; create experiments they can do themselves; use everyday items in novel ways. What follows is a little Wizardry for children and adults alike.

title: THE EPIDEMIC: DID THE PRESS CRY WOLF?
description: THE MYTH OF HETEROSEXUAL AIDS

title: And Then This U.F.O. Landed . . .
description: Any chance that Samuel Asbell had for a second term as Camden County prosecutor went up in gunsmoke last week. The day after New Year's, the official called a news conference to announce that he had been ambushed by two gunmen and became involved in a running high-speed gun battle. His car windows were shattered by machine gun fire, Mr. Asbell said, and he injured one of his assailants with a blast from the sawed-off shotgun he carried. The prosecutor opined that he had been set upon by drug thugs, or maybe Ku Klux Klansmen, or maybe just garden-variety terrorists. But police investigators could find no evidence to support Mr. Asbell's tale, and the State Attorney General concluded that ''the event was staged by Prosecutor Asbell, apparently acting alone.'' Mr. Asbell resigned and reportedly sought mental health care. Speculation on a possible motive centered on the notion that Mr. Asbell was hoping that derring-do would improve his chances for re-appointment by New Jersey's Governor-elect, James J. Florio.

title: Cars Fetching Sporty Prices
description: LEAD: DESPITE a sluggish economy and a continuing slump in new-car sales that has prompted heavy discounting by many Long Island automobile dealerships, some new sports cars and luxury sedans are selling at or above their list prices.

title: FLASHCARD
description: MOST Americans say they would personally pay an additional $200 a year in taxes to improve public education. Three-quarters of the 1,234 adults surveyed by the Gallup Poll said Federal spending on programs to improve public education should be increased. The poll found that the public supported increased spending on education even when the condition of higher taxes was added. Two out of five adults surveyed said they would be willing to pay $100 more in taxes each year to increase Federal spending on public education. The survey was conducted in October 1989 and has a margin of sampling error of plus or minus four percentage points.

title:
CONNECTICUT Q&A;: DR. JOHN LARSON;

'Highway Risks Are Too High for Games'
description: LEAD: HOSTILITY is on the upswing in society and many drivers are bringing their bad tempers onto the road, according to Dr. John Larson, a psychiatrist who directs the Institute of Stress Medicine at Norwalk Hospital.

title: Is Photojournalism Also Art?
description: To the Editor:

title: Dana Hokin and Robert Garvey Wed
description: Dana Marie Hokin and Robert Vincent Garvey were married yesterday at St. Malachy's Roman Catholic Church in New York by the Rev. James E. Russo. Alexandra Hokin was her sister's maid of honor and Joseph Garvey was his brother's best man.

title: Wonderland II
description: ELIZABETH Willse is going to a fair, but whom will she go with, and what will she wear?

title: Broncos Aim to Stop Steelers' Momentum
description: As the Denver Broncos head into the playoffs and take aim on a possible third Super Bowl appearance in the last four years, Coach Dan Reeves can take comfort in a rock-solid defense and productive running game, elements that generally win championships. But he is not a satisfied coach. Reeves is feeling obvious discomfort about his team's flaccid finish during the regular season.

title: On a Slide
description: To the Editor:

title: Using Puppets to Promote Pride
description: LEAD: SO far as Brad Brewer is concerned, a puppet is not a puppet is not a puppet. Rather, a puppet is ''the fantasy and magic I loved as a child and all the elements of art - sculpture, drawing and painting - that interest me as an adult artist.''

title: Congeleur Finally Ends Up a Victor
description: Congeleur, who has spent much of the last two winters running second to King's Swan and Its Acedemic in stakes races, finally turned the tables on those two yesterday and narrowly won the $86,700 Aqueduct Handicap.

title: UPDATE ON THE WOBBLY FORTUNES OF VIBRATO
description: Tastes change; the immutable verities of today seem dated and clumsy tomorrow. And often, a shift in one seemingly small area of taste reveals itself to be linked with larger changes in our cultural preferences.

title: A Shot at Indy 500
description: For years, he was the only American-born driver in Formula One racing and one of the few to have never raced in the Indianapolis 500. But in a shifting of gears, Eddie Cheever signed a multiyear contract Friday to drive an Indy-car for Chip Ganassi Racing.

title: Program Ties Rent Aid To Job Training
description: AN experimental program intended to encourage welfare recipients who head single-parent families to obtain counseling, job training and employment has proved more successful than had originally been anticipated, state officials say. As a result, plans are now being made to expand the program beyond the six New Jersey counties in which it is currently available.

title: As a Mayor Returns, Atlanta Is Rich and Poor
