description: THE words had both a familiar ring and a touch of paradox last week when Maynard Jackson was sworn in as Mayor.

title: Question Of the Week;   How Should N.C.A.A. Football Champions Be Decided?
description: Create a playoff system beginning sometime in early- to mid-December, culminating in a championship bowl on that boring late January weekend between the end of the pro season and the Super Bowl.

title: Robert Methven Weds Anne Kelly
description: The Roman Catholic Church of the Annunciation in Crestwood, N.Y., was the setting yesterday for the wedding of Anne Katherine Kelly, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred F. Kelly of Crestwood, and Robert Thomas Methven, a son of Helen Methven of Christchurch, New Zealand, and the late Robert W. Methven. The Rev. Vincent J. Duminuco performed the ceremony.

title: Phantom Of the Oilers
description: Someone might have to leave tickets for Jerry Glanville now.

title:
GARDENING;

More Greenery, Less Greenhouse Effect
description: LEAD: THOUGH New Year's Day has passed, it is still not too late to make resolutions. And perhaps as gardeners we can resolve to do more in behalf of the environment.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. I have read about the problem that some people have with condensation forming between the two panes of glass in double-pane windows, but my problem is different. My apartment has windows of this type, but with a metal frame. When outside temperatures drop below freezing, condensation forms on the metal and then freezes to form a coat of ice on the inside. When this ice melts, water runs down onto the sill and soils the draperies. Can you suggest how to eliminate this?

title: Space Shuttle Poised to Begin Mission to Retrieve a Satellite
description: In the most ambitious mission undertaken since the Challenger accident four years ago, the space shuttle Columbia is scheduled to be launched tomorrow to rescue and bring back to Earth a bus-size satellite that is slowly falling out of orbit.

title: In the Deep South Of the Soviet Fold, Complaints Rise In Many Tongues
description: EVERY time a new protest group announces itself along one of the mountainous turnings of the Soviet border, a vast frontier of disparate passions, Kremlinologists rush to their gazetteers the way they used to study the hierarchal lineup atop Lenin's tomb for hints of impending upheaval.

title: 4 Steps to Reality For School Sports
description: To the Sports Editor:

title:
INVESTING;

'Do-Gooder' Funds That Make Money
description: LEAD: The stock market's ups and downs are not the only reasons investors lose sleep. Many are troubled by the possibility that their money is financing industrial polluters, South African mines or nuclear weapons makers.

description: TRAFFICKING

title: CONSUMER RATES
Campus Life: Massachusetts;   Students Angered By Rise in Tuition For Out-of-Staters
description: Outraged student leaders and administrators at the University of Massachusetts faced the latest in a series of defeats Thursday when Gov. Michael S. Dukakis approved a tuition increase for out-of-state students.

title: Hundreds of Villagers Reported Slain in the Sudan
description: The Sudanese Government has unleashed Arab militiamen against African tribesmen, killing between 300 and 1,500 African villagers in one attack and many others in a series of raids, reports from Western officials in Khartoum say.

description: THE HIGHEST ALTAR

description: At the Westview Country Club in Miami, Nancy Beth Raffel was married last evening to Mark Russell Osherow. Rabbi David Sandmel, the bride's brother-in-law, officiated.

title: Dr. J. D. Altus Weds Leslie Hoffman
description: Leslie Jean Hoffman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jay Hoffman of Trumbull, Conn., was married last evening at Temple Israel in Great Neck, L.I., to Dr. Jonathan Drew Altus, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Altus of Forest Hills, Queens. Rabbi Eric A. Silver performed the cermony, assisted by Cantor Zion Yakar.

title: The Booty Of Drugs Enriches Agencies
description: The sheriff's department in Tulsa, Okla., has a ski boat that once belonged to a drug dealer and is now used to dredge the lake for evidence. The police in San Diego own two helicopters, taken in a drug raid, that they need but could not otherwise have afforded.

title: The Russians Are Coming, in Droves
description: As political developments seem to bring surprises every day in the Soviet Union, a surprising torrent of music from that country has been pouring our way on recordings. Some of it, by Soviet artists, is attributable to a confusing tangle of international distribution agreements that followed the recent split-up of the Soviet Melodiya label and Mezhdunarodnaya Kniga, the Soviet export company that formerly handled the label and still owns several hundred titles from the Melodiya catalogue. In addition, there has been a flood of new recordings on other labels and by non-Soviet players.

title: Renewed Muslim-Christian Battle in Beirut Kills 3
description: Tank, artillery and rocket duels resumed today across the Green Line that splits the Lebanese capital into Muslim and Christian halves, and the police said three people were killed and three were wounded.

title: Togetherness After the Age of Reason
description: WHEN my children were young, we took separate vacations. Each June I packed them off to their grandparents, a continent away, and when they returned, we were all glad to see each other again. I'd had a respite from single parenthood, and they'd had a month of unqualified approval and unlimited indulgence. Thus restored and renewed, we managed to negotiate the shoals of togetherness for another year.

title: Eurobeep
description: Little noticed among the rattling upheavals that dominate the news, the 12 nations of the European Community are formulating a plan to synchronize beepers. Unsuspecting observers may see this as no more than sensible coordination, removing yet another barrier to the free movement of commerce in the Common Market. But the wary will brace for a new dimension of Europower.

title: COLOMBIANS BALK AT A CRUCIAL PART OF U.S. DRUG PLANS
description: The Bush Administration's plan to step up military involvement in the war on drugs in Latin America was dealt a setback this week when Colombia balked at a crucial element, the stationing of United States vessels off its coast, Administration officials say.

title: 'SHE HAD TO COME FROM THE MOON'
description: THE BOOK OF MAMIE

title:
FOCUS: Retirement Developments;

Building Communities Close to Home
description: LEAD: A NEW retirement community taking shape in this rural area 30 miles southwest of Chicago is a prime example of the interest of development companies in bringing housing opportunities for the elderly closer to major population centers.

title: Riverhead's Grant To Buy Music Hall
description: The article ''Riverhead May Lose $300,000 Grant'' (Dec. 10) states incorrectly that I, Harold Smith, am the owner of the 1881 Vail-Leavitt Music Hall. In actuality, Music Hall is owned by the Council for the Vail-Leavitt Music Hall Inc., a nonprofit, tax-exempt organization that has been restoring and operating the building for the past six years without a deficit.

title: Haiti Schedules 2 Elections For President and Assembly
description: The Government has scheduled legislative elections for July and a presidential vote for October, state-run radio reported today.

description: CONFESSIONS OF A MAIL ORDER BRIDE

description: LEAD:

title: Merri Bergstein to Wed Peter A. Kingsly in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Melvyn Bergstein of Bernardsville, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Merri Lee Bergstein, to Peter Andrew Kingsly, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Sanford N. Kingsly of Short Hills, N.J., and Longboat Key, Fla. A June wedding is planned.

title: Gorbachev Meetings Are On, Moscow Says
description: Radio Moscow said today that President Mikhail S. Gorbachev had not canceled all January meetings with foreigners to deal with domestic problems, contrary to earlier reports that upset world financial markets.

title: Question Of the Week;   How Should N.C.A.A. Football Champions Be Decided?
description: There are 16 bowls in which ranked college teams play each other. Why not have the top 32 teams (based on average ranking between the polls of the writers, the coaches, and the New York Times computer) play each other, with No. 32 playing No. 31 and so on down the line?

title: Campus Life: Wellesley;   Trustees Approve Adding Faculty From Minorities
description: Reacting to a report that called Wellesley College ''covertly racist,'' the college's trustees have approved the hiring of five additional minority faculty members over the next five years. These new positions are in addition to the current faculty limit of about 320 that was established by the trustees.

title: RON BROWN'S PARTY LINE
description: Ron Brown has his work cut out for him in trying to implement a successful ''coordinated campaign'' for the Democrats (''Ron Brown's Party Line,'' by Robert Kuttner, Dec. 3). Here in Massachusetts, our state party is a disaster, lacking the money, skill and resources to provide effective campaign services for Bay State Democratic candidates. This situation comes at the worst possible time, on the eve of the 1990 elections. The G.O.P. is poised to take advantage of an angry and aroused electorate disgusted with Michael Dukakis and the state's abrupt transformation from ''Massachusetts miracle'' to fiscal crisis.

title: The Rock Hudson Story Gets Told. And Perhaps Retold
description: The networks are competing more fiercely and frequently over the rights to titillating true stories. Lately, ABC and NBC have been duking it out over the life and death of Rock Hudson, the Hollywood star who died of AIDS in 1985. Last year, NBC announced plans for a biography and commissioned a script, but ABC quietly moved in and beat the peacock to the punch. ABC's movie, ''Rock Hudson,'' has been completed and will be shown tomorrow night at 9, while NBC is still considering whether to junk its project and write off the money it has already spent or go forward with a second biography next season.

title: Question Of the Week;   How Should N.C.A.A. Football Champions Be Decided?
description: The traditional conference-to-bowl alliances should be preserved. When bowl bids to the five major New Year's Day games are extended, also designate the four games that will then be the quarterfinals of the playoffs. The winners of these games would meet in two semifinal games, and the winners of those would meet in the title game.

title: Suzanne Sunshine, M.B.A. Candidate, Is Wed to William Mendel, Producer
description: Suzanne Pauline Sunshine and William Robert Mendel were married last evening at the Plaza in New York by Rabbi Harvey M. Tattelbaum.

title: Article 388190 -- No Title
description: ON Jan. 16, James J. Florio will take the oath of office as New Jersey's 49th governor, lead a parade in the state capital and celebrate at an inaugural ball. It could be the last chance for Mr. Florio to smile for several months.

title: For Airlines, a Heated Push Into the Pacific Rim
description: A few years ago, Jerry Connelly, a fashion executive in New York who flies regularly to the Far East, booked his flights to cities like Hong Kong a just few days ahead of time. But no more. ''Now you need at least a week or two's notice,'' he said. ''Sometimes I can't even get a seat then.''

title: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST: Soviet Union;   Why They Can't Spell Communism At the Elite Party School in Moscow
description: Nowhere is the fragile future of communism more candidly admitted lately than within the Higher Party School, the elite finishing school for Communist apparatchiks. There, the rector, Vyacheslav N. Shostakovsky, no mean careerist himself, has been racing to accomplish these goals:

title: Lauren D. Putter Plans To Wed A.W. Menzin
description: May wedding plans have been announced for Dr. Lauren Dee Putter, a clinical psychologist in Philadelphia, and Dr. Andrew William Menzin, a resident in obstetrics and gynecology at the Hospital of the University of Pennsylvania.

title: A Dinner to Showcase a Fragrant Thai Curry
description: ALTHOUGH curry usually brings to mind Indian food or dishes flavored with a premixed packaged spice blend, the term is actually an umbrella for a variety of preparations. They do have in common a collection of spices, notably turmeric, cumin, coriander, ginger and pepper. These are the main components, but the list can be expanded with many others.

title: Jet Diverted to Boston After a Bomb Warning
description: A British Airways flight from London to Miami with 360 people aboard landed instead at Logan International Airport here today after an anonymous caller warned that a bomb would explode in flight.

title: SPECIAL SECTION: Science Under Scrutiny;   The Overlooked
description: A DECADE AGO, a nationwide effort was begun to increase the number of women and minority members pursuing science-based careers.

title: Review/Music;   Seeking Intelligence in Outer Space
description: Lower Manhattan is alive with mixed-media experiments, and ''Urchin 1,'' which ends a three-night run tonight at 8 at Performance Space 122, 150 First Avenue, is an energetic example of that all-encompassing genre. But before it blasts into Lincoln Center orbit, so to speak (this is a science-fiction piece), it needs enriching. Right now, it's a sometimes plodding, sometimes cute framework for some good bits and a lot that are a little lame.

title: Prospects;   Housing Bounces Back
description: Sales of new homes rose by 9.6 percent in November, the biggest jump in four months, according to the Commerce Department last week. The Northeast and Middle West posted the strongest gains. After months of soft prices and slow sales, do the November figures signal an end to the housing slump? Four experts give their views.

title: Views of Sport;   Giants' Fans Wake Up To the Pain Again
description: This year the Novocain began to wear off. The shot administered during the third quarter in Pasadena was at once more powerful and longer-lasting than Giants 39, Broncos 20. It blocked out 23 years of humiliation - Who's Rocky Thompson? What Fumble? - while cocooning us against the ensuing Strike Year and the woulda-coulda-shoulda of 1988.

title: Philippine Rebels Kill Mayor and Threaten G.I.'s
description: Communist guerrillas near an American base claimed responsibility today for the killing of a mayor and said the next targets would be American servicemen and five other town officials fighting the insurgency.

title: FICTION
description: ALICE ALONE. By Amanda Brookfield. (St. Martin's, $15.95.) No novel that includes a middlingly sympathetic dentist can be all bad, but Amanda Brookfield's ''Alice Alone'' comes close. Alice Hatton is an Englishwoman in her early 50's who, like countless other middle-aged people, has been left staring discontentedly at an empty nest when her children have grown. She comes face to face with vast spaces of time to be filled - and the bleak realization that years of bustling have masked her dislike of her self-absorbed husband, to whom she has nothing to say. At first she merely dabbles with a new image, dying her hair. But soon she drifts into a one-night stand, then into a longer affair with a dentist, who is a decent enough chap, separated from his wife. When the time comes - when, as Lorelei Lee warned, the louse goes back to his spouse - Alice is saved by the return of her youngest daughter, who is disillusioned with men (naturally) and pregnant (of course). If they were even marginally lifelike, the characters in ''Alice Alone'' would be unlikable. Nor does Ms. Brookfield shun a contrived plot. And the quality of her writing may be discerned from the book's final sentence: ''She felt the springs of a new life stirring within her; like all the raw elation of childbirth with none of the pain.''

description: Special reports in this issue include:

title:
IN SHORT;

ANTHOLOGIES
description: LEAD:

description: LEAD:

title: Reform by High-Tech
description: LAST OCT. 18, the morning after the California earthquake, Gerry Erickson, the librarian of the Cougar Valley Elementary School in Silverdale, Wash., discovered that one of her parent volunteers had experienced several earthquakes in Guatemala.

title: Review/Dance;   La Fosse and Kistler in Robbins's 'Faun'
description: Friday night's performance by the New York City Ballet featured the season's first view of ''Afternoon of a Faun'' and ''Antique Epigraphs,'' two ballets by Jerome Robbins to Debussy, and a surprise, a modified version of Peter Martins's ''Echo.''

title: Jane Mintzer Plans To Marry in March
description: March wedding plans for Jane Margaret Mintzer and David Louis Hoffman have been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. Steven A. Mintzer of West Islip, L.I. Mr. Hoffman is a son of Dr. and Mrs. William A. Hoffman of Westport, Conn.

title: ANTHOLOGIES
description: AND WE SOLD THE RAIN: Contemporary Fiction From Central America. Edited by Rosario Santos. (Four Walls Eight Windows, Cloth, $18.95; Paper, $9.95.) No Central American - save Guatemala's 1967 Nobel Prize winner, Miguel Angel Asturias - figured in the literary boom that brought so many young Latin American writers to print in the 1970's and 80's. With the publication of this groundbreaking anthology, North Americans have the chance to see 20 of the isthmus' relatively unknown writers as they forge powerful visions out of the civil wars, death squads, hopeless poverty, dislocation and crippling foreign debt that have exhausted and desensitized less tenacious observers. These writers speak individually, yet one hears a medley of voices crying out for sanity and justice. As the scholar and translator Jo Anne Engelbert remarks in her probing introduction, stories are the means by which the popular imagination can ''express sorrow, pain, and rage, reflect on contemporary events, and register dissent.'' But it is worth noting, lest we believe that it is now safe to speak openly throughout Central America about social injustice, that the stories in this book often do so through allegory, magic realism or surrealism. Among my favorite entries are a story from El Salvador's Jacinta Escudos, which tells how the poor and uncommitted get sucked into playing repressive roles in a war they care little or nothing about; the Guatemalan Rodrigo Rey Rosa's parable about a young boy who kills a canary and then expects it to come back to life to prove God's existence; and the Costa Rican Carmen Naranjo's hilarious tale, from which the collection takes its title, about a fictitious country's scheme to sell rain to an Arab emirate as a way of avoiding bankruptcy. Many of the translations, particularly those by Paul Bowles, Edith Grossman and George Yudice, are excellent. (It's a shame, though, that the translators' names could not have appeared in the table of contents, rather than being appended to the end of the stories.) ''And We Sold the Rain'' is an anthology that should give rise to the publication of a more generous sampling of contemporary fiction from Central America.

title: Being Left Out On a Special Day
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Illusion and Tragedy Coexist After a Couple Dies
description: The illusion of the perfect couple, secure in their jobs and striving for the next rung on the social ladder, persists here, despite the grotesque turn the story of Carol and Charles Stuart took this week.

title: English Is Making a Comeback in Sri Lanka
description: The English language, reviled and sidetracked for more than three decades by a Sinhalese majority intent on putting its ethnic stamp on the nation, is suddenly and unexpectedly back in fashion.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: THE READER'S DIGEST;

Where Recycling Generates Team Spirit
description: LEAD: THE Reader's Digest world headquarters here generates mountains of solid waste each day, but nobody is thinking in terms of total numbers. Ask Gregg Pascuiti, assistant facilities manager, and he will tell you, ''One ton of trash and 4,000 pounds recyclable paper per day.'' So oriented toward recycling is he, the statistics are expressed solely in those terms.

title: Performance to Benefit Spoleto Hurricane Fund
description: Philip Glass, Lynn Redgrave and members of the New York City Ballet and the Martha Graham Dance Company are to take part in a benefit for the Spoleto Festival U.S.A., Jan. 29 at 7:30 P.M. at Alice Tully Hall. The music, dance and theater series has been held in Charleston, S.C., for 13 years; this year's opening is May 25. Proceeds will help restore buildings damaged by Hurricane Hugo in September. Tickets at $500 and $1,000 include a supper after the performance; $100 tickets are for the show alone. Information: 840-0127.

title: Museum in Florida Is Hiring Ex-Director Of Disputed Exhibit
description: The woman who resigned as director of the Corcoran Gallery of Art last month after a six-month dispute over her decision to cancel an exhibit of Robert Mapplethorpe photographs has been named director of the Norton Gallery and School of Arts in Palm Beach, Fla.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: 12 Italian Cities Are Girding For World Cup

title: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST: Japan;   Tokyo Broadens Plan to Aid A New Poland and Hungary
description: In a signal of Japan's eagerness to take part in the emerging new order in Europe, Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu plans next week to announce a package of more than $1 billion in loans and guarantees for Poland and Hungary, Japanese officials said today.

title: Priest Who Imposed Dress Code Is Removed
description: A Roman Catholic priest who denied communion to worshipers who violated his dress code has been asked to leave his Dayton parish, a spokeswoman for the Archdiocese of Cincinnati said Friday.

title: Lost Battlefield
description: To the Editor:

title: Birds and Beasts Inhabit Mattatuck Show
description: NOT all the animals in the ''Animal Show'' are recognizable, some being fragmentary, others outright inventions. They cluster close, nonetheless, as if to keep the human world at bay. The small display, on view at the Mattatuck Museum in Waterbury, consists of works by Reuben Nakian as well as by Eddie Oates, Karen Rossi, Gil Scullion and Peter Woytuk, Connecticut sculptors to a man and woman.

title: IN THE REGION: Long Island;   Recent Sales
description: Bay Shore $550,000

title: To Start, Dinkins Sits Down And Serves Up Bad News for All
description: AS David N. Dinkins sat down last Tuesday for his first working day as Mayor of New York City behind the polished desk once used by Fiorello H. La Guardia, he looked at his deputies around him and smiled. ''Well, now,'' he said. ''Here we are.''

title: On the Sweetness of Cold Winter Air
description: SOMEONE should've warned me before I married him! The things one overlooks in the clutches of romance! Things so fundamental to compatible coexistence that they should be written into the marriage vows, possibly under ''worse,'' as in ''for better or worse.'' One of these is that thou shalt not suffocate thy partner through insufficient oxygenation!

title: Images of Blacks Refracted in a White Mirror
description: When white American artists looked at black Americans, what did they see? Stereotypes, like banjo players, watermelon eaters, slaves and idlers? Or dignity and purpose? All of the above, as evidenced by a and idlers? Or dignity and purpose? All of the above, as evidenced by a complex new show, ''Facing History: The Black Image in American Art, 1710-1940,'' to open at the Corcoran Gallery of Art in Washington on Saturday. (After closing in Washington, it will move to the Brooklyn Museum in New York, opening April 25.) The show was organized by Guy C. McElroy, a black art historian, and takes cues from the ''new'' scholarship that examines works of art in their political and socioeconomic context. It documents the ways in which American artists ''reinforced a number of largely restrictive stereotypes of black identity, '' as Mr. McElroy writes in his introduction to the handsome catalogue. Yet so subtly were some of of many of the artists, that they are not always apparent to the viewer. In recent years, many art historians have been digging into such works as John Singleton Copley's ''Watson and the Shark,'' a 1788 painting of a rescue attempt, to find in it a subtext of racial and political conflict.

title: Taxi Fares Increase Today
description: Taxi fares in New York City are increasing today. The drop charge is rising to $1.50 from $1.15 and the rest of the ride is increasing to $1.25 a mile from $1.20.

title: Fernandez Reorganization Will Cut Jobs and Bureaus
description: Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez yesterday announced a sweeping reorganization of his central headquarters staff that will eliminate 14 bureaus and 218 jobs.

title: Aromatic Dishes From India
description: IN a university town like New Haven one might expect to find a variety of inexpensive, ethnic restaurants and indeed that is the case. But in all this diversity there is just one Indian restaurant, India Palace.

title: Help! My S.&L.'s in Trouble
description: It's a depositor's worst nightmare come true. That friendly savings and loan association down the street, which had been paying some of the highest rates in town, is suddenly declared insolvent. What is a person to do? Below are answers to some commonly asked questions.

title: Alison S. Aymar, Student, to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. John vanBeuren Aymar Jr. of Darien, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Alison Simms Aymar, to Kevin Douglas Hancock, a son of Mr. and Mrs. K. David Hancock of Casco, Me. A July wedding is planned.

title: Ford Sets Sights On an Elusive Title
description: Besides increased television coverage, one reason for auto racing's current state of vigor worldwide is the extent of participation by major automakers.

title: Recitals to Rouse One From Holiday Slumber
description: LEADING the way out of the holiday slumber today are recitals by Chamber Music Plus in Hartford and the Sunday Afternoons Live series at First Congregational Church of Greenwich.

title: New Lesson In Humanity For M.B.A.'s
description: THE University of Chicago Graduate School of Business has long been known for producing captains of industry, not leaders of humanity. Now the school is trying to redress the imbalance, using a new Leadership Education And Development program as the counterweight.

title: Assuaging Children's Fear of Surgery
description: WHEN 10-year-old Amanda Bagatta of Smithtown was wheeled into the operating room for surgery to remove her tonsils and adenoids, her father went along with her, holding her hand along the way. And he stayed in the operating room until the anesthetic had taken effect.

title: Knicks Are Beaten by Pistons
description: The Detroit Pistons, determined to keep their position as National Basketball Association champions, wanted to deliver a message to the Knicks tonight. And after 48 minutes of pulsating basketball, the Pistons did indeed have the last word.

title: A RELUCTANT EDUCATION
description: Paulette Bates Alden wrote the article I had always wanted to write (''A Reluctant Education,'' Dec. 10). I have been through the same: post-coital tests, biopsies, nagging (or cajoling) my husband to have intercourse at what I estimated to be the precise moment of ovulation.

title: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST: Azerbaijan;   Angry Soviet Crowd Attacks What Is Left Of Iran Border Posts
description: Crowds began tearing down remaining border installations along a stretch of the Soviet frontier with Iran today, but troops patrolling the troubled region in Soviet Azerbaijan did not intervene.

title: CARTER REDUX
description: The article on Jimmy Carter's new career was accompanied by brief biographies of other Presidents who had active public careers after their White House years. You stated that John Quincy Adams was the only former President to serve in Congress. However, Andrew Johnson was elected to the United States Senate from Tennessee in 1875, six years after his Presidential term ended. He served in that body from March 4, 1875 until his death, later that year, on July 31.

title: HOW DO I LOATHE THEE?
description: THE GROWN-UPS

title: NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Orleans, Mass.;   Cape's Sales Continue Slide
description: LAST January, Donald Fulcher and his wife, Susan, year-round residents on Cape Cod, put their modest two-bedroom, one-bath house in South Yarmouth on the market for $119,000. Nothing happened.

title: Illinois and Kentucky at Odds Over a Disputed River Border
description: A dispute between Illinois and Kentucky over a stretch of the Ohio River has lawyers researching sand, riverboats and fishing licenses.

title: Gooden Upbeat for 90's After Up-and-Down 80's
description: Dwight Gooden, who came out of the 1980's with a sore right shoulder and lingering memories of his ordeal with drugs, reports that he is entering the 1990's with no qualms, no fears and no demons and says, ''I couldn't be more upbeat.''

title: Ms. Ellant to Wed Howard J. Reiter
description: Dr. and Mrs. Paul Ellant of Great Neck, L.I., and Boca Raton, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Jody Patricia Ellant, to Howard Jay Reiter, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Stanley F. Reiter of New Haven. The wedding is to be this winter.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL/3-16

title: POSTINGS: 14th for Newark;   New Airport Hotel
description: Hampton Inns of Memphis is building a 154-room hotel near Newark International Airport, the 14th to serve the terminal's immediate area. The $5 million facility on Route 1-9 in Elizabeth, N.J., facing an entrance to the airport, is expected to be finished in about a year. Airport officials attributed part of a major increase in hotel business around the terminal to the growing practice among business executives of flying in, attending meetings overnight in conference rooms and returning home the next day.

title: A Black Theater Group Faces New Hurdles
description: Twenty-three years ago, black American drama was not yet a part of the country's cultural milieu. Largely unwelcome on Broadway, black playwrights had their work confined mainly to a few Off Broadway and Harlem-based theaters. When the Negro Ensemble Company opened in Greenwich Village in 1967 - and in that inaugural year staged plays by Richard Wright and Wole Soyinka - it ushered black drama into the mainstream, helping to alter the nation's cultural landscape. Today, partly because of the company's pioneering efforts, the work of black dramatists can be found on and off Broadway and in many of the nation's regional theaters.

title: A RELUCTANT EDUCATION
description: My heart went out to Paulette Alden. Having gone through an ordeal of my own to have children, I understand only too well. In my case, after five pregnancies (one miscarriage, one ectopic pregnancy and two near-miscarriages where I had to have bed rest for the first trimesters), I now have three sons. I wish you luck, Ms. Alden.

title: Allegre Activated
description: The Giants activated Raul Allegre, Eric Dorsey and Damian Johnson from injured reserve today for Sunday's playoff game here against the Los Angeles Rams, Sports Ticker reported.

title: A Fair Share Of Medicare Taxes
description: The Nov. 26 article ''State's Elderly Gain Influence as Lobby Group'' described the power of some of the elderly in getting the 1988 expanded Medicare bill repealed this year. As one senior citizen who would have been paying a surtax in the expanded Medicare program, I am disgusted by the opposition of the more affluent seniors to helping their more needy peers.

title: Forecasting Tools for the Novice
description: Every business depends on forecasting, whether its executives know it or not. How many new franchise stores should we open in 1990? Will we have enough cash on hand in November to pay expenses? Will our current staff be adequate to meet manufacturing demand in 1992? When do we need to reorder widgets? Forecasts are intended to answer those questions.

title: Cold Snap Tests Service Agencies
description: LEAD: LARGELY because of services and programs in place by public and private agencies, Long Island seems to have weathered December's severe cold in relatively good shape.

title: Treasure House of Gods of India
description: IT is a land of vast and ancient temples, of spices and brightly dyed cloth, a land whose wealth was once proverbial. Today, Madras and its state, Tamil Nadu, retain the visible marks and the continued tradition of India's Dravidian-speaking peoples, whose Hindu culture preceded all the many foreign invasions. Within some 40 miles of the city center two great sites, Kanchipuram and Mahabalipuram, stand witness to the splendors of the Tamil culture; and just as spectacular, the collections of the Madras Government Museum and Art Gallery gather masterpieces of a quality as high as that of the greatest sculpture anywhere.

title: 2 Little White Lies, And a Plot Darkens
description: IN Alan Ayckbourn's farce, ''How the Other Half Loves,'' now at the Arena Players Theater in East Farmingdale, Bob Philips is having an extramarital affair with Fiona Foster, his boss's wife.

title: East Europe Joins the Market And Gets a Preview of the Pain
description: THE Eastern European countries that have paid with blood and struggle for their freedom to depart from Communism may decide some day that this was the easy part. Politics and economics remain as inseparable as the Marxists kept saying they were, and the new leaders in Poland, Hungary, Czechoslovakia, East Germany, Rumania and Bulgaria are making painful decisions more slowly than they would if they weren't so worried about the domestic political cost - a factor in every country in the region.

title: Hamden Boardinghouse Is Seed of an Idea
description: LEAD: ELI WHITNEY, best remembered as the inventor of the cotton gin, left his mark in New Haven in many ways. But not even he could have foreseen a modern-day concept that was inspired by his early 19th-century pragmatism: workers' housing.

title: Ms. Doherty Is Engaged to J. D. Perris
description: Catharine Hereford Doherty, the head kindergarten teacher at St. Ann's School in Brooklyn, and John David Perris, a lawyer in New York, plan to marry in April, the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. John H. Doherty of Kennebunkport, Me., have announced. Mr. Perris is a son of Eleanor H. Perris of Brooklyn and John R. Perris of Tucson, Ariz.

title: Q and A
description: Delinquent Mortgage

title: Childhood Music Lessons That Put the Stress on Fun
description: DANIEL PARRELLA of Pawcatuck loves music, from Mozart to the Rolling Stones. So when he turned 4 last fall, his parents signed him up for Kindermusik, a program of music instruction for children 4 to 7.

title: IN THE NATURAL STATE
description: LEAD: THE path led down an incline, merging at the bottom with the main trail. Though it was still early, still dark, the great avenue was already crowded with members of the herd - great multicolored beasts en route to their daytime haunts. There were scores in view at once. Before the sun was high in the sky, thousands would pass in review.

title: Review/Music;   Rock Group From Poland
description: Perfect, a rock band that has drawn stadium-size audiences to rock concerts in its native Poland, made its New York debut Thursday at CBGB. In Poland, Perfect has been a legendary dissident band - formed in 1979, disbanded under pressure in 1983, reunited in 1987 with the blessing of Solidarity. Here, playing a short set (only the songs that they have translated into English), Perfect was an aggressive, accomplished band whose songs suggested that in rock, Poland is a British colony.

title: POSTINGS: 'New England Vernacular'
description: The Beekman Estate, a private investment and development company in Manhattan, is seeking to add a new building to a shopping center it bought a year ago in Westport, Conn. The 6,200- square-foot addition to the Jennings Plaza shopping center, at 1045 Boston Post Road Extended, would be finished in about a year if expected approval is given later this month by the Westport Planning and Zoning Commission.

title:
BLACKBOARD;

Education Made Into A Moving Experience
description: LEAD: IN THE style of earn-while-you-learn, an elementary school outside St. Louis has created Project Upbeat, one of the nation's first learn-while-you-ride bus programs, which plugs students into headsets and cassette tapes with everything from Aesop's fables to ''Les Miserables.''

title: New Yorkers, etc.
description: Some nice gestures cost a lot of money. Others entail an expenditure of something perhaps still more precious: time. But even accepting this as a given does not mean that nice gestures should go by the wayside. For the fact is that the most meaningful of gestures cost nothing but a second or two of thought.

title: Review/Dance;   Isadora Duncan Repertory From Her Soviet Period
description: In 1921, Isadora Duncan, the great pioneer of American modern dance, went to teach and choreograph in the Soviet Union. Excited by the social changes she saw, she created several dances to Soviet workers' songs. Five rarely revived ones were offered Friday night at Eden's Expressway in a program called ''From the Repertory of Isadora Duncan,'' and the stagings by Julia Levien and Hortense Kooluris proved fascinating.

title: Let's Make the Cable TV Industry Live Up to Its Promises
description: WHEN the Cable Communications Policy Act of 1984 was passed, the cable industry made great promises in exchange for deregulation: promises of a technological utopia in which cable made anything from synchronized traffic lights to expanded educational opportunities possible.

title: Food;   Celtic Cuisine
description: AT MY FIRST WHIFF OF THE STEAMING GOLDENJU bowl of chowder thick with mussels, scallops ringed by coral roe, salmon and sole, I knew this was not the Ireland of old. That was a place I'd visited many times for the sound of Gaelic, for warm folk and cold Guinness, but never for food. A smoking peat fire, the slosh of fishermen's boots, a roaring laugh in Boluisce's Seafood Bar at Spiddal - all this was as familiar as the brine of wild Galway oysters. But in the old days, that's all there was, eked out by dry soda bread and breakfast bacon. Now, one bite of Boluisce's brown bread, moist and nearly black with flecks of toasted bran, and I knew that my next trip to Ireland would be for food alone.

title: Do Songs About The World's Ills Do Any Good?
description: Anyone who follows pop music's ongoing hit parade must have noticed the unprecedented convergence on the charts of hit singles with lyrics bearing social messages, about topics from homelessness to race relations to child abuse. In the national top 30 singles at year's end, no fewer than six songs took note of the world's ills.

title: Judith A. Wilner to Marry Donald Lawrence in May
description: A May wedding is planned by Judith Anne Wilner, a doctoral candidate in clinical psychology at New York University, and Donald Paul Lawrence, a third-year student at the Albert Einstein School of Medicine. Dr. and Mrs. Milton Wilner of Long Island City, Queens, made the announcement of their daughter's engagement to the son of Mr. and Mrs. Roy B. Lawrence of San Diego.

title: STAND UP AND SNEER
description: THE BRIDESHEAD GENERATION

title: 2 KOREAN PARTIES SEEK AN ALLIANCE
description: Two of the country's three opposition parties announced today that they would seek an alliance to prepare for local elections this year.

title: Residents Urged To Stand Up And Be Counted
description: LEAD: IN about a month, television viewers who watch the announcements of winning Lotto numbers will likely hear another message as well, one urging them to complete the census forms that should arrive in their mailboxes by April.

title: Failures Offer Lessons on Winning
description: FAILURE - a word fraught with emotion, easily spoken in daily conversation, but feared by the person to whom it is applied. Error, mistake, wrong, defeat, loss, all words that when directed at us evoke embarrassment and pain. We are trained and culturally conditioned to want to succeed, to be the best, to win. Being on top justifies self-esteem, whereas being at the bottom condemns us to self-recrimination.

title: A Mother's Lot: Exhaustion
description: I AM at home recovering from an illness. My son's. Nothing serious; just the usual virus that a 7-year-old seems to get every other month. He's trying to see how far he can shoot up the mercury before Mommy passes out. Anything less than 104 and he's toying with me. Put the toys away, Mama. 105.

title:
GARDENING;

More Greenery, Less Greenhouse Effect
description: LEAD: THOUGH New Year's Day has passed, it is still not too late to make resolutions. And perhaps as gardeners we can resolve to do more in behalf of the environment.

title: A Maker of Bells for Any Occasion
description: WANT to keep track of your cows? Festoon your sleigh or your mantel? Summon the butler to bring some tea or call your guests to the barbecue? For these and other tasks, Bevin Brothers has the bell for you.

title:
IN SHORT;

NONFICTION
description: LEAD:

title: Charm Versus News Coverage
description: To the Editor:

title: Secret Diplomacy Is the Best Kind
description: To the Editor:

title: More for Martin
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Campus Life: Clemson;   Student's Death Raises Questions About Drinking
description: The death of a 20-year-old sophomore at Clemson University has raised questions about drinking by under-age students on campus.

title: Campus Tours for the College-Bound
description: IF the wind-chill factor is minus 7 degrees and it's Sunday, we must be inspecting the campus of the University of Massachusetts in Amherst. I am a few years out of practice in looking at campuses, but it all came back recently when I made a round of New England colleges with a high school senior to test a new travel offering: college tours conducted by a Long Island company that takes a van or bus of young people between Friday afternoon and Sunday evening, providing driver, hotel rooms, chaperones, meals and transportation for $315 a person. The enterprise rates an A for organization and a B for execution. To an adult, the food rated D for dismal, but that may just be the state of campus cuisine.

title: A Giant Sale By Uncle Sam
description: The biggest real estate sale in American history is under way as the Federal Government acts on Administration orders to move quickly to dispose of properties taken over from failed savings and loan institutions. Last week the Resolution Trust Corporation, the agency handling the dispositions, listed about 30,000 properties it had acquired since Sept. 30. The list includes mansions, small houses, office buildings, hotels, shopping centers and tracts of land. The agency was swamped with calls from bargain hunters, but officials said the Government was determined to get at least 95 percent of the appraised value. Some experts were expressing concern that the assets, many of them in the Southwest, would be ''dumped'' in real estate markets that are already depressed. The supply of such properties will grow; only 318 of a projected 500 institutions have been taken over, and many analysts say the projection is low.

title: Diana Tasco Is Wed to John B. Meyer
description: Diana Lee Tasco, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank J. Tasco of Manhasset, L.I., was married there yesterday to John Barry Meyer, the son of Beverly Barry Meyer of New York and John DeBard Meyer of Brooklyn. The Rev. James P. Swiader performed the ceremony at St. Mary's Roman Catholic Church.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: No Blah Ma and Pa

title: TALKING: Mortgages;   V.A. Loans Regaining Acceptance
description: AN unexpected byproduct of the weaker real estate market has been the return of the Veterans Administration mortgage as a popular financing tool, one that developers and sellers appear keener to honor than in the mid-80's, when sales were booming and any loan subject to possible bureaucratic delay was scorned.

title: A RELUCTANT EDUCATION
description: I am an adoptive mother. I, too, had a ''reluctant education'' in infertility. None of us - and there are millions of us - were raised to deal with this. Our life scripts all were written with children, easily conceived, probably in our 20's.

title:
MUSIC;

Not All Old And Not All New
description: LEAD: THE Da Capo Chamber Players like to combine old and new music in a concert, a mixture they find more effective than either one alone.

title: Mimi Anne House To Wed in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Stanley H. House of Shawnee Mission, Kan., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Mimi Anne House, to Jay Anthony James, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Edmund H. James of Verona, N.J. A June wedding is planned. Miss House, who is 23 years old and a graduate of the University of Arizona, is a candidate for a master's degree in English at the University of California at Los Angeles. Her father is the managing partner of Laventhol & Horwath, a Kansas City certified public accounting concern with headquarters in Philadelphia.

title: Hint of Summer at Boat Show
description: Although we'll gain less than 45 minutes of daylight between now and the end of the month, daydreams of long, soft summer days afloat on river, lake or ocean might be engendered by a visit to the 80th New York National Boat Show, which this year runs from Saturday through Jan. 21 at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center in Manhattan.

title: Lark Quintet Opens Chamber Series
description: THE herald of our budding 1990 concert year in Westchester is the Lark Quartet. This top-notch, prize-winning ensemble - the violinists Eva Gruesser and Robin Mayforth, the violist Anna Kruger and the cellist Astrid Schween - plays at 3 P.M. today, as the Sunday Chamber Series resumes at the Hudson River Museum in Yonkers.

title:
ART;

Conundrums That Betray a Human Hand
description: LEAD: THE relationship between art and science is a complex one, but one that is in the forefront of artistic concerns lately. It is a sort of reaction against Expressionism, which relies on imprecision for its force. But the ''science and art'' question is part of a larger debate on what kind of art best reflects the way life will be led into the next millenium.

title: The Invisible but Giant Indispensible Giant
description: When the All-Pro or Pro Bowl teams are chosen, some specialists are hailed for their skills. Place-kickers, punters, even special-team tacklers. But never a blocking back. Although success in football has been defined by coaches from Amos Alonzo Stagg to Bill Walsh as boiling down to blocking and tackling, there is no such species as the All-Pro blocking back or a Pro Bowl blocking back. It's as if all those All-Pro running backs were doing it by themselves. But more than any other players, they know better. Especially when they arrive at the Pro Bowl and the coaches start diagramming plays.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. I have read about the problem that some people have with condensation forming between the two panes of glass in double-pane windows, but my problem is different. My apartment has windows of this type, but with a metal frame. When outside temperatures drop below freezing, condensation forms on the metal and then freezes to form a coat of ice on the inside. When this ice melts, water runs down onto the sill and soils the draperies. Can you suggest how to eliminate this?

title: IN THE REGION: Westchester and Connecticut;   Recent Sales
description: Bedford, N.Y. $375,000

title: FICTION
description: BOY, GIRL, BOY, GIRL. By David Michaelis. (Bantam, Paper, $7.95.) Sam Simon is one of the first boys to enroll in Miss Little's School, a private all-girl academy. The setting of this first novel is Concord, Mass., the time 1971 - and the prospects for adventure rich. Which is not to say that Sam and his older brother, Murray, prosper in their new milieu. Sam narrates the story of his and his brother's education, which the reader soon knows will not be narrowly confined to books and the classroom. The boys' real instruction is given by the Mansfield sisters, two glowing, nubile teen-agers who are knowledgeable about such basics as contraceptives and skinny-dipping. Berry, the older sister, has hair the color of ''wild honey'' and the flesh of a ''brand-new egg-filled woman.'' Emma, the younger, is an artist who likes to murmur soulful remarks just when Sam longs to squeeze her waist, which is as ''soft and warm as custard.'' Sam's great, lasting hope is to lose his virginity with either sister, though his lust eventually gathers round the bosomy Berry. In his quest, Sam learns a painful lesson: the Mansfield beauties are impossible to snare. Unfortunately, David Michaelis never extends his reach any further than the depiction of Sam's romantic frustration. The tension that arises from being one of a handful of boys amid so many girls is quickly snuffed out after a few chapters and replaced with the more particular anxiety of chasing Berry and Emma. And so the plot veers away from anything more serious than adolescent angst. But what it does give us is pungent writing - and a clear vision of a boy's growing awareness of the fickleness of the heart.

title: Uprooted by Blast, Gramercy Park Residents Return Home, to New Horrors
description: Patti McCarthy returned home to Gramercy Park yesterday for the first time since she and others were forced out by a steam-pipe explosion last summer and found an elderly neighbor sobbing in the lobby, heartbroken by the condition of her apartment. So Miss McCarthy asked another neighbor to go with her into her own apartment for support.

title: Another Bowl to Miami
description: The University of Miami will receive tangible evidence - a large, ornate silver bowl named after Gen. Douglas MacArthur - to go along with its selection in the polls as the nation's No. 1 college football team.

title: Get With The Program
description: To the Editor:

title: Shelley B. Weinstock Engaged to Paul V. Bartick
description: Dr. Shelley Beth Weinstock and Paul Vincent Bartick plan to marry in March.

title: Ilene S. Kleckner To Marry in April
description: Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Kleckner of Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Ilene Sondra Kleckner to Kent Richard Friedman, a son of Alfred Friedman of Hallandale, Fla., and the late Carol Z. Landham. An April wedding is planned.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Dec. 24 about the preparations for the Panama invasion misidentified an American killed in the operation. He was Pfc. Roy Dennis Brown Jr.

title: Pastimes;   Stamps
description: The awful and wonderful events in Rumania over the past three weeks bring to mind a forgotten mini-collection that dates back to the days just after World War II. The wreckage that was Rumania had just come under Soviet Communist domination, when Rumanian stamps became the subject of an obscure decree.

title: Freedom Is a Sanctuary In a Changing World
description: LIKE love, missed only when it isn't there, freedom is all too often taken for granted. The political upheavals in Eastern Europe and the mass exodus of East Germans looking for a freer life brought into sharp focus my own family's flight from oppression. Seeing the happy but bewildered faces of East Germans crossing into West Berlin, I am reminded of our own state of mind when, back in 1942, we first set foot on American soil.

title: IN QUOTES
description: ''If the retailer hadn't had the hook out, he wouldn't have had any customers in the stores.''

title: Scott Carneal to Wed Katherine M. Swan
description: Mr. and Mrs. William Channing Swan of Dover, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter Katharine Moore Swan to Scott Hamilton Carneal, a son of Mr. and Mrs. George U. Carneal of McLean, Va. A March wedding is planned.

title: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST: Bulgaria;   Thousands of Slavs, Defying Sofia, Continue Anti-Turkish Protests
description: Thousands of people from Bulgaria's Slavic majority defied the Government and kept up protests today in at least four cities to try to overturn new laws granting religious and cultural freedom to ethnic Turks.

title: Campus Life: LeMoyne-Owen;   College Reaching Out To Serve Its Neighbors
description: LeMoyne-Owen College, a predominantly black, liberal arts institution with 1,000 students, is a 15-acre educational oasis in a desert of poverty and crime in Memphis. In the last two years, LeMoyne-Owen's president, Irving P. McPhail, has been working to make that desert bloom by founding the Office of Community Outreach and ''adopting'' the nearby LeMoyne Gardens Housing Development.

title: Say Which
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Artist Seeks to Rescue 'Poisoned Nature'
description: LEAD: A FROZEN cloud of white acid hangs over barren mountains, a sterile river, a skeleton tree. In a corner of the painting, a tiny factory's chimneys fly red flags of smoke. In that smoke are toxins that poison rivers and kill trees. Acid rain, a byproduct of a careless and prosperous society, destroys whatever breathes and grows.

title: Jacqueline K. Nash Weds Peter W. Rea
description: Jacqueline Kate Nash and Peter Wilson Rea were married yesterday at the Palm House of the Brooklyn Botanic Garden by Chief Judge Thomas C. Platt of Federal District Court for the Eastern District of New York.

title: Sensory Overload
description: LIKE the Chimera of Greek mythology, multimedia - a combination of techniques, hardware, software and applications - is a fabulous creature comprising elements of several familiar beasts. It encompasses computers, television, textbooks, libraries, overhead projectors and blackboards. As electronic technology makes multimedia more sophisticated, it has become - depending on whom you ask - either the most revolutionary educational technology since the textbook, or a marketing buzzword concocted by computer makers to sell more machines.

title: Vermont
description: To the Editor: When one was raised in a place as remote as northern Vermont, it comes as quite a surprise to see an article promoting the area as a base for sightseeing (''Where Vermont and Quebec Meld,'' Travel, Sept. 24). The article, which recently came to my attention, nicely captures the similarities and distinctions between the American and Canadian cultures.

title: THE QUIZ
description: By their quotes you may know them - at least that's the challenge in this quiz: quotes to tax your memory, quotes to test your history, quotes to try your patience and good humor (since not every one is what it seems). But don't quote us on that.

title: In Marketing, It's Bracketing Brides and the Over-45 Set
description: The manufacture of sterling flatware is among the oldest industries in the nation. None of the leading silversmiths is less than a century old, and some trace their origins to before the American Revolution. From one generation to the next, these companies had always considered their market to be forever green. In their view, silver virtually sells itself.

title:
THE JANUARY REPORT;

Wayout West
description: LEAD: IF LOCATION is an indicator of lofty academic goals, then World College West, the smallest four-year liberal arts college accredited by the Western Association of Schools and Colleges, is perfectly placed: perched on a hillside near Petaluma in rural northern Marin County, Calif., with a view that could easily inspire Utopian thinking.

title:
IN SHORT;

ANTHOLOGIES
description: LEAD:

title: Meaning's Value
description: To the Editor:

title: Fines and Bans
description: The National Hockey League got in the last licks yesterday when it announced fines and suspensions for some of the combatants in the pregame fight between Chicago and Minnesota players 10 days ago. Wayne Van Dorp of the Blackhawks and Shane Churla of the North Stars were suspended for 10 games each without pay and their teams were fined $25,000 each.

title: Question of the Week: Next Week;   Is the N.F.C. The Better Conference?
description: The Times welcomes letters from readers. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. Letters should be addressed to The Editor, Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: Julie P. Brooks Plans to Marry
description: Maj. and Mrs. Gary D. Fraley of Springfield, Va., have made known the engagement of Mrs. Fraley's daughter, Julie Patricia Brooks, to Robert Anthony Rouse, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony J. Rouse of Berkeley Heights, N.J. A March wedding is planned.

title: Marilyn Horne and Gay Men's Chorus
description: Marilyn Horne will be the guest soloist in a benefit concert by the New York City Gay Men's Chorus, March 1 at 8 P.M. at Carnegie Hall. Proceeds from the event will benefit the chorus's AIDS Outreach Fund, which makes donations to organizations that help people with AIDS. The mezzo-soprano will sing Brahms's ''Alto Rhapsody'' and excerpts from ''L'Italiana in Algeri'' and ''Tancredi,'' both by Rossini. Also on the program: excerpts from Beethoven's ''Fidelio,'' Berlioz's ''Damnation of Faust'' and Mussorgsky's ''Boris Godunov.'' Tickets: $15 to $100. Information: 247-7800.

title: Parent Urges Yankee Rebirth
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. I have read about the problem that some people have with condensation forming between the two panes of glass in double-pane windows, but my problem is different. My apartment has windows of this type, but with a metal frame. When outside temperatures drop below freezing, condensation forms on the metal and then freezes to form a coat of ice on the inside. When this ice melts, water runs down onto the sill and soils the draperies. Can you suggest how to eliminate this?

title: CY TWOMBLY'S TUSCAN NOTES TO HIMSELF
description: One of the best art shows of last year was saved until the very end, and has just become one the best of this year: an exhibition of paintings Cy Twombly made in a villa near Bolsena in central Italy during the summer and early fall of 1969. The series of 12 exuberantly drawn and painted abstract landscapes has never been exhibited complete, but until Feb. 10, eight of them are on view at the Gagosian Gallery on Madison Avenue. The gallery is owned by Larry Gagosian, who is perhaps the most criticized art dealer of the moment (more of that later), but he and his staff have once again assembled a small, focused exhibition of a quality that is all too rarely seen in museums.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: LEAD:

title: Some Big Issues for N.C.A.A.
description: Proposition 42, the N.C.A.A. bylaw that angered John Thompson and others when it was adopted last year, will be back on the table with some modifications when the National Collegiate Athletic Association opens its three-day convention on Sunday.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: THE DIANE GOODE BOOK OF AMERICAN FOLK TALES & SONGS

title: Bagging Noriega Is Not the Same as Winning the Drug War
description: THE transformation of Manuel Antonio Noriega from invincible leader of Panama and foreign nemesis to manacled criminal defendant in Miami buoyed the American psyche. It was a political triumph for President Bush.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM: MILITARY PROCUREMENT;

The Real Threat to the Arms Industry
description: LEAD: The most troublesome threat to the leadership of America's defense industry does not come from across the Pacific in the factories and research laboratories of Japan. The United States is an innovative and inventive society, and some of our greatest talent and energy resides in the defense industry.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: CROSS-COUNTRY SKIING

title: STREETSCAPES: The Christian Herter Home;   Another Transformation For a 'Modern French' House
description: IT has always been one of the most striking buildings on Madison Avenue - an ancient limestone facade over a newer but still elegant iron storefront below. Now the 1893 Christian Herter house at 819 Madison, at 68th Street, is in the middle of a renovation - at least of its 1933 storefront - and the results should be available for inspection this spring.

title: CARTER REDUX
description: How wonderful it was to see former President Jimmy Carter's portrait on the cover of The New York Times Magazine (''Carter Redux,'' by Wayne King, Dec. 10). As a Democrat, I am thrilled to find the true Jimmy Carter rediscovered. I only hope my party also will recognize the contributions he made.

title: Dentist Article Hit a Nerve
description: We get the impression from the letters ['Dentists Fail to Smile in Response to ''Smile, Darn You, Smile,'' ' Dec. 24] that Barbara Klaus's article about dentists hit a nerve. Apparently there has been considerable erosion of the funny bone. Come, gentlemen, you must allow us our gibes as you laugh all the way to the bank.

title: Waterways Council To Publish Newspaper
description: HOPING to increase its membership, the State Council on Waterways plans to begin publishing a newspaper in February.

title: Golden Gate, Silver Screen
description: IT'S that film noir city in ''The Maltese Falcon'' (1941), in which a world-weary Bogart shadows slippery criminals and a double-crossing dame through thick fog. It's that boozing, brawling Barbary Coast of ''San Francisco'' (1936), where the egotistical cad Clark Gable is finally humbled by a street-splitting, tower-toppling earthquake. It's that modern, lawless Baghdad by the Bay in ''Bullitt'' (1968), where high-speed car chases through steep streets seem to be an everyday occurence.

description: MEGATRENDS 2000

title: Cool Reception for Devils' Latest Import
description: While Moscow Dynamo was on the ice on Thursday preparing for tonight's exhibition game against the Devils at Byrne Meadowlands Arena, Aleksei Kasatonov was alone outside the Devils' dressing room, using a saw to take an inch or two off the edge of his stick for his National Hockey League debut.

title: In 'Minor' College Sports, Big Pressure
description: College presidents and athletic directors gathering today in Dallas for the 84th National Collegiate Athletic Association convention will once again wrestle with the excesses of big-time basketball and football.

title: THE ULTIMATE DECISION
description: I do not believe that there is such a thing as a ''good death,'' but after reading Andrew Malcolm's article, I do feel that some deaths are better than others.

description: ADVANCE, RETREAT

title: SPECIAL SECTION: Science Under Scrutiny;   Hands On
description: SCIENCE IS BORING, and scientists are just this side of crazy. At least that is what children think, according to Rebecca L. Lubetkin, executive director of the Consortium for Educational Equity at Rutgers University, which provides training and assistance to educators.

title: FICTION
description: ALL ABOUT WOMEN. By Andrew M. Greeley. (Tom Doherty/Tor, Cloth, $18.95; Paper, $12.95.) As he did with his 1986 novel ''Patience of a Saint,'' the Rev. Andrew M. Greeley affixes an introductory note to this collection, explaining that its title is less audacious than it sounds. He does not, he says, ''purport to know 'all about women.' '' Rather, each of these 23 stories is about a woman, and in each ''a woman either is or creates an opportunity of grace . . . or is visited by an offer of grace.'' Father Greeley's best story, ''Andrea,'' provides an absorbing and chilling account of an eerie young widow being driven through Arizona by a former Navy officer, who is as captivated by her beauty as he is haunted by guilt over the men who died under his command in World War II. Three other interrelated tales - ''Peggy,'' ''Paula'' and ''Deirdre'' - present the collection's only rounded and convincing character, Peggy Walsh, a woman struggling to resume her life after the death of her husband. Unfortunately, despite the benevolence behind them, the remaining stories in ''All About Women'' contribute to the mounting evidence that Father Greeley's talents are best displayed in his theological polemics rather than in his novels and short stories. Long a champion of a more powerful role for women within the church, he treats them here with a syrupy reverence that itself becomes patronizing. As if to serve as a metaphor for the collection, the Virgin Mary is a contemporary character in one story (passing as Ms. Mary Carpenter), and even she cloys. Father Greeley's women simply aren't real. But then, neither are the pulpy narratives in which they appear. These are cumbersome, antiseptic tales whose sentimentality is reminiscent of Hollywood movies in the 1930's and television comedies in the 1950's. Often narrated with thin sanctimony by haughty priests, many of these stories might be retitled ''Father Knows Best.'' That may be so, but not when it comes to fiction.

title: A Fan Club For the Designs of the Roadside
description: MARK GRAMPP loves old drive-in movie theaters. Steven Hirschberg admires the Pride Cleaners building in Danbury and the Carvel stand on the Darien-Norwalk border. Philip Langdon wrote a book about chain restaurant buildings and is also fond of gas stations. Stuart Sachs goes for gaudy commercial strips.

title: In the Citadel, A New View of Jerusalem
description: When King Herod ruled Judea, Jewish sages said of its capital, ''Whoever has not seen Jerusalem in its splendor has never seen a fine city.'' In fact the splendor of Jerusalem changed dramatically during the centuries under the influence of several major religions. Today visitors can trace the city's history in a new museum actually woven into the ruins of its most ancient fortress.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: FISHING SCHOOL

title:
IN THE REGION: New Jersey;

Coping With a Soft Residential Market
description: LEAD: THE state's residential market is still feeling the effects of a major boom in housing construction and selling activity in the mid-80's and, saddled with a lingering supply of new and resale houses, the market is expected to remain soft through the coming year.

title: Cuomo Gives A Speech, So Everyone Is Talking
description: NO sooner did Gov. Mario M. Cuomo utter the word ''global'' in his State of the State address last week than many Albany politicians began to speculate out loud that he would run for President in 1992.

title: FLASHCARD
description: A 1989 study of elementary-school children in North Carolina found that teachers judged latchkey children (children who care for themselves after school) to be better adjusted than children with other after-school child-care arrangements. Researchers at the University of North Carolina at Greensboro reported that teachers found no difference in the academic performance achievement of latchkey children and other students. Parents, however, say they experience more stress and less satisfaction when children are in a latchkey arrangement instead of at a child-care center or with their mothers at home. The survey of 544 children, kindergarten through sixth grade, from randomly selected schools in North Carolina was sponsored by Project Home Safe, a nonprofit national program to improve the well-being of children in self-care, which is funded by the Whirlpool Foundation. A fifth of the children in the study were in latchkey arrangements, two-thirds in parents' care and the rest in child-care centers.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Nashua, N.H.;

Vacancies Rise In Office Slump
description: LEAD: DEVELOPERS and landlords in southern New Hampshire's two major cities, Nashua and Manchester, are trying to work their way out of a regional office-market slump.

title: Add-ons Ease the Pain of Shrinking Sterling Sales
description: With consumer demand for silver sinking, silversmiths in the 80's started to cast about for other products that could benefit from their venerable names. To survive, several began to import and market stainless steel and to move into other tabletop products like crystal and china to fill out their lines and make their accounts more attractive to department store retailers. Some also made a stab at markets unrelated to the dining table, expanding their lines of silver baby goods and branching out into off-table products without silver as their base.

title: Should a County Sell Liquor? No Way, Says Student Group
description: When Susan Bergeron, a high school senior who is a local official of Students Against Driving Drunk, learned that Montgomery County was selling its own brand of liquor, she was furious.

title: DEPARTMENT STORES: SHOP AND LEARN
description: Department stores are in trouble these days. Several are singing the bankruptcy blues, while economists and accountants look for answers in their charts. But if they really want to know the cause, they need only try a shopping trip or two.

title: Praising Big Blue

title: The Menorah On the Town Green
description: Regarding the Dec. 10 article ''Effort to Display Menorah on Town Green Finally Succeeds,'' it is unfortunate that the Teaneck Town Council has decided to follow the United States Supreme Court's lead in Allegheny County v. Greater Pittsburgh A.C.L.U. and now allows a menorah on the municipal green. There will probably be more to come in other towns.

title: Argentina's Economic Pain Makes Just Getting By a Struggle
description: When Yolanda Mendolia saw the dizzying ascent of prices that began before the holidays, and how low her husband's salary was by comparison, she decided her only choice was ''to put myself in the hands of God.''

title: Bed and Breakfast
description: To the Editor: Interest in bed and breakfast establishments has been spurred by articles and photographs in slick magazines and newspapers. Quite naturally, the most lavishly decorated rooms receive special treatment and have led the public to expect a great deal. I write as the owner of a reservation service organization on Cape Cod to acquaint your readers with the definitions of bed and breakfast in Massachusetts as they appear in House Bill 1064 signed by the Governor on May 10, 1988, quoted below:

title: Eleanor Dillon Plans to Marry
description: Mr. and Mrs. Martin P. Dillon of Merrick, L.I., have made known the engagement of their daughter Eleanor Ann Dillon to Daniel Petigrow, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Charles Petigrow of Stony Brook, L.I. A November wedding is planned. Miss Dillon, 24 years old, graduated from Cornell University and is an account executive at Burson-Marsteller, a public relations company in New York. Her father, a labor relations lawyer, recently retired as the executive vice president of the Printers League of the Association of Graphic Arts in New York. Her mother, Susan Dillon, is a teacher of the gifted at the Wheeler Avenue Elementary School in Valley Stream, L.I.

title:
BLACKBOARD;

West Coast Wordsmiths

At least that's the sales pitch for the oversize, soft-cover yellow and blue dictionary titled ''U.C.L.A. Slang: A Dictionary of Slang Words and Expressions Used at U.C.L.A.

title: Artful Science
description: IN HIS two published volumes of poetry, Roald Hoffman, a Nobel Prize-winning chemist and the John A. Newman professor of physical science at Cornell University, has struggled to unite the worlds of science and art, of reason and instinct.

title: Animal Shelters And Care
description: This long-delayed letter is in response to an article about the Elmsford animal shelter [''Animal Shelter in Elmsford Faces Charges on Crowding,'' Nov. 19] . It was disturbing.

title: IN THE TRENCHES OF THE DRUG WARS
description: The United States' ''war on drugs'' was first declared by President Richard Nixon in the early 1970's. The current drug crisis provides ample proof that this particular war has been a colossal failure. The reasons range from obscene profits and widespread corruption to national interests and geopolitical maneuverings.

title: Whose Broker Is It, Anyway? Albany Offers An Answer
description: SUPPOSE a house-hunting couple wants to make a bid on a house. They aren't sure how much under the asking price to offer, so they ask the broker. The broker says, ''Well, the house has been on the market for six months, you saw how old the furnace is, so why don't you try this number?''

title: Folk Tales Of the Hudson Recaptured in Manuscripts
description: ''Anyway, they tell some queer stories about Money Hill. There is Lige Byliss, come from over back Alipartis way; used to be one of the Point fishing crew that had a seine over there when shad used to run more plentiful than they do now. Lige was ready to swear that the hill was haunted; never would go near the place at night, after what he said he saw there one time.''

title: HEIDEGGER FOR FUN AND PROFIT
description: Martin Heidegger's centenary year has come and gone, and just as well. It came at a bad time. In Berkeley, New Haven, Moscow, Chicago, Paris and Marburg (and other places besides), conferences and parties have been celebrating the philosopher's birth. Two or three years ago, when these jamborees were planned, it was still possible for most people to write off Heidegger's flirtation with Nazism as merely that - a foolish minor entanglement, which Hannah Arendt, who was briefly his lover, could generously attribute ''partly to the delusion of genius, partly to desperation.''

title: SPECIAL SECTION: Science Under Scrutiny;   Where the Talent Goes
description: THEIR stories are inspiring - of children who experienced a calling, of teen-agers clasped in the exhilarating grip of curiosity, of adults still driven by the delicious joy of discovery.

THE JANUARY REPORT;

Freshman Blues
description: LEAD: PARENTS of college freshmen fall into two groups. Group A parents have children who by Thanksgiving have telephoned home to say they hate their roommates, haven't made any friends and can't keep up with the work.

title: A Bid to Put a Drug House To Good Use
description: A LARGE wooded and secluded piece of property in the shoreline town of Clinton where its former owner sold drugs could end up as a new elementary school or even a police station.

title: NO RETURNS
description: ART BUCHWALD DID A COLUMN recently about his lucky wife. She had fallen in front of their house, as I recall, and broken her wrist. ''Lucky it was your left wrist and not your right,'' one friend said. ''Lucky you were so close to home,'' said another. ''Lucky you were at the foot of the stairs and not the top,'' said a third. From all these well-wishers, Mr. Buchwald concluded that his wife was indeed an extremely lucky woman.

description: Caroline Livingston Neville and James Raymond Freney were married yesterday at St. Edward Roman Catholic Church in Palm Beach, Fla. Msgr. Gerald A. Hughes performed the ceremony.

description: There is no glamour down there. It is dirt and grass stains, grunting and grabbing, a sea of arms and feet and numbers, and a pile of bodies. It is everything about football and yet nothing.

title: Shopping Isn't Fun For Retailers Either
description: I can certainly appreciate Mr. Fluhrer's complaint about the somewhat dubious joys of shopping during the holiday season [''Why Shopping in Department Stores Is No Fun,'' Opinion, Dec. 17] . It is true that though we in the retail profession may deck the halls and staff the malls (as best we can in a tight labor market), shopping may not be the exhilarating experience one would wish for.

title: Grand Touches in Woodcuts
description: COINCIDING with the invention of type, woodcuts began as crude, simple images. But those produced for the cognoscenti by Durer and Cranach can scarcely be told from engravings, so fine are their lines and so sparkling their tones.

title: Marriage Plans For Joan E. Iler
description: Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Borden Iler of Middletown, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Joan Elizabeth Iler, to Christopher Stuart Burdge, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Richard M. Burdge of Shelter Island, L.I., and Boca Grande, Fla. A September wedding is planned.

title: ARKADY RENKO GOES TO MUNICH
description: IN AN UNLIT PARKING LOT, JUST OFF the road leading north out of Munich, the prostitutes are in their jeeps. It's about 10 P.M., and there are maybe two dozen vehicles in the lot, some of them dark, with curtains drawn around the side and back windows. In the others, the cab lights are on so the men who are walking or cruising by in their own cars can get a good look at the girls inside.
