title: Mutual Funds Turn to the Hard Sell
description: Time was when the managers of the Janus Capital mutual fund group paid scant attention to their customers. Cash-flow multiples and moving averages concerned them far more. But faced with persistent redemptions, Janus concluded in 1987 that performance alone wasn't enough. The marketing specialists came in, the advertising budget went up, and in 1989 the company's accounts doubled.

title: Villanova Surprises Syracuse at Dome
description: Greg Woodard scored a career-high 27 points tonight as Villanova took advantage of another poor shooting night by Syracuse and sent the Orangemen to their first loss of the season, 93-74. The loss ended Syracuse's home winning streak at 15.

title: Soothing Scents
description: CRYSTALS, PSYCHIC READINGS, NEW-age music, organic food, holistic medicine - aromatherapy fits right in with all those ideas that are passing from the counterculture to the trendy. Welcome back, Age of Aquarius.

title: MOSCOW PROMISES TO BACK RUMANIA IN ITS NEW POLITICS
description: Hailing the Rumanian revolution that ousted President Nicolae Ceausescu, Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze of the Soviet Union said today that he found the new atmosphere here ''absolutely purifying'' and pledged Moscow's support for any political system Rumanians chose.

title:
INVESTING;

Birth of a Catholic Bond Fund
description: LEAD: Two years ago, when the prospectus for a debt offering by an arm of the Catholic Church crossed his desk, John I. Dickerson, a Denver money manager, was startled. ''I was reading it and began to think, 'Boy, this is awfully high quality and yet with a good yield,' '' he said.

title: Karen Cox Weds John J. Mandy Jr.
description: At the Presbyterian Church in Rye, N.Y., Karen Leslie Cox, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bert George Cox of Rye and Boca Grande, Fla., was married yesterday to John Joseph Mandy Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Mandy of New Paltz, N.Y. The Rev. David L. Uhl performed the ceremony, assisted by Msgr. Donald J. Pryor, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: Nan Silver, Editor, to Wed Arthur Katz, Lawyer
description: The engagement of Nan Clarissa Silver to Arthur Shaye Katz, the son of Flora Dae Katz of Creve Coeur, Mo., and Albert M. Katz of Brentwood, Mo., has been made known by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Murray Silver of Woodmere, L.I. An April wedding is planned.

title: Miss Proctor Engaged To Dr. Eliot N. Heller
description: The engagement of Bridgette Lefaye Proctor to Dr. Eliot Naphtali Heller, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Eugene Heller of Huntington, L.I., has been announced by the prospective bride's mother and stepfather, Mr. and Mrs. William Puller of St. Petersburg, Fla. A February wedding is planned.

title: Lifestyle: Sunday Outing;   When the Next Snowstorm Hits, Here's Where to Go With Your Sled
description: With every snowfall, New York City's parks are taken over by an army of sledders who swarm the hills, large and small. It is one of the less-heralded pleasures of city life; when snow crunches under the blades of your Flexible Flyer, the hustle and bustle of New York can seem very far away.

description: DESPITE the rising cost of employee health insurance that businesses in the county have had to pay in recent years, hospitals are reporting increasing financial losses and warning that quality health care is being jeopardized.

title: PRO HOCKEY: Midseason Report;   Rangers Hoping To End Free Fall

title: Rodgers and Bird Out
description: As a result of separate incidents in a game the previous night, neither the head coach nor the chief player traveled with the Boston Celtics to Landover, Md., yesterday for their game last night against the Washington Bullets, which the Celtics won. Coach Jimmy Rodgers was missing because he was suspended without pay for one game by the National Basketball Association after he bumped a referee during an argument Friday night. The star forward, Larry Bird, was absent because he sprained his left ankle in the same game.

title: Bush Releases Disaster Aid
description: President Bush has authorized the release of $184.6 million in disaster aid to help with the recovery from Hurricane Hugo, which struck the South in September, and the earthquake in California in October.

description: IT may not be exactly home, but for some of the county's homeless and runaway teen-agers, it is a lot better than being out on the street at this time of year.

title:
BLACKBOARD;

Sofa As Teaching Tool

But after a visit to her home from a Carrollton kindergarten teacher, Mrs. Crowder said she had a new appreciation for ways she could prepare her son,

title: Communist Paper Reports Revolt at Prison in Slovakia
description: Inmates have rioted at a prison in Slovakia, taking over some parts of the building, the Communist Party newspaper reported today.

description: Closings in the week ended Dec. 23

title: CRIME
description: After more than 30 years of duty in the 87th Precinct, Detective Steve Carella has seen it all - almost. In VESPERS (Morrow, $18.95), a shocking new chapter in Ed McBain's continuing morality tale about the forces of good and evil in the big city, this decent Everycop confronts another crime to try his soul: the senseless murder of a Roman Catholic priest. ''If people like that are getting killed,'' the despairing Carella reasons, what's next? The Devil himself on horseback?

title: Carol Rifenburg Marries R. J. Miller Jr.
description: Carol Elaine Rifenburg and Richard Joseph Miller Jr., an associate in the New York law firm of Dewey, Ballantine, Bushby, Palmer & Wood, were married yesterday at Westminster Presbyterian Church in Albany. The Rev. S. Albert Newman performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. Randall Patterson, a Roman Catholic priest.

title: Corrections

title: Arthur Kennedy, Actor, 75, Dies; Was Versatile in Supporting Roles
description: Arthur Kennedy, who appeared in more than 70 Hollywood films and won a Tony Award on Broadway for creating the role of Biff in Arthur Miller's ''Death of a Salesman,'' died of a brain tumor on Friday at the Connecticut Hospice in Branford. He was 75 years old.

title: Battling to Reclaim A 'Lost Semi-Eden'
description: In Pete Dunne's ''In the Natural State'' (Dec. 3), I was particularly aggrieved by the words ''as a lifelong New Jersey resident wrestling with his future - with the question of remaining here, or seeking a place that is what New Jersey was...''

title: Israeli Denies He Served as Noriega Adviser
description: The man identified by American officials as a top aide to Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega appeared on Israeli television tonight to deny that he had served as security adviser to the fallen Panamanian dictator.

title: FLASHCARD
description: THE United Nations has proclaimed 1990 International Literacy Year. A fourth of the world's adults are illiterate, but the problem is not confined to developing nations. Thirteen percent of Americans 20 years old and older are considered functionally illiterate. The basic skills of functional illiterates do not reach beyond the fourth grade. - Unesco and the U.S. Department of Education, Adult Literacy Program

title: I'll Talk With the P.L.O. Again

title: Businesslike Business School
description: LAST JULY, two months before fall semester began, William Glavin toured Babson College, in Wellesley, Mass. He went into every dorm room, every classroom. He checked the sports fields and gyms.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption with the Stage View column on page 5 of the Arts and Leisure section today refers incorrectly in some copies to ''The Art of Success.'' The New York production is that of the Manhattan Theater Club.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in the Education Life section today about a new approach to computers in public schools gives an incorrect location for Cougar Valley Elementary School. It is in Silverdale, Wash.

title: Robinson Lesson: Keep It Alive
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Campus Life: Texas Tech;   4 Students Face Charges of Making False Licenses
description: What do some college students under age 21 do when they want a drink and the legal drinking age is 21? They may find a bar that does not force the issue, or, failing that, find false identification.

title: To the Brink and Back in Real Estate
description: Back in the late 1960's, most people saw nothing more than cattle and horses rambling over the rolling prairie northwest of Dallas. Ben Carpenter saw the community of the future. So, in 1969, he set about building it.

title: Khmer Rouge Claim Assault on Major City
description: Khmer Rouge guerrillas claimed today they had attacked Cambodia's second-largest city, setting it ablaze and forcing Government troops to call for reinforcements.

title: Lifestyle;   There's More to Coin Laundries Than Just Getting the Wash Done
description: Lily McKinley tossed small handfuls of clothes into a large yellow dryer at the West 79th Street coin laundry last week while listening to a description of Videotown Laundrette, which is scheduled to open on the next block in two weeks. She shook her gray hair and light blue knit cap skeptically at the tanning salon and video rentals the new laundry will offer.

title: About Men;   Finally Answering The Call
description: We hardly knew each other. He and his wife had left the city, as we had, relocating to this small town in upstate New York with the idea of finding cleaner air and less noise and russet-colored dogs in russet-colored leaves. I had two young sons, he had three, and we shared the conviction that this small, clean, safe part of the world would insure our children ''a better way of life.'' We shared as well a religion, and so we would sometimes encounter each other at the little synagogue which, for Jews in these parts, was the only game in town.

title: Cuomo Remarks on Abortion Confuse Both Sides
description: In an unusual section of his State of the State Message that confused advocates on both sides of the abortion issue, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo this week called national abortion statistics sobering and vowed to propose funds ''specifically allocated for promoting the value of abstinence for young people.''

title: Corrections
description: A report on Dec. 10 about the marriage of Zerlina Stall and Dr. Edward J. Kaplan included outdated information on the officiating clergy. Rabbi Charles M. Feinberg performed the ceremony alone; Rabbi Erwin Zimet had become ill and has since died.

title: Subtracting Insult From Injury
description: Crew members of the munitions train that ran over S. Brian Willson in 1987 insisted that they, too, had been traumatized by the incident. So while Mr. Willson, whose legs were severed as he sat on the tracks to protest American arms shipments to Central America, was suing the Government, the train's crew was suing Mr. Willson. But last week a Federal judge in San Francisco ruled that the train workers could not sue Mr. Willson and other protesters for causing them emotional distress. The judge said that the crew could have stopped the train that Mr. Willson was trying to block, thereby avoiding ''the ensuing mutilation of Mr. Willson and emotional distress of the crew members.'' A lawyer for Mr. Willson and his wife said they were greatly relieved ''to be no longer facing claims that they are required to compensate the crew for the emotional distress caused by running over them.'' Mr. Willson's suit against the Government is scheduled to go to trial in April.

title: Susan A. Epstein To Marry in Fall
description: Susan Amy Epstein and Eric S. Aledort, 1988 graduates of the Georgetown University Law Center, plan to marry in October. The couple's parents are Mr. and Mrs. Stanley H. Epstein of New York and Dr. and Mrs. Louis M. Aledort of Tenafly, N.J.

title: Immigrants Swell Language Classes
description: Every time the young welder from Haiti called a factory or a restaurant about a job he'd seen advertised, he was told it was already filled.

title:
IDEAS & TRENDS;

Drug Treatment Is Scarcer Than Ever For Women
description: LEAD: WITH the population of drug addicts and alcoholics vastly outnumbering the available beds in treatment centers, seeking help for chemical abuse is frustrating for all involved. But a growing number of doctors, government officials and counselors say that the pressures are most severe for women, especially those who are pregnant or have children.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Streetscapes column on Dec. 3 misidentified the religious services conducted in the Church of Sweden by the Swedish Seamen's Church. They are Lutheran, not Baptist.

title: Towle Makes a Second Stab at Reorganizing
description: The turmoil of the last decade has slightly reshuffled the silver industry. At least one company, Towle, is in dire straits. One of the fine old names in silver, dating back to the late 1600's, the company in September filed for protection from its creditors under Chapter 11 of the bankruptcy laws - again.

title:
SHOPPER'S WORLD;

French Supermarkets of Stylish Wares for the Home
description: LEAD: MENTION France, and most shoppers will probably think of at least one of the traditional triumvirate of perfumes, designer clothes and food. There is no denying the pleasure of snapping up the latest tie or scarf at Hermes, dallying over the choice of a scent at Caron or Guerlain or indulging in bittersweet chocolates at Dalloyau.

title:
THE JANUARY REPORT;

Played Out?
description: LEAD: EVERYONE was depending on me,'' Jose Cavazos remembers.

title: Portrait Of the Artist As Elderly
description: AN 87-year-old woman once told Nola Denslow: ''They try to keep us alive so long, and then they don't know what to do with us when they succeed.''

title: Going to Pieces
description: Designers have uncovered their plans for this year's bathing suits, and the news is revealing. The two-piece is back, in plenty of new variations.

title: East Woos West in a Romantic Soviet Rock Opera
description: It took six years, the denouement of the cold war and the passion of a French couturier to bring the first Soviet rock opera to the United States. ''Junon and Avos: The Hope,'' which opens tonight at City Center, will offer New York audiences a taste of contemporary Soviet pop culture.

title: For Abused Women, Progress on Protection
description: LEAD: IN separate incidents a year ago, three Long Island women were killed by their husbands, despite the fact that each was under a Family Court Order of Protection. At the time, professionals wondered whether this would discourage battered women from seeking help.

title:
LONG ISLAND INTERVIEW: JOEL J. FLAX;

When Push Comes to Shove: Dealing With Runaway Youth
description: LEAD: SINCE April 1979, Joel J. Flax of Freeport has been executive director of the Runaway Youth Coordinating Council, a tax-exempt, nonprofit organization supported by the Nassau County Youth Board, the State Division for Youth and the United States Department of Health and Human Services.

title: Baseball Notebook;   Yanks Champs! In 80's Payroll, That Is
description: If there ever was any doubt that George Steinbrenner is the biggest spender in baseball, doubt it no longer. The Yankees' owner spent so much more money on players in the 1980's than anyone else that the Players Association should erect a monument to him at Yankee Stadium in the form of a giant, 24-carat gold dollar sign.

title:
IN SHORT;

ANTHOLOGIES
description: LEAD:

title: Giants Are a Bit Short In Playoff Experience
description: The last time the Giants were in the playoffs was three years ago, when they finished with a 14-2 record and went on to win Super Bowl XXI. Compared with the current Giants, the 1986 version was older, more experienced and more sophisticated.

title: 'American Power'
description: To the Editor:

title: Facts On File
description: TEACHERS are discovering that not all computer software comes puter software comes on floppy disks, and stupact disk can be used to store more than just the latest rock hits from New Kids on the Block or Guns 'n' Roses.

title: Ku Klux Klan Leader Plans To Move to North Carolina
description: James W. Farrands, the first northerner in 120 years to be elected Imperial Wizard of the Ku Klux Klan, plans to move to North Carolina, where, he said, the people are ''more genteel.''

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, a front-page article yesterday about protests in Bulgaria referred incorrectly in some copies to the position taken by the demonstrators. They oppose religious and cultural freedom for Bulgarian Turks. Later developments in Bulgaria are reported today on page 14.

title: Mysteries That Matter
description: If the cold war is truly over, isn't it time to bring its mysteries in from the cold? Eastern Europe's new governments have a rare chance to serve both justice and history by unlocking the secret archives of their former Communist masters. When tyrannies collapse so suddenly, there's little time to shred papers. Almost overnight, reformers have taken custody of billions of documents that could finally disclose the truth about some monumental mysteries.

title: Tour Grades From a Student
description: The success of the College Preview Tour depends on the individual tour leader at each university. The tour guide at Tufts was so enthusiastic about his school that he made me wonder why I had not previously considered it. However, the guide at UConn gave the distinct impression that four years there could the worst four years of your life.

title: Agents Meet to Coordinate Effort in Bomb Inquiry
description: Federal agents and law-enforcement officials from three states met this week to coordinate their investigation of the recent rash of bombings in the Southeast.

title: THE ANSWERS
description: Fold Back to Quiz on Page 32

title: Archie Bunker's South African Cousin Has TV Debut
description: The plot would seem familiar to American television viewers: an amiable white bigot in a working-class neighborhood finds his complacent prejudices under assault when a family of color moves in next door.

title: Buildup to a Revolution
description: THE PHOTOGRAPH ABOVE, TAKen in Bucharest before the overthrow of the Rumanian Government, illustrates a work in progress that will now likely never be completed. The Victory of Socialism Boulevard, a cruelly ironic name in the light of the popular uprising, is a three-mile stretch of largely unfinished apartment buildings and stores cutting through the heart of the city and leading to the Palace of the People, the government center that was opened last summer.

title: SPECIAL SECTION: Science Under Scrutiny;   High Hopes
description: TO THE AVERAGE American high school student, science education is often a lesson in boredom. There are hundreds of technical terms to memorize, outdated books to plow through and teachers who drone on and on.

title:
Style Makers;

Jean Hueges, Souvenir Designer
description: LEAD: ''I like to think there is something better then plastic Eiffel Towers,'' said Jean Hueges, the mastermind of a Parisian souvenir shop that appeals to the French as well as to tourists.

title: Virginia McGraw Becomes Bride Of C. B. Seaverns
description: St. Thomas Episcopal Church in New York was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Virginia Snyder McGraw to Charles Bushnell Seaverns. The Rev. John Andrew performed the ceremony.

title: FLASHCARD
description: MORE than 7 in 10 public-school teachers in the United States are women. Moreover, male teachers seem to cluster in specific parts of the country - in the North, for example, which has more male teachers than the South. Oregon, Minnesota, Washington State, Massachusetts, Pennsylvania and Wisconsin have teaching forces that are about 38 percent male. States with the smallest percentage of male teachers -about 18 percent of the teaching force - are Georgia, Louisiana and South Carolina. - National Education Association

title: A Late Goal Wins As St. Louis Rallies
description: Mike Richter, who had been both humbled and heroic in the most important game of his season, extended his left pad as far as he could, stretched out his glove as far as it would go.

title: Pastimes;   Bridge
description: The American Contract Bridge League has a membership of about 190,000 - just about what it was a quarter of a century ago. But a downward trend has been reversed, thanks to a number of innovative efforts to attract new members.

title: FLASHCARD
description: THE Federal Government provides three-quarters of financial aid to college students. States furnish 6 percent and individual institutions contribute the remaining 19 percent. Student aid amounted to $26.7 billion during the 1988-89 academic year. - The College Board, ''Trends in Student Aid: 1980-1989''

title:
IN THE REGION: Long Island;

Islands of Success in a Sea of Hard Times
description: LEAD: IN a housing market that has seen some developers mothball their projects and walk away until better times return, there still are success stories. And although they were the exception last year, they indicated a strong demand for houses tailored to the needs of the marketplace that offered what buyers perceived to be good value.

title: Kai Cramer and Mark Bergman Marry
description: Kainan Kelly Cramer, the president of Cramer & Sirras, a legal recruiting firm, and Mark Steven Bergman, an associate in the law firm of Paul, Weiss, Rifkind, Wharton & Garrison, both in New York, were married yesterday at the Army Navy Country Club in Arlington, Va. Rabbi Harold S. White officiated.

title: This Is Ridiculous
description: When I was a correspondent for The New York Times in Asia and Eastern Europe, traveling Americans often found their way to my office to read the paper.

title: PATIENT OVERFLOW ALARMS HOSPITALS
description: Health-care experts, unable to identify any single cause for the record crush of emergency-room visits in New York City last week, say the sudden accumulation of patients in hospital corridors is an ominous sign of the public-health system's flagging ability to meet the city's needs.

title: Reviews/Music;   Playing Bowls of Water: An Indian Tradition
description: The idea of filling bowls of different sizes with varying amounts of water so that each bowl produces a different pitch when struck, is both basic and ancient. It is also fairly universal: makeshift instruments of this sort have appeared in many cultures, although few serious traditions of performance on such instruments have come down through the centuries.

title: Bad Times, Bold Plans for Brazil
description: Fernando Collor de Mello, Brazil's 40-year-old President-elect, has some ambitious plans for his troubled nation.

title: New Zealand's Tougher Treks
description: WHILE planning a recent hiking trip to New Zealand, I mulled the paradox of the Milford Track. The three-day trek from lake to sea is so renowned for its scenic glories that it's billed as ''the most beautiful walk in the world.'' But the Milford is also a popular tourist destination and is strictly controlled by the authorities. On a typical day in season, two or three hundred people tread its mossy rocks, and the rules require most hikers to stay in huge motel-like lodges along the way. Not my style.

title: HAS FIFTH AVENUE BECOME BESIDE THE POINT?
description: There is a fragility inherent in the symbolism of every great street in New York: Broadway stands for a theater that is perpetually in crisis, Wall Street for financial empires that seem ever ready to decamp to New Jersey, and Fifth Avenue, perhaps the most celebrated of them all, for a luxury and a style that once seemed unique to New York, but now feels more and more like what can be found in every medium-sized city and shopping mall from here to La Jolla. Something has gone from Fifth Avenue, and it is difficult to put your finger on exactly what it is, since the avenue in some ways is grander now than it has ever been: today there are more super-expensive shops, particularly around the epicenter of conspicuous consumption at the intersection of 57th Street, and there are several new skyscrapers, including one of the city's most luxurious new office towers. The avenue is booming by most conventional measures, despite the abrupt and widely mourned closing of one of its great landmarks, B. Altman's, perhaps as beloved a piece of retail architecture as Fifth Avenue has ever had. (But Altman's demise is the result of an overleveraged corporate owner, not of any ailment attributable to Fifth Avenue itself, even though its location at 34th Street, south of most of the avenue's fancy retailing, didn't help matters any.) Fifth Avenue from 34th Street to Central Park has always embodied the most endearing side of Manhattan's ability to satisfy haute bourgeois fantasies: a street of grand shops, fine department stores, churches, and a smattering of banks, clubs, hotels and office buildings, all organized to make a coherent, though hardly repetitive, whole. As on all the best streets in New York, the buildings were different one from the next, but not too different: St. Patrick's Cathedral enjoyed a cordial relationship with Saks Fifth Avenue, Bergdorf Goodman had something to say to Tiffany. And presiding over it all for more than half a century now have been several buildings that are not only truly great works of architecture but active, functioning parts of the public realm: the Plaza Hotel, Rockefeller Center and the New York Public Library. To have its greatest monuments also be places with which the public interacted constantly, buildings rich in symbolism but also central to daily life - what street could ask for more?

title: Old Enough To Offer Help For Neediest
description: David I. Farber of Port Washington, L.I., received a $100 birthday gift. As he explained it in a letter to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, ''I got it for my ninth birthday. From my aunt. It was originally for college, but I changed my mind. I thought that I should give my money to charity more than college. Because I think alot about people (in New York City should have enough money for school and for shelter and food). It is my plesure to give this money to charity instead of college.''

title: POSTINGS: Ocean Grove Victoriana;   Seaside Condominiums With Porches
description: A small seaside hotel and an adjoining waterfront residence on Ocean Avenue in Ocean Grove, N.J., are being rehabilitated into 11 condominium apartments. The Victorian-style hotel, built in 1870, and the home, built in 1920, had been used as rental apartment houses and had fallen into neglect when they were bought for $750,000 last summer by the Booth Development Company of Ridgewood, N.J. Booth is carrying out the renovation in partnership with John Courtet & Son, a construction company in Morristown, N.J.

title: British Bullies Toppled From Pulpit
description: PLAYGROUND bullies in Britain may be learning a lesson or two these days, thanks to an experimental program that encourages schools to set up ''bully courts.''

title:
DINING OUT;

Outstanding Choices in French Cuisine
description: LEAD: IT'S a little difficult to find La Maison des Poeles, a French restaurant in Somerset County that opened in July just a few hundred yards south of the Matheney School on the main street in Peapack. This may be because the building does not look like a restaurant.

title: TOO INTIMATE WITH THE ATOM
description: GRAND OBSESSION

title: Bed and Breakfast
description: To the Editor: There are still a large number of reasonably priced B & B's in both urban and rural areas. There are plenty of people (probably the majority of B & B travelers) who are not looking for all those luxuries and amenities offered by these so-called bed and breakfast places. In my opinion such places should call themselves inns and omit the words bed and breakfast completely.

title: Drug Fight Attracting Recruits to Coast Guard
description: THE slogan on the recruiting posters has a definite savor. ''The Law on the Sea,'' it says. There are flags flapping in the background and the tall bow of a cutter slicing the waves.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We do not accept dictatorship.

title: Single-Handle Faucet Woes
description: SINGLE-HANDLE kitchen and bathroom faucets often feature replaceable cartridge valves. Signs that a cartridge faucet needs repair are water dripping from the spout, difficulty in adjusting the water temperature, hot water entering cold water outlets like toilet supply lines and inadequately heated water at some faucets.

title: JOE MONTANA: STATE OF THE ART
description: Through the writings of Kahn, Angell and Giamatti, the dynamics of baseball have been elevated to the stuff of pure poetry (''Joe Montana: State of the Art,'' by Irvin Muchnick, Dec. 17). Conversely, I have always believed a bias existed against football as fodder for good journalism and literature. The brutishness of football combined with the complexities of the game may seem daunting to the sensibilities of many writers. However, Irvin Muchnick's profile of quarterback Joe Montana was a wonderful ode to the talent of the player as well as the poetry of his sport.

title:
CHATHAM JOURNAL;

From a Fish and Game Agency to a Friendly Social Center
description: LEAD: ANOTHER day. Pat Jones rises from her bed, pulls on her socks and takes a running start before sliding across a lacquered wood floor in the ballroom of her home. She opens the blinds and turns the radio on low, the way her guests like it. The pre-dawn haze is beginning to lift.

title: Campanella Is Ailing
description: The former Brooklyn Dodger catcher Roy Campanella was listed in serious condition yesterday at the Northridge (Calif.) Hospital, where he was being treated for pneumonia, which developed after he was admitted to the hospital on Dec. 30 suffering from a cold.

title: On Language;   Trick or Treaty?
description: WE ALL REMEMBER the names of old battles and wars, but few of us are attuned to the nomenclature of peacemaking. ''Faraway Places With Strange-Sounding Names,'' as the song had it, form the basis of much of the language of treatying. Worldly economists and geopolitical scientists - the sort of people who begin their questions with given and begin their answers with absent - like to stud their argot with pact-impact.

title: Shopping Is a Pleasure At Some Stores
description: There are department stores that make shopping a pleasure. One is Nordstrom, a Seattle-based family-owned store that is coming to the Northeast. Another is Swezey's, a Long Island family-owned store with locations in Patchogue, Riverhead and Setauket.

title: U.S. Pledges Fund Of Up to $3 Million To Resettle Contras
description: The United States is prepared to provide up to $3 million to an international commission to begin planning the voluntary relocation of contras to Nicaragua, provided that democratic conditions exist there, the State Department said Friday.

title: For Poor Children: A Powerful Proposal
description: Imagine a mother who lives in a rotten apartment, whose neighborhood is worse and whose baby is failing to thrive. Imagine her going to five different agencies for five different kinds of help, waiting for hours in a pediatrician's office, leaving the baby alone because she's desperate for a break. To imagine her is to understand why Governor Cuomo's new proposal for Neighborhood-Based Initiatives is such a winner.

title:
BUSINESS FORUM: EUROPEAN CROSSROADS:;

Toward a Unified Germany
description: LEAD:

title: Co-op Troubles
description: To the Editor:

title: Belatedly, the 'Plot Against Harry' Hatches
description: Like a man who appreciates equally a good joke at his expense and his ultimate vindication, Michael Roemer recalls the day in 1970 that he showed the movie he had just finished to executives of Columbia Pictures. Written and directed by Mr. Roemer, it is an intricate but low-key black-and-white comedy about a small-time Jewish racketeer called ''The Plot Against Harry.'' The screening, an effort to persuade Columbia to distribute it, had been arranged by the late Bosley Crowther, who had by then retired as a critic for The New York Times, but who had seen the film and liked it.

title: Discovered: Four-Ton Flesh-Eater, Ugly, Vicious
description: THE name Epanterias amplexus doesn't have quite the ring of Tyrannosaurus rex, long considered the largest of the flesh-eating dinosaurs. But now the tyrannosaur may have to abdicate its position as king of the reptiles to its lesser-known predecessor, which stalked the earth 30 million years before the first tyrannosaur was born. While the creatures might not be quite as popular as they were a few years ago, when Macy's opened a dinosaur boutique, one can imagine toy and T-shirt makers rushing to obtain artists' conceptions of the newly appreciated beast.

title: THE NORIEGA CASE: The Trial;   Noriega's Prosecutors Seek Deals And Documents to Fortify the Case
description: Working on an indictment of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega that draws heavily on the testimony of convicted drug traffickers, Federal prosecutors are scrambling to make deals with co-defendants and searching for new witnesses and documentation to fortify a case that involves not only individual guilt or innocence but also the Bush Administration's political influence.

title: Cold Month Underlines Dependence On Oil
description: LEAD: AFTER a leap to near-record levels last month, the price of the oil that heats and lights Long Island was expected to subside, according to analysts, as temperatures moderate.

title: Wedding in April For Johanna Lief
description: The engagement of Johanna Lief to John Miller Socolow, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Edward L. Socolow of Chappaqua, N.Y., has been made known by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Robert Lief of New York and Weston, Conn. An April wedding is planned. Miss Lief, 28 years old and a graduate of the Tisch School of the Arts at New York University, is a television producer at A. C. & R. Advertising in New York. Her father is a member of the New York Stock Exchange. Her mother, Ginger Lief, is a partner in Kupin-Lief Associates, interior designers in New York.

title: THE NORIEGA CASE: Panama City;   New Talk, New Photos, New Army (Or, Adjusting to Life After Noriega)
description: With a collective click of their heels, hundreds of soldiers from Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega's disbanded army snapped smartly to attention today as their civilian President, Guillermo Endara, walked onto the grounds of the new Panamanian police force.

title: Soviet-American Base A Good Antarctic Idea
description: To the Editor:

title: Environmental Groups Work With Africa
description: To the Editor:

title: Seasonal Delight: Holiday Cards
description: I was sorry to read about your card anxiety, Elex Ingersoll (Opinion, Dec. 17), since I anticipate this seasonal occupation. It is such fun! Usually, I write notes along with the card, as well as receive a few from numerous friends and relatives who incidentally, have escaped me in these mobile times. It is great to hear from them and know they are still alive and well; a few of course, regrettably, are in bad health or have departed from this world. Either way, it's a yearly communication, and along with the long-distance cards, I send greetings to immediate and close friends. As a result, it is delightful to see the many varieties light up my mantlepiece!

title: CARTER REDUX
description: Your article on Jimmy Carter brought back fond memories of May 30, 1984, when my sixth-grade students and I gathered around the conference telephone in our school library, in East Windsor, N.J., to speak to Mr. Carter in his office in Georgia. They questioned the former President on issues that ranged from the peace treaty negotiated between Israel and Egypt, to deploying nuclear missiles in Western Europe, to friendship between China and the United States.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN: Boston
description: Boston in the wintertime has a nasty reputation. The snow flies, the slush forms and the wind howls on a daily basis. But the city is small and easy to negotiate, and the crowds are thin. Cars should be left at home if possible; the city's public transportation is reliable and fairly inexpensive, and in many cases it is possible to walk unless the precipitation is truly blinding, which is rare.

title: F.A.A. Proposes Fine of $70,000 on Delta
description: The Federal Aviation Administration has proposed to fine Delta Air Lines $70,000 and suspend the licenses of a Delta pilot and a dispatcher for operating a mechanically faulty jetliner last June 17.

description: To the Editor:

title: CONFIDENT AT 11, CONFUSED AT 16
description: THE ATMOSPHERE IN CAROLJU Gilligan's office at the Harvard Graduate School of Education could hardly be less like my own days as a Harvard graduate student - those seminars mired in torpor from which students were periodically roused by revivifying jolts of pedagogical bad temper. Professor Gilligan's faculty and student colleagues at the Project on the Psychology of Women and the Development of Girls seem relaxed and almost unaccountably buoyant as they gather around the conference table on a rainy Cambridge morning to describe their current work. Indeed the only face in the room that seems less than fully engaged is that of Virginia Woolf, gazing wistfully into the distance from a photograph on the wall.

title: NONFICTION
description: INVISIBLE MATTER AND THE FATE OF THE UNIVERSE. By Barry Parker. (Plenum, $23.50.) Barry Parker explores what may be the ultimate mystery in ''Invisible Matter and the Fate of the Universe,'' combining history, astronomy, cosmology and physics. Mr. Parker, a professor of physics and astronomy at Idaho State University, traces a line of research from the first faint questions about our own galaxy's missing mass in 1932 to those questions' growth into a major concern for thousands of astronomers worldwide. He argues that only 10 percent of our universe may be observable using current methods. So where is the missing matter? Moreover, what is the missing matter? Various researchers propose small planets, burned-out stars or stars that never quite started burning, black holes, neutrinos and exotic particles as the missing mass. Mr. Parker surveys the field and reports on advocates of these theories and their solutions to the mystery. He makes it clear that learning more about missing matter will be crucial in determining the fate of the universe. In an earlier book, ''Creation,'' Mr. Parker gave a stunning description of the first moments of the universe as cosmologists understand it. In the latter part of this new book he conjectures about whether the universe might continue expanding forever or eventually collapse back on itself. Guessing about the past is much simpler than guessing about the future, so it should not be surprising that this book is not as powerful as ''Creation.'' Both, however, help bring cosmology well within the grasp of the lay reader.

But now, bankers find themselves wondering why they did not see that the New England euphoria would soon come crashing to an end.

title: DATA UPDATE: January 7, 1990
Lessons From a Cat On Letting Go

She is out of the nest, on her own, flown the coop - whatever cliche we use to describe the process of an adolescent becoming an adult and leading her own life.

title: A Woman In Uniform
description: Women in the armed forces continue to be barred from direct combat roles, but that does not mean they are not prepared for the day that policy changes. There was praise all around last weekrr as word spread that during the invasion of Panama, Capt. Linda L. Bray became the first woman to command American troops in combat. Captain Bray headed a 30-member military police unit that was ordered to capture a Panamanian Defense Force guard dog kennel that was assumed to be unguarded but which turned out to be heavily defended. A 30-minute firefight ensued in which three Panamanian soldiers were killed. ''It was an important military operation,'sasaid Marlin Fiwawar,r, the White House spokesman. ''A woman led it and she did an outstanding job.'' For Captain Bray, it was all in a day's work. ''I joined the Army for the excitement, the challenge and loyalty to my country,'' she said. ''I haven't been let down a day.''

title: Schools Try to Sell Students on Lunch
description: LEAD: A MONTH ago, Asa Rossoffs won a ski pass to Mohawk Mountain in Cornwall in a drawing at Litchfield High School, where he is a student. Only those who had bought a school lunch that week were eligible for the drawing. And a week or so later, children at the Middlebury and Southbury Elementary Schools were given plastic Santa

title: The Voting Booth Stall
description: How much longer must New York City elections remain hobbled by outmoded manual voting machines prone to breakdowns? The decrepit booths should have been replaced years ago. Yet an indifferent Board of Elections still dawdles over the choice of a vendor for modern voting equipment. A 1985 study of the board's operations by the New York City Partnership, a coalition of civic-minded business leaders, set as a top priority the purchase of electronic voting equipment commonly used in other big cities. Former Mayor Edward Koch then appointed a special oversight panel comprised of city officials and private executives. But the final authority still rests with the Board of Elections, an independent state agency whose bipartisan supervisors are picked by party leaders.

title: Science Under Scrutiny
description: LIKE highway-fatality statistics, the numbers coming out of the National Science Foundation have lost their ability to shock. But for those who can still bear to look, there is blood on the floor: In a recent science test taken by high school seniors in 14 countries, American students ranked 14th. College enrollments in science courses are at an all-time low; of high school students who do enter college intent on pursuing science careers, as many as 40 percent drop out after the first course, 60 percent by graduation.

title: Traditions Offer Shelter From the World
description: AT Aunt Ruth's house there is always candy. And every child who visits there eats tons of it. Aunt Ruth believes children need candy. Their mother believes they need fruit. But she gives in, for the debate is a sham, and Aunt Ruth always wins. The children know to head straight for the chocolate as soon as their mother grins. She smiles for the sureness of it, the sameness of it, and for the wonderful ritual joy of it. For the certainty of vast quantities of candy at a particular time in a particular place is important in a world where much is uncertain and even less seems safe.

title: Pastimes;   Camera
description: Photographers equipped with SLRs and interchangeable lenses may have been tempted lately by ads trumpeting a new breed of lenses. title: DEVALUING THE TUSK
description: With his knack for publicity, Richard Leakey became an important leader in the campaign to ban the sale of elephant ivory and crush a flourishing illegal international trade supported by poaching. Last October, with strong backing from the United States, a ban was adopted at a meeting of the 103 member countries of the Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species of Wild Fauna and Flora (known as CITES and pronounced sight-ese) in Lausanne, Switzerland.

While the B & B's described by Mr. Berg are certainly a growing phenomenon across the country, traditional B & B's are hardly on their way out.

The Kitchen's Style Is Spare but Pure

In a way, the setting reflects the style of the kitchen: no sweet, starchy or precious sauces mask the clean, pure, intrinsic flavors of the food; fresh ingredients stand very much on their own considerable merit.

title: From Russia, In Love
description: If the world needed one last sign of new warmth between East and West, it came last week. Susan Eisenhower, granddaughter of the cold war's first general, President Eisenhower, announced her engagement to Roald Z. Sagdeyev, a former chief of the Soviet space program. The couple, who met at a conference on Soviet-American relations in 1987 and got to know each other better a year ago when she helped him work on his memoirs, admitted they had felt some trepidation about how officials in their countries would react. Mr. Sagdeyev, a member of the Congress of People's Deputies, said that when he informed one of President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's advisers, ''I saw, in a fraction of a second, his expresssion change from astonishment to shock to a kind of excitement.'' And after Miss Eisenhower informed the State Department, President Bush called to wish her well, as did former President Richard M. Nixon, the father-in-law of Miss Eisenhower's brother, David. Not that the two thought they needed anybody's approval. ''We thought that whatever people would think would be worth it,'' she said.

title: Our Suburban Children Could Learn Much From the Immigrants Among Us
description: THIS new year is the 100th since the last of my ancestors left Eastern Europe to settle in Connecticut. 1990 is therefore a coming of age for my family, and I've been thinking how fitting it is that our anniversary falls during one the largest periods of immigration in recent American history. These days, however, the immigrants often come from other directions: South America, the Caribbean and Asia. And it's anybody's guess whether these contemporary immigrants are more unwelcomed than my Eastern European ancestors were a century ago.

title: Pastimes;   Coins
description: In 1921, the anthropologist Wallace E. Armstrong travelled to Rossel, the easternmost island in the Louisiade archipelago of Papua New Guinea. He found a group of 1,500 islanders cut off from their neighbors, a group possessing a vastly different language and set of customs from the other Melanesian peoples of the area. Armstrong's was the most extensive visit by outsiders since an 1859 shipwreck left 327 Chinese stranded on the island - two survived, the rest were eaten. And he found what must have been the world's most complicated currency system.

title: Singular Scenarios In the Manner Of Adrian Noble
description: With ''The Art of Success,'' Nick Dear's earthy comedy about William Hogarth and his times, New York has the opportunity to experience the work of Adrian Noble, who, during the last decade in England, has proven himself to be one of the most consistently imaginative of directors. While his Royal Shakespeare Company directorial colleagues - Trevor Nunn, Terry Hands and John Caird - have been achieving international reputations, Mr. Noble has gone his own quiet but commanding way carving out a career as an intelligent interpreter of classics. With justification, he is considered one of the more likely successors to Mr. Hands when he retires as artistic director of the R.S.C. in 1991.

title: Pakistan Arrests Switchman In Worst Railroad Calamity
description: The police have arrested a switchman in Pakistan's worst rail disaster, in which 307 people were killed and 700 injured when two trains collided in a station, officials said today.

The VCR is turning the business of movies upside down and even affecting the kinds of movies we see. Movies will never be the same again.

THE NATION: New Rules;   California the Clean Faces Up to Corruption
description: NEARLY three quarters of a century ago, as their state emerged from its rambunctious frontier days when money and water equaled power, Californians imposed strict new rules of government under the idealistic Progressive Party Governor, Hiram Johnson. Provisions were made for the recall of elected officials, for lawmaking by public initiative and for nonpartisan local elections - measures emulated elsewhere and credited with having kept state politics comparatively honest.

title: Out of Office In the Bronx
description: More and more, Bronx political careers seem to end not at the polls but in the courts. Like the Bronx Democratic chairman Stanley Friedman and Representative Mario Biaggi before him, Representative Robert Garcia was caught up in scandal and convicted and now faces sentencing. In a move that his friends said was calculated to win leniency from the judge who is to sentence him later this month on conspiracy and extortion charges, Mr. Garcia resigned from office last week. The former Congressman and his wife, Jane, could each get up to 45 years in prison and fines of $750,000 on the charges, which grew out of his involvement with the Wedtech Corporation, a Bronx military contractor. The Garcias, who were found guilty last October of extorting $76,000 from Wedtech, have denied wrongdoing and are appealing. The six-term Representative issued a brief statement on his resignation, saying that serving his Bronx constituents had been ''the greatest honor I could ever know.'' He added, ''But I have always said that if I could not serve their best interests, I would leave office.''

title: Browns Hold Off Bills in Playoff Shootout

title: After A Fashion

But these days some public schools, too, are seeing salvation in standard student dress. Uniforms or dress codes, they reason, will put an end to clothes-horse competitions. Rules and regulation dress will not end the competitive spirit, however, or the exuberant self-expression exemplified by floating shirttails, over-the-shoulder ties, off-the shoulder jackets, untied sneaker laces, jaunty caps and colorful knapsacks.

So it was only fitting that the 8,000 or so invited guests who watched while New York City's new Mayor was sworn in last Monday comprised a most stylish group. Luxurious fur coats were in abundance, as were cloth coats with rakishly turned-up collars. About as eye-catching as the coats were the scarfs that went with them: white or polka-dot silk scarfs and long, colorful, African-print Kinte scarfs that nearly touched the ground.

In mid-December, the Vatican added to this library. With papal approval, the watchdog Congregation for the Doctrine of the Faith issued a 7,000-word warning to Catholics on the pitfalls of meditation derived from Eastern faiths.

IN SHORT: NONFICTION;

CHANGING THE LOOK OF MAGAZINES

Richard Avedon, a student in Alexey Brodovitch's Design Laboratory at the New School for Social Research in the mid-40's, complained he couldn't draw. Brodovitch countered, ''Why not to use spaghetti?'' Inventiveness characterized the autocratic Russian emigre's career, thoughtfully re-examined in an elegantly designed monograph, BRODOVITCH (Abrams, $39.95).

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. I have read about the problem that some people have with condensation forming between the two panes of glass in double-pane windows, but my problem is different. My apartment has windows of this type, but with a metal frame. When outside temperatures drop below freezing, condensation forms on the metal and then freezes to form a coat of ice on the inside. When this ice melts, water runs down onto the sill and soils the draperies. Can you suggest how to eliminate this?

title: Forward March

It turned out that the kennel contained more than dogs; inside there were also P.D.F. troops. The shooting began, and by the time it stopped, three P.D.F. men were dead and the American soldiers had captured the kennel.

Dentists lose hands down when it comes to laughing at themselves, as demonstrated by the anguished letters of protest over Barbara Klaus's column of Dec. 3 (''Smile, Darn You, Smile'').

title: SPECIAL SECTION: Science Under Scrutiny;   Losing the Race

A familiar air of crisis prevailed when the physical sciences faculty gathered for a special convocation at the University of California at Los Angeles last month to hear the Dean of Physical Sciences, Clarence Hall Jr., warn: ''Unless there is a revolution in the way we teach and the way we help students learn, it is obvious that the nation's economic standards will follow those of the test scores and the number of majors in math and physical science.''

title: NONFICTION
description: EASTER ISLAND: The Mystery Solved. By Thor Heyerdahl. (Random House, $24.95.) The explorer Thor Heyerdahl argues in ''Easter Island,'' as he has in such books as ''Kon-Tiki,'' that ancient peoples were more developed and mobile than modern thinking gives them credit for. Easter Island, off South America in the Pacific Ocean, has long been a subject of scientific speculation for its large stone statues, its cultural history, its language and even its plant life, all of which are distinct from those of its island neighbors. On his first visit to the island in 1955, Mr. Heyerdahl was struck by the similarity of Easter Island's sculptures to those of pre-Incan Peru. Scientists found numerous plants on Easter Island that exist nowhere else in Polynesia but do grow in South America - more evidence to bolster the legend that an early king arrived from a land to the east, a legend that had been summarily rejected by scientists. Mr. Heyerdahl, however, finds the legend both compelling and plausible. In fact, the mobility of ancient peoples has penetrated the public consciousness so thoroughly that his extensive arguments now seem almost redundant. The account of Mr. Heyerdahl's 1986 return to Easter Island is fascinating, as his team finds further links to South American civilizations and even to the ancient Hittites. Most intriguing is that scientists finally show how enormous 20-ton stone statues were moved from quarries to their resting places all over the island. The islanders had always said that their statues ''walked'' - were transported by humans - and, of course, the scientists had always rejected that answer. It is this triumph of ancient civilization and the humbling of science that should most appeal to the general reader.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: MARGARET OF THE IMPERFECTIONS, by Lynda Sexson. (Persea, $9.95.) In one of these stories about the tradeoffs people make between the hard edges of reality and their own more malleable inner lives, a woman is going crazy - or she might be witnessing a visitation from an angel. In 1988 our reviewer, Walter Wangerin Jr., said, ''Ms. Sexson's characters, drawn with strong lines like a Reformation woodcut - sometimes with grotesque exaggerations, sometimes with a limpid beauty, sometimes with bold and realistic good sense, always with a sharp, satisfying delineation - are much the makers of their own worlds.''

In one row there may be a middle-aged professional actor, an ex-marine who studies Amish philosophy, a wife and husband who separated during the term, a young day-care worker who hugs abused children every day, a French emigrant and an intelligence officer who says he was left to die in an outpost in Vietnam because he refused to perform illegal activities.

I scanned the beach in both directions: a David Hockney sky, light surf, talcum powder sand, the landscape punctuated by perhaps 25 beach chairs. This man has never gone to Rehoboth or Rockaway in August, I thought.

After the formalities, the debutantes held their own rock-and-roll dance in a separate room. There they kicked off their shoes, their escorts discarded their jackets and the dancing began in earnest.

description: Bill Curry, the football coach at the University of Alabama, announced today he would resign his job and seemed headed for the head-coaching post at Kentucky.

description: A dispute has broken out over accounts of the Panama battle in which American troops were commanded for the first time by a woman.

title: Rams Win Toss and Game as Giants' Season Ends
description: The Giants lost the coin flip at the start of overtime today, and the Los Angeles Rams chose to receive the kickoff. Sixty-six seconds later, the Giants' season was over.

What Price Art? Ask Japanese Collectors.
description: Japanese art buyers may have become a dominant force in Western auction houses, but in Japan this flood of money is increasingly a source of gloom for many members of the art establishment.

title: Upheaval in the East: The Dissident;   A Ceausescu Political Prisoner Says He Betrayed Ex-Ruler, Not Country
description: Mircea Raceanu, the last political prisoner to be released by the security forces as the dictatorship of Nicolae Ceausescu fell, said today that he felt vindicated but not vindictive about his time on death row here.

title: Bridge
description: Computers make possible some types of bridge events that would be impossibly tedious without them. Pairs events scored by imps, requiring many calculations, are now commonplace as a result. Thanks to a specially devised computer program, the first individual event on these lines will be Omar Sharif's World Individual, to be played at the Showboat Hotel and Casino in Atlantic City on May 6-10 with a prize pool of $200,000.

title: Frisch's Restaurants Inc reports earnings for 12wks to Dec 10
description: b-After a gain of $951,064, or 18 cents a share, from the cumulative effect of change in accounting.

title:
Designs for Europe;

Europe in 1990: Shadows of 1947
description: LEAD: As the Soviet empire crumbles, taking with it the postwar order, stability in Europe has once again become a central preoccupation. No clear successor order is visible, but the potential sources of insecurity are. At the center of concern are the future size and role of Germany and the fractionalization of Eastern

title: Corporate Management Group reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
At Electronics Show, Phones of the Future
description: The public got its first glimpse of what home telephones of the future will look like at the winter Consumer Electronics Show, which opened here this week.

title: Cintas Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Critics' Award to 'Drugstore Cowboy'
description: ''Drugstore Cowboy,'' Gus Van Sant Jr.'s tale of a small commune of middle-class junkies in Portland, Ore., was voted the best film of 1989 by the National Society of Film Critics, a 39-member group representing critics from New York, Boston, Washington, Los Angeles and other cities. Mr. Van Sant was also voted best director. The screenplay for ''Drugstore Cowboy,'' co-written by the director and Dan Yost and based on an unpublished novel by James Fogle, was also cited.

title: Travelers to Cut Back on Medical Coverage
description: Citing poor financial results, the Travelers Corporation has said it plans to stop selling major medical health insurance to individuals. Another large insurer, Aetna Life and Casualty, is considering a similar move.

title: Margaret Kelly, 91, Grace Kelly's Mother
description: Margaret Kelly, the mother of the late Princess Grace of Monaco and the matriarch of the famed Kelly family of Philadelphia, died of pneumonia Saturday at a convalescent home here. She was 91 years old.

title: Freda Corp reports earnings for 13wks to Aug 26
description: Revenue represent gross revenues.

title: Khmer Rouge Report Attacking Battambang
description: Khmer Rouge guerrillas said today that they had attacked Cambodia's second-largest city, setting it ablaze and forcing Government troops to call for reinforcements.

title: Drug Programs Needed For Mothers-to-Be
description: To the Editor:

title: New Markets Are Found for Large-Print Books
description: In a test to determine whether it should publish large-print books, Random House recently published a large-print edition of Robert Fulghum's best seller, ''It Was On Fire When I Lay Down On It.''

title: Cabot Medical Corp reports earnings for Year to Oct 31
FLURRY OF RUMORS IN A MURDER CASE
description: For the last week, the Boston police and the news media have let loose with a barrage of reports and rumors about the slaying of Carol Stuart and the apparent suicide of her husband, Charles. The case has aroused nationwide interest and inflamed old racial animosities here.

title: In Northeast, a Battle Over Fuel
description: An energy war is taking shape, as the owners of giant natural gas reserves in the Canadian Rockies prepare to challenge the oil barons from Houston to Riyadh. The battleground is the Northeast - the part of the country most reliant on fuel oil.

title: Bush's Double Vision
description: Most of the television news networks have rejected, respectfully but properly, President Bush's request that they inform him before they again use the common split-screen technique in broadcasting one of his news conferences.

title: Nets Defeat Hawks And End Slide at 5
description: For almost two weeks, the Nets had been wondering what it would take to win a game. Tonight, they found out.

title: Awaiting the Shakeout on Fleet St.
description: Rupert Murdoch's highly profitable British newspaper empire may be the envy of its competitors, but Andrew Knight certainly did not think he had landed a cushy job when he agreed to oversee the five newspapers.

title: Accounts
description: * Twin Med Inc., Santa Monica, Calif., to Mandelbaum Mooney Ashley, San Francisco, for its Epi Products subsidiary's home health-care products with billings of $2 million. The agency also won the account of New Zealand Fruit Co., Seattle, whose billings previously were $600,000.

title: Digital Tape Machines Expected by July
description: Digital audio tape recorders, which could become the next major advance in home stereo equipment, should begin reaching the American market by the middle of this year, two leading manufacturers said this weekend.

title: Reviews/Music;   The Residents' Dark Vision of American Music
description: The Residents have a peculiar way of showing how much they love American music. The San Francisco group has brought ''Cube-E: The History of American Music in Three E-Z Pieces'' to Florence Gould Hall (55 East 59th Street) through Sunday. ''Cube-E'' has segments built on cowboy songs (''Buckaroo Blues''), early blues and gospel music (''Black Barry'') and Elvis Presley hits (''The Baby King''). During intermission, snippets of American music, from country-blues to Gershwin, are played, winding up with commercial jingles.

title: Cambodia Emerges - After the Vietnamese Occupation.;   Phnom Penh, Eye on West, Tries To Shed Image as Hanoi Puppet
description: Since the announced withdrawal of Vietnamese occupation troops in September, the Government of Prime Minister Hun Sen has taken a number of steps to establish Cambodia as a nation reviving politically and economically, ready to change to get rid of its image as a puppet regime. The goal is to gain increased international recognition, especially in the West.

title: CULT LEADER SEIZED IN FAMILY'S KILLING
description: Federal agents today arrested a religious cult leader wanted in the slayings of a family of five in Ohio and numerous weapons were seized, including an AR-15 assault rifle, the authorities said.

title: Cam Data Systems reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
Crownamerica Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 2
description: The latest first quarter results included about $89,000, or 8 cents a share, in foreign exchange gains and proceeds from disposal of surplus equipment. Year-ago period included a gain of $349,000, or 33 cents a share, from the sale of its U.K. subsidiary in September 1988, and exchange gains of about $415,000, or 39 cents a share.

title: Upheaval in the East: Bucharest;   Rallies Criticize Rumania's New Leaders
description: The new Government of Rumania came under criticism today at separate rallies of university students and supporters of the revived National Peasant Party.

title: Reviews/Music;   Introspections Translated to Sound
description: Saturday night's concert at Washington Square Church, sponsored by the World Music Institute and featuring the flutist James Newton, the cellist Abdul Wadud and the komungo player Jin Hi Kim, seemed like the presentation of intensely personal music. The musicians are virtuosos, and they have an introspective way of playing that intimates that each phrase has disclosed some thoughts.

title: Bond Invites Buyout Offer
description: A spokesman for Bond Corporation Holdings Ltd. said today that the company is willing to listen to Jeff Reynolds, an American businessman who announced Saturday that he wanted to take control of the Australian company.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A2-9

title: Indians and Neighbors Are at Odds Over Waste Dump on Reservation
description: This desolate patch of windswept high desert seems an odd place for two seemingly disparate national issues to intersect: Indian rights and the disposing of mountains of urban garbage.

title: In Chile, Economic and Political Success Go Hand in Hand
description: To the Editor:

title: Macon Journal;   Georgia's Very Own: A-Wop Bam Boom
description: William C. Randall has nothing against the state song, ''Georgia on My Mind.'' As a gospel enthusiast, he admits to being moved by its mournful and bluesy evocation of a place where ''an old sweet song'' is like ''moonlight through the pines.''

title: Broncos Overtake Steelers
description: He has done this kind of thing so often that John Elway no longer seems struck by its magnitude. When he talked about it later, dissecting the plays and recalling the moments that brought the Denver Broncos down the field in the fourth period today, it was as if he were detached from it all.

title: An Economic Overhaul Has Poland Grumbling
description: Although the Polish people are famous for making huge sacrifices for causes they believe in, there has been grumbling aplenty this week in bakeries, butcher shops, train stations - and even economists' offices - about a program to overhaul the economy.

title: Only One Winning Ticket for Big Jackpot
description: Only one winning ticket was sold for Saturday night's $35 million Lotto jackpot, and if it belongs to just one buyer, it is the richest prize ever given in the New York State Lottery, officials said yesterday.

title: What Exactly Do We Want From Our Schools?;   'I Hate Cocktail Parties'
description: To the Editor:

title: In Bensonhurst, a New Course Tackles Bias
description: The memory and the lesson of Yusuf K. Hawkins's death came alive again recently in a high school classroom in the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn, not far from the street on which the black 16-year-old was shot dead last year.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Below are the major economic indicators to be released this week.

title: Chile Airline Stake Sold
description: Scandinavian Airlines System has agreed to pay around $15 million for a 30 percent share in LAN, the Chilean airline, LAN's president, Guillermo Carey, said Friday. Mr. Carey told the Santiago newspaper Mercurio that the agreement would not affect LAN's traffic rights, which include profitable routes to the United States and several Latin American countries. LAN, which was established four decades ago as a state-owned airline, was sold last year to a private investment group headed by Mr. Carey as part of a far-reaching program to privatize state companies.

title: Business and the Law;   Panel Urges End Of Diversity Rule
description: A 200-YEAR-OLD rule that has provided the basis for Federal court jurisdiction in many commercial disputes is coming under attack again.

title: OPEC's Output at 1989 High
description: Oil output of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries reached a 1989 high of 23.6 million barrels a day throughout December and will probably remain strong in early 1990 despite a new production-cutting accord, oil industry, government and shipping sources said last week.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: GOLF

title: Diane Edbril and Richard Levitan Are Married
description: Diane Edbril, a lawyer in New York, and Richard Mark Levitan, a medical student, were married yesterday at the Ballroom of Windows on the World in New York by Rabbi Steven Rosman.

title: Sri Lanka Tamils Retaking Territory
description: In a turnabout that is only beginning to be fathomed in a country at war with itself for more than a decade, a Tamil guerrilla army pounded by the Sri Lankan military and hunted down by Indian troops is closer than ever to its goal: domination of the Sri Lankan northeast, the homeland of the Tamil-speaking people.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Jan. 7, 1990:

title: Body Found on Prison Land Is of Man Last Seen in 1988
description: The skeletal remains found on the grounds of the Federal prison in Danbury last week have been identified as those of a 34-year-old Connecticut man.

title: Hungary to Raise Prices Over 25%
description: The Government tripled water and sewer rates today and raised prices by more than 25 percent on milk, meat and bread to move the economy toward capitalism.

title: Beeba's Creations reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Reviews/Dance;   'Cortege Hongrois,' Big and Cheerful, From City Ballet
description: George Balanchine created ''Cortege Hongrois'' in homage to Melissa Hayden on her retirement from the New York City Ballet in 1973. His third nod to the ''Raymonda'' of his Imperial Ballet days in St. Petersburg, ''Cortege Hongrois'' is an artificial blending of two elements of the third-act divertissements of ''Raymonda'' and a galloping salute to Russian ballet classicism, character dancing and spectacle. It is also the grandest of grand program finales and City Ballet gave it an appropriately large scale and cheerful performance on Saturday night at the New York State Theater.

title: Deltak Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Plan to Maintain Housing Dies as a Deadline Passes
description: With the backing of city officials and local lawmakers, a group of community organizers and private investors went to Washington recently with an innovative plan to save a financially troubled apartment building here as housing for low-income residents.

title: Church and State Clash Over AIDS Education
description: Robert Scott pays income tax but refuses to vote. He owns a safety-eyeshield business here but shuns the Chamber of Commerce. His children attend public schools but do not socialize with other students.

title: Keeping Their Eyes On Their Batons And the Bottom Line
description: A session of the annual Conductors' Guild conference was about to begin at Columbia University, but the 80 conductors who had come to the three-day conference from around the United States were more interested in making contacts and comparing notes.

description: The share earnings were adjusted to give retroactive effect to a 5 percent stock dividend declared on Sept. 7, 1988.

title: Tokyo Journal;   Emperor Stops for Traffic Lights; Is It a Portent?
description: A year to the day after Emperor Hirohito died, Japan today completed the ceremony of burying him, and perhaps with him some of the memories of Japan's militaristic past that shadowed the Japanese royal family through Hirohito's life.

title: People
description: * William M. Backer, president and worldwide executive creative director of Backer Spielvogel Bates, has been named chairman of the advisory board of the 1990 Clio awards.

description: Lawyers for Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega today ruled out any plea arrangement with prosecutors and attacked expected Government witnesses as lacking credibility.

description: JUST the other day, the National Hockey League's leading scorer, in town to spruce up his image with a haircut, stopped off at his customary diner for a bite. Nobody made a fuss, which suited him. Pat LaFontaine, on whose shoulders the Islanders are staking their claim to fame in the new decade, likes to leave the hoopla at the rink.

description: The new Government has dismissed an opposition party corporation that controls major utilities and services here in the capital, accusing it of inefficiency.

description: Bo Schembechler, whose 27-year football coaching career ended with Michigan's 17-10 loss in the Rose Bowl last week, will become president of the Detroit Tigers early this week, sources said today.

description: WHEN Amleto Monacelli, a 22-year-old little-known bowler from Barquisimeto, Venezuela, joined the Professional Bowlers Association Tour in 1982, he knew that the business of making a name for himself would be no easy task. After all, he had a sponsor to find, a language to learn and a lot to prove.

title: Landing the Bargain Boat
description: A SOFT boating market in 1989 is good reason to take a hard look at what the industry is offering consumers this year. The New York National Boat Show, which opens Saturday at the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center, offers the chance to shop and compare. Here are a few tips.

description: Like many of the people waiting to enter the Underground on Friday night, Yvette Garner knew that three young men, including two bystanders, had been shot in front of the nightclub a week before.

description: b-Net income The loss is primarily due to expenses of about $1,434,000 relating to the funding of its majority owned start-up company, Omni Solutions, a one-time charge of about $352,000 in connection with the termination of its acquisition of Ciprico Inc., and a combination of higher marketing and sales expenses and slightly lower gross margins.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE ECONOMY

title: Changes in Accounting Leave Big Firms Strong
description: Several months after mergers reduced the nation's Big Eight accounting firms to the Big Six, the leading firms have experienced little drop, if any, in their influence over accounting policy as a price for their global ambitions.

description: b-After a gain of $3.3 million, or 13 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting. The company said the latest 6 months' period included 26 weeks and the year-ago period, 27 weeks.

title: Many Covet Leadership of Education Panel
description: Although Assemblyman Jose R. Serrano has yet to announce formally that he is running for Congress, his colleagues are lining up for the Education Committee chairmanship he would leave behind if he moves to Washington.

title: SALVADOR LEADER LINKS THE MILITARY TO PRIESTS' KILLING
description: President Alfredo Cristiani said tonight that an investigative commission had found that the army was involved in the killing of six Jesuit priests, their housekeeper and her daughter at a university here in November.

title: Crew of Halted Freight Train Robbed by Masked Gunman
description: A gunman wearing a handkerchief boarded a halted Conrail freight train, robbed the crew and fled before dawn Saturday, a sheriff's dispatcher said.

title: Ault Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 26
Strategies for Salvaging an Off Day on the Slopes
description: ALMOST every skier occasionally experiences a down day when the skis won't turn, the feet won't stay together, you're up when you should be down, off balance and out of sync. The problem is not unusual; the best skiers in the world admit to down days. The difference is that excellent skiers have developed secret ways to deal with this trying condition.

title: Battered DeConcini Fights for His Reputation
description: Senator Dennis DeConcini began last Friday with a relentless, 75-minute news conference, answering one question after another about the intricacies of the Lincoln Savings and Loan Association failure and his action on behalf of the institution's chairman, Charles H. Keating Jr. Then Mr. DeConcini turned himself over to the less-than-tender mercies of talk radio, to the suspicions and inquiries of ''Jim from Phoenix'' and any other Arizonan with a telephone and the inclination to grill his or her Senator.

title: Interest Rates Are Expected To Be Stable
description: Credit market analysts expect money market interest rates to remain in a fairly narrow trading range for the next few weeks, despite the recent statistics that suggest that the Federal Reserve Board will remain committed to lowering short-term rates soon.

title: Shift of Control at Kao
description: In an unusual move for a Japanese company, the Kao Corporation said Friday that it was shifting worldwide control of two divisions to the United States and West Germany. A spokesman for the giant consumer products concern said the heads of the two divisions would be an American and a West German. He said its floppy disk division would be controlled by its Kao Infosystems Company subsidiary in Hyannis, Mass., because sales of the disks in the United States were several times more than in Japan.

title: Canonie Environmental Servces Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Joe Robbie, Owner of Dolphins Of Pro Football, Is Dead at 73
description: Joe Robbie, the owner of the National Football League's Miami Dolphins since their inception in 1965, died today. He was 73 years old.

title: Player Uses Shelter To Store Dreams
description: Donald Taylor is a basketball player for Prospect Heights High School in Brooklyn who prays daily to thank God for what he has. It is evident that he does not have much.

title: Elisa Amitay, Executive, Weds J. S. Mazen, Trader
description: Elisa Amitay, a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Noach Amitay of Tinton Falls, N.J., was married last evening at Congregation B'nai Israel in Rumson, N.J., to Jeffrey Steven Mazen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. David Mazen of New City, N.Y. Rabbi Jack M. Rosoff performed the ceremony, assisted by Cantor Marla Barugel.

title: 6 Children Die as Fire Sweeps a Foster Home
description: Fire swept a foster home in a rural area early today, killing six young children and an elderly woman, officials said.

title: Two Decades Of Suffering In Cambodia
description: March 18, 1970: Prince Norodom Sihanouk is ousted by Lon Nol after nearly 30 years as leader of Cambodia. With American backing, Lon Nol fights North Vietnamese troops and the Cambodian Communist rebels of the Khmer Rouge. From exile in China, Prince Sihanouk heads the Khmer Rouge liberation front.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;

New Operating Chief Is Selected at Centex
description: LEAD: The Centex Corporation, one of the most active builders of houses in the United States, has promoted William J. Gillilan 3d to chief operating officer.

title: This Year's Cold
description: It makes you cough. It makes you sweat. It makes you stare aimlessly at telephones you can't find the strength to dial and at television channels you haven't the energy to switch. It makes ''phlegm'' the buzzword of the week and possibly -heaven forfend - of the month. It's the thing that's going around.

title: Shira Tokayer Weds Barry Rozenberg
description: Shira Tokayer, a daughter of Rabbi and Mrs. Marvin Tokayer of Great Neck, L.I., was married last evening at the Great Neck Synagogue to Barry S. Rozenberg, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Nathan S. Rozenberg of Brooklyn. Rabbi David Halpern and the bride's father performed the ceremony.

title: MGI Properties reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: The latest year included a gain from sale of real estate investments of $310,000, or 3 cents a share. The year-ago quarter and year included a gain of $3,024,000, or 39 cents a share, from the sale of real estate investments.

title: 49er Defense Getting Tougher
description: After the game Saturday afternoon, Ronnie Lott of the San Francisco 49ers stood at his locker under the glare of camera lights and was quizzed about Minnesota's first drive, a 70-yard, 14-play and nearly eight-minute affair that ended in a Viking field goal and a 3-0 lead.

description: To the Editor:

description: Lee Stringer is 40 years old and lives in Grand Central Terminal.
