description: DURING the Giants' preparations for the Los Angeles Rams, the players were often reminded by Bill Parcells of the importance of ''understanding what goes on'' in the Super Bowl playoffs.

description: The television industry gathered to hug itself last night. The Academy of Television Arts and Sciences, which presents the Emmy awards, installed seven new members in its Hall of Fame.

Both quarterly income figures reflected the company's use of the LlFO method of accounting for inventory costs, which was adopted in fiscal 1989.

description: Senator James A. McClure, Republican of Idaho, said Friday that he would not seek re-election in 1990, ending his 24-year career in Congress.

title: The Man Who Saved the Subways
description: When David Gunn took over as president of the New York City Transit Authority six years ago, the subway system was a municipal embarrassment, a shabby symbol of a city in decline. As he leaves there is broad agreement that it has staged a remarkable recovery. That's a proud legacy.

title: Israeli Army Kills Infiltrator
description: An Israeli Army patrol shot and killed a Jordanian soldier who had crossed the border into Israeli territory south of the Sea of Galilee, the army said today.

description: Patrick Ewing has been the Knicks' leader all season, but last night, he was more dominating than usual.

title: Commercials Become News, And the Air Time Is Free
description: Advertisers are increasingly using their commercials not for the tried-and-true purposes of showcasing products or appealing to consumers' emotions, but to generate controversy that they hope will translate into free air time and press clippings.

title: Ferrer Sworn In As Bronx Chief For 4-Year Term
description: The Bronx Borough President, Fernando Ferrer, taking the oath of office for his first full term, told an enthusiastic Bronx audience yesterday that ''together we have begun to transform this borough'' from ''the national symbol of urban failure'' to ''the leading example of urban revival.''

description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $151,000, or 3 cents a share, reflecting the company's purchase, at a discount, of its convertible subordinated debentures. c-Net loss and included extraordinary credits of $531,000, or 9 cents a share, and $1,841,000, or 30 cents a share, for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, reflecting the company's purchase, at a discount, of its convertible subordinated debentures. On-Line said operating income for the second quarter of fiscal 1990 included $400,000 of non-recurring severance expense resulting from a management restructuring. Last year's second quarter included a net non-recurring expense of $1,547,000. title: Leo Burnett Quietly Builds Its Renown for Ads
description: At first glance the Leo Burnett Company seems to be a provincial advertising agency steeped in the cozy Midwestern style it has created for clients like McDonald's, Kellogg and Keebler. Every visitor to the agency, for example, is offered a shiny red apple - more than 400,000 are handed out each year at its headquarters here.

title: Ian Charleson, 40, An Actor Acclaimed For 'Chariots of Fire'
description: Ian Charleson, who won international fame in the 1981 film ''Chariots of Fire'' as a devout Scottish runner competing in the 1924 Paris Olympics, died of AIDS on Saturday night at his home in London. He was 40 years old.

description: The Ford Motor Company will make air bags for the driver and front-seat passenger standard on all its cars by the mid-1990's, Harold Poling, Ford's vice chairman, said today.

title: The Lethal Fist

title: Carena Development reports earnings for Year to Oct 31
description: Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Reviews/Music;   Pop Culture With a Strong Undercurrent of Psychedelia
description: Friday night's show at the Knitting Factory, the first of two put on by the New York-based avant-rock record label Shimmy-Disc, was fine if one agreed with one or more of the following premises: that collegiate humor is worth anything at all; that the early 1970's deserve thought; that the personal isn't as important as pop culture's power.

title: Liable for Action
description: WHEN it comes to contact sports, everything from bruises to broken bones are generally attributed to the breaks of the game, the inherent risks of playing a rough-and-tumble sport. But in Nebraska, at least, athletes who cause injuries can sometimes be held responsible for them and for the resulting damages, even when there was no intent to injure.

title: Review/Theater;   A Soviet Musical That Mixes Romance and Idealism
description: The most exciting moment in ''Junon and Avos: The Hope,'' the Soviet rock musical at City Center, comes late in the first act when the 19th-century Russian explorer Count Rezanov, joined by sailors from the Russian Imperial Navy, sets sail for America.

description: b-Included an extraordinary gain of $106,111, or 1 cent a share.

title: Shasper Industries reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-Net income Figures are in Canadian funds. The company said earnings were affected by non-recurring losses related mainly to the liquidation of the inventory of the Laynco division, which was closed in 1988.

title: DCX Inc reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: U.S. Woman Tells of Salvadoran Ordeal
description: Jennifer Jean Casolo, the American seized in El Salvador in November and expelled from the country after 18 days in prison, offered new details yesterday about her arrest and imprisonment.

title: Mikros Systems Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss Results from operations for the latest 3 months and 9 months included the effects of certain revisions to cost estimation procedures relating to the company's research and development contracts. All of these revisions are reflected in the 3 months ended Sept. 30, 1989.

title: Key Cases Before the Court
description: These are some of the major cases the Court of Appeals is to hear early this year. The court sets its calendar only a few months in advance.

title: Devtek Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Non-Persons No Longer
description: In the last year, the Phnom Penh Government has recruited increasing numbers of non-Communist professionals who were either students or public officials associated with the old Sihanouk and Lon Nol Governments.

title: The U.S. and Panama: Diplomacy;   NO MORE PANAMAS, BUSH AIDES PREDICT
description: Pursuing a campaign to smooth relations with Latin American countries, top aides to President Bush said today that the Panama invasion did not portend a new policy of using the military to pursue drug dealers or to police elections in other countries.

title: Clarke Taylor, Correspondent, 46
description: Clarke Taylor, a New York correspondent for The Los Angeles Times who wrote film and television reviews and articles for more than a decade, died of AIDS on Friday at Beth Israel Hospital in Manhattan. He was 46 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Banco Popular de Puerto Rico reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Harold Field Kellogg, Architect, 72
description: Harold Field Kellogg Jr., an architect who restored or altered 200 town houses in Manhattan, died of a heart ailment Jan. 1 at Cottage Hospital in Nantucket, Mass. He was 72 years old and lived on Nantucket island.

title: U.S. Disputes Korean's Account
description: The United States took the unusual step of criticizing former President Chun Doo Hwan's ''distorted'' testimony last week regarding American actions during the 1980 Kwangju incident in order to stem anti-American sentiment, officials said on Saturday.

title: U.S. Farm Credit Agency to Price Its Bonds
description: The Treasury's schedule of issues this week includes today's regular weekly auction of three- and six-month bills, Wednesday's auction of seven-year notes and Thursday's auction of one-year bills.

title: Review/Television;   The Life, Death and Secrets of Rock Hudson
description: Having spent most of his life trying to keep his homosexuality secret, Rock Hudson ended up having his AIDS-related death sensationalized internationally. No more hiding. The all-American guy, the very image of handsome ruggedness, was gay. Ironically, his death was a turning point in the strenuous efforts by concerned citizens, especially gay groups, to have serious attention focused on AIDS. Ronald Reagan, who for a long while would not even utter the dreaded word in public, finally began to stir when a Hollywood star was stricken.

title: Move by Russ Togs
description: Russ Togs Inc., a New York apparel manufacturer, picked Buckley/ DeCerchio to handle its advertising. The account, with a $4.2 million budget, was formerly handled in house.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Matco Mart Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $247,110, or 7 cents a share. The results are in Canadian funds.

title: Networks Seek a Winner After a Weak Fall Season
description: THE network television season so far has been like the lottery.

title: National Defense: Against What?
description: It won't be enough. In the 1991 budget about to go to Congress, the Administration will probably propose a cut of only $6 billion in military spending. The President and Defense Secretary Cheney will have to make deeper cuts. As the Soviet threat recedes, Congress will press to reduce the deficit and spend more for domestic needs.

title: Ewing at the Heart Of Knick Thrill Show
description: ''And here they are, New York's biggest thrill, the New York Knickerbockers!'' says Mike Walczewski, the public address announcer, before he introduces the starting lineups at the Garden.

title: Argentine Stocks Fall 53%; Inflation Soars
description: Prices on the Buenos Aires Stock Exchange plunged an average of 53 percent in value today when the market reopened for the first time since Dec. 28.

title: Giant Telescope Prepares to Take Its First Look Skyward
description: PLOWING through the final thickets of technical and human problems, builders say that the Keck Telescope, the largest and most powerful optical telescope in the world, will be ready to open its huge glass eye to the heavens this spring.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Many people will make up their minds on further aid to El Salvador based on the way this case is handled.''

title: Two Noriega Assistants Seek Haven in Embassy
description: Two of Manuel Antonio Noriega's top associates have taken refuge in the Peruvian Embassy, Panamanian government officials said, and today United States troops ringed the embassy grounds.

title: Crucial Time for New York Stores
description: In the embattled terrain of New York-area retailing, seven key department-store groups remain in the fight not only for customers but for survival itself in the most difficult period American retailing has faced in decades.

title: Archibald Tunick, 82, Ex-Connecticut Judge
description: Archibald H. Tunick, a former Connecticut Superior Court judge, died of heart failure on Sunday at Greenwich (Conn.) Hospital. He was 82 years old and lived in Greenwich.

title: Q&A
description: Mind Your Own

title: Parrots in the Snow: A Comeback
description: IN the rugged Chiricahua Mountains, where the winter landscape is shrouded in snowy silence, a handful of thick-billed parrots are on the wing, the survivors of a program to take birds seized from smugglers and reintroduce them to the wild.

title: Credit-Card Law Bars Requiring Addresses
description: Chalk one up for consumer privacy.

title: Interco Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $4,475,000, or 12 cents a share, for the quarter and $91,536,000, or $2.28 a share, for the 9 months. c-Net income d-After income from discontinued operations of $15,082,000, or 40 cents a share, for the quarter and $38,207,000, or $1.01 a share, for the 9 months. The income from discontinued operations for the latest periods included net gains of $3.9 million for the quarter and $78.2 million for the 9 months, both from the sale of assets. There were no share earnings for the latest 9 months after preferred dividend requirements of $62.8 million, or $1.57 a share. The year-ago periods were restated to account for the General Retail Merchandising Group as discontinued operations.

title: Promotion at Viking
description: Christine Pevitt yesterday was appointed senior vice president and publisher of Viking Penguin, the American book publishing company owned by Pearson P.L.C. of Britain. She had been editor in chief since joining the company in 1987. Before that, Ms. Pevitt was editor in chief of Charles Scribner's Sons. Marvin S. Brown had been president and publisher of Viking Penguin until last November, when he was named chief operating officer of Penguin USA. A spokeswoman for Penguin said the title of editor in chief ''has been retired for the time being.''

title: C. Robert Devine, 72, Ex-Magazine Official
description: C. Robert Devine, a retired executive of the Readers Digest Association Inc., died of prostate cancer on Saturday at Calvary Hospital in the Bronx. He was 72 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Indiana, Behind by 20, Defeats Michigan, 69-67
description: Indiana held Michigan scoreless for seven minutes, overcame a 20-point deficit and won, 69-67, tonight.

title: Futures Buying Lifts Stocks; Dow Up 21.12
description: Stock prices rose moderately yesterday, spurred by futures-related buying about an hour before the close. The Dow Jones industrial average gained 21.12 points, to 2,794.37.

title: Politics Aside, Flyers and Soviets Resume Action Tonight
description: Late last week, Ed Snider, the owner of the Philadelphia Flyers, reacted angrily when Aleksandr Mogilny of the Buffalo Sabres was ordered to sit out a game against a touring Soviet team.

title: INSIDE
description: New Transit Head Named

title: Opposition to Nuclear Power Grows Stronger;   No Disposal Solution
description: To the Editor:

title: A Handy Kit Provides More Than One Tool
description: QUICKSOFT, the maker of PC-Browse, likens the program to a Swiss Army knife: sure, you can buy separate tools to do the jobs it can do, but it brings them all together in one handy package.

title: 50-Year Sentence Imposed In 'Wood Chipper' Murder
description: A Newtown man convicted of killing his wife and shredding her body with a wood chipper was sentenced today to 50 years in prison after his sister complained he had shown no remorse.

title: White House Denies Plans For Blockade Off Columbia
description: The Bush Administration said publicly today that it was not planning a naval blockade off Colombia as part of its fight against drug trafficking. Some Colombian officials had accused the United States this weekend of moving toward a naval and air blockade.

title: E. Leland Webber, 69; Led a Chicago Museum
description: E. Leland Webber, who worked at the Field Museum of Natural History in Chicago as an usher at age 13 and eventually became its president, died of cancer Sunday in Evanston (Ill.) Hospital. He was 69 years old and lived in Wilmette, Ill.

title: Father Ritter's Slow Bleed
description: By one solid estimate, three of every four ''street kids'' who seek help in New York City seek it at Covenant House, the rescue mission for runaways. The organization's open door policy makes help accessible to hundreds of runaway youngsters who can't or won't navigate the intake procedures of other city agencies. The program also operates in nine other cities and five foreign countries.

title: Avondale Layoffs
description: Avondale Industries, a Louisiana shipbuilder, laid off about 300 workers, and a company spokesman said another 615 workers might be released to cut costs. The company, one of the nation's most active shipbuilders, has about 8,500 employees. It has a $2 billion backlog of work, but much of it will not begin before later this year, the spokesman said. Avondale's shares fell 62.5 cents today, to $12.50, in over-the-counter trading.

title: Review/Music;   Remembering Richard Tucker Telegenically
description: The tenor Richard Tucker, who died 15 years ago, was an earthy, colorful character, and one can only wonder what he would have made of the 15th annual Richard Tucker Music Foundation concert at Avery Fisher Hall on Sunday evening. The long succession of opera excerpts seemed at times a curiously bloodless, unoperatic if not anti-operatic affair.

title: Continental Plans $9 One-Way Fare
description: Continental Airlines introduced a $9 one-way fare within Texas and a few destinations outside the state but with several restrictions.

title: Readicare Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Included extraordinary credits of $157,000, or 2 cents a share, and $538,000, or 7 cents a share, for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. c-Included extraordinary credits of $90,000, or 1 cent a share, and $364,000, or 5 cents a share, for the quarter and 9 months, respectively. Revenue represent patient revenue.

title: 2 Studies Rate U.S. and States On Meeting Children's Needs
description: The Federal Government and 44 states are not providing adequate programs to help children in need and the nation is falling behind other industrialized countries in reducing infant mortality, the Children's Defense Fund said today.

title: Liftoff Of Shuttle Is Delayed By Clouds
description: A mass of clouds, rolling in with the wind as predicted, disrupted plans to launch the space shuttle Columbia today on a mission to retrieve a falling satellite. Another launching attempt will be made Tuesday morning.

title: Khmer Rouge Report of Raid Is Called Inflated
description: Claims by the Khmer Rouge on Sunday to have made a frontal attack on Cambodia's second largest city, setting it ablaze, appear to have been exaggerated, Western and Asian diplomats said here today.

title: Loss of Gas Disrupts Life In Chelsea And Village
description: Bonnie Munshin and a friend, John Setaro, were roaming the streets of Greenwich Village yesterday in search of a hot meal. Some restaurants were closed, others were offering only drinks, and still others were serving only sandwiches and salads.

title: On Horse Racing;   Two Surprise Choices For Eclipse Awards
description: rrIt's a good thing for horseplayers that no one was taking bets on who would win racing's Eclipse Awards for 1989, most of which were announced yesterday.

title: Rosedale Fights a New Holding Center for Aliens
description: To Federal immigration officials, the two-story former factory in Rosedale, Queens, is the answer to a long-standing problem: Where to detain foreigners who arrive at nearby Kennedy International Airport but are found to be inadmissible to the United States?

title: Eye Drug Approved By F.D.A.
description: The Government has approved a type of food poisoning bacteria for use as a treatment for two eye muscle disorders.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Accounts
description: * A.T.& T., to Wahlstrom & Co., for the Yellow Pages advertising of its consumer products units.

title: Goliaths of Frogdom Put Contest in Turmoil
description: An importer here has made some people hopping mad by entering giant frogs in an annual Frog Jump Jubilee: his contestants are up to 3 feet long and can weigh 15 pounds.

title: Less Expensive Infiniti Planned
description: The Nissan Motor Corporation's Infiniti division plans to introduce a model less expensive than its current ones, Bill Bruce, the vice president of the division, said today.

title: Judge Says Murphy's Movie Is Based on Buchwald's Idea
description: A Superior Court judge ruled today that the Paramount Pictures Corporation must pay Art Buchwald for a script idea that the columnist contended was the basis for the hit movie ''Coming to America,'' which starred Eddie Murphy. But the judge, Harvey A. Schneider, also said the studio had not acted in bad faith and was not obligated to pay the humorist millions of dollars in damages.

title: Recovering From the Flooding
description: Two water main breaks over the weekend - one at Waverly Place and Broadway, the other on Fifth Avenue between 18th and 19th Streets -disrupted utilities in the West Village and Chelsea. Water and subway service have been restored, but the following services continue to be disrupted:

title: B. Boszormenyi-Nagy, A Piano Instructor, 77
description: Bela Boszormenyi-Nagy, a Hungarian-born pianist who taught in the United States and Canada for more than 50 years, died of esophageal cancer on Saturday at Brigham and Women's Hospital in Boston. He was 77 years old.

title: Mandela Expects to Be Released Soon, His Wife Says
description: Nelson R. Mandela, the long-imprisoned anti-apartheid leader, indicated today for the first time that he expected to be freed within weeks, his wife said.

title: Way Stations En Route to Pros
description: On today's college sports scene, the image of the hungry inner-city athlete playing basketball and football as a way out of poverty has been supplemented by that of equally hungry suburban athletes playing golf and tennis with hopes of professional careers.

title: China Buys U.S. Wheat
description: China has bought an additional 300,000 metric tons of United States wheat under a price subsidy program, the Agriculture Department said today. Delivery of the wheat is scheduled for May. The sales were part of one million tons authorized for China under the department's Export Enhancement Program on Dec. 5.

title: From Adolfo, Accent on Evening
description: Adolfo's snappy fashion shows always share the spotlight with the Adolfo styles worn by his audience. It is usually against the rules for women to enjoy turning up in the same room with others in identical clothes, but the exceptions are Adolfo's shows, when everyone scans the audience to check the winning number.

title: Reviving Affirmative-Action Issue, Court Will Decide on F.C.C. Rules
description: Setting the stage for a renewed debate over Government-sponsored affirmative action, the Supreme Court today agreed to decide the constitutionality of two Federal programs aimed at increasing the number of radio and television stations owned by minorities.

title: Chronicle
description: STU JACKSON, the coach of the New York Knicks, has more on his mind than basketball. His wife, DR. JANET TAYLOR, is scheduled to deliver twins Thursday by Caesarean section.

title: Chief of Defunct Angola Rebels Offers Plan
description: The leader of a long-dormant Angolan insurgent group proposed a peace plan today involving a meeting of Angola's leaders, a United Nations peacekeeping force and free elections after an 18-month transition period.

title: The Choreographers In Man-Made Festival Ponder How to Learn
description: Stephen Petronio was 19 years old when he took his first dance class. Soon after, he found a sign on a college bulletin board calling for pieces for a dance program. ''I thought I might as well try,'' Mr. Petronio said the other day. ''There was a photograph by Ben Shahn of boys playing handball in the 1930's, and I thought I'd use it to jump off. I made a 30-minute piece, with 12 or 13 people from my class. Dancing in silence. What did I know?''

title: Pentagon Looks for Ways To Stave Off Budget Cuts
description: As the annual ritual of presenting and selling the Defense Department budget to Congress approaches, the Pentagon is searching for new ways to help justify its spending plans.

title: Chaump to Coach Navy
description: George Chaump, the Marshall University football coach, who has never had a losing season in eight years of college coaching, was named yesterday as the Naval Academy's coach.

title: Opposition to Nuclear Power Grows Stronger
description: To the Editor:

title: The Shortest Days
description: To the Editor:

title: Robert Graham, Policy Analyst, 74
description: Robert W. Graham, a former personal representative of Defense Secretary Caspar W. Weinberger at the Vienna arms talks, died Friday of respiratory failure. He was 74 years old.

title: A Seductive Tax Cut; Dangerous, Too
description: Last week every American worker began paying higher Social Security taxes. Suppose someone proposed to cancel the increase to help low-wage workers and also expose the true size of the Federal deficit. An irresistible offer, right? Wrong.

title: Diplomats See Barriers to a Trial of Salvador Military
description: Despite President Alfredo Cristiani's announcement that an investigation has revealed Army involvement in the killing of eight people, including six outspoken Jesuit priests, there are major obstacles to a successful prosecution, diplomats and lawyers here said today.

title: In Shuffling Cards, 7 Is Winning Number
description: IT takes just seven ordinary, imperfect shuffles to mix a deck of cards thoroughly, researchers have found. Fewer are not enough and more do not significantly improve the mixing.

title: Retailer's Fiscal Woes Are Reverberating on Wall Street
description: When the Campeau Corporation acquired Federated Department Stores two years ago for $6.6 billion, Wall Street beamed with pride as investment bankers and lawyers were showered with more than $200 million in fees.

title: Comptroller Cites Increase In Bad Consumer Loans
description: The chief regulator of nationally chartered banks said today that a significant number of consumer loans made by commercial banks were turning sour.

title: Treasury Notes and Bonds Drop
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds fell again in fairly active trading yesterday, as dealers sold securities in the wake of a big drop in the dollar.

title: Consumer Debt Rises At 7.2% Rate
description: Americans took out $4.24 billion more in consumer credit than they retired in November, the largest increase in outstanding debt in nine months, the Federal Reserve reported today.

title: Ash Gathered After Blast at Mount St. Helens
description: Scientists took samples of gritty ash from the flanks of Mount St. Helens on Sunday in hope of learning whether the volcano's latest burst will bring more explosive activity.

title: Navy Postpones Sea Search For Stricken Jet's Cargo Door
description: The Navy has postponed searching the ocean floor for the cargo door that tore off a United Air Lines Boeing 747-100 last Feb. 24, creating a hole through which nine passengers were sucked to their deaths.

title: Infested Traffic Lights
description: An irresistible attraction to electric fields is causing fire ants to wreak havoc on traffic signal systems in Texas and several other Southern states. As a result of infestation, researchers reported, ''The fire ant has become a potentially serious problem to the security and efficacy of signal systems in Texas.''

title: BRIEFS
description: * Cipher Data Products Inc., San Diego, a maker of magnetic tape drives, is negotiating a confidentiality and standstill agreement with the Archive Corp., Costa Mesa, Calif., about Archive's hostile bid of $8 a share.

title: 2 Deadlines Intensifying Pressures on Campeau
description: As deadlines approach for the troubled Campeau Corporation to come up with the money to meet its obligations, the company has given no indication of how it intends to address its problems.

title: Dr. Harry L. Shapiro, Anthropologist, Dies at 87
description: Dr. Harry Lionel Shapiro, an anthropologist and former curator at the American Museum of Natural History, died on Sunday at Lenox Hill Hospital, where he was admitted Dec. 23. He was 87 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Insider Case Accord Set
description: A Connecticut man who is said to have traded on inside information obtained when one of his tenants opened someone else's mail agreed to pay almost $20,000 in fines and penalties, Federal officials said today.

title: Ganse Little, 85, Dies; Headed Presbyterians
description: The Rev. Dr. H. Ganse Little, a clergyman, author and former head of the United Presbyterian Church, U.S.A., died of complications of Alzheimer's disease last Tuesday at the Sweet Brook Nursing Home in Williamstown, Mass. He was 85 years old and lived in Williamstown.

title: Children in the Groves
description: LEAD: When there is extended cold weather in the South, as there was last December, everybody suffers. But none more so than thousands of children of migrant farm workers.

title: Phnom Penh Journal;   G.I.'s Were Here. Gods, Too. A Journey in Time.
description: The road from Ho Chi Minh City to Phnom Penh leads backward in time, from a primitive rural 20th-century society to a still more primitive 19th-century society.

title: Pacific Telesis Plan
description: The Pacific Telesis Group said it would repurchase up to 25 million shares of its stock, totaling about $1.2 billion, based on Friday's closing price. The stock rose $1.25 today, to $49, on the New York Stock Exchange. ''We continue to believe that repurchasing our stock at current prices is a very good investment for our shareowners,'' said Sam Ginn, Pacific Telesis's chairman and chief executive. The company recently completed a repurchase of about 10 million shares, bringing the total number of shares it has bought back to 30 million.

title: Mellon Chief to Head Fidelity Bancorporation
description: In a move that caught many in the banking industry by surprise, Anthony P. Terracciano was named late yesterday to be chairman, president and chief executive of the First Fidelity Bancorporation, a regional bank holding company based in Lawrenceville, N.J.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   People
description: * Sam Rand has been promoted to president of Ketchum Advertising's Philadelphia office.

title: Chess
description: Three players won the 1989 United States Championship, held at the Hyatt Regency Hotel in Long Beach, Calif., from Nov. 9 to Dec. 3. Two of them, the 45-year-old Roman Dzindzichashvili of New York and the 29-year-old Yasser Seirawan of Seattle, were eminent grandmasters who had each won the title previously. The third, a big surprise, was the 20-year-old Stuart Rachels of Birmingham, Ala., the youngest winner or co-winner since Bobby Fischer captured the championship in 1957 at 14.

title: A Tradition Of Donating To Neediest
description: To some people, forgetting to contribute to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund is unthinkable. Their habit is ingrained by more than half a century of giving.

title: Wide Beliefs On Depression In Women Contradicted
description: NEW research findings from Europe, little noted in America, contradict widespread beliefs about the risks of depression that women face after childbirth, hysterectomy and menopause.

title: Volt Information Sciences Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 3
description: b-Included extraordinary gains on repurchase of debt of $215,000, or 3 cents a share, for the quarter and $385,000, or 6 cents a share, for the year; the year also included a loss from discontinued operations of $1,403,000. c-Included losses from discontinued operations of $315,000 and $2,107,000 for the quarter and year, respectively; the year also included an extraordinary gain of $5,355,000, or 81 cents a share, from a change in accounting principle. Latest quarter results included a gain of $850,000, or 8 cents a share, from the sale of a building. Latest year results included a gain of $2,513,000, or 28 cents a share, from the sale of its investment in Triad Systems Corp. common stock; a gain of $2,140,000, or 21 cents a share, from a settlement agreement with Triad, and an expense of $1,500,000 related to past years' workers compensation insurance premium adjustment. Results for 1988 included a loss of $206,000 from the sale of securities. The year-ago periods have been restated to conform with the current year's presentation.

title: Hanna-Barbera Follows Disney Map
description: David Kirschner is the Hollywood producer and illustrator who made his reputation by creating ''An American Tail,'' the animated movie hit that chronicled the adventures of an immigrant mouse from Eastern Europe.

title: Lesson From Frog's Mating Call?
description: FEMALE tungara frogs favor lower-frequency mating calls, and the males of the species have evolved to exploit this preference, scientists at the University of Texas report in the current issue of the British journal Nature.

title: Full-Blooded Candor Is Revived, and Evils Not of Dracula Unfold
description: Up at the castle, the truth, at last, can be told.

title: For Broncos and Browns, It's a Familiar Encounter
description: When they were done tossing cliches Sunday night, the Denver Broncos faced the one thing that has become their destiny in the post-season: the inevitability of playing the Cleveland Browns in order to reach the Super Bowl.

title: Limerick 2 Plant Opens
description: Ten years late and either several billion over budget or $382 million under, depending on how it's counted, the Philadelphia Electric Company's Limerick 2 plant began commercial operation yesterday, the company said.

title: 25 Nominated for Awards From Book Critics Circle
description: Twenty-five books were nominated yesterday by the National Book Critics Circle as the most distinguished books published in 1989. The nominees incude ''Spartina,'' by John Casey, which won the National Book Award for fiction in November.

title: Quake Jars Part of Alaska
description: A moderate earthquake was felt around Fairbanks early Sunday, but no damage or injuries were reported. Alex Medberry at the Tsunami Warning Center in Palmer said the 2 A.M. quake was centered 40 miles northwest of here. Charlotte Row of the Alaska Earthquake Information Center placed the Richter scale reading at 5 and said there were several small aftershocks.

title: Rate on Note Issue Set by Sallie Mae
description: The Student Loan Marketing Association, known as Sallie Mae, yesterday announced the interest rate for a $500 million issue of floating-rate notes due July 12, through various securities dealers.

title: Warm Temperatures Send Energy Prices Down Again
description: Energy prices continued to plunge yesterday as unseasonably warm weather covered most of the nation.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a mechanical error, two pictures on Saturday with coverage of Eastern Europe were reversed in some editions. The picture of a large group carrying signs showed Muslims demonstrating in Bulgaria as protests over ethnic rights spread; the other picture on the same page showed people gathered in Prague discussing President Vaclav Havel's statement that Czechoslovakia owed Sudeten Germans an apology.

title: Refugees Report Liberian 'Scorched Earth' Drive on Rebels
description: Refugees fleeing fighting in northeastern Liberia have told of a ''scorched earth'' policy by the Liberian Army, sent into Nimba Province to put down an insurgency that started there two weeks ago.

title: Baker to Visit Moscow to Discuss Arms Pact
description: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d will go to Moscow early next month to try to remove obstacles to a new Soviet-American treaty sharply reducing long-range nuclear missiles, Bush Administration officials said today.

title: Researchers Prepare For Fist Human Tests Of an Artificial Lung
description: A DEVICE that adds oxygen and removes carbon dioxide from the blood has been developed as a temporary artificial lung, ready for its first human tests. The device is to be inserted in a vein in the groin or neck and then guided into the body's main vein in the chest, where it can stay in place for up to a week, easing the burden on the lungs while they heal.

title: UAL Board Responds To Coniston
description: Buffeted for months by takeover efforts, the UAL Corporation said today that it had asked its financial advisers to explore the feasibility of recapitalizing the airline company.

title: Uranium Miners Inherit Dispute's Sad Legacy
description: From 1947 until the early 1960's, two Federal agencies struggled in secret over the fate of thousands of men who were being exposed to hazardous levels of radiation while mining uranium for the nuclear weapons industry.

title: Kiley Selects Transit Head From Houston
description: Alan F. Kiepper, a native New Yorker transplanted to the arid flatlands of Houston, was named yesterday as president of the New York City Transit Authority, a system struggling to be reborn.

title: Barry Shrugs Off Report on Jackson, Jews and Sex
description: Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. of the District of Columbia, facing another embarrassing incident, today brushed aside comments attributed to him in a newspaper interview in which he boasted of his sexual prowess, criticized Jewish supporters who have abandoned him and mocked the Rev. Jesse Jackson, a potential rival for City Hall.

title: Editors' Note
description: An article yesterday about the New York State Assembly mentioned seven prominent candidates to succeed Jose E. Serrano as chairman of the Education Committee.

title: DCNY Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
A Natural Laboratory on Hazards of Breathing Thin Air
description: THE thin air atop this extinct volcano poses a potentially lethal hazard to workers at the numerous observatories proliferating on the mountaintop. But the hazard has created an unusual opportunity to study the physiology of altitude sickness.

title: ALC Acquisition By Telecom-USA
description: Telecom-USA Inc. of Atlanta signed a letter to acquire the ALC Communications Corporation for about $97.1 million. Under terms of the proposed transaction, holders of ALC's common stock and its series B and C preferred stock will receive Telecom-USA units worth $3 a share. The holders of ALC's series A preferred stock would get units valued at $20 a share plus accrued unpaid dividends.

title: Grandview Journal;   One Town's Barricades against AIDS and Drugs
description: This western Missouri town has never reported an AIDS case and people here admit they would not know a crack house if they saw one. But the whole community is waging an all-out war on those and other social problems just the same.

title: Foreign Press Helps Bombed Bogota Paper
description: White paint, fresh plaster and new furniture still wrapped in plastic are signs that an international rescue campaign is restoring life to a newspaper gravely wounded here by a truck bomb.

title: Simms May Face A Tryout
description: For most of the last 11 years, Phil Simms has been the Giants' starting quarterback. Next season, he may be challenged for the job by Jeff Hostetler, a backup for the last six years.

title: Soviets and Partners Say Comecon Needs Repair
description: The Soviet Government agreed with its Eastern European trading partners today that there is ''no dynamism'' in their Comecon trade bloc but insisted that the association was needed and could be repaired.

title: Opposition to Nuclear Power Grows Stronger;   Commitment Is Needed
description: To the Editor:

title: President Quits Post at Varian
description: Varian Associates Inc. said to-day that Norman H. Pond had resigned as president and a director to pursue other interests. Mr. Pond, who is 51 years old, joined Varian in 1984 from Teledyne Inc. and was named president in 1987.

title: By Design;   Unburdening the Shoulder
description: They are not the first part of the anatomy that comes to mind as an erogenous zone. But when you stop and think about it, shoulders are pretty potent.

title: Tadeusz Brzezinski, Ex-Polish Diplomat, Dies at 93 in Canada
description: Tadeusz Brzezinski, a former Polish consular official and the father of President Carter's national security adviser, Zbigniew Brzezinski, died of pneumonia on Sunday at a nursing home in Montreal. He was 93 years old and a resident of Montreal.

title: Chronicle
description: JACQUES COUSTEAU has set sail again, this time for Antarctica. Along with diving gear and cameras, he has also taken six youngsters from six continents. Their presence is supposed to dramatize Antarctica's importance to the future.

title: Giants Knock, but Rams Answer
description: The Monday morning quarterbacks found many reasons why the Giants were knocked out of the National Football League playoffs Sunday by the Los Angeles Rams.

title: N.C.A.A. Eases Its Restrictions on Aid to Athletes
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association voted overwhelmingly today to allow incoming student-athletes to receive financial aid based on their family income, even if they fall short of academic requirements for athletic scholarships.

title: PRESIDENT OPENS LEGISLATIVE DRIVE
description: President Bush opened the legislative battle of 1990 today, attacking ''demagogues'' in Congress, renewing his demand for a cut in the capital gains tax and calling for a new five-year farm bill that would allow grain farmers more choice in deciding what crops to produce.

title: KEY RATES
Reawakened Volcano Spews Ash in Alaska
description: In its largest eruption since reawakening last month, Redoubt Volcano hurled an anvil-shaped plume of steam and ash more than eight miles into the air today.

title: Avibras Industria
description: Avibras Industria Aeroespacial S.A., one of Brazil's largest weapons makers, said today that it was seeking bankruptcy protection from its creditors. The company said one client had owed it $40 million for more than a year. People at Avibras identified the client as Iraq. Avibras, a private company, said it had $100 million worth of equipment ready for shipment to the same client, which has not been shipped because of nonpayment of the debt.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A2-15

title: Bryant and Tillmon Steal Show for Hoyas
description: When the exploits of the Georgetown basketball team are bandied about, the names mentioned first are John Thompson, the coach, and Alonzo Mourning, the gifted center.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;

2 Top Officers Resign Oklahoma Bank Posts
description: LEAD: Two Tulsa, Okla., bankers abruptly resigned their positions last week: Francis X. Henke 3d as chairman and chief executive of the Banks of Mid-America Inc. and James A. White as president of the holding company's First National Bank and Trust Company of Tulsa subsidiary.

title: Officer Quits At Doskocil
description: The Doskocil Companies, the Hutchinson, Kan., food processing concern, said today that its president and chief operating officer, David S. Smoak, had resigned last week to pursue other interests.

title: Jet Whose Engine Fell Off Had Repeated Repairs
description: The Northwest Airlines jet that lost one of its three engines over northern Florida on Thursday had a history of maintenance problems months before the engine fell off, aviation officials said yesterday.

title: Reader's Digest Adds Magazine
description: Reader's Digest said yesterday that it had agreed to buy American Health magazine for $29.1 million.

title: Phone Company Chief Selected for SUNY Post
description: Frederic V. Salerno, the president and chief executive of the New York Telephone Company, was nominated today by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo to head the Board of Trustees of the State University of New York.

title: Financing to Buy Bond
description: A 28-year-old Texan who hopes to rescue Australia's embattled Bond Corporation Holdings Ltd. said today that he was close to securing $3.13 billion to buy the brewing and media empire.

title: G.M. Denies Funds a Role On Its Board
description: Responding to two large pension funds that asked to be included in talks about management succession, the General Motors Corporation said today that such deliberations were the purview of its board alone.

title: Market Place;   Behind Delay in Farley Deal For West Point-Pepperell
description: It has been nine months since William Farley took control of West Point-Pepperell Inc. with the promise that all remaining public shares would be promptly purchased at $58 each.

title: Review/Music;   Composer's First Opera Reopens Schubertiade
description: Two years ago, the 92d Street Y began a Schubertiade, an ambitious series in which the complete works of Franz Schubert - more than 1,000 pieces - are to be performed chronologically in 10 annual installments. The series is patterned after a similar project in Austria undertaken by the baritone Hermann Prey, who is not only serving as the Y's artistic consultant for the project, but who is also one of the Schubertiade's principal drawing cards.

title: Argonaut Group Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Braves' Pact for Evans
description: Darrell Evans prepared for his 21st major league season yesterday, accepting a minor league contract with the Atlanta Braves just hours before the midnight deadline that pertained to him and two other free agents, Joel Youngblood and Carmen Castillo. If their 1989 clubs did not sign them by midnight, they would lose rights to them until next May 1.

title: Our Towns;   An Osprey Dies, And the D.E.C. Stoops to Ticket
description: It was in September that a man walking his dog along a creekbank in Kerhonkson came upon a wounded osprey, possibly savaged by a fanged animal, perhaps a fox or a dog.

title: Metro Datelines;   Police Officer Held On Drug Charges
description: A 23-year-old police officer was arrested yesterday for selling cocaine and an Uzi submachine gun to undercover officers from the New York Drug Enforcement Task Force, officials of the Federal Drug Enforcement Administration said.

title: Vice President Named To Intel's Top Team
description: The Intel Corporation named Craig R. Barrett its executive vice president yesterday, a move that makes him the likely heir apparent to Andrew S. Grove as president and chief executive officer of the semiconductor manufacturer. Dr. Grove, who is 53 years old, has said he will retire at 55.

title: Bronko Nagurski Is Dead at 81; Star Runner for Chicago Bears
description: Bronko Nagurski, whose great strength as a running back and tackler seemed to football fans of the 1920's and 1930's the epitome of bonecrushing power, died Sunday night at Falls Memorial Hospital in International Falls, Minn. He was 81 years old.

title: Doctor's Lawyer Blames Hospital In Trial on AIDS
description: A 32-year-old doctor is dying of AIDS because of improper hospital procedures, the doctor's lawyer said yesterday during opening statements in a $175 million lawsuit in Brooklyn.

title: LARGE BANKS CUT KEY LENDING RATE TO 10% FROM 10 1/2%
description: The nation's largest banks yesterday reduced the prime rate to 10 percent, from 10 1/2 percent, the first cut in the closely watched lending rate since July.

title: Kentucky Hires Curry
description: Bill Curry, who resigned Sunday as head coach at Alabama, became the coach at Kentucky yesterday after his hiring was approved by the board of directors of the school's Athletics Association.

title: Books of The Times;   Letters From an Unlikely Literary Friendship
description: Henry James and Edith Wharton

title: Hack Politics for Public Education
description: It sounded like somebody's idea of a parody. Arthur Katzman, the New York City Council's new Education Committee chairman, said, ''With the black and Hispanic children, there appears to be no liking of learning.'' It was no parody. The 85-year-old lawmaker apologized yesterday, saying he'd been ''insensitive'' and had meant merely to make a point about poverty.

title: Edward Ennis, 82, Ex-Prosecutor And Head of Civil Liberties Union
description: Edward J. Ennis, a former Federal prosecutor who became chairman of the American Civil Liberties Union, died of complications of diabetes on Sunday at Lenox Hill Hospital. He was 82 years old and had homes in Manhattan; Lido Beach, L.I., and Palm Beach, Fla.

title: Photronic Labs reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net loss and included tax benefits of $700,000 and $1,025,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: U.S. Faulted for Search of Nicaragua Residence in Panama
description: The Organization of American States declared in a resolution tonight that the penetration by American troops of the Nicaraguan Ambassador's residence in Panama was a violation of international laws that insure the immunity of diplomatic missions.

title: '90 Detroit Church Closings
description: The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of Detroit announced Sunday that it would close five more churches in the city this year. The diocese closed 30 last year. The five parishes were among 25 subjected to a yearlong test of viability by Edmund Cardinal Szoka. Nineteen parishes passed the test and one new parish will be formed from two of those to be closed, said Jay Berman, a diocesan spokesman. Eighty-two parishes will remain after the new round of closings, he said.

title: U.S. Tells Calmer Story of Woman's Role in Commanding Attack
description: The United States military, seeking to clarify differing accounts of a firefight involving a female military police captain in the Panama invasion, today provided a detailed description of the episode that was less dramatic than the version presented by the White House and initial news reports.

title: Dinkins to Cut Spending More Than $200 Million
description: The Dinkins administration yesterday sent New York City agencies requests for spending cuts ranging from one-half of 1 percent to 4 percent of their budgets to help close a projected total budget gap of more than $200 million in the current fiscal year.

title: Knogo Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Addendum
description: * Metropolitan Outdoor, an outdoor advertising company, has acquired eight-sheet operations of Transportation Displays Inc., which was formerly called AMNI America, in New York and Los Angeles for $30 million.

title: Grand Met Deal
description: Grand Metropolitan P.L.C. said it would buy 20 Wimpy restaurants in Britain and convert them to Burger King outlets. In announcing the purchase from Allied Leisure P.L.C. of London, Grand Met said the sale was to be completed by Jan. 29. No terms were disclosed. In the last three months, Burger King has doubled the number of its outlets in Britain and now operates 60 restaurants there. It operates about 6,000 restaurants worldwide, including more than 5,400 in the United States.

title: Ex-Boesky Partners Get $248 Million Settlement
description: A group of limited partners of Ivan F. Boesky, the arbitrager who pleaded guilty to securities fraud, received a $248 million payment yesterday, in the culmination of a complex settlement reached in recent months among Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., the partners, Mr. Boesky and other parties.

title: Panama, Without an Army
description: Our Panamanian brothers and sisters have lived through difficult times, but new opportunities lie open for them. We must all collaborate with Panama and its people for them to overcome the challenges they face today, and, in this hour of great confusion and violence, for them to undertake historical decisions that may change that country's destiny forever.

title: Military Trials of Security Forces Begin
description: The new Government announced today that special military courts had begun proceedings against members of the state security forces who were caught shooting at civilians after the fall of President Nicolae Ceausescu on Dec. 22.

title: Brave Stand for Justice in El Salvador
description: In El Salvador, which too often resembles an army with a country attached, a conservative civilian President now links the military to a barbarous human rights crime. In a nationally broadcast speech, Alfredo Cristiani said that ''elements'' of the armed forces were indeed involved in the November slaying of six Jesuit priests, their housekeeper and her daughter. That was the finding of a high-level special commission named by Mr. Cristiani ''to deduce responsibility and make sure justice is done.''

title: Police Kill 12 in Kashmir Riots
description: Paramilitary troops shot and killed at least 12 people today during anti-Indian riots in parts of the Kashmir valley, officials there said.

title: Fare-Card System Coming to New York City Subway and Buses
description: To the Editor:

title: Chronicle
description: In his memoirs, ''A Native's Return: 1945-1988,'' arriving in bookstores this week, WILLIAM L. SHIRER offers his version of why he was dismissed from CBS in 1947 after a successful career as a war correspondent and broadcaster.

title: Lemieux Scores 4 Against Lackluster Rangers
description: Mario Lemieux didn't set a record for filling the net last night. He might have, though, established an unofficial mark for emptying Madison Square Garden. Lemieux, who had four goals before the game was 25 minutes old, drove the Rangers to distraction and defeat, and in the process sent the crowd of 15,849 streaming into the streets with a full third left in a miserable 7-5 mismatch.

title: Georgia-Pacific's Nekoosa Shares
description: The Georgia-Pacific Corporation said it had been tendered 41.4 million shares, or more than 75 percent, in its offer for a rival papermaker, the Great Northern Nekoosa Corporation Georgia-Pacific also extended its sweetened hostile bid of $63 a share, or $3.6 billion, to Jan. 22. The previous bid expired on Friday.

title: Review/Television;   New Co-host on 'Today' Eases Her Way Into the Job
description: After weeks of made-for-television promotion and emotion, Jane Pauley's seat on ''Today'' was occupied yesterday by Deborah Norville, beginning what her co-host, Bryant Gumbel, called ''an exciting new chapter in the rich history of this program.'' How did Ms. Norville, NBC's new star, do on her first day? Well, she lived up to the requirements of the job.

title: Talking Business; with Kelly of Resolution Trust;   Property Auction On an Epic Scale
description: Lamar C. Kelly Jr. is the Government official with the task of organizing the sales of thousands of single-family homes, apartments, office buildings and other properties held by hundreds of troubled savings institutions now controlled by the Resolution Trust Corporation.

title: What's Bad About Acting Like Hulk?
description: rrAll right, who's going to leave the tickets for Jerry Glanville? He brought a bit of color into our lives by pacing up and down the sidelines in all black garb, a mix of Johnny Cash and Darth Vader.

title: Terry-Thomas, 78, Actor Who Satirized Britons
description: Terry-Thomas, the comedian and character actor who satirized virtually every type of Briton from upper-class cads to crooks, from dandies to daredevils, died of Parkinson's disease yesterday at a nursing home in Godalming, Surrey, England. He was 78 years old.

title: U.S. Falls Short On Its Debt Plan For Third World
description: In the 10 months since it was announced, the Bush Administration's strategy for easing third world debt has fallen well short of its stated objective.

title: DISCORD IN BERLIN ON SECRET POLICE
description: East German groups advocating democracy today forced an early adjournment of weekly talks with the Communist Party on the nation's future, demanding proof that the secret police were being disbanded as promised.

title: Year of Elections
description: This is going to be the year of elections, in the U.S. and West Germany, because elections come with regularity. In the Soviet Union, local and municipal elections will be part of Mikhail Gorbachev's effort to get rid of the old apparatus paralyzing his perestroika.

title: Temple H. Buell, 94, Philanthropist, Is Dead
description: Temple Hoyne Buell, an architect, developer and philanthropist, died Friday at his home in Denver. He was 94 years old.

title: Joseph V. Giffuni, 77, Builder and Developer
description: Joseph V. Giffuni, a New York City builder and real-estate developer, died on Friday at his home on the Upper East Side. He was 77 years old.

title: Teledyne Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included gains on sales of investments, after tax, of $77.6 million.

title: Governments Minimizing Message of 'Drug Wars'
description: More than any other single event in recent times, the murder of a United States Drug Enforcement Administration agent in Mexico five years ago soured relations between the two countries. Now, Mexican and American officials fear that a television mini-series about the murder could reopen those wounds, and they are seeking to blunt the program's impact through an unusual exercise in television diplomacy.

title: Metro Datelines;   Police Investigating How a Patient Died
description: The police and the Brooklyn District Attorney are investigating whether a hospital patient's life-support equipment was tampered with, causing his death yesterday.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Electronics Retailer Hires 'Crazy' Pitchman
description: Crazy Eddie may be bankrupt, but Jerry Carroll's career as an electronics pitchman continues. Mr. Carroll, who screamed the praises of Crazy Eddie's ''insane'' low prices for 17 years, has agreed to create a character for Sixth Avenue Electronics, which operates two stores in Manhattan and one in Paramus, N.J.

title: Bayly Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: Revenue represents total revenues.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Can Shops Stay Small And Alone?
description: ''THERE is a fresh new wind blowing in the advertising business,'' James H. Quest said two years ago about the improved prospects for small national agencies, citing client dissatisfaction with the conglomeration of the industry.

title: New Details, but No Answers, in Killings
description: While investigators remained tight-lipped about possible motives in the Stuart shooting and suicide case, new details emerged today about the activities of Charles Stuart, who jumped to his death from a bridge last week after learning that he was a suspect in the slaying of his wife and baby son.

title: Metro Datelines;   Bomb Case Figure Receives Probation
description: An animal-rights advocate was sentenced yesterday to the time she has spent in jail and three years of supervised probation for possession of two powerful pipe bombs found in her Queens apartment.

title: For Type With a Twist, Programs Make It Easy
description: IF we wanted the headline on this column to curve in a graceful arc, the printers in the newspaper composing room would have a fit. Wrapping letters along a curve takes technical and artistic skill, which they have in abundance, but it also takes a lot of time, which they lack.

title: Color and Curves From Burrows
description: The newest designer to introduce a collection of custom-made clothes is Stephen Burrows. He is to present the mostly jersey collection at the photography studio of Charles Tracy this morning, just six months after he introduced his first ready-to-wear collection in eight years.

title: Engineer Leads Morrison Knudsen Unit
description: Walter C. Bell, an engineer who has overseen construction projects in the Middle East, Asia and Latin America, has been named president and chief executive of international activities of the Morrison Knudsen Corporation. He has been given the mission of directing the giant construction and engineering company's aggressive re-entry into the worldwide market.

title: Joe Robbie, 73, N.F.L. Owner Who Founded Miami Dolphins
description: Joe Robbie, the owner of the National Football League's Miami Dolphins since their inception in 1965, died Sunday. He was 73 years old.

title: Horse Racing's Oscars
description: Here is the voting for thoroughbred racing's Eclipse Awards of 1989, which were announced yesterday. The Horse of the Year and the awards for champion jockey and trainer will be announced Jan. 27.

title: OFFICIALS PLANNING TO MOVE NORIEGA
description: The Federal authorities plan to move Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega from a holding cell in Miami to a more secure prison out of state, and the likely site is the Federal penitentiary in Atlanta, a person involved in the move said today.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an entry in the Executive Changes listing of Business Day on Thursday misidentified a British conglomerate and located a division incorrectly. The company is Hanson P.L.C., and its Weber Aircraft division is in Fullerton, Calif.

title: Birthday Celebration In Nixon's Hometown
description: Former President Richard M. Nixon's 77th birthday on Tuesday is a holiday in his hometown, which is proudly planning for this summer's opening of the Nixon Presidential library.

title: Detroit Tigers Name Schembechler President
description: Bo Schembechler, who recently retired as football coach at Michigan, has decided to devote his organizational skills to baseball.

title: AMTRAK REVENUE AT ALL-TIME HIGH
description: Despite a slight decline in the number of passengers on its trains, Amtrak reported yesterday that it earned record revenue last year, reducing its reliance on Federal subsidies to the lowest level ever.

title: Voices of Bulgaria Tell Story of Hate
description: Around the equestrian statue of Czar Alexander II, the 19th-century Russian liberator of Bulgaria from Turkish domination, the talk today was of civil rights and racism, of patriotism and perfidy.

title: Results Plus
description: N.B.A.

title: Op-Ed Columnists
description: The days on which Op-Ed columnists appear are customarily rotated every six months.

title: Councilman Issues Apology For Comments on Minorities
description: The chairman of the City Council's Education Committee apologized yesterday for what he acknowledged was his insensitivity in saying that among black and Hispanic children ''there appears to be no liking of learning.''

title: Conditions Threaten Collections At Museum of City of New York
description: The 58-year-old building that houses the Museum of the City of New York has deteriorated to such an extent that its director says its collections are in jeopardy. The museum houses a vast store of New York artifacts, from elegant doll houses to vintage fire engines.

title: Dawn Steel Quits Columbia Pictures Post
description: With her left leg in an ankle-to-thigh brace and a smile on her face, Dawn Steel resigned today from her position as president of Columbia Pictures.

title: Doug Jones Arbitration
description: Doug Jones, the Cleveland Indians' ace relief pitcher, is seeking $1.15 million in salary arbitration. Jones, who last year earned $307,500, submitted that figure yesterday. The Indians filed a salary of $950,000 for the pitcher, whose 69 saves the past two seasons are only 3 fewer than the 72 compiled by Mark Davis for San Diego.

title: Careers;   Ever-Rising Demand for Paralegals
description: THE Labor Department recently estimated that the need for paralegals would increase by 75.3 percent between 1988 and 2000, making paralegal work the nation's fastest-growing field. Its projection: the 83,000 paralegals employed nationwide in 1988 will increase to 145,000 by the turn of the century because of rapid growth of the legal services industry as well as widening use of paralegals in corporations and elsewhere.

title: Digital Communications reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain on the sale of assets of $3,867,000, or 26 cents a share, for both periods. The company said the gain is the net result of a gain on the sale of its Network Communications Group and the writeoff of certain assets. c-Net loss d-Included an unusual charge of $12,579,000 for research and development costs for the quarter and 6 months.

title: Missile Attack on Tokyo Royalty
description: Two homemade missiles struck near the home of Emperor Akihito's brother today and a third missile was found outside the Imperial Garden in Kyoto, the police said. No casualties or damage were reported.

title: Elynuik's Late Goal Ends Devils' Winning Streak
description: The Devils were slow tonight breaking out of their defensive zone and they showed little coordination in the neutral and attacking zone. This inability to attack against Winnipeg led to a 4-3 victory by the Jets at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Acclaim Entertainment, Oyster Bay, L.I., a home-entertainment products company, promoted Robert Holmes to president.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Chronicle column yesterday about the chairmanship of the John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington misidentified the orchestra associated with the center. It is the National Symphony Orchestra, not the American Symphony.

title: Horace C. Stoneham, 86, Owner Who Moved Giants to West Coast
description: Horace C. Stoneham, the longtime owner of the baseball Giants who moved the club from New York to San Francisco in 1958, died in a nursing home in Scottsdale, Ariz., Sunday. He was 86 years old.

title: Lotto Bunkum and Bubbly Get Reporters to Bite Again
description: New York City's news organizations were the target of an elaborate hoax on Sunday in which a professional actress claimed to have won the $35 million Lotto jackpot in Saturday night's lottery drawing.

title: Lazare Kaplan International reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-After extraordinary credits of $346,000, or 11 cents a share, for the quarter and $624,000, or 20 cents a share, for the 6 months. c-After extraordinary credits of $78,000, or 2 cents a share, and $106,000, or 3 cents a share, for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Waterford in Talks On Selling Interest
description: The Waterford Wedgwood Group P.L.C., the troubled china and crystal maker, said it was in talks that might lead to a cash offer for a large, but not controlling, stake in the company. Analysts have speculated that Waterford has been seeking a minority shareholder to give it needed cash.

title: Genetic Maps May Point the Way To Healthier and Sturdier Crops
description: EVEN as plans are being made for an international effort to map the entire genetic blueprint of humans, plant scientists are proposing similar efforts to understand the hereditary messages that control the characteristics of plants.

title: Communist Parties in West Are Shaken and Squabbling
description: Having seen their political influence wane throughout the 1980's, the Communist parties of Western Europe are now being shaken by painful soul-searching and bitter infighting as they struggle to survive the collapse of traditional Communist governments in Eastern Europe.

title: j Check Here for Tax Refund Lottery
description: To the Editor:

title: WITH DEATHS TIED TO SALVADOR ARMY, AID FIGHT IS LIKELY
description: Responding to a Salvadoran statement that military men were involved in the killing of six Jesuit priests in November, Administration officials acknowledged today that future aid to El Salvador would hinge on satisfying Congress about the progress of the investigation.

title: Patterns
description: West Meets East . . .

title: Witnesses in Noriega Case Are Few
description: The Government's emerging case against Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega appears to hinge on a handful of witnesses, including some who have portrayed the deposed Panamanian dictator as a vain opportunist who demanded up to $200,000 to protect drug flights.

title: Sharp Rise in Sabotage Is Reported in Ethnic Conflict in Azerbaijan
description: An increase in hostage-taking and a sharp rise in sabotage were reported today in the ethnic conflict in Nagorno-Karabakh, a troubled region in the Soviet republic of Azerbaijan.

title: Nine Contras Go Home to Take Part in Vote
description: A top official and eight others from the United States-backed contras today ended their armed fight against the leftist Sandinista Government to return home and take part in the electoral process.

title: Shiite Muslim Factions Allow A 7-Hour Truce in Lebanon
description: After 17 days of ferocious fighting in southern Lebanon, warring Shiite Muslim factions observed a seven-hour truce today, allowing the Red Cross to tend to the dead and wounded.

title: Unisys Talks On Settling Fraud Case
description: The Unisys Corporation said today that it was engaged in ''constructive talks'' with the Justice Department aimed at a settlement of charges in the department's long-running inquiry into Pentagon fraud.

title: Bridge
description: Since 1953 the American Contract Bridge League has published a most important annual record of hands played in the world championship. This started as a bare record of the facts, but is now a sophisticated production with photographs and detailed analyses.

title: Jazz Bands to Perform In Benefit at Hofstra U.
description: Buck Clayton and his Swing Band and Arvell Shaw and his Louis Armstrong Legacy All-Stars Band are to be featured at a benefit at 8 P.M. on Jan. 27 at Adams Playhouse of Hofstra University, Hempstead Turnpike, Hempstead, L.I.

title: Upheaval in the East;   Bulgarian Panel Is to Investigate Corruption
description: An official commission investigating charges of corruption by Bulgarian officials said today that it had collected enough evidence to start criminal proceedings against the country's disgraced former leader, Todor I. Zhivkov.

title: Total System Services Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
'Miss Saigon' Weighs Postponing Opening As It Seeks a Theater
description: ''Miss Saigon,'' the smash hit London musical about the last days of American involvement in the Vietnam War, may not be coming to Broadway this fall as originally planned. Cameron Mackintosh, the show's producer, said yesterday that it might not arrive until the spring of 1991, or even later.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Business People column on Monday about a new chief operating officer at the Centex Corporation misidentified the company's chairman. He is Paul R. Seegers.

title: Apartment Rules Will Stop Landlords From Heartless Evictions
description: To the Editor:

title: Kean Stresses Need to Help Urban Poor
description: In a joyous and familial farewell to the state he governed for eight years, Gov. Thomas H. Kean delivered his final State of the State address today, warning New Jerseyans not to forget the problems and people left behind after an era of buoyant economic growth.

title: 3 Whites Accused Of Racial Menacing
description: Three white teen-agers were arrested yesterday and charged with yelling racial slurs and menacing four black youths with a tire iron outside a high school in Brooklyn, the police said.

title: U.N. Agency to Provide Aid To Ethiopia Drought Victims
description: The World Food Program said today that it will provide almost $8 million in emergency food aid for drought victims and refugees in Ethiopia.

title: Denying Slurs, Capital Mayor Repudiates Article
description: Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. said today that an article in The Los Angeles Times in which he was quoted as mocking the aspirations of the Rev. Jesse Jackson and criticizing Jewish supporters was both inaccurate and racist.

title: Sanka Spot Change
description: Kraft General Foods and its advertising agency, Young & Rubicam, have agreed to alter a commercial for Sanka to make it clear that actors, not consumers, are offering testimonials for the coffee. The spot, depicting rush-hour train commuters who stop to enjoy Sanka, will now be labeled a ''dramatization.'' The change was made at the request of the Massachusetts Executive Office of Consumer Affairs and Business Regulation.

title: Review/Television;   Robert Bly Tells Moyers What's Wrong With Men
description: Having brought public broadcasting stardom to Joseph Campbell, who taught and wrote about the place of myth in human history, Bill Moyers now presents Robert Bly, the poet, who, like Campbell, purveys interpretations of myth for the guidance of others. As Campbell advised those who tuned in to Mr. Moyers's popular interviews to ''follow your bliss,'' so Mr. Bly advises young men to follow their elders.

title: Telemedia Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: A Nursing Aide Admits Killing Elderly Patient
description: A former nursing assistant with AIDS who confessed killing seven elderly patients, then said the confessions were untrue, pleaded guilty today to murdering one of those patients and was sentenced to life in prison.

title: Bridge
description: For players in the New York area, the first major tournament of the 90's begins at the Rye Town Hilton in Port Chester, N.Y.

title: The U.S. and Panama;   Peruvians Give Asylum To a Noriega Associate
description: Peru said today that it had granted diplomatic asylum to a Noriega associate who is wanted by the United States and to 11 others who took refuge in the Peruvian Ambassador's residence in Panama City.

title: Accounts
description: * Bugle Boy Industries, to DDB Needham Los Angeles for the creative portion of its broadcast advertising, and to International Communications Group for media buying, with a total budget of $12 million.

title: Books of The Times;   Politician and Soldier, in Tandem
description: Roosevelt and Marshall

title: AIDS Trial Recesses as Doctor Takes Stand
description: A 32-year-old doctor with AIDS took the witness stand yesterday in her $175 million suit against the New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation. But the physician, Dr. Veronica Prego, did not testify, because the court stenographer's machine broke down. Justice Aaron D. Bernstein of State Supreme Court in Brooklyn recessed the trial until this afternoon.

title: Article 483490 -- No Title
description: The Chubb Capital Corporation, a unit of the Chubb Corporation, is offering $100 million in notes due in 1993 through underwriters led by J. P. Morgan Securities.

title: Article 515490 -- No Title
description: The president of the National Urban League called for a $50 billion ''domestic Marshall Plan'' today to train minority workers to help the United States compete in the international marketplace in the 1990's.

title: Percentage of Blacks in South Rose in the 80's
description: The percentage of black Americans living in the South increased in the 1980's for the first time in the 20th century, the Census Bureau reported today.

title: Upheaval in the East: Tokyo Venture;   Suzuki Reaches Deal to Build Hungary's First Car Factory
description: In the biggest investment yet by Japan in Eastern Europe and its first effort to capitalize on the region's popular uprisings, the Suzuki Motors Company said today that it had agreed to build a $140 million automobile manufacturing plant in Hungary as part of a joint venture.

title: McCaw Plans New Shares
description: McCaw Cellular Communications Inc. said today that it plans to distribute new shares of stock as part of its agreement last month to acquire the Lin Broadcasting Corporation.

title: France Plans to Reopen Kabul Embassy
description: Despite American objections, France has decided to become the first Western country to send its diplomats back to Afghanistan, French and American officials said today.

title: Food Notes
description: Peel and Eat

title: Merrill Lynch Trims Staff at Research Unit
description: Merrill Lynch & Company said yesterday that it had dismissed 10 of the 130 employees in its equity research department as part of a program to improve profitability by reducing costs.

title: 4 Soldiers Are Killed In Crash of Helicopter
description: An Army UH-60 Blackhawk helicopter crashed during desert exercises today, killing all four soldiers aboard, a base spokesman said.

title: Eating Well
description: THERE is a long list of horror stories connected with the consumption of sugar: hyperactivity in children; criminal behavior in adults; diabetes; elevated cholesterol. There is little good scientific evidence that sugar causes these conditions, but under certain circumstances it is thought to aggravate them. While the relationship between diet and health is far from an exact science, the relationship between diet and behavior is even less clear.

title: Patients to Benefit From Reforms for Interns;   No Way to Learn
description: To the Editor:

title: CHRONICLE
description: MARTIN E. SULLIVAN has long admired the Heard Museum in Phoenix for its commitment to Indian culture. Now, he is leaving his job as director of the New York State Museum in Albany and is to take up his new one as head of the Heard on March 1.

title: Bloomingdale's Chief Sought Payment Delays
description: In a last-ditch effort to help the American retail units of the Campeau Corporation avert a possible bankruptcy, Marvin S. Traub, the chairman and chief executive of Bloomingdale's, the centerpiece of Campeau's operations, asked key fashion manufacturers this week to allow the store to postpone payments on December bills, which come due today.

title: National Bancorp of Alaska reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included $8 million decrease in the provision for loan losses.

title: Oneok Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Paramount Quits Agency
description: The Paramount Pictures Corporation has withdrawn its $60 million advertising account from D'Arcy Masius Benton & Bowles, the agency said yesterday.

title: Control Data Loss
description: The Control Data Corporation said today that it expects its fiscal year 1989 restructuring costs to climb to more than $650 million with the addition of a fourth-quarter charge of $210 million. With the restructuring charges, the computer maker said it would incur a loss in the fourth quarter and for the year. For the first nine months of its fiscal year, the company posted a net loss of $484 million. Shares of the company closed up 12.5 cents, at $17.875, on the New York Stock Exchange today.

title: The Next Summit's in June. Hurry.
description: The next Bush-Gorbachev meeting is five months away - only five months. What happens starting now will show whether the two leaders can ride the tigers Mikhail Gorbachev has set loose or whether they'll lose a momentous opportunity to reduce weapons and promote peace.

title: EX-DEFENSE CHIEF OF PERU IS KILLED
description: A former Peruvian Defense Minister was shot and killed today, and security officials said Maoist guerrillas were responsible.

title: Mexico Inflation Rate
description: Mexico's inflation rate was 19.7 percent last year, the country's lowest since 1978, the Government announced Monday. Thus, Mexico ended the year meeting its goal of keeping inflation at 18 percent to 20 percent, the Government said in a report.

title: Rose Kushner, 60, Leader in Breast Cancer Fight
description: Rose Kushner, a vigorous and tenacious advocate for women with breast cancer, died Sunday of the disease. She was 60 years old and lived in Kensington, Md.

title: City to Suburb: Commuting Turns Around
description: With a glass-walled apartment 32 floors above the Upper East Side and plenty of friends below, David Perlmutter is happily ensconced in Manhattan. But each weekday morning, the 27-year-old developer drives to work here in the suburbs.

title: Violent Protests Growing in Kashmir
description: An Indian intelligence official was killed by unidentified gunmen in the northern state of Kashmir today, while at least 25 people were wounded in the second straight day of clashes between police officers and separatist demonstrators.

title: Mary O'Neill, 84, Dies; Children's Book Writer
description: Mary O'Neill, a children's book author, died of heart failure on Jan. 2 in Yuma (Ariz.) Regional Medical Center. She was 84 years old.
