title: Upheaval in the East;   Communist Luminaries Shot a Lot
description: Leonid I. Brezhnev, Fidel Castro and other Communist luminaries would bag up to 2,000 hares and pheasants a day on luxury hunting estates in Czechoslovakia, the state press agency said today.

title: London Journal;   At the Secular Funeral, a Tango May Be Tasteful
description: The mourners listened solemnly to the song of praise for the deceased, a man who loved to dance. Then, in their own creative tribute, they did a sedate tango out the door.

title: Books And the Hippodrome
description: In ''Clarence Darrow for the Defense,'' by Irving Stone, a passage has remained in memory as a striking and most unexpected dollop of good sense. Darrow, the guest speaker at a high school commencement exercise in Chicago 70 or so years ago, listened to a pompous principal lecture 500 graduates about their great responsibilities when they left that auditorium.

title: Apartments Rules Will Stop Landlords From Heartless Evictions;   Legislative Inaction
description: To the Editor:

title: The U.S. and Panama: Legal Issues;   Scholars Say Arrest of Noriega Has Little Justification in Law
description: The apprehension of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega on drug charges is largely unprecedented and was basically a blunt political act with only an after-the-fact legal rationale, several legal scholars say.

title: KEY RATES
CHRONICLE
description: CARL McCALL decided yesterday against being a candidate for New York State comptroller. He had been GOV. MARIO M. CUOMO's first choice as the Democratic nominee.

title: People
description: * Bruce I. Carlson has been named chairman of Grant/Jacoby Advertising, Chicago, replacing Robert L. Flink, who is retiring. R. Milton Lynnes will replace Mr. Carlson as president.

title: United Stationers reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Figures for 1988 have been reclassified.

title: 2 Accused As Insiders
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission accused two individuals today of illegal insider trading based on information contained in advanced copies of Business Week magazine.

title: Aero Systems Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net loss

title: John L. Clive, Harvard Historian And an Acclaimed Biographer, 65
description: John L. Clive, a Harvard professor of history who won a National Book Award in 1974 for his biography of Thomas Babington Macaulay, the 19th-century Scottish historian, died Sunday while being driven to his home in Cambridge, Mass. He was 65 years old.

title: Bridgestone Seeks Worker Buyouts
description: Bridgestone-Firestone Inc., the company created by the buyout of the Firestone Tire and Rubber Company by the Bridgestone Corporation of Japan, has given hundreds of United States workers until Jan. 31 to decide whether to leave their jobs in a cost-cutting move, a spokesman said. The spokesman, Bob Troyer, would not say how many workers the company wanted to cut.

title: Social-Service Professionals Make Donations to Neediest
description: Few people are as likely to understand the plight of the needy as those who work in social services and urban affairs. Professionals from a variety of nonprofit organizations have sent gifts to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, along with letters that resonate with special feeling.

title: Waterford Unions Reject Demands
description: Workers at Waterford Crystal P.L.C. rejected a drastic cost-cutting plan late Monday after a group led by Anthony F. J. O'Reilly, Irish-born chairman of the H. J. Heinz Company, proposed a big investment in the crystal and china company. Mr. O'Reilly was said to be heading a group of overseas investors negotiating to buy 29.9 percent of Waterford for more than $100 million.

title: Ceausescu's Main Victims: Women and Children
description: LEAD: One of the first acts of the new Rumanian Government, the Council of National Salvation, was to release a 23-point ''radical plan'' for change. Some outside observers were surprised that the plan included liberalization of the abortion law. They shouldn't have been. Abortion is no minor issue in Rumania.

title: U.S. to Study Oil Profits Resulting From Surge in Prices
description: Under pressure from Congress, an Energy Department official said today that the department would immediately begin a study of any profits earned by the heating oil industry when prices increased as much as 50 percent in the Northeast last month.

title: Rare Sea Mammals Die In Florida Cold Wave
description: A record number of manatees have been found dead in Florida waterways over the past nine days and more than half may have been victims of the recent cold snap, state officials said.

title: Corrections
description: The cast listing with a television review yesterday about the ''Today'' program misidentified its directors and the newscaster who appeared on Monday. The directors are John Libretto and Steve Rosen; the newscaster was Keith Morrison, not John Palmer.

title: Dekalb Genetics Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Josephine Case, 82, RCA Board Member And Poet and Writer
description: Josephine Young Case, a poet and writer and the first woman to be a director of the Radio Corporation of America, died on Monday at the Harding Nursing Home in Waterville, N.Y. She was 82 years old and lived in Van Hornesville, N.Y.

title: Lessons
description: Donna Wall, a substitute kindergarten teacher, was half an hour into a crayons-and-scissors exercise at the Bartlett Elementary School in Lowell, Mass., when she realized that some of the students, having finished their assignment, were wandering all over the classroom.

title: Consolidated Gas
description: The Consolidated Natural Gas Company said it plans to sell four million shares of common stock to raise nearly $200 million. It said it would use the money to expand its pipeline and transmission operations in the Northeast, increase exploration and production and complete the $160 million purchase of the Virginia Natural Gas Company.

title: Patients to Benefit From Reforms for Interns;   Approach Is Too Broad
description: To the Editor:

title: Ewing Carries the Knicks Through Overtime Again
description: Last night, the Knicks won their second consecutive overtime game, and again, it was Patrick Ewing who scored the deciding points.

title: About New York;   Those Who Color Rainbow Room Finally Sit Down
description: The gentleman let the wine roll around his mouth, the perfect cap to a perfect meal. ''This is very good port,'' he pronounced.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary yesterday about Edward J. Ennis, a former president of the American Civil Liberties Union, misstated the period of his service. It was 1969 to 1976.

title: Status of Spring Training Is Questionable
description: The status of spring training for the major leagues, scheduled to begin in five weeks, was thrown into question yesterday with the disclosure that the owners will meet Feb. 9 to decide whether to open camps.

title: The Two New Commissioners;   Albert F. Appleton, Environmental Protection
description: Albert F. Appleton's vocation and avocation could blend into a perfect marriage of environmental advocacy and managerial dexterity in his new job as Commissioner of the city's Department of Environmental Protection.

title: A Slow Start Is Seen for The Infiniti
description: The initial sales of the Nissan Motor Company's Infiniti, the newest Japanese entrant in the profitable luxury car segment, have not been as strong as expected, some industry analysts and dealers say.

title: The U.S. and Panama: The Press;   Paper Noriega Crushed Is Reborn as a Watchdog
description: Guillermo Sanchez Borbon had a bit of a fright when he returned this week to his newspaper office, which had been closed for 23 months. There were four heavily armed soldiers outside the front door.

title: Evans Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 25
description: b-Included a pretax gain of $531,000 for the sale of properties.

title: Big British Fight Shapes Up On Hong Kong Emigre Plan
description: Some members of the British Parliament, including many Conservatives, have begun a major battle against Government plans to offer refuge in Britain to 50,000 of the most successful people in Hong Kong and their families before China takes over the colony in 1997.

title: Suntrust Banks Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CHRONICLE
description: The New York City Schools Chancellor, JOSEPH A. FERNANDEZ, has abandoned his plans to live in Staten Island. He fell in love with Brooklyn Heights.

title: Is Cuba the Next Communist Domino?
description: LEAD: Now that Eastern Europe's dominoes have fallen, the prospects are better than ever that the anti-Communist momentum will jump the Atlantic and end 31 years of Communist rule in Cuba, particularly if the Cuban people get some help from democratic friends abroad.

title: Restoring a Work by More Than One Master
description: The denouement of a scholarly detective story was presented today at the National Gallery of Art with the unveiling of the newly restored ''Feast of the Gods,'' a 16th-century masterpiece by Giovanni Bellini.

title: Net Increases At Paramount On Unit Sale
description: Paramount Communications Inc. said yesterday that its net income for the fourth quarter of the 1989 fiscal year rose more than eightfold because of a special gain from the sale of the Associates First Capital Corporation, its financial-services business.

title: Jerusalem Post Fills 2 Jobs Left Vacant by Resignations
description: The Jerusalem Post has named a new managing editor and magazine editor in the first replacements of high-ranking staff members who resigned last week in a dispute over the newspaper's editorial policy.

title: The Real Commons, on Screen
description: British television viewers today saw the worst uproar in the House of Commons since cameras were allowed into the chamber in November.

title: Big Owner of Department Stores Appears on Brink of Bankruptcy
description: With bills for merchandise coming due today and a deadline from its banks looming on Monday, the American retailing operations of the Campeau Corporation, which include Bloomingdale's, Abraham & Straus, Jordan Marsh and six other leading chains, appear to be on the brink of bankruptcy.

title: Ruling Spares Utilities a Tax on Deposits
description: The Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that the security deposits that many public utilities require of their customers are not taxable as income to the utilities.

title: I.O.C. Opens Link To South Africa
description: A group of anti-apartheid advisers to the International Olympic Committee held a formal meeting with South African sports officials for the first time today, but the I.O.C. people said a great deal needed to be done before South Africa could rejoin the Olympics.

title: Awakening After Boston's Nightmare
description: The story leaped into the news, a suburban nightmare become suddenly, horribly flesh: a young middle-class couple, the wife eight months pregnant, are kidnapped while driving home from birthing class. The abductor, drug-crazed, remorselessly kills the wife and wounds the husband, who heroically guides the police to their car using his cellular phone.

title: Goodfellow Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Included extraordinary credits of $2,286,000, or 64 cents a share, for the latest quarter and $376,000, or 10 cents a share, for the year-earlier period. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: 60-Minute Gourmet
description: THE prospects are dim for a substantial bay scallop harvest in Long Island Sound this year. The results of the devastating brown tide of 1988 linger, and the few bay scallops that survive will be exceedingly expensive. Hence, sea scallops are in greater demand than ever.

title: S.A.S.'s Chile Deal
description: The Scandinavian Airlines System said the Chilean Government had approved its acquisition of 30 percent of the Lan Chile airline and an increase of its stake in the carrier to 35 percent later this year. S.A.S. said the parties had agreed that S.A.S. would occupy three of the nine seats on the Lan Chile board. S.A.S. had guaranteed a $29.85 million loan to the Chilean trading company Icarosan in September, enabling Icarosan to buy a 51 percent stake in Lan Chile from the Government for $42.3 million.

title: Palestinian Radical Denies Link to Flight 103 Bombing
description: The leader of a radical Palestinian faction, Ahmed Jabril, today dismissed as unfounded accusations that his group was involved in the 1988 bombing of Pan Am Flight 103 over Lockerbie, Scotland.

title: International Paper reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Computer Chaos Called Mistake, Not Felony
description: A Cornell University student made a ''mistake'' in allowing a computer program he designed to go wild and paralyze a national computer network, his lawyer told jurors today in opening arguments at his felony trial.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about the suicide of Charles Stuart, a suspect in the killing of his wife in Boston, erred in reporting results of ballistics tests.

title: Rangers Surrounded By Loud Trade Talk
description: Neil Smith, the general manager of the Rangers, who has become incensed as much by his team's failure of nerve as its failure to win, left for Florida and the meeting of National Hockey League general managers last weekend. He had, in the days leading up to his departure, publicly mocked his team's efforts and broadly hinted that it was a team likely to have been reshaped by his return Friday.

title: Star Banc Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a gain of $3,066,000, or 11 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting.

title: U.S.-Laos Anti-Drug Effort
description: The United States and Laos agreed today to establish ground rules for cooperation in combating drug smuggling, the State Department said. The department spokeswoman, Margaret D. Tutwiler, said the agreement, signed in Laos, reflects a ''significantly improved'' American relationship with the Communist Southeast Asian country, a major opium producer.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A3-13

title: Revival Bought With Tourist Dollars
description: A small but growing number of American towns, no longer able to prosper from the industry, mining or farming that once defined them, are using imagination and ingenuity in hopes of snaring some of the tourist dollars that usually flow to big metropolitan hot spots.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Corrections
description: A brief profile on Sunday about Dexter Lehtinen, the United States Attorney for the Southern District of Florida, referred incorrectly to his education. He graduated from the University of Miami and received his law degree from Stanford Law School. Mr. Lehtinen also received master's degrees in political science and business administration at Columbia University. An adjoining brief profile of Mr. Lehtinen's deputy Myles Malman referred to him incorrectly. He is not engaged.

title: Nets Win as Celtics Have 6-Point Second Quarter
description: Even without Larry Bird, one would never expect the Boston Celtics to score just 6 points in the second quarter. One would never expect the Celtics to score just 78 points in a game. And one would never expect those two events to happen against the Nets.

title: Versace Fined $3,500
description: For verbally abusing a referee and failing to leave the court in a timely manner after Indiana lost to the Charlotte Hornets, 117-111, last Saturday night, Coach Dick Versace of the Pacers was fined $3,500 yesterday by Rod Thorn, the National Basketball Association's vice president of operations.

title: Treasuries Finish Little Changed
description: Concern about a rush of new longer-term securities continued to build in the credit markets yesterday as dealers prepared to place bids on $7.5 billion of seven-year Treasury notes.

title: Wegener Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 1
description: b-Included a loss of $334,000 from the cumulative effect of change in accounting method.

title: Detection Methods Raise Issue of Student Rights
description: A New York City pilot program using metal detectors and X-ray machines to reduce the numbers of weapons getting into schools is also discouraging students from carrying illegal drugs and alcohol in some buildings, school officials say.

title: C.P.A. Group Adopts Rule
description: The American Institute of Certified Public Accountants said yesterday that its members had approved a bylaw change to require all of its members who audit public companies to undergo regular reviews by their peers. The measure was approved by 87 percent of those who voted, the group said.

title: Social Security Agency Can Act to Gain Trust
description: To the Editor:

title: Southwestern Public Service Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Washington Talk;   Graying of the Senate: A Long-Distance View
description: Strom Thurmond of South Carolina is 87 years old, Claiborne Pell of Rhode Island is 71, Howell Heflin of Alabama is 68 and Mark O. Hatfield of Oregon is 67. But all four are seeking re-election to the Senate this year.

title: Continental Bank Job Reunites Old Friends
description: When Richard L. Huber accepted a new job as vice chairman at Continental Bank, it was a reunion of sorts with Thomas Theobald, chairman of Continental and Mr. Huber's former boss at Citibank early in the 1980's.

title: Economic Scene;   Subsidy, Not Tax, To Spur Recycling
description: LIKE a desert cloudburst, a Bush Administration initiative to encourage recycling made a brief splash last week and then disappeared without a trace. But the idea of taxing manufacturers who do not make maximum use of recycled materials, reportedly shot down by Administration political operatives distressed by the mere mention of the T-word, is likely to rise again - if only because Washington is under increasing pressure from state and local officials to do something about the municipal garbage mountain.

title: 13 Fewer Rigs Working
description: The number of United States rigs drilling for oil and gas dropped last week by 13, to a total of 1,029, Baker Hughes Inc., an oil-services company, said on Monday. The number of working rigs a year ago was 872. The weekly count reflects the number of rigs actively exploring for oil and gas, not those producing oil and gas.

title: BRIEFS
description: * AMI Healthcare P.L.C., London, a hospital group, said talks were under way with a number of potential purchasers for the 65 percent stake in the company owned by American Medical International Inc.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * American Home Products Corp., New York, the drug, food and household products company, appointed Charles E. LaRosa president of its American Home Food Products division. He replaces David P. Jaicks, who was named chairman of the division.

title: New Options Rule Cleared
description: Richard C. Breeden, the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, said today that he had decided not to delay a new rule that would allow an option to be listed on more than one exchange in the United States.

title: Beyond Crumpets: Tea Trade Woos Youth
description: THE television ad focuses on a mysterious beverage factory. A professor appears, followed by a crowd of eager visitors.

title: At the Nation's Table
description: LEAD: EXCEPT for the warm Hawaiian sun overhead and the stream of tourists, Hana Highway, the main street of Paia on the island of Maui, could be the main street of a thousand other towns. From the outside, Dillon's Hideaway looks much like any other small-town restaurant. But once you step inside, one glimpse of the New Guinea tribal masks in the waiting area or the sarong-clad waitress with the slight

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about an alien detention center in Rosedale, Queens, referred incorrectly in some copies to comments by Susan Noreika, chairwoman of Community Board 13. She said the Immigration and Naturalization Service and the Wackenhut Corrections Corporation, the private company that operates the center, should have notified the community of their plans to establish it but were not legally required to do so.

title: Wilder Holds to the Middle as Governorship Nears
description: Virginia's Governor-elect, L. Douglas Wilder, who captured the historical and sociological imagination of the nation two months ago when he became the first black ever to be elected governor of any state, appears to be relying on the same political principle in setting up his new administration that he relied upon to run his successful election campaign: He is sticking to the middle of the road, avoiding extremes.

title: Addicts Awaiting Treatment Often Face Delays and Panic
description: Beauvais J., a crack addict, moved in with his sister and her four children in Brooklyn because there was no room for him in a drug-treatment program.

title: Upheaval in the East: Trade Bloc;   Moscow Proposes That Trade Bloc Begin Using Real Market Prices
description: The Soviet Union today formally presented to its Eastern European partners a proposal to begin trading next year on a hard-currency basis at real market prices.

title: Market Place;   Is '84 Weakness About to Return?
description: TO some, 1984 may forever be linked to George Orwell and Big Brother, or to Ronald Reagan's landslide re-election, but on Wall Street it is remembered for the only slow and sustained decline in stock prices of the 1980's bull market.

title: Robert J. Smith, 90, Ex-Airline Executive
description: Robert J. Smith, a former airlines industry executive, died of a heart attack on Dec. 31 at his home in Dallas. He was 90 years old.

title: Reviews/Dance;   Of Elegance, Tchaikovsky and Variations
description: Choreographically, the theme is elegance; the variations are displays of brilliance to some of Tchaikovsky's most sumptuous music. George Balanchine first used the ''Tema con Variazioni'' from Tchaikovsky's Suite No. 3 as the accompaniment for ''Theme and Variations,'' an abstract ballet he created in 1947. He choreographed the rest of the suite in 1970, and the variations now bring a distinguished ballet to a festive conclusion.

title: Oilers Name Pardee To Succeed Glanville
description: Jack Pardee, whose teams compiled a 44-46 record when he was a National Football League head coach during two seasons with the Chicago Bears and three with the Washington Redskins in the 1970's, returned to the N.F.L. yesterday. He succeeded Jerry Glanville as head coach of the Houston Oilers.

title: Gun That May Be Stuart's Is Found
description: Divers found a revolver in a river north of Boston today that law-enforcement officials believe may be the gun used in October to kill Carol Stuart, a pregnant Boston woman whose husband committed suicide last week.

title: Late Drop Sends Dow Down 28.37, to 2,766
description: Stocks ended sharply lower yesterday as trading accelerated near the close of the session. The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 28.37 points, to 2,766.

title: Man Charged in Death Plot To Inject Woman With Virus
description: A man planned to kill his former girlfriend by hiring someone to inject her with the AIDS virus, officials say.

title: Harding Associates reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Revenue represented gross revenues.

title: Brooklyn Teen-Ager Killed For Failing to Give a High-5
description: A 15-year-old died early yesterday after being shot Monday night in Brooklyn in a feud that started when he refused to give another youth a high-five greeting, the police said.

title: Giants Going Home On an Optimistic Note
description: The coach was disappointed. The players were disappointed. But even though the Giants were eliminated from the playoffs Sunday, there have been few hang-dog looks.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: LETTER from a failed ballerina:

title: It's On! Tyson-Holyfield Set for June
description: The heavyweight match everyone has looked for - Mike Tyson vs. Evander Holyfield - at last is on the fight calendar. After much rhetorical warfare and posturing by the opposing camps, a deal was completed yesterday in Las Vegas, Nev., for a June 18 bout between the unbeaten stars.

title: Soviet Team Continues Dominance In Series
description: The crowd of 17,423 at the Spectrum tonight seemed spirited even during warm-ups, with some fans holding small American flags that had been handed out by arena workers. Some fans held a large, star-spangled banner behind the glass, near the blue line, at the end where Central Red Army of the Soviet Union took its warm-ups. This flag stretched horizontally at least 10 seats wide.

title: Upheaval in the East: Rumania;   Two Student Militants Tell of Death Threats
description: The threatening phone calls started last Saturday night for Marina Ranta, Tiberio Stoichici and eight other students of the Polytechnical Institute, a section of Bucharest University.

title: Aloft in Shuttle: Sketches of Astronauts
description: For the flight of the space shuttle Columbia, the space agency chose two astronauts with experience in space and three who will be making their first shuttle flights.

title: The Two New Commissioners;   Lucius J. Riccio, Transportation
description: Lucius J. Riccio brings to his new post as New York City Commissioner of Transportation all the skills of a master sand-castle builder.

title: N.C.A.A. Shortens Spring Practice and Basketball Season
description: After a dramatic floor battle between college presidents and athletic directors, delegates to the National Collegiate Athletic Association convention voted today to limit spring football practice in Divisons I and I-AA and reduce the length of the basketball season.

title: Topics of The Times;   Yankee Ingenuity
description: Americans distressed by Japanese inroads into fields like automobiles and electronics sometimes find comfort in the Extrapolation Explanation. They believe that the disciplined Japanese skillfully exploit known technologies to their fullest potential in the marketplace. But, the theory goes on, it is stubbornly independent Americans who devise new technologies. That theory may or may not work generally but to judge from two recent publications, it holds water in the realm of bed and bath.

title: Pannell Kerr Merger Talks
description: Senior partners from Pannell Kerr Forster and Spicer & Oppenheim have explored merging the two mid-sized accounting firms, Pannell's chairman said yesterday.

title: Electric Revenue Bonds Are Priced
description: The Sacramento Municipal Utility District, in California, yesterday tentatively priced a $125 million issue of electric revenue bonds with a maximum yield of 7.18 percent for a bond due in 2018. The issue was priced through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company.

title: C.D. Yields Down for Week
description: Yields on certificates of deposit and money-market accounts at commercial banks and savings institutions were mostly lower for the week ended yesterday.

title: Boston College and Harvard Start Upward Moves
description: Boston College and Harvard, the preseason favorites in the East's Division I leagues, made auspicious moves after slow starts as the second half of the college hockey season commenced last week.

title: Upheaval in the East: Economic Goal;   Unsnarling a Tangled Trade Alliance
description: As the current Comecon negotiations in Bulgaria make clear, both the Soviet Union and the nations of Eastern Europe are eager to untangle their economic embrace. The $10 billion question yet to be decided is how rapidly and on what terms.

title: Farm Debate to Center on Pesticides
description: Proposals intended to make American agricultural practices safer and less polluting are likely to emerge as the most contentious issues in the Congressional debate over national farm policy, farm groups, trade organizations and influential farm policy makers say.

title: Nursing Homes To Increase Beds For AIDS Cases
description: New York State and the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, which operates the only AIDS nursing home in New York City, announced plans yesterday to increase by nearly five-fold the number of AIDS beds there and in nursing homes elsewhere.

title: Those Mister Wonderfuls
description: The mail is full of football questions, so let's get to them right away, mail fans.

title: PRESIDENT ASSAILS BOMBINGS IN SOUTH
description: Signing a proclamation for the Martin Luther King Jr. holiday, President Bush voiced outrage today over bombings linked to a white supremacist group and vowed ''to bring the perpetrators of these hideous crimes to justice.''

title: 6 in South Africa Die in Clash Of Black Transport Workers
description: Six people were killed today as black transport workers fought each other with clubs, sticks and knives at a railway station here. The clash was one of the most violent incidents of recent South African labor unrest.

title: Palmer and Morgan Join Hall First-Timers
description: Jim Palmer and Joe Morgan, who shared in post-season honors in 1975 and 1976, shared in post-career honors last night. The pitcher and the second baseman were elected to the Baseball Hall of Fame in their first year of eligibility.

title: Ruth Newman Schwarz, Social Worker, 81
description: Ruth Newman Schwarz, an early psychiatric social worker, died of cancer Dec. 28 at Lenox Hill Hospital. She was 81 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Transylvania Is Famous Beyond Dracula
description: To the Editor:

title: The U.S. and Panama: Civilian Dead;   The Invasion's Civilian Toll: Still No Official Count
description: Nearly three weeks after United States troops toppled Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega's Government, killing what military spokesmen said were 314 of his troops, officials acknowledge that there is still no reliable count of how many Panamanian noncombatants died as a result of the fighting and street disorders.

title: G.M. Appoints Director
description: The board of the General Motors Corporation on Monday elected Ann D. McLaughlin as a director. Mrs. McLaughlin served as United States Secretary of Labor from 1987 to 1989. Her appointment increases the number of directors to 18.

title: Paul A. Kennon, 55, Honored Architect And a Dean at Rice
description: Paul A. Kennon, an award-winning architect who was dean of the School of Architecture at Rice University, died of a heart attack on Monday at the Texas Medical Center in Houston. He was 55 years old and lived in Houston.

title: Goetz Files Libel Suit And Assails Lawyers
description: Bernhard H. Goetz, acting as his own lawyer, contended in a $40 million libel suit filed yesterday that lawyers for a victim of his shooting on the IRT had called him a ''walking time bomb and a racist.''

title: MGM/UA Communications Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $1,581,000, or 3 cents a share, related to the purchase of $7 million face amount of subordinated debentures on Nov. 8, 1989.

title: Barton Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: New Move For Buyout Of UAL
description: The management of the UAL Corporation and the unions at its United Airlines unit are preparing another effort to assemble a buyout proposal, people involved in their discussions said yesterday.

title: Coopers & Lybrand Leases New Offices
description: Mayor David N. Dinkins took time out from the city's financial woes yesterday to announce a new tenant for a large portion of one of Manhattan's midtown office towers, which he said was proof that ''in good times and bad New York City remains at the heart of the international economy.''

title: Exxon Admits a Year of Breakdowns in S.I. Oil Spill
description: Exxon officials said yesterday that a leak detection system that had been malfunctioning for at least a year, sending off false alarms, was ignored by its operators last week as more than a half-million gallons of oil hemorrhaged from a pipeline into the Arthur Kill off Staten Island.

title: Commodity Case Details Emerging
description: A wealth of details has emerged in the Government's case against 19 Chicago soybean traders charged with illegal trading and defrauding customers.

title: First National Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago 1988 results were restated to reflect the 1989 acquisitions of Peoples Bank of Forsyth County and Pickens County Bank, both on a pooling-of-interests basis.

title: U.S.-Soviet Park Proposed Along Strait
description: A team of American and Soviet officials today recommended the creation of an international park along the Bering Strait, long a sensitive border area between the two powers.

title: Moscow Circus Cooks Food in Cramped Spaces, Then Eats It!
description: LEAD: STEP right up, ladies and gentlemen, to the astonishing Moscow Circus! Feast your eyes on stunning feats of derring-do! See the death-defying aerial act! The Gibadullins' lightning-fast juggling! The Agayev family's anti-gravitational tightrope exploits! Tamerlan Nugzarov and his Caucasian Dzhigits' daredevil horsemanship!

title: Adding Noise to Cut a Car's Noise
description: Automobile engineers seeking to make a car quieter have typically padded body panels with a bit of cloth or fiberglass and added rubber to motor mounts. Now, researchers at Lotus Engineering in Britain have devised a way to cut interior noise with microphones and microchips, a technique dubbed ''anti-noise.''

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A.

title: At the Nation's Table
description: LEAD: EVERY chef strives to leave his imprint on the culinary scene, and Reimund Pitz is no exception.

title: Cable TV Is No Longer A Stepchild
description: AS if it weren't bad enough that advertising executives have to deal with three networks and Fox television, the dozen large advertiser-supported cable services are demanding more attention. And their numbers continue to grow.

title: Georgia-Pacific In Nekoosa Move
description: The Georgia-Pacific Corporation asked a Federal judge to cut the number of votes needed to dismiss directors of the Great Northern Nekoosa Corporation in the proxy battle between the rival paper companies. Great Northern has resisted Georgia-Pacific's unsolicited $3.8 billion tender offer on antitrust grounds.

title: CHRONICLE
description: And in Chicago, RICHARD J. PHELAN, the 52-year-old lawyer whose work for the House Ethics Committee helped bring down House Speaker Jim Wright last year, is reconsidering his primary run for president of the Cook County Board in the wake of personal and political difficulties.

title: Fish Truly Worthy of the Word Fresh
description: LIKE sweet corn that goes directly from the field to the pot in midsummer, fish that is on the table within hours of being caught transcends the accepted meaning of fresh.

title: U.S. Cuts Funds to U.N. Food Agency Over P.L.O.
description: The United States has sharply cut its financial contribution to the United Nations Food and Agriculture Organization as a result of disputes over the agency's support for the Palestine Liberation Organization and its new budget.

title: Rutgers to Name Coach
description: Doug Graber, a defensive coach with the Tampa Bay Buccaneers the last three years and with the Kansas City Chiefs the four years before that, will be named head football coach at Rutgers University today, according to reports published in several newspapers. Dick Anderson, the former coach, was dismissed last month with five years left on his contract after a six-year record of 27-34-4.(AP)

title: Tyco Laboratories Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Results of Mueller Co. have been included since the date of its acquisition on Sept. 30, 1988.

title: Redlaw Industries reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $8,850,000. c-Net income and included a loss from discontinued operations of $1,917,000. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Plan Unveiled for Improving Minority Education
description: Citing a ''glaring gap between minority and nonminority educational achievement'' in the United States, a group of educators and business and community leaders presented an extensive plan today to improve the education of minority students.

title: Book Notes
description: 'Crazy Horse' Suit

title: The Upwardly Mobile Snifter
description: FIRST Stolichnaya, Absolut and other ''super premium'' vodkas arrived. Then came a parade of single-malt Scotches that sold extraordinarily well, even as Americans' consumption of spirits continued to decline.

title: CBS Ends Contract Of Program Executive
description: CBS announced yesterday that it has reached an agreement with Barbara Corday, the executive vice president of programs, to terminate her contract. Her departure completes a housecleaning of the top ranks of the CBS Entertainment division. The head of the division, Kim LeMasters, resigned under pressure in December and was replaced by Jeff Sagansky. Mr. Sagansky has moved quickly to put his personal stamp on CBS Entertainment, canceling two shows, ''Beauty and the Beast'' and ''Snoops,'' and shelving ''The Famous Teddy Z'' until April.

title: Southern Lebanon Truce Holds
description: Rival Shiite Muslim militias continued to observe a truce in southern Lebanon today as a senior Iranian mediator said here that a durable cease-fire was imminent.

title: Providence Rallies to Set Back Seton Hall, 78-70
description: Carlton Screen scored 6 of his 20 points early in the second half tonight to spark Providence to a 78-70 victory over Seton Hall in a Big East game.

title: Patients to Benefit From Reforms for Interns
description: To the Editor:

title: Tarlow-Cosmopolitan
description: Citing a limited potential for growth, Tarlow Advertising has resigned the $1 million trade advertising account of Cosmopolitan magazine. ''I want us to be working in areas where if you a do a great job, you reap the benefits,'' said Dick Tarlow, the agency's president. George H. Simpson, a spokesman for Cosmopolitan, said creative differences had existed as well.

title: Clemson Reveals It Is Under Inquiry by N.C.A.A.
description: The Clemson University football program is being accused by the National Collegiate Athletic Association of more than a dozen illegal recruiting contacts and of giving players up to $150 in cash from 1984 to 1988, an N.C.A.A. report released today said.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''If there is a 'smoking gun' to be found that demonstrates discrimination in tenure decisions, it is likely to be tucked away in peer review files.''

title: Circon Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Children's Book Medals Awarded
description: The 1990 John Newbury Medal for the most distinguished contribution to American literature for children has been awarded to ''Number the Stars,'' by Lois Lowry (Houghton Mifflin).

title: 5 Countries to Meet on Reviving Cambodia Peace Talks, Paris Says
description: Amid new concern over stepped-up attacks by Khmer Rouge guerrillas, the United States, the Soviet Union, China, France and Britain are to meet here on Monday to discuss ways of reviving stalled peace efforts on Cambodia.

title: Excerpts From Court Decision Requiring Universities to Yield Tenure Data
description: Following are excerpts from the Supreme Court's decision today requiring universities to disclose their tenure files. Justice Harry A. Blackmun wrote the unanimous opinion.

title: The Pop Life
description: Promoting Lambada

title: Colonial High Income Municial Trust reports earnings for As of Dec 31
description: Assets represented net asset value. The company said there are no year-ago comparable results because the fund began investment operations Feb. 16, 1989.

title: Bio-Logic Systems Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: The company said during the 1989 periods, miscellaneous income included $90,000 relating to a grant of rights to a company trademark during November 1989.

title: The U.S. and Panama: Soldiers of Fortune;   An Untold Guerrilla War: Noriega Foes Rule Border
description: When invading American troops seized key installations throughout Panama last month, this vital border crossing was sealed off by a far different army, one that was formed as a secret alternative to just such a United States invasion.

title: College Officials Fear Loss of Frankness in Deciding Tenure
description: University officials across the country said yesterday's Supreme Court ruling could make it harder to evaluate candidates for tenure because professors would not speak as bluntly about their colleagues if they knew their comments could be made public.

title: Upheaval in the East: Czechoslovakia;   Prague Wants Soviet Pullout by Year's End
description: Czechoslovakia said today that it will push for the withdrawal of Soviet troops from its territory by the end of the year while its own army tries to re-establish an independent identity after years of control by Moscow.

title: Reviews/Dance;   A Mixed Troupe From Japan And the U.S.
description: Ballet is very popular in Japan today. And the 21 teen-age Japanese dancers who performed on Friday night at the Marymount Manhattan Theater in ''Young Ballet Dancers From Japan and New York'' were well trained and often personable. But few were developed performers. The performing highlight of the evening was the minxish Mihoko Sasao's easy and authoritative portrayal of the 19th-century Danish ballerina Lucile Grahn, in a staging of ''Pas de Quatre'' by Katsuko Okamoto. Nayumi Shiotani offered accomplished performances in a variation from the grand pas de deux in ''The Sleeping Beauty'' and as the ballerina in ''Paquita,'' where she turned out dazzlingly fast and fluid fouettes. James L. Fayette, her cavalier, danced with a winning buoyancy and modesty and secure and sensitive partnering.

title: Answering the Car Phone When Away From the Car
description: At the Consumer Electronics Show here this week, a company introduced a portable handset system that allows people with cellular car phones to receive calls up to 1,000 feet from their vehicles.

title: ABC May Curtail Ads in Show's Premiere
description: As part of an extensive promotional effort to identify a forthcoming prime-time dramatic series as unusual television, ABC is considering broadcasting the two-hour premiere of ''Twin Peaks'' without any network commercials, Capital Cities/ABC executives said this week. The show would include commercials sold by local television stations, however.

title: Children's Names: Mirror of a Society
description: IF a child's name tells more about the parents than it does about the child, then the 1980's may well be remembered as a decade in which some parents were self-indulgent, ambitious, proud of their heritage and just a little outrageous.

title: Real Estate;   Sprucing Up Marcos Gem On Wall St.
description: FOR a brief time 60 years ago, 40 Wall Street proudly held the honor of being the tallest building in the world. More recently it made news as one of the troubled Manhattan properties of Ferdinand E. Marcos, the late Philippine President.

title: Lord Gardiner, Ex-Judicial Head And Reformer of Laws, Dies at 89
description: Lord Gardiner, who as Lord Chancellor, or head of the judiciary, from 1964 to 1970 presided over the abolition of the death penalty in Britain, died on Sunday, his family said. He was 89 years old.

title: Topics of The Times;   Franking Frenzies
description: With great fanfare, Congress last fall tightened lawmakers' free mailing privileges. The Senate now gives itself $24 million for mass mailings for the fiscal year that began Oct. 1. That's still high, but more reasonable than the $35 million spent last year. Further, the old rules put no dollar cap on individual senators. This year, amounts are allocated according to population.

title: MGM/UA Sale Plan on Hold
description: The MGM/UA Communications Company said today that it had put on hold plans to sell itself and would instead try to rebuild by increasing film production.

title: Rumania Seeks Trade Status
description: The new Government said today that it would seek most-favored-nation trading status with the United States. Nicolae Ceausescu, the executed dictator, renounced the American trade agreement in February 1988, when it appeared that Congress would not renew it because of rights abuses under Mr. Ceausescu. The Foreign Ministry said it was ''empowered to nullify'' that declaration.

title: Shuttle in Orbit; Satellite Chase Begins
description: Five astronauts aboard the space shuttle Columbia rocketed into orbit today on a complex mission to deploy one satellite and after an intricate three-day chase to retrieve another.

title: Dinkins Appoints Transportation and Environment Commissioners
description: Bypassing the incumbent who had been recommended for reappointment by his advisory committee, Mayor David N. Dinkins yesterday named a deputy in the transportation department, Lucius J. Riccio, to be New York City's new Commissioner of Transportation.

title: Congressman Joins Race for Governor
description: United States Representative Bruce A. Morrison, a Democrat from the New Haven area, declared his candidacy for governor Monday, putting himself into conflict with Gov. William A. O'Neill, a fellow Democrat who has said he will run for a third term.

title: A Rich New Biotech Frontier
description: Biotechnology companies are developing potentially revolutionary new treatments for rheumatoid arthritis, diabetes, multiple sclerosis and other disorders in which the body's disease-fighting system attacks the body's own tissues.

title: New York Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company, which is the holding company for Home Federal Savings Bank, said its earnings for the quarter were significantly affected by a $600,000 increase in legal and other expenses related to a proxy contest by dissident shareholders. Without those expenses, net income would have been $1,200,000, or 35 cents a share, in the 1989 first quarter.

title: U.S. Forgives Portion Of Kenya's Loan Debt
description: The United States today formally agreed to forgive all economic-assistance loans to Kenya, as part of an effort to give economic relief to Africa, including some of the continent's poorest countries.

title: Interest Rates Rise At Citicorp Sale
description: Interest rates rose yesterday at Citicorp's weekly auction of 91-day and 182-day commercial paper.

title: UNIVERSITIES LOSE SHIELD OF SECRECY IN TENURE DISPUTES
description: Rejecting broad assertions of academic freedom, the Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that universities accused of discriminating in tenure decisions must make the relevant personnel files available to Federal investigators.

title: REAL $35 Million Winner Is Auto Assembly Worker
description: The real winner of the New York State Lottery, an automobile assembly-line worker from Westchester County, stepped forward yesterday to claim the $35 million Lotto jackpot prize.

title: INSIDE
description: Air Travel Fee Considered

title: Wine Talk
description: THERE was a time, not too long ago, when buying wine by the glass in a restaurant didn't seem to make much sense. A full bottle of good, inexpensive wine always seemed preferable to a glass of indifferent medium- or high-priced wine.

title: On the Trail Of Mexico's Accent Herb
description: LEAD: THE search for the elusive herb epazote ended on a seedy street here. There is nothing to lure the average tourist to Calle 9A, but it seemed likely that in its tiny groceries and shops, someone could provide a lead - after all, epazote is common in many Mexican kitchens.

title: Abortion, Harassment and RU 486
description: ''When [abortion] was illegal, the fear was of losing my medical license and going to prison. I had numerous blackmail attempts and people pulled guns on me,'' Dr. Curtis Boyd told a New York Times reporter recently. Now, he said, ''the harassment is tremendous. Every day I have to walk through picketers who call me a murderer.''

title: Rawley Agrees to Pact
description: The Boston Red Sox, trying to bolster their starting pitching rotation, reached agreement yesterday with Shane Rawley, a free agent whose 1989 team, the Minnesota Twins, chose not to sign him. Rawley, a left-hander who earned $4.25 million in his previous five-year contract, accepted a nonguaranteed $350,000 salary. If he starts regularly for the Red Sox, he can earn an additional $415,000.

title: Upheaval in the East: Japanese Aid;  $1 Billion Plan for Poland and Hungary
description: Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu of Japan announced a $1 billion economic aid package for Poland and Hungary today, and said Japan should play a political as well as economic role in Eastern Europe.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: COMPANIES

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;

Radice Fills Joint Post Of President and Chief
description: LEAD: James M. Adams 3d has been named president and chief executive of the Radice Corporation, a real estate development company based in Boca Raton, Fla., that emerged from bankruptcy in June.

title: Students' Skills Termed 'Dreadfully Inadequate'
description: Despite the efforts made in the 1980's to improve schools, the reading and writing skills of American students remain ''dreadfully inadequate,'' Education Secretary Lauro F. Cavazos said today in releasing the latest results of a national education assessment.

title: Recommendation Made
description: East German track and field officials have recommended that Wolfgang Schmidt, one of the top discus throwers in the world, be allowed to compete for West Germany, the East German newspaper Deutsches Sportecho reported yesterday.

title: Action Staffing Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Included losses from discontinued operations of $55,266. The company said year-ago shares outstanding were adjusted for 100 percent stock split effected in the form of a dividend, distributed on April 24, 1989.

title: Laidlaw Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: The results are in U.S. dollars.

title: User Fee to Expand Airports Gains Favor
description: Aviation officials in government and industry are expressing growing enthusiasm over the idea of letting airports levy a departure fee on every passenger to help pay for expanding the nation's air transportation system.

title: Browns' Mack Back in Form After an Unhappy Autumn
description: They talk about Kevin Mack on the Cleveland Browns as if he were a returning hero and not a fullback who missed much of the season because he was in prison on a drug charge.

title: Sales of Genentech Drug Improve
description: Genentech Inc. said today that sales of its main product, tissue plasminogen activator, grew 30 percent in 1989, to $196.4 million, compared with $151.4 million in 1988.

title: Riggs National reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Repligen Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Electrosound Group reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Included extraordinary tax credits of $72,000, or 3 cents a share, for the quarter and $214,000, or 8 cents a share, for the 6 months. c-Net loss and after an extraordinary tax credit of $351,000 for the quarter and 6 months. The company said the latest 6-month income from continuing operations of $397,000, or 15 cents a share, included a gain of $418,000 on sale of certain operations. Year-ago losses from continuing operations of $5,505,000 and $7,313,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, included a charge of $4.4 million from disposal of an investment.

title: Paramount Communications Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $1,247,700,000 and $1,453,900,000, or $12.12 a share, for the quarter and year, respectively. The income from discontinued operations and net earnings for the current year periods included a net gain of $1.2 billion from the sale of Associates First Capital Corp. Also included is an after-tax charge of $30.8 million to provide for additional costs applicable to certain operations previously discontinued. c-Included income from discontinued operations of $64,500,000 and $231,900,000, or $1.94 a share, for the quarter and year, respectively. Results for the latest periods included an after-tax charge of $84.3 million related to a major re-evaluation of the company's publishing business and a net gain of $7.4 million from the sale of two small Prentice Hall units. Latest year results included an aftertax charge of $48.3 million for costs incurred in the company's bid to acquire Time Inc.

title: Hong Kong After 1997: Blueprint for Rule Expected in March
description: As alarm mounts over China's tough attitude toward Hong Kong and hopes rise that Britain will introduce greater democracy here, there is a growing sense that Hong Kong's future will be largely determined in the next few months.

title: Colonial Investment Grade Municipal Trust reports earnings for As of Dec 31
description: Assets represented net asset value. The company said there are no year-ago comparable results because the fund began investment operations May 26, 1989.

title: Upheaval in the East;   A Frontier Turns Up Jewish Relics
description: Relics of a Jewish neighborhood, including a disused synagogue and a well-preserved cemetery, have come to light in the former death strip at the border with West Germany, it was reported today.

title: Article 612590 -- No Title
description: The Bristol-Myers Squibb Company said yesterday that it was writing off $855 million in the fourth quarter of 1989 to cover the costs of the Oct. 4 merger of the Bristol-Myers Company and the Squibb Corporation.

title: Trustco Bank Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results for 1988 have been adjusted for a 10-percent stock dividend paid in October 1989.

title: Poindexter Argues Reagan Should Have to Testify
description: Lawyers for John M. Poindexter urged a Federal judge today to reject legal arguments by former President Ronald Reagan that he should be excused from appearing as a witness in the Iran-contra trial of his former adviser.

title: Upheaval in the East;   Party to Organize in the East
description: The ultra-rightist Republican Party of West Germany, denounced as ''neo-Nazi'' by the East German Government, will organize for East German elections, its leader, Franz Schonhuber, said today at a news conference.

title: Review/Opera;   Balancing Farce and Poignancy In First 'Cosi' of the Met Season
description: Opera as a medium of musical expression is apparently not dead. The first ''Cosi Fan Tutte'' of the Metropolitan Opera's season on Monday evening proved this in a performance that effectively fluctuated between low farce and deepest poignancy. Led by Carol Vaness, a Fiordiligi who showed the vocal and emotional range of a young Elisabeth Schwarzkopf, the cast struck a fine balance in a work that requires high-wire poise by all concerned.

title: The U.S. and Panama: Noriega;   JUDGE POSTPONES MOVING OF NORIEGA
description: A Federal District Court judge today ordered the Government to delay moving Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega from a jail cell in downtown Miami to a more secure site out of town after defense lawyers demanded assurances that they would have adequate access to him.

title: Death of Patient, 78, Is Ruled a Homicide
description: The death of a 78-year-old Brooklyn man who died at Kings County Hospital on Monday after being disconnected from his respirator was ruled a homicide yesterday by the Medical Examiner's officer.

title: At the Nation's Table
description: IT is not easy to find a vegetarian restaurant in a blue-collar, burger-and-beer kind of town like Bridgeport. For that matter, it is not easy to find one anywhere in the New York metropolitan region. Perhaps that is why nonmeat eaters from Baltimore to Rhode Island flock to Bloodroot, a vegetarian restaurant and bookstore run by the Bloodroot feminist collective in Bridgeport's almost-gentrified Black Rock section.

title: A New Deal for Transit Cops?
description: For 30 years, New York law enforcement officials and politicians have debated the sensible idea of folding the Transit Police into the larger New York City Police Department. The election of a new Transit Police union leader alters the politics in a way that could finally break the stalemate.

title: U.S. Opposing Bid by Gillette
description: The Justice Department said today that it planned to file an antitrust suit to block the Gillette Company's acquisition of the Wilkinson Sword wet razor blade business outside the European Community.

title: Review/Theater;   Siamese Twins in a Musical That Stars Extremities
description: The search for bizarre material for musicals hits barrel bottom with ''20 Fingers, 20 Toes,'' a musical about Siamese twins, in this case the Hilton sisters, who starred in Tod Browning's film ''Freaks.'' Because the show is at the WPA, the company that first presented ''Little Shop of Horrors,'' one begins with expectations of a musical noir. Instead, ''20 Fingers, 20 Toes'' is merely monstrous, and coming so soon after '' Buzzsaw Berkeley,'' the abominable chain-saw musical, it should make the WPA jettison its so-called Silly Series.

title: Diagnostic Medical Instruents Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net income The company said the loss for the quarter was attributable to lower sales and a $457,000 write-off of excess inventory of components for older models of the company's existing products.

title: Dense-Pac Microsystems Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 25
description: b-Net income The company said that the loss in the latest 9 months was due to the company's inability to obtain sufficient memory chips to fill its orders due to worldwide shortage of these parts.

title: $12,000 Ceiling Seen For G.M.'s New Line
description: The General Motors Corporation's new division, the Saturn Corporation, will sell most of its cars for $10,000 to $12,000, a Saturn executive said today.

title: High Court, 5-4, Reaffirms Curbs On Trial's Use of Illegal Evidence
description: The Supreme Court, in a 5-to-4 decision, today reaffirmed its longstanding rule that illegally obtained evidence must be excluded from a criminal trial.

title: Mux Lab Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net income Results are in Canadian funds.

title: To Keep the Home Fires Burning
description: SINCE 1827, the William H. Jackson Company has sold ''everything for the fireplace.'' So when thoughts turn to having a fire on cold days and nights, this is one place to turn for andirons, screens and fireplace tools.

title: Spud Chandler, 82, Star Yankee Pitcher On 7 Pennant Clubs
description: Spud Chandler, who was voted the American League's most valuable player in 1943 and was twice a 20-game winner for the Yankees, died Tuesday. He was 82 years old. The cause of death was not disclosed.

title: Found Money Being Recycled To Assist the Neediest Cases
description: Sometimes the coins found on the streets of New York end up in the coffers of The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: SRI LANKA MUSLIMS THREATEN TO FIGHT
description: Leaders of Sri Lanka's Muslim minority, fearful that their interests will be ignored in the granting of more autonomy to Tamil areas, are threatening to appeal to Islamic nations for support.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Friday about AIDS in Texas rendered the numbers incorrectly in a state legislator's comment on the idea of adding $48 million to spending on AIDS programs. Apparently unable even to imagine an increase of that size, the legislator said, ''Four to eight million - why, that's unthinkable!''

title: Metro Datelines;   Part of 5th Ave. Shut In Search for a Leak
description: Fifth Avenue from 34th to 28th Streets was closed yesterday afternoon as engineers from the Environmental Protection Department searched for a water leak. A leak was reported at 12:20 P.M. in a building at 29th Street, and a crew opened a valve too wide and overloaded sewer lines, a spokeswoman for the department, Tina Casey, said. With nowhere else to go, the water bubbled up through manholes until the valve was closed just after 4 P.M. Repair crew continued to work on a major watermain break at Fifth Avenue and 18th Street that occurred last Saturday, knocking out some water and gas supplies in the immediate area.

title: Mets Keep Lyons
description: Barry Lyons and the Mets agreed yesterday to a one-year contract for $220,000, almost double Lyons's 1989 salary of $115,000. The catcher batted .247 last season. . . . John Candelaria of the Montreal Expos became the second player to file for salary arbitration. . . . Rafael Santana, released by the Yankees, joined the Cleveland Indians with a one-year nonguaranteed contract for $250,000. .(AP)

title: Deeds, Not Quayle
description: George Bush says he'll send Vice President Dan Quayle to patch up Latin American resentments of recent U.S. strong-arm tactics south of the border. That will cause some Americans to echo Casey Stengel's plaintive cry about the original New York Mets: ''Can't anybody here play this game?''

title: Quayle Urges U.S. Innovation on Space
description: Vice President Quayle, head of the White House's National Space Council, said today that the nation's space programs take too long and cost too much, and he called on the space agency to get new ideas and new technology from universities, Federal laboratories and private business.

title: Mist in Grocery's Produce Section Is Linked to Legionnaires' Disease
description: Health officials said today that an automatic misting machine in a Louisiana supermarket caused a major outbreak of Legionnaires' disease recently, and supermarket chains around the country said they had stopped using similar machines as a precaution.

title: Sale by Duriron
description: The Duriron Company sold its Janssen subsidiary's operations in Belgium and France to a French concern. Duriron did not disclose the sale price. Duriron, which makes equipment for the chemical industry, said the operations had been sold to Performance Plastic Products, a subsidiary of Compagnie Plastic Omnium.

title: Top Aide to Senator Riegle To Resign Post on March 1
description: The embattled chairman of the Senate Banking Committee, Donald W. Riegle Jr., announced today that his staff director, Kevin C. Gottlieb, will resign March 1 and be succeeded by Stephen B. Harris, the committee's general counsel.

title: Syracuse Goes Inside and Comes Out on Top
description: It was an annoying evening of basketball tonight for St. John's that grew more and more frustrating each time Syracuse worked the ball inside.

title: Sotheby's Is Ending Its Art Sales on Margin
description: Sotheby's said yesterday that van Gogh's ''Irises,'' the most expensive painting in the world, was back on the market. At the same time, the auction house disclosed that it was modifying its widely assailed policy on extending loans to art buyers.

title: Life Among the Stars: A Photographer's Dim View
description: For 30 years Douglas Kirkland has made his living by doing what some photographers might gladly do without charge: taking pictures of glamorous celebrities. In creating the kind of poster-perfect images publicity agents dream of - Marilyn Monroe clad only in silk sheets, Jack Nicholson with a burning match between his teeth, Kelly McGillis sliding out of her clothes on a California beach - he has few peers.

title: With Martial Law Lifted, An Eerie Quiet in Beijing
description: The streets of the capital were quiet this morning after the lifting of martial law, more than seven months after it had been imposed to crush the pro-democracy movement. But there appeared to be no slackening of the authorities' determination to suppress any new sign of unrest.

title: Alan Handley, Television Director, 77
description: Alan Handley, a television director and producer, died of a heart attack on Friday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 77 years old.

title: Chronicle
description: MARGARET E. MAHONEY, president of the Commonwealth Fund, will be the first woman to serve as a trustee of the Century Association. She is on the unopposed slate - all the others are men - that is to be elected tonight at the club's annual meeting in Manhattan.

title: Metro Bancshares Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The year-ago first quarter's per share earnings were not meaningful prior to conversion to stock ownership on Nov. 10, 1988.

title: Hollywood Starts an Invasion Of Europe's Booming Market
description: Hollywood has taken a close look at the growing European film market, and it likes what it sees.

title: Business Student in Crack Bust
description: A 19-year-old freshman at the University of Pennsylvania was arrested Tuesday night in a Harlem crack den, the police said yesterday.

THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;

Isidore & Paulson Wins
description: LEAD: Isidore & Paulson won a new-product assignment from Kraft General Food's cereal division. No information about the product was released. Billings were not disclosed either, but industry officials said that product-introduction campaigns typically have first-year billings of $10 million to $20 million.

title: Results Plus
description: N.B.A.

title: Endotronics Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: The company said comparable prior full year results are unavailable as the company was reorganized effective April 4, 1988.

title: U.N. Seeks Expanded Cambodia Role
description: As diplomatic efforts increase to revive negotiations for a peace settlement in Cambodia, a senior United Nations official said today that the organization was ready to play a sharply expanded role in the country.

title: Kenya Stressing Tea
description: Kenya said Tuesday that it would increase payments to its tea producers in an apparent bid to increase output of the commodity. President Daniel arap Moi announced that the Government would raise its initial payment to tea farmers some time this month to 3 shillings (14 cents) a kilogram (2.2 pounds) from 1.9 shillings (9 cents). Tea industry sources speculated that the price increase was aimed at stimulating tea-growing, which appears to have better prospects than coffee, Kenya's main export.

title: Children and Their Pets: Unexpected Psychological Benefits
description: In new research into the bonds between humans and animals, therapists are discovering that pets provide unexpected psychological benefits for children beyond the obvious.

title: From Nissan, The Future On Wheels
description: THOSE taking the pulse of future automobile design often look beyond industry soothsayers to concept cars. If Nissan Design International Inc.'s Gobi concept car, introduced last week at the North American International Automobile Show in Detroit, is any indication, trends for the 1990's will include soft squeezable materials and a separation of components vaguely reminiscent of deconstructivism.

title: Boston Technology Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Included extraordinary credits of $175,409, or 1 cent a share for the quarter and $450,065, or 2 cents a share, for the 9 months. c-Net loss

Reeds Jewelers reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Included an accounting adjustment gain of $446,000, or 13 cents a share.

title: Bush Plans Trips South
description: President Bush will travel on Jan. 19 to Atlanta for a speech and Miami for a fund-raising dinner for Gov. Bob Martinez of Florida. Mr. Bush's Atlanta speech will be to the National Association of Homebuilders, the White House said. In Florida, he will tour Everglades National Park before the dinner.

title: Conston Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 25
Sunair Electronics Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $7,339,000. c-Net income and after a loss from discontinued operations of $2,950,000 and an extraordinary credit of $358,000, or 24 cents a share. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: BRIEFS
description: * BC Sugar Refinery Ltd., Vancouver, British Columbia, said it would acquire a 50 percent stake in Lantic Sugar Ltd., a division of Steinberg Inc., Montreal, an operator of retail food markets and department stores, for $110 million Canadian ($94.8 million United States).

title: Soviets Are Still Stockpiling Ammunition, U.S. Study Says
description: The Soviet Army is maintaining large stockpiles of ammunition and fuel in Eastern European nations as it withdraws some of its units, the Defense Intelligence Agency concluded in a recent assessment.

title: Design Flaw Is Cited in School Collapse
description: A state commission concluded today that a flawed design contributed to the collapse of a school cafeteria wall in high winds last November and the subsequent deaths of nine children.

title: Owners Offer Revenue-Sharing Deal
description: In an effort to implement a pay-for-performance salary scale, negotiators for baseball's club owners offered yesterday to share 48 percent of their revenue with the players.

title: A New Producer Is Hired for 'Roseanne'
description: Executives at ABC and the network's most successful program, ''Roseanne,'' said this week that concerns about the star of the show prompted a decision to hire an additional executive producer on the program.

title: Court Bars Bid for Drug Therapy on Demand
description: A legal move to force New York City and State to provide drug treatment to anyone who demands it has been dismissed in State Supreme Court in Manhattan.

title: Albany's Optimism Wanes As Budget Shortfall Grows
description: After several months of maintaining what analysts said was an overly optimistic view of New York's finances, the Cuomo administration today acknowledged that the state would end the fiscal year with a shortfall of almost $700 million.

title: F.D.A. Withdraws Approval for Jarvik-7 Heart
description: The Food and Drug Administration has withdrawn its approval of the continued experimental use of the Jarvik artificial heart because of deficiencies found in the manufacturer's plant operations, an FDA spokesman said today.

title: Noriega Co-Defendant Seeking Secret Papers
description: Lawyers for two defendants named in the drug-trafficking case against Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega filed a series of motions today in Federal District Court, including one requesting classified documents.

title: U.N., Bowing to Soviets, Halts Its Baltic Contacts
description: Bowing to Soviet pressure, the United Nations Secretariat has agreed to suspend the informal contacts it has conducted for several months with Baltic nationalist groups seeking independence from Moscow, a senior official has announced.

title: Maston E. O'Neal Jr., Former Congressman, 82
description: Maston E. O'Neal Jr., a Democrat who served three terms in the House of Representatives in the 1960's, died of heart disease on Tuesday at his home in Bainbridge. He was 82 years old.

title: Personal Health
description: In March 1982, the Centers for Disease Control, the nation's final authority on communicable diseases, predicted that measles would be eradicated from the United States within six months.

title: Founder Resigns as Chief Of the Carter Organization
description: Donald C. Carter, the flamboyant adviser to a generation of takeover artists, resigned his administrative duties yesterday at the Carter Organization, the firm he founded in 1974 to solicit proxies from shareholders in takeovers and other corporate contests.

title: Intermagnetics General Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 26
New Coach at Rutgers Is an N.F.L. Assistant
description: Doug Graber, a stranger to New Jersey and Rutgers football, was named today as the head coach of the Scarlet Knights.

title: Home S&L reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the decrease in earnings resulted mainly from a $500,000 increase in the loss reserve on bonds owned by the association that are secured by pools of Mobile Home Loans issued by a Conner Corp. unit.

title: Looking Back for Designs of the Future
description: THE National Endowment for the Arts has published a resource for designers, ''By Design 2,'' that describes all the design projects it sponsored from 1977 to 1987.

title: Egyptian Bonds Are Selling Slowly
description: Egypt has sold only 11 percent of the new dollar bonds it issued in November but is optimistic that it will eventually find buyers and create a new capital market, Mahmoud Abdel-Aziz, deputy chairman of the National Bank of Egypt, said today.

title: CAMPEAU'S STORES MEET THE DEADLINE TO PAY SUPPLIERS
description: The American retailing operations of the Campeau Corporation, which include some of the nation's most famous department stores, said yesterday that they had met a deadline for paying suppliers for December merchandise.

description: Midstream

title: Nigerian Military Chief Postpones Visit to U.S.
description: Confronted with a shake-up in his Cabinet, the President of Nigeria, Gen. Ibrahim Babangida, has postponed a visit to the United States.

title: Xerox Loses Suit Over Age Discrimination
description: More than $9 million in damages has been awarded to a Texas woman by a Federal District Court jury that found that the Xerox Corporation discriminated against her because of her age.

title: Sheldahl Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 1
description: b-Included $1,212,000 tax credit and a $3.2 million charge to close an operation. c-Net income

description: All share earnings have been adjusted to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid Nov. 6, 1989; a 25 percent stock dividend paid March 16, 1989; and a 50 percent stock dividend paid March 31, 1988.

title: McCormick & Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $83 million, or $3.78 a share. c-After a loss of $923,000 for the quarter and income of $721,000, or 3 cents a share, for the year, both from discontinued operations, and the year also included a gain of $6.4 million, or 27 cents a share, from the cumulative effect on prior years of accounting change for deferred tax liability. The latest periods' share earnings from the income from continuing operations included gain of 11 cents a share on sale of operations in Brazil. The year-ago periods' share earnings from the income from continuing operations included gain of 2 cents a share for the quarter and 14 cents a share for the year on the sale of a product line.

title: Dionex Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Hallmark Cards In Stock Buyback
description: The greeting card giant Hallmark Cards Inc. said it had bought back $289 million of its own stock from the Hall family and from the company's employee stock ownership plan. The stock was bought Dec. 28 with ''available corporate cash reserves,'' a Hallmark spokesman, Steve Doyal, said. The shares were repurchased so the employee plan would have enough cash to pay for future retirements, he said.

title: Intertrans Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
School District Won't Eat Tuna
description: Aurora's schools have crossed tuna off the lunch menu at the behest of a dozen students who object to fishermen's using nets that can drown dolphins. An associate district superintendent, Dave Zeckser, who approved the ban, said the 43 schools use 40 cases of tuna a year. The 26,000-student district is following the lead of schools in Milford, Conn., where a tuna boycott was begun as part of a nationwide effort to pressure fishermen into using fishing lines instead of nets.

title: 5% Stake Acquired In Paine Webber
description: The Tweedy, Browne Company, a New York investment firm, has purchased a 5 percent stake in the Paine Webber Group. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Tweedy, Browne said the shares had been purchased as an investment.

THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;

Accounts
description: LEAD: * Reader's Digest magazine, to John Emmerling, for its trade advertising, with billings of $2 million.

title: Israeli Camping Store Offers Tips From Afar
description: At first glance, it looks like an ordinary camping store stocked with waterproof flashlights, down-filled sleeping bags and 12 brands of bug spray. But a schedule on the front window gives a hint of the shop's larger purpose.

title: Barkley's 12-Footer Wins It
description: Charles Barkley ended the Knicks' comeback run tonight.

title: Seven-Year Notes Well Received
description: A successful auction of $7.5 billion worth of new seven-year Treasury notes helped to bring prices in the credit markets off their lows yesterday. As a consequence, prices in the secondary market for Treasury notes and bonds closed narrowly mixed.

LAOS IS COURTING NEW BENEFACTORS
description: Laos, one of the world's least-developed countries by the standards of the United Nations, is seeking several sources of foreign aid to replace assistance from Communist countries that now have other preoccupations.

title: Lewis Assails Johnson
description: Carl Lewis has accused Ben Johnson of having supplemented his steroid use with an amphetamine before competing in the 100-meter race at the Olympic Games in Seoul, South Korea. Lewis made the accusation in a report published Tuesday in The Washington Post. He refused to specify the amphetamine.

title: Fuller (H.B.) Co.  (O) reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Ozone Issue: Economics of a Ban
description: As industrial nations move toward a ban on ozone-depleting chlorofluorocarbons - the refrigerant used in air-conditioners and refrigerators -by 2000, another problem looms: the likely replacement, although an improvement, also harms the atmosphere.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Tuesday about competition among New York department stores misstated the amount of debt held by R.H. Macy & Company when it bought the California-based Bullock's and I. Magnin stores in May 1988. It was $3.5 billion, not $7 billion. Macy's current debt is $4.8 billion.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Tuesday about Horace Stoneham, the baseball owner who moved the Giants to the West Coast, misidentified his daughter. She is Valleda Rupert.

description: Several governors whose states have already cut the air pollution causing acid rain today denounced a plan that would have them help pay for reducing the problem in other parts of the country.

description: The Devils were so efficient in every aspect of their game tonight in their 6-3 triumph over the Penguins that it infuriated Mario Lemieux.

description: Defaults on corporate bonds more than doubled in 1989, according to an investor research company that tracks the fixed-income markets.

description: The Ziff-Davis Publishing Company, the unit of the Ziff Communications Company that publishes magazines about computers, announced Tuesday that William Lohse had resigned as president.
