title: Cutbacks by Ames
description: Ames Department Stores Inc. cut 85 jobs in its corporate offices and announced plans to rename the last surviving Zayre stores as Ames outlets. The discount retailer, acknowledging that it had overestimated customer loyalty to the 392 Zayre stores it bought in 1988, also said that a sluggish fourth quarter would prevent the company from showing a profit this year.

title: At Campeau, All Details Are Secret
description: The board of the Campeau Corporation met today for the third day in a row, amid great secrecy, to consider its options in the face of the possible bankruptcy confronting its American retail subsidiaries.

description: b-Included a net gain of $944,000 on sale of interest in Direct Action Marketing Inc. c-Net loss

title: KEY RATES
Late Goal By Leetch Brings a Tie
description: Brian Leetch, his hockey stick the wand it can be instead of the useless instrument it had been, plucked the puck out of the air. Sliding backward, he pulled the puck to the top of the slot and shot.

title: Helen Steele Reece, Educator, 99
description: Helen Steele Reece, founder and director of the Reece School, a private elementary school for children with emotional and learning disabilities, died in her sleep on Monday at her home in Manhattan. She was 99 years old.

title: Veronex Resources Ltd. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Last year Veronex reported a $15,052,000, or $1.59 a share, revaluation of assets.

title: No Special Shield for Universities
description: The Supreme Court has ruled unanimously that universities, as employers, enjoy no special exemption from civil rights laws that allow Federal investigators to see their personnel files. It is a correct decision, even if too glibly dismissive of serious arguments for confidentiality in academic employment decisions.

title: Publishing Units Merge
description: John Wiley & Sons Inc. announced yesterday that it had combined its domestic scientific and technical publishing division with its domestic professional and trade publishing division. Stephen Kippur, who heads professional and trade publishing, will become group vice president of the combined operation. William Pesce, who was also promoted to group vice president, will continue to manage Wiley's North American educational publishing sector.

title: N.C.A.A. Stiffens Drug Penalties And Expands Testing in Football
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association voted overwhelmingly today to require random, year-round testing of players in major football programs for performance-enhancing drugs, and to impose stiffer penalties for violators, in any sport, of the N.C.A.A.'s drug policies.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;

Shift for Mayonnaise
description: LEAD: CPC International Inc. has awarded the advertising account for its Hellmann's and Best Foods mayonnaise brands to BBDO New York. In winning the $20 million account, BBDO beat out the incumbent, Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising, and Jordan, McGrath, Case & Taylor. Last year BBDO won CPC's Skippy peanut butter account.

title: Turnaround on the Farm As Price of Milk Rises
description: Gene Woodward stood looking out over a barnyard where his cows stood chewing, a cold drizzle dampening their black and white flanks. Their bellies were full and their udders heavy with milk.

title: Gencorp Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Included losses of $5 million for the quarter and $7 million for the year, from discontinued operations, a loss of $1 million and a gain of $209 million, or $6.58 a share, for the quarter and year, respectively, both on the sale of discontinued operations. c-Net income d-Included income from discontinued operations of $4 million, or 11 cents a share, for the quarter and $3 million, or 10 cents a share, for the year, and gains on sale of discontinued operations of $4 million, or 11 cents a share, and $9 million, or 27 cents a share, for the quarter and year, respectively; the year also included a gain of $3 million, or 10 cents a share, from the cumulative effect on prior years of an accounting change. The company said both the latest quarter and year included a $52 million pretax provision for restructuring and unusual items, compared with a $12 million provision in the previous year for both the quarter and year.

title: U.S. to Seek Lower Federal Role in Transportation
description: In a preview of the Bush Administration's national transportation policy, Transportation Secretary Samuel K. Skinner today called for state and local governments to pay more of the costs of programs that have been financed primarily by the Federal Government.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: WOODWORKING clamps are perhaps most often associated with furniture making and repair. But they are also a boon in tackling home maintenance projects. Knowing how to select and use clamps broadens the range of tasks that can be performed and makes many of them easier.

title: Police Say Man's Family Cut Respirator
description: After disconnecting the respirator that was keeping an elderly Brooklyn man alive, three of his children physically held doctors back from reconnecting the life-support equipment, the police and officials at Kings County Hospital said yesterday.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: A Teary Doctor Tells of AIDS From a Needle
description: Dr. Veronica Prego calmly recounted yesterday her four years of terrifying uncertainty from the time she pricked her finger with an AIDS-contaminated needle at Kings County Hospital in Brooklyn to the day she learned she had contracted the disease.

Kentucky Utilities Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a gain of $11,470,000, or 30 cents a share, from the cumulative effect on prior years of accrual of unbilled revenues.

title: Chronicle
description: STU JACKSON, the coach of the New York Knicks, became a father a day earlier than planned yesterday when his wife, DR. JANET TAYLOR, gave birth to twin girls by Caesarean section at Northern Westchester Hospital in Mount Kisco, N.Y. The girls, still unnamed, weighed 6 pounds 10 ounces and 4 pounds 8 ounces.

title: Calls Abroad May Cost Less
description: The MCI Communications Corporation today announced cut-rate calling plans to Western Europe, the Pacific and Canada. The plans - Call Europe, Call Pacific and Call Canada -will provide flat per-minute rates on weekdays and all weekend for a $3 monthly fee, MCI said.

title: Asiana in Tokyo Debut
description: South Korea's fledgling second airline, Asiana, made its inaugural international flight today when a Boeing 737-400 flew to Tokyo from Seoul with 147 passengers, a company spokesman said. The private airline, competing with Korean Air Lines, also privately owned, will fly to Tokyo four times a week. Asiana began domestic flights in December 1988 and now serves 10 domestic routes. The airline is owned by the Kumho Group, which also operates a road transport network.

title: Great Bay Bankshares Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Contender for Health Chief Attacked on AIDS
description: Advocates for AIDS patients are mobilizing to stop the appointment of the top contender for New York City Health Commissioner, the Health Commissioner of Indiana, saying they object to the AIDS policies he supported there.

title: Immucor reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Talman Home Federal S&L Assn reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Beijing's Very Small 'Big Event'
description: Prime Minister Li Peng presents China's lifting of martial law in Beijing as ''a big event.'' And the Bush Administration claims it as vindication of Brent Scowcroft's recent highly visible visit to Beijing. They are wrong.

title: Joseph Dermody, 84, Former Labor Leader
description: Joseph Dermody, a retired labor organizer and former president of Local 12 of the United Electrical, Radio and Machine Workers of America, died of complications of diabetes on Friday at the Waverly Care Center in New Canaan, Conn. He was 84 years old and lived in New Canaan.

title: BI Inc reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Dan Graham's Social Commentaries
description: DAN GRAHAM'S photographs of suburban tract houses and model-home interiors explore the cliches of the 1960's, ''the ticky-tacky houses that the folk singers sang about,'' said the 47-year-old artist, who grew up in, yes, the suburbs.

title: Who's Demagoguing Capital Gains?
description: ''I am sick and tired of the demagogues who call this a tax cut for the rich.'' Thus President Bush blasted critics of his plan to cut the capital gains tax. But such talk shouldn't frighten the critics, who have a lot to offer Mr. Bush on this subject - if he'd only, well, cut out the demagogy.

title: Talking Deals;   Social Stature's Role in Takeovers
description: THE Social Register would seem to be an unlikely place to look when predicting the course of a takeover battle. But a new piece of business research suggests that might be a good idea.

title: Farm Credit Issues Total $635 Million
description: The Federal Farm Credit Banks Funding Corporation yesterday priced at par a total of $635 million in consolidated systemwide bonds with maturities of three years and five years.

title: Why a Drink for a Woman Acts Like Two for a Man
description: Women become drunk more quickly than men because their stomachs are less able to neutralize alcohol, scientists have found.

title: Reporter's Notebook;   From Dictator of Panama to Dictator of Fashion
description: Manuel Antonio Noriega may have driven tourists from Panama, but he is the object of a promising cottage industry here in his temporary residence.

title: Banponce Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Hong Kong's Governor Seeking to Ease Strain
description: Hong Kong's Governor, Sir David Wilson, arrived today in Beijing for three days of talks with Chinese leaders intended to ease the hostility and recriminations that have developed between China and Hong Kong since the military crackdown in June.

title: Jail Officers File Suit Over Abortion Rule
description: A suit filed yesterday against the New York City Correction Department contended that pregnant officers were told to have abortions or resign. The suit, in Federal District Court in Manhattan, said a policy for pregnant officers was ''designed to harass, intimidate and abuse.''

title: Soviet Bloc Trade Group Says It Needs to Make Big Changes
description: Leaders of the Soviet bloc's trade group, Comecon, agreed today that their crisis-ridden organization needed a drastic overhaul to guide it toward a market-oriented system after four decades of stifling central planning.

title: Butler Aviation Chief Sees a Brighter Future
description: The Butler Aviation Corporation, a company that has had some finanacial and performance problems, is getting a fresh start with new owners and a new chief executive, William W. Boisture Jr. The appointment comes four months after a Fort Worth investment firm, Acadia Partners L.P., which is backed by the Robert M. Bass Group, bought Butler from North American Ventures Inc. for $83 million.

title: Perkin-Elmer Accord Seen
description: A Federal Government official familiar with the negotiations said yesterday that an agreement had been reached to insure that at least part of the Perkin-Elmer Corporation's troubled Semiconductor Equipment Group was purchased by an American buyer.

title: Battle Starts Before Game
description: In the final days before they play for the American Football Conference championship, the Denver Broncos and the Cleveland Browns continued to wage a small war about the mile-high air.

title: 4 Soldiers Are Killed In Crash of Helicopter
description: An Army UH-60 Blackhawk helicopter crashed during desert exercises Tuesday, killing all four soldiers aboard, a base spokesman said.

title: Machine Technology Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
East German Coalition Is Pulling Apart
description: Three non-Communist parties in East Germany's Government threatened today to leave the coalition if the Communist Prime Minister, Hans Modrow, did not hasten reforms and abandon efforts to create a new domestic security force to replace the one that was disbanded.

title: Yields End Week Down
description: Yields of tax-exempt and taxable money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report were down for the week ended yesterday.

title: Cooperstown Doors Open Quicker Now
description: rrYear by year, the brethren of baseball writers seem to be getting softer. Or smarter. Or maybe both.

title: Cablevision Refunds
description: About 72,000 Cablevision subscribers in Long Island, New York City and Yonkers will get a total of $1.1 million in refunds from the state's largest cable television company because of Yankee, Ranger and Knick games they were either overcharged for or did not receive. The agreement was announced today by Gov. Mario Cuomo and State Attorney General Robert Abrams.

title: Unisys, I.B.M. Set Up Units
description: The International Business Machines Corporation and the Unisys Corporation said separately yesterday that they had set up special units to help customers manage computer operations.

title: Margaret E. Hasebroock, Club Leader, 83
description: Margaret E. Hasebroock, former president of the General Federation of Women's Clubs, died Sunday at Bryan Memorial Hospital, Lincoln, Neb., after a brief illness. She was 83 years old and lived in Lincoln.

title: Doubt Raised on Noriega Prosecutor
description: When Dexter Lehtinen took charge of the United States Attorney's office here 18 months ago he pictured himself as a battlefield commander. At one meeting he waved a replica of a Russian-made AK-47 assault rifle and circulated a two-sentence message: ''No Guts. No Glory.''

title: SHUTTLE DEPLOYS A NAVY SATELLITE
description: The crew of the space shuttle Columbia released a Navy communications satellite in orbit today and sped toward their planned rendezvous with a satellite they hope to snatch and bring back to Earth.

title:
VOICES OF THE NEW GENERATION;

America Needs Its Nerds
description: LEAD: There is something very wrong with the system of values in a society that has only derogatory terms like nerd and geek for the intellectually curious and academically serious.

title: Wounds of Polish-German Border Don't Heal
description: To the Editor:

title: I.R.A. Political Aide Charged in Terror Case
description: Danny Morrison, a senior official of Sinn Fein, the political wing of the Irish Republican Army, was formally charged today with conspiring to commit murder and two other terrorism offenses.

title: Metro Matters;   Out-of-Towners Vs. New Yorkers: Vying for Posts
description: Lee P. Brown, Joseph A. Fernandez and Alan F. Kiepper have something in common besides being named to the three most prominent appointive public posts in New York City: None is a New Yorker.

title: Canadian Pacific's D.&H. Bid Chosen
description: Canadian Pacific Ltd. won the right to buy the bankrupt Delaware & Hudson Railway for $35 million, beating five other bidders. Francis P. Dicello, a Washington lawyer who is the trustee of the D.& H., announced his selection of Canadian Pacific in United States Bankruptcy Court.

title: To Avoid Measles: A Vaccination Guide
description: Here is a summary of the new measles vaccination recommendations issued by the Federal Centers for Disease Control:

title: Dragone Elevated to N.Y.R.A. Chairman
description: Allan R. Dragone, who is better known in business circles than the racing world, was elected yesterday as the chairman of the New York Racing Association, the nonprofit corporation that operates Aqueduct, Belmont Park and Saratoga.

title: Notebook;   Rumors and Intrigue in Toronto
description: The intrigue at Maple Leaf Gardens is like the court politics of the throne room in a castle of an ancient kingdom.

title: Surprise and Skepticism On Campeau Payments
description: Executives at some of Seventh Avenue's largest fashion houses were pleasantly surprised and elated yesterday when the Toronto-based Campeau Corporation notified them that they were going to be paid for goods shipped in December.

title: Note Cards Created For a Cause
description: INSPIRED by Unicef, the Design Industries Foundation for AIDS has recently published a series of 12 boxed note cards by leading graphic designers. Under the aegis of ID Magazine, the designers - Neville Brody, Ivan Chermayeff, April Greiman, Milton Glaser, Michael Vanderbyl and M & Co. - were asked to create cards that could symbolize the foundation. ''Some approached it from a very political point of view, others from the strictly decorative,'' said Chee Pearlman, ID's associate editor.

title: Villanova Star Named Top Female Athlete
description: Vicki Huber of Villanova, the National Collegiate Athletic Association champion in the indoor and outdoor 3,000 meters, has been awarded the Honda-Broderick Cup as outstanding collegiate female athlete of the year. She received the award Tuesday at the N.C.A.A. convention in Dallas.

title: Tyson Promoter Sued
description: Donovan (Razor) Ruddock, a heavyweight contender, and Murad Muhammad, his promoter, are suing Don King, the promoter for the heavyweight champion Mike Tyson, for breach of contract.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''No matter what may happen in the world, we shall unswervingly follow the socialist road.''

title: Corrections
description: An article on the Health page on Dec. 28 about breast implants misidentified a New York City lawyer who represents women who received them. She is Denise Dunleavy.

title: Orion Pictures Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Washington Journal;   The Dress for Success A Second Time Around
description: ''Secondhand Rose,'' the Fanny Brice song of pluck and pathos, has become an anthem of the up-and-coming here, with two Capitol Hill consignment stores doing land-office business reselling the pinstripes of the powerful.

title: Q&A
description: Keeping Decks Young

title: Gillette Reacts To U.S. Move
description: The Gillette Company said today that it was surprised and disappointed by a Federal Government decision to bring an antitrust suit to block its acquisition of the United States operations of Wilkinson Sword Inc.

title: Bank of Granite Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
From Concert Operas to Cliburn, Carnegie Plans a Starry Season
description: Carnegie Hall announced details yesterday of its star-studded 1990-91 centennial season, which will include an ambitious concert-opera series, 14 newly commissioned compositions, the return of Van Cliburn to the hall stage, a six-week folk-music festival in Weill Recital Hall and a 10-day festival culminating in a gala concert on the hall's 100th anniversary on May 5, 1991. Throughout the season, there will be a more lavish than usual array of visiting American and international artists, orchestras and ensembles.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * R. R. Donnelley & Sons Co., Chicago, the printing concern, named Roger D. Missimer senior vice president of its book group.

title: Metro Datelines;   Woman, 88, Killed In Her Apartment
description: An 88-year-old woman was found beaten to death in her ransacked Queens apartment last night, the apparent victim of a robbery, the police said.

title: HONG KONG CAMPS TERMED INHUMAN
description: An American refugee monitoring group said today that conditions in Hong Kong's closed detention camps for Vietnamese, where more than 44,000 men, women and children are imprisoned, were ''inhuman.''

title: Newmil Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Purina Setting Up New Pet Food Unit
description: The Ralston Purina Company said it would establish a new division for its specialty pet food unit and to promote its premium Pro Plan pet foods. Pro-Visions Pet Specialty Enterprises will market Pro Plan products to pet shops, feed stores and veterinarians, the company said.

title: Douglas MD-11 Ready for Flight
description: The MD-11, a new wide-body jetliner from the McDonnell Douglas Corporation, is ready for flight. The plane is the first new trijet introduced since the Douglas DC-10 and Lockheed L-1011 two decades ago.

title: Richard P. Hayes, Theater Teacher, 60
description: Richard P. Hayes, a theater arts teacher and drama critic, died after a heart attack on Monday in his Manhattan home. He was 60 years old.

title: Lead Effects Still Harmful Over Years
description: Young adults who were exposed to lead early in life have trouble reading and finishing high school, suggesting that even relatively small amounts can cause permanent brain damage, a new study indicates.

title: Review/Dance;   And Now It's Men's Turn To Show Off At the Joyce
description: Last year it was Womanworks. This year it is Man-Made. The Joyce Theater, with an unabashed gift for obvious marketing gimmicks, has just opened a series devoted to male choreographers - the counterpart of a season that focused on women.

title: ACC Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Bridge
description: Many bidding guidelines seem valid until they are examined closely: irritating exceptions occur, and they are difficult to classify.

title: A Town Puts Itself Up for Sale
description: When residents here decided that their corner of Palm Beach County was becoming too crowded and noisy, they put the town up for sale: the 75 houses, the streets and sidewalks, the town hall, the steeple and all.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;

People
description: LEAD: * Frank Blaney, Kevin Brown, Thomas Deska, Mark Liska, Thomas Luke and Henry Smith have been named senior vice presidents at Campbell-Mithun-Esty Advertising.

title: Savings Directors Penalized
description: Regulators today penalized two directors of the failed Silverado Banking Savings and Loan Association in Denver.

title: Times Appoints Chief Art Critic
description: The appointment of Michael Kimmelman as chief art critic of The New York Times was announced yesterday by Max Frankel, executive editor. Mr. Kimmelman succeeds John Russell, who asked to retire from daily coverage but will continue to contribute reviews and articles to The Times.

title: An Office Tower On Park Ave. Will Be Rebuilt
description: The 32-story former ITT building in Manhattan will be redesigned and substantially rebuilt starting early next year, Mayor David N. Dinkins said yesterday, making it ''the first new building project on Park Avenue in more than a decade.''

title: First Federal Savings Bank of Puerto Rico reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Computer Data Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Catholic School Expels 17-Year-Old Bride
description: The principal of a Roman Catholic high school has expelled a newlywed student, saying her marriage set a bad example.

title: Review/Jazz;   From a Hard-Bop Revivalist
description: Jazz's younger generation flexed its muscles on Monday night at the Knitting Factory, where Ralph Peterson Jr. led a quintet in music from his album, ''Volition,'' to be released in early March. As composer and drummer, Mr. Peterson is a wholehearted hard-bop revivalist, working in the style of Art Blakey's Jazz Messengers and the mid-1960's Miles Davis quintet members at their most complex.

title: U.S. to Pare War Games in South Korea
description: The United States and South Korea will reduce the size of their annual joint military maneuvers to improve the climate for negotiations between North and South Korea, President Roh Tae Woo said today.

title: Chronicle
description: Treasury Secretary NICHOLAS F. BRADY is back at work on crutches this week, a little more than three weeks after he had surgery to replace his right hip. Mr. Brady, 59 years old, had suffered from arthritis for many years and had begun to walk with a pronounced limp.

title: CLOSE TO HOME
description: A FRIEND said once that he wished I'd write about men. But I will have nothing to say, I protested. I don't make gender distinctions. I think about men the same way I think about women: I either like somebody or I don't. Neither sex has a premium on any one quality. I couldn't possibly begin a sentence with ''Men are . . .'' or ''Men do . . . .'' I couldn't possibly generalize. No, really.

title: Leaking Exxon Pipe Ran Through Regulatory Limbo
description: The Exxon leak-detection system that failed off Staten Island last week had never been checked for flaws by any oversight agency because of a series of gaps in regulatory responsibilities, company executives and various Federal and state officials said yesterday.

title: Washington Federal Savings & Loan reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Coke Settles Case in Europe
description: The European Community Commission said Tuesday that it had closed an anti-competition case against the Coca-Cola Company, satisfied that the soft-drink maker had ended anti-competitive practices in the European Community.

title: Mansho T. Khilnani, Radiologist, 70
description: Dr. Mansho T. Khilnani, a radiologist and educator, died of a chronic heart ailment on Jan. 4 at Coral Reef Hospital in Miami. He was 70 years old and lived in Scarsdale, N.Y.

title: Metro Datelines;   Award Honors Head Of Landmarks Fund
description: Friends of the Upper East Side Historic Districts, a historic preservation group, will present its Ralph C. Menapace Memorial Award to Barbaralee Diamonstein-Spielvogel, chairwoman of the New York Landmarks Preservation Foundation, this evening at the Asia Society, at Park Avenue and 70th Street. A reception will follow the 6 P.M. ceremony.

title: Zubki Duze Journal;   To Market, to Market: How Will Garden Grow?
description: Jan Kitlinski's 30-acre farm is undeniably primitive, with a horse-drawn cart that lugs coal to his home and dozens of squawking fowl wandering about the bare-earth front yard.

title: Review/Television;   The Care and Grooming of Beauty Queens
description: The scenery of tonight's edition of ''48 Hours'' consists mainly of beauty-contest beauties posing, parading and dancing, sort of, in bathing suits, evening dresses and other snugly fitted costumes. ''Behind the Smile'' takes us offstage and backstage to meet several young women competing for the title of Miss California, Miss U.S.A. and other crowns. There they are, working on their hair, faces and bodies, practicing how to walk and smile at the same time, talking about their lives, dreams and nose jobs and trying, touchingly, to seem bright and upbeat in interviews.

title: European and Asian Buyers Push Gold Sharply Higher
description: Precious metals prices climbed yesterday, led by increased demand for gold in Europe and Asia.

title: When Hollywood Was Golden, the Movie Sets Were, Too
description: THE Staffordshire dog slammed against the wall is bound for an oblivion it well deserves. The topiary deer suffers a decapitation as merited as Marie Antoinette's. As for the glitzy chandelier in ''The War of the Roses,'' that appalling confection looks better smashed into smithereens as the movie ends.

title: Peoples Bancorp-N.C.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
In the East Bloc, It's Trade or Fail
description: Moscow's proposal that members of Comecon, the Soviet-led trade bloc, begin trading at market prices is a sign that the old order is crumbling. To help fill the void, the West should move quickly to encourage new forms of economic collaboration among Eastern European nations. Otherwise, support for democratic government and for reform itself could be undermined.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;

President's Post Filled At a Recovering MAI
description: LEAD: MAI Basic Four Inc., a minicomputer company recovering from a costly attempt to acquire a competitor, yesterday named Fred D. Anderson Jr. its president and chief operating officer.

title: Exxon Names Executive on the Environment
description: The Exxon Corporation yesterday named Edwin J. Hess, a veteran executive, as corporate vice president for the environment and safety, the first time it has elevated environmental concerns to the senior executive level.

title: Banks Told to Add Reserves
description: Federal regulators have ordered banks to more than double their reserves for loans to Argentina, an official said today.

title: Groups Protest Nissan Ad, Saying It Glorifies Speeding
description: For Super Bowl watchers, the extravagantly produced commercials shown during the football classic are sometimes as exciting as the action on the field. But some highway safety advocates, insurance companies and physicians have expressed outrage over a Nissan advertisement, scheduled for broadcast during Super Bowl XXIV, that they say glorifies dangerous high-speed driving.

title: Chronicle
description: Today is moving day for JOYCE DINKINS and DAVID N. DINKINS. They are leaving their three-bedroom apartment in the Washington Heights section of Manhattan for Gracie Mansion, the formal, Federal-style mayoral residence on the East River.

title: Taxpayer Bears the Expense of Public Pensions
description: To the Editor:

title: 49ers Not Exactly One Big Happy Family
description: Last year in Miami, Tim McKyer offered sights and sounds not often seen before a Super Bowl. There he sat at a news conference beside his fellow cornerback, Don Griffin, promoting ''the Coverage Brothers.'' He was wearing a T-shirt that read ''the Blanket'' and Griffin wore one that read ''the Quilt.'' McKyer explained how the San Francisco 49ers' secondary would smother the Cincinnati Bengals' receivers, mixing humor and candor that reporters flocked to record.

title: Letter: On Yugoslavia;   Why Not Ethnic Self-Determination?
description: To the Editor:

title: S.E.C. Cites Lawyer Over Grand Met
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday charged a Minneapolis lawyer with trading on inside information about Grand Metropolitan P.L.C.'s takeover of the Pillsbury Company in 1988.

title: Primaries Also Needed For Special Elections
description: To the Editor:

title: Stocks Continue to Slide; Dow Off by 15.36
description: The stock market continued to retreat yesterday on sharply higher volume.

title: Protesters Are Pleased, But Housing to Proceed
description: Yonkers officials who defied a court-ordered housing integration plan were encouraged today by a Supreme Court ruling in their favor, but they said it would not delay the construction of low-income housing that is to begin in March.

title: Lilly Industrial Coatings Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: The share earnings and shares outstanding were adjusted for a 5 percent stock dividend paid in August 1989.

title: Review/Jazz;   Bill Dobbins Plays Ellington
description: Bill Dobbins is a jazz pianist whose repertory ranges from Scott Joplin and Jelly Roll Morton to Thelonious Monk and McCoy Tyner. But at the opening on Tuesday of his five-day engagement at the Fortune Garden Pavilion (209 East 49th Street), he put his primary focus on some of the less frequently heard compositions of Billy Strayhorn and Duke Ellington.

title: Cambex Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 2
U. S. EASING CURBS AS CHINA DECLARES MARTIAL LAW OVER
description: China lifted martial law in Beijing today, and within hours the United States announced that it was easing its blanket opposition to World Bank loans to China.

title: Insurers Seek Help for Uninsured
description: Under pressure from government, business and consumer critics, many of the nation's health insurance companies are calling for new Federal and state laws to provide more affordable coverage for millions of working Americans who have no insurance.

title: New S.E.C. Chief
description: Roy Kramer, athletic director at Vanderbilt University, announced yesterday at the National Collegiate Athletic Association convention in Dallas that he was accepting an offer to become commissioner of the Southeastern Conference.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;

Vice Chairman Named By Saatchi Worldwide
description: LEAD: Jim Lindsey has been named vice chairman of Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising Worldwide, where he will take responsibility for the global development of the agency's Toyota Motor Corporation account. Saatchi said that Ed Wax, president and chief executive of Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising, would also take on Mr.

title: OPEC Output at High
description: Oil production by the OPEC nations rose to an average of 23.7 million barrels a day in the last quarter of 1989, the highest level since early 1981, the International Energy Agency said on Tuesday.

title: Ranger Draftee Felled
description: The Rangers announced yesterday that Ludek Cajka, the defenseman from Czechoslovakia whom they drafted in 1987, injured his spine severely in a game last week and has reportedly been left paralyzed.

title: PANAMA TO ASSIST U.S. ON DRUG WAR
description: Panama's new civilian Government signed an accord with the United States today in which it pledged to cooperate in efforts to crack down on narcotics trafficking and money laundering.

title: Teledyne Canada reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Criticare Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: New Jersey Casinos Fight Plan for Taxes On Gifts to Gamblers
description: Atlantic City's casinos today tried to head off talk of a new tax on the complimentary items they dole out to high rollers with a study that they say shows Nevada is a far more hospitable place to do business.

title: Correction
description: A topic yesterday misidentified a Japanese magazine for American entrepreneurs. It is Business Tokyo.

title: Systerm Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 3
description: b-Included an extraordinary loss of $2,421,253 for the quarter and 9 months. c-Net income Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Pages From the Catalogue: A Decorator's Workshop
description: YOU might call it one-stop decorating for those who never do it themselves. Noel Jeffrey does it for them. His new office is a three-dimensional catalogue of furniture, finishes and fabrics, and the interior designer is the salesman. ''I felt it would be easier to show prospective clients things in my office than to take them running all over town,'' said Mr. Jeffrey, who specializes in residential interiors. He has just moved his 20-year-old practice into glamorous new 3,400-square-foot offices in a small East Side building.

title: Tele-Metropole reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 26
description: Figures for 1988 were restated. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Mexico Eases Import Rules
description: The Mexican Government has relaxed rules on technology transfers, removing obstacles to imports and ending limits on royalties, according to published reports Tuesday.

title: Royal International Acquisition Is Set
description: The Royal International Optical Corporation said it had an agreement to be acquired by the privately held U.S. Vision Inc. Royal said the holders of up to 80 percent of its shares would receive $12.50 a share. Holders not electing to receive cash will receive one common share of the merged company for each Royal share. The merged company will continue to be called the Royal International Optical Corporation.

title: INSIDE
description: Political Strains In East Germany

title: Mercury Finance Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: All share earnings have been restated to reflect a 4-for-3 split in December 1989.

title: Bulgaria Pledges an Investigation Of Bizarre '78 Killing in London
description: It was one of the more bizarre episodes from the reviled rule of Todor I. Zhivkov, Bulgaria's recently ousted Communist leader.

title: Seymour Krim Memorial
description: A memorial service for the writer and critic Seymour Krim is to be held on Sunday at 3 P.M. at the Village Gate, Bleecker and Thompson Streets. Among those scheduled to participate are the writers Dan Wakefield and Nora Sayre and the composer David Amram.

title: Lithuanians Cry 'Freedom!' On Eve of Gorbachev Visit
description: A day before President Mikhail S. Gorbachev is to arrive in Lithuania, tens of thousands of Lithuanians gathered here today in the center of their capital, carrying signs calling for ''Independence for Lithuania,'' and chanting, ''Freedom!''

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;

Time Warner Lawyer Is Nominated to S.E.C.
description: LEAD: President Bush yesterday nominated Philip R. Lochner Jr., Time Warner Inc.'s deputy general counsel, to the Securities and Exchange Commission.

title: Market Place;   Hewlett-Packard Divides Analysts
description: DESPITE the largest introduction of computer systems in the company's history, shares in the Hewlett-Packard Company continued to drift downward yesterday. They closed at $47, down 12.5 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Flamemaster Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Excerpts From Speech Ending Martial Law
description: Following are excerpts from Prime Minister Li Peng's speech today announcing the lifting of martial law in Beijing, as distributed in translation by the official New China News Agency:

title: Tokyo Market Uneasy On Fears About Soviets
description: Fears about political turmoil in the Soviet Union helped undermine a record-setting stock market rally, causing prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange to skid over the last week in an increasingly nervous investment climate.

title: Excerpts From Yonkers Ruling: Limits on Power
description: Following are excerpts from the Supreme Court's decision today overturning contempt fines against four Yonkers City Councilmen. The vote was 5 to 4. Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist wrote the majority opinion. Justice William J. Brennan Jr. wrote the dissenting opinion.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-16

title: Flowers Industries Inc. reports earnings for 12wks to Dec 16
description: b-After an extraordinary loss of $3,924,000.

title: Washington at Work;   For Judge in Keating Case, Being on the Bench Is Not Sitting on the Sidelines
description: It was a moment that Judge Stanley Sporkin obviously relished.

title: Don't Despair of the World the Young Will Build
description: To the Editor:

title: CBS Plans TV Film On Slaying and Suicide
description: CBS yesterday announced plans to produce a made-for-television movie about the Boston man who committed suicide last week after learning that the police suspected him of killing his pregnant wife. The story of Carol Stuart's death on Oct. 23 and the failed attempt to save her baby son's life, generated headlines nationwide after her husband, Charles M. Stuart, asserted that he and his wife had been attacked in their car by a black man.

title: Peru Detains 15,000 in Hunt For the Killers of Ex-Minister
description: The police detained 15,000 people today in a search for the killers of Enrique Lopez, the former Minister of Defense who was the most prominent victim of Peru's decade-long guerrilla war.

title: Confusion Grows Over Boston Murder
description: Confusion over the case of Charles Stuart increased today as an insurance company denied a report that it had prepared a $480,000 check for Mr. Stuart, whose pregnant wife was shot to death last October.

title: Ex-Drug Addict Is Acquitted In Giving Out Clean Needles
description: A former addict has been found not guilty of illegally distributing clean needles and syringes to drug addicts to prevent the spread of AIDS.

title: A.T.&T. Sues MCI; Says Rival Switched Clients
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company filed a lawsuit yesterday charging its main rival, the MCI Communications Corporation, with ''unfair and deceptive'' marketing practices and with switching some of A.T.&T.'s residential customers over to MCI's long-distance network without the consumers' consent.

title: Businessland Cuts
description: Businessland Inc., a leading computer retailer, is expected to announce substantial layoffs at a news conference Thursday and may close some of its less active stores, people close to the industry said. The move by Businessland, based in San Jose, Calif., comes as personal computer sales have softened nationwide, but also stems from the chain's loss of the Compaq Computer Corporation account in April, said Seymour Merrin, a computer retail consultant.

title: Educational Development reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Metro Datelines;   Her Purse Is Grabbed And Victim Is Killed
description: A woman whose pocketbook had just been grabbed on Park Avenue by someone in a passing van was killed yesterday afternoon when she fell beneath the vehicle's wheels, the police said.

title: Parents in Sweden Will Get 15 Months' Maternity Leave
description: Parents in Sweden can look forward to 15 months of paid maternity leave after the birth of a child under the budget proposed today.

title: Court Overturns Contempt Fines Against Councilmen in Yonkers
description: The Supreme Court today overturned the contempt fines that a Federal judge imposed on four Yonkers City Councilmen for their refusal to vote for legislation needed to carry out a public housing plan.

title: Stateswest Airlines reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
PARENT & CHILD
description: FOR many adults, the amount of money they make and how they choose to spend it is the most private of affairs. Money is a topic laden with symbolism, a source of pride or of shame, a standard for measuring success and competence after concern with school grades or football touchdowns has passed. It also brings about conflicting feelings of competitiveness between parents and children, who can be both proud and jealous of each other's success.

title: Corrections
description: A chart yesterday showing the weekly Nielsen television ratings reversed the figures for two networks. CBS was second last week, with 22 percent of the prime-time audience; ABC was third, with 19 percent.

title: Bells, Whistles, Microchips
description: THE glittering gold and crimson arch on the main floor of the Winter Consumer Electronics Show here last weekend seemed the entrance to a vast electronic casino filled with 70,000 players. Like the darkened game rooms just a short ride away, it was full of diversions, deals and flashing lights.

title: Reviving Classic Country Furniture
description: LEAD: Country furniture of the 18th century may appear unsophisticated next to pieces made by leading cabinetmakers in urban centers.

title: In the Urban Jungle, Rooms for Play
description: Baby boomers are producing their own baby boom, and where will all the children play? If they live in new apartment buildings in big cities, the children may never have to leave home. Partly to comply with zoning regulations and partly to attract buyers with young children, developers are providing playrooms.

title: LaFontaine Sparks Islander Victory
description: Pat LaFontaine extended his goal-scoring streak to 10 games tonight with his league-leading 37th and 38th goals of the season as the Islanders defeated the Toronto Maple Leafs, 3-1.

title: Student Loan Marketing Assn.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
A Time To Talk Gardening
description: Garden Talks, Horticultural Society of New York, 128 West 58th Street; 212-757-0915.

title: Time Made To Order
description: RETHINKING everyday objects is the raison d'etre of Zebra Design Inc., so when its partners, Steven Holt and Thomas Bley, began to consider clocks, they decided there was no reason designers should have all the fun.

title: FNW Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
American Capital & Research reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding are fully diluted.

title: In Rural Panama, Hard Questions Remain About Who's in Charge
description: When word came that invading United States troops were on their way, Hermel Rodriguez Aguilar came out of hiding, summoned up his courage and went to claim power from the local military officials who had made a habit of beating and jailing opposition politicians like him.

title: Upheaval in the East;   U.S. CRITICIZES U.N. OVER BALTIC MOVE
description: The Bush Administration criticized the United Nations today for bowing to Soviet pressure to cut off informal contacts with representatives of Baltic nationalist movements seeking independence from Moscow.

title: Beckett Took the Student to a Nearby Cafe;   The Success of 'Godot'
description: To the Editor:

title: Chronicle
description: As an 80th birthday present for CHARLES H. DYSON, his family gave more than $12 million to several organizations. Then they told him they had.

title: Clorox's Move
description: The Clorox Company said yesterday that it had transferred the Clorox Detergent advertising account from DDB/Needham in Chicago to the Foote, Cone & Belding office in San Francisco. A Clorox spokesman said the move had been made to consolidate its Clorox brand laundry products at one agency; Foote, Cone already handles the others. A spokesman for DDB/ Needham said the account had been expected to bill $18 million.

title: Iran Welcomes Offer By Moscow on Talks
description: Iran has welcomed an offer by the Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, to sponsor a meeting of Iranian and Iraqi foreign ministers to break the deadlock in talks on the Gulf war, the Iranian press agency I.R.N.A. said today.

title: Mexico Pact Called Near
description: Mexico and its commercial bankers are expected to sign their landmark debt reduction agreement early in February, according to the chairman of the 15-bank advisory committee and the Mexican under secretary of finance.

title: Top Coaches Named
description: Bill McCartney of Colorado was named 1989 Kodak Football Coach of the Year in Division I-A, the American Football Coaches Association announced at its annual convention yesterday in San Francisco. McCartney led the Buffaloes to an 11-0 regular season before losing by 21-6 to Notre Dame in the Orange Bowl.

title: Lord Macaulay, on the 1990's
description: As commentators attempt to forecast political events in 1990 and the decade, they would be well advised to confer with Lord Macaulay, a 19th century British historian and arguably the finest designer of dramatic narrative ever to inhabit a page.

title: Customs Is Testing Plan To Ease Airport Delays
description: With international travel to the United States soaring, the Customs Service is testing new procedures to prevent the long delays that have characterized peak travel seasons at the nation's busiest airports.

title: Outdoors;   Telemark Skiing Makes Fast Tracks
description: rrTelemark skiing, considered an exotic hybrid of cross-country and downhill skiing just a few years ago, is growing rapidly in popularity. More skiers are learning how to do it; they are participating in a variety of events, and the equipment is improving and becoming more specialized.

title: Mentor-Silicon Merger Is Set
description: The Mentor Graphics Corporation of Beaverton, Ore., said today that it would acquire the Silicon Compiler Systems Corporation for about $110 million in newly issued Mentor shares.

title: Leary Signs for a Year
description: Tim Leary, who began his major league pitching career with the Mets nine years ago and was acquired by the Yankees in a trade with Cincinnati last month, signed a one-year contract yesterday that will pay him $825,000, a raise of $155,000.

title: U.S. Penalty On Silverado
description: Federal regulators said today that they had penalized the former chairman of the Silverado Banking, Savings and Loan Association of Denver and confirmed they met this week with a son of President Bush who was a director of the institution.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''My personal fate is linked to this choice. The two states must live together.''

title: Metro Datelines;   Former Accountant Is Sentenced in Theft
description: A former deputy director of the city's Department of General Services was sentenced yesterday to 5 to 15 years in prison on charges of stealing more than a $1 million from the city.

title: Businessland Planning To Reduce Its Staff
description: Businessland Inc., a leading computer retailer, said today that it would lay off from 5 percent to 7 percent of its worldwide work force of 3,900.

title: Dealer Is Jailed In 1988 Slaying Of Drug Officer
description: Grim and silent, about 200 off-duty New York City police officers, many of them from distant precincts, crowded into a Manhattan courtroom yesterday to witness the sentencing of a drug dealer convicted last year of murdering an undercover police officer on the Upper West Side.

title: A European Market for Consumer Goods Opens;   In Alexanderplatz
description: To the Editor:

title: Gen. B. O. Okello, 61, Uganda Rebel Leader
description: Lieut. Gen. Basilio Olara Okello, a Ugandan rebel leader who led a coup against the civilian Government of President Milton Obote in 1985, has died of diabetes complicated by malaria. He was 61 years old.

title: Auctions
description: The pair of exuberantly carved Philadelphia Chippendale chairs stood for more than 25 years in the entrance hall of the Benjamin Dulany house in Alexandria, Va., a gray brick mansion that Howard and May Joynt called home starting in 1936. Now, after Mr. Joynt's death in July at the age of 86, Mrs. Joynt and their children are selling the Rococo chairs and the rest of the collection of mostly 18th-century American furniture, silver, paintings and decorations in a two-session sale next Friday afternoon and Saturday morning at Christie's in New York.

title: Review/Rock;   Down-Home Country Sounds in the Heart of Metropolis
description: New York City is a long way from the country, but that doesn't stop some of New York's best bar bands from twanging their own kind of down-home music - high-octane honky-tonk that adds a modern urban kick to old-fashioned rockabilly. At the Lone Star Roadhouse on Wednesday night, Roscoe's Gang and the World Famous Blue Jays shared a bill of New York country-rock.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: COMPANIES

title: Using Architects' Designs to Sell Land
description: LEAD: Selling plots of raw land to sophisticated buyers expecting to build houses costing $1 million or more is a tricky marketing proposition, especially if the plots are mountainous, heavily wooded and only partly accessible by road.

title: Philips Industries Sees Lower Profit
description: Philips Industries announced it expects lower third-quarter earnings, casting a shadow over its planned buyout deal with a Merrill Lynch unit, analysts said. ''Merrill Lynch may use this as an opportunity to restructure the deal or reprice the deal,'' said Elliot Schlang of Prescott, Ball & Turben Inc. Philips, a maker of components for the building and transportation industries, said it expects earnings for the quarter ended Dec. 31 of about 14 cents a share, compared with 32 cents last year.

title: Drew Middleton of The Times Dies at 76
description: Drew Middleton, who covered World War II and postwar Europe for The New York Times and later served as the newspaper's military correspondent, died quietly in his sleep Wednesday night at his apartment on the Upper East Side of Manhattan. He was 76 years old.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Kellogg Co., Battle Creek, Mich., appointed Carlos M. Gutierrez vice president for product development.

title: Review/Music;   Guarneri Plus Davidovich
description: Schumann's Piano Quintet (Op. 44) - with which the Guarneri String Quartet, joined by the pianist Bella Davidovich, ended its concert on Wednesday evening at Alice Tully Hall - is one of the composer's ripest creations. Using a combination of instruments almost wholly novel in 1842, the composer immediately mastered it, producing a rich amalgam of emotion, ebullience and intelligence. For a contrapuntal tour de force near the end of the finale, having already evolved and exploited one fugue subject, he combines it with the first theme of the work in an exciting passage of double fugue.

title: Robert Pirie, 84, Dies; Retired Vice Admiral
description: Robert B. Pirie, a retired vice admiral who was Deputy Chief of Naval Operations for air when he retired in 1962 after a 40-year career in the Navy, died of congestive heart failure Tuesday at the Belvoir Woods Health Care Center, Fort Belvoir, Va. He was 84 years old and had lived for many years in Delray Beach, Fla.

title: U.S. HALTS THE USE OF JARVIK HEART
description: In an action that stunned heart researchers, the Food and Drug Administration has withdrawn its approval of continued experimental use of the Jarvik artificial heart because of deficiencies found in its manufacture.

title: India's Premier Offers Concessions to Sikhs
description: Prime Minister V. P. Singh offered key concessions to Sikh separatists today, but said he knew of no sure way of ending the violence.

title: Knight's 229 Leads Big Ten
description: Anderson led an 18-2 second-half run with 11 points as Indiana turned a 6-point deficit into a 10-point lead and a 77-63 victory over Northwestern tonight, making Bob Knight the top-winning coach in Big Ten Conference history.

title: Two Noriegas: Trafficker, Law Enforcer
description: LEAD: A mystery surrounds President Bush's contention that he ordered the invasion of Panama in part to stop the drug-running of dictator Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega. The mystery concerns the numerous commendations General Noriega received - including a 1987 letter from the head of the Drug Enforcement Administration, Jack Lawn - for his efforts to combat drug trafficking.

title: Fee Increase Is Sought For Mining U.S. Land
description: Reversing a Reagan Administration decision, Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan Jr. has proposed raising the fee coal companies pay to mine Federal land.

title: INSIDE
description: East Berlin to Create Force

title: Study on Cable Competition
description: Cable television may need competition at the local level, the Federal Communications Commission said today in deciding to study possible changes in rules that allow just one cable system in most communities.

title: Boat Show Opens Today
description: The 80th New York National Boat Show opens today at 10 A.M. in the Jacob K. Javits Convention Center in Manhattan. Today's session, which runs from 10 A.M. to 6 P.M., is for so-called red-carpet visitors, those willing to pay $15 a ticket to avoid the crowds.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article on Wednesday and an article on Thursday about the killing of a former Peruvian Defense Minister misidentified him. He was Enrique Lopez Albujar.

title: SOUNDS AROUND TOWN
description: 'Carried Away' Again

title: Metro Datelines;   Suspect in Slayings Indicted in 9th Case
description: Arthur J. Shawcross, who is accused in a series of slayings in the Lyons area, was charged yesterday with a ninth killing.

title: Beckett Took the Student to a Nearby Cafe
description: To the Editor:

title: Lodestar Rebuffed By Kinder-Care
description: Kinder-Care Learning Centers Inc. said a special committee of its board had determined that the previously announced takeover bid by Kind Acquisition Group, an affiliate of Lodestar Group, was not in the best interest of the company or its stockholders. Lodestar said it had accepted the committee's decision and had withdrawn the offer.

title: 5 Acts at CBGB
description: The Black Rock Coalition will present J. J. Jumpers, Eye and I, Faith, Mascara and Karen Davis on Sunday at CBGB. 315 Bowery, at Bleecker Street (982-4052). Music begins at 9 P.M.; admission is $10.

title: Review/Art;   Al Held's Passage in the 50's From Action to Abstraction
description: ''Beautiful'' and ''graceful'' may have been the last words Al Held would have chosen to describe the paintings he produced between 1953 and 1955. Adjectives like muscular, crude and raw might have been more in the artist's mind at the time, and they do apply to these Abstract Expressionist works. But beautiful and graceful and elegant also fit the bill. Two dozen of the paintings Mr. Held completed after he returned to the United States from a lengthy sojourn in Paris are now at the Robert Miller Gallery, and they look wonderful.

title: Blues and Zydeco
description: Fernest and the Thunders, a blues and zydeco band from Lafayette, La., is appearing tonight through Sunday at Tramps, 45 West 21st Street. Sets begin at 8:30 and 11 P.M. and 12:30 A.M. tonight and tomorrow, 8 and 10:30 P.M. and midnight on Sunday; there is a $12 cover ($10 on Sunday) and a two-drink minimum at tables.

title: 4 Assembly Plants Are Shut Down by Ford
description: The Ford Motor Company temporarily shut down four assembly plants with a total of 9,700 hourly workers because of slumping auto sales, the company said today.

title: Rumanians Report 207 Died In September Ship Collision
description: The new Government said today that 207 Rumanians were killed in September when a passenger ship sank after colliding with a Bulgarian tugboat on the Danube river.

title: SHUTTLE MOVES IN ON AILING SATELLITE
description: Switching orbital lanes and climbing in altitude, the astronauts of the space shuttle Columbia maneuvered into position today for their planned retrieval of a faltering bus-size satellite Friday morning.

title: New Year Inspires Donations For the Neediest Cases Fund
description: The arrival of a new year and a new decade inspired donors to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund to express a multitude of hopes for the destitute and the sick.

title: Why Connecticut Didn't Go Along With Metro-North Fare Rise
description: To the Editor:

title: Georgie Auld, 70; Was a Saxophonist With the Big Bands
description: Georgie Auld, a saxophonist who played with Bunny Berigan, Artie Shaw and Benny Goodman, died of lung cancer on Monday at his home here. He was 70 years old.

title: Royal Ballet Drops Plans To Tour U.S.
description: The Royal Ballet announced today that it had canceled plans for a United States tour in July and August because the company could not obtain adequate financing.

title: Jackson, Barkley Are Fined For Bets
description: Mark Jackson, the Knicks' playmaker, and Charles Barkley, the Philadelphia 76ers' All-Star forward, paid yesterday for what Commissioner David Stern called the informal wagers between themselves in the game Wednesday night.

title: A Cigarette Campaign Under Fire
description: Here in the root and stalk of tobacco country, everyone knows that marketing something that carries a health warning from the Surgeon General is bound to provoke an argument. Mix in race and you really have a shouting match. Just ask the R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company.

title: Books of The Times;   Hollywood Wanted Movies To Be Better Than Life
description: The Dame in the Kimono

title: All Nippon Deal
description: The All Nippon Airways Company bought the Westin Hotel in Washington, for an undisclosed sum, a company spokesman said. The name of the 416-room hotel will be changed to the ANA Hotel in January 1991. The company plans to expand its ownership of hotels in overseas cities where it flies or plans to fly, the spokesman said.

title: Pratt & Whitney
description: Ansett World Aviation Services of Australia has ordered $110 million worth of jet engines from Pratt & Whitney to power as many as 12 Airbus aircraft, Pratt & Whitney said. Ansett ordered PW4000 engines for six A300-600R Airbus twinjets, a total of 14 engines including spares, and took options on 12 more engines to power another six planes, said Pratt & Whitney, a unit of the United Technologies Corporation. If Ansett chooses to order all 26 engines, the value of the orders would be $225 million, Pratt & Whitney said.

title: Harold Zyskind Dies; A SUNY Professor, 72
description: Harold Zyskind, professor emeritus of philosophy at the State University of New York at Stony Brook, L.I., died of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, also known as Lou Gehrig's disease, on Tuesday at the Veterans Hospital in Northport, L.I. He was 72 years old and had been in the hospital for the last 15 years.

title: Pleased With Past, Kean Looks to Future
description: Eight years ago a former Assemblyman named Thomas H. Kean moved his belongings and a wobbly new administration into the Statehouse here, after stunning the public and himself with a 1,797-vote victory over Representative James J. Florio.

title: 2 Top Conservatives Fault Chirac On Role Since Loss to Mitterrand
description: With power struggles already tearing at France's Communist and Socialist Parties, the country's conservative Gaullist movement has now been shaken by an unexpected onslaught on its longtime leader, Jacques Chirac.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Panama Needs No Army
description: An army's primary mission is supposed to be the defense of national territory. In Latin America, that is rarely the reality. Costa Rica's President, Oscar Arias, proposed on the Op-Ed page this week that Panama abolish its army, as his country did in 1948. His suggestion makes good sense.

title: Observing Martin Luther King Jr. Day
description: A number of events are taking place in observance of Martin Luther King Jr. Day on Monday. Here is a sampling of events this weekend and on Monday.

title: Metro Datelines;   Dismembered Body Of Woman Identified
description: The dismembered body of a woman found in the Bronx Monday night was identified yesterday as a bank secretary from Brooklyn, the police said.

title: Stephen H. Mayer, 74, Chairman of MEM Co.
description: Stephen H. Mayer, chairman of the MEM Company, a toiletries concern with headquarters in Northvale, N.J., died of a stroke on Wednesday at Tucson (Ariz.) Medical Center. He was 74 years old and had homes in Tucson and Denver.

title: Alexander Lowenthal, Businessman, 91
description: Alexander Lowenthal, a Pittsburgh businessman who was active in civic affairs, died of congestive heart failure Dec. 29 at his home in Pittsburgh. He was 91 years old.

title: Continental Air Cuts Staff by 150
description: The Texas Air Corporation's Continental Airlines laid off about 150 employees earlier this week as part of a ''belt tightening'' program, a Texas Air spokesman, Art Kent, said. The layoffs, which occurred Tuesday, affected employees who have no direct contact with customers, Mr. Kent said.

title: Estee Lauder U.S.A. Hires Chief Executive
description: Robin Burns, who climbed quickly in the cosmetics industry with the success of Calvin Klein's Obsession, is going on to a new challenge as president and chief executive of Estee Lauder U.S.A., a unit of the cosmetics maker Estee Lauder Inc.

title: Bush Hails a Thaw in China; Congress Is Skeptical
description: President Bush today hailed the lifting of martial law in China as ''a very sound step,'' but he found little support in Congress for his view that China's action was significant or that his policy toward Beijing was effective.

title: Tourism Up In Sri Lanka After a Slump
description: The nervous young waiter in his obviously new orange uniform was clearly smitten by the first French tourist of the season.

title: Dudley Field Malone, Theatrical Agent, 59
description: Dudley Field Malone, a theatrical agent and manager, died of lung cancer on Jan. 1 at his home in Bellport, L.I. He was 59 years old.

title: Chronicle
description: Arriving neatly between the spring and fall collections, Nell Neuville Merlo was born Wednesday to the designer CHARLOTTE NEUVILLE and her husband, KEN MERLO.

title: Review/Theater;   A New View of Israel's History, in 'The Return'
description: A note in the program for ''The Return,'' Frederic Glover's play at the Jewish Repertory Theater about conflict between two leading Zionists, alerts the audience to something that is often left unsaid in television docudrama.

title: Upheaval in the East;   Doubts and Fears of Rumania's Lingering Germans
description: Jurgen Breitenstein, a 30-year-old mathematics teacher, decided a year ago to join the thousands of ethnic Germans who had left Rumania for West Germany in search of freedom and opportunity. Now, after the toppling of Nicolae Ceausescu, Mr. Breitenstein is not sure whether to follow through on his decision or stay and support the dwindling German community here.

title: Bayer Investigated On Deal With Iran
description: The West German Government is investigating whether the chemical giant Bayer A.G. sold equipment to Iran that could be used to produce poisonous gases, West Germany's public prosecutor's office said today. Bayer, West Germany's third-largest chemical company, has previously denied the accusation, which first arose in November, that the equipment for producing dilute agricultural pesticides could be used to make chemical weapons.

title: UAL Chief Warns on A Buyback
description: Stephen M. Wolf, the chairman and chief executive of the UAL Corporation, has warned employees that a recapitalization of the company, which owns United Airlines, would ''cripple United financially.''

title: Orange Losses Are Put at 29%
description: Florida's orange harvest will plunge by some 29 percent this year because of damage from the Christmas weekend freeze, the Department of Agriculture estimated today.

title: Notebook;   Unbridled Emerges as a Hot Item for the Winter
description: The prime winter racing season in Florida unofficially begins in the coming week, with the Tropical Park Derby on closing day at Calder on Sunday and the opening of Gulfstream Park two days later.

title: Holiday on Monday
description: Monday is the birthday of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Here are holiday schedules.

title: GORBACHEV URGES LITHUANIA TO STAY WITH SOVIET UNION
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev implored Lithuanians today to remain within the Soviet Union, warning that secession would mean economic calamity for this tiny republic, while weakening Soviet security and endangering his own position and program.

title: Review/Film;   At Long Last, The Story of A Gangster's Redemption
description: Harry Plotnik has been kept under wraps for 20 years, but he is none the worse for wear. Harry is the glum Jewish gangster at the center of ''The Plot Against Harry,'' a funny, sharply drawn and appealingly modest film that very nearly missed seeing the light of day.

title: Reporter's Notebook;   Business as Usual at City Hall (the Tone Is What's New)
description: In the worn old corridors of New York's City Hall these days, police guards at the metal gate outside the Mayor's wing are armed not only with pistols but with newspaper pictures of new deputies and commissioners, to avoid the embarrassment of stopping the wrong people.

title: Chronicle
description: The wedding took place outdoors in Port Antonio, Jamaica, on New Year's Day in a stylistically suitable Palladian ruin befitting JOHN F. SALADINO, the interior designer who has said that a living room ''is meant to have the feeling of age and decay.''

title: Flu Hits Texas and Spreads Across U.S.
description: The winter scourge of influenza has made an early appearance this year, already striking hard in Texas and rapidly spreading its trail of aches across the country.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;

First Executive Corp. Appoints a President
description: LEAD: The First Executive Corporation, a Los Angeles-based insurance company, said yesterday that it had named Alan C. Snyder president and chief operating officer.

title: California Says Law on Aliens Fuels Job Bias
description: A state panel in California has concluded that the 1986 immigration law has resulted in widespread job discrimination against Hispanic residents and others.

title: Record Number of Ratings Lowered by S.& P. in 1989
description: A record number of debt ratings were lowered by the Standard & Poor's Corporation last year, according to preliminary figures compiled and released yesterday by the financial rating service.

title: 2 File for Arbitration
description: Wally Joyner, the California Angel first baseman, and Juan Nieves, a Milwaukee Brewer left-hander, filed for salary arbitration yesterday, leaving 184 players still eligible to file by the deadline next Tuesday. Arbitration hearings will be scheduled for the first three weeks of February.

title: Harmony and Dissonance as N.C.A.A. Meets
description: When the National Collegiate Athletic Association began its 84th convention last Sunday, Richard Schultz, the association's executive director, made it clear that he wanted to change what seemed to be a prevailing public perception that the N.C.A.A. was a scandal-ridden, do-nothing organization whose primary function was managing the greed of its members.

title: Upheaval in the East;   Lithuania; AT A GLANCE
description: Government

title: Metro Datelines;   Black Ministers Meet On Rise in Attacks
description: Some 40 black ministers met yesterday to coordinate a response to what they called an escalation in political and personal attacks against blacks.

title: Publisher at Scribner's
description: Barbara Grossman has been named publisher of Charles Scribner's Sons, effective Jan. 29, the company announced Wednesday. She is currently a senior editor at Crown Publishers, where she has worked for eight years. The current Scribner's publisher, Robert Stewart, will have his own imprint at Scribner's and will be a senior editorial vice president of the adult trade division of the Macmillan Publishing Company, of which Scribner's is an imprint. Macmillan is owned by the Maxwell Communication Corporation.

title: Business Wary About End Of Martial Law in Beijing
description: While foreign companies welcome the lifting of martial law in the capital, the action is unlikely to have an immediate effect on their commercial or investment activities here, officials of a dozen companies said today.

title: Money Fund Assets Up
description: The assets of the nation's 483 money market mutual funds surged by $6.82 billion, to $375.23 billion, for the week that ended on Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. The assets of the 144 institutional funds increased by $1.91 billion, to $90.14 billion. The assets of the 241 general-purpose funds were up by $1.26 billion, to $124.50 billion. The 98 broker-dealer funds increased by $3.65 billion, to $160.59 billion, the institute said.

title: Promotion At Dayton
description: The Dayton Hudson Corporation, owner of Target and Mervyn's retail stores and the Dayton Hudson Department Store Company, yesterday named Stephen E. Watson president beginning Feb. 1.

title: Treasury Security Prices Down
description: Prices of Treasury securities dipped in very sluggish trading yesterday, as dealers moved to the sidelines in advance of two important economic reports today.

title: No Headline
description: Poland's sweeping new economic reform plan has just one goal: to increase economic growth. To achieve that goal, the Government is relying on companies like Dresso, one of the nation's largest sportswear makers.

title: Results Plus
description: N.B.A.

title: Japan Seen Extending Auto Quotas
description: The Japanese Government is expected to announce soon that it will extend its ''voluntary'' quotas on automobile exports to the United States, but Japan's major manufacturers note that the action is now an annual political gesture that has no effect on the sales of Japanese cars.

title: Carolyn Haywood, 92, Illustrator And Author of Children's Books
description: Carolyn Haywood, a popular author and illustrator of children's books who is best known for her ''Betsy'' and ''Eddie'' series for 7-to-10-year-olds, died of a stroke yesterday at her home in the Chestnut Hill section of Philadelphia. She was 92 years old.

title: G.M. Near Agreement On Venture in Hungary
description: The General Motors Corporation said today that it was at an advanced stage of negotiations to assemble cars and engines in Hungary.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the vacant position of New York City Health Commissioner referred incorrectly to the extent of opposition to the candidacy of Dr. Woodrow A. Myers, Health Commissioner of Indiana. Some advocates for AIDS patients not all, oppose his appointment. Further developments are reported today on page B4.

title: Exceptions, Rules and the Court;   In Criminal Law, a Line Maintained
description: For years, prosecutors have been barred from using illegally obtained evidence at criminal trials. But for years, with the Supreme Court's blessing, they've used a backdoor tactic to get such evidence before juries. For example, when the defendant takes the witness stand, prosecutors will introduce such evidence during cross-examination - not, in theory, to prove guilt, but to impugn the defendant's credibility.

title: Our Towns;   It's the Last Call At Rosie's Diner, And on the Road
description: Rosie's Farmland Diner on Route 46 in Little Ferry may be the best-known diner in America, but it is still a real diner.

title: Metro Datelines;   Schools Experience Continuing Violence
description: The city schools underwent their fourth consecutive day of violence yesterday when a youth at Junior High School No. 4 was stabbed in an argument with another student, and hospitalized with injuries.

title: Billy Conn, 72, Takes On Robber
description: A robber got more than he bargained for when he held up a convenience store on Wednesday and ran into Billy Conn, the 72-year-old former light-heavyweight champion, the police said.

title: Review/Dance;   Small Troupe Revives 'Annabel Lee' From 1951
description: Every major ballet company seems to be rummaging in the dustbin of recent history for a forgotten work to expand its repertory and satisfy the public's thirst for the new.

title: Islanders Move Into 2d; LaFontaine Streak at 11
description: Pat LaFontaine extended his goal-scoring streak to a club-record 11 games with his league-high 39th goal and added five assists tonight as the Islanders beat the Minnesota North Stars, 8-4, for their fifth consecutive victory.

title: The Rivalry Has Begun;   Anderson and Hurley, 2 Top Guards, Square Off in Atlanta
description: They are acquaintances at best, having met about a half-dozen times at all-star games and summer basketball camps. Yet Kenny Anderson and Bobby Hurley, last year's most highly rated high school playmakers, know plenty about each other, and will soon learn a lot more.

title: Victor J. Maritato, Priest, 65
description: The Rev. Victor J. Maritato, a priest in the Diocese of Brooklyn who had served as a Navy chaplain for 21 years, died Sunday at his home in Pompano Beach, Fla. He was 65 years old.

title: Restaurants
description: If one were to study up-to-date restaurant-industry consumer research, read all the media soothsaying about dining in the 1990's and then go out and build a new restaurant, it would probably resemble Ten Twenty-Two. Christopher Idone, the owner (and the co-founder of the caterer Glorious Foods), is nothing if not canny about popular taste.

title: Robinson Was Worth The Wait
description: rrThe cooks at the United States Naval Academy used to wonder if any nuclear submarine fuel had been slipping into David Robinson's hardtack and gruel, the way he shot up toward 7 feet on government time.

title: Saints Ready for Indoor Season Opener
description: Introducing some of his players at a news conference today, Tom Flatley, the general manager of the New York Saints, described Scott Huff as an enforcer. Huff seemed to preen.

title: Fuel Plane Explodes at Base
description: An empty Air National Guard KC-135 refueling tanker exploded in flames today as it lay parked on a ramp at Pease Air Force Base, said a base spokeswoman, Sgt. Susan Rau. She said one base firefighter was slightly injured fighting the fire.

title: Utility Rewards Jurors Who Upheld It in Court
description: Jurors who gave the Houston Lighting and Power Company a favorable verdict in a $419 million lawsuit will be flown from Dallas to Houston at the utility's expense for a tour of its nuclear plant and a stay at a luxury hotel.

title: Dining Out Guide: Hamburgers
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication; restaurants mentioned in Diner's Journal do not have stars. Prices are current. Corner Bistro Diner's Journal (Dec. 4, 1987), 331 West Fourth Street (242-9502) - This is a funky neighborhood tavern where regulars gather to watch sports on television. Sit at one of the high-backed booths across from the bar, or in the snug rear dining room. The juicy ''bistro burger'' is a sizable handful wrapped in bacon and topped with cheese, tomato and lettuce ($5). A stack of good french fries to go with it is $2. The mildly seasoned chili is fresh and amply portioned for $3.50, and with this all-American menu the preferred beverage is McSorley's ale on tap ($1.50). Open from 11:30 A.M. to 4 A.M. Monday to Saturday, noon to 4 A.M. on Sunday. Joe Allen

title: 3 Victories in a Row? Break Up the Nets!
description: Whenever a Nets victory appeared questionable, Purvis Short's jump shot was the answer tonight.

title: An East German-U.S. Deal
description: A state-owned East German printing machinery company has bought a marketing concern in the United States in what is believed to be the first such deal with a Western company.

title: Pentagon Plans $2.3 Billion Saving in '91 by Cutting 16,000 Jobs
description: Secretary of Defense Dick Cheney announced today that improved management would save the Pentagon $2.3 billion and eliminate 16,000 jobs next year, but he declined to go into detail on what jobs would be cut.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the dairy industry misidentified a farmer from Maize, Kan. He is Gene Woodard.

title: F.D.A. Accused of Improper Ties In Review of Drug for Milk Cows
description: A veterinarian dismissed from the Food and Drug Administration said today that the agency's review of a genetically engineered drug designed to make dairy cows produce more milk had been marked by overly close ties to the animal drug industry.

title: Gregg Smith Singers
description: The Gregg Smith Singers will present a concert of secular music, set to texts by William Shakespeare and Ben Jonson, and Italian and German madrigals by Don Carlo Gesualdo, Heinrich Schutz and Paul Hindemith tomorrow at 8 P.M. at St. Peter's Church, 54th Street and Lexington Avenue. The group's Saturday concert series continues through Feb. 10. Tickets are $15. Information: 874-2990.

title: 3 Lawyers Accused of Using Bribes and Faked Evidence
description: Three members of a personal-injury law firm in Manhattan have been indicted on Federal charges that they falsified evidence and bribed witnesses to lie in 19 accident cases dating to 1979, United States Attorney Andrew J. Maloney announced yesterday. Four private investigators and an office manager for the firm were also charged.

title: The U.S. and Panama;   An Israeli in Panama: Whose Broker?
description: As American investigators try to piece together the business and political affairs of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, one of the most intriguing figures remains an Israeli who some say was a key adviser to the former Panamanian strongman.

title: After Battle On Abortion, A Struggle To Recover
description: Eleven months ago, a team of doctors performed an abortion on a comatose Long Island woman, Nancy Klein, in a desperate attempt to help her chances of recovery.
