The operation culminated a wrenching two-week court battle for her husband, who fought opponents of abortion all the way to the Supreme Court to gain legal guardianship of his 32-year-old wife and the right to decide on her abortion and, perhaps, her last chance for life.

title: Falcon Coach Arrested
description: Jim Hanifan, who was named interim head coach of the Atlanta Falcons when Marion Campbell resigned Nov. 28, was hospitalized and in police custody yesterday after being arrested on charges of driving under the influence of alcohol. He was also charged with having no proof of insurance, committing simple battery on an officer and driving without lights.

title: Review/Theater;   Language As a Toy, In One-Man Comedy
description: ''Terminal Hip,'' Mac Wellman's ''Spiritual History of America Through the Medium of Bad Language,'' is a post-Joycean Jabberwocky. Expect no exegesis. Just sit back and enjoy the torrent of language, as Mr. Wellman zigzags through time, space and participle.

title: A European Market for Consumer Goods Opens;   Boring No More
description: To the Editor:

title: Upheaval in the East;   Havel Traces Passage 'From Jail to the Castle'
description: President Vaclav Havel's third-floor office in the Prague Castle these days has the urgent chaos of a theater stage the day after opening night. Mail is piled on the floor. Young secretaries and assistants rush in and out. Unwanted paintings stand around against the wall like discarded scenery. Telephones ring and ring and often go unanswered.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: FRIDAY

title: Accounts
description: * Ryobi America Corp., to Doe-Anderson Advertising Agency, Louisville, Ky., for its power tools, with a budget of $1 million.

title:
Upheaval in the East;

East Berlin to Ignore Threat By Opposition on New Force
description: LEAD: The East German Prime Minister said today that plans to create a new domestic security force would be carried out despite opposition parties' threats to walk out of round-table talks intended to pave the way for multiparty democracy.

title: Far Out in Space, a Giant Discovery
description: Astronomers reported today that they had confirmed the existence of one of the largest concentrations of galaxies and matter ever found. The finding could change the way astronomers think about the structure of the universe.

title: Witherspoon Stops Sims in 5 In Heavyweight Comeback Bout
description: Tim Witherspoon , a former heavyweight champion, continued successfully his comeback tonight when Referee Frank Cappuccino stopped his bout against Jeff Sims after the fifth round of a scheduled 10-round bout at Trump Plaza.

title: Cuomo Pledges Rise in Spending In Range of 4%
description: Pledging to keep state spending increases in the next fiscal year below the inflation rate, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo said today that he would present a tight budget next week that would grow by a little more than 4 percent.

title: Federal Officials Order Exxon to Explain Leak in Arthur Kill
description: Already facing the threat of lawsuits and criminal prosecution by the attorneys general of two states, the Exxon Corporation was ordered yesterday to explain to Federal environmental officials what caused the leak of more than a half-million gallons of oil from a pipeline off Staten Island 11 days ago.

title: The Jerusalem Post's Owners Pledge an Independent Policy
description: The owners of The Jerusalem Post have pledged to respect the newspaper's editorial independence, but 30 senior journalists who resigned over the issue rejected an offer to return to work.

title: U.S. Proposes Higher Coal Mining Fees
description: Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan Jr., reversing a Reagan Administration decision, today proposed raising the fee that coal companies pay to states and the Federal Government for mining on Federal land.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: Richardson Emerges

title: Their Drug War - and Ours
description: As a woman starts across the street, a van roars up. Strong arms wrest her purse from her grasp. As the van lurches away, she falls beneath the wheels and is crushed to death. . . . Members of a drug gang kidnap an enemy's 12-year-old brother, hack off the boy's finger and enclose it with a ransom request. . . . A group of teen-age boys blame a 12-year-old girl for stealing $45. They take out their anger by raping her and torturing her with a heated knife and an ice pick.

title: SOUNDS AROUND TOWN
description: Link to Ellington

title: Deals
description: Baseball

title: White House Rejects a Tax Cut
description: The White House said today that it opposed Democratic proposals to change the Social Security tax, including one that would cut the amount 130 million workers pay over two years by $62 billion.

title: A European Market for Consumer Goods Opens
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Dance;   Men at Work in City Ballet 'Gentilhommes'
description: The New York City Ballet has an interesting crop of young male dancers moving up the ranks in the company. And a slew of role debuts in a performance of ''Les Gentilhommes'' on Wednesday night at the New York State Theater offered a good chance to watch some of those dancers at work.

title: Review/Art;   Heady and Hectic Works From Jennifer Bartlett
description: Jennifer Bartlett has always divided opinion, and it is not in her nature, or in her art, to do anything else. Her ambition, once fired, has no limit. It was doubtless natural that one or two people would be disconcerted, and one or two professional feathers ruffled, by the original and imaginative design for a garden in Battery Park City that she has designed in partnership with Alexander Cooper and Nicholas Quennell. Nothing further from traditional municipal gardening could be imagined. But the good news is that the project, by now several years in the planning, is going ahead.

title: Review/Film;   Physicality on Many Levels in 'Internal Affairs,' a Police Drama
description: Mike Figgis's films could be watched at any hour, but they're really best suited to the middle of the night. With only two theatrical features to his credit, the terrific 1988 sleeper ''Stormy Monday'' and now ''Internal Affairs,'' a dizzying police thriller, Mr. Figgis has established himself as a master of steamy sex appeal and brooding, nocturnal murk.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Dec. 30 about the legacy of the playwright Samuel Beckett misstated the date of his death. It was Dec. 22.

title: Ballet Theater Splits With Ex-Bolshoi Star
description: Andris Liepa, a former principal dancer with the Bolshoi Ballet, has withdrawn from his contract with American Ballet Theater after failing to appear for scheduled rehearsals, the company announced yesterday.

title: Ann Stringer, 71, Dies; A War Correspondent
description: Ann Stringer, a war correspondent who in 1945 transmitted the first report of the linkup of American and Russian forces, died of a heart attack Wednesday at the Skyrest Nursing Home in Carbondale, Ill. She was 71 years old and had lived until 1987 in Manhattan and Amagansset, L.I.

title: Campeau Takes Steps to Bolster The Credibility of Its U.S. Stores
description: Pressing for a way to restore its credibility with creditors and suppliers, the directors of the Campeau Corporation took steps last night to allow the company's American retailing divisions to operate independently.

title: Malpractice Award Stuns Houston Lawyers
description: A Federal jury has stunned lawyers here by awarding $17.5 million in a malpractice case against a local law firm.

title: Arthur J. O'Brien, 80, Ex-Head of a Retailer
description: Arthur J. O'Brien, former president of the Associated Dry Goods Corporation, died of a heart attack Monday at his home in Jupiter, Fla. He was 80 years old.

title: Savings Unit Seized by U.S.
description: Federal regulators today seized Atlantic Financial Federal, Pennsylvania's largest savings institution, transferring control to a new agency created to handle failing or troubled institutions.

title: Review/Film;   Two Early Scorsese Profiles, of His Parents and of an Actor
description: Many of the characters in Martin Scorsese's films are inspired storytellers, fired by the gift of gab. Can anyone who's seen ''Mean Streets'' forget the magnificent excuse that Robert De Niro's Johnny Boy rattles off in explanation of why he's neglected to pay his creditors? Can anyone forget the ''Taxi Driver'' sequence in which an overeager, fast-talking gun dealer bluffs his way through a sales pitch and discovers, to his delight and amazement, that Mr. De Niro's Travis Bickle is the best customer any gun dealer ever had?

title: Stallings Replacing Curry at Alabama
description: The University of Alabama, where the pressure of being head football coach is so intense that Bill Curry left after a 10-2 season, yesterday hired as Curry's replacement Gene Stallings, who has a losing record as both a college and a professional coach.

title: Diner's Journal
description: The Polo for Brunch

title: Panel Sees Cover-Up of Teacher's Assault Record
description: A man convicted of exposing himself to a child was licensed as a New York City teacher even though licensing officials knew he had covered up the fact that he had once been convicted in an assault case, an investigative commission said yesterday.

title: J. P. Morgan Earnings Fall 40% in Quarter
description: J. P. Morgan & Company yesterday reported sharply lower profits in its fourth quarter and a loss for the year.

title: Economic Scene;   Trade Pressures On the Japanese
description: THE drop in the Tokyo stock market earlier this week, attributed partly to fears of turmoil in the Soviet Union that could weaken the outlook for Japanese involvement in Eastern Europe, knocked down the yen and lifted the dollar. The weakening yen is likely to worsen the huge United States trade deficit with Japan and intensify the increasingly bitter dispute between the two countries.

title: Exceptions, Rules and the Court;   In Yonkers, Officials Must Still Obey
description: To judge from their initial preening for the TV cameras, you'd think that officials in Yonkers, N.Y., had been vindicated by the Supreme Court for resisting a Federal judge's order to build low-income housing. True, the Court does say the judge was too quick to impose contempt fines against four City Councilmen who defied his order, and does absolve them of personal liability. But it does not relieve their public responsibility to obey the law.

title: Martin H. Newman, Theater Executive, 76
description: Martin H. Newman, executive director of the Will Rogers Memorial Fund and former president of Century Theaters, died of cancer Monday in New York Hospital. He was 76 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A2-16

title: Top Morgan Stanley Officer Quits to Start Merger Firm
description: One of Wall Street's leading merger and acquisition advisers, Eric J. Gleacher, resigned yesterday from Morgan Stanley & Company to start his own firm.

title: KEY RATES
Federal Judge Blocks a New Anti-Abortion Law in Pennsylvania
description: A Federal judge today blocked sections of a new anti-abortion law scheduled to take effect next week.

title: Chip Index Posts Rebound
description: The semiconductor industry's leading indicator rebounded in December as United States semiconductor shipments and orders increased, signaling a recovery from the summer slowdown, the Semiconductor Industry Association said today.

title: F.B.I. SETTLES SUITS BY BLACK WORKERS ON DISCRIMINATION
description: In what appears to be a significant admission of racial problems within the Federal Bureau of Investigation, the agency has reached out-of-court settlements in recent months in major discrimination cases involving black employees.

title: Photography: Images of Past and Future
description: The observance of photography's 150th anniversary may have ended in December, but you wouldn't know it from the number of exhibitions of photographs on view this month. It's as if a brand new season has begun in the art world, with photographs once again playing a major role. There's a feeling of fresh possibility in the air, in part because the 1980's are now history, and in part because history itself -in particular, the history of art - suddenly seems a subject on artists' minds. This month's photography shows range all over the art-historical lot, from an eye-opening survey of the Victorian idylls of Henry Peach Robinson, opening today at the International Center of Photography, to the latest computer-generated composite portraits by Nancy Burson, at the Jayne H. Baum Gallery.

title: TV Weekend;   Mexican-American Drama on 'Wonderworks'
description: One of public television's more adventurous and distinguished excursions into family entertainment, ''Wonderworks,'' returns for a new season this weekend, having been moved to 10 o'clock on Sunday mornings on Channel 13 from early prime time. The series is produced by a consortium of stations that is headed by WQED in Pittsburgh and that, perhaps significantly, does not include Channel 13.

title: Blues and Rock
description: Joan Osborne is singing blues and rock songs at tomorrow at 11 P.M. at Delta 88, 332 Eighth Avenue, at 26th Street (924-3499). There is a $7 cover and a $5 minimum at tables, no cover at the bar.

title: Editors' Note
description: An article on Jan. 2 reported on a dispute at The Jerusalem Post, where journalists have accused the new publisher of trying to turn a liberal daily into a right-wing platform.

title: Chronicle
description: The Boys Choir of Harlem, founded by DR. WALTER J. TURNBULL, has a lot to celebrate when it observes its 20th anniversary on the Martin Luther King Jr. holiday on Monday.

title: New York City Study Of Motorists Killed Finds Tie to Cocaine
description: Almost one of every four drivers between the ages of 16 and 45 who were killed in New York City traffic accidents in recent years tested positive for cocaine use, a new study has found.

title: Review/Concert;   A Conductor With a Flair for the Contemporary
description: The ever-busier Gerard Schwarz resigned last year as music director of the Music Today series at Merkin Concert Hall. But his absence, along with the apparent good taste of the series' new music adviser, Andre Emelianoff, has opened up this ensemble to a variety of alternative leaders.

title: Outside Tiananmen Square, Little Sense of Drama
description: Bundled like mummies against the freezing winds, those few Beijing residents who are now permitted to walk in Tiananmen Square strolled there and quietly speculated about whether the shifting political breezes may be carrying the first signs of a thaw.

title: Daniel Brockman, 86; Helped Save Carnegie
description: Daniel David Brockman, a prominent tax lawyer and supporter of the arts, died of cancer at his home in Manhattan yesterday. He was 86 and had homes in Manhattan, East Hampton and Marbella, Spain.

title: Report on Hospital Death Rates Is Challenged
description: The results of a Government study on death rates in nearly 6,000 hospitals were challenged today by researchers who said the Federal analysis failed to account for variations in the severity of patients' illness when they were hospitalized.

title: Washington Talk;   Traveling Salesman Of 'Retail Politics'
description: As President Bush wrapped up his first year in office with a quick hop to Malta, an afternoon in the Caribbean, a political swing through the Southwest, some hunting and fishing in Texas and Alabama and two trips to Florida, an old friend mused about the busy schedule.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about the winner of a $35 million Lotto prize misstated the Federal tax he will have to pay. While 20 percent will be withheld from his 21 annual checks, the actual tax owed would be 28 percent under current Federal law.

title: Market Place;   The Big Losers From Campeau
description: SOME of the biggest losses from Robert Campeau's spending binge on department stores have been borne by individual investors who purchased ''junk bond'' mutual funds that bought large quantities of bonds issued to finance the Campeau Corporation's purchases.

title: Banker Without Ads
description: Starting Tuesday, The American Banker, a daily trade newspaper, will appear without a front-page ad for the first time in a century. Gerald Taylor, the senior vice president for advertising, said that this and other design changes had been made so that American Banker ''will no longer look like a high school newspaper.''

title: SALVADOR REBELS BACK PEACE TALKS
description: Leftist rebels accepted a Government proposal today to ask the Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar of the United Nations to mediate peace talks, and proposed that negotiations start within 30 days.

title: Georgia Tech Loses At Last in Duke Rally
description: Duke overcame a 10-point deficit in the last nine minutes to defeat previously unbeaten Georgia Tech by 96-91 last night.

title: BRIEFS
description: * American Telephone and Telegraph Co. said it would set up a trust to borrow about $550 million through a private placement to buy stock that will be used for future company contributions to its existing non-management employee savings plan.

title: AIDS Doctor Tells of a Fatal Future
description: Dr. Veronica Prego testified yesterday about fearing the future because she knows ''what is coming'' as a result of her having AIDS.

title: Stock Prices in Rebound As Dow Climbs 10.03 Points
description: Stocks rebounded yesterday as investors sought bargains in the wake of the market's recent weakness. The Dow Jones industrial average, ahead as many as 22 points at midmorning, closed the day 10.03 points higher, at 2,760.67.

title: On Stage
description: A Friendly House Call for 'Annie'

title: Hong Kong Journal;   Help! Wicked Satirist Is Loose. Colony Skewered.
description: Larry Feign's Hong Kong Chinese are shameless racists who love to gamble, toss garbage out their apartment windows and make money. A greedy, materialistic lot, they prefer stability and prosperity to democratic freedoms.

title: Albania, on Its National Day, Rejects Democratic Changes
description: Hard-line Albania celebrated its national day today, firmly rejecting democratic changes that have broken the Communist grip on power elsewhere in Eastern Europe.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about an increase in corporate bond defaults in 1989 misstated the financial situation of Integrated Resources Inc. The company is seeking to reorganize itself but has not filed for Chapter 11 protection under the bankruptcy laws.

title: Review/Music;   American Composers Orchestra
description: Listening to the concert of the American Composers Orchestra on Sunday afternoon at Carnegie Hall, one couldn't help but reflect on a curious argument that seems to be gaining currency: that the symphony orchestra, as an outgrowth and repository of European musical tradition, is an artificial overlay on American culture, superfluous if not subversive of homespun values. As American orchestras find it ever harder to make ends meet, the musical public is advised not to lament the attrition, which is natural and inevitable, but to face it with brave equanimity.

title: Mexico Toasts, and Jeers, the Spanish Monarchs
description: The arrival here of King Juan Carlos and Queen Sofia of Spain for a state visit has reawakened all the ambivalent and contradictory feelings Mexico harbors for its mother country, with the Spanish couple getting a reception oscillating between warmth and hostility.

title: New York Officials Mobilizing for Drive For an Exact Census
description: With New York's share of Federal aid and the size of its Congressional delegation at stake, officials here and in New York City have recruited the help of several powerful unions in an effort to have the state's population fully counted in the Census.

title: Ruling on Serving the Under-Age Is Reversed
description: New York State's highest court today overturned a decision revoking for 10 days the license of Dorrian's Red Hand restaurant in Manhattan, where Robert E. Chambers met Jennifer Levin before killing her in Central Park in 1986.

title: Ammirati To Leave Omnicom
description: ENDING a protracted and occasionally bitter eight-month negotiation, the Omnicom Group and Ammirati & Puris announced yesterday that Ammirati, the New York advertising agency known for its stylish promotions for BMW cars and Club Med resorts, is buying itself back from the giant conglomerate.

title: Juliet Berto, Actress, 42
description: Juliet Berto, who starred in the Jean-Luc Godard films ''Weekend,'' ''La Chinoise'' and ''Le Gai Savoir,'' died of cancer on Wednesday. She was 42 years old.

title: 3 Steelers Vying for Hall
description: Three pillars of the Pittsburgh Steelers' four Super Bowl victories - the running back Franco Harris, the linebacker Jack Lambert and the wide receiver Lynn Swann - head the list of 15 finalists for induction into the Pro Football Hall of Fame.

title: Review/Music;   A Collection Of Keyboard (Neo)Classics
description: The ''Evening of 20th-Century Keyboard Classics'' offered on Monday at Merkin Concert Hall was eccentric in its length and juxtaposition of diverse performing forces. It might also have been better named ''An Evening of 20th-Century Keyboard Neo-Classics.'' But it was full of good music well performed, and it built to two really excellent combinations of creation and re-creation at the end.

title: New Dances Explore Offbeat Themes
description: YOU can see a dance this weekend called ''I'm a Frayed Knot,'' inspired by Nathaniel Hawthorne's ''Scarlet Letter.'' Home videos are featured in another dance, ''Malad Justed,'' in which a fish responds to Navy war exercises in its sea. But two other dances, by choreographers known for their individualism, will tackle relatively familiar dance subjects - women and clowns. This is a weekend to explore the unexpected in dance.

title: Ballet Theater to Receive $1 Million
description: American Ballet Theater announced yesterday that it will receive a bequest of $1 million from Eugenia Doll, the philanthropist and former wife of the choreographer Leonide Massine. The company said the bequest by Mrs. Doll, who created the role of the Flower Girl in Massine's ''Gaite Parisienne,'' was earmarked for its newly established endowment fund.

title: Oregon and Washington Floods Rout 3,000
description: Flood water lay across southwest Washington and northern Oregon today, closing part of a busy Interstate highway and other roads and forcing about 3,000 people to leave their homes.

title: California May Deny Import of Giant Frogs
description: Bureaucrats have thrown a hurdle in the way of the giant frogs from Cameroon that a man wants to enter in Calaveras County's annual frog jump.

title: Clash Over Secret Data in Noriega Case
description: The Government raised the issue of national security for the first time today in the drug-trafficking case of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, arguing that classified information had been improperly disclosed.

title: A Scholarly Mystery: ''Z'' Writes Darkly of Communism, but Who Is ''Z''?
description: Who is ''Z''?

title: National Standards Won't Improve Education
description: To the Editor:

title: Mitsubishi to Drop A Biblical Quotation
description: In response to viewer complaints, Mitsubishi Motor Sales of America has agreed to alter a television commercial for its Galant car that quotes in part from St. Paul's Letter to the Corinthians. The voice-over for the spot, set outside a New England church, originally began: ''Yea, when I was a child I spoke as a child and acted as a child. But yea, when I became an adult, I put away childish things . . .''

title: Quilting Bee
description: Come Quilt With Me Inc., a quilting-supply mail-order business, and the 92d Street Y are sponsoring their ninth annual quilting bee at the Y on Sunday from 1 to 5 P.M. There will also be talks on quilting in America and Japan throughout the afternoon. Admission is $5, and quilts may be appraised by the quilter Genie Barnes for $20. The Y is at 1395 Lexington Avenue. Information: (718) 377-3652.

title: Win or Lose, Noriega Case Means Victory for Lawyer
description: Until two years ago, Frank Rubino was the typical Miami ''white powder'' lawyer, representing defendants in drug cases. His most notorious client was a high official in the operation of Carlos Lehder Rivas, the convicted Colombian drug smuggler. His client list included Tony Roman, a.k.a. Antonio Piedra; Giuseppe Pellerito, a.k.a. Joseph El Italiano, and Michael John Flowers, a.k.a. Raymond DuBois, a.k.a. Big Mike, a.k.a. Fat Michael. But now, through a combination of good luck, good connections and good work, the 44-year-old Mr. Rubino, a former Secret Service agent who once protected Richard M. Nixon in Key Biscayne, Fla., has landed the most conspicuous criminal defendant in the world: Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega of Panama.

title: Backers Defend Top Contender For Health Post
description: Supporters of the top contender for New York City Health Commissioner, who has been criticized by some advocates for AIDS patients, rallied to his defense yesterday.

title: 2 Successes In the Quest For Creative Uniqueness
description: Two of jazz's great individualists, the singers Betty Carter and Abbey Lincoln Moseka, will step on stage tonight and give a lesson or two on how to secure a place in jazz history. After a phrase or so, the singers will show off carefully constructed personalities built not out of economic necessity, but out of an act of the imagination. Living examples of a jazz law that demands originality in exchange for greatness, they know just how to turn the nuances of the personal into something powerfully evocative. The most repressed audience crumbles under their emotional weight; the two women can draw tears from a rock.

title: For Children
description: Shows, Nature, Museums ''CHARLOTTE'S WEB,'' a musical based on E. B. White's story about a spider named Charlotte, performed by On Stage Productions, 3 and 7 P.M. tomorrow and at 3 P.M. on Sunday. Last performances. At Hartley House Theater, 413 West 46th Street. Tickets: students and the elderly, $8; others, $10. Information: 666-1716. ''PETER PAN,'' a play with music, by Michael Taubenslag Productions, 1 and 2:30 P.M. on Sunday, at the Jan Hus Playhouse, 351 East 74th Street. Admission: $4.50. Information: 772-9180. ''THE SECRET GARDEN,'' a musical based on the story by Frances Hodgson Burnett, 12:30 P.M. tomorrow and Sunday, presented by Theaterworks/USA, at the Promenade Theater, 2162 Broadway, at 76th Street. Tickets: $12 and $15. Reservations: 677-5959. ''THE SNOW QUEEN,'' a show by Puppetworks, noon Saturdays, 1 and 3 P.M. on Sundays, through Feb. 25, at the group's theater, 287 Third Avenue, at Carroll Street, Park Slope, Brooklyn. Children, $4; adults, $5. Information: (718) 834-1828. ''ALFRED THE DRAGON AND THE WIZARD,'' a play about a shy dragon who lives in Central Park and a sly wizard, written by Miranda McDermott, with child actors of the New Media Repertory Company, 3 P.M. on Saturdays, at 512 East 80th Street. Tickets: children, $4.50; adults, $5. Reservations required: 734-5195. ''ONE, TWO, MONSTER ZOO,'' a puppet show by Rod Young, 11 A.M. and 1 P.M. tomorrow and Sunday, at the Puppet Playhouse, 555 East 90th Street. Tickets: $3.50. Reservations: 369-8890. ''HUMPTY DUMPTY FALLS IN LOVE,'' a play by the Little People's Theater Company, directed by Robert Stark, 1:30 P.M. tomorrow and Sunday, and ''Cinderella,'' 3 P.M. tomorrow and Sunday, at the Courtyard Playhouse, 39 Grove Street. Tickets: $6. Reservations required: 765-9540. ''WINTER DAZZLERS,'' a program of songs and stories, 1:30 P.M. Sunday, at the Dairy, in Central Park, near 64th Street, just north of the Wollman Rink. Free. Reservations required: 397-3165. ''HANSEL AND GRETEL,'' a puppet show by the Papageno Puppet Theater, with Susan Delery Whedon, who sings with recorded music in an abridged version of the Humperdinck opera, 1:30 P.M. on Saturdays and Sundays, at the West 72d Street Studios, 131 West 72d Street. Admission: $4. Information: 874-3297. ''MOSTLY MAGIC,'' a magic show with audience participation, with Bob McAllister and and Imam, 2 P.M. on Saturdays, at 55 Carmine Street. Admission: $7.50. Information: 924-1472. ''DO YOU SEE WHAT I SEE,'' a new eyes-on exhibition, based on a concept that originated with the Hood Museum of Art at Dartmouth College, 1 to 5 P.M. Tuesdays through Fridays and on Sundays; 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. on Saturdays through March 4 at the Katonah Gallery, 28 Bedford Road, Katonah, N.Y. Free. Information: (914) 232-9555. ''THE DANGEROUS CHRISTMAS OF RED RIDING HOOD,'' with music by Jule Styne, lyrics by Bob Merrill and book by Robert Emmett, 7:30 P.M. today and 1 and 3:30 P.M. tomorrow and Sunday. Final performances next weekend. Tada Theater, 120 West 28th Street. Admission: $5. Reservations required: 627-1732.

title: J. Henry Smith, Insurance Leader And New York Official, Dies at 79
description: J. Henry Smith, a former chairman of the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States who later became New York City's Human Resources Administrator, died of pneumonia Wednesday in the infirmary of Meadow Lakes, a retirement community in Hightstown, N.J., where he lived. He was 79 years old.

title: Workers of the World
description: The most striking development inside the Soviet Union in the past year has been the emergence of a genuine labor movement.

title: P.L.O.'s Lebanon Commander Threatens to Attack
description: The commander of P.L.O. guerrillas in the Sidon area of southern Lebanon threatened today to retaliate for attacks against his men by Lebanese Shiite Muslim militiamen.

title: Pro Bono
description: * Friends of Libraries U.S.A. has selected Martin Marshall Jaccoma Mitchell to create a campaign to promote literacy and reading.

title: Boston Murder Suspect Sought a Brother's Help, Lawyer Says
description: Charles Stuart asked one of his brothers to help him kill his wife ''weeks before'' she was fatally shot on Oct. 23, a lawyer for the brother said today.

title: Clean Subways Are Emphasized By Transit Head
description: The new president of the New York City Transit Authority vowed yesterday to continue the rebuilding begun by his predecessor. He also described the subway system as unfriendly and said he would emphasize improving the appearance of trains and stations.

title: A Frustrated Bronco Receiver Seeks More Moments in the Sun
description: It was late morning and the sun had already risen high above the field where the Denver Broncos were preparing to begin their day of work. Mark Jackson stepped into the warmth, seated himself on a table and squinted into the glare that has suddenly returned after a season that still somehow seems lost and full of misery.

title: An Early Independence Is Now Seen for Namibia
description: Aided by a spirit of conciliation that has overtaken its long-contentious political factions, Namibia could be ready to declare its independence ahead of schedule, officials involved in the process say.

title: Trophy for Montana
description: Joe Montana, the National Football League's top quarterback, won the Jim Thorpe Trophy yesterday as the league's most valuable player. He is the third successive San Francisco 49er player to win the award, following Roger Craig and Jerry Rice.

title: Fewer Flights, but More Air Traffic Delays in 1989
description: The number of air traffic delays rose sharply last year, especially at the nation's five most congested airports, Government officials reported yesterday. Aviation experts found the figures particularly disturbing because delays increased even though the number of flights fell slightly.

title:
LAW;

National Rules for Child Witnesses?
description: LEAD: With a growing number of children taking the witness stand, judges, lawyers and Congress have begun searching for ways to lessen the intimidation and trauma many children experience in court while insuring a defendant's right to a fair trial.

title: Philippines Says U.S. Is Violating Bases Pact
description: Manila accused the United States today of violating provisions in an agreement on two United States military bases in the Philippines and warned that the issue could affect negotiations on the bases' future.

title: Salvadoran Leftist Abducted
description: A prominent Salvadoran leftist was kidnapped today in the Guatemalan capital, party officials said. Hector Oqueli Colindres, deputy secretary general of the National Revolutionary Movement, was seized with a Guatemalan woman who was driving him to the airport, the group said in a statement released in San Salvador.

title: First Boston To Absorb Voute Coats
description: Five former Salomon Brothers executives, who last year founded a bond-trading ''boutique'' called Voute Coats Stuart & O'Grady, will be joining the First Boston Corporation, the two companies announced yesterday.

title: Astronomers Say X-Ray Glow Is Produced in Active Galaxies
description: The glow of X-ray radiation that suffuses the universe, mysterious since its discovery 28 years ago, is apparently issuing from distant galaxies that are giving birth to new stars, astronomers said today.

title: Zavitz Technology reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $76,026, or 1 cent a share. c-Net income The 1988 results represented a 10- month period. The company changed its fiscal year-end to Sept. 30 from Nov. 30. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: CONSUMER'S WORLD: Guidepost ;   Reviewing Investments
description: The first quarter of the new year is a good time to review or plan personal investment portfolios. Thus far many market strategists are making stocks the early choice as the lead component for most portfolios. Inflation is in check and the economy is gradually slowing, lowering interest rates. Stocks and bonds benefit from lower rates. Portfolios should reflect individual preferences and needs, with stocks used to increase personal wealth and bonds to generate future income. Here are some model portfolios being suggested to clients by some leading brokerage houses: $ Brokerage Stocks Bonds Cash Dean Witter 85% 15% 0% Gruntal 55% 30% 15% Merrill Lynch 50% 50% 0% Paine Webber 60% 29% 11%

title: Overtime: Knicks' Standard Time
description: The Knicks defeated the Indiana Pacers, 101-96, in overtime tonight.

title: Six Musicians to Open Highlights in Jazz Series
description: The 17th annual Highlights in Jazz series opens at 8 P.M. on Feb. 1 at New York University, Loeb Student Center, 566 La Guardia Place, with a concert by six noted musicians.

title: Is New York's Tax Cut Slipping Away?
description: It appears Gov. Mario Cuomo is preparing to torpedo the state income tax cut millions of New Yorkers were expecting this year. No other conclusion can be drawn from his State of the State message, where in 178 pages of text he never once mentioned the pending reduction. The omission casts a shadow over the final phase of the four-year Tax Reduction Act, which became law in 1987.

title: Printronix Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 29
description: b-Net loss

title: Autodie Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Donors' Races to Be Sought To Identify Rare Blood Types
description: To ease a chronic shortage of rare blood types, the New York Blood Center will for the first time begin asking donors to volunteer information about their racial and ethnic backgrounds.

title: Salick Health Care reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
New Jersey Suit Says Exxon Violated Laws on Pollution
description: New Jersey filed a civil lawsuit yesterday against the Exxon Corporation, charging that the company violated the state's pollution control laws when a pipeline ruptured, releasing more than a half million gallons of heating oil into the Arthur Kill.

title: Jack Lazar, Founder Of Knitwear Maker And Style Setter, 79
description: Jack Lazar, the founder of Kimberly Knitwear Inc., in Manhattan, died Thursday at his home in Teaneck, N.J. He was 79 years old. With his wife, the former Helen Bandow, as the designer, Mr. Lazar opened the company in 1946. Over the years, Kimberley's knit dresses and other items came to be fashion staples in wardrobes of women from the Duchess of Windsor to secretaries.

title: Accugraph Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Moffat Communication reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Review/Dance;   Of Movement for Movement's Sake
description: Movement as movement was the thing for two choreographers, Randy Warshaw and Mark Dendy, in the second program Thursday night in the ''Manmade'' series.

title: Flanigan's Enterprises Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Wordstar International Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Indian Shift on Bhopal Case
description: The Indian Government said today that its predecessor was wrong to agree to absolve the Union Carbide Corporation of criminal liability in the 1984 Bhopal gas disaster, and it called the $470 million settlement inadequate.

title: Oak Hill Sportswear reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Real-Estate Investment Concern Bears Its Founder's Image
description: Time Equities, the real-estate investment company whose investments in renter-occupied cooperatives have been hurt by a slow sales market, is synonymous with one individual, Francis Greenburger, 41 years old, who founded it 20 years ago.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Q&A column of Science Times on Jan. 2 about air temperature and precipitation gave an incorrect location for Pennsylvania State University. It is in University Park.

title: Century Communications Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
The Times Names 3 Editors
description: Appointments to three major editing positions at The New York Times were announced yesterday by Max Frankel, the newspaper's executive editor.

title: Patents;   States Held Immune on Infringement
description: In a decision viewed by some experts as a blow to inventors, the Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit in Washington has ruled that state governments are immune from charges of patent infringement.

title: Review/Circus;   The Daredevils From Moscow
description: Almost reflecting the way things are going back home, the Moscow Circus moved into Radio City Music Hall on Thursday in a dazzle of spin, whirl and precarious stability.

title: Books of The Times;   A Politician Indicted By His Associates' Wit
description: The Lone Star

title: Frost Flirts With Record
description: David Frost came within a stroke of the PGA Tour's 18-hole scoring record today when he shot a 12-under-par 60 in the second round of the Tucson Open. Only a bogey on the 16th hole of his round, the seventh on the Randolph Park municipal course, prevented Frost from matching the 59 Al Geiberger shot at the 1977 Memphis Classic.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball

title: T-Shirt Makers Have Us by the Neck
description: LEAD: Virtually everyone has noticed what is going on with tags in our clothing. However, I am sure not enough people have really thought about it, because there are no demonstrations in the streets and no occupations of corporate boardrooms about this business of tags.

title: CHRONICLE
description: ALAN MIRKEN, vice chairman of Random House is leaving that position at the end of the month.

title: Buenos Aires Journal;   Carlos, Carlos, How Does Your Economy Sink?
description: As President Carlos Saul Menem struggles to salvage and reform the chaotic Argentine economy, he suffers a daily dose of front-page advice and criticism from a tennis-playing friend who thinks he could do it better.

title: At 85, Shirer Rounds Out His Story
description: William L. Shirer, now 85 years old and, by his own admission, slowing down a bit, gives this illustration of what he calls his lucky habit of being in the right place at the right time.

title: Anne Izard, 74, Dies; A Children's Librarian
description: Anne R. Izard, a retired children's librarian in Westchester County, died of complications from cancer on Monday at her home in Gwynedd, Pa. She was 74 years old.

title: Pilot Survives Crash of Jet In a Suburb of Philadelphia
description: A single-seat jet fighter crashed in a heavily populated neighborhood in suburban Philadephia yesterday, but the authorities said the pilot suffered only minor injuries and nobody on the ground was injured.

title: Shaw Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 30
Systerm Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 3
description: b-Included an extraordinary loss of $2,421,253 for the quarter and 9 months. c-Net income Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: A. Schulman reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Share earnings have been adjusted for the 3-for-2 stock split paid in the form of a 50-percent stock dividend on March 22, 1989.

title: Webster, 63, Dies; Actress and Art Dealer
description: Nell Webster, an actress and art dealer, died of ovarian cancer on Thursday at her home in Manhattan. She was 63 years old. Miss Webster was named Gloria Caroline Gall when she was born, in New York City. She changed her name when she became an actress. For a decade, she appeared at clubs throughout the United States in a one-woman comedy act she had developed.

title: Temtex Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $82,000, or 3 cents a share, from a tax credit.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, JANUARY, 13, 1990
description: The Economy

title: Gtech Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 25
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $2,405,000 for the quarter and 9 months; the 9 months was also after a gain of $974,000, or 10 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting.

title: Medical Management of America reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Included charges of $375,000 and $6,152,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, related to the company's sale of its non-medical real estate assets. c-Included gain of $105,000 from discontinued operations. d-Net income

title: Rebels' Allies Stand Firm in Salvador
description: Every morning he combs the local newspapers, looking anxiously for the names of captured and killed guerrillas.

title: Datapoint Suitors
description: Martin Ackerman, a New York businessman, and Fidenas International Bank Ltd. of Nassau, the Bahamas, said they had told the Datapoint Corporation they were interested in exploring the possibility of acquiring the company. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mr. Ackerman and Fidenas said they jointly hold a 7.4 percent stake. Datapoint, a San Antonio business computer company, has said it will explore various alternatives, including the possible sale of the company. Its stock slipped 37.5 cents a share today, to $3.25, on the New York stock Exchange.

title: IMC Fertilizer Group reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Review/Cabaret;   Bach, Rock and Musical Comedy
description: Midway through ''Two Guys and a Piano,'' the new show at the Algonquin Hotel (59 West 44th Street) on Tuesday evening, the musical comedy duo of Bill Daugherty and Robin Field broke into a suite of songs from ''South Pacific'' that illustrated their musical strengths more strikingly than anything they have done in the past.

title: Langer Biomechanics Group reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net income

title: Religion Notes
description: John Cardinal O'Connor of New York will ordain a married man with four children to the priesthood today.

title: Temple Player on Center Stage, at Last
description: If Duane Causwell had had the choice when he was growing up in New York, he would have been a baseball player.

title: Tide West Oil Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Canadiens Manage a Rare Road Victory as Devil Defense Falters
description: Don't tell the Devils the Canadiens are having problems playing away from home.

title: Japan Does Good, and Well
description: It's a stylized performance. The politician up for re-election dons the statesman's mask and travels abroad in search of good visuals. But the trip to Europe by Prime Minister Kaifu of Japan is no mere ritual play for attention. It's the clearest sign yet that Japan is ready to use its economic power for responsible political ends.

title: Review/Dance;   'Prodigal Son' Weaves Poignancy and Motion
description: Slight and fair-haired, Ib Andersen is not the prototypical hero of ''The Prodigal Son,'' a signature ballet by Balanchine set to music by Prokofiev. The role has been defined, in part, by dark and muscled dancers. But Mr. Andersen's performance of the title role with the New York City Ballet on Thursday night at the New York State Theater was so poignantly realized that it was almost painful to watch at times.

title: Charge Cards That Pick Up the Pieces
description: Now that American Express has set the pace, Mastercard and Visa are running close behind in providing charge-card programs that insure purchases against loss, damage or breakage.

title: Shuttle Astronauts Snare a Battered Science Satellite
description: After a three-day chase round and round the world, the astronauts of the space shuttle Columbia caught up with a bus-size science satellite today, snared it with a robot arm and tucked it away in the cargo bay for the trip home to Earth.

title: Congress Is Warned by Bush Not to Cut Pentagon Budget
description: Seeking to fight off deeper cuts in the military budget than those proposed by the Pentagon, President Bush today warned Congress against trying to ''naively cut the muscle out of our defense'' to provide more money for other programs.

title: The U.S. and Panama;   Noriega Judge Orders Lawyers Not to Talk About Move of General
description: In another move to tighten security in the case of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, a Federal district judge today ordered lawyers not to discuss with reporters a possible move of the defendant from downtown Miami.

title: A Furless Joy
description: It is now O.K. to join a crowd and hiss people who wear fur coats.

title: What Brooklynites Really Miss Isn't Loehmann's, but Ebinger's
description: To the Editor:

title: Fur Vault Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 2
description: b-Net income Year-ago periods ended Nov. 26.

title: AIDS Panel Endorses Doctor for Health Post
description: Mayor David N. Dinkins said last night that the ''impediment'' against naming Dr. Woodrow A. Myers Jr. as health commissioner had been removed by his endorsement from a diverse panel of AIDS experts, but the Mayor stopped short of announcing the appointment.

title: Northern Calloway, Actor, 41, on Stage And 'Sesame Street'
description: Northern J. Calloway, who played David, the proprietor of Mr. Hooper's store, on public television's ''Sesame Street,'' died Tuesday. He was 41 years old and lived in Ossining, N.Y.

title: Donald F. Bowler, Investigator, 69
description: Donald F. Bowler, an investigator best known for helping send the gangster Mickey Cohen to prison for tax evasion, was found dead on Tuesday at his home in Canoga Park, Calif. The cause of death was not made known. He was 69 years old. Mr. Bowler, as intelligence chief of the Internal Revenue Service for Southern California, directed the grand jury investigation in 1960 and 1961 that led to Mr. Cohen's imprisonment for hiding about $400,000 from tax collectors.

title: Upheaval in the East: Warsaw Pact;   Historians Dig Up Dark Hints Of 1980 Plan to Invade Poland
description: Did the Warsaw Pact plan an invasion of Poland in 1980 to suppress the Solidarity labor movement? In the heady atmosphere of Eastern Europe these days, it is not hard to find people who believe that it did.

title: News Summary
description: International 3-9

title: Retail Sales Rose 0.2% Last Month
description: Retail sales rose two-tenths of a percent in December, and holiday spending was the weakest since 1985, the Government reported today. For the year, sales increased 5 percent, the slowest gain in seven years.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A.

title: Treasury Bond Prices Fall Sharply
description: Treasury bond prices tumbled and yields climbed yesterday, largely because of heavy overnight selling of domestic and United States securities by Japanese and European institutions.

title: Corrections
description: A theater review yesterday about ''The Return,'' a play by Frederic Glover at the Jewish Repertory Theater, misidentified the director in some editions. He is Michael Bloom, not Byam Stevens.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary yesterday about Martin Newman, a theater executive, misidentified one of his positions. He was a former executive vice president of Century Theaters, not a former president.

title: Expansion Set For Disneyland
description: The Walt Disney Company announced today what it called its most ambitious expansion plans ever for its original theme park, the highly profitable 35-year-old Disneyland in Anaheim.

title: Lyle Wheeler, 84; Art Director Won 5 Academy Awards
description: Lyle Wheeler, an art director who won five Academy Awards for such classics as ''Gone With the Wind'' and ''The Diary of Anne Frank,'' died of pneumonia on Wednesday at the Motion Picture Country Home and Hospital in Woodland Hills. He was 84 years old.

title: Report Cites Officers' Acts In Cell Death
description: A Brooklyn man who died in a police holding cell last week suffocated when officers squeezed his chest and neck while trying to subdue him, the New York City Medical Examiner's office said yesterday.

title: Preparing Tax Returns On Home Computers
description: As income-tax time approaches, growing numbers of Americans are using personal computers to complete their returns.

title: Inside
description: Campeau Move Is Examined

title: Upheaval in the East: Albania;   Harsh Security Measures Are Reported in Albania
description: The official Yugoslav press agency reported today that the authorities in Albania had imposed ''extremely strict'' security measures, but a senior Albanian Communist Party leader called the reports of unrest there ''slander.''

title: SPORTS OF THE TIMES
description: As he lay in a ward in Harlem Hospital, with five other patients and no telephone, he said he remembered how the crowd at Madison Square Garden would chant his name: ''Wing-o! Wing-o!'' It usually came late in the game. He had sat at the end of the Knicks' bench, his bony knees nearly hiding his eyes, as he heard the appeal for him to play. ''Ah man,'' he said now, ''that felt good, but it made me a little embarrassed.'' And he smiled, a familiar, gentle smile.

title: The Little Engine That Might
description: General Motors's new Impact electric car works, but the assembly line is still far off. G.M. must first establish the car's economic viability, then develop production technology. Even so, the prototype is a welcome demonstration that battery power has a future beyond golf carts.

title: Nu Horizons Electronics Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
AIDS Doctor Is Asked Details About Needle
description: Dr. Veronica Prego testified under persistent cross-examination yesterday that she could not remember many details of the incident when she accidentally pricked her finger with an AIDS-contaminated needle.

title: KEY RATES
Oxygen for Sale
description: Portable oxygen is now being sold as a ''pick-me-up.'' Doctors say it doesn't do anything of the sort.

title: U.S. and Britain Near Air Pact
description: Britain and the United States are near a short-term agreement to expand air services between the two countries, the British Transport Secretary, Cecil Parkinson, said today.

title: EAST GERMAN CHIEF SCRAPS NEW PLANS FOR SECRET POLICE
description: The East German Prime Minister bowed today to growing pressure from the public and the opposition and scrapped plans to form a new security service, at least until after the elections scheduled for May.

title: Florafax International Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net income

title: Wisconsin Toy reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Patents;   A 'Videowindow' For Teleconferences
description: Two engineers at Bellcore, a research consortium owned jointly by the ''Baby Bell'' regional telephone companies, have patented a ''videowindow'' that they said makes participants in a long-distance teleconference feel as if they are in the same room.

title: U.S. PLANS STUDIES OF HOW A-PLANTS
description: Sweeping aside much of the secrecy that has governed the production of nuclear weapons since World War II, the Energy Department announced today that it would prepare two comprehensive studies on the public health and environmental consequences of its program to clean up and modernize atomic weapons plants.

title: Producer Prices Up 4.8% in '89, Most in 8 Years
description: Paced by big increases for energy and tobacco, producer prices jumped seven-tenths of 1 percent in December to bring 1989 inflation by this measure to 4.8 percent, the highest rate since 1981.

title: A Good Place to Act Affirmatively
description: In the broadcasting field, white males are anything but an endangered species. A decade ago blacks and Hispanics owned less than 1 percent of the nation's radio and television licenses. Modest Federal Communications Commission programs have doubled that rate - to 2 percent. Yet two of those programs are under constitutional attack in the Supreme Court. If these mild doses of affirmative action are too strong, it's hard to imagine what can survive.

title: Teledyne Canada reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Upheaval in the East;   Talks on Summit Meeting
description: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d and Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze of the Soviet Union will hold talks in Moscow on Feb. 6 and 7 to prepare for the June summit meeting in Washington between President Bush and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the two Governments said today.

title: Free Election Air Time Could End Tax Checkoff
description: To the Editor:

title: Why So Slow?
description: Much has been said about the speed of collapse in Eastern Europe. It is true that, like an earthquake or an avalanche, the televisual action came all of a sudden. But it is also true that, like such natural upheavals, the dynamics that triggered the movement were building up for a long time.

title: Patents;   Fixed Mortgages Down
description: Fixed-rate home mortgages are averaging 9.80 percent, according to a national survey released today by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation. That rate was down from a rate of 9.83 percent last week. On one-year adjustable-rate mortgages, lenders were asking an average initial rate of 8.41 percent this week, up from 8.35 percent the week before.

title: RJR Nabisco Leaving The PGA Tour in 1991
description: The most powerful player in professional golf's money boom, RJR Nabisco Inc., will sever its major ties with the PGA Tour beginning in 1991.

title: Dr. Jerome I. Sashin, Psychiatrist, Dies at 49
description: Dr. Jerome I. Sashin, a psychiatrist who was chairman of the research committee of the Psychoanalytic Institute of New England East in Needham, Mass., died of lymphoma on Jan. 5 at Massachusetts General Hospital in Boston. He was 49 years old and lived in Boston.

title: Canadian Home Shopping reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Egypt Cotton Profits Off
description: Cotton, once known as Egypt's ''white gold,'' faces another year of much lower profits in 1989-90 as farmers grow less and imports rise. Cotton exports are expected to earn Egypt about $200 million this season, the Egyptian Cotton Authority said Thursday, down about $100 million from last season. Egypt also expects to import 130,000 bales of United States cotton in the 1989-90 season, up from 100,000 bales the year before.

title: Upheaval in the East: Rumania;   Requiem for a Dictatorship, Sung Slightly Off-Key
description: In many parts of this country, the popular uprising against Rumania's Communist Government was a scene of tragic bloodshed. But here in the heart of Moldavia, it has unfolded more like an operetta.

title: Virginia Adloff, 86, A Writer on Africa And Southeast Asia
description: Virginia Thompson Adloff, an author and teacher who wrote extensively on the countries of Southeast Asia and French-speaking Africa, died on Tuesday at the home of her sister in La Jolla, Calif. She was 86 years old and a longtime resident of Manhattan.

title: Frederick Hurd, 86, Investment Counselor
description: Frederick Hurd, a retired investment counselor and a trustee of the Children's Aid Society, died of a heart attack on Wednesday at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center in Manhattan. He was 86 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Hi-Shear Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net income

title: Dr. Joseph J. Copeland, 82, Dies; Led City College in Turbulent Era
description: Dr. Joseph John Copeland, a biologist who became acting president of City College at the height of racial turbulence there in May 1969, died of pneumonia on Thursday at the Paul Kimball Medical Center in Lakewood, N.J. He was 82 years old and had moved to a retirement community in Lakewood from Mount Vernon, N.Y., three years ago.

title: COMPUTER MAKERS HALT A CHALLENGE TO JAPANESE CHIPS
description: A trail-blazing attempt at cooperation among American manufacturers in the face of a challenge from Japanese industry is being abandoned because it has failed to attract enough investors, people in the computer industry said today.

title: Valley Resources Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Your Money;   Global Investing For the Cautious
description: The tumultuous events of Eastern Europe in recent weeks have given rise to capitalist hopes, and many small investors have rushed to buy shares of companies that they expect to profit from trade with East Germany, Poland, Hungary and other East bloc nations.

title: Court Allows New York City To Take Over Welfare Hotel
description: New York City said yesterday that it had won court approval to take over a bankrupt welfare hotel on West 43d Street that has been cited for more than 1,000 code violations.

title: Melamine Chemicals reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Bridge
description: One of the most exciting bidding environments is never faced by tournament players. It occurs in Chicago (four-deal) bridge, or in traditional rubber bridge, when both sides are vulnerable and both sides have a part score. Consequently almost any part score may earn a vulnerable game bonus, and innocuous hands become crucial.

title: Abbott Laboratories reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Japan Goes Full Throttle on Tests of Magnetic Levitation Trains
description: To the Editor:

title: In Everett, the Rams Trust
description: If the San Francisco 49ers are entering the National Conference championship game as the team of the last decade, then what are the Los Angeles Rams? Frustrated, for sure. While the other teams in the National Football League futilely tried to match the 49ers' mastery in the 1980's, the Rams know how tedious that task has been in a special way. In the 80's, the Rams finished second to the 49ers in the N.F.C. West Division six times, including the last two years.

title: Senior Service Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net income The company attributed the losses in part to unrealized net foreign exchange losses of $328,179 in the quarter and $339,780 in the 6 months.

title: Sonics' Ellis Is Injured In Traffic Accident
description: Dale Ellis, who is leading the Seattle SuperSonics in scoring with a 23.6-point average, suffered a collapsed lung in a traffic accident early yesterday and will be out indefinitely, the club announced. He was arrested for investigation of reckless driving and driving while intoxicated but was not taken into police custody because of his injuries.

title: The U.S. and Panama;   Paratroopers Jump Into Welcome-Home Gathering
description: Parachutes filled the sky Friday morning as nearly 2,000 soldiers parachuted to a triumphant return home after invading Panama.

title: Upheaval in the East: Washington;   Tough Choice for the U.S.: Baltic States or Gorbachev
description: The drive for independence in Lithuania and the other Baltic states has presented the United States with a diplomatic quandary, Administration officials said today.

title: The U.S. and Panama;   Pilot in Cocaine Ring Is Given 2 Life Terms
description: An American pilot for the Medellin cocaine ring in Colombia was sentenced today to two consecutive life terms and fined $2 million.

title: Cairo Ousts Hard-Line Interior Minister
description: President Hosni Mubarak dismissed his Interior Minister today in what seemed intended as a show of increased authority. The announcement signaled the most dramatic change of the political lineup here in months.

title: Lithuania and the U in U.S.S.R.
description: Three triumphs for peace and freedom:

title: After Fatal Purse-Theft, A 'Safe' Area Is Edgy
description: Park Avenue at 92d Street is in a neighborhood that residents call peaceful and beautiful. When the Brick Church preschool lets out, mothers, nannies and children crowd the sidewalk. Doormen help tenants with grocery bags. Elderly women stroll ''the Avenue.''

title: Time Doesn't Improve Peary's North Pole Claim
description: To the Editor:

title: Earl D. Johnson, 84, Aviation Figure And Cabinet Officer
description: Earl D. Johnson, who was an Under Secretary of the Army and a top executive at General Dynamics and Delta Airlines, died in his sleep on Thursday at a nursing home in Greenwich, Conn. He was 84 years old and lived in Greenwich.

title: Hovnanian Enterprises reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Included $6.6 million, or 32 cents a share, non-cash reserve against certain properties in Florida and New York for both periods. c-Included one-time benefit of $2.6 million, or 13 cents a share, due to a change in method of accounting for income taxes.

title: Reserve Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $447,543, or 23 cents a share, which included a gain of $305,224 from extinguishment of debt and $142,319 from tax loss carryforward.

title: Holiday on Monday
description: Monday is the birthday of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Here are holiday schedules.

title: The U.S. and Panama;   Congressman Criticizes Use Of Stealth Plane in Panama
description: The chairman of the House Armed Services Committee today praised the military's planning and execution of the strike in Panama but criticized the use of the Stealth fighter plane as ''show biz.''

title: Cup Dispute Nears End
description: A two-and-a-half-year court dispute over the America's Cup has moved closer to a resolution.

title: Decade's Nought but 10
description: To the Editor:

title: Upheaval in ht e East;   Pope Praises Christian Role In Collapse of Communism
description: Pope John Paul II pronounced a stinging epitaph for Communism in Europe today but said the road to a world of freedom and justice was strewn with obstacles.

title: Marcos Allies Held Liable in Deaths of Foes
description: Two allies of Ferdinand Marcos, the former Philippine President, were found liable in a civil lawsuit today in the killings of two opponents of the Marcos Government who were gunned down in 1981.

title: Corrections
description: A listing in Weekend yesterday about holiday activities for the birthday of Martin Luther King Jr. misstated the day for a video program at the New York Society for Ethical Culture, 2 West 64th Street. It is 11 A.M. to 1 P.M. tomorrow, not today.

title: Patents;   Using Special Viruses To Fight Tooth Decay
description: Alan H. Norris, a chemical engineer in Rome, Ga., has patented a method for fighting tooth decay using customized viruses.

title: Schembechler Scolded
description: James E. Delany, the commissioner of the Big Ten Conference, yesterday publicly reprimanded Bo Schembechler, the former football coach at Michigan, for comments ''unduly critical of a game official'' made after the Wolverines' 17-10 loss to Southern California in the Rose Bowl on New Year's Day.

title: Kay Jewelers
description: Kay Jewelers Inc. said that as a result of recent inquiries from third parties about a possible acquisition of the company, it had decided to retain an investment banking firm to advise the board of directors about its alternatives. No negotiations are in progress, and no agreements have been reached with any party concerning a transaction, the jewelry-chain owner said. Kay's stock jumped $2 a share today, to $15.875.

title: Wilding Is a Crime, Except in Law
description: Whatever else needs to be done in New York City, we must maintain law and order. No constructive social program can work if we descend into chaos.

title: Retrieved Craft Tested Stealth Materials
description: One of the science experiments on the satellite retrieved yesterday by the space shuttle Columbia is a secret military effort to make ''Stealth'' satellites that are difficult to track by radar.

title: Clayton Homes Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Premier Resources Ltd. reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-Net income and included an extraordinary credit of $668,000, or 12 cents a share. The 1988 income included a gain of $2,778,000 from the sale of a significant Canadian partnership interest.

title: Delchamps Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 30
description: b-Net loss

title: CHRONICLE
description: NICOLA RESCIGNO waves his baton over the Dallas Opera for the last time tomorrow. Mr. Rescigno has resigned, effective after tomorrow's matinee, as artistic director and principal conductor, positions he has held since 1957 when he co-founded the company with Lawrence V. Kelly.

title: As 2 Soviet Teammates Battle, Devils Sit Back and Smile
description: A rivalry that could benefit the Devils immensely is developing between Vyacheslav Fetisov and Aleksei Kasatonov.

title: Cost-Reduction Steps Are Begun by G.M.
description: The General Motors Corporation said today that it was beginning a new round of cost-cutting measures, including voluntary separation packages for salaried employees, in the face of depressed revenue and profits from the North American car market.

title: Kaufman & Broad Home reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Year-ago quarter and prior year results restated to include the consolidated results of the company's mortgage banking subsidiaries in compliance with SFAS No. 94.

title: CHRONICLE
description: After eight months of campaigning and three post-election vacations, RUDOLPH W. GIULIANI is back at his desk at White & Case, the Manhattan law firm where he is a partner. The question is: for how long?

title: Rochester Slaying Suspect Is Called Kind but Violent
description: For Christmas, Arthur Shawcross gave one female friend a new coffee maker, and another a set of steak knives. He baked pies and cookies. And between the 15th and 26th of December, the police say, he killed three prostitutes, the last of 11 women he is accused of slaying since March 1988.

title: Upheaval in the East: Caucasus;   Irate Azerbaijanis Seize Radio Station
description: Azerbaijanis blockaded government offices and seized a radio station in a Caspian Sea port, and Georgians demanding independence drove bureaucrats from their offices in the Caucasus, according to reports in Moscow today The turmoil coincided with a visit to Lithuania by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, who is trying to counter an independence drive in that Baltic republic.

title: Review/Film;   A Preppy Policeman Cast Into the Inner City
description: The Beach Boys and several rap groups slug it out for supremacy in ''Downtown,'' a film that contrasts the cushy working conditions enjoyed by policemen along Philadelphia's Main Line (computer-equipped offices, freshly ground coffee beans) with those endured by their inner city counterparts (shootouts in the office practically every day). Emphasizing this clash of cultures, ''Downtown'' may be the only film in which a white, preppy policeman (Anthony Edwards) has taught the kids of a black downtown cop (Forest Whitaker) how to surf.

title: When the Playwright's the President, Now That's Really a Premiere
description: Czechoslovakia's most prominent playwright, President Vaclav Havel, was finally able this week to see the Prague premiere of a play he wrote 16 years ago. So were a few lucky members of the public, which packed the tiny Cinoherni theater off Wenceslas Square for four performances of ''Audience'' this week.

title: Stanley Wilson Jailed
description: Stanley Wilson, the Cincinnati Bengals running back who was banned from the National Football League for using cocaine the night before the Super Bowl last year, was arrested yesterday in Gardena, Calif., for possession of drug paraphernalia, the police said. Wilson missed the 1985 and 1987 N.F.L. seasons because of suspensions for violations of the league's substance-abuse policy.

title: Another Jet Candidate
description: Vince Tobin, the Chicago Bears' defensive coordinator, was interviewed by Dick Steinberg, the Jets' general manager, last night in San Francisco.

title: Walter J. Brownstone, Executive, 89
description: Walter J. Brownstone, the former president of a chain of clothing stores, died Thursday at his home in Manhattan after a long illness. He was 89 years old.

title: International Electronics Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Nets' Brundy Suspended For Drug Use
description: Stanley Brundy, a seldom-used rookie forward with the Nets, has been suspended for the rest of the National Basketball Association season for failing a random drug test.

title: The U.S. and Panama;   In Tiff Over a Tie, Noriega Is Told: Come as You Are
description: The secret courtroom deliberations in the case of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega are not limited to sensitive matters like national security. There is also the question of what to wear.

title: Leonard Hutton, 87, A Dealer in Works By German Artists
description: Leonard Hutton, an art dealer specializing in German Expressionist and Russian avant-garde works, died of a heart attack Thursday at his home in Manhattan. He was 87 years old. He also had a home in Southampton, L.I.

title: Don't Forget World War II Rumanian Ferocity

Software Services of America Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30

description: The company said latest quarter and 9 months figures included income before taxes of $1,628,000 from liquidation of LIFO inventories. Year-ago quarter and 9 months results included income before taxes of $778,000 from LIFO liquidation.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Everything went just the way we wanted it to.'' - Capt.

title: McMartin Jurors Ask About a Split Verdict
description: Jurors in a preschool molestation trial here asked the judge today if they could convict one defendant while acquitting the other of a shared conspiracy charge.

title: Price Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 24
description: Latest quarter represents 16 weeks.

title: Bankruptcy: Some Hard Calculations
description: A decision to file for bankruptcy requires a difficult trade-off: a company gains time, but loses autonomy.

title: Rumania Bars Communists
description: Bowing to demands of thousands of irate demonstrators, leaders of Rumania's governing Council of National Salvation agreed to outlaw the Communist Party. Page 7.

title: Hong Kong Calls China Talks Useful but Sees No Progress
description: The Governor of Hong Kong said today that his three days of talks with Chinese officials had been useful, but neither side reported major progress in easing tensions between Hong Kong and Beijing.

title: Senate Suggests Arts Grant-Making Panelists
description: The way has been cleared in the Senate for the appointment of members of a Presidential commission that will review the grant-making procedures of the National Endowment for the Arts.

title: Selfix Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Poles Protest Price Increases
description: A group of young anti-Government protesters broke a window of the National Assembly today and set a fire at Communist Party headquarters to protest recent price increases. Calling themselves the Intercity Anarchists, the group of about 200 marched to the National Assembly, where the Senate was in session. They shouted: ''We have had enough of price rises!'' and ''Soups for Kuron!'' a reference to Labor Minister Jacek Kuron, who has established soup kitchens for the poor.

title: Upheaval in the East: The Baltics;   Nationalists in Vilnius Turn Down Soviet Call for New Secession Law
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev implored Lithuanians today to remain within the Soviet Union, warning that secession would mean economic calamity for this tiny republic, while weakening Soviet security and endangering his own position and program.

title: Air France Buying Into 2 Carriers
description: In a move likely to trouble the European Community's antitrust regulators, Air France announced today that it would acquire control of two French airlines: Air Inter, the large French domestic airline, and Union de Transports Aeriens, a long-haul carrier.

title: Upheaval in the East;   Kissinger Predicts Baltic Split
description: Henry A. Kissinger, the former Secretary of State, said today that the Baltic republics would secede from the Soviet Union despite appeals by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. ''If he has really forsworn the use of force, then he probably cannot control events and then I think the Baltic states will break away,'' he told the BBC.

title: Obsession in Boston: Mystery of Couple's Deaths
description: The story of Charles and Carol Stuart has become an obsession here, from the drawing rooms of Back Bay to the bar stools of Revere, the working-class suburb where Mr. Stuart grew up.

title: Upheaval in the East: Buying Time in Lithuania;   His Choices Severely Limited, Gorbachev Is Forced to Sell the Virtues of Federation
description: Barnstorming across Lithuania this week, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has undertaken the most desperate diplomatic endeavor of his career: a campaign to preserve the integrity of the Soviet Union by personal persuasion.

title: Review/Film;   Meanwhile, Pops Is Back At the Lodge
description: Beware of movies that feature sweet old men named Pops. If the writers can't do any better on a name, what can you expect from the rest? ''Ski Patrol'' has a Pops - Ray Walston, in about five brief scenes, as the owner of a resort - and sure enough, it turns out to be a perfect example of the nothing-is-too-obvious school of comedy. When the bad-guy ski instructors try to sabotage the good-guy ski patrollers in order to make poor old Pops lose his lodge, we get: the scene where mice are turned loose in a crowded room; the scene where a man on a skimobile crashes into a women's restroom; the scene where the ski patrollers win a talent contest with the world's worst imitation of Mick Jagger and Tina Turner. There are many more scenes, but not one smile, never mind a laugh.

title: Upheaval in the East: Rumania;   Rumanian Leaders Outlaw Ousted Communist Party
description: Bowing to demands of thousands of irate demonstrators, leaders of Rumania's governing Council of National Salvation agreed tonight to outlaw the Communist Party and to hold a national referendum on restoring the death penalty.

title: Pentagon Imposes a Hiring Freeze That Could Eliminate 50,000 Jobs
description: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney announced today that he had imposed a freeze on civilian hiring through Oct. 1, a move that Pentagon officials said would probably eliminate more than 50,000 jobs from a work force of 1.05 million civilians.

title: Ford Selling Aerospace Unit As Military Spending Slows
description: Facing a slowdown in military spending and continued retrenchment in the auto business, the Ford Motor Company has said it will sell its Ford Aerospace subsidiary.

title: Dinkins Seeks Albany's Help In Cordial Talk
description: Despite the friction that usually smolders between state and city governments in times of fiscal gloom, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and Mayor David N. Dinkins began their first budget dance today with a bow of studied cordiality.

title: City Penalized for Not Fixing Police Radios
description: A judge placed the financially troubled city of East St. Louis on one year's probation today for potentially endangering its police officers.

title: Upheaval in the East: Arms Control;   U.S. May Revise Its Position On Concealing Missile Data
description: As the Bush Administration moves toward completion of a strategic arms treaty with the Soviet Union, officials have been struggling to refine a longstanding and seemingly simple American proposal for unfettered access to data on missile tests.

title: Upheaval in the East;   Czechoslovaks Pursue Diplomatic Initiatives
description: Czechoslovakia's new coalition Government is energetically exploring new avenues in foreign relations in Eastern and Western Europe and farther afield.

title: Tele-Metropole reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 26
description: Figures for 1988 were restated. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Bronx Principal Named in Cover-Up Is Suspended
description: A Bronx principal was suspended yesterday, one day after an investigative commission accused him of hiring a teacher with an arrest record and covering up allegations that the teacher had sexually molested two students.

description: The first time the lowly Quebec Nordiques visited the Islanders this season, on Nov. 9, the announced attendance at Nassau Coliseum was 10,307. That included a walk-up sale of 390 tickets on the day of the game, recalled Jim Johnson, director of sales.

description: A day after he said no, no, he was not a candidate for Congress, Wendell Foster, a City Councilman from the Bronx, said yesterday that yes, yes, he is a candidate.

description: For almost two years, the police in this small town in the Chagrin River Valley watched Jeffrey Lundgren.

description: Each year, thousands of Americans are baffled by the ever-more complicated electronic devices they receive as holiday presents or are tempted to buy at sales. Service centers say they are flooded with calls from customers who cannot set up or operate their gifts or purchases.

title: Parole Board Under Scrutiny In Murder Suspect's Release
description: The State Parole Board decision to release Arthur Shawcross from prison in April 1987 has been sharply criticized after his arrest in the murders of 11 women here over the last 21 months.

title: Corrections

description: Stock prices tumbled yesterday amid new concerns about higher interest rates and a resurgence of inflation. The drop followed declines in other important stock markets around the world.

Analysts Are Cautious On Effort by Campeau
description: The move by the Campeau Corporation on Thursday to establish independence for its troubled American retail operations failed to generate confidence among financial analysts but gave new support to the managers of the Campeau stores.
