description: Some weeks ago, a big fellow in a Times Square saloon had presented himself as the best pinball player in the world. ''The Joe Montana of the Silver Ball'' was a phrase that kept careening around one columnist's gray matter. Probably just another barroom braggart, but still . . .

As Market Struggles, So Do Some Co-op Buildings
description: At least 88 residential cooperatives with nearly 9,000 apartments in the New York City area are facing severe financial difficulties. And the number of such co-ops is growing, causing concern among owners and in the State Attorney General's office, which monitors co-op conversions.

title: Hurricane Relief Is Said to Skip Many Poor
description: Thousands of rural poor people have been bypassed by relief efforts since Hurricane Hugo smashed into the coast, nearly four months ago, community leaders say.

description: The market for stretch limousines - the new-money status symbols of the 1980's - is shrinking.

title: Applying for State Grants
description: Seminars to assist cultural organizations and individuals in obtaining grants from the New York State Council on the Arts are to be held on Tuesday and Thursday at the offices of the Arts Council, 915 Broadway, at 21st Street. The Tuesday seminar is to be open to new applicants; the Thursday session is for previous applicants. Both will be held from 6 to 9 P.M. Information: 614-2905.

title: Four Are Accused of Trying to Buy Antiaircraft Missile for the I.R.A.
description: Four people believed to be members of the Irish Republican Army were arrested today while trying to buy an antiaircraft missile and other weapons from undercover agents, the Government announced.

description: Government and opposition representatives reached an agreement today aimed at defusing ethnic tension between Bulgarians and Muslims.

title: Campus Life: Evergreen State;   School Seeks Minority Voices In Its Classrooms
description: Evergreen State College has announced a new admissions policy that it hopes will increase the number of minority and handicapped students at the school, as well as add more diversity to its classrooms.

title: Tiny Oasis Braces for Influx of Wealthy
description: LEAD: HOUSES going up on land long untouched is a fact of life on the East End. While the development of each new piece means the loss of farmland and woods and attractive open space, it also can mean increased tax revenues and more employment.

title: Beth Posnack to Wed Robert M. Hecht
description: Mr. and Mrs. Stanley Posnack of Airmont, N.Y., have made known the engagement of their daughter Beth Allyson Posnack to Robert Morris Hecht, a son of Mr. and Mrs. David M. Hecht of Grand Rapids, Mich., and Vail, Colo. The couple plan to marry in May.

title:
GARDENING;

Avoiding the Damage of Winter's Snow
description: LEAD: THIS has been a winter of extremes. December was exceptionally cold, while early January turned out quite warm. There has been both ice and snow though neither has been especially severe. But asmidwinter approaches, it is not unreasonable to expect at least one major storm that will result in damage to plantings.

title: FASHION: European Report -- Paris;   Lurching Into the 90's
description: In fact, the Saint Laurent Rive Gauche collection, the final showing during a week of presentations last October for spring and summer 1990, was not only a strange, strong statement but also a compendium of the current state of fashion in general. One must always remember that Paris is the font of most fashion directions for the rest of the world. So what happens there ultimately affects the looks seen around the globe.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Our sliding glass doors are difficult to slide. We have vacuumed the tracks and sprayed with a silicone lubricant, but this helps only temporarily. Any suggestions?

title: L.L. BEAN PRESENTS 'THE SHOES OF THE FISHERMAN'?
description: When I first heard that Whittle Communications would publish books that carry advertising, I was aghast! We book publishers have always boasted that of all the media we alone have not been corrupted by the advertising dollar. We swim or sink on the quality of our editorial product, not on the trendy whims of Philip Morris or Procter & Gamble. But with many wise people now saying our book sales are in the doldrums, I'm not so sure we can afford to stay so snooty.

title:
Outdoors;

Hybrids Rattled Food Chain
description: LEAD: Every August from 1983 through 1988, the New York State Department of Environmental Conservation stocked 8,600 white rock bass in Swinging Bridge Reservoir. The nine-mile-long reservoir is the largest of three power-generating reservoirs operated by Orange and Rockland Utilities on the Mongaup River in south-central Sullivan County.

title: China Seeks Respectability, But Painlessly
description: DENG XIAOPING is gambling again. The 85-year-old Chinese leader, who has proved an astute political oddsmaker, is betting that by ending martial law Beijing will reap economic and diplomatic benefits without risking further unrest.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Providence, R.I.;

Converting A Historic Site
description: LEAD: TWO 19th-century houses - the 1825 Lewis House and the 1886 Weeks House - and three factory buildings have been renovated for professional offices and retail operations in the Jewelry District, an industrial area of this capital city.

title: QUESTION OF THE WEEK: Next Week;   Was the Bet By Jackson And Barkley Improper?
description: The Times welcomes letters from readers. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. Letters should be addressed to The Editor, Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: Joseph Pepe Engaged To Francine Kravetz
description: The engagement of Francine Amy Kravetz to Joseph Pepe, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene N. Pepe of Bronxville, N.Y., has been made known by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Walter Kravetz of Armonk, N.Y., and Pompano Beach, Fla. An August wedding is planned. Miss Kravetz, a graduate of Boston University, is a registered representative of Merrill Lynch, Pierce, Fenner & Smith in White Plains. Her father is the director of ''The MacNeil/Lehrer Newshour.''

title: OUR ANALGESIC CULTURE
description: THE PRESENCE OF MYTH

title: Spacecraft Sees Few Traces of a Tumultuous Creation
description: First glimpses of the heavens by a new spacecraft looking for evidence of the beginning of existence have revealed an almost too perfect universe, scientists said today.

title: Oysters, a New Orleans Passion
description: DAVID ENGERT, a 39-year-old manager of a Los Angeles computer company, traveled nearly 2,000 miles to get to his native New Orleans for the holidays. One of the main reasons, he said: to eat oysters at the Acme Oyster House, on Iberville Street in the French Quarter.

title: Walking on Air
description: For his teammates on the Chicago Bulls, the Hornet contest was just another game. For Michael Jordan, Friday night's match against the Hornets was a homecoming.

title: A Piano Concerto Brings Ligeti Back To the Orchestra
description: Now that the ethnic and geographical divisions of Eastern Europe are becoming newly familiar in this season of liberation, it is less difficult than formerly to digest the identification of Gyorgy Ligeti that opens his entry in the New Grove Dictionary of Music and Musicians. Here it is, exactly as it appears there, with all the diacritical marks that Western newspapers normally omit:

title: Creaking Floors, Sleeping Children
description: THERE are not many sights more ridiculous than a 40-year-old father crawling out of a sleeping toddler's bedroom. On my knees, moving one hand at a time, I try to leave the room without making a sound. Putting a child to bed will unwind even the most assertive and confident parent.

title: Sara Orenstein and David Kober Wed
description: Sara Orenstein and David Matthew Kober were married last evening at the Pierre in New York by Rabbi Jerry Orenstein, an uncle of the bride, and Rabbi Saul Berman, an uncle of the bridegroom.

title: Should Sotheby's Be Strictly Cash and Carry?
description: ART collectors were euphoric when, less than a month after the Wall Street crash of 1987, Sotheby's sold van Gogh's ''Irises'' for $53.9 million, the highest price ever paid for a painting at auction. Then, two years later, it was revealed that the auction house had given the buyer a loan amounting to half the price of the painting and was still holding the artwork as collateral.

title: Silicon Valley Is Changing Programs
description: SILICON VALLEY, where it once seemed growth had no limits, is in the midst of a midlife crisis. Faced with fierce Japanese competition and a market for personal computers that is growing more slowly than the industry's early visionaries predicted, high technology has lost some of its luster. If boom times are to return, the valley's engineers and entrepreneurs will have to find ways to make the personal computer cheaper, more powerful and portable enough to live up to its name.

title: For the Capital Cathedral, a Slow Finishing Touch
description: Symbolism and symmetry mean a lot in this city of monuments, memorials, diplomats and politicians.

title:
IN THE REGION: Long Island;

Anchors Crucial in the Soft Retail Market
description: LEAD: ANXIETY over the economy has made retailers cautious about expansion and relocation, thus softening the retail rental market on Long Island. But developers and brokers say there is still strong demand for space in large, well-anchored shopping centers that are well located and well planned.

title: Black-Jewish Coalition Is Named as a Model
description: LEAD: ''WITH blacks and Jews there is a common thread of oppression and suffering,'' said the Rev. Vernon Shannon of the St. Catherine African Methodist Episcopal Zion Church of New Rochelle. ''Slavery was a crime upon human history and for the Jews the Holocaust was also a crime on humanity. If there are two groups of people who ought to work together it ought to be the blacks and Jews.

title: U.S. Attorney in Miami to Take No Active Role in the Noriega Trial
description: Dexter Lehtinen, the United States Attorney here, announced today that he would not take an active role in the prosecution of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, ending days of speculation over whether Bush Administration officials thought Mr. Lehtinen was qualified to handle the case.

title: A Battle for the Voters, and the 90's, Begins
description: ELECTION 1990 is hardly uppermost in the minds of American voters. Non-presidential elections are often seen as mere housekeeping for democracy, and the stunning changes in Eastern Europe have overshadowed domestic politics.

title:
New Jersey Q & A: John Cronin;

Hudson Riverkeeper, a Pollution Detective
description: LEAD: AS riverkeeper of the Hudson River, John Cronin travels by boat, or by pickup truck along the shoreline, investigating reports of industrial pollution and bringing offenders to court.

title: For the Dollar, More Weakness
description: The American dollar and the Japanese yen continued their 1990 swoon last week, as the West German mark, the Swiss franc and the Canadian dollar all gained ground. This week could be more of the same. The West German Bundesbank meets on Thursday, but analysts are not expecting the central bank to raise rates again. A rise in rates would make the mark even stronger.

title: Islanders Win 6th in Row
description: One personal streak ended but two team streaks continued tonight as the Islanders defeated the slumping Washington Capitals, 4-2, at Nassau Coliseum.

title: FICTION
description: THE BOOK OF MARVELS. By Christopher T. Leland. (Scribners, $17.95.) Lila Mae Bower Pietrowsky has been having a tough time. First there is the divorce, still a shock to a good Baptist girl, even though ''it was a miracle - an honest-to-goodness one - she'd managed to hold her marriage with Eddie together as long as she had.'' Her job as a nurse's aide at Quiet Meadows would challenge even the most Christian woman, which Lila Mae is. And then there's Wellesley Coe, an all too real man who is all too eager to get close to Lila Mae. So it's understandable that Lila Mae has organized her day to revolve around ''World of Love,'' an evangelical television program that never raises the ''larger theological questions'' that always ''gave her a headache.'' In his third novel, Christopher T. Leland strikes just the right tone. He's funny without belittling his characters, whose weaknesses are always obvious yet always well integrated with their strengths. It's no surprise when Ted and Becky Standish, the smiling ''World of Love'' couple, do a moral nose dive parallel to that of the real-life Jim and Tammy Bakker. And as she is disillusioned by her television religion, it's also no surprise that Lila Mae begins to put her life back together, deciding that maybe she was just a tad too judgmental about Wellesley Coe. This section of the novel, in fact, feels uncomfortably contrived. Mr. Leland, and his characters, are more intriguing in the seeking than in the finding.

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT/VIDEO: AND KEEP IN MIND
description: Here are some notable releases of the last few months. BATMAN - Michael Keaton, Jack Nicholson and Kim Basinger star in a ''shapeless, big-screen reincarnation'' set in a ''nightmare version of megalopolis.'' (Vincent Canby) 1989. Warner. $24.95. They have been the subject of newspaper and magazine articles around the world. They readily give interviews. They play Gershwin, Scott Joplin and pop music. So when they were engaged last year by the St. Louis Symphony to play the Mozart two-piano concerto, the conductor, Leonard Slatkin, wondered what he had on his hands.

title: County Residents Welcoming an Influx of Soviet Visitors

When she uses regular computers, she says she has to hug the screen in order to read the text. But she now uses a word-processing program that displays enlarged letters at the Adaptive Technology Laboratory at Southern Connecticut State

She thought she might have broken a rib, but when she went to the doctor he discovered that she had lung cancer that had metastasized to her breast, her pelvic bone, and possibly to her liver.

But even those who find themselves in the Big Easy after the party's over - or before it's begun - can experience Carnival. The trappings - the floats, costumes, masks and lore - are there for the viewing year round at museums and shops in the French Quarter and at Blaine Kern's Mardi Gras World, in the West Bank neighborhood of Algiers.

description: THE national touring company of Alfred Uhry's Pulitzer Prize-winning ''Driving Miss Daisy,'' which has understandably been called the Julie Harris Company for the last 15 months, is making its 28th and final stop at the Shubert in New Haven, through next Sunday, and that's all a sensible theatergoer needs to know.

title: Can Gorbachev Stay On if Lithuania Chooses to Leave?
description: MIKHAIL S. GORBACHEV has never seemed lonelier than he did last week, stumping the alienated precincts of Lithuania, pleading for the wayward republic to trust him, help him, save him, by preserving the union.

description: A PLAN to require all practicing New York State lawyers to take continuing legal education courses has met with mixed reactions from Long Island lawyers and their county bar associations.

description: The relatives and friends of Mustaq Ahmed Khan, a 22-year-old man killed this week in a skirmish between the police and Muslim militants, were filled with anger.

title: Costs of Cable: False Comparisons
description: The Dec. 17 article [''Cable TV vs. Consumers: Battleground Emerges''] included a chart titled ''The Cost of Cable,'' which compared Cablevision's Long Island rates in 1986 (before deregulation of the cable industry) and in 1989. The chart provided an incorrect and invalid comparison between basic cable service in 1986 and family service in 1989 on Long Island.

description: West German Youth Hostels

title: Broadway Stars Step Into the Breach
description: WHEN a weeklong tour of ''Stardust,'' a Broadway-bound musical portrait of the four decades from the 1920's through the 50's, at Bushnell Memorial Hall in Hartford was canceled, into the breach stepped Lucie Arnaz, Donna McKechnie and Michael Maguire, to present ''On Broadway,'' from Tuesday through next Sunday. The show is being billed as a ''theatrical concert.'' Ms. Arnaz's part of the program is a salute to Irving Berlin; Ms. McKechnie will reprise some of the songs she introduced in ''A Chorus Line,'' and Mr. Maguire, a 1987 Tony Award winner for his performance in ''Les Miserables,'' will sing the tunes of leading men of the Great White Way.

title: Programs Combating Increase In Illiteracy
description: LEAD: A STEADY increase in the adult illiteracy rate in New Jersey is causing alarm among government and education officials and corporate managers. But legislators, educators and business leaders have begun to combat the problem.

title: THE $20 MILLION SECRET
description: LEAD:

title: 'Every Night Was an Opening Night'
description: ''It wasn't just one opening night,'' Agnes de Mille explained recently, recalling the debut of American Ballet Theater a half-century ago. ''During that first season, almost every night was an opening night. They had ballets by Fokine, Mordkin and Adolph Bolm. They had premieres by Tudor and Eugene Loring. There was a small but enthusiastic audience. Lucia Chase lost a lot of money. At the end, everything went into storage. They were hoping they'd have the money for the next year's rent.''

title: Meg Jacobs Plans To Wed in March
description: Margaret Louise Jacobs, an associate of the Washington law firm of Arnold & Porter, and Samuel Allan Flax, a partner in the firm, plan to marry in March. Ms. Jacobs, known as Meg, is the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph K. Jacobs of Nashville. Mr. Flax is a son of Mrs. Louis Flax of Rockville, Md., and Helena, Mont., and the late Mr. Flax.

title: NONFICTION
description: TRACKINGS: Composers Speak With Richard Dufallo. By Richard Dufallo. (Oxford University, $35.) No one should require more of this book of splendid interviews. Still, how wonderful it would be if Richard Dufallo's ''Trackings'' rekindled the old passions and rancor surrounding 20th-century music before the composers and their scores fade into the next century. The interviews are with 26 men who explain what they have tried to do in their work since World War II. They talk and talk about how and why they tried to shift harmonies, rhythms, orchestration and scoring away from 19th-century traditions. Their talk is technical, as if they were speaking with a peer, which Mr. Dufallo, a conductor, indeed is. What they describe is fascinating, from new types of scoring to electronically synthesized music to stealing themes from other composers. A revealing anecdote comes from John Cage about a concert in the Netherlands at which several musicians preferred to drink too much and leave the hall rather than perform what he wanted. George Rochberg asks a telling question: ''Can we compose again with passion? That's what I miss in almost everything that's written these days.'' Suddenly, the avant-garde is old. Mr. Cage, the former enfant terrible, is 77 years old; Aaron Copland is 89. They all stuck to their creative guns without much carping about public indifference. I wonder, though, how these distinguished men, accused of writing awful music in their time, feel about the fame and fortunes earned by the cacophonous sounds of rock-and-roll. That is the only question Mr. Dufallo failed to ask.

title: ALL ABOUT/Minivans;   Zippy Hybrids Win a Place in the Family Driveway
description: For sheer inventiveness, there is little in the automotive world to rival theVoyager III, the Chrysler Corporation's vision of the ultimate minivan. As a whole, it resembles a bulbous, stretched-out van. It has two engines and four rear wheels. With the flip of a few switches and levers - voila! - the van separates into two parts: a three-seat urban commuter car and a rear module that can be parked until needed. Chrysler suggests the rear module might be used for camping or carrying passengers.

title: HER FRIENDS WERE EVERYTHING
description: BECOMING A POET

title: New Running Game
description: Some politicians learn the intricacies of politics by studying political science, others by working in political campaigns. Dave Cowens is learning the hard way.

title: First Lady Ends Treatment
description: Barbara Bush underwent the last of 10 radiation treatments at Walter Reed Army Medical Center Friday for an eye affliction that has impaired her vision. Doctors say they will not know for at least two months whether the radiation was effective on Graves' disease, an immune system disorder that had affected Mrs. Bush's thyroid as well, said Anna Perez, the First Lady's press secretary.

title: 11 Wounded in Gaza Clashes
description: Israeli troops shot and wounded 11 protesters today in scattered clashes in the Gaza Strip, hospital officials said. Two Palestinians in the area were killed by fellow Arabs, but it was unclear whether those attacks were related to nationalist politics. The officials said that a 54-year-old man was stabbed to death today in Gaza City, but residents said he was not known as a collaborator with the Israeli authorities.

title: A FEW WORDS FROM JENNY HOLZER
description: Jenny Holzer's concoctions are interesting - but no more so than the thoughts Arsenio Hall occasionally passes on to his audience to make them go, ''Hmmmm.'' At least Mr. Hall has taste enough not to pass off his random thoughts as art.

title: 'Tara! Tara! Tara!'
description: To the Editor:

title: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST: Intelligence;   Kremlin Watchers Cope With Data Glut
description: After 40 years of foraging for bits of data on the Soviet Union and its allies, American intelligence analysts are struggling to cope with a cascade of information, including Kremlin statistical reports, periodicals and word-of-mouth from foreign business travelers and military officers who can visit once-forbidden reaches.

title: Karen S. Temes, Nurse, to Marry
description: Karen Sue Temes, a nurse in neonatal intensive care at Brigham and Women's Hospital in Boston, and Dr. Lewis Milrod, a fellow in behavioral neurology at Children's Hospital there, plan to marry in May. The engagement was announced by her parents, Dr. Lloyd Temes and Dr. Roberta Temes, both of Manhattan Beach, Brooklyn.

title: JERSEYANA
description: LEAD: IF you think your line of work is tough, consider Ira L. Reeves, whose job it was to keep New Jerseyans sober. Sisyphus, move over.

title:
IN SHORT;

FICTION
description: LEAD:

title: Lifestyle: Sunday Lunch;   Hearty Soups to Warm Wintry Days
description: There is no better antifreeze on a frigid winter day than a lusty bowl of soup. Good soup is not that easy to find. Many restaurants consider it something they have to offer on their appetizer lists, but they don't really put extra effort into it.

title: Seize The Decade
description: TWO weeks into the 90's and I'm still writing 80-something on my checks. At least the prognosticators have stopped trying to name the decade and wandered off in search of hemline lengths or women who love men who love themselves too much.

title: What Top Performers Bet On
description: Their bets paid off and they came out ahead in 1989. So what are last year's top-performing mutual fund managers thinking about now? The front page. The ''renaissance of capitalism sweeping around the world'' makes David D. Alger think corporate price/earnings ratios will rise for well-managed American companies. He believes top performers will be classical growth stocks of companies with solid balance sheets, like Toys ''R'' Us and Pepsico.

title: PEAK EXPERIENCE
description: A crescent moon resting on a Pakistani mountain peak; a red dawn rising over the Serengeti Plains where young lions play; a rainbow caressing the rooftops of a Tibetan palace; a bear cub resting against its mother near Alaska's McNeil River - these wondrous images and more can be found in magnificent color in THE ART OF ADVENTURE (Collins Publishers, $45), a breathtaking pictorial essay by Galen Rowell. In 1972, Mr. Rowell sold his small automotive business in California and took off with camera in hand on an odyssey that would take him in search of adventure around the world. He traversed Pakistan's Karakoram Mountains, a 285-mile trek across uninhabitable highlands, where the temperature dropped to 25 below. On a one-day climb of Mount McKinley in Alaska, he slipped and fell toward an ice cliff that plunged 3,000 feet, before being rescued by a teammate. During an expedition to the top of Fitz Roy, an Argentine peak known for its vicious weather, Mr. Rowell's team, forced by darkness to spend the night trapped on an icy ledge a few hundred feet from the top, jogged in place to keep warm while waiting for dawn. Mr. Rowell's photograph of the Fitz Roy range - sheer granite towers draped in ice reaching up into an indigo sky brushed in a light that looks like molten gold - is one of the more spectacular in the book. The beauty of ''The Art of Adventure'' is not so much in the photographs but in the words that relay to us the courage and sheer joy the author gets from his experiences. Mr. Rowell lets us know that adventure is not in the dreaming but in the doing.

title: Who's Left, Who's Right in Post-Wall Europe?
description: To the Editor:

title: Strickland's Spurt Rescues Knicks
description: Trade Rod Strickland, keep Mark Jackson. Trade Jackson and keep Strickland. That kind of talk has surfaced time and again ever since the Knicks began to team the talented playmakers, their 1987 and 1988 first-round draft choices.

title: If You're Thinking of Living in: Bernardsville
description: LONG before the dawn of civilization the area that is now Bernardsville was a meeting ground. There, New Jersey's two major rock formations - the red shale of southern New Jersey and the Precambrian gneiss of the north - meet, in the same area where the Great Wisconsin Glacier halted at the foot of the Watchung Mountains.

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: KING OBSERVANCES

title: DATA UPDATE: January 14, 1990
description: *4*BUILDING PERMITS ISSUED (Housing units) Nov. 89 Oct. 89 Nov. 88 New York 2,856 4,530 3,473 New Jersey 2,411 2,683 2,751 Connecticut 835 1,270 1,241 (Source: Census Bureau, U.S. Department of Commerce) *2*MORTGAGE INTEREST RATES (Averages) Last Week Previous Week Year Ago New York Conventional (30-yr) 10.09 10.05 11.12 Adjustable Rate (1st yr) 8.58 8.55 8.62 New Jersey Conventional (30-yr) 9.89 9.87 10.90 Adjustable Rate (1st yr) 8.36 8.38 8.48 Connecticut Conventional (30-yr) 10.00 9.96 11.01 Adjustable Rate (1st yr) 8.53 8.48 8.92 Co-ops (N.Y.) Treasury security 7.82 7.80 9.17 National Mortgage Contract Rate 9.80 9.80 9.16

title: Mosaic Metaphor Serves Many Masters
description: To the Editor:

title: Say 'Hair Deprived'
description: To the Editor:

title: 10 Die in Pakistani Bus Crash
description: Two buses collided head on today, killing 10 people and seriously injuring 5, Pakistan's official press agency said. The accident occurred 60 miles east of Islamabad, The Associated Press of Pakistan said. Officials said the two buses had been speeding.

title: CAN OPERA SURVIVE FRIENDS LIKE THIS?
description: How comforting to know in a turbulent world that one of Western culture's most venerable traditions survives: the visionary interview granted by the freshly anointed artistic director upon taking office. The organization changing pilots may be as formidable and unwieldy as a major opera company or as marginal as an amateur chamber orchestra. It may be heavily subsidized by governments and corporations or may exist at the whim of a well-off patron or two. No matter. Change a word here or there and the new director's inaugural manifesto will be interchangeable with that of the previous anointee and the previous one and the previous one.

title: Bronx Arts Museum Loses One Gallery but Gets Another
description: THE Bronx Museum of the Arts lost a satellite when the gallery at Krasdale Foods headquarters recently moved into the orbit of The Lehman College Art Gallery. But the museum has since gained one at the Jewish Home and Hospital for Aged. That institution, at 100 West Kingsbridge Road, is the complex of buildings filling the block bounded by Kingsbridge and West 190th Street on the short sides and Webb and University Avenues on the long.

title: Blurred and Shaky Images That Burn in the Mind
description: While the photography world was busy congratulating itself last year on the 150th anniversary of the medium, and while photojournalism was being recognized as an art in several touring museum exhibitions, the public territory of still photography was quietly eroding. World events, which still photography has long memorialized, rushed by so rapidly at decade's end that cameras seemed for once unable to keep up.

title: Ivy League Holds Its Own
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Correction
description: A report in the Travel Advisory column on Dec. 10 about sesquicentennial events in New Zealand misidentified the capital. It is Wellington.

title:
MUSIC;

Pianist Finds Own Mold
description: LEAD: GARRICK OHLSSON is a pianist who does not want to be typecast as a specialist in the music of any particular composer. He is equally at home with the works of Chopin and of Charles Wuorinen. He has won awards for his recordings of Carl Maria von Weber, and he performs Beethoven often.

title: Terri L. Newman, Lawyer, Engaged
description: The engagement of Terri Lynn Newman to Steven David Bleiberg, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence J. Bleiberg of Greenwich, Conn., and Sarasota, Fla., has been made known by her parents, Dr. and Mrs. Nathan A. Newman of Lloyd Harbor, L.I. A March wedding is planned.

title: Review/Music;   Violinist in New York Debut Recital
description: The program the young violinist Yuri Vodovoz presented in his New York debut recital at Merkin Concert Hall on Thursday evening was clearly intended to make a statement, demonstrating the breadth of his musical interests and the stylistic versatility of his playing. Admirably, Mr. Vodovoz - who was born in Odessa, immigrated to this country in 1978 and lives in Chicago - ranged widely before intermission, flanking Beethoven's Sonata in A minor for Piano and Violin (Op. 23) with American works, Henry Cowell's Neo-Baroque Suite for Violin and Piano (1924) and Ellen Taaffe Zwilich's more squarely modern Sonata in Three Movements (1974).

title: Lisa Kerr Grimmelmann Is Affianced
description: Mr. and Mrs. Ihler F. Grimmelmann of Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Lisa Kerr Grimmelmann to Dr. Miles Oakley Bidwell Jr., the son of M. Oakley Bidwell of Nassau, the Bahamas, and the late Frances J. Mott. A June wedding is planned.

title: Short Stories Featured In Series of Readings
description: Stories by Virginia Woolf, Bernard Malamud and Italo Calvino will be read at the opening of the sixth season of ''Selected Shorts: A Celebration of the Short Story,'' on Jan. 24 at 6:30 P.M. at Symphony Space, Broadway and 95th Street. The actors Irene Worth, David Margulies and John Shea will read from Malamud's ''Idiots First,'' Woolf's ''Duchess and the Jeweler'' and Calvino's ''Adventure of a Reader.''

title: In Name Only?
description: The Cleveland Browns know they want to beat the Denver Broncos today when the two teams meet to decide the American Football Conference championship. Cleveland Brown isn't so sure. That's because Brown, a public transportation worker who lives in Littleton, Colo., just outside Denver, cannot decide whether to pull for the team he has rooted for since moving to Colorado four years ago or the team that bears his 55-year-old name.

title: The Stakes Are Rising in Poland's Gamble
description: BEFORE a bold new economic program took effect on New Year's Day, Poles were unequivocally enthusiastic about its goals: to make their nation the first in Eastern Europe to trade in Communism for capitalism and to help turn Poland into a prosperous Western country.

title:
EXECUTIVE LIFE;

Business Stars Wary Of Paparrazzi, Too
description: LEAD: Time was when the paparazzi were satisfied with movie stars, socialites and rock musicians. But with the tireless celebration of business during the Reagan years, chief executives have become as shutter-conscious as any Hollywood starlet. And today, many of them are managing their public images with the kind of fervor previously reserved for social climbing or corporate gamesmanship.

title: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST: Rumania;   Government in Bucharest Curbs Protests
description: Amid indications that its authority is in danger of collapsing, Rumania's provisional Government restricted political demonstrations today and decided that its executive board would meet daily rather than sporadically.

title: THE FEMININE MYSTIC
description: RADICAL SPIRITS

title: To Get Ahead, Consider a Coach
description: A few years ago Alix Kane, then a self-described ''lowly peon'' in the Guardian Life Insurance Company of America's human resources department, was charged with helping to set up a training program. She and her boss asked Roger Flax, a behavior coach, to hold seminars on behavioral change.

title: In Giving to Neediest, Many Really Mean the Homeless
description: ''Every year I 'meant' to send a check, but. . . . This year, seeing so many homeless on the streets, I realized it was time,'' Barbara Dixon of Manhattan wrote in a note she sent with her $100 donation to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: A Magazine for the Environment
description: LEAD: CONVINCED that the 1990's will be the Decade of the Environment, Doug Moss of Westport and a small staff have begun a nonprofit magazine, E, ''to deal with all sides'' of the environmental spectrum.

title: More Trouble With Oiled Waters
description: Exxon is not having a good year. Nor is the environment. Last March brought the Valdez oil spill. On Christmas Eve, an Exxon refinery in Baton Rouge exploded. And on New Year's Day, 500,000 gallons of heating oil burst through a ruptured pipe into Arthur Kill, a 13-mile stretch of water off Staten Island that is a vital breeding ground for herons and egrets. Oil and the environment don't mix. Why can't Exxon keep them better separated?

title: New in the Business Section
description: New information for investors in everything from certificates of deposits to mutual funds and foreign stocks is available on Sundays in The New York Times beginning today.

title: Christina Maloney (Bachrach) Christina Codo Wed in Florida
description: The marriage of Christina Codo, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Norman F. Codo of Hinsdale, Ill., and Boca Raton, Fla., to Patrick Joseph Maloney, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Patrick J. Maloney of Elizabeth, N.J., took place yesterday at the Boca Raton Hotel and Club. Judge Thomas E. Sholts of the 15th Judicial Circuit in West Palm Beach, Fla., officiated.

title: LEARNING TO TAKE CALIFORNIA SERIOUSLY
description: It is not true that there was no California architecture before Esther McCoy. But there was almost no writing about it, and that made all the difference, since before Esther McCoy began her career as an architectural historian almost no one took California seriously as a place where great buildings could be made. Esther McCoy discovered a California that was not just freeways and oranges but the place where the American dream fused more naturally, and more intensely, with the 20th-century's language of modernism than it did anywhere else. And she wrote about this combination, and about the architects who made it happen, with such dogged determination that her work gave birth to an entire realm of architectural history.

title: Coming to Justice?
description: Ian Fleming could have written the plot. In September 1978, Georgi I. Markov, an exiled Bulgarian writer and critic of the Communist regime, was standing at a bus stop in London when he was jabbed in the leg with an umbrella. Four days later, he was dead, from poison apparently injected by the umbrella tip. His widow, Annabel Markov, and Western diplomats were convinced that he had been killed by agents of Todor I. Zhivkov, the hard-line Communist leader, because of Mr. Markov's writings and radio broadcasts to Bulgaria. But the Bulgarians never looked into the killing. Then, in November, Mr. Zhivkov was ousted. Last week, Mrs. Markov met with Alexander Lilov, a new member of the Bulgarian Politburo, who promised a full inquiry into Mr. Markov's death. Mr. Markov has also been reinstated posthumously in the Bulgarian Writers Union, so his works can be openly sold in Bulgaria. ''I have always believed evil does not go unpunished,'' Mrs. Markov said. ''There is real hope now that my husband's killer may be tracked down. It is very important for Bulgaria that it be settled so this kind of thing cannot happen again.''

title: After Rumania, Chinese Reproach Themselves
description: The success of the popular rebellion in Rumania seems to have accentuated the mood of self-reproach in the capital. Young Chinese intellectuals wonder aloud why the Rumanians persevered, even in the face of gunfire, to overthrow the Government, while last June the Chinese protesters eventually retreated after being bloodily put down.

title: FICTION
description: SELF-PORTRAIT OF SOMEONE ELSE. By Vincent Eaton. (Viking, $16.95.) Vincent Eaton's dark, angry and intense first novel uses police documents, psychological evaluations, interviews, straight narration and interior monologues to chronicle the self-destruction of Tim Buckles. At 28, Buckles appears at first to be leading a normal life. He has a steady job as a lifeguard, a bungalow in Los Angeles and a loving girlfriend named Alisa. The problem is, he feels as if he's living someone else's life. When Alisa becomes pregnant, she encourages him to take a job in her father's business. Tim's feelings of alienation escalate. A drowning and then a disastrous visit to his elderly parents, who have become more miserable with the years, push Tim over the edge. In sparse prose, Mr. Eaton leads us through a series of violent events, many of which take place inside Tim's mind. In the most powerful sections of the book, Tim pretends he is a healthy and productive individual, telling everyone exactly what they want to hear. At the same time, both Tim and the reader realize that he is descending into madness. Mr. Eaton is not subtle. He immerses us in Freudian nightmares and is not afraid to twist psychoanalytic cliches into graphically detailed scenes, such as the lurid one in which a son takes the ultimate revenge on an unloving father. In ''Self-Portrait of Someone Else,'' Mr. Eaton concocts a puzzle out of a depraved childhood, a retarded twin brother, multiple murder mysteries, flashbacks, hallucinations, a love story and self-analysis. The pieces all come together in a brave literary debut about an intelligent man who, struggling to understand and control his rage at his past, ''realizes himself away.''

title: A FEW WORDS FROM JENNY HOLZER
description: Regarding Grace Glueck's article ''And Now, a Few Words From Jenny Holzer'' (Dec. 3), I would like to draw attention to a use of words in art before this century. In an engraving titled ''Laocoon'' (circa 1820), the artist and visionary poet William Blake crowds aphorisms pertaining to art, Christianity, Classicism and economics around a central image of the famous Hellenistic sculpture. These pithy sayings are directed at Blake's enemies in London's Royal Academy and reveal his pejorative view of Classicism. Blake's statement ''Where any view of Money exists Art cannot be carried on, but War only'' is so timeless that it could flash beside Holzer's ''MONEY CREATES TASTE.''

title: 2 Deaths Are Reported In Strife in Azerbaijan
description: Mobs attacked homes today in a former Armenian district of Baku, the capital of Soviet Azerbaijan, and at least two people were killed, reports from the area said.

title: Transactions
description: Baseball

title: A Better Choice For a Ferry Terminal
description: The ferryboat from Hoboken to lower Manhattan is a good idea (''Ferryboats Again Becoming a Familiar Sight Along Hudson,'' Dec. 24), but the Battery Park City terminus is a poor choice.

title: India's Ambassador to Washington Resigns
description: Karan Singh, the Indian Ambassador to Washington and son of the last Maharajah of Kashmir, has resigned his post, it was announced today.

title:
ART;

State Poses for Its Portrait In a Pleasurable Photo Show
description: LEAD: AS many people know, 1989 was the 150th anniversary of the invention of photography, and almost every museum and arts center in the country acknowledged this in some way. Coming in under the wire (it opened on Dec. 2) is ''Stated as Fact: Photographic Documents of New Jersey'' at the New Jersey State Museum.

title: Sports of The Times;   Were Jackson and Barkley Halted in Time?
description: All around them, Mark Jackson and Charles Barkley can observe people lined up buying lottery tickets. They can see the state of Oregon taking book on their performances.

title: Lee R. Jamieson,Student, Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Thomas Crawford Jamieson Jr. of Princeton, N.J., and Londonderry, Vt., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Lee Reddan Jamieson, to Ronald Jerome Kane Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Kane of Princeton. A June wedding is planned. Miss Jamieson, 24 years old, expects to receive a J.D. degree next year from Fordham University. An alumna of the Stuart Country Day School, she graduated with honors from Brown University. Her father is a senior partner in the Princeton law firm of Jamieson, Moore, Peskin & Spicer.

title: POSTINGS: $900,000 Project;   Restoration On Madison
description: The 82-year-old French Gothic apartment house at the corner of Madison Avenue and East 66th Street, often regarded as one of the most distinctive structures on the East Side, has emerged from a coccoon of scaffolding that had enveloped it during more than two years of exterior restoration.

title: Mach 3 Passengers? No Simple Formula
description: By about the year 2010, it may be possible for globe-trotters to fly from Los Angeles to Tokyo at two or three times the speed of sound - cutting the nine-hour trip to three or four hours - and pay only slightly more than they would for a ticket on a Boeing 747.

title: The Call of the Roads Brings A Driver Back Home
description: ON a June afternoon my friend Sherry's driver's license arrived in the mail. She drove over to my house, honked, and waited for me behind the wheel of her mother's white-walled, baby-blue Buick Catalina, with the motor running. I slipped into the front seat, shivering less from the air-conditioning than the sight of her white moccasin caressing the gas pedal.

title: A VINTAGE ASSORTMENT FROM NURSERY TO ROOFTOP
description: The American folk art acquired by Edith and Bernard M. Barenholtz over 18 years focuses mostly on sculptural objects that are historical and exuberantly patriotic. More than 275 of the vintage rooftop, storefront and nursery decorations that they bought are to be auctioned at Sotheby's in New York on Jan. 27 in what the house describes as the most important folk-art holding to come to the market in a decade. Sotheby's estimates that the sale will bring $1.6 million to $2.3 million.

title: Inquiry Is Sought of New York Insurance Bureau
description: State Comptroller Edward V. Regan has accused the agency overseeing insolvent New York insurance companies of fraud and mismanagement, and has called for the State Inspector General to investigate.

title: Pastimes;   Coins
description: Congress will have to deal with several bills concerning coins in the next few months. One will change the look of the coins. Another will abolish the cent in favor of a new coin valued at one dollar. Both bills are mired in controversy. The bill to change the design on the reverse side of the coins is supported by the American Numismatic Association and by many collectors. The Bill of Rights has been suggested as the theme of the new design, but there's one problem. With only five coins and 10 original rights the choice will be hard. Should a design glorifying the First Amendment's guarantee of a free press push aside the design proclaiming the Second Amendment's right to bear arms? A vote on that question could tie up Congress and lobbyists for eternity.

title: Pastimes;   Camera
description: Despite repeated warnings not to take brand-new cameras on once-in-a-lifetime travel vacations, some people persist in tempting fate.

title: Who's Watching The Tube
description: To the Editor:

title: Turnpike Seen as Metaphor for America
description: POSING for newspaper photos on a small hill overlooking the New Jersey Turnpike here, a Rutgers University professor turned to a colleague standing beside him.

title: Lifestyle: Sunday Menu;   Risotto With Seafood
description: There are several kinds of short-grain rice available in Italy for making risotto. The most common, of course, is Arborio. It has become so popular in this country that supermarkets in many large cities carry it.

title: PAPERBACK BEST SELLERS: January 14, 1990
description: $ Weeks This On Week List Fiction 1 12 THE DRAWING OF THE THREE, by Stephen King. (Signet/NAL, $5.95.) Continuing the horror story begun in ''The Gunslinger.'' 2 9 THE SANDS OF TIME, by Sidney Sheldon. (Warner, $5.95.) A struggle between the Spanish Army and Basque separatists. 3 4 A THIEF OF TIME, by Tony Hillerman. (Harper Paperbacks, $4.95.) Tracking down a missing archeologist, missing artifacts and a murderer. 4 48 THE SHELL SEEKERS, by Rosamunde Pilcher. (Dell, $4.95.) A woman and a painting tie together three generations of an English family. 5 1 THE LONG DARK TEA-TIME OF THE SOUL, by Douglas Adams. (Pocket, $4.95.) The detective of ''The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy'' pursues the meaning of an explosion at an airport. 6 2 SPY HOOK, by Len Deighton. (Ballantine, $5.95.) The agent Bernard Samson on the trail of a financial scam within the British secret service. 7 1 UNICORN POINT, by Piers Anthony. (Ace, $4.50.) The scandalous life of the Hollywood superstar Marilyn Taylor. 10 7 CAT'S EYE, by Margaret Atwood. (Bantam, $5.95.) James Bond contends with the villainous leader of a cult dealing in vice and terrorism. Q 13 * 1 A ROCK AND A HARD PLACE, by Peter David. (Pocket, $3.95.) Commander Riker fights for survival in a new ''Star Trek'' novel. Q 14 16 BREATHING LESSONS, by Anne Tyler. (Berkley, $5.50.) The many facets of a 28-year marriage are revealed during a drive to a funeral. Q 15 7 THORNYHOLD, by Mary Stewart. (Fawcett, $5.95.) Q 3 8 THE BLOODING, by Joseph Wambaugh. (Bantam, $5.95.) The murder of two teen-age girls in an English village is solved through genetic Q clues. Q 4 5 NEW KIDS ON THE BLOCK, by Grace Catalano. (Bantam, $3.50.) The lives and predilections of the five members of a teen-age singing group. Q 5 325 THE ROAD LESS TRAVELED, by M. Scott Peck. (Touchstone/S&S, $10.95.) A new collection of cartoons. Q 2 15 THE PREHISTORY OF THE FAR SIDE, by Gary Larson. (Andrews & McMeel, $12.95.) The cartoonist's sketches and notes from the past 10 years. Q 3 6 THE WORLD ALMANAC AND BOOK OF FACTS 1990. (World Almanac, $6.95.) The latest edition of a reference work. Q 4 1 THE NEW BASICS COOKBOOK, by Julee Rosso and Sheila Lukins. (Workman, $18.95.) A wide variety of tastes, ingredients and techniques are celebrated in 875 recipes. Q 5 27 YUKON HO! by Bill Watterson. (Andrews & McMeel, $6.95.) More ''Calvin and Hobbes'' cartoons.

title: SPIES & THRILLERS
description: Frank O'Neill's ROMAN CIRCUS (Simon & Schuster, $19.95) may not be everybody's dish. It may be too introspective, too literary, too novelistic. Give it a chance. Brilliantly written, with superb characterizations, plenty of action and a Felliniesque social setup, it is to most books of its genre what a Henry James novel is to a Horatio Alger story.

title: On Fire, a Soviet Jet Crashes, Killing 23 People in the Urals
description: A Soviet airliner with a flaming engine crashed today while attempting an emergency landing on a field in the Ural Mountains, killing 23 people, the official press agency Tass said. Thirty people were injured, the agency said.

title: Ticket Lottery At Meadowlands
description: If you want to participate in the lottery to be able to buy tickets to the Eastern regional semifinals of the National Collegiate Athletic Association basketball tournament at Byrne Meadowlands Arena March 24 and 26, you must follow this procedure:

title: Isadora's Dances Take On a Life of Their Own
description: A young woman in a short red tunic leaps out with a tattered flag, skips and falls ''wounded.'' Immediately, a second woman enters to take up the banner, and as she falls, two women materialize. Five bodies lie on the ground and two more appear with raised fists, overlapping in their jumps. On tape, the Red Army Chorus sings the ''Varshavyanka,'' a turn-of-the-century Polish-Russian revolutionary song. The wavelike relay continues until all lie inert. But the first woman rises, followed by the others, arms up: The spirit of revolution is reborn.

title: GIVE MANAGEMENT ITS DUE, I.B.M. IS MORE THAN A QUARTERLY STATEMENT
description: To the Editor:

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I don't see any tragedy in a multi-party system if it arises and actually answers the interests of society. We should not be afraid of it, the way the devil is of incense.''

title: Scuba Diving With Sharks
description: A HALF-DOZEN hammerhead sharks came straight at us when we dropped to about 20 feet below the surface. They moved past at an angle, apparently uninterested, then disappeared into the hazy distance as we continued to sink into the blue.

title: Elizabeth Leiman To Wed in March
description: Mr. and Mrs. Leonard M. Leiman of New York have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Anne Leiman, to Ruben Kraiem, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Leon Kraiem of Mexico City and New York. A March wedding is planned.

title: Almeida Captures Grand Gestures Of 'La Juive'
description: In the first two decades of this century, Halevy's ''Juive'' -the epitome of the French romantic grand opera - still loomed large on the operatic stages. It faded from view in the 1930's until 1973, when a few performances were staged in various places for the late Richard Tucker, the opera's tireless champion. Some of those performances are still circulating in ''unofficial'' recordings, but, except for a misguided and amateurish venture many years ago, a comprehensive recorded account of this opera has not been available until the current release of Philips 420 190 on three CD's, LP's or cassettes.

title: Fashion;   At Gucci, Calvin and the Rest, 50% Off Is the Norm
description: If you go, be prepared to find only a few things you like and to spend what seems like years schlepping from place to place. Hours vary from store to store, but most are open seven days a week. On to the bargains:

title: Erica Buchsbaum, an Editor, To Marry
description: June wedding plans have been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Ladislav Buchsbaum of Wyncote, Pa., for their daughter Erica Ruth Buchsbaum and Dr. Andrew C. Goldberg, the son of Anshel Goldberg of South Orange, N.J., and the late Marsha Goldberg.

title: Salvadoran President Announces Arrests of 8 in Killing of 6 Jesuits
description: President Alfredo Cristiani today announced the arrest of a colonel, two lieutenants and five lower-ranking soldiers in the slaying of six Jesuit priests in November. He said another soldier was being sought in the killings.

title: Needed: Better Job by Colleges
description: To the Sports Editor: rrAs the head of a foundation that has several programs dealing with college-bound athletes in track and field, I read William C. Rhoden's article about the challenge facing colleges to integrate the black athlete into the school community, ''Searching for a Moral Imperative,'' (The New York Times, Dec. 23) with great interest.

title: William M. Freeman Dies at 76; Ex-Financial Writer for The Times
description: William M. Freeman, a business and financial news reporter, columnist and editor for The New York Times from 1932 until his retirement in 1976, died of a heart attack on Tuesday at St. Peter's Hospital in Albany. He was 76 years old and lived in Cambridge, N.Y.

title: Jazz Group Is Facing Bankruptcy
description: LEAD: A LAST-MINUTE infusion of funds will keep the International Art of Jazz, the Stony Brook-based jazz presenter, in business through the month.

title: Have Cast, Will Travel: Performing for the Love of It
description: THE reason you sit down to the piano even if they all laugh is something that Bob Gemson, Dr. Stuart Rappaport, Hayley Kobilinsky and Barbara Brand know only too well.

title: A DARK LENS ON AMERICA
description: AT THE EDGE OF THE FRENCH QUARTER IN New Orleans, where the city's charm falls off into skid row, David Lynch is directing a scene from his new film ''Wild at Heart.'' On a scouting mission during the morning he had liked several of the people who gather here in the bars before noon, and has now decided to incorporate them into the shots. The action of the film, which stars Nicolas Cage and Laura Dern as young lovers, has the couple always on the run from sinister, adult forces. New Orleans is only one of their many hideouts.

title: Sisterhood Isn't So Powerful In the Movies
description: LEAD: Who are you going to discuss your wedding night with? Your husband?Sometimes a woman needs another woman, a great friend. Sisterhood can, indeed, be powerful. It can be fun, too - or poignant or exhilarating. And you would think it could make a terrific movie.

title: Mosaic Metaphor Serves Many Masters
description: To the Editor:

title: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST: Soviet Union;   GORBACHEV HINTS HE WOULD ACCEPT MULTIPARTY RULE
description: In his most conciliatory comments to date on the prospect of a multiparty system, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev said today that ending the Communist Party monopoly on power in the Soviet Union would not be a ''tragedy.''

title: Carbon Paper 1, Technology 0
description: Fat forms - invoices, purchase orders, bills of lading and other multipart documents that require a number of copies - are the bane of most small-business computer printers. The cries of anguish seem to peak at this time of the year when companies start trying to print W-2 forms. Each Federal, state and local agency wants its own copy of the wage statement that employers are required to provide to employees. In New York State, for example, that can result in at least six copies, in a form with five sheets of carbon paper, for a total of 11 sheets.

title: Into the Surly Skies
description: THE multicolored ticket folder sits on a corner of my desk, tucked beneath two days' worth of memos and reports. Although it's out of sight, it's not out of mind. As much as I try to forget about it, as much as I try to avoid thinking about it, the dread never leaves my mind. It's time for another business trip. It's time to fly.

Monaco, was married yesterday to Vance John Anderson, a son of Marna S. Anderson of Upper Montclair, N.J., and the late Cyrus T. Anderson. The Rev. Marie Reed performed the ceremony.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: THE ROARING '80s, by Adam Smith. (Penguin, $8.95.) In his portraits of the borrow-and-spend decade just behind us, Adam Smith looks for signs that the bubble is about to burst. ''We could not ask for a more genial, knowledgeable companion for a tour of the national financial landscape,'' Susan Lee said here in 1988. ''He is able to describe events in a common-sense way that makes them accessible and that puts him way ahead of most financial commentators.''

title: In Affluent Towns, The Working Poor Are Filling Shelters
description: LEAD: WESTPORT, with its country clubs, marinas and million-dollar mansions, is not a town where you would expect to find a soup kitchen or a shelter for the homeless. Still, a few dozen people find their way every day to the Interfaith Housing Association's soup kitchen for a hot meal, and another 15 fill the nonprofit agency's shelter each night.

Rennert, and Dr. Lewis Berman, both residents in internal medicine at Presbyterian University Hospital in Pittsburgh. Dr. Berman is the son of Dr. and Mrs. Abraham Berman of Cedar Grove, N.J.

title: Drug Arrest Disrupted C.I.A. Operation in Panama
description: Nine months before American forces invaded Panama, a covert Central Intelligence Agency program to support political opponents of General Manuel Antonio Noriega ended abruptly after the Drug Enforcement Administration arrested one of the Panamanians involved, according to Government officials.

description: LEAD: FOR families of gravely ill children whose spirits were buoyed by Sheila Petersen, founder of the Friends of Karen, news of her death in a car crash earlier this month brought questions about the fate of her small organization. But it now appears that her effort will be carried on.

title: Rentals Abroad
description: To the Editor: This summer my wife and I spent 10 weeks in Britain, staying 8 of those weeks in the countryside in self-catering cottages - and they are an excellent solution, particularly for a long-term stay in a foreign country.

title:
IN THE REGION: New Jersey;

For Elizabeth, a New Downtown Image
description: LEAD: THE redevelopment wave that altered the face of central business districts in many older cities across the state in the 1980's bypassed Elizabeth, leaving its midtown area to stagnate.

title: 'Native Inspiration,' A Departure for the Griswold
description: FOR almost a century, Florence Griswold's mansion, at 96 Lyme Street in Old Lyme, has been closely associated with Impressionism - first, as the boardinghouse where the artists themselves stayed, but more recently as a museum specializing in their work. ''Native Inspiration,'' the museum's current show, is therefore a departure since it incorporates artists from movements preceding, paralleling and following Impressionism.

title: Works in Progress;   A Lot of Hot Air
description: THE LAST TIME RICHARD BRANSON and Per Lindstrand tried something like this they nearly died. In 1987, the pair became the first people to cross the Atlantic Ocean in a hot-air balloon. ''There was a rather hairy ending,'' Branson says of the touchdown on the coast of Northern Ireland. ''The explosive bolts that were meant to fire and get rid of the balloon didn't fire. We were dragged across the water, rather in danger of drowning.''

The building, One Chestnut Place, is a $33 million joint venture of NYNEX Properties Company, the development arm of the regional telephone company, and St.

description: They have been joined in what seems to be a decadelong struggle: the Denver Broncos and the Cleveland Browns, bothering each other like gum on a shoe.

title: U.N. Secretary General Taking His Afghan Plan to Moscow
description: During two days of talks in Moscow starting on Monday, Secretary General Javier Perez de Cuellar will seek Soviet backing for a new peace initiative to end the civil war in Afghanistan, diplomats and United Nations officials say.

title: A Nation Tries to Decide How to Recall Martin Luther King
description: THE nation will honor the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. tomorrow, the holiday that marks his birth 61 years ago. But increasingly, the holiday is becoming a time when his admirers ponder not just the meaning of his life, but also the more delicate question of how best to carry on his work 22 years after his death.

title: Kathleen Raftery To Marry in May
description: The engagement of Kathleen Ann Raftery to Dr. John W. Danaher, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William J. Danaher of Goshen, Conn., has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Michael R. Raftery of Riverside, Calif. A May wedding is planned.

title: Back Home Again With Indiana
description: It makes some sense to watch the Indiana Jones trilogy backward - or more precisely, in reverse chronological order. INDIANA JONES AND THE LAST CRUSADE, which will be released on video at the end of the month (1989, Paramount Home Video, $24.95), begins with Indiana as a Boy Scout, before he became the world's most daring archeologist-adventurer, before he was even Harrison Ford. The long opening sequence, with River Phoenix as the young Indiana, is a playful feast of clues that allows Steven Spielberg to fill in some crucial details about his hero; here Indiana acquires his trademark fedora, whip and fear of snakes. And we discover that he has an irascible scholar-father, Henry Jones.

title: New Jersey Official Named To Regional Office of H.U.D.
description: A new head of the United States Department of Housing and Urban Development's New York-New Jersey regional office was named by Housing Secretary Jack F. Kemp yesterday.

title: Question Of the Week;   Is the N.F.C. The Better Conference?
description: The two conferences are very close.

title: Overcoming Obstacles to a Civil-Rights Chronicle
description: In 1965, Henry Hampton, the executive producer of ''Eyes on the Prize,'' marched for civil rights in Selma, Ala. Today he works in a corner office piled high with books and papers, with a view of Shawmut Avenue, a thoroughfare in this city's South End that is, in his words, ''about the only integrated neighborhood in Boston.'' Over his desk is a somber portrait of William Butler Yeats; on one wall is a poster-sized drawing of a time line, with major civil-rights events from the 1950's to the 80's inked in by hand.

title: Sports of The Times;   How Two Trades Rehorned the Rams
description: In pro football, most trades are listed quietly in ''transactions,'' not trumpeted in thick headlines. Unlike the big trades in baseball, pro basketball and hockey, National Football League teams seldom dare to hijack another club's touted rookie quarterback or swap a running back galloping toward career records.

title: FICTION
description: THE GARDEN WHERE THE BRASS BAND PLAYED. By Simon Vestdijk. Translated by A. Brotherton. (New Amsterdam, $18.95.) Originally published in the Netherlands in 1950, ''The Garden Where the Brass Band Played'' is now being published in an able translation by A. Brotherton as part of a series of modern Dutch classics. But while Simon Vestdijk's novel may be considered modern in his native country, its tone and subject seem to belong more to 19th-century Dickensian sagas. Its narrator, Nol Rieske, introduces himself to the reader almost as early in life as David Copperfield, and provides just as many details of his sentimental education. Unlike most of Dickens's protagonists, however, Nol is born into privilege, the son of a judge. And unlike the 19th-century master of epic fictional memoirs, Vestdijk takes such a circuitous route through Nol's life that it is difficult to determine just what his maturation is supposed to illustrate. At first, Nol's story seems to focus on family relationships, as the author reveals Nol's distant dealings with his father, his restrained worship of his mother and his enmity toward his spoiled older brother, Chris. Then the book becomes a celebration of musical genius when Nol, at age 8, is mesmerized in the town garden by a brass band conducted by Henri Cuperus, an eccentric who later becomes the boy's piano teacher. Finally, the novel fixes on the timeworn theme of class distinctions versus romantic love, as a grown-up Nol pursues Trix, Cuperus's mercurial daughter. Led astray by a member of the local aristocracy, Trix has a tarnished reputation that threatens to destroy any chance of happiness with Nol. Unfortunately, the reader can't enjoy the enigmatic Trix much longer than Nol can. And the other pivotal figures in his life - his mother and Cuperus - seem more silly than saintly. Even Nol himself reveals his snobbish upbringing. In the end, reading the novel is like perusing the diary of someone you don't much like - distaste ultimately triumphs over curiosity.

It was ''deteriorating,'' the Croton-on-Hudson resident said, and she thought a quilt based on river scenes might draw attention to the Hudson's attributes and motivate people to protect it.

Indian Regional Cuisine in White Plains

title: Encouraging a Healthy Life Style Is Just Good Business
description: A COOLING economy in Long Island is not the only challenge facing Nassau and Suffolk County employers. The rising cost of health insurance has become a serious drain on revenues and makes it increasingly difficult for companies to grow and compete in a chilly economic climate.

title: NAZIS ON THE CUTTING ROOM FLOOR
description: LEAD:

title: Coming Home
description: Unlike some Japanese soldiers who spent decades in the jungles of the Pacific and Southeast Asia, Shigeyuki Hashimoto (left) and Kiyaoki Tanaka knew at least that they were no longer fighting World War II. When Mr. Hashimoto and Mr. Tanaka emerged from the woods last week after 45 years, they made it clear that they had stayed on after the big war to fight a smaller one. They joined the local Communist insurgents in 1948 to fight for Malaysian independence from Britain. Though Malaysia won its independence in 1957, the Communist guerrillas did not officially lay down their arms until last month. The 71-year-old Mr. Hashimoto said that for he and his comrade, now 77, it was a matter of honor. ''We thought Malaysians would think we were taking advantage of them if we let Britain reclaim their country,'' he said. When the two arrived in Tokyo yesterday, Mr. Hashimoto's sister said, ''I did not hear from him for nearly 50 years, so of course I was worried.''

title: Costly Opinion
description: After the World Cup soccer draw last month, Diego Maradona, the captain of the Argentine national team, said that he believed the pairings in the six four-team groups had been determined beforehand and that the official ceremony had been staged ''just for the fun of television watchers.''

title: Memory Enshrined In an Apple Peel
description: THE sun, belying the thermometer's frigid reading, streamed through the panes of the kitchen window, resting on the counter where the apple sat.

title: Cold Warriors, From A to Z
description: Ever since Mikhail Gorbachev came to power in 1985, neoconservatives and other hard-liners have strained to find new rationales for old cold war animosities. It hasn't been easy. Mr. Gorbachev doesn't fit the mold of Soviet leaders with his political and economic reforms, his unilateral force reductions, his freeing of Eastern Europe, his willingness to reveal the lies of his predecessors and now his statement that a multiparty system in his own country would not be a ''tragedy.''

title:
GARDENING;

Avoiding the Damage of Winter's Snow
description: LEAD: THIS has been a winter of extremes. December was exceptionally cold, while early January turned out quite warm. There has been both ice and snow though neither has been especially severe. But asmidwinter approaches, it is not unreasonable to expect at least one major storm that will result in damage to plantings.

title: Want a Hit? Don't Flunk Marketing
description: Robert de Niro and Dustin Hoffman, arguably the two greatest film actors of their generation, went belly-up at the box office this Christmas. But Chevy Chase and Sylvester Stallone, who can be found elsewhere on the great acting spectrum, made out just fine. What happened? It wasn't a direct consequence of the films themselves, since all four vehicles in which these actors appeared were disappointing. And even if the others didn't pander to the kiddie audience as shamelessly as Mr. Chase's ''National Lampoon's Christmas Vacation,'' none of the remaining three - Mr. De Niro's ''We're No Angels,'' Mr. Stallone's ''Tango & Cash'' and Mr. Hoffman's ''Family Business'' - took the high road, either.

title: Pillars of Conservatism

title: SALVADOR LEFTIST IS SHOT TO DEATH
description: The body of a prominent Salvadoran leftist who was reported kidnapped in Guatemala City on Friday has been found near the border, a spokesman for his political party said here today.

title: Unwanted Horses Find Greener Pastures
description: IT seems the quintessential Connecticut pastoral scene: a group of horses basking in the wintery sunshine, contentedly nibbling on hay. But not long ago some of the horses were near death, having been starved and neglected, and others were destined for the slaughterhouse. That was before Patricia Whalers of New Milford came into their lives. ''People come out here and say, 'Where are all the skinny horses?''' said the 28-year-old Ms. Whalers, who devotes herself to the rescue, rehabilitation and adoption of neglected or unwanted horses. ''They don't realize that once we get them, they aren't skinny for long.''

title: Hoosiers Surprised By the Boilermakers
description: Tony Jones scored 21 points as Purdue rallied from a 16-point deficit, tied cold-shooting Indiana on a basket by Ryan Berning with 35 seconds left in regulation, then beat the Hoosiers, 81-79, in overtime.

title: Arrest in Slayings at Club
description: A Brooklyn man was arrested yesterday and charged with shooting three men, including two bystanders, outside a Manhattan nightclub early in the morning of Dec. 30, the police said. Two of the men were killed and the third was seriously wounded.

Nonetheless, most of the concerts in this marathon will still take place at the Y, and Thursday evening marked the first of this year's Y events.

The ''chamber'' was eventually dropped, and this season a ''symphony'' has been added, so Saturday's 8 P.M. concert at Horace Greeley High School will officially be by the Chappaqua Symphony Orchestra.
