title: Giving the Athletes a Voice in College Sports
description: Last week in Dallas, National Collegiate Athletic Association executives, university and college presidents, athletic directors and some coaches met to discuss and formulate the rules that govern college athletics. The only constituency not represented in Dallas was, perhaps, the most important: the athletes.

title: Ms. McAndrew To Wed in June
description: The engagement of Patricia Mary McAndrew and Martin J. MacCormack has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. John J. McAndrew of Short Hills, N.J. Mr. MacCormack is a son of David McCormack of Washington and Jean Walsh MacCormack of Bethesda, Md. The couple plan to marry in June.

title: Amy Freedman To Wed in June
description: Walter G. Freedman of Chicago and Mrs. Henri Axel Schupf of Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Amy Elizabeth Freedman to Daniel Shaw Jurkowitz, a son of Dr. Marianne Jurkowitz Alexander of Worthington, Ohio, and the late Dr. Lawrence Jurkowitz of Whitestone, Queens. A June wedding is planned.

title: Question Of the Week;   Is the N.F.C. The Better Conference?
description: The good teams in the N.F.C. (49ers, Giants, Rams) are better than their A.F.C. counterparts (Broncos, Browns, Bills) and should win the Super Bowl. But the bad teams in the N.F.C. (Cowboys, Falcons, Cardinals) are worse than their A.F.C. counterparts (Jets, Chargers, Patriots). The average teams in each conference are about the same. Therefore, based upon overall strength, the answer is no. The N.F.C. is not the better conference; the conferences are equal.

title: WHAT YOUR BRAIN IS UP TO
description: THE REMEMBERED PRESENT

title: Style Makers;   Mariya Solomin, Soviet Fashion Editor
description: ''It's bigger than our House of Fashion,'' exclaimed Mariya Solomin after a tour of Calvin Klein's workrooms and offices, which occupy six floors at 205 West 39th Street. Mrs. Solomin is the fashion editor of Zhurnal Mod, the Soviet Union's major fashion magazine.

title: EAST BERLIN DIARY
description: I read Christoph Hein's article ''East Berlin Diary'' (Dec. 17), and memories of my many trips to East Germany over the years came back to me. My first visit to East Berlin was in 1963, just 18 months after the wall was built. My first trip to Leipzig, in East Germany, was in 1964. After that I must have crossed Checkpoint Charlie at least 100 times.

title: Preventing Expo 2000
description: To the Editor:

title: A Portrait Of Justice Douglas
description: ''MAYBE I'm giving you too much of a wagonload, but that's your problem.'' Agitatedly sorting out the pieces of his life after a stroke, William Orville Douglas, Associate Justice of the Supreme Court, recalls those words, once spoken by his father.

title: In Space News Conference, Astronauts Hail Their Good Catch
description: With their major objectives accomplished, the astronauts of the space shuttle Columbia settled down today to work on engineering and medical experiments for the rest of the mission, which is to end next Friday morning.

title: Dumont Journal;   Homeless Shelter Plan Raises Moral Question
description: A PROPOSED shelter for homeless people on the grounds of a Roman Catholic church here has left a neighborhood and parish bitterly divided and raised a moral question: Do property values supersede the observance of Christian values?

title: IN THE REGION: Long Island;   Recent Sales
description: Amityville $200,000

title: Truth Can Be Stranger Than Stereotypes
description: In San Francisco, we're used to the hype.

title: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST: Aid From the West;   New Bank to Help East Bloc Revive Its Economy
description: Senior officials from the leading industrial nations and Eastern Europe are to meet here on Monday to plan the establishment of an Eastern European development bank. The bank would lead to one of the largest regional assistance efforts since the Marshall Plan.

title: The Triple Demerits in Tokyo
description: Rising interest rates, a declining yen and higher oil prices are undermining the usually buoyant Tokyo stock market, hurting the stocks of large companies and sending shivers through other markets around the world.

title: It's Deadline Time for George Ball
description: Time is running out for George L. Ball. The 51-year-old chief executive of Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. has spent the last five years, and hundreds of millions of dollars, trying to turn a sleepy retail brokerage operation into a glamorous global investment bank. Mr. Ball wanted Pru-Bache to join the big leagues on Wall Street, doing mega-deals and issuing high-risk, high-yield ''junk bonds'' with the rest of them.

title: A New Stress on Communication Skills
description: ''I TELL clients that their workers don't have to work harder to become productive, they have to work smarter,'' said Sybil Conrad, a Scarsdale communications consultant. ''For example, in one of my workshops, I teach employees that they can begin to work smarter by listening better.''

title:
Connecticut Q&A;: Dr. Robert Watson;

Insomniacs Have Plenty of Company
description: LEAD: THERE is a saying that you're never more alone than when you're awake at 3 o'clock in the morning. It might not help bring on sleep, but insomniacs might be comforted to know that they have plenty of company. According to the American Sleep Disorders Association in Rochester, Minn., 32 percent of Americans report suffering some degree of insomnia and 15 to 20 percent of them consider their sleep problems serious.

title: Richard Weiler Jr.Weds Lori S. Hill
description: Lori Susan Hill and Richard Carl Weiler Jr. were married yesterday by the Rev. J. Ronald Miller, a Methodist minister, at the Wilson Memorial Union Church in Watchung, N.J. The bride is a daughter of Mildred E. Hill of Scotch Plains, N.J., and Robert A. Hill of Barnegat, N.J. The bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Weiler of Watchung.

title: For Refugees From Southeast Asia, Adapting Is a Slow Road
description: WHEN Joseph Quy Vu came to this country from Vietnam, he spent two months in a refugee camp and several more months finding a job and a place to live. That was 15 years ago. Now, though his children belong to local soccer and baseball teams and he has made some friends in his South Windsor neighborhood, he still finds adjusting to Western culture a difficult task.

title: Steal Helps Redmen Stop Panthers
description: Jason Buchanan stole the ball from Jason Matthews near midcourt with 4 seconds left yesterday to prevent Pittsburgh from attempting a winning shot, and the steal lifted St. John's to a 71-70 victory over the Panthers before 10,884 at Madison Square Garden. But a shot Pat Cavanaugh missed with 12 seconds remaining was just as crucial as the one the Panthers never attempted.

title: North Salem May Ban Foam Cups
description: NORTH SALEM could become the first community in Westchester to ban polystyrene foam containers when village officials consider the measure later this month. But opposition from local retailers is mounting, and the outlook for passage of the local law is uncertain.

title: Lisa Rieger Wed To M. W. Claman
description: Lisa Rieger, a daughter of Jack (Chip) Rieger of New York and Joan Rieger of Brentwood, Calif., was married yesterday in San Francisco to Matthew Warren Claman, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Lawrence Claman of Dallas. Judge Joseph Karesh of Alameda County (Calif.) Superior Court officiated at the Page Brown Mansion.

title: 10 Floors for Parking Planned On Top of a Chicago Church
description: For Chicago motorists and Catholic parishioners, the Old St. Mary's Catholic Church and Self-Park facility will be a 12-story blessing: 10 floors of parking space on a two-story church.

title: Anna Esaki Wed To Craig S. Smith
description: Anna Esaki and Craig Spencer Smith were married yesterday in a civil ceremony at the Quaker Meeting House in Chappaqua, N.Y., by Dr. Bruce Gilchrist, the acting marriage officer of the Town of New Castle, N.Y.

title: Campus Life: Minnesota;   Students Debate Legal Status For Marijuana
description: Students for and against the legalization of marijuana debated Thursday at the University of Minnesota, surrounded by a noisy, jeering crowd of 300 spectators.

title: Apartment Hunting And the Dog Factor
description: THE easy part was selling our house. Finding an apartment in Bronxville should have been easy, except for one problem.

title: Building a Fire, Building a Nation
description: THIS nation has a short past but a vivid one, and Americans spend a good deal of effort trying to recreate it. I work for a magazine of American history, and all such attempts interest me, from the serene and majestic spread of Colonial Williamsburg to Walt Disney's ebullient fantasy of the Midwestern main streets of his youth.

title: Praising 'New Mainstream,' Wilder Takes Virginia Oath
description: Lawrence Douglas Wilder, a grandson of slaves, was sworn in today as Governor of Virginia in a 30-second ceremony that changed the political face of the United States.

title:
IN SHORT;

NONFICTION
description: LEAD:

title: Inside the Department of Pain and Suffering
description: ALMOST from the day it was set up in 1966 as New York City's main weapon in the war on poverty, the huge Human Resources Administration has itself been under attack. Mayor David N. Dinkins has called running it ''the toughest job in the City of New York,'' even tougher than being Mayor. James Dumpson, a former administrator who heads the Mayor's committee to find a new executive, has called the agency ''an administrative monstrosity'' that should be dismembered.

title: Too Old to Fly to Chicago, but Not to the Moon
description: To the Editor:

title: Ex-Klan Leader Finishes Last In Bid for Senate Nomination
description: Louisiana Republicans today endorsed a New Orleans State Senator for the party's nomination for the United States Senate, decisively rejecting a former Ku Klux Klan leader.

title: KASPAROV BEATS DEEP THOUGHT
description: IN A CROWDED AUDITORIUM, THE CHAMPION hunches over a chessboard. He is surrounded by cameramen. Taking refuge in himself, he pillows his jaw in his hands. He is thinking hard in order to make himself think harder. His opponent, also a champion, is some 300 miles away, pondering the next move, engaged in calculations on a scale too colossal for anyone in the audience to grasp.

title: Long Island Journal
description: Praise the Lord, Thrice

title: Still Crazy After All These Years
description: LEAD:

title: Bypassing the Dangers of Toxic Prints
description: LEAD: ALTHOUGH artists frequently use their medium to deliver a message, the medium itself rarely is the message. That is, until ''Au Naturel: The Toxic Free Print'' opened yesterday at the Sabbeth Art Gallery in Glen Cove.

title: JoAnne, Allison and a Cruel Promise
description: Neither JoAnne Johnson, 19, nor Allison Atlas, 20, has very long to live - not unless they receive bone marrow transplants that might defeat their leukemia. But JoAnne is black and Allison is Jewish, which means they can't look to the National Marrow Donor Program's registry for help. Neither can most of the 9,000 Americans who might benefit from transplant surgery. They could, though, if Congress, having established the registry, did not leave it so poorly funded as to be almost useless.

title:
LONG ISLAND SOUND;

What Will Be Hot, and What Not
description: LEAD: JAN. 14: The midway point between hearing what the year's new trends are and realizing that there is no way on earth that we will ever keep them. But not all new trends are life-threatening. Take 1986's shoulder pads, which made dieting obsolete. Or the years that produced innovations like couch potatoes, the empty nest and liposuction, when women took off one-quarter of their total body weight in an hour and a half.

title: 4 Are Killed in South Africa In Feud Among Black Rivals
description: Four people were killed in fighting among gangs vying for control of black townships in Natal Province, the police said today.

title: TALKING: Tree Care;   Winter Is the Time To Prune
description: FEW external features enhance the value and attractiveness of a home more than its trees, those actually on the property as well as any street trees that might frame the setting. A careful program of pruning - whether through a professional landscaper, in cooperation with the municipality or by one's own labors - is therefore not a luxury but an integral part of any prudent property maintenance program.

title: Wedding Plans For Miss Pressey
description: Mr. and Mrs. James C. Pressey of Sag Harbor, L.I., and San Miguel de Allende, Mexico, have made known the June wedding plans of their daughter, Katharine Allen Pressey, and Jeffrey Stuart Rosenberg, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Edward C. Rosenberg of Jericho, L.I.

title: A Blue-Chip Name Is Not Enough
description: It was a dirty decade. From check-kiting at E.F. Hutton to insider trading at Drexel Burnham Lambert, Wall Street misbehavior was to the 1980's what bootlegging was to the 20's - the crime that defined the era.

title: Massachusetts Town Votes To Remove Indian Swastikas
description: Officials of this seaside community near Boston have decided to remove a floor whose tiles have American Indian swastikas inlaid in them. The floor was laid in Town Hall 66 years ago, before the Nazis adopted the ancient mystic emblem.

title: A HIGH-STEPPING, LIGHT-FOOTED GRAPHIC ART
description: ''Pierre Bonnard: The Graphic Art'' at the Metropolitan Museum is in itself a self-sufficing delight, even if it was initially overshadowed in the minds of many visitors by the temporary proximity of two big-name neighbors (Velazquez and Canaletto). But those neighbors have now taken their leave, and we have until Feb. 4 to linger over the Bonnard exhibition and recognize it as a major event in its field.

title: Last-Gasp Foul Shots Stop Nets
description: With one second left in tonight's game, Sam Bowie trembled when he heard the referee's whistle. He knew what it meant.

title: Pope Warns on Rekindling of Rivalries in East
description: Pope John Paul II today hailed the ''irrepressible thirst for freedom'' that has ''broken down walls and opened doors'' in Eastern Europe, but he warned that the rapid political changes could unleash nationalist feelings and ethnic conflicts.

title: Pastimes;   Stamps
description: Postal history is a notoriously ill-defined term; philatelic journals are full of back-and-forth about what it means. There is a long-running debate about how competitive postal-history exhibits should be judged.

title: Regina M. Reilly To Marry in May
description: Regina Mary Reilly, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Paul W. Reilly of Locust, N.J., and Lieut. James Roger Cochrane, U.S.N., a son of Assemblyman and Mrs. John C. Cochrane of Brightwaters, L.I., plan to marry in May, her parents have announced.

title:
THE VIEW FROM: THE Y.M.C.A. OF CENTRAL AND NORTHERN WESTCHESTER;

Drawing From Original Mission, Y Answers Community Needs
description: LEAD: WHEN Kenneth H. Brockway talks about outreach programs, he means it almost literally. Mr. Brockway, the new president and chief executive officer of the Y.M.C.A. of Central and Northern Westchester, which has its headquarters here, is particularly excited about a plan to raise money to buy three vans to pick up people and take them on outings.

title: FSX - Japan's Last Bad Deal
description: JAPAN'S defense is keyed to America's security needs, not our own, which is an anomaly that reflects our subservient relationship. It is time for us to step out of Uncle Sam's shadow and build a military force suited to our own needs. The place to begin is the next-generation support fighter, code-named the FSX, short for fighter support experimental. If we decide now to pursue the independent development of this advanced airplane, rather than continue to develop it jointly with the United States, it would upgrade our defense capability, end the era of postwar American tutelage and bolster our national pride. The resultant equal bilateral partnership is in the interests of both countries.

title: New York City Clergy Hope Neighborliness Will Help Race Relations
description: Religious leaders in New York are gambling that, to mend the city's racial divisions, many New Yorkers will try anything, even neighborliness.

title: Winning By Design: System Puts 49ers on Top
description: If the San Francisco 49ers defeat the Los Angeles Rams here today and leap toward the franchise's fourth Super Bowl title, Joe Montana, Jerry Rice and Roger Craig will, once again, be applauded. George Seifert will be praised for guiding a return trip to the Super Bowl in his first season as head coach. And the 49ers will be crowned title favorites regardless of their American Conference champion opponent. That is guaranteed. It is also obvious, and a reward for a franchise that in the 1980's arguably displayed the best schemes, the best players and the best coaching.

title: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST: Budapest;   Police Spying Dies Hard in Hungary
description: In a sign of how awkward the transition to a democracy can sometimes be, the Hungarian secret police admitted this week that it has been spying on registered opposition parties, just as it did when they were considered outlawed dissidents not so long ago.

title:
Style Makers;

Cindy Alwan and Karen Schein, Silk Marbleizers
description: LEAD: When Cindy Alwan and Karen Schein took a class a few years ago to learn the hand-marbleizing technique they admired in exquisite Venetian paper products, they found that while they liked the process they did not enjoying working on paper.

title: A Break With Tradition
description: I COULDN'T believe the news! My baby daughter had just visited the pediatrician. My wife called me at my office to render the verdict. I was stunned. I asked her to repeat it. The same answer came through again, loud and clear.

title: POSTINGS: 3 Jim Dine Sculptures;   Venus on the Avenue
description: When the former J. C. Penney building was acquired by the Tishman Speyer Trammell Crow Limited Partnership in 1988, the architectural firm of Skidmore Owings & Merrill was hired to offer advice about renovating the structure and its sunken plaza on the west blockfront along the Avenue of the Americas between West 52d and 53d Streets. Sculpture for a street-level plaza was decided upon and Jerry I. Speyer, who is both president of Tishman Speyer Properties and a member of the board of trustees of the nearby Museum of Modern Art, eventually commissioned works by Jim Dine.

title:
YOUR OWN ACCOUNT;

Going After the Gold
description: LEAD: During the holiday shopping season, Visa ran full-page newspaper ads touting its million-dollar sweepstakes. ''Any time you use Visa Gold,'' the ads read, ''you're entering the Visa Our Treat Sweepstakes.'' The winner will receive the Visa Millionaire's Card with $1 million in prepaid charging power.

title: BASEBALL'S DESIGNATED THINKER
description: TAKE TIME FOR PARADISE

title: A Textbook Victory for Devils
description: A display of fundamental hockey by Janne Ojanen, the rookie forward from Finland, helped the Devils gain a 5-4 triumph over the Nordiques tonight at the Colisee.

title: R. K. Fitts to Wed Sarah A. Watkins
description: Myrna S. Watkins of Wellesley Hills, Mass., and Dr. Mark E. Watkins of Syracuse have announced August wedding plans for their daughter Sarah Anne Watkins and Robert K. Fitts, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Donald D. Fitts of Penn Valley, Pa.

title: In Georgia Reprise, Maddox on Stump
description: ''Those Spiro Agnew and George Wallace watches were pin lever movements, cheap pieces of junk,'' said Lester Maddox, proudly brandishing the watch on his wrist with its chicken leg for an hour hand and pick handle for a minute hand. ''This is a 17 jewel.''

title: Hoyas' Power Too Much for DePaul
description: Alonzo Mourning scored 26 points and Mark Tillmon added 21 today to lead undefeated Georgetown to a 74-64 victory over DePaul.

title: A LITTLE REGULATION, PLEASE
description: LEAD:

title: Campeau Bankers Are Posing Some $2.3 Billion Questions
description: Only two years ago, banks were lining up to lend money to Robert Campeau and earn the rich fees that they expected would flow from helping the Canadian real estate mogul buy one of the nation's most vaunted retailers, Federated Department Stores.

title: NIBBLED AT BY NEIGHBORS
description: THE PREDATOR

title: New Orleans: It's Nonstop Music
description: WHAT'S this? A New Orleans jazz hall with lace curtains? Pale peach damask tablecloths and crisp damask napery? Low-calorie specials on a menu printed in English and Japanese? Unlikely as it seems, the new Palm Court Jazz Cafe on Decatur Street in the French Quarter, a neighborhood once thronged by waterfront toughs, is the latest hot spot in the birthplace of jazz. While patrons have come to expect halls that are often gritty and pitch dark, they have been trekking in to the Palm Court undeterred by the stylish decor.

title: THERE'S NO JUSTICE IN WALL STREET'S FORCED ARBITRATION
description: To the Editor When the Supreme Court gave stockbrokers the power to insist that aggrieved customers submit their disputes to arbitration, it accorded them something given to no other American industry. (''When Naivete Meets Wall Street,'' Dec. 3) No other industry is privileged with a dispute resolution system in which the adjudicator is not required to explain the basis of the decision and no mechanism is available for review and correction of mistakes. Judges surely would do a faster job of deciding cases if no explanation was required of the basis for decision and there was no concern over review by a higher court. That Congress has done nothing to correct this gross imbalance is certainly evidence of the continued value we place on property in contrast to persons.

title: Chronology Of Betrayal
description: This is the chronology of the American betrayal of the struggle for freedom in China. It is worth studying. There is still a chance to recover some of America's honor.

title: Bond Issue Advances L.I. Plans To Buy Land
description: LEAD: WHEN Gov. Mario M. Cuomo proposed a $1.9 billion bond issue earlier this month to buy open land, support recycling and cap landfills, the environmental agenda that held Long Island's attention in recent years seemed on the way to becoming the state's agenda in the years ahead.

title: Pastimes;   Chess
description: Not so many years ago, if anyone came into a chess club and asked, ''Would you like to see the brilliant game I played against the computer?'' he would have been laughed out of the place. But what was surely one of the most imaginative games in the American Open Tournament, Nov. 23-26 at the Hyatt Regency Hotel in Long Beach, Calif., was won by a human against one of several computers entered.

title: 'Successful People Laugh at Themselves'
description: One of the few treasures to be found, every other week, in the Sunday Long Island Weekly is the Barbara Klaus column. It never fails to put a smile on your face or a good feeling in your heart. In our house, it almost invariably gets clipped out and shown or mailed to my office staff, friends and family.

title: About Cars;   Cadillac's Latest in Touring
description: It is 6:30 A.M., a time when I am usually in suspended animation.

title: EAST BERLIN DIARY
description: The current turmoil in Communist countries is often described as a struggle between freedom (which is assumed to require a free-enterprise economy) and Communism (dictatorship combined with a socialist economy). Christoph Hein cuts through this confusion between political and economic issues to make it clear that democracy versus dictatorship and private enterprise versus socialism are separate issues.

title: Raffi Gregorian Wed in Australia To Miss Dawson
description: Bernadette Dawson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. R. J. Dawson of Melbourne, Australia, was married yesterday in Belgrave, a suburb of Melbourne, to Raffi Gregorian, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Vartan Gregorian of New York and Providence, R.I. The Rev. Peter Carcuran performed the ceremony at St. Thomas More's Roman Catholic Church.

title: Another Disk Revolution In the Offing?
description: Will laser be the people's choice in the 1990's? ''Laser videodisk will be to home entertainment in the 90's what the VCR was during the 80's,'' said Martin Greenwald, the president of Image Entertainment in a statement last summer. Since Image makes disks for Orion, MGM, Disney, CBS/Fox and about 50 other companies, he is entitled to some enthusiasm. But most people in video - Mr. Greenwald among them - acknowledge that as popular as disk may become, it will in no way supplant videotape.

title: A 'White Knight' Draws Cries of 'Patent Blackmail'
description: Most people who have heard of Eugene M. Lang know him as the New York philanthropist who struck an imaginative deal with a class of Harlem sixth graders: If they finished high school, he would pay their college expenses. The idea, which has been widely copied, brought Mr. Lang national celebrity.

title: POSTINGS: Hackensack Conversion;   Death of a Fox
description: The 2,500-seat Fox Theater on Hackensack's Main Street, together with the 2,000-seat Oritani Theater, directly across the street, were social focal points for more than 50 years. On weekend nights, these movie houses were the teen-age magnets that discos became in the 70's and malls in the 80's.

title: Wall of Fame
description: He played only one season at Arizona State before embarking on a 21-year major league career that will land him in the Hall of Fame, but yesterday, Reggie Jackson saw his number retired by the university. And it wasn't the number he actually wore.

title: PERSPECTIVES: Downtown Brooklyn;   Creating a Critical Mass at Metrotech
description: BY a curious quirk of timing in the mid-70's, Citibank found itself building the imposing Citicorp Center project at Lexington Avenue and East 53d Street when new office construction generally in Manhattan was tomb silent.

title: Review/Music;   Industrial Clankings With Guitar Backing
description: Drum machines went ''boom-chucka-boom'' and singers growled and glared in a triple bill of industrial rock Thursday night at the Ritz. Ministry, KMFDM and Controlled Bleeding all make music that draws its power from the deepest, loudest thuds the musicians and electronics can produce. Guitar and keyboard sounds and the chanted vocals are subordinate in songs that try to turn the depersonalized sounds of assembly-line machinery into statements of personal fury and horror.

title: Montana
description: To the Editor: On Nov. 12 you published a ski guide to the United States. Imagine our surprise when a concerned individual informed us that Montana was not included.

title: Restarting a Balky Furnace
description: PROLONGED cold weather taxes home heating equipment, thus increasing the likelihood of an unexpected shutdown.

title: Coming to Papa
description: In a sort of artistic paternity suit, a California court last week ruled that the hit movie, ''Coming to America,'' had sprung from the mind of Art Buchwald. The ruling obligated the Paramount Pictures Corporation, which made the movie, to live up to a contract in which the columnist and Alan Bernheim, a producer and co-plaintiff, were promised $250,000 and 19 percent of the profits from any film produced from a story idea that Mr. Buchwald sold to the studio in 1983. Paramount contended that ''Coming to America'' was based on an idea developed by Eddie Murphy, who starred in the movie and was not named in the suit. But the court said the plot lines of Mr. Buchwald's ''King for a Day'' and the Paramount movie were definitely consanguine: Each is about a member of African royalty who comes to the United States and ends up working in a menial job. The studio said it would appeal the ruling. In the meantime, another phase of the trial will determine just how much money the movie made - and how much is due Mr. Buchwald, who appeared unconcerned with that aspect of the case. ''This is probably the fourth or fifth happiest day of my life,'' he said.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Washington;

Mixed Uses For an Odd Lot
description: LEAD: AFTER long delays, an $8 million mixed-use building is finally under construction on an odd-shaped lot at 3307 M Street in historic Georgetown. The four-story, 112,000-square-foot office, retail and residential structure is rising in an area that is becoming an opulent shopping district.

title: Campus Life: UConn;   Proposal to Close Teaching Center Is Angering Students and Faculty
description: A steady reduction of services to students at the University of Connecticut, prompted by recent state budget cuts, have been greeted with murmurs of protest in the last few months. But the most recent money-saving effort - the planned closing of the Center for Educational Innovation, which helps student teachers and university faculty members improve their teaching skills - has upset not just students, but faculty and union members as well.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Our sliding glass doors are difficult to slide. We have vacuumed the tracks and sprayed with a silicone lubricant, but this helps only temporarily. Any suggestions?

title: Miss Bancroft, Actress, to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. William W. Bancroft of Old Brookville, L.I., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Sturges Bancroft, to Joseph Edward Barnes, a son of Mrs. Harry G. Barnes Jr. of Virginia Beach, Va., and the late Commander Barnes, a Navy aviator. A May wedding is planned.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: ART LECTURES

title: Laura Gant Plans To Marry in May
description: Mr. and Mrs. Donald R. Gant of Vernon, N.J., and Amelia Island, Fla., have made known the engagement of their daughter Laura Ross Gant to Peter Cahn Lilienfield, the son of Elizabeth C. Askow of Winnetka, Ill., and the late Edward W. Lilienfield. A May wedding is planned.

title: Why Do Students Yawn at History?
description: THE past few months have certainly had more than their share of historic events. As 1989 wound down and a new decade began, it seemed that each day brought some stunning change in the world, some major new development to interpret and discuss with my ninth-grade students in social studies.

title: Eugenia M. Middleton Is Engaged to Lars Toomre
description: Mr. and Mrs. John Middleton of Rumson, N.J., have announced June wedding plans for their daughter Eugenia Matthews Middleton and Lars Toomre, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Alar Toomre of West Newton, Mass.

title: If They've Won, Can Conservatives Still Be Important?
description: THE transformations sweeping Eastern Europe have reverberated through the institutes and offices, the meeting rooms and magazines that, for the past decade or so, have made up the most influential body of American political thought: conservatism. The echoes, in fact, are the sound of a victory chorus, even if the conservatives' detractors do not believe they should be the only ones to celebrate.

title: Sandstrom Scores The Game-Winner
description: Tomas Sandstrom sat and smiled, the enigma insisting he wasn't at all made uncomfortable by the paradox.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN: Barcelona
description: Barcelona is a city lover's city, a pulsating, vibrant city that mixes the fertility of the Mediterranean with the intellectual consciousness of Europe, a city of great factories and a brawny port, a citizen's city so justifiably in love with itself that posters everywhere for a campaign of cleaning building facades proclaim ''Barcelona, Make Yourself Beautiful.''

title: How People With Cancer Can Change the Quality of Their Lives
description: To the Editor:

title:
FOCUS: Boston;

An Experiment in Urban Transformation
description: LEAD: EIGHTEEN months after the first of Harbor Point's 58 buildings was opened, a cooled-down real estate market has brought unexpected competition to the $225 million, mixed-income development and a slower rate of rental for its 1,283 apartments. But there is optimism that when it is completed in the spring, rentals will pick up and there will be new answers to the problem of providing low-cost housing and publicly assisted mixed-income projects.

title: Review/Music;   War Horses by Mehta and Philharmonic Soloists
description: Conceptually, one of the most laudable aspects of Zubin Mehta's tenure as music director of the New York Philharmonic has been his habit of providing his principal players, and sometimes his players below the rank of principal, with solo showcases. The current subscription program at Avery Fisher Hall, which is a warmup to a Live from Lincoln Center telecast Wednesday night, carries that practice to a national audience.

title: Yonkers Seeks to Block Housing Plan
description: Mayor Henry Spallone, buoyed by the United States Supreme Court's ruling that overturned contempt fines against four City Councilmen in the city's desegregation case, has asked municipal officials to examine the options of further legal action to prevent construction of court-ordered integrated housing.

title: CONNECTICUT GUIDE
description: CHARLES IVES

title:
IN SHORT;

NONFICTION
description: LEAD:

title: Fashion: On the Street;   Just the Thing For Cowpokes Urban Style
description: Bob Mackie, the free spirit who has designed some of Cher's most memorable get-ups, is hardly fashion's man for the masses. But one of his recent bits of business seems to have caught on in a relatively big way. It's a jacket with horsehead appliques that face each other, like knights on a chessboard.

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT/VIDEO: NEW VIDEO RELEASES
description: Eddie and the Cruisers II: Eddie Lives

title: Elegant Dinners in a Victorian Setting
description: THE Copper Beech Inn, occupying the shade of a venerable copper beech tree on Main Street in Ivoryton, has been considered one of Connecticut's most elegant restaurants for almost 20 years. It has survived a change in ownership, menu changes and minor tinkering and has managed to maintain its reputation for leisurely dining in restful and attractive surroundings.

title: State to End New York City Corruption Office
description: Seventeen years after it was established to uproot corruption in New York City's criminal-justice system, a state investigative agency is going out of business.

title: Pavlovsk
description: To the Editor: Having recently returned with my wife and daughter from our first trip to the Soviet Union, and with our visit to Pavlovsk fresh in my mind, I was dismayed by several aspects of the article on the palace (''Russia's Reborn Slendor'' by Olivier Bernier, Travel, Oct. 1.

title: Question Of the Week;   Is the N.F.C. The Better Conference?
description: The N.F.C.'s preeminence is reminiscent of the National Football League's superiority to the American Football League during most of the 60's, before the two leagues merged, when the Packers (winners of the first two Super Bowls) and other N.F.L. teams were considered superior to any A.F.L. team.

title: COMMERCIAL PROPERTY: Tin Pan Alley;   Rodgers & Hammerstein Is Moving to Broadway
description: THE cacophony of Tin Pin Alley has long been stilled, but enough of the music industry remains on Broadway to have lured the Rodgers & Hammerstein organization from Madison Avenue after four decades on the East Side.

title: Saving the Bacon
description: PORK AND I WERE NOT ON TASTING TERMS FORJU nearly 25 years. Our disagreement had nothing to do with religion, although it did start in church. The evening I was scheduled to play an angel in a pageant, my mother baked a big, juicy ham for dinner and I got sick as the devil.

title: Mixed Messages With the Seafood
description: J W.'s SEA GRILL in the new Marriott Wind Watch Hotel in Hauppauge cannot decide whether it wants to be the Plaza Hotel or a Holiday Inn.

title: Hints of Change as Board Convenes
description: THE spirited sense of expectation that envelops the Board of Legislators when it convenes as a new body every two years was present, as usual, last Monday, with members being sworn in and leaders appointed before admiring friends and relatives.

title: Question Of the Week;   Is the N.F.C. The Better Conference?
description: Recent history says yes. From 1984 through 1989, no N.F.C. team won its division with less than 10 victories. But six A.F.C. teams managed to win. In the last two seasons, four N.F.C. teams have missed the playoffs despite winning 10 games, none have done that and missed in the A.F.C.

title: Christa M. Carey Weds Richard Dunn
description: Christa Marie Carey was married last evening to Richard Wolfe Dunn at the Marsh Chapel at Boston University by the Rev. Neil Mullaney, a Roman Catholic priest, and Rabbi Allen Press. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Edwin J. Carey Jr. of Duncan, Okla. The bridegroom is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Leo Dunn of Boston.

title: IN THE REGION: New Jersey;   Recent Sales
description: Jackson $123,000

title: Barroom Biology: How Alcohol Goes To a Woman's Head
description: THOUGH barroom lore has long had it that women get drunk faster than men, the phenomenon has attracted little scientific attention. Since women generally have smaller bodies than men it seemed natural to expect that they would be more quickly overwhelmed by alcohol.

title: STREETSCAPES: The Cloud Club;   Still Exciting, but Still Vacant
description: THE private Cloud Club at the top of the Chrysler Building, New York's flashiest skyscraper, seemed to its early members to be an Art Deco Shangri-La. Although it turned out to be as much banker's traditional as jazz-age modern, the club's three floors, designed by William Van Alen, constitute one of New York's most exciting spaces. Despite that, the club is entering its second decade as a vacant space looking for a tenant.

title: Pastimes;   Bridge
description: Tournament players occasionally find themselves playing a difficult slam bid against the clock with penalties looming if they play too slowly. But the time pressure the declarer suffered from on the diagramed deal was of quite a different kind.

title: In 'Bull's-Eye!' the Aim Is Laughter
description: This stately home was refuge for the children of Charles I during the London plague year of 1646; the house from which Lady Jane Grey set out by river for her nine days' reign as Queen of England before her beheading; the starting point for the dramatic ride to London by Henry Percy and Guy Fawkes the night before Fawkes's Gunpowder Plot was revealed - and now the house where Michael Winner directed Michael Caine and Roger Moore in scenes from Mr. Winner's next film, a caper comedy called ''Bull's-Eye!''

title: Campus Life: M.I.T.;   Officials Seeking Grant to Establish Course in Chinese
description: Five days a week during the academic year, Andrea Li boards the No. 1 bus at the steps of the Massachusetts Institute of Technology's main building for a 15-minute ride to Harvard University, where she is studying Chinese.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: When Wit Works Too Hard

title: Spelling Out the Generation Gap
description: ''I SPELLED eleemosynary like it was cat or dog,'' explains Echo, the national spelling champion in ''El-ee-mos-y-nary,'' the occasionally fascinating play by Lee Blessing now at Studio Theater.

title: Radicals Fought The Color Bar
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Stephanie A. Maxwell to Wed Jeffrey R. Binder
description: Dr. and Mrs. William J. Maxwell have announced June wedding plans for their daughter, Stephanie Anne Maxwell, and Jeffrey Ross Binder, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Lou Binder. Both families live in Teaneck, N.J.

title: Finally, Amtrak Looks Like a Way To Run a Business
description: FOR most of its 19 years, Amtrak has been regarded as a kind of lost cause. Its trains were derided as unreliable, its service and food as primitive and its budget as a drain on the Federal treasury. But the national railroad appears, at last, to be moving in the right direction.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: Florida Levies Drug Fund Fee On Rental Cars

title: Question Of the Week;   Is the N.F.C. The Better Conference?
description: No A.F.C. team has won the Super Bowl over the last five years, but the A.F.C. holds the edge in interconference games, 54-52, over the last two years, including post-season play. Also, in 1988 the three teams with the worst records belonged to the N.F.C. and in 1989 the two worst did. The five most consistently bad teams over the same time period also belonged to the N.F.C. The N.F.C. is no better than the A.F.C. The A.F.C. has just reached a balance of power while the N.F.C. has not.

title: Plan for Interim U.N. Rule in Cambodia Gains
description: On the eve of a new international effort to end the war in Cambodia, the United States, the Soviet Union, China, France and Britain appear close to endorsing a plan to install a temporary United Nations administration in Phnom Penh until free elections can be organized.

title: Hers;   Working on The Mechanics
description: ARE YOU CRAZY?'' friends in New York had said. ''Why on earth would you want to do such a thing?''

title: Companies Are Finding Fitness Is Good Business
description: A REGULAR exercise program, experts say, makes a person feel better, look better, require less sleep and possess more energy. Fitness is ''in.'' And people who exercise are generally healthier than those who don't; healthy people spend less time with doctors and more time at work.

title: STILL COMING HOME FROM VIETNAM
description: THESE GOOD MEN

title: >Breakfast Offerings That Stand Up to the Elements
description: BREAKFAST, the health experts tell us, is the most important meal of the day. But most people try to get by with cereal, juice and a cup of coffee. This may be all very well if your morning is spent in front of a desk. But if you plan to keep going on the ski slopes - or indeed, in any form of vigorous outdoor winter exercise - you will need something considerably more substantial. Nothing does the job better than a plate of pancakes, piled high and served with hot country ham and maple syrup.

title: DATA BANK: January 14, 1990
Bomb Inquiry Focuses on String-Tying Machin
description: Since a mail bomb killed a black Savannah lawyer in December, Federal law-enforcement officials say they have been trying to track down the source of an unusual type of string used to tie the package as well as the owner of an automatic tying machine that cinched four such parcels with identical knots.

title: Guidelines on Dying Urged by Both Sides Of Case in Missouri
description: A family that wants to let a comatose daughter die, and the Missouri Attorney General who opposes that request, have endorsed legislation to set up guidelines in such cases.

title: To Mr. Floria: Words of Advice
description: EVERY New Jersey governor takes office as the head of a different state. New problems constantly demand different solutions and innovative approaches to deal with economic cycles, a changing population, shifting employment patterns and, lately, global changes that present new challenges and opportunities.

title: Pastimes;   Around the Garden
description: For This Week: Now, while woody plants are dormant, is an excellent time to prune, especially trees and summer-blooming shrubs. But if the plants bloom early in spring, delay pruning until immediately after bloom. Start seed indoors of early flowering plants such as pansies. Check coldframes to be sure young plants and seedlings are secure and their soil moist.

title: Serene Haven of Buddhist Art
description: THE road north from Chongqing, city of fog and ferries far up the Yangtze River, undulates through market towns by fish ponds, brick kilns and mulberry bushes. Bamboos brush gray slate roofs, leathery men working in the fields hold pink umbrellas above their sweating brows, pigs are being carried to an urban fate in a special cane basket called ''pig's sedan chair,'' and heavily made-up young women in high heels by the muddy roadside call out invitations to take meals at their aromatic private cafes.

title: Fighting for Your Life
description: To the Editor:

title: A JOURNAL OF A PLAGUED LIFE
description: DANIEL DEFOE

title: In Europe, a Time for Humility
description: LEAD: A controversy has broken out in Prague over Vaclav Havel's statement, made before his election to the Presidency: ''We have a duty to apologize to the Germans who were expelled after the Second World War.'' The discredited Czech Communists, playing the nationalist card, have jubilantly attacked Mr.

title: Press Is Criticized In Boston Slaying
description: The tangled Stuart murder case, a near obsession for the Boston news media for the last three months, has prompted charges that the press has been racist, incompetent and reckless. But news executives there vigorously defend the performance of their organizations.

title:
DANCE;

State's Legacy From Ballet Theater
description: LEAD: AS the American Ballet Theater celebrates its 50 years of dance in a gala performance today at the Metropolitan Opera House in Manhattan, New Jersey balletomanes might consider that stellar company's legacy in New Jersey. The New Jersey Ballet carries the names of four Ballet Theater alumni on its masthead, a lineage that contributes to the high-caliber product consistently offered by one of the state's premier ballet companies.

title: View Down Fifth
description: To the Editor:

title: A FEW WORDS FROM JENNY HOLZER
description: I have no doubt that Jenny Holzer is an artist, but to think of her as a visual artist, which is the implication of her selection to represent the United States at the Venice Biennale, is to have ''proved'' finally that painting is dead. Slowly but surely the single fixed image - the heart of so-called two-dimensional expression - has been usurped. The text has finally devoured the image.

title: Lithuania: A Land Dominated by Grasping Neighbors
description: ''What was stolen must be returned.''

title: Question Of the Week;   Is the N.F.C. The Better Conference?
description: Sure. The N.F.C. has won seven out of the last eight Super Bowls including the last five.

title: PATH and Access For the Disabled
description: Daniel Censullo, chief operating officer of PATH, spoke about current and future improvements of the PATH system in the Nov. 26 New Jersey Q & A. Nowhere is access to PATH for the disabled community mentioned.

title: Is Anybody Listening?
description: To the Editor:

title:
Lifestyle: Sunday Outing;

Just the Thing for People Who Like to Rub Shoulders With a Shotgun
description: LEAD: Firing a shotgun at a fast-moving clay target and seeing the target shatter in midair can be an exhilarating outdoor activity, as growing numbers of people are discovering.

title:
Pastimes: Gardening;

There's More to Bonsai Than You Think
description: LEAD: The miniaturized trees known as bonsai are popular items. Florists and specialty plant shops sell them ''ready made.'' But the appeal to buyers often contributes to the plant's downfall. Many bonsai owners believe that these little trees are well suited to life indoors. The majority of bonsai are not, which explains why many first-time owners take just weeks to kill bonsai that required years to develop.

title: Miss Johnson to Marry Patrick Rogers in June
description: Mrs. H. Alden Johnson Jr. of Marblehead, Mass., has announced June wedding plans for her daughter Cynthia Cole Johnson and Patrick Joseph Rogers, a son of Mr. and Mrs. W. John Rogers of Rochester.

title: Lori Ann Calvelo Weds
description: At the Terrace on the Park in Flushing, Queens, Lori Ann Calvelo, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gabriel Calvelo of Brentwood, L.I., was married last evening to Keith Steven Babbitt, a son of Harvey Babbitt and Anita Babbitt, both of New York. Rabbi Jonathan Glasser officiated. Mrs. Babbitt, 23 years old, is an assistant at the accounting firm of Rudolph, Cinammon & Calafato in Ocean, N.J. Mr. Babbitt, 27, is an assistant vice president of Merrill Lynch Capital Markets in New York.

title: U.S. to Relax Verification Proposal in Arms Talks
description: In a effort to speed up the lagging conventional arms talks, the Bush Administration plans to drop its long-standing demand for permanent inspectors at airfields, ports and rail lines in Europe, officials said today.

title:
GARDENING;

Avoiding the Damage of Winter's Snow
description: LEAD: THIS has been a winter of extremes. December was exceptionally cold, while early January turned out quite warm. There has been both ice and snow though neither has been especially severe. But asmidwinter approaches, it is not unreasonable to expect at least one major storm that will result in damage to plantings.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. Our sliding glass doors are difficult to slide. We have vacuumed the tracks and sprayed with a silicone lubricant, but this helps only temporarily. Any suggestions?

title: Diana Fortuna, New York City Official, to Wed
description: Diana Fortuna, a deputy director of the New York City Office of Management and Budget, and David Yassky, a third-year law student at Yale University, plan to be married in May.

title: High Schools Add Athletic Trainers
description: LEAD: THREE years ago, Robert Byiteck, the athletic director at Staples High School in Westport, made a decision he said was one of the most significant in his 12 years at the school. He hired Janet Bovaird to become the high school's first full-time trainer.

title:
GARDENING;

Avoiding the Damage of Winter's Snow
description: LEAD: THIS has been a winter of extremes. December was exceptionally cold, while early January turned out quite warm. There has been both ice and snow though neither has been especially severe. But asmidwinter approaches, it is not unreasonable to expect at least one major storm that will result in damage to plantings.

title: A House Fire in Jacksonville Kills 6, Including 5 Children
description: Six people, including five children, died in a house fire early today after they were trapped inside by window bars intended to guard against break-ins, the authorities said.

title: Barbara Cooper Is Married
description: Barbara Cooper and Paul T. Brensilber, Ithaca College graduates, were married last evening at Temple Emanuel in Kings Point, L.I., by Rabbi Michael Katz, who was assisted by Cantor Kalman Fliegelman. Mrs. Brensilber, 28 years old and a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Cooper of Dix Hills, L.I., is studying for a master's degree at the Bank Street School of Education. Mr. Brensilber, 31, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Harold Brensilber of Jericho, L.I., is an owner of Streamline Management, a Manhattan real-estate management firm.

title: UConn Capitalizes On Seton Hall Mistakes
description: The Connecticut Huskies, after dropping their first two Big East Conference games, captured their third consecutive one tonight with a 79-76 victory over Seton Hall at Byrne Meadowlands Arena.

title: Looking Ahead
description: MONDAY: The stock markets are open, but most banks and Government offices are closed for Martin Luther King Jr. Day. The Campeau Corporation's Allied and Federated retailing units are to assure a banking group, which loaned Campeau $2.34 billion, that they are solvent. Otherwise, the group could demand substantial, immediate repayment and force the retailers into bankruptcy.

title: Ms. Linton to Marry Daniel Levinson
description: Mr. and Mrs. Donald Nunziato of Lincoln Park, N.J., have announced the engagement of her daughter, Lorraine Janis Linton, to Daniel Ross Levinson, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Levinson of Singer Island, Fla. Ms. Linton is also a daughter of Robert Linton of Atlanta. An August wedding is planned. Ms. Linton is the promotion director for Bride's Magazine in New York. She attended Ramapo College and New York University. Her stepfather is an independent real-estate developer and builder in New Jersey and on Curacao in the Netherlands Antilles. Her mother, Terese K. Linton Nunziato, is an artist.

title: Is the Future of Television in the Numbers?
description: At the outset of the new decade, the outlook for television and video is exciting but uncertain. Great technical changes are in the offing, but the exact form of these changes is still undecided. Several competing technical proposals for High Definition Television (HDTV) lay claim to the future, each championed by different countries and their industrial giants. The contest is one of politics and market manipulation as much as it is a scientific joust.

title: Residential Resales
description: Closings in the week ended Dec. 30

title: Somers Book Looks at the Way It Was
description: SOMERS has changed greatly since it was known by the Kitchawank Indians as Appamaghpogh or Amapaugh (''freshwater fish'') and later - from 1788 until 1808 - as Stephentown, after Stephen Van Cortlandt who in 1734 owned 5,000 acres in the area.

title: ACTRESS AND MAN CUT IN 2 ATTACKS
description: Two people, one of them the actress Viveca Lindfors, were slashed on the face within minutes of each other in separate incidents yesterday morning, apparently by members of a group of young people roaming Greenwich Village, the police said.

title: Helen Laupheimer, Student, Engaged
description: Mrs. William E. Zabel Jr. of Bryn Mawr, Pa., and John D. Laupheimer of London have made known the engagement of their daughter Helen Huston Laupheimer to Kenneth Edward Ramonat, a son of Mr. and Mrs. H. E. Ramonat Jr. of Harvard, Mass. A May wedding is planned.

title: Out-of-State Workers Finds Jobs at G.M. Plant
description: IN a reprise of a role it has not played for more than a decade, the county has recently become an industrial-employment mecca, in this case providing jobs for hundreds of General Motors employees who were laid off at 12 plants nationwide.

title:
THEATER;

A MACBETH WITHOUT THE WIMP FACTOR
description: LEAD: Within the theater community ''Macbeth'' occupies an odd little corner. It's ''unlucky'' Shakespeare, a late, unusually short tragedy, so plagued by ill fortune that it wears the nervous pseudonym ''the Scottish play.'' Of course, it may well be that the reputation resides in a singular difficulty: convincing audiences that the deaths of that bloody, ambition-obsessed man and his fierce, haunted wife are worth mourning.

title: Amy Elizabeth Barbash To Marry Eric H. Sahn
description: Mr. and Mrs. Bob Barbash of New York and Beverly Hills, Calif., have announced May wedding plans for their daughter Amy Elizabeth Barbash and Eric Howard Sahn, a son of Mrs. Arthur G. Sahn of New York and the late Mr. Sahn.

title: A Place to Shop for Jung or 'Archie' Any Time of Day
description: LEAD: A JUGHEAD doll from the ''Archie'' comic books stands atop a copy of Marshall McLuhan's classic, ''The Medium Is the Message,'' on the spot next to the cash register reserved in most bookstores for the week's best seller. It is the first indication that Book World, on Chapel Street in downtown New

title: OUT OF DE FOREST AND ONTO THE AIR CAME MUSIC
description: Anniversaries aren't just sentimental occasions. They are useful pegs for marking the position of events in the stream of time. They give us perspective.

title: Lifestyle;   Wanted: Pen Pals For Peace
description: The letter was addressed to ''Deaz amerizan fziends.'' It was dated Nov. 28, 1989, Moscow, and signed ''Yuri.''

title: FASHION: European Report -- London/Milan;   Marketing the Millennium
description: In his most recent show of women's fashions, Rifat Ozbek staged a scene that shimmered with nostalgia. Spinning above the bleachers, shooting squares of light above the spectators' heads, was a mirrored disco ball.

title: GETTING THE LAST LAUGH: MY LIFE IN COMICS
description: LEAD: It was 1937. The newspaper comic strip was in its heyday. The strips were so popular that some inventive businessmen were starting to repackage them as whole books. The comics field, even in the bleak 30's, seemed to have a bright future. A cartoonist who could draw for the funny pages had reason to hope, anyway.

title: The Lamp That Got Away
description: LEAD: PARIS, 3:58 A.M. A sleepless night, filled with images. I can't believe I did it again. Found, then lost, the object of my desire. This time it was the promise and beauty of a lamp, not a man, but the principle is the same. The principle is, when you find the one you want - the man, the sofa, the gem, the lamp - act.

title: Margaret Young To Wed in June
description: June wedding plans have been announced by Mr. and Mrs. Ronald Faris Young of Lake Forest, Ill., for their daughter Margaret Randolph Young and J. Sargeant Reynolds Jr., the son of Mrs. Alexander Hamilton 4th of Richmond and the late Mr. Reynolds, a Lieutenant Governor of Virginia.

title: 'I FELT FREEDOM IN MY BONES'
description: FORGED IN BATTLE

title:
WESTCHESTER Q&A;: BARRY J. KLARBERG;

Planning for, Yes, Both Ethics and Taxes
description: LEAD: IT is closing in on tax time. The Internal Revenue Service, as usual, did not even wait for the new year to begin before mailing out tax forms. And as these forms have become more complicated, more Americans have turned to professionals for help. And the message from professionals is that year-round tax planning is often crucial.

title: A Bohemian Quarter In the Heart of Buenos Aires
description: ON the silent paths of the Recoleta Cemetery, where marble and granite mausoleums are crowned by ornate sculptures of imploring angels, tearful Madonnas or heroes of Argentina's independence from Spain, it is difficult to imagine the burst of life just beyond the red brick walls. Facing the graveyard, in an unusual cohabitation of life with death, is a row of deluxe restaurants, outdoor cafes and nightclubs that have cornered much of Buenos Aires's leisure time.

title: A Careless Hunter, a Changed Life
description: I AM enrolled in an adult development course that spans life crises from ages 17 through death. In class we discuss death, and even though only 29, I sometimes find myself contemplating my own. I think about how my own children (yet unborn) will react to my old age. I wonder if I will outlive my husband. I dream about inevitable life events while I am still in the security of being young and knowing these moments are many years away. But today a hunter nearly killed me. I almost got shot in George C. Waldo State Park in Southbury. In the fraction of a second it would have taken that hunter to pull the trigger, I would have been dead.

title: Overnight Transformation At Midtown Welfare Hotel
description: It was only 24 hours since New York City took over operations at one of the most squalid Manhattan welfare hotels, but already Glynis Slater, a 33-year-old mother of two, could see some improvement.

title: Football Awards
description: Andre Ware, the record-smashing all-American from the University of Houston, yesterday was named the winner of the ninth annual Davey O'Brien national quarterback award. Ware, winner of the Heisman Trophy and the leader of the Cougars' run-and-shoot offense, will be honored Feb. 12 at a dinner in Fort Worth.

title: A POET'S POLAND
description: I WAS HERE, AFTER 60 OR SO YEARS, in the northeastern corner of Poland, at the house of my adolescent vacations. The manor still stood, though it had been remodeled into apartments for workers in Poland's Forestry Service. What had been the park was now an impassable tanglewood descending to the lake shore, with no trace remaining of the paths. I asked an old peasant about names and people. He remembered the day in 1939 when the Germans arrived; I knew the rest - how the owners had been arrested, taken to the concentration camp of Sachsenhausen.

title: Stuart's Lie: An American Tradition
description: LEAD: We are shocked but we should not be surprised by the revelation that Charles Stuart, and not a black, male attacker robbed and killed his pregnant wife. Mr. Stuart used the white public's fear of black people and antipathy toward them to mask his heinous act. His reliance on race as a diversionary tactic has a long history.

title: Mosaic Metaphor Serves Many Masters
description: To the Editor:

title: A.C.L.U. Revises Its Strategy In Attempt to Mold Opinion
description: After years of telling officials what they cannot do to keep guns and other weapons out of the city's troubled schools, the American Civil Liberties Union here this week adopted a completely different tack: It presented its own plan to tighten school discipline and security.

description: THE BEST AMERICAN ESSAYS 1989

title: An Array of Spices in Istanbul
description: IF you walk along the right bank of the Golden Horn through the maze of street vendors, porters and all kinds of vehicles, then turn south just opposite the Galata Bridge, you enter a world of pungent Oriental spices, medicinal herbs and essences, some very familiar, others quite unfathomable.

title: Press Reports Conflict on Albanian Turmoil
description: Newspapers today quoted an Albanian border guard who fled the country as saying that the security forces had fired on protesters last week and that one city was in a state of ''revolution.''

title: Scuba Diving
description: To the Editor: With the recent rise in the popularity of scuba diving, readers of Jane Adams's article ''Into the Void, and Back'' (Travel, Dec. 10) unfamiliar with the sport should be alerted to the possibility that the author might have been experiencing a major danger of scuba diving known as nitrogen narcosis, also called rapture of the deep, not to be confused with the bends or nitrogen saturation of the blood.

title: POSTINGS: Horse-Farm Homes;  $950,000 and Up
description: Two horse farms in Columbia County, N.Y., are being developed into a group of expensive homes designed to mimic the architecture of the Hudson River Valley. Named Tory Hill, the 550-acre project adjoins Route 22 in the hamlet of Hillsdale and is on the site of the former Sir William Horse Farms, where Arabian horses once were bred.

title: AN UNEASY WALKER IN THE CITY
description: OUR NEW YORK

title: Economic Pulse: The Oil States -- A special report:   3 States, Once Fat on Oil, Try to Break With Past
description: Fearfully contemplating a future without oil, Texas, Louisiana and Oklahoma are trying to reinvent themselves.

title: Starting Today: an expanded Business section
description: The Times introduces a revised and expanded Sunday Business section today. It includes revised financial tables, new graphical presentations of business news and new columns that report on, among other things, Wall Street, mutual funds, executive life styles, world stock markets and personal finance.

title: SAY GOODBYE TO THE STUFFED ELEPHANTS
description: WHIPPED UP BY A SUDDEN SQUALL, THE SEA between Majuro and Mili islands in the South Pacific began lashing the small sailboat. One of its passengers, Phyllis Rabineau, a 30-year-old senior exhibition developer who works for the Field Museum of Natural History in Chicago, was scared. ''I felt as if I were in a Jack London story,'' she recalls, ''where you're on a boat and everything imaginable goes wrong.''

title: Peruvian Still Outraged By Invasion of Panama
description: High above the presidential palace here, the flag of Panama flutters next to that of Peru.

title: 49ers-Rams: Defenses Better Duck
description: When the 49ers face the Los Angeles Rams in San Francisco today for the National Conference championship and a Super Bowl berth, the game will offer exciting offenses.

title: Evening Hours;   A Gala With Cardin And a Party for Art
description: Pierre Cardin, the self-proclaimed ''fashion capitalist,'' invited about 1,000 of his New York friends to a private party last Sunday. It started with a cocktail reception at Mr. Cardin's Madison Avenue restaurant, Maxim's, then went on to a performance of the Soviet rock musical ''Junon and Avos: The Hope,'' at City Center. After the performance, Mr. Cardin, his friends and the cast returned to Maxim's for a late-night supper.

title: Lifestyle;   Pushing On in Spite of the Flu
description: Gretchen L. Mergenthaler caughtthe flu over Christmas weekend, and throughout the following week she sneezed, coughed, sipped orange juice and breathed through her mouth when she slept. Her ears hurt so much that ''when I went outside, it felt like two anvils hit me in the side of the head,'' she said. ''I think a normal person would have stayed home.''

title: On Language;   Of 'Of'
description: DEAR ACE,'' BEGINSJU a note from an old friend.

title: WHEN THE MEN IN BLUE FADE INTO BLAND
description: Climbing from the bottom to the top of the ratings heap during the last decade or so, NBC was adventurous, taking chances on series such as ''Miami Vice,'' ''Hill Street Blues,'' ''Cheers'' and ''The Cosby Show.'' Today, undoubtedly under pressure to stay a very profitable No. 1, the network, now owned by General Electric, has become noticeably more cautious. Instead of shaping popular tastes, NBC is struggling merely to reflect them. Discouraging proof is currently available in the new series called ''True Blue,'' broadcast on Fridays at 9 P.M. Oddly enough, at a time when commercial network audiences are eroding because of stiff competition from cable and VCR's, the need for programming innovations at CBS, NBC and ABC might seem obvious. But ''True Blue'' is pure old-style formula. Its roots can be traced at least as far back as the early 1970's when ''Emergency,'' another NBC series, offered weekly compilations of interwoven incidents involving the Los Angeles County Fire Department's Paramedical Rescue Service. Randolph Mantooth, as trivia collectors will recall, became a television star playing Paramedic John Gage. Countless television series have used the same formula, regularly serving up a stew of funny, sad, sentimental and tragic anecdotes.

title:
IN SHORT;

NONFICTION
description: LEAD:

title: Campus Life: Trinity;   Residents Enjoy Having Dormitory Just for Freshmen
description: In an effort to provide an academic environment without the customary dormitory distractions - like noise, rowdiness and other behavior deemed inappropriate by college officials - Trinity College has created an experimental freshmen dormitory that includes a basement classroom. Kristina B. Dow, the college's director of residential services, said Trinity's approach is unique.

title: Q and A
description: Co-op Fire Damage

title: IN THE REGION: Connecticut and Westchester;   Recent Sales
description: Larchmont, N.Y. $555,000

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: BUSINESS DIARY: January 7-12
description: COMPANIES

title: Miss Kittredge to Wed R. P. Wastrom
description: Mrs. David Brayton Kittredge of Charlotte, Vt., has announced the engagement of her daughter Jennifer Ann Kittredge to Richard Paul Wastrom, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert Dale Wastrom of Upper Saddle River, N.J. The bride is also a daughter of the late Mr. Kittredge. A June wedding is planned. Miss Kittredge, 29 years old, is a senior public-relations coordinator for Little, Brown & Company in New York. She graduated from New Canaan (Conn.) High School and the University of Vermont. Her father owned and operated Woodbury's of Shelburne, a wood crafting business.

title: Social Events
description: Historic Hymn

title: 12 Cases of a Severe Lung Disease Found Among Workers at A-Plant
description: Twelve people who were exposed to the metal beryllium while working at the Rocky Flats nuclear weapons plant have contracted an incurable lung disease, according to an Energy Department study obtained by a newspaper.

title: Where Dueling Memos Agree: A Lockout Is Looming
description: Labor negotiations between the owners and the players, which will very likely delay the start of spring training - and, conceivably, the season - have for the moment become a paper war of dueling memos.

title: Campus Life: New Mexico;   Nanny Training: storytelling And Diapering
description: Five days a week Catherine Gerlach is a nanny for the children of Justin and Mary Lee Collins of Santa Fe. Ms. Gerlach, 27 years old, is a psychology major from the University of New Mexico in Albuquerque.

title: College Names And the 'Grand Word'
description: The effort of state and private colleges in New Jersey to call themselves universities (''Colleges Ask to Be Called Universities,'' Dec. 3) is an example of what the 19th-century British poet and critic Matthew Arnold called ''the grand word without the grand thing.''

title: Serena Harding-Jones Plans to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Michael R. Harding-Jones of Miami have announced the engagement of their daughter Serena Barbara Harding-Jones to William Douglas Lese, a son of Ruth E. Lese of New York and William M. Lese of New York and London. A March wedding is planned.

title: BLOOMING WHILE THE SUN WENT DOWN
description: THE JEWS OF VIENNA IN THE AGE OF FRANZ JOSEPH

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL/3-16

title: U.S. WEIGHS SHIFTS IN AFGHAN POLICY
description: President Bush sent a delegation of senior American officials to South Asia today to accelerate efforts to find a negotiated settlement of the war in Afghanistan.

title: 2 Die as Ambulance Carrying Mother Teresa Loses Control
description: The brakes failed on an ambulance in which Mother Teresa was riding today, and two people were killed when the runaway vehicle hit them, the police said. Mother Teresa was not hurt.

title: The Sole Issue In Cablevision Dispute
description: The Dec. 24 article on cable television in New Jersey (''Towns Challenge Cable TV Companies'') contains a broad misstatement regarding Cablevision and the Madison Square Garden Network (MSG).

title: Who's Left, Who's Right in Post-Wall Europe?;   That's Not Socialism
description: To the Editor:

title: It's Time For a Grandchild
description: I THINK I'm ready to be a grandmother. Lately I've caught myself exhibiting all the symptoms. I have that feeling of wanting to hold an infant in my arms again, watch its velvet hand grip my fingers.

title: All the Names Will Be New on the Nigerian Ballot
description: Two years from now, if all goes as scheduled, Nigeria will have a new national legislature, 21 new state governors and a new democratically elected President. What it does not have now are candidates for any of those jobs.

title:
DINING OUT;

New American Fare and Exciting View
description: LEAD: At last, a restaurant has opened on the west bank of the Hudson that is worthy of the spectacular midtown Manhattan view. Arthur's Landing, named after its owner, Arthur Imperatore, the developer, has a panoramic glass-walled outlook from the water's edge.

title: Dentists Are Lacking A Sense of Humor
description: As a faithful reader of Barbara Klaus's Long Island Sound columns from almost its inception, I was able to take her article ''Smile, Darn You Smile'' as I'm sure it was meant: a tongue-in-cheek poke at my profession containing many of the cliches about dentists that I have heard for years. This column was certainly not one of her most humorous, but I found myself chuckling in several places. However, I was shocked to read the vitriolic letters from my colleagues in the Dec. 24 Long Island section.

title: As the Sun Sets Slowly in the West . . .
description: Few home-grown myths have exerted a more powerful influence on popular culture than that of the American cowboy. Pictured as a heroic loner, a visionary frontiersman, a glamorous outlaw and a man's man in movies, television, songs and cigarette ads, he has stood as an icon of American masculinity for decades, though recently his supremacy has been challenged by fictional descendants from James Bond to Luke Skywalker, and revisionist historians have set about demolishing the romanticism of the Old West.

title: Unequal Collaborators
description: To the Editor:

title: Hambletonian Co-Winners
description: An administrative law judge on Friday declared Park Avenue Joe and Probe co-winners of the 1989 Hambletonian, but allowed the owners of Park Avenue Joe to keep 50 percent of the purse and owners of Probe to keep 25 percent.

title: Ellin Paquette to Wed F. C. Haab Jr.
description: Mr. and Mrs. Joseph F. Paquette Jr. of Gladwyne, Pa., have announced June wedding plans for their daughter Ellin Louise Paquette and Frederick Christian Haab Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Haab of Villanova, Pa., and St. Michaels, Md.

title: Beware The Lesser FSX Role
description: The unfortunate truth about the FSX agreement to jointly develop a new Japanese fighter plane is that it was a compromise that ended up pleasing almost no one. The agreement was a contravention of free trade principles, a waste of resources and an inefficient method of meeting our defense needs. It may be that no permutation of the FSX agreement to transfer American technology abroad would have adequately addressed these central objections.

title: JPW RAP MOVES TO TELEVISION'S BEAT
description: Ask most pundits about rap music, and they'll describe it as rude, jumbled noise. A few others may consider it million-selling post-modernism in audible form - songs as mix-and-match collages that treat the history of recorded music as a scrapheap of usable rubble and, often, trade narrative and logic for a patchwork of bragging, storytelling, speechifying and free-form rhymes.

title: New Haven in Cup Race
description: The New York metropolitan area may well be part of soccer's 1994 World Cup after all, if New Haven and the Yale Bowl can be considered part of the New York metropolitan area.

title: Bridge Loans Cast Shadows On the Street
description: Engineers demand firm foundations on both sides of a bridge. Investment bankers don't have engineering degrees. Shaky bridge loans these days have more than a few Wall Streeters quaking, and played a role in Friday's stock market tumble. Rising interest rates and worries over inflation also played a role, as producer prices were reported to have risen 4.8 percent in 1989, the largest annual gain since 1981. The interest-sensitive Dow Jones utilities average has fallen 6.1 percent so far in 1990, its worst fortnight since the 1987 crash. But fear that easy takeover financing is at an end may be the biggest reason that the Dow Jones industrial average ended the week down 84.04 points, to 2,689.21.

title: O'CONNOR ORDAINS A MARRIED PRIEST
description: Speaking just before the ordination of a married man with four children to the Catholic priesthood yesterday, John Cardinal O'Connor of New York said that the event did not augur any change in the Catholic Church's insistence that in most of its branches only men vowed to celibacy can serve as priests.

title:
Style Makers;

Roberto Lucifero, Designer of The Illusive
description: LEAD: Where do you turn when you're desperate for a papier-mache triumphal arch for the courtyard of your palazzo or you need someone to confect a l7th-century happening for you?

title: Martin Luther King: The Books Are Getting Better
description: Tomorrow is the fifth official celebration of the Martin Luther King holiday, and enough time may have passed for at least a preliminary reckoning of this new national institution. There has been a strained, showman's smile about the holiday since it sprang unexpectedly from Congress in 1983, as though in recompense for the 20-year institutional disengagement on most public issues touching race - from cities and transportation to schools. Under cover of his poise, President Ronald Reagan caught the hard, taut side of the national mood: he expressed doubt about King's fundamental loyalty to the United States on the very day he signed legislation establishing him among the Founding Fathers as a shrine of American democracy.

title: Maps That Try to Hide Their Age
description: IF the map says French Indochina, it is probably not the best one to buy for getting around in Southeast Asia. But failing such startling evidence of age, it is difficult these days to tell how old a map in a store may be. Copyright laws have been eased and some cartographers have been chary about saying how long it has been since a map was revised, even though it may have a fresh new design on the cover.

title: Wrong Place at the Wrong Time: Stray Bullets Kill More Bystanders
description: It was all over in a few seconds, but what lingers in Milord Bonny's mind is the sight of his 14-year-old grandson, sinking to his knees on a Brooklyn sidewalk.

title: Review/Theater;   'Jonquil,' the 3d Play in a Saga of Black History
description: With harshness as well as equanimity, Charles Fuller's ''Jonquil'' reveals the obstacles to full emancipation in the South immediately after the Civil War. Through a voting rights episode in a small South Carolina community, the author views the Reconstruction period as one of the uglier chapters in the nation's history. ''Jonquil,'' the third play in Mr. Fuller's projected five-play series about black Americans in the second half of the 19th century, opened Saturday at the Negro Ensemble Company.

title: More Than Housing
description: To the Editor:

title: Pennview Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
'Fourth of July' Unfair to Syracuse Police, Some Residents Say
description: A group of Syracuse residents led by a State Senator and former anti-war protester yesterday criticized the recently released film ''Born on the Fourth of July'' for what they say is an unfair and inaccurate depiction of their city police.

title: Review/Music;   A Glimpse of Azerbaijan
description: Nisim Nisimov came to New York to visit relatives, but when the World Music Institute found out he was in town, it booked him for the concert he played Friday night at the Washington Square Church.

title: Dreco Energy Services reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Results are in U.S. dollars. The company is listed on the Toronto Stock Exchange.

title: Laurence J. Peter Is Dead at 70; His 'Principle' Satirized Business
description: Laurence J. Peter, who climbed the best-seller lists with a book meant to satirize ladder climbers everywhere, died Friday at his home in Palos Verdes Estates, Calif. He was 70 years old.

title: How to Honor Dr. King
description: If the Rev. Martin Luther King Jr. were alive, how might he view the state of black America? It's presumptuous to say, but there are some clues in the legacy of his achievements that America honors today.

title: I.R.S. Has Plan to Prevent Misconduct by Its Workers
description: The Internal Revenue Service has announced a series of actions intended to prevent misconduct by its senior employees.

description: b-Included extraordinary credits of $17,347, or 1 cent a share, for the latest quarter and $9,227 for the year-earlier period. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: U.S. Foundations Seek an East Bloc Role
description: American foundations and research groups are playing an active role in shaping Eastern Europe's transition to free markets, even helping to draw up an economic action plan for the next Hungarian Government.

description: Figures for 1988 are on a pro forma basis. The company said pro forma income statements for 1988 were derived from combined historical statements of income from continuing operations of Southern Pacific Pipe Lines Inc. and San Diego Pipeline Co. and reflected certain pro forma ajustments as if transactions to form the partnership had occurred on Jan. 1, 1988. The partnership was formed on Dec. 19, 1988.
