title: Bulls-Knicks Is No Rematch
description: The last time the Knicks saw Michael Jordan was last May 19 at noisy Chicago Stadium in the sixth game of their Eastern Conference playoff semifinal. Rick Pitino was the Knicks' coach and Doug Collins was the coach of the Chicago Bulls. The Knicks relied heavily on pressure defenses and the Bulls on Jordan, then their point guard.

title: Bryn Mawr Bank Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Investors Defy Risks to Start Publishing Houses
description: The large publishers are worried about eroding profit margins, and the small publishers worry about cash flow and getting their books into stores. So it may be difficult to imagine why anyone would consider starting a book publishing company.

title: In Berlin, Kohl Nearly Walks Into Political Confrontation
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany made a surprise private visit to East Berlin today and almost bumped into one of his chief political adversaries.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Jan. 14, 1990:

title: U. of Michigan Fights the Taint of Racial Trouble
description: Three years ago, the University of Michigan was wrenched by a series of racial incidents that threatened its reputation for social tolerance and liberalism.

title: King's Birthday Today
description: Today is the birthday of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Here are holiday schedules.

title: James V. Delaney, Property Director, 28
description: James V. Delaney, an assistant acquisitions director for New York City's Division of Real Property, died of cancer Wednesday at Cabrini Medical Center. He was 28 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: IP Timberlands Ltd. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings are in class A depositary units.

title: Florio Plans An Assault On Poverty In the Cities
description: Governor-elect James J. Florio envisions an aggressive administration that will experiment with new approaches to protecting the environment and begin an assault on urban poverty.

title: Prescription Drugs Cheaper in Europe
description: To the Editor:

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Accounts
description: * Five Star Chevrolet/Geo Dealers Association of Pennsylvania, southern New Jersey and Delaware to Demaine, Vickers & Associates, Alexandria, Va., with a budget of $6 million.

title: Europe Taking a Lead in Growth
description: The benefits already flowing from the European Community's continuing effort to create a single market by 1992 and the changes in Eastern Europe are prompting economists to predict that Western Europe's economic growth will exceed that of the United States in the 1990's.

title: Planters Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
If Israel Put a Bounty on Arafat
description: LEAD: Suppose Israel put a bounty on Yasir Arafat - $1 million for anyone whose information led to bringing the chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization to justice in Jerusalem.

title: Review/Concert;   The Juilliard and Beethoven: Lasting Musical Symbiosis
description: In 43 years of existence, the Juilliard String Quartet has developed a highly varied repertory. Yet to the general public it remains best known for its periodic traversals of two standard bodies of literature, the 16 quartets of Beethoven and the six of Bartok. According to the program the Juilliard gave the first complete Beethoven cycle in New York in 1948-49, and has since played all 16 works more than a hundred times around the world.

title: The Pentagon Pool, Bottled Up
description: The invasion of Panama offered the first true test of the Pentagon's system for giving journalists access to live combat. The system failed. More precisely, the Pentagon failed the system. It is the President's job to make it work.

title: CHRONICLE
description: FRANCES LEHMAN LOEB and her family have given time and money to many things, including Lewisohn Stadium, Adele Lehman Hall at Barnard College, the Children's Zoo and the Loeb Boathouse in Central Park, and the Loeb Student Center at New York University.

title: Excerpts From a Speech by Gorbachev Before the Lithuanian Communists
description: Following are excerpts from an address by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev at a meeting with Communist Party dissidents in Lithuania on Saturday, as recorded and translated by Tass, the official Soviet press agency: A Time of Baltic Euphoria My stay in the republic and participation in this meeting, at which both wings of the Communist movement in Lithuania are present, indicates that you, comrades, have not yet got out of the state of euphoria and that it is so far difficult to direct the process of the comprehension of what is happening in your republic into a deeper channel.

title: CHRONICLE
description: It was an eventful weekend for TOM LANDRY, the legendary coach of the Dallas Cowboys for 29 years until he was dismissed last February by JERRY JONES, the team's new owner.

title: CHRONICLE
description: CHRISTOPHER MORRONGIELLO has won a 1990 Marshall scholarship for two or three years of study at the British university of his choice. He is the first lutanist, and only the eighth musician, to receive the award, established in 1953. The competitive scholarship is considered comparable to a Rhodes scholarship to Oxford.

title: Key to Sears Turnaround: Patience
description: Despite widespread pessimism over the prospects of Sears, Roebuck & Company, some industry experts think the nation's largest retailer has bottomed out and will eventually become the turnaround story of retailing in the 1990's.

title: Sports of The Times;   Joe Montana: Cleaner Than a Surgeon
description: MOST of his 49er teammates had the look of little kids who had been playing in Candlestick Park's muddy slick grass. They had mud on their scarlet jerseys, mud on their golden khaki pants. But as Joe Montana stood in the 49er locker room after yesterday's 30-3 dissection of the Rams, his pants had only a thin smudge along the right thigh (as if he had dried his passing hand there) and another smudge along the red stripe down his left leg. Some tiny splotches soiled his left kneecap. But the backside of his pants was as clean as if it had just come out of a washing machine.

title: American List Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Included income of $24,583, or 1 cent a share, (a loss of $45,746 from operations and a gain on disposal of $70,329) from discontinued operations.

title: Domco Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: The company said results in the latest quarter and year included about $3 million in writeoffs. Year-ago sales results were restated. Results are in Canadian dollars.

description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $1,165,000, or 7 cents a share, from non-recurring gains on the acquisition of loans from Yankee Bank and the sale of Cirrus to Mastercard. c-After extraordinary credits of $1,995,000, or 13 cents a share, for the quarter and $9,176,000, or 58 cents a share, for the year, both from non- recurring gains on the acquisition of loans from Yankee Bank and the sale of Cirrus to Mastercard.

title: Bill Auction Is Delayed Because of Holiday
description: The Treasury's schedule of issues this week is confined to tomorrow's auction of three- and six-month bills. The auction, normally held each Monday, will be delayed because today is Martin Luther King Day. Late Friday, the outstanding three-month bill was bid at 7.49 percent, while the six-month bill was bid at 7.44 percent.

title: A Painful Ending for Kosar
description: He had limped slowly off the field as someone else's celebration began. The small piece of rubber that had been taped to the base of the index finger on Bernie Kosar's right hand was no longer necessary to help him try to throw a football.

title: DFSoutheastern Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said there is no comparable share earnings information available for full year 1988. The company's Decatur Federal Savings & Loan Association completed its conversion from a mutual thrift institution to a stock thrift institution on Sept. 30, 1988.

title: NBS National Benefit Services reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Review/Dance;   Stephen Petronio Company In 2 Small-Scale Works
description: Stephen Petronio's choreography has been described as kamikaze ecstasy. And that about sums up the quality and look of ''Surrender II (Part 1)'' and ''Close Your Eyes and Think of England,'' works by Mr. Petronio that were performed by his company on Saturday night at the Joyce Theater (175 Eighth Avenue, at 19th Street), as part of the Man-Made festival.

title: 49ers and Broncos Go Marching Into the Super Bowl;   Denver Wins, 37-21, As Elway Sparkles
description: Three years ago, when the Denver Broncos beat the Cleveland Browns for the American Conference championship and a Super Bowl berth, they avoided defeat at the end of regulation time with what became known as the Drive. Two years ago in the championship game, the Broncos saved a victory over the Browns by recovering what became known as the Fumble.

title: American Medical Internaional reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net income The company said latest quarter figures included non-recurring costs of about $128.2 million relating to IMA Holdings Corp.'s buyout of about 86 percent of American Medical. Year-ago period results included $13 million in additional malpractice insurance provisions and $11 million in lease buyout costs.

title: Trump Group To Raze Hotel
description: Donald J. Trump said Saturday that he and his partners will raze the Ambassador Hotel, where Robert F. Kennedy was assassinated in 1968, to build a large commercial and residential complex.

title: Federal National Mortgage Assn reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said all share earnings results reflected a 3-for-1 common stock split approved in September 1989.

description: * Lord Einstein O'Neill & Partners has moved to 20 West 43d Street in Manhattan.

description: Danza, Schulman & Glennon Advertising is making its national advertising debut with a series of print ads for ''J.uK. Lasser's Your 1990 Income Tax,'' a book published by the Prentice Hall trade division of Simon & Schuster Inc. Illustrated by Robert Weber, a cartoonist for The New Yorker, the ads list some expenses that are deductible, like hair transplants, and some that are not, like entertainment during fishing trips.

description: b-Included an extraordinary credit of $76,026, or 1 cent a share. c-Net income The 1988 results represented a 10- month period. The company changed its fiscal year-end to Sept. 30 from Nov. 30. Figures are in Canadian funds.

Molinari Sworn As New Leader
description: ''Staten Island today has become a dirty island. It's something I'm not proud of.''

title: U.S. Restricts Valley Federal
description: The Valley Federal Savings and Loan Association has been declared a ''troubled institution'' by the Federal Office of Thrift Supervision and ordered to stop all new lending and investment.

title: Market Place;   Investors Relish Bet Against Japan
description: AMERICAN investors may buy Japanese cars, but they don't like Japanese stocks.

title: Ziegler Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
NASA Losing 30-Year Monopoly In Planning for Moon and Mars
description: The White House is reaching beyond NASA in a search for new ways to advance the nation's manned space program, challenging a near monopoly the agency has held for more than three decades. It is doing so mainly out of frustration with the agency's high cost estimates for space ventures.

title: International Data Group
description: International Data Group, a provider of information technology services, said Friday that it had formed a division, the IDG Book Company, to publish books on computer technology. The new company will be based in Mountain View, Calif. International Data, which has annual revenues of $500 million, is based in Framingham, Mass.

title: A Needed Revolution
description: On the anniversary of Martin Luther King's birthday, those who have grown complacent about the racial situation in America can find plenty of evidence - if they'll look - that his work is not finished, and nowhere less so than in education.

title: Review/Art;   Black Artists' Work Exhibited 'Against the Odds'
description: An exhibition that does honor to the Newark Museum, and to the museum profession in general, is ''Against the Odds: African-American Artists and the Harmon Foundation,'' which opens Monday. In the context of a museum in which American art of the 19th and 20th centuries is memorably well covered in the permanent collections, ''Against the Odds'' introduces us to a number of black artists with whose work few visitors will be familiar.

title: Belzberg Family Enters Bidding for Koor
description: The wealthy Belzberg family of Canada, known for its takeover forays, has become the latest bidder for Koor Industries, offering to buy Israel's troubled industrial concern for $130 million.

title: City National Corp. reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included non-recurring net income of $3,424,000 and $1,929,000, for the latest and year-ago periods, respectively. Share earnings are adjusted to reflect a stock split effected in the form of a 25 percent stock dividend paid Oct. 16, 1989.

title: Fifth Third Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago quarter and year results included after-tax gains of $1.4 million, or 4 cents a share, and $2.6 million, or 7 cents a share, respectively, from the sale of residual positions in equipment leased. Latest quarter and year results included after-tax gains of $1,432,000, or 4 cents a share, on certain pension settlements. Prior year results included an after- tax gain of $1,955,000, or 5 cents a share, on certain pension settlements. Year-ago quarter and full year results restated to include First Ohio Bancshares Inc. of Toledo, Ohio, acquired Nov. 30, 1989 and 1st Security Bank of Hillsboro, Ohio, acquired Dec. 13, 1989. Both acquisitions were accounted for as poolings of interest. Per share amounts for all periods adjusted to reflect the 3-for-2 stock split effected in the form of a stock dividend payable Jan. 13.

International Dairy Queen reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Quotation of the Day
description: ''There were leaflets all over the square, calling for the Armenians to be driven from the city. They listed the addresses of Armenian houses and apartments.''

title: Motive Remains a Mystery In Deaths That Haunt a City
description: After dinner at a restaurant last September, a close friend says, Charles Stuart complained that he had noticed something about his pregnant wife, Carol, that he had never seen before, ''that she had the upper hand'' in their marriage.

title: Gamez Wins In Debut
description: With his veteran opponents unable to apply any pressure, Robert Gamez, a PGA Tour rookie, coasted over his home course to a four-stroke victory today in the Tucson Open.

title: Liberty National Bancorp Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
In Refugee Community, Killings and a Healing
description: Any day now, Ing Khorn and her husband, Phoun Nam, are expecting a baby - a girl, they hope, to fill the void left when their 6-year-old daughter was killed a year ago by a deranged gunman who raked a schoolyard here with assault rifle fire.

title: New Government Starts To Put Panama on Track
description: Slowly, sometimes painfully, the new civilian Government here has begun grappling with the problems of getting post-Noriega Panama up and running again.

title: A Fishing Watch
description: rrA watch for fishermen has been designed to keep track of tides and temperatures as well as time. rrTimex has developed a timepiece called the Hooks. The watch is made with a thermometer for reading air or water temperature. The face of the watch has a ring for estimating tidal changes. By adjusting the bezel to a known tide, you can read the time at which to expect the next tide.

title: RIVAL SHIITES NEAR TRUCE IN LEBANON
description: Warring Muslim Shiite factions are close to an agreement to end three weeks of large-scale fighting in southern Lebanon, the spirtual mentor of the Iranian-backed Party of God said today.

title: Outdoors: Winter Travel, Step by Step
description: IF a desire to wander in the winter woods has been growing within you, snowshoes might be the way to go.

title: BB&T Financial reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
49ers and Broncos Go Marching Into the Super Bowl;   San Francisco Routs Rams, 30-3
description: It was billed as a battle for California bragging rights, as the real Super Bowl between the real heavyweights of pro football. But in the end, it was simply another display of San Francisco's mastery and might as the 49ers toppled the Los Angeles Rams by 30-3 here today before a Candlestick Park record crowd of 64,769 and claimed the National Conference championship for a second consecutive year.

title: First Wachovia Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said share earnings are adjusted for a 20 percent stock dividend during the third quarter of 1989.

title: Dallas Radio Station Sale
description: Shamrock Broadcasting Inc. in Burbank, Calif., the private investment arm of the Roy E. Disney family, said this week that it had agreed to sell its Dallas radio station, KMGC-FM, to Cook Inlet Partners L.P. for $22 million.

title: Banner Names President
description: Banner Industries appointed Emanuel J. Fthenakis as president and chief operating officer. Mr. Fthenakis will also continue as chairman and chief executive of Fairchild Industries, which Banner acquired last summer. The company also said it had appointed its vice chairman, Samuel J. Krasney, to the position of chairman and chief executive of Banner's aerospace distribution group.

title: New Parks Commissioner Has Opportunity to Do a Lot of Good
description: To the Editor:

title: A Capital Race: See Barry Run Hard
description: Although he continues to be dogged by speculation that he is finished politically, Marion S. Barry Jr. is forging ahead with plans to run for a fourth term as Mayor of the District of Columbia.

title: Venezuela Eases Rule
description: Venezuela's economic cabinet has agreed to ease regulations on foreign investment.

title: 3 LATIN LANDS JOIN U.S. IN A DRUG PACT
description: The United States and three cocaine producing nations, Bolivia, Colombia and Peru, tentatively agreed today to include military units from each country in a stepped-up war on drugs.

title: Collaborative Research Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 2
Review/Television;   In His Debut as Host, Koch Plays Alphonse to Dinkins's Gaston
description: Everybody knows you have to get up pretty early in the morning to outtalk Edward I. Koch. Now you have to get up early to hear and see him, too. At 8 A.M. yesterday, the former mayor made his debut as a television talk-show host. The weekly one-hour program, ''Channel 2 News Sunday Edition With Jim Jensen and Ed Koch,'' offered as its first guest Mayor David N. Dinkins.

title: Motorola Completes Shifts in Top Ranks
description: Motorola Inc., a leading maker of pagers and cellular telephones, has completed a long-planned management transition, with George M. C. Fisher succeeding Robert W. Galvin, son of the company's founder, as chairman.

title: First Financial Savings reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Attacks in Peru Drive Out Foreigners
description: The killing of two French sightseers in Peru's Andean highlands on Friday highlights how terrorist attacks are forcing a wide withdrawal of foreign aid workers, archeologists and tourists from remote areas of this country's mountainous interior.

title: Lift Manufacturing Ban on Phone Companies;   Trans-Soviet Cable
description: To the Editor:

title: Rage Over a Gas Pipeline Appears to Cool in Connecticut
description: When Hank Dutton moved to this rural, one-stoplight town two decades ago to start a 20-acre hobby farm, he never figured on sharing his prized back pasture with a 24-inch-wide natural-gas pipeline.

title: Michael Fuchs, Mover Who Led Archives, 78
description: Michael Fuchs, the president of Whitehall Business Archives, a pioneer in the storage of corporate records, died of a heart attack on Friday at St. Clare's Hospital. He was 78 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: SOVIET AZERBAIJAN IN ETHNIC TURMOIL
description: The southern Soviet republic of Azerbaijan has erupted in civil violence, leaving at least 25 people killed in the capital city, Baku, and several towns in disarray, official reports and residents reached by telephone said today.

title: Shelton Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
David Wells MacEachron, 66, Ex-Leader of the Japan Society
description: David W. MacEachron, who retired last year as president of the Japan Society after leading the nonprofit group for 15 years, died of colon cancer on Saturday at his home in Hastings-on-Hudson, N.Y. He was 66 years old.

title: A CEAUSESCU SON TO BE TRIED SOON
description: The trials of Nicolae Ceausescu's older son, of Communist cronies and of members of the Securitate police force are expected to begin this week, Rumanian state television said today.

title: In Each Corner, a Changed Challenger
description: THE policeman appeared at dinner time at Gerry Cooney's training camp in Scot-run, Pa. Gil Clancy, the trainer, was finishing his meal when the uniformed visitor asked him to step outside.

title: King's Son, in Yonkers, Rebukes City's Officials
description: Martin Luther King 3d, the eldest son of the slain civil rights leader, said today that it was a ''shame and disgrace'' that the City of Yonkers was still battling low-income housing 22 years after Congress passed the Fair Housing Act.

title: William G. Phillips, Lobbyist, 66
description: William G. Phillips, a lobbyist and former Congressional aide, died of heart failure Saturday at his office near the Capitol. He was 66 years old and lived in Potomac, Md.

title: Airlines Give Break To Business
description: A year after announcing tighter restrictions on many discount fares used by business travelers with an eye toward increasing revenue, the nation's airlines have been quietly giving large companies a break.

NORIEGA LAWYERS OBJECT TO PHOTO
description: Those who have any doubts about the identity of the country's best-known prisoner have only to pick up a newspaper, magazine or turn on the television for a mug shot of a chastened looking Manuel Antonio Noriega.

title: Suspend Shanahan, Nordiques Urge
description: Brendan Shanahan, an integral part of the Devils' top line, faces a suspension from the league for a high-sticking major penalty he drew in Saturday night's 5-4 triumph over the Nordiques in Quebec City.

title: Business Scene;   Are True Profits Falling or Rising?
description: CORPORATE profits are in decline. Company after company is reporting sinking net income and the trend seems certain to continue, given the weak economy. But there are several ways to measure profitability and some show American business to be in not such bad shape.

title: Panel Stresses Productivity In Budget Fight
description: New York City should increase the productivity of municipal workers by using more one-officer police cars, closing underused firehouses and introducing one-worker garbage trucks among other measures, a private budget-monitoring group urged in a report released yesterday.

title: Buchwald Ruling: Film Writers vs. Star Power
description: Art Buchwald's victory in court against Paramount Pictures cheered writers, who frequently complain that they are not given proper credit for their part in a movie's success.

title: River Forest Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
The Marketing Of a Legend
description: SECRETARIAT, the legendary Triple Crown winner who died in October at the age of 19, earned $1.3 million in his brief but brilliant racing career and perhaps $50 million in his 16 seasons at stud.

title: State Street Boston Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Review/Music;   Mozart to Neo-Baroque, By Boston Chamber Players
description: Alice Tully Hall, which bills itself as the home of the Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center, played host on Saturday evening to the Boston Chamber Music Society. Founded in 1981, evidently on the model of the Lincoln Center group, this society, too, is a malleable and somewhat unwieldy constellation of instrumentalists (a dozen, including three violinists and three pianists), but it is certainly no tired imitation. Indeed, as the New Yorkers, under the new direction of Fred Sherry, scrape off some of the barnacles of their own first two decades, with mixed results, the Bostonians appear shipshape.

title: 2 Children Are Killed In a Suspicious Blaze
description: Two children died last night in a fire dubbed suspicious by officials here, a police spokeswoman said.

title: Amid the Boos and Scuffles, It's Order on the Court!
description: ALONZO MOURNING walked across the Civic Arena floor one night last week and nodded sheepishly at John Clougherty, an official working the game between Georgetown and Pittsburgh. Then the 6-foot-10-inch Mourning, who towers over Clougherty by more than a foot, smiled at him in much the same way he might smile when he meets a new girlfriend's father: It was a show of respect.

title: Egypt Cotton Profits Off
description: Cotton, once known as Egypt's ''white gold,'' faces another year of much lower profits in 1989-90 as farmers grow less and imports rise. Cotton exports are expected to earn Egypt about $200 million this season, the Egyptian Cotton Authority said last week. That compares with about $300 million earned last season.

title: Comprehensive Care Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Included a pre-tax gain of $5 million related to the forgiveness of debt due First Hospital Corp. as a result of the termination of the reorganization agreement in October 1989; expenses related to the reorganization totaling about $1.2 million, and pre-tax losses on the sale and writedown of certain assets totaling about $4.3 million. c-Net income The company announced it has consummated the sale of its 70 percent interest in the BMC joint venture to Parkside Medical Services Corp. Revenues from BMC accounted for about 6 percent of the company's operating revenues for the 6 months ended Nov. 30, 1989.

title: A New Hands-On Manager For New York City Transit
description: When Alan F. Kiepper took over Houston's troubled mass transit system in 1982, he frequently visited the bus barns at 4 A.M. so he could personally diagnose the problems that were keeping vehicles from hitting the streets on time.

title: MINERS THREATEN NEW SOVIET STRIKE
description: The Siberian miners who started a nationwide coal strike last summer say they are likely to resume their walkout, in defiance of a Government ban, because life remains miserable for their families despite the Kremlin's promise of improvements within six months.

title: Metropolitan Federal S & L Assn reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income Latest quarter and 6 months included an added provision of $5 million for possible loan losses because of continued softness in the real estate sector.

title: About Face. . . .
description: FOR someone who ran the fastest 100-meter and 200-meter sprints in women's track last year, Dawn Sowell had a surprisingly cavalier attitude toward the starting blocks, those adjustable metal footplates sprinters push off from to begin a race.

title: Puberty Rite for Girls Is Bitter Issue Across Africa
description: In the sprawling cattle country of southwestern Kenya, a 12-year-old girl walked bravely along a dirt track, swathed in a brightly colored cloth and carrying an open black umbrella. Shilling notes dangled from her headgear, framing her face, as village people dressed in tree branches clapped and sang to her.

title: TCBY Enterprises Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30

description: To the Editor:

title: The Editorial Notebook;   Flavors of Capitalism
description: Free trade is best, everyone agrees, but what should the United States do when its partners distort trade by closing their markets or targeting special industries for support? The answer is a subject of hot debate, as demonstrated anew in a study group commissioned by the Twentieth Century Fund, a New York research foundation. The group divided so sharply it issued two reports, one favoring traditional free trade, the other calling for revision of trade policy.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-11

title: Disturbing Signs From the Bush Team
description: LEAD: During my 29 years in Washington, I believe I have learned to recognize certain early warnings of trouble in the behavior of a new Administration. Some are already evident in George Bush's.

description: All figures have been restated to reflect the acquisition of First National Bank of Cudahy, Wisc.

title: Fierce Football Battle Involves TV Rights
description: Negotiations for the rights to ''Monday Night Football,'' which ABC has owned for 20 years, are expected to be the most hotly contested portion of the television rights deal that executives of the National Football League are now informally discussing with broadcast and cable television networks.

title: Man Held in Death Of Mutilated Wife
description: The husband of a Brooklyn woman whose dismembered body was found burning on a deserted Bronx street turned himself in Saturday and was charged with murder, the police said.

title: Ruth Michelson Weds David A. Kahan
description: Ruth Leah Michelson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Mark Avram Michelson of Brookline, Mass., and David Alan Kahan, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Alfred Kahan of Brookline, were married yesterday at Congregation Mishkan Tefila in Newton, Mass. The ceremony was performed by the bride's grandfather Rabbi Avraham Freedman, assisted by Rabbi Gershon Gewirtz and Cantor Aryeh Finklestein.

title: Metro Matters;   Housing Project Poses Quandary: Is It Affordable?
description: It was, Mayor Edward I. Koch declared at City Hall, ''probably the single most important announcement in the last five years made here in this room.''

title: U.S. Acknowledges Arrest of Agent
description: United States officials confirmed today that the Soviet Union had arrested an American agent working deep within the Soviet bureaucracy, and expressed mild surprise that the Russians had made public his capture.

description: The Federal case against a Luxembourg bank charged with money laundering has opened a window on the international finances of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, prompting bank lawyers to threaten to detail the financial relationship between the former Panamanian leader and the United States.

title: Rangers Beat Flyers in Overtime, 4-3
description: Ken Wregget, the goaltender for the Flyers, never saw the shot. As for the Rangers, it was a shot that before last night they had seen perhaps only in their wildest dreams.

description: Arthur Laurents wrote the book for the Broadway musical ''Gypsy,'' which opened in 1959 and which starred Ethel Merman. He also directed the current revival, which opened to critical acclaim this season at the St. James Theater and which stars Tyne Daly. And he has no doubts about which he prefers.

title:
SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS: BASEBALL;

Souvenir Drama
description: LEAD: THE playwright James O'Connor, a Mets fan and longtime season-ticket holder, often wondered what would happen if a fan refused to give up a record-breaking baseball. He wrote to the late baseball commissioner, A. Bartlett Giammati, whom he said replied that there are no historic precedents; in the past, baseballs have been returned.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Coghlan Rolls in Comeback
description: The test came with about 60 meters to go. Three laps before, in his first 3,000-meter race of the indoor season Friday night, Eamonn Coghlan had moved from third to second and now was chasing down the leader, Graeme Fell, the Canadian steeplechase champion.

title: School Spurs Alumni Gifts To Neediest
description: Some lessons imparted by a school and its teachers last for decades. Many letters to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund from graduates of the Horace Mann School in Riverdale, recall the impact of William J. Nagle, who taught Latin and Greek there from 1911 to 1952 and was head of the classical languages department.

title: Car Reported Stolen Leads Jersey Police On a 60-Mile Chase
description: A car reported stolen in Pennsylvania led the New Jersey State Police on a cross-state chase, reaching speeds of more than 115 miles an hour, that began in Trenton yesterday morning and ended with the car crashing at a roadblock near the Holland Tunnel in Jersey City.

title: First Derby Prep to 16-1 Shot
description: Run Turn, a 16-to-1 shot who began his career as a $30,200 claimer, pulled away from seven rivals today to score a surprising 4 1/4-length victory in the $110,700 Tropical Park Derby at Calder Race Course.

title: Corrections
description: A brief article in the Sports section yesterday about the lottery for tickets to the N.C.A.A. Eastern Regional tournament at the Meadowlands gave incorrect dates for the mailing of ticket requests. The requests must be postmarked no earlier than Jan. 14 and no later than Jan. 21.

title: Reporter's Notebook;   Amid the Jealousies, a Suspicion That the U.N. Works
description: ''A dangerous place'' - that was how Daniel Patrick Moynihan described the United Nations when he served there as the United States representative in the mid-1970's, a time of ferocious East-West rivalry.

title: Results Plus

title: Weapons Plant Workers Contract a Lung Disease
description: Twelve people who were exposed to the metal beryllium while working at the Rocky Flats nuclear weapons plant have contracted an incurable lung disease, according to an Energy Department study obtained by a newspaper.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary by The Associated Press on Tuesday about Temple H. Buell, a Denver architect and developer, referred incompletely to a philanthropic venture. In the 1960's Mr. Buell announced a $25 million donation to Colorado Women's College, which renamed itself Temple Buell College. The money was to be presented posthumously, but other donors, apparently unaware of this, stopped contributions. The trustees decided to refuse the gift and resumed the old name. The college was eventually dissolved because of financial problems.

title: Met-Coil Systems Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
OUST COMMUNISTS, SOFIA CROWD YELLS
description: More than 50,000 people sang, cheered and shouted anti-Communist slogans today in a demonstration demanding more radical democratic reforms and a fair deal in elections this year.

title: Cairo Journal;   For Women Only: A Train Car Safe From Men
description: When the idea was first put into effect on Cairo's rapid transit system, some said it would mean the creation of a kind of harem on wheels. Others said it just wouldn't work.

title: As Before, Blazers Stop Nets
description: Tonight was another occasion on which Buck Williams was happy he no longer plays for the Nets.

description: More than five years after John McEnroe won his last Grand Slam title, he is not fooling himself about his chances of winning another in the heat of the Australian Open, which starts Monday.

title: Rise in Rates Is Expected To Continue

description: The cleanup of more than 500,000 gallons of heating oil pumped through a leaky Exxon pipeline into the Arthur Kill has begun to wind down, state and Coast Guard officials said yesterday.

title: Philips Deal Is Stopped
description: Philips Industries, a Dayton-based manufacturer, said Friday that a planned merger for $24 a share, or $672 million, with a unit of Merrill Lynch & Company would not go through as scheduled because of problems with financing.

title: Glanville to Coach Falcons
description: Jerry Glanville, who won games and lost his job with the Houston Oilers, became coach of the Atlanta Falcons today.

title: Review/Concert;   Music of Afghanistan With Indian Influences
description: As part of the New Americans series of the World Music Institute, Ezzatullah Mojaddidi, an Afghan now living in California, came to New York City on Saturday night and rocked Washington Square Church. Playing the dutar, a giraffe-necked 14-string lute, and accompanied by a group of musicians, Mr. Mojaddidi turned in a raucous, improvisatory performance that had the audience clapping along.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   An Agency As Depicted On a TV Hit
description: MYSTICAL and manipulative, Miles Drentell is every advertising person's nightmare: an agency boss who speaks in epigrams, pits copywriters against art directors and has a god complex that rivals that of a minor deity.

description: The percentage of low- and middle-income black and Hispanic youths entering college from high school declined sharply in the past decade, the American Council on Education reports.

description: 100 in Both Leagues

description: The boyfriend of a 22-year-old woman who disappeared in November confessed to her strangulation after her remains were discovered, the Suffolk County police said yesterday.

title: Washington Talk;   Scoring Political Points On Social Security Tax
description: Despite Republican claims, Federal taxes over all were not cut in the Reagan-Bush years. But Democrats have failed to persuade voters of that, or to call attention to the way the mix of taxes has changed.

title: Hong Kong Extending Its Reach
description: After enjoying extremely rapid growth in this territory, many large Hong Kong companies are looking abroad to find new sources of profits. But instead of going north to China, as they used to, many are reaching far in other directions.

title: Review/Television;   Recalling the Pursuit of a Still-Elusive Prize
description: In the mid-1960's, the civil rights movement, which had seemed on a victorious course, was dramatically split. Black Muslims, drawing support from inner-city ghettos, where hard conditions had not been alleviated by the triumphs in the courts, brought to the field a new antiwhite militancy that stirred many young blacks. That militancy disturbed older followers of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. and it shook white liberals.

title: 43 Die in Fire at Spanish Discotheque
description: An electrical fire broke out in a discotheque here early today, giving off poisonous smoke that killed 43 people and injured 3 others, officials said.

title: U.S. Soldiers Detain Cuban
description: American soldiers briefly detained the Cuban ambassador today, officials said. It was the second time the envoy, Lazaro Mora Secades, was stopped and searched since the Dec. 20 American invasion to oust Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega. The Cuban Embassy has given refuge to the general's family.

title: JAPAN STILL WARY OF LOANS TO CHINA
description: Despite the lifting of martial law in Beijing last week, Government officials say Japan is not prepared to resume talks on arranging $5.6 billion in loans suspended after the Chinese crackdown in Tiananmen Square in June.

description: Dr. Marian Paula Markowitz and Dr. Alan David Haber were married yesterday at the Harrison (N.Y.) Jewish Center by Rabbi Arnold Turetsky.

description: The latest share earnings is after capital gain distributions of $1.36 a share paid in 1989. Assets represents net assets.

title: Mount Everest Not for Experts Only
description: IT'S easy to find ways to stay fit these days. But the opportunity to face the ultimate measure of physical fitness, nature itself, comes less frequently.

description: ALISON LELAND, the widow of Mickey Leland, the Texas Congressman, had twins yesterday in Atlanta. The night before, she accepted a Salute to Greatness award from the Martin Luther King Center for Non-Violent Social Change, on behalf of her late husband.

title: Runners Keep in Step As Time Marches On
description: WHILE cross-training and easy-does-it running will continue to mark fitness programs in the 1990's, there are still individuals who run every day and prosper from it. At this time of year, that approach comes under scrutiny because January is when some runners pledge to run every single day without a voluntary break.

title: Cleanup of Waste Site Criticized by Residents
description: The Industrial Excess Landfill, an aptly named pit that sits amid Amish farmhouses and suburban homes, is packed with chemicals that are contaminating underground water and tainting the air in this semirural community.

description: In West Germany as in East Germany, the euphoria of last year's grand German reunion has given way in the new year to some hard reassessments, tough politicking and even anxiety.

description: Not every runner can tolerate the stress of daily workouts. If you feel you can, keep the following suggestions in mind.

title: President Is Appointed At Beal Securities Firm
description: M. R. Beal & Company, a securities firm in New York that is owned by women and members of minority groups, has named Diana L. Taylor president. Ms. Taylor was among the founders of the firm in June 1988. she said that so far, helping run her own business has been fun, because the firm's success has surpassed the founders' hopes. ''We've been having a great time,'' she said. ''There's nothing more rewarding than being part of a growing business. It's had its ups and downs, as any business will, but over all, it's been a lot of fun.''

description: A ferry carrying about 150 people sank tonight in a river outside Dhaka, and about 50 passengers reportedly swam to shore, the police said.

The provision for credit losses for 1989 totaled $2.045 billion, compared with $200 million in 1988. There was no latest fourth quarter provision for credit losses, but the year-ago period totaled $100 million.

title: Review/Pop;   Lambada, Would-Be Craze by Way of Paris
description: The pop version of lambada, a prefabricated dance craze hoping to happen, arrived in New York when Kaoma performed at the Palladium on Friday night. Kaoma - a Paris-based group that includes musicians from Brazil, Africa, the Caribbean and France - has sold four million copies of its single ''Lambada'' since its release in Europe last summer. The song is an international hybrid, a digital-era French production of an eminently catchy Bolivian melody featuring the sound of a button accordion, lyrics in Portuguese, and a version of the lambada rhythm that originated in northeastern Brazil.

title: Homer G. Bishop, 57, Commander Of Firefighters in New York City
description: Fire Chief Homer G. Bishop, the highest-ranking commander among New York City's uniformed firefighters, died early yesterday at Mount Sinai Hospital in Manhattan. He was 57 years old and lived in Middle Village, Queens.

title: SI Handling Systems Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 26
60 Gunmen Seize Tourists, Destroying Homes in Corsica
description: About 60 masked gunmen burst into a vacation camp on this island today and held tourists at gunpoint while they set off explosives to destroy vacation homes.

title: First Empire State reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $9,455,000 from an adjustment in accounting. The company said it adopted the accounting adjustment in December and applied its affect to 1989 first quarter results, which have been restated. First Empire said latest quarter earnings improved over the year-ago period primarily because of pre-tax charges in year-ago quarter of $2,803,000 from losses on the sale of bank investment securities and $1,750,000 for restructuring costs.

title: Companies
description: A bank syndicate extended a deadline for Campeau's retailing operations. The American and Japanese banks, which are owed $2.34 billion, gave Federated Department Stores and Allied Stores until Friday to provide assurances that the nine department store chains they own are solvent, banking and retailing executives said. The banks' decision came after Federated and Allied said they hoped to name a new American chief executive with a merchandising background some time this week. Despite the four-day extension, financial and retailing executives said they expected Campeau to file for bankruptcy protection sometime this week. [Page A1.]

title: Review/Television;   'Unspeakable Acts': Sex Abuse in Day Care
description: Sexually abused children: few subjects lend themselves more notoriously to cheap exploitation. On television, the social nightmare has been explored in movies and on talk shows, many of them clearly more interested in sensationalism than in illumination. At least one talk host has brought on young victims and, clearly with ratings in mind, encouraged them to go into excruciating details in front of the cameras. Care and sensitivity are too often at a premium.

title: Corrections
description: A chart on Sunday headed ''Jobless Rate in the Region,'' about three southern oil-producing states, mislabeled the yearly bars showing unemployment rates. A corrected version appears today on page A18.

title: Nicaragua Watchers
description: To the Editor:

title: Commerce Bancshares reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Painting Slashed at Modern
description: A Marcel Duchamp painting in the museum of Modern Art was slashed late last month, museum officials confirmed yesterday.

title: Business and Health;   Health Insurers' Changing Role
description: HEALTH-INSURANCE executives say their business has changed radically in the last two years in the nation's struggle with double-digit growth in medical spending. Many insurers say their traditional work of assuming risks has been eclipsed by services to help their customers' health dollars go further.

title: South Carolina Coach Courts Local Players
description: South Carolina has not had a player from the New York City area make a significant contribution since Mike Doyle of the Bronx averaged 12.6 points in 1979-80. It is noteworthy because of the legacy of Frank McGuire.

title: French Airline Deal Inquiry
description: The European Community's Executive Commission said today that it would investigate Air France's planned takeover of the private French airline U.T.A. to see if it violated the community's laws on monopolies.

title: Judge Quickly Assumes Active Role in the Stores
description: In signing five orders yesterday morning, a Federal bankruptcy judge in Cincinnati quickly showed how involved he would be in the operations of one of the world's largest retailing empires.

title: Lawyers for Noriega to Seek His Release on Bail
description: In a reversal of legal tactics, lawyers for Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega said today that they would argue that their client be freed on bail.

title: Communications Transmision Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: The company said consolidated losses for fiscal 1990 included 100 percent of the loss reported by the company's subsidiary, ALC Communications Corp. Communications Transmission is required to report 100 percent of ALC's losses rather than the company's about 55 percent equivalent common stock ownership percentage in accordance with accounting rules. In the prior year period, Communications Transmission was not required to report all of ALC's losses.

title: TRC Cos. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income TRC said the loss is a direct result of actions taken at its wholly owned Metatrace Inc. unit.

title: Opera Is Ready for a Comeback in the Amazon
description: Battling tropical termites and jungle humidity, workers and engineers are bringing this city in the heart of the rain forest ever closer to realizing its perennial dream of once again hearing opera in the Amazon.

title: United's Pilots Working on Deal
description: The leaders of the United Airlines pilots' union said their governing body will meet Jan. 24 to put together an employee stock ownership plan to buy the UAL Corporation, the carrier's parent. The meeting is a day before UAL's board is to receive a recapitalization plan from its bankers.

title: Troubled 'Annie 2' Closing Out of Town; Revisions Planned
description: ''Annie 2: Miss Hannigan's Revenge'' is not coming to Broadway this season, its producers announced yesterday. Instead, they are hoping to bring a revival of the original ''Annie'' to Broadway in the spring.

title: News Summary
description: International A3-13

title: In the Ebb and Flow Of Ancient Glaciers, Clues to Next Ice Age
description: THE climatic history of the last half-million years is largely a history of ice and cold, punctuated every 100,000 years or so by brief, glorious intervals of unusual warmth called interglacials. If nature takes its course, scientists say, the current interglacial - the one in which human civilization developed - should begin to end within the next 2,000 years or sooner. But nature may not take an unaltered course. Unprecedented concentrations of heat-trapping carbon dioxide in the atmosphere could extend the present interglacial by a millennium or more and transform it into a ''super-interglacial'' with average global temperatures higher than any seen in the last million years, say a number of scientists who study the advance and retreat of the great glaciers.

title: Computer Failure Disrupts A.T.&T. Long Distance
description: Millions of people were unable to make long-distance calls yesterday after the American Telephone and Telegraph Company suffered a major failure in the computer program that operates its new long-distance switching equipment.

title: Davox Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss c-Included a non-recurring, restructuring charge of $1,750,000 for the quarter and year.

title: Sagan Urges Clerics to Join To Save Globe
description: CARL SAGAN, a professor of astronomy and director of the Laboratory for Planetary Studies at Cornell University, appealed yesterday for religion and science to join hands in preserving the global environment. He was joined in his appeal by 22 well-known scientists.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc., New York, named James Ednie and Rosemary Johnson senior vice presidents. Kurt Feuerman, Philip W. Friedman and Nicholas P. Heymann were appointed managing directors.

title: Chase Profit Off in Period; Loss for Year
description: The Chase Manhattan Corporation, parent of the Chase Manhattan Bank, reported yesterday that fourth-quarter profits fell 36.4 percent and that it had a loss for the year.

title: First Capital Corp. reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Senator's Troubles Test Minnesotans' Tolerance
description: In a state that likes to think of its politics as especially clean and genteel, Minnesota Democrats see special opportunities in Senator David Durenberger's problems.

title: On 59th St., The Topic Is a Hot One
description: The Campeau Corporation's decision to put its American department stores into Chapter 11 bankruptcy proceedings was topic No. 1 on both sides of the counters at Bloomingdale's yesterday.

title: Review/Television;   Life Since the Intifada, As Viewed by Israelis
description: Whatever else it does or fails to do, ''A Search for Solid Ground'' lets viewers know from the start what they are getting. The hourlong documentary, at 8 tonight on Channel 13, carries the subtitle ''The Intifada Through Israeli Eyes.'' It opens with a statement that no Palestinians have been interviewed and that this program offers the perspective of mainstream Israelis on the Palestinian uprising, or intifada, which began in December 1987 in the West Bank and Gaza Strip. Given that intention, ''Solid Ground'' is a most effective piece of work.

title: U.S. Can Help Soviet Private Entrepreneurs;   Don't Listen, Lithuania
description: To the Editor:

title: McEnroe Displays Top Form And Gains
description: John McEnroe, showing his old artistry and a renewed commitment to reach the top of the tennis world again, gave a virtuoso performance today in his first-round match at the Australian Open.

title: The Breed Lives On
description: Not all European Stalinist heads have rolled. As a French commentator said, Georges Marchais's advantage is that he is not in power so he can't be brought down by hundreds of thousands demonstrating in the streets.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article yesterday about the aftermath of a shooting spree that killed Cambodian refugee children last year in Stockton, Calif., misstated the number of Southeast Asian children injured. Of the 29 who were hurt, 21 were Southeast Asians.

title: Learonal Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Europe Wary On New Ties
description: The European Community told the six European Free Trade Association nations today that it would not be pushed into a hasty agreement on closer ties.

title: Data Translation Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Upheaval in the East: Bulgaria;   BULGARIAN PARTY LOSES DOMINANCE
description: This country today became the last of the Soviet Union's East European allies to strip the Communist Party of its dominant role, following the others in a halting transition to multiparty democracy.

title: Books of The Times;   The Story of How ABC Plunged From the Mountain
description: Beyond Control

title: Intech Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 8
description: b-Net loss Year-ago share earnings adjusted for 5 percent stock dividend paid in September 1989.

title: Landmark Graphics Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $314,000, or 5 cents a share.

title: Hong Kong and Britain Faulted on Boat People
description: Amnesty International sharply criticized Hong Kong and Britain today for what it said were policies that put Vietnamese boat people who deserved to be treated as political refugees at risk of being returned to Vietnam to face persecution.

title: DMI Furniture Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 2
description: The company said share earnings assumes conversion of convertible stock into common.

title: Sandy Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net loss Results for year-ago quarter were affected by costs associated with restructuring.

title: Charles Rex Jr. Weds Miss Bothamley
description: Elizabeth Anne Bothamley, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Merrill Bothamley of Newport Beach, Calif., was married yesterday to Charles Gordon Rex Jr., a son of Betty Soubricas of Fairfield, Pa., and the late Mr. Rex. The ceremony was performed in New York at St. Patrick's Cathedral by the Rev. Christopher Maloney, a Roman Catholic priest, and the Rev. Dr. James Boice, a Presbyterian minister.

title: Lindsay Manufacturing reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Automatic Data reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said during the latest quarter it repurchased about 1.7 million shares and issued about 3.5 million shares on conversion of its 6 percent convertible subordinated debentures.

title: Ihsan Abdel Kuddous, An Egyptian Writer, 71
description: Ihsan Abdel Kuddous, an Egyptian journalist, novelist and short-story writer, died last Thursday after suffering a stroke. He was 71 years old. Mr. Abdel Kuddous, whose works were translated into several languages, also wrote regular syndicated columns in Cairo's Government-owned newspapers and magazines. In his column, ''At a Cafe on Politics Street,'' he addressed current issues through the device of customers talking in a cafe.

title: 4 Men Convicted in Drug Case
description: Four men were convicted today in a major drug smuggling operation, but 16 other defendants in the 2 1/2-month-long trial were found not guilty.

title: Raychem Chief Foresees No 'Giant Revolution'
description: The Raychem Corporation said yesterday that Robert J. Saldich had been named president and chief executive, effective April 1. Based in Menlo Park, Calif., Raychem manufactures products for the aerospace, automotive, electronics and telecommunications industries.

title: Our Towns;   In Greenwich, Teen-Agers Want Their Own Room
description: For four years, Emily Rosen, who is 17 years old and a senior at Greenwich High School, has been trying to get a teen center built in this pleasant Fairfield County town of 60,000.

title: Stocks End Broadly Lower; Dow Off 19.84
description: Stocks fell broadly yesterday in slow trading as many investors observed the Martin Luther King Day holiday.

title: Campbell Soup's New Chief Offers Strategy for Growth
description: In an energetic first day in office, David W. Johnson, the Campbell Soup Company's new president and chief executive, outlined his plans to revitalize the big food company, pledging to maintain its independence and to increase profits by curbing costs and possibly pruning operations.

title: KEY RATES
Key Tronic Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 16
Hispanic People Victimized More by Crime, Study Shows
description: Hispanic Americans were more likely than others to be victims of violent crimes, particularly robbery, in the seven years ending in 1986, the Justice Department reports.

title: King World Productions reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Included an increase in income of $2,905,000, or 11 cents a share, from the cumulative effect of a change in accounting for income taxes.

title: Montana-Elway Matchup
description: Although the championship game of the National Football League is known as the Super Bowl, it has rarely been super. It has often been a blowout, and it may be a blowout when the San Francisco 49ers meet the Broncos on Jan. 28 in New Orleans.

title: Blind Rape Victim Identifies Suspect by Scent and Touch
description: A blind woman has identified a 14-year-old boy as the person who allegedly raped her by smelling his cologne and touching his hands, the police say.

title: Investor Cools On Bond Bid
description: A little-known investor, Jeff Reynolds, said Friday that he would probably withdraw his proposal to buy a majority stake in Bond Corporation Holdings Ltd., the ailing Australian business empire.

title: Amtrak Presses Northeast Strategy, But Riders and Rivals Seem Unfazed
description: With Amtrak nearing profitability, its managers are looking to several areas to push the railroad into the black, and one of their best hopes is the market now dominated by the Washington-to-New York air shuttles.

title: Disaster Aid for Florida
description: President Bush today declared part of Florida a major disaster area from the freeze last month that devastated citrus and other crops. John Herrick, a White House spokesman, said the declaration covers the counties of Broward, Collier, Dade, Hendry, Lee, Monroe and Palm Beach. It makes those left without jobs by the freeze eligible for unemployment compensation and other Federal assistance.

title: King Holiday Observances Point Out Both Pain and Triumphs
description: In a day dominated as much by the pain of the present as the triumphs of the past, the nation yesterday marked the fifth anniversary of the Martin Luther King Jr. National Holiday on what would have been his 61st birthday.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A.

title: Mexico Calls Slain U.S. Drug Agent a Trafficker
description: In a bitter manifestation of growing tension with the United States over cooperation in fighting drug trafficking, Mexico's Government-owned television network has accused an American drug agent who was slain here of having been part of a major cocaine smuggling ring and of having used his position to blackmail drug dealers and enrich himself.

title: Egypt Said to Routinely Use Torture Against Its Prisoners
description: An Egyptian human rights group charges that torture and sexual abuse of prisoners has become so widespread that it ''now appears to be a matter of policy by security forces'' holding those detained both for political and nonpolitical reasons.

title: Streptococcal Infections Are Rising in U.S.
description: Serious streptococcal infections, including strep throat and rheumatic fever, are on the rise and have re-emerged as a public health problem, Federal health officials say.

title: Patricia Clark Greene, Volunteer, 64
description: Patricia Clark Greene, former president of the Rehearsal Club, a low-cost residence for women in the performing arts, died on Friday at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center after a long illness. She was 64 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Banc One Corp., Columbus, Ohio, said it would extend until the end of January its acquisition of MCorp's failed Texas bank from the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp.

title: Mission West Properties reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Included a $786,000 provision for losses in the third quarter. c-Net income

title: Housing Police Ask Merger With New York Force
description: The head of the union that represents New York City housing police officers called yesterday for a merger of that force with the city's Police Department.

title: To Help New Democracies, Cut Aid to Israel, 4 Others
description: It's always a little risky to predict history's verdict on contemporary events. But even from today's sometimes shortsighted perspective, it is safe to declare 1989 as one of the watershed years of the 20th century - the year in which Communism collapsed and the long dormancy of freedom suddenly and dramatically blossomed in places from Poland to Panama.

title: Q&A
description: ''Even birds that don't have an obvious crest will be seen to raise the feathers on their heads when interacting,'' Mr. Nutter added.

title: Carbide Defends Bhopal Settlement
description: The Union Carbide Corporation said a $470 million settlement for victims of the industrial disaster in Bhopal, India, was binding even though the country's new Government had disavowed it. ''There is simply no basis for overturning it,'' said Joseph E. Geoghan, Union Carbide's vice president and general counsel.

title: Careers;   Recruiting Trends for The Decade
description: THE growing trend of companies' hiring outside managers is expected to be a leading trend of the 1990's, Richard M. Ferry of Korn Ferry International, the largest management recruiting firm, said recently.

title: Number of Grade I Stakes Reduced
description: For the last three years, a very small band of racing critics has complained that the American racing calendar is bloated with second-rate or redundant races masquerading as Grade I events. Finally, the people who assign the roman numerals to the year's most important races have listened, agreed and acted.

title: Bridge
description: Two players from Schenectady, N.Y., who have won World Team titles, captured the Regional Knockout Team title in Port Chester, N.Y., on Sunday.

title: Scientists Learn to 'Listen' for Avalanches
description: AVALANCHE warnings can be improved by using special microphones that detect low-frequency sounds from more than 50 miles away, a research team has reported.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption with the television listings yesterday about Gordon Parks misstated his contribution to the ballet ''Martin.'' He wrote the music; the choreographer was Rael Lamb.

title: Optek Technology reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 27
description: b-Included tax credits of $150,893, or 4 cents a share, and $360,433, or 11 cents a share, for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Net income

title: Fielder Rejoins Majors And Signs With Tigers
description: In 1988, Cecil Fielder batted .230 and hit 9 home runs in 74 games for the Toronto Blue Jays. Then he left the major leagues and played in Japan last year. Now he is coming back to the majors - with the Detroit Tigers - and he is coming back a lot wealthier.

title: New Producer for 'Today'
description: NBC News announced today that Tom Capra would become executive producer of the ''Today'' show on Jan. 29, replacing Marty Ryan. The change is part of an overhaul of the top-rated morning program, which has already added a senior executive in charge of the program, Dick Ebersol, and a new co-host, Deborah Norville.

title: Marjorie Van Ness, 75; Served on Farm Board
description: Marjorie Schuyler Van Ness, the first woman to be appointed to the New Jersey Board of Agriculture, died on Saturday at her horse farm in Raritan Township in Hunterdon County. She was 75 years old.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''The cataclysmic changes we have seen in Eastern Europe, in China and South Africa since last year have deep roots in this very pulpit.''

title: Market Place;   Manager Favors Depressed Bonds
description: CLOSED-END bond funds have been an out-of-favor investment category shunned by many analysts for the last six months. But while others have been selling these funds, Thomas J. Herzfeld Advisors of Miami has been buying them since mid-December. In Mr. Herzfeld's view, they offer the best bargains in the closed-end market these days.

title: Publishers Honor Editor Of Good Housekeeping
description: What is bad for network television is good for magazines, said John Mack Carter, and that means magazines are feeling pretty good. ''I don't see publishers going out now with the fear they had a few years ago,'' said the editor in chief of Good Housekeeping, who will be honored tonight by the Magazine Publishers of America with its highest honor, the Henry Johnson Fisher Award.

title: Huskies Jump Out Early And Upset Orangemen
description: Chris Smith and Tate George scored 17 points apiece as Connecticut led almost the entire way tonight and beat Syracuse, 70-59.

title: Todd-AO Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
44 Injured in Italian Theft
description: A holdup went awry today when an explosive that robbers planned to used to blast open a safe went off prematurely, injuring 44 people in a crowded post office, the police said. Among the wounded were retirees lining up to receive their monthly pension payments, the police said.

title: Petroleum & Resources reports earnings for As of Dec 31
description: Assets represented net assets. Share earnings for latest period is after capital gain distributions of $1.20 paid in 1989 and $29,895,000 stated value $1,575 convertible preferred stock outstanding.

title: Capitals Will Try Another Murray
description: The Washington Capitals dismissed Bryan Murray as their coach yesterday and replaced him with his brother, Terry Murray.

title: Octel Communications Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Cherry Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net income

title: 23 Are Killed as Jet Crashes South of Costa Rican Capital
description: A twin-engine commuter airplane carrying 23 people crashed into a mountain in driving rain shortly after takeoff near here this morning, killing all aboard, officials said.

title: First Citizens Bancshares reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Shuttle Is Troubled Briefly By Phantom Sensor Signals
description: The astronauts on the space shuttle Columbia pursued a series of experiments today after their sleep was interrupted by an alarm signaling a brief problem with a navigation system.

title: Unusual Microbe, Once Dismissed, Is Not Taken More Seriously
description: EVIDENCE suggests that a mysterious microbe, whose discovery three years ago was dismissed as a finding of no significance, can cause disease among AIDS patients and even kill people not infected with the AIDS virus. Laboratory tests hint that several antibiotics could control the microbe, but this and other findings need to be confirmed.

title: Dinkins Says an Increase In Property Taxes Is Possible
description: Mayor David N. Dinkins, in his strongest statements yet on the prospect of new taxes to balance New York City's budget in the coming fiscal year, said yesterday that higher property taxes were a real possibility.

title: Upheaval in the East: Siberia;   Miner Guards Flame of a Rustic Past
description: Over the hard Siberian horizon beyond the frozen river, legions of families must wait in the city 10 years or more on a Government list simply to move from their one-room apartments to a two-room existence in the soulless tenement towers of Communism.

title: U.S. IS SAID TO LAG IN SCHOOL SPENDING
description: The United States spends relatively less on elementary and secondary education than do 13 other industrial countries, according to a report made public today.

title: Lexington Precision Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net income and after an extraordinary loss of $175,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary credit of $150,000, or 4 cents a share, for the 6 months. Lexington Precision said it results included a net gain of $323,000 in the latest quarter and a net loss of $233,000 in the year-ago quarter from the sale of marketable securities. The company said for the 6 months it recorded net gains of $382,000 for 1989 and $3,991,000 for 1988 from the sale of marketable securities. It also recorded direct charges to stockholders equity of $724,000 in the latest quarter and $1,242,000 in the latest 6 months to reduce the carrying value of common stock held for long- term investment purposes.

title: Chase Manhattan Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included total $1.26 billion third quarter after-tax provision, which included a possible additional to reserves for possible credit losses relating to Chase's extension of credit to LDCS, an $85 million after-tax charge relating to real estate assets in Chase's Arizona banking subsidiary, and a $25 million charge related to restructuring of its securities business. c-Included a gain of $217 million from the collection of interest from Brazil for the quarter and year. d-Net income The provision for possible credit losses for the latest periods totaled $130 million for the quarter and $1,737,000,000 for the year and included $1,250,000,000 applicable to the refinancing countries and a $47 million special provision for possible problem real estate loans at Chase Bank of Arizona. The year-ago periods' provision for possible credit losses totaled $300 million for the quarter, of which $200 million was related to refinancing countries. The year's provision totaled $750 million and included $350 million applicable to the refinancing countries.

title: Canadian Satellite Communiations Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Cost Cuts Announced By Apple
description: Facing a possibly protracted slowdown, Apple Computer Inc. said today that it would begin a number of cost-cutting measures. These measures include a reduction of employees at the company's headquarters in Cupertino, Calif.; a revised profit-sharing plan; less frequent salary increases, and the elimination of company cars for executives.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about the relationship between cocaine use and traffic fatalities in New York City included a scientist's incorrect figure in some copies, on the extent of cocaine use. A 1986 survey by the State Division of Substance Abuse Services reported that 11 percent of New Yorkers between 18 and 25 had used cocaine within the previous six months, not that 11 percent of the entire population used cocaine regularly.

title: Fiscal Restraint Urged by Wilder
description: Gov. L. Douglas Wilder called for fiscal conservatism today in his first State of the Commonwealth speech as the first black elected governor in the nation.

title: O'Toole's Group reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 3
Joint Venture for Memory Chips Officially Declared Dead
description: U.S. Memories, a ground-breaking attempt by American computer companies to cooperate in producing memory chips, was officially declared dead today by its organizers.

title: Beirut Government, Facing Rivals, Asks U.S. Arms
description: The Syrian-backed Government of President Elias Hrawi is seeking weapons from the United States to build up its military strength against Gen. Michel Aoun, the Maronite Christian officer who leads most of the country's armed forces, according to Government officials here.

title: Robert-Mark Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: The company said the net loss for the latest third quarter is partly attributable to nonrecurring expenses associated with the company's assumption of the on-going operations of Rams Marketing Inc., as well as from the general slowdown in real estate sales in the company's market area.

title: Manville Venture
description: Manville International B.V. and the Belgian-based Recticel have formed a partnership to make and market foam insulation products in Europe. Manville International is a subsidiary of the Denver-based Manville Corporation. Recticel is a subsidiary of the Societe Generale de Belgique, which is based in Brussels.

title: Joseph S. Clark Is Dead at 88; Ex-Mayor and Reformist Senator
description: Joseph S. Clark, a reform-minded politician who in 1951 became Philadelphia's first Democratic Mayor in 67 years and who went on to serve two terms in the United States Senate, died Friday at his home in the Chestnut Hill section of Philadelphia. He was 88 years old and had been in declining health in recent years.

title: Desperation Shot Lifts Knicks Over the Bulls
description: Trent Tucker accomplished the impossible yesterday. With a tenth of second left on the Madison Square Garden clock, the Knicks' guard caught an inbounds pass, turned and let fly a high-arcing 26-footer that hit nothing but net and gave the Knicks a 109-106 victory over the Chicago Bulls.

title: Court Blocks a Newsletter From Printing Ernst Article
description: The Atlanta newsletter that in May broke the story of the merger of Ernst & Whinney and Arthur Young, two large accounting firms, has been temporarily blocked by the surviving firm from publishing an article on the merger in its January issue.

title: National City Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Cornell Names Coach
description: Jim Hofher, the quarterback coach at the University of Tennessee, was named yesterday as head football coach at Cornell, where he played quarterback from 1975 to 1978.

title: Chess
description: If you aren't doing well in one tournament, try another, preferably at the same time.

title: Research Effort Is Financed
description: The Alfred P. Sloan Foundation has given a $2.97 million grant to establish a research consortium of five universities to explore the competitiveness and economic performance of the United States, foundation officials said last week.

title: A Storybook Development With an Uncertain Ending
description: When Federal regulators seized control of New Jersey's largest savings institution last month, one of the troubled properties that came with it was Port Liberte, a storybook development of sumptuous town houses rising above lazy canals on the cluttered waterfront here.

title: TSS Ltd. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Fries Entertainment Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Middlebury to Require Women in Fraternities
description: Fraternities at Middlebury College must admit women or close, the school's trustees voted Saturday.

title: Human Genes Turn Plants Into Factories For Medicines
description: SCIENTISTS are inserting human genes into plants and turning the plants into miniature factories that can produce large quantities of useful human proteins.

title: Men at 65: New Findings On Well-Being
description: THE secret of emotional health among older men is not a successful career, a happy marriage or a stable childhood, new findings suggest. It lies instead in an ability to handle life's blows without passivity, blame or bitterness.

title: Petitions Filed for a Vote on Casinos in Ohio
description: Petitions calling for a statewide vote to authorize casino gambling in as many as eight cities in Ohio have been filed with the state, seven months after a proposal to allow casinos in just one city died in the State Legislature.

title: N.B.A. Frowns on Duel
description: A National Basketball Association official has been quoted as saying the league will not sanction a proposal for a $1 million one-on-one duel between Michael Jordan of the Bulls and Magic Johnson of the Lakers.

title: TSR Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Where Savings Crisis Hits Hard
description: This overbuilt city, only a few years ago an illustration of solid growth in the West, has now become a clear example of the difficulty the Government faces in selling the vast real estate holdings it has acquired in the savings and loan crisis.

title: Strikers Disrupt British Ford Plants
description: More than 1,000 workers at three Ford Motor Company Ltd. plants in Britain began wildcat strikes today, two days before their unions and the auto maker were scheduled to resume contract negotiations. The company said the strikes had disrupted work at an engine plant in Bridgend in Wales and at two assembly plants in Halewood in northwestern England.

title: Western Microwave reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
Patterns
description: A Markdown for Me, Too

title: RPM Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Mubarak Saves Life of a Sudanese
description: A quick trip by President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt here last month apparently persuaded the governing Sudanese junta not to hang a physician found guilty by a military tribunal of fomenting a strike.

title: Mutual Funds Top $1 Trillion
description: United States mutual funds went over $1 trillion in assets for the first time last week, but they may have dipped right back under that figure, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.

title: Humphrey Is Hurting, But He Wants to Play
description: In that brief period between the initial satisfaction of winning a conference championship and the start of serious preparations for the Super Bowl, Bobby Humphrey of the Denver Broncos faced an additional complication at the end of his rookie season.

title: Mother Teresa Wasn't Riding In Ambulance, the Police Say
description: The police say they mistakenly reported over the weekend that Mother Teresa was riding in an ambulance involved in a fatal accident.

title: Identifying Schools Most in Need Is First Step to Helping Them
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Dance;   A Feeling of Family as Ballet Theater Turns 50
description: American Ballet Theater celebrated its 50th birthday on Sunday night at the Metropolitan Opera House with a gala performance that was a grand affair - focused, unusually, on superb dancing from its present members rather than on cameo appearances from alumni in retirement.

title: Upheaval in the East: East Germany;   Angry Crowds of East Germans Ransack Offices of Spy Service
description: Crowds of angry protesters invaded the 3,000-room state-security headquarters today, destroying files and furniture in a show of popular frustration with the pace of change.

title: F.B.I. Agent Remains Silent In Racial Harassment Case
description: An agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation and another main witness have cited their Fifth Amendment right to silence in refusing to answer questions about a black agent's allegations of racial harassment.

title: Dunkin' Donuts Makes Deal To Purchase Rival Concern
