description: LEAD: In a move that would expand the nation's largest doughnut retailer, the International Multifoods Corporation said yesterday that it agreed to sell its Mister Donut franchise operation to Dunkin' Donuts Inc.

title: Temple Loses Two
description: Duane Causwell and Joseph Robinson of the Temple basketball team have been declared academically ineligible. Causwell, a senior from Cardozo High School in Queens, was the Owls' starting center and was averaging 11.3 points, 8.3 rebounds and 4 blocked shots a game. Robinson, a freshman from Philadelphia's Central High School, joined the team as a walk-on.(AP)

title: Loan Spree Seems Over
description: The money was easy, and there was confidence that companies would never stop rising in value. Some people who had gone deeply into debt to buy companies had become very rich, and others were determined to follow.

title: With Notes of Charm, Children Help Neediest
description: Children tend to give smaller gifts to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund than adults. They have, after all, just their allowances, earnings from household chores or holiday and birthday gifts to draw from. But the wishes they express are eloquent and direct.

title: Metropolitan Federal S & L Assn reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income Latest quarter and 6 months included an added provision of $5 million for possible loan losses because of continued softness in the real estate sector.

title: Republic Bancorp Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After gains from utilization of net operating loss carryforwards of $9,000, or 1 cent a share, for the quarter and $55,000, or 2 cents a share, for the year.

title: Ecolab Buyback
description: Ecolab Inc., which markets cleaning and maintenance services, repurchased about 1.8 million of its shares for $55.3 million, or $30.75 a share, from the Carlyle Group and its affiliates It said Carlyle had agreed not to buy more Ecolab shares or otherwise try to influence Ecolab. Ecolab said that under its buyback program it had bought back about 2.4 million shares for about $72 million.

title: Upheaval in the East: Espionage;   Spy Reported in Soviet Hands Was a Top Agent, U.S. Says
description: Donald F., the senior Soviet diplomat whose 30-year career as a spy for the United States was disclosed in the Soviet press on Sunday, was one of the most important recruits to serve American intelligence, current and former Government officials said today.

title: Coors Enters Bottled Water Market
description: For the first time since Prohibition, the Adolph Coors Company is selling a nonalcoholic beverage. The new product is called Coors Rocky Mountain Sparkling Water.

title: Autrex Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $1,908,000 for the quarter and year from a writeoff of the goodwill recorded on the acquisition of Pyloin Electronic Development Co. c-Net income and included an extraordinary credit of $213,000, or 4 cents a share, for the quarter and year. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly

title: Upheaval in the East: Rumania;   Taking a Step Back From Anarchy
description: There was a moment last Friday night when it appeared that an angry mob of several thousand was dictating policy in the capital to the frightened provisional leadership of this country. At the same time, army generals were taking command in the cities of Timisoara and Iasi.

title: Review/Concert;   John Carewe Conducts Mahler's 7th
description: A big musical reputation in one country does not always transfer effectively to another. The young English conductor Simon Rattle, for example, in various appearances in this country, has failed to receive anything like the acclaim he almost invariably amasses at home.

title: Foreman Wins in 2d Round and Sends Cooney Into Retirement
description: George Foreman, an evangelical preacher from Humble, Tex., smote an opponent tonight.

title: Parker Drilling Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Included an extraordinary gain of $4,212,000 from subsidiary debt settlement. c-Net loss

title: Boeing, Japanese In Talks About Jet
description: The Boeing Company said it might give three Japanese aerospace companies a larger share in a new version of its 767 jetliner. ''Boeing continues to have ongoing discussions on an exploratory basis with Mitsubishi Heavy Industries, Kawasaki Heavy Industries and Fuji Heavy Industries,'' said Dick Schleh, a Boeing spokesman.

title: Frederick's of Hollywood Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 2
description: Year-ago shares outstanding adjusted to reflect two 3-for-2 stock splits effective March 17, 1989, and Aug. 28, 1989.

title: G.I.'s and Envoys Sparring in Panama
description: Although American military officials say it is business as usual, a low-intensity war of nerves is still raging around the Cuban, Nicaraguan and Libyan embassies here, as well as the homes of the Peruvian and Vatican ambassadors to Panama.

title: Inside
description: New Age: Hold the Ice

title: Hawkeye Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CHRONICLE
description: MILOVAN DJILAS, the dissident Yugoslav writer, flies to Moscow from Belgrade today as the guest of the Soviet journal Literaturnaya Gazeta. In a conciliatory mode, the Russians have invited him to participate in a round-table discussion of Moscow's break with Yugoslavia more than 40 years ago, the very break that he helped precipitate.

title: Upheaval in the East: Czechoslovakia;   Prague and Moscow Begin Talks on Soviet Pullout
description: Talks between Czechoslovakia and the Soviet Union began here today on the Czechoslovak request for a withdrawal of all Soviet troops by the end of the year.

title: Off-Duty Israeli Soldier Is Stabbed in Jerusalem
description: An off-duty Israeli soldier was stabbed as she walked along a narrow street in Jerusalem's Old City today, and 30 Palestinians were detained for questioning, the police said.

title: Grey Advertising Gets Wonder Bread Account
description: Wonder Bread will now be pitched by Grey Advertising. The Continental Baking Company, the subsidiary of the Ralston Purina Company that bakes Wonder, has consolidated its bread line at Grey, which already handles the Home Pride, Oatmeal Goodness and Beefsteak Rye brands.

title: Tagliabue Considering New Draft Rules
description: Paul Tagliabue, the commissioner of the National Football League, said yesterday that he was leaning toward changing N.F.L. draft rules to permit some players who still have college eligibility to turn pro.

title: Sudbury Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $303,000, or 2 cents a share, and $318,000, or 2 cents a share, for the quarter and 6 months, respectively; the 6 months also included a loss of $4,596,000 from an adjustment in accounting. Figures for 1989 have been restated due to the disposal of the company's steel tubing segment.

title: Jackson Opens a Drive for Capital Statehood
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson immersed himself deeper in this city's politics today by opening an office to push for statehood for the District of Columbia.

title: Riverside Journal;   New Reign For Queen Of Hotels In West?
description: Riverside gave the world the navel orange, but not even the fruit has defined this locality like the Mission Inn, the gaudy, sprawling hotel created by Frank Augustus Miller, an entrepreneur.

title: RSCG Group Extending Its Reach
description: CONTINUING its transformation from a small, creative Paris advertising agency to an international marketing-services conglomerate, RSCG Group S.A. yesterday offered to buy one of the world's largest sales-promotion companies, KLP Group P.L.C. of Britain.

title: First Team Sports Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Medical Dynamics reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Festival of Foreign TV At Museum of Broadcasting
description: Award-winning programs from abroad, most of them never broadcast in this country, are the focus of the New York World Television Festival opening today at the Museum of Broadcasting at 1 East 53d Street.

title: Old Kent Financial Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Upheaval in the East;   Dole Asks Bush to Switch Aid to East Bloc
description: The Senate Republican leader, Bob Dole of Kansas, is urging that United States foreign aid be reallocated to Eastern European countries and Panama.

title: Upheaval in the East;   An Abundance Of Hired Guns
description: A senior East German Government official gave a detailed report today on the history and scope of the Office of State Security.

title: Rite Aid Trial Scheduled
description: Charges that the Rite Aid Corporation and its president bribed a member of the Ohio Board of Pharmacy will be heard in a trial set to begin April 16, officials of Cuyahoga County Common Pleas Court have said. Judge Lillian J. Greene had previously set a tentative trial date of Jan. 15. Rite Aid and its president, Martin Grass, have been charged with bribing Melvin L. Wilczynski, a member of the Ohio board, to resign in an effort to gain influence on the Board. Both the company and Mr. Grass have pleaded not guilty.

title: Aim Telephone reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net income

title: Nellcor Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Pacific Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest year's per share earnings adjusted for a 2-for-1 stock split in March 1989.

title: 'Junk Bond' Prices Little Changed
description: The long-awaited bankruptcy filing by two of the Campeau Corporation's primary subsidiaries had little effect on prices in the high-yield ''junk bond'' market yesterday.

title: Central & South West Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Gordon Jackson, an Actor, at 66; Hudson in 'Upstairs, Downstairs'
description: Gordon Jackson, an actor known to millions of television viewers as Hudson, the archetypal butler in the popular series ''Upstairs, Downstairs,'' died on Sunday in Cromwell Hospital in London. He was 66 years old. The cause of death was not disclosed, but Mr. Jackson's agent, Michael Anderson, said the actor had been ill for a short time before being hospitalized.

title: SALVADOR EVIDENCE ESCAPED U.S. ENVOY
description: The American Ambassador to El Salvador recently suggested that six Jesuit priests there might have been killed by leftist guerrillas wearing Salvadoran military uniforms, a member of Congress said today. The Ambassador was unaware of evidence already available to the United States Army implicating Salvadoran military men.

title: Disney Outlines Plans for Florida
description: The Walt Disney Company's chief executive, Michael Eisner, announced plans to expand Disney's three Florida theme parks and said a fourth would be added during the 1990's. Mr. Eisner declined to provide details about the new park.

title: 2 Florida Players Are Suspended
description: Florida's senior center, Dwayne Schintzius, the Gators' leading scorer with a 19.1-point average, faced a felony charge today after a weekend fight at a fraternity house and was suspended indefinitely along with another player by Coach Don DeVoe.

title: Americans Still Trade Real Estate for Beads
description: To the Editor:

title: 5-Nation Panel Considers U.N. Role in Bringing Peace to Cambodia
description: With France calling for action to prevent the Khmer Rouge from returning to power, the five permanent members of the United Nations Security Council met here today to analyze a plan to involve the United Nations in bringing peace to Cambodia.

title: Nicaragua, Altering Policy, Keeps Out Some Journalists
description: Apparently revising its longstanding policy allowing easy access for foreign journalists, the Sandinista Government has begun denying and delaying visas for journalists trying to cover the campaign for national elections here Feb. 25.

title: Cause of Bus Accidents
description: Traffic congestion, not drugs or alcohol, is the primary cause of public transit bus accidents in the Municipal Railway System in San Francisco, researchers at the University of California at Berkeley report.

title: Rocky Mountain Chocolate Factory Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net loss

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE CAMPEAU FILING

title: Auditors Not to Blame For Thrifts Crisis
description: To the Editor:

title: Mad Dashes to Cash the Stores' Checks
description: When Federated Department Stores Inc. and the Allied Stores Corporation announced last week that they would issue checks to pay suppliers for more than $100 million in merchandise, some suppliers went to great lengths to try to cash those checks before the stores could file for bankruptcy.

title: Four Executives Guilty in $52 Million Fraud
description: Four New York area businessmen pleaded guilty on Friday to Federal charges of using their furniture business to defraud 400 investors of $52 million.

title: Cogeco Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Results are in Canandian dollars.

title: Square Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Included a net gain on sale of real property of $313,000, or 27 cents a share.

title: 'Smart' Typewriter May Be an Intelligent Choice
description: THE caller said his old electric typewriter had finally given up the ghost, and he wanted to know what kind of personal computer to buy to replace it. He said he wrote 10 or 20 business letters a week, along with an occasional brief report. His daughter would also use it to write her school papers. They had no interest in data bases, spreadsheets, charts or communications.

title: Brooke of Devils Overcomes Comparisons With Broten
description: Bob Brooke was aware comparisons with Aaron Broten would be unavoidable when he joined the Devils earlier this month from Minnesota in exchange for the popular forward.

title: Mexico and Banks Said To Close Financing Gap
description: Mexico and its bankers have agreed on how to cover the $300 million shortfall in their landmark deal under which most of the banks involved will reduce the value of the country's existing debt by 35 percent, according to bank and Mexican officials.

title: Deals
description: BASEBALL

title: Montreal Bank's Head Young, Conservative
description: The Bank of Montreal finished installing a young management team yesterday by naming Matthew W. Barrett, 45 years old, as chairman to succeed W. D. Mulholland, who is retiring at age 63 after eight years in the post.

title: Corrections
description: A report in the Advertising column of Business Day on Thursday about a new product assignment for the Isidore & Paulson advertising agency misstated the agency's relationship to two Kraft General Foods cereal accounts. It handled only the introduction of the cereals, Crispy Critters and Honey Bunches of Oats.

title: Hachette Signs A Soviet Deal
description: Hachette S.A., a leading French publisher, said today that it had signed a deal late last month with Progress Publishers of the Soviet Union that will allow unknown Russian authors to be published for the first time in the West.

title: Struck Dumb by the Incredible: 1-800-NOTHING
description: In an age of instant communication, when entire encyclopedias of information are transmitted over telephone lines in minutes and businesses count on getting through to far-flung offices in seconds, the loss of telephone service is unthinkable.

title: Basic Beyond Simple
description: FOR anyone who wants to learn something about programming, it would be hard to find an easier or more cost-effective source than ''Learn Basic Now,'' a book-disk combination at $39.95 from Microsoft Press.

title: Trident 2 Missile a Success In 4th Test From Submarine
description: The crew of a nuclear-powered submarine sent a Trident 2 missile aloft today in the fourth consecutive successful test flight for the Navy's newest and most powerful weapon.

title: Grand Valley Gas reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Sixers Sign Lloyd
description: Lewis Lloyd, who was waived by Houston after having been reinstated at the beginning of season from a suspension for substance abuse, has signed a 10-day contract with the Philadelphia 76ers. Lloyd, a 30-year-old forward, averaged 7 points in three games this season with the Rockets before being waived Dec. 12.(AP)

title: G.E. Shutdown
description: Because of slowing orders, the General Electric Company plans to close its factory here for the week of Jan. 22-26, idling nearly 1,700 workers. The factory makes residential electricity meters. The drop in orders reflects slowness in the construction industry, a G.E. spokeswoman said.

title: Vivigen Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Illusion Is Slain In Camelot
description: LEAD: From the start, Boston has shaped our loftiest aspirations, our most exalted dreams. It was there that John Winthrop built his ''city on a hill''; that Sam Adams stirred yearnings for a free commonwealth; that William Lloyd Garrison demanded that we redeem our pledge of equality; that John F. Kennedy conceived a society in which men would ask first what they could do for it.

title: Cool Layers of Simplicity for Summer
description: ''This is the way I'm going to work next summer,'' said Donna Karan as she slipped into an oversize short black poplin dress lightly fitted to the body with a drawstring just below the waistline. Under it she wore a T-shirt and stretch tights.

title: Marilyn Neale, Executive, 37
description: Marilyn Neale, a vice president of Ruder Finn & Rotman Inc., the public relations firm, died on Sunday of breast cancer at her home in Manhattan. She was 37 years old.

title: State-O-Maine Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
CHRONICLE
description: WILLIAM J. GRINKER, until last October the head of the New York City Human Resources Administration under Mayor Edward I. Koch, is leading a study of drug-treatment programs in a project financed by the Twentieth Century Fund and several other foundations. Mr. Grinker, 54, once a senior program officer at the Ford Foundation, will explore existing treatment alternatives, research and methods of disseminating information. The goal is to develop an organization to manage and measure drug-abuse information programs.

title: To Our Readers
description: Some prices for stocks traded on the New York and American stock exchanges, as well as for stock options, may not reflect the final close in the tables beginning on Page D11 because of a telephone company circuit failure in New York that interfered with delivery of the markets data to The Associated Press, which provides the tables.

title: Selvac Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Included tax benefits of net operating loss carryforwards of $47,000 and $109,000, or 1 cent a share, for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. c-Included tax benefits of $228,000, or 1 cent a share, and $340,000, or 2 cents a share, for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Herbert B. West, 73, Ex-President Of the New York Community Trust
description: Herbert Buell West, a retired foundation president and a former advertising executive, died of abdominal cancer on Sunday at his home in Darien, Conn. He was 73 years old.

title: Newspaper on Space
description: A new four-color weekly newspaper devoted to news about the business and politics of space began publishing today after three months of preview issues. Space News is a publication of the the Times Journal Company of Springfield, Va. The company also publishes Army Times, Navy Times, Air Force Times, Federal Times, Defense News and Journal Newspapers in suburban areas of Washington.

title: ECI Environmental reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: The company attributed its improved earnings to higher-than-expected revenues at its Northern California operations, continued growth in its Burbank office, and the fact that efforts to improve abatement program efficiencies and cost controls resulted in pretax margins in excess of 15 percent.

title: Nursing Home Is Denied Fees In Coma Case
description: A state judge has ruled that a Long Island nursing home cannot collect fees of more than $100,000 for continuing to care for a comatose woman whose family wanted life-sustaining treatment stopped.

title: General Microwave Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
16 Hurt in Nevada Plane Crash
description: A commuter plane crashed while trying to land in a snowstorm today, injuring all 16 people on board, officials said.

title: NCR Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Seton Hall Plagued by Turnovers
description: Frantz Volcy wears a Band-Aid on each elbow, covering wounds the Seton Hall forward has received during games in recent weeks.

title: 49ers' Nice Guy Finishes First
description: The road that George Seifert has traveled to Super Bowl XXIV has been full of anonymity, a road laden with smoldering fires that he has watered with an unassuming nature and a keen sense of exactly what place he says he believes his ego belongs and how much his inner satisfaction is his greatest reward of all.

title: Neogen Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Bank South Corp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Imagine Being in the Other Person's Shoes
description: To the Editor:

title: The Editorial Notebook;   After the Election: Surprise!
description: Remember David Dinkins, candidate? He was the indecisive one, so bad at making decisions that even some supporters predicted he'd be merely a ceremonial mayor while those around him did the heavy lifting. Now look. Mr. Dinkins announced, just two days into the job, that because of budget problems, the city would have to delay hiring 1,800 police officers. A few days later, he directed city agencies to cut their spending. And the sobering declarations keep coming. Now he says a property tax increase is a possibility.

title: 2 Named at Plain Dealer
description: Alex Machaskee, vice president and general manager of The Plain Dealer, has been promoted to publisher of the Cleveland newspaper, and Thomas H. Greer, executive editor, has become editor. The appointments were announced Sunday by Thomas Vail, who had been president, editor and publisher and now becomes president and chairman. Mr. Machaskee, 52 years old, has been with the newspaper for 30 years, during which he served as promotion director, assistant to the publisher, labor relations director and general manager. Mr. Greer, 47, was named managing editor of the newspaper in 1986 and executive editor in 1989.

title: Study for War Changes With Europe
description: As the faculty of the Naval War College at Newport, R.I., sat in a conference room puzzling over what changes are needed in their curriculum to respond to the dramatic events unfolding in Eastern Europe, 50 generals and admirals from the North Atlantic Treaty Organization were playing an annual war game next door.

title: How Knicks Beat Clock And Bulls
description: When Bob Billings resumes his regular job as principal of the Immaculate Heart of Mary Grammar School in Scarsdale, N.Y., today, his students may want to look at him with new respect.

title: Koor Halts Debt Payments
description: Koor Industries suspended payments today on its $1 billion debt, and its chairman resigned in protest against plans to sell the group.

title: Florio's Bright and Loyal Inner Circle
description: The top advisers James J. Florio will bring with him when he is sworn in as governor of New Jersey on Tuesday are known for having many of the same traits as their boss: intelligence, loyalty, liberal instincts and reputations as tough political operatives.

title: First Chicago Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After extraordinary credits of $7.8 million, or 11 cents a share, for the quarter and $23.6 million, or 36 cents a share, for the year. c-After extraordinary credits of $26.8 million, or 43 cents a share, for the quarter and $95.7 million, or $1.63 a share, for the year. The latest year's net income included a pre-tax gain of $60.4 million on sale of business and a special reserve of $238 million in the third quarter from additional provisions for credit losses. The company said the net impact of these third quarter special items was to reduce full year net income by $1.82 a share. The extraordinary items were due to tax loss carryforwards.

title: Triton Energy reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Included tax credits of $43,000 and $198,000, or 1 cent a share, for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. The loss in the latest second quarter and 6 months is attributable primarily to lower-than-expected operating results and start-up costs from recent acquisitions in the aviation sales and services segment. The loss for the prior year resulted principally from writedowns of assets.

title: Review/Theater;   A Surgeon's Crisis of Faith In a Marsha Norman Work
description: Marsha Norman's ''Traveler in the Dark'' aims to be a play about a crisis of faith but becomes an unresponsive argument between a skeptic and a believer. The work is didactic when it needs to be humanizing, single-edged when it should be at its most penetrating. First presented in 1984 at the American Repertory Theater in Cambridge, Mass., ''Traveler in the Dark'' is having its New York premiere at the York Theater Company. It is interesting only as an attempt on Ms. Norman's part to confront metaphysical concerns, but it adds nothing to one's appreciation of her work.

title: NBD Bancorp Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Per share earnings have been adjusted to reflect the 3-for-2 stock split in June 1989.

title: Upheaval in the East: Azerbaijan;   GORBACHEV ISSUES EMERGENCY DECREE OVER AZERBAIJAN
description: The Soviet Union declared a state of emergency in parts of Azerbaijan tonight and ordered army, navy and K.G.B. security forces to help contain ethnic hostilities that officials portrayed as verging on civil war.

title: Upheaval in the East;   Albania Denies Unrest Reports
description: The President of Albania today dismissed reports of unrest in his country and accused neighboring Yugoslavia of trying to stir up trouble.

title: Morton International Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The 1988 results were restated to reflect the spin-off of the company's aerospace division in July 1989.

title: Man Charged in Cake Death
description: A man was charged Sunday in the death of a 3-year-old girl who apparently suffocated when she was force-fed a chocolate cake, the police said. Frank F. Johnson, 46, of Baton Rouge, was accused of murder in failing to help the girl, Myra Griffin, when the incident occurred on Dec. 21, Officer Jeff Wesley said. The girl's mother, Marjorie Griffin, 23, was charged with first-degree murder last month.

title: Din of Assembly-Line Justice in New York
description: A din filled courtroom 941 at State Supreme Court in Brooklyn the other day as Justice Nicholas Coffinas looked down from the bench. Before him was a spindly young man who had been caught with an unregistered pistol. Minutes before, an admitted burglar had his turn before the judge. Then had come a purse snatcher, a man accused of selling drugs and a man charged with splitting another man's lip in a street brawl.

title: Georgia Gulf To Recapitalize
description: The Georgia Gulf Corporation, which has been trying to fend off corporate raider Harold C. Simmons, said today that its board had approved a debt-financed recapitalization plan that would give stockholders a one-time cash payment.

title: For Shoppers, Shopping as Usual
description: Yesterday's bankruptcy filing by Federated Department Stores and Allied Stores should have no effect on customers.

title: CHRONICLE
description: BRUCE SPRINGSTEEN and his companion, PATTI SCIALFA, are expecting a baby, The Associated Press reports. A spokeswoman for Columbia Records confirmed the report, but did not say whether the couple would marry. Ms. Scialfa was Mr. Springsteen's backup singer.

title: After Months of Unsubtle Hints, Cuomo to Seek a Hold on Tax Cut
description: After months of dropping all-but-delicate hints, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo on Tuesday will formally recommend suspending the next phase of the state's income-tax cut, aides to the Governor said today.

title: EXPERTS DIAGNOSE TELEPHONE 'CRASH'
description: Engineers at A.T.&T. tentatively concluded last night that the telephone system crashed because of a fault in a new signaling system, a part of the telephone network that helps complete long-distance calls.

title: Belichick Interviewed
description: The Phoenix Cardinals yesterday interviewed Bill Belichick, the Giants' defensive coordinator, for the team's head-coaching job. The 37-year-old Belichick is the third person to be interviewed so far by the Cardinals' general manager, Larry Wilson.

title: Beijing Journal;   Stilled by the Unthinkable, a Singer Tries His Voice
description: Like a thick carpet of snow, silence has settled over China. In muffled voices, among friends, some people still mock their leaders and dream of change, but despite the lifting of martial law last week they are quiet in public, or they are in jail.

title: For Man With a Dream, A Humbling Nightmare
description: The financial and legal troubles facing the Campeau Corporation's American retailing units are undoubtedly a personal humiliation for Robert Campeau, the French Canadian entrepreneur whose debt-burdened dream was to own a national chain of shopping malls housing prestigious stores.

title: American Bionetics reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Included a one-time litigation settlement charge of $147,084 for the quarter and 6 months.

title: Corrections
description: A brief article in SportsMonday this week about the ticket lottery for the N.C.A.A. Eastern Regional basketball tournament misstated the dates for the event, the ticket price and the method of payment. The semifinals of the tournament will be played on March 22 and the final on March 24. Tickets cost $43 each plus a $2 fee for each order. A money order for the full amount must accompany the order; checks and credit cards will not be accepted.

title: U.N. Official Views Africa
description: African economies improved slightly in 1989 but failed to keep up with population growth, and on average Africans became worse off, an economist said today.

title: How to Fulfill the Promise of Malta
description: Halve the U.S. and Soviet strategic nuclear arsenals. Slash both sides' chemical weapon stockpiles to 20 percent of current U.S. levels. Cut Warsaw Pact and NATO conventional forces in Europe to equal levels below those now maintained by NATO.

title: Chrysler Layoffs
description: Faced with slumping auto sales, the Chrysler Corporation of Canada said it would lay off about 1,000 workers at its assembly plant in Bramalea, Ontario, for five weeks starting immediately. The plant makes the Eagle Premier and the Dodge Monaco. Earlier this month, Chrysler announced it would lay off 1,200 workers at its Jeep plant in Brampton, Ontario, and 2,100 workers at its van plant in Windsor, Ontario.

title: South Carolina National Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Rorer Is In Talks To Merge
description: The Rorer Group Inc. said yesterday that it was negotiating with a company that might acquire 68 percent of Rorer's stock for cash and stock rights. The deal, if completed, values the drug company at $73 a share, or $2.3 billion.

title: Risk of High Blood Pressure Is Same for Sexes by Age 55
description: By 55 years old, women are as likely as men to have high blood pressure, and more than half of American women that age have high cholesterol levels, the American Heart Association has reported.

title: Microcom Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Employee Benefit Plans Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Included extraordinary tax benefits resulting from utilization of loss carryforward and net gain on extinguishment of debt of $814,792, or 15 cents a share, for the quarter and $936,722, or 20 cents a share, for the 6 months. c-Included extraordinary tax benefits resulting from utilization of loss carryforward and net gain on extinguishment of debt of $13,000 and $93,000, or 2 cents a share, for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: U.S. Can Help Soviet Private Entrepreneurs
description: To the Editor:

title: Briggs & Stratton Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: U.S. Memories: Too Short
description: An unusual cooperative venture with the apt name of U.S. Memories has failed to raise the necessary funds from American computer companies to go into the business of making memory chips. A major opportunity to guard against future pressure from Japanese competitors thus seems to have been frittered away.

title: CHRONICLE
description: ALTHEA WETHERBEE, a Long Islander, finished the Tenneco Marathon in Houston on Sunday, the oldest woman to do so. But her son, Lieut. Comdr. JAMES D. WETHERBEE, fell asleep before he heard the news. Commander Wetherbee is currently orbiting the earth as pilot of the space shuttle Columbia.

title: James A. Clark Jr., 69, Air Ace and Executive
description: James Averell Clark Jr., a World War II fighter pilot who led a varied career in business after the war, died of a stroke on Thursday at his home in Manhattan. He was 69 years old.

title: Santa Fe Pacific Pipeline reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Figures for 1988 are on a pro forma basis. The company said pro forma income statements for 1988 were derived from combined historical statements of income from continuing operations of Southern Pacific Pipe Lines Inc. and San Diego Pipeline Co. and reflected certain pro forma ajustments as if transactions to form the partnership had occurred on Jan. 1, 1988. The partnership was formed on Dec. 19, 1988.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: In, Out and Over; Trend Industry Looks Back at the 90's
description: Janet Jackson will be in, Michael Jackson will be out. Cellular telephones will be everywhere, until they are replaced by flip-top, hand-held ''personal communicators'' in ''Star Trek'' style.

title: Study of Acid Rain Uncovers a Threat To Far Wider Area
description: A HUGE Federal study has found that acid rain has turned many lakes and streams acidic not only in the Northeast but also in other areas of the East and parts of the Midwest, including northern Florida, the Appalachians and the New Jersey Pine Barrens.

title: Celanese Canada Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company is listed on the Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: By Design;   Hats Floppy and Flexible
description: You could just as easily stuff them into your pocket as pull them onto your head. That is one of the nice features of the rakish but casual hats spotted around town. Made of soft fabrics like velvet, wool or rayon ribbon, they can be put on any old way. Floppy and flexible, they adjust to the whims of the wearer.

title: CAMPEAU INVOKES BANKRUPTCY CODE FOR ITS BIG STORES
description: The American retailing operations of the Campeau Corporation filed for court protection from creditors yesterday, saying they had debts of about $7.5 billion.

title: LSB Bancshares reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Lessons
description: Shortly after the doors of the Ramon Emeterio Betances School opened at 7 A.M. one recent day, Margarita Albibal arrived with her two daughters.

title: Simmons Raises Lockheed Holding
description: Harold C. Simmons, the Dallas financier, has raised his stake in the Lockheed Corporation to 17.9 percent from 16.9 percent. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Mr. Simmons did not amend his previous statement that he has no immediate plans to take over the military contractor, which is based in Calabasas, Calif.

title: Review/Television;   Prince Pronounces on State of Architecture
description: Who thinks that architecture isn't a fit subject for television? Not Prince Charles, surely. Tonight, he will appear on Public Broadcasting Service stations nationwide (at 10 P.M. on Channel 13) in ''H.R.H. Prince Charles: A Personal View of Architecture,'' a film produced last year for the BBC. The hourlong program is precisely what it claims to be: the Prince, as both writer and star, chats, converses and pronounces on the state of architecture as he sees it. He focuses mainly on Britain but briefly crosses the Atlantic, most often to point to Manhattan as an example of what not to do, but also to show us Seaside, the small, villagelike new town on the Gulf Coast of Florida that is made up mostly of wooden cottages set on traditional streets.

title: Aristech Gets Bid
description: The Aristech Chemical Corporation's stock rose $5.50, to $24.625, on the New York Stock Exchange today, after the company said it had received a cash bid of $26 a share, or $845 million, from a group that includes Aristech's chairman, Thomas Marshall, and the Mitsubishi Corporation of Japan. The Pittsburgh-based company has virtually ignored a previous offer of $25 a share made in October by Jon Huntsman, a Salt Lake City investor.

title: Laws Aim to Turn Off Ear-Splitting 'Boom' Cars
description: Acting on citizens' complaints, states are beginning to take action against the latest violation of the social contract: the boom car.

title: FOES OF PRETORIA GATHER IN ZAMBIA
description: After nearly 30 years of guerrilla struggle, many of the top figures in South Africa's most powerful black nationalist group, the African National Congress, have gathered here this week to discuss the possibilities of ending white rule by negotiations.

title: New Faces Revive Old Dispute on Merging 3 Police Forces
description: A combination of fiscal pressures, union shakeups, management changes and political realities has reinvigorated one of the oldest disputes in New York City government: should the nation's largest city have a single police force?

title: Robert Burritt Hiatt, A Surgeon, Dies at 72
description: Robert Burritt Hiatt, a surgeon and teacher, died of cancer on Saturday at Kennebec Valley Medical Center in Gardiner, Me. He was 72 years old and lived in Dresden, Me.

title: Ruth Bunzel, 91, Dies; Taught Anthropology
description: Ruth L. Bunzel, a retired adjunct professor of anthropology at Columbia University, died Sunday at St. Vincent's-Roosevelt Hospital Center, after a long illness. She was 91 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: A World Drug Court Could Try a Noriega
description: To the Editor:

title: Intel Profit Up Sharply
description: The Intel Corporation today reported strong gains in earnings and revenue for the fourth quarter ended Dec. 30. Revenue for the year was a record, but 1989 earnings declined from last year's level.

title: Temple Drops Causwell
description: Duane Causwell, who was Temple's starting center, has enrolled at the Community College of Philadelphia, according to Temple officials. Charles Theokas, Temple's athletic director, said the athletic department was told Sunday that Causwell had been dismissed from Temple's College of Health, Physical Education and Recreation and Dance.

title: Review/Film;   A Cerebral and Sexual Look At Character and Emotion
description: Alain Tanner, the Swiss director of ''La Salamandre,'' ''In the Middle of the World'' and ''Jonah Who Will Be 25 in the Year 2000,'' has been one of the most securely cerebral of European film makers. Like Eric Rohmer, with whom he otherwise has little in common, Mr. Tanner makes films about people who think and talk and argue about matters of importance, often at cross-purposes and sometimes for little ultimate effect. Mr. Rohmer's films are blithe comedies. Mr. Tanner's tend to be witty without being especially funny, and frequently solemn.

title: Graf And Lendl Coast
description: Steffi Graf, playing in slow motion compared with her rapid-fire practice with Boris Becker, easily advanced to the third round of the Australian Open today, beating the 17-year-old American Erika DeLone, 6-1, 6-2.

title: Court Takes Price-Fixing Case
description: Urged by state attorneys general, the Supreme Court agreed to decide if states can bring Federal antitrust suits charging energy producers with illegal price-fixing. Page D1.

title: 60-MINUTE GOURMET
description: IN this age of fettuccine with radicchio and goat cheese, foie gras ravioli and exotic risottos, the notion of serving spaghetti with meatballs seems downright primitive.

title: Rorer Details Value of Merger
description: The Rorer Group Inc., a maker of pharmaceuticals, said that a merger plan it is discussing with another company would value Rorer at $3.14 billion. Rorer, based in Fort Washington, Pa., said it had authorized 43 million shares of common stock, including only 32 million shares outstanding, two bond issues that would convert into 10.2 million, and shares held by an employee stock ownership plan.

title: President Is Selected At Citibank and Parent
description: Richard S. Braddock, for many years a key executive in Citicorp's highly profitable consumer banking business, yesterday was named president of Citicorp and its main subsidiary, Citibank.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Lowe's U.S. Head
description: The Lowe Group of Britain has appointed Adelaide Horton to the new position of chief operating officer of its American unit, Lowe Group USA. She was formerly a senior vice president at Chiat/Day/Mojo. The Lowe Group's roster of agencies includes Lowe Marschalk.

title: Meditrust reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
'Geezer' Setting Sights On Tyson
description: It was 2 in the morning, and on the fourth floor of Caesars Atlantic City, just down the hall from his room, the Geezer still had himself an audience.

title: Florio Takes Office and Calls Auto-Insurance Session
description: Pledging leadership that is ''disciplined, tough, persistent and honest,'' James Joseph Florio took the oath of office as the 49th governor of New Jersey today and immediately called for a special session of the Legislature next Monday to solve the problem of high automobile insurance rates.

title: Manufacturers Hanover reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included for the quarter $35 million after-tax charge resulting from a fraud at the firm's Geneva, Switzerland branch; a $69 million after-tax gain from sale of 60 percent interest in CIT Group; a $57 million after-tax charge relating to refinancing country portion of Manufacturers Hanover's reserve for possible credit losses, and an $8 million after-tax charge related to the selling of company's municipal bond portfolio; the year reflected addition of $1.1 billion to corporation's reserve against refinancing country debt, and operating earnings included $16 million after- tax gain from the sale of an interest in a foreign leasing company. c-Included $146 milllion after-tax in past due interest payments from Brazil. d-Net income The 1988 year's operating earnings included gains on asset sales totaling $578 million, including the sale of a consumer finance unit and an office building in London. The company said 1989 and 1988 included the recognition of tax benefits of $70 million and $200 million, in the respective periods, relating to the corporation's refinancing country reserving actions.

title: Parker's Real Service
description: To The Living Section:

title: No Plan for Skating Into Sunset
description: They are such good friends, and with one project after another, they are now virtually inseparable. One could easily get the wrong impression.

title: Chip Maker's Net Improves
description: The Advanced Micro Devices Corporation today reported improved earnings for the fourth quarter and the year. The company said sales of its core products remained strong through the quarter, but with intense price competition.

title: Moscow Dispatches 11,000 Troops to Azerbaijan
description: The Soviet Government airlifted 11,000 army and internal police troops today to the embattled regions of Azerbaijan, where armed bands of Armenian and Azerbaijani militants were reported still locked in conflict.

title: Citizens & Southern Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
A Mongoose In a Beret And Goatee
description: After only 1 minute 57 seconds of the second round, the Puncher turned out to be the Preacher. George Foreman's right hand convinced Gerry Cooney into ''getting on with the rest of my life.'' And now the heavyweight champion from another era, who just turned 41 years old, who clubbed the title from Joe Frazier in Jamaica in 1973 and was rope-a-doped out of it by Muhammad Ali in Zaire in 1974, is suddenly being hyped as an eventual opponent for Mike Tyson somewhere down the road to millions. Don't laugh. Gil Clancy didn't. ''When George got Gerry hurt, he didn't just hit him with ordinary punches, he hit him with five bombs,'' Cooney's trainer said. ''You can imagine George connecting with Mike Tyson and wobbling him a bit. lf that happens, George could realize his dream.'' So could Archie Moore. Wearing a royal purple beret crocheted by his wife, Joan, his wisp of a gray goatee fluttering when he spoke, his eyes closing when he laughed, Archie Moore insisted ''I'm not a trainer. I'm an adviser.'' But even more important, he's Archie Moore and that's enough. For all those who decry Foreman's comeback, it's worth it if only for having returned the Mongoose to the scene.

title: Cuomo Proposes More Anti-Drug Spending, but the Legislature Is Wary
description: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo today proposed adding more than $250 million to the $1 billion a year the state already spends on anti-drug programs. But several of his top aides, citing bureaucratic delays and community opposition to drug-treatment centers, conceded that they would not be able to spend all of the money in the coming year.

title: Public Service Enterprise Group reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: First City Bancorp of Texas reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The bank's results for the year 1988 reflected a period from April 20 through Dec. 31, and not the entire year.

title: Early-Month Vehicle Sales Up Sharply
description: Sales of cars made in the United States jumped by 29.8 percent in early January compared with a sluggish period a year ago, as buyers took advantage of factory incentives and flocked to showrooms after an absence of several months. Light-truck sales also surged, rising by 22.8 percent.

title: G.M. Orders Ad Slowdown
description: The General Motors Corporation has ordered its divisions to cut or delay media advertising spending by 25 percent as part of its cost-cutting efforts, the company said today.

title: Fear Grows That Ethiopia Will Bar Relief to Famine-Stricken Area
description: Concern is growing over the reluctance of the Ethiopian Government to allow relief agencies to distribute food to the four million to five million people facing starvation in northern areas of the country, relief officials and American legislators say.

title: Late Foul Shots Lift St. John's Past Villanova
description: Jayson Williams scored 13 points and Jason Buchanan made two crucial free throws with 48 seconds left to help St. John's beat Villanova by 64-58 tonight in a Big East Conference match.

title: T.W.A. Sells Jets To Raise Cash
description: Trans World Airlines Inc. said it had sold 11 jumbo jets for $210 million to two leasing companies to raise cash and reduce its large debt, company officials said. It was the second time in less than a month that the airline had announced the sale of assets. On Dec. 18, it said it planned to sell its Chicago-London route and related assets to American Airlines for $195 million. That deal must be approved by the Federal Government.

title: New York Region and the Budget: School-Aid Proposal Is Big Change
description: Like most aspects of Gov. Mario M. Cuomo's proposed budget, the line items that most affect New York City and its suburbs are what Assembly Speaker Mel Miller called ho-hum - neither greatly enhanced nor greatly diminished from last year's appropriations.

title: Fernandez Acts to Oust District Head
description: Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez yesterday ordered the removal of the superintendent of Community School District 9 in the Bronx, which has been troubled by charges of corruption and mismanagement for several years.

title: Breast Implant Safety
description: To The Living Section:

title: From Dictatorship to Revolt, Rumanian Defends a House
description: There are nine bullet holes in the walls and ceiling of Venera Darian's bedroom in the residential district of northern Bucharest where she has lived for most of her 89 years.

title: Czechoslovak-Soviet Meeting About Troops Adjourns Early
description: Talks with the Soviet Union about withdrawing the 70,000 to 75,000 troops it has stationed here since 1968 proved more difficult than expected today, and they were adjourned until early next month in Moscow, the Czechoslovak Foreign Ministry said.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Deadline Extension
description: The deadline for entries to the 1990 One Show has been extended to Feb. 9, from Jan. 31, because of a water main break on Fifth Avenue in Manhattan that temporarily closed the club's office on 18th Street.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Corrections
description: An article in Science Times on Jan. 9 about card shuffling misstated the value of 52 factorial, or 52 X 51 X 50, etc. It is approximately 0.8 X 10 to the 68th power.

title: EATING WELL
description: SONOMA COUNTY, one of the most prolific food-growing regions in northern California, may be unique in one respect. The menus in the very best restaurants offer diners a limited but appealing selection of dishes that promote a healthy heart.

title: Books of The Times;   Why Liberals and Their Beliefs Will Rise Again
description: The Resurgent Liberal (And Other Unfashionable Prophecies)

title: Healy Stops 51 Shots in Shutout as Islanders Win 7th in Row
description: Glenn Healy, the Islander goalie, grabbed many pucks tonight with his glove hand, juggled some once or twice, and stopped a few with his stick and pads.

title: Israeli Inflation Up in '89
description: Consumer prices rose by 20.7 percent in Israel in 1989 despite an austerity program aimed at reducing inflation, the Government said Monday. The increase compared with a rise of 16.4 percent in 1988 and 16.1 percent in 1987. The Government said prices rose 1.1 percent in December, compared with 1.3 percent in November and 1.6 percent in December 1988.

title: 18 Tourists Killed in Brazil
description: At least 18 Argentine tourists, including 4 children, died today when their bus overturned near the southern Brazilian city of Porto Alegre, radio reports said. The bus had left the town of Trenque Lauquen in Argentina on Sunday loaded with tourists bound for the coastal Brazilian town of Camboriu when it flipped on its side before dawn, the reports said.

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Bank of America, San Francisco, named Gary J. Matus senior vice president and manager of its media and entertainment industries unit.

description: To the Editor:

title: Transactions
description: BASEBALL

title: Options Board Re-elects Head
description: Karsten Mahlmann was re-elected chairman of the Chicago Board of Trade in a rare contest for the job, exchange officials said tonight.

title: Economic Scene;   Blue-Collar Blues: Who Is to Blame?
description: ARE you better or worse off than you were four years ago, asked Ronald Reagan in 1980. But George Bush's image-makers chose not to press the rhetorical point in his Presidential campaign, and for good reason.

title: Pinnacle West Names Chief
description: The Pinnacle West Capital Corporation said today that it had appointed Richard Snell chairman, president and chief executive of Pinnacle West and chairman of the Arizona Public Service Company, its utility subsidiary.

title: Hillenbrand Industries Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 2
description: The company said that on a comparable fourth quarter basis, which included one extra week in 1988, both industrial and insurance groups contributed to 1989's revenue increase.

description: Earlier in the season, while Harvard struggled and its shots did not go into the goal, the veteran coach, Bill Cleary, remained patient. His squad was so talented, he said, it would right itself in time.

description: Figures are in Canadian funds.

description: b-Net loss In the latest quarter, the company said it accrued $1,000,000 for legal, accounting and investment banking services related to its planned merger with Marsh & McLennan's TBS Group Inc.

title: BOND HEARING HELD FOR NORIEGA ALLY
description: A former Panamanian military commander charged in the drug trafficking case of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega was portrayed by character witnesses at a bond hearing today as a family man who deserves bail.

title: CBS Programmer's Goals: New Talent and No. 2 Spot
description: Citing a need for CBS to ''romance'' the best producers and actors in Hollywood, Jeff Sagansky has charted a course for CBS Entertainment that he believes will carry the network back to prime-time leadership by the time his five-year contract as president of that division expires.

title: Fresh Start for Campeau in U.S.
description: G. William Miller, an investment banker and businessman who was Treasury Secretary and chairman of the Federal Reserve Board during the Carter Administration, yesterday was named chairman and chief executive of the American retailing operations of the Campeau Corporation.

title: About Education
description: Education research too often ignores the people it claims to serve -the children and teachers. So says J. Myron Atkin, a professor of education and teacher of science at Stanford University, where he was dean of the Graduate School of Education from 1979 to 1986.

title: Chronicle
description: As national chairman of President Bush's first Presidential Inaugural Anniversary Gala, HENRY R. KRAVIS has been in Washington beating the bushes for money.

title: Stoneridge Resources reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Year-ago quarter results included a pretax gain of $1.8 million from the disposition of real property.

title: Citicorp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a provision of $1 billion for possible LDC credit losses and a charge of $68 million to restructure the United Kingdom equities business. c-Net income The bank said last year's final quarter was raised by two years of Brazilian interest payments. Citicorp said results for the year- ago fourth quarter and full year included $160 million in carryforward tax benefits. Full year 1989 results included a gain of $77 million from the sale of premises in Tokyo. Full year and fourth quarter 1988 results have also been restated to reflect a change in reporting of securities sold, but not yet purchased, beginning in the latest fourth quarter.

title: Off-Duty Officer Shot in Head While Washing Car
description: An off-duty police officer was shot and critically wounded as he washed his car on a Brooklyn street yesterday afternoon, the police said.

title: Young Team at the Top Has Big-Time Troubles
description: It has been a trying season for the basketball team rated No. 1 in many preseason polls.

title: The Reagan Boom - Greatest Ever
description: Almost everyone knows that the greatest depression the U.S. ever had was in the 1930's. It was known as the Great Depression, and its infamy merits a separate section in economics textbooks. But what was its counterpart? When did our greatest economic expansion occur?

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising Addenda
description: * Livingston & Co., a Seattle advertising agency that also has a San Francisco office, has agreed to acquire Melmon Tawa & Partners, an agency in Palo Alto, Calif., with about $6 million in billings.

title: Kimberly-Clark Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Magnetek Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Quotation of the Day
description: ''We didn't live up to our own standards of quality. We didn't live up to our customers' standards of quality. It's as simple as that.''

title: For Every Five Young Women, Six Young Men
description: SOCIAL myth: There are not enough young men for all the young women looking for boyfriends or husbands.

title: N.F.L. Draft Lures Star Junior at Alabama
description: Keith McCants, a junior linebacker who won all-America recognition last season at the University of Alabama, said yesterday that he would pass up his final year of eligibility to enter the National Football League draft in April. He said his main motive was financial security.

title: Ex-State Dept. Officer Takes Job at Fujitsu By MARTIN TOLCHIN
description: In what United States negotiators consider a major loss, the State Department officer who helped develop the negotiating strategy with Japan on high- technology issues ranging from semiconductors to space stations has joined Fujitsu Ltd., a Japanese electronics conglomerate.

title: Egyptian in Washington for Talks To Revive Stagnant Peace Process
description: The Egyptian Foreign Minister flew to Washington today carrying what diplomats called an appeal to the United States to continue its newest Middle East peace effort.

title: Jeff Alexander, 79; Composer for Screen
description: Jeff Alexander, a composer who worked in radio, television and motion pictures for more than 50 years, died of cancer on Dec. 23 at his home on Whidbey Island in Washington. He was 79 years old.

title: Corrections
description: An illustration with the Personal Health column on Jan. 4 about cross-country skiing depicted a technique improperly. In the basic motion, as the column said, when one leg is forward, the opposite arm is also forward, pushing off with the pole.

title: Archer Daniels Midland reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago quarter and 6-month results are restated to reflect the 5 percent stock dividend in September and the 3-for-2 stock split in December.

title: India Edwards Dies; Advocate of Women In Politics Was 94
description: India Edwards, former vice chairwoman of the Democratic National Committee, who worked to advance the role of women in politics, died Sunday at Fircrest Convalescent Hospital in Sebastopol, Calif. She was 94 years old and lived in Greenbrea, Calif.

title: Opposition's Talks With Communists in Sofia Off to a Rough Start
description: The first round of talks between ruling Communist officials and members of the Bulgarian opposition began today. But they quickly hit a snag, with the opposition demanding access to news media and office space and the Communists, who still maintain near-total control, asserting that they were being confronted with ultimatums and grandstanding.

title: For Neediest, Gifts to Honor A New Mayor
description: The inauguration of a new mayor in New York City and the hope that his administration will bring better times to the impoverished have inspired several gifts to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: Fund and C.D. Yields Drop
description: Yields on certificates of deposit and money market accounts at commercial banks and savings institutions were down for the week ended yesterday. Analysts said conflicting signals on the state of the economy had slowed the decline in yields and could keep them near current levels.

title: Sales Increase by 0.7%; Inventories Up by 0.5%
description: Business sales and inventories rose in November, but economists said slower sales in December would probably mean weaker numbers for that month.

title: Excerpts From Florio Speech: 'New Ideas Preserve Old Ideals'
description: Following are excerpts from the text of Gov. James J. Florio's inaugural speech today:

title: Panama Coverage: One Big P.R. Job
description: LEAD: During wartime, most Americans follow the flag. That was clear as our 24,000 troops took on Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega's Panama. An overwhelming majority commended George Bush for a job well done. That included the news media.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Akzo N.V., Arnheim, the Netherlands, a chemical company, said it would discontinue its two joint ventures with Kollmorgen Corp., Simsbury, Conn., and had set up a new joint venture with AMP Inc., Harrisburg, Pa., a maker of electrical and electronic connectors. The new joint venture will acquire the business of Additive Products Co., one of the joint ventures of Akzo and Kollmorgen. Kollmorgen will be paid $50 million for its 50 percent of Additive.

title: A New Way to Attack Illness With Drugs
description: Capitalizing on new tools in molecular research, large drug manufacturers and about a dozen start-up companies are racing to develop drugs that combat illness by controlling the molecular switches that govern human cells.

title: Chronicle
description: ISAAC ASIMOV barely made it to his own party last night. The prolific author slipped out of the cooperative-care unit at Tisch Hospital, where he has been in treatment for several days.

G.E. to Build A Powerful New Engine
description: Anticipating rising demand for large jetliners with only two engines, GE Aircraft Engines, a subsidiary of General Electric, said yesterday that it would build the world's most powerful commercial jet engine.

title: Russell Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
6-Goal Capital Rally Stops Devils
description: Playing with an overdose of emotion and intensity to impress their new coach, the Washington Capitals ended an eight-game losing streak tonight with a 9-6 triumph over the Devils.

title: Review/Theater;   'Macbeth,' Its Lessons Ever Apt And Ever New, With Raul Julia
description: That indelible image of Nicolae Ceausescu's lifeless body lying on the ground could be the final scene in a modern-dress staging of ''Macbeth.'' The earlier images of Ceausescu and his partner in dictatorship, his wife, Elena, staring down a military tribunal could also be taken from Shakespeare's tragedy, as could the entire Rumanian nightmare of a married couple's lust for autocratic power at any brutal price. When Lady Macbeth tells her husband how she would even have ''dashed the brains out'' of ''the babe that milks me'' to get what she wants, does not one recall the eyes of that dead baby staring out of the photograph of the massacre at Timisoara?

title: Book Notes
description: With Vaclav Havel

title: Supreme Court to Consider An Antitrust Suit by States
description: At the urging of the attorneys general of a majority of the states, the Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether states can bring Federal antitrust suits charging energy producers with illegal price-fixing.

title: State Dept. Endorses Dole's Call For More Flexibility in Foreign Aid
description: The State Department today endorsed a call by Senator Bob Dole to give the Administration greater flexibility in allocating foreign aid. But it stopped short of saying, as the Senate Republican leader did, that some money now designated for Israel, Egypt and other large aid recipients should be redirected to Eastern Europe and Panama.

title: Centuries of Strife Between 2 Groups
description: Antagonism between Azerbaijanis and Armenians is longstanding, caused by religion, nationalism, territorial friction and other factors, experts at United States universities said in interviews this week.

title: Lomax Retires
description: Neil Lomax, the Phoenix Cardinal quarterback who sat out last season with degenerative arthritis in his left hip, announced his retirement from the N.F.L. yesterday.

title: Loudon Bows Out OF 'Annie' Revival'
description: Dorothy Loudon will not take part in a planned revival of the musical ''Annie,'' her agent, Lionel Larner, said yesterday.

title: UJB Financial Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Mr. Dole Milks a Miniature Cow
description: Senator Bob Dole has never been shy about sounding a clanging alarm in the middle of policy debate. He did so again on the Op-Ed page yesterday. Mr. Dole urged that foreign aid funds be shifted from favored clients like Israel and Egypt to the emerging democracies of Eastern Europe, and to other countries where freedom has ''suddenly and dramatically blossomed.''

title: Rollins Environmental ServFices Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $1,064,000.

title: Arson Blamed As Fire Kills 4 In Brooklyn
description: A 33-year-old woman and three of her children were killed early yesterday morning when a fire set by an arsonist consumed a rickety frame building in Brooklyn where at least four families lived and worked, the police and fire officials said.

title: MDS Health Group Ltd.  reports earnings for Year to Oct 31
description: Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Jack DiGiovanni, 54, A Financial Executive
description: Jack L. DiGiovanni, financial director of The New York Times circulation department, died yesterday at the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center after a short illness. He was 54 years old and lived in Oradell, N.J.

title: Koop Backs Bill to Set Drug Testing Standards
description: A Senate bill to set Federal standards for private companies that test employees for drug use would provide consistency and eliminate lawsuits, Dr. C. Everett Koop, the former Surgeon General, and other supporters of the legislation said today.

title: Exxon Executive on Arthur Kill Is Retiring
description: The Exxon Corporation announced yesterday that Edward T. DiCorcia, the vice president in charge of domestic refineries, will retire on Feb. 1. The announcement came two weeks after the company summoned Mr. DiCorcia from its headquarters in Houston to oversee the company's response to a leak of more than 500,000 gallons of heating oil into the Arthur Kill.

title: Charles A. Anderson, Geologist, 87
description: Charles A. Anderson, a former chief geologist of the United States Geological Survey, died of Alzheimer's disease today in Pomona, Calif. He was 87 years old.

title: Rostropoviches Regain Their Soviet Citizenship
description: The cellist and conductor Mstislav Rostropovich and the soprano Galina Vishnevskaya have had their Soviet citizenship restored 12 years after the Government took it away, Tass reported today.

title: Review/Rock;   Aerosmith: Power Ballads and Double-Entendres
description: Advice to underrated rock bands: Stick around, keep your sense of humor, and if you're lucky, what once sounded secondhand will turn out to be classic.

title: Adolph O. Krisch, Hotel Owner, 73
description: Adolph Oscar Krisch, a founder of what became the largest Holiday Inn franchise in the United States, died at his home Thursday, apparently from a self-inflicted gunshot wound to the head, a medical examiner said. He was 73 years old.

title: Tax Cuts: No, Yes, Maybe, No
description: These are some comments made over the years by Gov. Mario M. cuomo as he has changed his position on the four-year-tax-cut:

title: A Pragmatist Is Selected by Campeau
description: G. William Miller, the new chairman and chief executive of Federated Stores Inc., has a dazzling resume in business and Government, but he has never run a giant retailing concern.

title: Rowan Cos. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income c-Included a one-time gain of $24.4 million, or 34 cents a share, from physical loss of drilling rig for both periods.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Friday about the rise of Vaclav Havel to the presidency of Czechoslovakia misstated the country's system for dividing high offices between Czechs and Slovaks. A conference last year between the Government and the opposition agreed that the President must be a non-Communist Czech since the Prime Minister, Marian Calfa, was a Communist Slovak. In the past, Slovaks have held the presidency.

title: Chronicle
description: The show doesn't always go on. Succumbing to the flu, ANTHONY HEALD and NATHAN LANE, the two leads of ''The Lisbon Traviata,'' did not appear last night at the Promenade Theater in Manhattan. Because both actors have the same understudy, the performance was canceled.

title: Citicorp Has Deficit In Quarter
description: Citicorp, the nation's largest banking company, announced yesterday that it lost $784 million in the fourth quarter of 1989, as it set aside $1 billion in reserves to cover losses on its loans to less developed countries.

title: Seventh Avenue Suppliers Are Breathing a Little Easier
description: Only the most perceptive and dedicated shopper would have found Bloomingdale's lacking in goods yesterday. And on Seventh Avenue, there was a sense of relief one day after the American retailing units of the Campeau Corporation filed for bankruptcy, with suppliers getting ready to ship goods normally to such stores as Bloomingdale's, Abraham & Straus and Jordan Marsh.

title: New Wyse Models
description: Wyse Technology Inc. said it had added to its product line the first in a series of Unix systems for the midrange multi-user computer market. The new computers include the Wyse Series 9000I, which supports symmetric processing and is based on the Intel Corporation's 386 microprocessor. The family of computers supports up to 128 users. Prices for the new machines range from $10,795 for entry-level machines to about $85,000 for the top-of-the-line model.

title: SOVIETS' RESPONSE GETS U.S. SUPPORT
description: The Bush Administration today openly endorsed President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's use of troops to quell ethnic fighting between Armenians and Azerbaijanis in the southern Soviet Union.

title: A Day to Forget
description: There are some mornings so lousy that you know the rest of the day is going to stink.

title: Paris Journal;   Piecing Together a Boulevard's Broken Dreams
description: Standing in the Place de la Concorde and contemplating the Champs-Elysees as it sweeps past gardens and palaces toward the Arc de Triomphe, who would want to dispute its claim to being the world's most elegant promenade?

title: Housebuster Wins Handily At Gulfstream Park Opener
description: Housebuster, an unproven but awfully quick 3-year-old, scored a handy 2 1/4-length victory today in the $65,000 Spectacular Bid Stakes on opening day at Gulfstream Park.

title: Rights Gains Reversed In Korea, Group Finds
description: A two-year trend of human rights improvements in South Korea has been reversed, Amnesty International, the international human rights group, said today.

title: Man Who Made Threat On a Plane Is Arrested
description: A man claiming he had a bomb took over an America West airliner late today and demanded to be flown to Cuba, but he was arrested soon after the plane made an emergency landing in here, the police said.

title: Review/Opera;   Popular High-Decibel Delights of 'La Gioconda'
description: ''La Gioconda'' is not the worst opera ever written, far from it. The competition is too stiff even to allow Ponchielli's melodrama of lust and treachery in 17th-century Venice to contend for that distinction. It certainly is, however, one of the crudest musical efforts to keep a place in the repertory for more than a century, going toe-to-toe with the best Mozart, Verdi and Wagner could offer. What explains such a work's longevity? Hardly more than the naive delight the human ear takes in being flooded with high-decibel, preferably sonorous sounds.

title: Mary DuBois Schwarz, Board Member, 79
description: Mary DuBois Schwarz, a board member and secretary of the Union Theological Seminary, died on Saturday at the Mary Manning Walsh Nursing Home in Manhattan. She was 79 years old.

title: Fuji Is Seeking Rest of Subaru of America for $149 Million
description: Fuji Heavy Industries Ltd., the Japanese maker of Subaru cars, said today that it had offered to buy the half of Subaru of America it does not own.

title: A Clockwork Inauguration, With an Ad Lib for Honesty
description: James J. Florio has been called a ''hands on'' official so often since his election in November that the words almost seem part of his name. And his inauguration as Governor today can only add to his reputation for detail.

title: Trace Products reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Included tax credits of $16,000 and $426,000, or 4 cents a share, for the quarter and 9 months, respectively.

title: White House Hopes to Still The Siren Song of a Tax Cut
description: Concerned that a proposal to cut Social Security taxes could turn into a political quagmire, top White House officials have been conducting an intensive campaign to keep conservative Republicans from endorsing an enticing idea in an election year.

title: Vitalink Communications Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $1,386,000, or 12 cents a share, which represented net gain on sale of discontinued operations; and also included an extraordinary credit of $1,018,000, or 9 cents a share, from a tax credit.

title: GREATER U.N. ROLE IS URGED TO SETTLE CAMBODIA CONFLICT
description: The five permanent members of the United Nations Security Council called today for the United Nations to administer Cambodia and supervise free elections there.

title: Hartmarx Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
A Price on Their Heads
description: To the Editor:

title: Court Takes Up Molestation Issue: Child's Fears vs. Suspect's Rights
description: In two cases with national implications for child abuse prosecutions, the Supreme Court agreed today to decide what steps states may take under the Constitution to shield young victims of sexual abuse from facing their suspected assailants.

title: James Heffernan, Photographer, 79
description: James Heffernan, a retired photographer for the New York City Fire Department and for the Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York, died of colon cancer on Saturday at Calvary Hospital in the Bronx. He was 79 years old and lived in Jackson Heights, Queens.

title: Northwest and Delta Match $12 Surcharge for Fuel Cost
description: Northwest Airlines and Delta Air Lines matched American Airlines yesterday in adding a $12 surcharge on every round-trip ticket to help cover the rising cost of fuel.

title: Renowned Renoir to Be Auctioned in May
description: Pierre Auguste Renoir's 1876 depiction of an open-air dance hall in Montmartre, ''Au Moulin de la Galette,'' will go on the auction block in New York on May 16, Sotheby's announced yesterday.

title: Syntrex Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 27
description: b-Included loss of $1,538,726 from termination of proposed acquisition.

title: Northern Trust Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The per share earnings for 1989 reflected the issuance of common stock to the company's employee stock ownership plan, additional shares related to performance incentives and the conversion of convertible stock into common stock, partially offset by the stock buyback program.

title: Radiation Risk Hardly Below Regulatory Concern
description: To the Editor:

title: Citicorp to Cut 215 Jobs at Unit
description: Citicorp said today that it would cut 215 jobs in a reorganization of its money-losing Citicorp Scrimgeour Vickers equities unit.

title: Bridge
description: The New Jersey Bridge League lost one of its leading players and most colorful personalities when Frank Burstein of Springfield, N.J., died Friday at the age of 56 after heart surgery. He is survived by his wife, Phyllis, a past president of the league.

title: Lee Goldstein, Composer, 37
description: Lee Goldstein, a conductor of operas and musical-theater pieces and a former composer in residence at the Lyric Opera of Chicago, died on Friday at St. Joseph Hospital in Chicago. He was 37 years old.

title: Treasury Issues Move Downward
description: Prices of Treasury notes and bonds fell further and short-term bill rates shot higher yesterday as market participants sold securities in the aftermath of another big drop in prices on Japanese financial markets.

title: Burlington Northern Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss c-After income from discontinued operations of $44,417,000, or 58 cents a share, for the quarter and $57,048,000, or 73 cents a share, for the year. The company said during the fourth quarter of 1988, it reported an extraordinary loss of $108.5 million (net of income taxes of $66.5 million) relating to the settlement of an antitrust action for the quarter and year. At the insistence of the Securities and Exchange Commission, the total settlement amount of $175 million has been reclassified as an unusual item.

title: Seen More Ofter: Man (or Woman) Eating Alligator
description: LEAD: JOHN TANNER stands on the bank of a canal at the Merritt Island National Wildlife Refuge in the shadow of a launching pad at the Kennedy Space Center. Staring at the water, he emits a series of guttural, gulping grunts. The canal simmers, and several alligators pop to the surface. Only their bumpy nostrils, knobby, listless eyes, and rows of scutes - the bony protrusions on their backs - are visible.

title: Carbon Monoxide Kills Five In a Colorado Springs Home
description: Carbon monoxide fumes from a furnace killed a woman and four children a week after they moved into their home here.

title: A.T.&T. Pinpoints Cause of Phone Disruption
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said yesterday that it had traced the huge disruption in long-distance service that occurred Monday to a single computer program that malfunctioned and caused a chain reaction in the network.

title: Blue Chips Lead Rebound; Dow Up 23.25
description: Blue-chip stocks rose strongly yesterday on sharply higher volume, as the stock market bounced back from two losing sessions.

title: No Headline
description: RESTAURATEURS across the country have seen the future and it is cheap. Or at least less expensive. While the best restaurants with opulent appointments, large staffs and high-priced food will always have their place, many have seen customers move on to less expensive food and more casual surroundings. The restaurateurs' response has been to extend their empires with restaurants where the tab is often half what it is in the parent establishment.

title: Writing Children's Textbooks: Too Many Cooks?
description: Kate McMullan is not sure just what snapped on the day she decided to stop writing school textbooks.

title: Georgia Gulf's Plan Is Backed
description: The head of the company that controls 9.9 percent of the stock of the Georgia Gulf Corporation, the Atlanta-based chemicals maker, said he would support a recapitalization plan announced Monday by the Georgia Gulf board.

title: Robert Campeau's Special Genius
description: Any corporate executive can figure out how to file for bankruptcy when the bottom drops out of the business. It took the special genius of Robert Campeau, chairman of the Campeau Corporation, to figure out how to bankrupt more than 250 profitable department stores. The dramatic jolt to Bloomingdale's, Abraham & Straus, Jordan Marsh and the other proud stores reflects his overreaching grasp and oversized ego.

title: Notre Dame Prevails Against Rutgers, 74-69
