description: Notre Dame and Rutgers, two teams that figured to be in more prominent positions at this juncture of the college basketball season, offered little indication tonight that the preseason predictions were accurate.

title: Basil D. Henning, 79, Resident Master at Yale
description: Dr. Basil Duke Henning, an educator, author and the resident master of Saybrook College at Yale University for 29 years, died Monday at Yale University Health Services Center in New Haven after a long illness. He was 79 years old and lived in New Haven.

title: Reveille for Sophomores
description: Space flight, once the most glamorous of enterprises, has become about as interesting as a crew of furniture deliverers at work. And as the flights have lost their glamour, an associated tradition that once seemed amusing - the morning wake-up call to the astronauts - has become annoying.

title: 'One New Jersey'
description: What George Bush deprecates as ''the vision thing'' is, in the hands of James Florio, vision, and it does credit to the voters who chose him as New Jersey's new Governor. His success at realizing it will depend on fiscal good luck and his stomach for hard choices.

title: The Pop Life
description: Home for Rock-and-Roll

title: Elcor Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included extraordinary tax credits of $385,000, or 5 cents a share, and $1,516,000, or 21 cents a share, for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: Aristech Chemical Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain of $23,700,000, or 63 cents a share, from a cumulative effect on prior years of change in accounting for income taxes.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Accounts
description: * Oracle Corp., to Chiat/Day/Mojo San Francisco, for its data-base management systems and software, with a budget of $8 million to 10 million.

title: Centrust Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a charge of about $42 million to record a writedown to lower of cost or market value on $258 million principal amount of certain corporate debt securities that mature after June 30, 1994, but may not be held by the bank after that date under the Financial Institutions Reform, Recovery, and Enforcement Act (FIRREA) of 1989. c-Net income Centrust attributed the loss in the latest fiscal year to a variety of factors, primarily arising from changes in law and regulatory directives, including: a regulatory directive to take an additional writedown on defaulted securities; a provision for loan and securities losses aggregating about $42 million; a $21 million annual charge against earnings attributable to the amortization of Centrust's goodwill, and the accumulation of lower-yielding, shorter-term assets in anticipation of the pending branch sale to Great Western Bank, who is awaiting regulatory approval and is part of Centrust's plan to come into compliance with FIRREA.

title: Dinkins Again Delays Picking A New Health Commissioner
description: Mayor David N. Dinkins has again postponed his appointment of a health commissioner for New York City while attempts are made to resolve persistent criticisms of the leading candidate, Dr. Woodrow A. Myers Jr. Despite Dr. Myers's national reputation as an advocate on AIDS issues and his endorsement Friday by a panel of New York City AIDS experts, he has been dogged by controversy over his record in his current post as Indiana's Health Commissioner.

title: U.S. to Ease Passport Curbs on Visitors Infected With AIDS Virus
description: The Federal Government is easing, but not eliminating, restrictions on the freedom of people infected with the AIDS virus to enter the United States, and will no longer use a stamp on passports to indicate the holder is infected with the virus, Federal officials said today.

title: A Talk With Takeshita: Japan's Former Leader Denies He's Still in Charge
description: Seven months after resigning in one of the worst scandals of Japan's postwar era, former Prime Minister Noboru Takeshita winces when it is suggested that he continues to wield as much power as ever, perhaps even more power than the current occupant of his old job.

title: Brainard Cheney, Novelist, 89
description: Brainard Cheney, the author of five novels set in the swamp country of Georgia, died at a nursing home Monday after a long illness. He was 89 years old.

title: New York State Food Policy
description: To The Living Section:

title: Real Estate;   A New Face For Stretch Of Fifth Ave.
description: AN accelerating building boom is changing the face of Fifth Avenue between the New York Public Library and the Empire State Building, an internationally famous area that had started to lose its luster.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Prudential Switches to Marschalk
description: IN a blow to one British-owned American advertising agency and a boost to another, the Prudential Insurance Company of America yesterday withdrew its $60 million account from Backer, Spielvogel, Bates and awarded it to Lowe Marschalk.

title: Text of the U.N. Declaration On the Conflict in Cambodia
description: Following is the text of a declaration on Cambodia issued here today at the end of a two-day meeting of the five permanent members of the United Nations Security Council - the United Sates, the Soviet Union, China, Britain and France:

title: Security Pacific Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company attributed a net loss for the year of $142 million in Arizona to higer real estate related loan losses, especially in the fourth quarter.

title: Japan to Keep Its Auto Quota
description: Japan will continue to voluntarily restrict exports of passenger autos to the United States to 2.3 million cars a year in the coming year, trade officials said today.

title: Fluke (John) Manufacturing (A) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 29
A Superhuman Collapse;   A.T.&T.'s Troubles Show How Computers Defy Understanding Even When They Fail
description: The failure of American Telephone and Telegraph Company's long distance switching system on Monday is a warning of the troubling vulnerability of the nation's complex computer networks to unpredictable breakdowns, either accidental or deliberate, computer scientists said yesterday.

title: Club Med Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Net loss The company said results for the year-ago periods were negatively affected by closings at several of its sites because of construction difficulties, hurricane Gilbert and the political climate in Haiti.

title: Older Than Forks, Safer Than Knives
description: THIS is a plea for chopsticks. Chopsticks for pasta. Chopsticks for string beans. Chopsticks for french fries. Chopsticks for grilled chanterelles. Indeed, chopsticks for just about anything, except perhaps a thick hunk of meat. I have one friend who even uses them to eat ice cream.

title: Roseanne's Tough Act: Is It Too Harsh?
description: Is the ubiquitous Roseanne Barr in danger of losing it? Is she about to carry her tough-guy persona a little too far and thereby alienate the audience she once charmed with her impudent bulk and nasally quips? True, her weekly sitcom still hangs up there at the top of the television ratings, often in the No. 1 spot. Her book, ''Roseanne: My Life as a Woman'' (Harper & Row, 1989), also is on best-seller lists around the country. But her first movie, ''She-Devil'' was an out-and-out bomb, grossing just over $12.8 million in its first 38 days of release - and sinking fast.

title: Southeastern Public Service Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Included a $300,000 realized gain on the sale of marketable securities.

title: Intel Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 30
Market Place;   First Boston's Losses on Campeau
description: The First Boston Corporation emerged yesterday as by far the largest unsecured creditor of the two principal retailing subsidiaries of the Campeau Corporation, but the investment banking firm insisted its actual exposure was far less than the $526.3 million that the bankruptcy filings stated it was owed.

title: Northern California Jolted
description: An earthquake shook a sparsely populated area in Northern California today but no injuries or major damage was reported, the United States Geological Survey said. The epicenter was off the Pacific Coast, about 50 miles southwest of Eureka. A spokesman for the earthquake center here said the tremor, which measured 5.3 on the Richter scale, was unrelated to the major earthquake that shook the San Franciso Bay area last Oct. 17.

title: Noriega's Party Wants a Role Again
description: Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega's Government may be history, but his civilian political party - at least part of it, anyway - is still around. In fact, four members of the party faithful emerged from seclusion today and announced that they had decided to become the loyal opposition.

title: East Berlin Faults Opposition on Raid
description: The East German police asserted today that protesters who raided State Security headquarters on Monday had caused millions of dollars in damage, and they said the opposition group New Forum was partly to blame for the incident.

title: WINE TALK
description: Call it mont-ra-SHAY or MOAN-ra-shay: however you pronounce it, Montrachet, at 239 West Broadway (White Street) in TriBeCa, has been a hit since it opened five years ago.

title: First Virginia Banks Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Kopeck Capers
description: Not the least of Mikhail Gorbachev's problems is the Soviet Union's unbalanced budget. To trim the deficit, he is taking a substantial bite out of military spending, and otherwise looking for small savings wherever he can find them.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Jan. 6 about the coming marriage of Susan Eisenhower and Roald Z. Sagdeyev, a Soviet scientist, referred incorrectly to the institute where he does research. It is the Institute for Advanced Study in Princeton, N.J.

title: Jack Ashby, 78, Dies; Kaiser Steel Executive
description: Jack L. Ashby, an investment banker and a retired president of the Kaiser Steel Corporation, died Jan. 7 at Children's Hospital in San Francisco, where he had been taken after a short illness. He was 78 years old.

title: Review/Theater;   A Minimalist 'Othello' Focuses on the Play
description: It is something of a mystery why so many directors, often intelligent and talented ones, feel the need to find some gimmick to make the plays of William Shakespeare palatable to the doltish groundlings who make up a modern theater audience.

title: CUOMO PROPOSES AUSTERITY BUDGET WITH MORE TAXES
description: Saying that ''there is a huge gap between what we want to spend and what we can afford to spend,'' Gov. Mario M. Cuomo presented an austere budget today that would increase state spending by the lowest rate in more than a decade and would force cuts in dozens of state programs.

title: First Union Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said fourth quarter results were affected by several non- recurring and other unusual expenses totaling $42 million pre-tax, or 25 cents a share, after tax.

title: 157 More Request Salary Arbitration
description: Kevin Mitchell, the San Francisco Giants slugger who was considered the best player in baseball in 1989, reached the $2 million salary plateau yesterday. The agreement kept him out of salary arbitration, but 157 other players, including Jose Canseco, Will Clark, Paul Molitor and Bo Jackson, filed for arbitration on a record-setting day.

title: FOOD NOTES
description: 4688, the Horse The celebration of the Chinese New Year 4688, the Year of the Horse, begins on Jan. 27. For a preview this Saturday, Howard Goldberg, who runs Adventure on a Shoestring tours, will lead a walking tour of Chinatown and explain the celebrations.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   USA Today Selects Babbit
description: USA Today has named the new office of Babbit & Reiman in New York, a spunky, creative boutique with headquarters in Atlanta, to handle its advertising account.

title: Europe's Military Chiefs Meet In a Step to Reduce Tensions
description: The military chiefs of 35 countries, including the United States and the Soviet Union, sat down together at the same table for the first time today at an extraordinary seminar intended to reduce tensions in Europe.

title: Alloys Expanding the Use of Plastics
description: rrThe Monsanto Company's chemical division has created a variety of plastic alloys that it says are harder and more resistant to shattering, high temperatures and hazardous chemicals.

title: Georgia Pacific Seeks New Nekoosa Board
description: The Georgia Pacific Corporation, which is engaged in a battle to win control of the Great Northern Nekoosa Corporation, said yesterday that it had begun to solicit proxies to remove Great Northern's board at a special shareholders meeting.

title: Former Lion Sentenced
description: Reggie Rogers, a former Detroit Lion convicted of negligent homicide, was sentenced yesterday in Pontiac, Mich., to up to two years in prison for the deaths of three teen-agers in a 1988 traffic accident involving the vehicle he was driving.

title: U.S. Halves Dosage for AIDS Drug
description: The Federal Government yesterday halved the recommended dose of AZT, the only drug approved for the treatment of AIDS, after concluding that the lower dose was just as effective and caused fewer dangerous side effects.

title: Parents Face the Music for Truants
description: Three parents who let their daughters skip school for a rock concert have volunteered to serve detention time in the principal's office in place of their children.

title: 2 Miguels Stride Boldly in Wine-Making
description: NO one has ever accused the Torres wine-making family of lacking boldness.

title: Grand Met Buying 2 Liquor Stakes
description: Grand Metropolitan P.L.C., the British food and liquor giant, said its International Distillers and Vintners unit would buy a 49 percent stake in the French liquor company Remy Martin et Cie S.A. and a 19 percent holding in Cointreau et Cie S.A. Grand Met is buying the stakes from the Max Cointreau family. The remaining stakes are held by Cointreau family members.

title: Rochefort Returns
description: Norman Rochefort returned to the Rangers yesterday and was to play his first National Hockey League game in almost a year tomorrow, against the Penguins in Pittsburgh.

title: Newsletter To Publish Ernst Report
description: The editor of Accounting Today said yesterday that his newsletter would publish in its Feb. 5 issue what he believes to be the confidential document that Ernst & Young went to court to block another newsletter from publishing.

title: Chronicle
description: Once the most prominent figure in the Arab oil world, SHEIK AHMED ZAKI YAMANI cut a colorful figure with his lavish life of private jets, many residences and perfect French suits. He was abruptly dismissed as Saudi Arabia's oil minister by King Fahd in 1986 in a disagreement on oil-price policy.

title: Colonel Held in Salvador Ordered Killings of Jesuits, Cristiani Says
description: President Alfredo Cristiani said today that a colonel arrested in the killing of six Jesuit priests had ordered the slayings and that two lieutenants had named him in their confessions.

title: PRAGUE HONORS MARTYRED STUDENT
description: In an act as symbolic as Jan Palach's self-immolation 21 years ago, the people of Prague today renamed Red Army Square for the student who burned himself to death to protest what the Soviet occupation in 1968 had done to his country.

title: Some 'Fiftysomething' Achievers Are Neither Silent Nor Male
description: To the Editor:

title: New York City Real Estate's Value Rising by 10.8%
description: The taxable value of real estate in New York City will rise to $77.7 billion in the fiscal year beginning July 1, an increase of 10.8 percent over the current year's figure, tentative city figures showed yesterday.

title: Doctor Blames Error by Intern For AIDS Case
description: Dr. Veronica Prego acknowledged yesterday that she knew of no witnesses to corroborate her version of how she accidentally stuck her finger on a syringe needle that had been used to draw blood from an AIDS patient.

title: U.S. WILL EXAMINE A METAL'S EFFECTS
description: The Department of Energy announced today that it planned to conduct a study to determine the effects of beryllium, a toxic metal, on thousands of workers in nuclear weapons plants exposed to the substance, The Energy Department designated a special panel, which is already looking into how well the department is assessing the health of its workers, to help design the study on beryllium.

title: Leader of Opposition Returns to Nicaragua
description: The leading opposition presidential candidate, Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, returned to Nicaragua today and was apparently in good health after receiving treatment in the United States for a broken right knee.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   People
description: * Fred Berger, a former vice chairman of Hill & Knowlton, has been named a deputy director for external affairs of Partnership for a Drug-Free America. Bernie Gross is leaving BBDO, where he was a senior vice president, to become deputy director of communications, and Ginna Sulcer was named deputy director for creative development and research.

title: Hilton Hotels Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a $2.4 million, or 5 cents a share, after-tax loss from a property transaction.

title: INSIDE
description: Japan's Ex-Leader Speaks

title: Dukakis Says Harm Of Presidential Bid Was Unanticipated
description: In his final State of the State speech, Gov. Michael S. Dukakis said tonight that he had not anticipated the damage his Presidential campaign would have on Massachusetts and his family.

title: Slovenia Seeks Party Change
description: Slovenia's party leadership demanded today that Yugoslavia's ruling League of Communists transform itself into a loose coalition of regional communist parties. The proposal is to be discussed at a national party congress scheduled for Saturday, the state Tanjug news agency reported.

title: Jets' Hunt Goes On
description: Dick Steinberg, the Jets' new general manager, has met with Floyd Peters, the defensive coordinator of the Minnesota Vikings, in the team's search for a head coach, the Jets said yesterday.

title: Loyola Capital Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Metropolitan Diary
description: WHEN Peggy Rosen boarded the downtown IRT local at 72d Street, she noticed a fur-lined leather glove fall to the floor just as a well-dressed man rose and prepared to exit. Having lost countless gloves, scarfs, umbrellas and other accessories to the city's transportation system, Ms. Rosen could not ignore the incident. Instinctively, she pounced on the expensive-looking glove and, with a flair worthy of Dwight Gooden, whammied it onto the platform just as the doors were closing.

title: Profits Scoreboard
Knicks Off on a Perilous Road Trip
description: ''The dog days of January are upon us,'' Paul Silas, the Knicks' assistant coach, proclaimed after the victory Monday over the Chicago Bulls at Madison Square Garden.

title: Drawing by the (Ethnic) Numbers
description: Irene Trivas, an artist, stopped accepting assignments to illustrate children's readers four years ago, partly out of frustration over publishers' efforts to ''be everything to everybody,'' as she put it. Here is her account of the instrucitons she received for one book:

title: Rockwell International reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said its fiscal first quarter was adversely affected by lower interest income and higher interest expense, which together reduced earnings by 5 cents a share, compared to the first quarter of last year.

title: R. Peter Nyquist, Administrator, 31
description: R. Peter Nyquist, a physicians' assistant and administrator of the AIDS Team at Bronx Municipal Hospital Center, died of complications of AIDS on Jan. 9 at Montefiore Medical Center in the Bronx. He was 31 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary on Thursday about the founder of the Reece School in Manhattan, a private school for children with emotional and learning disabilities, misidentified her. She was Ellen Steele Reece.

title: Abilene Journal;   Centennial Lifts Spirit Of Ike's Hometown
description: Dorothy Lehman was only 17 years old when a Life photographer caught her and some fellow students snake dancing through Abilene streets, a moment that captured the spirit of Gen. Dwight D. Eisenhower's first Presidential victory.

title: Linseman-Poulin Trade
description: Ken Linseman, who began his National Hockey League career with Philadelphia in 1978, returned to the Flyers yesterday when the Boston Bruins traded him for Dave Poulin in an exchange of 31-year-old centers.

title: Ceausescu's Burmese Twin
description: To the Editor:

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A2-13

title: 2 Foreign Bank Units Plead Guilty to Money Laundering
description: In the first Federal case of money laundering against a large international bank, two principal units of the Luxembourg-based Bank of Credit and Commerce International agreed today to plead guilty to reduced charges and to forfeit $14 million.

title: Officials' Handling of Suspects in Boston Killing Prompts Questions
description: Nearly two weeks ago, the Suffolk County District Attorney held a news conference to announce that Charles Stuart had become the focus of the investigation into the killings last autumn of his wife and unborn child.

title: Security Pacific Chief Decides to Step Aside
description: The Security Pacific Corporation, the nation's fourth-largest banking company, said yesterday that Richard J. Flamson 3d had stepped aside as chief executive at the age of 60 and had been replaced by Robert H. Smith, who formerly headed the company's major bank subsidiary.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about the sale of the Mister Donut franchise operation by its parent, the International Multifoods Corporation of Minneapolis, to Dunkin'

title: Talks on Bank to Aid the East Bloc End in Dispute
description: An East-West meeting on establishing a development bank to help Eastern Europe's troubled economies ended today with some dispute over whether the bank's lending should be limited to only the private sector.

title: Mellon Bank Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary gain of $29 million, or 68 cents a share, on the early retirement of debt. c-Net loss There were no per share earnings in the latest quarter after preferred dividend requirements. Provisions for credit losses for the latest periods totaled $147 million for the quarter and $297 million for the year, compared with $54 million and $321 million for the year-ago periods, respectively. Mellon reported gains for the latest fourth quarter of $27 million from the sale of Mellon Investdata Corp., $18 million from the sale of equity securities and lease residuals, and $11 million from the settlement of pension obligations.

title: Japan Promises More Economic Aid for Hungary
description: Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu of Japan promised increased economic aid to Hungary today as he completed a 10-day trip in which Japan's largess made him a big hit in Eastern Europe and its huge trade surplus made him a big target in Western Europe.

title: Maxtor Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 24
RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Campeau Situation

title: U.S. Postpones Deploying Ships Near Colombia
description: The Administration has postponed plans to deploy an aircraft carrier battle group off the coast of Colombia to help prevent drug shipments from Latin America to the United States, Administration officials said today.

title: Wells Fargo & Co reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said earnings in the fourth quarter and the year 1989 benefited from increased net interest income, which primarily results from an increase in domestic loans.

title: Everyday Dish That's a Classic
description: POT-AU-FEU, the French boiled meat and vegetable dish, was the classic winter Sunday lunch of my youth. Then, lunch was the biggest meal of the day and dinner usually consisted of leftovers from lunch with fruit and cheese.

title: About New York;   Poverty Loses When Roberto, 3, Reads This 'R'
description: Roberto F., the 3-year-old in the red turtleneck, studied the object he had been asked to identify. ''Pencil,'' he said.

title: Are Invasions Sometimes O.K.?
description: LEAD: While the U.S. invasion of Panama provoked a great deal of debate, there was no argument about possible French and Russian intervention in Rumania. And that raises an important question: Could big-power intervention -so often used in the past by Washington and Moscow to establish repressive regimes - now become a positive force wielded on behalf of democracy and human rights?

title: Iran Asks Soviets to Respond With Caution
description: Iran, expressing concern about violence across its border in the Trans-Caucasus region of the Soviet Union, urged Moscow today not to use force in the area.

title: Orange-Co reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net income

title: Briton Pledges Hong Kong Changes
description: The British Foreign Secretary wound up a four-day visit here today, saying Hong Kong wanted to see the pace of democratic changes quickened as the colony moves toward its return to Chinese control in 1997.

title: Boy, 12, Is Fatally Shot In Queens Apartment
description: A 12-year-old boy was fatally shot while playing in his Queens apartment last night when a gun owned by a 17-year-old youth apparently misfired, striking the boy in the chest, the police said.

title: Settlement Reached on Home for Retarded
description: In a landmark housing discrimination case, a Federal district judge today approved a settlement allowing the construction of a home for retarded people in Chicago Heights, a suburb of Chicago.

title: Advanced Micro Devices reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss c-Included unusual charge of $17,260,000 associated with a work force reduction, closure of a manufacturing facility and other restructuring actions for the quarter and year. Year-ago quarter and year ended Dec. 25, 1988.

title: Calling All Bankruptcy Lawyers . . .
description: This morning at 8:30 sharp, a swarm of lawyers and journalists descended on the Federal Bankruptcy Court here to get the first public look at the mounds of documents in the Chapter 11 bankruptcy filing of the Campeau Corporation's American retailing operations.

title:
Currents;

Miniature Rooms: Details at a Glance
description: LEAD: MINIATURE rooms appeal on several levels. These microcosms of period settings can be easily taken in at a glance, and yet another look reveals extensively crafted detail. Thirty such rooms will be on display tomorrow through Jan. 28 at the Winter Antiques Show at the Seventh Regiment Armory at Park Avenue and 66th

title: U.S. Arts Endowment Names Two Officials
description: Two administrators with the National Endowment for the Arts in Washington have been named directors of programs at the endowment.

title: BRIEFS
description: * American Pioneer Inc., Orlando, Fla., the parent company of American Pioneer Savings Bank, said it would sell certain assets and operations of its Catalina Homes Inc. and Jonathon Group Inc. units for $65.7 million to Catalina Homes Acquisition Ltd., a Florida limited partnership.

title: Review/Art;   Black Images of the Past: Servile, Subhuman
description: ''Facing History: The Black Image in American Art, 1710-1940'' is an exhibition that no thinking person can walk through without feeling a measure of both sorrow and anger. The 100 or so paintings, sculptures and drawings gathered at the Corcoran Gallery of Art testify to a racism so ingrained in the American consciousness that artists - the overwhelming number of whom were white, but some of whom were black - thought nothing about stereotyping blacks as ''grotesque buffoons, servile menials, comic entertainers or threatening subhumans,'' writes Guy C. McElroy, the show's curator, in the exhibition catalogue.

title: Connecting Consumer and Product
description: A STARK photograph shows a father and son sitting in the living room, the son watching TV, the father facing away. It is part of a series of advertisements that depict families in crisis. Public service ads for a family counseling center, perhaps? Promotions for ''thirtysomething''? No. They are the latest ads for Johnson outboard motors.

title: Centrust Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included a charge of about $42 million to record a writedown to lower of cost or market value on $258 million principal amount of certain corporate debt securities that mature after June 30, 1994, but may not be held by the bank after that date under the Financial Institutions Reform, Recovery, and Enforcement Act (FIRREA) of 1989. c-Net income Centrust attributed the loss in the latest fiscal year to a variety of factors, primarily arising from changes in law and regulatory directives, including: a regulatory directive to take an additional writedown on defaulted securities; a provision for loan and securities losses aggregating about $42 million; a $21 million annual charge against earnings attributable to the amortization of Centrust's goodwill, and the accumulation of lower-yielding, shorter-term assets in anticipation of the pending branch sale to Great Western Bank, who is awaiting regulatory approval and is part of Centrust's plan to come into compliance with FIRREA. Corrected from yesterday's editions.

title: Beyond Coziness: Throws to Cling To
description: LEAD: FOR the back seat of a car, for the bare sofa arm in need of a flourish or for the house whose thermostat is set at an invigorating 62 degrees, a lap throw, sometimes called a rug or a shawl, is as essential to winter as a sweater is to autumn. And throws are everywhere this season, in cotton, wool, linen, silk, cashmere and blends.

title: For Pregnant Athletes, Reassurance on Exercise
description: For active athletes who become pregnant, new evidence offers reassurance that vigorous exercise does not damage the fetus.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I didn't want a lawyer. I said, 'The first lawyer who can bring my daughter back, I'll hire.'

title: First Interstate Sets Changes at the Top
description: First Interstate Bancorp said yesterday that Edward M. Carson, its president, would become chairman and chief executive. He will assume the position on June 1, after the retirement at age 65 of Joseph J. Pinola, who has led the Los Angeles-based banking company for 12 years.

title: Missouri Executes Man in Slaying of His Girlfriend
description: A man who was convicted of killing his girlfriend was executed by injection early today, becoming the the 121st nationwide since 1976, when the Supreme Court allowed states to restore the death penalty.

title: Turnovers Hurt Duke In Loss to the Tar Heels
description: North Carolina's intense defense and Rick Fox's 19 points led the Tar Heels to a stunning 79-60 victory over Duke tonight in an Atlantic Coast Conference game.

title: 85 Candles for Backer Of Fly Fishing Center
description: Friends and admirers of Lee Wulff have planned a gala birthday party for him Feb. 10 at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel.

title: Hibernia Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
First Alabama Bancshares reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Dominion Bankshares reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Upheaval in the East;   TOUGH TERMS END A DEAL IN GDANSK
description: Workers hailed a Polish-born heir as a savior when she offered to buy the shipyard where Solidarity, the independent labor union, was born. But when she made her terms clear, the deal unraveled.

title: 3 Held as Thugs Who Used Vans To Rob Women
description: Three men have been charged in a series of assaults and purse snatchings in New York City in which vans were used as getaway vehicles, the police said yesterday.

title: Upheaval in the East;   Troops Seek to Calm Azerbaijan; Soviets Debate Cause of Violence
description: Soviet troops tried to impose martial law in Azerbaijan today as the country began to debate the causes of a blood bath that seemed both unthinkable and inevitable.

title: 'Perking Pot' Theme Back at Maxwell House
description: Joining a long list of American advertisers who are waxing nostalgic, Maxwell House coffee is reintroducing the ''Perking Pot'' theme song that it all but abandoned in 1975.

title: Burmese Ban Top Opposition Candidate
description: The most popular opposition leader in Myanmar, formerly Burma, was disqualified today from running in elections scheduled for May, Western diplomats said.

title: PRAGUE DISMAYED AT TROOP TALKS
description: A Czechoslovak official said today that negotiations with the Soviet Union on withdrawal of its forces stationed here by the end of this year may have been slowed by Moscow's preoccupation with domestic political problems.

title: Harper's Season Ends
description: Ron Harper of the Los Angeles Clippers will be sidelined for the rest of the season because of a severe injury to his right knee, the National Basketball Association team said yesterday.

title: Knicks Come Up a Bit Short In Yet Another Close Game
description: The Knicks tried tonight to repeat last Saturday night's script and beat the San Antonio Spurs for the second time in five nights.

title: Morgenthau Opposes Legalization of Drugs
description: Pledging ''swift and certain punishment'' for all drug offenders, District Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau of Manhattan came out strongly yesterday against recent proposals to legalize drugs.

title: Multibank Financial Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Hungarian Security Chief Said to Have Resigned
description: The chief of state security has resigned after allegations that his agency illegally monitored opposition activities, the Hungarian press agency said today.

title: H.U.D. Is Ending an Insurance Program That Lost a Billion
description: Housing Secretary Jack F. Kemp today ended a Reagan Administration program in which private lenders committed the Government to insuring mortgages.

title: Parent & Child
description: FOR many children, a transfer from one school to another can seem an overwhelming challenge that not only tests their academic skills but also forces them to re-evaluate who they are and where they fit in the world. The changes in their lives and relationships can lead to feelings of isolation and failure or to feelings of greater competency and higher self-esteem.

title: First Commercial Bancorp reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
Uriel G. Foa, Psychologist, 73
description: Uriel G. Foa, a social psychologist and professor emeritus at Temple University, died of an aortic aneurysm Monday at Osteopathic Hospital in Philadelphia. He was 73 years old and lived in Penn Valley, Pa.

title: Warminster Journal;   Gloom Vanishes in Harmonica Magic
description: Under the paper dinosaurs, apple trees, turtles and snowmen hanging from the ceiling of Room 32, Jim Prushankin is tapping his foot, smiling and throwing out compliments like handfuls of confetti to a circle of second-graders who are learning to play ''When the Saints Go Marching In'' on the harmonica.

title: High Prices Prompt Gifts for Neediest Cases
description: Sometimes a price tag is the impetus for a donation to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: Soviet Wheat Purchase
description: The Soviet Union has bought an additional 525,000 metric tons of United States wheat at subsidized prices for delivery in March under a long-term grain-supply agreement, the Agriculture Department said today. The wheat was sold by four private companies, which will receive subsidies under the department's Export Enhancement Program. The seventh year of the United States-Soviet grain agreement began on Oct. 1. With the latest sales, the Soviet Union has bought about 2.3 million tons of wheat for 1989-90 delivery.

title: Article 690090 -- No Title
description: Dave Stewart, the only pitcher who has won 20 or more games in each of the last three years, vaulted to the top of baseball's salary list yesterday, reaching agreement with the Oakland Athletics on a two-year contract extension worth $7 million.

title: Article 643690 -- No Title
description: Federated Stores Inc., the renamed holding company for the Campeau Corporation's American retailing operations, paid more than $3.74 million in legal and accounting fees as part of its preparations for its bankruptcy filing on Monday, court papers show.

title: Jury in Molest Case Says It Is Deadlocked
description: Jurors have reached verdicts on 52 counts of molestation of children who attended the McMartin Pre-School, but they said today that they are deadlocked on the remaining 13 charges in the nation's longest criminal trial.

title: PNC Financial Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results for 1989 quarter and year reflected a $180 million additional provision for credit losses, a writedown of PNC's investment in a Brazilian subsidiary and a one-time tax expense related to the potential repatriation of off-shore income.

title: NBC Interested in Keeping Up With Joneses
description: Of all the fighters at the 1988 Olympics, Roy Jones Jr. was regarded as the most talented.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Common Stock

title: Personal Health
description: Your eyes may or may not be windows to your soul, but your fingernails can reveal a lot about your habits and your health.

title: L.I. Baymen Resist Shellfishing Ban
description: A battle between state officials and the baymen of eastern Long Island over closing rich shellfishing waters has erupted. The issue is not polluted seas, but the number of state inspectors available to test the waters.

title: Ameritrust Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
AMR Net Falls 66.7% In Quarter
description: The AMR Corporation, the parent of American Airlines, yesterday reported sharply lower earnings in the fourth quarter mainly as a result of rising fuel costs.

title: First Tennessee National Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said its latest quarter results were reduced by one-time charges of $4.2 million from the restructuring of several bank operations and by the loan loss provision.

title: Oil in Arthur Kill: Publicity and Peril for Urban Marsh
description: Donald Decker, a big truck driver with a fondness for chickens and house cats, first noticed the birds along the slow, muddy waters of the Arthur Kill and mentioned them to a bird-watcher friend.

title: Syracuse Will Kick Off
description: Southern California, the Rose Bowl winner, and Syracuse, an Eastern independent, will open the 1990 college football season in the eighth annual Kickoff Classic at Giants Stadium in late August, organizers said today.

title: Westinghouse Net Up 29.8%
description: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation said today that its net income rose 29.8 percent in the fourth quarter as nearly all its main business units posted gains in operating profits.

title: U.S. Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
COLOMBIAN ADMITS DRUG CONSPIRACY
description: A Colombian who prosecutors say ran a network to help drug traffickers hide the source of their money pleaded guilty today to his part in a $32 million worldwide money laundering case.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Things may be looking up for the troubled Detroit Symphony Orchestra. Last August, its members voted to take a 10 percent pay cut to keep the orchestra alive. Earlier, the Michigan Legislature withheld nearly $1.3 million in aid, threatening to picket concerts if the orchestra did not hire more black musicians. And in 1982 the orchestra's famed conductor, Antal Dorati, resigned.

title: Bridge
description: Many of the world's best players from 12 countries, including the United States, will be busy in Western Europe for the rest of this month. The Staten Bank World Top Pairs competition begins today in the Hague. A week later, the circuit moves to London, where The Sunday Times Pairs, a tournament with a great tradition, has been revived after a nine-year hiatus.

title: Critic's Notebook;   How Set Design Can Bolster or Sabotage, and 2 Heroes of the Art
description: In a newsletter published recently by the League of New York Theaters and Producers, Aldo Scrofani, an executive with Jujamcyn Theaters, tells an archetypal theatrical anecdote. ''When Anne Bancroft previewed in 'Golda' at the Wilbur Theater in Boston, an early morning fire destroyed the set and just about everything on stage,'' he reminisces. ''We quickly arranged to move the show across the street to the Shubert and presented it on a bare stage with a desk from the carpenters' room, some chairs, lights and black backdrop. Guess what happened? Yes, magic - theater - at least the Boston audiences thought so.''

title: Shifts at W. B. Doner
description: Following the death two weeks ago of its founder, W. B. Doner, W. B. Donor & Company has formally established operating committees in its Detroit and Baltimore offices. The committees, whose members had conferred with Mr. Doner, will be headed by Herb Fried, the agency's chairman and chief executive.

title: Stocks Drop on Low Earnings Reports
description: Stocks fell broadly yesterday after disappointing earnings reports and some futures-related trading quelled a midmorning rally.

title: Rig Count Slips in Week
description: The number of working oil and gas rigs in the United states dropped by 10 last week, to a total of 1,019, Baker Hughes Inc. reported on Monday. The count, which dropped for the fourth consecutive week, remains above the 840 rigs recorded a year earlier. Baker Hughes's rig count, a widely watched industry index of drilling activity, reflects the number of rotary rigs exploring for oil and gas as of last Friday.

title: Detectives Seek Leads in Officer's Shooting
description: Detectives investigating the shooting of an off-duty police officer in Brooklyn on Tuesday night were left with more questions than answers yesterday as the officer remained in a coma at Kings County Hospital Center, police officials said.

title: The Boss Lauds a Champion Sleeper
description: In response to a note to President Bush asking for some comments about Marlin Fitzwater, the President typed this note in the White House study. The Scowcroft Award that he mentions is named after the national security adviser, who likes his Oval Office naps. The award is given to the White House official who can fall asleep in the most embarrassing situation with no remorse. The ranking committee Mr. Bush refers to is a mythical body that rates potential tennis partners. For the record, the liquid diet mentioned in the note was Optifast, not Slimfast, and helped Mr. Fitzwater lose 55 pounds.

title: Upheaval in the East;   Coal Miners in Poland Strike for Higher Pay
description: More than 6,000 coal miners are on strike for higher pay in southern Poland, and the Finance Minister met today with a delegation of miners to discuss their demands, according to the official press agency.

title: The Big Stick
description: To the Editor:

title: From Art of Marbleizing To Southwest Samplers
description: Folk Art Studies, Folk Art Institute, 61 West 62d Street; 212-977-7170.

title: New York Life Names Successors to Leader
description: The New York Life Insurance Company, one of the nation's largest life insurers, yesterday named a new management lineup to take charge on Aug. 1.

title: First Commercial Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Home Improvement
description: BEFORE wallboard, paneling or accoustical tile can be attached to finished and sometimes to unfinished walls and ceilings, a grid of narrow wooden strips called furring usually must be applied. They provide smooth, flat surfaces to fasten the new material to, and to support it.

title: An Alliance For All Europe
description: As the new decade begins, Europe heads the surprise list. In contrast to the Europe of the early 1980's, the Western system is now clearly ascendant. But Eastern Europe's broad yearnings to duplicate the success of the West, especially its economic success, are not the same as a triumph of Western values, as some too readily proclaim.

title: CHRONICLE
description: As Willy Loman in ''Death of a Salesman,'' DUSTIN HOFFMAN earned great accolades. Tuesday night, he threw a verbal bouquet to the man who made it possible.

title: Main Foes of Apartheid Appear Split
description: Leading figures in South Africa's black nationalist movement began a meeting here today amid signs that they are divided over ways to respond to the increased flexibility of the Pretoria Government under President F. W. de Klerk.

title: Noah and McEnroe Dazzle Just Like They Once Did
description: Yannick Noah is back in all his glory and threatening to crash a party that seemed reserved for the usual big names in tennis.

title: Upheaval in the East;   Rumanian Leaders Cancel a Vote On Banning the Communist Party
description: Reversing itself for the second time in five days, the provisional Government of Rumania canceled a referendum today on banning the Communist Party and on restoring the death penalty.

title: Max Gordon, Daily Worker Editor, 79
description: Max Gordon, who was city editor of The Daily Worker when he broke with the Communist Party in 1956 and who later was a medical writer for Purdue-Frederick, a pharmaceutical company, died of a heart attack Monday at the West Boca Raton (Fla.) Medical Center. He was 79 years old and lived in Boca Raton.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A.

title: Japan to Retain Auto Quota
description: The Japanese Government said today that it would retain its ceiling on car exports to the United States in an effort to defuse trade tensions.

title: Florio to Continue Freeze on State Spending
description: Jim Florio's first public announcement as Governor today declared that his administration would continue a state spending freeze as a first step toward addressing a growing budget shortfall.

title: Lawrence C. Freer Jr., Executive, 69
description: Lawrence Clayton Freer Jr., a business executive, died Saturday at Palm Beach Regional Hospital in West Palm Beach, Fla., where he had lapsed into a coma after liver failure. He was 69 years old and lived in West Palm Beach.

title: Bogota Statement Claims to Offer A Surrender by the Drug Cartels
description: A message that purported to come from Colombia's drug trafficking cartels said today that the Government had won in the war on drugs and offered to halt illegal activities in exchange for an amnesty.

title: Yvon C. Dihe, Advertising Executive, 49
description: Yvon C. Dihe, an advertising agency executive and a fashion industry publicity director known for his extravagant presentations, died of complications of AIDS yesterday at Doctor's Hospital in Manhattan. He was 49 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: $5 Billion Bailout Bond Sale Is Set
description: The Resolution Trust Corporation, the agency overseeing the bailout of the nation's savings and loan industry, will sell $5 billion of 40-year bonds next week, the Treasury Department announced yesterday.

title: Silber of Boston University Enters Massachusetts Race
description: Saying his role as a political outsider was an asset, John Silber, the president of Boston University for 19 years, declared today that he would seek the Democratic nomination for Governor of Massachusetts.

title: 3 Nights of Love Songs For St. Valentine's Day
description: A trio of concerts for St. Valentine's Day is to begin on Feb. 12 at 8 P.M. at the Judson Memorial Church, 55 Washington Square South. Al Carmines, a composer and former minister at the church, and David Vaughan, a dance historian, are to sing love songs from the turn of the century to the 1940's; Mr. Carmines is also to play the piano. The program includes songs by Irving Berlin, Jerome Kern, Johnny Mercer and Mr. Carmines.

title: At Last, Dawn for Cambodia?
description: There seems, finally, to be the promise of life in the Killing Fields. If all goes well, the Khmer Rouge fanatics who slaughtered more than a million Cambodians in the 1970's will, under a plan sponsored by the five permanent members of the United Nations Security Council, be denied control of Cambodia. Significantly, the group includes China, until now the principal benefactor and armorer of the hateful Khmer Rouge.

title: 3 Cases Raise Questions on Boston Police Methods
description: The Boston Police Department, whose methods are already under intense scrutiny in the Charles Stuart case, also faces questions about its handling of two other cases: the 1988 shooting death of a detective and the fatal stabbing of a 19-year-old student this week.

title: Gorbachev in Danger, Kennan Says in Testimony
description: George F. Kennan said today the economic and political problems boiling over in the Soviet Union have put President Mikhail S. Gorbachev in ''danger,'' but he is not likely to be replaced in the near future because his troubles are so acute that even his rivals may not want his job.

title:
Currents;

Chairs With Past And Future
description: LEAD: THE black beechwood armchairs with circular ash motifs in the new Fendi shop on Fifth Avenue at 56th Street are not this year's Italian version of the Regency chair.

title: U.S. CUTS BACK TRIP QUAYLE WILL MAKE IN LATIN COUNTRIES
description: Lingering anxiety among Latin American nations over the American invasion of Panama has forced the Bush Administration to limit a diplomatic mission by Vice President Dan Quayle by putting off trips to Mexico and Venezuela, Administration officials said today.

title: Mr. Cuomo, at Least, Is Serious
description: He might have started sooner, but Gov. Mario Cuomo has now faced up directly to the harsh fiscal reality facing New York. There will be debate about details of his austere new state budget but taken as a whole, it represents a serious response to a chill fact: Tax revenues are in sharp decline.

title: Duke Paper Scolded
description: Believing they had been invited to meet the Duke varsity basketball team, 10 members of the sports staff of The Chronicle, the Duke student newspaper, accepted an invitation from Coach Mike Krzyzewski to visit the team locker room Monday.

title: Sudan Government Can Restore Liberties
description: To the Editor:

title: Citizens First Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Close to Home
description: A FRIEND has given me a picture book titled ''Tiffany Parties.'' I suspect somebody gave it to him, and I plan to pass it on to a third person, a neighbor who is beside herself with excitement. She can hardly wait, she says, and will keep it right next to a treasured biography of Elsie de Wolfe Mendl. I am a bit vague about Elsie de Wolfe Mendl, but aware enough to know that 50 or so years ago she was a famous decorator, that she ascribed her longevity to frequently standing on her head and that her husband, Sir Charles Mendl, had his custom-made union suits embroidered with the year of purchase. My neighbor tells me that Lady Mendl pops up in several books, the best of which includes luncheon recipes. I envision thin women eating creamed chicken in patty shells, the sun over Sutton Place striking a bottle of Pouilly-Fuisse, and chatter akin to that in the autobiography of Lady Mendl's fellow decorator, Billy Baldwin. ''I simply adored Mrs. Weldon,'' reads a typical passage, ''but she was a devil and one of the rudest women I've ever met.''

title: Jay Stuart Haft, Marine Supplier, 62
description: Jay Stuart Haft, co-founder of the Jay Stuart Haft Company, died of leukemia on Monday at Montefiore Medical Center in the Bronx. He was 62 years old and lived in Longboat Key, Fla.

title: Talking Deals;   East Germany As Capitalist
description: A EUROPEAN manufacturer of printing presses and auxiliary equipment was unhappy with the performance of its American sales and service agent. So it decided to buy the distributor to gain direct control of its operations in the United States.

title: PROFITS SCOREBOARD
description: See accompanying notes for special items. (Loss) *Loss in year-earlier period.

title: Greenwich Rejects Building Teen-Agers' Center by a Park
description: A plan to build a center for teen-agers over a parking lot adjoining a town park on Greenwich Harbor was rejected early today by the Representative Town Meeting by a vote of 105 to 89.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The new president of Johns Hopkins University is DR. WILLIAM C. RICHARDSON, the provost of Pennsylvania State University. Dr. Richardson will begin work July 1.

title: Alcoa Profit Falls 24.7%
description: Hurt by the slowdown in the nation's industrial economy, the Aluminum Company of America said today that its fourth-quarter earnings fell 24.7 percent, and the report sent its stock tumbling.

title: U.S. Trust reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: U.S. Trust said its year-ago fourth quarter results reflected a $2 million reduction of income taxes recorded in the 1988 quarter related to the sale of Advanced Information Service Co.

title: Ford Strike Vote
description: Union leaders rejected a two-year pay offer from the Ford Motor Company Ltd. and called a strike vote for next week. Ford's latest offer was a 10.2 percent pay increase in the first year and a choice between 8 percent, or the inflation rate plus 2.5 percent in the second year. It was rejected during talks at the company's London offices. If the union votes Tuesday to reject the proposal, union members will begin an all-out strike beginning with the final shift Jan. 26, officials said. About 9,000 employees were already off the job today, some for a 24-hour strike and some continuing indefinite strikes begun Monday. Ford said it had responded by laying off more than 10,500 employees. It employs 32,000 workers at 22 British plants. Levi Strauss Closing Plant DALLAS, Jan. 17 - Levi Strauss & Company said today that it would close one of three sewing plants in San Antonio in April and lay off 1,100 workers.

title: Time for a Danube Basin Common Market
description: To the Editor:

title: EXECUTIVES
description: * Alsy Corp., Hicksville, L.I., a maker of portable lamps, named John M. Eikenberg chairman, president and chief executive. He succeeds Sy Stewart as chairman and Al Gindel as president. Mr. Stewart and Mr. Gindel retired.

title: A Looking Glass Takes a Delicate Touch
description: LEAD: Mirrors of brass are mentioned in the Bible, and the Greeks and Romans made mirrors of polished silver and bronze. But it is only during the last 300 years that people have been able to take a very good look at themselves, and for much of that time only a privileged few could.

title: Another for Montana
description: The Maxwell Football Club of Philadelphia yesterday named Joe Montana the winner of the 31st annual Bert Bell Award as this season's outstanding professional football player.

title: Nagasaki Mayor Is Shot in Attack
description: The Mayor of Nagasaki, who has received numerous death threats from right-wing groups over his suggestion that the late Emperor Hirohito bore some responsibility for World War II, was shot in chest today by a lone gunman in front of the City Hall in his home city.

title: Joe Alex Morris, 85, a Journalist And a Biographer of Rockefellers
description: Joe Alex Morris, a journalist and author who specialized in foreign affairs and biography, died of pneumonia Tuesday at White Plains Hospital. He was 85 years old and lived in the Riverdale section of the Bronx. He also had homes in Guilford, Conn., and Vineyard Haven, Mass.

title: Dr. Y. C. James Yen Is Dead at 96; Led International Self-Help Group
description: Y. C. James Yen, founder of a movement to combat illiteracy, poverty and hunger in developing countries on three continents, died of pneumonia yesterday at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center. He was 96 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Greater Reliance on Foreign Oil Feared as U.S. Output Tumbles
description: America's oil production suffered its biggest single-year decline ever in 1989, falling by more than half a million barrels a day, the American Petroleum Institute reported yesterday.

title: Contrasts on Chips;   As a Joint Venture Collapses in U.S., Japanese Companies Act Like a Cartel
description: The contrast was striking: On the day last week when American electronics companies decided to abandon their cooperative venture to make computer chips, their competitors in Tokyo had already moved in lockstep.

title: Singapore Orders Jets From U.S.
description: Encouraged by recent alliances with American and European airlines, Singapore Airlines said it had placed an order for 30 Boeing B747-400's for $5.5 billion and 20 McDonnell Douglas MD-11's for $3.1 billion.

title: Upheaval in the East;   Gorbachev Is Backed On Azerbaijan Combat
description: Expressing deep concern over the latest tumultuous ethnic conflict to unsettle their country, many Soviet citizens voiced overwhelming support today for the decision by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev to send troops to control violent fighting in parts of Azerbaijan.

title: Nerve Protein Raises Hope for Paralyzed
description: Using a genetically engineered protein, Swiss researchers have succeeded in getting nerves in severed spinal cords in rats to grow again. The finding could ultimately lead to new clinical treatments to repair nerves damaged from accidents, strokes and a wide variety of degenerative nervous system diseases.

title: Liberty National Bancorp Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
First Florida Banks reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After charge for restructuring and voluntary early retirement plan of $7.6 million. First Florida said during the latest fourth quarter, it increasedits provision for loan losses by $5 million, of which $1.5 million was utilized to cover additional charge-offs.

title: Eye Drops and Soda Make Federal Drug Tests Too Easy to Beat
description: To the Editor:

title: Foxmoor Files For Protection
description: Dylex Ltd. said today that its subsidiary the Foxmoor Speciality Stores Corporation had filed in New York for protection under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code.

title: Trade Gap Widened in November
description: The nation's trade deficit grew in November to $10.5 billion, the biggest monthly gap of 1989, the Commerce Department reported today.

title: U.S. Judge Sets Noriega Trial for Week of March 5
description: A Federal judge today set the week of March 5 as a target date for starting the trial of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega and five co-defendants on charges of trafficking in drugs.

title: The Budget As Politics
description: At first blush, it does not look like an election-year budget.

title: Washington at Work;   In Bush's White House, the Press Secretary Is the One With the White Hat
description: Marlin Fitzwater is pulling hats out of a closet.

title: Home Loan Banks' Bonds Are Priced
description: A $1.76 billion financing by the Federal Home Loan Banks was priced yesterday at par through various securities dealers. Maturities available to investors include one year, three years, five years and ten years.

title: DEALS
description: BASEBALL

title: G.O.P. Blurs Focus on Abortion, To Dismay of Some Party Faithful
description: Republican leaders have begun a subtle operation to recast their party's approach to abortion in the 1990 elections, and the effort is already stirring concern in the party's anti-abortion wing.

title: Upheaval in the East;   Kohl Says Germans Don't Want Border Debates
description: Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany said today that the Germans had no intention of setting off a debate about borders that could undermine peace in Europe.

title: Sales Tax on Religious Goods Upheld
description: The Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that states may apply their general sales taxes to religious organizations' sales of religious books and articles.

title: Housewares New and Biodegradable
description: Mindful that growing numbers of Americans are concerned about pollution, housewares manufacturers are increasingly turning out products that they say are environmentally safe. The proof was at the 91st National Housewares Show, which ended today after a three-and-a-half-day run at the McCormick Place exposition center here.

title: Comerica Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
The Writing on the Wall Foretells an Adventure
description: EAT your heart out, Norman Mailer.

title: Review/Comedy;   Comic Safari: Five Hours On the Trail Of Laughs
description: Comedy, more than any other entertainment form, tends to be treated like the show-business equivalent of fast food. All that's needed to produce it is a microphone, a brick wall and a ready supply of comics with 20 minutes of humorous chatter.

title: Edward Strong, 88, Berkeley Chancellor At Time of Turmoil
description: Dr. Edward W. Strong, chancellor of the University of California at Berkeley in the early 1960's, died of cancer Saturday at his home in Berkeley. He was 88 years old.

title: Bozell Revamping
description: Bozell yesterday announced a restructuring of its European operations. Roger Neill, the deputy chairman of WCRS Worldwide, now part of Eurocom WCRS Della Femina Ball Ltd., will join Bozell as chief executive of Bozell Europe, effective Feb. 15. Winston Fletcher, chairman of DFSD Bozell in London, was appointed chairman of Bozell Europe. Andre Gohet was named executive vice president of the European operation.

title: Household Finance Prices Certificates
description: The Household Finance Corporation, a unit of Household International Inc. and one of the largest issuers of home equity loan securities, yesterday priced a total of $903 million in certificates that are backed mostly by home equity loans.

title: Summit Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
O'Connor Asks Legislative Votes on Abortion
description: John Cardinal O'Connor said today that the Legislature should vote on anti-abortion bills, even if the bills lack the support to become law. He sharply criticized legislative leaders for suggesting that there was no need to vote on such measures, including one that would require parental consent for a minor's abortion.

title: In 2 Shows, Rooms of Whimsy
description: IN two furnishings shows in New England - one in Providence, R.I., the other in Cambridge, Mass. - whimsy prevails.

title: MNC Financial reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: All shares outstanding and per share earnings have been restated to reflect a 100 percent stock dividend distributed Oct. 5.

title: Perfect Record Restored
description: The Illinois High School Association today restored the 14-0 record to the basketball team at Martin Luther King Jr. High School in Chicago. But a player the association declared ineligible will stay that way.

title: Dinkins Searches for a Health Chief, but Finds a Dilemma
description: Mayor David N. Dinkins, whose cautious reliance on advisers has generally served him well, is facing a thorny issue because he relied on advisers to screen candidates for health commissioner, and their recommendation has deeply divided some of the Mayor's strongest supporters.

title: Political Leaders in Greece Agree to Elections by April
description: Greek political leaders agreed today to hold elections by early April, the third attempt in 10 months, to try to resolve political and economic crises and to allow American military bases to stay for at least another six months.

title: Small Study Challenges Role of Oat Bran in Reducing Cholesterol
description: The value of eating oat bran has been challenged by a small study that found oat fiber no more effective in lowering people's cholesterol levels than foods made from low-fiber refined wheat flour, which produced far fewer unpleasant side effects.

title: Moynihan's Right, but. . .
description: Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan recently advanced a proposal to reduce Social Security payroll taxes by $55 billion in 1991 and corresponding amounts in later years, thereby moving the Social Security system closer to pay-as-you-go financing. Such a change of policy, however, would damage the economy. Congress should reject this proposal.

title: Don't Stop There
description: The 1980's were full of useful innovations, as low tech as the Snugli infant carrier and as high tech as the magnetic resonance imaging that gives sharp pictures of the inside of the body. But in some respects, it was a decade in which innovators didn't go far enough.

title: Review/Music;   At Frick, Chamber Works Performed in a Chamber
description: Public performances of chamber music these days seldom take place in chambers of the size for which much of the music was crafted, and when they do, adjustments are necessary. Accustomed to having to project into the void of a small or even large concert hall, performers must scale down their sound a bit, and listeners, used to straining to hear a wee distant sound, must prepare for the immediacy and sheer volume of the close encounter.

title: Lebanon General Shuts Paper
description: The Christian general who is fighting for control of Lebanon has closed a newspaper for violating an order of his affecting reports on the Lebanese Government.

title: Time for a Danube Basin Common Market;   Cold War Not in Vain
description: To the Editor:

title: KEY RATES
Foster Placement by Skin Shade Is Charged
description: In an effort to place hundreds of abused and neglected children into foster care each week, New York City has resorted to distributing them to private foster-care agencies on the basis of gradations of skin color and hair texture, a report charged yesterday.

title: 3 Men Accused of Violating Computer and Phone Systems
description: The Federal Government today charged three men in California with engaging in a widespread pattern of breaking into Government and telephone company computers and obtaining classified information from a military computer.

title: INSIDE
description: H.U.D. Halts Insurance

title: Upheaval in the East;   At Conference, Soviet General Sees Changes in Warsaw Pact
description: A senior Soviet military official said today that political change sweeping Eastern Europe would require a major reorganization of the Warsaw Pact, but he stressed that the military alliance would continue to exist.

title: Review/Music;   'Vespri Siciliani' in Concert, Conducted by Eve Queler
description: ''I Vespri Siciliani'' (1855) is a sweeping historical pageant that has never quite established itself in the repertory as securely as some other middle-period Verdi masterpieces. Like ''Don Carlo,'' it taps the vast resources of the French grand-opera tradition, and like that later score, it would be ideally heard in its original French.

title: First American Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Hearing Set on Effort to Subpoena Reagan
description: A Federal judge today ordered a hearing in connection with John Poindexter's effort to subpoena former President Ronald Reagan as a witness at Mr. Poindexter's trial.

title: Appeal Filed By Art Dealer In Mosaics Case
description: An Indianapolis art dealer has asked an appeals court to reverse a court order directing her to hand over four rare Byzantine mosaics from the sixth century to the Greek Orthodox Church of Cyprus, court records showed today.

title: CHRONICLE
description: CARL A. CAPASSO's troubles continue. His ex-wife, NANCY R. CAPASSO, continued her bitter legal war yesterday by filing a $70-million Federal civil suit against him and others under the Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act.

title: Three-Year Extension For Shula Reported
description: Don Shula, the Miami Dolphins' coach, has agreed to a three-year contract extension, The Palm Beach Post reported yesterday. Shula's current contract expires in six weeks.

title: Republic New York Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a pre-tax gain on the sale of an option to purchase real estate of $51.2 million. c-Included a provision of $200 million for loan losses in the third quarter related to developing countries debt obligations and the above mentioned gain on the sale of an option to purchase real estate of $51.2 million. d-Included a gain of $15.1 million related to the sale of new common stock by Safra Republic Holdings S.A., a European bank holding company, in which the corporation holds a 48.6 percent interest and recognition of $20.9 million of cash payments on outstanding Brazilian debt.

title: Mexicans React Furiously to an NBC Drug Series
description: In a matter of days, the joint war against drug trafficking conducted in this country by Mexico and the United States has been transformed into what Mexico's Attorney General today called ''a war of paper and images,'' with Americans and Mexicans lobbing salvos at one other through the press and television, and each accusing the other of being in league with drug dealers.

title: Star Who's a Face in a Crowd
description: HANDSOME he is not. His appearance is distinguished by owlish glasses, a fixed, goofy grin and a knit cap topped with a red pompon.

title:
Currents;

Lessons in Small-Scale Architecture
description: LEAD: ARCHITECTS turn to art and design as a respite from the demands of large-scale construction. But the results are usually small-scale object lessons on architecture. About 50 projects are on display in ''Architects' Art'' at the Gallery of Functional Art in Santa Monica, Calif., until March 12.

title: Panama's New Chief to Ask U.S. Aid
description: Panama's new civilian President said today that he would go to Washington ''as soon as possible'' to ask for emergency economic aid, including $200 million for a public-employment program and $40 million to rebuild homes destroyed in the invasion that toppled Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega.

title: Arafat Denounces Arab Dealings With Israel Over Palestinian Issue
description: Signaling frustration within the Palestinian leadership with the stalemated Middle East peace process, Yasir Arafat denounced today what he described as ''Arab impotence to stand up to Israeli arrogance.''

title: Murdoch Units Shift Officials
description: The News Corporation, the worldwide media company controlled by Rupert Murdoch, and its United States subsidiary, News America Publishing, have reorganized their top ranks.

title: Newark Prize: Winner Keeps His Car
description: Parking a car on the streets of Newark has become such a gamble that Mayor Sharpe James conducted a drawing today to give away 1,750 anti-car-theft devices and increase residents' odds of keeping their cars.

title: Correction
description: An obituary on Friday about Dudley Field Malone, a theatrical agent and manager, misidentified a position held by his father, who bore the same name. He was Assistant Secretary of State under President Woodrow Wilson, not Assistant Secretary of the Navy under Franklin D. Roosevelt.

title: Books of The Times;   Vidal's Remaking of the American Myth
description: Hollywood

title: Meeting Narrows Gap Between U.S. and Japan
description: Shintaro Ishihara, the Japanese economic nationalist who argues that the resentment in a declining America of his country's growing economic success is largely rooted in racism, crossed swords here today with a Congressman from Detroit.

title: Richter Is Bringing Life to a Lackluster Season
description: Mike Richter, his entire body having wound up in the net in his attempt to keep the puck from doing the same, stared out through the cage of his goaltender's mask into the lights and applause of Madison Square Garden. One of the sport's singular moments - a penalty shot - had become just another of his multiple successes.

title: Review/Theater;   The Details of Daily Life, Surrealistically
description: Although ''Casa,'' Denise Stoklos's new performance piece at La Mama, bills itself as a comedy, it could just as accurately be called a mystery. In her one-hour play, this Brazilian director, performer and writer, who calls her physically sparse, mimelike style of drama essential theater, heads a cast of eight actors, including her two children, who act out rituals of daily life in surrealistic caricature. ''Casa'' appears to tell a story about a specific woman, her family, friends and thoughts. But if many details are shown, the actual course of events remains ambiguous.

title: The Punishment: To Knit
description: A few people convicted of misdemeanors in Marquette County have been handed knitting needles and told by a local judge, Patricia Micklaw, to knit away their debt to society. With yarn donated by a church, the offenders are knitting afghans, scarves, mittens and the like for the needy.

title: Israel Has Mixed View On Tide of Soviet Jews
description: As Soviet Jewish immigrants arrive in Israel at a rate now exceeding 1,000 a week, Israeli officials acknowledge that they have still not devised a plan for handling the mass immigration, and construction of even the first new apartment to house the immigrants is months away.

title: Capital Gains Tax Cut Would Promote Fairness
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: ECONOMY

title: Turning the Tables
description: ''The Republicans,'' Ronald Reagan once declared, ''are the party of July Fourth and the Democrats are the party of April 15.''

title: Isabel Beck, Gynecologist, 91
description: Dr. Isabel Beck, a gynecologist and a pioneer in the field of family planning, died Tuesday at her home in New Rochelle, N.Y. She was 91 years old.

title: Chrysler Recalls 625,000 Cars and Trucks
description: The Chrysler Corporation announced today that it plans to recall about 625,000 cars and light trucks to replace a faulty valve cover and valve cover gasket, a move that could cost the auto maker more than $50 million.

title: Corestates Financial reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Before payment of $2,905,000 in preferred dividends. Preferred stock was redeemed in May 1988.

title: Earnings Rise At Ameritech
description: Ameritech, the Chicago-based telephone holding company for Illinois, Indiana, Michigan, Ohio and Wisconsin, today reported a 7.1 percent rise in its earnings in the fourth quarter.

title: Holiday Inn Sale Backed
description: Shareholders of the Holiday Corporation approved a plan to sell the Holiday Inn hotel system to Bass P.L.C. of Britain for $2.2 billion. Bass is acquiring 55 owned or leased properties as well as franchise agreements, joint venture agreements and management contracts covering 1,400 Holiday Inn hotels in North America. Terms of the sale call for Holiday stockholders to draw one-quarter share of Bass stock for each of their Holiday shares.

title: HONG KONG FACING REFUGEE LAWSUIT
description: An international legal effort has been organized to challenge the way this colony screens Vietnamese boat people to determine which ones are genuine refugees fleeing persecution and which ones are illegal immigrants who must return home.

title: Gilding Comes of Age Once More
description: THE gilded age is back. ''People are into opulence, 18th-century furniture, fabric with fringe and sumptuous living, and they like gilding,'' said Maryalice Huggins, who has been restoring and gilding furniture for eight years at her shop, Antique Conservation Inc. in Greenwich Village.

title:
Currents;

Towers and Turrets at Harlem Meer
description: LEAD: ''WE made it a collection of towers and turrets,'' Samuel White, an architect with Buttrick White & Burtis, said of the design for Harlem Meer Center. ''You see only one bit at a time.''

title: Fleet-Norstar Fincl Group reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Review/Television;   Enter Poirot, Ever the Natty Narcissist
description: ''Mystery'' has finally apprehended Hercule Poirot, Agatha Christie's best known detective. In the nine-part series that begins tonight at 8 on Channel 13 and at 9 on Channel 49, the nattily turned-out little egoist is played by David Suchet, exuding superiority from the shine of his pomaded hair to the sheen of his spats. It is a less florid interpretation than Peter Ustinov's, but it does justice to the portrait on the page.

title: Huntington Bancshares reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Per share earnings reflected 15 percent stock dividend paid in July 1989.

title: Ex-Official Is Defended
description: The State Department today defended a former officer who helped develop negotiating strategy with Japan on high-technology issues and left on Jan. 1 to join Fujitsu Ltd., a Japanese electronics conglomerate.

title: Capital Gains Tax Cut Would Promote Fairness;   1040 Lottery Drawbacks
description: To the Editor:

title: Brainard Cheney, Novelist, 89
description: Brainard Cheney, the author of five novels set in the swamp country of Georgia, died at a nursing home Monday after a long illness. He was 89 years old.

title: Integra Financial Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: CUBA LOSES ALLURE FOR NICARAGUANS
description: For the last 10 years, Managua's hottest New Year's party has been given by the Cubans, celebrating the anniversary of the revolution that brought Fidel Castro to power in 1959 and inspired the Sandinistas' own uprising two decades later.

title: In a Month For Books, 3 Welcome Volumes
description: JANUARY is the slack time in my gardening year, and never more so than this year. Prolonged and bitter cold during most of late November and December killed back the heaths I usually count on for mid-winter bloom.

title: Review/Recital;   An Evening Of Miscellany For Piano By Mozart
description: A large audience was on hand for Richard Shirk's all-Mozart piano recital on Tuesday evening at Merkin Concert Hall. Mr. Shirk is on the faculties of the Manhattan School of Music and the Mannes College of Music, and he has performed regularly as both a soloist and a chamber music player since he won the Leschetizky Competition in 1981.

title: Bulls Protest Tucker's Shot
description: The National Basketball Association said yesterday that it had been notified by the Chicago Bulls that they intended to protest the Knicks' 109-106 victory Monday at Madison Square Garden. The Knicks won the game on a 3-point basket by Trent Tucker with one-tenth of a second remaining.

title: All-Star Game Will Compete With N.B.A. on TV
description: The return of the National Hockey League to a major, over-the-air, American television network will face major competition in the ratings.

title: News Summary
description: International A3-17

title: U.S. Asks Exxon for $20 Million To Assess Spill Damage in Alaska
description: Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan Jr. asked the Exxon Corporation today to provide $20.4 million more to help assess the damage to Alaska's Prince William Sound caused by oil spilled from the Exxon Valdez last March.

title: First Financial Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
PERES PLANS VISIT TO CAIRO FOR TALKS
