description: At the invitation of President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt, Shimon Peres, the leader of the Israeli Labor Party, is to visit Cairo early next week for talks about the stalled efforts to hold negotiations between Israeli and Palestinian delegations.

title: Islanders Win Again, Earning Share of First
description: In a giddy locker room tonight, the Islanders were trying to put into words their feelings about an improbable and stunning reality. As a result of an astonishing seven-week surge, they are in first place in the Patrick Division, tied with the Devils.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Some people go into orbit about their birthdays, but CAPT. DANIEL BRANDENSTEIN was in orbit on his. The commander of the space shuttle Columbia celebrated his 47th birthday Tuesday, when he was awakened to ''Danny Boy'' and a rendition of ''Happy Birthday,'' taped by staff members at the Johnson Space Center in Houston.

title: Mel Most, Correspondent, 75
description: Mel Most, a former foreign correspondent and public-relations agent, died of a heart attack on Jan. 6 at Cabrini Hospital. He was 75 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Yuzuru Abe, 73, Dies; Headed Steel Company
description: Yuzuru Abe, a Japanese steel industry executive, died of liver failure on Sunday at his home in Tokyo. He was 73 years old.

title: Calendar: Showing Antiques, Gardens
description: 67 Strong, Seventh Regiment Armory, Park Avenue and 66th Street; 212-665-5250.

title: A Not-So-Ebullient Bazaar for New TV Shows
description: The city known for letting the good times roll seemed a natural setting for an industry unsurpassed in its love of gleeful excess. Yet this meeting of the National Association of Television Program Executives, an annual gathering where local television station executives gamble on buying the next Oprah Winfrey or ''Wheel of Fortune,'' is emerging as a curiously tepid affair.

title: Net Up 56.8% At Microsoft
description: Despite a broad-based slowdown in the personal computer market, the Microsoft Corporation today reported its best financial results ever.

title: Japan Foreign-Aid Program May Finance U.S. Projects
description: The Government-owned Export-Import Bank of Japan, whose principal mission is to help heavily indebted third world countries build their economies with low-interest loans, is contemplating its first loans to an industrialized country: the United States.

title: Negotiators for Owners and Players Ready to Zero In on Numbers
description: In 1981, the players struck the baseball season in June. In 1985, the players struck in August. In 1990, the owners are prepared to stage a pre-emptive strike of their own.

title: Steel Imports Decline
description: Steel imports in November fell 13 percent from October's level, and represented 18.9 percent of the domestic supply, the American Iron and Steel Institute said today. The November imports came to 1.49 million tons, compared with 1.7 million tons in October and 1.8 million tons in November 1988, the institute reported. Imports for the first 11 months of the year were down 16 percent, to 16.29 million tons.

title: Foyt in V8 Campaign
description: A. J. Foyt, the leading winner in Indy-car racing, will be part of the Chevrolet Indy V8 engine program in 1990. The announcement was made yesterday in Detroit.

title: Fernandez Plans to Act Against Brooklyn Board
description: Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez has decided to move against a Brooklyn school board that voted to replace its superintendent with a principal who has been linked to elective politics, school officials said.

title: Earnings Fall 74.8% At I.B.M.
description: Ending a difficult year on a disappointing note, the International Business Machines Corporation reported yesterday that its fourth-quarter net income fell 74.8 percent from the comparable period a year earlier.

title: Inquiry Looks At Bush's Son
description: Federal regulators are scheduled to meet on Thursday to determine whether Neil Bush, the President's son, violated Federal banking laws as a board member of a Colorado savings and loan institution that became insolvent.

title: Southmark Files Plan To Keep Savings Unit
description: The Southmark Corporation, the troubled Texas real estate and financial services concern, filed a plan of reorganization in United States Bankruptcy Court today that would allow it to keep its troubled savings and loan institution, the San Jacinto Savings Association in Houston.

title: Bond Corp. Offer Is Dropped
description: A young entrepreneur who said he was seeking control of the Bond Corporation Holdings Ltd. without explaining how he would finance his $197 million bid or address the Australian conglomerate's immense debt said on Tuesday that he had abandoned the offer.

title: Valley National Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Chicago Merc Re-elects Chief
description: John T. Geldermann was re-elected today as chairman of the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. He was not challenged in his bid for a second consecutive one-year term.

title: Market Place;   Georgia-Pacific Expected to Win
description: THE protracted battle between the Great Northern Nekoosa Corporation and its unwanted suitor, the Georgia-Pacific Corporation, continues to play in the companies' board rooms, as well as in the courts. There will be a special meeting of Great Northern shareholders on March 2 to resolve a number of issues. But for the most part, analysts seem virtually sure that Georgia-Pacific will ultimately be successful in its $63-a-share, $3.8 billion cash bid for the rival forest products giant, which is fighting to remain independent.

title:
Currents;

A Desk That Sends a Definite Message
description: LEAD: IN the high-powered business world, executives come and go. While they are around, they often want to make a strong statement about their corporate authority. The C.E.O. Desk, above, should fulfill this need.

title: Review/Theater;   A Magical Journey Through Life, Love and Art
description: Pierre Corneille, France's first great ''L'Illusion Comique'' a strange and capricious ''monster'' of a play. Coming from the man who is best known as the author of the heroic ''Le Cid,'' it is certainly an oddity - a fanciful comedy on the subject of love, paternity and the art of theater itself.

title: Levi Strauss Closing Plant
description: Levi Strauss & Company said today that it will close one of three sewing plants in San Antonio in April and lay off 1,100 workers.

title: Yields Post A Decline
description: Yields of tax-exempt and taxable money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report were down for the week that ended yesterday.

title: Buenos Aires Journal;   Where the Perons Lived, Inertia Has a Monument
description: From its commanding location overlooking the estuary of the Rio de la Plata, the immense shell of Argentina's unfinished national library threatens to become a relic for future archeologists to ponder over.

title: Where 21 Youths Died, Lawyers Wage a War
description: There is a comforting mythology about tragedy, in which grief brings strength to survivors and builds bonds among neighbors.

title: Metro Matters;   State-City Ties: Albany Panel Takes First Steps
description: Gov. Mario M. Cuomo may be guilty of some sins of omission in his proposed budget, but not of commission.

title: Greece Says Albanian Will Visit on Jan. 26
description: The Greek Government has announced that the Albanian Under Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs, Sokrat Plaka, would visit Athens on Jan. 26.

title: Conrail Sets $1.3 Billion Buyback
description: For months, takeover talk has been driving up the stock price of the Consolidated Rail Corporation. Yesterday, the railroad company, known as Conrail, moved to defend itself by announcing plans to spend about $1.3 billion to buy back more than a third of its outstanding shares.

title: Society for Savings Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After extraordinary gain of $14,529,000, or $1.22 a share, from sale of all credit card receivables and accounts and loss from accelerated amortization of goodwill.

title: Bowie Leads Way As Nets Top Bullets
description: If the Nets had lost tonight, nobody would have wanted to spend much time around Bill Fitch. The Nets' coach spent 10 minutes shouting at his team following its loss to Portland on Sunday. Then on Tuesday, Fitch put his club through a grueling three-hour practice.

title: Lee Goldstein, Composer, 37
description: Lee Goldstein, a conductor of operas and musical-theater pieces and a former composer in residence at the Lyric Opera of Chicago, died on Friday at St. Joseph Hospital in Chicago. He was 37 years old.

title: Bush Aide Is Sent to Manila To Dramatize U.S. Support
description: President Bush sent a senior foreign policy adviser to the Philippines today to dramatize the Administration's strong support for the Government of President Corazon C. Aquino.

title: Shanahan's Strange Season
description: The players were gone from the Denver Broncos' training complex on their day off. The sun had gone down, and the telephones, which not so long ago had been ringing steadily with talk about another Bronco Super Bowl, were very nearly silent. But outside, in the darkness, after another session in the video room, Mike Shanahan was on the otherwise empty practice field, jogging around its edges.

title: Banc One Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Secret Ernst Document Discusses Profit Split
description: The partners of Ernst & Whinney will take home roughly 65 percent of all profits that they earn jointly with Arthur Young for the next three years, while Arthur Young's partners will share the rest, according to a confidential document that was circulated among the two accounting firms' partners before their union in June.

title: S.I. Port Loses Its Linchpin, A Battleship
description: The battleship Iowa, which was to have been the linchpin of the new naval center on Staten Island, will be mothballed later in the year, Pentagon officials say. That leaves open the question of what vessels will be based at the $300 million base that is taking shape in the shadow of the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge.

title: First Bank System reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss The 1988 periods included results of Central Bancorp since Dec. 2, 1988. First Bank said the results for 1988 included losses of $506.3 million resulting from the decision to sell a significant portion of its investment securities. The 1989 fourth quarter also included a provision for credit losses of $175 million. Total 1989 provisions for credit losses were $253.5 million, compared with $76 million in 1988.

title: Dirty Money, Dingy Justice
description: Money launderers don't get their hands dirty. They barely handle the cash that buys the drugs. What they do is take the proceeds of drug sales and run them through as many transfer accounts as it takes to make the money look legitimate. They don't poison American children; they merely bankroll the poison.

title: Q&A
description: Painted Concrete

title: First of America Bank Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago quarter and year results have been restated to reflect the Nov. 1 acquisition of Midwest Financial Group. The company also said it took a one- time after-tax charges related to the acquisition of Midwest Financial, which added $7,019,000, or 34 cents a share, to 1989 fourth-quarter expenses, and $8,708,000, or 42 cents a share, to 1989 full-year expenses.

title: Exxon Sends Documents on Leak to E.P.A.
description: Responding to an ultimatum by the Federal Environmental Protection Agency to explain what caused the leak of more than 500,000 gallons of oil into the Arthur Kill, Exxon delivered a box containing several hundred pages of documents to the agency yesterday. The delivery forestalled, for at least a day, any fines against the oil company.

title: William White, Lawyer, 75
description: William White, a Philadelphia lawyer, died Monday at a nursing home in Haverford, Pa., after a long illness. He was 75 years old and lived in Bryn Mawr, Pa.

title: Mobile Phone System for Beijing
description: L. M. Ericsson, the Swedish telecommunications company, and Pacific Link Communication Ltd., a Hong Kong-based company in which Millicom International Inc. has a 28 percent stake, are giving a mobile phone network to the city of Beijing.

title: The Shack as Art and Social Comment
description: IN large, vibrant drawings, color photographs and evocative small wood structures, all set against the stark white walls of a SoHo art gallery, Beverly Buchanan celebrates the lowly shacks of the South in a new show. The 30 pieces by Ms. Buchanan, a 49-year-old artist who lives in Athens, Ga., will be on view through Feb. 6 at the Bernice Steinbaum Gallery, 132 Greene Street (Houston Street).

title: Sumitomo Bank of Calif.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Production Climbed 0.4% In December
description: Industrial production rose a strong four-tenths of a percent in December, bolstered by abnormally cold weather and the end of a strike at the Boeing Company, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

title: Animal Rights Groups Vow Suit to Save Monkeys
description: Animal rights advocates said today that they would go to court to try to prevent the killing of several monkeys that have been the focus of a national debate over the treatment of research animals.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: With Accordions

title: Clorox Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,175,000 and $2,049,000 for the quarter and 6 months, respectively.

title: General Datacomm Industries Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary tax credit of $515,000, or 4 cents a share. c-Net loss

title: Alberto-Culver Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
AMR Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Approval of Bush, Bolstered by Panama, Soars in Poll
description: As he completes his first year in office, George Bush, helped by overwhelming support for the invasion of Panama, stands higher in the public's approval than any President has at an equivalent point in his administration since John F. Kennedy, the latest New York Times/CBS News Poll shows.

title: Premier Financial Services reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary gain of $408,000, or 25 cents a share, from a tax loss carryforward.

title: An Apartment Hotel Opens on West 48th Street
description: A 479-unit rental apartment house, which just opened in the theater district of Manhattan, offers prospective tenants the option of leasing an apartment fully furnished - with bed linens, dining and kitchen equipment in place - for an added monthly fee. The concept is an echo from the 1940's and 1950's, when dozens of rental buildings on the Upper West Side offered such amenities and were dubbed apartment hotels.

title: Leading Backers Turn From Applicant for Health Post
description: The tortured search for a New York City health commissioner took another twist yesterday as two major gay-rights groups and the expert who nominated the leading candidate withdrew their support for him. Mayor David N. Dinkins met last night with members of his search committee but did not reach a decision on the appointment.

title: Our Towns;   Disease Closes Homeless Center And Fear Lingers
description: It was on a Wednesday afternoon a little over two weeks ago when Judy Moriarty, an advocate for the homeless who works at a nonprofit agency here called Gateway Communities, walked up to the door of a soup kitchen and shelter for the homeless on West Main Street. She was going to pick up some meals for homebound AIDS patients too sick to come to the shelter themselves. On the door she found a Health Department warning that read ''Unfit for Human Habitation.''

title: Microsoft Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
India Names New Governor for Troubled Kashmir
description: The Government of Prime Minister V. P. Singh reassigned a popular former Governor today to Jammu and Kashmir state, where a secessionist movement is taking on alarming proportions for India.

title: Doubleday Names New President
description: Stephen Rubin, the publisher and editor in chief of adult books at Bantam Books, was named president and publisher of Doubleday yesterday. He replaced Nancy Evans, who resigned.

title: Investor Denies Gdansk Deal Is Dead
description: An aide to Barbara Piasecka Johnson denied yesterday that the Polish-American heir's proposed purchase of the Lenin Shipyard in Gdansk was unraveling and said that she remained eager to invest in the birthplace of the Solidarity movement.

title: At the> Movies
description: After 'Glory'

title: Federal Judge Inzer B. Wyatt, 82; Presided at Acquittal of Roy Cohn
description: Judge Inzer B. Wyatt, a senior judge in the Federal District Court in Manhattan, died of pneumonia and heart failure Wednesday at the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 82 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Ameritech reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a $34 million net gain on the sale of its Cantel unit. Share earnings for the year-ago quarter and year reflect a 2-for-1 stock split paid Dec. 30, 1989.

title: In a West German Camp, Those Who Lost Hope for Change
description: Thomas Dierkes had marched in each of the weekly Leipzig demonstrations. He had defiantly chanted ''We are the people!'' at the old East German Government. And he had celebrated when the Berlin wall came down.

title: Darnell to Notre Dame
description: Gary Darnell was named defensive coordinator at Notre Dame yesterday after a half-season as interim coach at Florida and a successful stint there leading the Gators' defensive unit.

title: On Stage
description: The Right Space

title: Review/Film;   Sex and So Many Characters In a Comedy by Almodovar
description: Pedro Almodovar approaches comedy the way others approach nuclear fission: with confidence that if enough particles bombard one another with sufficient energy, sooner or later something is bound to explode. His characters collide wildly, furiously, comically and, although the frenzy of their interactions sometimes conceals this, more or less at random.

title: Fehr Raises Questions On Revenue Sharing
description: Are baseball's club owners ready to have players or their representatives sitting in their offices, sharing in their decision-making process?

title: Persian Folk Music
description: Reza Derakhshani, a performer on the tar and the sehtar, two varieties of Iranian lute, will perform Persian folk music at the Uris Auditorium of the Metropolitan Museum of Art on Sunday afternoon at 2:30. Mr. Derakhshani's ensemble includes Kamran Rouhani on the tar; Arieh Aghajani on the santur, a hammered dulcimer; Kamran Hatami on the kamancheh, a fiddle, and Behzad Allahyar on the daff, a drum. Tickets are $10. Information: 206-1050.

title: Quantum Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-15

title: Becton Dickinson reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $4,696,000, or 12 cents a share.

title: JB's Restaurant Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 18
Crown Crafts Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said latest quarter results included loss reserves established against all accounts receivable from Allied Stores and Federated Department Stores. The reserves reduced latest quarter and 6 months net by one cent a share.

title: Economic Scene;   Behind the 80's Takeover Spree
description: THE bankruptcy filing this week by Federated Department Stores and Allied Stores, the American retailing operations of the Campeau Corporation of Canada, has raised anxieties about what will happen to the economy if the wave of debt-financed takeovers, leveraged buyouts and managerial buybacks of the 1980's should crash in the 1990's.

title: Premieres at Carnegie
description: The violist Paul Neubauer is to be the soloist with the National Orchestral Association in the world premiere of Joel Phillip Friedman's Concerto for Viola and Orchestra at Carnegie Hall tonight at 8. The program, which is to be conducted by Jorge Mester, is part of the National Orchestral Association's New Music Orchestral Project, in which the ensemble presents recently composed works. Also on the program are the world premieres of Frederick Bianchi's ''Rauschenberg Variations,'' Jeffery Cotton's ''Fantasia,'' Laurence Widdoes's ''Visitors'' and Anne LeBaron's ''Strange Attractors.'' Tickets are $5 to $20. Information: 247-7800.

title: Mayor Who Faulted Hirohito Is Shot
description: The Mayor of Nagasaki, who broke one of the nation's most sensitive taboos by saying a year ago that Emperor Hirohito bore some responsibility for World War II, was shot today, and the police arrested a 40-year-old ultranationalist.

title: Ferranti Talks End
description: Ferranti International P.L.C., the beleaguered British military electronics group, said in a statement that Thomson-CSF had ended talks on a possible bid for Ferranti. Thomson has been considering the possibility of making a general offer for Ferranti, which is seeking a rescue from the effects of a reported fraud involving a United States unit.

title: New York Schools Chief Challenges Boards' Power
description: Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez mounted a frontal assault yesterday on New York City's decentralized school system, demanding that its 32 local boards clear all candidates for district superintendent with him.

title: Atlantic Group Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net income c-Net loss The company said share earnings include the effect of payment of preferred stock dividends.

title: Lattice Semiconductor Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 30
Chicago Bonds
description: The Chicago Park District of Cook County, Ill., is offering $50 million in general obligation capital improvement bonds to the public through underwriters led by Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company. Yields on the tax-exempt issue include 6 percent in 1991, 6.40 percent in 1995, 6.85 percent in 2000 and 7.10 percent in 2005. Underwriters said the bonds were rated A-1 by Moody's Investors Service Inc. and AA- by the Standard & Poor's Corporation.

title: Beijing to Limit More Posts In Hong Kong to the Chinese
description: China, which has said it will bar holders of foreign passports from top government jobs in Hong Kong after Beijing resumes sovereignty in 1997, will extend the ban to more posts, a Chinese official said today.

title: Quake Jolts California Coast
description: A moderate earthquake jolted the Northern California coastline early today, but no injuries or damage was reported. The epicenter of the earthquake, which registered 5.1 on the Richter scale, was at the juncture of the San Andreas and Mendocino faults, 30 miles northeast of here, said a spokeswoman for the United States Geological Survey in Menlo Park.

title: Delay on Betting Bill Not Really a Victory
description: Competition from increased legal sports betting may be the greatest battle in horse racing in the years ahead, and the sport appeared to lose an early skirmish this week.

title: Bernstein and Thomas Head New Pacific Music Festival
description: Leonard Bernstein and Michael Tilson Thomas are to be the artistic directors of the first Pacific Music Festival, a $7 million event to be held in Sapporo, Japan, from June 26 to July 13.

title: Profit Outlook At Times Co.
description: The New York Times Company said yesterday that it expected to report earnings of 83 cents to 88 cents a share from continuing operations in 1989. In 1988 the company reported earnings from continuing operations of $2 a share.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Complaints On Proposed Regulations
description: A QUARTET of advertising and media industry leaders addressed the question ''Advertising: An Endangered Species?'' yesterday by insisting, ''No, no,'' while implying ''Yes, yes.'' Their remarks gave an audience packed with communications professionals strong doses of the self-flagellation and Washington-bashing that have been familiar medicine at recent industry gatherings.

title: Lemieux Gets 2 To Even The Score
description: Outshot and Outmanned

title: Eastern Enterprises reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the fourth quarter was adversely affected by unusually cold weather in December which hampered barge movements for Midland Enterprises and resulted in higher operating expenses for Boston Gas Co.

title: Uncovered Short Sales Decline by 6.4% on the Big Board
description: The New York Stock Exchange reported yesterday that short interest declined by 35.3 million shares, or 6.4 percent, in the four-week period ended Jan. 12. Short interest is the number of shares sold short by investors and not yet covered.

title: Candy Jones Dies; Ex-Model, Teacher, And Writer Was 64
description: Candy Jones, a 1940's cover girl whose career later encompassed teaching, broadcasting and writing, died of cancer yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital. She was 64 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Smart About Sex
description: Every year, more than a million youngsters get pregnant, most of them unintentionally, and half undergo abortions. Many Americans may not yet be ready to do what's necessary to reduce this horrendous teen-age pregnancy rate, but a new survey shows that New Yorkers are.

title: Franklin H. Middleton, Banker, 83
description: Franklin H. Middleton, a retired New York banker, died of kidney failure on Wednesday at the Fort Myers (Fla.) Care Center. He was 83 years old and lived in Fort Myers.

title: Pop/Jazz;   Remember Mickey Katz? No? Well, Just Listen to This.
description: WHEN the young clarinetist Don Byron steps on stage at the Knitting Factory tomorrow, he'll be reclaiming the music of a long-forgotten composer working in a long-forgotten genre. The 30-year-old Mr. Byron, along with a 10-piece band, will be performing a concert of pieces by Mickey Katz, a clarinetist, a musical director for Spike Jones, a klezmer musician, a composer and the father of the actor Joel Grey.

title: International Minerals & Chemical reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $300,000 from discontinued operations for the quarter and 6 months. c-After income of $8.4 million, or 35 cents a share, from discontinued operations, for both periods. The latest periods' income from continuing operations included net charges of $200,000 for the quarter and $1.8 million for the 6 months, related to stock-based compensation plans. The year-ago periods' income from continuing operations included gains of $400,000 for the quarter and $600,000 for the 6 months, related to compensation plans. The 6 months also included a net gain of $21.5 million related to a public offering. The latest periods included the results of Coopers Animal Health since date of acquisition, July 5, 1989.

title: CHRONICLE
description: CRAIG WASHINGTON, the Congressman-elect from Houston, was held in contempt of court there on Tuesday. He neglected to appear as the defense attorney in a five-year-old manslaughter case.

title: Sounds Around Town
description: Trumpet and All

title: National Securities reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: A History of the Molestation Charges
description: Aug. 12,1983: The mother of a child at the McMartin Preschool calls the Manhattan Beach Police Department and says she believes her 2 1/2-year-old son was molested by Raymond Buckey, who worked at the school.

title: Pacific Telesis Group reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results for the latest periods included one-time and out-of-period adjustments that increased net income by $36.4 million, or 9 cents a share. Results for the year-ago periods included one-time and out-of-period adjustments that reduced net income by $33.6 million, or 8 cents a share.

title: Rising Opposition To Soviet Garrisons
description: The Hungarian Government told an international conference on conventional forces in Europe that it wants the Soviet Union to withdraw all its troops from Hungarian soil. And in a meeting with a Soviet official in Gdansk, the Polish union leader, Lech Walesa, demanded the removal of the Soviet garrison in Poland.

title: Stone & Webster Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Latest and prior years included revenue of $4,155,000 and $12,585,000, respectively, from the sale of investment securities. Latest and prior years also included net income of $2,774,000, or 18 cents a share, and $8,577,000, or 57 cents a share, respectively, from the sale of investment securities. Year-ago quarter and prior year results restated to reflect the 2-for-1 stock split declared in June 1989. Revenue represented gross earnings.

title: Risk Is Seen in Needless Removal of Asbestos
description: Removing undisturbed asbestos from schools and other buildings could needlessly expose the removal workers to cancer, scientists say.

title: Gerber Products Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included $4,500,000 charge from consolidation of U.S. and Canadian manufacturing operations. c-After a loss from discontinued operations of $479,000. d-Included income of $359,000, or 1 cent a share for the quarter and a loss of $2,011,000 for the 9 months, both from discontinued operations. The $4,500,000 third quarter consolidation charge reduced share earnings by 12 cents a share. The company said it took a $600,000 provision in the quarter for anticipated losses on accounts receivable from Campeau Corp. companies which filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection. The company said the 1988 third quarter included a charge of $1,600,000 for disposal of certain fixed assets. The company said fiscal 1989 financial data has been restated to reflect consolidation of insurance operations and discontinuance of child-care operations.

title: Texaco's Profit Declines 3%; Environmental Costs Cited
description: Texaco Inc. said its fourth-quarter earnings declined 3 percent, partly because of a $355 million charge for environmental improvement programs.

title: Being Young and Black Was Suspicious Enough
description: To the Editor:

title: Provena Foods Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain of $862,044 from the sale of a building.

title: Bear, Stearns Files Unit Trust Plans
description: Bear, Stearns & Company said yesterday that it had filed a registration statement with the Securities and Exchange Commission for the first in a series of unit investment trusts intended to provide tax-free income for New York residents.

title: Keith Group of Cos reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net loss

title: Home Intensive Care reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: b-Net income The company said net income for both periods included a pretax fourth quarter charge of $8,827,000 for closing costs and the writedown of certain assets related to the company's home dialysis business. The charge resulted from the Budget Reconciliation Act of 1989 which contains a provision that reduces the company's current home dialysis reimbursement rate by about 50 percent, effective Feb. 1.

title: Argentines Take to the Streets Against Inept Police
description: In a notable shift from the fear Argentines felt of the police during the military Government just a decade ago, residents of several provincial towns have recently risen up in mass protest and accused their local police of corruption and laziness.

title: Rock Hall of Fame Opens The Gates to Pop Artists
description: From the stage of the Waldorf-Astoria's Grand Ballroom, Ray Davies of the Kinks surveyed the music-business crowd assembled for the fifth annual Rock-and-Roll Hall of Fame induction ceremonies. ''Rock-and-roll has become respectable,'' he said, gazing at all the tuxedos (including his own) and formal gowns. ''What a bummer.''

title: Rebirth of Plant May Help Shoreham
description: Contemplating a post-nuclear era, the purchasers of the idle Shoreham reactor on Long Island today toured a failed nuclear project here that is about to emerge as a huge gas-fired electric plant.

title: Applied Magnetics Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Texaco Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included charges of $355 million for the establishment of financial reserves relating to the company's environmental programs, as well as a reduction in the valuation of an investment in an offshore California platform and production facilities. The year included a net restructuring gain of $1,552,000,000, or $6.02 a share, comprised of a first-quarter gain of $1,190,000,000 primarily relating to the sale of Texaco Canada Inc., and the fourth-quarter gain of $362 million. c-Included a $42 million gain due to a change in accounting policy for foreign pension plans and a $42 million last-in, first-out inventory drawdown benefit. The year included a net restructuring gain of $181 million, or 74 cents a share, representing gains from the sale of Deutsche Texaco and the formation of the Star Enterprise joint venture, and charges for the writedown of U.S. producing properties targeted for sale. Results of latest fourth quarter also included a gain of $362 million, or $1.36 a share, associated with the sale of a stock interest in a subsidiary holding certain U.S. producing properties. The gain was reduced by charges for financial reserves relating to environmental programs at facilities sold as part of restructuring.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Mavericks Bracing For Knicks
description: When the Dallas Mavericks gathered for practice this morning to prepare for Friday night's game here with the Knicks, they met to talk about such problems as how to end their five-game losing streak, and how to get more scoring from Herb Williams, Randy White, Brad Davis and Anthony Jones. Those key bench players have been outscored by the opponent's bench by an average of 34.8 points to 18.5 in the last 12 games.

title: Susan D. Hanson, 49, Relief Agency Director
description: Susan D. Hanson, a project director for AmeriCares, an international relief agency based in New Canaan, Conn., was killed on Monday along with her mother, Phoebe Dunn, a commercial photographer, and 19 other people in the crash of a Costa Rican airliner near San Jose, the capital city. She was 49 years old and lived in New Canaan.

title: Baseball Wouldn't, Would It?
description: Great baseball weather in the East this week. For the last few days, you could have held a World Series game without needing Bowie Kuhn's long johns. And there wasn't even an earthquake.

title: Bowater Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Union Pacific reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $31,400,000, or 28 cents a share, and $85,200,000, or 75 cents a share, for the quarter and year, respectively. Net income for the 1988 fourth quarter and 12-month period included the earnings and one-time impact of gains from the sale of discontinued refinery operations. Earnings per share in 1989 reflected the benefits of the company's stock repurchase program and the Dutch auction completion in June 1989.

title: Scientists Use Gravity To 'See' Invisible Matter
description: Astronomers are developing an ingenious way to use a gravitational phenomenon of the heavens to reveal the presence of the mysterious invisible matter believed to constitute the bulk of the universe. This may lead them to an understanding of forces that shape galaxies, clusters of galaxies and even larger cosmic agglomerations.

title: The U.N. Today
description: Economic and Social Council

title: Review/Art;   18 Works of an Evolving Rothko, a la Francaise
description: The Pace Gallery's latest look at Mark Rothko's achievement is a selection of 18 transitional canvases from 1946-48 that cast the painter in a new role, a role more openly hedonistic and flawed than the Rothko of Abstract Expressionist fame. These abstract paintings glow with intimations of Rothko's maturity: the saturated colors, the soft-edged forms that push those colors toward the eye. But they also catch the painter on the move, before he reduced his compositions to simple, hovering rectangles that glower with tragic import. They indicate an artist with a lot on his mind, especially when it came to paint handling, and not always sure of himself, and they provide rich terrain for anyone interested in how painters develop.

title: Biopharmaceutics reports earnings for Qtr to Sept 30
description: b-Included losses from discontinued operations of $200,784 and $304,952 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Included losses from discontinued operations of $79,310 for the quarter and $54,503 for the year.

title: Pfizer Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Agents Kill Two Linked to Series Of Bank Thefts
description: F.B.I. agents and New York City detectives who were following a car linked to a series of bank robberies opened fire yesterday on two masked men who left a savings and loan branch in Brooklyn with guns drawn and a satchel of cash. One suspect, still wearing a stocking mask and a ski cap, died in the barrage of bullets. The other died at Maimonides Hospital.

title: Kent Electronics reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 30
Cigna to Buy Equicor In $777 Million Deal
description: The Cigna Corporation, the insurance holding company, said yesterday that it had agreed to pay $777 million in cash to buy Equicor from the Hospital Corporation of America and the Equitable Life Assurance Society of the United States, the joint owners of Equicor.

title: A.J. Ross Logistics reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Included after-tax gain of $1.9 million, or 14 cents a share, from sale of its epoxy coating operations and related property, plant and equipment in Bath, Pa.

title: Prosecutors and Politics: a Feud Reopens the Debate on the Propriety of Such a Match
description: Three guesses: What famous former Federal prosecutor wanted to be elected mayor of New York City, United States senator or, it sometimes seemed, any other high-ranking position that might come open?

title: Pace of Giving To Neediest Is on Increase
description: With the 78th annual New York Times Neediest Cases Fund drive now past its midpoint, proceeds are ahead of last year's collections by more than a quarter of a million dollars. If giving continues at the same pace, the drive will again break records when it closes on Feb. 28. Last year, the $4 million mark was reached for the first time.

title: Westinghouse Electric Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a restructuring provision of $123 million, essentially offsetting a gain from the sale of the remaining interest in Westinghouse's transmission and distribution business. c-Included a restructuring provision of $384 million, which essentially offsets the gains from the sale of the Westinghouse elevator business and from the divestiture of the entire transmission and distribution business. d-Restated downward to reflect a higher tax provision after adoption of SFAS No. 96.

title: Review/Film;   Underground Creatures and Dread Events
description: ''Tremors'' is a jokey attempt to re-create the pleasures of those post-World War II B-pictures about commonplace creatures - ants, worms, flies, whatever - that, through some horrible mistake (usually related to radiation), become voracious giants.

title: Antonio Cipollone, 66; Won Suit on Smoking
description: Antonio Cipollone, whose lawsuit against three cigarette makers resulted in the first jury award against the industry involving the death of a smoker, has himself died, his wife said today. He was 66 years old.

title: Noriega Aide's Lawyers Say 3 Witnesses Were Harassed
description: Lawyers for a co-defendant of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega asserted late this afternoon that prosecutors had sought to intimidate three defense witnesses today, sending immigration agents to their homes to investigate their legal status after they had testified.

title: Wolverines Turn Back Buckeyes
description: Demetrius Calip's patience tonight helped Michigan make order out of chaos.

title: International Research & Development Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Tandem Computers Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Reynolds Metals Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results for the 1989 fourth quarter included a pre-tax benefit of $38.7 million from LIFO inventory liquidation, partly offset by a pre-tax charge of $24 million for estimated costs related to plant modernization and environmental activities.

title: Continental Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After loss from discontinued operations of $80.4 million represented loss from business held for sale (First Options of Chicago Inc.) c-Net income and after loss from discontinued operations of $6.8 million, representing same footnote as above. The 1989 results included $83 million in gains from real estate sales, compared with $82 million of combined net gains in 1988 from the sale of real estate, the corporate restructuring and a pension settlement.

title: Rangers in 'Hot' Pursuit of Nicholls
description: The Rangers, having dropped hints for the last two weeks that they were close to making a major trade, could well complete a deal by the weekend that would land Bernie Nicholls of the Los Angeles Kings.

title: Market Place;   Industry Attack On Market Study
description: EXECUTIVES in the securities and futures industry have mounted an intense lobbying campaign to change the conclusions of a draft report by an independent Congressional agency that questions some fundamental aspects of the nation's financial system.

title: Jacobs Engineering Group reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the latest period included income of $518,000 from the sale of marketable equity securities.

title: CHRONICLE
description: When the model JERRY HALL makes her London stage debut on Thursday, she may have more than comedy on her mind. She and her longtime companion, MICK JAGGER, are to be married.

title: Legg Mason Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
CHRONICLE
description: ''I drank so much beer,'' said WOLFGANG PUCK, recalling his youth in Austria, ''so now I'm making it.''

title: G.O.P. Chiefs Meet to Plan a Strategy on Abortion
description: The Republican National Committee opened its winter meeting today with a determination to avoid any public confrontation over abortion, while holding a series of private briefings over how to deal with the issue in 1990.

title: 300 Fans Join Brawl After Foul
description: A 15-minute brawl tonight between players and spectators at a basketball game between visiting North Carolina Central and North Carolina A. & T. sent at least seven people to the hospital and suspended the game with 8 minutes 4 seconds left.

title: 2 Die as Jet Crashes in Ohio
description: A twin-engine cargo jet crashed today in a rural area 15 to 20 miles northwest of here, killing the pilot and a passenger, aviation officials said. The Lear 23 jet, chartered by Aero Flight Services, was on its way from Ypsilanti, Mich., to Louisville, Ky., to pick up cargo when it crashed, a Federal Aviation Administration spokesman said.

title: Review/Film;   Two Sisters Too Odd for Anyone Else
description: ''Sweetie'' was shown as part of the 1989 New York Film Festival. Following are excerpts from Vincent Canby's review, which appeared in The New York Times on Oct. 6, 1989. The Australian film opens today at Lincoln Plaza 1, Broadway and 63d Street.

title: Osicom Technologies Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
Doctor With AIDS Is Expected to Live For a Year of Less
description: As Dr. Veronica Prego listened with tears in her eyes, a medical professor testified yesterday that the AIDS-stricken doctor probably has a year or less to live.

title: Dover Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included pretax gain of $2.9 million from the sale of real estate, net of other charges, which also was partly responsible for an unusually low tax rate in the period. These items improved 1988 quarter and year earings by about 10 cents a share.

title: An Israeli Rights Group Fights for Palestinians
description: Dedi Zucker did not expect that founding the only Israeli organization that monitors human rights abuses in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip would help bring threats to his life by angry Jewish mobs.

title: High Cholesterol Poses Heart Risk in Older Men, Study Says
description: Older men whose cholesterol levels are above normal face an increased risk of developing coronary heart disease, according to new findings from a large, ongoing study.

title: Signet Banking Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Signet said its 1989 fourth quarter earnings included a net gain of $10.8 million from the sale of about $83 million of credit card receivables. The gain offset an after-tax $9.6 million of solicitation and upfront systems costs incurred to implement more sophisticated credit card account acquisition and management techniques. The 1989 year earnings included a net gain of $2.3 million from the sale of four branches. In the 1988 year, Signet recorded a net gain of $29.2 million from the sale of a subsidiary and $12 million of tax benefits related to less developed country loans.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We must resist the unworthy efforts of the tobacco merchants to earn profits at the expense of the health and well-being of our poor and minority citizens. This trade-off between profits and good health must stop. And it will stop if, around the country, our citizens rise up and say, 'Enough - no more!''

title: U.N.'s Secretary General Agrees To Accept Invitation to Albania
description: The United Nations Secretary General has agreed in principle to visit Albania, the last bastion of Stalinism in Europe and a nation accused of serious human rights abuses, diplomats and United Nations officials said today.

title: Changes to Cut Pillsbury Jobs
description: In a move to improve the operating efficiency of its Pillsbury Inc. division, Grand Metropolitan P.L.C. today announced a $140 million plant modernization program that will result in the elimination of up to 1,300 jobs as outdated production operations are closed.

title: American Air's Route Changes
description: Faced with a shortage of planes, American Airlines juggled its international routes to add new distinations and postponeothers on its trans-Atlantic routes to Europe.

title: Ciatti's Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Graf Gains Quick Recovery From Errors (and Herself)
description: Steffi Graf accidentally clunked her head with her racquet and survived 39 unforced errors today in the Australian Open.

title: Washington Criticized for Identifying Army Informant in Salvador Killings
description: While Salvadorans and diplomats here continue to debate what motivated President Alfredo Cristiani to announce the arrest of military men in connection with the killings of six Jesuit priests, almost as much curiosity has been aroused by another aspect of the case: why was the officer who provided information about the suspects detained, publicly identified and presumably exposed to reprisals?

title: Review/Art;   Soviet Artist as a Storyteller Of Not-Always-Pretty Tales
description: For many years, the only unofficial Soviet artist to have achieved a measure of fame in the West was Ilya Kabakov. Mr. Kabakov's works were shown in Western Europe as early as 1965, and he became known as the leader of a generation of artists whose activities were not sanctioned by the authorities in Moscow. But few if any of Mr. Kabakov's colleagues and followers had a chance to exhibit their works outside the Soviet Union.

title: Health Chief Assails A Tobacco Producer For Aiming at Blacks
description: The nation's top health official, Dr. Louis W. Sullivan, expressed outrage today at the R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company for ''deliberately and cynically'' test-marketing a cigarette aimed primarily at blacks, and he assailed the company as ''promoting a culture of cancer.''

title: Maker of Documentary That Attacks G.M. Alienates His Allies
description: Michael Moore knew he was tramping on some pretty big toes when he selected the General Motors Corporation and its chairman as his foils for the documentary ''Roger and Me.'' But Mr. Moore, the former editor of Mother Jones magazine, never dreamed he might also alienate onetime ideological allies, including the United Auto Workers union and the dean of G.M. Motors antagonists, Ralph Nader. The widely acclaimed film, which Mr. Moore directed and narrated, describes his efforts to persuade G.M.'s chairman, Roger B. Smith, to visit Mr. Moore's hometown, Flint, Mich., and inspect the social damage caused by G.M.'s 30,000 layoffs there in the last decade.

title: Underage Casino Gambler In '87 Case Is Guilty Again
description: A 20-year-old whose father described her as a ''poster child for compulsive gambling'' was fined $750 today for underage gambling.

title: Sankyo Buys Drug Maker
description: The Sankyo Company, Japan's second-largest pharmaceutical concern, agreed today to acquire a majority interest in the privately held Luitpold-Werk Group, a drug maker and distributor based in Munich, West Germany.

title: American Electric Power reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said share earnings for 1988 and 1989 are based on 193.5 million average shares outstanding.

title: Worried About Its Own Azerbaijanis, Teheran Acts With Caution
description: The armed revolt in Azerbaijan has been received with apprehension in Iran, where an estimated 16 million Azerbaijanis represent the largest ethnic minority and have at times challenged the authority of the Teheran Government.

title: Education Panel Chief Assailed by Protesters
description: A meeting of the City Council education committee in City Hall was disrupted yesterday by a protest by about two dozen adults and school children objecting to what they described as racist and white supremacist remarks by the committee's new chairman.

title: Relief Groups to Cross Rebel Lines in Ethiopia
description: The Ethiopian Government has decided to let church-run relief agencies deliver food aid to one million people threatened by famine in a rebel-held northern province, the Archbishop of Canterbury said today.

title: Cambodia Peace Effort: A Bit More Realism
description: After an important but limited two-day meeting on Cambodia in Paris this week, diplomacy on this complicated issue appears to have finally moved off dead center. But no one is ready to say that the Cambodian conflict is about to be solved, only that a bit more realism is being applied by the proxy powers.

title: The Case For Dr. Myers
description: New York City has health problems. It festers with diseases caused by drugs and poverty; the AIDS epidemic rages. The New England Journal of Medicine reports that a black man in Harlem is less likely to live till the age of 65 than a man in Bangladesh. That makes all the more dismaying the delay in appointing a promising candidate for city health commissioner, Dr. Woodrow Myers.

title: SOVIET TROOPS BOGGED DOWN BY AZERBAIJANIS' BLOCKADES OF RAILROADS AND AIRFIELDS
description: Soviet troops were apparently bogged down by widespread obstruction today, including airfield and railroad blockades, sabotage, hostage-taking and civil disobedience, as they tried to control the violence in Azerbaijan.

title: Phoebe Dunn, 75
description: Mrs. Dunn, who was 75, specialized in photographing children and was one of the early users of color film for advertising layouts. Her photographs appeared on the huge Kodak screen on the Grand Central Terminal concourse. She took the photographs for ''The Little Animals,'' a series of best-selling children's books in the 1960's for which another daughter, Judith Spangenberg, wrote the texts.

title: School Reform Again? (Sigh)
description: LEAD: It goes against my natural disposition to be a contrarian in these times in which New York City is ushering in a harmonious new age of the love-in. But I simply can't park my common sense, reason or the facts staring us in the face everywhere we turn - especially with respect to the schools. I'm still old fashioned enough to think that our democratic institutions and freedoms are in danger without effective public education.

title: Grand Juries Can Defend Rights of the Accused
description: To the Editor:

title: George Washington Falls to Rutgers, 90-82
description: Keith Hughes scored 25 points and Earl Duncan had 23 tonight as Rutgers held off George Washington, 90-82, in an Atlantic 10 Conference game.

description: b-Included charges of $109 million for costs of non-union work force reduction program; $92 million for increase in casualty reserves, based on an actuarial valuation; and $33 million for realignment and consolidation of certain administrative and operating functions. c-Net income

title: BRIEFS
description: * Bass P.L.C. said its shareholders had approved the company's acquisition of the Holiday Inn hotel business in North America of the Holiday Corp., Memphis.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: Friday

title: Bankrupt Banking
description: Banking is the business of risk. A good banker lends depositors' money when he sees little risk of the borrower's inability to repay; he acts both as an informed source of credit and a restraining hand.

title: Restaurants
description: Lightheartedness is not a trait that comes to mind when one thinks of sun-starved, hard-working Scandinavians. So I'm never surprised upon entering Aquavit, the Nordic palace on West 54th Street, to encounter an impassive hostess at the door who whispers, ''Reservations?''

title: Review/Art;   Contemporary Works From Africa
description: ''Contemporary African Artists: Changing Tradition,'' opening on Sunday at the Studio Museum in Harlem, is important. It comes at a time of increasing openness to art outside Europe and the United States, and in a careful, measured way, it lays groundwork and builds bridges others can use. Eye-opening exhibitions will follow.

title: Cincinnati Bell reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Dispute Results in Changes In Rules for Antiques Show
description: The Winter Antiques Show, now in its 36th year, has fewer dealers than in memory - 67, compared with 73 a year ago. But there are also seven new dealers in the fair.

title: Doubleday's New Chief Moved Quickly to Top
description: Stephen Rubin is not shy about the fact that he has risen rapidly in the publishing business. The new president and publisher of Doubleday confesses that about five years ago he had to ask his boss at Bantam Books what a royalty was.

description: Bank of New York Company executives are hinting that they are reconsidering the previously agreed-to acquisition of the Northeast Bancorp, a Shelton, Conn., company.

For Jurors, Facts Could Not Be Sifted From Fantasies
description: In the end, the jurors said, the facts and fantasies that blend in the memories of small children, influenced by the comments of parents and legal questioners, did not offer a firm enough basis for a conviction in the McMartin child molestation trial that ended today.

description: The Soviet public is receiving only incomplete news reports on the violence raging in the southern Soviet Union as editors in Moscow are asserting that the problems of coverage are similar to those involved in reporting foreign conflicts.

description: Ruby Keahaaina McDonald spends much of her day here in the Office of Hawaiian Affairs trying to figure out who is a native Hawaiian and who is not.

Soviets Said to Withdraw Fighters and Bombers From Vietnam Base
description: The Soviet Union has withdrawn all of its MIG-23 fighter planes and about half of its TU-16 bombers from its base at Cam Ranh Bay in Vietnam, Pentagon officials said today, in a move the officials said would reduce Soviet military abilities in Southeast Asia.

title: First, a Unified Berlin
description: LEAD: As the Communist edifice in East Germany disappears, pundits far and wide are discussing the decades-old ''German question.'' But there is no need to answer the German question right away: Few East German human rights activists are enthusiastic about reunification, and the reformers have yet to complete the job of sweeping away the Communist

title: Ruskin Spear, 78; Painter of Portraits Was Often Satirical
description: Ruskin Spear, who painted realistic and often satirical portraits of famous Britons, died on Tuesday at his home in the Hammersmith section of London after a short illness. He was 78 years old.

description: The Federal Government's announcement that a man had obtained classified military data from a computer drew skeptical reactions today from some computer security experts.

description: The company said prior year results included 10 months of revenue and expenses from the company's transfer agency, which was acquired Feb. 29, 1988.

title: BUCHAREST SEIZES COMMUNIST ASSETS
description: The provisional Government today announced the confiscation of all the property and assets of the defunct Communist Party, including 21 large palaces used by Nicolae Ceausescu.

title: World Record Unlikely for Bile
description: It's unlikely that Abdi Bile will run a world indoor record time in the mile at the Sunkist Meet on Friday night or earn the $100,000 bonus that goes to anyone who does.

title: Grand Juries Can Defend Rights of the Accused;   Who Made It So?
description: To the Editor:

title: Betsy R. Gordon Becomes a Bride
description: Betsy Ribakoff Gordon, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene J. Ribakoff of Palm Beach, Fla., and Boston, was married yesterday to Richard Charles Sheerr, a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Stanley I. Sheerr of Philadelphia. Rabbis Henry Cohen and Aaron Landes officiated at the Beth David Reform Congregation in Gladwyne, Pa.

title: Yugoslavia's Turn Is Surely Coming
description: To the Editor:

title: Ending of H.U.D. Program Seen as Blow to Developers
description: Several housing experts warned today that the Government's decision to end a housing insurance program managed by private lenders could result in long delays in obtaining mortgages for private low- and moderate-income apartment buildings.

title: Johnson in Car Accident
description: Ben Johnson, the Canadian sprinter who was stripped of the 100-meter gold medal he won in the 1988 Summer Olympics after he tested positive for steroids, received a summons after he was involved in a minor accident on Wednesday in Lincoln, Ontario, the Niagara regional police said.

title: Motorola Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Review/Pop;   Black Rock Coalition Sunders Stereotypes
description: Over the last four years, the Black Rock Coalition, an organization of more than 30 bands that was created to support black musicians playing rock-related music, has slowly but surely been attacking pervasive social problems in the music industry. By regularly presenting concerts featuring groups that defy musical categorization and the racial stereotyping that goes with it, it has exposed an ugly way of thinking that has been intertwined with the marketing, consumption and criticism of music. And by having a major success - the group Living Color was a founding member of the coalition -the organization has shown that there is a large audience that happily ignores such stereotypes.

title: Draft Changes Are Discussed
description: Paul Tagliabue, the commissioner of the National Football League, and Richard D. Schultz, the executive director of the National Collegiate Athletic Association, met for 90 minutes yesterday, discussing ways to accommodate underclassmen who seek to be drafted by the N.F.L.

title: Outjo Journal;   U.N. Namibia Team Makes Some Unlikely Friends
description: The United Nations was greeted with widespread suspicion and some outright hostility when its workers arrived in this tidy farming community nine months ago to help monitor Namibia's transition to independence.

title: Kennametal Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BankAmerica Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Fourth quarter of 1988 figures reflected significant items, notably $351 million of interest income from Brazilian obligations and and $167 million of non-recurring restructuring costs. BankAmerica said its latest fourth quarter included a $320 million provision for credit losses, compared with a $310 million provision for year-ago period. The latest quarter results also included a $125 million extraordinary credit resulting from utilization of tax loss carryforwards, compared with a $71 million credit in the year-ago period. Fiscal year 1989 results included a $283 million extraordinary credit, compared with a $179 million credit a year earlier.

title: Modine Manufacturing Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 26
2 Acquitted of Child Molestation In Nation's Longest Criminal Trial
description: The former director of a preschool and her son were acquitted today on 52 counts of molesting young children at their school, bringing a dramatic end to the longest and costliest criminal trial in American history.

title: Analysts International Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
European Assembly Urges Grant to Armenia
description: The European Parliament urged the European Community today to grant emergency aid to Armenia and the Nagorno-Karabakh region in Azerbaijan, but did not specify an amount.

title: Sovran Financial Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
The Right-to-Die Dilemma, Answered
description: The tragic case of Nancy Cruzan, the 32-year-old woman whose family contests the state of Missouri's refusal to let her die, seems headed for a settlement. It can't be a happy ending, for Nancy is in a vegetative state, caused by an auto accident seven years ago. But even as her case awaits the Supreme Court's decision, her family and the state are working out new, clear rules that can ease the pain for everyone.

title: TV Weekend;   Michael Caine Takes His Turn at 'Jekyll and Hyde'
description: In films like ''Dirty Rotten Scoundrels,'' Michael Caine is adept at playing charming con men. On television, though, he has taken to exploring seriously the darker side of Victorian society. Last year, he played the Scotland Yard inspector pursuing the vicious serial killer in ''Jack the Ripper,'' directed by David Wickes. On Sunday at 9 P.M. on ABC, he can be seen in still another Wickes production, playing the title roles in ''Jekyll and Hyde.'' Mr. Wickes's script is described as ''derived from'' the novel by Robert Louis Stevenson. The adaptation is, as they say, loose.

title: Biogen Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss The company said latest quarter and year shares earnings reflects preferred dividend payments of $1,466,000 and $2,988,000, respectively.

title: Shuttle Set to Return After Escaping Erratic Spin
description: Faulty navigational commands from the ground sent the space shuttle Columbia into an erratic spin last Wednesday, but the astronauts, roused from their sleep, brought the craft safely under control and then prepared for their scheduled return to Earth this morning.

title: On Land and in Air, Kennedy Delays Persist
description: Even as Kennedy International Airport embarks on a $3 billion redevelopment, airline officials warn that the plan does not address congestion, especially on the expressways leading to the airport, that threatens its position as the nation's premier international gateway.

title: Auctions
description: The huge Americana auction Wednesday to Jan. 27 at Sotheby's is to include some remarkable examples of silver and porcelain tableware made for colonists and post-Civil War tycoons. The sale of more than 1,490 lots will also offer porcelains, prints, genre paintings, ancestor portraits, folk art and furniture.

title: Network Equipment reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
FDP Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Net income and the year included a gain of $324,191 representing the cumulative effect of a change in accounting for income taxes.

title: Washington Talk;   Rethinking Priorities on Foreign Aid
description: All through 1989, experts and commentators kept saying that the tumult in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe was going to change politics and priorities all over the world.

description: Shows, Nature, Museums

title: Heldor Industries reports earnings for Year to Oct 31
description: b-Net income

title: Inland's Net Drops by 63%
description: Inland Steel Industries said yesterday that its fourth-quarter profits plunged 63 percent, reflecting its higher costs and eroding profits in its service center business, which buys steel and shapes it to customer specifications.

title: 1 Killed as Eastern Jet Rams a Small Plane on an Atlanta Runway
description: An Eastern Airlines jetliner landing here tonight collided with a twin-engine aircraft that had just touched down, killing one person and injuring another aboard the smaller plane, officials said.

title: White House Says a Drop In Interest Rates Is Justified
description: In an unusual public comment for the Bush Administration on Federal Reserve policy, the White House said today that current economic conditions justified lower interest rates.

title: The Long Road Back for a Disgraced Patrician
description: At the Center for Constitutional Rights, Mahlon F. Perkins Jr. is something of an oddball. Among its young, polyglot legal staff, he is a 71-year-old patrician, who looks and speaks like Robert Frost. His colleagues wear beards or blue jeans; he favors herringbone trousers. They like rock music; he watches birds. They come to work by subway; he takes the 9:17 from Greenwich.

title: Serendipity Is the Password At the Antiques Show
description: ANTIQUES shows are invariably made memorable by the regal objects antiques dealers present. This year's Winter Antiques Show has a generous representation of ancient gods and goddesses decked out in Neo-Classical finery, stern-faced ancestor portraits, and such exotica as Louis XIV's wine cooler from Versailles (a marble tub with gilded images of sunbursts and lions' faces), and George Washington in the form of an aristocratic stove figure. But the traffic stopper of the fair is something much humbler: a two-passenger sleigh with bright red rails painted like a stage set. Few people will overlook this folk-art extravaganza at the show, which opens today in previews and tomorrow to the public for a nine-day run at the Seventh Regiment Armory.

title: Fight Over Tax Cut Heats Up As Bush and Moynihan Dig In
description: An emerging battle over whether to cut Social Security taxes heated up today with President Bush sharply criticizing the proposed cut while the author of the proposal, Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan, said he would not budge.

The company said the extraordianry items represent writeoffs of deferred debt acquisition costs and premiums paid on bond redemption; the accounting asjustments represent a change in the method of accounting for income taxes.

Kickers Face Tougher Task
description: The National Collegiate Athletic Association football rules committee has voted to reduce the distance between goal-post uprights from 23 feet 4 inches to 18 feet 6 inches, the width used in the National Football League.

title: Marie Vale, Government Aide, 46
description: Marie Vale, a Republican fund raiser and a former government aide, died of leukemia on Tuesday at the New York University Medical Center. She was 46 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: M/A-COM Deficit
description: M/A-COM Inc. said it expects to post a loss of about $115 million for its quarter ended Dec. 30. Stock in the Burlington, Mass., company fell 50 cents today, to $4.125, on the New York Stock Exchange, where its decline of 8.1 percent was the fifth worst of the day. The loss will cover an operating loss and an estimate of the impact closing some business and product lines and shrinking others. The microwave and digital communications company said it would close its Governent Systems Division and certain smaller units with annual sales of about $170 million.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Wednesday about Ethiopian famine relief misidentified the Soviet First Deputy Foreign Minister. He is Yuli M. Vorontsov.

title: Met Officials Visit Rumania To Help With Damaged Art
description: Rumania's National Museum of Art, severely damaged in last month's popular uprising, was visited today by two senior officials of the Metropolitan Museum of Art who said they wanted to see whether American art institutions could help in the restoration.

title: Corrections

description: Pfizer Inc., the New York-based pharmaceutical company, reported yesterday that its net income fell 5.9 percent in the fourth quarter of 1989 as a stronger dollar hurt sales overseas.

title: BankAmerica Broke $1 Billion Profit Mark in '89
description: BankAmerica's fourth-quarter profit of $270 million, or $1.21 a share, was slightly higher than the $265 million, or $1.36 a share, of a year ago. Because profits in late 1988 were swollen by the collection of two years' worth of interest on loans to Brazil and other special items, analysts noted that the latest earnings showed that BankAmerica was continuing to recover strongly from its woes of the mid-1980's.

description: Several hours after creating a secret software experiment, a suspended computer science student recalled today, he returned to his terminal at Cornell University, to discover that his program had gone awry and was jamming a nationwide network of computers.

A Second Newspaper Is Shut by Lebanese General
description: Gen. Michel Aoun closed a second daily newspaper in the Christian sector today, barred publications from the Muslim part of Beirut and said journalists who did not agree with his policies should leave the country.

title: Treasury Issues Decline Sharply
description: Prices of Treasury securities fell sharply and long-term interest rates rose to their highest levels in more than six months yesterday in a selloff that traders said was largely spurred by comments from two Federal Reserve Board governors that suggested the Fed was not about to ease monetary policy again any time soon.

title: Ecuador Court Orders Arrest Of Ex-President Over Funds
description: The Supreme Court today ordered the arrest of former President Leon Febres Cordero on charges of embezzling public funds in a case that arose from accusations against his son-in-law.

description: The Indiana Health Commissioner, Dr. Woodrow A. Myers Jr., is often described by his supporters as ''impressive'' - smart, hardworking and charming.

description: N.B.A.

title: FCS Laboratories Inc.  reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
Phillips to Take A Write-Down
description: The Phillips Petroleum Company will take a $280 million after-tax write-down on its offshore California investments that will cause the company's fourth-quarter earnings to plunge, company officials said. The investments include the oil-rich Point Arguello field off Santa Barbara, which could hold as many as 500 million barrels of oil. Phillips holds 40 percent and 50 percent interests in the blocks that are part of the field.

title: NCNB Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

description: To the Editor:

title: Suspect Shot In Terminal At Rush Hour
description: A man the state police said was a suspect in a burglary in Dutchess County was shot and seriously wounded by the Metro-North police last night at Grand Central Terminal as he got off a train he had taken to Manhattan. Metro-North officials said the officers fired after the man pulled a revolver and pointed it at the officers who met the train.

title: George Peck, 58, Dies; Theology School Head
description: The Rev. George Peck, president of the Andover Newton Theological School in Newton Centre, a village in Newton, Mass., died of a heart attack Wednesday at his home in Little Compton, R.I. He was 58 years old.

title: Judge Strikes Down Law Forcing Release of College Tests
description: A Federal judge has ruled that New York's truth-in-testing law, which requires standardized testing services to release questions and answers from their examinations, is unenforceable because it conflicts with Federal copyright law.

title: Review/Music;   St. Louis Symphony Offers a Premiere by Ligeti
description: Time is at once the composer's ally and enemy. Ally because music exists over a certain measurable span or it does not exist at all. Enemy because it forces the composer, like the listener, to face the fact of its frightening, inexorable flow.

description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $330,690, or 2 cents a share. Year-ago results are restated to reflect the sale of the assets and operations of the Graphics Products Group. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Panama-Latin Ties Linked to a Pullout
description: Although President Bush and Vice President Dan Quayle are opening a round of diplomacy to bolster the Panamanian Government, Administration officials said today that it was unrealistic to expect formal recognition by major countries in the region until the United States invasion force is withdrawn.

title: Gold Search in Portugal
description: The Consolidated Ramrod Gold Corporation of Canada has won the right to explore for gold in Portugal, energy officials said today. The deals involve more than 500 million escudos, about $3 million, and reflect growing interest in Portugal's mineral wealth, the officials said.

title: Consumer Prices Up 4.6% in '89
description: Consumer prices climbed four-tenths of 1 percent last month, the same as in November, the Labor Department reported today. Increases quickened for fuel oil and natural gas, while food prices and medical care rose more slowly than in the previous month.

description: b-Net loss c-Included an $800,000 pretax writedown on certain programs for both the quarter and 9 months.

title: A False Start on Cambodian Peace
description: LEAD: Once again, the press and policy experts are talking about a breakthrough in Cambodia.

title: Edward H. Kass, 72, Researcher on Toxic Shock
description: Edward H. Kass, an epidemiologist who was a leading researcher into the mechanism of toxic shock syndrome in menstruating women, died of lung cancer Wednesday at his home in Lincoln, Mass. He was 72 years old.
