description: b-Net loss

title: Sandwich Chef Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Prague's Leader Quits the Communist Party
description: Prime Minister Marian Calfa has resigned from the Communist Party, the Government said today.

title: Chemical Banking Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a $600 million special addition to the allowance for loan losses related to loans to countries engaged in debt rescheduling and $300 million of special provisions at Texas Commerce Bancshares Inc. c-Included recognition of $205.4 million of interest income on the company's Brazilian loans representing interest from February 1987 to December 1988. d-Net income and included pre-tax gains of $53.8 million on the settlement of a part of pension obligations and $41.3 million on the sales and closures of certain nonstrategic businesses, as well as the recognition of the $205.4 million of interest received on its Brazilian loans in the year-ago fourth quarter. Chemical Banking said its results reflected the Jan. 3 merger of Horizon Bancorp of New Jersey into the company.

title: Apple Computer Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 29
Money Fund Assets Soar
description: The assets of the nation's 488 money market mutual funds soared by $5.29 billion, to $381.11 billion, for the week that ended on Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. The assets of the 147 institutional funds increased by $2.03 billion, to $92.65 billion. The assets of the 243 general-purpose funds were up by $1.85 billion, to $126.66 billion. The 98 broker-dealer funds increased by $1.41 billion, to $161.81 billion, the institute said.

title: Czech-Vatican Ties Restored
description: Czechoslovakia's new Government decided today to restore full relations with the Vatican after a break of more than 40 years. The official news agency C.T.K. said the Government had decided that ''diplomatic contacts with the Holy See be restored'' but gave no details.

title: World Economic Aide Sees Trouble for Warsaw Policy
description: After a three-day visit to Poland, the leader of a delegation from the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development said today that there were major difficulties ahead for Poland's economic liberalization program.

title: China Reports Release of 573 Held in Revolt
description: The Government said today that it recently released 573 people who had been imprisoned for taking part in the democracy movement last year.

title: Burlington Resources Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $16,718,000, or 12 cents a share and $43,588,000, or 30 cents a share for the quarter and year, respectively, and the year also included an extraordinary credit of $265,611,000, or $1.77 a share which is related to the sale of substantially all of the assets and business of Plum Creek Timber Co. completed in June 1989. c-Included income from discontinued operations of $19,117,000, or 12 cents a share for the quarter and $64,668,000, or 43 cents a share for the year. The company said the latest quarter's continuing operations of $32,281,000, or 21 cents a share excluded real estate and forest products reduced by $8 million after tax, or 5 cents a share, for non-recurring charges to settle various environmental and litigation issues. Including real estate, the latest fourth quarter net income from continuing operations would have been $49 million, or 33 cents a share, compared with $34 million, or 23 cents a share, in the year-ago fourth quarter. The company also said the latest year's continuing operations of $148,941,000, or 99 cents a share, excluded real estate and forest products. Including results from real estate operations, 1989 net income would have been $172 million, or $1.15 a share; however, real estate results were reported as discontinued operations due to the planned sale of that business during 1990. Fiscal 1988 continuing operations of $7,411,000, or 3 cents a share, is after a $143 million, or 95 cents a share, after- tax special charge related to the company's estimate of its natural gas take-or-pay contract exposure. Including real estate operations, 1988 net income from continuing operations would have been $17 million, or 10 cents a share.

title: Filion Driver of the Year
description: Herve Filion, who won a world-record 814 races and passed the 12,000 mark in career victories, was named Driver of the Year for 1989. The award was the 10th for Filion from Harness Tracks of America, which has 43 members in the United States and Canada. Filion got 92 points. John Campbell was second with 80.(AP)

title: Bank of Boston reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest quarter and year included non-recurring pre-tax gains of $199 million from sale of the company's credit card business and settlement of a portion of its pension obligations.

title: Linear Technology Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Bulgarian Party Leader Is Under House Arrest
description: Todor Zhivkov, the ousted Communist Party leader, was put under house arrest today, charged with inciting ethnic hostilities and misuse of Government property and money, Bulgarian State Radio announced tonight.

title: Israelis Accuse a P.L.O. Aide
description: A military court today identified a leading West Bank Palestinian as a supporter and financial backer of the so-called Palestine Popular Army in an indictment of five alleged members of the group.

title: Celebrity Twist to Savings Failure
description: In the current savings industry crisis, the collapse of Colorado's Silverado Banking, Savings and Loan Association would stand out even if one of its former directors were not Neil M. Bush, a son of the President.

title: Caterpillar Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
French Agree to Buy Rorer for $3.14 Billion
description: The Rorer Group Inc. said yesterday that it had signed a preliminary agreement with Rhone-Poulenc S.A., the chemical company owned by the French Government, to merge with Rhone-Poulenc's pharmaceutical operations. Rorer said the deal valued its stock at $73 a share, or $3.14 billion.

title: Public Service Enterprise Group reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Corrected from yesterday's editions.

title: Crossland Savings reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $89.5 million from the cumulative effect of a change in accounting for the quarter and year. c-Net income There were no per share earnings for the 1988 year because of preferred stock dividend requirements. Crossland said its 1989 fourth quarter loss included an unrealized loss of $22.3 million resulting from the lower- of-cost-or-market (Locom) adjustment of its high-yield, non-investment grade securities portfolio; a $9.3 million writeoff loss representing the balance of an investment; net charges of $4.9 million on certain real estate investments, and a gain of $6.4 million on the sale of about $43 million of its credit card portfolio. A $4.5 million million non-cash charge in lieu of income tax expense was also recorded as a result of the early adoption of SFAS No. 96 (accounting for income taxes.) The bank also said its loss for the year included a $143.6 million writedown of goodwill; provision for possible loan losses of $50.9 million; a $22.3 million Locom adjustment to its high yield portfolio; and an $18 million charge in lieu of income tax expense resulting from the effect of the adoption of SFAS No. 96.

title: The Bronx Is Giving Itself a Birthday Party
description: The Bronx, a borough with two unique distinctions from the other five, is giving itself a 350th-birthday party -in the Bronx, of course.

title: Aluminum Co. of America reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included unfavorable translation and exchange adjustments of $14.5 million, or 16 cents a share for the quarter and $8.9 million, or 10 cents a share for the year. c-Included net negative adjustments of $49.1 million which included a charge of $37.3 million for translation and exchange adjustments. d-Included unfavorable translation and exchange adjustments of $87 million, or 99 cents a share.

title: Contract Talks Stalemated Between Mets and Strawberry
description: The Mets introduced their three new players and two new coaches yesterday, and predicted they would help revive the glory found and lost in the 1980's. But they also admitted they were consternated behind the scenes by a problem that's escalating into a crisis for the 1990's: they are stalemated in negotiations with Darryl Strawberry, who has threatened to leave as a free agent unless he gets a blockbuster four-year contract.

title: Leonard Forfeits Crown
description: If Sugar Ray Leonard fights again, it won't be as a champion.

title: Apple Net Falls 11.2% in Period
description: Amid a broad-based slowdown in the personal computer market, Apple Computer Inc. today reported an 11.2 percent decline in earnings and a 5.7 percent gain in revenues for its first fiscal quarter, which ended Dec. 29.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: Economy

title: Clemson Drops Ford With $1 Million Deal
description: Danny Ford, armed with a $1 million settlement from Clemson, resigned under pressure today, ending an 11-year coaching tenure that attracted national prominence and a National Collegiate Athletic Association inquiry.

title: Boeing Plans Worker Cuts At Factories
description: Despite an $80 billion backlog of orders for commercial airliners, the Boeing Company said yesterday that its factory work force had grown too large and would be reduced this year by 5,000 workers.

title: Gendex Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Airlines Urged to Hide Bomb Threats
description: The Bush Administration will urge airline industry officials on Friday to continue to comply with Government policy and not tell passengers of security threats against their flights in most cases.

title: Charles Hernu, Official in France Hit by 1980's Scandal, Dies at 66
description: Charles Hernu, a French Socialist politician whose time as Defense Minister in the early 1980's was clouded by scandal, died of a heart attack Wednesday in Villeurbanne, a Lyons suburb where he had been Mayor for more than two decades. He was 66 years old.

title: Nationalism at Its Nastiest
description: Azerbaijan is no Lithuania. True, resurgent nationalism arouses people in the Caucasus just as it arouses the Baltic republics. But there the comparison ends - and the trouble for Moscow begins.

title: Oberlin Choir
description: The Oberlin College Choir will give the world premiere of Edward Miller's ''Bad Dreams,'' a setting of poetry by Donald Justice, tomorrow evening at 8 at Town Hall, 123 West 43d Street. The program, which is to be conducted by Daniel Moe, also includes Stravinsky's Mass. Tickets are $7.50 to $15. Information: 840-2824.

title: Stocks Mixed Despite Rally In Blue Chips
description: Blue-chip stocks rallied in the final half-hour of trading yesterday, but the overall market finished the day mixed.

title: Books of The Times;   The Harsh Judgments of a White South African

title: Ex-Danbury Mayor's Trial: Extortion Tale Unfolds
description: When a former mayor of Danbury, James E. Dyer, was indicted on extortion and racketeering charges last year, few believed that his trial would include testimony as titillating as allegations of payoffs in restaurant restrooms, cash hidden between the pages of The Wall Street Journal and illegal deals cut over coffee in City Hall.

title: Sale Accord Set For British Bank
description: The owners of Yorkshire Bank P.L.C. agreed to sell the regional bank to National Australia Bank for the equivalent of $1.65 billion. Under terms of the deal, which must be approved by British regulators, National Australia Bank, one of Australia's big four commercial banks, will pay $1.6 billion in cash plus interest.

title: International Business Mahines Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest quarter and year's costs and expenses included $2.42 billion from restructuring initiatives, investment revaluations and other actions. The year-ago quarter included $270 million for estimated costs of consolidations and the year's costs and expenses included $870 million for estimated costs of announced consolidations. The year-ago full year figures included a gain of $315 million from the cumulative effect of a change in accounting.

The company said fourth quarter figures have been restated to reflect Xidex operations that are being included in continuing operations.

title: U.S. AGENTS ARREST WASHINGTON MAYOR ON DRUG CHARGES
description: Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr., who over the past several years has repeatedly denied allegations that he used drugs, was arrested tonight at a downtown hotel on a narcotics charge by local and Federal law officers, the United States Attorney's office said.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Once, BILLY JOEL wanted to be a history teacher. But making records is ever more rewarding, so he will enter the classroom on tape.

title: Norwest Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
U.S. IS RELEASING INVASION CAPTIVES
description: American military officials announced today that out of a total of 5,300 Panamanians detained for questioning since the United States invasion last month, nearly all had been freed as of this week.

title: Bank of New York Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The bank said the latest year net was affected by a special addition of $600 million to the allowance for loan losses, recorded in the third quarter.

title: Hungary Seeks Withdrawal Of Soviet Forces in Two Years
description: Hungary called today for the withdrawal of all Soviet troops from its territory by the end of 1991 as part of the reduction of conventional forces in Europe currently being negotiated here by NATO and the Warsaw Pact.

title: Prodigy at 8, Winner at 21
description: Less than 48 hours after shocking the golf world by winning the first tournament he had ever entered as a PGA Tour professional, Robert Gamez's bliss was disturbed by a frightening voice that filled the California desert with a dark vision of his future.

title: Review/Dance;   'Crossing the Line,' a Suite Rooted in Black History
description: Alfred Gallman has absorbed the lessons of his years as a student at the Alvin Ailey American Dance Center and as a dancer with the Fred Benjamin Dance Company. And he has used them to create something of his own, judging by a performance by Mr. Gallman's Newark Dance Theater on Wednesday at the Joyce Theater as part of the Man-Made festival, in a program shared with the Deja Vu Dance Theater.

title: Troubled by Migration From East, Bonn Sharpens Reunification Call
description: Alarmed by a continuing flood of East German immigrants, the West German Government said today that a freely elected East German government must join Bonn in declaring German unity as their goal.

title: Missouri Executes Man Convicted in Slaying of His Girlfriend
description: A man who was convicted of killing his girlfriend was executed by injection early today, becoming the the 121st nationwide since 1976, when the Supreme Court allowed states to restore the death penalty.

title: New York High Court Bars Forced Care to Save a Life
description: New York State's highest court today expanded the individual's right to refuse lifesaving medical care, ruling that the state could not compel treatment, even though it argues that a child's interests would be harmed by the death of a parent who refused such treatment.

title: Indiana's Head Coach Retiring After 33 Years
description: He is 69 years old. He has tasted national and worldwide success and he is considered the dean of swimming coaches. So there was not much surprise yesterday in Bloomington when Indiana University announced that James (Doc) Counsilman would be retiring after one more lap as head coach.

Digital Down; Tandem Off
description: The Digital Equipment Corporation reported sharply lower earnings today for its second fiscal quarter ended Dec. 31. The results were below analysts' already pessimistic estimates, sending its shares down $5.875, to $82, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Talks Open in Yugoslav Province
description: Communists in troubled Kosovo province met for the first time today with ethnic Albanian opposition figures to discuss proposals for democratic change.

title: Trouble Goes to Hawaii For 'Murder in Paradise'
description: ''Murder in Paradise,'' tonight's ''NBC Movie of the Week,'' is about the burned-out New York City cop of the week. Charlie Raski can be encountered at 9 P.M. beach-bumming and bar-boozing in Hawaii. His problem is that he still wakes up sweating to nightmares about a murderer who killed his wife and eight other people back home with a nylon stocking and painted their faces, too. So how do you think Raski feels when a face-painting stocking strangler sets to work in Hawaii? He feels he's being picked on.

title: 3 Tied for Lead in Bob Hope Classic
description: Peter Jacobsen's bogey on the last hole cost him sole control of the second-round lead today in the Bob Hope Chrysler Classic.

title: Why Noriega Can't Get a Fair Trial
description: LEAD: Legal experts and politicians eager to support President Bush's invasion of Panama have been quick to assert that the way the U.S. brought Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega to trial poses no barrier to his conviction. They correctly point out that a criminal trial will not be dismissed unless the manner in which the prosecution obtained jurisdiction over the defendant ''shocks the conscience.

description: It had neither the drama of the crumbling of the Berlin wall nor the setting of the maritime summit meeting in Malta. But the cloakroom in the Hofburg Palace this week may well merit a place among images that chart the waning of the cold war.

description: When renting ski equipment, take your time and be choosy. You will be asked your skiing level: I, II, or III. Beginners who ski slowly and prefer gentle slopes are Level I. Intermediate skiers, Level II, prefer a variety of terrain including, at times, the most difficult. Advanced skiers, Level III, seek the steepest terrain. Assess your ability as accurately as possible. You will be asked for your height, weight and age. With this information the rental shop will be able to give you a ski that has the right length and stability for your level, and a binding that will release when you want it to. title: Review/Music;   Stravinsky's 'Oedipus Rex,' Without Attic Trappings
description: ''Oedipus Rex,'' Stravinsky's ''opera-oratorio after Sophocles,'' was written in 1927 while the Russian composer lived as an exile in France. In a gesture characteristic of his rootless artistry throughout a long career as a displaced person, he decided that a work by a Russian drawn from a Greek tragedy would be sung in a dead language, Ciceronian Latin, and narrated in the language of whatever country in which it was performed. Furthermore, he intended that the theatrical style be static and impersonal, with singers preferably masked to enhance what tradition insists was the ritualistic aura of ancient Grecian tragedy.

description: Several programs in the two-week Man-Made festival, which ends on Sunday at the Joyce Theater, have suggested that modern dance, at least in New York, has come into an age of elevated inconsequence. Grand themes and choreographic visions seem to be out these days. Exploration is in, but too often it is relatively superficial exploration of such concerns as the structuring of a dance or ways to push the human body to physical extremes. The last new program of the festival, presented on Thursday, was a good illustration of those poles of artistic expression.

title: The Boundaries of War
description: Popular revolts and Communist change have, in weeks, redrawn Europe's political map. In the West, the European Community debates opening its doors to the East. In the East, nationality questions long frozen by totalitarian rule again glow hot. With so much in flux, strategists, statesmen and bureaucrats grope for constants. That's why they insist so tenaciously on the permanence of the borders established in 1945. Their tenacity is reinforced by treaty commitments -and by fear that reopening border questions might risk new war.

title: Mayor of Washington Is Yielding Most Duties After Cocaine Arrest 44>
description: Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. turned over most of his duties to the city manager today after appearing before a Federal magistrate on a misdemeanor charge of using crack cocaine. He went into seclusion amid a growing belief that his political career is shattered.

title: World Steel Output Up
description: World crude steel output rose to a record of 783.5 million metric tons in 1989, up five-tenths of 1 percent from 1988, the International Iron and Steel Institute said this week. The rise was led by developing countries, which increased output by 3.7 percent, to a record 100.9 million tons, from 97.3 million tons in 1988, the institute said. In the Western nations, production was 495.9 million tons in 1989, up 1.4 percent from 488.9 million tons in 1988, the survey of 33 steel producing countries showed.

description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $3,340,000, or 7 cents a share, and $4,792,000, or 10 cents a share, for the quarter and 6 months, respectively, and an extraordinary charge of $3,760,000 for both periods from a loss of pre-payment of debt. c-Included income from discontinued operations of $1,017,000, or 2 cents a share, and $2,047,000, or 4 cents a share, for the quarter and 6 months, respectively. The 6 months also included an extraordinary income of $21,698,000, or 44 cents a share, from cumulative effect of an accounting changes.

title: Hubco Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
C-Cor Electronics Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 29
Gotbaums Have Alien Maid; Dinkins Stands By Appointee
description: Mayor David N. Dinkins said yesterday that a report that Victor and Betsy Gotbaum had employed an undocumented alien as a maid for the last five years would not influence his decision to appoint Mrs. Gotbaum as Parks and Recreation Commissioner.

title: Ruddick Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Panama's Operation
description: THE UNITED STATES faced a similar problem in Korea in the 1950's: if only the Congress can declare a war, what was the military struggle that the U.S. conducted in the name of the United Nations to be called? President Harry S. Truman liked police action; the Congress, which had to appropriate money to pay veterans' claims, settled on an official short-of-war moniker: the Korean conflict.

title: What Shapes a New Apartment House?
description: THE 13-STORY St. Andrew Hotel guarded the northwest corner of Broadway at its intersection with Amsterdam Avenue and 72d Street for half a century until it was pulled down during the Great Depression to make way for a two-story retail development that, in those hard days, paid a better return than old hotels.

title: Driving 'Miss Daisy' From Here to There and Back
description: After 15 months on the road, the national touring company of ''Driving Miss Daisy,'' starring Julie Harris and Brock Peters and featuring Stephen Root, closes today in New Haven. Charlie Willard, the company manager, will take down the photos in the theater lobby, settle up at the box office, check the company's travel arrangements and head for his cabin in the Adirondacks. He is trying to be philosophical.

title: In Paris, Lace and Luxe
description: AT Sabbia Rosa, where silk robes spill from padded hangers in streams of coral and peach, customers eye delicate bras edged in lace. The tiny Left Bank shop on the Rue des Saints-Peres has long been a magnet for those who appreciate fine lingerie and Miss Rosa's sweet tooth for color. A vivacious woman with a froth of curly hair, she proudly shows off her guest book, with signatures from the actor Dustin Hoffman and the model Cindy Crawford. Like the rest of her customers, Miss Rosa says, they want the best.

title: Outdoors;   Tuna Protection Is Studied
description: Among the chores awaiting Congress is deciding whether the United States should have the right to control the catch of the various species of tuna that swim within 200 miles of this country's shores.

title: Care for Sick Children Whose Parents Work
description: LEAD: THE Visiting Nurse Association of Madison is asking companies in 12 shoreline and neighboring towns to finance a new service that would provide at-home care for the sick children of their employees.

title: How Yonkers Has Held Off on Housing
description: IT has been 10 years since the Justice Department, later joined by the N.A.A.C.P., brought suit against Yonkers, and five years since a Federal judge found the city guilty of intentional discrimination in housing and schools. But after all the litigation, not one unit of housing has been built to remedy the discrimination and the fight is far from over. Education officials moved quickly to integrate the schools, but a slender majority on the City Council, spurred on by neighborhood groups, has resisted the court-ordered plan for integrated housing.

title: Jittery Over Junk Bonds, Wall Street Hits the Books
description: Getting investors today to pony up for high-yield bonds will take more than a convincing sales pitch. In the wake of recent disasters in the ''junk bond'' market and the bankruptcy filing last week of Federated Stores Inc. and the Allied Stores Corporation, Wall Street brokerages are having to respond to a new call by investors for more puncture-proof research.

title: Rousing Tribute to Vaudeville's Last Days
description: WHEN we last saw Big Bertha, Papa Du, Ma Reed and Thelma, they were carrying on in the 1979 Off Broadway hit ''One Mo' Time,'' a re-creation of black vaudeville as played at the legendary Lyric Theater in New Orleans. Conceived and written by Vernel Bagneris, the show was set in 1926, the year before the Lyric was destroyed by a fire.

title: Campus Life: Grinnell;   Students Skip Vacation Pleasures To Serve the Poor and Homeless
description: Thirty students from Grinnell College spent the final week of their winter vacation in Des Moines, working in local shelters for the homeless, renovating low-income housing and helping bring medical care to people living on the street.

title: Carol Goodwin and Douglas Fuller Are Married
description: Carol Warren Goodwin, a financial analyst, and Douglas Swanson Fuller, a real-estate executive, both of New York, were married yesterday at the Union Congregational Church in Peterborough, N.H., by the Rev. Gary Hauze.

title: POSTING: Brewhouse Conversion;   Orange Rentals
description: An 1890's brewhouse in Middletown, N.Y., abandoned for more than half a century, is being redeveloped into 53 moderate and low-rent apartments. The three-story structure at one time produced ''Orange County - The King of All Beers - The Cream of All Ales,'' popular in the area until the mid-30's. Local historians have cited the brewhouse, a three-story brick building with an ornate facade, as a good example of a type of local brewery that flourished in the Hudson and Mohawk Valleys in the early part of the century.

title: Missouri Upsets Kansas
description: With his players trailing Kansas by 3 points, having played as if they had seen ghosts, Norm Stewart, the Missouri coach, sat his rattled Tigers down at halftime and told them to get a grip on themselves. If anyone should be nervous, he told them, it's the visiting Jayhawks.

title: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST: Eastern Bloc;   In the East, the Selling of Democracy Takes On a New Fervor
description: As Eastern Europe gropes toward democracy, political consultants are rushing in with advice, which is almost as sought after these days as Western consumer goods.

title: Mutual Funds;   Reassessing Eastern Europe
description: When the Iron Curtain ripped open, investment managers rushed through, seeking profits in the chaos of Eastern Europe. Shares in Hungary and Germany funds have been sold and plans are in the works for Poland and Berlin funds.

title: BLACKS In ART;   Art as a Decoding Exercise
description: To the Editor:

title: Garment Steamers Recalled
description: The J. C. Penney Company is recalling more than 1,000 electric garment steamers that present a possible hazard to users, the Consumer Product Safety Commission says. Consumers reported that a locking mechanism on a steamer plug could be broken during use, releasing hot water and steam.

title: Style Makers;   Howard Jay Fleischer, Toy Designer
description: Almost everyone doodles, but not everyone doodles his way into something called a ''Polygonzo,'' a multidimensional sculpture cube that has become a chic executive toy, as addictive as worry beads. It can be twisted, folded and pulled into 20 geometric shapes, almost every letter of the alphabet and numerous other odd and wonderful configurations.

title: SIXTEEN - THE THIRD TIME AROUND
description: I have not walked in Isabel Davis's shoes, nor am I in the business of judging the circumstances under which consenting adults should or should not have intercourse (Hers: ''Sixteen - The Third Time Around,'' Dec. 17). But why did she take on faith the assurance of this stranger that he was ''just back from a year meditating with a Buddhist monk?'' (Back that very afternoon, one would suppose.) So she felt ill at ease and shy. Had she tested positive for the HIV virus, what was she going to say to her family? (Gee, I was ill at ease and shy?) Indeed, what would she say, as a parent and, presumably, a responsible member of society, if she learned that her daughter had behaved with a similar lack of intelligence.

title: Brooks Barton Plans to Marry
description: Malcolm Brewster Barton of Bedford, N.Y., has announced April wedding plans for his daughter, Brooks Barton, and Gerald Scott Cantini, the son of Gerald Peter Cantini of Manchester, Vt., and Mrs. Barry Hyde Chappel of Norwalk, Conn. Miss Barton also is the daughter of the late Cynthia Towell Barton.

title: IN THE NATURAL STATE
description: LEAD:

title: THE HATED SEASON
description: I am not a hunter, but Gordon Batcheller's descriptions of nature are wonderful. However, wouldn't it be nicer to shoot these creatures with his camera and let the scene remain for others to appreciate?

title: Is License to Kill Really a Victory for Women?;   Fighting Units
description: To the Editor:

title: August Wedding For Randi Justus
description: The engagement of Randi Michele Justus to Howard Keith Simon, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Lawrence J. Simon of Jericho, L.I., has been made known by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Michael Justus of East Northport, L.I. An August wedding is planned.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary by The Associated Press on Dec. 31 about Hermann Julius Oberth, a West German rocket scientist, misstated his birthplace. He was born in Nagyszeben, in Transylvania, an area that is now part of Rumania.

title:
DANCE;

When Choreography Meets Physics
description: LEAD: CLOUDS achieve substance and shape as described in dance terms by the choreographer Geulah Abrahams, whose company will perform Saturday at 8 P.M. at the Peddie School in Hightstown. For the eight dancers who currently make up the roster of Geulah Abrahams Danceworks, a modern-dance troupe based in

title: Smooth Landing for Shuttle After a Record Time in Space
description: The space shuttle Columbia landed safely in the darkness of early morning today, ending the longest and one of the most successful rescue missions in the history of the shuttle program.

title: THEY SHOULDN'T BE HOSTAGES
description: In recent days, the Alabama linebacker Keith McCants, a marvelous athlete against whom we have competed, announced he would leave school a year early to enter the 1990 National Football League draft.

title: Currency;   Drawing Strength From the Fed
description: It turned out to be an up week for the American dollar. While it was buffeted by news of the jump in the November trade deficit, the dollar was pushed higher by the growing belief that the Federal Reserve, concerned about inflation, would not be lowering interest rates any time soon. Firm interest rates tend to support the dollar. More support came from continued indications that the Bundesbank would not push interest rates any higher in West Germany, where the mark is felt to be strong enough. Meanwhile, the Canadian dollar was heading down, down, down. The Bank of Canada gave its first signal that it would let high interest rates there start to drop. In response, the Canadian dollar fell 2.3 percent against the American dollar, to 84.48 cents, from 86.40.

title: Suzanne W. Brask Married
description: Suzanne Whitsun Brask, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John H. Brask of South Orange, N.J., was married there yesterday at the Episcopal Church of St. Andrew and Holy Communion to Robert Frederick Learsch, the son of Mr. and Mrs. F. Robert Learsch of New Monmouth, N.J. The Rev. Robert B. Wardrop officiated. Mrs. Learsch is a landscape architect with the engineering firm of Edwards & Kelcey in Livingston, N.J.; her husband is a real-estate broker with Coldwell Banker Commercial in Parsippany, N.J.

title: For the Best to Excel, Students Should Be Grouped by Ability;   Shortchanged Middle
description: To the Editor:

title: Delaware Tries to Erase Image of Its Poor Health
description: Gov. Michael N. Castle has a problem: scientific studies saying that people who live in Delaware are among the least healthy in the nation.

title: COMMERCIAL PROPERTY: As-of-Right Construction;   Kalikow Opts for a 58-Story Lower Manhattan Hotel
description: PETER S. KALIKOW did not want to spend any more time going through the complex approval process necessary to build a 29-story office building in lower Manhattan. So he decided to go the easier route and build a 58-story hotel instead.

title: A Spot for Music and Light Meals
description: THE former owner of Breakaway in Fairfield has gone south, but not far. East Coast, Marty Levine's new restaurant, is just over the town line, in Westport, in a building that once housed Beeksteak Charlie's.

title: It May Be Water, but Is It Fit to Drink?
description: LEAD: ON a recent Saturday in the Village of Oyster Bay, when the frosty temperature kept the sidewalks empty of even the most ferocious shoppers, a line of people could be seen shivering near the entrance to a municipal parking lot.

title: Carol N. Sherwood Wed to J. S. Pettee
description: Carol Nelson Sherwood was married yesterday at the First Congregational Church in New Canaan, Conn., to Jonathan Starr Pettee. The Rev. Charles Crawford Smith officiated. Mrs. Pettee is the daughter of Edythe N. Sherwood of New Canaan and Peter F. Sherwood of Stratford, Conn. Her husband is a son of James Pettee of Bethesda, Md., and the late Mary Tetlow Pettee.

title: Track and Field;   Foster Keeps Winning Pace
description: Greg Foster, ranked as the world's best high hurdler for most of the last decade, is 31 years old and showing little sign of slowing down.

title: THE HATED SEASON
description: Mr. Batcheller has painted a lovely picture of a nature lover out for a quiet morning walk, not a picture of hunting at all. Those of us who do endeavor to enjoy a marsh at dawn during hunting season, however, take our lives in our hands.

title: Kudos Come When Actors Abandon Type
description: Meryl Streep acts silly, Tom Cruise looks grungy and Danny DeVito is the voice of reason; this season's films have been a parade of big-name stars acting against type. And while Ms. Streep is hilarious as the husband-stealing romance writer draped in acres of pink satin in ''She-Devil,'' and Mr. Cruise flawless as the paraplegic Vietnam veteran in ''Born on the Fourth of July,'' their performances are enhanced by an undeniable layer of surprise. It is as if audiences were saying, ''Meryl Streep, of all people, being funny!'' or calculating Mr. Cruise's tragic course and disheveled appearance against his hidden glamour-boy looks. And there is a metaphorical wink at the audience in Mr. DeVito's role as well, for the hot-tempered Louie DePalma of ''Taxi'' and the small-time con man of ''Romancing the Stone'' and ''The Jewel of the Nile'' emerges as the most logical, least impassioned character in ''The War of the Roses.''

title: Deborah J. Hall, Executive, Weds
description: Deborah Jane Hall and James Cameron Woods were married yesterday at St. John's Episcopal Church in North Haven, Conn., by the Rev. John H. Elledge Jr. The bride is a daughter of Mrs. Almon Blakeslee Hall of Wallingford, Conn., and the late Mr. Hall. Mr. Woods is the son of Col. James R. Woods, U.S.A.F., retired, and Mrs. Woods of Saranac Lake, N.Y.

title: Hitting Volleys and the Books
description: Her name is Angelica Gavaldon and she is a 16-year-old high school junior from California who came to the Australian Open with schoolbooks and racquets in tow.

title: 'Invisible Thread': Unfair Stereotype
description: I read with interest the article by Judy Chicurel about ''The Invisible Thread,'' a newly published book that intends to dispel myths and stereotypes about Jewish women in America [Women in a Jewish Tapestry, in Words and Pictures,'' Dec. 31] . I was disturbed, though, by a quote from a college student who was one of the 60 interviewees in the book. She talked about the unfairness of being stereotyped as a Jewish-American Princess because of her upscale Long Island address. She then said, ''There are a lot of non-Jewish girls who are just as spoiled as Jewish girls.'' I wish the word ''some'' had preceded the phrase ''Jewish girls.''

title: Kaboom!
description: To the Editor:

title: IN THE REGION: New Jersey;   Recent Sales
description: Freehold $223,500

title: Alicia Ruggiero To Wed in July
description: Mr. and Mrs. Anthony W. Ruggiero of Princeton, N.J., have announced July wedding plans for their daughter Alicia M. Ruggiero and Jonathan I. Brodsky, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert G. Brodsky of Boca Raton, Fla.

title: Fewer Turf Battles, More Drug Arrests
description: QUIETLY, virtually unnoticed by most New Yorkers, a three-year effort by Federal and local law-enforcement officials has made some notable gains against some of the city's most notorious narcotics traffickers. Government officials say that 150 dealers, including some major traffickers who controlled drug distribution in parts of Manhattan and Queens, have been locked up since 1986 in an operation that has become a model for Federal and municipal cooperation.

title: NONFICTION
description: LONE TREE: A True Story of Murder in America's Heartland. By Bruce Brown. (Crown, $17.95.) Shortly before noon on Dec. 9, 1985, Dale Burr, an Iowa farmer, grabbed his shotgun, entered the kitchen where his wife of 40 years was baking cookies and shot her through the heart. He then drove into town, where he killed his banker. He was not finished. At a neighboring farm, he pumped two lethal shots into a young farmer against whom he had held a grudge. The last of Burr's acts of brutality, all of which took place in under an hour, was to turn the gun on himself, blowing two holes in his chest. Bruce Brown, the author of ''Mountain in the Clouds: A Search for the Wild Salmon,'' has chosen this shocking incident as the basis for ''Lone Tree,'' a thoroughly researched sociological examination of the plight of the American farmer. It is not a pretty picture. That same fall, reports Mr. Brown, ''three first-rate Iowa farmers committed suicide in one seven-day stretch.'' These men, like Burr, had been successful farmers and model citizens. But around the time President Jimmy Carter chose to fight Russian expansionism with an American grain embargo, farmland values tumbled, as did crop prices. Left with huge debts and no way to pay them off, farmers were distraught; foreclosure notices became as commonplace as garage sales. As one neighbor remarked: ''If farming would have been paying off, Dale would have farmed forever, wouldn't he? . . . Some people can handle debt, and some people can't.'' Mr. Brown meticulously details problems faced by American farmers over the years, and notes the Government's grim prediction that half of this country's 2.2 million farms will be eliminated over the next 14 years. As he writes, ''The deeper personal tragedy of Dale Burr was the fact that he became a victim of a historic process that he himself advanced.''

title: THE DARK AT THE END OF THE TUNNEL
description: ESCAPES

title: NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Houlton, Me.;   Historic Square In a Comeback
description: MORE than $2.5 million from public and private sources has been spent in the last few years to fix up Market Square, the downtown area of this northern Maine town of 6,700 people. The area is listed on the National Register of Historic Places as a fine example of turn-of-the-century commercial architecture, said Charles Upton, the town's Director of Community Development.

title: 'Roar of the Greasepaint' Is Reborn in Westport
description: IN ''The Roar of the Greasepaint, the Smell of the Crowd'' - you will be subjected to the title just once - an elitist (Sir) and a commoner (Cocky) play the Game (of life, of course), or something like that.

title: Martin's Estate Under $100,000
description: Billy Martin, who died in a Christmas night automobile accident in front of his home, has left an estate that legal papers say is worth less than $100,000.

title: Inmates Help to Save Injured Wild Animals
description: LEAD: TED UBRY was on the way to his soybean fields one recent evening when he spotted something unusual perched in a tree. At first he thought it was a wayward swarm of honeybees that had escaped from a neighbor's hive.

title: Airport Security: A Case in Point
description: ISSUES of travel security make everyone uneasy. The yes-no aspect of an airport is an example. At departure, an airport is supposed to lure you in and cosset you into the wonders of travel; at the end of the flight, the arrival airport is supposed to welcome you to the new place and hint at its attractions. Instead, corridors are full of barricades that have nothing to do with the architect's plan; plastic shields and conveyor belts impede vistas. It seems unlikely that this stuff, however temporary looking, will ever disappear. On the contrary, airports will in time probably be built to incorporate tight security. will perhaps one day be put into booths or behind panels with little windows like those used by X-ray technicians. The only way that most travelers can cope with hazards beyond their control is to shut them out. If some event makes passengers anxious, they may find themselves in a tug of war between saying nothing - and letting the trip continue, presumably without event - or pointing out a problem and creating a fuss.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Boston;

Revitalizing A Sears Site
description: LEAD: A $268 MILLION restoration and expansion of a nine-acre Sears, Roebuck and Company warehouse and retail complex into a biomedical research center has been approved by the Boston Redevelopment Authority.

title: Evening Hours;   Saluting Ballet, a Park And 9 Decades
description: American Ballet Theater celebrated its 50th anniversary last Sunday night with a gala performance at the Metropolitan Opera House. A champagne supper dance for 1,200 guests followed in a heated tent over the terrace pool on the north side of the Opera House. The Henry Moore sculpture ''Reclining Figure'' separated the two dance floors. The curtain didn't come down on Hank Lane's music until 3 A.M.

title: World Markets;   Will Tokyo's Slide Snowball?
description: It is becoming a regular reflex to check the Nikkei 225 - Tokyo's closely watched stock index - early in the evening in New York. Since the beginning of the year, it has been plunging with regularity and has helped bring down many other major markets.

title: Jacobsen Fights Drought in Desert
description: Peter Jacobsen is determined to put past disappointments behind him as he tries to win his first PGA Tour tournament in six years at the Bob Hope Chrysler Classic.

title: IN THE REGION: Long Island;   Recent Sales
description: Bethpage $198,000

title: Fisk Is Signed
description: With 336 home runs, he leads American League catchers in the record book and at 42 years old, Carlton Fisk is not through yet. Yesterday, he signed a one-year contract with the Chicago White Sox for $1.75 million.

title: East Europe's Next Test: To Survive Democracy
description: IF 1989 gave the world the indelible image of vast crowds on the cobbled squares of Eastern Europe demanding democracy, then 1990 may be the year when those same crowds learn that chasing out a clutch of ham-fisted commissars was the easy part.

title: Panama Has No Dictator, But It Has a Big Brother
description: AMONG the heroes of every American history textbook is the indefatigable Teddy Roosevelt, who dared to snatch Panama from Colombia to build the Panama Canal. Nearly a century later, President Bush tried to carve out a similar place in history by conquering Panama again.

title:
MUSIC;

A Rarely Heard Duo: Trumpet and Oboe
description: LEAD: ALTHOUGH the trumpet and the oboe are rarely paired as a duo, there is a small selection of works featuring the two instruments.

description: LEAD:

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS
description: MIRANDA AND THE MOVIES

title: Wind Players to Take The Spotlight
description: PIANISTS and violinists are rarely in short supply, but next weekend it will be the wind players who will be in the spotlight at chamber and orchestral concerts around the state.

description: PING CHONG

title: Flutist Took Delayed Route to Virtuosity
description: LEAD: DEIRDRE MANNING is the first to concede that her route to flute virtuosity was not exactly orthodox. There are not too many professional flutists who pick up the instrument for the first time at the age of 19, start playing immediately and, five years later, have a conservatory degree and a career in music.

title: QUESTION OF THE WEEK: Next Week;   Is Betting On the Super Bowl Excessive?
description: The Times welcomes letters from readers. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. Letters should be addressed to The Editor, Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: On Deadline
description: To the Editor:

title: Senator Dole's Jackpot Question On Foreign Aid Stirs Up Congress
description: SENATOR BOB DOLE set off a stormy debate on foreign aid last week by saying aloud something that has only been whispered on Capitol Hill: Given the limited resources the United States has for foreign aid, wouldn't it make sense to cut by a mere 5 percent the grants made to Israel and the four other largest aid recipients, reallocating that money to Eastern European countries and Panama?

title: Deirdre Slavin to Wed R. B. Mitchell
description: The engagement of Deirdre Jane Slavin to Richard Bates Mitchell, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry E. Mitchell of Groton, Mass., has been made known by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Raymond D. Slavin of Darien, Conn. A July wedding is planned.

title: Winfield Would Shift
description: Right field is still his position of choice, but Dave Winfield, the 38-year-old Yankee slugger who missed last season after back surgery and watched as Jesse Barfield took over his familiar ground, has made it clear that he is a team player first and last.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Dec. 3 about Judge Carl B. Stokes of the Cleveland Municipal Court misstated the year of his unsuccessful bid for a seat on the Common Pleas Court. As Mr. Stokes pointed out in a recent letter, it was 1986, not 1988.

title: WELFARE FOR EVERYBODY
description: LEAD:

title: Why So Rigid on Eastern Europe?
description: Eastern Europe's courageous effort to leap from controlled to market economies creates a desperate need for Western help. It would be tragic if ideological rigidity blocked that aid.

title: Question Of the Week;   Was the Bet By Jackson And Barkley Improper?
description: Completely. The future portends that this could just be the beginning of a less than innocent one-on-one bet. Point-shaving and dumping loom for others if rules are not abided. Considering their salaries, I believe the fine was too lenient.

title: Saying It With Music as Well as the Words
description: Words, as every poet knows, have a music of their own, especially when spoken sonorously by gifted performers. So why paint the lily? Yet the wedding of words to music is almost as old as poetry itself, and when the collaboration is between geniuses, even though centuries apart - as when Mendelssohn underscored ''A Midsummer Night's Dream'' - the results can be thrilling.

title: CORRECTION
description: The Talking column on Jan. 14 gave an incorrect telephone number for ordering seedlings and saplings from the Long Island office of the New York State Department of Environmental Conservation. It is (516) 751-7900, ext. 234.

title: Cindi Studin to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Abraham Studin of Orangeburg, N.Y., have announced May wedding plans for their daughter Cindi Studin and Dr. Mitchell Russ Berger, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Sanford Berger of Brooklyn. Ms. Studin, a graduate of Ithaca College, is an account executive at PMK Public Relations in New York. The prospective bridegroom, a fellow in oncology at the Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center in New York, graduated cum laude from Cornell University and received a medical degree from Jefferson Medical College.

title: In Beijing, Wishful Whispers That Li Will Fall
description: The whispers among Chinese officials these days are all about power struggles or major reshuffles in the leadership.

title:
ABOUT LONG ISLAND;

The Changing Face of the Migrant Farm Work Force
description: LEAD: WHIZZING past Long Island's agricultural scene, a driver can see visible changes in the farm economy, where the traditions of raising ducks, fruits and potatoes have been largely replaced by the growing of ornamental trees, shrubs and flowers, sod and grapes.

title: Mornings on TV: Fine-Tuning a Sweet Formula
description: The other day, NBC's ''Today'' show got a new executive producer, about a week after it had acquired a new co-host. Last fall, a new executive producer took over ''CBS This Morning'' and hired several new reporters. And no doubt something or someone new will soon be added to ABC's ''Good Morning America,'' although it has been doing very well in the ratings. Yet, for all the changes and all the competition, any viewer who attends closely to the morning talk shows, as I recently did for one week, is likely to be struck more by their similarities than by their differences.

title: The Extra Man Is the Man of the 90's
description: THE plight of older women in search of available, interested men became a cultural cliche of the 1980's. Now it seems that the lament of the 90's might come from younger men. Demography dictates that they will have to fight over a smaller pool of potential mates.

title: A New Name And, Soon, a New Home for Museum
description: IN designing a new home for the Katonah Gallery - now to be known as the Katonah Museum of Art - Edward Larrabee Barnes was on familiar territory.

title: Jennifer Houlton, Actress, Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Frank William Houlton of New York and Fair Harbor, L.I., have made known the engagement of their daughter Jennifer Mann Houlton to Kosmo Vinyl, the son of Harold Dunk of London. A July wedding is planned.

title:
ART;

New Decade, New Direction
description: LEAD: THE concept of a fresh approach is appropriate to the start of a year. With this in mind, the Graphic Eye Gallery in Port Washington, Long Island's oldest printmakers' cooperative, invited its 24 members to participate in ''Bring in the New,'' an exhibition emphasizing ideas, subject areas and stylistic directions that the artists have begun to explore and expect to develop in 1990.

title: F.B.I. Man and Bank Suspect Slain in Shooting in St. Louis
description: A bank robbery suspect and an agent of the Federal Bureau of Investigation died in a shootout here Friday night after the agent and two others had burst into the suspect's house.

title: Suspicions Came Too Late in Boston
description: To almost everyone, Charles Stuart's story that a black gunman had killed his pregnant wife and then shot him in the stomach seemed so believable. But specialists in family violence now say the police, the press and the public should have been more suspicious of Mr. Stuart from the start.

title: Lifestyle: Sunday Menu;   Pizzocheri: Buckwheat Makes It Chewy
description: Pizzocheri is a moderately well-known form of Italian pasta. What distinguishes it from those that are best known is its predominant grain, buckwheat.

title: Ambulance Corps Turn to Teen-Agers
description: LEAD: FIVE years ago, Matthew Garnett was in gym class at Middlesex Middle School in Darien when a classmate fell and broke his arm. An ambulance was dispatched from nearby Explorer Post 53. ''The Posties came and helped him,'' Mr. Garnett recalled. ''And I was just amazed by what they could do. I decided I wanted to do that.

title: Review/Music;   Premiere Of Ashley's 'Brother'
description: Whatever Robert Ashley does, it's extreme. His compositions have always tested audience endurance, from the amplified shouting over roaring electronic distortion of his early ''Wolfman'' (1964), to the protracted television operas of the 1980's, with his own mumbling monologues, rockish percussion and vocal interjections and cocktail-jazzish piano filigrees.

title: PAST PERFECT
description: Some furniture and objects are forever classics. Take, for instance, a wicker chair or a child's cradle. For generations, both have had a specific place and purpose in the home. Now, as more and more architects and interior designers are manufacturing their own furniture, many are looking at the classics for inspiration. Call it reinventing the wheel or recasting old ideas, but these contemporary versions have a spirit and style all their own.

title: Conference to Explore the Stages of Adoption
description: LEAD: PARENTS PLACE, a nonprofit drop-in center here for parents with very young children, is sponsoring a daylong conference next month on adoption.

title: Insider Offers Look at Czech Revolt
description: IVAN M. HAVEL, the brother of Vaclav Havel, the President of Czechoslovakia, spoke last week to an audience here about ''the revolution of intellectuals'' in his country that ''literally laughed the Communist Government out of power.''

title: Plan to Buy Condos As Public Housing Stirs Wide Interest
description: INTEREST has been so strong in a state plan to buy hundreds of condominiums to rent or sell to moderate- and low-income families that officials at the Department of Housing have had to add more sessions this week to explain details of the plan.

title: No Deal?
description: Barbara Piasecka Johnson (right, with Lech Walesa), who went to work as a chambermaid after immigrating from Poland in 1968, has doubtless learned a little something about capitalism since she inherited $570 million or so a few years ago. Mrs. Johnson, who married J. Seward Johnson, the Johnson & Johnson heir, three years after going to work in his New Jersey mansion, last year met Mr. Walesa and offered to invest up to $100 million in the financially troubled shipyard in Gdansk. But Polish officials said last week that they were looking into alternatives because Mrs. Johnson drove too hard a bargain. A Solidarity official said that she demanded a five-year ban on strikes and proposed wages that were half the prevailing level. A spokesman for Mrs. Johnson denied that there were any firm demands along those lines and said Mrs. Johnson might still invest in the shipyard where Solidarity was born. Nevertheless, a Government spokeswoman called Mrs. Johnson's offer ''a joke.''

title: Correction
description: An article on Jan. 7 about gains in Coast Guard enlistment resulting from the campaign against drug smuggling located the Coast Guard Training Center incorrectly. It is in Cape May.

title: Don Cossacks: Classical Ballet Isn't for Them
description: ''The Cossacks were indeed warriors - that's part of history - but it's misleading to think of them as mean and nasty people.'' So asserts Anatoly Kvasov, artistic director of the Don Cossacks Song and Dance Company of Rostov, which opens on Tuesday night for a 16-performance engagement at the Neil Simon Theater.

title: Laura Sheppe to Wed Michael Miller
description: Mrs. P. Peter Sheppe of Scarsdale, N.Y., has announced December wedding plans for her daughter, Laura Elizabeth Sheppe, and Michael Bruce Miller, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald E. Miller of Calabasas, Calif.

title: Who Else Painted Bellini's 'Feast'?
description: One of the most rewarding exhibitions in recent months is hardly an exhibition at all. It focuses on a single painting, ''The Feast of the Gods,'' long attributed to Giovanni Bellini and Titian. In the possession of the National Gallery since 1942, it was removed from display five years ago to be cleaned and is now back on the wall.

title: Herbert Wehner, 83, Key Member Of the Social Democrats in Bonn
description: Herbert Wehner, a leading member of West Germany's Social Democratic Party who was once described as an ''oratorical volcano'' and ''a boulder in the desert of German politics,'' died on Friday at his home in Bad Godesberg, a suburb of Bonn. He was 83 years old.

title: Gold's Lure vs. Indian Rights: A Brazilian Conflict Sets the Amazon Aflame
description: Named Operation Free Forest, a two-week police action in the northern Amazon has led a third of 45,000 illegal gold prospectors to leave Yanomami Indian lands, Justice Ministry officials say.

title: Sheila Anne Carey T Wed in March
description: Mr. and Mrs. Raymond B. Carey Jr. of Locust, N.J., and Nantucket, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter Sheila Anne Carey to Parker Stephen Bryan, a son of Carleton Felton Bryan of San Francisco and the late Carol Bryan. A March wedding is planned.

title: Review/Ice Capades;   Cutting Capers for a 50th Anniversary
description: The Ice Capades 50th-Anniversary show, which opened on Friday night for a two-week run at Madison Square Garden, gets off to a surprisingly listless start. But just as one begins to despair of seeing the good, old-fashioned cornball ice dancing on which the show has built its reputation, along comes a second act that lives up to all the hype.

title:
NORTH BERGEN JOURNAL;

Volunteer Squad Enforces Laws on Dumping and Littering
description: LEAD: A NAPKIN fluttered to the ground next to an empty milkshake container that had been tossed from a car of teen-agers parked at the Burger King on Bergenline Avenue. Louis Cardenas left his car and walked swiftly in their direction.

title: INTOXICATED BY MY ILLNESS
description: As a former cancer patient, I can identify with Anatole Broyard's feelings of buoyancy while undergoing treatment of his illness (About Men: ''Intoxicated by My Illness,'' Nov. 12). During chemotherapy treatment, which left me bald, weak and loaded with mouth sores, I continued to play sports, to the amazement of my friends. I became special. It was as though I represented ''every man'' who might come down with cancer in the future. I had the support of everyone. It was marvelous. All I had to do was survive, and I was a hero.

title: Giving Credit To Teacher of Russian
description: I strongly object to the omission of the name of the instructor of Russian language at Morristown High School in the Dec. 17 article ''Studying the 'Critical Languages.''' The article gave the name of the principal, who does not teach a critical language, the name of the chairman of the foreign langauge department, who does not teach a critical language, and the name of a teacher who monitors, not teaches, the course in Japanese, which is transmitted by satellite.

title: Is License to Kill Really a Victory for Women?
description: To the Editor:

title: Long Island Journal
description: Geri-Olympics

title: A GOOD ROAD TO SOMEWHERE
description: A PLACE OF LIGHT

title: WE HAVE MET THE ELDERLY AND THEY ARE US
description: RISKING OLD AGE IN AMERICA

title: Question Of the Week;   Was the Bet By Jackson And Barkley Improper?
description: The N.B.A. did a terrific job stopping Jackson and Barkley early with fines. To allow petty betting would surely open a dire Pandora's box of big time gambling in professional and college sports of whose consequences even the most fanatical advocates should shudder.

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT/RECORDINGS: RECENT RELEASES
description: CLASSICAL

title: Leora Joseph to Wed in July
description: Rabbi and Mrs. Howard S. Joseph of Montreal have announced the engagement of their daughter, Leora H. Joseph, to Michael Wechsler, the son of Dr. and Mrs. Morris Wechsler of Montreal. A July wedding is planned. Miss Joseph, 21 years old, is a senior at Barnard College. Mr. Wechsler, 21, a magna cum laude graduate of Harvard University, will enter the McGill University Medical School in September.

title: Rooms Of Their Own
description: When Ellen Baxter was working on a report about the homeless people of New York City, she went into shelters and subway stations and parks to talk to them about their lives. The problem was enormous but her conclusion was simple. ''It was so obvious to me that what they wanted was a place to live,'' she says. ''They wanted a key and a room where they could lock the door.''

title: Goodbye 'Mom's Limo,' Hello New Life
description: THIS was not the first time I had sold a car. But this was the first time in 19 years that a station wagon (or Mom's Limo, as ours was fondly called) would not be replaced by another station wagon as our family car.

title: No Credible Doubt That Contras Murdered Nuns
description: To the Editor:

title: Chicago
description: To the Editor: The readout to the headline ''On the Lam in Old Chicago'' used the word gunsels for gunmen. Some years ago I read that the first use of gunsel was attributed to Max Brand, a successful writer of Western stories and books. After he used gunsel for gunslinger, hordes of pulp writers who had probably never been west of the Hudson, not to speak of the Mississippi, copied this seemingly authentic bit of the real West. When asked about this word years later, Mr. Brand said that it meant ''goose'' (presumably in Yiddish). The Western meaning has now apparently been accepted, appearing in my Random House Dictionary.

title: Yugoslavia Catching East Europe's Political Fever
description: For months, this nation of scrappy and independent burghers and farmers watched calmly as other East European nations swept away in anger the Communist systems that unlike the one here were imposed by Moscow.

title: Mike Figgis Likes Looking at Life On the Dark Side
description: Mike Figgis was not only down in the dumps the day his directing career turned around a few years ago, he was literally down in a Dumpster as well, standing hip deep in five-inch recording tape boxes in an enormous trash bin in an alley in London's Soho district when the big break came.

title:
GARDENING;

Laying Out a Plan for the Landscape
description: LEAD: Though we are barely a third of the way through winter, the stack of seed and nursery catalogues has already grown so tall that it has to be divided into two piles to keep it from falling over. Each year these earliest harbingers of spring begin to arrive before the Christmas decorations have been put away, as a reminder it is time to get plans of spring planting under way.

title: Still Punching
description: In a sport where 30 is old and 40 is ancient, George Foreman beat the odds -and Gerry Cooney - last week. Foreman (above, delivering a punch), the oldest and heaviest of heavyweights, was so impressive as he knocked Cooney out in the second round that sportswriters, who had joked that the 253-pound Foreman would be ordering food between rounds, turned to speculating that the 41-year-old former champion might make a fit opponent for the current titleholder, 22-year-old Mike Tyson. Foreman, who returned to the ring in 1987 after a 10-year absence during which he became an evangelical preacher, turned reporters' earlier derision to his advantage. The press had called the Atlantic City fight ''two geezers at Ceasars,'' so Foreman said that his ring name would henceforth be The Geezer. Archie Moore, the 70-ish former light-heavyweight champion, declared that Foreman's victory had cosmic significance beyond boxing. ''People are going to look at all 40-year-old people differently,'' he said. ''And people 40 years old are going to look at themselves differently.''

title: Wall Street, Salivating Over Bankruptcies
description: To the Editor:

title: Polished and Gracious Italian Fare
description: THERE were no postholiday doldrums at La Rondinella, and no wonder. Some of the best food in the Five Towns is found at this gracious Italian restaurant in Woodmere. There is a Mediterranean feel and spirit at this simply appointed spot with its creamy walls, mirrors, wood lattices and fresh flowers. Yet the centerpiece at La Rondinella is the food.

title:
IN THE REGION: New Jersey;

Attached Housing Growing in Princeton
description: LEAD: PRINCETON TOWNSHIP, covering 16.5 square miles, has long been characterized by winding roads and large single-family detached homes with spacious backyards. But in recent years the scarcity and rising cost of easily buildable land has generated a spurt of multifamily developments.

title: BLACKS In ART;   Tortured Optics
description: To the Editor:

title: Data Bank/January 21, 1990
Technology;   A Pioneer is Out on a Limb Again
description: Twenty-two years ago, when a young professor of computer science at the California Institute of Technology predicted that single chips containing millions of transistors would one day be commonplace, his vision was greeted with incredulity.

title: Enrollment Slips at Many Private Schools
description: PRIVATE elementary and secondary schools in New Jersey have experienced some slippage in enrollments as they try to cope with a declining school-age population and a slowdown in the economy.

title: Conflict Over Aide Wins Dinkins Respect
description: Mayor David N. Dinkins's response to the first big dispute of his administration - his appointment of Dr. Woodrow A. Myers Jr. as New York City's Health Commissioner - seemed to show last week that any suggestions of softness in the new Mayor's spine are greatly exaggerated.

title: BLACKS In ART;   Straining Credulity
description: To the Editor:

title: Experience Alters a View Of Disabled
description: THE summer I was 19 my friend Razel had a job assisting the social director of a nursing home on Riverside Drive in Manhattan. A whirlwind of energy and optimism, she would go in with a guitar and try to cheer up the residents with a song. Then she would take the time to chat about their grandchildren or perhaps about their younger, stronger days.

title:
IN SHORT;

NONFICTION
description: LEAD:

title: Review/Music;   Orchestra of Young Players In Five World Premieres
description: The program notes for the concert of five premieres by the National Orchestral Association at Carnegie Hall on Friday evening offered a freewheeling mix of analysis, apologia, boosterism and criticism. Of Frederick Bianchi's studiedly amorphous ''Rauschenberg Variations,'' readers were informed, evidently on behalf of the composer, ''As long as the performers are honest and try their hardest, any performance - whether by an amateur group or by the world's most virtuosic orchestra - is correct.''

title:
FOCUS: Z Lots;

Staggered Siting for Detached Houses
description: LEAD: THE Z-lot, a house-siting design said to have been used first in Paris and then more widely in California, Florida and Colorado, has been adapted for a project northwest of Baltimore where land prices have been rising sharply.

title: THE REVENGE OF THE ONE-NIGHT STAND
description: EXES

title: Protests in Georgia Strain Security Budgets
description: With white supremacists demonstrating again this weekend in downtown Atlanta, officials here are increasingly asking a difficult question: who should pay the bills when free speech gets expensive?

title: How Outrage in U.S. Spurred Action in Jesuit Case
description: Behind the arrests of eight military men in the killing of six Jesuit priests and two women in El Salvador lies an extraordinary campaign of pleas to the Bush Administration by church groups and of pressure on the Salvadoran Government by American officials demanding a full investigation.

title:
ART;

Quality in Show of Small-Scale Works
description: LEAD: THE host this year for the annual members' exhibition of the Huntington Township Art League is the Northport Galleries, the artists' cooperative in Huntington. The show, which features small-scale works by 125 of the league's members, will be on view through next Sunday.

title: Pride of the Garden State
description: To the Editor:

title: Managing;   Media Manipulation 101
description: The battle lines used to be clearly drawn: Reporters were the predators, executives were the prey, and public relations people ran interference between the two.

title: Beginning a New Chapter As a Party of One
description: I HESITANTLY approach the entrance. I have no experience to help me. This is not one of the learned behaviors that I have repeated often enough to classify as a reflex action.

title: Bittersweet Trip
description: To the Editor: Like Leslie Maitland's parents, who returned to Freiburg, West Germany (''A Bittersweet Pilgrimage,'' Travel, Dec. 17), my wife and I were invited to return to my native town, Vallendar, after 51 years.

title: S. Fannie Simon, Teacher, 88
description: S. Fannie Simon, a retired teacher and labor leader, died of a ruptured appendix Wednesday at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center in Manhattan. She was 88 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: HAS ANYBODY HERE SEEN GORING?
description: LEAD:

title: 'Human Dimension' For DES Victims
description: After reading Candice Tedeschi's article, ''DES Victims: Search Must Go On'' (Long Island Opinion, Dec. 24), I feel compelled to write, in an attempt to emphasize the human dimension of an issue that has not received adequate media attention.

title: CRIME
description: Hector Belascoaran Shayne works nights and shares his Mexico City office with a sewer expert, which no doubt contributes to the morbid outlook he presents in AN EASY THING (Viking, $16.95), the first of Paco Ignacio Taibo 2d's many crime novels to be published in English.

title: BLUE MAX CAN DELIVER AN EARFUL
description: Audio isn't just a matter of nuts, bolts and other assorted hardware. Equally important to good sound reproduction is the study of psychoacoustics - a hybrid science straddling various borders between physics, music, engineering and biology. Its aim is to understand the ways in which human beings perceive sound.

title:
GARDENING;

Laying Out a Plan for the Landscape
description: LEAD: Though we are barely a third of the way through winter, the stack of seed and nursery catalogues has already grown so tall that it has to be divided into two piles to keep it from falling over. Each year these earliest harbingers of spring begin to arrive before the Christmas decorations have been put away, as a reminder it is time to get plans of spring planting under way.

title:
Your Own Account;

Ending the Partnership
description: LEAD: The loss of tax advantages for limited partnerships and the collapse of the national real estate market have left millions of investors holding what they fear are worthless real estate limited partnerships. What should they do? There is a way to sell them, but the advice of many analysts is: Let the seller beware.

title: Lost Without Men?
description: LOOKING FOR LOVE

title: The Business of Health Helps a School Regain Its Prominence
description: JOHN L. LAHEY, president of Quinnipiac College in Hamden, recalls that in 1988, when the school began raising money for its Echlin Health Sciences Center, its only fund-raising experience was a $1 million campaign 10 years earlier that fell 25 percent short of its goal.

title: In the Desert, a Jim Thompson Novel Blossoms on Film
description: The town is called Mecca, and the street names are Bagdad, Damascus and Cairo. In the 1930's, local businessmen imported date palm trees from the Middle East to the Southern California desert, and they created their own ersatz Saharan village.

title: Dorsett Returns To Super Bowl
description: After 12 seasons, Tony Dorsett's career is ending where it began.

title:
IN SHORT;

FICTION
description: LEAD:

title: Ms. Roosevelt Weds C. H. Silberstein
description: Laura Delano Roosevelt, a daughter of Mrs. Erasmus Helm Kloman of Washington and the late Franklin Delano Roosevelt Jr., was married yesterday to Dr. Charles Henry Silberstein, a son of Mrs. Herbert F. Storfer of New York and the late Dr. Richard M. Silberstein. Acting Justice Shirley Fingerhood of State Supreme Court in Manhattan officiated at the Colony Club in New York.

title: Campus Life: Berkeley;   Into Each Lap A Little Cake Did Fall
description: Oski the bear, the official mascot of the University of California, has been suspended for two weeks, after the furry cheerleader threw a layer cake into the crowd at a basketball game, splattering an estimated 15 people.

title: Loryn R. Cohen to Marry
description: Mr. and Mrs. Arnold S. Cohen of Scarsdale, N.Y., have announced May wedding plans for their daughter Loryn R. Cohen and Michael Lawrence Kass, the son of Harriet Marcus and Dr. Alfred M. Kass, both of Columbus, Ohio. Ms. Cohen, 24 years old, is a graduate of Tulane University and a marketing associate at Bear, Stearns & Company in New York. The prospective bridegroom, 24 and a summa cum laude graduate of Tulane, is an associate at Lazard Freres & Company in New York.

title: Fashions;   Put a Vest in the Closet, Pull Out Lots of New Looks
description: Winter sales racks have been overgrazed. Spring merchandise is just starting to trickle in. But the fashion urge cannot be stilled. One way to satisfy it right now is with one of the new vests that department stores and boutiques are stocking. In ethnic or vintage materials, they lend a one-of-a-kind look to wardrobe basics. Bright knits and silks bring an early breath of fresh air.
