title: What Women Want Is Simple Respect
description: AS far as I'm concerned, Women's Lib will have done its job if it merely succeeds in gaining women respect. That may seem simple, but it's not. With this accomplished, though, the specific goals of the movement should fall into place. Let me make my case.

title: The City of Mayor Barry: Achievement and Decay
description: On Friday afternoon, David A. Clarke, the chairman of the City Council here, said with evident anxiety, ''The most important thing I want to project to the people of Washington and across the nation is that this city is under control.''

title: Mia M. Hylfelt Weds Mark S. Clowes
description: Mia Magdalena Hylfelt, a daughter of Magda A. Hylfelt of Bardonia, N.Y., and the late Kai W. Hylfelt, was married yesterday to Mark Stetson Clowes, a son of Annette Foisie of Rowayton, Conn., and Everett Clowes of Norwalk, Conn. The Rev. Francis Geer performed the ceremony at St. Philip's Episcopal Church in the Highlands in Garrison, N.Y.

title: Witness Says Troops 'Shot at Everything'
description: Aris Yunusov, an Azerbaijani political centrist who spent the predawn hours walking through the streets of Baku, said today that army and Interior Ministry troops converged on the city from the north, south and west, with the most intensive battles in the north.

title: S. Maynard Bronstein to Wed Melissa E. Zeidman
description: August wedding plans for Melissa Ellen Zeidman and S. Maynard Bronstein, a son of Patricia Honeyman of Oakton, Va., and Dr. Seymour Bronstein of Hazelton, Pa., have been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Dr. and Mrs. Howard Zeidman of Cherry Hill and Harvey Cedars, N.J.

title: Realtors Compete for the Soft Sell
description: LEAD: THE exhibit appears to be no different than most art shows. There are well-lighted rooms around which the works have been carefully hung. Discreet tags list the titles and prices for interested buyers. There are champagne and refreshments and visitors chatting up the artist. But this exhibit has a broader purpose.

title: SUSPECT ARRESTED IN RAZOR ATTACKS
description: After a weeklong search that took detectives to Miami Beach, a Brooklyn teen-ager was arrested yesterday in the razor-slashings of two people, including the actress Viveca Lindfors, as they walked in Greenwich Village on Jan. 13. The police said the suspect was high on LSD and alcohol during the attacks.

title: Alison W. Hunter Becomes the Bride Of Cary N. Potter Jr. in Connecticut
description: Alison Webb Hunter and Cary Nicholas Potter Jr. were married yesterday at St. Mark's Episcopal Church in New Canaan, Conn., by the Rev. Roland M. Jones.

title: Correction
description: A picture caption on Dec. 31 with an article about New Orleans misidentified the saxophonist playing at the Maple Leaf Bar. He was John Hart.

title: AT 75, Tennis Star Fights Another Foe
description: LEAD: WHENEVER the tennis star Marga Lee Mahony of Bedford wins a national seniors title, she celebrates two triumphs: one for the championship and the other against a grim and ever-menacing adversary. For nearly 12 years she has been fighting Parkinson's disease. The tremors caused by the disease come and go, she says.

title: A PAWN OF WAR
description: IT HAD ALREADY BEEN A BAD NIGHT. CBS NEWS CORRESPONDENT Juan Vasquez, editor John Mondello and I were covering the United States invasion of Panama as best we could from our edit room on the mezzanine of the Marriott Hotel. We were on an open phone line to the control room in New York, able to go on the air at any time. At 12:30 A.M., New York told us to stand by - the White House was going to make an announcement. This was it. The invasion had begun. Just then, I looked down to the lobby and saw a band of paramilitaries. Gunmen from the Dignity Battalions were rounding up Americans and taking them away. We shut the door, turned out the light, and broadcast to New York for the next two and a half hours, cowering in the dark. I heard constant yelling in the lobby. At 3:30 A.M., there was a knock on our door and a CBS driver told us it was safe to come out. From then on, we were busy trying to report from the hotel, mostly by looking out the windows of the 15th floor at the burning city. Journalists came and went with information that we passed along to CBS in New York, which stayed on the air all night.

title: Appeals Court Says Alabama May Fly the Confederate Flag
description: A Federal appellate court has affirmed Alabama's right to display the Confederate flag on the top of its Capitol, ruling that it does not violate the Constitution.

title: Those Awful Shuttle Fares
description: On Wednesday morning, Jan. 3, weekday Shuttle passengers on the Washington-New York and New York-Boston routes received a nasty New Year's present from the glitzy self-promoter Donald J. Trump. His Trump Shuttle raised its one-way weekday fares by an unprecedented 20 percent, to $119 from $99, thereby exacerbating the already excessive unrestricted air fare gouge that presently afflicts most of the nation's business (and many other) travelers. Its principal competitor on these busy routes, Pan American World Airways Inc., promptly matched the Trump Shuttle's increases.

title: Forging a Global Empire in a Sluggish Market
description: These are not the easiest of days for the Marriott Corporation, the largest hotel company in the world. The company's chairman, J. W. Marriott Jr., is recuperating from open-heart surgery. The Marriott hotel in Panama endured a harrowing seige during the United States invasion last month. Business at some of the company's lodging properties has been so sluggish that the company last month announced a $150 million write-down. And the company's stock has been flat for several years.

title: Bus Plunge Kills 25 in Nepal
description: Twenty-five people died when a crowded bus plunged off a Himalayan mountain road, the Nepali television said today.

title: Endless Trails in Western Canada
description: TO understand how much mountain there is to ski at Whistler Resort in British Columbia, imagine taking a chairlift from the floor of Manhattan to a point nearly four times the height of the World Trade Center. From the apex of one of Whistler Resort's twin peaks, about a mile above the base, a skier can glide for days and never cover the same run twice.

title: The Wrong Cavaty
description: To the Editor:

title: Questions on Closing A Dental School
description: The recent article on the closing of the Fairleigh S. Dickinson Jr. College of Dental Medicine raises some fundamental questions about the responsibility of a state for encouraging and maintaining private institutions for the benefit of its residents.

title: Lifestyle: Sunday Outing;   Strolling Around the Yale Campus
description: Perhaps it is because its sand-colored stone buildings so tidily fit the popular notion of the ideal campus that Yale University in New Haven seems so familiar, even to the first-time visitor. Or perhaps it is because of the pervasive influence of the school that gave the world ''Doonesbury,'' William F. Buckley Jr., ''Love Story'' and President Bush.

title: Ms. Dinneen Wed On Long Island
description: At the Armenian Orthodox Church of the Holy Martyrs in Bayside, Queens, Jane Dinneen, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. W. James Dinneen of Port Washington, L.I., was married yesterday to Gregory Derian, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Albert Derian, also of Port Washington. The Rev. Asoghik Kelejian performed the ceremony, assisted by the Rev. John Gordon, a Roman Catholic priest and a cousin of the bride.

title: TRAVEL ADVISORY
description: U.S. Warnings On Visiting 4 Countries

title: Tourist Trade Needs Visitors' Tax
description: ''Tourist Trade Seeks to Sustain Growth'' (Dec. 31) identifies our potential as well as our problems. Both of these circumstances can be addressed by the enactment of a visitors' tax. Suffolk and Nassau Counties will compete more effectively with the dozens of other tourist destinations that advertise their activities through a levy on visitors.

title: Social Events
description: Harlem Celebration

title: Czechs Don't Regard Benes as a Hero
description: To the Editor:

title: Donations for the Needy Come From Faraway
description: Proceeds from The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund drive are used to help people in the city's five boroughs, but there are no limits to how far from New York the donations may come.

title: Japanese Face Turning Point in Vote Next Month
description: One of the most politically turbulent periods in Japan's postwar era is expected to reach a turning point next month with national elections that will test the resilience of the long-entrenched economic and political establishment.

title: Gulotta Takes A Hard Look At Rising Taxes
description: LEAD: THE proposal by Nassau County Executive Thomas S. Gulotta for a two-year moratorium on additional tax assessments for homeowners who make home improvements has far to go before it is enacted.

title: Ruth V. Washington, Envoy, 67; Was About to Leave for Gambia
description: Ruth V. Washington, the Ambassador to Gambia and a retired United States Magistrate, died after an automobile collision early yesterday near her home in the Hartsdale section of Greenburgh, N.Y. She was 67 years old.

title: 3d Time's the Charm for Shoemaker
description: Bill Shoemaker, in his farewell ride to Florida racing, slipped Beau Genius through an opening in the final yards to score a dramatic and sentimental victory today in the $65,500 Hallandale Handicap at Gulfstream Park.

title: EL SALVADOR'S ARMY
description: It should be noted that El Salvador's military apparatus is in place not against any outside threat; there is none. It is in place against its own people - to police them (''El Salvador's Army: A Force Unto Itself,'' by Joel Millman, Dec. 10).

title: New Albums Lead Rap Down Different Roads
description: Though rap is often seen as a monolithic force, in reality it's a genre jam-packed with contentious styles and ideologies. Two terrific new albums - from the historyoriented Jungle Brothers and the commercially minded Young M. C. - show how different rap's subcultures can be.

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: Is Irony Affirmative Action?

title: Review/Opera;   'Dutchman': Robert Hale In Met Debut
description: August Everding's thoughtful if clumsily designed and executed new production of Wagner's ''Fliegende Hollander'' appeared Wednesday night at the Metropolitan Opera with entirely different singers from the ones who performed at the Dec. 11 opening. The new cast was consistently superior to the old one.

title: AEROPICTORIAL LUNCH
description: LEAD:

title: TALKING: Sponsors;   Strategies If They're In Arrears
description: THE rash of news about the failure of some sponsors to meet their financial obligations to New York City co-ops raises the question of what tenant-shareholders and board members can do to recoup lost income and safeguard the financial integrity of their buildings.

title: Austerity Is No-Show Amid Antiques
description: The new Age of Austerity may have begun, but the back-to-back preview parties for the Winter Antiques Show were pretty grand. The show is still the premier event for antiques collectors and connoisseurs as well as interior decorators and their clients.

title: Linda Fessler Engaged To Michael Weinstein
description: Mr. and Mrs. Harvey Fessler of Merrick, L.I., have announced August wedding plans for their daughter, Linda Beth Fessler, and Michael Jeffrey Weinstein, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald Weinstein of Jericho, L.I.

title: Lifestyle: Sunday Menu;   A Warm Salad With Chicken on the Grill
description: The recipe direction to grill does not have much meaning in January for most of us, unless the kitchen comes equipped with a charcoal grill. But last year I was introduced to an indoor alternative that takes up less room than a frying pan and fits neatly on the top of a burner.

title: Deliberately Unheroic
description: To the Editor:

title: A Latin American Perspective
description: AN exhibition of Latin American art is not the rarity it was, even a decade ago. Only last year, a major peak was scaled when the Bronx Museum of the Arts mounted its ''Latin American Spirit: Art and Artists in the United States, 1920-1970,'' which is now visiting the Vero Beach Center for the Arts in Florida. But there is still room for improvement.

title: Cole Porter Series
description: Five programs devoted to the music of Cole Porter will be featured in this year's Lyrics and Lyricists series, to begin on Jan. 28 and 29 at the 92d Street Y, at Lexington Avenue. A different aspect of the songwriter's music will be discussed at each session. Subscriptions to the Monday programs are $130 to $110, and tickets for single sessions are $27.50 to $22.50 (students and the elderly may buy half-price tickets on the day of the session). Information: 996-1100.

title: Soviet Dissidents Join In Big Strategy Session
description: In the most open challenge thus far to the Soviet Communist Party's hold on power, dissidents from 78 cities and more than 100 political organizations gathered in Moscow to debate how to create a viable political opposition.

title: Pastimes;   Bridge
description: The turmoil in Eastern Europe serves as a reminder that the Czarist regime produced remarkable talent at the bridge table as well as the chess board. Half a century ago London was full of bridge luminaries who were born on the fringes of the Russian Empire or in areas that have since been behind the Iron Curtain.

title: Review/Jazz;   Louis Hayes And Drums, Plus Four
description: The drummer Louis Hayes is leading hard-bop blowing sessions -earthy and eccentric tunes, plenty of time for soloists - through Sunday at the Village Vanguard, 178 Seventh Avenue South. His trim, brisk drumming, with its careful cymbal accents, supports a quintet that features two experienced players with too little New York exposure, the trumpeter Charles Tolliver and the saxophonist Gary Bartz.

title: A Hint of Progress On Yonkers Plan
description: KAREN HILL has been struggling for more than a year here to find developers who will accept financial and zoning incentives in return for building the subsidized and market-rate housing called for in a 1986 Federal desegregation court order. Now Ms. Hill, the director of the Yonkers Fair Housing Office, has given the first indication that a long stalemate may be ending.

title: Notre Dame Gets a Nod
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST: Soviet Union;   In Moscow, Heated Cry for an Opposition
description: Freely debating how to create a viable political opposition, political insurgents from across the country met today in a gathering that presented the most open challenge thus far to the Communist Party's dominance over Soviet public life.

title: 250 Protest I-95 Plan for Mamaroneck
description: THE most dangerous curve in the village of Mamaroneck is a serpentine monster on Mamaroneck Avenue that has claimed two lives and caused 22 accidents in the last five years. But this stretch of road could be carrying up to 200 more vehicles an hour under a plan by the New York State Thruway Authority to alleviate the danger at a nearby interchange on Interstate 95.

title: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST: Albania;   U.S. Group Accuses the Albanians of Crushing Basic Freedoms
description: An American human rights organization has accused the Communist Government in Albania of suppressing freedom of religion, expression and movement.

title: Jean M. Hanavan Wed in Delaware
description: Jean Marie Hanavan and Christopher John Kelly were married yesterday in the Roman Catholic Church of St. Joseph-on-the-Brandywine in Greenville, Del., by Msgr. Francis J. Evans. The bride is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Taylor W. Hanavan of Wilmington, Del., and Northfield, Mass. The bridegroom is a son of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph A. Kelly of Schenectady, N.Y.

title: Crown a Bit Shaky
description: If Sugar Ray Leonard is really determined to give up his World Boxing Council supermiddleweight title, he has a fight on his hands, against the W.B.C. president, Jose Sulaiman.

title: Selling a Business? Mum's the Word
description: SO, you want to sell your business. How do you go about it? Very carefully and quietly, caution the experts.

title: WHY PLANE TRAVEL ISN'T ALWAYS FAST
description: USAir Flight 188 from Washington to Cleveland had a perfect record in November. It was never on time.

title: Report Warns of Pollution in Eastern Europe
description: While efforts to restore clean air to the United States have met with partial success, there is a far greater ecological disaster brewing in Eastern Europe, a report on worldwide air pollution said today.

title:
Pastimes: Gardening;

Scanning The Catalogues For New Seed Introductions
description: LEAD: Every year, new vegetables, herbs, flowers, bulbs, shrubs and trees are introduced in mail-order catalogues. Many novel varieties originated in this country, others hail from Europe, India and Japan. Their descriptions sometimes are ''the best ever'' or ''a stunning horticultural achievement'' making the choices pure agony.

title: SNET to Test 6 Options: No Plan for Caller ID
description: The Southern New England Telephone Company will test six new services in three Connecticut communities, but will not any time soon introduce the caller identification system, which allows people to see before they answer the number of the telephone from which the call was made, a spokesman said last week.

title: Fees for Disposing Of Medical Waste
description: In response to the recent article ''Medical Waste Law Survives a Challenge'':

title: New Police Chief Facing a Familiar Task of Building Bridges
description: When Lee P. Brown walks into the red-brick Police Headquarters building tomorrow morning to be sworn in as New York City's 36th police commissioner, he will be taking charge of an embattled department struggling against an explosion of violent crime with a shrinking force.

title: LONG AND MIRACULOUS AWARD FOR SCOOTER
description: When Phil Rizzuto was told to dust off his tuxedo in order to be properly attired while receiving the William J. Slocum Award for long and meritorious service to baseball at the New York baseball writers' dinner tonight, he sounded confused.

title: Question Of the Week;   Was the Bet By Jackson And Barkley Improper?
description: Rather than discussing what the next bet should be, Barkley and Jackson should concentrate on the game and ways to help their teams win. A coach with any respect for his team would have benched and/or suspended the player for several weeks, unless, the word team really does have an ''I'' in it.

title: If Cuomo Has Fiscal Problems, Republicans Can Put Them to Use
description: ANYONE forgetting that this is an election year had only to read the press releases spewing from the offices of Republican legislators after Gov. Mario M. Cuomo proposed deferring the New York income tax cut last week. The Republicans, who signaled long ago that they were eager to exploit the tax issue, seemed engaged in a contest to construct the least complimentary metaphor about the Governor.

title: Karen E. Winston To Marry in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Jan M. Winston of Westport, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter Karen Eve Winston to David Charles Norman, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Alex Norman of New Rochelle, N.Y. The couple plan to marry in June.

title: Pastimes;   Around the Garden
description: For This Week: Indoors, start seed of long season annuals such as snapdragons, impatiens, petunias and geraniums. Check house plants for mealybugs; examine jade plants, look under leaves of streptocarpus, African violets and other gesneriads, also check cactuses to be sure insects are not hiding near the bases of the spines.

title:
IN THE REGION: Westchester and Connecticut;

Regulatory Maze Frustrating Builders
description: LEAD: DEVELOPERS and others in the real estate industry say a maze of municipal regulations and public sentiment against development are making it difficult to build in Westchester County and thus driving up costs.

title: Raise 'User Fees' on Alcohol To Reduce Drinking-Related Problems
description: To the Editor:

title: A 'Salesman' as Powerful as Ever
description: ONE of the classics of the American stage is Arthur Miller's ''Death of a Salesman.'' As the current revival at Theater Three in Port Jefferson proves, the Pulitzer Prize-winning ''Death of a Salesman'' is as powerful today as it was when it made its debut 40 years ago.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''There were growing calls for a seizure of power by force.''

title: IN THE GRIP OF THE NAZI PAST
description: 20TH CENTURY JOURNEY

title:
WESTCHESTER Q&A;: HENRY G. MILLER;

A Watchdog on the World of Politics
description: LEAD: IN the aftermath of the Koch administration scandals in New York City more than two years ago, the State Legislature adopted ethics legislation affecting the larger local governments, including counties. A key provision of that law requires all public officials with decision-making power - whether they are elected or appointed - as well as political party leaders to file a detailed financial-disclosure statement by

title: First Target for Congress: The Sewer
description: When Congress reconvenes this week, it will have no more important task than to clean up financing of its election campaigns. Chastened by scandal, House and Senate leaders say they will act, and powerful remedies are available: tight limits on contributions and spending and public funding in place of special-interest millions.

title: Nina Purviance to Wed Andrew West
description: Mr. and Mrs. James A. Purviance of Middletown, R.I., have made known the engagement of their daughter Anna Harris Purviance to Andrew Phelps West, a son of Patricia S. Bradshaw of New York and the late Davenport West Jr. A June wedding is planned.

title: Taking a Timeout At a Truck Stop
description: WHERE you stop on the road can make a big difference to the journey. I've long since sworn off McDonald's, Burger King, Roy Rogers, Red Robin and all the other dispiriting chains, with bored high-school dropouts on minimum wages staring at you blankly as you ask for something that isn't listed among the plastic letters of the ''menu board.'' If you drive a lot, an alternative is a must.

title: No First Names For Me, Please
description: I HANG UP the phone if the call comes from some affable but unknown salesman who calls me Bill. Call me a curmudgeon, but it turns me off if I don't hear Mister. I mister everybody if I don't know them.

title: Teachers Have No Chance To Give Their Best
description: NO one in the advanced 10th-grade English class has the foggiest notion who King Kong is. The last book read, they seriocomically inform me, was the one I assigned as a book report.

title: ALL ABOUT/DISK DRIVES
description: Naming this area Silicon Valley, some say, was a mistake. It should be called Ferrite Valley, after the magnetic materials used in disk drives even before the emergence of silicon-based semiconductors. Dozens of disk-drive start-ups blossomed, much like the semiconductor companies, in the area of San Jose. And like semiconductor makers, disk-drive companies have faced relentless pressure to lower costs and improve performance.

title: Office Sublets
description: To the Editor:

title: For the Best to Excel, Students Should Be Grouped by Ability
description: To the Editor:

title: More Exotic Ways to Prepare Fish
description: NOW that fish is no longer something that makes a grudging appearance at the table once a week, ways of serving it are becoming increasingly exotic. For people keeping an eye on their salt and fat intake, a touch of spice can make all the difference.

title:
GARDENING;

Laying Out a Plan for the Landscape
description: LEAD: Though we are barely a third of the way through winter, the stack of seed and nursery catalogues has already grown so tall that it has to be divided into two piles to keep it from falling over. Each year these earliest harbingers of spring begin to arrive before the Christmas decorations have been put away, as a reminder it is time to get plans of spring planting under way.

title: In Winter, the Beach Beckons
description: MY husband and I find ourselves gravitating more to Jones Beach in the off seasons. In the middle of winter, bundled for the wind and the cold, we'll park at Field 6 and walk very briskly to the Central Mall about 15 minutes away.

title: INSIDE
description: Murdoch's Hungarian Move

title: L. D. Chafee Wed To Miss Danforth In Rhode Island
description: Stephanie Birney Danforth, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Murray S. Danforth of Providence and Exeter, R.I., was married yesterday to Lincoln Davenport Chafee, a son of Senator and Mrs. John H. Chafee of McLean, Va., and Warwick, R.I. The ceremony was performed by the Rev. Daniel Warren, an Episcopal priest, at the Exeter home of the bride's parents.

title: Question Of the Week;   Was the Bet By Jackson And Barkley Improper?
description: Absolutely not. As a matter of fact, it made both players' games better. How many players, coaches, managers and most of all fans, bet on games off the books, and nothing happens to them? As long as it doesn't get out of hand, and it gets players pumped up, I'm all for it.

title: Top Gun
description: Considering the rocky relations between Houston police officers and their last chief, Elizabeth M. Watson (left) may have taken the comments of the head of a patrolmen's group there as a compliment. ''I can't think of anything bad to say about her,'' he said. If, as expected, she is confirmed, Ms. Watson, a Houston cop for 17 years, will become the first woman to head a large police force, replacing Lee P. Brown, now of New York City, who drew frequent criticism from the Houston police. Even skeptics like Mark R. Clark, the head of the patrolmen's group, thought she would win acceptance. ''Police have their surges of machoism,'' he said. ''But they will fall in line. This is 1990.'' But if the local police seemed grudging, other experts were sanguine. Said Dr. Susan Martin, author of a new study on female police, ''This is like the first woman C.E.O. of a Fortune 500 company.''

title: Sauce for the Gander
description: To the Editor:

title: 'What It Means to Be a Human Being'
description: STUDYING the humanities, an educational and cultural program based on the classics and embellished with the notion of human dignity, is a way for people to understand and come to terms with the complexities of modern society, according to David Danahar, dean of the College of Arts and Sciences at Fairfield University.

title: 31 Artists Take a Decade's Measure
description: WHAT if life had always been measured by the decade? To express it in contemporary terms, 100 years ago the Divisionist 80's were giving way to the Symbolist 90's, nostalgia for the lost Impressionist 70's was doubtless brewing, and the artists may already have known to call themselves Post-Impressionists. But without the media in control, cultural accounts can't be rendered, at least not as they are now, at the end of each decade (if not before).

title: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST: Yugoslavia;   Communists in Belgrade Delay Move to Yield Monopoly on Power
description: Hard-line and liberal Communists clashed today at the opening of a pivotal party congress over how quickly to renounce their 45-year guaranteed monopoly on power, and the hard-liners succeeded in delaying a vote on democratic changes.

title: Jordan Gains Outside View
description: Michael Jordan is on his way to a fourth consecutive National Basketball Association scoring title. The Chicago Bulls' guard has led the league in steals. He has won the slam dunk contest. He has been voted the N.B.A.'s most valuable player and its best defensive player.

title: New & Noteworthy
description: PROFSCAM: Professors and the Demise of Higher Education, by Charles J. Sykes. (St. Martin's, $9.95.) The problem with higher education is not the students or the administrators, the author says, but the professors, who expend less energy teaching undergraduates than they do pursuing grants and tenure. ''Mr. Sykes' vivid and occasionally eloquent expose is sure to provoke howls of indignant rage in the academy,'' Roger Kimball said here last year. ''As a report from the front, 'Profscam' is an incisive and convincing indictment that deserves to be read by anyone concerned about the future of American higher education.''

title: A JAILBIRD'S SCHEME
description: TRUST

title: FLASHBACKS
description: In their never-ending quest for inspiration, designers often rifle through the past. Anything is fair game. Done well, this delving into the archives results in new clothes with familiar, even classic connotations. While these designs may be redolent of nostalgia, they are modern in line. This season, for instance, the French house of Hermes dipped into its horsy heritage to come up with racy 1990's styles. And in New York, Calvin Klein and Norma Kamali appear to have gleaned romantic motivation from the way glamorous movie stars of yesteryear were garbed.-

title: Karen Lee Young to Wed
description: Karen Lee Young and Barry Stewart Dirkin plan to marry in May, the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Robert N. Young of Clifton, N.J., have announced. Mr. Dirkin is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Harry Dirkin of Woodbury, N.J. The future bride, 28 years old, is on the staff of the New Jersey Pinelands Commission in New Lisbon. A graduate of Union College, she received a master's degree in agronomy from Cornell University. Mr. Dirkin, 34, graduated from the University of Wisconsin. He is an associate at Lord, Anderson, Worrel & Barnett, engineers and environmental consultants in Burlington, N.J.

title: The A.N.C. Is Torn Between Generations
description: OVER the years, when whites in South Africa have made their arguments against black rule, the most common contention has been that blacks are not ready for the responsibilities of power. But beginning in the 1950's, these same whites have supported a Government that has banned, imprisoned or driven into exile most of the blacks who would have been most likely to play that role. In the process, the Government removed a group that had pledged to secure a future for whites after racial barriers are removed.

title: PRO BASKETBALL: N.B.A    Friday's Games;   Magic's Running Ends Slide
description: It was a running game, both sides agreed, and Otis Smith was the front-runner in a power drive that ended the Orlando Magic's four-game losing streak.

title: Carolyn J. Nourie To Marry in June
description: The engagement of Carolyn Josephine Nourie to Donald Bernard Aspinall Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Aspinall of Villanova, Pa., has been made known by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Richard F. Nourie of Strafford, Pa. A June wedding is planned.

title: Reissue Series Traces the Early Development of Genius
description: The Verdi scholar Julian Budden, writing in his ''Operas of Verdi'' (Oxford) of the composer's early works, says there is no opera from those pre-''Rigoletto'' years ''which does not show an interesting musical advance in some quarter, even if the work is unsatisfactory as a whole.'' Unfortunately, not many operagoers have had the chance to see most of those early operas on the stage, but back in the 1970's Philips Records issued a cycle of many of them on LP - all conducted by Lamberto Gardelli - that gave a whole generation of opera lovers and record collectors the chance at least to hear many that had never been recorded in their entirety.

title: THE GRANDDADDY OF ALL TAKEOVERS
description: BARBARIANS AT THE GATE

title: Susan Barth Becomes Bride
description: Susan Barth and Martin Ehrlich were married last evening at the Sephardic Temple in Cedarhurst, L.I., by Rabbi Walter S. Wurzburger. Mrs. Ehrlich, 25 years old, is a daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Louis Barth of Freehold, N.J. A graduate of George Washington University, she is an employment representative at Simon & Schuster, publishers in New York. Mr. Ehrlich, 28, is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Ray Ehrlich of Cedarhurst. A graduate of Clark University, he is an an advertising executive at Wells, Rich, Greene in New York.

title: Wall Street;   New Faith in Old Money
description: Old money. America has always been fascinated by family wealth, rooted in some corporate bedrock and carefully handed down from one generation to the next.

title:
GARDENING;

Laying Out a Plan for the Landscape
description: LEAD: Though we are barely a third of the way through winter, the stack of seed and nursery catalogues has already grown so tall that it has to be divided into two piles to keep it from falling over. Each year these earliest harbingers of spring begin to arrive before the Christmas decorations have been put away, as a reminder it is time to get plans of spring planting under way.

title: China Imposes Tighter Curbs on Foreign Reporters
description: China imposed new restrictions on foreign journalists today and banned articles that in the view of the authorities ''distort facts'' or violate ''the public interest.''

title: Making the Home Safer for Children
description: LEAD: HOME is where the accidents are. National statistics show that in 1988, 22,500 people died - including 3,100 children 14 years old and younger - as a result of household accidents.

title: All the Work That Really Goes Into a Dream
description: WHEN I called my daughter Tracey, I laughed as I listened to her answering machine message. ''Hi, this is Tracey,'' it said. ''I'm not in my new condo right now.''

title: Fashion;   A Cashmere Look That's Soft on the Pocketbook
description: Acrylic is still a word that's short on cachet. But reformulated under names like Cashmink, Cashmaire or Cashmore, the fiber is turning up in some of the best places.

title: Cranston Decides to Fight in Effort to Overcome Image in Savings and Loan Failure
description: Declaring himself ''bloodied but unbowed,'' Senator Alan Cranston has abandoned his tactic of lying low in the Lincoln Savings and Loan failure and come out swinging in a fight to save his political life.

title: The Big Bang Survives an Onslaught of New Cosmology
description: IN recent weeks, a cascade of discoveries has thrown into confusion cherished concepts about the evolution of the universe.

title: GOOD AND EVIL ON CANVAS
description: Imagine receiving national acclaim as a painter at the tender age of 22, only to slip into the shadows of a fickle, mostly uncaring art world for the rest of one's long and prolific career. Such has been the discouraging story for Jack Levine, one of the foremost Social Realists of his generation, a satirist whose gritty urban iconography and brassy style have often led to comparisons with Goya and Daumier. The son of poor Lithuanian Jews, born in 1915 in Boston, Mr. Levine came to painting with all the ideological baggage of his times. Schooled on the Expressionism of George Grosz, Max Beckmann and Oscar Kokoschka, on Brecht's ''Threepenny Opera'' and the social themes of the Mexican fresco painters, Mr. Levine is dedicated to painting as storytelling, a medium through which one could dramatize good and evil. His has always been an art with a moral edge, an art peopled with victims and villains: skid row derelicts, pompous socialites, corrupt politicians. All of this Mr. Levine tells us in a refreshingly lucid monograph, JACK LEVINE (Rizzoli, $45). Except for the brief and illuminating introduction by Milton W. Brown, a professor at the City University of New York Graduate Center, who helps place Mr. Levine in some historical context, most of the commentary has been taken from recorded interviews. If at times this informality allows for emotional digressions - for example, when Mr. Levine inveighs against the Abstract Expressionists or the shabby treatment he feels he has received at the hands of the art establishment - it is not his rancor that the reader will remember. Rather, it is his humor, erudition and high ideals - and the raw power of his paintings, nearly 200 of which have been reproduced in this handsome volume.

title: Jury Begins Hearing Gotti Trial in Shooting of Union Leader
description: John Gotti, the nation's reputed top organized-crime boss, went on trial in Manhattan yesterday as a state jury heard sharply conflicting views of the evidence and of Mr. Gotti's character.

title: 46 Island 'Heroes' to Be Honored
description: LEAD: ''I heard the words 'trapped,' 'children, 'fire.' My mind just clicked. I wasn't thinking of the danger at the time.''

title: Volunteer Service Bureau Turns 40
description: LEAD: IN 1950, the Volunteer Service Bureau interviewed and placed its first volunteer. The budget that year was $285, and 25 volunteers found positions by choosing among 12 institutions listed with the bureau.

title: SIXTEEN-THE THIRD TIME AROUND
description: I don't get it. If Isabel Davis was so embarrassed about the possible pregnancy resulting from her one-night stand, why did she describe the experience in The New York Times Magazine?

title: Leader of Church of England Says Terry Waite Is Still Alive
description: The Archbishop of Canterbury, the Most Rev. Robert Runcie, said today he believed that Terry Waite was still alive three years after the Anglican Church envoy disappeared in Lebanon on a mission to free Western hostages.

title:
DINING OUT;

Cuisine With Flavors From Many Places
description: LEAD: AT first glance, Sam's, a six-month-old restaurant in Somerset County opposite the Ortho Biotech building, about a mile south of Somerville Circle on Route 202, gives every appearance of being a steakhouse.

title: Fernandez and DeLeon on Verge of Joining Virtuoso Pitchers
description: If their 1989 performances can be viewed as a prelude, Sid Fernandez and Jose DeLeon could be ready to burst onto the level of virtuoso pitchers this year. A study of 1989 pitching records finds their names dominating various areas. They worked so effectively, in fact, that it would seem that they should have gained more victories.

title: PITT ENDS SLUMP, EDGING PIRATES
description: Pittsburgh, one of the Big East Conference's dominant teams for three years, hadn't won a conference game this season. But Bobby Martin blocked that failure out of his mind before the Panthers' game against Seton Hall today.

title: HOME ENTERTAINMENT/RECORDINGS: AND KEEP IN MIND
description: Here are some notable releases of the last few months. Recordings are available on CD, LP and cassette unless otherwise noted.

title: Prof. Moynihan Wakes the Class With Truth About Taxes
description: DANIEL PATRICK MOYNIHAN, Ph.D., was a professor before he became a Senator. Although his recent proposal to cut Social Security taxes has turned out to be a clever political stroke that has embarrassed President Bush, it was meant mostly as a teaching device. Angry and frustrated that no one seemed to be listening to his economics lessons, the New York Democrat chose a sharp political instrument to make these blunt points about economics:

title: BRITISH TAX PLAN SPURS TORY MUTINY
description: Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's Government survived a Conservative Party mutiny on Thursday night over a plan to replace real-estate taxes levied by local governments with a ''community charge,'' or head tax, on every adult.

title: Capital Mayor's Arrest Seen As 'Catharsis' by Prosecutor
description: Jay B. Stephens, the Federal prosecutor who supervised the sting operation that snared Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. on drug charges, said today he viewed the arrest as a ''catharsis'' that could open the way for a new generation of political leaders in the city committed to combatting drug use.

title: Review/Operetta;   Helen of Troy, With Heavy Metal
description: The Bronx Opera Company, one of New York's many small but inventive troupes, has built its reputation largely on presentations of operatic rarities - works like Nielsen's ''Masquerade,'' Smetana's ''Secret'' and Offenbach's ''Bluebeard.'' But the company also edges toward the standard repertory every now and then, and for the opening production of its 22d season, it offered a lively staging of an Offenbach favorite, ''La Belle Helene.''

title: Lisa Joseph Wed To Daniel Zelson
description: Lisa Beth Joseph and Daniel Mark Zelson were married last evening at the Burden Mansion in New York by Rabbi Herbert Brockman. The bride is the daughter of Carole Young of Westport, Conn., and New York and William K. Joseph of New York. Her husband is the son of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph Zelson of Orange, Conn.

description: East Germany's Communist Party resisted calls from grassroots members to disband, saying today that its continued existence is vital for political stability.

description: Aldo Gucci, the last surviving son of the founder of the elite Italian fashion house that bore his family name, died on Friday in Rome, the company said today. He was 84 years old.

description: TRYING to tie up some loose ends from his last seven years in office, County Executive Andrew P. O'Rourke offered a progress report this month on ocean dumping, the cleanup ofthe Long Island Sound and an emergency 911 telephone system.

description: Shari Ellen Birnbaum, a law student at Harvard University, and David Howard Dreier, a management consultant in Boston, plan to marry in August. Mr. and Mrs. Ira M. Birnbaum of Wesley Hills, N.Y., have made known their daughter's engagement. Mr. Dreier is the son of Judge and Mrs. William A. Dreier of Warren, N.J.

title: Cold, in the Winter Years
description: The golden years. Senior citizenship. These aren't necessarily euphemisms for age and infirmity. Many Americans age gracefully, in good health, with sound finances and close to children and grandchildren. A half-century of advances in medicine and Social Security has made retirement something to look forward to. For many. For many others, the winter of life is not warmed by any such golden glow. What they are closest to is pain, poverty, loneliness and despair. They may lack a permanent home or -look at the streets - any home at all. That is why The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund pays special attention to older adults. The fund tries to bring warmth and comfort to shivering bodies and desolate minds. It helps many to retain their independence and to avoid institutionalization. For instance, many can remain in their own homes if given assistance, like regular visits by trained and caring aides who can help them shop and cook and provide occasional companionship.

title: FICTION
description: BALANCING ACTS: Contemporary Stories by Russian Women. Edited by Helena Goscilo. (Indiana University, Cloth, $39.95; Paper, $17.50). What do Russian women want? Everything, apparently, that many other women do: the stable love of a good man and the mad passion of a lover, the security of home and hearth and the fulfillment of professional achievement, the gratitude of their children and freedom from the noose of motherhood. Yet having it all isn't possible, in the Russian view. In ''Balancing Acts,'' 14 modern Russian women look at the contradictions facing them in Soviet society and come up with some poignant portrayals of life's sober realities. In most of these stories, life is a battle between clashing desires on the professional and private fronts, between secret hopes and daily exigencies. The embittered heroine of ''The Wall,'' by Galina Shcherbakova, has risen high on the job, but lives with her husband in mutual loathing. The childless, fading leading lady of Maya Ganina's ''Stage Actress'' sheds her latest lover and wonders what she has lived for. Anna Mass examines both sides of the personal/professional coin: the heroine of one story puts her work first and alienates her young son; in another, a 32-year-old geologist learns she is pregnant and joyfully plans to give up her career. The strongest of the stories capture the universal in the individual, and some of them are about men: ''Peters,'' by the brilliant Tatyana Tolstaya, analyzes, for example, the bittersweet existence of a born outsider. Cleanly translated by a variety of American specialists in Russian literature, this sampling of some of the best writing in today's Soviet Union provides a revelatory glimpse of life ''over there'' and asserts once again the simple truth that in the end, in the things that count, we are all alike.

title: POSTING: Calculated Optimism;   More Offices For Stamford
description: Why would a real estate development company invest $40 million to put up a pair of towers containing 325,000 square feet of office space in a city that already has 3.6 million square feet of vacant office space? Three reasons, said Larry Feldman, a partner in Feldman Equities of Lake Success, L.I., which developed the just-completed Stamford Towers project in the business district of Stamford, Conn., where about 25 percent of the office space is unoccupied.

title: Review/Music;   New Leads In 'Porgy' At the Met
description: When all goes smoothly, the Metropolitan Opera's uncut version of ''Porgy and Bess'' runs to a Wagnerian length of nearly four hours. All did not go smoothly at the Thursday evening performance: a stage elevator malfunctioned between the Kittiwah Island and Catfish Row scenes in the second act, forestalling Bess's return to Porgy after a tropical dalliance with Crown by about 15 minutes.

title: Chicago
description: To the Editor: William E. Schmidt's article (''On the Lam in Chicago,'' Travel, Nov. 19) on gang landmarks has some notable omissions. Both the city map and itinerary of the Untouchable Tours ignore Al Capone's adjoining West Side suburban Cicero headquarters, the hotel-restaurant on the south side of Cermak Road (22d Street) just west of Cicero Avenue, where the most awesome machine-gun shelling in gangland history took place when Bugs Moran led a motorcade attack, which Capone miraculously escaped.

title: THE VIEW FROM: THE 20TH CONGRESSIONAL DISTRICT Lowey Says No Matter Where She Goes, Issues Are the Same
description: LEAD: THE room was drafty, the lighting harsh, but Representative Nita M. Lowey of the 20th Congressional District didn't seem to notice as she stood in front of a group of her constituents at the Community Center here. It was one of a series of town meetings she has been holding to talk about the things that have mattered to her since she took office just more than a year ago.

title: Tourism Trade Needs Visitors' Tax
description: Whenever an article about the tourism industry on Long Island appears, I read it with concern for the inaccuracies it might contain. There seem to be more spokespersons for our tourism industry than I care to count. Many consider themselves experts and the quotes of these persons are usually accepted as fact.

title: A Mayor's Word On Hispanic Issue
description: I am writing this letter with great concern over some of the statements made concerning my actions by a professional social worker by the name of Rosa M. Calderon. In an article concerning the Mount Kisco Hispanic community [''Tensions Rise Over Illegal Hispanic Immigrants,'' Dec. 24] , Ms. Calderon made some inflammatory remarks concerning me.

title: Five Jerusalem Museums
description: JERUSALEM straddles its hills and cascades into its valleys, sitting upon layer after layer of history. Often, literally, scoops of earth are dug up and yet another archeological find is discovered.

title: Auto Rental
description: To the Editor: A warning to your readers: Despite all the mental gymnastics you go through to anticipate that the price that car rental agencies quote you will be the price ultimately charged, you cannot anticipate everything.

description: The former British police official who tried to investigate charges of a ''shoot to kill'' policy among the anti-terrorist police in Northern Ireland says he has a document that shows that senior British civil servants were involved in removing him from the inquiry in 1986.

There was Clint Eastwood's ''Heartbreak Ridge,'' which exalts the United States' invasion of Grenada. We've also had the phenomenally successful ''Top Gun,'' in which Tom Cruise comes very close to starting World War III.

Mr. Oundjian is the first violinist of the Tokyo String Quartet, and he and Ms. Vered have substantial careers as soloists.

description: TELLING anyone, especially one's son, that you don't really want his wonderful, thoughtful gift is enough to make mental anguish sound like a vacation.

title: SOME KEEPSAKES
description: They are ideas whose time has come. Notions that once seemed far-fetched or just fanciful, they've found a lasting place in the fashion lexicon. Some, like the lean six-button suit, the unmatched vest or the raucously patterned, bottle-shaped tie, have been around before. Wardrobe staples of earlier decades, they've emerged in new contexts as classics for the 1990's. Other now-classic looks once stood at fashion's vanguard. Here to stay, for the foreseeable future at least, are mock turtleneck T-shirts, bold-shouldered jackets and unpadded sport coats with a sweatery feel. Partnerships that would have seemed jarring or even unthinkable only a decade ago are suddenly respectable. Hooded sweatshirts now combine with prep-school blazers; sturdy parkas top off suits. Like the sweatshirt, favored by Manhattan bicycle messengers, a few of these fashions have worked their way up from the streets. Others, once strictly reserved for the woods or high seas, the locker room or the basketball court, are turning up increasingly in urban settings. It's a rare man these days who hasn't tossed an oilcloth slicker over a business suit, toted his files in a backpack, dressed up a denim workshirt with a tie or hiked to the office in sneakers.These days, stiff dress codes seem dated, and style is defined by the way clothes are mixed. ''As the decade progresses,'' predicts Wilkes Bashford, the forward-thinking San Francisco merchant, ''men will consider dressing less of a science and more of an art.'' -

title: Police Pension Fund Will Invest in Loans Guaranteed by U.S.
description: For the first time, a New York City employees' pension fund will invest in federally guaranteed bank loans as part of a city effort to promote greater economic growth by making more loan funds available for small businesses.

title: THE VIETNAM WAR RICOCHETS INTO THE GALLERIES
description: In many ways the war in Vietnam was the most relentlessy visual war America has known. While it was going on, it was brught home to countless television sets by the newly available portable TV cameras. Since its close, and especially since the release of ''Apocalypse Now'' in 1979, it has been a regular presence in America movies, where it has been variously dramatized, scrutinized, criticized or, in cases like the Rambo series, wildly romanticized.

With share prices weakening last week as interest rates rose and housing starts hit a six-year low, the most depressing news at the New York Stock Exchange may have been the year's first sale of a seat in that august body. The price: $390,000, the lowest tab since 1985.

title: THE BOUNTY HUNTER
description: RECENTLY, A DEAR fried came to visit from Seattle. I met her at the baggage Carousel where she stood surrounded by luggage and one crisp, square box. The label read ''perishable,'' and I knew instantly what was inside. That box contained a wealth of brilliant, fresh seafood. My friend confirmed my suspicions with a smile as wide as Broadway: ''I wanted to bring you a present, and I thought this would please you the most.''

title: Where Italians Speak Ladin
description: THE sign on a fir tree near a cascading stream shows an empty food can, crossed out in black, under the words ''Tenion net l Bosch.'' Underneath, in smaller letters, are translations into Italian and German: ''Keep the forest clean!'' The ecological message on top is in Ladin, an ancient language still spoken by some 17,000 inhabitants of two valleys in the autonomous Italian Alpine province of Alto Adige or South Tyrol.

title: The Great British Breakfast

It may not be a meal to be savored for its culinary delights, but it can be a feast for the eyes and ears at some of London's decidedly atmospheric morning eateries.

''We didn't have the money to buy exactly the house we wanted,'' said Mr. Krolikowski, a music teacher, whose wife is an accounts manager for a packaging company. ''But at the same time, we were earning too much to qualify for one of the town's affordable housing programs.

title: HIS BUS CAME IN
description: STORIES FROM THE STREETS ARE RICH WITH THE improbable. Here, for instance, crossing Columbus Avenue and coming into view, is a man with a preposterous past. When fortune attended, he ran a union; when it was wanting, he cracked safes. At 35, he declared himself an actor. Up to that point, he had emoted anonymously - into a microphone announcing bus routes. Now he's a veteran of Broadway and Hollywood, this year perhaps a candidate for an Academy Award. He grew up poor with his father absent. Not long ago at a black-tie dinner in his honor, he wore a $3,000 tuxedo and gave a speech about love - ''the wind beneath my wings,'' he called his wife and his mother. Such stories are legend in New York, ben trovato. This one likely is true.

One contractor told me to put plastic on the ground to prevent moisture from rising, another said I should install a fan to circulate the air. Still another suggested a heater. What would you advise?
