title: NONFICTION
description: P. T. BARNUM: The Legend and the Man. By A. H. Saxon. (Columbia University, $32.95.) Ah, yezz. P. T. Barnum - Phineas Taylor, by name. Connecticut boy, born and bred; staunch believer in ''a cheerful Christianity.'' Smart fellow, and clever, too. Had a wicked sense of humor for practical jokes - those Yankees weren't all glum and gloomy. Has been described as con artist, charlatan, hypocrite. Insisted he always gave value for money paid, despite being the self-described ''Prince of Humbugs.'' Supposedly said ''There's a sucker born every minute,'' but did he? (According to A. H. Saxon, definitely not.) Big museum man in New York before he went into circus work. Made a lot of money and set the standard for natural history museums since. Liked to let people know about his achievements; would have been a gold mine for a good public relations man. Also had side ventures in Philadelphia, Baltimore and Boston. First traveling show, in 1871, was ''P. T. Barnum's Museum, Menagerie, and Circus''; great title. Understood the power of promotion and was brilliant at it. ''Advertising,'' he said, ''is like learning -a little is a dangerous thing.'' Fascinating, complex character. ''P. T. Barnum: The Legend and the Man'' should have been a riveting book. Doubt that P. T. would have written it like Mr. Saxon, the editor of ''Selected Letters of P. T. Barnum''; reads like a dissertation: very scholarly, but without much soul. Pity.

title: Adrienne Knoll to Marry
description: Adrienne M. Knoll, a speech writer for Borough President Howard Golden of Brooklyn, and Kenneth Brown, a Brooklyn newspaper editor and publisher, plan to marry in the fall. Ms. Knoll, 29 years old, is a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Philip Knoll of Coral Springs, Fla., and a graduate of Brown University. Mr. Brown, 36, is a son of Mr. and Mrs. Murray Brown of Eugene, Ore., and a graduate of City College. He is the editor in chief of Courier-Life Publications and the publisher of Flatbush Life and other weekly papers in Brooklyn.

title: Hugh C. M. Ross Is Dead at 91; Conductor of Schola Cantorum
description: Dr. Hugh C. M. Ross, a choral director who, as conductor of the Schola Cantorum of New York, worked with some of the greatest figures in 20th-Century music, died of a heart attack at his home in Manhattan yesterday. He was 91 years old.

title: 1790 Broadway
description: To the Editor:

title: Persian Folk Music
description: Reza Derakhshani, who plays tar and sehtar, two varieties of Iranian lute, will perform Persian folk music at the Uris Auditorium of the Metropolitan Museum of Art this afternoon at 2:30. Mr. Derakhshani's ensemble includes players of the tar, santur (a hammered dulcimer), kamancheh (a fiddle) and daff (a drum). Tickets: $10. Information: (212) 206-1050.

title: Sad Vigil for Ramos Family
description: In the early hours of the day, while life goes on around them, the parents of Ramon Ramos rise from their bed in an empty hospital room, dress, and walk the short distance to the room where their son sleeps.

title: Gaps Found In Rules on Preventing Oil Spills
description: AS investigations and lawsuits proceed after the Exxon Corporation's oil spill in the Arthur Kill on Jan. 2, officials here and in Washington say that because of deficiencies in Federal and state laws and regulations that govern oil corporations and pipelines, they would be powerless to avert a similar accident.

title: Pastimes;   Coins
description: One disadvantage of owning a camera is that you're out of the picture most of the time. Whenever I look at my family album, I'm struck by the absence of one vital participant - me. But photographers don't have to be missing persons.

title: Lifestyle;   Some People Ski in the Wintertime, But Thousands of Others Go to Class
description: She put up with her job as chief of radiology at the Veterans Administration Hospital in Manhattan for too long. Then she worked hard to make her private practice go. All the while, she took care of the house, her husband and her two children, now in their teens, and had not ''done a thing for this old body for a long time.''

title: World Beat Has Become An Industry
description: Most movements in popular music arise without any clear understanding by participants or observers as to what is going on. At some point, after audiences and styles establish themselves, spontaneity begins to give way to calculation, and self-consciously created modes vie for domination. For example, by the time ''Saturday Night Fever'' played in movie theaters, disco was poised to catch on as a prepackaged way of life. And in 1984, Run-D.M.C. brought a whole new audience to rap by intentionally welding heavy-metal rock to heavy funk beats in its single ''Rock Box.''

title: Pyper Davis and Hartley Rogers to Wed
description: Mr and Mrs. Carlisle Ragland Davis Jr. of Birmingham, Moch., and New York Have announced the engagement of their daughter Elizebeth Pyper Davis to Hartley Raymond Rogers, a son of Prof. Hartley Rogers Jr. and Dr. Adrianne E. Rogers of Winchester, Mass. A june wedding in planned.

title: Casual Route
description: To the Editor: I was very pleased to see Martha White's article (''Taking the Casual Route,'' Travel, Nov. 19), which described some of the lesser-known pleasures of traveling. Over the summer my sister and I decided to take a car trip before returning to our respective colleges. We arranged to take five days off from work, got the car tuned up and took off early on a Sunday morning before our parents knew what we were up to. We had no particular destination in mind, but as long as we had the big book of road maps and a trunk full of (warm) soda and munchies, we were prepared.

title: Residential Resales
description: Closings in the week ended Jan. 6

title: Why Be Surprised At the Budget Crisis?
description: IN the words of New Jersey's Yogi Berra, it's deja vu all over again. A newly elected governor, who had predicted on the campaign trail that he could balance the state budget without a tax increase, is dropping hints that higher taxes might be necessary after all. He says he has discovered new information that was unavailable to him before the election.

title: Once Free-Spirited, Jackson Leads Calmly
description: In preparation for a 14-day trip on the West Coast earlier this season, Coach Phil Jackson of the Chicago Bulls spent an afternoon in a bookstore. He bought a novel for each of his players, ranging from Elmore Leonard's ''Glitz,'' to ''Things Fall Apart,'' by Chinua Achebe.

title: 800 Protest Outside Albania U.N. Mission
description: An estimated 800 people demonstrated outside the Albanian Mission to the United Nations yesterday, declaring that the Communist Government there would be the next one to fall in Eastern Europe.

title: Miss Connolly, Administrator, Becomes Bride
description: Elizabeth Ann Connolly and Robert Leon Alexander were married yesterday at the St. Petersburg (Fla.) Yacht Club. The Rev. Ignatius Tuoc, a Roman Catholic priest, and Rabbi Samuel Manuel Silver officiated.

title: Irritants
description: To the Editor:

title: MOST COLLEGIANS ARE TOO YOUNG
description: With the alluring prospect of multimillion-dollar contracts, the question for many college football players is, ''Why not take the money now?'' Underclassmen are being barraged with more information than ever about professional football and the possibility of becoming instant millionaires.

title: Deedee Rodolitz to MarryAlan Ransenberg in March
description: March wedding plans for Diane L. Rodolitz and Alan J. Ransenberg, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Kurt Ransenberg of Skokie, Ill., have been made known by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Allan Rodolitz of Woodmere, L.I.

title: Are We Shielding the Killers of Salvador's Priests?
description: The massacre of six Jesuit priests, their housekeeper and her daughter in El Salvador in November brought to center stage the failure of U.S. assistance to end political killings by the Salvadoran Army. Congress must find out why, after $1 billion in aid and a decade of U.S. training, that army is still killing priests and if the U.S. Government was involved in shielding the murderers of the Jesuits.

title: But How Will It Play in Westchester?
description: LEAD: IF you want to know what's going to be a box-office hit at the movies, grab the horn to the Coast. If you want to know what promises to be a Broadway smash, you might call the Shubert organization. If you want to know what may be socko in Westchester, talk to Thom Wolke.

title: The Plot Thickens for Plotless Dances
description: Drama is dancing its way into choreographic abstractions. A remarkable number of modern dancers are offering works which, because they are plotless, could be termed abstract; at the same time, they appear to concern changing human relationships. Productions of this sort are not entirely new, and they are also devised by ballet choreographers. But they have become especially prevalent in modern dance. The best of them are visually striking, emotionally stirring and intellectually provocative.

title: Campus Life: Buena Vista;   For Study of Race, All-White School Calls on an Actress
description: Black hands met white hands on Thursday as Tommie Stewart, an actress, moved through an auditorium of college students, touching and hugging them before she went onstage.

title: Pastimes;   Chess
description: the others have finished their games early and gone off to the movies, the bridge table or the bar, there you are slaving over a minuscule-advantage end game.

title: Corrections
description: A music review last Sunday about a concert featuring the violinist Yuri Vodovoz misidentified the city where he lives. It is New York City, not Chicago.

title: 2 Army Women Being Investigated For Disobeying Order in Panama
description: The Defense Department said today that it was investigating an incident in which two women in the Army refused an order to drive other soldiers into downtown Panama City early on Dec. 20, the day that United States troops invaded Panama.

title: Suit Contests Hasidic District
description: The New York State School Boards Association filed a lawsuit on Friday challenging a new school district created by the state to accommodate Hasidic children.

title: Style Makers;   Anna Somers Cocks, Magazine Editor
description: The art world is a microcosm of the world, says Anna Somers Cocks. ''It has economics, commercialism, politics, religion, gossip, scandal, all aspects.''

title: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST: Azerbaijan;   SOVIET MILITARY TAKES CONTROL OF BAKU; SCORES OF AZERBAIJANIS KILLED; COUP AVERTED, GORBACHEV SAYS
description: Soviet troops claimed control of the Azerbaijani capital of Baku today and began settling in for a probable long-term occupation after a night of urban conflict that left scores of civilians and several soldiers dead.

title: Report Notes Low Radiation At Millstone 3 Nuclear Plant
description: The Millstone 3 nuclear plant gets high marks for lower-than-average radiation levels, effective daily management, and ''safe and conservative plant operations,'' in a new evaluation by the Federal Nuclear Regulatory Commission.

title: If You're Thinking of Living In: Northport
description: MAIN STREET, in downtown Northport Village on Long Island Sound, is Main Street, U.S.A.: the quintessential American hybrid of versatility, accessibility and old-fashioned neighborliness that is fast becoming extinct.

title: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST: Iran;   Teheran Is Said to Back 'Islamic Zeal' but Not Separatism in Azerbaijan
description: Iran has encouraged Muslims in Soviet Azerbaijan to express their Islamic identity and religious feelings, but has not tried to inflame separatist sentiment there for fear that violence might spill over into the two Azerbaijani provinces of Iran, American experts said today.

title: Art of the State
description: THERE'S A SELFISH SIDE TO THE project, as even Gerry Holzman would admit. ''It's an opportunity to do just about anything that a woodcarver can do,'' he says. But all in all, the creation of the Empire State Carousel must qualify as a labor of love. ''Making a living museum of New York's history and culture,'' is how Holzman describes it. ''That's the altruistic part.''

title:
IN SHORT;

FICTION
description: LEAD:

title: Murdoch Buys Share of 2 Hungarian Tabloids
description: Rupert Murdoch, the Australian-born entrepreneur, announced today that his company had bought 50 percent of two independent Hungarian newspapers, making him the first Westerner to make a significant investment in Eastern Europe's emerging free press.

title: Q and A
description: New Post Office for Ninth

title: Fashion: On the Street;   Spring Teases, Lightening The Shoulder And the Heart
description: It was spring in January last week - almost. Temperatures danced in the 50's and 60's, bringing fashion out from behind the smothering cloaks of winter. Women appeared in layers of sportswear - jackets, sweaters, skirts and blouses, some of it in lightweight winter white. And lightweight seasonless gabardine suits and Chanel tweeds were seen everywhere.

title: Wetlands Protection Brings a Backlog to Projects
description: ASK Hemraj Khona about the United States Army Corps of Engineers and it's likely to start his head throbbing.

title: Making a Name One's Own
description: THE other day I watched my 6-year-old son Eric slowly, painfully print out his full name at the top of a first-grade assignment. It seemed like some important rite of passage, this unquestioning writing of our last name as if it naturally was his own.

title: Haiti Army Declares State of Siege And Reportedly Seizes Opponents
description: The military Government declared a state of siege tonight after the slaying of an army colonel, and the police reportedly arrested several opposition leaders.

title: EL SALVADOR'S ARMY
description: The views expressed in your article on the Salvadoran Army could apply to many, if not all, third-world countries. The history of Central America is a sad one of many military-ruled governments. That is why we need to support the concept of freely elected civilian-controlled governments in all of Central America and the third world.

title: Johnson Loses Marks
description: He may be the fastest sprinter the world has ever seen, but Ben Johnson is no longer a world-record holder. Citing Johnson's admitted use of steroids over most of the last decade, track and field's international governing body voted yesterday to strip the 28-year-old Canadian runner of his three remaining records, in the 100-meter dash and the indoor 50- and 60-meter events.

title: Nicholls Finally A Ranger
description: Neil Smith, the general manager of the Rangers, who took over the team preaching patience and frowning on the rampant trading that was the trademark of the previous regime, yesterday completed a blockbuster deal the equal of any Phil Esposito ever concocted.

title: NONFICTION
description: FAMILY. By Susan Hill. (Viking, $18.95.) At the center of this absorbing story of an English mother's struggle to have a second child is a baby named Imogen. Born prematurely at 25 weeks in Oxford, Imogen lived for five weeks. She was tiny: she weighed one and a half pounds, and her entire hand was only as large as the top joint of her mother's thumb. As recorded here by her mother, the novelist Susan Hill, Imogen's was a staccato life of fits and starts: she was infected during delivery and required antibiotics and a blood transfusion; delicate surgery was required to remove an obstruction in the baby's bowels. Yet, like most preemies, Imogen was a conundrum - one day she was thriving, pink and wriggly, grasping her mother's finger; the next day she developed apnea and suddenly stopped breathing. Ms. Hill describes how she remained dauntless, eager to cling to the small chance that her baby would survive. In fact, Ms. Hill's determination is what drives ''Family'': her first pregnancy at the age of 35 was smooth, and her daughter was born healthy and on time. Ms. Hill tells how, attempting to conceive again, she encountered serious hurdles: she miscarried three times before giving birth prematurely to Imogen. A year and a half after Imogen's death, Clemency was born. Ms. Hill's detailed chronicle should inspire those women who have had problems with pregnancies or are starting families at an older age. Most especially, this book offers a telescopic look at one very young and courageous life.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. I own a year-round home in the mountains that has a 3-foot-high crawl space. The floor of the crawl space is bare earth. There are eight vents to keep air circulating, but in the summer condensation accumulates. One contractor told me to put plastic on the ground to prevent moisture from rising, another said I should install a fan to circulate the air. Still another suggested a heater. What would you advise?

title: DEADLY SERIOUS
description: Filmed at the medical intensive care unit of Boston's Beth Israel Hospital over a period of six weeks, Frederick Wiseman's ''Near Death'' looks unblinkingly at patients and their families and doctors facing the end of life. The six-hour black-and-white documentary will be shown on the Public Broadcasting Service this afternoon at 2.

title: Campus Lief: Wellesley;   Shadow Program Aims to Illumine Life After Degree
description: January means winter term and almost no one is on the campus, but more than 150 Wellesley College students are getting some education about life after graduation. The students are participating in the annual Shadow Program, which enables a woman to follow an alumna in the field of her choice for a day in January. Organized by the college's Career Center, the program takes place in seven major cities.

title: Getting a Lift To Untracked Powder
description: JUMP out of the helicopter and sink to your knees in snow. Stay low and move slowly. But the rat-a-tat-tat of the chopper and the pulse of your heartbeat make you want to sprint away. The chopper lifts, glides sideways and hovers over space before gliding down the canyon and out of sight and sound.

title: Wedding in May For Miss Fordyce
description: Mr. and Mrs. Donald M. Fordyce of Darien, Conn., and Fort Lauderdale, Fla., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Elizabeth Ann Fordyce, to Scott Kevin Barrett, a son of Mr. and Mrs. James D. Barrett of Cherry Hill, N.J., and Castleton Corners, Vt. A May wedding is planned.

title:
Campus Life: Minnesota;

'Action Agenda' Outlines Goals And Initiatives
description: LEAD: Citing dire statistics on student dropouts, the University of Minnesota's new president, Dr. Nils Hasselmo, is proposing an ''action agenda'' for reorganizing the undergraduate program at the Minnesota system's five campuses. But the specifics are pending the recommendations of administration-faculty committees that will be meeting throughout the next six months.

title:
ART;

The Computer as the Medium
description: LEAD: COMPUTERS, which caused a great revolution in the 1980's, show signs of having merged with humdrum daily life as the 1990's begin. Strong evidence of this union is seen in ''Crash,'' an exhibition whose title is an acronym for ''Computer Assisted Hardcopy,'' at the Morris Museum in Morristown through Feb.

title: Business Diary: January 14-19
description: COMPANIES

title: Looking Ahead
description: MONDAY: An Office of Technology Assessment advisory committee considers recommendations to revamp the securities and futures industries.

title: A Question of Performance
description: To the Editor:

title: New Field To Conquer
description: He spent a full four years in college, but with three major sports to distract him he didn't get a degree.

title: Two Pianos, Three Hands And One Composer
description: Commissioning a concerto for three hands at two pianos is like designing a three-legged cow. It can be done. But why bother?

title: Bill of Rights? Or Bill of Goods?
description: LEAD: While Philip Morris is touting the Bill of Rights in television and print ads, it may be undermining the privacy rights of every individual who calls its Bill of Rights hot line.

title:
NEW JERSEY Q & A: DR. JAY A. ERLEBACHER;

Putting 'Very Smart' Pacemakers to Work
description: LEAD: TO correct abnormally slow heart rates, cardiologists in New Jersey implant about 4,000 pacemakers every year. Dr. Jay A. Erlebacher, a cardiologist and pacemaker expert, has performed hundreds of implants to help recipients lead virtually normal lives.

title: Dr. Sullivan's Unfiltered Anger
description: ''At a time when our people desperately need the message of health promotion, Uptown's message is more disease, more suffering and more death.'' So said a furious Secretary of Health and Human Services, Dr. Louis Sullivan. Uptown is the name of the menthol cigarette the R. J. Reynolds Tobacco Company had hoped to market. ''Our people'' are African-Americans like Dr. Sullivan - and Uptown's hoped-for consumers.

title: WHY ROCK REMAINS THE ENEMY
description: Those who fret that rock is dead - which usually means that the music they grew up with has been supplanted by something younger folk like - might take comfort in its continued ostracism. On the theory that anything continually attacked must have some life left in it, rock seems very much alive.

title: DATA UPDATE: January 21, 1990
CITY OF COUCHES
description: FREUD'S VIENNA AND OTHER ESSAYS

title: WHAT'S DOING IN: Melbourne
description: Called the garden city of Australia for its tree-lined streets and 2,000 acres of gardens and parklands, Melbourne still has many of the grand Victorian buildings built in the gold rush years of the late 1800's, when it was the port of arrival for thousands of new settlers who came from the United States and Europe in search of their fortunes.

title:
NORTHEAST NOTEBOOK: Pittsburgh;

90's Forecast: Less and More
description: LEAD: WITH an eye on the move-up market, the home construction industry this year will build fewer houses than it did in the 80's, but they will be bigger and more expensive, says Thomas DiOrio, regional marketing manager for Ryan Homes of Pittsburgh, one of the country's largest home builders.

title: POTTERY SHAPED BY A JAPANESE ESTHETIC
description: Vases and bowls surfaced with vibrant splashes of color, asymmetric imagery, frogs in high relief and exotic motifs represent the Japanese style that dominated American ceramics from 1880 to 1930. Various manifestations of this development are presented in ''Fragile Blossoms, Enduring Earth: The Japanese Influence on American Ceramics,'' an exhibition at the American Craft Museum, 40 West 53d Street, through March 25.

title: Incaviglia Signed
description: The Texas Rangers said Pete Incaviglia, their slugging outfielder, had signed a one-year-contract with the club. . . . Bubby Brister, the Pittsburgh Steeler quarterback, had minor surgery Friday to repair a joint at the top of his left shoulder that was injured in an off-season weight-lifting session. (AP)

title: A PRIMARY SCHOOL TESTS FOR DRUGS
description: Some students at a Roman Catholic elementary school have been reporting to a hospital to give urine samples in what may be the nation's first primary-school drug testing program.

title: Installing Crown Molding
description: CROWN molding is installed around the top of a room to conceal the seam between the walls and ceiling. Used tastefully, it can greatly enhance a room's appearance.

title: The New Organized Crime
description: John Gotti, you poor, obsolete loser. You've missed the boat. You forgot Willie Sutton's lesson - go where the money is. Just before Christmas, when I was in New York, I saw on the local news a story about the police in Queens ''busting'' a gambling ''bank.'' A veritable army of police cruisers were outside a pitiful-looking building next to a bakery. Inside, a few equally pitiful-looking men and women in polyester and T-shirts sat on ratty couches while a policeman showed the camera stacks of $20's the gambling bank allegedly had taken in recently.

title: Victoria Hong Weds John McElrone
description: Victoria Misa Hong, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Sung Ho Hong of Neenah, Wis., and John Daniel McElrone, a son of Mr. and Mrs. John Joseph McElrone of Rivervale, N.J., were married yesterday in New York.

title: Lawsuit by Telephone Company Accused of Wiretaps Goes to Jury
description: A jury has begun deliberating a civil case in which two former phone installers for the Cincinnati Bell Telephone Company are accused of defaming the company and two of its managers by charging them with engaging in a vast scheme of illegal wiretapping over more than a decade.

title: Barbara Stanwyck, Actress, Is Dead in California at 82
description: Barbara Stanwyck, the luminous protagonist of such classic movies as ''Stella Dallas,'' ''The Lady Eve'' and ''Double Indemnity'' and the award-winning western television series ''The Big Valley'' in the 1960's, died of congestive heart failure yesterday in a hospital in Santa Monica, Calif. She was 82 years old.

title: Still Engaged - Again
description: This could be the story of the couple who cried ''betrothed!'' In their 12 years of unformalized domesticity, Mick Jagger and Jerry Hall (right) have issued, along with two children, numerous announcements and hints that marriage was imminent. In 1983, Mr. Jagger said they would be married ''any day now.'' Then in 1986, after the birth of their son, reports emanated from the Jagger-Hall camp that Mr. Jagger had simply put off the nuptials until a male heir was born. Four years later, Miss Hall has announced that, ''For the first time, we both think marriage is a good thing.'' It was presumed that she meant marriage to each other. Miss Hall, who was in London to star in a revival of ''Bus Stop,'' declined to name the date. Mr. Jagger was unavailable for comment, but one report quoted a Jagger spokesman as saying, ''There are no marriage plans at the present time.''

IN SHORT;

FICTION
description: LEAD:

title: Don't Fault Phil Simms
description: To the Sports Editor In the midst of the recriminations thrown right and left about the Giants' overtime loss to the Rams, a couple of vital points have not been mentioned in any of the press reports I read. Forget the disputed pass-interference penalty against Sheldon White in overtime. That can be argued from now until doomsday without a resolution.

title: Brazil's Churches, Bold And Baroque
description: LEAD: A VISITOR to Brazil need not seek far beyond the churches that mark every city, town and village to acquire an appreciable insight into the country's history and culture. Among the churches are extravagantly Baroque edifices financed in the 17th century by owners of mines and plantations and designed by Portuguese and Brazilian architects and artists.

title: STREETSCAPES: The Saint Urban;   A New Roof in an Old - but Not the Old - Material
description: AT the moment it is the brightest thing on the Central Park skyline - 6,000 square feet of Day-Glo orange. No, it is not a new Christo wrap sculpture or a high-rise HoJo's; it is the protective tarpaulin around the great roof and tower of the 1906 Saint Urban apartment house at the southwest corner of 89th Street and Central Park West.

title:
THEATER;

Mabou Mines Sets Lear on a Hot Tin Roof
description: LEAD: If a new production of ''King Lear'' seems like no big deal, reconsider for a moment. In the director Lee Breuer's adaptation, a woman plays the title role, not as a man but as a classic mother figure confronting what the director believes is the crucial issue facing women today: can they have love and power at the same time?

title: In Washington, It's the Year for Clean Air
description: UPON its return this week, the Senate will immediately face the moment of truth on strengthening the Clean Air Act, a goal that has eluded Congress for a decade.

title: FICTION
description: VOICES IN THE EVENING. By Natalia Ginzburg. Translated by D. M. Low. (Arcade/Little, Brown, $16.95.) Natalia Ginzburg has been recognized for many decades as a major force in Italian letters, but it is only in recent years that her work has begun to be read and appreciated in the English-speaking world. ''Voices in the Evening,'' a short novel first published in Italy in 1961, is the story of a northern Italian factory town during and after World War II. In its pages, quiet ironies abound, despite an occasionally awkward translation. The local patriarch, old Balotta, is a Socialist who has grown rich as the owner of the local textile mill; Purillo, his adopted son, becomes a Fascist, yet is put in control of the business by Balotta because he ''has a good brain.'' Aside from Purillo, Balotta's children are of two kinds: some leave home for vaguely defined lives in other countries, while others stay near their native village. The novel is principally about these latter souls, suffocated in a society that no longer either sparks or nourishes. Elsa, a local woman who narrates most of the book, is only a gentle background presence, transmitting the minutiae of village gossip. The daughter of the factory's accountant, she eventually falls in love with Tommasino, the youngest of Balotta's children; yet this handsome, rich and intelligent young man finds he is unable to love her in return, or indeed to feel anything at all with genuine passion. ''Those others before me,'' he complains, ''they have already consumed all the reserves, all the vitality that there was for us.'' The war, in this fatalistic context, has a curiously intimate quality, as if the characters found it only one more in a series of domestic agonies.

title: Miss Matheson Weds David Hilliard
description: Helen Dow Matheson, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Tompkins Matheson of The Plains, Va., was married there yesterday to David Shelburne Hilliard, a son of Landon Hilliard of Oyster Bay Cove, L.I., and Mary Eichert Hilliard of New York. The Rev. S. Neale Morgan officiated at Grace Episcopal Church.

description: CAVERNS

title: Dr. Denise Mack Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Joseph G. Mack of Garden City, L.I., have announced July wedding plans for their daughter Dr. Denise Marie Mack and James Stewart Fraser, a son of William T. Fraser of Babylon, L.I., and the late Helen Fraser. The prospective bride, 31 years old, is the chief resident in surgery at Pennsylvania Hospital in Philadelphia. Mr. Fraser, 32, is the president of Hydrodynamic Engineering and Design, a marine consulting and research concern in Arlington, Va.

title: Greece Seeking to Bar Publicity for Terrorists
description: In an effort to combat terrorism in Greece, which has been criticized in the West for inadequate security, a parliamentary committee has introduced a bill that would bar news agencies from publicizing statements by terrorist groups.

title: Style Makers;   Mitchell R. Cutler, Book Dealer
description: Mitchell R. Cutler began selling books many years ago when he was working for an art collector. ''I like doing this and think I could do it, so why not?'' he recalled asking himself.

What would you advise?

title: Hospital Shop Is Not Just Toothpaste
description: LEAD: WHEN the Hospitality Center of the White Plains Hospital Medical Center opened on Jan. 22, 1940, the gift shop was stocked with tooth paste, razor blades and a few other necessities, plus baby booties, caps and sweaters knitted by one volunteer. The coffee shop sold coffee for a nickle and sandwiches for a dime.

There are eight vents to keep air circulating, but in the summer condensation accumulates. One contractor told me to put plastic on the ground to prevent moisture from rising, another said I should install a fan to circulate the air. Still another suggested a heater. title: An Old War Horse Takes On Hospitals
description: LEAD: As Harry Gray tells it, it wasn't his idea to be the chief executive and chairman of American Medical International Inc.

title: Miss Lamb Engaged to Edward Cote Jr.
description: Storrs Heathcote Lamb and Edward Troutman Cote Jr., the son of Mr. and Mrs. Cote of Ligonier, Pa., are engaged, the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Lawton Storrs Lamb of Katonah, N.Y., have announced. The couple plan to marry in May.

title: Andrea I. de Cholnoky To Wed Scott Wilson
description: The engagement of Andrea Ilona de Cholnoky to Scott Curtis Wilson has been announced by the future bride's mother, Ingrid de Cholnoky of Greenwich, Conn. A March wedding is planned.

title: THE LEGAL VIEW OF N.F.L. DRAFT POLICY
description: The National Football League policy against drafting underclassmen imposes unjustifiable injury on college athletes and is therefore legally insupportable. It constitutes a conspiracy by all employers in this industry to bar from gainful employment a group that is ready, willing and able to work.

title: Ending Long Standoff, Pope Plans to Visit Prague
description: The Vatican said today that Pope John Paul II would travel to Prague in the early spring, his first visit to an Eastern-bloc country other than his native Poland.

title: Monet Joy Berger Is Bride
description: Monet Joy Berger, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Berger of Las Vegas, Nev., was married there last evening at Bally's hotel and casino to Daniel Smith Levinson, the son of Linda Levinson and Fred Levinson, both of New York. Rabbi Melvin Hecht officiated. Miss Berger, 20 years old, is a student at the University of California at Los Angeles. Mr. Levinson, 31, is the president of Dan Corps, a film company in Los Angeles and New York.

title: Colleen Cooper and Joseph Reardon 3d to Wed
description: The engagement of Colleen Ann Cooper and Joseph A. Reardon 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Reardon Jr. of Bloomfield, N.J., has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Raymond V. Cooper of Rockaway, N.J. A fall wedding is planned.

title: Lifestyle;   The Lambada, a Torrid New Dance, Is Not for the Bashful or the Demure
description: Eight pairs of professional dancers did slow turns on a shiny black floor at the Palladium nightclub to the thump of tropical music, the right thigh of each man between his partner's legs as their hips swiveled in unison. Astride their partners' right knees, the women occasionally performed deep back bends followed by several fast pirouettes that set their miniskirts flying.

title: Aspen: The Call of the Wild
description: THE SUN FIRST PEEKS OVER the Continental Divide just after 6 on New Year's Day, and particularly at this hour, it seems there could be no more beautiful place on earth than the Roaring Fork Valley - red-tinged clay, bright white snow and a pure blue in the sky that only high altitudes can produce. Below, the narrow streets of Aspen, Colo., are empty, yielding no signs of the previous night's parties. Instead of whoops of frivolity there is only the squawking of jays and nutcrackers.

title: U.N. Council Is Pursuing Its Postwar Mission
description: The five victorious World War II Allies are putting on the peacemaker's mantle that the United Nations gave them more than 40 years ago, a mantle they have had difficulty wearing until recently, specialists on the United Nations say.

title: Question Of the Week;   Was the Bet By Jackson And Barkley Improper?
description: There was not just one bet between Barkley and Jackson. The first came during last season's playoffs. Then there was a series of three during the Jan. 10 game, each coming before critical situations. Betting can become infectious and contagious. The $5,000 fines to players earning megabucks has little impact. Three-game suspensions were more in order.

title: About Cars;   Collectors Are in High Gear
description: During the 70's, I prided myself on spending no more than $600 for a car, and I bought some very nice used automobiles.

title: Increasingly, Bush Seems Right on China
description: LEAD: Like virtually all Americans, and most people in the Western world, I was shocked and outraged as well as saddened by the massacre of several hundred demonstrators in Beijing in early June.

title: Arizona Trips Up Sooners by 78-74
description: Sean Rooks and Jud Buechler scored 18 points each today as Arizona held off Oklahoma, 78-74, extending the nation's longest home-court winning streak to 41 games.

title: March Wedding For Ms. Murphy
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Murphy of Wethersfield, Conn., have made known the engagement of their daughter Marguerite Amelia Murphy to Samuel Baumgarten Solomon, the son of Dr. Jolane Solomon and Bernard Solomon of Brookline, Mass. A March wedding is planned.

title: Jerk, Jamaica's Fiery Barbecue
description: SINCE dawn, Taylor Dudley of Boston Beach, Jamaica, has been at work turning a pig and plenty of hot peppers into jerk, the island's devilishly hot answer to barbecue. At outdoor pits like Mr. Dudley's, roadside stands and restaurants throughout Jamaica, pork, plus chicken, conch and native fish are given the distinctive jerk treatment.

title:
IN SHORT;

NONFICTION
description: LEAD:

title: Teen-Agers and the Trap of Affluence
description: I SIT in the back row of the Seaport deli, that twilight hub of East Setauket, alternately reading a newspaper, picking at a plate of fried seafood and surveying the comings and goings of teen-agers who casually drift in and out.

title: Conservative vs. Conservative
description: To the Editor:

title: Arizona Race in Turmoil As Governor Bows Out
description: Gov. Rose Mofford threw Arizona's 1990 gubernatorial race into confusion with her announcement on Thursday that she would not seek election to the office she inherited less than two years ago.

title: A New Life Beckons Organ Recipients
description: LEAD: NOT long ago, many people whose critical organs were deteriorating faced an uncertain future and a life of diminished quality. Today, organ transplantation is a relatively common procedure for certain ailments and, because of the anti-rejection drug cyclosporin, most transplant recipients now lead full, active postoperative lives.

title: POSTING: 3-Story Living Room;   Halston Town House Sold
description: An East Side town house designed by the architect Paul Rudolph and called ''extremely sophisticated, starkly modern'' by the Landmarks Preservation Commission has been sold for $5 million.

title: New Yorkers, etc.
description: Breathes there anyone who is never in a bad mood? If so, beware - that person is a disguised creature from another planet and definitely not human. Real people, even nice real people, are grumpy sometimes, down in the dumps at least occasionally and mean-mad, mean-tired or plain mean once in a while.

title: Question Of the Week;   Was the Bet By Jackson And Barkley Improper?
description: I think that both players should not only be fined, but also suspended without pay for a couple of games. Pete Rose was suspended for life for betting on baseball, yet Barkley and Jackson get off with only a fine for betting on basketball. Something doesn't seem right.

title: Libraries Continue Season of Poetry
description: THE Poet's Voice, launched its 12th season with the first of six readings in November at the Ferguson Library in Stamford. Five more readings are scheduled to take place at other Fairfield County libraries this year.

title: POSTING: From the McAlpin;   Nautical Tiles, Anyone?
description: A collection of colorful terra cotta wall panels designed by the late muralist Fred Dana Marsh that depict New York City's nautical heritage is looking for a new home. For over 40 years the 24 panels were the backdrop for the 250-seat Marine Grill at the McAlpin Hotel on Herald Square, which opened in 1912 and between World Wars was one of the city's more fashionable restaurants.

title: In the Galleries, a Delayed-Action Explosion
description: Even though American movies have scrutinized the Vietnam War, art about the conflict has been scarce, perhaps because it has taken many years for artists to come to terms with what happened there. But such art exists, and some of it movingly incorporates the contradictions that permeated that era. Roberta Smith appraises some of these works, which are increasingly visible both at the center and the margins of the art world. Page 31.

title: A Battle Over Swans: Beautiful or Beastly?
description: To most people, bird-watchers in particular, the mute swan is a graceful and statuesque creature that adds a storybook presence to ponds and inlets along the Atlantic flyway, especially in New England.

title: Museum Internships
description: A special internship program for those interested in museum careers is to begin in September at the National Gallery of Art in Washington. The two internships in the program, which is underwritten by a grant from the Southwestern Bell Foundation, will be open to black, Hispanic and American Indian applicants. The nine-month positions will offer specialization in such areas as administration, archives, conservation, public relations and installation and design. Information: (202) 842-6258.

title: Jill Akin and J. B. Schulman Are Wed
description: Jill Blair Akin and J. Brett Schulman were married last evening at the Pierre in New York by Rabbi Ronald B. Sobel.

title: A New View Of Pressures
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Question Of the Week;   Was the Bet By Jackson And Barkley Improper?
description: Deafening in their silence are the Knicks and the 76ers. Jackson and Barkley turned their team's efforts into a game of one-on-one. They bet - gambled - put the outcome of the game (perhaps the season?) and the fortunes of their teammates on the line. Yet neither team, nor its management, said or did anything. That is appalling.

title: WORLD WIDE PLAZA: SO NEAR AND YET SO FAR
description: If you believe in the religion of gentrification, the arrival of Cravath, Swaine & Moore on Eighth Avenue last fall is the equivalent of the coming of the Messiah. Did anyone ever think the day would come when Cravath, the white shoe-est of all white-shoe law firms, would abandon the solid precincts of Wall Street not for Rockefeller Center but for Eighth Avenue? Eighth Avenue - the scourge of midtown Manhattan, that tawdry street of pornographic movies and the Port Authority Bus Terminal? Were Cravath's partners so busy last year trying to rescue their client Time Inc. from the clutches of Paramount that they didn't hear the real estate broker correctly, and thought he said Park Avenue?

title:
IN SHORT;

FICTION
description: LEAD:

title: Reviews/Music;   A Clarinetist With Some Good Moves
description: Like a cobra intent on doing some charming of its own, the clarinetist Paul Green weaved, darted and hovered over his instrument at his recital in Merkin Concert Hall on Wednesday evening, conjuring gorgeous sounds. If the gyrations had anything to do with the superb musical results, perhaps other clarinetists should study his choreography.

title: Shooting in Nagasaki Stirs Fears of Speaking Out
description: Nagasaki's Mayor is out of danger now, his suspected assailant is in custody and the sprawling, busy city that the world still pictures in nuclear ruin is back to work.

title: The Making of a Post-Communist Disorder
description: THE Popular Front of Azerbaijan first emerged in the fall of 1988 as an earnest, ineffectual circle of intellectuals, banded together in emulation of the national democracy movements in the Baltic republics. The founders included a poet, a few historians, a linguist, some journalists, a physicist. They drafted slightly self-important declarations, and were treated with official condescension. By the time tanks rumbled into the center of Baku early Saturday morning, they had become the leaders of an urban vigilante force, trying to barricade Baku's streets against the Soviet Army and wailing charges of genocide.

title: QUERY, MR. MAHLER: WHEN DID YOU KNOW IT?
description: There is a mysterious juncture early in the career of important composers when all at once they begin speaking in a voice that is theirs and theirs alone. For Mahler, that time came at age 20 in 1880, when he finished ''Das Klagende Lied,'' a large-scale cantata that he submitted to Vienna's Gesellschaft der Musikfreunde in hopes of winning a prize. The cantata was rejected, but Mahler later called it ''the first work in which I really found myself as a composer . . . I call that work my Opus l.''

title: DYING LIKE AN EXPERT
description: IN THE FACE OF DEATH

title: Q and A
description: Entry to East Germany

title: DINING OUT South, West and Southwest in Port Chester
description: LEAD: >HE Black Sheep certainly has a lot going for it: both upstairs and downstairs dining rooms have an airy, tropical feel suggested by towering, well-tended plants, a soft sculpture of a palm tree and faux Gauguins - open-faced, trusting islanders who smile down their benedictions over the repast. A good sound system belts out easy-to-take popular tapes, candlelight flickers, service is personal.

title: PERSPECTIVES: The Dunbar Apartments;   Switching to the Rental Track in Harlem
description: THE best news for the Dunbar Apartments in Central Harlem may be the city-sponsored rehabilitation activity around it, which gives a lift to the area's rental market and helps secure the Dunbar's future.

title: THE HATED SEASON
description: I read Gordon R. Batcheller's letter concerning his reason for hunting (Letters, Dec. 31, in response to ''The Hated Season,'' by Steven Lewis, About Men, Nov. 26). He says he has given up trying to explain to people why he hunts; nevertheless, he presents us with a half-complete, self-justifying statement about ''what it's like to hear a wild turkey gobble . . . or to feel the thrill of being 15 yards from a white-tailed deer buck.''

title: Captain Kirk Keeps Devils in Orbit
description: Kirk Muller was furious. The Devils were going through a power-play drill at their training center last Thursday, and with the All-Star break imminent and their next game five days away, there was clearly a lack of intensity on the part of some of Muller's teammates.

title: Upheaval in the East;   MOSCOW'S TROOPS CONSOLIDATE HOLD OVER AZERBAIJAN
description: The Soviet Army consolidated its occupation of Baku today as leaders of the Azerbaijan Popular Front made plans to stage a general protest strike throughout the strife-ridden Soviet republic.

title: Sun Leads in Work Stations
description: Sun Microsystems Inc. continues to lead the worldwide market in work stations with a 28.7 percent share, up from 27 percent in 1988, according to a survey by the market research firm Dataquest.

title: BBDO Quits Account
description: BBDO Los Angeles has resigned the account of Coldwell Banker Residential Real Estate, citing difficulty in working with the client. Billings are believed to be about $8 million.

title: 7th Avenue Ponders Unpleasantness
description: Along the coatrack-clogged sidewalks of Seventh Avenue in Manhattan, the garment industry took out its handkerchief and dabbed its sweaty brow and talked last week about Federated Stores Inc., the renamed American retailing operations of the Campeau Corporation.

title: The Word Is Out: Players Are Free
description: ONE of the truly great sweetheart deals in sports has been the long and loving association between real professional football and more-or-less professional football called college football.

title: The British Are Coming, And Winning
description: IN a classic British television commercial of the 1980's, two characters in a cinematic melodrama anguish over their relationship in words that are curiously out-of-synchronization with their lip movements. But when they each quaff a beer, their voices and lips miraculously harmonize.

title: Books of The Times;   Engineering a Perfect Pencil, and Thoreau's Part in It
description: The Pencil: A History of Design and Circumstance

title: Lakers' Defense Stops Pistons
description: The Los Angeles Lakers, playing tough, bone-rattling defense, shed their Hollywood image for Detroit's old ''Bad Boy'' look today as they won, 107-97, snapping a losing streak against the Pistons at seven games.

title: Upheaval in the East: East Germany;   East German Party Purges Ex-Leaders
description: Faced with growing rebellion and defections in its ranks over the slowness of internal change, leaders of East Germany's Communist Party decided after an emergency session that ended early today to purge several more former leaders, but rejected calls that it dissolve altogether.

title: On-the-Air Diary of a Passage Toward Death
description: Once a week here on the evening news, television viewers are making the acquaintance of a man with AIDS, hearing firsthand about his fears and frailties and watching his jaunty passage toward death.

title: Inflation Up in Britain
description: The inflation rate in Britain rose three-tenths of 1 percent in December and was up 7.7 percent for the year, the Government said Friday. The Central Statistical Office attributed the December rise in the retail price index to increases in food prices and housing costs. The rate was better than the 7.8 percent rise that the financial markets had been expecting and was good news for the Government, which has been fighting inflation with 15 percent interest rates.

title: Boom! McEnroe Is Ejected
description: So much for Mr. Nice Guy.

title: For Top Flexibility, Avoid Exercises in Futility
description: FOR the last 10 years, the staff at the Somax Posture and Sports Clinic in Corte Madera, Calif., has been studying the relationship between joint range (flexibility) and the range of motion of the body's joints during sports activity.

title: Pro Bono
description: * Employees of the advertising agency Al Paul Lefton Company spent Saturday restoring the Edgecomb, a homeless shelter in Washington Heights, in northern Manhattan.

title: Metro Matters;   One-Man Show Ending in Blaze At Parks Agency
description: Seabury Place near Crotona Park in the Bronx was named years ago for the nation's first Episcopal bishop. No similar distinction was ever bestowed on his great-great-grandson, Judge Samuel Seabury, whom Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia once hailed as ''the father of good city government.''

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Living Section on Jan. 3 about the Maytag Dairy Farm in Newton, Iowa, misidentified the university that isolated a mold spore used in the manufacture of the farm's blue cheese. It was Iowa State University at Ames, not the University of Iowa at Iowa City.

title: Upheaval in the East: Mongolia;   2,500 Mongolians in Protest Are Undisturbed by the Police
description: At least 2,500 Mongolians defied a ban on demonstrations today by gathering in the Mongolian capital, Ulan Bator, to demand human rights and other concessions from the country's Communist leadership.

title: A Vice Chairman at Ann Taylor
description: Thomas H. K. Brooks, who joined Ann Taylor Inc. in April, has been named a vice chairman of the fashion chain, which is rapidly expanding under his father, Joseph E. Brooks.

title: Bridge
description: A British partnership scored a victory yesterday in one of the strongest events on the tournament calendar. Tony Forrester and Andrew Robson, playing in the Staten Bank World Top tournament in The Hague, overtook two Brazilian world champions in the final stages.

title: Harassment Makes Doctors Fear Abortions
description: To the Editor:

title: One-Shot Victory for Jacobsen
description: Although Peter Jacobsen has been known as many things in his 14 years on the PGA Tour - a gifted ball striker, unerring impressionist, entertaining musician and even actor-in-waiting - it has been a long time since he has been recognized for what he most wants to be: a winner.

title: Unaware of It, O'Connor Says Of Shaking Her Head in Court
description: Justice Sandra Day O'Connor of the Supreme Court sometimes seems to be shaking her head involuntarily from the bench in an up-and-down motion, like someone expressing affirmation.

title: Hatfield to Clemson And Squad Relents
description: Ken Hatfield of Arkansas accepted the head coaching job at Clemson today, and a threatened player boycott was averted after he met with the team.

title: Handbook Tells Scouts to Prepare for 90's
description: The new Boy Scout handbook still tells Scouts to be prepared and how to use a compass, build campfires and tie knots. But it also aims to help them cope with life in the 1990's.

title: Carl Goldmark Jr., 80, Physician at Lenox Hill
description: Dr. Carl Goldmark Jr., an obstetrician and gynecologist and a former president of the New York State Medical Society, died Friday at Lenox Hill Hospital in Manhattan. He was 80 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Chronicle
description: LETITIA BALDRIGE, the arbiter of manners for the 80's, made her first public gaffe of the 90's. Ms. (a form she approves of) Baldrige, the author of several etiquette books and ''New Manners for the 90's,'' is to speak on Wednesday at a luncheon about her favorite subject. Invitations were mailed in late December.

title: Chronicle
description: JOHN E. FROHNMAYER, the new head of the National Endowment for the Arts, spent the weekend in New York getting acquainted. On Saturday he toured the Metropolitan Museum's Canaletto exhibition. Today he speaks at a meeting of chamber music groups.

title: Nicklaus, 50, Still Striving
description: Jack Nicklaus turned 50 years old today with his competitive fires still burning. He said he planned to win events on both the regular PGA Tour and the Senior PGA Tour this year.

title: Group Plans To Tour '94 Sites
description: Just as the next few months will become critically important for the team that will represent the United States in the 1990 World Cup finals in Italy, the time will also be crucial for the organizing committee of the 1994 tournament, which will be staged in the United States.

title: Edward H. Cleary, 82, Lawyer and Professor
description: Edward H. Cleary, a lawyer, professor and authority on legal procedure who helped draft the uniform rules of evidence used in Federal courts, died of congestive heart failure on Friday at Scottsdale (Ariz.) Memorial Hospital. He was 82 years old and lived in Scottsdale.

title: Reporter's Notebook;   An AIDS Courtroom Drama, Permeated by Tragedy
description: A sense of tragedy seems to fill the small Brooklyn courtroom where a jury is hearing the trial of a $175 million lawsuit by Veronica Prego, the doctor who is dying of AIDS.

title: Korea Accepts Du Pont Plant
description: After a four-year delay, South Korea has authorized E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company's application to build a $97 million titanium dioxide plant with a local company, the Finance Ministry said Friday.

title: Experts Doubt Entrapment Plea by Barry
description: Reports by clergymen and friends that Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. has told them he has a drug problem - and his wife's saying that he admitted he needed ''help'' -will make it more difficult for him to use a claim of entrapment as a defense to a misdemeanor charge of cocaine possession, legal experts and Government lawyers said.

title: Why the Fed Is Largely Uncriticized
description: President Bush and his spokesman last week broke his Administration's policy of keeping quiet about the policies of the Federal Reserve.

title: Hong Kong Leaders Criticize Beijing-Dominated Draft of Charter
description: A new draft of the charter that will govern Hong Kong has aroused bitter opposition from political leaders, and even some businessmen who had been reluctant to oppose China said they could not support the planned political model.

title: Knicks Lose As Jordan Scores 42
description: The Knicks did very little right today.

title: Market Place;   Super Bowl Nears And Theories Fly
description: THERE are just five trading days until the Super Bowl is played, and unless share prices rise this week the outcome could be bad news for San Francisco and for stock buyers.

title: Upheaval in the East;   Tale of Panic at Execution of Ceausescus
description: In a chilling new account of the last hour of Nicolae Ceausescu, the deposed Rumanian dictator, and his wife, Elena, a prosecutor was quoted as saying that they ran wildly around the courtyard where they were to be shot until troops hunted them down.

title: Accounts
description: * Farmland Industries, Kansas City, Mo., an agricultural cooperative, to Grey Advertising, with a budget of $4 million.

title: Mergers Off 8.3% in '89; Japan Acquisitions Rise
description: The number of mergers and acquisitions worldwide declined last year, based on figures released on Friday by IDD Information Services, although the American market accounted for a higher percentage of those deals.

title: Another American Tragedy
description: If Theodore Dreiser were alive, he would be avidly read about the Stuart murder case in Boston. The parallels between it and his novel ''An American Tragedy'' are striking.

title: Edouard Izac, Honored As a Hero, Dies at 100
description: Edouard V. M. Izac, a World War I Navy hero who served as a Congressman from California in the 1930's and 40's, died of congestive heart failure on Thursday at the home of a daughter in Fairfax, Va. He was 100 years old.

title: The Best Ever?
description: TO his teammates, Joe Montana is revered as the Legend.

title: State Of the Drug War
description: In the past month, the U.S. Government's ''war on drugs'' won two victories.

title: Gorbachev Is at Fault, Chess Champion Says
description: The world chess champion, Gary Kasparov, said today that Soviet troops should withdraw from the Azerbaijani republic and that President Mikhail S. Gorbachev should take full responsibility for the ethnic violence there.

title: Portugal Investment Up
description: Foreign investment in Portugal more than doubled last year, to $2.4 billion, the Government said Friday. In 1988, direct foreign investment totaled more than $920 million. The Trade and Tourism Minister, Joaquim Ferreira do Amaral, said Britain provided the most investment in Portugal, followed by France, Spain, the United States and Japan.

title: Miss Engelbourg Becomes a Bride
description: Karen Ann Engelbourg, the New England regional director of development at Brandeis University in Waltham, Mass., was married yesterday at the Faculty Center at Brandeis to Donald Bruce Stewart, the executive director of public relations at Wheaton College in Norton, Mass. Edward English, the City Clerk of Newton, Mass., officiated.

title: Campus Security Bill
description: To the Editor:

title: Debate Over Dummies Delays Car Safety Rule
description: Will the real dummy please be seated?

title: Would Armenians Fire on Armenians?
description: LEAD: Soviet troops' difficulties in trying to control the violence in Azerbaijan raise questions that, for Mikhail Gorbachev, surely add up to a nightmare. What would happen to the Soviet Union's stability and cohesiveness if brushfire warfare swept across the country from the Baltic to the Pacific - 11 times zones - as he pursues his reform program?

title: Review/Television;   Meredith Monk's Blend Of Medieval and Modern Life
description: Meredith Monk has been an anomaly for much of her 27-year career as a composer and choreographer, creating dances that were operas, operas that were dances and mythic theater pieces that were operas and dances. To complicate matters, Ms. Monk is also a film maker. In ''Book of Days,'' to be shown tonight at 10 on Channel 13 as part of the ''Alive From Off Center'' series, she has created a film that is essentially a moving picture.

title: Designer Conjures A Lost New York For 'Enemies'
description: It is a world where women in hair nets and men in fedoras occupy wicker seats in the Sea Beach Express, heading for their rendezvous with the Wonder Wheel, the Parachute Jump and the Cyclone. It is a universe of linoleum-floored rooms, Arvin radios, Raleigh cigarettes and indestructible seltzer bottles. It is a place where mammoth advertising placards say ''Read the Sun,'' and where news kiosks shoulder an astonishing burden of Collier's, Photoplay, Life and Look magazines.

title: Honda to Make Chips
description: The Honda Motor Company said Friday that it plans to make gallium arsenide semiconductors on an experimental basis at a plant it is building at a cost of two billion yen, or about $13.7 million, at its laboratory in Tochigi Prefecture near Tokyo. It plans to produce prototypes of the heat-resistant chips by the end of this month and to mass-produce the semiconductors in the early 1990's for use in sensors and other electronic devices.

title: Review/Music;   Outings of a Newly Ubiquitous Instrument
description: The accordion, that lowly and often mocked instrument, has spent the last decade getting revenge. Once the simple butt of jokes, it is now heard everywhere, from highbrow stages at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, where accordionists play art music, to albums by quirky rock groups and clubs featuring hard-rocking regional dance bands. Some weekends, like this past one - when Nathan and the Zydeco Cha-Chas were playing at Tramps, and Santiago Jimenez Jr. y su Conjunto and Willis Prudhomme and the Zydeco Express were performing at Symphony Space - accordions seem hard to avoid. These are three bands heavy with the wheeze and whine of an accordion.

title: Topics of The Times;   Arthur Goldberg's Titles
description: Arthur Goldberg, who died last week at the age of 81, may go down in legal annals as a brilliant lawyer and restless public servant who persisted in seeking other callings. He was a hard-bargaining labor lawyer, an architect of the A.F.L.-C.I.O. union merger in 1955 and a hustling mediator as Secretary of Labor before becoming a Supreme Court Justice in 1962.

title: Haiti Deports Some Opposition Leaders
description: The military Government of Haiti has begun expelling political leaders and at least one presidential candidate was reported in hiding today, a day after the imposition of a state of siege.

title: Barbara Stanwyck, Actress, Dead at 82
description: Barbara Stanwyck, the luminous star of such classic movies as ''Stella Dallas,'' ''The Lady Eve'' and ''Double Indemnity'' and the award-winning western television series ''The Big Valley,'' died of congestive heart failure late Saturday at St. John's Hospital and Health Center in Santa Monica, Calif. She was 82 years old. The actress played a rich mix of characterizations in more than 80 films but developed a distinctive image as a gutsy, self-reliant and self-assured woman whose husky voice and cool exterior usually masked a warm heart.

title: Old and New Help Clear Hurricane-Felled Trees
description: Amid the shattered grandeur of the Francis Marion National Forest, Buddy, Prince, Duke and Joe took a break the other day from the logging operations that are clearing trees felled by Hurricane Hugo. It was lunchtime, and on the menu was a mixture of oats, corn and molasses.

title: Rangers Mull Nicholls's Role
description: The price, Tomas Sandstrom and Tony Granato, was high. The cost, roughly $700,000 a year, will be considerable. The trade for Bernie Nicholls: Was it, is it, will it be worth it?

title: New Line From Intel
description: Expanding its role as a computer manufacturer, the Intel Corporation will introduce a new line of work stations Monday.

title: For Gov. O'Neill, Bitter 3d-Term Prospects
description: Gov. William A. O'Neill, whose popularity soared with the economic boom of the mid-1980's and sank as financial woes rocked the state government last year, will face the toughest battle of his career when he seeks re-election to a third term in November, supporters and opponents say.

title: Upheaval in the East: Secret Police;   East Europeans Are Making Big Brother Smaller
description: The new editor of the Czechoslovak Communist Party daily, Rude Pravo, placed an article on the front page of his newspaper this week, an announcement by the Interior Ministry that the secret police would be dissolved and their domestic spying activities abolished.

title: Egghead Executive Shift
description: Egghead Inc., which owns the Egghead Discount Software retail chain, said Friday that its president and chief executive, Stuart Sloan, had also become chairman, succeeding the company's founder, Victor Alhadeff. Egghead said on Jan. 11 that Mr. Alhadeff intended to buy the company's Egghead University unit and would resign his posts. Egghead, with 205 retail outlets, is the largest personal computer software merchant in North America, in terms of volume.

title: Max Roach Takes 3-Night Look at His Music
description: Often enough, a jazz musician's artistic life traces a predictable pattern: an explosive period of youthful creativity metamorphoses into a period of refinement. The growing artist's desire for change is replaced by the classicist's concern for rules, a type of formalism that fits right in with the demands of the jazz audience, which usually wants its musical icons to defy time and stay the same.

title: Review/Pop;   Booker T. and the MG's Recapture the Past
description: Less is still more in the music of Booker T. and the MG's, who reunited last weekend at the Lone Star Roadhouse. Booker T. Jones on organ, Steve Cropper on guitar and Donald (Duck) Dunn on bass were three-quarters of the Stax Records studio band from 1961 to 1971. They backed up the top Memphis soul singers - including Eddie Floyd, who joined the group for part of the set - and, as the MG's (Memphis Group), put out classic soul instrumentals. Mr. Cropper's terse rhythm-guitar chords and concise blues licks have been memorized by generations of guitarists. With Danny Gottlieb on drums in place of the late Al Jackson, the MG's recaptured not just their old repertory, but also the spark behind it.

title: Agencies Faulted for Latitude Given to Contractors
description: In another report of Reagan Adminstration lapses in supervision, the General Accounting Office has found that the Department of Energy and the Environmental Protection Agency gave too much responsibility to contractors for the performance of essential Government functions.

title: 5 Are Hurt in Newark as Gunmen Open Fire
description: Two gunmen opened fire on a quiet residential street on the south side of Newark yesterday evening, wounding five people. The police said the shooting may have been drug related.

title: When Your Ski Boots Become a Pain in the Ankle
description: MIDWAY through the skiing season, many skiers find that the ski boots they once thought were comfortable have become sources of torture. Ankles are rubbed raw. Insteps are afflicted by cramps. Shins are red and tender. Many people try to solve the problem by stuffing foam rubber into their boots, putting pads under their heels, or pasting moleskin on their feet. Sometimes they have ski shops stretch the boots or punch out spots to ease painful pinching.

title: Ethnic and Disabled Actors Ask for a Chance
description: ''For those of us living and working in this city,'' said the playwright Jules Feiffer, ''writing in the realistic or naturalistic mode for whites only has become unreal and unnatural.''

title: Strong Start for the Schools
description: For years, school reformers in New York City have lamented the absence of a strong chancellor. But now that Joseph Fernandez, only three weeks into the job, is asserting his authority with unusual breadth and swiftness, critics furrow their brows. Is he, as some assert, overstepping legal bounds? Probably not. Since his early targets for discipline have been minority officials in minority districts, is he being bigoted? Surely not. These have been three promising weeks.

title: Upheaval in the East: Communists;   400 Insurgent Soviet Communists Form an Organization for Prodding or for Opposing
description: Insurgent Communists from across the Soviet Union created an organization today that is to serve as a prod for rapid democratization of the Communist Party and, failing that, as the nucleus for a formal political opposition.

title: Transcript of Comments by Mayor and His Wife at Church
description: Following are the comments made today by Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. and his wife, Effi, at St. Timothy's Episcopal Church. The comments were recorded by the Federal News Service, a transcription service.

title: Frederick C. Shrady, 82, Sculptor Best Known for Religious Figures
description: Frederick Charles Shrady, a sculptor best known for his works on religious themes, died of cancer on Saturday at Greenwich (Conn.) Hospital. He was 82 years old and lived in Easton, Conn.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly

title: Bush to Nominate Chairman To End Safety Board Vacancy
description: President Bush will nominate James L. Kolstad to be the chairman of the National Transportation Safety Board, ending a long stalemate with Congress over who should run the agency, a White House official said today.

title: Upheaval in the East: Bulgaria;   From Iron Rule to Ridicule in Bulgaria
description: A short announcement on the radio early last week was enough to send streams of people through the second floor of a Sofia art gallery to gape, chuckle, even laugh out loud at hundreds of caricatures mocking the foibles of their former leader, Todor Zhivkov.

title: Lowe Marschalk Becomes Its Own Best Ad
description: Lowe Marschalk had been one of the best-kept creative secrets in advertising. It was the kind of agency that most people on Madison Avenue simply used to ignore.

title: Harassment Makes Doctors Fear Abortions;   Getting RU 486 Tested
description: To the Editor:

title: 1,440 Minutes
description: WHAT with SportsChannel, SportsChannel America, SportsChannel Plus, MSG and ESPN, not to mention occasional offerings on HBO, USA and the like, cable television would seem to have sports and the alphabet pretty well covered. Wait, there's more. On Feb. 1, Mizlou Communications, the seasonal syndicator of college bowl games and other sports events, will begin the Mizlou Sports News Network, an around-the-clock, 48-half-hours-a-day, 365-days-a-year cable network devoted exclusively to news about sports.

title: A Tearful Mayor Barry Pledges To Seek Help for 'Weaknesses'
description: His personal and political life shattered by a criminal charge that he smoked crack, a repentant Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. said today, in public and in tears, that he had ''weaknesses'' and would seek help for them.

title: Peres Visiting Prague; Renewal of Ties Seen
description: Shimon Peres, the Deputy Prime Minister of Israel, arrived in Prague today on the first visit to Czechoslovakia by an Israeli minister since ties between the two countries were cut in 1967.

title: Bull to DDB Needham
description: The French computer company Groupe Bull has awarded its new corporate advertising account to DDB Needham France. The image-building account, which will cover North America, Europe and Southeast Asia, will have billings of $10 million. The other finalists for the account were TBWA, Publicis and HDM.

title: Joan Fuld Is Wed To Frank Strauss
description: Joan Fuld and Frank Strauss, officials of the Council of Jewish Federations in New York, were married yesterday at the home of the bride's parents in New York by Rabbi David Posner.

title: New Retrieval Software By On Technology Inc.
description: Three years after resigning as chairman of the Lotus Development Corporation, Mitchell D. Kapor is to introduce today the first software product developed by his new company, On Technology Inc.

title: Beyond The Jackpot
description: If anybody doubted it, recent polls show that Lee Atwater, the Republican national chairman, was right as well as crass when he said the death and destruction of the Panama invasion had won President Bush a political ''jackpot.'' As poker players know, while the winners crack jokes, the losers can only say ''deal!''

title: Savings Bank's Chief Resigns
description: William E. Gibson resigned unexpectedly Friday as chairman, president, chief executive and a director of the American Federal Savings Bank.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: HORSE RACING

title: Economic Calendar
description: Below are the major economic indicators to be released this week.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in Business Day on Jan. 4 about Sematech, the Government-industry alliance formed to improve ways of making computer chips, referred imprecisely to Semi-Gas Systems Inc. Despite the juxtaposition with a reference to other companies' troubles, Semi-Gas is profitable and currently has no long-term debt. The adjoining article also described part of Semi-Gas's business incorrectly. The company is the largest supplier of equipment for handling special gases used in semiconductor production; its customers include semiconductor manufacturers in many major industrial nations.

title: Perles and the Jets: It's Almost Final
description: The Jets are expected to have a new head coach today after George Perles of Michigan State flies to New York to hammer out the details of a contract.

title: Review/Recital;   Debussy and Schumann With a Soupcon of Chopin
description: The most immediately striking quality of Katsurako Mikami's performance at Weill Recital Hall on Saturday afternoon was the smooth, rounded tone she drew from the hall's Steinway piano - an instrument that can sound glaring in less careful hands.

title: Upheaval in the East: Yugoslavia;   COMMUNIST SESSION IN BELGRADE SPLIT
description: In a tense atmosphere of a crew fighting for control of a sinking ship, Yugoslavia's ruling Communists today insulted, challenged and prodded each other on nationwide television, displaying a split in their ranks on the second day of the party's national congress.

title: U.S. and Soviet Miners Meet and Find Surprises
description: Nine Soviet miners, who helped organize a nationwide strike last summer to change their future, came to the Appalachian coalfields last week to learn from Americans who are striking to preserve the gains of the past.

title: Question Box
description: Record Before Ruth

title: Barry Pledge Wins Sympathy
description: It was a day of redemption and renewal today within the high walls of the First Rising Mount Zion Baptist Church, an anchor in the capital's poor black Shaw neighborhood.

title: Lemieux Steals The All-Star Show
description: Mario Lemieux, who has been adored by hockey fans in Pittsburgh and elsewhere around the National Hockey League, may have enhanced his sport's image today with his performance in the league's 41st All-Star Game.

title: Iran's Prisons, From Inside and Out
description: LEAD: In a few days, for the first time in a decade, a United Nations human rights fact-finding mission is scheduled to visit Iran.

title: Churches to Close in Chicago
description: Roman Catholics in the nation's second largest archdiocese learned today that about 30 churches and at least 6 schools would be closed to ease what church officials called a critical financial situation.

title: LEBANESE LEADER MEETS SYRIA CHIEF
description: President Elias Hrawi of Lebanon held talks in the Syrian capital with President Hafez al-Assad today on what Government officials here described as ways to oust Gen. Michel Aoun, the Christian leader.

title: Color Analysis
description: A golf ball designed with red, yellow and blue stripes has been developed to give players a visual cue on where to hit the ball and how to gauge its spin.

title: Fate of Daily News Seen at Stake as Labor Talks Start
description: After months of bitter verbal sparring, labor and management at the 70-year-old Daily News began the collective-bargaining process last week on negotiations that both sides say are apt to save the paper or sink it.

title: Deceit and Disaster in Myanmar
description: If anybody deserves to be disqualified from next May's elections in Myanmar, formerly Burma, it is those who have run the country into the ground during the last 28 years of military misgovernment. Instead, the regime has disqualified the opposition leader likely to give the architects of the disastrous ''Burmese Road to Socialism'' the most trouble.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE ECONOMY

title: CART Develops Insider Information
description: Championship Auto Racing Teams, the Indy-car sanctioning group created more than a decade ago out of car-owner discontent, was reshaped last October out of that same dissatisfaction.

title: 'Jack of All Trades' Named To Chairman's Job at Boots
description: The Boots Company, the British retail and pharmaceuticals group, has appointed Sir Christopher Benson chairman. He will succeed Robert Gunn, who had the post for the last five years and will retire in July at age 65.

title: Alfred Olcott, Financial Planner, 70
description: Alfred Van Santvoord Olcott, a financial planner and founder of a maritime historical society, died of complications of heart surgery at the University of Pennsylvania Hospital in Philadelphia.

title: Hispanic Community Leaders Have Been Active in AIDS Fight
description: To the Editor:

title: Tokyo's Wary Money Managers
description: It takes only one shout of, ''It's the Japanese; they're buying!'' in a Wall Street dealing room to throw traders into fits of nervous activity. It is easy to understand why.

title: People
description: * Arnold J. Blum, who has been senior vice president and creative director of the international team of McCann-Erickson Worldwide, will become executive vice president and co-creative director of Trahan, Burden & Charles in Baltimore.

title: A United Europe Seems Closer Than Ever
description: To the Editor:

title: First Executive Sees Loss
description: The First Executive Corporation said last week it expects to report a charge of about $515 million against its fourth-quarter earnings, partly because of its holdings in the Campeau Corporation, which sought bankruptcy protection last week.

title: Cuba Is Said to Arrest 4 in Communist Youth
description: At least four leading members of Cuba's Communist youth organization have been arrested in Havana after complaining about lack of democracy in their country, the Spanish newspaper El Pais said today.

title: Highland Springs Captures Appleton
description: Highland Springs, who won two stakes races and set a course record at Saratoga last summer, scored his first victory since then when he pulled away in the stretch to win the $100,000 Appleton Handicap today at Gulfstream Park.

title: Congressional Leaders Take Issue With Moynihan Plan to Cut Taxes
description: Congressional leaders of both parties took issue today with Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan's proposal to cut Social Security taxes, and President Bush's budget director, Richard G. Darman, called the plan ''the most irresponsible idea of the '90's.''

title: Listing Shows Homeless Sites To Aid Census
description: New York City has made its first concerted effort to list the places where homeless people spend their nights, in the hope of guiding the Census Bureau to those who live in shelters, subway stations, parks, doorways and abandoned buildings - and who would otherwise go uncounted.

title: Harbin Journal;   In the City of Ice, Heat Brings the Biggest Shivers
description: It is a cold so chilling that it requires new metaphors: not just icy cold, or freezing, but a subzero cold that quickly disables cameras and makes even the hardy pushcart vendors shiver as they shout for customers: ''Ice cream! Buy your popsicles here.''

title: Corrections
