description: Because of a transmission error, the diagram of the deal with the bridge column Saturday duplicated two cards and was missing two cards.

title: Outdoors: Time for Tending to Tackle
description: ALTHOUGH we've still got a long way to go before the whippoorwill's persistent three-note song celebrates soft summer nights, this is the best time of year to begin sorting out, refurbishing and replacing fishing tackle.

title: BRIEFS
description: Common Stock

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I'm going to find a way to begin to heal my body, mind and soul.''

title: 4 Golden Globe Awards To 'Born on 4th of July'
description: ''Born on the Fourth of July,'' the Vietnam drama, won four Golden Globe Awards Saturday night, including best dramatic picture, best dramatic actor for Tom Cruise and best director.

title: Business and the Law;   States to Regulate Money Transfers
description: THE sweeping set of regulations for commercial transactions is about to get the most significant addition in decades.

title: One Dead and Six Missing As Fishing Boat Breaks Up
description: A chartered fishing boat with nine people aboard capsized and broke up in 15-foot swells in a river's mouth today, leaving one person dead and six people missing, Coast Guard officials said.

title: Delta Air Lines Reports 24.6% Fall in Profit
description: Delta Air Lines on Saturday reported a 24.6 percent drop in profit for its second quarter, reflecting higher fuel costs and weaker-than-expected holiday travel.

title: India Seeks to Reopen Bhopal Case
description: Prime Minister V. P. Singh said today that his Government wanted to set aside a $470 million settlement with the Union Carbide Corporation to compensate victims of the world's most deadly industrial disaster.

title: Conference Ponders Nature of Crafts
description: All day Friday and half of Saturday, a group of nearly 280 artists, art historians, curators, museum directors, dealers and critics took over the lower level of the American Craft Museum. They constituted a sold-out symposium titled ''A Neglected History: 20th-Century American Craft.''

title: Upheaval in the East;   Rally to Support Armenians Is Staged in New York City
description: More than 150 people demonstrated near the Soviet Mission to the United Nations yesterday, calling on the Gorbachev Government to protect the lives of Armenians in Azerbaijan and to allow self-determination in Armenia.

title: A Poor Way to Save
description: President Bush's misguided urge to cut the tax on capital gains finds a dubious companion in his ''family savings plan.'' Floated during the 1988 campaign and now being readied for submission to Congress, it shares at least two faults with the gains tax: it is weak medicine for America's low savings rate, and it would create new budget problems for the future.

title: Stephen Sondheim Bows as Oxford Don
description: The Broadway composer and lyricist Stephen Sondheim has begun his new role as professor, addressing an overflow crowd of 250 people at Oxford University.

title: San Francisco Journal;   Milestone In Church: Gay Clergy Ordained
description: When Jeff Johnson was a boy, he prayed in the Rev. Lyle Miller's church and went camping with the pastor's children. When Mr. Johnson entered the seminary, his spiritual mentor was as proud as if he were family.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Calvin Klein Cosmetics Co., a unit of Unilever United States, named Kimberly Delsing president and chief executive.

title: Topics of The Times;   Banned in Beirut
description: One of the few glories of Beirut to survive 15 years of sectarian violence has been its lively press. Three papers published in the Christian East sector of the city and seven in the Muslim West have circulated on both sides of the dividing Green Line, offering an antidote to unfounded rumors and managed information.

title: Pregnant Woman Is Charged With Child Abuse for Drinking
description: A pregnant woman has been charged with child abuse after prosecutors accused her of excessive drinking.

title: Can 'Thirtysomething' Fans Accept a Bout With Cancer?
description: Last Tuesday, fans of ABC's ''Thirtysomething'' got unsettling news. Nancy, a major character in the critically praised television series, was discovered to have ovarian cancer.

title: 3 Issues in This Week's Treasury Auctions
description: The Treasury's schedule of issues this week includes today's auction of three- and six-month bills and Wednesday's auction of two-year notes.

title: INSIDE
description: Barbara Stanwyck Dies

title: Environmentalists Seek To Buy Off Development
description: Tremper Mountain rises gently over this Catskill village, its slopes an unbroken mass of evergreens and white birch. New York State owns the summit, but much of the lower mountain is in private hands, and some of those hands belong to developers with plans to subdivide the land.

title: News Summary
description: International A3-8

title: Goodenow Is Hired By N.H.L. Players
description: Bob Goodenow, a lawyer and player agent from Detroit, was named the deputy executive director of the National Hockey League Players Association today.

title: Harassment Makes Doctors Fear Abortions;   Fetus Is Different
description: To the Editor:

title: Mitsuo Horiguchi, Club Director, 82
description: Mitsuo Horiguchi, a former director of the Nippon Club in Manhattan, died of emphysema and heart failure on Wednesday at Rye General Hospital in New Rochelle, N.Y. He was 82 years old and lived in Larchmont, N.Y.

title: Rift Ends for Spanish Bank Over Who Will Be Its Head
description: A bruising five-week leadership struggle at Spain's largest private bank ended Saturday when the board of the Banco Bilbao Vizcaya approved the appointment of a Basque financier, Emilio Ybarra Churruca, as its chairman.

title: Dominick Lamanna, Teacher, 42
description: Dominick Lamanna, a physics teacher at the Bronx High School of Science who worked with students in independent research, including helping them prepare entries for the Westinghouse Science Talent Search, was killed on Wednesday in an automobile accident on the Taconic State Parkway. He was 42 years old and lived in Poughkeepsie, N.Y.

title: New Police Chief Brings a Sense of Loyalty That Left Rift in Houston
description: One of Lee P. Brown's last acts as police chief here, before starting work as the New York City Police Commissioner on Monday, was to dismiss four officers involved in two highly publicized and widely criticized shootings of civilians.

title: Din Forgone
description: THOUGH the University of Connecticut's Field House has been a good-luck charm for the basketball team, for years it has been the bane of the school's coaches.

title: Dribbling And Traveling
description: COLBY COLLEGE's 96-80 victory last week over the University of Southern Maine in a Division III basketball game at Southern Maine's Hill Gymnasium in Gorham did more than preserve Colby's unblemished record.

title: Quiet Arrival for Broncos
description: There were no brass bands and no welcoming committee as the Denver Broncos arrived in New Orleans today for the Super Bowl. Players and coaches quickly left a chartered jet and boarded buses at New Orleans International Airport for the trip to a downtown hotel.

title: Man Rushing to Aid His Mother Is Killed
description: A Bronx man was shot to death late Saturday night as he tried to come to his mother's aid during an attempted robbery, the police said.

title: The Bundesbank's Partial Success
description: With its aggressive strategy to strengthen the mark, the Bundesbank of West Germany has shown again why it is considered the most skilled of the West's central banks and a primary player in the economic future of Europe. But not everything has gone according to plan.

title: Gifts to Neediest Reflect Gratitude of Elderly
description: ''And although there are many signs and symptoms of my age, I feel privileged and grateful to offer the enclosed check, which includes cash gifts I received on my birthday, to be earmarked to the care and life enhancement of the needy elderly,'' she wrote.

title: Virginia Tops Georgia Tech in Overtime
description: Kenny Turner, who had not scored since the first half, hit a 10-foot jump shot with 6 seconds to play in overtime today to give Virginia an 81-79 victory over Georgia Tech.

title: No. 7 Could Make the Broncos No. 1
description: WHEN you play Denver, the key to your game is what you can do about No. 7. Because John Elway is such a big-play performer, your best defense is to have your offense control and keep the ball so No. 7 stays on the sideline. The 49ers are good at that.

title: Tilford E. Dudley, 82, Dies; New Deal Labor Aide
description: Tilford E. Dudley, a labor lawyer who served in President Franklin D. Roosevelt's New Deal era, who clashed with President Lyndon B. Johnson over the Vietnam War and who continued to help social causes in the 1980's, died Thursday at the family home in Bellingham, Wash. He was 82 years old.

title: New Rules Forcing Cuts by Builders
description: Most housing analysts concluded months ago that fewer first-time home buyers, a slowing economy and rising land and development costs would curb home construction this year and next. But builders in many regions are starting to slash operations even more deeply than they had planned, because of tough new lending policies Congress forced on savings and loan institutions in August.

title: For Cable Systems, the Takeover Frenzy Cools
description: The rush to buy cable television systems appears to be slowing, industry executives and media brokers say.

title: Upheaval in the East: Rumania;   Rumanians Call for Freedom in Schools
description: Student leaders, addressing a crowd of about 3,000 of their classmates today, demanded far-reaching changes in the faculties of Bucharest University and other Rumanian institutions of higher learning.

title: Syndicators Find a Winner: The Successful Game Show
description: GAME shows are gold mines.

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Jan. 21, 1990: MONDAY Kennametal Inc Philadelphia Elec Co Lubrizol Corp TUESDAY Ahmanson HF & Co Jostens Inc Amoco Corp Kansas Gas & Elec Co Ball Corp Legg Mason Inc Black Hills Corp Norfolk Southn Corp Cilcorp Inc Nui Corp Consol Edison Co NY Inc Rollins Inc Edo Corp Schering Plough Corp Fedders Corp Shelby Williams Indstry Inc Glenfed Inc USLife Corp Great Westn Finl Corp Weis Mkts Inc WEDNESDAY Alltel Corp Hillenbrand Inds Inc AMP Inc Johnson Ctls Inc Ashland Oil Inc Kansas Pwr & Lt Co Baker Hughes Inc Minnesota Pwr & Lt Co Beckman Instrs Inc New Russell Corp Belo AH Corp Standex Intl Corp Burlington Res Inc Tokheimm Corp Donaldson Inc Wisconsin Energy Corp Energen Corp Zero Corp Hexcel Corp THURSDAY Amer Home Prods Corp Pfizer Inc Avery Intl Corp Pope & Talbot Inc Delta Air Lines Inc Potlatch Corp Empire Dist Elec Co Potomac Elec Pwr Co Handy & Harman PSI Hldgs Inc Health Care Ppty Invs Inc Quaker St Corp Iowa Ill Gas & Elec Co Sara Lee Corp Morton Intl Inc Ind Smucker J M Co Olin Corp Universal Foods Corp Oregon Stl Mls Inc FRIDAY Acme Elec Corp Kysor Indl Corp Del Dean Foods Co Mobil Corp Ferro Corp Natnl Med Enterprises Inc Harlan John H Co Tyler Corp New Homestake Mng Co Wicor Inc

title: Brooklyn Teen-Ager Found Fatally Shot on the Street
description: A 15-year-old Brooklyn youth was fatally shot in the chest yesterday, apparently due to a dispute that began earlier in the day, the police said.

title: East-German Party Prevails
description: Leaders of East Germany's Communist Party decided to purge several more leaders, but rejected calls that it dissolve altogether. Page A7.

title: A New World With New Issues Born in the Recess Is Awaiting Congress
description: The 101st Congress returns to work on Tuesday in a world made new.

title: Hours for Emergencies On Metro-North
description: To the Editor:

title: Judith Mazo Is Wed to Louis Seidman
description: Judith Frances Mazo, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Earl Mazo of Washington, was married there yesterday to Louis Michael Seidman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Benedict S. Seidman of New Rochelle, N.Y. Judge Frederick H. Weisberg of Superior Court of the District of Columbia officiated at the bride and bridegroom's home.

title: Chronicle
description: From the woods of Oregon, BARRY LOPEZ is making a rare trip to Manhattan. In a nostalgic mode, the author is to talk to high school students today at the Donnell Library Center, which he used when he was a student at Loyola High School. His subject is ''the meaning of nature to city kids,'' a spokesman for the library said.

title: Harper & Row Takes a Gamble on Mass-Market Paperbacks
description: Publishing executives at other houses have long asserted that Harper & Row pays too much for books, and they solemnly predicted that the company would fall on its face when it began its mass-market paperback division.

title: Chronicle
description: The Federal Bureau of Investigation has named THOMAS E. DuHADWAY as the agent in charge of the bureau's Washington metropolitan field office. He had been a deputy assistant director of the intelligence division, which tracks and occasionally catches spies.

title: Harassment Makes Doctors Fear Abortions;   Problem for Couples
description: To the Editor:

title: Taylor-Gordon Wins
description: Six months after it resigned the $5 million Helmsley Hotel Corporation account over a fee dispute, Taylor-Gordon, Aarons & Company has returned to the hospitality field. The agency has won the account for the Vista International Hotel at the World Trade Center in New York. Billings for the new account, formerly at Albert Frank-Guenther Law, are projected at $1 million to $2 million.

title: Japanese Rate Surge Felt in U.S.
description: For the first time since Japan became a financial superpower, the market for its Government bonds is playing a critical role in the movement of interest rates in the United States.

title: China Says Grain Harvest Hit a Record Level in 1989
description: China's recent grain harvest, an indicator of national well-being, has set a record, narrowly exceeding the level in 1984, the Government announced Friday.

title: Frank Gervasi, Author And Correspondent, 81
description: Frank Gervasi, a reporter who covered the Spanish Civil War and World War II in Europe, died yesterday after a stroke at Doctors Hospital in Manhattan. He was 81 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: More Weapons Than the Pentagon
description: THE San Francisco 49ers are not an unbeatable football team. But if the Denver Broncos are going to be competitive they better have their best players on the field at all times paying strict attention. The 49ers can beat you in so many ways. If you stop this, they'll try that. They keep after you relentlessly. The 49ers know New Orleans and the Superdome. They play there every year. The Broncos have played in the Superdome only once, last season, and they lost, 42-0. They don't know New Orleans and all the things that can happen to a young man there. That's an edge for the 49ers.

title: Upheaval in the East: Soviet Union;   Hornet's Nest in the Soviet South: Is Azerbaijan Another Afghanistan?
description: By sending troops to impose order in the southern republic of Azerbaijan, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev has committed himself to a prolonged occupation that supporters already fear could be his domestic Afghanistan.

title: Doris Bernstein, Psychoanalyst, 57
description: Doris Bernstein, a psychoanalyst and past president of the Institute for Psychoanalytic Training and Research, died of cancer on Friday at her home in Manhattan. She was 57 years old.

title: Upsets Give an Assist to an Amazed Missouri
description: Less than 24 hours after watching his team snap Kansas' winning streak at 19 games, Norm Stewart, Missouri's head basketball coach, sat in an empty locker room this morning, stunned by a succession of upsets that had put his Tigers in position to be the country's top-ranked team for the first time in eight years.

title: BUSH WOULD AGREE TO ELEVATE E.P.A.
description: President Bush, reversing his previous position, would accept a vote in Congress to make the Environmental Protection Agency a Cabinet-level department, Administration officials say.

title: 35 Reported Dead as Indian Army Opens Fire on Kashmir Protesters
description: The Indian Army opened fire today in clashes with demonstrators defying a curfew in the Kashmiri city of Srinagar, and at least 35 people were killed and 100 wounded, Indian news agencies reported.

title: William McEwen, 77, Former Hofstra Provost
description: Dr. William Peter McEwen, an educator and former provost of Hofstra University, died of cancer on Wednesday at the Berkshire (Mass.) Medical Center. He was 77 years old and lived in Becket, Mass.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Insufficient Funds
description: The building that was once B. Altman stands on Fifth Avenue, solid as a rock, pathetic as an abandoned house. Two women mount the steps and peer inside the glass doors. ''I was on their bridal registry,'' said one sadly.

title: New Leader of Police Pledges 'Partnership of Trust'
description: Pledging to make the New York City Police Department ''a part of the community, not apart from the community,'' Lee Patrick Brown yesterday accepted from Mayor David N. Dinkins the 14-karat gold shield whose five platinum stars mark him as Commissioner of the nation's largest police force.

title: The Cloud Over Congress
description: First, honor.

title: Evergreen Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The 1988 year's shares outstanding and per share earnings were adjusted for a 3-for-2 stock split paid in September 1989.

title: Beijing Starves the Hong Kong Goose
description: China's weekend decision to impose a Big Brother political system on Hong Kong is bad news for the colony, for London and for the United States, home to Hong Kong's major customers.

title: Dr. Prego Ends 7 Days of Testimony
description: Dr. Veronica Prego finished testifying yesterday in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn, ending seven days of detailed questioning about her painful illness and expected death from AIDS.

title: T. Fleischmann, 94; Took Photographs Of Famous Subjects
description: Trude Fleischmann, a portrait photographer known in her native Vienna as the Photographer of the Famous, died on Saturday at the home of her nephew in Brewster, N.Y. She was 94 years old.

title: Reviews/Opera;   City Opera's 'Boheme' Tour Has Early Stop in Brooklyn
description: Last fall's strike by the New York City Opera orchestra killed the company's regular season, but it did not cast its shadow over the endeavors of its touring troupe, the New York City Opera National Company, which offered a likable, slightly scaled-down version of Lloyd Evans's production of Puccini's ''Boheme'' on Sunday afternoon at the Brooklyn Center for the Performing Arts at Brooklyn College. The work was sung in Italian, with English supertitles.

title: Lake Shore Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago periods' per share earnings were adjusted for a 5-for-4 stock split paid in December 1989.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   People
description: * Ronald Arnold, Mark Hughes, Frank Fleizach and Robert High have been promoted to executive vice presidents at HDM New York.

title: Gretzky's All-Star Play Falls Far Short of Great
description: Wayne Gretzky, perhaps the greatest hockey player ever, spent a miserable weekend here attending the National Hockey League's 41st All-Star Game.

title: Land-Use Chief Off to a Rocky Start
description: For 15 years, Jerry L. Crispino, like most of his colleagues on the New York City Council, performed his duties with little fanfare. He had a few streets renamed, made sure the trash was collected in his Bronx district and earned a good living as a lawyer.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''We agreed to put a full stop to politics that bring confrontations and splits over partisan interests.''

title: Dean S. Butler, Tax Lawyer, 69
description: Dean S. Butler, a tax lawyer and financial adviser to President Richard M. Nixon, died of heart failure on Wednesday. He was 69 years old.

title: Chess
description: Conservative play was the key to victory in the 1989 United States Championship, which ended Dec. 3, in Long Beach, Calif.

title: Results Plus
description: HORSE RACING

title: Peach Bottom Journal;   Amish Man Vs. a Law: Centuries Collide
description: Jacob J. Herschberger Jr., a 36-year-old horse trader, spent 15 days in the Lancaster County Prison last fall because he built a house without a sewer system.

title: NBB Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: NBB said that in addition to its increased fourth quarter loan loss provision, the bank also took a writedown during the period of $847,000 against a condominium project that had been developed by the Taunton Savings Bank subsidiary which NBB acquired in 1988.

title: American Brands Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss of $900,000 for the quarter and income of $39,200,000, or 40 cents a share, for the year, both from discontinued operations. The company said income from continuing operations for 1988 reflected restructuring charges totaling $44 million for the quarter and $52 million for the year. During 1988, the company sold Sunshine Biscuits, Pinkerton's Andrew Jergens, the remaining components of Pumpsd and Valves and Case Cutlery. Proceeds from the sale of these companies approximated $648 million and resulted in a net gain of approximately $58 million. This gain, partly offset by losses from operations of discontinued subsidiaries, resulted in income of $39 million for the 12 months ended Dec. 31, 1988. Discontinued operations for the 12 months and 3 months ended Dec. 31, 1988 included income tax expense of $76 million and $1 million, respectively. The company also said low exchange rates for foreign currencies, principally the British pound, adversely affected revenues by $218 million, or 8 cents a share, in the latest fourth quarter and by $594 million, or 23 cents a share, for the year. Results are in U.S. dollars.

title: Profits Scoreboard
Meritor Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After extraordinary credits of $402,000, or 1 cent a share, for the quarter and $5,912,000, or 17 cents a share, for the year, both from early extinguishment of debt.

title: Naruhiko Higashikuni, 102, Dies; Led a Postwar Japanese Cabinet
description: Naruhiko Higashikuni, a member of the Japanese imperial family who became the country's first Prime Minister after World War II, died Saturday. He was 102 years old.

title: McEnroe's Theatrics Get Mixed Review
description: The reaction to John McEnroe's misadventures at the Australian Open, where Flinders Park became his Flanders Field, has been less than incredulous.

title: Topics of The Times;   Ball of Fire
description: Ordinary people walk. Barbara Stanwyck strode, and when she did, the screen crackled. She was many people - the sad, silly Stella Dallas, the icy murderess of ''Double Indemnity,'' the enchanting con woman of ''The Lady Eve'' and the slangy showgirl of ''Ball of Fire'' - but all of them were monuments to vitality. She made them that way.

title: Iran Reports Series of Quakes
description: Eight earthquakes measuring between 4.0 and 5.2 on the Richter scale hit areas of Iran near Firuzkuh, east of Teheran, in the past 24 hours, the Iranian press agency I.R.N.A. said today. The agency, monitored in Nicosia, did not say if the earthquakes caused any casualties or damage. It said two tremors registering 3.3 and 3.7 on the Richter scale also shook Birjand, 490 miles southeast of Tehran, today.

title: Charles Stuart Capitalized on Racial Fears;   A Detail in the Story
description: To the Editor:

title: Once Abortion Foe, State Senator Reverses Stand
description: A Republican State Senator who had been a strong opponent of abortion reversed his position today, providing a further sign of the intense political pressure on abortion foes. The move also bolstered predictions that abortion restrictions are unlikely to come up for a vote in the Legislature this year.

title: Mayor Barry Enters a Florida Clinic As His Top Aide Takes Over the City
description: Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. today checked into a Florida clinic that treats drug and alcohol dependency, leaving behind a heated debate over his legal situation and the political consequences of his arrest on a charge of smoking crack.

title: By Design;   Trend-Setting Accessories
description: So far the couture collections have been filled with pretty clothes, but the accessories are even better; they are the sort that start trends. Take the shoes - or mules, as the case may be. The slippers that Christian Lacroix chose for evening are like bedroom scuffs of fairyland princesses. They are conceived by Sidonie Larizzi, a well-known Parisian shoe designer, to complement Lacroix's clothes. They are spindly high-heeled backless sandals with pointed toes of clear plastic overlaid with lace. Often a bit of frippery - a little ostrich feather, a jeweled clip - has been added to the instep. They're hot stuff. The classic pump that will be shown with the new Chanel collection Wednesday has been completely revamped by Karl Lagerfeld's team. Now the heel is high and shaped like an exaggerated Louis line. The patched toe is tapered to an elegantly squared shape and the fabrications are often linen or silk faille with a patent toe tip.

title: Chronicle
description: The new Mayor of New York has taken on a second new job. He'll play himself in ''H.E.L.P.,'' a series to be broadcast on ABC-TV.

title: Loral Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After income of $707,000, or 3 cents a share, from discontinued operations. c-After income from discontinued operations of $6,208,000, or 25 cents a share, for the quarter and $18,998,000, or 76 cents a share, for the 9 months. The latest quarter and 9 months included a non-recurring charge of $10.5 million to cover costs of settlement with the U.S. Justice Department for a contract dispute regarding the ALR- 56M radar warning receiver.

title: First Colonial Bankshares reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
British Telecom Weighs Mitel Sale
description: British Telecommunications P.L.C. said it was considering selling its 51 percent stake in the Mitel Corporation, the Canadian telecommunications equipment manufacturer. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, British Telecom said its board had ''agreed that the option to be considered immediately was for British Telecom to sell its stake in Mitel, provided reasonable terms including price could be secured.''

title: Glasnost and Sex
description: LEAD: Surely, sex in the Soviet Union predates perestroika. But the eroticization of popular culture now afoot has glasnost writen all over it.

title: Amoco Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said earnings for 1989 were adversely affected by restructuring costs and provisions for estimated costs of environmental programs. It also said results for 1988 included a number of favorable items, primarily representing natural gas settlements.

title: Calmat Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included net gains on disposal of real estate assets of $18,700,000, or 60 cents a share, in the quarter and $21,968,000, or 71 cents a share, in the year.

title: Chronicle
description: ANN POLLARD, who was sentenced to five years in prison in connection with thy spying case of her husband, JONATHAN POLLARD, has been released from Federal prison in Danbury, Conn., and is living in a halfway house in Greenwich Village.

title: Chemical Said to Plan Job Cutbacks
description: The Chemical Banking Corporation is planning to cut more than 300 jobs in its consumer banking business in an effort to improve profits by reducing expenses, according to Chemical employees, who asked not to be indentified.

title: Counsel Due For Inquiry On Dinkins
description: At the request of Mayor David N. Dinkins, a special counsel will be appointed to continue a city inquiry into some of his activities while he was Borough President of Manhattan, including a transfer of his stock in a broadcasting company.

title: Safeco Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Claire B. Adler, Professor, 94
description: Dr. Claire B. Adler, associate professor of mathematics at New York University, died of stomach cancer Friday at Flushing Hospital in Queens. She was 94 years old and lived in Jamaica Estates, Queens.

title: In Search of lower Insurance Rates
description: Major parts of Gov. Jim Florio's plan to lower automobile insurance premiums in New Jersey, which now average more than $1,000 a year:

title: Sports People: PRO FOOTBALL;   Millard Arrested For Drunken Driving
description: Keith Millard, the Minnesota Viking tackle recently selected as the National Football League's defensive player of the year, was arrested early yesterday in Bloomington, Minn., on charges of drunken driving and speeding. The arrest marked the 12th drunken-driving incident in four years involving Viking players.

title: Alabama Town Is Searched In Investigation of Bombings
description: Federal agents, armed with the first search warrants in the investigation of a series of bombings last month, descended on this southeastern Alabama town today, searching a warehouse, a vacant pawn shop and the home of a resident.

title: U.S. Prosecution of Noriega: Signs of Trouble at the Start
description: The Federal prosecution of Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega has been plagued by a lack of preparedness, sniping among current and former prosecutors, and early missteps in what many officials believe was a weak case from the start.

title: To Control Drugs, Legalize
description: LEAD: The idea of legalizing addictive drugs conjures up images of crack being sold like cigarettes at corner news stands or heroin like whisky at local bars. Such concepts have been quickly - and correctly -categorized as surrender to the devastation of drug use.

title: Israel Gives Assurance About Cluster Bombs
description: The United States has been assured that Israel is not selling cluster bombs to Ethiopia, the State Department said today.

title: Topics of The Times;   No Shortage of Ideas
description: In 1988, American workers dropped 1,010,889 ideas into their suggestion boxes, according to the National Association of Suggestion Systems. Their bosses adopted more than 293,000 of those ideas, roughly 29 percent, and thereby saved $2.2 billion.

title: Books of The Times;   Evoking the Vanished Past Of a Family in Dissolution
description: Sweet Talk

title: First Interstate Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After gains of $11,312,000, or 24 cents a share, for the quarter and $27,417,000, or 59 cents a share, for the year, both from the cumulative effect of an accounting change; the quarter also included an extraordinary loss of $29.9 million. c-Net income and after an extraordinary gain of $27 million, or 60 cents a share, for the quarter and year.

title: Luxury Brooklyn High-Rise Fails to Win Planning Votes
description: The New York City Planning Commission, in a series of votes yesterday, dealt a serious setback to a luxury high-rise development proposed for the Brighton Beach section of Brooklyn.

title: Corrections
description: An article in The Home Section on Thursday about an apartment with passages from Italo Calvino on the walls misidentified the project designer for the headquarters of Windham Hill Records in Palo Alto, Calif.

title: Drexel Aide Said to Quit
description: A spokesman for Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. said yesterday that Jeffrey Beck, an investment banker who was the subject of a lengthy Wall Street Journal article yesterday, had tendered a preliminary resignation to the firm several weeks ago.

title: Computer Intruder Is Found Guilty
description: A Federal jury today found Robert Tappan Morris, a 24-year-old computer science student, guilty of intentionally disrupting a nationwide computer network in November 1988 by writing a program that copied itself wildly in thousands of separate machines.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Changes at Thompson
description: The J. Walter Thompson Company has overhauled its upper management, creating a North America division to oversee Thompson U.S.A. and Thompson Canada. The agency named James B. Patterson, formerly chief executive of Thompson U.S.A., chairman of the North America division. Ronald S. Burns was named chief executive, while remaining chairman of Thompson Canada and director of the Goodyear and Kraft General Foods accounts worldwide.

title: York Financial Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
North Side Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago first quarter results included those operations of Richmond Hill Savings Bank for only the two- month period from Oct. 31, the date of merger, to Dec. 31, 1988, while the results for the latest quarter reflected combined operations for the entire quarter.

title: Market Plan, Under Fire, To Be Revised
description: After hours of harsh criticism by executives in the securities and futures industries, officials of an independent Congressional agency said today that they would make significant revisions in a draft report that questioned some fundamental practices of the two industries.

title: 2 PARTIES IN SEOUL AGREE TO A MERGER WITH RULING GROUP
description: President Roh Tae Woo's party and two opposition parties announced today that they would merge into a conservative majority party to break a two-year political deadlock in Parliament.

title: Upheaval in the East: Poland;   First Solidarity Mayor Aims to Clean Up a City
description: At home, late at night, after being bombarded by a dozen phone calls from townspeople seeking help, Waldemar Bohdanowicz sometimes asks himself why he ever wanted to be mayor of this grimy textile center.

title: KEY RATES
Upheaval in the East: East Germany;   East German Premier Offers a Coalition
description: Facing spreading disaffection and a growing loss of confidence in his leadership, the head of East Germany's interim Government urged the opposition today to join his Cabinet and share the responsibility for guiding the country through its troubles.

title: Troopers Bolstering Hartford Police
description: A state plan to help overworked local police departments combat street crime by sending in a little extra muscle from the state police has turned into a fight over jurisdiction, public perception and ruffled pride.

title: Merrill Lynch & Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 29
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $3,981,000, or 4 cents a share. c-Net income and included a loss from discontinued operations of $5,983,000 for the quarter and a gain of $17,287,000, or 17 cents a share, from discontinued operations for the year. Latest quarter and year results included a $395,000,000 aftertax restructuring charge. Year-ago quarter and year results included a $254,700,000 after-tax gain from the termination of the firm's pension plan.

title: Universal to Sell Cheese Division
description: The Universal Foods Corporation, which successfully fought a hostile takeover bid last year, tentatively agreed to sell its cheese division to the unit's management. The company said the proposed sale, which should be completed this spring, is intended to generate capital for other investment opportunites. Terms were not disclosed.

title: Polish Crew Tells of 3-Week Ordeal After a Red Sea Attack
description: A crew of Polish seamen, captured and held prisoner on the remote beaches and rugged mountains of Eritrea, today recounted the surreal drama that occurred when their cargo ship carrying cotton was bombarded with cannon, bazooka and machine-gun fire by guerrilla fighters in speedboats.

title: Jennings Creates a Gun-Control Special
description: Tomorrow night at 10, ABC will present ''Peter Jennings Reporting,'' the first of at least four hourlong programs this year in which the anchor will examine contentious public-affairs issues. The first program, on gun-related violence, is part of an unusual collaboration between ABC News and Time magazine, which features a cover story on the gun lobby in its current issue.

title: Talking Business: with Guarascio of General Motors;   G.M.'s Cutbacks On Advertising
description: The General Motors Corporation spent $1.3 billion on domestic advertising in 1988, the last year for which it disclosed the spending. But tough conditions in the market have forced the company to cut or defer some advertising plans, although it will not say by how much. Philip Guarascio, executive director for advertising and strategic merchandising, discussed the company's plans.

title: Tarpley Cleared For Mavericks
description: The Dallas Mavericks' forward, Roy Tarpley, who was suspended Nov. 16 for violating his substance-abuse aftercare program, was reinstated to the team today on advice of a doctor.

title: Banco Santander reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The latest year's results were converted at a rate of 109.72 Spanish pesetas per $1.00. The year-ago results were converted at the 1988 prevailing exchange rate of 113.45 pesetas per $1.00. The company said each Banco Santander ADS is equivalent to one ordinary Spanish Banco Santander share.

title: Atlantic Richfield Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the 1989 results reflect a $345 million charge for future environmental expenses and other provisions, as well as 50 percent less contribution from the earnings of Lyondell.

title: Magna Group Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Magna Group said latest fourth quarter net income included about $500,000 from the sale of two bank charters. The 1988 year earnings included a net gain of $1.2 million, or 10 cents a share, from the sale of the servicing rights of Magna Mortgage Co.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in some copies of Sports Pages on Jan. 10, about the Pittsburgh Penguins' victory over the New York Rangers, misidentified the Rangers' goalie. He was John Vanbiesbrouck.

title: Anti-Apartheid Rebels Tilt Toward Negotiation
description: Nearly 30 years after mounting a guerrilla struggle against South Africa's white Government, the African National Congress is moving toward an effort to negotiate for black-majority rule.

title: 'M. Butterfly' Run May Extend to March
description: The closing notice for ''M. Butterfly'' went up at the Eugene O'Neill Theater last night, but the show may remain there until March when ''Cat on a Hot Tin Roof'' is to move in. David Henry Hwang's drama, which won three Tony awards, opened on Broadway on March 20, 1988.

title: No-Frills Mathematics Instruction
description: THERE is plenty of educational software, much of it so enhanced with color and pictures that learning seems like a game. Nothing is wrong with that, especially for younger children, but sometimes a more straightforward approach can be refreshing, especially for older students.

title: U.S. Set to Ease High-Tech Curb On Eastern Bloc
description: Under intense pressure from American business and Western European allies to relax curbs on exports of high technology to Eastern Europe, the Bush Administration said today that it would work toward opening the door.

title: Bandag Inc. reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Accounts
description: * Brioschi, an antacid, to Taylor-Gordon, Aarons & Company, with a budget of $1 million.

title: Israel Releases a Leading Palestinian
description: The Israeli authorities released a leading Palestinian nationalist from jail on bond today as they continued investigating charges that he helped organize potentially violent activities in the Arab uprising.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Addendum
description: The Block Group, New York, a public relations and promotional marketing firm, has merged with the graphics division of Everett Studios, White Plains. The new firm, Block Everett Nardizzi, will have offices in those cities and will be based in Stamford, Conn.

title: Chrysler Deal to Make Mini-Vans in Europe
description: Hoping to transfer the success of its popular mini-van overseas, the Chrysler Corporation said today that it had signed a preliminary agreement with an Austrian manufacturer to produce mini-vans for the European market.

title: Federal Paper Board reports earnings for 16wks to Dec 31
Professor at Harvard To Head Benckiser Unit
description: ''This is a good chance to practice what I preach,'' said Thomas V. Bonoma, a Harvard Business School profesor who has written 17 books on marketing. Mr. Bonoma has been named president of Benckiser Consumer Products Inc., the maker of Electrasol dishwasher detergent and other household brands.

title: Final Score on Panama
description: President Garcia of Peru refuses to meet with President Bush on drug issues . . . Colombia discourages the U.S. Navy from patrolling its coasts . . . Mexican and Venezuelan leaders stiff-arm Vice President Quayle. Has the Bush Administration relieved its Noriega headache at the cost of paralyzing itself elsewhere in Latin America? Not necessarily. But recovering Latin good will will require renewed attention to the style and substance of several sensitive issues.

title: Putnam Trust Co. of Greenich reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
First Interstate Shows Loss
description: The First Interstate Bancorp of Los Angeles, hit hard by losses on real estate loans at its Texas and Arizona bank subsidiaries, announced a large loss yesterday for the fourth quarter and a deficit for all of 1989.

title: G.M. Saturn Plant Makes Friends
description: The $2 billion Saturn project, which General Motors hopes will prove it can match the best from Japan on its own, will not begin production until June. But there are early indications of success in a number of ways, say experts who have criticized G.M. in the past, as well as workers and managers at the new plant here.

title: California State Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Bankruptcy Is Better for Petitioners in America
description: Four recent articles in Business Day about the bankruptcy filing of Federated Stores Inc. - one on Jan. 20, one on Jan. 23 and two on Tuesday - misidentified the United States trustee who is overseeing the proceedings. He is Conrad Morgenstern.

title: Rule to Widen Trading In Options Takes Effect
description: A new Securities and Exchange Commission rule that will allow stock options to be traded on more than one exchange went into effect today.

title: Consolidated Papers reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Our Towns;   Where Muscles And Characters Are Being Built
description: It was a Saturday morning meeting of the Trenton Volcanoes, and 15-year-old Lewis Williams led the opening prayer. He gave thanks for Brother James and the others who were helping out, and concluded with a special supplication.

title: Jets and Perles Remain In Limbo on Coach's Job
description: The confusion surrounding the Jets' coaching job became more confusing today as Dick Steinberg, the team's newly appointed general manager, intimated that he had offered the job to George Perles of Michigan State but later seemed to back off.

title: Britain Raises an Objection To Goldsmith's B.A.T. Offer
description: The British Government has issued a preliminary objection to a proposal by Sir James Goldsmith to acquire two of the British-based insurance subsidiaries of B.A.T. Industries, the conglomerate that has been the target of a takeover attempt by Sir James for six months.

title: Corrections
description: An article on the Consumer's World page on Saturday about water-treatment devices gave an incorrect number for the safe-drinking-water hot line of the Environmental Protection Agency. Its number is (800) 426-4791.

title: Teco Energy reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago share earnings included an 11-cent-a-share writeoff of coal mining assets by Teco's coal mining subsidiary in November 1988.

title: Upheaval in the East: Yugoslavia;   Yugoslav Communists Vote To End Party's Monopoly
description: The Yugoslav Communist Party voted today to give up its 45-year monopoly on power and to permit a new political system in which other parties may compete.

title: Man Who Burned His Son in 1983 Is to Be Freed From California Jail
description: A man who set fire to his son in 1983 in what he said was a murder-suicide plan leaves prison on Wednesday, but prison officials are keeping relocation plans secret.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: Defense Tactics in the AIDS Doctor's Suit
description: In the course of their work, lawyers have to wear many hats - as advocates, counselors, publicity agents and confessors. And, as the recent experience of Stanley Friedman, a lawyer for the New York City Health and Hospitals Corporation makes clear, at least some of those hats must be black.

title: Luang Prabang Journal;   If the Buddha Is Laughing, There's a Good Reason
description: This large village on the Mekong River, deep in the interior of a landlocked and underdeveloped country, was once a royal capital and, with its dozens of pagodas, also a capital of the celebration of Buddha.

title: BellSouth Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included extraordinary loss of $22.3 million on early extinguishment of debt and a gain of $68.4 million from the cumulative effect of a change in accounting methods. The company said its 1989 results were favorably impacted by $89 million in payments associated with the termination of Bellsouth's agreement to merge its domestic cellular business with that of Lin Broadcasting Corp. The company also said the acquisition of MCCA, completed last April, diluted earnings in 1989.

title: Kashmiris Clash With India Troops for Second Day
description: Bitter clashes between Indian troops and pro-independence crowds defying curfews continued for the second day today in Kashmir, where the death toll is said to have risen to around 50, reports from the area said.

title: Bush Talks in Gentler Tone To Abortion Foes in Capital
description: Tens of thousands of anti-abortion demonstrators marched from the White House to the Capitol and the Supreme Court today after President Bush praised their cause with more restraint than he did on the same occasion a year ago.

title: Review/Music;   A Trio Performs a Prize-Winning Work
description: Aequalis, the piano, cello and percussion trio that performed at Merkin Concert Hall on Saturday evening, may seem oddly constituted. But contemporary-music groups that commission new works, as Aequalis does, have the luxury of calling their own shots in the realm of instrumental deployment.

title: Harris Bankcorp Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Western Digital reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 30
description: b-Included gain of $1.1 million from open market purchase of $7.5 million face value of the company's 9-percent convertible subordinated debentures due 2014.

title: Georgetown Survives Scare
description: A driving layup by Alonzo Mourning put Georgetown ahead with 18 seconds left and the Hoyas held on for a 70-69 victory over Villanova tonight in a Big East Conference game.

title: American Wheat Habit Was Killing Nigeria;   African Multiplicity
description: To the Editor:

title: Article 877190 -- No Title
description: The Florida Power and Light Company issued $50 million worth of sinking-fund preferred stock yesterday through Merrill Lynch Capital Markets. The Miami-based utility is selling 500,000 shares of $100 sinking-fund preferred, with a yield of 8 5/8 percent. Nonrefundable for five years, the stock features sinking-fund payments that begin in 1996 and reduce the outstanding shares by 5 percent each year.

title: Amerada Hess Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a charge of $30,300,000 for capitalized exploration expenses related to certain properties for which the company had no current development plans for both the quarter and year.

title: Review/Television;   For Good or Bad, Exposing a Demagogue
description: There are two ways to look at ''So Proudly We Hail,'' if you are going to look at it at all: as an effort to bring some real political and social issues to the tube in the form of entertainment, or as the exploitation of those issues for prime-time purposes.

title: Art Institute of Chicago Receives Two Grants
description: The Art Institute of Chicago has been given $1 million by a Hong Kong businessman and a grant from a Japanese newspaper to complete a renovation of its Asian art collection, one of the largest in North America.

title: Sports People: COLLEGE FOOTBALL;   Arkansas Names Coach
description: One day after Ken Hatfield resigned as head coach at the University of Arkansas to fill the same job at Clemson, the Razorbacks named Jack Crowe, the offensive coordinator at Arkansas, as Hatfield's successor. Last year, Hatfield hired Crowe, 41, from Clemson, where he had been the quarterback coach and offensive coordinator.(AP)

title: Antibiotics Cut Infection If Used Before An Operation
description: A DOSE of an antibiotic given to patients before they undergo breast surgery or hernia operations sharply reduces post-operation infections, a new study has found.

title: African Wildlife Parks: Is Less Wild the Way of the Future?
description: AT high noon, in the glaring sun that washes out the sky to a barely perceptible blue, cars jam the paved roads in Kruger National Park as visitors peer from windows and sun roofs at a cluster of elephants or a pride of lions.

title: American Wheat Habit Was Killing Nigeria
description: To the Editor:

title: Ethyl Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After income of $11,864,000, or 10 cents a share, from discontinued operations. c-After income from discontinued operations of $4,066,000, or 3 cents a share, for the quarter and $36,717,000, or 30 cents a share, for the year. The company said year-ago quarter and prior year results are restated to reflect the spinoff of aluminum, plastics and energy businesses in mid- 1989.

title: Park Land Swap Steals From Our Children
description: To the Editor:

title: Student Found Guilty In Computer Jamming
description: Robert Tappan Morris, a suspended graduate student at Cornell University, was convicted of computer fraud and abuse yesterday in the disruption of a nationwide network of computers in 1988.

title: LSI Logic reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included one-time pre-tax charge of $43 million associated with restructuring manufacturing operations in the third quarter. c-Net income and after an extraordinary credit of $859,000, or 2 cents a share, for the quarter and year, from a gain on retirement of debt. The latest quarter's loss before item of $1,661,000 included payment of net interest expense caused the firm to report a loss. Interest expense in the latest quarter was $5,223,000, compared with $4,008,000 in the previous year.

title: New Theory on Spread of AIDS-Related Cancer
description: A CANCER that has been thought to be a direct result of AIDS virus infections may actually be an independent sexually transmitted disease, researchers from the Centers for Disease Control say. In a separate report, a researcher in New York City said he had seen at least eight gay men who have the cancer but not AIDS.

title: Scientists Trace Aberrant Sexuality
description: THE derailed sexuality of child molesters, exhibitionists, rapists and deviant murderers, as well as others with peculiar erotic interests that are less repugnant, has its roots in early childhood when the first links between love and sex are forged, a pioneering researcher has demonstrated.

title: Galleries: Westward Ho to Santa Monica
description: You can still be a pioneer by going west in this sprawling city, and three years ago the art dealer James Corcoran did just that. He was the first major dealer to move his gallery from West Hollywood to Santa Monica, about 10 miles away, where he says the air is cleaner and the customers are closer. Other dealers quickly followed suit, and today the Riviera-like setting could - with some license - be called the SoHo of the West Coast.

title: Loctite Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Cincinnati Microwave Inc., Cincinnati, an electronics company, said John A. O'Steen had resigned as president. James L. Jaeger, the chairman, will become interim president.

title: Sports People: Pro Football;   New Pact for Everett
description: The Los Angeles Rams quarterback Jim Everett has signed a six-year contract with the team. Everett, 27, would have become a free agent on Feb. 1. Terms were not disclosed.(AP)

title: Porwik Eliminates 16-Year-Old Galvadon
description: Angelica Gavaldon, the American amateur who had earlier upset the two-time Australian Open champion, Hana Mandlikova, lost in a quarterfinal match today to Claudia Porwik of West Germay.

title: Dow Tumbles 77.45 to End at 2,600.45
description: The stock market yesterday posted its biggest loss since Oct. 13 as the Dow Jones industrial average plummeted 77.45 points, or 2.89 percent, to 2,600.45.

title: Deals
description: Baseball

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   United Savings Shift
description: United Savings Association of Texas FSB has chosen GSD&M Advertising for its $9 million advertising and marketing account, which was formerly at Winius-Brandon Advertising/Houston.

title: BRIEFS
description: * Colgate-Palmolive Co., the maker of health products and toilet articles, extended until Friday its $14-a-share offer for Vipont Pharmaceutical Inc., Fort Collins, Colo. The offer was to have expired yesterday.

title: Ranieri, Wilson Founder Quits
description: Less than two years after helping to found Ranieri, Wilson & Company, a small, New York investment firm, Kendrick R. Wilson 3d will be stepping down as president and leaving the company.

title: Marine Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Intergraph Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest year's share earnings included 17 cents a share from gain on sales of investments in affiliated companies.

title: 49er Offense's Unknown Factor
description: After William (Bubba) Paris left the University of Michigan as an all-America tackle in 1982 and became the first offensive lineman Bill Walsh used a first draft pick to select, the hoopla and optimism over Paris's career crumbled in one play. In the San Francisco 49ers' last preseason game that year, Paris crushed his right knee so severely against the Seattle Seahawks that doctors said his career was probably finished. Paris would not believe it. ''I made up my mind that I would play again,'' Paris recalled in an interview late last week. ''I prayed. I went to a prayer meeting at Christ Temple church in Menlo Park near our training facility, and a linebacker on our team then, Willie Harper, went with me. In the services, they laid their hands on my knee. It was the start of me coming back, all the way.''

title: Madrid Jolted by Influence-Peddling Charges
description: Less than three months after winning a third successive term in office, Spain's Socialist Government has been shaken by accusations of influence-peddling by the brother of the Deputy Prime Minister.

title: Penn Central Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $9,300,000, or 13 cents a share.

title: Tyson Foods reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 30
Dime Financial Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Supreme Court Roundup;   Justices, 5-4, Say an Impartial Jury Needn't Be a Cross-Section
description: The Supreme Court ruled today that while the Constitution requires juries to be drawn from a fair cross-section of the community that cross-section need not be reflected in the composition of a particular jury.

title: 6 Days Before Kickoff, Party Begins
description: Super Bowl XXIV may be six days away, but this city of good times has begun to let the good times flow.

title: President Is Named At Prime Computer
description: Prime Computer Inc. yesterday named as its new president John J. Shields, a former senior vice president at the Digital Equipment Corporation, and said he would become chief executive in a year.

title: New A.T.&T. Plan On Service Breaks
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said yesterday that in the event of another serious service disruption to its long-distance network, its operators will tell customers how to place calls on other long-distance carriers. When A.T.& T.'s long-distance network suffered a computer failure last week that disrupted millions of telephone calls, its operators refused to tell subsribers how to reach competing carriers.

title: 'City of Angels' Songs Echo the Jazzy Youth Of Their Composer
description: When Cy Coleman sat down to the write the score for the hit musical ''City of Angels,'' the composer, whose theater music has ranged in style from circus tunes (''Barnum'') to comic opera (''On the 20th Century,'') reached back for inspiration to his youthful career as a jazz pianist.

title: Strategic Arms Talks Resume
description: United States-Soviet talks on long-range nuclear weapons resumed today, and negotiators expressed confidence that they could meet the Malta summit goal of completing a treaty this year. An agreement was signed allowing trial inspections of each side's nuclear warheads, with the goal of finding ways to insure that the number of warheads on each missile does not exceed the agreed limit. The negotiations are intended to reduce the number of long-range missiles on each side by 30 to 50 percent.

title: Phelps Dodge Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Reflected a non-recurring aftertax charge of $237 million, or $6.79 a share, for the quarter and $6.62 a share for the year, for the write-downs of certain non-producing assets. The per-share figures are different for the quarter and year because of a difference in the company's average shares outstanding. c-Reflected a $50 million pretax charge for temporarily closed facilities. d-Net income

title: Upheaval in the East: Azerbaijan;   Story of Action in Baku Is Framed in Questions
description: Between the tight rationing of official information and the unchecked explosion of rumors presented as fact, the outside world can still claim only an incomplete picture of what happened Saturday when Soviet troops rolled into Baku.

title: Using the Toxin From Tiny Frogs, Researchers Seek Clues to Disease
description: THE tiny dart-poison frogs of the American tropics are helping scientists understand nerve and muscle cell functions that play a central role in a variety of devastating disorders, from abnormal heart rhythms to Alzheimer's disease.

title: The Greeks Said It
description: To the Editor:

title: Harry Traulsen Sr., 82, Refrigeration Executive
description: Harry Traulsen Sr., founder of Traulsen & Company, a commercial refrigeration business in Queens, died yesterday at his home in Manhattan after a long illness. He was 82 years old and also lived in Deering, N.H.

title: Article 931390 -- No Title
description: Merrill Lynch & Company yesterday reported the full cost of its mammoth reorganization effort that began last November, saying that it would take a charge of $470 million against earnings for the last quarter of 1989 to pay for it.

title: Ahmanson's Profits Dip; Great Western Shows a Loss
description: H.F. Ahmanson & Company, the nation's largest savings and loan company, today reported a slight decrease in earnings for the fourth quarter because of higher tax payments.

title: Londontown Corp.
description: The Londontown Corporation, which makes London Fog clothing, said yesterday that it had retained Kidder, Peabody & Company to find ways to reduce its debt from a management buyout. Mark Lieberman, the company's chairman and president, said Londontown hopes to restructure the debt to reduce its interest burden. In 1988, Interco Inc. of St. Louis sold Londontown, based in Eldersburg, Md., for $178 million to a group of senior Londontown managers.

title: Will Clark Package Zooms to $15 Million
description: Will Clark jumped to the top of baseball's salary list today when he agreed to a $15 million, four-year contract with the San Francisco Giants that calls for the first $4 million salary in baseball history.

title: ARREST OF BARRY CONCERNS N.A.A.C.P.
description: Benjamin Hooks, executive director of the N.A.A.C.P., said today that his organization would investigate the arrest of Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. in response to ''widespread concern'' among black Americans that the case was racially motivated.

title: Withholding Cut in Belgium
description: In an attempt to stem a flight of capital, the Belgian Government approved plans today to reduce its rate of withholding tax on investors' interest income.

title: PLOT ON BUSH'S JET POSSIBLE, U.S. SAYS
description: United States intelligence has picked up indications that Colombian drug traffickers may be planning to attack President Bush when he visits the city of Cartagena next month for a four-nation meeting on narcotics, Administration officials said tonight.

title: A CORPORATE LAG IN RESEARCH FUNDS IS CAUSING WORRY
description: For the first time in 14 years, spending on corporate research and development in the United States has not even kept pace with inflation, raising concerns that the nation is lagging in its efforts to hold a competitive edge in high technology.

title: Hartford Steam Boiler Insur reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Cardinal Szoka Leaving Detroit for Vatican
description: Edmund Cardinal Szoka of Detroit announced yesterday that he would be resigning as the Roman Catholic Archbishop of Detroit to take up new duties in June, heading the Vatican's budget office.

title: Coaching Change
description: Texas A&M's Shelby Metcalf, the winningest coach in Southwest Conference basketball history, was relieved of his duties today and reassigned within the athletic department.

title: Raids Reported at Radio Stations As Crackdown Goes On in Haiti
description: The military Government continued its crackdown on dissent today with police raids that halted broadcasts by three independent radio stations in the northern port of Cap-Haitien, a witness said.

title: Saudi Oil Find Said to Be Vast
description: A newly discovered Saudi oilfield yielding high-quality light crude could have recoverable reserves of at least 30 billion barrels, the Middle East Economic Survey said today.

title: Upheaval in the East: Iran;   CROSSINGS TO IRAN SAID TO BE CLOSED
description: The official Iranian radio said today that the Soviet Union had sealed its border with Iran in the Azerbaijan region, allowing Soviet Azerbaijanis who had gone to Iran to return but permitting no further travel across the border by Soviet citizens.

title: Bancorp Hawaii Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Bancorp Hawaii said excluding the effects of the 1988 sale of the Waikiki property and non-recurring expenses, its 1988 net income would have been $62,197,000 or $4.36 a share.

title: American Home Products Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said shares outstanding during each period is assuming full conversion of preferred stock. The results for 1988 and 1989 have been restated to include the operations of A.H. Robins Company, which was merged into the company on Dec. 15, 1989 and accounted for as a pooling of interests transaction.

title: Thieves Hoist Mobile by Calder
description: Art thieves removed a glass dome from atop a Madison Avenue gallery over the weekend and stole a mobile designed by Alexander Calder valued at $1.4 million dollars, the police said last night.

title: Upheaval in the East;   Azerbaijan Vows to Secede if Soviet Troops Stay
description: The Parliament of Azerbaijan today demanded the prompt withdrawal of Soviet troops from the republic's battered capital and threatened secession if the demand was not met.

title: Sports People: PRO BASKETBALL;   Gervin Gets a Break
description: A San Antonio judge yesterday agreed to extend the terms of the former San Antonio Spurs guard George Gervin's probation, sparing Gervin an arrest on probation violation charges.

title: United Technologies Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago full-year results included a charge of $148.8 million from restructuring actions. The company also said that in the first half of 1988, it sold two subsidiaries and its share in a German joint venture for a total pre-tax gain of $197.4 million. In the third quarter of 1988, it sold additional subsidiaries, resulting in a pretax gain of $33.3 million.

title: Gateway Bancorp Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago per share earnings adjusted for a 10 percent stock dividend paid in April 1989.

title: Bridge
description: The idea of ''instant match points'' was a brilliant conception, and is gaining in popularity. Immediately a deal is played, the players are made aware of their match-point scores, predetermined by the organizers on the basis of a past tournament and unrelated to the other tables in the same location.

title: Nuclear Winter Theorists Pull Back
description: SINCE 1983, scientists have been bitterly divided over whether a nuclear war is likely to result in a catastrophic global chilling. But the five scientists who introduced the term ''nuclear winter'' now acknowledge that they overestimated its severity, and their concession appears to have moderated the longstanding debate.

title: National Convenience Stores reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Players From Outskirts Who Bide Their Time
description: When Tim Crawford makes a rare trip from his cozy seat on the Notre Dame bench to the scorers' table at the Joyce Athletic and Convocation Center in South Bend, Ind., the eager crowd steadily increases its roar. When Crawford steps onto the basketball court, thousands of fans give him a standing ovation.

title: Golden West Financial Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Columbia First Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a net gain of $1.1 million related to settlement of litigation.

title: Dichter Anniversary
description: The final sonatas of Beethoven and Schubert are to be performed in a special concert by the pianist Misha Dichter on Feb. 15 at 8 P.M. at Carnegie Hall. Mr. Dichter will celebrate the 30th anniversary of his first public performance with the concert, which is also to include works by Brahms and Schumann. Tickets range from $5 to $35. Information: 247-7800.

title: National Westminster Banorp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The company said in the latest year its loan loss provisions included a special $295 million provision related to lesser developed countries. Loan loss provisions in the latest quarter and year included additions of $15.4 million and $39.9 million, respectively, reflecting chargeoffs resulting from the deterioration of the real estate construction market in New Jersey. The company did not report per share data; it is 100 percent owned by its parent, National Westminster Bank Plc.

title: Tandy Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Few Blessings But Still Some For Neediest
description: No matter how deep their own pain nor desperate their problems, some people are determined to give what they can to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund.

title: Love Gets in the Way as 'Rocky V' Starts Filming
description: Sylvester Stallone is to Philadelphia what Woody Allen is to Manhattan, though that comparison is not quite right because this city has so few other nationally known celebrities except Julius (Dr. J) Erving, the retired star of the Philadephia 76ers basketball team.

title: Charles Stuart Capitalized on Racial Fears
description: To the Editor:

title: The Story of Yugoslavia
description: 1918: In the aftermath of World war I, the Kingdom of Serbs, Croats and Slovenes is proclaimed. In 1929, it takes the name Yugoslavia. The movements for unification led by Serbia had been a major cause of the war. In 1914 only Serbia (including present-day Macedonia) and Montenegro were independent; Croatia, Slovenia and Bosnia and Herzegovina were under the Austro-Hungarian monarchy.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Business Week Venture
description: Business Week magazine and Hirlapkiado Vallalat, a Budapest publishing company, have agreed to publish Business Week Hungary beginning in May, with articles culled from Business Week and Business Week International.

title: Ahmanson (H.F.) & Co.  (N) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the latest quarter included a 5 cent-a-share after-tax profit from real estate operations, down from 26 cents in the year-ago quarter. Latest year included 7 cent-a-share after-tax gain on the sale of loans and mortgage-backed securities, down from 21 cents a share in 1988. Latest year also included a 21 cent- a-share after-tax profit from real estate operations, down from 32 cents a share in 1988.

title: Johnson Is Lakers' Man for All Positions
description: The Los Angeles Lakers, here tonight for their annual visit to play the Knicks at Madison Square Garden, are doing many different things to compensate for Kareem Abdul-Jabbar's retirement.

title: Journalist Reports Hearing Shots in Albania
description: A Hungarian radio correspondent in the Albanian capital, Tirana, reported hearing shooting outside the city today gut said it might have been from army training.

title: Keycorp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain on sale of capital assets of $20,427,000 for the quarter and year.

title: United Federal Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included pre-tax charge of $55,000 reflecting effect of marking to market the bank's high yield investment portfolio, and a pre-tax gain of $815,000 on the partial sale of Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp. preferred stock. There were no per share earnings in year-ago periods because United Federal converted from mutual to stock ownership on Feb. 15, 1989. Prior year results were affected by the reinstatement of the Pennsylvania mutual thrift institutions tax.

title: Upheaval in the East;   East Germany Discloses Serious Accident at Nuclear Plant in 1976
description: The East German Government said today that a power plant on its Baltic coast had suffered the country's ''most serious and grave'' nuclear accident in 1976, and that a single pump might have prevented the reactor's radioactive core from melting down after a fire.

title: At Clinic, Goal is to Achieve Catharsis Through Sharing
description: The clinic in southern Florida that Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. of Washington entered today is run by an organization whose drug-and alcohol-treatment program is one of the most highly regarded in the country.

title: No Cleanup Is Planned For Alaska Fuel Spill
description: Coast Guard officials have decided to let nature clean up the estimated 57,600 gallons of gasoline that spilled from a grounded tanker into the scenic Inside Passage off southeastern Alaska.

title: CML Proxy Fight Planned by Jacobs
description: Spurned in his effort to acquire the CML Group Inc., Irwin L. Jacobs, the Minneapolis investor, said he planned a proxy fight for control of the board of the Acton, Mass., retail store company. Last week, directors of CML, which operates the Nature Company, Carroll Reed Stores and other retail outlets, rejected Mr. Jacobs's $25-a-share offer, which had a total value of $167.5 million.

title: Appeals Court Upholds Convictions of LaRouche and Four Others
description: The convictions of Lyndon H. LaRouche Jr. were upheld today by a Federal appeals court.

title: Crane Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $13,297,000, or 39 cents a share, from Medusa Corp. segment distributed to shareholders in October 1988. Year-ago share data is adjusted for a 50 percent stock distribution in September 1989.

title: The Marlin's Secret
description: The powerful leaping abilities and the fighting movements of the great blue marlin are a result of its flexible structure, and not the spring-like property of its backbone, as scientists once theorized, a zoologist has found.

title: Sports People: BASEBALL;   Surgery for Polonia
description: The Yankee outfielder Luis Polonia had arthroscopic surgery to remove loose cartilage from his right knee yesterday and is expected to be ready by the start of spring training. Polonia, acquired from Oakland last summer in the Rickey Henderson trade, batted .300 for the season with 3 homers and 46 runs batted in.(AP)

title: News Summary
description: International A2-17

title: Justice Fortas Told President About Case, Researcher Says
description: Associate Justice Abe Fortas of the Supreme Court violated judicial ethics about the confidentiality of cases by providing information to President Lyndon B. Johnson, a history professor says after studying newly released records of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.

title: After 400 Years, a Challenge to Kepler:He Fabricated His Data, Scholar Says
description: JOHANNES KEPLER, the father of modern astronomy, fabricated data in presenting his theory of how the planets move around the Sun, apparently to bolster acceptance of the insight by skeptics, a scholar has found.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   WPP Buys Agency
description: The WPP Group P.L.C. announced yesterday that it had acquired Thomas G. Ferguson Associates Inc., a health-care marketing and advertising communications agency based in Parsippany, N.J. Ferguson has about $130 million in billings and a client roster that includes Johnson & Johnson and the Warner-Lambert Company. The deal reportedly consists of an initial payment of $12.5 million in cash and stock, plus future payments, depending on performance, of up to $41.7 million.

title: Irving Schachtel, 80, Hearing-Aid Leader And Former Lawyer
description: Irving I. Schachtel, former president of the Sonotone Corporation, a manufacturer of hearing aids, died yesterday at his home in Manhattan after a series of strokes. He was 80 years old.

title: Legent Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included costs of $975,000 related to acquisition of Business Software Technology Inc.

title: Upheaval in the East: Espionage;   Cold-War Riddle: A Most Unusual Spy
description: From the day in 1961 that he first met F.B.I. agents in Manhattan, Donald F. seemed a most unusual spy.

title: Upheaval in the East: Rumania;   AMERICANS MISSING, BUCHAREST FRETS
description: For weeks now, Rumanians have watched a parade of high-level Western and Eastern European officials arriving in the capital of this stricken country, along with millions of dollars' worth of food and other emergency aid. Now, in puzzlement, they are asking: ''Where are the Americans?''

title: British Aid to East Bloc
description: Britain announced today that it was forming a big aid package to help the emerging democracies of Eastern Europe rebuild their economies. Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd, before flying to East Germany for a three-day visit, said a ''know-how'' fund already in place for Poland and Hungary would be extended to other countries.

title: Oryx Energy Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain of $85,00,000 from an accounting change. c-Net loss and included an after-tax charge of $260 million from the writedown of assets and other matters.

title: In Paris, Magic of Lacroix and Versace
description: The haute couture is hardly fashion's sedate old lady anymore. She parties all night. She flaunts her knees and bares slivers of flesh. She can be vampish or demure. In the spring and summer showings that began over the weekend, Christian Lacroix has already wonthe prize for imagination and vitality.

title: Man Held in Beating Death of Homeless Man After Subway Fight
description: A 39-year-old unemployed plumber, punched and spat at by a homeless man while standing on a subway platform Sunday night with his 3-year-old son, beat the vagrant so badly that he died a few hours later, the transit police said.

title:
SPORTS OF THE TIMES;

How A Game Can Reveal A Problem
description: LEAD: ''I remember the Super Bowl parties when I grew up,'' Marc said. For 10 years he has been known by his first name at meetings of Gamblers Anonymous. ''There would be about 10 people that had heavy action on the game. They'd have to see every play.''

title: Corning Inc. reports earnings for 12wks to Dec 31
description: b-Included non-operating gains of $59.3 million after tax, and $61.9 million after tax, for the 12 weeks and 52 weeks, respectively, restructuring provision of $45 million after tax for both the 12 weeks and 52 weeks, and tax benefits carryforward of $300,000 (net positive impact per share of 15 cents) for the 12 weeks and $1.6 million (net positive impact per share of 19 cents) for the 52 weeks. c-Included non-operating gains of $16.4 million after tax for the 12 weeks and $96.8 million after tax for the 52 weeks, restructuring provision of $19.1 million after tax for the 52 weeks, and tax benefits carryforward of $200,000 (net negative impact per share of 3 cents) for the 12 weeks and $2.2 million (net negative impact per share of 4 cents) for the 52 weeks, and the 52 weeks also included impact of accounting change of $83.9 million. Share earnings have been adjusted to reflect the 2-for-1 stock split effective Jan. 17, 1989.

title: Out of the Welfare Roll and Into the Soup Kitchen, Albany Style
description: To the Editor:

title: F.D.A. Generic Drug Inquiry
description: The Food and Drug Administration said today that it is investigating whether a generic drug manufacturer bought large supplies of a drug from an unauthorized distributor.

title: Boise Cascade Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Servicemaster L.P. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Qintex Accord With MCA
description: LOS ANGELES, Jan. 22

title: Intel Chip Pact With Japanese
description: The Intel Corporation said today that it had formed a venture with NMB Semiconductor of Japan to manufacture and sell dynamic random access memory chips, or D-RAM's.

title: Patterns
description: Attention-Getter

title: Indian Government Lodges First Charges In Weapons Scandal
description: The Government of Prime Minister V. P. Singh formally opened a criminal investigation today into allegations of official corruption in a 1986 weapons purchase by the Indian Army.

title: Federated Asks to Keep Benefits for Employees
description: Four recent articles in Business Day about the bankruptcy filing of Federated Stores Inc. - one on Jan. 20, one on Jan. 23 and two on Tuesday - misidentified the United States trustee who is overseeing the proceedings. He is Conrad Morgenstern.

title: Avery International Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Irwin Union Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
