description: b-Included after-tax gain of $1.1 million on the sale of credit card portfolio. Per share earnings restated for 3-for-2 stock split in September 1989.

title: Organized-Crime Turncoat Testifies in gotti Prosecution
description: Prosecutors in Manhattan began presenting their evidence against John Gotti yesterday with an unusual expert witness, an admitted Mafia turncoat and informer.

title: Quaker Oats reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Britain Exempts Hong Kong From Ivory Ban
description: HONG KONG, a leading center for the manufacture and export of ivory objects, has been exempted by the British Government from a worldwide ban on the trading of ivory that went into effect last Thursday.

title: Varian Associates Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 29
Delta Air Lines reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Great Western Financial reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The company said the reduced earnings in 1989 and the loss in the latest quarter were the result of a $200 million writedown of commercial and multi-family real estate and the year- end increase in loan loss reserves. Share earnings are fully diluted.

title: BellSouth Net Up in Quarter
description: The BellSouth Corporation, a regional Bell telephone company based in Atlanta, said yesterday that its profit in the fourth quarter of 1989 rose 11.9 percent and that its earnings for the year increased 4.2 percent on relatively flat revenues in both periods.

title: American Home Profits
description: The American Home Products Corporation, a diversified health and consumer products company based in New York, said yesterday that its net income rose 19 percent in last year's fourth quarter, as sales increased 7 percent.

title: Cyprus Minerals Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said full year 1989 figures included a pre-tax gain of $6.7 million from the sale of Clay operations; full year 1988 results included a pre-tax gain of $28.9 million from the sale of assets.

title: Upheaval in the East: Emigres;   Armenians in U.S. Say the People of the Homeland Are in Danger, but What Can Be Done?
description: Khachatur Nagapityan, a track and field coach, came here from Soviet Armenia just two years ago, but he is ready to return whenever he is needed to fight for what he sees as his people's survival.

title: Lightning Is More Powerful in South
description: SCIENTISTS have long assumed that lightning strikes with the same power wherever it occurs, but a new study contradicts that notion.

title: Treasury Issues Are Down Again
description: Prices of most Treasury notes and bonds continued to slide in lethargic trading yesterday, as dealers focused on coming auctions of securities.

title: Detroit Edison Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss Year-ago results resulted from accounting changes and from the write- off of certain disallowed power plant costs.

title: 3 Bank Robbers Steal $500,000 in Brooklyn
description: Three men wearing ski masks took more than $500,000 from a Brooklyn bank yesterday in what the police described as one of the largest bank robberies in recent memory.

title: Bronco Defense's Father Figure
description: Everyone in town, in every town, seemed to know Wade Phillips's father.

title: Review/Dance;   From Doom And Death To Goofy Cavorting
description: Two facets of Jerome Robbins were on view on Sunday afternoon, when the New York City Ballet presented ''In Memory of . . .'' and ''The Four Seasons.'' The first ballet, a programmatic work inspired by its score by Alban Berg, is at its best a haunting look at that old subject, death and the maiden. The second ballet is as much about its score, here by Verdi, but it uses the music as a departure point for four acts of goofy but fairly pure classical ballet dancing.

title: Careers;   Reducing The Stress On Lawyers
description: ROGER W. TITUS made a hurried trip to New York last week for a panel discussion on how lawyers can cope with stress. The session was part of the New York State Bar Association's 113th meeting.

title: Westamerica Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Roman Vishniac, 92, a Biologist And Photographer of Jews, Dies
description: Dr. Roman Vishniac, a biologist whose brilliant talent for photography captured an extraordinary range of subjects, from Jewish life in Eastern Europe on the eve of the Holocaust to hitherto unseen life under the microscope, died of colon cancer yesterday morning at his apartment in Manhattan. He was 92 years old.

title: Bass Group Holds 5.6% Pentair Stake
description: An investment group led by Acadia Partners, a Fort Worth investment partnership that is backed by the Robert M. Bass Group Inc., has acquired a 5.6 percent stake in Pentair Inc., a St. Paul-based paper products concern. In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Acadia said that the shares were for investment.

title: Sports People: PRO HOCKEY;   Berthiaume Traded
description: Under criticism for allegedly cursing at children seeking his autograph, the goalie Daniel Berthiaume was traded yesterday by the Winnipeg Jets to the Minnesota North Stars for future considerations. Mike Smith, the general manager of the Jets, said the goalie's trade was related to his off-ice actions. Berthiaume apologized on television for swearing at autograph-seekers, then a day later denied the incident ever took place and said he had been ordered to apologize by management.(AP)

title: Monsanto Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included one-time, after-tax gain of $36 million from the sale of analgesics business.

title: Daily News Reveals Its Plan To Sell Its Routes to Drivers
description: Executives at The Daily News released the details yesterday of their tentative plan to sell the right to deliver the paper to newsstands and stores in many areas.

title: Integrated Programs
description: INTEGRATED programs typically combine several applications in one package, including a word processor, a spreadsheet, a data base, a communication module, a program for creating charts, etc., and perhaps some other odds and ends, like a macro generator or a calendar or a grammar checker.

title: Barry Case Puts Political Spotlight on Jackson
description: The fall of Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. has created a hard political choice for the Rev. Jesse Jackson, who is under enormous pressure to enter the race for mayor here.

title: Chronicle
description: PRINCESS ANNE of Britain denied reports yesterday that she was planning to divorce her estranged husband, MARK PHILLIPS, despite their six-month separation.

title: Senior Note Issue Priced by Kroger
description: The Kroger Company, the large Cincinnati-based retail food company, yesterday priced $250 million in senior notes due in 1998 through Goldman, Sachs & Company. Underwriters offered the notes at par, to yield 11 1/8 percent, with interest on the securities payable March 15 and Sept. 15 annually, beginning this March.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Shuttle Hires Consultants From Politics
description: BATTLING for the loyalty of air travelers in the Boston-New York-Washington corridor, the Trump Shuttle has retained two prominent political consultants, one Democrat and one Republican, to advise it on marketing strategy.

title: Champion International Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
MCA Taking Loss In Sale of Toy Unit
description: MCA Inc., the diversified entertainment company with interests in motion pictures, records and television, said it planned to sell its LJN Toys Ltd. subsidiary. Analysts said the toy company, which MCA acquired in 1985 for $66 million, had been losing money for the last three years. MCA said it will record a $53 million after-tax loss from discontinued operations for 1989 because of the decision to sell the company.

title: J. Ernest Wharton, 90, A Former Congressman
description: J. Ernest Wharton, a lawyer and a former Republican Congressman from upstate New York for eight terms, died of a stroke on Friday at his home in Summit, N.Y. He was 90 years old.

title: On Horse Racing;   Running Down Another 'Bias'
description: For those students of thoroughbred handicapping who believe that ''track bias'' is an overrated and abused concept, opening week at Gulfstream Park has been quite a challenge -to their beliefs and to their bankrolls.

title: INSIDE
description: Yugoslav Party Eases Grip

title: Reviews/Opera;   At a Lower Pitch, 'Fidelio' By the Lubo Company
description: Sunday afternoon's concert version of ''Fidelio'' at Alice Tully Hall was one of those events that appear more virtuous before than after the fact. Beethoven's opera was done by the Lubo Opera Company at a pitch considerably lower than today's - A equaling 430 cycles per second instead of today's A-440.

title: Market Place;   First Executive Sinks With 'Junk'
description: AS Fred Carr campaigned in New York yesterday, trying to persuade investors that there is still value in the First Executive Corporation, the company's shares tumbled in reaction to the company's large ''junk bond'' write-offs.

title: Florio Presents Plan for Reducing Car Insurance Costs About 20%
description: Laying blame for high automobile-insurance costs on the insurance industry, Gov. Jim Florio today proposed a drastic change in the way automobile insurance works in New Jersey with a plan his aides said would reduce what drivers pay to $860 annually, from $1,112, within one year.

title: Q&A
description: Whooping Cranes

title: Abrams Says He May Run for D'Amato Seat
description: Attorney General Robert Abrams said today that he was considering running for Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato's seat in 1992.

title: Chronicle
description: A new broom swept out an old rug yesterday, as PRESIDENT BUSH replaced a rug from the Reagan era.

title: Fighting Between Muslim Factions Flares in Beirut
description: Rival Shiite Muslim militiamen clashed with rockets, mortars and heavy machine guns in Beirut's densely populated southern suburbs today in an expansion of a conflict that broke out in southern Lebanon a month ago.

title: Supreme Court Says Strike By Lawyers Violated Law
description: Rejecting free-speech arguments, the Supreme Court ruled today that a group of criminal defense lawyers here violated Federal antitrust law six years ago when the lawyers refused to accept more cases representing indigent defendants until the local government raised their pay.

title: Profits Mixed at 3 Big Oil Companies
description: Sharply higher oil prices and natural gas production helped offset reduced profits from chemical, refining and marketing operations in the fourth quarter at Amoco Inc. and ARCO, the oil companies said today.

title: Grey Names Directors For Cover Girl Account
description: Grey Advertising has found the creative leadership it was seeking for the Noxell Corporation's Cover Girl account, which the agency won from Lintas in November.

title: Prosecutors Seek More Time to Prepare Noriega Case
description: The Government today asked for more time to produce documents in the drug-trafficking case of Manuel Antonio Noriega, an action that defense lawyers derided as evidence that the prosecution was unprepared.

title: Brother Luke, Teacher And a Missionary, 95
description: Brother Cornelius Luke, an educator, missionary and former overseer of educational training centers for the Brothers of the Christian Schools, died of complications of diabetes on Monday at De La Salle Hall in Lincroft, N.J. He was 95 years old and had retired to De La Salle in 1983.

title: Accounts
description: * Solow Realty Company, to Great Scott Advertising, for several residential properties, with a budget of $2 million.

title: Alan K. Magary, Executive, 78
description: Alan K. Magary, a former executive of Seth Thomas, the clockmaker, died on Saturday at his home in Woodbury, Conn., after a long illness. He was 78 years old.

title: Woman in the News;   Putting a Rational Face on a Government in Turmoil
description: ''Process'' was the watchword in Marion Barry's administration back in 1979. The administration was new and full of promise, and Carol Thompson had just been hired in the city's housing department. Process. It meant: Figure out how to make a decision, get all the information, check all the bases, and know all the pitfalls.

title: Upheaval in the East: Czechoslovakia;   COMMUNISTS DELAY A SHIFT IN PRAGUE
description: Angry at the way their party has been steadily yielding power since the popular uprising last November, Communist members of the Czechoslovak Parliament balked briefly today at an agreement to give up their legislative majority. Later, they approved the law requiring them to surrender 90 to 100 of the seats they have held.

title: Ferranti Deal Set
description: The General Electric Company of Britain will buy the business and assets of the Ferranti Defense Systems Group, based in Edinburgh, and part of Ferranti's interests in Italy in a deal worth $:310 million, the Ferranti board said. Ferranti Defense Systems Group is a subsidiary of Ferranti International P.L.C., which was seeking a rescue from the effects of a reported fraud by a United States subsidiary.

title: Midlantic Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After $75 million addition to the provision for possible loan losses, which reduced after-tax earnings by $49.5 million, or $1.25 a share. The per share earnings are fully diluted.

title: Franklin Resources Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago quarter share earnings and shares outstanding are restated for a 3-for-2 stock split paid Jan. 15, 1990 to shareholders of record Dec. 31, 1989.

title: Japan Parliament Dissolved; Elections Are Set for Feb. 18
description: Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu dissolved the lower house of Parliament today, clearing the way for national elections on Feb. 18 in which the governing Liberal Democratic Party is considered virtually certain to lose a large number of seats.

title: Greater N.Y. Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After extraordinary credits of $873,000, or 6 cents a share, for the quarter, and $7,107,000, or 56 cents a share, for the year, both from realization of federal income tax benefits of net operating loss carryforward. c-After extraordinary credits of $2,164,000, or 17 cents a share, for the quarter and $5,589,000, or 44 cents a share, for the year, both from realization of federal income tax benefits of net operating loss carryforward.

title: Merck & Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Transcanada Pipelines reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $13,400,000. c-Net loss and included losses from discontinued operations of $13,400,000 and $80,900,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. Results for 1989 included a tax benefit of $21.1 million, or 14 cents a share. For the first 9 months, the company reported a tax benefit of $14.6 million, or 10 cents a share. The benefit in the fourth quarter is an estimated $6.5 million, or 4 cents a share. Figures are in Canadian funds. Some year-earlier figures have been restated due to an accounting change.

title: Shortage of Ph.D.'s Imminent, Report Says
description: A study by university deans predicts an intense tug of war among government, industry and academia for people with doctorate degrees.

title: Howard A. Golieb, Broker, 77
description: Howard A. Golieb, a stockbroker and account executive, died of pneumonia on Sunday at New York Hospital. He was 77 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Military Erred in Cocaine Report
description: The Pentagon today retracted claims made after the Panama invasion that United States soldiers had found a large cache of cocaine in a guest house used by Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega.

title: Dahlen Gives Nicholls His Number, Then Scores Twice
description: It was an act of humility and decency, and it didn't take Ulf Dahlen more than a minute to make. Dahlen, who has worn No. 9 throughout his brief career with the Rangers, met Bernie Nicholls, the high-profile acquisition from Los Angeles who had worn No. 9 with the Kings, and immediately offered to give up his jersey.

title: Washington Talk;   'Umbrella' on Abortion Delays G.O.P. Decision
description: Republicans have grown adept at pursuing two-track strategies, with the White House sending one message and party leaders another.

title: The Pop Life
description: 'Under My Skin'

title: Barkley and Thomas Fined for Altercations
description: Charles Barkley of the Philadelphia 76ers and Isiah Thomas of the Detroit Pistons were among seven players fined for incidents during National Basketball Association games last week.

title: 'Points of Light' for Poland: Seed, Tools, Feed
description: LEAD: A looming confrontation between farmers and city dwellers threatens Poland's brave plunge into market-oriented reform. Already, Lech Walesa is expending his political capital shuttling between restive workers, who demand affordable food, and angry farmers, who are withholding grain for higher prices.

title: Voting Proposals Don't Meet New York's Needs
description: To the Editor:

title: Coach K. Gives Stately Duke an Undignified Jolt
description: Along with a reputation for clever and intimidating cheers, the students at Duke University relish their inspirational role in the performance of the school's basketball team. Mike Krzyzewski, the head coach, has gone to considerable lengths to foster that involvement, often lauding the students as his squad's ''sixth man.''

title: Europe Sets Prices for Japan's Chips
description: The European Community said today that it would set minimum prices for computer memory chips sold by Japanese manufacturers.

title: No Headline
description: TO 46-year-old Ina Pinkney, this is the Decade of the Blobb.

title: Freeport McMoran Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included after-tax loss of $1,022,000 and an after-tax gain of $26,678,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Included after-tax gains of $8,471,000 for the quarter and $141,530,000 for the year.

title: Moody's Cuts Some Merrill Debt Ratings
description: Moody's Investors Service downgraded more than $12 billion in debt of Merrill Lynch & Company yesterday, one day after the firm announced that the full cost of its reorganization effort begun last November would be $470 million.

title: Mobil Says Earnings Fell 3.2%
description: The Mobil Corporation, the nation's second-largest energy company, said today that its fourth-quarter earnings declined 3.2 percent.

title: Dow Rebounds by 14.87 to Close at 2,615.32
description: Stock prices were mixed yesterday, with the blue chips accounting for much of the gains in the popular averages.

title: Upheaval in the East: Hungary;   Hungarian Prime Minister Reports That Moscow Has Agreed to Withdraw Its Troops
description: The Hungarian Prime Minister told Parliament today that Moscow had agreed in principle to withdraw its troops from Hungary.

title: Why There's No U.S. Market for Electric Cars
description: To the Editor:

title: Chinese Quietly Cripple Policies of Crackdown
description: It was a whodunit with a twist: everyone knew the name of the culprit, except the detectives. They were searching for the person who had hung a banner from the Xiehe Hospital, welcoming the changes in Rumania, but nobody would tell the police who did it.

title: Bofors to Cut Jobs
description: Bofors A.B., Sweden's largest weapons producer, will cut its work force by 500 because of falling orders from the Swedish military. The decision, which is to take effect July 1, follows a reduction last October of 1,300 workers. Bofors had counted on continued orders from India, but they were suspended amid allegations that Bofors paid bribes to secure a $1.3 billion artillery sale in 1986. In all, the number of Bofors employees will be cut to about 3,000.

title: Upheaval in the East;   Where Fear and Death Went Forth and Multiplied
description: The dictatorship of President Nicolae Ceausescu caused extreme hardships for all but a few hundred thousand of Rumania's 23 million citizens. But in the case of mothers and babies, his rule apparently had the most tragic consequences.

title: Addenda
description: * Earle Palmer Brown has signed a letter of intent to buy the Madison Public Affairs Group in Washington.

title: Books of The Times;   A Satire on the Brezhnev Era From 2044
description: Astrophobia

title: Mother of Slain Baby In Deal to Avoid Prison
description: A woman who confessed last year to killing her baby in 1952 reached a plea bargain with prosecutors today that is likely to allow her to avoid a prison term.

title: CHRONICLE
description: When a forum on the environment ended in Moscow Friday, it was after sundown. So RABBI ARTHUR SCHNEIER, the senior rabbi of Park East Synagogue in Manhattan, promptly conducted a sabbath service. In a hallway in the Kremlin.

title: Drug Maker Says It May Have Given Investigators Bad Data
description: Lawyers for a generic drug company say it submitted what appear to be false documents in an effort to block the removal of one of its main products from the market.

title: Santa Fe Pacific Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a pre-tax restructuring charge of $389.6 million for the quarter and year; the year also included a gain of $210 million, or $1.32 a share, from the cumulative effect on prior periods of an accounting change. c-Net income and after income of $33.4 million, or 21 cents a share, from discontinued operations. d-Net loss and after a loss of $193.2 million from discontinued operations. e-Included a gain of $136 million on the sale of 56 percent of its pipeline operations in December 1988 for both periods.

title: Freeport-McMoran Gold reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
U.S. Bond Auction Goes Poorly
description: The Federal Government's first auction of 40-year bonds since the mid-1950's went poorly yesterday, as investors demanded higher-than-expected interest rates on $5 billion worth of bonds issued by the Resolution Funding Corporation that will be used to finance the bailout of insolvent savings institutions.

title: Review/Jazz;   Half of Max Roach's Double Quartet
description: The Uptown String Quartet embodies a wonderful idea - a string quartet that can not only handle European classical style but that can also swing and improvise, and that plays music steeped in black American traditions. But in its enjoyable New York debut on Monday night at the 92d Street Y, the quartet - Diane Monroe and Lesa Terry on violins, Maxine Roach on viola and Eileen Folson on cello - ran up against its technical limitations. As with another jazz-inflected string quartet, the more avant-gardist Black Swan Quartet, the price of its improvisatory skills was a lack of ensemble finesse.

title: Profits Scoreboard
Chesapeake Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Elitist Visions Won't Feed China's Masses;   A Haven Then and Now
description: To the Editor:

title: Elitist Visions Won't Feed China's Masses
description: To the Editor:

title: Freeport McMoran Copper reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Radio Revenues Up
description: Network radio revenues rose by 11.9 percent last year, to $427.2 million, according to the Radio Network Association. Revenues in New York rose just 1 percent, to $224.3 million, the group said.

title: Insurance Industry Disputes Florio Attack on Profits
description: Gov. Jim Florio's plan to reduce auto-insurance premiums raises two big questions for politicians and drivers. Are insurance companies to be blamed for the high rates? And will the industry foot the bill for lower ones?

title: Bush Replaces Leadership Of Legal Services for Poor
description: In an effort to end the ideological battle that has left the Legal Services Corporation in disarray over the last eight years, President Bush has selected a new board of directors for the agency that oversees legal programs for the poor.

title: Borden Chemicals & Plastics L.P.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Lukens Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included $5.9 million pre-tax gain from sale of assets for the quarter and year; the year also included a $900,000 pre-tax gain from sale of subsidiary. c-Included $900,000 pre-tax gain from sale of subsidiary; $1 million unfavorable LIFO adjustment for quarter and year; the year also included a $1.1 million pre-tax gain from sale of a facility.

title: Search in Bombings Expands, But U.S. Names No Suspects
description: Federal investigators looking into a rash of bombings in the South expanded their search in this small southeast Alabama town today, but they made no arrests and identified no suspects.

title: Seton Hall Routs B.C. To Snap 4-Game Slide
description: A blend of youth and experience combined for 50 points tonight at the Byrne Meadowlands Arena, helping Seton Hall end a four-game losing streak and dealing Boston College its seventh consecutive defeat in Big East Conference play.

title: Haiti Imposes Restrictions On Radio News Broadcasts
description: The military government told radio stations today they may broadcast only officially approved news and nothing ''likely to incite agitation.''

title: $15 Million to Aid Partnership of Teachers, Parents and Pupils
description: The Rockefeller Foundation will spend $15 million in the next five years expanding a program that seeks to better the educational performance of poor children, especially from minorities, by promoting a shared belief in the value of education among teachers, parents and pupils.

title: Book Notes
description: Beyond the Cold War

title: In First Talk as Health Chief, Myers Tries to Calm His Foes
description: In his first appearance in New York City since being named Health Commissioner, Dr. Woodrow A. Myers Jr. faced some of his critics at an AIDS conference yesterday and struck a conciliatory tone.

title: Market Place;   Dow Back Above 200-Day Average
description: THE stock market yesterday faced a substantial technical test, one that it seems to have passed.

title: Old Stone Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included reserve additions and writedowns totaling $78.1 million. c-Net income Fourth quarter results included several significant items: a $21.3 million pre-tax gain realized on the sale of Academic Management Services Inc.; additional reserves of $9.4 million against domestic loans established in 1989's fourth quarter, compared with $4.2 million in year-ago period; provided reserves of $5.7 million related to real estate development projects while there were no similar real estate investment reserves established in 1988, and a $900,000 loss recorded on the corporation's perpetual preferred stock portfolio to reflect the loss it anticipates upon sale of the portfolio early in 1990.

title: Algeria Acts on Debt
description: Algeria has taken a step toward lightening its crippling $24 billion foreign debt by ordering state companies to restrict short-term borrowing. The central bank governor, Hadj Nasser, said in an interview that the move was part of a strategy to spread Algerian debt over a longer period, easing the immediate strain on the economy. From Jan. 5, state companies have had to pay cash for imports of under $2 million, unless they can draw on existing credit. The central bank's new Committee of Foreign Borrowings must approve any bigger short-term credit, Mr. Nasser said.

title: Martin Marietta reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Reflected for both periods a charge of $1.05 a share to provide reserve for estimated future losses on commercial Titan program, and the year also reflected a gain of $2.55 a share on sale of Hoskyns Group Plc. The year also included a tax credit of $39,100,000, or 73 cents a share.

title: Most Employers Coveting Frequent-Flier Bonus Miles
description: Corporations are increasingly wrestling with their employees to claim frequent-flier bonuses from airlines as travel costs soar and the economy slows.

title: INSIDE
description: Cool Welcome for Bonds

title: Morgan Stanley Group Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share and per-share data have been retroactively adjusted to give effect to a 3-for-2 common stock split, which became effective Feb. 27, 1989. Revenues in the latest fourth quarter included pretax investment gains of $137.7 million, principally from the restructuring of the company's investment in Container Corp. of America. Revenues for the full year 1989 included pretax investment gains of $246.5 million, compared with $159.3 million in 1988. Revenue represented total revenue.

title: Ingersoll-Rand reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After extraordinary credit of $8.5 million, or 17 cents a share, from utilization of capital loss carryforward.

title: From Hacker to Symbol
description: If the Federal Government intended to send the nation's computer hackers a message in the prosecution of Robert Tappan Morris, that message may not be clear until Federal Judge Howard G. Munson sentences the former 24-year-old computer science student.

title: Senate Opens Debate on Proposal For Stiffer Clean-Air Regulations
description: The Senate began debate today on legislation that would provide powerful new tools for removing pollution from the nation's skies.

title: Upheaval in the East: Yugoslavia;   Yugoslavia on the Brink
description: Deep in the night, when the Slovenes stalked out of the grand hall, turning their backs on the red flag, the bust of Tito and 1,000 fellow delegates, they did more than paralyze the National League of Communists, Yugoslavia's only national party.

title: Inaugural Fund For Dinkins Shows Surplus
description: As they did in his campaign for mayor, supporters of David N. Dinkins raised more than was needed for his inaugural ceremony and related activities and festivities.

title: Dinkins Appoints Advisers on Drugs And Top Positions
description: Mayor David N. Dinkins yesterday named Nicholas deB. Katzenbach, a former United States Attorney General, to head a study group to recommend a strategy for fighting drug abuse.

title: Futures Trader Pleads Guilty
description: A Treasury bond futures trader pleaded guilty on Monday to racketeering charges, in the first admission of a conspiracy to cheat customers in Chicago's futures pits.

title: Five Housing Officials Suspended in Passaic
description: Housing Secretary Jack F. Kemp has suspended five housing officials in Passaic, N.J., saying they accepted grossly excessive salaries.

title: Japan Stakes Out Nearby Markets
description: From Taipei to Bangkok to Jakarta, Japan's largest securities firms are rushing to open new offices, beef up their staffs, set up new investment funds and start joint ventures in their own backyard - Asia.

title: U.S. Petroleum Data
description: In millions of barrels except refinery utilization

title: Angolan Chief Is Said to Cancel Plans to Visit U.S.
description: Americans close to the Angolan Government said today that President Jose Eduardo dos Santos had canceled a visit to the United States scheduled for next month.

title: Bell Atlantic Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the latest quarter and year included a one-time $320 million charge associated with an early- retirement program, debt refinancings and asset revaluations.

title: CHRONICLE
description: The French celebrated the 40th birthday of SNOOPY in a manner usually reserved for loftier subjects - with a museum retrospective of his life.

title: 3M Net Grows 7.4% in Quarter
description: The Minnesota Mining and Manufacturing Company said today that its earnings increased 7.4 percent in the fourth quarter and 7.8 percent for the year.

title: Detective Saved By a Steel Vest; Suspect Is Slain
description: A police detective shot and killed a man during a struggle in Brooklyn last night after the man fired at the detective and another officer while they were hunting for robbery suspects, police officials said.

title: Upheaval in the East: Soviet Union;   AZERBAIJAN TENSE AS CLASHES GO ON AND TOLL MOUNTS
description: Sporadic clashes and a deepening mood of civil resistance were reported today from the rebellious Soviet republic of Azerbaijan as officials of the central Government talked of compromise and dialogue with separatist leaders in Baku.

title: Shearson Lehman Hutton Holdings Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Reflected a $37 million aftertax gain from the sale of the Institutional Money Management businesses of Lemco and a $16 million pretax reversal of reserves established in 1986 to cover potential losses stemming from the suspension of trading in tin by the London Metals Exchange. Offsetting these gains are a $35 million pretax writedown of MCorp securities owned by Shearson, $31 million in non-recurring pretax expenses associated with the move to Shearson Lehman Hutton Plaza and $31 million of pretax severance expenses relating to previously announced staff reductions. c-Net loss and results reflected a $70 million pretax charge from the reduction in the carrying value of MCorp securities and $21 million of pretax non- recurring expenses related to the acquisition of E.F. Hutton. d-Included $165 million of pretax non-recurring merger-related expenses associated with the firm's acquisition of E.F. Hutton Group Inc. in January 1988 and a $100 million pretax writedown of MCorp securities. Partially offsetting these charges was the $33 million pretax gain from the sale of the firm's interest in McLeod Young Weir, a Canadian securities firm. Share earnings are after preferred dividend requirements.

title: Trading Halt In Centrust
description: Federal regulators today ordered a suspension of trading in the stock of the Centrust Savings Bank because of what they called misleading and inaccurate financial reports from the troubled institution.

title: Owens Award Finalists
description: Said Aouita of Morocco, Roger Kingdom of the United States and Javier Sotomayor of Cuba are the finalists for the 1990 Jesse Owens International Trophy Award. The winner will be honored Feb. 6 at a dinner at the Waldorf Astoria. The award is given to the athlete who best personifies excellence in athletic performance and promotes understanding among people of all nations.

title: Dominion Textile reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company is listed on the Montreal Stock Exchange. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Northern Telecom Limited reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included restructuring costs of $200 million. c-Net loss

title: From Schools Comes Money For Neediest
description: The Social Studies Honor Society at Forest Hills High School in Queens held a bake sale. So did Class 2-7 at Public School 346 in Brooklyn. Class 2-102 at P.S. 221 in Little Neck, Queens, sold used games, books and toys in a white elephant sale. A fourth grade at Rye Country Day School in Rye, N.Y., did odd jobs, and the middle-school student council at the Birch Wathen School in Manhatan conducted a raffle.

title: Atwater Defuses the Doubts
description: Nine months after the Denver Broncos faced the kind of difficult decision that can determine the success or failure of a draft, it no longer seems so surprising that Steve Atwater would become an important part of a rebuilt defensive secondary.

title: Editor at People Named To Post at Putnam's
description: Andrea Chambers, an associate editor at People magazine, was named vice president and executive editor of G. P. Putnam's Sons yesterday. She will assume her new position in mid-March.

title: Harris Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 29
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $2,739,000 for the quarter and $5,182,000 for the 6 months. The company said latest quarter results included three months operating results of GE Solid State, compared with one month in the year-ago period. GE Solid State was acquired in November 1988. The latest second quarter also included the results of Lanier Worldwide, formerly Harris-3M, which became a wholly owned Harris subsidiary in April 1989.

title: Rome Journal;   Campuses Aflame Again: Just Tools of Industry?
description: From Palermo to Turin, and on more than a dozen campuses in between, Italian universities are being rocked by student protests that had all but disappeared in the passive, self-absorbed 1980's.

title: 60-Minute Gourmet
description: BUSY cooks looking for fast and easy weeknight meals seem to have an insatiable appetite for recipes that use chicken breast. That's because it is easy to pick up boned chicken breasts on the way home and prepare a full meal in well under an hour.

title: Self-Defense Claim in Subway Death
description: Saying he acted in self-defense to protect himself and his 3-year-old son, a 39-year-old Manhattan man pleaded not guilty yesterday to first-degree manslaughter charges in the death of a homeless man who had spat at him and punched him on a subway station platform.

title: More Nixdorf Cuts
description: Nixdorf Computer A.G., the troubled computer maker that has agreed to be acquired by Siemens A.G. said it would reduce its work force by about 4,880 as part of a reorganization. About 1,600 jobs, out of a total of 31,000, were cut as part of an earlier reorganization.

title: Food Notes
description: Dining for Charity

title: Corrections
description: The Advertising column of Business Day on Jan. 17 about a new account for the Lowe Marschalk agency misstated the relationship between the Interpublic Group of Companies and the Lowe Group, the owner of Lowe Marschalk. Interpublic owns 35.4 percent of the Lowe Group, not 29 percent.

title: Freeport-McMoran Energy Partners reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Merck's Net Increases by 20% in Quarter
description: Buoyed by strong gains in sales volume, Merck & Company, the world's largest drug maker, said yesterday that net income rose 20 percent in the fourth quarter of 1989 and 24 percent for the year.

title: Wine Talk
description: In 1989, for the third year in a row, Americans drank less wine than the year before. But as they have been doing regularly for more than a decade, they continued to drink more good wine: sales of premium wines, while they constitute only a tiny segment of the wine business, were up.

title: Thomas C. Renner, Author, 61
description: Thomas C. Renner, a newspaper reporter for 36 years and the author of several books about organized crime, died of heart disease on Friday at the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center in Manhattan. He was 61 years old and lived in Smithtown, L.I.

title:
VOICES OF THE NEW GENERATION;

We're Talking the Wrong Language to 'TV Babies'
description: LEAD: Generations who grew up with TV communicate differently than previous generations. Yet many have not caught on to this phenomenon. This is a problem, because we are losing the younger generation to a host of societal ills. Despite all our efforts to reach it, we're talking the wrong language.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * D. H. Blair & Co., New York, an investment banking firm, appointed Thomas N. Hennigan executive vice president of corporate finance.

title: Best Buy Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
For Scots, It's Time to Drink, Eat and Gladly Pay the Piper
description: TOMORROW, Scots the world over will celebrate the birth of Robert Burns, the plowman-poet born in 1759 who immortalized their national dish and whisky in his poems ''To a Haggis'' and ''Scotch Drink.''

title: Bemis Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Hanna (M.A.) Co.(N) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Death Sentence Ordered in Florida Slaying
description: Overriding a jury's recommendation for a life sentence, a judge today sentenced to death a man whose background as an Australian Aborigine was used in a plea for mercy after he was convicted of raping, robbing and strangling a woman.

title: Knicks Left in the Dust By Freewheeling Lakers
description: After the Los Angeles Lakers came down harder on the Knicks last night than any other opponent this season had, Stu Jackson, the New York coach, uncharacteristically came down on his team even harder.

title: Hubbell Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: All share earnings adjusted to reflect a 5 percent stock dividend Feb. 2, 1990 to shareholders of record Jan. 12.

title: Disney's Net Is Up by 17.6%
description: The Walt Disney Company reported today that its earnings for the quarter ended Dec. 31 increased 17.6 percent, but the results did not stop a slide in the company's stock price.

title: Upheaval in the East;   Havel Plan for Summit Site
description: President Vaclav Havel today offered Prague instead of Washington as the site of the next summit meeting between President Bush and President Mikhail S. Gorbachev.

title: BARRY GRAND JURY HEARS FROM MODEL
description: In a move that intensified the pressure on Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. to resign, Federal prosecutors today brought before a grand jury the former fashion model who lured Mr. Barry into a videotaped arrest on drug charges last week.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''Republicans as well as Democrats are going to vote in the House to override the President's veto. The President has simply made a mistake, but the American Congress and the American people stand very strongly with those people in China.''

title: Crazy Eddie Cash Sought
description: A Federal district judge in Newark yesterday ordered Eddie Antar, the founding owner of the Crazy Eddie electronics stores, to repatriate more than $50 million that the Securities and Exchange Commission said Mr. Antar had transferred to Israel.

title: Victory Streak Stops At 9 Games for Isles
description: For the first time in 1990, the Islanders have lost.

title: Ford to Defer Merit Raises
description: The Ford Motor Company said today that it would defer first-quarter merit pay increases for 55,000 salaried workers in the United States to cut costs in a soft and unpredictable auto market.

title: Astronaut Testifies for AIDS Doctor
description: An astronaut who is a physician and research expert testified yesterday that an AIDS researcher failed to follow proper procedures to safeguard the anonymity of Dr. Veronica Prego and others in a study of health-care workers.

title: Sinopoli to Conduct 2 Programs With Philosophical Connections
description: At a glance, the two programs in which Giuseppe Sinopoli is to conduct the Philharmonia Orchestra of London in New York might seem fairly staid. Mr. Sinopoli, believed by many to be in the running for the music directorship of the New York Philharmonic after Zubin Mehta leaves in 1991, is leading his ensemble in the Mahler First Symphony and Berlioz's ''Nuits d'Ete,'' with the soprano June Anderson, at Carnegie Hall tonight; and he is offering Brahms's Fourth Symphony and First Piano Concerto, with Andre Watts as soloist, at Avery Fisher Hall on Monday evening.

title: Boatmen's Bancshares reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss c-Included non-recurring merger expenses of $41.4 million for the quarter and $47.2 million for the year.

title: Francis H. Philp, 59, Investment Executive
description: Francis Higginson Philp, a senior vice president of the Fiduciary Trust Company International, died of a heart attack on Thursday at Presbyterian Hospital. He was 59 years old and lived in Larchmont, N.Y.

title: Cautious Course Is Charted in Kashmir
description: The new Governor of Jammu and Kashmir state, sent specially from New Delhi to deal with anti-Indian agitation by Kashmiri militants, said tonight that he will not allow Kashmir to slip away from India.

title: Jets Foiled in Effort to Hire Spartans' Perles
description: The Jets' flirtation with George Perles as their next head coach ended last night when Michigan State refused to let him out of his contract, but offered him the additional role of athletic director.

title: Colombia Envoy Angry About U.S. Trade Policy
description: Recent Bush Administration trade decisions are squeezing Colombia's earnings and making its war against cocaine trafficking more difficult, the country's Ambassador, Victor Mosquera Chaux, said today.

title: Police in Egypt Fire on Protest by Militants
description: Egyptian policemen opened fire to disperse Muslim fundamentalist demonstrators on Monday night, killing one person and arresting 12, security officials said.

title: Adaptec Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 29
Chanel Is Saucier, Ungaro Is Cooler And Venet Livelier
description: Calm, dependable Philippe Venet was supposed to provide the curtain raiser for today's blockbuster spring and summer couture collections. But it did not quite work out that way. Venet emerged with vigor from his unpreposessing mood. Emanuel Ungaro, after his recent marriage to Laura Fanfani, did not give up his sexy clothes but toned them down considerably. The hero of the day turned out to be Karl Lagerfeld, who has thoroughly assimilated the message of Chanel and put it into play for the contemporary world. The Chanel look is flourishing.

title: KEY RATES
Haircut Ordered
description: Dwayne Schintzius, the Florida center indefinitely suspended from the team for his role in a fraternity house fight, will not be allowed to return until he cuts his hair, Coach Don DeVoe said yesterday.

title: Plan to Push Unruly Homeless Out of the Subways Is Failing
description: To the frustration of Transit Authority officials and the dismay of subway riders, a campaign to purge New York City's subways of unruly homeless people has made no discernible headway after almost three months.

title: Upheaval in the East: U.S. Policy;   Congress Starts Review Of U.S. Military Posture
description: The Bush Administration and Congress began work today on what is likely to be a basic reshaping of American military strategy and spending in the wake of political and social upheavals in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe.

title: Players Try Their Way With Words
description: This was Media Day for the San Francisco 49ers, the Denver Broncos and the hundreds of reporters, photographers and camera crews already here to cover the teams' meeting Sunday in Super Bowl XXIV.

title: International Lease Finance Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Chronicling Politics as An Industry
description: HOLLYWOOD has Daily Variety to report on the business and politics of entertainment. Now, several Washington publishing professionals want the nation's capital to have a daily newspaper to chronicle the business and entertainment side of politics.

title: Gotti Lawyers Attack Tape Recordings
description: John Gotti's lawyers tried yesterday to use two prosecution witnesses to sow doubts about the central evidence - secret tape recordings - against the reputed Mafia crime leader at his assault and conspiracy trial in Manhattan.

title: IBM Credit Corp.  reports earnings for 12mo Dec 31
description: The 1988 net earnings included a one-time gain of $52.3 million for an acccounting change. The total assets totaled $9.5 billion for 1989 and $7.4 billion for 1988.

title: Real Estate;   Construction Without Loan Or Tenants
description: AS a cadre of dignitaries looked on, ground was broken on Monday for a new 28-story office tower in Fort Lee, N.J.

title: Judge Limits Poindexter Bid To Subpoena Reagan at Trial
description: John M. Poindexter must produce a list of specific questions he intends to ask former President Ronald Reagan at Mr. Poindexter's trial on charges relating to the Iran-contra affair, a Federal district judge ruled today.

title: Japanese Moon Flight Is Delayed by Problem
description: Space officials postponed Japan's first mission to the Moon just 18 seconds before liftoff today, but they said they would try again Wednesday if they could correct a technical problem.

title: Great Northern Nekoosa reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a pretax charge of $20.3 million related stock appreciation rights and stock performance units booked in the quarter. The company said the latest quarter also included a charge equal to 11 cents after-tax related expenses associated with the unsolicited offer for the company from Georgia-Pacific Corp.

title: Foreman Looms as Top Contender
description: Suddenly there is life beyond Mike Tyson in the heavyweight division.

title: No Decision Yet On Neil Bush
description: Federal regulators have not reached a decision on whether Neil M. Bush, the President's son, violated Federal banking laws as a board member of the bankrupt Silverado Banking, Savings and Loan Association in Denver.

title: On China, Trust Is Not Enough
description: Congress now has an excellent opportunity to show Beijing, and President Bush, how the American people feel about the backward-looking policies of China's fading leaders, and the Administration's shameful apologetics on their behalf. It can do so by voting this week to override Mr. Bush's veto of a measure that could help guarantee Chinese students in this country a chance to stay.

title: Disease Killing British Cattle
description: LEAD: A disease that has caused fatal brain disorders in thousands of British cows has led 18 nations, including the United States, to restrict cattle or beef imports from Britain and has raised consumer fears at home.

title: For New Year, Fish, Hong kong Style
description: BECAUSE the Chinese words for fish and for prosperity or abundance are pronounced the same - yu - fish is one of the symbolic foods for the Chinese New Year celebrations that begin Saturday.

title: Consolidated Edison reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Prior year results are restated for a 2-for-1 stock split effective June 1989.

title: Centel Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $220,901,000, or $2.61 a share which included a gain on the sale of cable television operations of $239.2 million for the quarter and $432,775,000, or $4.98 a share, which included a gain on the sale of cable television operations of $440 million for the year, and the year also included an extraordinary tax credit of $1,426,000, or 2 cents a share. c-Included income from discontinued operations of $4,505,000, or 5 cents a share and $16,486,000, or 18 cents a share for the quarter and year, respectively, and an extraordinary tax credit of $8,807,000 for both the quarter and year.

title: Metropolitan Diary
description: SCENE: Sung Tieng restaurant in Greenwich Village.

title: Allen W. Brown, Bishop, 81
description: Allen W. Brown, Bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of Albany from 1961 to 1974, died on Friday at the Meadow Wind Nursing Home in Massillon, Ohio. He was 81 years old and lived in Fort Myers, Fla., and in Massillon.

title: Why There's No U.S. Market for Electric Cars;   Experimental Models
description: To the Editor:

title: Tim Curry Plunges Ahead Into the Past, Part IV
description: Sitting in the lobby of the Manhattan Theater Club, a smile on his face, is Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart, William Shakespeare, Tristan Tzara and William Hogarth. Or, to put it another way, sitting in the lobby of the Manhattan Theater Club, a smile on his face, is the English actor Tim Curry.

title: Back to the Past in Haiti
description: Haiti's nightmare continues. There is no justification for Gen. Prosper Avril's crackdown on Haiti's moderate opposition. The promise of democracy raised by the overthrow of Jean-Claude Duvalier in February 1986 keeps receding ever further. Washington's sharp, prompt signal of disapproval is the right response.

title: It Takes Astronauts To Retrieve Satellites
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Music;   After 84 Years of Composing, a Bit of Advice: Be Flexible
description: Concerts that pay tribute to elder composers tend to fall into a pattern: a sample of the artist's works is presented, the honoree rises to acknowledge the ovation and applauds the performers whether they deserve it or not. That is that. At Monday evening's concert by the North/South Consonance entitled ''Otto Luening: 90th Birthday Salute,'' the saluted one broke with tradition: he took the Merkin Concert Hall stage and gave a remarkably succinct outline of the contemporary music movement in Europe and the Americas.

title: Haste Urged in Savings-Asset Sales
description: Congress today prodded Federal regulators charged with disposing of the assets of insolvent savings institutions to step up their pace and urged them to sell some single-family homes to low-income buyers.

title: Editors' Note
description: An article yesterday reported a decision by a New York State Senator, Nicholas A. Spano, to join the abortion-rights side in the Legislature after strongly opposing abortion.

title: Review/Theater;   'Forbidden Broadway 1990' Nips the Hand That Feeds It
description: During a dim theatrical season, an actor in ''Forbidden Broadway'' announced a parody of the current hit shows - followed by a prolonged silence. There is no such dearth of targets in ''Forbidden Broadway 1990.'' With gleeful malice, Gerard Alessandrini, as author and director, mocks Dustin Hoffman, ''City of Angels'' and that new Tommy Tune musical, ''Grim Hotel'' and throws comic brickbats at Broadway Brits. The new version of this four-person musical revue opened last night at Theater East.

title: Barnum Cues Fed Scam
description: Dr. Harold J. Liverworth, the world's foremost authority, sits for an interview on what in the name of Barnum are the Feds doing with our Social Security money. Can you tell us, Doctor, who Barnum was?

title: Francis P. Coombs, 74, A Dermatologist on L.I.
description: Dr. Francis Place Coombs, an educator and dermatologist, died of cancer Sunday at Community Hospital in Glen Cove, L.I. He was 74 years old and lived in Old Westbury, L.I.

title: Famed Restaurants In Japanese Hands
description: RESTAURANT ASSOCIATES, the trend-setting operating and consulting group that has been an important force in the American hospitality industry for nearly five decades, was sold yesterday to the Kyotaru Company, a Japanese food-service company, for an undisclosed sum.

title: Dime Savings Bank of New York reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included for the quarter a tax charge of $7,120,000 relating to net operating loss carryforward and charge of $2,510,000 for early extinguishment of debt; the year included a charge of $2,510,000 from the early extinguishment of debt. c-Net income and after tax credits of $8,514,000, or 38 cents a share, for the quarter and $34,511,000, or $1.52 a share, for the year, related to net operating loss carryforward. The company said the latest fourth quarter included a special addition of $80 million to its loan loss reserves. Dime Savings said the loss for 1989 is primarily attributable to the addition to loan loss reserve and restructuring actions announced last month which included: a special addition of $80 million to the loan loss reserve; the sale of $293 million of low-yielding, fixed-rate investment securities at a pre-tax loss of $35 million; and facilities restructuring resulting in the writeoff of excess offfice space and closing of loan offices outside of its Core market at a pre-tax cost of $23.9 million.

title: CHRONICLE
description: TOM BROKAW, the NBC anchor, conceded that the report was unusual for network news. ''But several of my sophisticated friends called this morning,'' he added, ''and said, 'That's the one I'm going to remember.' ''

title: Tricking a Molecule to Create a Coating
description: Fooling Mother Nature is helping a New Jersey company develop coatings that prevent corrosion and adhere more tightly to solid surfaces than other forms of plastics.

title: Bankers Trust New York Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income A income tax benefit of $5.8 million was recorded for the 1989 fourth quarter, compared with income tax expense of $66.8 million for year-ago period. Loan loss provisions for the latest periods totaled $147 million for the quarter and $1,877,000,000 for the year, compared with $30 million and $50 million for the year-ago periods, respectively.

title: BRIEFS
description: * DIG Acquisition Corp. said it would extend until Friday its $30-a-share tender offer for all common shares of Di Giorgio Corp., San Francisco, a food and consumer products company.

title: Disruption In London
description: Trading on the London Stock Exchange suffered a minor disruption today when a computer problem interrupted the quotation of the stock exchange market indexes for two hours and 20 minutes.

title: Central Bancshares of the South reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Shawmut National Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Last year's results included a net non-recurring gain of $92.1 million from the sale of the corporation's Boston headquarters building. This gain is less provisions for investments in unconsolidated affiliates, less $40.4 million of reserves for consolidation activities and less $56.3 million in additions to reserves for exposure in developing countries.

title: Kansas City Southern Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After income from discontinued operations of $15.6 million, or $1.50 a share, for the quarter and $10.8 million, or $1.04 a share, for the year. c-Net loss and after losses from discontinued operations of $2.3 million for the quarter and $8.5 million for the year; the year also included a gain of $14.8 million, or $1.44 a share, from the cumulative effect of change in accounting for income taxes. The losses from continuing operations for the year-ago periods included $82 million pre-tax provision to settle litigation. The 1988 periods restated to reflect discontinued operations.

title: CHRONICLE
description: It was a story made for television. A California woman revealed in November that as a child she had witnessed her father murdering her best friend. Twenty years later the woman accused her father and said she would testify against him. As a result, her father has been charged with first-degree murder.

title: Clifford V. Coons, 78, Manufacturing Chief
description: Clifford V. Coons, retired president of the Rheem Manufacturing Company, died on Monday at Boca Raton (Fla.) Community Hospital. He was 78 years old and had homes in Boca Raton and Highlands, N.C.

title: Disney (Walt) Co.(N) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Morgan Stanley Net Jumps; Shearson Has a Slim Profit
description: Defying the downturn on Wall Street, the Morgan Stanley Group Inc. said yesterday that it had a substantial jump in profits in the fourth quarter and for the year.

title: 2 Ex-Phone Workers Guilty in Ohio Wiretap Trial
description: A jury concluded today that two former telephone installers for the Cincinnati Bell Telephone Company had defamed the company and two managers by contending that they had ordered the installers to perform hundreds of illegal wiretaps from 1972 to 1984.

title: Ulster Policeman Slain
description: Gunmen killed a police officer as he was making a cup of coffee in his kitchen Monday night, the Royal Ulster Constabulary said today. Inspector Derek Monteith, 35 years old, was hit in the head and died instantly at his home in Armagh, the police said. No group claimed responsibility. The gunmen fired at least five shots from the back yard of the house through a glass door, the police said.

title: The U.N Today
description: General Assembly

title: Taking Message on Road, Bush Pushes Crime Bill
description: Evoking the legends of Bat Masterson and Wild Bill Hickok to bolster his anticrime message, President Bush today urged Congress to adopt his proposal for new laws on drug abuse and violent crime and attacked a Democratic alternative as a "Trojan horse" that would bind the hands of the police and prosecutors.

title: Bank Yields Down in Week
description: Yields on certificates of deposit and money market accounts at commercial banks and savings institutions were down for the week that ended yesterday.

title: Examination for Hinson
description: Roy Hinson, the Nets' starting power forward, will have his right knee examined today to determine if he will be placed on the injured list.

title: Electronic Teacher: A Mississippi Experiment
description: Mississippi, where one of every three adults is functionally illiterate, is embarking on an ambitious experiment in electronic education: put an I.B.M. computer program in every kindergarten and first grade, and try to have every child reading and writing by the end of the first grade.

title: News Summart
description: International A2-13

title: Questions Raised on Role of Cheese in Salmonella
description: Health officials in Minnesota said yesterday that cheese may be a more important source of salmonella infections than scientists now believe. They also raised questions about whether testing methods for salmonella bacteria in dairy products are adequate.

title: Municipal Bond Upgradings Were Favorable in 1989
description: Upgradings in the ratings of municipal bonds in 1989 were the most favorable in recent years, according to a report released this week by the public finance department of Moody's Investors Service Inc.

title: Minnesota Mining & Mfg.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Medication Misclassified On List With Steroids
description: To the Editor:

title: Imperial Oil Ltd. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Imperial Oil said its earnings included results of McColl-Frontenac Inc. acquired last Feb. 24. Results are in Canadian funds.

title: G.E.'s Profits Climb For Quarter and Year
description: The General Electric Company, one of the nation's largest diversified corporations, said yesterday that its profit rose 15.8 percent in the fourth quarter and 16.2 percent for the year.

title: In Canada, Two Vie to Lead the Liberal Party
description: Hoping to reinvigorate Canada's main opposition group after six years in the political wilderness, one of the country's most seasoned politicians is squaring off against a former Montreal shipping executive for the leadership of the Liberal Party.

title: Topics of The Times;   Special Counsel, Special Care
description: Mayor Dinkins of New York, dogged by charges of ethical lapses during his campaign, shows welcome sensitivity. He has asked for appointment of a special counsel to complete an inquiry by the Department of Investigation into business deals when he was Manhattan Borough President. They include a transfer of Inner City Broadcasting stock also under scrutiny by Federal prosecutors.

title: A van Gogh Now at Met Is to be Auctioned
description: Vincent van Gogh's ''Portrait of Dr. Gachet,'' completed six weeks before the artist's suicide in July 1890, is soon to be removed from the Metropolitan Museum of Art so that it can be auctioned on May 15 at Christie's in New York. The auction house expects it to bring $40 million to $50 million.

title: Upheaval in the East;   Rumania Ousts Envoys To the U.S. and the U.N.
description: Rumania's new leaders recalled their country's envoys to the United States and the United Nations this month, soon after the execution of Nicolae Ceausescu, and canceled their diplomatic accreditation, United Nations and State Department protocol officials said today.

title: Shamir and Sharon in Bitter Fight to Run Israel
description: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir and his chief Likud party rival, Ariel Sharon, are deep into a bitter political war two weeks before a party meeting at which the future leadership of the nation, and the future of the Government's moribund peace initiative, may well be decided.

title: Newmont Mining Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a loss of $3,649,000 on disposal of discontinued operations. c-Included for the quarter income from discontinued operations of $71,992,000, or $1.07 a share, which consisted of a loss of $157,000 from discontinued operations and a gain of $72,149,000 on the disposal of discontinued operations. The year included income from discontinued operations of $82,779,000, or $1.23 a share, which included $71,410,000, or $1.06 per share, gain on disposal of discontinued operations. Results for the latest quarter included a $63.5 million gain on the sale of Newmont Australia shares and extraordinary charges of $10.6 million for relocation, among other things. Results for the latest year included a $63.5 million gain on sale of Newmont Australia shares and $15.5 million of unusual charges for relocation, among other things. Results for the year-ago quarter included $5.7 million in miscellaneous extraordinary charges. Results for the 1988 year included $81 million gain on sale of securities and $35.2 million of unusual charges for relocation reserves, currency translation losses and charges related to the settlement with Ivanhoe Partners.

title: Interim Head Selected At Brush Wellman Inc.
description: Brush Wellman Inc., a company that mines the specialty metal beryllium and turns it into a finished product, announced yesterday that its chief executive for the last two years had resigned.

title: Whitman Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a loss of $9,000,000 and $37,500,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, from discontinued operations. c-Included a loss of $8,800,000 from discontinued operations for the quarter and a gain of $35,500,000, or 34 cents a share, from discontinued operations for the year. The year also included an accounting adjustment gain of $23,700,000, or 22 cents a share.

title: Jerome H. Dols, Banker, 54
description: Jerome H. Dols, a senior vice president of Chase Manhattan Bank, died of cancer Friday at Overlook Hospital in Summit, N.J. He was 54 years old and lived in Chatham, N.J.

title: Cray Research Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
China Disputes Western Accounts Of Secret Trials of Demonstrators
description: China today denied reports that it had held secret trials of those involved in last year's democracy movement and also appeared to deny that it had arrested as many as 10,000 people in connection with the movement.

title: G.M. Plans Recall Of 244,000 Fieros, Citing Fire Hazard
description: The General Motors Corporation will recall 244,000 four-cylinder Pontiac Fieros -every one ever made - because of a nagging engine-fire problem that contributed to the company's decision to stop making the two-seater.

title: For Salvador, Democracy Before Peace
description: The November military offensive by the Farabundo Marti Liberation Front guerrillas in my country has created a tragic paradox. While it demonstrated that there is no military solution to the costly civil war, it has hardened the armed forces' opposition to serious negotiations and to the democratic forces that support this alternative. How the United States acts in the next few months will be critical.

title: Louisiana-Pacific Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included net from discontinued operations of $18.4 million, or 48 cents a share, and an extraordinary gain of $146 million, or $3.82 a share, representing final settlement of Redwood National Park condemnation.

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.B.A.

title: Democrats Seek Advantage on Tax Cut Plan
description: Returning to Capitol Hill after an eight-week adjournment, Congressional Democrats sought today to gain political mileage from Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan's proposal to cut the Social Security tax without actually having to embrace the plan.

title: Review/Television;   'Hallmark' vs. 'American Playhouse'
description: Two of television's more prestigious purveyors of plays, the ''Hallmark Hall of Fame'' and ''American Playhouse,'' compete for the upscale audience tonight at 9, as Hallmark's ''Face to Face,'' on CBS, goes head to head with ''Sensibility and Sense,'' on PBS.

title: Strike Vote Taken At Ford in Britain
description: Workers of the Ford Motor Company in Britain voted today on whether to accept an improved pay offer from the automaker or go on strike. The results are not expected to be released until Thursday. The 32,000 workers at Ford's 22 plants in Britain voted on a proposed pay increase of 10.2 percent in the first year, and 8 percent or a choice of the inflation rate plus 2.5 percent in the second year. Most Ford workers earn an average $369 a week.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about Gov.

title: Birmingham Deal Loses Financing
description: A deal for the acquisition of the Birmingham Steel Corporation foundered when the buyer indicated it would not be able to obtain financing for the deal. In a letter to Birmingham, Duffy Holdings Inc. said its financial adviser, Bear, Stearns, did not believe an acquisition of Birmingham could be financed because of deteriorating financial results at Birmingham.

title: Johnny Mac, Darryl and Chemistry
description: John McEnroe says that if he had known the rules, he would have controlled his temper, not have thrown his racquet, not have tried to intimidate a lines official, not have screamed at the chair umpire, not have issued a string of vile language at the head supervisor (the supervisor's quote), not have thrown his opponent off his game with his abusive deportment and nearly drilled him in the back with an angry whack of a ball, not have shouted to a mother in the stands to feed her squalling infant. And, he surely would not have made a substantial portion of the fans, out for an afternoon of tennis entertainment, sick to their stomach.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Jan. 3 about the effect of Pentagon cutbacks on New York, New Jersey and Connecticut referred incorrectly to the status of Fort Dix, near Wrightstown, N.J. Under a Defense Department plan, the Army is to stop using the fort for basic training by 1995, but reductions in permanent personnel or trainees have yet to occur.

title: Hilton to Discuss Bids; Stock Price Plummets
description: The Hilton Hotels Corporation said today that its board would meet next week to consider bids for the company as well as restructuring plans that would not involve a sale.

title: Acxiom Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Goldome reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss Latest quarter included a gain of $40 million from the sale of selected New York City branches and charge- offs of commercial loans and other real estate totaling $16 million. The loss for 1988 included a charge of $13.9 million related to sale of real estate.

title: Mariano Rumor, 74, Italian Chief During Student and Labor Strife
description: Mariano Rumor, a five-time Prime Minster who steered Italy's democracy through the shoals for part of its most trying period since the fall of Fascism, died Monday night of a heart attack in Vicenza, the town of his birth 74 years ago.

title: New Task for the Computer: Making Clothes
description: Engineers and computer scientists at two colleges here say they have harnessed computers to standard industrial sewing machines to produce a larger variety of garments more quickly and cheaply than conventional clothing factories do.

title: EXTRADITION SET FOR ACCUSED NAZI
description: A Federal judge today ordered the extradition of a retired grocery clerk to West Germany to face charges that he killed three prisoners while serving as a Nazi concentration camp guard in World War II.

title: Income Down 45% at Bankers Trust
description: The Bankers Trust New York Corporation announced yesterday that its fourth-quarter earnings dropped 45 percent as sharply higher profits from bond and foreign-exchange trading only partly compensated for losses in its loan business.

title: U.N. Women's Rights Convention, 10 Years Old, Gets Mixed Review
description: While the 10th anniversary of what is essentially an international bill of rights for women is being hailed this year, women who have gathered in the last few days to evaluate the treaty have greeted its achievements with only a tentative sense of triumph.

title: Syria Agrees to Aid Lebanon in Ousting General
description: Syria has agreed to give the Lebanese Government military aid to enable it put down a revolt by the Christian general who controls a chunk of central Lebanon, officials here said today.

title: Hudson Foods reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 30
East German Weekly
description: An East German publishing house said on Monday that next month it will start putting out Die Wirtschaft, a weekly business newspaper whose title means ''The Economy.'' Its predecessor of the same name was shut in 1983. At the time, the Communist Government said a shortage of paper had forced the closing. Dittmar Kiermaier, the deputy editor, said Die Wirtschaft would be modeled on Western business papers, taking a hard look at the Government's reform moves. It will carry advertising.

title: Now It Can Be Told: The Dark Tale of Red Clam Chowder
description: ON Dec. 25, 1978, Austin Phelps Winters sat down at his typewriter to set about straightening out the facts as they pertained to his grandfather William H. Winters and Manhattan clam chowder.

title: EDUCATIONLessons
description: The pervasive practice of holding back low-performing students to repeat a grade presents a curious paradox. Few educational causes get more popular applause than refusing to promote students just because they are a year older, yet few current policies have been shown to be as ineffective.

title: Space Plane Developers Join Together
description: Four of the nation's largest military suppliers joined forces today to design an aerospace plane that would take off from conventional airports and then fly in orbit at 25 times the speed of sound.

title: General Electric Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Fiscal Crisis Could Open Door to the G.O.P. in Massachusetts
description: The precipitous decline in Gov. Michael S. Dukakis's popularity and a budget crisis that has paralyzed state government have set the stage for a wide-open governor's race - so wide open that people are talking about the possibility that a Republican candidate could win for the first time in two decades.

title: Topics of The Times;   More Franking Follies
description: Anyone who doubts the ingenuity of Congress might consider the wrinkles it has built into new rules on the franking privilege, the right to send free mail.

title: Corrections
description: An entry in the Company Briefs listing of Business Day yesterday misstated the expiration date of the $14-a-share offer by the Colgate-Palmolive Company for Vipont Pharmaceutical Inc. It is Feb. 2.

title: The Longest Trial - A Post-Mortem;   Collapse of Child-Abuse Case: So Much Agony for So Little
description: The case of the Virginia McMartin Preschool began six years ago with lurid news reports of children being raped and sodomized, of dead rabbits, mutilated corpses and a horse killing, and of blood drinking, satanic rituals and the sacrifice of a live baby in a church.

title: Devils Earn Victory By Stopping Lemieux
description: With the All-Star emblem erased from the ice at the Civic Arena, Mario Lemieux seemed to lose his inspiration. In his return to regular action in the National Hockey League tonight against the Devils, Lemieux was limited to just an assist in New Jersey's 4-2 triumph over the Penguins.

title: Kodak Plans Issue Of Floating Notes
description: The Eastman Kodak Company is making a public offering of $500 million in floating-rate notes that are due to reach final maturity on Jan. 20, 1993, and are tied to rates on commercial paper.

title: The Party Is Over
description: The Trumbull Little League All-Stars, the toast of the World Series, the White House, and the chicken-dinner circuit since bringing home the world championship to Connecticut in August, are being benched.

title: Wilander Topples Becker in Australian Open
description: LEAD: Boris Becker, who is the world's second-ranked player and was seeking his third consecutive Grand Slam title, was upset today by Mats Wilander of Sweden, 6-4, 6-4, 6-2, in the quarterfinals of the Australian Open.

title: Capital Restaurants Born of Global Politics
description: Ten years ago Gabriel Aubouin, the private chef for the French Ambassador in Washington, decided to open a restaurant. ''A backer offered me $100,000,'' Mr. Aubouin, 43 years old, said. ''That was the opportunity I was waiting for.''

title: Computer Associates reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago results are restated to reflect acquisition of Cullinet Software Inc. on a pooling of interests basis. Share earnings are adjusted to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split effect on May 30, 1989.

title: Jackson Undecided on Future
description: The Rev. Jesse Jackson said tonight that he had no plans to run for mayor of the nation's capital, but he refused to rule out the option.

title: U.S. Rethinks Strategy
description: The Bush Administration and Congress began work on reshaping American military strategy in the face of upheavals in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe. Page A11.

title: Two 49ers' Routes Converge Once Again
description: As boyhood friends in Davenport, Iowa, they frolicked in golden leaves on sandlot football fields until the sun turned copper, sharing a bond that would include attending the same schools from elementary through college.

title: At the Nation's Table
description: LEAD: WHEN you push open the glass doors at Acme Smoked Fish you'd swear you were in Flatbush, not Fort Lauderdale. The room is redolent of pickled onions, herring and smoked whitefish. Behind the display case elderly counter workers are busily but very carefully slicing smoked salmon while kibitzing with the customers.

title: Freeport-McMoran Resource reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding represent units.

title: Gordon Buehrig, 85, A Leading Designer Of Specialty Autos
description: Gordon M. Buehrig, an automobile designer who numbered among his creations the sporty low-slung Cord 810 that electrified visitors to the 1935 New York Auto Show, died of heart failure Monday at his home in Grosse Pointe, Mich. He was 85 years old.

title: CHRONICLE
description: Former Mayor JOHN V. LINDSAY was taken to a hospital yesterday afternoon after he had a dizzy spell at lunch that may have been a mild heart attack. Mr. Lindsay, who has a history of heart disease, was reported in stable condition in the emergency room at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center as doctors performed tests to determine whether he had experienced a mild heart attack, a hospital spokeswoman, Diana Golden, said.

title: Upheaval in the East: Turkey;   Crackdown in Azerbaijan Leaves Turks Torn Between Politics and Kinship
description: As Turkish officials contemplate the Soviet crackdown in Azerbaijan, they are torn between anger at what they call repression of ethnic kinfolk and a desire to avoid greater bloodshed or strains with the Soviet Union.

title: Union Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Injuries Bring a Controversy Over Surface at the Open
description: The serious ankle injuries suffered by Gabriela Sabatini and Mark Woodforde in the Australian Open have started a controversy over the surface at the National Tennis Center.

title: Michigan National Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
