description: b-Included a gain from the cumulative effect of an accounting change of $8,325,000. The company said that the increase in earnings for 1989 is primarily attributable to the $225 million pre-tax gain on the sale of the credit card portfolio in July 1989.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: MARKETS

title: Bridge
description: A few experts, notably Boris Koytchou, Sami Kehela and the late Ivan Erdos, learned their bridge in Europe, crossed the Atlantic and later represented North America in world championships. There has also been some traffic in the opposite direction.

title: About New York;   Hospital Worker, Loose Needle, Gnawing Fear
description: For the last three weeks, Carol Beckmann has had trouble sleeping, waking up often. ''Sometimes I dream about it,'' she said in a birdlike voice.

title: American Wins Friends and Influence at the U.N.
description: When Thomas R. Pickering, the United States representative here, started whispering into a portable phone during the Security Council debate on Panama last month, he reinforced the split image that many people have of him after his first year on the job.

title: Bensonhurst Statements Blocked
description: The defense won a victory yesterday in the Bensonhurst fatal racial attack case when the judge upheld defense motions to suppress three statements made by one of the defendants.

title: 2 Regional Phone Companies Report Declines in Earnings
description: The Bell Atlantic Corporation and the Southwestern Bell Corporation, two regional telephone holding companies, yesterday reported lower earnings for the fourth quarter.

title: Mobil Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $21,000,000, or 5 cents a share, and $56,000,000, or 14 cents a share, for the quarter and year, respectively. Year-ago quarter results included $37 million from the effect of U.S. and foreign income tax rate changes under FAS 96. Year-ago full year results included $194 million from such effects.

title: Cleric Assails Cuomo Stand On Abortion
description: The debate over abortion, an issue that politicians of both parties have said they want to leave untouched here this year, flared anew with an unusual exchange today between Gov. Mario M. Cuomo and a Roman Catholic bishop who is in jail for trespassing at a local abortion clinic.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;

President of HomeFed Is Promoted to Chief
description: LEAD: In the latest changes in leadership among savings and loan institutions, the HomeFed Corporation of San Diego, the owner of the nation's seventh-largest savings institution, said yesterday that Robert F. Adelizzi had been named chief executive of the corporation and its main subsidiary, the HomeFed Bank.

title: IRISH LEADER BACKS TALKS ON ULSTER
description: Prime Minister Charles J. Haughey of Ireland has joined the British Government in urging talks among parties in Northern Ireland to try to break the political deadlock there.

title: Eating Well
description: ANOTHER magic bullet has plowed into the dirt. A study published in The New England Journal of Medicine last week said that oat bran may not lower cholesterol after all. But then again it may. Americans have just been treated to a behind-the-scenes look at what goes on in the world of science every day. Scientific research is not static; it evolves constantly. It can take years before there is fairly conclusive proof about the relation between particular foods and health.

title: Upheaval in the East: Muslims;   Islamic Population Gain A Challenge to Soviets
description: Experts on the Soviet Union say they expect to see more violence in areas populated by Muslims, who account for a large, rapidly growing share of the Soviet population.

title: Upheaval in the East: Rumania;   Rumanian Leaders Accede To Pleas to Delay Elections
description: Responding to appeals from newborn political parties seeking time to organize, the provisional government voted overwhelmingly today to postpone elections a month, to May 20.

title: Venezuela Plane Crash
description: A military transport plane crashed into a hillside near the Venezuelan capital early today, killing all 24 people aboard, rescue officials said. The cause of the crash was under investigation. National guardsmen on the scene said fog was suspected as the cause.

title: WHITE HOUSE ASKS AN IRATE CONGRESS FOR CHINA SUPPORT
description: The Bush Administration pressed returning members of Congress today to support the President's handling of relations with China, but the effort was greeted by a storm of opposition from both Democrats and Republicans.

title: How to Pay for Social Security
description: I thought I understood what Senator Moynihan had in mind with his proposal to cut the Social Security payroll tax. He wants to stop using a tax that bears hardest on the poor to reduce the Federal deficit. That sure sounds nice. But if we reduce the payroll tax, won't benefits be threatened for people who retire in the future?

title: At the Nation's Table
description: ALTHOUGH it has been open almost eight years, the restaurant at the Basque Cultural Center in South San Francisco is still a revelation to many of the Bay Area's most devoted restaurant goers. Just 10 minutes south of downtown San Francisco in this working-class suburb, the restaurant preserves the culinary and convivial appeal of the city's popular Basque restaurants, famous for the abundance of their fare at prices ranging from reasonable to incredibly cheap, but it is light years away from the city's crowds and often insurmountable parking problems.

title: Upheaval in the East: Bulgaria;   East Germans' Revisions Urged for Bulgaria
description: A prominent opposition leader said today that Bulgaria must follow the democratization model of East Germany and Czechoslovakia rather than Soviet perestroika, because the Soviet Union faces chaos.

title: People
description: * H. Robert Greenbaum has been named a creative director of BBDO New York.

title: Five Die in 15-Vehicle Crash
description: Five people were killed today when as many as 15 vehicles collided in dense fog in the San Joaquin Valley, where fog often poses a road hazard. Four members of one family and the driver of another vehicle were killed, California Highway Patrol said.

title: Dining In the Capital: It's a New Deal
description: An avid diner in this city once told a story about going to an Italian restaurant in the mid-1970's that was favored by Congressmen and legislative aides for its pasta with clam sauce. It was a rough-edged place, with Formica tables, a dimly lighted bar and a disheveled chef. On the menu was pasta with both red and white clam sauces.

title: Fame for Four Bruins
description: Four former basketball players who gained all-America honors at least three times while playing at the University of California, Los Angeles, will be honored at Pauley Pavilion on Feb. 3 at halftime of a game against DePaul. The first Bruin basketball players to have their numbers retired will be Kareem Abdul-Jabbar (33), Bill Walton (32), Ann Meyers (15) and Denise Curry (12).(AP)

title: Economic Scene;   U.S. Memories: Who Is the Loser?
description: U.S. MEMORIES, R.I.P.: The joint venture formed last year to rescue the American computer industry from the clutches of a Japanese chip cartel died of financial anemia last week. The giant companies it was intended to protect just could not bring themselves to sign checks amounting to a few days' worth of the industry's annual investment budget.

title: A Drug Dealer Finds Many Eager To Launder His Drug Money
description: By the time he was 24 years old, Thomas Mickens, a high school dropout turned cocaine dealer, had amassed a fortune.

title: FMC Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After extraordinary charges related to San Jose earthquake and restructuring of long-term debt of $8,000,000 for the quarter and $20,400,000 for the year.

title: Stocks Drop in Tokyo
description: Share prices fell on the Tokyo Stock Exchange this morning as the United States dollar recovered slightly from its lows. Stocks fell almost across the board, and the 225-issue Nikkei average lost 535.01 points, or 1.43 percent, to end the morning at 36,843.01. The index had gained 121.01 points on Tuesday. By late morning, the dollar was trading at 146.00 yen, up from its opening of 145.88 yen. Kozo Hasunuma, a dealer with the Yamaichi Securities Company, said the Nikkei dropped as arbitragers sold stocks in an attempt to widen the price spread between stocks and stock futures.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Monday about labor negotiations at The Daily News misstated the expiration date of union contracts at The New York Post. It is March 30, 1991.

title: Nathan N. Rosen, Rabbi, 85
description: Rabbi Nathan N. Rosen, a chaplain at Brown University, Providence, R.I., for 25 years, died of cancer yesterday at Long Island Jewish Hospital. He was 85 years old and lived in Jamaica Estates, Queens.

title: Gaylord Container Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a net gain of $3.4 million, or 21 cents a share, from sale of a mill.

title: The Talk of the South Fork;   Baymen Find No Warmth This Winter
description: The bushel of steamers that Tom Lester harvested last week is still in his cellar, and it is starting to stink. ''I can't sell them,'' said Mr. Lester, a burly 48-year-old baymen whose day's work normally fetches between $75 and $100. ''No one wants them at any price.''

title: Lomas & Nettleton Mortgage Investors reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Mayors Seek More U.S. Drug Aid
description: The nation's mayors charged today that the states were shortchanging the cities in allocating Federal money to combat drugs.

title: Waterford Workers To Protest Plans
description: Waterford's 2,300 crystal employees plan to hold three work stoppages this week to dispute management cost-cutting proposals for their company. The workers, who agreed six months ago to a three-year wage freeze, said the two-hour stoppages would protest what they said was Waterford Wedgwood P.L.C.'s refusal to show them sales figures.

title: Noriega's Trial Not Like North's;   Demobilize Panama
description: To the Editor:

title: American Express Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $9,600,000, or 2 cents a share, for the quarter and $50,700,000, 12 cents a share, for the year.

title: Eldec Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 24
description: b-Included $652,000, or 12 cents a share, gain on sale of property in Whittier, Calif. c-Included income from discontinued operations of $5,345,000, or 99 cents a share, for the quarter and $5,861,000, or $1.09 a share, for the 9 months. Included in the income from discontinued operations for the quarter and 9 months is a $5,201,000, or 97 cents a share, gain on sale of a unit.

title: Typeface Program Wins Copyright
description: Adobe Systems Inc. said today that it had received the first copyright registration issued by the United States Copyright Office for a computer program that generates a particular style of type.

title: National Banc of Commerce reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Race to Retain Power Begins For Tokyo's Governing Party
description: Japan's political leaders today opened what is expected to be a closely contested parliamentary election campaign in which the Liberal Democratic Party of Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu is fighting to continue its 35 years of uninterrupted control of the Government.

title: Bridge
description: Before reaching for an angry pen to complain about the typography of today's diagram, read on. All will be revealed.

title: Stephenson, Attacked, Fractures a Finger
description: Jan Stephenson, the professional golfer, suffered two fractures in her left ring finger when she was attacked and robbed Tuesday night in Miami, The Phoenix Gazette reported.

title: Key Centurion Bancshares reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results reflected the addition of First National Co., Pikeville, Ky., from July 1989 and Guyan National Bank, Barboursville, W. Va., from August 1989.

title: Washington Federal Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
AMP Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Tyson Floored in Japan
description: Japanese sports fans - or sports editors - were shocked that Mike Tyson, the undefeated world heavyweight champion, was knocked flat on his back Tuesday with a right hook from a sparring partner, Greg Page.

title: Cleveland-Cliffs Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,000,000 for the quarter and $1,900,000 for the year, and an extraordinary charge of $100,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary credit of $7,700,000, or 66 cents a share which included gains on sale of interests in a coal mine, hydro electric facilities, among other items for the year. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $2,200,000 and $3,400,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, and an extraordinary charge of $1,500,000 for the quarter and an extraordinary credit of $3,000,000 which included gains on sale of interests in a coal mine, hydro electric facilities, among other items. Year-ago results are restated to classify the metallurgical sales segment as a discontinued operation. The latest quarterly figures are not necessarily representative of annual results due to seasonal and other factors.

title: British Ford Strike Averted
description: Workers at the Ford Motor Company Ltd. voted by nearly 3 to 2 to accept a 10.2 percent pay increase, averting a nationwide strike, union leaders said today.

title: Microsystems Net Is Off 32%
description: Sun Microsystems Inc. today reported second-quarter earnings below the levels of the period a year earlier, but significantly higher than its first-quarter earnings.

title: 11.4% Gain for American Express
description: The American Express Company said yesterday that its profits rose 11.4 percent in both the fourth quarter and for all of 1989, bolstered by strong gains in travel-related services, financial services and back-office operations it conducts for others.

title: Allied Bankshares (Ga.) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Chronicle
description: Will EMANUEL UNGARO soon be designing maternity clothes? The French couturier, who is known for his sexy revealing dresses, and his wife, LAURA, are expecting a baby in May. They were married last month.

title: USAir Group reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Charley E. Johns, Ex-Florida Official, 84
description: Charley Eugene Johns, who was Acting Governor of Florida for 15 months in the mid-1950's, died at Alachua County Hospital in Gainesville, Fla., on Tuesday after a long illness. He was 84 years old.

title: Summer Camps Put Their Best Recruiting Faces on Videotape
description: SCENE: A clear blue lake surrounded by rolling mountains.

title: Lester S. Vander Werf, Educator, 79
description: Lester S. Vander Werf, retired dean of Long Island University's Graduate School of Education, died of internal bleeding on Monday at Fairview Hospital in Great Barrington, Mass. He was 79 years old and lived in Sheffield, Mass.

title: Kentucky Rejects Bill to Bar School Smoking
description: A bill that would have banned student smoking inside elementary and high schools has been rejected by lawmakers in this state where tobacco is the leading cash crop.

title: Dr. Lucien Rubinstein Dies at 65; Expert on Nervous System Tumors
description: Dr. Lucien J. Rubinstein, a neuropathologist who was director of the division of neuropathology at the University of Virginia Health Sciences Center since 1981, died Monday after a cerebral hemorrhage at his home in Charlottesville, Va. He was 65 years old.

title: Sysco Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 30
Miami Officer Is Sentenced to 7 Years for 2 Killings
description: A Hispanic police officer whose killing of two unarmed blacks set off rioting here a year ago was sentenced today to seven years in prison. The 30-year-old officer, William Lozano, will remain free pending the outcome of an appeal.

title: Where Silk Is Crafted as of Old
description: LEAD: FOR centuries, English judges, barristers and scholars have worn robes made or trimmed with silk, giving rise to the expression ''to take silk.'' For the past 150 years much of this silk has been manufactured at the Whitchurch Silk Mill on tiny Frog Island in the River Test. The mill is the last of its kind in the south of

title: Hoping to Finish With a Flourish
description: Sebastian Coe of Britain, who has set 11 world records and won 4 Olympic medals in his illustrious career, will retire from competition after the Commonwealth Games, which begin today in Auckland, New Zealand. He could leave the track in a blaze of glory.

title: Metro Matters;   On the Question Of Legal Drugs, A Vote for Maybe
description: Add Nathan Glazer's voice to the chorus suggesting that drugs be legalized. Even Nicholas deB. Katzenbach, the former United States Attorney General named this week by Mayor David N. Dinkins of New York to explore strategies for fighting drug abuse, is circumspect about rejecting legalization of heroin and cocaine.

title: Arab Says Israel Offered Him Deal to Confess
description: A prominent Palestinian nationalist said today that the Israeli secret police tried to coerce an admission of illegal political activity from him last week by offering to release imprisoned Arabs if he confessed.

title: Flu Time: When the Sunspots Are Jumping?
description: Sir Fred Hoyle, a British astrophysicist whose unorthodox theories frequently raise the hackles of scientific colleagues, has concluded that sunspots may cause flu outbreaks.

title: LSI Logic reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included one-time pre-tax charge of $43 million associated with restructuring manufacturing operations in the third quarter. c-Net income and after an extraordinary credit of $859,000, or 2 cents a share, for the quarter and year, from a gain on retirement of debt. The latest quarter's loss before item of $1,661,000 included payment of net interest expense caused the firm to report a loss. Interest expense in the latest quarter was $5,223,000, compared with $4,008,000 in the previous year.

title: Rohm & Haas Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Screen Writers and Directors Reach Pact
description: Writers and directors, who for years have been not only close collaborators but also bitter foes in the making of motion pictures, called a truce today in one of Hollywood's oldest wars.

title: Market Place;   'Junk' Forecast: Wide Premiums
description: A RECENT study by a bond research organization concluded that ''junk bond'' interest rates would have to remain 5.3 percentage points above Treasury yields to reward investors fairly for the high risk of default.

title: Preferred Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The bank said that the primary reason for the loss in the latest quarter was additional provisions for losses on loans, real estate and investments totaling $3 million.

title: Cytogen Corp. reports earnings for 13wks to Dec 30
Review/Television;   '48 Hours' On the Trail Of a Settled McCartney
description: Try as it might, the CBS News team behind ''48 Hours'' cannot turn its coverage of Paul McCartney's current tour into an update of ''A Hard Day's Night.'' The 90-minute program, to be broadcast tonight at 8 on CBS, searches out some of the same ingredients as Richard Lester's 1964 film: eager fans, backstage drollery, limousines, applause.

description: Year-ago per share earnings adjusted for a 3-for-2 stock split paid in August 1989.

Du Pont (E.I.) de Nemours & Co.  (N) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings reflects a December 1989 3-for-1 stock split. The company attributed its depressed fourth quarter results to softening in the automotive, housing and electronics sectors of the economy. Revenue represented sales and other income.

title: He Cut It
description: Dwayne Schintzius, the Florida center suspended from the team after a fraternity-house fight, yesterday got the haircut that Coach Don DeVoe had demanded as a condition of his reinstatement.

description: b-After a loss from discontinued operations of $3,068,000.

Tribute to Eisenhower
description: The Senate minority leader, Bob Dole of Kansas, has introduced a resolution to change the name of Dulles International Airport to Eisenhower International Airport. Renaming the airport would be a fitting tribute to Dwight D. Eisenhower, the 34th President, who was Supreme Allied Commander in Europe and ''helped save the world from tyranny'' in World War II, Mr. Dole said.

title: BankAmerica Change Seen
description: A. W. Clausen, who led the BankAmerica Corporation back from the brink of financial ruin, is expected to retire this year as the bank's chief executive, banking industry officials said today.

title: Schering-Plough Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Potlatch Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Protesters Occupy the Communist Party Headquarters in Warsaw
description: As protesters occupied Communist Party buildings to demand that they be taken over by the state, more than 100 members of the Polish Parliament rallied today behind proposed legislation that would seize Communist Party property and turn it over to the state.

title: Lebanese Discuss Replacing Syrian Troops in West Beirut
description: Fighting broke out on two fronts in Beirut today as the Government of President Elias Hrawi discussed plans for having Lebanese Army troops replace Syrian soldiers on patrol in the Muslim western half of the city.

title: S.I. Man, 44 Stabbed Dead On His Beach
description: A Vietnam War veteran suffering from emotional problems was hunted down and stabbed to death on a remote beach on Staten Island Monday night by two men because they thought he was a homosexual, the police said yesterday.

title: Central Maine Power reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Intergraph Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The latest year's share earnings included 17 cents a share from gain on sales of investments in affiliated companies.

title: For 'Fur People'
description: IN 1986, Lady Slipper Designs in Bemidji, Minn., a cottage industry that provides jobs for low-income people, introduced the American Birdhouse Collection, and birds were finally able to perch on miniature Victorian, Greek Revival or Georgian houses.

title: Mark Twain Bancshares reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
WAR OF NUMBERS ON BUDGET REOPENS
description: Washington's annual war of numbers commenced officially today, with the Congressional Budget Office telling lawmakers they will have to find $74 billion in spending cuts or new tax revenue to reduce the 1991 deficit to the level required by law.

description: b-Included a gain of $6,000,000 from sale of a unit.

title: Yields' Slide Is Slowed
description: Yields of tax-exempt and taxable money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report were down for the week ended yesterday, but the decline was not as steep as a week ago.

LPL Technologies Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain on sale of a unit of $14,478,000, or $1.91 a share. c-Included a gain of $1,274,000, or 15 cents a share, on the sale of marketable securities for the quarter and year. Share earnings reflected 3-for-2 stock split effective Aug. 18, 1989.

title: California Paroles Man Who Set Son Afire
description: A former Brooklyn man who severely disfigured his 6-year-old son seven years ago when he tried to burn the boy to death as a result of a custody dispute, was freed on parole today with $200 in his pocket and an ''electronic leash'' strapped to his body.

title: Iraq Pledge on Oil Quota
description: Iraq's oil minister, Issam Abdul-Rahim al-Chalaby, pledged in remarks published Tuesday that Iraq was committed to its OPEC supply quota of 3.14 million barrels a day despite the expansion of its oil-shipping capacity. He told The Baghdad Observer that Iraq's export capacity was about 5 million barrels a day.

title: Washington Talk;   Panama Invasion Costly In a Far Wider Theater
description: The domestic political verdict is in:

title: BankNorth Group Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Atek Metals Center reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

Deals
description: Baseball

title: Redmen Defeat Friars By 83-75
description: Boo Harvey started an 8-0 run tonight by hitting two free throws with 4 minutes 40 seconds left, and he made 10 of 12 foul shots in the final five minutes to lead St. John's to an 83-75 Big East victory over Providence.

title: Unions Set To Make UAL Offer
description: Unions representing pilots, machinists and flight attendants at United Airlines will present a buyout proposal today to the board of the UAL Corporation, the airline's owner. The buyout would give employees a 75 percent stake in the company, while the rest of the stock would remain in public hands, the unions announced yesterday.

title: BUSH IS SET BACK BY HOUSE OVERRIDE OF VETO ON CHINA
description: Handing President Bush a major defeat, the House of Representatives today overwhelmingly reaffirmed legislation protecting Chinese students in the United States from deportation. The Senate is expected to vote on Thursday, and the outcome is too close to predict.

title: A Chat With Jesse
description: Over the phone, Jesse Jackson's voice was so painfully raspy with laryngitis that it seemed discourteous to engage him in conversation.

title: Baker Hughes Profit Up
description: Baker Hughes Inc., an oil tool maker, posted a 45.9 percent gain in quarterly profits, despite a worldwide decrease in drilling activity, the company announced today. Earnings for the three months ended Dec. 31, the company's first quarter, were $25.4 million, or 20 cents a share, on revenue of $578.9 million, compared with earnings of $17.4 million, or 13 cents a share, on revenue of $566.3 million a year earlier.

title: B.A.T. Plans to Close 2 Operations
description: B.A.T. Industries P.L.C., the London-based conglomerate fighting off a $21 billion takeover attempt by Sir James Goldsmith, said yesterday that it was dismantling its Batus Inc. American management arm as well as its Batig unit in West Germany.

title: Study of Teen-Agers Hints Gain for Those Having Abortions
description: A federally financed study of unmarried, sexually active teen-age girls has found that those who obtained abortions did better economically and educationally and had fewer subsequent pregnancies than those who chose to bear children. Those who had abortions even fared better than those who were not pregnant at the start of the research project.

title: Notebook;   Elite System Suffers a Setbacks
description: The changes that have swept through the East German sports system since December reached the national Olympic committee earlier this month, when Manfred Ewald, the committee president, and Rudolf Hellmann, a vice president and former Communist party leader for sports, resigned under pressure.

title: Drug Stamp Tax For New Capones
description: To the Editor:

title: Building on History of Success;   Former Teacher Keeps Niners' Offense Going Strong
description: When Mike Holmgren returned in 1971 to his hometown of San Francisco to teach high school history, he thought teaching would be his job for the rest of his life. Holmgren was happy, content. But then he began coaching in high school, and then moved on to San Francisco State and on to Brigham Young University.

title: Carolina Power & Light Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said earnings for the fourth quarter 1988 were positively impacted by a net 14 cents a share related to one-time accounting adjustments. They were reduced in the third and fourth quarters due to one-time write-offs that were required by regulatory treatment of a portion of the company's investment in the Harris plant. Without the write-offs, 1988 share earnings would have been 67 cents for the fourth quarter and $3.93 for the year.

title: U.S. Softens Its Stance on Return Of the Boat People in Hong Kong
description: The United States has softened its opposition to the forced repatriation of Vietnamese refugees in Hong Kong by indicating at an international meeting here that some boat people could be sent back after a one-year moratorium. But the American insistence on the moratorium effectively prevented any consensus from being achieved at the meeting.

title: Corrections
description: An article on Jan. 11 about van Gogh's ''Irises'' misattributed the news that the painting is on the market. Sotheby's, the auction house that sold the painting in 1987, did not say the painting was now on the market.

title: All the G.O.P. Needs Now Is a Candidate
description: From his remodeled office, J. Patrick Barrett presides over New York State's Republican Party with the nervous readiness of a cook preparing dinner for company who may not show up.

title: Tecumseh Products Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said its previously-announced acquisitions of L'Unite Hermetique and Tecnamotor SPA contributed significantly to growth in sales and earnings.

title: First Federal Savings-Elizaethtown reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
U.S. Deficit Up in Month
description: The Federal budget deficit increased $14.64 billion in December, bringing the deficit total so far this fiscal year to more than two-thirds the amount permitted for the entire year, the Treasury Department said Tuesday.

title: Skaneateles Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a pre-tax gain of $6,000 on the sale of securities. c-Included a loss of $1,898,000 on the sale of securities for latest year, compared with a gain of $18,000 for 1988.

title: Bytex Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
In Kashmir, Muslim Police Go on Strike
description: One hundred local policemen shouted Islamic and anti-Government slogans today as they briefly went on strike to press for relief of long-simmering frustrations at a time when the Indian state of Jammu and Kashmir is being swept by a separatist upsurge.

title: Profits Double at Porsche
description: Porsche A.G., the West German maker of sports cars, has turned the corner after a two-year slump, with earnings doubling in the fiscal year ended July 31, the company said today.

title: CLOSE TO HOME
description: SOMEONE has written to ask if I would speak at a local gathering, and suggests several possible subjects. One of them is what my neighborhood, which is also the writer's and probably that of everyone at this gathering, means to me. I'm not sure what it means to me. All I know is that when I cross West 14th Street, I am crossing the border into another country. Even my relatives, strangers to the city, recognize the difference. Once, when my mother and aunt were visiting, I overheard the one say to the other, ''Guess we should go to New York today.'' But weren't they already in New York? No. They were in the Village.

title: Profits Off At Chevron And Exxon
description: Two giant oil companies, the Chevron Corporation and the Exxon Corporation, reported today that they had reduced their profits by a total of more than $1.7 billion in the fourth quarter, in large part to deal with their environmental problems.

title: Morgan Guaranty In Note Offering
description: The Morgan Guaranty Trust Company of New York yesterday priced $200 million in bank notes due Feb. 1, 1992, through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

title: Apple Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary tax loss carryforward of $3,941,000, or 85 cents a share.

title: Review/Television;   The Role of Journalists In the Stuart Case
description: ''The Boston Hoax,'' tonight's edition of ''The Other Side of the News,'' at 9 on Channel 13, begins with a dramatic two-minute excerpt from the CBS ''Evening News'' in October. Viewers heard the halting voice of Charles Stuart, calling for police help from his car telephone, telling of a late-night attack on him and his pregnant wife, Carol.

title: Elbows Off the Table, Please
description: IN 1956, Walter Hoving, then the president of Tiffany & Company, decided to teach his customers the art of table setting, or how not to be afraid of a fish knife. That year, the first table-setting show was held at the Fifth Avenue store, commencing a series that has become legend.

title: HOME IMPROVEMENT
description: A COMMON style of lavatory faucet is the double-handled type with valves for hot and cold water and a central spout. Perhaps because of their simplicity, inexpensive, inferior models abound, and it is often necessary to replace them. The job is usually easy, though awkward.

title: Qintex Entertainment Inc. reports earnings for Year to July 31
description: Prior-year figures are not directly comparable. The company said adjustments for events related to its Chapter 11 bankruptcy filing in October increased its year-end loss by about $27,000,000. The company described those adjustments as writedowns to net realizable value of certain television series and films and an increased reserve for notes receivable related to its stock.

title: L.I. Nurse Gets 50-Year Term In Four Killings
description: Richard Angelo, the 27-year-old nurse convicted of killing four patients with lethal injections at a Long Island hospital, was sentenced today to 50 years to life in prison.

title: Gotti Jury Hears 'Boss' on Secret Tape
description: A Manhattan jury yesterday began hearing John Gotti's secretly recorded conversations - words that prosecutors contend prove he is the nation's top organized-crime leader.

title: Bankers First Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Latest fourth quarter included provision for loan losses of $1.8 million.

title: New Loans Seen for Mexico
description: The World Bank could lend Mexico more than $7 billion over the next three years, the bank's president, Barber B. Conable Jr., said today.

title: A Commuter Rail Link to Kennedy Airport Still Makes Sense
description: To the Editor:

title: Sterling Chemicals reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
United Illuminating Co. reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: b-Included a charge equivalent to $10.95 a share from the effect of a change in accounting principle. c-Net income and included a charge equivalent to $2.37 a share from the effect of a change in accounting principle. The final loss for 1989 was due primarily to non-cash writeoffs to recognize reductions in the recoverable cost of Seabrook Unit 1.

title: MOSCOW ARRESTS AZERBAIJAN REBELS
description: Soviet troops arrested dozens of insurgents and outlawed ''illegally functioning organizations'' in defiant Azerbaijan today in a selective crackdown aimed at consolidating the Kremlin's hold on the republic, the authorities and residents said.

title: Exide Electronics reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Benefit for the Homeless
description: The Da Capo Chamber Players will play a benefit concert for the Coalition for the Homeless on Feb. 14 at 8 P.M. at Town Hall, 123 West 43d Street. The program will include the premieres of two works, John Harbison's ''November 19, 1828,'' which commemorates the day of Schubert's death, and Bruce Adolphe's ''Machaut Is My Beginning.''

title: Northern States Power reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
In the Garden District
description: IN the past 10 years, design books have been narrowing their focus, from countries to regions to cities. In S. Frederick Starr's ''Southern Comfort: The Garden District of New Orleans, 1800 to 1900'' (M.I.T. Press, $35), the focus is even more specific: the historic area two miles up river from the French Quarter.

title: Pikeville National Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Dr. Hugh E. Potts, 87, Biologist and Teacher
description: Dr. Hugh Eustis Potts, a biologist and an educator, died of heart disease on Jan. 16 at New Milford (Conn.) Hospital. He was 87 years old and lived in Washington, Conn.

title: Florio Appoints a Prosecutor For Environmental Concerns
description: With a firm warning to polluters and sharp criticism of Exxon for the recent oil spill in the Arthur Kill, Gov. Jim Florio appointed an environmental prosecutor today to coordinate enforcement of New Jersey's environmental laws and regulations.

title: Splendid Season at Missouri
description: When Norm Stewart returned to coaching basketball at Missouri this fall after seven months of recuperation from surgery for colon cancer, there was hope that the old coach would have mellowed as a result of his ordeal. That hope was short-lived. A few days into practice, the players realized that their coach may have lost 30 pounds, but was as cantankerous as ever.

title: Teco Energy reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago share earnings included an 11-cent-a-share writeoff of coal mining assets by Teco's coal mining subsidiary in November 1988.

title: Chinese Paper Places Ideology Over Ability
description: A revolutionary outlook, rather than education or competence, is the most important criterion in choosing and promoting Communist Party officials, the party declared today in what some experts saw as a reversal of its previous position.

title: New England Electric System reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a net gain of about $11 million, or 16 cents a share, from a settlement agreement with a joint venturer. c-Net loss and included an after-tax writedown of $179 million related to the Seabrook Nuclear power plant.

title: Dr. Selden Dickinson, Pediatric Surgeon, 62
description: Selden Jerome Dickinson, a pediatric surgeon, died of lung cancer yesterday at his home in Manhattan. He was 62 years old.

title: Claire McGlinchee, Professor, 91
description: Claire McGlinchee, emeritus professor of English at Hunter College, died on Tuesday at her home in Manhattan. She was 91 years old. Dr. McGlinchee, a graduate of Radcliffe College and a Shakespearean scholar, came to the college as an assistant instructor of English in 1924 and retired in 1969.

title: Allen Collins, 37; Played Rock Guitar For Lynyrd Skynyrd
description: Allen Collins, one of the original members of the rock group Lynyrd Skynyrd, died of pneumonia on Tuesday. He was 37 years old.

title: Americans' Challenge: Teaching Democracy
description: American teachers and scholars are helping schools in Eastern Europe with a new task: how to teach democracy, and practice it, in societies that for decades have known only dictatorships.

title: Curb Weighed on Accounting Rules
description: The Financial Accounting Foundation, the administrative body that oversees the establishment of accounting rules, is considering a new procedure in response to criticism that too many new rules have been issued.

title: Poisoning Chances for Mideast Peace
description: If Israeli and Palestinian leaders really want to explore the possibilities of peace, they know how. All they have to do is stop making demands they know the other side cannot accept.

title: Sun Microsystems Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 29
Bush Ready to Ask $1 Billion in Funds To Repair Panama
description: President Bush is preparing to propose an aid program for Panama totaling more than $1 billion to help the country recover from recent warfare and long years of corrupt military rule, an Administration official said tonight.

title: Businessland Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary credit from early extinguishment of debt of $1,047,000, or 3 cents a share, for the quarter and 6 months. c-Net income The company said the latest quarter loss from continuing operations of $2,256,000 and 6 months' income from continuing operations of $2,007,000, or 8 cents a share both included a pre-tax charge of $7,500,000 related to restructuring costs.

title: A New Yankee Stadium Is Proposed in the Bronx
description: The Bronx Borough President proposed yesterday that the city and state build a new stadium for the New York Yankees at Ferry Point Park, a 414-acre site at the north end of the Bronx-Whitestone Bridge.

title: Bush to Seek $1.2 Billion For a Bigger Drug War
description: As part of an additional $1.2 billion he proposes to add to the nation's budget for the war on drugs, President Bush plans a 50 percent increase in money for the military to intensify efforts to halt international drug smuggling.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Appointments At TV Guide
description: Michael A. Lipton, a senior editor of TV Guide, will become executive editor of the magazine's national features section, Joe Robinowitz, the top editor at the magazine, announced this week. Jack Curry, the deputy managing of USA Today, will become managing editor of the magazine, which is owned by Murdoch Magazines.

title: Talking Deals;   A Team Approach For Orbital Plane
description: FOR the last five years some of the nation's largest aerospace companies have been competing to design and build an aircraft that could take off from a runway and fly at 25 times the speed of sound directly into orbit. But this week, faced with daunting technological challenges and the prospect of Federal budget cuts, the companies said they wanted to stop competing and start cooperating. The creation of a single team is one of the first attempts by military contractors to shake up the traditional way of doing business with the Government at a time of declining procurement and research budgets.

title: Washington Trust Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Rewriting Auction Records
description: IN 1989, defying reports of a softening economy, many antiques and collectibles enthusiasts paid record prices for the rarest works, some with choice pedigrees, in the booming auction market.

title: Lincoln Financial Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Joining Space Race, Japan Launches Rocket to Moon
description: Japan tonight became the third nation, after the United States and the Soviet Union, to launch an unmanned rocket to the Moon.

title: South Carolina Federal reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included tax credits from net operating loss carryforwards of $36,000 or 2 cents a share, for the latest first quarter and $116,000, or 5 cents a share, for year-ago period. Year-ago first quarter included a non-recurring pre-tax gain on the sale of Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp. preferred stock of $1,553,000.

Latest quarter results included a $62.8 million pretax restructuring charge and a $116 million pretax gain resulting from the sale of a 30-percent interest in the company's Taiwan manufacturing subsidiary.

description: The Czechoslovak Foreign Minister has promised that the country will end its lucrative worldwide arms exports immediately.

title: Options Tables Are Incomplete
description: The tables on Page D17 listing trading in stock options are incomplete. The Associated Press said it had not received complete information from a number of options exchanges.

title: A.T.& T. Cutback
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said its New River Valley electronics plant, with 1,000 employees, would phase out its operations within 15 months. Jay Walters, the plant's manufacturing director, said the shutdown resulted from excess capacity throughout A.T.& T.'s microelectronics business. Most of the electronic components made at the plant will be transferred to an A.T.& T. factory in Dallas. The company began operating the southwest Virginia plant in September 1980.

title: Farm Credit Issue Top Yield Is 8.2%
description: A $3.145 billion financing by the Federal Farm Credit Banks Funding Corporation was priced at par yesterday. The financing includes consolidated systemwide bonds with maturities of three months, six months and one year.

title: Bush Aide Optimistic On South African Shift
description: The top Bush Administration official dealing directly with South African affairs offered an unusually optimistic assessment today about prospects for a political system that would offer ''democracy'' for all racial groups, after three days of talks with President F. W. de Klerk and other senior officials.

title: Books of The Times;   James's Dalgliesh Tracks a Copycat Killer
description: Devices and Desires

The company also said it took one-time charges of about 7 cents a share in the fourth quarter in connection with previously reported severance payments and the writedown of a minority in a start-up company.

title: Generosity Begets Charity, and Neediest Benefit
description: ''Here is my check for $1,000. Wish I were Paul Newman.''

title: 3 Youths Held In Wounding Of an Officer
description: A 15-year-old was charged yesterday with attempted murder in the shooting of an off-duty police officer in Brooklyn. The police said the youth and two friends attacked the officer because one of them needed $20 to join a basketball league.

title: BSD Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Saint Laurent Draws Cheers And Tears
description: Yves Saint Laurent followed his last model, 16-year-old Lucie de la Falaise, down the runway at the Inter-Continental Hotel shortly after noon today and the place exploded. Trim and healthy looking, he waved to friends in the audience and put an arm protectively around the teen-ager in a shell-pink bridal dress, and everyone was standing, applauding madly. Paloma Picasso and Nan Kempner had tears streaming down their faces. It was some kind of epiphany.

title: Savings Rescue Cost Seen Rising
description: The $50 billion committed by the Government to rescue depositors at failed savings institutions will run out by mid-1991 and taxpayers will need to supply additional money, L. William Seidman, chairman of the Resolution Trust Corporation, told Congress today.

title: Curtice-Burns Foods reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 29
description: The company said net sales have been restated to conform to general food industry presentation. Share earnings have been adjusted for a 3-for-2 stock split in December 1989.

title: Personal Health
description: Before she was thrown from a horse more than 12 years ago, Janet Reed was an active sportswoman and an administrator for the National Industries for the Severely Handicapped. Since then she has been paralyzed from the waist down and must use a wheelchair.

title: Solti Selected to Head Salzburg Easter Festival
description: The Salzburg Easter Festival is to announce today that Sir Georg Solti has been appointed director of the Easter festival beginning in March 1992. The appointment begins almost exactly a year after Sir Georg's final concerts as music director of the Chicago Symphony, which are to take place at Carnegie Hall in April 1991.

title: Famine Threatens as Fighting Flares in the Sudan
description: The civil war in the Sudan has flared anew in the last six weeks, and Western aid officials say the fighting and Government obstruction of relief efforts make another large-scale famine appear likely.

title: Heartfed Fincl reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Review/Cabaret;   Anecdotes Amid the Singing
description: Arthur Siegel is one of perhaps a handful of people who know that a particular Jerome Kern melody was set with two lyrics, one by Otto Harbach in 1931 and the other by Dorothy Fields 20 years later. The Harbach version, ''Don't Ask Me Not to Sing,'' is an amusing comic number dropped from the show ''The Cat and the Fiddle,'' while the Fields version, ''Opening Night,'' which presents a sardonically funny list of things that can go wrong at a show's Broadway opening, was written for the movie ''Lovely to Look At,'' but also not used.

title: Chronicle
description: The Librarian of Congress, JAMES H. BILLINGTON, is taking a leaf from the books of many libraries around the country. He has established the James Madison National Council, a select group of folks who will act as an advisory body.

title: Can Injured Humphrey Run?
description: The cracked sixth and seventh ribs on Bobby Humphrey's left side, the focal point in the Denver Broncos' effort to present a balanced offense in Super Bowl XXIV, have improved enough that Humphrey can rest comfortably.

description: Federal regulators today seized the Empire of America Federal Savings Bank, New York State's third-largest savings institution, which has been losing millions of dollars since it bought out 13 failing institutions around the country.

title: The Legal Services 'Emergency'
description: Using loopholes to evade the intent of Congress is an odd way to provide a board of directors for the Legal Services Corporation, the Federal program of legal help for the poor. Yet President Bush has chosen to do just that.

title: Police in Kosovo Break Up Albanian Protest
description: Riot policemen used tear gas and water cannon today to disperse about 40,000 ethnic Albanians demanding the lifting of emergency rule in Kosovo province, witnessess said.

title: Premier Bankshares reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Outdoors
description: rrYou don't have to be 70 years old to race in the United States Ski Association Alpine Masters events. But that age won't prevent you from racing either.

title: Review/Dance;   Don Cossacks Return For First Time Since 1976
description: The Don Cossacks surged into the Neil Simon Theater on Tuesday night for a two-week run with music and dance guaranteed to charm the most jaded of audiences. The performing lies somewhere between the simplicity and straightforwardness of the Red Army Chorus and the sophisticated professionalism of the Moiseyev Dance Company. The scenes of village life are not so very different from the usual folk-troupe fare, though the strong, massed Cossack voices and the rhythmic weave of some of the stamping footwork are special. What reaches so directly across the footlights is the warmth and humor of the performers, particularly the men.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a mechanical error, an article from Prague yesterday about an offer of the city as the site of the next Soviet-American summit meeting omitted a phrase. The last paragraph should have read: ''Czechoslovakia began negotiations with the Soviet Union on Jan. 15 on a withdrawal of the 70,000 to 75,000 Soviet troops that have been stationed here since the Warsaw Pact invasion of the country in 1968. When he sees Mr. Gorbachev in Moscow, Mr. Havel is expected to press the country's demand that half of them leave by June and all by the end of this year.''

title: Zelia Ruebhausen, 75, Long a Civic Leader
description: Zelia P. Ruebhausen, a civic leader, died of ovarian cancer yesterday at her winter home in Rancho Santa Fe, Calif. She was 75 years old and also lived in Manhattan.

First Federal S.C.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

description: Latest fourth quarter and year share earnings after giving effect to dividends on convertible preferred stock issued in April 1989.

title: Battle Lines Are Shifting on Women in War
description: Many of the women on this Army post in central Texas were baffled and a bit annoyed to see Capt. Linda L. Bray lionized on television screens during the invasion of Panama. When Captain Bray led a military police unit into combat while conducting her mission, they insist, she was just doing her job.

title: U S West Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

title: Idea in Albany: A No-Fault Plan For Malpractice
description: The New York State Health Commissioner, Dr. David Axelrod, floated the novel concept of no-fault medical malpractice insurance today, saying it would compensate malpractice victims more fairly while protecting doctors from the trauma of litigation and skyrocketing insurance premiums.

title: Shipshaped By Starck
description: PHILIPPE STARCK does not just design furniture, hotels and pasta. Since 1985, he has been designing sailboat interiors for Beneteau of St.-Hilaire-de-Riez, France. Last week at the New York Boat Show, the 35s5 became Mr. Starck's first boat to be introduced to the United States.

title: Bristol-Myers Posts a Loss
description: The Bristol-Myers Squibb Company yesterday reported a net loss of $352.7 million for the fourth quarter of 1989. The loss reflected the company's previously announced $855 million write-down to cover the costs of the Oct. 4 merger of the Bristol-Myers Company and the Squibb Corporation.

title: Haiti About-Face: General 'Looking Like Dictator'
description: After 16 months of tentative hope for democracy, Haiti appears to be slipping back into dictatorship.

title: Business Digest
description: The Economy

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Tuesday about trading of futures contracts for orange juice concentrate misidentified the exchange that handles such trades. It is the New York Cotton Exchange.

title: Poll Finds U.S. Expects Peace Dividend
description: Three out of four Americans say the warming of relations between the United States and the Soviet Union can open the way for cuts in military spending, and by a wide margin they want this ''peace dividend'' spent to fight problems here at home rather than to cut taxes or close the budget deficit.

title: Beijing Journal;   With Fish as Bait, the Leaders Troll for Approval
description: As one lunar year fades into another, the emblem of the holiday seems to be fish - live, frozen, bagged or wrapped in an old newspaper - and city dwellers carry packs of them on the fronts and backs of their bicycles, already weighed down by other bounty of the Chinese New Year.

title: Calendar: Antiques And Art
description: Winter Antiques, Westchester County Center, Central Avenue and the Bronx River Parkway, White Plains; 914-949-8900.

title: No-Fault Faults for New Jersey
description: New Jersey Governor Florio's auto insurance reform proposals, unveiled Monday, look more like cost-shifting than cost-cutting. He says they'll reduce the average driver's premium by 22 percent, from $1,112 a year to $860. But what the Governor calls the ''organized ripoff'' of New Jersey drivers won't end until the state perfects its no-fault system and mounts an attack on fraud in insurance claims and repairs.

title: Wider Search Is Seen In Mail-Bombing Case
description: A Federal investigation into mail bombings that killed a judge and a civil rights lawyer appeared today to be widening, with one law-enforcement official saying new agents had been assigned to this small town that has become the center of the case.

title: Lin Expecting Loss in Quarter
description: The Lin Broadcasting Corporation said yesterday that it expects a net loss for the fourth quarter because of the costs of its settlement with the BellSouth Corporation after its merger agreement with the telephone company was canceled.

description: A FEW months ago Eileen Seeley broke up with the man she had been dating. Her 6-year-old daughter, Brianna, who had become quite attached to the man and his two young children, was very upset.

description: James J. Downey Jr., a construction company executive and former president of the General Society of Mechanics and Tradesmen of the City of New York, died in his sleep on Tuesday at his home in Manhattan. He was 84 years old.

title: Bennett's Sham Epidemic
description: LEAD: There may or may not be a cocaine emergency in the U.S. But those who rely on William Bennett for information on the subject are headed for trouble. That's especially true of President Bush, who will amplify his antidrug strategy today.

description: E. I. du Pont de Nemours & Company said today that its fourth-quarter earnings dropped 3.4 percent, prompting some analysts to lower expectations of the company's 1990 results.

title: Rangers' Dahlen Is Back on Track
description: Ulf Dahlen climbed into Tomas Sandstrom's car late Sunday afternoon for what would be a quiet ride to the Ranger practice arena in Rye, N.Y. The friends, having shared a traditional Swedish dinner, drove through the darkness, sad and taciturn. They were no longer teammates, though their hearts wished otherwise.

description: Cecelia M. Kenyon, retired professor of government at Smith College, died Monday after a heart attack at her home in Northampton, Mass. She was 67 years old.

description: When Hazel Diane (Rasheeda) Moore emerged from a Federal courthouse where she testified before a grand jury on Tuesday, she proved why she had been a top student at the Cappa Chell Finshing School and Model Agency in suburban Virginia.

description: Donald M. Bachmann, a retired certified public accountant and a former New York official, died, apparently of a heart attack, on Wednesday at his home in Sherman, Conn. He was 55 years old and also had a home in Manhattan.

As the article said, the former employees were found liable for having defamed the company and two managers by contending they had been ordered to perform illegal wiretaps. There was no finding of guilt.

description: The New York Times/CBS News Poll was based on telephone interviews conducted from Jan. 13 to Jan. 15 with 1,557 adults around the United States, excluding Alaska and Hawaii.

title: Exxon Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a charge of $500 million representing provisions for costs associated with the Valdez accident and an accounting change. The company said an accounting change in 1989 reflected adoption of the new income tax accounting standard, FAS 96, which increased first quarter and full year earnings by $535 million. The company also said in the latest fourth quarter an added provision of $500 million was made for the Valdez accident, bringing the full year 1989 provision to $1.38 billion.

title: Chevron Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After charges of special items of $1.203 billion and $1.207 billion for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Net income and included special charges of $266 million. d-Included benefit of $77 million from special items. The company said the largest special charge in the latest fourth quarter was a $598 million write-down of the company's investment in certain producing and non-producing oil and gas properties. This included a $445 million write-down of the Gian Point Arguello Field, located offshore Southern California, where prolonged permitting delays have prevented production start-up. The company also said other provisions made in the latest quarter included $325 million for future environmental cleanup costs, $164 million for adjustmens to prior years' income taxes, $63 million for a property write- off and other items associated with Chevron's uranium and geothermal operations, and $53 million for additions to reserves for various regulatory and other issues.

title: After Frigid December, A Warm January, Alas
description: On the University of Chicago campus, ranks of ice sculptures carved for the school's annual Winter Festival are melting slowly into January's mud, and plans to build a giant snow house have been called off.

title: New Art, Fabled Sources
description: LEAD: As the price of artwork soars out of the reach of most people, two Los Angeles women say they have tapped into a source of affordable original paintings and drawings.

title: Pentagon Freezing Construction As Bush Reviews Arms Priorities
description: The Pentagon today imposed a three-month freeze on military construction, and President Bush said he would submit a new budget to Congress next week that would begin to ''restructure America's defenses in the wake of the dramatic changes'' in Europe.

title: Browning-Ferris reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Azerbaijani Strife Expected to Lift Oil Prices Throughout the World
description: Western experts say the ethnic strife in Azerbaijan has begun to disrupt production of oil in the Soviet Union, the world's largest oil producer by far and a large exporter. The resulting drop, which comes on top of a decline that began in mid-1987, is expected to contribute to tighter supplies and higher prices for oil around the world at a time when production is also falling in other regions.

title: Schools Chief Seeks Rise in Spending
description: While New York City officials have urged him to scrimp, Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez proposed yesterday a budget that calls for increasing spending by $483 million, in part to hire more than 1,200 new teachers and guidance counselors and to repair decaying schools.

title: An Exercise in Introspection Lets Goldman Bare Its Soul
description: Goldman, Sachs & Company, the largest private partnership left on Wall Street, has a stellar reputation and a prestigious list of corporate clients.

Televideo Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Oct 31
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $2,900,000 and $3,169,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $142,000 and $534,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. Results for the latest year included certain charges totaling about $12.7 million, consisting primarily of the write-down of excess inventories and prepaid royalties related to product lines which are being phased out and costs of relocation and consolidation of the company's operations. The company said the loss per share for the quarter ended Oct. 31, 1989 reflected the losses of Delta Data Systems, as well as the write-down by Televideo of certain assets, primarily receivables, and intangible assets related to Delta Data Systems. Year-ago quarter and prior-year results restated to reclassify the operating losses of Delta Data Systems, which is 51-percent owned by Televideo and is now reported as a discontinued operation.

title: 250 Jobs to Be Cut By Perkin-Elmer
description: Citing sagging sales, the Perkin-Elmer Corporation said it would cut 250 jobs within two weeks, most in its semiconductor business. Edward Bloch, a company spokesman, said most of the layoffs would be at the company's optical lithography unit in Wilton. He said skilled and unskilled jobs would be cut.

title: Mid-America Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a gain of $669,000, or 11 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting.

title: Northeast Utilities reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $5,858,000, or 5 cents a share. c-Included income from discontinued operations of $3,748,000, or 3 cents a share, and $9,078,000, or 8 cents a share, for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Rochester Community Savngs Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
Conner Peripherals Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Seacoast Banking-Fla.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Barry's Lawyer Terms Resignation Of Mayor 'Not a Viable Option'
description: The lawyer for Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. today rebuffed speculation that his client might resign in a plea bargain with prosecutors, saying that ''resignation is not a viable option.''

title: Hewlett-Packard Retirement Plan
description: The Hewlett-Packard Company said it would offer an enhanced early retirement program to about 2,400 longtime employees in the United States in a program to reduce its work force and slow the growth of expenses.

title: A Bug Bites 2 Niners
description: A stomach virus struck Guy McIntyre and Roger Craig of the San Francisco 49ers today.

title: SALVADOR POLICY AROUSES CONGRESS
description: Conflict over United States policy toward El Salvador flared up today in Congress as a Bush Administration official defended the conduct of the Salvadoran armed forces and resisted efforts to reduce American aid.

title: Dun & Bradstreet reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said 1988 included one-time non-tax deductible costs of $14.3 million, or 8 cents a share, associated with the acquisition of IMS International.

title: Hogan Systems reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Chips & Technologies Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Five Women Executives Quit Goldman
description: Five women quit as vice presidents of Goldman, Sachs & Company yesterday to form a ''boutique'' investment firm specializing in municipal finance The new venture, which includes a sixth woman, from Citibank, will have offices in New York and San Francisco and is to be called Artemis Capital Group Inc., after the Greek goddess of hunting.

title: U.S. FACES STRAINS FROM GLOBAL JUMP IN INTEREST RATES
description: Interest rates in Japan and West Germany are suddenly surging, in the process dragging up American rates at what most economists say is just the wrong moment for the nation's fragile economy.

title: Loctite Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
BRIEFS
description: * L. M. Ericsson Telephone Co., Stockholm, a maker of telecommunications equipment, said it had received two orders totaling $135 million from Telecom Australia for equipment to be used in that country's public- and cellular-telephone networks.

title: Aceto Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Trinova Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $1,087,000. c-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $853,000 for the quarter and income from discontinued operations of $275,000, or 1 cent a share, for the year. Latest-quarter results recognized a net gain on the disposition of certain investments of $4 million ($2.5 million, net of tax, or 7 cents a share). In the 1989 third quarter, the company recorded a provision for restructuring its continuing operations amounting to $53 million, which reduced income from continuing operations for the 1989 year by $38.5 million, or $1.13 a share. Also during the third quarter, the company made a provision of $8 million ($5 million, net of tax, or 15 cents a share) for costs to write down the value of a flexible manufacturing system (FMS) at one of the company's production facilities. Trinova's 6-percent convertible debentures, which are common stock equivalents, have not been included in average shares outstanding for the year 1989 because the effect of their inclusion would have been anti-dilutive. The laminated products group business, sold in March 1989, has been reported as discontinued operations and previously reported financial statements have been restated. Results for 1988 included a settlement gain from the termination of a defined-benefit pension plan amounting to $6.1 million ($3.3 million, net of tax, or 9 cents a share).

title: Grady L. Huffman, 72, A Texas Lawbreaker
description: Grady Lee Huffman, who was shot 17 times in 30 years of robberies, burglaries and prison escapes, died of cancer Tuesday. He was 72 years old.

title: Fame, Then Silence and Death: Isaac Babel's Daughter Reflects
description: ''It is not easy, being the daughter of Isaac Babel,'' Nathalie Babel Brown, the only child of the celebrated Soviet author, said the other day. ''The children of famous people always have it a little difficult. But in the case of Babel there is a special element: his life was such a complicated, tragic and historical event. Through the years I have oscillated between acceptance and rejection of being his child.''

title: Dow Off 10.82, A Comeback After Plunge
description: The Dow Jones industrial average plunged 62 points in the first half-hour of trading yesterday, then climbed back during the balance of the day to close at 2,604.50, down 10.82.

title: Centex Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Richman Brothers Gets A New Chief Executive
description: A chain of clothing stores owned by the Woolworth Corporation has promoted Lee A. Sunderland, its executive vice president since 1983, to president and chief executive.

title: New Plan By Owners Rejected
description: The baseball players' union yesterday rejected a proposal by the owners under which the players could accept the owners' revenue-sharing plan, with its pay-for-performance salary scale, but still qualify for elements of the current system, such as salary arbitration.

title: Fansteel Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $4,336,000, or 50 cents a share, for the quarter and $2,721,000, or 32 cents a share, for the year. c-Net loss d-Included losses from discontinued operations of $1,576,000 and $1,101,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: Review/Jazz;   Doky Brothers as a Duo
description: Since graduating magna cum laude from the Berklee College of Music in Boston in 1984, the 25-year-old pianist Niels Lan Doky has become a firmly established figure in the New York jazz world, both as a solo performer and in groups that often include the drummer Terri Lyne Carrington, a fellow student at Berklee.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Central Point Software Inc., Beaverton, Ore., a computer software company, appointed Corey Smith president and chief operating officer.

title: Super Bowl Drug Testing Tightened
description: As usual, the Super Bowl hoopla involves what's upfront and obvious: Joe Montana and John Elway, the 49ers' quest to repeat as champions, the Broncos' aversion to losing for the third time in four years. But underneath lurk three real-world factors: the specter of Stanley Wilson's sudden suspension for having used cocaine the night before last year's game, a $1 million bet, and a point spread reminiscent of the 1968 Jets' upset of the Baltimore Colts as a 17-point underdog.

title: 'Tel Aviv Strangler' Is Jailed For Life for Multiple Killings
description: An Israeli court jailed for life plus 40 years a Palestinian known as the ''Tel Aviv Strangler,'' who claimed to have killed seven people to prove he was not a collaborator with the Israelis.

title: Brooklyn Union Gas reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Not Your Plain Old Everyday Toaster
description: SOMEDAY, toasters may be transparent, flexible or portable, judging from Black & Decker's ''Toast to the Future'' contest, which was co-sponsored by the Kansas City chapter of the Industrial Designers Society of America. The winners were awarded prizes, ranging from $5,000 to $10,000, in Chicago on Jan. 14.

title: 'Non-Real' House For TV
description: ON ''House Party,'' an NBC-TV show of cooking, fashion and decorating tips, ''the stars are known by the furniture they keep,'' said Eugene Lee, the show's set designer.

title: Review/Dance;   Mystic Aura in Jamison's 'Forgotten Time'
description: As a star of the Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, Judith Jamison commanded attention with her authoritative stage presence, dramatic intensity and concern for expressive details. Those theatrical virtues have helped make her effective both as a choreographer and as a director of her own dance group, the Jamison Project, which opened a week's engagement Tuesday night at the Joyce Theater, 175 Eighth Avenue, at 19th Street.

title: Oil Find in Eastern Syria
description: Petrofina, the Belgian oil company, said this week that an exploration well in which it has a share had struck oil in eastern Syria. The Al Bishri test site is operated by Total Syria, of which France's Compagnie Francaise des Petroles has a 60 percent share. Petrofina has 20 percent and London and Scottish Marine Oil has the rest. Analysts estimated the reserves at 50 million to 100 million barrels.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: Probation for Secord

title: Chittenden Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Mercantile Bancorp Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a $94,821,000 provision for loan losses in 1989, and $60,288,000 in 1988.

title: Lindsay in Stable Condition
description: Former Mayor John V. Lindsay, who was hospitalized after he had a dizzy spell at lunch Tuesday, was in stable condition yesterday, Linda Franklin, an administrator at the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center, said. She said doctors were awaiting results of tests to determine whether he had experienced a mild heart attack. She added that he had not had any more dizziness and would probably be released today or tomorrow. Mr. Lindsay, who had bypass surgery several years ago, had a mild stroke last year.

title: Greening the Cabinet
description: In proposing to promote the Environmental Protection Agency to cabinet status, President Bush yesterday pre-empted attention for a costless project that Congress, eager to strike blows for the environment, is likely to approve anyway. The idea sounds good; it may even do some good.

title: Louisiana Governor Refuses to Pardon Black in '74 Killing
description: Gov. Buddy Roemer today rejected the State Pardon Board's recommendation of clemency for Gary Tyler, a black civil rights advocate who says he was framed for the killing of a white student during desegregation violence in 1974.

title: Profits Scoreboard
DPL Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Santa Fe Pacific To Cut 2,700 Jobs
description: The Santa Fe Pacific Corporation said it planned to reduce employment on its railroad by 2,700 jobs over five years. The reductions would take place through job buyouts, attrition and possible layoffs, and would affect union and white-collar workers, said Robert Gerht, a spokesman for Chicago-based company.

title: Ball Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included an after-tax provision of $6.2 million to cover the projected cost to complete a fixed-price development subcontract for a U.S. Air Force program for both the quarter and year. c-Included the effect of pre-tax unusual items of $30 million in the quarter and $24.1 million in the year, and the year also included a gain from an accounting adjustment of $17,800,000, or 17 cents a share. The company said the lower net earnings for 1989 also reflect after-tax effects of the Employee Stock Ownership Plan adopted during the year which amounted to $2 million, or 9 cents a share. Share earnings in 1988 of $2.17 benefited by 13 cents as a result of a change in accounting, offset by several unusual items.

title: The Bishop And the Chairman
description: Governor Cuomo of New York is in ''serious risk of going to hell'' for his support of abortion rights - so says a Roman Catholic bishop who is serving a 10-day jail sentence for trying to block the entrance to an abortion clinic in Albany.

title: President's News Conference on Foreign and Domestic Issues
description: Following is a transcript of President Bush's news conference yesterday in Washington, as recorded by The New York Times:

title: Peres Optimistic on Setting Up Arab Peace Talks
description: Shimon Peres, the Labor Party leader, left a meeting with the Egyptian President, Hosni Mubarak, in Cairo this afternoon broadly optimistic that his party and the Egyptian Government could arrange Israeli-Palestinian peace talks in the near future.

title: 3 Small Parties Denounce Bucharest's Ruling Group
description: Leaders of three political parties today denounced the provisional Government's plan to run its own candidates in national elections in May, and demonstrators at two rallies shouted slogans against its President.

title: Graf Plays Sluggishly But Moves Into Final
description: Steffi Graf, suddenly looking vulnerable, escaped an upset today to reach the Australian Open final. Mary Joe Fernandez, the calm and confident American teen-ager, also reached the final, which is scheduled for Saturday.

title: Valley Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
New Biography, New Debates on Jackson Pollock
description: The troubled life of Jackson Pollock, a hero of Abstract Expressionism, is once again haunting his family and friends. His world, his art and his psyche have been relentlessly explored in a new biography, ''Jackson Pollock: An American Saga,'' by Steven Naifeh and Gregory White Smith, which has already sparked a lawsuit.

title: Alltel Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses on investment from loan investments and merger expenses of $17,491,000 for the quarter and $9,068,000 for the year.

title: A Fear of Pogroms Haunts Soviet Jews
description: LEAD: At the historic Congress of Jewish Organizations held in Moscow in December, the most talked-about worry was the real possiblity of pogroms in the near future. This month's slaughter of Aremenians by Azerbaijanis in Baku, which has repeatedly been described as a pogrom, suggests that during the nationalist unrest across the Soviet Union Jews could again become mob victims.

title: Banks of Mid-America reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income and after a extraordinary credit of $11,409,000 from a gain on extinguishment of debt. c-Net loss and after an extraordinary credit of $11,409,000 from a gain on extinguishment of debt.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Accounts
description: * Van Doren Rubber Co., to Eisaman, Johns & Laws, Los Angeles, for its Vans shoes, with a budget of $3 million.

title: Hardware, Antique or Merely Odd
description: GREENWICH VILLAGE has been home to the P. E. Guerin foundry, makers of hardware, since 1892. If a piece of furniture is missing hardware, says Andrew Ward, the president, the company can duplicate the needed part. ''We will replace anything,'' he said.

title: Short-Term Gains Tax Draws Bentsen's Interest
description: In the first indication of how Democrats would reshape President Bush's proposal to cut capital gains taxes, Senator Lloyd Bentsen said today that raising the tax rate for short-term capital gains, to discourage investors from selling assets to realize quick profits, appealed to him.

title: Imex Medical Systems Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Garvey Off the Air
description: Steve Garvey, the former baseball star who has been troubled by low ratings in his new career as a radio talk-show host in the San Diego area, was dismissed yesterday by XTRA after six months at the AM station.

title: U.S. Notes and Bonds Fall Again
description: Even as prices of Treasury notes and bonds moved lower again yesterday, some market participants and analysts said they saw the early signs of a strong technical rally.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Fairness Complaints
description: The National Advertising Division of the Council of Better Business Bureaus promises that by April 1 it will cut in half the time to decide claims of unfair advertising. The advertising industry's self-regulatory group averages five to six months to resolve claims, said Mary-Jane Raphael, senior vice president of the National Advertising Division. Under the new guidelines, she said, cases will take a maximum of three months.

title: G.E. Manager to Head Warner-Lambert Unit   Richman Brothers Gets A New Chief Executive
description: The Warner-Lambert Company says it has succeeded in making a biodegradable plastic from starch, a process that it calls a major advance in materials science. And yesterday, it named Philip M. Gross, an executive from the General Electric Company, to bring the product to market.

title: After the Boston Killing: A Deluge of Books About It
description: The Charles Stuart case has provoked a deluge of books and ideas for books about the killing, and the result, several agents and publishers contend, will be a slew of hastily produced mediocrity.

title: BUCHAREST ENVOY TO U.S. IS NAMED
description: Rumania's provisional Government has named new Ambassadors to Washington, Moscow and Paris and forbidden its diplomats from joining political parties, the country's United Nations Mission said today.
