title: Franklin Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Per share earnings for year-ago quarter was less than 1 cent a share.

title: Sihanouk Quits Opposition Post And Severs Ties to Peace Process
description: Prince Norodom Sihanouk, the leader of the Cambodian opposition and probably a key figure in any resolution of his country's conflict, said today that he would resign as head of the exile government and withdraw from future discussions on a peaceful settlement in Cambodia.

title: Worms That Turn Wood to Dust
description: LEAD: There is a saying among old-timers at English and European auctions that if woodworms would just put their feet out, the furniture could walk to its new home. Don't let that happen to your possessions.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   3 New Books Published About the Ad Business
description: Jay McNamara, the retired president and chief operating officer of McCann-Erickson Worldwide and a former president of Young & Rubicam USA, has collected his management philosophy in a book. Published by Dow Jones-Irwin ($24.95), the book is called simply ''Advertising Agency Management.'' Noting that agency executives receive mostly on-the-job training, Mr. McNamara said, ''My hope is this book will spare some of the trial-and-error frustrations inherent to that means of learning.''

title: For Keeping Up With the Joneses, A Dual-Career Pair
description: By their houses, ye shall know them.

title: Wesbanco Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Subway Garble
description: To the Editor:

title: Harrods in Canada
description: Harrods, regarded by many as London's finest store, will open its first North American outlet in Toronto International Airport's new terminal, set to open in September, the company said. Harrods, which has in the past sold itself on being only one store, now has outlets at the Frankfurt airport in West Germany, on board the liners Queen Elizabeth 2 and Queen Mary and in the Mitsukoshi Ltd. department stores in Japan, said Michael Cole, a spokesman for House of Fraser P.L.C., which owns Harrods.

title: Birmingham Steel reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After deducting about $817,000 for investment banking and legal fees for both the quarter and 6 months. The company said the latest quarter's results reflect losses at its Kankakee Mill due to delays in construction and startup of its new melt shop, and poor operating performance from its Norfolk Steel Mill.

title: Quake-Repair Bond Issue
description: Officials will ask voters to approve the largest bond issue in San Francisco history, $334.4 million, for repairing buildings and pipelines damaged by the Oct. 17 earthquake.

title: Keystone Heritage Group reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Vanfed Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Per share earnings for year-ago periods were not available; company went public in January 1989.

title: A Late Goal Leaves Devils Alone in First
description: John MacLean, who had two goals in the victory Tuesday night at Pittsburgh, gave the Devils a 3-2 triumph over the Capitals tonight by scoring the winning goal with three seconds left. The victory also moved the Devils into sole possession of first place in the Patrick Division with 52 points.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A3-14

title: North Fork Bancorporation reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
KEY RATES
Winn-Dixie Stores Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Jan 10
Prado Opens the Largest Show Of Velazquez's Work Ever Held
description: In the presence of King Juan Carlos and with more than a nod of gratitude for help provided by the Metropolitan Museum of Art in New York City, the Prado Museum this week opened the largest exhibition of paintings by Velazquez ever held.

title: Western Digital Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 30
description: b-Included gain of $1,099,000 from repurchase of convertible subordinated debentures for the quarter and 6 months.

title: United National Bancorp-N.J.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago per share earnings adjusted to reflect 6 percent stock dividend paid in November 1989.

title: Peoples Heritage Fincl Gr reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: During the fourth quarter, the company said it wrote down its investment of 293,000 shares of One Bancorp of Portland, Me., to year-end market value, resulting in a $3.8 million charge against earnings.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''This vote is a referendum on human rights that will be heard around the world.''

title: Despite Moscow's Warning, Teheran Increases Coverage of Turmoil
description: Despite a sharp warning from Moscow to keep a distance from the conflict in Azerbaijan, the official Iranian press agency increased its reporting on the situation today with a dispatch saying that Soviet Azerbaijanis were building a new bridge across the Araks River, which forms the Soviet-Iranian border.

title: Trustcorp Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included charges of $22 million to recognize one-time expenses, incurred in connection with the merger with Society Corp., for severance costs, and the writeoff of computer software, operating systems and signage made obsolete by the integration of the two companies and other matters. c-Included provision for loan losses of $116.4 million, of which $96.6 million was recorded in the second quarter. d-Net income The merger of Trustcorp into Society, a pooling of interests, was consummated on Jan. 5, 1990, as a result, the company felt that per share data was not meaningful.

title: Defendant in 59th St. IND Killing May Waive Immunity and Go Before Grand Jury
description: The lawyer for the man charged with killing a homeless man in the Columbus Circle subway station said yesterday that he was considering having his client waive immunity and appear voluntarily as a witness before a grand jury.

title: 10 FARM WORKERS DIE IN VAN PLUNGE
description: A van carrying farm workers plunged off a curve and into a canal in heavy fog here this morning, drowning 10 migrants from Mexico.

title: Kashmiris in Pakistan Press Self-Rule
description: As a new Government in India grapples day to day with an explosion of separatism in Kashmir, the issue is rapidly taking on international dimensions here, drawing Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto toward a potentially dangerous confrontation with New Delhi.

title: Zions Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After extraordinary credits of $1,750,000, or 29 cents a share, for the quarter and $3,750,000, or 63 cents a share, for the year. c-Net loss

title: Compression Labs Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Owens-Corning Fiberglas reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a charge of $18 million for the rationalization of operations in North America and a charge of $31 million for an addition to the company's reserves for asbestos liability. Latest-quarter results also included a gain of $38 million, or 90 cents a share, from the settlement with the Internal Revenue Service concerning the treatment of certain assets for tax purposes covering several years. In addition to the charges and credits reported for the fourth quarter, latest full year figures included a charge of $4 million for a reduction of equity income attributable to Fiberglas Canada Inc. before its acquisition. Full year 1988 figures included a charge of 20 cents a share from the early retirement of debt.

title: Spoleto Festival to Offer Mozart, Verdi and Glass
description: The Festival of Two Worlds at Spoleto this summer is to feature productions of classical and modern music ranging from Mozart's ''Nozze di Figaro'' to Philip Glass's ''Hydrogen Jukebox,'' the organizers said on Tuesday.

title: Inglis Ltd. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included pre-tax costs of $871,000 with respect to the removal of plant wastes from its Stoney Creek, Ont. property. c-Net loss d-Included a pre-tax gain of $2,062,000 from the sale of the Stoney Creek facility. Results are in Canadian funds.

title: I.B.M. Joins Siemens In Developing Chips
description: In a move to strengthen its ability to compete with Japanese semiconductor manufacturers, the International Business Machines Corporation said yesterday that it had agreed to work with the West German electronics giant Siemens A.G. to develop advanced computer memory chips for the mid-1990's.

title: Louisville Gas & Electric reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Fed Expects Slow Growth This Year
description: The nation's economy is expected to grow slowly in 1990, with improvements in some regions later in the year, the Federal Reserve Board said today.

title: Soviet Minorities Undeterred by Strife
description: Leaders of nationalist independence movements from the Baltic Sea to the Ukraine to Soviet Central Asia say their campaigns for greater liberty from Moscow will continue undeterred by upheavals in Azerbaijan, where Soviet troops are struggling to contain an insurgency.

title: Pennsylvania Power & Light Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said its strong generating capacity has enabled it to add another dimension of revenues by entering into a number of new capacity- related transactions with other electric utilities. These transactions produced about $23 million of additional revenues for the company, primarily in the last half of 1989, which equals about 19 cents a share.

title: Aeroflot Buys First Airliners From West
description: In its first order for Western aircraft, Aeroflot, the Soviet airline, bought five A310 airliners from Airbus Industrie, the European consortium said yesterday.

title: The Perles Mess: Who Did What to Whom?
description: In the end, George Perles is still Michigan State's head coach - and has been given the additional post of athletic director - and the Jets are still looking for Joe Walton's replacement.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Bloom Feels It's Arrived In New York
description: THE Bloom Companies wants its name added to a very short list: out-of-town advertising agencies that have made it in New York.

title: Bristol-Myers-Squibb Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The company said its latest fourth- quarter results included a pretax charge of $740.2 million recorded in connection with the company's plans to integrate the operations of Bristol- Myers and Squibb and to organize its pharmaceutical, nutritional, medical device and consumer businesses on a global basis. The 1989 quarter also included an additional $115 million charge for the costs of professional fees and other expenses related to the merger. The effect on net earnings of the two charges was $692.5 million. The 1989 year results included pretax charges totaling $855.2 million related to Bristol-Myers' merger with Squibb.

title: Tidewater Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Three Officers Are Charged In Thefts of Cash and Drugs
description: Three police officers and four other men were charged in a Federal indictment today with plotting to steal more than $1 million in cash, 110 pounds of cocaine and a ton of marijuana from drug dealers.

title: Shell Oil Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain of $35 million from an accounting change. No per-share figures were provided; the company is a unit of Royal Dutch Shell Group.

title: Q&A
description: Paint on the Carpet

title: Hartford Steam Boiler Insur reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Corrections
description: An article on Friday about the seizure of Communist Party assets in Rumania included two incorrect figures provided by an interpreter for the new Government at a news conference. The Government said the annual output of 60 industrial enterprises owned by the party was 16 billion lei, not 60 billion lei. It said the number of villages designated for elimination under the ousted Government was 300, not 3,000.

title: Old National Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The 1988 periods restated to reflect the mergers in 1989, on a pooling of interest basis, with First Service Bancshares Inc. of Greenville, Ky., on Feb. 28; Morganfield National Service Corp. of Morganfield, Ky., on March 31, and the First National Bank of Harrisburg, Ill., on May 31.

title: National Steel Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included tax credits of $8,000,000 and $23,000,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Included tax credits of $8,800,000 and $22,600,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. National Steel is a joint venture of National Intergroup Inc. and NKK Corp. of Japan.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Reprieve From Execution
description: A woman who was sentenced to death for the poisoning of her husband 19 years ago was granted a reprieve by the State Supreme Court today, less than 20 hours before she was to die in the electric chair. The 46-year-old prisoner, Judi Buenoano, would be the second woman to be executed in the United States since the Supreme Court reinstated the death penalty 13 years ago.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Addenda
description: * Doremus & Co. and Rifkind Pondel & Parsons said yesterday that they had combined their Los Angeles-based financial advertising divisions, forming Doremus/Pondel & Parsons.

title: Mazda-Ford Effort Planned for Europe
description: The Mazda Motor Company and the Ford Motor Company plan a venture to produce compact cars in Europe based on existing Mazda models, a Mazda official said. Japan's fourth-largest automobile maker and its American partner expect to produce the cars in southwestern West Germany, the official said. He declined to say whether the venture would require a new factory or use an existing Ford plant.

title: Hunt Manufacturing Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 3
Stratus Computer Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Corrections
description: A picture caption in The Living Section yesterday about Adirondacks restaurant in Washington misidentified the chef. He is Gethin D. Thomas; Michael McCarty is the owner.

title: Northeast Bancorp reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The company said chargeoffs grew to $39 million in the fourth quarter reflecting the sagging New England economy, and resulting in a doubling of the reserve for possible loan losses.

title: Mega-League Weighed
description: In a conference call yesterday, officials with nine football independents in the East and Southeast discussed forming an all-sports conference, Sam Jankovich, the University of Miami athletic director, said in Coral Gables, Fla. The talks were the latest in a series in recent years.

title: American Steel & Wire reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: First Northern Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included $76,500 of pre-tax costs from forming a holding company. c-Included gain of about $110,000 from curtailment of a pension plan and a gain of about $259,900 from sale of preferred stock in Federal Home Loan Mortgate Corp.

title: Scientists Link a Defective Gene To a Leading Cause of Blindness
description: A team of scientists in Boston has discovered a defective gene that results in one form of retinitis pigmentosa, an inherited disorder that is a leading cause of blindness.

title: Earnings of Some Suppliers Hurt by Debts of Federated
description: Several large suppliers will reduce the value on their books of the amounts owed them by Federated Stores Inc., which has sought protection of the bankruptcy court, Wall Street analysts said yesterday.

title: Cem Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Mission Valley Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Risk of Hearing Loss Is Growing, Panel Says
description: Millions of Americans are unwittingly suffering a hearing loss because of exposure to loud noises at home, on the job and during recreational activity, a Federal advisory panel said today.

title: Good People Are Not Hard To Place
description: ''DO you have a tie on today?'' asked Judy Wald. ''I'm used to talking to all these creatives who never wear ties, and I have to remind them that Laurent, the restaurant, requires a tie.''

title: Official Takes First Step For Better U.S. Statistics
description: Michael J. Boskin, the chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, yesterday announced the first step in an effort to improve the quality of Government statistics, from the monthly employment rate to the quarterly measures of the gross national product.

title: Ignorance Isn't Bliss in Patent Office Post
description: To the Editor:

title: Review/Art;   Exploring the Connections In a Multi-Faceted Career
description: The retrospective of about 50 of Alan Saret's works at the P.S. 1 Museum in Queens is organized by Alanna Heiss and Chris Dercon to honor someone who has been in many ways unjustly neglected over the last 25 years, although it is difficult to say whether the show does this artist more good than harm.

title: Phillips Reports Loss; Occidental Net Jumps
description: The Phillips Petroleum Company said today that it lost $255 million in the fourth quarter because of regulatory delays and economic misjudgments involving its long-held stake in the Point Arguello project off the southern coast of California.

title: Excerpts From President's News Conference on China and Other Matters
description: Following are excerpts from President Bush's news conference in Washington yesterday, as recorded through the facilities of CNN.

title:
THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING;

People
description: * Lawrence Stogel has been named president and chief operating officer of the Stogel Companies, a New York advertising agency. Philip Stogel will remain chairman and chief executive.

title: UAL Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $24,549,000 in the quarter and income from discontinued operations of $523,929,000 for the year. UAL sold Westin Hotel Co. on Jan. 31, 1988. During the fourth quarter of 1988, it recorded a $24.5 million charge to recognize additional costs assciated with the sale of its nonairline subsidiaries. The provisions for income taxes were $8.7 million in the fourth quarter of 1988 and $323.5 million in the year 1988. Latest fourth-quarter results recognized $60 million of actual and estimated fees and expenses incurred in connection with the pilots-management buyout offer, which collapsed in October after financing could not be arranged. Partially offsetting those buyout-related costs was a $40.7 million reversal of accrued expense for stock appreciation rights related to the plunge in the value of UAL stock after the original bid failed. Latest fourth-quarter results also included a $34 million gain on the sale of certain property rights and a $53.6 million gain on disposition of property, principally aircraft. The average number of common shares outstanding used in calculating earnings per share was 21,656,887 for the year 1989 and 29,681,394 for the year 1988. The difference in the number of shares outstanding during these periods resulted principally from UAL's purchase of 35,500,000 shares of its common stock on March 29, 1988, pursuant to a self-tender offer.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Advance Circuits Inc., Minnetonka, Minn., a manufacturer of printed circuit boards, named its president, Robert W. Heller, to the additional post of chief executive. He replaces Thomas F. Leahy, who will remain chairman.

title: Money Fund Assets Up
description: The assets of the nation's 490 money market mutual funds increased by $1.64 billion, to $383.07 billion, for the week that ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday. The assets of the 149 institutional funds decreased by $294.2 million, to $92.41 billion. The assets of the 243 general-purpose funds were up by $1.16 billion, to $128.08 billion. The 98 broker-dealer funds rose by $771.8 million, to $162.58 billion, the institute said.

title: Lin Broadcasting reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The latest quarter loss included non-recurring charges of $69,887,000 principally attributable to the termination in December of an agreement and plan of merger with BellSouth Corp. The latest year included non-recurring expenses related to BellSouth and takeover defense costs of $76,629,000.

title: Same Stage, Old Drive, New Role
description: In some ways, he was a defensive version of John Elway in Bronco orange and blue. During the consecutive seasons that ended with Super Bowl appearances, Karl Mecklenburg was an All-Pro-caliber player with skills that made him the most noticeable part of his unit.

title: Washington at Work;   Living With Washington Mayor: Sense of Realism as a Tonic for Rumors
description: Last Sunday, after Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. publicly and tearfully confessed to ''weaknesses'' and prepared to enter a substance abuse clinic, he turned and planted a big kiss on the cheek of his wife, Effi. ''She's just great,'' he said. ''For our family,'' she responded, ''this is just the beginning.'' Then, arm in arm, they departed. There was more to that exchange and departure than met the ear or eye.

title: Charles Goldstein, Postal Executive, 83
description: Charles Goldstein, former operations director of the New York branch of the Postal Service, died of bone cancer on Tuesday at his home in Bloomfield, N.J. He was 83 years old.

title: Kenyan Leader to Visit U.S.
description: President Daniel arap Moi of Kenya will begin a three-day private visit to the United States on Monday, diplomatic sources said today. Kenya is one of Washington's closest allies in Africa and the United States Navy has access to the base at the Kenyan port of Mombasa. Mr. Moi last visited the United States in March 1987.

title: Cuts in Social Security Could Go to Medicare
description: To the Editor:

title: PRESIDENT UNVEILS NEW DRUG EFFORTS
description: Declaring that the fight against drug abuse is the big test of his Administration, President Bush today unveiled a new narcotics program that immediately drew criticism for its continued emphasis on law enforcement and stopping drug shipments.

title: Security System at Nuclear Sites Adapted for Use at Airports
description: Security systems that guard nuclear arms sites are being adapted for an airport in a test program given high priority by the Federal Aviation Administration.

title: Sonic Guard Charged
description: Dale Ellis, the guard who leads the SuperSonics in scoring, was charged in Seattle yesterday with drunken and reckless driving during a car accident on Jan. 12 in which Ellis suffered three broken ribs and a punctured lung.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in Sports Pages yesterday about the baseball labor negotiations referred incorrectly to a method of making revenue-sharing acceptable to the players. The method was not offered by the owners, but was posed in a question to both sides by the reporter.

title: Deals
description: Basketball

title: Police Say Bias Crime Declines in New York
description: The Police Department said yesterday that bias crimes in New York City decreased slightly from 1988 to 1989, but officials said gay-related bias crimes increased slightly.

title: Chronicle
description: Former Mayor JOHN V. LINDSAY of New York was released yesterday from New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center, where he had been taken Tuesday after he felt dizzy at lunch at the Century Club. He had simply suffered a transient drop in blood pressure, said Diana Goldin, a hospital spokeswoman.

title: Alabama Tornado Injures 24
description: A tornado swept through a trailer park here early today, injuring 24 people. Among them was a boy who witnesses said was freed by a man who managed to lift the corner of the mobile home that had pinned the child down. No deaths were reported from the tornado, which hit about 5:30 A.M., when most people were sleeping in this community 40 miles south of Montgomery.

title: Chronicle
description: BARBARA BUSH chose a chum from Texas to head the new White House Endowment Fund, which is to keep up the public rooms at the executive mansion and its sizable collection of art, furniture, porcelain and crystal.

title: Japan Still No. 1 in Cars
description: Japan remained the world's largest auto maker in 1989, the country's leading automobile trade group said today. Analysts predicted it would maintain the lead in 1990. Japan's output in 1989 was 13.03 million vehicles, up 2.6 percent from 1988. Output surpassed the 10.85 million vehicles produced in the United States in 1989, the Japan Automobile Manufacturers Association said.

title: Falmer Journal;   When No Detail Is Too Trivial, Write It All Down
description: The personal observations and quiet reflections of ordinary people leading ordinary lives are coming together here as a vivid collage of life.

title: NBC Marketing
description: NBC-TV said yesterday that it was consolidating its varied marketing activities. The effort will be headed by John Miller, who was promoted to executive vice president for marketing. Mr. Miller will retain responsibility for the advertising and promotion for the network's entertainment, news and sports divisions. He will also oversee client, affiliate and network sales marketing.

title: Inquiry Finds Taxiway Takeoff
description: Federal investigators said yesterday that evidence had confirmed that an Eastern Airlines jet took off from a taxiway, rather than from the runway parallel to it, on a flight from Philadelphia last week. The pilots of the jet have consistently denied doing so.

title: Crawford & Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Traditions in Spanish Film: An 82-Year Retrospective
description: The names of Luis Bunuel, Carlos Saura and Pedro Almodovar are familiar to many American filmgoers. But there is a richer tradition of Spanish film making than even those names suggest, a tradition with provocative ties to the political and social ideologies that have long played an important part in Spanish life and thought. That is the thesis of ''Spanish Cinema: The Politics of Family and Gender,'' a 3-week festival of films by 19 directors that opened this week at the Anthology Film Archives.

title: Torchmark Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results included realized investment gains and losses. Per share investment losses were realized for the latest and year-ago quarters. For the full year, per share realized investment gains were less than 1 cent in 1989, compared with capital losses in 1988.

title: Pacts for 2 More
description: Ted Higuera of the Milwaukee Brewers and Glenn Davis of the Houston Astros reached agreements yesterday on 1990 salaries.

title: The Lady in Red
description: In the arrest of Mayor Marion Barry of Washington, the Department of Justice argues that a good end justifies bad means. Wrong.

title: Frederick C. Abdelnour, Merchant, 79
description: Frederick C. Abdelnour, former owner and president of Frederick's of Greenwich, a Connecticut clothing store for women, died of Parkinson's disease on Tuesday at a nursing home in Rye Brook, N.Y. He was 79 and lived in Mamaroneck, N.Y.

title: AT THE MOVIES
description: The Mermaid's Voice

title: Rochester Gas & Electric Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results for the latest quarter and year were increased by about 36 cents and 63 cents a share, respectively, by a change in accounting to include an estimate for unbilled revenues for energy already delivered. Results for the latest quarter and year were reduced by about 5 cents a share by estimates of disallowed expenses for the Nine Mile Two Nuclear Power Plant. These expenses are being negotiated with the Public Service Commission. The periods were also reduced 5 cents a share by deferral of 50 percent of the company's gas earnings for the 12 months ended July 1989 that were above the level authorized by the PSC.

title: Dow Corning reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Dow Corning is a joint venture between Dow Chemical Co. and Corning Inc. so there is no share earnings.

title: National Intergroup reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $10,659,000 and $31,426,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and extraordinary credits of $12,330,000 and $27,341,000 for the same periods, respectively. c-Included income from discontinued operations of $24,127,000 and $37,900,000 for the quarter and 9 months, respectively, and extraordinary credits of $4,400,000 and $9,715,000 for the same periods, respectively. d-Net loss Results for the latest quarter and 9 months included a $14.7 million gain on the sale of two aluminum divisions; extraordinary items of $10.2 million and $16.2 million, respectively, from utilization of net operating loss carryforwards; and $2.1 million and $10.9 million, respectively, for gains on the repurchase of subordinated notes. Year-ago quarter and 9-month results included an $18 million gain on the sale of a tube company; disposition losses of $10.7 million and $19.4 million, respectively, for certain Foxmeyer Corp. subsidiaries; and extraordinary items of $4.4 million and $9.6 million, respectively, from utilization of net operating loss carryforwards. Per share amounts are for income from continuing operations; discontinued operations and extraordinary items were not immediately available.

title: Washington's 2 Law Worlds Clash in Barry Case
description: As befitting a city with a split personality, Washington has two distinct groups of lawyers.

title: Upheaval in the East;   Five of the Financiers Investing in Hungary
description: Andrew Sarlos

title: Rorer Group reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said figures for the latest quarter and year included a $19.9 million pre-tax gain related to a merger-termination fee paid by A.H. Robins Co. The gain was partially offset by restructuring costs totaling $9,981,000 pretax.

title: Claiborne Hosiery
description: Altschiller Reitzfeld Davis/Tracy-Locke has won the advertising account for Liz Claiborne Inc.'s hosiery line, which was recently licensed to Hanes Hosiery, a division of the Sara Lee Corporation. The agency already handles the Liz Claiborne fragrance business. Billings for the hosiery account were not disclosed. An industry official said that new campaigns for such products typically bill between $5 million and $10 million.

title: No Headline
description: It has been eight years since a State Superior Court judge ruled that the overcrowding at the Hudson County Jail here was unconstitutional and ordered a new jail built.

title: Cooper Industries Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Latest quarter and year included results of Champion Spark Plug Co. from March 23, 1989 and Cameron Iron Works from Nov. 29, 1989. Year-ago quarter and prior year results are restated to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split on March 20, 1989.

title: New York State Electric & Gas Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Alka-Seltzer Puts Humor Back in Ads
description: Alka-Seltzer is at it again. In the 1960's and 1970's Alka-Seltzer entertained television viewers with a barrage of funny commercials that introduced such well-known lines as, ''Try it, you'll like it'' and ''I can't believe I ate the whole thing.''

title: Shed Light in All Corners of Academic Tenure;   Harvard Law Furor
description: To the Editor:

title: BRIEFS
description: * ABB Asea Brown Boveri A.G., the Swiss-Swedish engineering group, said it had put two U.S. subsidiaries, Georgia Kaolin Co. and C-E Minerals, up for sale. ABB acquired the mineral companies as part of its purchase of Combustion Engineering Inc. last year.

title: Even Good News Is Late With a Science Contest
description: Five weeks ago, a late package caused panic to sweep through Stuyvesant High School in Manhattan. Yesterday, a late letter inspired celebration.

title: Coppola and Company File for Bankruptcy
description: Francis Coppola and Zoetrope Productions, a wholy owned subsidiary of his Zoetrope Corporation, filed for Chapter 11 protection in a Santa Rosa, Calif., bankruptcy court this morning.

title: Diner's Journal
description: Middle Eastern Exotica

title: KEY RATES
Henry G. Russell, Professor, 77
description: Dr. Henry G. Russell, a professor and college administrator, died Monday at Doctor's Hospital, after a long illness. He was 77 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Union Carbide Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Latest quarter results included a non-recurring after-tax charge of $56 million, or 40 cents a primary share, mainly representing facility shutdown costs and severance and relocation benefits associated with restructuring the bulk and packaged gas business of Union Carbide's industrial gas subsidiary. This after-tax charge of $56 million included $45 million, or 32 cents a primary share, representing personnel costs and costs resulting from the shutdown of marginal facilities. The $11 million balance included costs involved in completing the worldwide realignment of the company's core businesses as subsidiaries of Union Carbide, and the cost of restructuring a carbon products facility in Canada. Year-ago quarter results included an after-tax charge of $58 million, or 43 cents a share, for the settlement of Bhopal litigation.

title: New Partner Joins Stride Rite Bid
description: Walsh, Greenwood & Company and FS Champ Associates said Roger Holland had agreed to join them in their effort to acquire the Stride Rite Corporation. The group has offered $32 a share for Stride Rite, a bid that values the shoe company at about $850 million. Stride Rite's board is to review the offer next Monday. Stride Rite's shares rose 37.5 cents today, to $25, on the New York Stock Exchange.

title: Southdown Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $1,569,000, or 9 cents a share, and $11,596,000, or 69 cents a share, for the quarter and year, respectively, and an extraordinary credit of $33,417,000, or $1.96 a share, for the same periods. c-Included income from discontinued operations of $8,841,000, or 53 cents a share, and $19,771,000, or $1.39 a share, for the quarter and year, respectively, and the year also included an accounting adjustment gain of $19,600,000, or $1.39 a share.

title: The Man Who Would Be Elway
description: rrA sportswriter whispered to another yesterday morning that John Elway was not feeling so hot. In fact, the source said from behind the back of his hand that the Denver star quarterback had lost 10 pounds in the last few days with some kind of mysterious virus, perhaps, or maybe it was something he ate.

title: Amdahl Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 29
description: b-Restated to reflect the acquisition of Key Computer Laboratories Inc., in February 1989. The acquisition was accounted for as a pooling of interests, combining Key's financial results in prior years with those of Amdahl.

title: Walter John Lee, Publisher, 83
description: Walter John Lee, the owner and publisher of The Westfield (N.J.) Leader for 62 years, died on Wednesday at his home in Westfield after a long illness. He was 83 years old. Mr. Lee took over The Westfield Leader, a weekly newspaper, from his father in 1928, shortly after graduating from Lehigh University. He was still publishing the 100-year-old newspaper at the time of his death.

title: Fox Broadcasting to Seek Syndication Rules Change
description: In a break with other Hollywood studios, the 20th Century-Fox Film Corporation's Fox Broadcasting unit plans to ask the Federal Communications Commission to change the regulations that have prevented networks from maintaining a financial interest in the programs they broadcast, the studio's chairman, Barry Diller, said last night.

title: Coke-Disney Pact
description: The Coca-Cola Company and the Walt Disney Company signed a 15-year marketing agreement, extending an association that dates to 1942. The deal calls for Coke products to be available exclusively in all Disney theme parks. Coca-Cola will also have exclusive rights to use certain Disney characters in advertising. Terms of the deal were not disclosed.

title: Wide Abuse of Medical Students Found
description: Abuse and mistreatment of medical students are widespread and often leave long-lasting emotional scars that may affect their care of patients as physicians, new studies being published today show.

title: Dance Bands Whose French Isn't Gallic
description: Spanish, the saying goes, is the loving tongue, but French, increasingly, is the language the world dances to. It's not the French of Maurice Chevalier or Edith Piaf; it's Creole-ized French from places where colonizers and emigrants ran into the African diaspora - in the Caribbean, in Africa and on the Louisiana bayou. It is the language for the dance music coming out of Paris studios as well as for the homegrown, accordion-driven party music of Gulf Coast dancehalls, and while the dialects change from country to country, the exhortation ''Allons dansez!'' is a universal imperative.

title: FLUORIDE HELD CLUE TO CANCER IN RATS
description: Researchers have found preliminary evidence that fluoride causes cancer in male rats, Federal officials said today. But they cautioned that the study did not suggest that the fluoride in water and toothpaste would cause cancer.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: THE ECONOMY

title: Chronicle
description: After distributing a couple of million dollars in scholarships for minority students, OPRAH WINFREY has gone one step further. She bought all the tickets for the first Broadway performance of AUGUST WILSON'S new play, ''The Piano Lesson.'' Then she gave them to A Better Chance, an organization in Boston that arranges for minority students to attend leading private schools.

title: Tibet's Martial Law Must Also Be Lifted
description: To the Editor:

title: The Supplemental Income Poor Deserve More
description: To the Editor:

title: Laclede Gas Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Data General Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 30
Japan's Far Right Lauds Shooting Of Mayor Who Criticized Hirohito
description: Less than a week after the Mayor of Nagasaki was shot and critically wounded for suggesting that Emperor Hirohito was partly responsible for World War II, more than two dozen far-rightist groups have publicly endorsed the attack.

title: MANDELA APPEAL CALLS ON PRETORIA FOR NEGOTIATIONS
description: In his first major public pronouncement since he was imprisoned for life more than a quarter of a century ago, Nelson Mandela has appealed to South Africa's white rulers to move urgently toward negotiations for majority rule so as to save the country from ''civil strife and ruin.''

title: Ruth Jaeger, Psychoanalyst, 89
description: Dr. Ruth Jaeger, one of the first American women to practice psychoanalysis, died of a heart attack yesterday at Middlesex Memorial Hospital in Middletown, Conn. She was 89 years old and lived in Middletown.

title: Louisiana Land & Exploration reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $2.8 million from the early retirement of debt, and included a $12.5 million gain on sale of real estate. c-Net loss and after a gain of $36.9 million, or $1.19 a share, from an adjustment in accounting, and included a $54 million after-tax restructuring charge and an $11.7 million after-tax provision for pending litigation.

title: Treasury Prices Move Downward
description: A news service report about comments by Alan Greenspan, the Federal Reserve chairman, sent shudders through the credit markets yesterday and pushed down prices of Treasury notes and bonds.

title: Acme Steel Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary tax credit of $1,010,000, or 17 cents a share.

title: Threat of Oil Shortage by '93 Seen
description: The deputy chairman of the British Petroleum Company predicted today that oil supply shortages could occur as early as 1993 or 1994 because of OPEC's inability to expand production. A possible increase in demand for oil from Eastern Europe could add to the strain on supplies, he added.

title: General Public Utilities reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said that included in 1989 results was an accounting change under which costs for scheduled nuclear outage maintenance are recorded when related revenues are realized, not as costs are incurred. This change reduced net income for the quarter by $4.1 million and for the year by $12,868,000.

title: Shell Canada Ltd.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Results are in Canadian funds. The company is listed on the Toronto and Montreal stock exchanges.

title: Ava Gardner Is Dead at 67; Often Played Femme Fatale
description: Ava Gardner, a North Carolina sharecropper's daughter who became one of the most bewitching movie actresses in the world, died of pneumonia yesterday at her home in the Kensington section of London. She was 67 years old.

title: Large Gap Separates Owners and Players
description: Two weeks before the day the owners will decide whether or not to begin spring training as scheduled, negotiators for the owners and the players are no closer to reaching an agreement on a new labor contract than when they began talking two months ago.

title: Donnelley (R.R.) & Sons Co.(N) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a net gain of $3.4 million from the sale of land. c-Included a one-time gain of $5.6 million from the purchase of certain tax benefits under the Alaskan Native Claim Settlement Act.

title: Square D Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $2,041,000. c-Included income from discontinued operations of $397,000, or 1 cent a share, and $5,478,000, or 20 cents a share, for the quarter and year, respectively. Latest periods' income from continuing operations included a charge for restructuring costs of $17.8 million.

title: Unisys's Creator Stepping Down
description: With his dream of competing head-on against the International Business Machines Corporation and the Digital Equipment Corporation still an illusive goal, W. Michael Blumenthal said yesterday that he was stepping down as chief executive of the Unisys Corporation to become a limited partner at Lazard Freres & Company.

title: International Technology reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Quotation of the Day
description: ''I now consider it necessary in the national interest for the African National Congress and the Government to meet urgently to negotiate an effective political settlement.''

title: Nynex Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income Results for latest quarter and year included after-tax charges of $325 million including operational restructuring, asset writedowns, work stoppage, benefit plan changes, and regulatory and other items. The company said that regarding dampening effects on its telecommunications operations, it recorded charges of about $120 million for operational restructuring, including early retirement incentive programs, which combined are expected to reduce the workforce by about 4,200, and various business consolidations. Under asset writedowns, the company took charges totaling about $90 million for items such as unusually large inventory and billing adjustments. In addition, the company said it had fourth-quarter charges of about $100 million for such items as deferred vacation payments, delayed installations, and other strike-related matters. The company also recorded a charge of about $90 million relating to changes in the benefit plan. In regulatory and other areas, the company took total charges of about $110 million, mostly related to the tentative agreement between the New York State Public Service Commission staff and New York Telephone. Also included in this category were charges for network software enhancement and debt refinancing.

title: Bay State Gas Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Worst Loss Of Season For Knicks
description: Maybe the Knicks will find happiness Saturday night in Denver against the Nuggets, the next stop in what shows signs of being a trip to nowhere.

title: Review/Film;   Toil And Trouble In Emerging Africa
description: Francis Girod's 1978 film ''L'Etat Sauvage'' (''The Wild State''), based on Georges Conchon's 1964 Prix Goncourt novel, is a seriously half-baked movie that oversimplifies problems of genuine political and social interest. The film opens today at the Public Theater.

title: A.T.& T. Has a Profit; Nynex Reports Loss
description: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company yesterday reported strong profits for its fourth quarter, helped by cost-cutting measures, the removal of two important regulatory restrictions and modest revenue growth.

title: Judith Kaufman Weds B. S. Levin
description: Judith Mandelkorn Kaufman and Bernard S. Levin were married last evening by Rabbi Howard Kaplansky at the United Hebrew Temple in St. Louis.

title: Stock Split At Teledyne
description: Teledyne Inc. said today that its directors had approved a 5-for-1 split of its common stock and a plan to spin off its insurance and finance units.

title: Review/Art;   Minimalism On the March: More and More Less and Less
description: MINIMAL ART, that paragon of 1960's modernism, has never completely dropped from view, but right now it is so omnipresent that it looks like the flavor of the month. In numerous galleries, most of them in SoHo, Minimalism's simplified forms and surfaces are visible in various guises, phases and degrees of originality - and from different generations.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: International A2-13

title: Getting Mad, Getting Even
description: In heading off what looked three days ago like a sure defeat on the China issue, President Bush proved today that a popular leader, if sufficiently aroused, can still change votes on Capitol Hill, even in this day of lax party discipline and constantly shifting coalitions.

title: Seven in Detroit Hospital Die of Common Bacteria
description: A mysterious outbreak of a bacterial infection in a hospital's surgical ward has been implicated in the deaths of seven patients and has forced the isolation of 20 others, officials said today.

title: Review/Recital;   Ukrainian Violinist Returns To Carnegie After 19 Years
description: When Alfred Schnittke wrote the solo work ''A Paganini'' in 1982 for the Ukrainian violinist Oleg Krysa, he was obviously banking on a brilliant technique matched by a fiery and rather quirky temperament. Mr. Krysa's Carnegie Hall recital on Sunday afternoon, complete with a gripping performance of ''A Paganini,'' triumphantly bore out Mr. Schnittke's assumptions and revealed other aspects of the violinist's artistry and personality as well.

title: Carol Wincenc, Flutist
description: Carol Wincenc is to be the soloist with the American Composers Orchestra in the world premiere of Joan Tower's Flute Concerto at Carnegie Hall on Sunday afternoon at 3. The program, which will be conducted by Hugh Wolff, also includes John Adams's ''Short Ride in a Fast Machine,'' Walter Piston's Symphony No. 4 and the New York premiere of Gerald Levinson's ''Anahata.'' Tickets: $28 to $9. Information: 247-7800.

title: Try Again With Solo Police Cars
description: The idea of using one-officer patrol cars has come and gone in New York City, and now it's back. The new Police Commissioner, Lee Brown, is considering the idea, and a civic group, the Citizens Budget Commission, is energetically lobbying for it. The police union objects, arguing that solo patrol isn't safe. But with the city's finances so weak that the Mayor had to delay hiring 1,800 police recruits, the proposal at least deserves a test.

title: McDonald's Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share earnings and shares outstanding are restated for 2-for-1 common stock split declared in May. Systemwide sales for the latest periods totaled $4,471,274,000 for the quarter and $17,333,430,000 for the year, compared with $4,138,184,000 and $16,063,639,000 for the year-ago periods, respectively.

title: Israeli Warplanes Hit Guerrillas Near Sidon
description: Israeli fighter jets destroyed a southern Lebanon base of a radical Palestinian guerrilla group today, in the second such air strike in a week, the police said.

title: History, Justice and Heroism In the Films of John Ford
description: IN John Ford's final film, a doctor in a cowboy hat rides a horse into town, battles a cholera epidemic and dies to save innocent people from a horde of marauding bandits - a scenario almost too typical to mention, except that the doctor is Anne Bancroft. The female hero of ''Seven Women'' is as unusual for Ford as the film itself, a now-laughable 1965 melodrama about a gaggle of American missionaries in China in 1935. But by the time ''Seven Women'' is over, Ms. Bancroft's tough-talking, noble Dr. Cartwright also seems suspiciously like other Ford heroes, from John Wayne's fair-minded outlaw in ''Stagecoach'' to the fugitive Henry Fonda thirsting for social justice at the end of ''The Grapes of Wrath.''

title: Pope, Citing Third-World Needs, Begins Visit to 5 African Nations
description: Pope John Paul II began a journey today to some of the world's poorest countries with a plea that the turmoil in Eastern Europe not overshadow pressing third world needs.

title: Benefits Approved for Koch Officials Under Eased Severance Rules
description: Severance benefits as high as $80,000 have been approved for dozens of senior officials in the administration of former Mayor Edward I. Koch under personnel rules liberalized by Mr. Koch four years ago.

title: International Rectifier reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: Reviews/Theater;   Mabou Mines Creates a 'King Lear' All Its Own
description: To that perennial list of suspects thought by some to be the true authors of Shakespeare's plays - the Earl of Oxford, Christopher Marlowe, Francis Bacon - one is now tempted to add John Waters, the Baltimore film maker best known for ''Hairspray,'' the classic retro movie about early 1960's rock-and-roll and racial conflict. Or so one might think after taking in the Mabou Mines production of ''Lear'' at the Triplex Theater.

title: Bruins Use 3d-Period Scoring Burst to Show Up Islanders
description: The Islanders, who for the last month have been the hottest team in the National Hockey League, tonight stood skate-to-skate with the best team in the league and were ultimately dwarfed by it.

title: Upheaval in the East: Hungary;   U.S. Envoy in Hungary Quits To Handle Investment in East
description: R. Mark Palmer, the United States Ambassador here, is resigning from the State Department to manage a new consortium of North American financiers that today announced the purchase of half interest in a Hungarian bank, the first in what was projected as a series of ambitious investments in Eastern Europe.

title: A New Bullock's
description: R. H. Macy & Company said it would open a 240,000-square-foot Bullock's department store in the Regional Shopping Center complex in Burbank, Calif. The new Bullock's, the first in Burbank, will open in the fall of 1992. Macy's said that the new store was part of a commitment to expand the Bullock's chain in Southern California and that it was among seven new stores Macy's plans to open in the next four years.

title: Energy Project Imperils a Rain Forest
description: Bulldozers and drill platforms have come here to the Wao Kele O Puna, the last big tropical rain forest in the United States, where a showdown over the fate of this jungle may ultimately determine the fate of modern Hawaii as well.

title: SOUNDS AROUND TOWN
description: On Piano

title: Corrections
description: An article and a summary chart on Tuesday about automobile insurance in New Jersey misstated the percentage of drivers insured by the Joint Underwriting Association, a state agency established to cover high-risk drivers. At its peak, the association insured half of the state's drivers; it now insures 40 percent.

title: Allergan Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company, formerly a division of SmithKline Beckman Corp., became a stand-alone public company on July 27, 1989, resulting in a new capital and administrative structure. Therefore, financial data was adjusted to a ''pro forma'' basis to meaningfully compare 1989 with 1988 results.

title: Home Resales Off 4.6% in '89
description: Sales of existing homes edged down in December, bringing the 1989 total to 3.43 million units, or 4.6 percent less than the previous year's sales, a real estate trade group said today.

title: Belo (A.H.) Corp.(N) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a writedown of syndicated programming totaling $6.1 million pretax, which reduced net earnings by $4 million.

title: 43.46 Decline Leaves Dow At 2,561.04
description: The Dow Jones industrial average of 30 blue-chip stocks plunged 43.46 points, to 2,561.04, yesterday, as upward pressure on interest rates and the flow of poor corporate profits kept many investors on the sidelines.

title: Campbell Is Against a Sale
description: The Campbell Soup Company, which is facing calls for its sale from a dissident shareholder group, said today that it had decided to remain independent.

title: Auctions
description: Sotheby's Solution

title: Upheaval in the East: Rumania;   The Old Guard in a New Government
description: One month after Nicolae Ceausescu and his wife were executed as despots, this nation is lurching awkwardly under the influence of those who finally overthrew the old regime as well as those who had helped sustain it in power for 24 years.

title: Upheaval in the East: East Germany;   Berlin Party Sets Conditions for Staying in Cabinet
description: The East German Christian Democratic party, one of four small parties joined with the Communists in the interim Government now running the country, said today it would withdraw from the cabinet in two weeks and rejoin only in a grand coalition with the entire opposition.

title: Total Petroleum (North AmerFica) Ltd.(A) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included loss of $6.7 million relating to the planned disposal of participation in the Peace River Fertilizer plant. c-Included gain of $11.9 million and $15.7 million on the sale of oil and gas producing assets in the U.S. for the quarter and year, respectively, and the year also included a gain of $6.4 million resulting from a gas contract litigation settlement.

title: N.F.L.'s Drug-Testing Program Called Inconsistent and Unfair
description: The pregame hype that usually fills the air at the Super Bowl was overshadowed today by a swirl of rumors and accusations involving the National Football League's drug testing of players.

title: Arkansas Stops Texas To Gain First Place
description: Oliver Miller scored 8 of his 19 points down the stretch and Todd Day had a career-high 34 points as sixth-ranked Arkansas held off Texas, 109-100, tonight and took over first place in the Southwest Conference.

title: Mitsui Bank Joins in U.S. Buyout Fund
description: The Mitsui Bank, which started a modestly successful mergers and acquisition team in New York four years ago, announced yesterday that it had formed a relationship with the Carlyle Group, a Washington-based merchant banking firm.

title: Edberg and Lendl Gain Australian Final
description: LEAD: In a whirlwind effort that lasted 1 hour 23 minutes, Stefan Edberg of Sweden completely outplayed his friend and countryman Mats Wilander today and scored a 6-1, 6-1, 6-2 victory in the semifinals of the Australian Open.

title: Dining Out Guide: Chinese New Year
description: This is a summary of reviews of restaurants that have appeared in The New York Times. Stars are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current. Auntie Yuan

title: Georgia-Pacific Gains 21.7%
description: The Georgia-Pacific Corporation said yesterday that its fourth-quarter net ionome rose 21.7 percent, reflecting strong building-product sales and a share repurchase program.

title: First Victory in the Drug War
description: Just as President Bush was announcing his updated national drug control strategy yesterday, Democratic Senator Joseph Biden was distributing a drug control plan devised by the Senate Judiciary Committee. This was no quick rebuttal but a 236-page book based on a year of study and 24 hearings.

title: A Giant in 49er Cloth Enjoys His New Flock
description: Jim Burt is 30 years old. He is beginning to look his age despite a new hairstyle seemingly borrowed from a raccoon.

title: Excerpts From Essay By Mandela or Botha
description: Following are excerpts from a statement drawn up by Nelson Mandela before his meeting last year with P. W. Botha, then President of South Africa, and delivered to Mr. Botha before the meeting. The full text was printed today by a Cape Town newspaper.

title: G.M., Ford Add Closings
description: The General Motors Corporation and the Ford Motor Company said Wednesday that nine additional car and truck assembly plants would halt production for at least a week each in the next five weeks, laying off 24,700 employees.

title: Hooker Corp. Asks Aid on Real Estate
description: A Federal Bankruptcy Court has given the L. J. Hooker Corporation permission to hire a real estate concern to help it sell five properties in four states. The holdings are the Forest Fair Mall near Cincinnati; Richland Fashion Mall near Columbia, S.C.; Thornton Town Center Mall near Denver; the Gateway Mall site in Atlanta, and the almost-completed Ten Peachtree Office Center in Atlanta.

title: U.S. Blocking Chinese From American Study
description: Despite concern that China might stop allowing students to go to the United States, many Chinese students say the main obstacle to going abroad is the United States Embassy.

title: Addendum
description: * Scali, McCabe, Sloves has acquired a majority interest in a Dutch advertising agency, Kaspers Koetse Burger & De Roos, which has billings of $15 million.

title: MT.A. Proposes to $15 Billion Plan to Improve and Add Service
description: The chairman of the Metropolitan Transportation Authority said yesterday that up to $15 billion would be needed, starting in 1992, to continue improving service and to pay for the first major expansions of the region's subway and commuter rail systems since the early 1970's.

title: Boston Edison Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income Latest quarter and year included pretax charge of about $179 million relating to provisions for pilgrim nuclear power station litigation and rate proceedings. The company said latest year included an after-tax gain of $5.5 million on eminent domain taking.

title: Federated Recants on Retiree Discounts
description: Thousands of retired employees of the nine retail chains owned by Federated Stores Inc. lost their discounts of 20 to 40 percent when the stores filed for bankruptcy protection last week. It was one of the first cutbacks made after the bankruptcy filing.

title: Raychem Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included $7 million, or 14 cents a share, arising from the sale of two business units.

title: British Ford Plant Remains on Strike
description: One of the Ford Motor Company's main British plants remained closed today by an unofficial strike, even though the company's manual workers have accepted a pay increase. About 550 maintenance craftsmen are on strike at the Halewood factory in northern England. In response, Ford has laid off 8,000 manual workers there.

title: Dinkins Courting Volunteer Lawyers
description: Mayor David N. Dinkins said today that he wants the private sector to support New York City services, and will ask lawyers to volunteer to help reduce a backlog of more than 1,000 discrimination cases at the city's Human Rights Commission, and business executives to supplement drug education in public schools.

title: WEEKENDER GUIDE
description: FRIDAY

title: Hospital Death Not Homicide, Examiner Says
description: The New York City Medical Examiner reversed himself yesterday, ruling that the death of a 78-year-old Brooklyn man whose family disconnected his life-support equipment was not a homicide.

title: A Five-Year Plan Bears Fruit
description: The latest fashion statement on the University of Connecticut campus is a T-shirt with this week's Top 20 college basketball poll of The Associated Press on the front.

title: 40,000 Years of Treasures From a California Tar Pit
description: About 40,000 years ago, oil oozing from the earth's bowels congealed into a cluster of tar lakes along what is now Wilshire Boulevard in Los Angeles. Since then, the monster trap this created has been catching and preserving everything from mites to mammoths, and some of the tar's most interesting victims go on view at the American Museum of Natural History in Manhattan today.

title: Capital Inquiry Calls Some Barry Security Guards
description: Several officers of Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr.'s security detail have been summoned by a Federal grand jury in a widening investigation of drug use and corruption centering on Mr. Barry, Government officials said today.

title: P.&G.'s Net Up 7.7% in Quarter
description: The Procter & Gamble Company said today that its second-quarter earnings rose by 7.7 percent.

title: Topics of The Times;   Customs, Customized
description: Some 58,000 Californians who brought home trinkets from foreign travels last year are understandably furious at learning, after the fact, that they owe a 6.5 percent use tax. They are also learning the rigors of life in the age of computers.

title: Still in Disfavor
description: South Africa is closer to rejoining the Olympics than at any other time since its expulsion 20 years ago, Juan Antonio Samaranch, president of the International Olympic Committee, said at a news conference yesterday while visiting the Commonwealth Games in New Zealand. But he also said the Pretoria Government had a long way to go toward eliminating apartheid before the committee could consider letting the country back into the games. (AP)

title: Ewing Will Start In All-Star Game
description: Patrick Ewing will be making his fourth trip in five seasons to the National Basketball Association All-Star Game, but this year the Knicks' center will be going as a starter for the first time. The game will be played Feb. 11 in Miami.

title: Our Towns;   Pitched Battle: Six Apartments For the Homeless
description: It was five days before Christmas, and Marge Rogatz was delighted. After 18 months of frustration and delay, she had just signed the closing papers on a six-unit apartment building that would be the very first permanent housing for the homeless in the whole of Nassau County. It was also the first acquired by a private agency, Community Advocates Inc., the 18-year-old community-action group of which she is president.

title: Rachel Fitler, Socialite, 93
description: Rachel Fitler, heiress to a rope-manufacturing fortune, died Wednesday at her home in Villanova, Pa. She was 93 years old.

title: Quantum Chemical Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $133,300,000, or $5.31 a share, representing the sale of its Emery Chemicals division. c-Included income from discontinued operations of $5,900,000, or 25 cents a share, and $22,600,000, or 85 cents a share, for the quarter and year, respectively. Per share earnings in all periods were adjusted for 1 percent stock dividend in October. Latest fourth-quarter earnings were adversely effected by costs estimated at $10 million, or 40 cents a share, in excess of estimated insurance recoveries from the fire-related shutdown of the Morris, Ill., petrochemical plant. The company expects the plant to resume production in March.

title: Death of a 'Lost Soul': A Gentle Man Is Killed in His Sanctuary
description: All along the quiet, rundown streets of Charleston, S.I., Michael Taylor and Phillip Sarlo have a reputation for being troublemakers, heavy beer drinkers who start fistfights. One of their favorite targets of ridicule, neighbors say, was James Zappalorti, a 44-year-old emotionally disturbed man. They harassed him, the residents say, because they believed he was gay.

title: D&N Financial reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: What of Ford's Is Showing When
description: ''The Unknown John Ford,'' a five-week film series curated by Tag Gallagher and organized by Richard Koszarski, begins today and runs through March 2 at the American Museum of the Moving Image, 35th Avenue and 36th Street, in Astoria, Queens (718-784-0077). Screenings are included in museum admission: $5 ($4 for the elderly, $2.50 for students and children). Here is the schedule.

title: Phillips Petroleum reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a $280 million after-tax writedown of offshore California investments. c-Net income

title: Interlake Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The quarter and year results were affected by pre-tax losses of $2,358,000 and $26,470,000, respectively.

title: Douglas Reid Brash, Investment Banker, 66
description: Douglas Reid Brash, a retired investment banker, died of cardiac arrest on Wednesday at his home in Essex, Conn. He was 66 years old and lived in Essex and Point O'Woods, L.I.

title: Peggy van Praagh; Ballerina, Teacher And Writer Was 79
description: Peggy van Praagh, an English dancer, ballet mistress and teacher, died in Melbourne, Australia, on Jan. 15. She was 79 years old and had been in poor health for several years.

title: Consortium Set Up for New TV
description: Two rival consumer electronics manufacturers and the National Broadcasting Company said yesterday that they would join forces to produce the next generation of television technology.

title: At Least 24 Are Killed in Floods in Tunisia
description: At least 24 people have died, 32 are missing and thousands are homeless from flooding this week in Tunisia, the official press agency reported today.

title: Contel Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $6,000,000, or 4 cent a share, for the quarter and $10,000,000, or 6 cents a share, for the year. c-After losses from discontinued operations of $22,000,000 resulting from the disposition of Contel business systems and the International division of Contel ASC. for the quarter and $32,000,000 for the year which included an after-tax gain of $43 million, or 27 cents a share, resulting from an initial public stock offering by Contel Cellular Inc., a 90 percent owned unit.

title: Shaw's Self-Important Doctors and Their Totally Dubious Cures
description: Although Shaw called ''The Doctor's Dilemma'' a tragedy, it is of course intended as a comedy, a fact that is not amply in evidence in Larry Carpenter's cumbersome revival of the play at the Roundabout Theater Company.

title: Harman International Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Mencken and the Jews
description: To the Editor:

title: Eastern Sees More Losses Through First Half of Year
description: Eastern Airlines said yesterday that it expected to lose about $155 million in the first half of the year but would come closer to breaking even in the second half. The prediction was made in a reorganization plan presented to the airline's unsecured creditors.

title: Niagara Mohawk Power reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net loss

title: No Quick Fixes For Drug Addicts
description: Yesterday President Bush announced his 1990 National Drug Control Strategy, including $1.5 billion for support of drug treatment services. The President's plan does not, however, endorse what has come to be known as treatment ''on demand.'' Here's why.

title: Another Wasted Chance for Rangers
description: Bernie Nicholls, with a couple of lightning snaps of his wrists just a minute and a half apart, had turned what looked to be a 6-3 rout into a 6-5 slugfest against the Calgary Flames. The Rangers, who for much of the season wouldn't have had a prayer of rebounding from such a deficit, now had a chance.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, a caption in The Home Section yesterday, with a picture of two cartoon characters sold at auction, was erroneous in some copies. The picture was a rare black and white celluloid from ''Orphan's Benefit,'' by Walt Disney.

title: Olin Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a net gain of $13 million on sale of Olin water services, offset by a $12 million charge to exit certain specialty clad metal products and writedown of the company's investment in the interconnect materials business. c-Included a net charge of $10 million from the disposition of a water equipment and services subsidiary, and a $4 million tax benefit from various contributions including the Winchester historical gun collection.

title: MCA Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $39,988,000 for the quarter and $52,987,000 for the year. c-After losses of $1,081,000 and $25,874,000 for the quarter and year, respectively, from discontinued operations. Both 1989 periods' results included revenue of $100 million and a contribution to net income of $63 million from the previously reported sale of MCA's investment in Discovision Associates.

title: Boeing 707: the First U.S. Commercial Jetliner
description: The Boeing 707 was the first American commercial jetliner and has had a strong safety record over the 32 years since it first went into service.

title: Italian Bank in Iraq Accord
description: Italy's largest state bank, Banca Nazionale del Lavoro, which was stunned last August by the discovery that a branch had made $3 billion in unauthorized loans to Iraq, has struck a deal with Baghdad for two-thirds of the money.

title: Children Inspire Gifts to Neediest Cases Fund
description: There is something about working with children - as a social worker, a teacher, a pediatrician, a volunteer -that creates special sensitivity for deprived children.

title: The Roll-Call On China
description: Following is the 62-to-37 roll-call vote by which the Senate refused today to override President Bush's veto of a bill protecting Chinese students in the United States. Although a majority voted to override, the vote was four short of the two-thirds necessary. A yes vote was to override. Voting yes were 54 Democrats and 8 Republicans. Voting no were 37 Republicans. Senators not voting are denoted by xxx.

title: Topics of The Times;   Top Tabulator
description: The late Herman Hollerith has just been elected to the National Inventors Hall of Fame.

title: Conner Growth Claim
description: Conner Peripherals Inc., a manufacturer of hard disk drives for computer data storage, laid claim this week to being the fastest-growing manufacturing start-up company in American history. The San Jose, Calif., company reported revenues of $704.9 million in 1989, its third full year of operations. The Compaq Computer Corporation of Houston, which had said it was the fastest-growing new company until now, had sales of $503.9 million in 1985, its third full year. The growth of Conner is largely tied to the success of Compaq, which is its leading customer. Compaq, which owns a stake in Conner, accounted for 29 percent of Conner's sales in 1989, down from 48 percent in 1988. Conner's sales for the year were nearly triple the $256.6 million recorded in 1988. Earnings more than doubled, to $41.5 million, from $19.8 million in 1988.

title: Cooney on New Track
description: Gerry Cooney, who retired from boxing after being knocked out by George Foreman 11 days ago, has applied for a license to own race horses in New York State.

title: Illinois Awaits Inquiry
description: The University of Illinois basketball program is bracing for a full National Collegiate Athletic Association investigation into its recruiting practices. ''We believe the N.C.A.A. has sufficient information to warrant an official inquiry,'' the Illinois athletic director, John Mackovic, said Wednesday in Champaign. He said the school had not received a letter of official inquiry from the N.C.A.A., but was ''preparing for it.'' (AP)

title: Review/Music;   Band With a Motif of Terror
description: If a panic attack coupled with an existential crisis were turned into music, it might well sound like Voivod, the Canadian band that performed last Friday night at the Ritz. Voivod's music overlays a brutal fibrillating beat with dissonant guitar lines and lyrics that describe futuristic terrors - a dystopia of sadistic technocrats, enslaved workers and uncontrollable machines. As Denis (Snake) Belanger chants and sings in a nightmarish recitative, the music batters and screams, withholding even the pleasure of a regular beat from its listeners.

title: President-Elect of Brazil Pushing Free-Market Ideas
description: Beginning a nine-nation tour to put a ''new face'' on Brazil, the country's president-elect, Fernando Collor de Mello, vowed in New York yesterday to restore growth to Latin America's largest economy through privatization, fiscal discipline and debt relief.

title: PSI Holdings Inc. reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The latest and prior year results were charged 4 cents a share and 57 cents a share, respectively, for reserves to cover the anticipated cost of the tentative settlement of a lawsuit by Wabash Valley Power Association.

title: Article 917990 -- No Title
description: President Bush announced a $1 billion package of grants, loans and other types of assistance today to help Panama rebuild its economy after the American invasion and years of corrupt government by Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega.

title: Huntsman Move On Aristech Bid
description: The Huntsman Holdings Corporation said the Aristech Chemical Corporation had agreed to provide it with confidential financial information on the company. Aristech has rejected an offer of $25 a share, or $842 million, from Huntsman, the largest private chemical concern in the United States. Huntsman, in turn, said it would raise its bid.

title: Alexander & Baldwin Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain from an accounting adjustment of $18,269,000, or 36 cents a share.

title: Restaurants
Cabot Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Mead Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $11,400,000. Share earnings for the latest year included a non-recurring gain of 23 cents a share on sale of Mead Release Products, and the share earnings for the prior year included non-recurring gains of $1.67 a share on sale of 50-percent interest in Brunswick Pulp & Paper Co.

title: Economic Scene;   States Weigh Use Of Pension Funds
description: STATE politicians are increasingly eyeing the pension fund savings of state employees -which have grown to a mouth-watering $700 billion nationwide - as a means to promote local economic development.

title: Georgia-Pacific Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Mylan Laboratories reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Nets Give Orlando A Rare Road Victory
description: The Nets begin a six-game trip on Saturday, and this may be a good time for them to leave town. If they continue playing the way they did tonight, they will have even less fan support at home than they do now.

title: Curtain to Be Lifted on Noriega Wealth
description: The Government said today that it planned to submit documents Friday in Federal District Court here to prove that Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega would have access to adequate resources to flee the country if released on bond.

title: Upheaval in the East;   A Former K.G.B. Chief Champions Azerbaijanis
description: When Geidar A. Aliyev passed through the Moscow office of the Azerbaijani republic this afternoon, a turbulent crowd fell silent and men were startled from their seats, nodding and muttering ''salaam aleikhem'' to the tall, trim figure in navy blue pinstripes.

title: B.C. Telephone reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included an extraordinary credit from the disposal of Microtel's central office switching business of $10,000,000, or 10 cents a share, for both the quarter and year, and the year also included income from discontinued operations of $2,000,000. Year-ago results have been restated to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split. c-Included income from discontinued operations of $2,600,000, or 2 cents a share, for the quarter and $4,900,000, or 5 cents a share, for the year. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Bush in Panama: A Tragicomedy
description: Vice President Quayle's projected Latin American trip to explain that we gringos are good guys after all is a farcical and fitting sequel to the Panama invasion. Even more so, since it has been scaled down to a brief visit to our dependencies Honduras and Panama (with Jamaica thrown in). Now Mr. Quayle's audience is likely to laugh only behind his back, instead of in his face, when he relays President Bush's message to ''all of the countries of Latin America'' that we're still their ''friendly, supportive and respectful neighbor.''

title: Students Find U.S. Embassy a Barrier
description: In his news conference on Wednesday, President Bush pleaded with Congress not to ease the visa rules for Chinese students now in the United States. One of his arguments was that the action might lead China to cut back on future programs of study abroad, which he characterized as an important force for change in China.

title: LaFarge Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Books of The Times;   Dr. Jekyll and Mr. Hyde, as Observed by the Maid
description: Mary Reilly

title: Shed Light in All Corners of Academic Tenure;   Sloppy Work
description: To the Editor:

title: SOUNDS AROUND TOWN
description: Carbon, Percussively

title: Shed Light in All Corners of Academic Tenure
description: To the Editor:

title: The Last Domino
description: The democratic tide in Eastern Europe finally laps against the sealed borders of Albania. This hermetic Balkan enclave has for decades scorned every liberalizing current in the Communist world. But now its Stalinist rulers are busy denying reports of a ruthless police crackdown against dissenters in northern cities.

title: Japonica's Plan To Buy Allegheny
description: Japonica Partners, a New York investment firm, filed a proposal in Federal Bankruptcy Court under which it would buy Allegheny International Inc. for $650 million. Japonica said its plan provided ''substantially greater value'' than a competing plan filed by the company, which Japonica has valued at $570 million.

title: U.S. Health Agency Declares Flu Epidemic
description: The Centers for Disease Control declared yesterday that a nationwide influenza epidemic exists and that it is the most widespread outbreak of the disease since 1984-85.

title: Rep. Luken of Ohio to Retire
description: Representative Thomas A. Luken, Democrat of Ohio, who has served in Congress since 1976, announced Wednesday that he would retire when his term ends Jan. 1.
