Mr. Luken, 64 years old, a lawyer who is a former Cincinnati Mayor, said, ''I expect that this is my swan song in elective office.''

title: UAL Net Plunges by 67%
description: The UAL Corporation, parent of United Airlines, today reported a 67 percent drop in fourth-quarter profit.

title: Homeless: Craziness, Dope and Danger
description: LEAD: Horrifying, yes. But how many subway riders, wary of the deranged homeless who make the subterranean world so menacing, have not fantasized responding to assault with violence the way a passenger did Sunday under Columbus Circle?

title: S.E.C. Halts Bolar's Stock
description: The Securities and Exchange Commission suspended trading today in the stock of the Bolar Pharmaceutical Company for the next 10 days. The move was in response to reports that the New York-based generic drug manufacturer had provided false test data to Government health officials about one of its products.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: Preferred Stock

title: BLAMING U.S., CUBA SUSPENDS PULLOUT
description: Blaming the United States for a rebel attack on Cuban troops in Angola, Havana said today that it was temporarily suspending its troop withdrawal.

title: Selling Autos by Selling Safety
description: After years of insisting that safety features do not sell cars, auto makers have noticed that many prospective buyers think differently. Suddenly, many car ads talk of little else.

title: Occidental Petroleum reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Reduced by an aftertax provision of $45 million in connection with the settlement of an administrative proceeding with the Department of Energy. The company said its 1989 earnings results included a net extraordinary gain of $29 million from the federal income tax benefit realized from the application of a capital loss carryforward to offset capital gains, partially offset by extraordinary losses resulting from the early extinguishment of debt. Earnings for 1989 also included about $49 million of after-tax gains from asset dispositions. Results for 1989 also reflected an after tax charge of $35 million for the restructuring of domestic and oil and gas operations. Earnings results for 1988 included a net extraordinary loss of $11 million from the early extinguishment of debt. Earnings for 1988 also included about $190 million of after tax gains from the issue of stock by a subsidiary and asset dispositions. Occidental Petroleum said its 1988 earnings included gains of $176 million on the issuance of a 25-percent stock interest in a subsidiary owning Colombian operations and $26 million from the reversal of a windfall profits tax reserve no longer required. The company said those benefits were partially offset by a charge in connection with the settlement of the administrative proceeding by the Energy Department. In the 1988 fourth quarter, Occidental Petroleum said it recorded an after-tax charge of $31 million for plant write-downs.

title: Avnet Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 29
Shed Light in All Corners of Academic Tenure;   Cover of Anonymity
description: To the Editor:

title: INSIDE
description: Flu Epidemic Declared

title: McDonald's Net Up 13%
description: The McDonald's Corporation today reported record fourth-quarter earnings of $171.1 million, or 46 cents a share. That is an increase of 13 percent from $151.5 million, or 40 cents a share, in the 1988 quarter. For the year, McDonald's, based in Oak Brook, Ill., earned $726.7 million, or $1.95 a share, up from $645.9 million, or $1.71 a share, in 1988.

title: Review/Film;   Britten's 'War Requiem,' To Images by Derek Jarman
description: Taking Benjamin Britten's ''War Requiem,'' composed for the opening of the new Coventry Cathedral in 1962, Derek Jarman has made a movie of epic irrelevance that, when it rises to the occasion, is merely redundant. It opens today at the Quad.

title: Valentino's Spring Breezes, Givenchy's Bouquets
description: The main thrust of the spring and summer couture openings, which ended this morning, was on pretty clothes, not wild ones. There was little to alarm or perplex. Even the ultrashort hems that looked devastating on the runway will be somewhat modified when they are worn by real people in the real world, for these are, after all, made-to-measure clothes.

title: Witness Backs Prego View of How She Got AIDS
description: An AIDS researcher testified yesterday that he thought Dr. Veronica Prego had contracted the disease as a result of puncturing her finger on a contaminated syringe needle in 1983.

title: Cuts in Military Threaten Big Bases
description: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney is considering closing some of the nation's largest military bases and making deep cuts in the National Guard and reserves of virtually every state, Administration and Congressional officials said today.

title: Chrysler Buys Olympics Time
description: CBS said yesterday that the Chrysler Corporation had made the first purchase of time for the network's coverage of the 1992 and 1994 Winter Olympics.

title:
BUSINESS PEOPLE;

Lawyer to Retire April 1 From Top Hughes Post
description: LEAD: William R. Lummis, the Houston lawyer charged with unscrambling and reorganizing the diverse holdings of the billionaire Howard Hughes, has announced that he will retire as chief executive of the Summa Corporation and its parent, the Hughes Corporation, a real estate development company in which the

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly

title: Profits Scoreboard
Glenfed Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said the latest net included a net gain of 94 cents a share, on a fully diluted basis, resulting from an after-tax gain of $81.1 million on the sale of $350 million of discounted laans, offset by a $30.0 million special addition to general loan loss reserves and an after-tax charge of $20.4 million to adjust the amortization of Glendale Federal Bank's excess servicing asset.

title: It Pays to Count Minutes Rather Than Percentages
description: Robert Barnett, a Washington lawyer, is something of a pioneer in using traditional legal billing practices as a way to add new specialties to his practice.

title: Review/Concert;   June Anderson, With Sinopoli, Tries a New Field
description: It is always heartening when a musician with an established reputation in one area dares to sail out into uncharted seas. June Anderson, who has made a major career as a specialist in bel canto opera, took such a voyage on Wednesday evening at Carnegie Hall when she appeared as the soprano soloist in Berlioz's ''Nuits d'Ete.'' Presented as a cycle with orchestra, as they were in this instance, the six individual songs take on a moody, quasi-narrative flavor that challenges the imaginative gifts of singer and conductor as severely as anything in the vocal literature.

title: Wet Field Irks Coach
description: For the second straight day, the Denver Broncos slipped all over the Tulane University practice field today. The distraction angered Coach Dan Reeves as he continued to prepare his team for the game Sunday against the San Francisco 49ers in Super Bowl XXIV.

title: Public Service Co of Colo.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Unisys Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: 39 Die as Storm Pounds Britain With Gusts Exceeding 100 M.P.H.
description: At least 39 people were reported killed today as storm winds of 100 miles an hour, with even higher gusts and driving rains, swept Britain and surrounding seas.

title: Barnes Group Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income Latest quarter and year results included a $6.5 million pretax charge to cover restructuring costs at its associated spring group. It said the charge reduced 1989 fourth quarter and year earnings by 64 cents a share and 68 cents a share, respectively.

title: Citicorp Floating Securities Are Backed by Credit Cards
description: Citicorp yesterday priced the first-ever issue of floating-rate securities backed by credit card receivables. The bank holding company, the largest issuer in the $20 billion, three-year-old market for credit-card-backed securities, is offering $700 million of the new floating issue through the Money Market Credit Card Trust 1989-1.

title: Israeli Tied to Suspect Colonel Is Discovered Slain in Miami
description: An Israeli businessman linked to a mercenary suspected of training gunmen for Colombia's leading drug traffickers was found slain at Miami International Airport on Wednesday, his body stuffed into the trunk of a car, the police said today.

title: Accounts
description: * Greek National Tourist Organization, to Kaufman & Maraffi, from Scali, McCabe, Sloves, for its United States advertising, with a budget of $2.5 million.

title: Chronicle
description: Prime Ministers don't often have babies, so Pakistanis were understandably elated yesterday when BENAZIR BHUTTO gave birth to a girl. Her personal bodyguard passed out candy after the baby was born, by Caesarean section, at Lady Dufferin Women's Hospital in Karachi.

title: Kill the Spotlight; The Party's Over
description: When the Trumbull Little League All-Stars won the Little League World Series in Williamsport, Pa., last August, the young victors and their families expected a small hometown parade, a couple of plaques, a few local newspaper interviews and not much else, save for a lifetime's worth of memories.

title: Awards Are Given for Broadcast News
description: ''Frontline,'' the public-television documentary series, won the Gold Baton, the highest of the Alfred I. du Pont-Columbia University Awards for broadcast journalism, last night in the annual presentation at Low Library at Columbia University. Three network news divisions, CBS, ABC and CNN, won Silver Batons, for their coverage of the Chinese student rebellion last May.

title: 2 School Districts Told To Fix Bilingual Flaws
description: Schools Chancellor Joseph A. Fernandez ordered two Brooklyn school districts yesterday to submit plans to correct problems in their bilingual education programs by Feb. 2. Failure to do so, he warned, would lead to his taking over the programs.

title: Burnham Pacific Properties reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a one-time capital gain of $2,611,000 resulting from the sale and exchange of the Town & Country shopping center.

title: Dresser Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included extraordinary tax benefits of $2,900,000 and $6,600,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-After an extraordinary tax charge from a reversal of tax loss carryforwards of $14,600,000 for the quarter and the year included an extraordinary tax benefit of $11,300,000 and income from discontinued operations of $22,700,000.

title: Sotheby's Holdings reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said aggregate auction sales for the latest periods were $1.5 billion for the quarter and $2.95 billion for the year, compared with $850 million and $1.82 billion for same year-ago periods, respectively.

title: American President Cos.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income Preferred dividend requirements exceeded net income in the latest year.

title: Upheaval in the East: Tokyo;   Japanese Leader's Europe Trip Missed Mark
description: Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu returned from a trip to Poland, Hungary and Western Europe last week saying Japan had lived up to its new international responsibilities as an economic superpower by offering nearly $2 billion in financial aid to support democracy in Eastern Europe.

title: Bush to Propose Savings Plan Providing Tax-Free Interest
description: The Bush Administration has added the final details to a new savings plan and other programs that it hopes will address what many economists have identified as the nation's No. 1 economic problem, the lagging United States savings and investment rate.

title: GE Aerospace To Cut 5,600 Jobs
description: The General Electric Company's aerospace division said it would eliminate 5,600 jobs in the Eastern United States by 1991, citing tighter Pentagon budgets and mounting competition. The cuts amount to nearly 14 percent of the work force at GE Aerospace, the nation's third-largest military contractor.

title: San Francisco Journal;   Raiders of the Night On Mellifluous Mission
description: The commandos crouched in an unmarked van, cruising Columbus Avenue on a recent night, scouring the darkness for victims. Suddenly the doors flew open and a dozen infiltrators, dressed in red polka dots and leopard print stretch pants and armed to the teeth with Hohner accordions, dashed into a bustling restaurant and began loudly squeezing out ''Lady of Spain.''

title: Results Plus
description: GOLF

title: Illinois Central Railroad Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The 1988 results included a $61.3 million benefit from a change in accounting.

title: Large Secluded Houses And One Busy Road
description: The neighborhood in Cove Neck, L.I., where the Avianca jetliner crashed is one of secluded estates, large homes on sizable wooded lots -and only one road. Last night, that road was jammed with emergency vehicles and with onlookers hoping for a glimpse of the doomed plane.

title: It's the Year of the Horse in Chinese New York
description: Just when you thought that New Year salutations were finally over with, along comes yet another New Year to celebrate this weekend. Admittedly, the beginning of the Year of the Horse, 4688 on the Chinese calendar, may not be a major event for New Yorkers who are not of Chinese or East Asian background, but the holiday will be a time for festivities throughout the city's Chinese community.

title: Gatx Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Plane Crashes on L.I. With 149 Aboard;   At Least 9 Killed on a Boeing 707 From Colombia
description: A Colombian jetliner carrying at least 149 people crashed in heavy fog last night in Cove Neck, L.I., while approaching Kennedy International Airport for a landing, the authorities said.

title: Corrections
description: A headline about Poland yesterday referred incorrectly in some editions to the people occupying Communist Party buildings. They were protesters, not members of Parliament.

title: Not Too Late for Flu Shots
description: Experts on influenza say it is not too late to obtain immunization against the disease in the face of a nationwide epidemic declared yesterday by the Centers for Disease Control in Atlanta.

title: Procter & Gamble reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Share data adjusted for 2-for-1 stock split effective Oct. 20, 1989. Latest quarter and 6-month results included a gain of $91,000,000, or 26 cents a share, from the previously announced sale of the worldwide crush soft-drink business. The latest period earnings were reduced by $174 million, or 50 cents a share, for establishment of a reserve to complete the consolidations of certain major manufacturing facilities which P&G said will reduce costs and improve cash flow. The merger of Noxell Corp. on Nov. 30, 1989, was accounted for as a pooling of interests. Noxell's results are included in P&G results beginning July 1, 1989. Noxell's operations were not material to company's results, so prior year results were not restated.

title: Foreign Investing in U.S. Helps, Greenspan Says
description: Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, told Congress today that foreign investment in the United States spurred competition and new technology. He characterized as overblown concerns about a surge of foreign money invested in the United States.

title: Where to Find the City's Chinese Culture and Commerce
description: The Chinese community of New York, with 300,000 people the largest in the United States, embraces three neighborhoods in three boroughs, and both Chinese and Chinese-American culture and commerce can be found in hundreds of museums, shops, galleries and restaurants throughout the city.

title: Kiley Puzzles Over Meaning In Subway-Platform Slaying
description: The head of New York City's transit system said yesterday that he understood how a subway rider might have felt a ''fatherly instinct'' to protect himself and his 3-year-old son when he responded with what prosecutors called deadly force to an attack by a homeless man.

title: 4 Indian Servicemen Killed in Kashmir
description: Militant separatists here shot and killed four Indian Air Force men and wounded nine today, and the Indian Army took control of this capital of the northern state of Jammu and Kashmir.

title: Bonds in Illinois For Water Agency
description: The Central Lake County Joint Water Agency of Lake County, Ill., is offering $50 million in tax-exempt water-revenue bonds through underwriters led by Smith Barney, Harris Upham & Company. The bond issue offers a maximum yield of 7.35 percent for securities due in 2019 and 2020. For other long maturities, the yield is 7.25 percent for an issue due in 2010.

title: Class of '90 Slowly Marches to Derby Showdown
description: The Kentucky Derby class of 1990 is slowly being unveiled these days in morning workouts here at Gulfstream Park.

title: Upheaval in the East: Turkey;   Turks at Rally Assail Soviet Moves
description: In the snow-clad lee of Mount Ararat, where legend lays Noah's ark to rest, thousands of Azeri Turks gathered here today for a demonstration of support for ethnic kinfolk in Soviet Azerbaijan.

title: Upheaval in the East: European Community;   Britain Proposes Closer U.S. Ties
description: Foreign Secretary Douglas Hurd today proposed a stepped-up schedule of consultations between ministers of the 12 European Community countries and United States officials as part of what he called ''a new consultative partnership'' to deal with rapid change in Eastern and Western Europe.

title: Anna Hedgeman Is Dead at 90; Aide to Mayor Wagner in 1950's
description: Anna Arnold Hedgeman, an educator, civil rights advocate and the first black woman to be a member of a mayoral cabinet in New York City, died Jan. 17 in Harlem Hospital. She was 90 years old and had lived in Harlem for many years.

title: On Stage
description: Musical About Mahalia Jackson

title: New-Music Ensemble
description: Composer's Circle, a newly formed ensemble specializing in new music, is to make its New York debut at St. Peter's Lutheran Church, Lexington Avenue at 54th Street, on Sunday at 2 P.M. The program includes the premieres of sacred choral works by Blake Rowe, Philip Benson and Chandler Carter. Tickets are $5. Information: 935-2200.

title: Potomac Electric Power reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Pasquale to Chargers
description: When the Jets cleaned house after the season, releasing Coach Joe Walton and his assistants, Larry Pasquale, the Jets' special-teams' coach the last nine years, was swept out, too. Now the San Diego Chargers, under their new general manager, Bobby Beathard, are getting their house in order, and have dropped Joe Madden as special-teams coach. His replacement? Pasquale was hired for the job yesterday.(AP)

title: Approval Given To Four Seasons As a Landmark
description: The elegant Four Seasons Restaurant, regarded as a classic monument of modern restaurant design, and the Seagram Building in which it is situated were granted landmark status yesterday by the New York City Board of Estimate.

title: Bush Names 2d Nominee to Rights Post
description: President Bush announced today that he would nominate John R. Dunne, a New York lawyer and former State Senator, for the politically sensitive Justice Department post of Assistant Attorney General for civil rights.

title: Cummins Sues Large Holder
description: The Cummins Engine Company filed a lawsuit yesterday against Industrial Equity (Pacific) Ltd., contending that it had violated disclosure laws and the Hart-Scott-Rodino Antitrust Improvements Act while acquiring 14.9 percent of the engine maker.

title: Ameron Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-Included $1.4 million, or 33 cents a share, for the quarter and $3 million, or 70 cents a share for the year, both of non-recurring expense.

title: LOBBYING EFFECTIVE
description: The Senate voted by a narrow margin today to sustain the President's veto of a bill protecting Chinese students in the United States from deportation. The outcome spared Mr. Bush an embarrassing political defeat and left him relatively free to continue pursuing his own policy toward China.

title: $500 Million Issue By Two Utilities
description: The AEP Generating Company and the Indiana Michigan Power Company yesterday issued an equal amount of secured lease obligation bonds totaling $500 million through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs & Company. Both utilities are units of the American Electric Power Company.

title: LAW: At the Bar;   Of life, limb and the pursuit of unhappiness: An injury lawyer's exchange.
description: Ever represent anyone who's been thrown out of a Hovercraft or who's slipped on some terrazzo stairs? Has any client been forced at gunpoint to withdraw money from a cash machine? Or has a client been bitten by a hog and lost a leg? If so, your fellow lawyers are looking for you.

title: Family Split Over French Publisher
description: The latest episode in the bitter struggle for control of one of France's most prestigious publishing houses, Editions Gallimard, became public today as a Gallimard family member disputed the value of the privately owned empire.

title: American Telephone & Teleraph reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Reduced by $104 million and $393 million for the quarter and year, respectively, for a change in depreciation method and concurrent charges in estimates of depreciable lives and net salvage for certain telecommunications equipment. c-Net loss and included a one-time charge related to the accelerated conversion of its long distance network to fully digital operation of $6,724,000,000 for both the quarter and year. Latest results reflects the acquisitions of Paradyne Corp. and Eaton Financial Corp. in the first quarter and that of Istel Group Ltd. in the fourth quarter.

title: Intel Can't Meet Demand for Chips
description: The Intel Corporation said it was not able to meet the demand for its popular 386 and 386SX microprocessors. But the company said it expects to fulfill all orders by midyear.

title: End Is Seen to Siege Decree in Haiti
description: Haiti's military ruler indicated today that on Friday he would lift the state of siege that he imposed five days ago.

title: Dow Jones & Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included non-recurring gains of $164,149,000, or $1.63 a share, for the latest year and $68,034,000, or 71 cents a share, for the year-earlier period.

title: Upheaval in the East: Soviet Union;   Kremlin Turns Conciliatory Toward Azerbaijani Group
description: The Gorbachev Government took a more conciliatory tone today toward the Azerbaijani Popular Front, saying it undoubtedly included ''healthy forces'' with whom occupation authorities might negotiate.

title: 27-Story Condominium Going Up in Forest Hills
description: LEAD: The first major residential building to be built in Forest Hills, Queens, in almost two decades is nearing completion at Queens Boulevard and 75th Avenue, with buyers expected to take occupancy in May. The building, a condominium called the Embassy, joins a phalanx of older prestige buildings along that stretch of the boulevard.

title: Steinbrenner Promises A Kinder Season for Yanks
description: George Steinbrenner pledged a kinder, gentler world for the Yankees yesterday, promised to communicate more directly with his players, scolded his fellow owners for overspending on salaries and even guaranteed that Bucky Dent would survive the season as manager.

title: Market Place;   Pitfalls Awaiting Any Deal for UAL
description: UNITED AIRLINES' unions have a good chance of achieving their goal of buying the company's parent corporation in their second try, but it will take time. They face some pitfalls along the way though, and this may not be the best time to strike a deal.

title: Allied-Signal reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included income of $23 million, or 16 cents a share, related to an insurance settlement received by Union Texas Petroleum Holdings Inc., in which Allied-Signal has an equity interest. The company said year-ago figures included expenses for provisions of $125 million related to a streamlining and restructuring. Also in 1988 figures is a gain of $36 million, or 24 cents a share, from the sale of an investment and a gain of $81 million, or 54 cents a share, from the sale of a unit and formation of a joint venture.

title: Review/Art;   Tina Barney and Scenes Of Her Life, at the Modern
description: Looking at the photographic tableaux of Tina Barney at the Museum of Modern Art, there is a temptation to say: ''This is upper-middle-class American life.'' The roomy houses are surburban or rural. The people are for the most part healthy, sensitive and decent, and they have grown up with the feeling that outdoor barbecues, big-screen televisions and pink bathrooms are as much God-given rights as air is.

title: Elizabeth-Ann Knapp, A Former Architect, 76
description: Elizabeth-Ann Campbell Knapp, a former architect and chairman of the Campbell Family Foundation, died of cancer on Sunday at her home in Princeton, N.J. She was 76 years old.

title: I.C.H. to Make Offer For First Executive
description: The I.C.H. Corporation said today that it would form a group to make an offer for the First Executive Corporation, the insurance company stung last week by a huge write-off in its ''junk bond'' portfolio.

title: Sara Lee Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 30
description: Year-ago second-quarter and 6-month results included a net pretax gain of $32 million, consisting of a gain of $87 million from the sale of certain subsidiaries and a restructuring charge of $55 million. Share data reflected a 2-for-1 stock split in December 1989.

title: Sonat Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included about $34 million, or 83 cents a share, related to the settlement of Southern Natural Gas Co.'s rate case and Order 500 filing. c-Included about $15 million, or 37 cents a share, from the reversal of reserves related to a regulatory matter that was resolved in the period; $11 million, or 26 cents a share, for income tax refunds and adjustments; plus an extraordinary credit of $13,130,000, or 32 cents a share, due to the cumulative effect of a change in method of accounting for income taxes.

title: Computer Sciences Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Lotus Development Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain from the sale of a unit equivalent to 11 cents a share.

title: For Children
description: Shows, Nature, Museums ''THE SNOW QUEEN,'' a show by Puppetworks, noon on Saturdays and 1 and 3 P.M. on Sundays, through Feb. 25, at the group's theater, 287 Third Avenue, at Carroll Street, Park Slope section, Brooklyn. Children, $4; adults, $5. Information: (718) 834-1828. ''THE FUNZAPOPPIN MAGIC SHOW,'' a show of magic, comedy and music, by Michael Taubenslag Productions, 1:30 P.M. on Sunday; repeat show on Feb. 4, at the Jan Hus Playhouse, 351 East 74th Street. Admission: $4.50. Information: 772-9180. ''THE SECRET GARDEN,'' a musical based on the story by Frances Hodgson Burnett, 12:30 P.M. tomorrow and on Sunday, presented by Theaterworks/USA, at the Promenade Theater, 2162 Broadway, at 76th Street. Tickets: $15 and $12. Reservations: 677-5959. ''THE EARLY SHOW,'' a cabaret for and by children, with audience participation, at noon on Saturdays, at the Duplex, 61 Christopher Street. Admission: $7. Information: 255-5438. ''MAGIC SHOW,'' a show of magic and comedy by Merlin the Magician, 1:30 P.M. tomorrow, at the La Guardia Community College Theater, 31-10 Thomson Avenue, Long Island City, Queens. Tickets: children and the elderly, $2.50; others, $4. Information: (718) 482-5151. ''ALFRED THE DRAGON AND THE WIZARD,'' a play about a shy dragon who lives in Central Park and a sly wizard, written by Miranda McDermott, with child actors of the New Media Repertory Company, 3 P.M. on Saturdays, at 512 East 80th Street. Tickets: children, $4.50; adults, $5. Reservations required: 734-5195.

title: TV Weekend;   'Image,' a Drama on Ethics Of Investigative Reporting
description: For its first hour, ''The Image'' zips along as though it were on fast foward. The dialogue is snappy, the pace frenetic and the performances by Albert Finney as a star television reporter and John Mahoney as his producer and pal leave them little time to draw breath. New York is much in evidence, not only in the glimpses of Lincoln Center and Central Park West, of subway stations and stretch limos, but in the high-pressure drive of the television studio and those who run it and are run by it. The 90-minute show, which owes something to Paddy Chayefsky's movie ''Network,'' can be caught at 9:30 tomorrow evening on Home Box Office, the pay-cable network.

title: New Executive Team At Wickes Lumber
description: The Wickes Lumber Company, a major supplier of building materials, yesterday announced the appointment of a new management team: William A. Hensler, from inside the company, and Philip M. Chrusz, from outside.

title: The 1991 Budget: Nuclear Weapons;   Administration Plans No Money for Plutonium Processing Plant
description: The Bush Administration has notified Idaho lawmakers that it will not provide money in next year's budget to build a plutonium processing plant that was once the centerpiece of the Energy Department's plan to rebuild its deteriorating nuclear weapons industry.

title: Augat Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a net gain of $1.2 million from the sale of a facility for the quarter and the year included a pretax restructuring charge of $2.5 million. c-Net loss and included pretax restructuring charge of $39 million.

title: Enhancing Television for the Visually Impaired
description: ''When I first heard it, it was such a shock; I found myself walking around the room in tears,'' said an elated Jane Morin, who has been blind since birth.

title: Gallagher (Arthur J.) & Co.  (N) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago quarter and prior year results are restated for pooling of interests.

title: Morris M. Mintz, Lawyer, 81
description: Morris M. Mintz, a lawyer and former New York State Assemblyman, died of Alzheimer's disease Wednesday at the Liberty Hill Nursing Home in Delray Beach, Fla. He was 81 years old and lived in Delray Beach.

title: BCE Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $397,000,000 for the quarter and $440,000,000 for the year. c-Net income d-After losses from discontinued operations of $5,000,000 and $7,000,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. The company said loss from discontinued operations is from discontinued real estate operations. Year-ago results are restated. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Bronx Principal Is Found Guilty In Crack Case
description: Matthew Barnwell, the ousted Bronx principal whose drug arrest touched off a wave of investigations of New York City's local school boards, was convicted of cocaine possession yesterday.

title: Harland (John H.) (N) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Contrans Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: b-After an extraordinary credit of $925,000, or 17 cents a share. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: Sonoco Products reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Birtcher Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income The company said the latest figures included the results of Bard-Electromedical Systems Inc., acquired from C.R. Bard Inc. in November 1989.

title: Interstate-Johnson Lane Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included approximately $1.3 million of pre-tax losses incurred by certain specialized fixed-income operations that were terminated in December and January. c-Net income

title: Crompton & Knowles reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 30
description: b-After losses from discontinued operations of $1,397,000 for the quarter and $1,517,000 for the year. Share earnings are restated to reflect a 2-for-1 stock split effective June 16, 1989.

title: Standard Products reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Washington Fedl Savings reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After an extraordinary charge of $200,000. c-Net loss and after an extraordinary charge of $21,000. d-After an extraordinary credit of $123,000, or 4 cents a share.

title: Oshkosh Truck reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Plane's Debris Includes a Tangle of Relationships
description: When the aluminum skin of the Avianca jetliner split open on a foggy Long Island hillside 15 miles short of Kennedy International Airport, it lay bare the complex web of relationships and commerce between Colombia and the United States.

title: Keystone Financial reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Reflected an accrual for the 1988 trust contigency reserve of $5.5 million for the quarter and $10 million for the year. The reserve reduced earnings by 30 cents a share in the quarter and 55 cents a share for the year.

title: Pain of AIDS Prompts Gifts To Neediest
description: With The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund's drive approaching its third month, homelessness continues to be the predominant issue in letters from donors, but the scourge of AIDS also troubles many contributors. Some people specify that their donations go to homeless people with AIDS; other suggest that they help children with AIDS, other impose no limits beyond relevance to AIDS.

title: Mortgage Investments Plus reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
E. Clinton Towl, 84, a Founder And Ex-Head of Grumman, Dies
description: E. Clinton Towl, a founder and a former chief executive of the Grumman Corporation, died of cancer on Thursday at his home in Stuart, Fla. He was 84 years old.

title: Caldwell Partners InternaFtional reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Share earnings for the year-ago period was not provided because the company was not public. Results are in Canadian dollars.

title: New Hampshire Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Firstcorp Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a gain of $1,603,000, or 49 cents a share, from an adjustment in accounting.

title: Carla Hills to Lead Soviet Trade Talks
description: In a setback for Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher, President Bush has decided to give the United States trade representative, Carla A. Hills, the lead role in negotiating a new trade treaty with the Soviet Union, Administration officials said today.

title: Pervasive Deficiencies Hurting the Knicks
description: Ten days ago, the Knicks had the best record in the Eastern Conference and the third-best one in the National Basketball Association.

title: For Some, Hours of Waiting And Still There's No Word
description: In an unadorned banquet room of a Holiday Inn near Kennedy International Airport the wait for passengers of Avianca Flight 52 gave way yesterday morning to a painful lottery.

title: Release Opposition's Funds, Carter Warns Nicaraguans
description: Concerned over reports of intimidation of opposition candidates, former President Jimmy Carter warned today of a ''great uproar'' in the United States unless official delays in releasing United States funds to the opposition were stopped.

title: Ingres Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Island Telephone Co.  reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: Results are in Canadian funds.

title: The Price of Fudging on S & L's
description: The savings and loan troubles became a crisis because Washington dawdled. Losses at just one thrift, California's big Lincoln Savings and Loan, topped $2 billion because regulators dawdled. Even after President Bush proposed remedial legislation, hundreds of insolvent S & L's bled needlessly last year while Congress dawdled some more. The bill is law now, but the cost continues to climb, this time because of Administration dawdling.

title: The 1991 Budget;   Veterans Facing Plan To Alter Home Loans
description: For the first time, veterans would be required to make down payments to receive Government home loans from the Department of Veterans Affairs even for the most modestly priced houses under a proposal in President Bush's new budget.

title: South Jersey Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $83,000 and $381,000 for the quarter and year, respectively. c-Included a loss from discontinued operations of $113,000 and $308,000 for the quarter and year, respectively.

title: CNB Bancshares Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Children's Fate Points Up Seating Concerns
description: At least six children under the age of 5 survived the crash of Avianca Flight 52 and though it could not be determined yesterday whether any of them were saved by child-restraint seats, their fate points again to concerns about the safety of small children on airplanes.

title: Hayes-Dana Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After extraordinary credits of $385,000, or 3 cents a share, for the quarter and $1,537,000, or 10 cents a share, for the year. The company said the latest year's decline in sales included a reduction of $27 million as a result of the disposal of the Truck Train Group. Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Tagliabue's Rosy Picture of League Clouded by Furor Over Drug Testing
description: In his first Super Bowl news conference on the National Football League's stature and promise, Paul Tagliabue, the league's new commissioner, painted a rosy picture today. Attendance figures and fan interest are healthy, he said, eventual league expansion in the United States and around the globe is imminent and the N.F.L. enjoys the prospect of a favorable negotiation on fees for television rights.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I had time to say a prayer. I put my attache case over my knees because I didn't have a pillow. I bent over in the crash position. In about five seconds, we were crashing into the trees.'' - Jorge Lorano, a Bogota businessman. [1:1.]

title: Gilbert Associates reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 29
Intrex Financial Svcs reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After income of $400,000, or 9 cents a share, from discontinued operations for both periods. c-After an extraordinary charge of $1,320,000 for the quarter and income of $406,000, or 9 cents a share, from discontinued operations for the year.

title: Alternate Energy Sources Can Be Economical
description: To the Editor:

title: Israeli Slain in Miami Was Under U.S. Scrutiny
description: Federal-law-enforcement officials said today that an Israeli linked to Colombian drug traffickers and found slain in Miami on Wednesday had been under the scrutiny of at least three United States Government agencies in the weeks before his death.

title: The Elephant Wars
description: They burned rhino horns here Thursday, as they had burned elephant tusks last year. The huge pyre, also piled with leopard, lion and zebra skins seized by anti-poaching squads, was worth $2.5 million. Thick black smoke rolled up to the idyllic blue sky, splotched with idle cottony clouds.

title: CONSUMER'S WORLD: Coping;   With Price Anomalies
description: One of the more reliable shopping maxims is that consumers get more for their money when they buy goods in large packages. Usually the purchaser receives part of the saving from the reduced costs of factors like packaging, handling and storage. That is basic economics.

title: A Respected Air Carrier Based in a Troubled Land

But it has maintained a respectable safety record throughout, aviation experts said yesterday.

title: Patents;   A Device to Foil Radar
description: The race car champion Bobby Unser has patented a new device to foil police radar. The invention combines a radar detector, police scanner and citizens' band radio into one unit. A single microprocessor can simultaneously control the scanning for signals from each source, in theory increasing the chances of detecting a police presence in the area. Radar detectors are legal in all states except Connecticut and Virginia. Mr. Unser and his nephew, Al Unser Jr., are co-founders of Trycomm, a small company in Fishers, Ind., that began selling the device last year under the name Trident.

title: Pricing Pain
description: Dr. Veronica Prego's tragic dispute with New York City has been billed as a ''$175 million lawsuit.'' It's been that way ever since someone added up all the dollars in her original complaint that the city's negligence, in leaving a contaminated needle on a hospital bed, caused her to contract AIDS. As the legal world knows, such figures mean nothing. Plaintiffs can usually win damages whether or not amounts are specified in their civil complaints.

title: CONSUMER'S WORLD: Guidepost;   Silver for the Bride
description: This is time of year when most brides-to-be shop for silver. Diana Shiel, public relations director for the Silver Trust, a trade association, said the difference between sterling silver and silver plate is the amount of silver used. And she advised: ''Don't take the salesperson's word for it. Check.'' Here are some other tips. $ STERLING SILVER SILVER PLATE Markings Ask to see the sterling mark No stamp or (the words sterling or sterl) or the number markings, except that some pre-1920 items and some made in Britain are marked epns, for electro-plated nickel silver. Silver content 92.5% silver and 7.5% Has a base of nickel, lead or copper or other metals brass. The percentage of silver coating is measured in microns; 35 microns is about average. Useful life Indefinite. 25 to 50 years before replating. Price Five-piece place settings by Cristofle Five-piece flatware settings by range from $780 to $1,600. Cristofle are $165 to $325.

title: Review/Film;   Love Nudges Accountant Out of Shell
description: A black cat in a diamond choker adds a touch of glamour to the opening credits of ''Strike It Rich,'' but this proves mostly to be wishful thinking. And the specter of Cary Grant, summoned by both the Monte Carlo of 1956 (where most of this story is set) and the heroine who is named for him, has a similar effect. The amiable but lusterless ''Strike It Rich,'' written and directed by James Scott from Graham Greene's ''Loser Takes All,'' is badly in need of high style, or at the very least a few sparks. Even the love story upon which the film turns is lukewarm.

title: For Troubled Tryouts, Few Happy Endings
description: There was a standing ovation when ''Annie 2: Miss Hannigan's Revenge'' closed at the Kennedy Center Opera House on Saturday night, Jan. 20. While standing ovations are now more the rule than the exception in American theaters - where audiences often want to salute their own good taste as much as the performers on stage - why ''Annie 2''? With a $7 million budget, this was the most costly Broadway production ever to close during its out-of-town tryout and cancel its New York opening. Was the final Washington audience thumbing its nose at Variety and other savage critics of ''Annie 2'' and proclaiming that the show somehow, somewhere, someday (if not tomorrow) must go on?

title: RESULTS PLUS
description: N.H.L.

title: IS IT TIME TO TRUST HOLLYWOOD?
description: The road to adaptations is paved with good intentions, just as the road leading away is a vale of dashed hopes - the disappointment of readers for whom no cast or single interpretation can match the ideal images in the mind; the disillusionment of authors standing by the wayside clutching checks and crying Foul! No one, to hear tell of it, has ever witnessed a movie that did justice to the complexities, the nuances, the high ironies of a novel on which it was based, and writers and critics have got off some of their most withering bons mots at Hollywood's expense.

title: How 'Annie 2' Skidded Off a Bumpy Road To Broadway
description: The sun came out on Monday morning, Nov. 6, 1989, and so did the reporters and television news crews, for the first day of rehearsal of ''Annie 2: Miss Hannigan's Revenge.'' The $7 million musical continuation of ''Annie,'' which was one of the most successful shows in Broadway history, had been announced with much hoopla in June, and anticipation was high.

title: Owens Scores 36 As Syracuse Wins
description: For 21 seasons and through several changings of the guard, Syracuse basketball teams had been frustrated by their inability to beat Georgetown on its home court. For an entire week before this afternoon's game between the two Big East Conference powers, Syracuse's upperclassmen recounted stories about the string of failures since 1967-68, when Syracuse defeated Georgetown, 95-78, at McDonough Gymnasium.

title: A Biting Look at Life in a London Dump

In ''Entertaining Mr. Sloan,'' the Orton comedy currently on Theater Three's Second Stage in Port Jefferson, the holes are particularly wide.

title: Agent to Plead Guilty In H.U.D. Fraud Case
description: Marilyn Louise Harrell, a real estate agent whom investigators called ''Robin HUD,'' has agreed to plead guilty to fraud and tax evasion charges after Federal prosecutors accused her of stealing $5.67 million in Government housing money, a Federal law-enforcement official said today.

title: Final Minutes: Music but No Warning
description: The first hint of impending disaster was the soft but sudden intrusion of classical music over the loudspeaker.

title: Men and Women, Subjects and Verbs
description: The article by Nancy Ross (''Men, Women and the Revolution,'' Opinion page, Dec. 17), which included her observation that all four physicians attending the birth of her son were female, sent me down memory lane.

title: From Afghanistan to Azerbaijan, Discord Undermines the Red Army
description: AS revolution sweeps Eastern Europe and turmoil erupts across the Soviet Union, the Red Army, the foundation of Soviet superpower status, is in serious trouble. Its huge stocks of modern weapons remain, but the foundation of a fighting force is the people in uniform. In this respect, the state of the Soviet military today and its ability to carry out its traditional mission are worse than at any time since the Stalinist purges of the 1930's.

title: Genoa's Neighborhoods and Palaces
description: ''THE most mysterious city in Italy,'' a British critic said to me, a man who knows Italy better than most Italians. And, no matter how often I visit Genoa, I find it hard not to agree with him. And yet the Genoese are hospitable and the city - especially in bright weather - lies deceptively open on its hills along the sea, exposed, inviting. But it eludes the visitor's grasp. Maps, to begin with, are of little use. Of course, they tell you which street is where, but they do not - cannot - indicate the abrupt slopes, the sheer valleys, drops, ascents. Genoa is a city of steps, arches, tunnels, funiculars, elevators. You set out for one place, and you end up in another. Where is Genoa's focus? Is it the port? The Piazza De Ferrari? Or the 19th-century Via 20 Settembre with its hotels and shops? Other Italian cities have a specific center: in Naples it is Piazza del Plebescito and the Gallery; in Milan, La Scala or the Duomo; in Venice, Piazza San Marco. But in Genoa, the Duomo, with its tall, horizontally striped facade and its stunning works of art, is on a kind of side street, the open space in front of it is cramped, a dead end. And the Opera House, the historic Teatro Carlo Felice, currently being restored, also has no context, no square of its own.

title: Nurses Offer Medical Help at Churches
description: LEAD: IN the lower Naugatuck Valley, people are going to church to get medical help.

title: How to Unify Germany: Deliberately
description: Standing in the way of a stampede to unify Germany makes no sense. Neither does starting one. The westward rush of 2,000 East Germans a day creates twin pressures to speed unification. One is a sense that East Germany will collapse despite opposition efforts to shore it up; the other is a fear that West Germany will be overwhelmed by emigres.

title: Expect the Bold and Abstract In New Zealand Knitwear

title: Technology;   The Tilt-Rotor: Wall Street to Capitol Hill in 45 Minutes?
description: Among the military hardware vulnerable to Congressional budget cuts this year is a peculiar hybrid aircraft called the V-22 Osprey that is part helicopter and part airplane. It is powered by large rotor blades on each wing tip. When the blades are pitched up for takeoff or landing, it flies like a helicopter. With the blades facing forward, it flies like an airplane.

Just months ago the L-shaped space was home to another restaurant, called Saffron, and the decor remains much the same, with familiar orchid-colored banquettes in the rear and the same pink marbleized tabletops. New are the framed Ansel Adams photographs and Southwestern art posters that line the walls.

She has a knack for subtly suggesting atmosphere, usually dark, and her stories are resonant with extra meanings. But a program presented by Reka and Company Dance Theater on Monday night at the Ethnic Folk Arts Center suggested that she may be better at telling stories than at enunciating great themes.

title: Another Small Step for Man
description: THE IGOR I. SIKORSKY HUMAN-Powered Helicopter Competition, sponsored by the American Helicopter Society, offers a $20,000 award for the first non-engined rotor craft that hovers for 60 seconds and attains an altitude of 3 meters. In 10 years, no one has claimed the prize, but last November a team of students at California Polytechnic State University at San Luis Obispo managed, momentarily, to get off the ground - a first. And in a subsequent test, on Dec. 10 (above), their craft, Da Vinci 3, ascended eight inches and stayed aloft for eight seconds. It's not a winner, but as Neil Saiki says, ''No one had ever pulled themselves up by their bootstraps before. We're the first.'' Saiki (in dinner jacket, above and right), is a Cal Poly senior and manager of the Da Vinci project, with which he has been involved since 1988. Then, Da Vinci 2b was in the works, an improvement on two previous designs. But it didn't fly. Da Vinci 3 was conceived last June by Saiki and a fellow student, Kyle Naydo. They redesigned the ''cockpit,'' made the 100-foot wings thinner and rerigged the supporting guy wires, reducing the craft's weight from 140 to 97 pounds.

title: Spas
description: To the Editor: Your reports on Marienbad and Carlsbad in Czechoslovakia reminded me of my youth. My brother and I spent summer vacations at the home of our grandparents in Marienbad. They had a large house there called Villa Souvenir, which catered to summer guests with room and board and in later years served as a glorified bed and breakfast. It was quite elegant, and after the death of my grandparents, my mother ran it for several years before World War II. She had as a guest the Austrian poet and author Stefan Zweig, who came with his secretary for several summers.

title: FICTION
description: THE VOYAGE OF MAEL DUIN'S CURRAGH. By Patricia Aakhus. (Story Line Press, Paper, $12.95.) While the story elements central to Greek mythology have remained relatively stable, the oral tradition of Irish storytelling has frequently produced legends that have subtly shifted over time. Such is the case with the tale of Mael Duin, an ancient story of a questing son who sets out in a skin-covered boat called a curragh with a crew of 16 men in order to avenge his father's death. What he finds, as he travels in strange seas, is one bizarre and surrealistic island after another. In a series of dreamlike passages, the men encounter an impassable bridge of glass, giant insects, rivers of fire, strange sacrifices and rituals, and such sights as a small island inhabited by two flocks of sheep, one white and one black, with a brass fence dividing them. The first written fragments of this legend, which the writer and literary critic Frank O'Connor called ''autonomous and primary in the way of Greek and Hebrew literature,'' occur in medieval Irish Christian manuscripts. The monks who recorded the story in ''The Yellow Book of Lecan'' gave it a religious spin, incorporating God's will into the narrative. This shift, notes Patricia Aakhus in a useful introduction to her version of the quest, ''robs the story of dramatic tension.'' More recently, Victorian Celtic revivalists with another agenda cleansed the text of its pagan - and earthy - elements. Now, in this version by an American teacher, writer and actress, pagan elements are properly restored and superfluous additions have been stripped away. What remains is a scholarly yet exciting and vivid rendition of the voyage of Mael Duin, one that has never before been accessible to those without fluent Old Irish. It rings true, and that's what becomes a legend most.

title: Catskills
description: To the Editor: On Nov. 12 you responded to a query about the Catskill Mountain House (Q & A). You might care to pass on the information that there is a very handsome book, ''The Catskill Mountain House,'' by Roland Van Zandt, published by Hope Farm Press, Strong Road, Cornwallville, N.Y. 12418. This is a reprint of an earlier edition. This edition ($6.50) has all the black-and-white photographs but not the color plates of the first edition. The book encompasses the Mountain House from its beginning early in the 1800's until its demolition at 6 A.M., Jan. 25, 1963, and, indeed, the history of the region.

The bride, 26 years old and a cum laude graduate of the State University at Buffalo, is the M.B.A. recruiting coordinator at Price Waterhouse, accountants in New York. description: Here are some notable releases of the last few months.

title: The Hall of Famer Who Took the Bus
description: Franco Harris, wearing a dark suit, red tie, neatly trimmed black beard and a large smile that broke out and stayed out - like the Louisiana sun - held a news conference yesterday in a French Quarter restaurant.

title: ST. JOAN OF THE REGIONAL THEATRE
description: LEAD:

title: Shoreham Asset: Land and Location
description: THE Herculean labor involved in building the Shoreham nuclear-power plant may have been largely a waste, but a group of energy experts in Midland, Mich., hopes to convince Long Islanders not to overlook the value of an indestructible component: the land on which the plant sits.

title: IN THE REGION: New Jersey;   Recent Sales
description: Howell $112,900

title: The Process That Ate Washington
description: Arrival of the President's budget on Capitol Hill creates what is charitably known as the Congressional budget process. In truth it is less a process than a Rube Goldberg nightmare of unrealistic deadlines, overlapping jurisdictions and competing mandates involving every committee in Congress. The numbers, contradictory and ever changing, will be irrelevant by September, when the decisions that matter are made. Budget making often consumes an entire legislative session.

title: Currency;   Finally, Some Muscle for the Yen
description: The Japanese yen, which has been chronically weak against the dollar, finally found some muscle last week. Betting that the Japanese would raise interest rates after the Parliamentary election on Feb. 18, traders bought yen aggressively last week for the first time in months. By the end of the week, the dollar had fallen to 142.85 yen, down from 146.00. At the same time, the Canadian dollar continued to fall sharply against the American dollar as interest rates in Canada appeared to be headed even lower. Since the Bank of Canada signaled in mid-January that it would allow interest rates to fall, investors have been dumping their Canadian dollars. Two weeks ago, the Canadian dollar was worth 86.3 cents. Now it is down to 83.6 cents. title: Women Get Sidetracked
description: To the Editor:

title: DUMPED FOR THE HOMECOMING QUEEN
description: WHITE GIRLS

title: 'Call for Gay Ministry': Taking Issue
description: I read with interest the interview with the Rev. Robert Williams (New Jersey Q & A, ''Answering the Call for a Gay Ministry,'' Dec. 10). And I agree with his premise that the mainstream church has inadequately addressed the needs of the homosexual community. Yet I am compelled - theologically - to take issue with him on three fronts.

title: Pamela Dragonetti Engaged
description: June wedding plans for Pamela Veranna Dragonetti and Dr. Timothy Dee Hedden, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Larry D. Hedden of Mendham, N.J., have been made known by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. George M. Dragonetti of Mendham. Miss Dragonetti, 27 years old and a Syracuse University graduate, is a designer with the architectural firm of Jonathon E. Booth in New Vernon, N.J. Dr. Hedden, 33, a chiropractor, is a graduate of the University of Montevallo and of the Palmer College of Chiropractic in Daventport, Iowa.

title: WHAT'S DOING IN: Dallas
description: When the Morton H. Meyerson Symphony Center was inaugurated in September, Dallas boosters insisted that the $106 million building designed by I. M. Pei was proof that the city had survived the oil bust unscarred. Others maintained that the stunning concert hall took Dallas another step in becoming a cultural center of international importance.

title: The Legacy of C. S. Lewis
description: To the Editor:

title: In a Mexican Town After an Election, Two Rival Mayors and Four Bodies
description: Outside City Hall, barricades have been put up and men with machetes stand guard, ready to protect Roberto Salinas Herrera, mayor in the ''people's democratic government'' that took office here Jan 1. Six blocks away, Natividad Salas Estrada, mayor in the ''constitutional government'' sworn in the same day, signs official papers and receives petitioners at his temporary office, a bare concrete room in a private home.

title: Pilots Say Fuel Gauges on 707's Often Provide Inaccurate Readings
description: As Avianca Flight 52 circled above Kennedy International Airport on Thursday evening, Matias Moyano Rojas, the flight engineer on the Boeing 707, had to rely on fuel gauges that pilots said are often imprecise.

title: Be a Cossack! Be a Bandmaster!
description: The serviceable and sometimes ornate uniforms worn by doormen, chefs, chauffeurs and butlers have become coveted fashions in some quarters.

title: George Carter Carr, Federal Judge, 60
description: Federal District Judge George Carter Carr, the chief judge of the Middle District of Florida, died of a brain tumor on Friday. He was 60 years old.

title: Canadians Buy a Share of the American Dream
description: CANADIANS have for decades been accustomed to sleeping in Holiday Inns, eating Kentucky Fried Chicken and getting their Fords fixed at Midas, and many of them have come to resent the widespread presence of these and other American companies.

title: Caroline A. Keller To Marry in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Robert J. Keller of Dallas have made known June wedding plans for their daughter Caroline Anne Keller and William H. Pruden 3d, a son of Dorothy D. Pruden of Ridgewood, N.J., and the late Dr. Pruden.

title: NEW JERSEY GUIDE
description: LEAD:
