The figures are statistically adjusted to represent sales in all such outlets across the United States.

title: NONFICTION
description: UNFINISHED CONVERSATIONS: Mayas and Foreigners Between Two Wars. By Paul Sullivan, (Knopf, $22.95.) In the annals of peasant and Indian uprisings, the Mayan Caste War of 1847 ranks as one of the most prolonged revolts against a postcolonial government. For more than half a century, the oppressed Maya posed a serious threat to Mexican authority in the Yucatan Peninsula. For the Maya of Quintana Roo state, once a stronghold of the rebellion, it has accrued apocalyptic significance and, through legend and folklore, has served to define their relationship with outsiders and the nature of wars to come. In ''Unfinished Conversations,'' Paul Sullivan, who teaches anthropology at Yale University, uses an intriguing combination of anthropological, linguistic and historical methods to examine the effects of the Caste War on the Mayas' perception of outsiders - missionaries and scholars who have come into contact with the Mayas since the uprising. Relying on letters, journals and scholarly treatises, as well as on his own field work, Mr. Sullivan traces the evolution of that perception, which, over the years, has been characterized by both suspicion and a disarming trust. Most important, Mr. Sullivan's book reveals the process by which a historical event can embed itself in the collective memory of a contemporary society. For the Maya of Quintana Roo, the Caste War, far from being over, is expected to resume someday in the form of a decisive battle; already rumors have drifted in from places like Guatemala or El Salvador. That war, a total war, will once again determine the relationships betwen Mayas and foreigners.

title: Dance Booms Come, and Dance Booms Go
description: Every 30 years or so, an expansive period of extraordinary dance activity seems to be suddenly on the wane. Anyone looking for the end of the great dance boom that has marked American dance since the end of the 1960's might also consider the lessons of the past.

title:
MUSIC;

Innovative Project to Introduce Children to Jazz
description: LEAD: FILLING what they consider a serious educational need, the directors of two organizations here have come up with an innovative project to introduce children to jazz.

title: Vaness to Sing in 'Cosi'
description: The soprano Carol Vaness is to sing the role of Fiordiligi in the season's final performance of Mozart's ''Cosi Fan Tutte'' at the Metropolitan Opera, Saturday at 8 P.M., replacing Margaret Price, who is ill. Miss Vaness is also in the new production of Gounod's ''Faust,'' which opens on Thursday. Information: 362-6000.

title: Winfield Mistrial
description: He'd been hoping to have his tangled personal life cleared up before the baseball season, but now it appears that the dispute between the Yankee slugger Dave Winfield and his former common-law wife, Sandra Renfro, is going to drag on a bit longer.

title: New Yorkers, etc.
description: Now that it's become chic to not only shop in discount stores but admit it, to carry unprestigious shopping bags, and to own up to such things as eating frozen dinners and preferring inexpensive chocolate, certain other things follow. For instance, little quirks like eating while watching television, managing very well for a week or more without dusting, and virtually living in the bedroom, all of which have been done for years, are now being talked about openly and even proudly.

title: Pope Urges African Land to Shun Rigid Marxism
description: Sweeping through this impoverished and nominally Marxist nation on Africa's western coast, Pope John Paul II appealed today for an end to ''static and conditioned ideologies'' in favor of ''authentic human progress.''

title: Computer Network Speeds Local Courts
description: A TWO-YEAR-OLD state-financed computer system intended to increase efficiency and standardize procedures in the state's overburdened municipal court system has enabled courts to collect fines and process traffic summonses far more quickly than ever before, court officers and state officials say.

title: Elizabeth Waldron Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. David Roger Waldron of Flemington, N.J., have announced June wedding plans for their daughter Elizabeth Norris Waldron and Douglas Stephen Boothe, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Garland C. Boothe of Westfield, N.J. A graduate of Assumption College, Miss Waldron is a buyer and planner for the Warner-Lambert Company in Lititz, Pa. Mr. Boothe, a graduate of Princeton University, expects to receive an M.B.A. in May from the University of Pennsylvania.

title: Insuring Against A Canceled Trip
description: ''STANDARD trip-cancellation insurance'' is like a standard sized window: there is no such creature. If you are preparing for a major trip this year, and you are thinking about protecting yourself against losing your deposit money, or more, assume nothing. Get a copy of the insurance brochure and read it.

title: Katherine Evans Wed in Brooklyn
description: The marriage of Katherine Phillips Evans, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William M. Evans of Indianapolis, to William H. Baldwin 3d, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Baldwin Jr. of New Canaan, Conn., took place yesterday at the Roman Catholic Cathedral of St. James in Brooklyn. The Rev. Dennis M. Corrado performed the ceremony. Elizabeth Marie Tomic was the bride's maid of honor, and Douglas G. Baldwin, the bridegroom's brother, was the best man.

title: PLAN TO SHARE IDEAS EMERGES FOR CUP
description: America's Cup syndicates from the United States are reacting with cautious optimism to a new proposal asking them to share their basic technology for designing new boats.

title: Campus Life: Dayton;   Students Open And Run a Store For Student Needs
description: An idea four years in the making at the University of Dayton became a reality this month, when the student-run convenience store, Rudy's Fly-Buy, opened for business.

title: Cook's Data Might Shed Light on Race to Pole
description: The Library of Congress has been bequeathed a trove of photographs and papers from Frederick A. Cook, a rival claimant with Robert E. Peary to being the first to reach the North Pole. Experts say the material might shed light on the 80-year-old argument.

title: MENTALLY HYPERACTIVE AND PROUD OF IT.
description: ''Clever'' may be the most feared compliment in rock. A band can labor for a year over a set of songs, agonizing over every syllable and note and reverberation; it can rack its brains over the cover art and lie awake nights remembering whom to thank in the fine print. But let anyone suggest that the results are clever, and the party might be over. Cleverness is suspect, a sure sign that the musicians are (a) glib, (b) heartless, (c) overeducated, (d) insincere and (e) doomed to the ministrations of a cult following.

title: Lisa W. Clark, Lawyer, to Wed
description: L. Straight Clark of Laguna Niguel, Calif., has announced the engagement of his daughter Lisa Whitcomb Clark to Peter Godfrey Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Godfrey of Villanova, Pa. A June wedding is planned.

title: Low on Marquee Value But High on Tackling
description: At first glance, the San Francisco 49ers' defense does not possess the glitz and pizazz that the 49ers' offense features with each snap of the football. Even among the 49er defenders, the safety Ronnie Lott overshadows his peers, with Lott easily the most recognizable and heralded of the bunch.

title: Obligation to Educate The Handicapped
description: Jane Goldblatt's letter of Dec. 24 is timely in that it addresses an issue that Federal courts have recently decided. The issue concerns the education of all children, regardless of the extent of their handicaps.

title: Employers Seek Ways to End I-287 Congestion
description: THE county may be a victim of its own success. In the 29 years since the 10.3 miles of the Cross-Westchester Expressway opened, the roadway - I-287 - has been a magnet for business growth in the county. It has also been the scene of horrendous congestion. Now the companies that attracted the traffic in the first place are considering getting involved in transportation management themselves, to help solve the problem.

title: Mutual Funds;   Puritan's Troubling Junk Bonds
description: Buried in the news of the recent default of the Campeau Corporation was a startling bulletin for many shareholders of Fidelity's Puritan Fund.

title: Anne D. Berlin, Student, to Marry
description: Mr. and Mrs. Charles Berlin of Newton Centre, Mass., have announced August wedding plans for their daughter, Anne Deborah Berlin, and David Alan Ring, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Jordan L. Ring of Needham, Mass.

title: Water Rules Pit Baymen Against State
description: LEAD: WANTING only to work on the water like generations before them, baymen on the Island's East End have banded together against regulations they hold responsible for threatening to end their traditional way of life.

title: Lewis Mumford, a Visionary Social Critic, Dies at 94
description: Lewis Mumford, a philosopher, literary critic, historian, city planner, cultural and political commentator, essayist and perspicacious writer on the subject of architecture, died on Friday at his home in Amenia, N.Y. He was 94 years old.

title: A Low-Key 'Cocktail Hour' at the Paper Mill
description: IN ''The Cocktail Hour,'' in which the making of a martini is mentioned three times within the play's first three minutes or so, a middle-aged publisher (John) visits his well-to-do parents, asking for approval of a play he's written. The play, John announces to his father (Bradley), is about a family that's ''recognizably us.''

title: Taking a Small Step To Soviet Super Bowl
description: It was just one more small step toward their own Super Bowl. The Moscow Bears beat the Russian Braves, 20-0, today before they had to give up the field to a group of 10-year-old soccer players from the Central Army Sports Club.

title: Of Famous Arches, Beeg Meks and Rubles
description: In the dingy gray of a Moscow winter morning, the new McDonald's restaurant is an otherworldly presence, huge and sleek and lighting up Pushkin Square with a red and yellow Technicolor glow.

title: Paris Pays Belated Respects To a True Bohemian
description: Among the artists most responsible for the development of abstraction during the early decades of this century, probably none has received less credit than Frantisek Kupka. Consult the standard histories and you are likely to find only a sentence of two about the Bohemian-born painter. Kandinsky, Mondrian, Malevich, even Robert Delauney, have their own chapters in those histories, but Kupka, whose works at one time or another anticipated, echoed and paralleled the paintings of each of these artists, has, by comparison, been written off.

title: Jockey Dies Of Head Injuries
description: A jockey injured in a four-horse pileup Friday at Beulah Park died today of head injuries.

title: ABOUT NEW JERSEY
description: DESPITE New Jersey's reputation for being crowded, in only two of the state's six large industrial cities - the six sisters they're sometimes called - is it possible to take a few steps and stroll out of one city and into another.

title: Frank X. Gargiulo, 60, Of Civil Service Panel
description: Frank X. Gargiulo, a former member of the New York City Civil Service Commission, died Thursday of a brain tumor at the St. Rose of Lima Home in Manhattan. He was 60 years old and lived in the Carroll Gardens section of Brooklyn.

title: For Work Force, 2 Million Who'd Quit Retirement
description: Nearly two million nonworking Americans 50 to 64 years old are ready and able to work, a new survey shows.

title: As Their Visit Ends, Kirkland Pledges Aid to Soviet Miners
description: The president of the AFL-CIO, Lane Kirkland, has noted the end of a monthlong visit and union training session for nine Soviets miners by pledging to assist the free trade union movement in the Soviet Union.

title: Aimee Harrison to Wed Austin Reed
description: The engagement of Aimee Porter Harrison to Austin Reed, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Adrian Pryor Reed of Centreville, Md., and Hobe Sound, Fla., has been announced by the prospective bride's parents, Sarah Schutt Harrison and Herbert Preston Harrison, both of Richmond. A June wedding is planned.

title: CHILDREN'S BOOKS: Bookshelf
description: Additional titles of interest:

title: Scaasis and Tutus, Silver Plumes And Snowballs
description: The Plaza Hotel ballroom recaptured the grand style of a turn-of-the-century party on Wednesday. The event celebrated the 50th anniversary of the Girl Scout Council of Greater New York and honored the fashion designer Arnold Scaasi, a benefactor. More than 40 women wearing Scaasi dresses gathered with the Scouts on the ballroom stage to pay him tribute. Later that evening a supper-dance was held after a gala performance by the New York City Ballet to honor Alexandra Danilova, who is retiring from the School of American Ballet.

title: Man Killed in Subway Shooting
description: A beer-drinking subway rider, angered by three men who witnesses said were ''looking for trouble'' and bumped into him on a train in the Bronx yesterday, shot and killed one man and wounded the two others, the transit police said.

title: 10th Season for Yale Rep Winterfest
description: ''IT didn't come suddenly,'' said Lloyd Richards, artistic director of the Yale Repertory Theater and the dean of the Yale School of Drama. ''It took me a whole year.''

title: THE ROMANCE AND BANALIZATION OF THE TAJ MAHAL
description: On the face of it, ''Romance of the Taj Mahal'' at the Los Angeles County Museum of Art ought to have been an easy, unquestioned and almost ecstatic success with a very large public. For what is the Taj Mahal, if not the building that most people, worldwide, most want to see? Who ever came back from Agra and said, ''Watch out, folks. The Taj Mahal is a bust''?

title: Reven Wurman To Wed Ms. Heim
description: The engagement of Mary Elizabeth Heim and Reven T. C. Wurman, a son of Dorothy Horsman Wurman of Wayne, Pa., and Richard Saul Wurman of New York and Bridgehampton, L.I., has been announced by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Paul K. Heim of Morehead City, N.C. A March wedding is planned. Ms. Heim, a project marketing coordinator with Solomon Equities Inc., a New York real-estate development company, attended Our Lady of Mercy Academy and the University of Rhode Island and graduated with honors from C. W. Post College. The prospective bridegroom, a photographer in New York, graduated from the Art Center College of Design in Pasadena, Calif.

title: Hope Wins in Beckett's 'Happy Days'
description: BURIED waist-deep, and then knee-deep, in a mound of earth, Winnie, ''about 50, well preserved,'' chatters on sunnily about this and that - her happy memories, life's ''many mercies'' - even though ''sorrow keeps breaking in.''

title: Coming to the East Coast: An Electronic Salon
description: Nearly every day, Gerard Van Der Leun, a literary agent who lives in Southport, Conn., turns on his computer and begins having conversations with people he has never met. ''It can span from utter foolishness to extremely serious discussions,'' he said.

title: Bishop Leads Methodist Churches in Washington Drug Fight
description: Playing a new role in the drug war, the United Methodist Church has moved one of its bishops to the nation's capital to galvanize a grass-roots assault on violence and drug trafficking.

title: El Salvador Hits Home
description: IN one of those strange quirks of history, El Salvador has suddenly become one of the hottest political topics in Connecticut. Newspapers that normally eschew foreign affairs are discussing it and Panama regularly. Politicians whose eyes otherwise glaze over at anything more global than state patronage can't stop talking about it. Average citizens who could not locate El Salvador on a map are now charged up about it.

title: A Stream of Soviet Emigres Disturbs the Occupied Territories
description: THE Soviet immigrants from Leningrad had been in Israel only 48 hours, and here in one of the West Bank's largest Jewish settlements their suitcases still sat unpacked in an otherwise empty bedroom. But the couple already spoke with the conviction of hardened Israeli nationalists.

title: COMMERCIAL PROPERTY: New York City Assessments;   A Slower Climb in Valuations for Office Buildings
description: ALTHOUGH the overall value of New York City real estate has risen in the last year, flat rents and slow sales have led to a noticeable slowdown in the rate of increase for commercial properties, according to the tentative assessments announced earlier this month by the city's Finance Department.

title: School Costs Are Worsening Quality of Life
description: IN a recent newspaper article, Michael V. McGill, superintendent of the North Shore School District, spoke out against what he called a charge of ''military imagery'' against higher school taxes. The people, he said, ''need to understand more fully what is at stake.'' He offered no real solutions to the problem, nor did he come to grips with the reality of people being torn from their roots and forced out of their homes.

title: Perhaps It's Time For 'Faust' To Rise Again
description: The piece is no longer common property, so perhaps the once-standard jokes about its ubiquity will bear re-introduction. This is what W. J. Henderson wrote 93 years ago in these pages after one ''Faust'' too many at the Metropolitan Opera:

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''I joined because it's the only organization that explores the missing half of sexual liberation - the right to say no.''

title: Anne C. Lassen To Wed in March
description: The engagement of Anne Carter Lassen and William Julian Cortazzi has been made known by the prospective bride's parents, Jacqueline C. Lassen of Rosemont, Pa., and Charles W. Lassen of Mount Laurel and Barnegat Light, N.J. The bridegroom is the son of Sir Hugh and Lady Cortazzi of London and Vines Cross, East Sussex, England. A March wedding is planned.

title: If You're Thinking of Living in: Lewisboro
description: LEAD: AROUND the start of the 18th century, says Maureen Koehl, the Lewisboro Town Historian, Chief Catoonah of the Algonquin Indians invited colonials from Connecticut to resettle among them in the 29 square miles of lakes and wetlands, steep hills and rock outcroppings, streams and valleys that now constitute the town.

title: A Story of Love or a Tale of Deceit?
description: ON THE MORNING OF SEPT. 16, 1986, George Gardner picked up Patricia Nicely at a nursing home in Roanoke, Va. Only a year earlier, Nicely, a wealthy woman of 58, had been a high-level official at the National Science Foundation. Now, apparently in the grip of Alzheimer's disease, she had grown so incapacitated that a local judge had made Gardner, a 65-year-old lawyer and friend of Nicely's, her legal guardian. Today he would become her husband, too.

title: Other Walls May Fall, But in Fortress Cuba Castro Stands Firm
description: THE changes sweeping Eastern Europe are stirring hopes here and in some quarters of Havana that Fidel Castro's long reign over Cuba may be coming to an end. ''We are sure something has to happen in our sad country,'' a dissident in Havana wrote to a friend in the Miami area, where more than 500,000 Cubans have fled since Mr. Castro took power in 1959. Anticipation in Miami has reached such levels that the police have prepared plans to control celebrating crowds of Cuban exiles on the day Mr. Castro falls.

title: Julia Hotchkiss, Teacher, to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Gerald G. Hotchkiss of Bedford Hills, N.Y., have announced September wedding plans for their daughter Julia Anne Hotchkiss and David Reed Eaton, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Kendall C. Eaton of Farmington, Conn.

title: TAGLIABUE SWEEPS INTO ACTION
description: On warm 1950's summer nights on Columbia Avenue in Jersey City, where idle teen-agers argued on street corners over Willie, Mickey and the Duke, Paul Tagliabue's father used to take a couple of brooms and hand them to the youngsters.

title: WESTCHESTER GUIDE
description: LOTS OF DANCE

title: BUSINESS DIARY
description: THE ECONOMY

title: Drivers Feel The Sting Of New Law On Drinking
description: MORE than 600 people have been arrested and face suspension of their drivers licenses under Connecticut's new drunken driving law, and few of those motorists are fighting it, the state Motor Vehicles Department says.

title: PASTIMES: Stamps;   A Correction
description: The Stamps column last week misidentified the man on the 2-cent ''Black Jack'' that paid the drop-letter rate in 1863-65. It was President Andrew Jackson, not Gen. Stonewall Jackson.

title: Article 449390 -- No Title
description: Saudi Arabia gave the Palestine Liberation Organization $12 million today to support the two-year uprising in Israeli-occupied territories, the Saudi Press Agency said. Saudi Arabia has given the P.L.O. $850 million in the last 10 years under the terms of pledges by oil-rich Arab countries to help the P.L.O. and Arab lands in the conflict with Israel.

title:
WESTCHESTER Q&A;: MSGR. JOHN J. HEALY;

Beyond the Image of the Catholic School
description: LEAD: IN the minds of many, Catholic education still evokes an image of teacher-nuns with a no-nonsense attitude and children, separated at high school age by gender, in uniforms. It is an image that today is only partly correct. The uniforms are usually still there, but mostly the nuns are not. The discipline is perhaps stricter than in the public schools, but it is not like in days past.

title: FICTION
description: GOOD INTENTIONS. By Joy Fielding. (Doubleday, $18.95.) Joy Fielding's eighth novel introduces us to Lynn Schuster, a social worker, and Renee Bower, her divorce lawyer, as their seemingly perfect marriages are ending in sexual betrayal. Resentful children, unloving parents, embittered clients and sabotaging male bosses are carefully interspersed throughout the plot to develop well-paced parallels between the two women's experiences. Despite its title, the love in ''Good Intentions'' is warped by male control and female powerlessness; cruelties, both intentional and accidental, are the norm. Ms. Fielding has a keen ear for the stream-of-consciousness monologues of women with low self-esteem. In harsh contrast to the nurturing and assertive stances of their professional lives, Lynn and Renee delude and blame themselves indiscriminately. Renee's husband is a diabolical manipulator who consistently undermines his wife, but his humiliating acts are so overstated that one can't believe this seemingly intelligent woman wouldn't see right through him. Thus even Renee's belated escape evokes more exasperation than empathy. The reluctance behind her liberation, as well as Lynn's, evokes merely pity and implies little growth. One is left with only a cynical and simplistic message: men are strong, women weak.

title: A Magic Circle of Adult Students
description: OLDER than 40 and starting from scratch: I thought I was a unique item, but as soon as I peeked out of my shell I found a sea of women in similar positions.

title: Koussevitzky Treasures Through a Sonic Mire
description: Serge Koussevitzky was one of the musical giants of the 20th century. As a publisher in his native Russia he brought out the early works of Stravinsky. For his Concerts Kousevitzky in Paris in the early 1920's he commissioned Maurice Ravel to create his orchestration of Modest Mussorgsky's ''Pictures at an Exhibition.'' When he became conductor of the Boston Symphony in 1924 he sought out music by American composers for performance, forging a quarter-century long alliance unmatched in our history.

title: The Big Quandary Over Interest Rates
description: Like Blanche DuBois, the American capital system now finds itself dependent on the kindness - or at least the money - of strangers.

title: Article 938290 -- No Title
description: THE Westchester Library System has requested a special appropriation of $175,000 from the county delegation to the State Legislature. Maurice J. Freedman, director of the library system, which is based here, said this amount would offset an expected deficit of $135,000 and also help in some ''under-budgeted'' areas.

title: Skating by the Light of the Moon
description: VIVID memories flashed to the screen of my mind as I laced my skates. I hadn't skated since high school, over 20 years had passed, and here I was, incredulously, tying my old, forgotten skates. I had to laugh at the lunacy; no small child clamored at my side justifying the escapade.

title: Burmese Sell Off Part of Embassy in Tokyo
description: With its economy in shambles and its Government increasingly desperate for hard currency, Myanmar, formerly Burma, has sold one of its most valuable overseas assets: the better part of its embassy in Tokyo.

title: David's Island Is Timely Lunch Topic
description: MEETING over lunch last week, about 100 New Rochelle business and civic leaders talked about how the city could keep its bruising political frays from damaging its prospects for development.

title: Donors Give to the Neediest In Lieu of Street Handouts
description: Rather than give change to some panhandlers and not to others, many donors are delegating the responsibility of deciding to whom aid will go to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund. Often the gifts come with expressions of pained ambivalence about the growing armies of beggars.

title: A DETECTIVE IN SPITE OF HIMSELF
description: DEVICES AND DESIRES

title: Louella Luhrman Dies; Oldest Veteran, 108
description: Louella Luhrman, an Army nurse in World War I who became the nation's oldest veteran, died Friday. She was 108 years old.

title: For Youth, Memories of the Holocaust
description: LEAD: THREE children not more than 10 years old and resembling ragged bundles of frayed cloth huddle together on the wintry streets of a Polish ghetto in Lodz during the 1940's. The middle child, seemingly the youngest, sits with eyes closed and lips thrust out, dreaming of a crust of bread.

title: Hands and Hearts Across the Pacific
description: THE grayness of a late January Sunday afternoon settles over our town. I have just returned from a long walk, needed, somehow, to try to sort things out, to get reoriented to being a family of two again.

title: Alexei Yudenich, Ballet Dancer, 46
description: Alexei Yudenich, a former principal ballet dancer with the National Ballet of Canada who was a dance teacher in the South Jersey-Philadelphia area, died of cancer Thursday. He was 46 years old.

title: BARD OF THE BRITISH BOURGEOISIE
description: While other playwrights live in fashionable sections of London, jet back and forth to New York to arrange for Broadway productions and write screenplays for movies that are filmed in Hollywood or Moscow, Alan Ayckbourn stays home in Scarborough tending to his business of writing plays, directing them and running his small 300-seat theater. He is a man of the theater, in all senses of the word, a former actor and stage manager who has become England's most successful and prolific playwright. As such, he is an anomaly in Scarborough, a seaside resort on the northeast coast of England catering to middle-class families on holiday and pensioners who gather for ballroom dancing in the once-grand Grand Hotel. Artistically, Ayckbourn (pronounced ache-born), is nurtured by his adopted Yorkshire environment, often writing about the kind of people who live there. He could be considered the bard of the English bourgeoisie.

title: Spas
description: To the Editor: I am a lover of spas, and I have visited many in this country and in Europe. I decided to try Eastern Europe about a year ago and discovered a whole new spa experience in Yugoslavia, on the Adriatic coast.

title: Safety in Lower Numbers
description: MEETING GORBACHEV'S CHALLENGE

title: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST: Rumania;   CEAUSESCU'S AIDES RECALL LAST DAYS
description: Angered that his troops were not firing on demonstrators, Nicolae Ceausescu threatened on Dec. 17 to execute two of his top ministers, according to testimony read today in the first public trial of members of the ousted government.

title: THE WEDDING: TASTINGS
description: They have never been considered culinary meccas or odes to the nuances of flavor. Wedding receptions have always been more devoted to decoration than cooking. Ice sculptures, tomato roses, stuffed snow peas and sugar flowers may have become extinct were it not for weddings. In the movie ''True Love,'' a caterer persuades the beleagured young couple to serve sky-blue mashed potatoes to match the bridesmaids' dresses. ''You should feel that anything's possible,'' he says.

title: Lynn Lorenzo Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Roberto Lorenzo of Rochester have announced August wedding plans for their daughter Lynn Robin Lorenzo and Michael David Pollack, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald Pollack of New Rochelle, N.Y. Miss Lorenzo, 23 years old, and the prospective bridegroom, 24, are graduates of Princeton University. She is an investment analyst at Prudential Power Funding Associates in Newark. Mr. Pollack is an associate at Booz, Allen & Hamilton, management consultants in New York.

title: Limit Capital Gains Tax Cut to New Issues;   Wiser Countries
description: To the Editor:

title: When Takeout Is Quail And Rack of Lamb
description: FOR many commuters constant travel means tedium and exhaustion. But for Patty Cassidy of Greenwich, a long train ride led to a new business.

title: Salvador Promises Quayle Full Inquiry on Jesuits
description: The President of El Salvador assured Vice President Dan Quayle today that he would investigate the killings of six Jesuit priests to see if the evidence implicated anyone ranking higher than the nine military men accused in the slayings.

title: Managing;   Saying No to the 'Mommy Track'
description: Nearly three years ago, Cairy S. Brown, an audit manager at Arthur Andersen & Company, decided she wanted to spend more time with her new baby. The problem: What constitutes part time work for someone who might work a 90-hour week during a client's crunch time?

title: East Germany Arrests Nation's Former Press Chief
description: Joachim Herrmann, a former member of the Communist Party Politburo, has been arrested on suspicion of high treason in connection with his running of the state press and broadcasting, the official East German press agency reported today.

title: Raccoons Are Gone From the Attic but Not From My Heart
description: THE creaking noises became noticeable in midsummer, late one evening when I was reading a ghost story. The house is settling, I thought. The trees are scraping the windows. A squirrel must be running across the roof. I shivered. Within a week, however, I became accustomed to a still-occasional creaking sound in the attic. ''It's the people upstairs,'' I told the teen-agers who sat around the kitchen table with me.

title: BELONGINGS OF THE THUNDER DRAGON
description: The exotic temple art of Bhutan - scrolls, embroideries, vessels and musical instruments - derives its forms from Indian and Middle Eastern artifacts and its surface decoration from Chinese art. The first exhibition in New York of such Buddhist material, ''Art From the Himalayan Kingdom of Bhutan, Land of the Thunder Dragon,'' is at Asia Society Galleries through June 17.

title: Limit Capital Gains Tax Cut to New Issues
description: To the Editor:

title: For Winter's Blues, Handmade Jewelry
description: THE warm glow of gold and silver handcrafted jewelry is an antidote for midwinter blues as well as an answer for Valentine's Day gift giving. Visitors to the National Invitational Valentine Jewelry Show at the Sheila Nussbaum Gallery will find more than 300 pieces of work from which to choose.

title: Question Of the Week;   Is Betting On the Super Bowl Excessive?
description: Gambling, or betting, can be an addiction, like alcohol, or any drug. But what does this have to do with the Super Bowl? The Super Bowl is only one event, although the grandest, during the long, long year of the sports calendar.

title: Can the Old Spirit Of the MTM Studio Be Recaptured?
description: Television viewers may soon wonder if their favorite kitten has returned home. By spring, MTM Entertainment, whose meowing logo became synonymous with quality programming in the 1970's through the mid-80's, will, after a fallow period, have new shows on each of the big three commercial networks.

title: When the Weather's Cold, Try Braising
description: BRAISING is a technique that deserves to be in every cook's repertory, especially in cold weather. It is a slow cooking method, suitable for thick pieces of food.

title: Helping Prisoners With AIDS
description: It is no doubt true that, as Catherine Hanssens of the Department of the Public Advocate notes in the article ''Plan for AIDS Testing in Prison Raises Questions'' (Dec. 17), for people who have AIDS there is no more difficult place to be than prison.

title: Janice Fuchella To Wed in June
description: The engagement of Janice Fuchella to James P. Carroll Jr., a son of Mr. and Mrs. Carroll of Fort Salonga, L.I., has been announced by the prospective bride's mother, Ann Selobyt of Newton, N.J. Miss Fuchella also is a daughter of the late Joseph Fuchella of Greenwich, Conn. A June wedding is planned.

title:
Your Own Account;

The Lure of the Lump Sum
description: LEAD: The man is 62 years old, earning about $100,000 a year and thinking of retirement. But when he starts doing his pension numbers, he hits an increasingly common dilemma. Should he take the money in a lump sum - in this hypothetical case, $380,000 - and invest it himself? Or should be accept his company's guarantee of $40,000 a year for the rest of his life?

title:
DINING OUT;

Where Inventive Cuisine Is a Hallmark
description: LEAD: FOR a serious young chef, the ultimate dream is to open one's own restaurant. A small place containing perhaps a dozen tables, a limited, creative menu that reflects what's fresh in the market, and service by a caring and informed staff are usually at the top of the gastronome's wish list.

title: SPECTER IS RAISED OF NUCLEAR THEFT
description: The unrest in the Soviet Union has raised the question of whether nuclear arms there could fall into the hands of political extremists, military experts in the United States say.

title: Images on TV Highlight Calls to Protect Infants
description: Televised scenes of child after child being carried from the wreckage of Avianca Flight 52 by rescue workers have highlighted calls by consumer groups and flight attendants that child-restraint seats be required aboard aircraft, as they are required in cars.

IN SHORT;

NONFICTION
description: LEAD:

title: P. H. London Weds Katherine Shapiro
description: The marriage of Katherine Elisabeth Shapiro, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bertram Shapiro of Raleigh, N.C., to Peter Horace London, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Ephraim S. London of New York, took place yesterday at the home of the bridegroom's parents. Judge John A. K. Bradley of the New York City Civil Court officiated.

title: Early Birds
description: To the Editor: Carol Cott Gross's helpful guide to dining with parents in Florida (''Just Had Lunch? Sorry. Dinner Time!'' Travel,Dec. 3) is superb, but, if you'll excuse me, she left out a few important suggestions:

title: LIFE STYLE: Sunday Outing;   Reveling in Serenity and Culture at the Cloisters
description: Near Manhattan's northern boundary, nestled comfortably within an expanse of greenery, sits the Cloisters, John D. Rockefeller Jr.'s homage to the Middle Ages. Like the medieval monastery it resembles, this uptown branch of the Metropolitan Museum has many functions: a landmark to the traveler, a magnet to the aficionado of medieval art, an oasis to the seeker of calm. It is an institution that seems particularly in harmony with its environment, and in each new season, with changes of light and temperature, can seem like quite a different place.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. I have dark, wood-paneled walls in my den and would like to lighten the wood. Is it possible to paint over it and retain the look (knots and lines in the wood panels)?

title: TALKING: Unsold Units;   Low Prices Tempting Investors
description: A NEW, controversial and high-risk market is evolving in occupied apartments in converted New York City cooperatives, with many of them being offered to investors at deeply discounted prices. The big price breaks are a direct result of the troubles some conversion sponsors are experiencing in meeting maintenance and debt service charges on the apartments they still own in converted buildings.

title: Tennessee Republicans See an Election Weapon in State's Bingo Scandal
description: A yearlong round of indictments involving bingo operations and official corruption here has put Democrats on the defensive in a legislative election year and presented the generally somnolent state Republican Party with a wake-up call to arms.

title: ON MY MIND
description: Time is running out for Yasir Arafat and the Palestine Liberation Organization to grab the best political bargain they ever have been offered or are likely to get.

title: Ann L. Heilman, A Law Student, Becomes a Bride
description: Ann Leonard Heilman, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard J. Heilman of Exeter, N.H., was married there yesterday at St. Michael's Roman Catholic Church to David Michael Murphy, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William R. Murphy of Woodbridge, Conn. The Rev. James D. Decker performed the ceremony.

title: A Pipe Organ Stars In Series at St. James
description: THE innovative Music at Saint James series is held in the lovely village church in North Salem and is devoted - uniquely in the county -to chamber music with pipe organ. It begins its fourth season today at 4 P.M.

title: Corrections
description: An obituary and its headline last Sunday about a leading member of the Social Democratic Party in West Germany misidentified him in some editions. He was Herbert Wehner.

title: Reviews/Dance;   'Coppelia,' With Stars Of Future
description: The New York City Ballet celebrated its school and students on Wednesday night at the New York State Theater with a benefit performance of ''Coppelia,'' a production that owes much of its existence to Alexandra Danilova, who choreographed it with George Balanchine. The evening was dedicated to Miss Danilova, who was in the audience.

title: M. S. Astrachan to Wed Bethany Jane Carlucci
description: Mr. and Mrs. Angelo Carlucci of Greenwich, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Bethany Jane Carlucci, to Michael Sanders Astrachan, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Boris Astrachan of Hamden, Conn. A July wedding is planned.

title: Review/Dance;   Robbins and Balanchine Program by City Ballet
description: Competence may not be enough. The New York City Ballet danced competently for much of the time on Thursday night at the New York State Theater. Nevertheless, the program was often lacking in both excitement and eloquence.

title: Hakan Hagegard Recital
description: The baritone Hakan Hagegard will sing selections from Schubert's ''Schwanengesang'' and works by Ives, Duparc and Wolf at 3 P.M. today at Alice Tully Hall. Warren Jones will be the accompanist. Tickets are $18. Information: 874-6770.

title: Taking the Crucial Next Step at Genentech
description: Alarms shrieked through the headquarters of Genentech Inc. here one Friday morning last month, sending hundreds of employees scurrying to the parking lot.

description: To the Sports Editor:

title: Owners Propose Blend of the Borrowed, the Old and the New
description: The owners call what they are proposing a partnership. If they called it a marriage, they could speak of something old, something new, something borrowed and no more blues over player salaries if the players would only accept their proposal.

title: Cathleen Callery To Marry in May
description: The engagement of Cathleen Callery to Michael Gioffre, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Bruno J. Gioffre of Rye Brook, N.Y., has been announced by the prospective bride's mother, Ina H. Callery of Port Chester, N.Y. A May wedding is planned.

description: To the Editor:

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article on Dec. 10 about contacts between Baltic nationalists and the United Nations Secretariat misstated the United Nations' stand on the Soviet annexations of Latvia, Estonia and Lithuania. In response to inquiries from international lawyers, further checks by The Times - delayed through an oversight - have found no evidence that the General Assembly ever explicitly recognized the 1940 annexations.

title: POSTINGS: Rising in Mott Haven;   112 Affordable Two-Family Town Houses
description: The South East Bronx Community Organization, a private, nonprofit developer, began construction last week on St. Mary's Park Homes, a $20 million affordable-housing project that will create 112 town houses between East 144th and East 146th Streets, off Willis and Brook Avenues, in the Mott Haven section of the South Bronx. The architect is Davila-Petraglia of Manhattan.

title: Hilary G. Maslow To Wed in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Richard Maslow of Dallas, Pa., have announced June wedding plans for their daughter Hilary Gail Maslow and Mark Eric Naud, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph Henry Naud of Detroit.

title: Pistons Edge Wolves, 85-83
description: Joe Dumars made his first basket of the second half with only 1 minute 40 seconds to play, snapping a tie and lifting the Detroit Pistons to an 85-83 victory tonight over the Minnesota Timberwolves.

title: Big Game Shapes Up As a Big Mismatch
description: The Super Bowl matches the two conference champions, supposedly the two best teams in the National Football League. But in recent years most of these championship games have been runaways, and Super Bowl XXIV in the Louisiana Superdome Sunday could be the same.

title: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST: Poland;   Calling Party Too Weak to Go On, Polish Communists Act to Disband
description: Many of the 1,600 delegates at a Communist Party congress severely criticized their party today and moved toward dissolving it and replacing it with a new left-of-center political grouping.

title: Pittsburgh Surprises Arizona by 100-92
description: Pittsburgh had developed a reputation for beating top-level opponents and losing to lesser teams, until this season. This season, the Panthers had lost to good and bad alike.

title: A Dulles Opposes a New Name for Airport
description: A grandson and namesake of Secretary of State John Foster Dulles said Friday that he was dismayed by a proposal to rename Washington Dulles International Airport for Dwight D. Eisenhower.

title: Jennifer A. Leahy To Marry in April
description: Jennifer Anne Leahy, a daughter of Judge and Mrs. Vincent Francis Leahy of Newton, Mass., and Ronald Joseph Kim, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Hyung Kim of Glens Falls, N.Y., plan to be married in April.

title: Lewis Garnsworthy, Anglican Archbishop, 67
description: Archbishop Lewis Garnsworthy, an outspoken Anglican cleric who tangled with political leaders over school funding and once scolded his own church for being too ''respectable,'' died on Friday. He was 67 years old.

title: Dispute Stalls Tenant Legal Aid Plan
description: A New York State plan to provide lawyers to people in danger of losing their homes has been stalled by a dispute over rules proposed by agencies paying for the program.

title: Corrections
description: A picture caption in the [Arts and Leisure] section about actors playing against type misidentified the film in which Cher appeared. It was ''Moonstruck.''

title: All Work and No Play Makes Jack a Nerd;   Multiple Choices
description: To the Editor:

title: In Small Steps, Program Puts Homeless Into Jobs
description: As hundreds of communities struggle to check the spread of homelessness, an ambitious program to steer Louisville's homeless into jobs and stable lives has shown some real success. But success comes in tiny steps, and at the same time, failure abounds.

title: Banker, Heed Your Customer
description: To the Editor:

title: LIFE STYLE: Sunday Dinner;   Excellent Fresh Fish, Bistro Fare and More
description: This is a summary of reviews of Manhattan restaurants by Bryan Miller that have appeared in The New York Times. Ratings are followed by the date of original publication. Prices are current.

title: Techniques With Brush and Roller
description: USING a paint brush or roller effectively and without creating a mess takes practice. But skill is important, too. Here are some hints on handling brushes and rollers that may improve your abilities with both tools.

title: Davis a Natural for Denver
description: It snowed heavily Friday afternoon while the Knicks practiced at Westminster College in Salt Lake City. They had a plane to catch for their game here tonight against the Nuggets, but Coach Stu Jackson was in no hurry to leave. The Knicks were working on their transition defense and the coach wanted to make sure his team understood how important an element it was when playing the Nuggets.

title: Five Are Killed in Ethnic Violence In a Strife-Torn Yugoslav Province
description: At least five ethnic Albanians were killed in gun battles with the police today, the fifth day of riots in the Yugoslav province of Kosovo, the official press agency Tanyug said.

title: Broncos' Only Hope: Creating Turnovers
description: For nearly two weeks now, the Denver Broncos' defensive players have been studying films of the San Francisco 49ers' offense: Joe Montana slinging those quick arrows, Jerry Rice and John Taylor catching them, Roger Craig and Tom Rathman rumbling upfield. But today those films will come to life. Today the Broncos will take their Super Bowl XXIV test. Today the 49ers will spin out of the huddle, line up, Montana will take the snap and Jerry Rice, the most valuable player in the Super Bowl last year, will be trying to deceive Tyrone Braxton, the Broncos' left cornerback.

title: An Impassioned Bird Watcher's Tips
description: FRANK MANTLIK says he would go to just about any height to spot any bird rarely seen in Connecticut. Mr. Mantlik, a professional wildlife photographer, has been a bird watcher for 20 years.

title: Melanie Cohen Plans to Marry
description: The engagement of Melanie Cohen to Lawrence T. Greenberg, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Ronald Greenberg of Scarsdale, N.Y., has been made known by her parents, Dr. and Mrs. Lawrence S. Cohen of New Haven. An August wedding is planned.

title: World Markets;   How Long for German Funds?
description: ''Being a Scotsman, it goes against the grain to spend $1.50 to buy a $1,'' said Gavin Dobson, president of Murray Johnstone International, a Chicago money manger. He was explaining why he did not buy into the New Germany Fund Inc., which was launched last week. Plenty of other people did buy. The German stock market has fallen 4 percent since it hit a record high on Jan. 3, propelled downward partly by jitters over the outlook for the economic development of Eastern Europe, which have replaced much of the euphoria of last fall. But the New Germany Fund opened at 21 7/8, more than 50 percent above the initial offering price minus underwriting fees. On Friday it traded even higher, closing at 24, which meant buyers were paying an even higher premium of 72 percent. Those who bought more than 19 million shares over the two days - 76 percent of the fund's 25 million shares - were paying $1.57 to $1.72 for $1 of equity.

title: The Legacy of C. S. Lewis
description: To the Editor:

title: Another Perspective On Fuel Cooperatives
description: I am writing in response to an article, ''Price of Heating Oil Prompts an Outcry'' that appeared Jan. 7 in the Westchester Weekly. Overall the article was even-handed and among other things offered information on fuel co-operatives as an alternative to local fuel marketers. Please allow me to offer some insight as to how a typical co-op works.

title: Two Workers Killed In Fall From the Top Of 14-Story Building
description: Two construction workers fell 14 floors to their deaths yesterday when a ladder one was using on a concrete ledge projecting from the top floor of a midtown apartment building toppled, the police said.

title: LIFE STYLE: Sunday Menu;   Spicy Pork With an Oriental Flavor
description: Buying pork that is already ground will not give you lean meat. But if you buy a pork tenderloin, remove the small amount of excess fat and grind the meat in a food processor or an old-fashioned grinder, your final dish will not be swimming in fat.

title: About Cars;   Justy Is a Quality, High-Tech Econocar
description: When you spend a lot of money for a car, certain things are to be expected. You get fancy trim, maybe leather. You get performance. And, generally, you get high-tech electronics and mechanical doodads.

title: Mrs. Mandela Gloomier on Husband's Prospects
description: Nelson R. Mandela's wife said today that plans for her husband's release from prison had run into problems, and she criticized the South African Government.

title: Lisa R. Lipskin To Wed in June
description: The engagement of Lisa Rogers Lipskin to Thomas Michael Jardine, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Leonard Jardine of Providence, R.I., has been announced by her parents, Mrs. Marcus Anast of Chappaqua, N.Y., and Robert Lipskin of Cedarhurst, L.I. A June wedding is planned.

title: Marianne Kulla Is Engaged
description: Mr. and Mrs. Morton Kulla of Miami have announced June wedding plans for their daughter, Marianne Kulla, and Michael Strauss, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Stephen N. Strauss of New York and Belle Terre, L.I. Miss Kulla, 24 years old, is a candidate for an M.B.A. at New York University. She is a cum laude graduate of Wellesley College, where she was a Dana Foundation Fellow. Mr. Strauss, 29, is a lawyer in Port Jefferson, L.I. He graduated cum laude from Columbia University and received a J.D. from the Columbia School of Law, where he was a Harlan Fiske Stone Scholar.

title: When a Map Becomes a Board Game
description: LEAD: FIFTH GRADERS at the North Stratfield Elementary School in Fairfield are combining geography lessons with wordplay to learn about Connecticut. In the process, they are learning to work in teams and, the pupils say, having fun.

title: Bush Wants Billions of Trees For War Against Polluted Air
description: Aiming at both a greening of America and a cooling of the world, President Bush will announce in his State of the Union Message next week a program to increase the nation's tree cover by a billion trees a year for the next 10 years, Administration officials say.

title: DOMESTIC EFFORTS BEAR TOP BURDEN IN BUSH'S BUDGET
description: About half the $36 billion in deficit reduction that President Bush will propose in the budget he sends to Congress on Monday would come out of domestic programs, including some efforts in education, housing, transportation and health.

title: Foul Line Busy as Pirates Top Villanova
description: It was only fitting that tonight's game between Seton Hall and Villanova - teams with two of the poorest records in the Big East -was a sloppy affair marred by a constant parade to the foul line.

title: A World Of Butterflies In Florida
description: BUTTERFLY WORLD, a three-acre live butterfly park in south Florida, is the first of its kind in the United States and the largest in the world, according to Ronald Boender, its founder and co-owner.

title: Rethinking the Engineer Shortage
description: To the Editor:

title: About Time To Face The Music?
description: Let's rock. On Tuesday MGM/UA will release 10 titles: ''Rolling Stone Presents 20 Years of Rock-and- Roll,'' a new music video produced by the magazine and featuring the Beatles, The Who, The Doors, the Rolling Stones, Bruce Springsteen, Madonna and others; ''The Fastest Guitar Alive'' (also new on video), starring Roy Orbison and directed by David Lynch, and eight older rock titles from the MGM library.

title: East Europe Could Shed Light on Trotsky and Some Americans
description: To the Editor:

title: To Many in Panama, the New President Is an Enigma Wrapped in a Smile
description: To many people who know him only from afar, Guillermo Endara Galimany, a 53-year-old lawyer with a dimpled smile and a quick laugh, is something of an enigma.

title: Hers;   Dreaming Someone Else's Dreams
description: IT IS SATURDAY NIGHT, and I am writing my best friend in California. I am at home with my husband and three children. She is alone in a studio apartment, with romantic notions about my life as a wife and mother. We are not as close as we used to be. Dear - - -, On most nights, I'm just reading the last Dr. Seuss story to the kids while you're kicking off your high heels and settling into a stack of paper work.

title: Government By the People, Lots of Them
description: LEAD: JOHN B. MARGENOT Jr., the First Selectman in Greenwich, has a favorite line about the Greenwich Representative Town Meeting. ''I often say that if we held an R.T.M. meeting in a boat, it would probably capsize, so many people would be going from one side to the other,'' he said.

title: IN THE REGION: Connecticut and Westchester;   Recent Sales
description: Monroe, Conn. $118,000

title: Where Lewis and Clark Wintered
description: AS a hopelessly provincial Easterner I had always thought of Astoria as (a) the last name of a well-known New York hotel, (b) the only name of an area of New York City or (c) the title of a half-forgotten travel book by Washington Irving. Recently, however, I visited (d) the real thing - a handsome and historic city situated where the mighty Columbia River meets Oregon's thundering Pacific coast. I soon found to my delight that visitors to this Astoria can, within the space of only a few days or miles, relive the wild days of the early Northwest, wander through a neighborhood of superbly preserved Victorian houses and explore some of America's most magnificent coastal scenery.

title: Florida State Has His Vote
description: To the Sports Editor:

title: CORRECTIONS
description: The ''Your Own Account'' column last Sunday, discussing limited partnerships, misidentified the tax form required of investors. It is a Schedule K-1, Form 1065, not a K-9.

title: Replying to Critics, Yale Moves to Recruit More Minority Professors
description: Responding to a report that sharply criticized Yale's record on affirmative action, the university's president has outlined a five-year plan to recruit minority professors.

Publications in Manhasset, was picking up her 21-month-old son, Robbie, at the company's on-site day-care center. ''It's just a great feeling knowing that he's in the same building with me, and that I can spend time with him during lunch,'' Mrs.

Dallas of Englewood, N.J., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Linda Karen Dallas, a third-year law student at Georgetown University, to Dr. Louis William Kantaros, a resident in internal medicine at New England Deaconess Hospital in Boston. A September wedding is planned.

STYLE MAKERS;

Nicholas Graham: Underwear Designer
description: LEAD: In an open space two flights above a muffler shop, 31-year-old Nicholas Graham is leading his own boxer rebellion. Mr. Graham has founded a corporation on the premise that men will wear boxer shorts with zany designs like giant bananas, billiard balls and yellow happy faces. It turns out that women will wear them too, as outerwear: they account for 50 percent of the sales by Mr.

title: Susan L. Werber To Marry in June
description: Mr. and Mrs. Seymour Werber of Great Neck, L.I., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Susan Lynn Werber, to Dr. Andrew Scott Rokito, a son of Dr. Evelyn Wolf Rokito and Dr. Michael Rokito of Roslyn, L.I. A June wedding is planned.

title: All About/Cellular Telephones;   A Gadget That May Soon Become the Latest Necessity
description: Once gadgets of the rich and powerful, cellular telephones are moving into the mainstream. Still primarily business tools, the phones are increasingly showing up in the cars, handbags and pockets of the elderly, housewives, outdoor enthusiasts and others who need instant communications.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL 3-16

title: Elway Gets a 3d Chance
description: Someone else always goes to Disney World.

title: FASHION: On the Street;   With Down Out, The Cloth Coat Grows in the Job
description: In the last couple of years, the pouf seems to have gone out of the down coat, the overstuffed garment that wreaked winter havoc with coat-checkers and turned a lot of fashionable people into reasonable facsimiles of the Michelin Man. Still very much around, however, is the cloth coat, adaptable as ever to the winds of change.

title:
GARDENING;

Crab Apple: Fragrant, Pretty and Tough
description: LEAD: BECAUSE the flowering dogwood has had so many problems with disease in recent years, some horticultural experts are advising against planting them. A good substitute is the flowering crab apple.

title: Jets Have a Stake
description: Jets fans could have a special interest in the Super Bowl today. That's because two assistant coaches who will be on opposite sides of the field have emerged among the possible contenders for the team's head coaching job.

title: POSTINGS: Four on Lexington;   Deslivering Saves a Brownstone Row
description: When it appeared in the early 80's that sliver buildings would dominate the landscape, the owner of 1451 Lexington Avenue was poised to lead the march into the future. As things turned out, new owners decided to lead a march back to the past.

title: On Language;   Dark Words Of Disapproval
description: A WEEK BEFORE HIS arrest, Marion S. Barry Jr., Mayor of Washington, took umbrage at an article written about him by Bella Stumbo of The Los Angeles Times. The reporter quoted the Mayor, who is black, as saying of the Rev. Jesse Jackson, a new resident of Washington, ''He don't wanna be no mayor.''

title: Parasitic Mites Imperil Honeybees
description: A PARASITIC mite that preys on honeybees has invaded hives in four towns in the state, forcing the authorities to destroy the colonies in 11 hives.

title: Corrections
description: A front-page article in the Arts and Leisure section last Sunday about morning television talk shows misidentified a syndicated television series. It is ''Entertainment Tonight,'' not ''Entertainment Today.''

title:
IN THE REGION: New Jersey;

Sprucing Up Hoboken's Grim Riverfront
description: LEAD: BEYOND the rows of Hoboken's tightly packed houses lies a portion of its riverfront that is dotted with desolate piers and abandoned buildings, symbols of industry's departure during the 1970's from this once bustling port city.

title: Campus Life: Florida;   Trauma Team In Its First Week Moves Into Action
description: A trauma team set up by University of Florida administrators was pushed into unexpected duty during its first week of existence when a recent graduate was murdered on Jan. 17 near the campus.

title: The Right to Bear Arms: A Working Definition
description: FOR the American gun lobby, ''the right to keep and bear arms'' in the Second Amendment has become such a familiar refrain that the entire text is often overlooked: ''A well-regulated Militia being necessary to the security of a free State, the right of the people to keep and bear Arms shall not be infringed.''

title: NOTED WITH PLEASURE
description: A Poem a Day Keeps Daddy Away

title: The Image of Movie Music Is Changing Once Again
description: In ''Wonder Waltz,'' one of 15 surreal musical fragments composed by Elliot Goldenthal for the soundtrack of the movie ''Drugstore Cowboy'' (RCA Novus 3077-2; all three formats), a synthesizer, bells and delicately layered percussion combine to suggest a broken-down merry-go-round playing woozily in an underwater carnival.

title: Jennifer L. Clarke To Wed L. M. Hitt
description: A July wedding is planned by Jennifer Louise Clarke and Lorin M. Hitt, the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Warren Edward Clarke of Newton Centre, Mass., have announced.

title: PUBLIC & PRIVATE
description: Art imitates life in the offices of the National Abortion Rights Action League and the National Right to Life Committee. At Naral, the prints and posters are mainly renderings of women. In the offices of Right to Life, the pictures are of babies. The issue of abortion is framed, quite literally, on the walls of their Washington headquarters: which comes first, the woman or the fetus?

title: Tech Notes;   Searching for Hidden Oil and Gas
description: A new instrument that can find oil and gas hidden behind the metal walls of a well has been invented by a Washington company.

description: To the Editor:

title: THE WEDDING: FORMALITIES
description: THE BRIDE FLOATED INTO THE ROOM IN AJU hand-beaded, full-skirted wedding dress with a tumbling train and a long swoop of a veil. The groom wore white tie. At the reception, hundreds of off-white roses filled the ballroom, and a 20-piece orchestra played into the night. It was the kind of fairy-tale event usually reserved for young couples. But in this case, the bride, Vera Wang, was 40 years old, and the groom, Arthur Becker, was 39.

title: Review/Music;   Designing Instruments And the Sounds Therein
description: Tan Dun, a composer who came to New York from China four years ago, uses both Eastern and Western elements in his music. But in his works that have been heard in New York City - the opera ''Nine Songs,'' which was performed last year, and ''Soundshape,'' which had its premiere on Sunday evening at the Guggenheim Museum - he has made it clear that a cross-cultural blend is not quite what he is after.

title:
ART;

'Passages,' a Sense of Evolution
description: LEAD: VISITORS to ''Passages,'' the Discovery Gallery's current six-artist exhibition, would do well to head directly for the second of the gallery's two spaces in Glen Cove's Village Square.

title: Works With Shadings of Pygmalion
description: THE source of ''My Fair Lady,'' Shaw's ''Pygmalion'' is about a man bettering a woman, burnishing her rough edges, eliminating her telltale accent. Professor Higgins took the rough diamond that was Eliza Doolittle and turned her into a gem - no small feat in Edwardian England, where the quality was as alert to interlopers as are gazelles to the scent of lion.

title: The Subway Killing's Lesson
description: The nameless person attracted scant attention in life, despite his efforts to provoke people in the subway. One night last week he tried again, by spitting on and then punching Rodney Sumter, waiting for a train with his little boy. Enraged, Mr. Sumter fought back; within minutes the deranged, homeless man lay dead.

title: In Texas, the Door to Central Americans Opens a Crack
description: ALMOST a year ago the Immigration and Naturalization Service tried to cut the flow of illegal immigrants from Central America into south Texas by putting thousands of people in detention camps. Since then lawsuits and budget constraints have whittled away that harsh policy, and the Government has to find a new strategy for handling a new wave of migrants.

description: To the Editor:

Bistro Dishes Accented in Chappaqua
description: LEAD: LAST October, Bistrot Maxime - after some uncertainty about the name, with bistro retaining the final T in this Francofied version - emerged from its almost yearlong renovation. For those who may not have heard, this eating spot has evolved under the direction of Maxime Ribera of Maxime's and Bernard le Bris of Auberge Maxime, with Mr.

title: Correction
description: An article last Sunday about an Interstate 95 interchange in Mamaroneck misstated the village's population. It is 17,616.

title: THE FLAP OVER TOM WOLFE: HOW REAL IS THE RETREAT FROM REALISM?
description: I cannot offhand recall an article in a small magazine making a bigger splash in the literary pool than Tom Wolfe's manifesto, ''Stalking the Billion-Footed Beast,'' in the November 1989 issue of Harper's Magazine. Mr. Wolfe, an old hand at self-publicizing, has been busy widening the ripple effect by lecturing to full houses in places as disparate as Columbia University and the Century Club in New York City; he has appeared on ABC News's ''Nightline'' in his ice-cream suit and high-necked shirt, his demeanor, as always, bland and gentlemanly, to spar tangentially with Margaret Atwood while taking some gratuitous swipes at university writing programs. For its February issue, Harper's solicited responses from Philip Roth, Walker Percy and other novelists. And on Feb. 5, Lewis H. Lapham, the editor of Harper's, will moderate a discussion between Mary Gordon and Mr. Wolfe on Mr. Lapham's public television program, ''Bookmark.''

description: To the Editor:

description: By a wide margin, more Americans want the San Francisco 49ers to win the Super Bowl than prefer the Denver Broncos, a New York Times/ CBS News Poll shows.

description: OUT-OF-TOWN investors flocking to this city to scoop up real estate at rock-bottom prices have given rise to its newest sport - ''bottom fishing.''

description: THE best things in life may be free, but Wilson H. Faude apparently is not among those who think so.

description: New York Stories

title: Women Composers Find Things Easier - Sort Of
description: Composition, like conducting, has historically been a man's field, but when Ellen Taaffe Zwilich's Symphony No. 1 won the Pulitzer Prize for music in 1983, a woman had finally acquired a credential that could not be ignored. Today, Ms. Zwilich is awash in prestigious performances and commissions - including pieces for four of the Big Five orchestras in the next few years. In addition, a handful of other women, like Joan Tower, whose Flute Concerto will receive its premiere this afternoon in Carnegie Hall in a performance by Carol Wincenc and the American Composers Orchestra, are beginning to get attention as composers.

title: So What if College Players Turn Pro?
description: Now that the January orgy of bowl and all-star games has almost faded from memory, we spectators can turn to other, more elevating activities, like today's Super Bowl. The players, meanwhile, some 2,000 of them representing more than 30 bowl-qualifying football powers, have returned to their campuses and resumed what the National Collegiate Athletic Association likes to describe as ''normal academic lives.''

title: Justice in Anti-Dumping
description: While American politicians lecture the world on fair trade, our dumping laws are an inquisitorial nightmare for foreign companies, making a mockery of due process and justice at every turn. In the last 17 years, Congress and the Commerce Department have repeatedly expanded the definition of dumping. Between 1980 and 1986, the Commerce Department found only 6 percent of all imports it investigated not guilty of unfair trade practices.

title: Helsinki II, Road Map for Revolution
description: Eastern Europe's rush to freedom has inspired hope for a trans-European partnership. The superpowers concur that Europe's ''common house'' should extend from Moscow to Washington. But mixed with optimism is fear of a backslide, as democracy and free markets struggle to take root.

title: Nicaragua Approaches an Election That May Rise or Fall on Its Fairness
description: With less than a month to go before Nicaragua's elections, leaders of the governing Sandinista Front and their opponents are entering the final phase of what all sides say will be a decisive referendum on a decade of Sandinista rule.

title: Nor a Lender Be
description: To the Editor:

title: Robyn Hall Wed To Peter S. Stern
description: Robyn Ann Hall, a daughter of Jean H. Umbreit and W. Robert Hall, both of Bedford, N.H., was married yesterday at the Carlyle in New York to Peter Simon Stern, a son of Mrs. Morton Wiener of Palm Beach, Fla., and Otto Stern of Valley Cottage, N.Y. The ceremony was performed by Judge Arthur D. Spatt of the United States District Court for the Eastern District of New York.

title: For Non-Super Bowl Watchers, No Lines for Ski Lifts or Jazz Clubs

title: Addiction Recovery At a Hospital Unit

title: YEARNING FOR AN IRON HAND
description: THE REVOLUTION DAY PARADE IN THE western Siberian city of Tyumen has dwindled in recent years from a two-hour spectacle to a perfunctory 45-minute exercise, reflecting the collapse of the Communist faith. Last Nov. 7 the Tyumen city fathers, desperate to boost their ratings, agreed to permit a small show of dissent.

title: Fine Print Governs Your Rights in the Air
description: EVERYBODY has heard the stories, and almost every frequent flier can tell them in the first person: a flight delayed, a connection missed, a plane overbooked or a suitcase lost, and sometimes a confrontation with airline agents over compensation for the inconvenience.

title: Auto Insurance: New Plan Offers Tough Choices
description: THE man who crafted Gov. Jim Florio's new proposal for automobile insurance envisions a year of major changes for New Jersey drivers, a time when insurance costs rise for some people, drop for most others, and in the end, the administration hopes, leaves the state with an insurance system that is fairer and more sensible.

title: Letters;   CONFIDENT AT 11, CONFUSED AT 16
description: We would like to thank Francine Prose for her fine article ''Confident at 11, Confused at 16'' (Jan. 7), on our work with girls growing up, and to offer a point of correction. The discussion of the contrast between the voices of 11- and 16-year-old girls comes from a 5-year study of girls at Laurel School in Shaker Heights, Ohio (financed by the Cleveland and George Gund Foundations), and studies conducted in urban neighborhoods and schools in Boston (paid for by the Rockefeller and Boston Foundations and the Lilly Endowment).

description: AMBULATORY surgery means that you don't have to stay in the hospital. You get there in the morning, and in the afternoon they let you go home. No big deal, right?

title: Leslie Brody and Milo Geyelin Marry
description: Leslie Brody, a reporter in Princeton, N.J., for The Trenton Times, was married yesterday at her parents' home in New York to Emile Camille Geyelin 3d, a reporter in Philadelphia for The Wall Street Journal. The Rev. Arthur Seaman, a Presbyterian minister, performed the civil ceremony.

title:
LONG ISLAND SOUND;

Westward Ho, at 35,000 Feet
description: LEAD: WHEN the pioneers crossed this country, they worried about Indian raids, hazardous mountain trails and disease. Which shows what they knew about suffering. They didn't deal with airlines.

title: Review/Theater;   Bonding With the Land In Cather's 'O Pioneers!'
description: For Willa Cather, ''O Pioneers!'' was the novel in which she spoke for the first time in her own voice, free of influence and literary tradition. In it, she said, she had hit ''the home pasture,'' and the book was to set her off on her creative journey. Written in 1913, ''O Pioneers!'' remains one of the enduring works of American literature. With its tale of one woman's indomitability, it would seem to be a most natural choice for dramatization, except for the very important fact that the strength of the book is not in the dialogue but in the poetic depth of the author's narrative and her evocation of characters rooted in environment.

title: NICHOLL'S LIFE STYLE GIVES RANGERS A NEW DIMENSION
description: Bernie Nicholls's life is defined more by his MasterCard than any master plan. Nicholls does not have an agent. He retains no financial consultant. By his own frank admission and rough estimation, he has spent as much as $10,000 a month on dress suits.

title: From Abe to Zeus, Beards Are Business
description: SAL ALFANO can size up a beard in no time. ''That's a farmer's beard,'' he'll say to a new customer. Or, ''You look like Zeus.''

title: New & Noteworthy
description: A MOTHER'S STORY: The Truth About the Baby M Case, by Mary Beth Whitehead with Loretta Schwartz-Nobel. (St. Martin's, $4.95.) The surrogate mother who decided to keep the baby she was hired to bear tells her side of the story. Last year our reviewer, Josh Greenfield, said this account changed his opinion about the case. Mary Beth Whitehead and her co-author ''have produced a most moving book, often eloquent, and one certain to touch any of us who has ever felt a maternal pain or a paternal pang.''

title: Nuns Died in Contra Ambush, Rights Group Says
description: An investigation by Americas Watch, the New York-based human rights group, has concluded that contras were responsible for the deaths of two Roman Catholic nuns whose car was attacked on a remote Nicaraguan highway on Jan. 1.

description: The Bastille To Lift Curtain On First Opera

title: Accessing Jail?
description: As it happens, the rogue program that Robert Tappan Morris fed into a national computer network in 1988 did not launch missiles, disrupt the stock market or shut down the telephone network. But it did scare the wits out a lot of people who run computer systems. Now some of them would like to see the favor returned by means of a jail sentence for Mr. Morris, a 24-year-old computer science student who last week became the first person to be convicted by a jury of violating the Computer Fraud and Abuse Act of 1986. Mr. Morris admitted planting the rogue program that disrupted 2,500 to 6,000 computers, forcing the days-long shutdown of some systems. His lawyers cast the deed as simply a hacker's prank that went awry. But others argued that it was high time to start meting out real punishment to those who disrupted computer networks. ''This is too serious not to include jail time,'' said a law enforcement official. Federal District Court in Syracuse is expected to sentence Mr. Morris in early March. He could get five years in prison and fines up to $250,000.

title: PASTIMES: Chess

It was vital that he gain one more point to tie for fifth place because that would assure him a playoff match for the remaining slot in this year's Interzonal Competition for world championship aspirants.

title: On China, Congress Is Almost Assertive

''In both our societies there are voices of those who seek to redirect or frustrate our cooperation,'' he said. ''We must take bold measures to overcome these negative forces.''

title: Legislators Seek Ban On Foam Cups in County
