description: MONDAY: Personal income figures for December will be announced.

title: D. M. Ross to Wed Carol Ann Glazer
description: Carol Ann Glazer, a community development executive in New York, and David Michael Ross, a lawyer in New York, plan to marry in June. Ms. Glazer is the daughter of May Glazer of New York and the late Dr. Harold Glazer. Mr. Ross is a son of Raye N. Ross of Chicago and the late Dr. Jacob N. Ross.

title: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST: Berlin;   Abject and Crumbling, Berlin Wall Surrenders
description: The once-mighty Berlin wall is a pitiful sight these days.

title: Speeding Work on Landmarks
description: NEW YORK CITY'S Landmarks Preservation Commission this week begins implementing guidelines designed to speed the approval process for the repair or replacement of windows in buildings covered by the landmark laws.

title: SEX, VIOLENCE AND THE LAW
description: THE NEW POLITICS OF PORNOGRAPHY

title: Capacity Doubling at Drug Treatment Centers
description: OVER the last decade, as drug and alcohol abuse soared on Long Island and across the country, almost no treatment centers were opened on the Island. In the last few months, however, a spurt of construction will result in a doubling of treatment capacity to 400 beds on the Island. About 150 more are in the planning stages.

title: Things of Value: Worker or Tools?
description: AS a child of the Depression I was always told that, unlike the children of some of the more affluent families down the street, I would truly appreciate the hard-fought-for things I would accumulate in my life.

title: Corrections
description: Because of an editing error, an article in The Times Magazine last Sunday about Aspen, Colo., misstated Marvin Davis's role in the 20th Century Fox Film Corporation. He sold his interest in 1985.

title: BARRY CASE LEADS TO WIDER INQUIRY
description: The Federal grand jury investigation of Mayor Marion S. Barry Jr. is widening into a broader examination of official corruption and drug use, but deep-seated suspicions from Mr. Barry's supporters about the prosecutors' motives continue to haunt the case.

title: Small Quake Jolts Indiana
description: An earthquake measuring 3.5 on the Richter scale of ground motion jolted southern Indiana and northern Kentucky today, the United States Geological Survey said. No injuries or damage was reported. An agency spokeswoman said the epicenter of the quake, which struck about 9:06 A.M., was in Harrison County, Ind., about 30 miles west of Louisville, Ky., and was an aftershock to a temblor that registered 3.8 in the same area on Wednesday.

title: Plays-in-Progress at Yale Winterfest
description: ''PERHAPS one of this year's Winterfest plays will become a classic, playing 400 years from now,'' says this year's promotional brochure for the series now under way at the Yale Repertory Theater in New Haven. ''Perhaps not.''

title: Dark Visions Light Up the Movies
description: A man who likes making a public nuisance of himself and harassing corporate officials. A woman whose idea of a family is four perfect loons. A performer who dresses up in fishnet stockings and plastic hoop earrings, singing about his enthusiasm for illicit drugs. A loner who used to get some of his best ideas thanks to huge amounts of coffee and sugar, and who for a long while lived in a mostly unfurnished place, avoiding visitors because, as he later said, he was doing things he didn't want people to see.

title: Coming to Terms on Health Care
description: Unlike the great industrial wars of America's past, the recent strikes against the Pittston Company and the Nynex Corporation were not over wages or even work conditions, but over health benefits. Such disputes are becoming commonplace. Union officials view health insurance as a basic necessity. As one of the Nynex strikers' picket signs put it, ''Cutting Our Health Benefits Is Sick.''

title: Connecticut, No. 5 on the Charts, Tries a Pre-emptive Strike
description: WITH automobile insurance rates high and rising, Connecticut officials last week began a yearlong study to try to find calm solutions in advance of a storm.

title:
STYLE MAKERS;

Federica Matta: Jewelry Designer
description: LEAD: '' 'Art jewelry' makes you think of those women in ponchos with some big rock on their neck,'' Federica Matta said. Nevertheless, the 35-year-old sculptress and painter has found that the jewelry she makes helps explain her other art.

title: At Airports, Can Time Be Made to Fly?
description: REMEMBER the White Horse Cellar in London where Samuel Pickwick and his Pickwickians arrived early for the half-past 7 o'clock stagecoach to Bath? ''The travelers' room - the last resort of human dejection,'' Charles Dickens wrote with distaste. ''The travelers' room at the White Horse Cellar is of course uncomfortable; it would be no travelers' room if it were not.''

title: STREETSCAPES: B. Altman's;   The Life and Death(?) Of a Palace for the Chic
description: EVEN among turn-of-the-century big stores, B. Altman's full-block building at the northeast corner of 34th Street and Fifth Avenue was a particularly imposing palace of consumption. Its move to Fifth Avenue in 1906 also marked a new development in the history of the thoroughfare - a shift from elite, small shops to a mix of both the specialized and the colossal.

title: Long Island Journal
description: Saving Greyhounds

title: Political Memo;   Mayoralty Raises Questions, While Jackson Ups the Ante
description: The political galleries are full of people asking will he or won't he run for mayor here. But the Rev. Jesse Jackson, as he so often does, is playing a more elaborate political game, one in which his potential candidacy for office provides both a platform and his strongest bargaining chip.

title: If the Role Is At All Unlikely, Call Judi Dench
description: ''That's not me; I don't look like that at all,'' laughs Dame Judi Dench, as she recalls her begrimed, ruddy Mistress Quickly in the Kenneth Branagh film of ''Henry V,'' which has won acclaim in Britain and the United States. Backstage in her dressing room at the West End's Aldwych Theater, where she is starring in a revival of ''The Cherry Orchard,'' the short, stocky actress looks fresh-faced and ever so slightly elegant, as befits her part as a lady of the Russian gentry noted for her extravagance and frivolity.

title:
ART;

Precisionism and Surrealism, Paul Outerbridge's Photos
description: LEAD: AT least two of the many sides of the photographer Paul Outerbridge (1896-1958) are thoroughly aired at the Yale University Art Gallery in New Haven. But the exhibition is entitled ''Paul Outerbridge: A Singular Esthetic.'' It is singular because those two major sides - precisionism and Surrealism - are easily blended in his most compelling works.

title: Corrections
description: An article last Sunday about Washington and its Mayor, Marion S. Barry Jr., misstated the percentage of blacks in the city. It is about 70 percent.

title: Miss Limbocker to Wed Anthony Dick
description: The engagement of Hilary duPont Limbocker to Anthony Dick, a son of Mr. and Mrs. C. Mathews Dick Jr. of Washington, has been made known by her parents, Mr. and Mrs. Derek L. Limbocker of New York. A June wedding is planned.

title: AUDIO DEALERS BESTOW THEIR LAURELS
description: Every year, audio dealers throughout the country are asked to single out those components that strike them as particularly noteworthy and well done. This survey - conducted by Audio/Video International, a prominent trade journal - forms the basis for the annual audio Grand Prix awards. They are the nearest thing to an Oscar in the audio industry.

title: The Intellectual Issue For the 1990's Is Why America's Intellectuals Have Faded Away
description: IT has become commonplace to lament the passing of the day when thinkers like James B. Conant and Lewis Mumford played as influential a role in politics as today's media advisers. Even to those who consider themselves among the last holdouts, the question is no longer whether intellectuals are in hiding, but why.

description: With her third consecutive Australian Open title, Steffi Graf still reigns over women's tennis. But her crown rested uneasily after she had to struggle against Mary Joe Fernandez today in the title match.

description: More than 100 students voluntarily cut short their winter vacations to join a workshop at Swarthmore College last weekend intended to promote tolerance for diversity on and off campus.

Gorbachev declared emergency rule.

Claude Vilgrain and Jon Morris, who had been assigned to the Devils' Utica farm team, were recalled to the parent club to fill in for three injured forwards. . . . C. Grant Spaeth, a Palo Alto, Calif., lawyer, has been elected president of the United States Golf Association.

description: Arab countries and the Palestine Liberation Organization are trying to persuade Moscow to stop the flow of Soviet Jews to Israel, senior Palestinians say.

title: New Orleans Race Yawning Down to the Wire
description: One of the oddest political campaigns in recent New Orleans history is ending as it began: quietly, with an uncharacteristic lack of passion.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;

When the Broker Is Also Your Husband
description: LEAD: WHEN I inherited a small amount of money recently, I asked my husband, who is a stockbroker, to invest a portion of it in stock for me. That was mistake No. 1. Does the carpenter's wife ask her husband to repair the roof? I soon discovered that stockbrokers don't always pick conservative stocks, even for their wives.

title: To Save Social Security, Save
description: Washington Week is here: President Bush presents his new budget tomorrow; on Tuesday, he reports to Congress on the State of the Union. Yet even with these main events at hand, public debate remains preoccupied by a dazzling, poorly understood preliminary, the Moynihan plan.

description: Widely televised tableaux this past week showed Federal investigators scouring country ponds and septic tanks in Enterprise, Ala., in their investigation of bombings that left two people dead.

title: Views of Sport;   America's Pastime: Selling the Big Game
description: What's ''American''? Mom? Apple pie? What's truly ''American?'' Not apple pie. Nobody goes into a restaurant anymore and orders apple pie. Anyway, the best apple pie I ever had was in Ulm, Germany.

title: Katherine Mellon Planning to Wed Patrick Jones Jr.
description: Katherine Hopkins Mellon and Patrick Suydam Jones Jr. plan to marry in June, the prospective bride's mother, Mrs. Charles H. Mellon 3d of Far Hills, N.J., has announced. Miss Mellon is also the daughter of the late Mr. Mellon. Her fiance is the son of Mrs. J. Clark Grew of Lake Forest, Ill., and the late Mr. Jones. He is the stepson of the Rev. J. Clark Grew, the rector of the Episcopal Church of the Holy Spirit in Lake Forest.

title: Navigators
description: To the Editor: Please thank Ruth Wolff for her delightful article on navigating a car (''Navigator to Pilot: We're Lost,'' Travel, Nov. 5). Her observations were so accurate that I had to stop reading from time to time because I was laughing so hard that I could not read the words. It has brightened my day and will lighten the burden of navigating in the future. As I settle into my familiar seat in the car with a map in my lap and, nowadays, a magnifying glass close at hand, I will derive comfort from the fact that the next time I goof, I'll know I'm not alone.

title: Review/Music;   Hollander and Fleisher In Three-Hand Concerto
description: Publicity gimmicks have a long and occasionally worthy tradition in classical-music history, and this one was both elaborate and effective. In an acknowledged bid for attention for the Carnegie Hall concert of the Illinois Chamber Orchestra on Thursday evening, the group's first New York appearance since a little-heralded Alice Tully Hall event in 1987, its music director, Kenneth Kiesler, devised an unusual project that captured the imagination of several veteran musicians. He also managed to attract a sizable audience, undoubtedly including a number of curiosity-seekers.

description: LEAD:

title: NONFICTION
description: BODY MIKE: An Unsparing Expose by the Mafia Insider Who Turned on the Mob. By Joseph Cantalupo and Thomas C. Renner. (Villard, $18.95.) Any minute now, it seems, there will be more mob canaries with tell-all books than there are mobsters to sing about. ''Body Mike'' comes from Joseph Cantalupo, a Brooklyn real estate salesman, loan shark, con artist and hustler at large, and Thomas C. Renner, whose previous books include ''Mafia Princess'' and ''Mafia Enforcer.'' For years, Mr. Cantalupo had a front-row seat on the daily doings of the mob boss Joe Colombo, who used the realty office owned by Mr. Cantalupo's father as a cover. But Mr. Cantalupo was not privy to what went down behind the closed door where Colombo held court, which is the ultimate weakness of this ''insider'' book. Mr. Cantalupo ran with mob guys and saw and heard plenty, but he was not a ''made,'' or fully initiated, member. He cooked up his share of scams, but he was not a capo or even a soldier. He was not present when murders were plotted or carried out; only after the fact would he learn that someone was ''gone.'' He says he does not even know if his own father was a made member. So his book is a succession of cracked safes, punched noses and quick-buck grabs - sleazy, illegal and small-time. His greatest value as a witness in various Federal trials was his ability to confirm a chain of succession among mob bosses, although he had little contact with the executive branch. As a mere mob associate, Mr. Cantalupo did not flash the audacious perks of organized crime, like the $20,000 pinky rings sported by Colombo. Instead, he filled his days with adulterous trysts, betting, cardplaying, borrowing to bet and sweating out ways to make a quick score to stay ahead of the leg-breakers. He would even steal from the dead: $30,000, in one instance, from a scrubwoman's bank account, before the estate could notify the bank that she had died. Mr. Cantalupo got so deeply in hock that he turned Federal informant for six years. In the book, he whines that various Federal agencies used and discarded him, but his protests ring hollow. He's still hustling, and this book is his latest scam.

title: A Losing Temper
description: Like a couple of his forehand shots, John McEnroe went over the line during the Australian Open in Melbourne last week. After repeated displays of his well-known ill temper and foul mouth in a tough match against Mikael Pernfors, McEnroe was booted off the court, becoming the first player in 27 years to be disqualified from a Grand Slam event. The 30-year-old former champion at first claimed not to have known that stricter prohibitions against behavior like his went into effect this year. He cursed the umpire, attempted to intimidate a line judge, angrily hit a ball in the direction of the ballboy and, finally, cracked his racquet against the court. He did not apologize, but said that he would have acted differently if he had been aware of the rule change. ''I would probably have still broken my racquet,'' he said. ''But I wouldn't have said what I said to the guy.'' That guy was Gerry Armstrong, the umpire. Ken Farrar, the tournament's chief of supervisors, said that McEnroe's language was the worst he had ever heard in a tennis match. With Farrar's approval, Armstrong called, ''Code violation, further abuse, default Mr. McEnroe. Game, set, match.''

title: IN THE REGION: Connecticut and Westchester;   A $20 Million Center on the Housatonic
description: AFTER the B. F. Goodrich Company plant in Shelton was firebombed in an insurance fraud scheme 15 years ago, the company decided not to reopen its Connecticut operation and 4,500 jobs were lost. An already weak economy looked as if it might die until local officials worked to create a new and different Shelton, competitive with the rest of Fairfield County.

description: HELL-BENT MEN AND THEIR CITIES

title: Sunday Silence Horse of Year
description: Sunday Silence, who won three of four memorable duels with Easy Goer last year, today was named thoroughbred racing's Horse of the Year for 1989.

title: Jude Nwimo: Designer
description: At 22, Jude Nwimo already has six years' experience as a tailor and designer under his belt - a belt usually worn under the cinched vests and jackets of the retro-look suits he creates as a self-styled ''jazz tailor.'' This is one young Londoner who doesn't own a pair of jeans. ''That's what's known as casual clothing,'' he said, ''and casual to me means sloppy.''

title: Wrightstown Journal;   McGuire Reservists Tell of Their Experiences in Panama
description: MARTIN STEVENS is accustomed to long hours and tedious duties. As a pilot for United Airlines, he is used to flexible schedules taking him from one part of the country to another with little notice.

title: It's Midwinter. And Drab. Time To Look Ahead.
description: Midwinter is the fashion doldrums, when clothes worn since October seem tired and lackluster. It's too soon to switch to spring clothes, but the wardrobe definitely needs an injection of freshness.

title: Schools Help State Learn About Acid Rain
description: ANITA KELLY, a science teacher at the Independent Day School in Middlefield, placed a ladder against the one-story school building. Then she and Elizabeth McCormick, a sixth grader at the school, made their way up the ladder to the roof, to empty a container with a funnel on top. ''We're taking the rainwater that falls and sending it to Wesleyan University to be analyzed,'' Elizabeth explained.

title: Navajo Leader Faces Fraud Suit in Arizona Court
description: Peter MacDonald Sr., the leader of the nation's largest Indian tribe, has been ordered to face a trial in an Arizona state court in a civil suit accusing him of conspiring to defraud the Navajo Nation in a $33.4 million purchase of a ranch.

title: In Sitcoms, Cupid Is Often Only a Tease
description: After half a decade of denying, deploring, hinting at, acknowledging and sheepishly celebrating their mutual sexual attraction, Tony Micelli and Angela Bower have agreed they don't know their feelings well enough to discuss the future. Sam Malone, having spent five years getting together and breaking up with Diane Chambers, has been chasing Rebecca Howe for 28 months - to no avail. And earlier this month, Hannah Miller and Marty Gold trotted into their first New Year together in a state of carefully cultivated ambiguity. These virtuosos of irresolution are, of course, couples in sitcoms (NBC's ''Cheers'' and ABC's ''Who's the Boss?'' and ''Anything but Love'') whose plots depend on endless sexual tension between their protagonists.

title: Question Of the Week: Next Week;   Should N.F.L. Drug Testing Be Revised?
description: The Times welcomes letters from readers. Letters should include the writer's name, address and telephone number. Letters should be addressed to The Editor, Sunday Sports Section, The New York Times, 229 West 43d Street, New York, N.Y. 10036. We regret that because of the large volume of mail received, we are unable to acknowledge or to return unpublished letters.

title: WALL STREET'S WONDER BOYS: SLIGHTLY TARNISHED

Covering a combined debt of $7.5 billion, the Chapter 11 filing, which affected stores as venerable as Bloomingdale's, Abraham & Straus and Jordan Marsh, was the largest mercantile catastrophe in

title: Stacy Beth Bergmann Marries Robert J. Rosen
description: Stacy Beth Bergmann, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Martin Bergmann of Howard Beach, Queens, was married there last evening at the Rockwood Park Jewish Center to Robert Jay Rosen, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Joel Rosen of North Hills , L.I. Rabbi Rafael Saffra officiated.

title: The Executive Computer;   Bringing Microsoft's 'Windows' to Critical Mass
description: The recent arrival of the Microsoft Corporation's Word for Windows signals more than just a new entrant in the overcrowded word processing category. Word for Windows (which lists for $495 and is intended for high-end I.B.M. PC and PS/2 compatibles that use the DOS operating system) is the first program that combines advanced ''what you see is what you get'' word processing, desktop publishing features, an easy-to-use graphical command structure and powerful tools for customization. Simply put, Word for Windows is a model for the next generation of word processing programs for the DOS and OS/2 operating systems used by most personal computers. More than that, though, it may turn out to be the compelling application that finally prompts many users of DOS-based machines to embrace Windows. It is impossible to discuss Words for Windows without discussing Windows, an ''operating environment'' that sits atop DOS and replaces character-based commands with graphical ones. Windows was introduced by Microsoft nearly five years ago, but it is only now reaching critical mass. The first major Windows-based word processor, Ami, from the Samna Corporation, did not show up until last year, and Word for Windows is only the second to be widely distributed.

The Executive Life;

title: Review/Music;   Mighty Lemon Drops Provide Rock and Fog
description: The Mighty Lemon Drops, an English group that played at the Ritz on Saturday night, make music cloaked in a fog, both literally and figuratively. Its fog machines, which were working overtime and generated enough murk for the band to construct standard-issue MTV postures, cloaked them in diaphanous swirls. And the band's music, made by just a guitar or two, an occasional synthesizer, bass and drums, sounded murky and indeterminate as well.

title: Race for Governor of Texas Is Surprising in Both Parties
description: When Clayton Williams, the leading candidate in the campaign for the Texas Republican Party's gubernatorial nomination, suggested converting an environmentally sensitive wilderness area into a prison camp where young drug offenders would learn ''the joys of busting rocks,'' the proposal sparked little dispute because it came in a campaign already marked by oddities.

title: Question Of the Week;   Is Betting On the Super Bowl Excessive?
description: Everything about the Super Bowl is excessive. The best part of the Super Bowl is that it means the football season is finally over and that pitchers and catchers report in two weeks.

title: THE WEDDING: DECORATIONS
description: There we were, lined up at the entrance of the church, 10 of us clad in flowing pink taffeta with matching pink pumps and tiny strands of pearls. I wasn't sure whether we resembled overgrown sugarplum faires or bridesmaids, until small bouquets of white roses and baby's breath were thrust in our hands. Somehow, the bouquets made the whole thing seem real - an instant symbol of tradition and matrimony.

title: Mary Balderston, Gallery Executive, To Marry Richard Somerby, an Artist

title: Veteran Lawmaker Retiring
description: Representative Augustus F. Hawkins, veteran chairman of the House Education and Labor Committee and the longest-serving black in Congress, said Friday that he would retire at the end of the year. The 82-year-old Democrat has represented the primarily black and Hispanic Watts area of Los Angeles and surrounding Hispanic suburbs since January 1963.

title: PASTIMES: Bridge
description: New conventions are commonplace among tournament players, but seldom stand the test of time. They are much rarer in rubber bridge or four-deal games played in club or private homes where partnerships change constantly and the emphasis is on simple bidding.

title: Shiite Cleric Unhurt After Attack in Beirut
description: A car bomb exploded today near the home of the spiritual head of Lebanon's Shiite Muslims. He was not injured.

title: A Playwright Crunches the Numbers
description: ''There's no business like show business,'' goes that marvelous Irving Berlin song. As the author of ''Other People's Money,'' a play about business, and as a businessman turned playwright myself, I would have written the lyric differently: ''There's no business in show business'' would have been more like it.

title: BACH LOOKED AHEAD, OR WAS IT BACK?
description: I am prepared to believe, after sifting through all the available scientific evidence, that (1) oat bran lowers cholesterol and that (2) it does not. Meaning only that when confronted by the conflicting arguments of acknowledged experts, I tend to think both sides may be on to something. In any event, argument is the essence of truth-seeking, whether medical or musical.

title: Even Homeowners Need Heroes
description: I AM having a hard time adjusting to being a homeowner. I find myself doing things I used to laugh at my father for doing: raking every single leaf off the lawn, maniacally clipping every blade that escapes my lawn mower, picking up stray beer cans and McDonald's bags while shaking my head and muttering, ''Kids.''

title: When the Legislators Meet
description: The Board of Legislators, under new leadership in 1990, has decided to forgo afternoon meetings in favor of morning and evening sessions. To encourage attendance by the public, the Board has published a schedule of meetings (generally every other Monday) for the entire year.

title: Remembering Gambia Envoy-to-Be
description: ON a Saturday afternoon last November, Ruth V. Washington, the newly appointed United States Ambassador to the Republic of Gambia, paced the floor of her Hartsdale home and talked with excitement about relocating to the small, African country.

The town may not be bursting with hilarity, but its elegant, businesslike gravity has served it well in other ways. description: Four years ago, Jamil Abdul-Malik, a teacher and self-styled social engineer, approached Yonkers officials for help in building affordable housing on the West Side, where the city's black population is clustered. He received little encouragement.
