description: TWO years after Maine voters approved the expenditure of $35 million to protect land from development, the state finds itself owning more than 6,600 acres, including 16 miles of unspoiled oceanfront, and has begun to turn its attention to inland properties.

title:
IN SHORT: NONFICTION;

DOING GOOD IN CHICAGO
description: LEAD: The photographer Wallace Kirkland lived and worked at Hull House in the 1920's and 30's. Throughout those years he created a rich photographic record of daily life at the Chicago settlement house and of the Greek, Italian and Mexican neighborhoods that surrounded it. The institution captured in THE MANY FACES OF HULL-HOUSE: The Photographs of Wallace Kirkland (University of Illinois, Cloth, $34.95; Paper, $19.95) was no longer the center of social and political change it had been in its early years.

title: A Widow's Fate Stirs a Director to Action
description: In the early 1980's, Paul Brickman made his directorial debut with a buoyant film about a clean-cut Chicago teen-ager who turns over his parents' pristine home to a bevy of call girls. Called ''Risky Business,'' the kinetic comedy ended up a box-office hit.

title: Wendy Glazier to Wed R. L. Brainard
description: Mr. and Mrs. Earl W. Glazier Jr. of Toronto and New Hope, Pa., have announced August wedding plans for their daughter, Wendy Firth Glazier, and Robert Lovell Brainard, the son of Mr. and Mrs. John Edwin Brainard 2d of Edgartown, Mass.

title: N. R. Prouty Jr. Weds Allison Simmons
description: Allison Lovejoy Simmons, a daughter of Grant G. Simmons Jr. of Hilton Head, S.C., and Mrs. Edwin Thorne of Greenwich, Conn., was married yesterday to Norman Reginald Prouty Jr., a son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Prouty of Katonah, N.Y. The Rev. C. Hugh Hildesley performed the ceremony at the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest in New York.

title: Fire Safety
description: To the Editor: In the article on hotel fire safety (Practical Traveler, Nov. 19) Betsy Wade addressed a little-known fact about fire safety. Namely, it doesn't exist in many hotels across the United States.

title:
CONNECTICUT OPINION;

I'd Really Rather Take the Bus
description: LEAD: WHEN the time comes for us to cut our driving to a minimum or die of noxious air, I'll be the first one on the bandwagon, or the bus, as the case may be.

title: Armour Stretches Phoenix Open Lead
description: Tommy Armour 3d, who has led or shared the lead all the way, opened up a three-stroke advantage today in the third round of the Phoenix Open.

title: Menuhin to Conduct and Play in Stamford
description: SIR YEHUDI MENUHIN will conduct the English String Orchestra when it appears at the Palace Theater in Stamford next Sunday in a program that includes Elgar's Serenade in E minor, Benjamin Britten's ''Simple Symphony'' and the Walton Sonata for String Orchestra.

title: Schools' Plan to Sell Land Opposed
description: LEAD: TWO private nonreligious schools in the Five Towns that were established almost a century ago have decided to merge by next fall, forming a new school with more than 600 students.

title: As Drivers Pay More for Insurance, New Jersey Decides That No-Fault Isn't
description: THE plan Gov. Jim Florio announced last week to roll back automobile insurance premiums in New Jersey marks a turning point in the tortured history of an issue that has bedeviled regulators and confused consumers here since 1973.

title: THE FRUITS OF SIN
description: ANY WOMAN'S BLUES

title: PASTIMES: Stamps
description: Those simple symbols called bar codes on the bottom of envelopes can be deciphered by a bright first grader, but finding the rare error is challenging enough to interest adults.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. I have dark, wood-paneled walls in my den and would like to lighten the wood. Is it possible to paint over it and retain the look (knots and lines in the wood panels)?

title: Virginia P. G. Wiese, Student, to Marry Douglas Sesler, Investment Executive
description: The engagement of Virginia Pierson Goldthwaite Wiese to Douglas William Sesler, a son of Mr. and Mrs. William G. Sesler of Erie, Pa., has been made known by her mother and stepfather, Mr. and Mrs. Charles T. Maxwell of Bronxville, N.Y., and her father, Peter C. Wiese of New York. A July wedding is planned.

title: POSTINGS: Waterfront Reference;   Policy Tool
description: In the two decades between the proposing of the controversial Westway project for Manhattan's Hudson River waterfront and the scrapping of the plan in 1985, the fate of the affected area became a cause celebre, especially in Greenwich Village. Now, a new reference book has been published on the buildings and architecture that were at stake in the dispute.

title: Harley A. Farber, Designer, to Wed
description: Mr. and Mrs. Morton H. Farber of New York have made known February wedding plans for their daughter, Harley Alison Farber, and Robert Martin Raiff, a son of Elizabeth Haron of Greenwich, Conn., and Frederic Raiff of New York.

title: Campus Life: Columbia;   An Old Bar Is Reopening To a New Beat
description: A few names have been carved in the freshly lacquered oak tables. Beer prices have been lowered to compete with other bars. But after a 13-month closing and a change of management, the West End Bar, the fixture near Columbia University that was a stomping ground for Jack Kerouac and Allen Ginsberg, is striving to recapture its fans.

title: Cowens Outpolled
description: Fame may not always be fleeting, but in Massachusetts, at least, it appears to fade fast. That seems to be the case with Dave Cowens, who was the toast of the state in the 1970's as the Boston Celtics' center on two National Basketball Association champions, a player so good and so popular that he had his number 18 retired at Boston Garden.

title: Wall Street;   A Closer Look at Broker Ratings
description: How much of Wall Street's dirty linen should be aired in public?

title: Letters;   WORD OF THE YEAR: FREEDOM
description: I was saddened to see that William Safire has fallen for the simplistic Anglo-Saxon chauvinism of Strunk and White (On Language: ''Word of the Year: Freedom,'' Dec. 31). He writes that ''these Germanic words [like freedom] are punchier than their Romance-language counterparts: rich and hard are more telling than affluent and arduous.''

title: NOT LOVERS IN THE ORDINARY SENSE
description: HENRY JAMES AND EDITH WHARTON

title: 'OMIT THE ACTION OF SCARLETT BELCHING'
description: THE DAME IN THE KIMONO

title: It's a Constituent!
description: There is no easygoing ''mommy track'' for heads of state. Last week, only a day after Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto of Pakistan gave birth to her second child, a girl, the opposition staged a huge rally in Karachi aimed at pressuring the Bhutto Government while the Prime Minister recovers from the Caesarean birth. Opposition leaders had criticized her decision to have a second child, saying that the country would be leaderless while she was hospitalized. When that time came, Ms. Bhutto temporarily transferred authority to her mother, Nusrat, who is a member of the National Assembly. In contrast to the opposition, the Prime Minister's supporters danced in the streets a day earlier to celebrate. Ms. Bhutto apparently is the first world leader in modern history to give birth while in office. She and her husband, Asif Ali Zardari, also have a 15-month-old son. Mother and daughter, meanwhile, were doing fine, a hospital spokesman said Thursday.

title: Crew and Air Controllers Discussed Fuel
description: The crew of Avianca Airlines Flight 52 expressed concern to air traffic controllers about the plane's fuel supply 45 to 50 minutes before the Colombian jetliner crashed on Long Island on Thursday, the National Transportation Safety Board said last night.

title: SPEAKING THE LANGUAGE OF DESERT AND MOUNTAIN
description: What makes Antoine Predock so much of an architect is exactly what makes him not so much of an international celebrity: his insistence on designing buildings that relate to the spirit of the place in which he is working. Since nearly all Mr. Predock's projects have been in the Southwest (his office is in Albuquerque, N.M.), his architecture has become a kind of contemporary expression of the traditional architectural language of the desert and the mountains. That is his stylistic ''signature,'' if you will. There is not a particular way a Predock building looks, except that they all look more or less as if they belong in the Southwest.

title: A Script by an 18-Year-Old Blends Tragedy and Humor
description: When he was 6 years old, his mother committed suicide. At 18, he wrote a play, called ''Women and Wallace,'' about the calamity and the effect it has had on his life.

title: A Village That Treasures Its Privacy Blinks Unhappily in the Glare of Fame
description: For much of the last two days, Vincent Augello, shaken and annoyed, has been sitting alone in his freshly waxed, four-wheel-drive minivan parked between the red-brick gates in front of his five-acre estate on Tennis Court Road. He has been on guard, turning back the curious crowds and camera crews trying to cut through his weedy peach orchard for a glimpse of the wreckage of Avianca Flight 52.

title: Alyssa F. Domershick to Marry in Fall
description: Mr. and Mrs. Jerry Domershick of Malverne, L.I., and New York, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Alyssa F. Domershick, to Kenneth Gray Golub, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Gerald L. Golub of Chappaqua, N.Y., and Delray Beach, Fla. A fall wedding is planned.

title: Everything About the Place Spells Bistro
description: GEORGE MARTIN is a bubbling, boisterous bistro that has taken Rockville Centre by storm. Its old-fashioned yet new-fashioned look, spirited young staff and huge portions of well-prepared stick-to-the-ribs food serve as magnets to pull in a crowd.

title: 'Cinema Paradiso' Blows a Kiss To the Movies
description: There is only one movie house in the Sicilian town of Bagheria, outside Palermo. Giuseppe Tornatore, who at the age of 33 does not exactly go back very far, can remember when, as recently as the mid-1960's, his hometown managed to sustain eight theaters with a population half its present size.

title: UPHEAVAL IN THE EAST: Yugoslavia;   A Sign of Bad Times in Yugoslavia: Trade War Between Two Republics
description: Shoppers in the ''Beograd Woman'' department store will find that the mention of certain brand names can make the staff snap as though a curse had just been directed at them.

title: Q and A
description: Demolition Threat on First

title: 102 Companies Offering Help in Disasters
description: KING INDUSTRIES of Norwalk, which has been in the chemical business for 60 years, has a collection of protective suits, fire suppression foam and chemical analysis equipment and a staff of environmental scientists that no fire department could afford to maintain.

title: The Crowded Field in Balloon Angioplasty Therapy
description: C.R. Bard Inc., a leading maker of inflatable catheters used by doctors to unclog arteries, was riding high last year. But then the tips on some of its newest catheters began breaking off inside patients under treatment for heart and vascular disease.

title: Answering The Mail
description: Q. I have dark, wood-paneled walls in my den and would like to lighten the wood. Is it possible to paint over it and retain the look (knots and lines in the wood panels)?

title: Numbers That Lied
description: It now appears that in the far-reaching work that established him as the father of modern astronomy, Johannes Kepler was not above taking short cuts. In a recent issue of The Journal of the History of Astronomy, William A. Donahue said that when Kepler presented his theory nearly 400 years ago that planets moved in elliptical rather than circular orbits, he falsely claimed that he had confirmed his insight through independent calculations. In fact, said Dr. Donahue, a science historian, Kepler derived his calculations from his own theory. None of which is to say that the German astronomer is being demoted from the ranks of science immortals to the level of the Piltdown perpetrators. Experts everywhere, while not disputing Dr. Donahue, generally agreed that Kepler's reputation would not suffer. Nor did Dr. Donahue seem to lose any respect for the early scientist. ''He had a difficult time trying to convince people that the ellipse was correct,'' he said. ''So he fudged a little. That doesn't take him down a notch.''

title: Pincay Hurt in Spill
description: One day after he broke his right collarbone in a spill during a harness race for charity, Laffit Pincay Jr., who makes his living aboard thoroughbreds, said he expected to be sidelined four to six weeks.

title: Isles Regain A Share Of First
description: In a sometimes sloppy, somewhat surreal game that was part slap shot and part slapstick, the Islanders embarrassed the Pittsburgh Penguins, 9-3, this afternoon at Nassau Coliseum.

title:
PASTIMES: Gardening;

A Flowery Cure For Winter Blahs
description: LEAD: When the winter doldrums set in, many gardeners, longing for spring blossoms, try to force some of them into bloom indoors. Branches of flowering trees and shrubs are cut and encouraged to bloom. The old method used to be to soak the branches overnight in the bathtub filled with six inches of lukewarm water.

title: A Cuisine of Humble Origins.
description: ''ONLY a Ligurian,'' writes one of Columbus's biographers, ''could have conceived of the idea of sailing West to reach East.'' Incongruous contrast, in fact, is one of the most striking characteristics of Genoa, the capital of Liguria, the birthplace of Columbus and a city of more than one puzzling paradox.

title:
New Jersey Q & A: Barbara Legutko;

Using Art Therapy to Aid Sex Offenders
description: LEAD: BARBARA LEGUTKO, a former Pop artist and public school art teacher, has worked for 12 years as an art educator and therapist at New Jersey's only treatment center for male sex offenders. About 50 inmates of the 500 sentenced to the Adult Diagnostic and Treatment Center here come to the art room on a regular basis to make clay pots, to paint or to sew under her supervision.

title: WOMEN HARASSED ON TOURS IN ASIA
description: Harassment of Western women traveling in South Asia has turned increasingly violent, marring their vacations and undermining efforts by several countries to cash in on a recent boom in beach vacations, diplomats and tourists say.

title: Sharon Brodwin Wed To Gerald Laderman
description: At the Lincoln Square Synagogue in New York, Sharon R. Brodwin, the daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Gordon Brodwin of Malverne, L.I., was married last evening to Gerald Laderman, a son of Dr. and Mrs. Peter Laderman of White Plains. Rabbis Herschel Cohen and Mark L. Winer performed the ceremony.

title: PASTIMES: Coins
description: When the mercantile nations of Europe sent ships around the world in the 15th and 16th centuries, they introduced the notion ofmoney to many people who had relied on barter forthousands of years. Sometimes the results were strange. Among some tribes of western Africa, an object shaped like a Celtic torque or bracelet was held in high esteem. When the Portuguese landed on what is now Nigeria, the Africans asked for more of them. The Portuguese obliged, shipping thousands of the copper-lead alloy bracelets to Africa and tradedthem for slaves.

title: Allison E. Wolin To Marry in May
description: Judge and Mrs. Michael S. London of Holliswood, Queens and East Hampton, L.I., have announced May wedding plans for her daughter, Allison Emily Wolin, and Alan Michael Luckman, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerry Luckman of Sands Point, L.I.

title: Will Perestroika Cost Us More at the Pump?
description: Pumping 12 million barrels a day out of a global total of 63 million, the Soviet Union is the world's largest petroleum producer. It is also No. 1 in natural gas. Should economic and political disarray hinder Soviet energy production, the ripples would reach from Houston to the Persian Gulf.

title: Chastity Organization: Starting Over in Purity
description: With her heart aching from a painful breakup, Mary Meyer placed an advertisement in a singles' column: ''Female wanting to meet a man who would like to marry. Celibate before marriage only.'' More than 100 men responded. Most of them thought it was splendid for a woman to be chaste. But none were thrilled with the notion for themselves.

title: Data Bank/January 28, 1990
description: $ Steel Production Dec. Nov. Year Ago Thousands of net tons 7,221 7,385 7,954 Automobile Production Dec. Nov. Year Ago In units 430,449 538,465 573,102 New Orders for Durable Goods Dec. Nov. Year Ago By Manufacturers, in billions $133.54 $130.31 $130.80 Employment Cost Index 1989 1988 1987 Compensation cost, increase in percent 4.8 4.9 3.3 G.N.P. Price deflator IV Q'89 III Q'89 Year Ago Annual rate, in percent 3.5 3.2 4.7 Real G.N.P. Growth IV Q'89 III Q'89 Year Ago Annual rate, 1982 dollars, in percent 0.5 2.7 2.0 Consumer Price Index Dec. Nov. Year Ago 1982-84-100 126.1 125.9 120.5 Prime Rate Last Week Prior Week Year Ago Most major banks, in percent 10.00 10.50 10.50

title: Changes in Eastern Bloc Heighten Nationalist Yearnings of Basques
description: Never in need of much encouragement to proclaim their separate identity, nationalist groups in the Basque country and Catalonia are using events in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union to justify calls for regional self-determination in Spain.

title: Katonah Show Puts the Viewer in Charge
description: COMMUNISM has crumbled; now it is art appreciation's turn. ''Do You See What I See?'' is an all-out effort by the Katonah Museum of Art to give viewers the courage of their own perceptions, and anything goes. Well, almost anything: pedagogues hover in the wings with the facts behind the objects in the display, which originated last year in a somewhat different form at Dartmouth College's Hood Museum of Art.

title: THE DANGERS OF MEMORY
description: LEAD:

title: LONG ISLAND GUIDE
description: BLACK HISTORY MONTH

title: Landry, Harris and Lambert Among 7 in Pro Hall
description: Tom Landry, who built the Dallas Cowboys from a National Football League expansion team into a two-time Super Bowl champion, and Franco Harris and Jack Lambert, teammates on the four-time Pittsburgh Steeler champions of the 1970's, were among the seven figures voted into the Pro Football Hall of Fame today.

title: For Women Who Build Bodies: Brawn or Beauty? Muscle or Curves?
description: IT's not easy being muscular and a woman, said Lisa Ripi, who is both. Sure, no one is going to kick sand in your face, or insist you dance with them when you are a competitive body builder like Ms. Ripi of Island Park. But combining brawn and beauty has its drawbacks, she said.

title: Tribe Gets Free Use of Library
description: People living on the Mashantucket Pequot Indian reservation will have free use of the Ledyard library, after an agreement between town officials and tribal leaders. Although tribal lands are within town boundaries, town officials had required residents of the reservation to pay $19 for library cards, the same fee paid by out-of-town residents.

title: Stock Accord At Bank Leumi
description: The parent company of Bank Leumi Le-Israel, Israel's second-largest bank, has agreed to equalize the voting rights of all its shares.

title: String Confetti Aerosol Cans Are Recalled as Fire Hazards
description: The Government has announced the recall of three million cans of an aerosol string confetti because the propellant used in the product may be highly flammable.

title: Critic's Notebook;   After Pizza and Polite Squabbling, a Film Wins
description: For more than six hours on Friday, the judges of the dramatic competition at the Sundance U.S. Film Festival squabbled politely, ordered in pizza, listened to one another's impassioned speeches and finally wondered how to break or evade the rules. When their private deliberations were over and the awards to independent film makers were announced at a modest ceremony on Saturday night, the grand-prize winner turned out to be one of the least talked about, least traditional, most personal films in the festival: Wendell B. Harris Jr.'s ''Chameleon Street,'' the fact-based story of a quick-change artist.

title: Question Box
description: Picking Off Passes

title: Caterpillar to Promote President to Chairman
description: Caterpillar Inc., the largest maker of earth-moving machinery, has named Donald V. Fites as its chairman and chief executive, effective July 1. It also reorganized the executive suite, eliminating the posts of president and executive vice president, in a move to push decision-making further down the ranks.

title: Key Resignation Reported at Apple
description: A top executive at Apple Computer Inc. has resigned in what could be the start of an overhaul of the company's American sales and marketing organization, industry officials said this weekend.

title: 'Chase' Races Add Sightseeing to Skiing
description: THE notion that exercising can be fun is missing from many modern fitness routines. But there is a way to trade the long and arduous workouts for ones with a view. You may want to consider the Great American Ski Chase.

title: From Opera to Recital Hall
description: Vinson Cole's performances in opera and oratorio have been frequent and notable over the last decade. Mr. Cole, a lyric tenor, was a regular at the New York City Opera in the early 1980's, and he joined the Metropolitan Opera roster in 1987. He has made recordings with Herbert von Karajan and Carlo Maria Giulini. But surprisingly he had not been heard as a recitalist in New York until Thursday evening, when he made his debut in that capacity at Weill Recital Hall.

title: New Market Journal;   Nurturing New Seeds In a Garden Of Hopes
description: ''Public Auction Wipes Out Last of Highlander School'' read a 1962 newspaper headline, noting the apparent demise of the Highlander Folk School, one of the legendary incubators of the civil rights movement.

title: Right Word Is Crucial in Air Control
description: The investigation into the crash of Avianca Airlines Flight 52 points up the critical role played by communications between airline crews and air-traffic controllers, as well as among the controllers themselves, in guiding jetliners to safe landings.

title: Statehouse Candidate Assailed for Remarks
description: John Silber, who is seeking the Democratic nomination for Governor, has come under attack for separate statements that in one case have been called too lenient toward alcoholism and in another have been termed racist. The Silber camp has denied both charges.

title: OFFICIALS CITE GAP IN COMMUNICATIONS IN AVIANCA CRASH
description: The crew of the Colombian jetliner that crashed Thursday on Long Island told regional air traffic controllers that the plane was short of fuel and asked for priority clearance to land, but the information was not passed on to the local controllers who guided the plane's final descent, Federal investigators said tonight.

title: Chronicle
description: Four American psychoanalysts are to teach in the Soviet Union, the first such exchange in at least a decade. Organized by DR. ARNOLD M. ROTHSTEIN, program chairman of the American Psychoanalytic Association, the group will teach classes to 200 Soviet psychiatrists for one week, beginning April 23. They will be guests of the Soviet Union's National Mental Health Research Center in Moscow.

title: Reviews/Music;   Exploring Bricks and Mortar of New Music
description: Adaptive use - as recycling-minded city planners like to call it -argued with Futurism in interesting new-music concerts on Wednesday and Thursday evenings. At the Miller Theater, Anthony Korf's Parnassus offered pieces by Kurt Weill, Ursula Mamlok, Paul Hindemith, Luigi Dallapiccola and Donald Martino. The next night at Symphony Space the New Music Consort played Charles Ives, Kathryn Alexander, Charles Wuorinen, Milton Babbitt and Chou Wen-Chung.

title: Challenge for Panamanians: A Canal in Transition
description: Most first-time visitors to this famous vantage point on the Panama Canal, eight miles from the Pacific, come away dazzled by the majesty of the 51.2-mile waterway and the near-miraculous ingenuity and sacrifice that went into its construction more than 75 years ago.

title: China Using Electrodes To 'Cure' Homosexuals
description: When homosexuals are treated here for what most Chinese doctors regard as their mental illness, they are sometimes given painful electric shocks to discourage erotic thoughts.

title: 20,000 Stage a Rally in Rumania To Protest Against the New Rulers
description: Shouting anti-Communist and anti-Government slogans, about 20,000 people marched today to the headquarters of the ruling Council of National Salvation for an opposition rally that revealed the widening split over the country's political course.

title: Treasury to Sell Bills Today
description: The Treasury's schedule of issues this week is confined to today's auction of three- and six-month bills. Late on Friday, the outstanding three-month bill was bid at 7.68 percent, while the six-month bill was bid at 7.63 percent. This week, the Treasury is expected to announce the size of the quarterly refunding, including 3-year, 10-year and 30-year securities.

title: Lendl Wins Title as Edberg Pulls Out
description: Ivan Lendl was handed the Australian Open title when a pulled abdominal muscle forced Stefan Edberg to retire from the Australian Open final late in the third set with the score, 4-6, 7-6, 5-2.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Addenda
description: * Burson-Marsteller has formed a sports marketing division, Sports Partners International, which will incorporate Ohlmeyer Sports Marketing, a former division of Ohlmeyer Communications.

title: 49er Fans Rise Up and Cheer
description: It didn't seem to matter much tonight if all season long someone thought Montana was a state and Rice was something to eat. Today in San Francisco, people out for a good time joined die-hard football fans to cheer on and celebrate the 49ers.

title: Manila Arrests Fugitive General For Role in December Rebellion
description: The highest-ranking officer involved in the latest attempt to overthrow President Corazon C. Aquino was arrested today, the Philippine military authorities said.

title: Evelyn Ames, Portrayer of Nature In Poetry and Prose, Is Dead at 81
description: Evelyn Ames, a poet and prose writer whose works on wildlife and the environment were praised by reviewers as graceful and intense, but not sentimental, died on Thursday at St. Johnland Nursing Home in Kings Park, L.I. She was 81 years old and had homes in Cold Spring Harbor, L.I., and Martha's Vineyard.

title: Publisher Denies Delaying 'Satanic Verses' Paperback
description: A spokesman for Viking Penguin, the publisher of the novel ''The Satanic Verses,'' denied today that it had told Salman Rushdie, the author of the book, that it would not bring out a paperback edition.

title: Police Officer Fatally Shoots Youth in Back
description: A police officer shot an unarmed Brooklyn teen-ager in the back, killing him, as she was arresting him Saturday evening, the police said yesterday.

title: Caucasus Partisans Press Truce
description: Armenian and Azerbaijani partisans began withdrawing from a key battlefront today and agreed to discuss extending the truce between the two competing nationalist groups to other parts of the volatile region, spokesmen reported.

title: Poles Attack Soviet Consulate
description: About 1,000 Poles turned violent after a soccer match today in Cracow, smashing windows of the Soviet consulate and Communist Party headquarters and damaging cars, stores and apartments. The official press agency P.A.P. said the police dispersed the rioters after they surged through the southern city ''destroying everything in their path.''

title: Boston Banks Agree to Fight Racial Disparity in Mortgages
description: Faced with a new study showing a wide racial disparity in mortgage lending, a group of Boston banks has agreed to take part in a $430 million program to narrow the gap.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''There's a fine line between having an angle, having a strategy, and being improperly devious. Some of those who think there's deviousness here don't like him because it's so hard to second-guess him, to outwit him, to outplan him, and maybe it's very hard for some to risk sitting down with him to negotiate.''

title: A Return to Favor For a Catalan's Art
description: The Catalan artist Antoni Tapies, widely considered Spain's pre-eminent living painter and heir to modern Spanish masters like Picasso, Miro and Dali, is experiencing a renaissance.

title: Hoyas and Redmen Take a Thrashing
description: The walls didn't come tumbling down as they had seemed to do the previous week, when six of the country's seven top-ranked teams were upset, but there was some significant shaking going on in college basketball over the weekend.

title: Quayle Gets Warm Welcome in Panama
description: Vice President Dan Quayle got a warm welcome today from many Panamanians, who thanked the United States for invading their country and said they wanted American troops to stay.

title: Ametek Picks a Chief After a Realignment
description: Ametek Inc., a manufacturer of instruments and industrial equipment, has named Walter E. Blankley as its president and chief executive, effective in April.

title: Midseason Report;   It's All Up Hill, but Nets Know the Way
description: Things like rush-hour traffic, income taxes and Nets basketball are constant reminders that this world is not perfect.

title: Avalanche Closes Ski Resort
description: An avalanche prompted officials to close the Jackson Hole Ski Resort today, but no one was injured, officials said. The resort was closed for the day after the avalanche at 1:10 P.M. in an area called the Headwall, said Mike McCollister, director of operations. About 50 searchers with tracking dogs sifted through the snow for three hours and determined no one had been trapped.

title: Saar Vote Sets Stage For Challenge to Kohl
description: Oskar Lafontaine, the brash, quick-witted Premier of Saarland state, scored an impressive victory in the state election today, virtually insuring that he will be named the Social Democratic challenger to Chancellor Helmut Kohl in national elections next December.

title: Azerbaijani Blockade Imperils Armenians
description: To the Editor:

title: Books of The Times;   The Crack of the Bat, the Curve of the Ball
description: The Physics of Baseball

title: Walter Engel, Political Commentator, 78
description: Walter Engel, an announcer and political commentator for the Voice of America and an American diplomat in West Germany, died of heart failure Saturday at his home in Bethesda, Md. He was 78 years old.

title: Chronicle
description: PAUL TAYLOR has been commissioned to create a new work for the Paris Opera Ballet, and he's thinking about a rabbit. Not just un lapin ordinaire, either, but Peter Rabbit.

title: Force as a Last Resort: Armed Power Salvages Moscow's Facing Authority
description: It now seems clear that the main reason that the Soviet military stormed Baku on the morning of Jan. 20 was to prevent the Communist government of the Azerbaijan republic from falling, much as several national Governments in Eastern Europe have fallen in recent months under the pressure of popular uprisings.

title: Warning by Big Oil;   Larger Bites From Profits Expected Because of Environmental Standards
description: The charges against earnings taken by some oil companies in the most recent quarter to deal with environmental problems are a warning that pollution standards will be increasingly costly to meet and that more such charges are likely.

title: Test for New Sports Daily: Is Market Big Enough?
description: The National, a new daily tabloid devoted solely to sports, is poised to start testing whether this country's appetite for sports news is truly ravenous or merely enormous.

title: Budget Chief Defends Plans For Spending on the Military
description: On the eve of the submission of President Bush's new budget, his budget director, Richard G. Darman, today defended the size of the military budget, the proposed cut in the capital gains tax and the Administration's opposition to a reduction in the Social Security tax.

title: DEALS
description: BASEBALL

title: Reviews/Music;   Salsa From Willie Colon and His Band
description: Willie Colon's set at S.O.B.'s on Thursday night was neither forgettable nor especially exuberant; instead, it just cruised along functionally. Though Mr. Colon, who for the last 20 years has been pushing salsa in new directions, had the audience on its feet and shaking, the show never reached the cathartic levels of great dance music.

title: Review/Concert;   A Revised Critical Edition Of Rossini's 'Gazza Ladra'
description: In his chatty 1824 biography of Rossini, Stendhal included a firsthand account of the premiere of ''La Gazza Ladra'' at La Scala in 1817. The Milanese public was predisposed against the work, he wrote; but it was such a triumph that ''scarcely a moment passed without the entire audience rising to its feet as one man to shower Rossini with applause.''

title: Subway Panhandlers See Little From Legal Victory
description: News of his court victory arrived, appropriately enough, on the television set Joe Walley had bought with the proceeds of his trade: panhandling.

title: 2 in Car Fell Woman, 77, and Grab Purse
description: A 77-year-old Brooklyn woman was knocked to the ground and dragged nearly 20 feet late yesterday when one of two men driving by in a car leaned out the window and snatched her purse containing $400, the police said.

title: Reviews/Music;   Works Both Familiar and Rarely Heard
description: One of Nicola Frisardi's rewards for winning the Palm Beach International Piano Competition last year was his recital at Alice Tully Hall on Saturday night. Mr. Frisardi is an Italian in his early 30's, and was educated in his own country and in Austria.

title: Tool Orders Rose by 14% In December
description: Reversing a three-month decline, orders for American-made machine tools jumped 14 percent in December. For the year, however, machine tool orders were down 21.7 percent from their level for 1988.

title: Despite Year of Scandal, 'Money Politics' Seems as Strong as Ever in Japan
description: Two hundred leading corporate executives met the other day to listen to an urgent appeal to come together and help a valued client. It was not a business that was in distress, but the govering Liberal Democratic Party, which was in desperate need of cash.

title: Don't Cut Israel and Others to Aid East Europe;   Deserves a Try
description: To the Editor:

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: International

title: Lloyd Richards Is Leaving Yale Drama School and Rep
description: Lloyd Richards, the dean of the Yale School of Drama and artistic director of the Yale Repertory Theater, will leave both posts in June 1991, Yale University's president, Benno C. Schmidt Jr., announced yesterday.

title: Arabs Warning Against Influx of Soviet Jews
description: In many parts of the Arab and Muslim world, a clamor is building against a projected influx of Soviet Jews into Israel, reflecting fears that the emigres will displace Palestinians from the occupied territories and thwart the faltering diplomacy of peace.

title: NEWS SUMMARY
description: INTERNATIONAL A2-13

title: Bernard J. Ferguson, Lawyer, 88
description: Bernard J. Ferguson, a lawyer and former president of the Queens County Bar Association, died on Saturday at Mary Immaculate Hospital. He was 88 years old and lived in Bayside, Queens, and had previously been a resident of Flushing for more than 60 years.

title: Midseason Report;   Knicks Achieving Hard-earned Goals
description: For a good part of the first half of the National Basketball Association season, it appeared all Coach Stu Jackson had to do for the Knicks to win was play the numbers game.

title: Reviews/Music;   Toronto Symphony Offers Fresh 20th-Century Works
description: Technically, the honeymoon hasn't even begun for Gunther Herbig and the Toronto Symphony, though one might have thought otherwise in the second half of their concert at Carnegie Hall on Friday evening. The East German conductor, who has been the music director of the Detroit Symphony since 1984, is progressing to the Toronto altar in stages. Last season the orchestra's artistic adviser and now its music director designate, he will succeed Andrew Davis as music director in September.

title: Polish Communists Vote to Disband
description: Poland's Communist Party voted early today to dissolve itself after party members decided to create a new democratic and left-of-center party in the hope of winning public support.

title: Bridge
description: If an opponent opens the bidding, there is an argument for stretching to a borderline game. The declarer will have considerable information about the location of the opposing high cards, and the opponents will have defensive problems: One of them will be very weak, and virtually entryless.

title: India Tells of Foiling Uprising in Kashmir
description: Officials in Srinagar, the Kashmiri capital, said today that separatists had planned to declare independence from India on Friday and send thousands of supporters into the streets in a show of force timed to coincide with India's independence day. The officials say the plan was foiled after a number of leading Kashmiri militants were captured by the security forces.

title: Battery-Operated Ski-Boot Warmers
description: A new warmer for ski boots is designed with its heat source mounted on the outside of each boot. The heater comes with a recharger, which allows you to plug the boots' battery packs into a wall socket each night.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Ad Scene;   Films and Commercials Are A Growing Double Feature
description: WHEN Michael Jackson appeared recently at movie theaters, singing and dancing on the screen, delighted audiences cheered.

title: FINANCE BRIEFS
description: * Boston Technology Inc., Cambridge, Mass., is offering 2.8 million common shares at $6.5 each through Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.

title: Eric Brettschneider Weds Ms. Rostaing
description: The marriage of Jeanne Rostaing and Eric B. Brettschneider took place yesterday at the Forest Hills, Queens, home of Justice and Mrs. Richard A. Brown. Justice Brown, of the State Supreme Court's Appellate Division in Brooklyn, officiated.

title: Washington at Work;   Japanese Author Brushes Up His Image With Journey to U.S. Enemy's Lair
description: He wears $800 Saville Row suits and $80 Georgio Armani ties. He plays tennis, he sails, he paints, he writes best sellers. He has represented a Tokyo constituency in the Parliament for the past 22 years. But Shintaro Ishihara is an angry man caught in a name-calling game.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Saatchi Wins Mylanta
description: Saatchi & Saatchi Advertising has won the account for Mylanta antacid, which the agency said is the first product assignment from the Johnson & Johnson/Merck Consumer Pharmaceuticals Company. The joint venture acquired the product earlier this month when it bought the over-the-counter pharmaceutical business of Imperial Chemical Industries of London. The account was formerly at Sudler & Hennessey, a division of Young & Rubicam. Billings were not disclosed, but an industry official said that such accounts may bill in the $15 million range.

title: Frank X. Gargiulo, 60, Of Civil Service Panel
description: Frank X. Gargiulo, a former member of the New York City Civil Service Commission, died Thursday of a brain tumor at the St. Rose of Lima Home in Manhattan. He was 60 years old and lived in the Carroll Gardens section of Brooklyn.

title: Jack Iams, Novelist, Editor of Magazine And TV Critic, 79
description: Jack Iams, a journalist, a novelist and an editor, died of a stroke on Saturday. At the time of his death, he and his wife, Joan Walker Wenning Iams, were en route to New York City from London. Mr. Iams, whose journalistic career spanned more than half a century, was 79 years old.

title: Cuban Ballet Student Wins at the 18th Prix de Lausanne
description: Carlos Acosta Junior, a 16-year-old ballet student from Cuba whose exuberant virtuosity made him a favorite from the beginning among 93 other young contestants, was awarded the gold medal in the 18th annual Prix de Lausanne ballet competition tonight.

title: Yields Expected to Climb Further
description: Many credit market analysts say the gloom in the bond markets, prompted by an unexpectedly large increase in long-term interest rates, is not likely to evaporate quickly. As a result, yields could rise further, they said.

title: Robert Riddell, 65, A U.S.O. Director For New York City
description: Robert L. Riddell, executive director of the U.S.O. in New York City for more than 30 years, died of heart failure on Saturday at Long Island Jewish Hospital in Queens. He was 65 years old and lived in Flushing.

title: Change in Nurse Rules Will Hurt Patients
description: To the Editor:

title: Cuomo Urged To Increase Court Budget
description: Saying that New York State's court system is at risk of breaking down, a group representing virtually every bar association in the New York City area is calling for the state to allot $991 million for the courts.

title: Johannesburg Journal;   Glossy Magazine with a Difference: It's for Blacks
description: Between the glossy advertisements for Japanese cars, Scotch whisky, British knitwear, French-style lingerie, sparkling wines and designer kitchens, an editorial message of black pride is being pitched to a prospering minority among South Africa's impoverished black majority.

title: Nicaragua Will Let Congress Observe Voting, Carter Says
description: Former President Jimmy Carter said today that the Nicaraguan Government had reversed its position and would allow American Congressmen to observe the February elections.

title: Poland's Communists Vote to Dissolve Party
description: Poland's Communist Party, after ruling the country for 45 years, voted to dissolve itself. Party delegates had decided to create a new democratic, left-of-center party in the hope of winning public support, but a group of about 100 dissidents broke off to form a competing Social Democratic Party.

title: Correction
description: A front-page article in some copies yesterday about the Bush Administration's proposed budget for 1991 misstated the Administration's estimate of the deficit for the fiscal year 1990, which ends Sept. 30. The estimate is $123.8 billion.

title: Don't Cut Israel and Others to Aid East Europe;   Plight of Philippines
description: To the Editor:

title: Uranium Concern in Canada Shuts 2 Mines
description: A Canadian uranium producer, Rio Algom Ltd., has announced the closing of two mines as a consequence of a decade-long slump in prices.

title: Battle Rages in Italy To Control Publisher
description: After a long-simmering struggle, two of Italy's most powerful business executives are engaged in an all-out war for control of the nation's leading publishing group.

title: A Jittery Senate Confronts Its Ethics
description: Some of the smiles were very tight. Some in the audience were squirming.

title: Affordable Housing Issue Ruffles Idyllic Westchester
description: In a court battle over the future of Peach Lake, two suburban imperatives are colliding in this remote corner of Westchester County: the need for affordable housing and the yearning for open spaces.

title: Sony's Newest Portable Is an Electronic Book
description: A bit more than 10 years after it brought out the Walkman, the Sony Corporation has provided a glimpse of one of the device's most offbeat descendants: the Data Discman, for people who would rather jog through the park reading encyclopedia entries than listening to Simon and Garfunkel.

title: A Place for Hard Foster Care Cases
description: Robert Rivera, a 17-year-old from the Bronx, has been in New York City's foster care system since he was 12. Only in the last year, however, has he found a place that feels like home: the Glen Mills Schools in Concordville, Pa.

title: All in a Day's Work for 49ers' Quarterback
description: After a performance everyone agreed was marvelous, Joe Montana responded in his typical aw-shucks manner.

title: Outdoors: The Trusty Automatic Comes Through
description: WITHOUT a stiff breeze, waterfowlers are becalmed in frustration.

title: 1855 Louisiana Law On Abortion Is Barred
description: A panel of Federal judges has refused to let Louisiana resume enforcing an old criminal law against abortion, saying the 1855 statute had been superseded by newer laws.

title: Noriega Is Transferred To Cell in U.S. Prison
description: Manuel Antonio Noriega, the fallen Panamanian leader, was transferred from the Federal courthouse to a Federal prison south of Miami tonight, the warden said.

title: Economic Calendar
description: Below are the major economic indicators to be released this week.

title: Los Angeles Orchestra Set for Salzburg
description: The Los Angeles Philharmonic announced yesterday that it will be in residence at the Salzburg Festival in August of 1992. In addition to an undetermined number of symphonic concerts, the orchestra will play in the pit for four performances of Messiaen's opera ''St. Francois d'Assise'' in a new production. Gerard Mortier, the new head of the Austrian summer festival, has declined to release details on the opera performances, but it is known that the American director Peter Sellars has been negotiating with the Los Angeles orchestra for a new production of ''St. Francois'' in that city.

title: EXECUTIVE CHANGES
description: * Marine Transport Lines Inc., Secaucus, N.J., a bulk shipping company, announced the resignation of Dirk Langeveld, its executive vice president and chief operating officer.

title: Screeners Help Advertisers Avoid Prime-Time Trouble
description: Ron Blazer is paid to watch television - and take notes.

title: E. Blair Bolles, 78, A Retired Journalist And Colt Executive
description: Blair Bolles, a retired journalist, author and corporate executive, died of liver cancer Friday at his home in Bethesda, Md. He was 78 years old.

title: Pilot Guilty in Cocaine Plot
description: A Colombian pilot accused of flying cocaine for the Medellin drug organization pleaded guilty on Friday to conspiring to import cocaine into the United States. The pilot, Jorge de la Cuesta, faces a maximum sentence of life and a $4 million fine. He was accused of flying cocaine for Carlos Lehder Rivas, who has been convicted of smuggling drugs.

title: The U.N. Today
description: General Assembly

title: An Investment in Crossland
description: The Coast-to-Coast Financial Corporation, a savings and loan holding company affiliated with the Pritzker family of Chicago, has agreed to provide $150 million in capital to Crossland Savings, based in Brooklyn, Crossland announced on Friday.

title: Reading Gorby's Mind
description: My political philosophy will outlast Communism, even outlast capitalism. I have come to believe in improvisationism, the politics of dealing dazzlingly with the present.

title: Wisconsin's Learnfare: A Bust
description: LEAD: ''I'll go to school if I get a pair of Air Jordans.''

title: Reviews/Music;   Harpist's Version of Mozart's Piano Sonata
description: Marie-Pierre Langlamet, a 22-year-old harpist from France, made an impressive recital debut on Tuesday evening at Merkin Concert Hall. Ms. Langlamet, who lives in New York and is a member of the Metropolitan Opera orchestra, has won a handful of European contests since 1983, as well as the Concert Artists Guild New York Competition last year.

title: Language Purists Might Ask, What's the Usage?
description: To the Editor:

title: Reviews/Music;   Schoenberg, Before And After Serialism
description: Under the title of Focus 1990, the Juilliard School and its students are examining the world of Arnold Schoenberg. Six concerts - stretching through this week - began Friday night at Alice Tully Hall. JoAnn Falletta conducted the Juilliard Symphony in the composer's ''Verklarte Nacht'' and Violin Concerto, separating the two with Mahler's ''Kindertotenlieder.''

title: Scenes From a Moscow 'Tragi-Farce'
description: It is midwinter in the dispirited capital of Communism: Chekhov is coming to life again as sure as Lenin's corpse was reinserted into his mausoleum display case the other day, freshly recosmeticized for a new decade of uncertain revolution.

title: The Big Easy: Fat City for Montana and 49ers;   Broncos Fall, 55-10, And So Do Records
description: In redundantly spectacular fashion, the San Francisco 49ers trounced the Denver Broncos, 55-10, here today in Super Bowl XXIV, leaving no doubt that the superior team of the last decade enters the new one with the same zeal and the same excellence.

title: J. W. Mirandon, 69, A Banker and Official
description: J. Wilmer Mirandon, a banker, New York State official and retired chairman of a tuition-aid program, died of lymphoma on Friday at Dartmouth Hitchcock Medical Canter in Hanover, N.H. He was 69 years old and had homes in Weathersfield, Vt., and Manhattan.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Bozell French Move
description: A partnership between Bozell and Eurocom in France has ended. Bozell said Friday that it had traded its share of their jointly owned Synergie Bozell for Eurocom's majority interest in another French agency, Iceberg. Bozell is taking several clients from Synergie to Iceberg, including the Chrysler Corporation and Texas Instruments Inc.

title: Acid Rain: Plenty Bad Enough
description: The rain that falls over much of the northeastern United States is mildly acidic from pollutant gases. Like many weak poisons, its effects are subtle and hard to pinpoint. The preliminary results of a monumental 10-year Federal study now establish just how harmful this acid deluge is. They lend urgency to proposals now before Congress that coal-burning utilities sharply cut their emissions of acrid gases.

title: Grandfather Is Charged In Fund-Raising Fraud
description: A 65-year-old repairman has been charged with defrauding his fellow employees by telling them his granddaughter was sick and needed thousands of dollars for medical bills.

title: Budget Director is Praised As Smart and Faulted for It
description: When word spread recently that the Administration's budget would be presented this year in one large book instead of the usual collection of smaller volumes, the response around town, from Congress and the bureaucracy, from lobbyists and reporters, was the same: What is Darman up to now?

title: The Editorial Notebook;   Wood Men and Desert Men
description: For most Americans, what is happening in Azerbaijan might as well be occurring on the moon's dark side. TV presents a montage of people slain in an ethnic civil war, of shouting demonstrators and Soviet troops under attack. It all tends to be boiled down to a religious conflict between Muslim Azerbaijanis and Christian Armenians.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Continental And Ayer Part Ways
description: CONTINENTAL AIRLINES abruptly dismissed Ayer as its advertising agency on Friday and said it would put its account into a formal review involving four or five agencies.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Needham in Canada
description: DDB Needham, a unit of the Omnicom Group, has increased its presence in Canada through the acquisition of Carder Gray Advertising of Toronto, which it will merge with DDB Needham Canada. The new agency, to be called Carder Gray DDB Needham Advertising, will have billings of $85 million, with $55 million of that coming from Carder Gray.

title: Is Syrian-Israeli Detente Possible?
description: LEAD: Until very recently, the sweeping changes in East-West relations have had a limited effect on the Middle East, which was long an active and important arena of superpower rivalry. But the changes are beginning to affect the region, as the re-establishment of diplomatic relations between Syria and Egypt indicates.

title: Mt. Vernon Pit Tells How Slaves Lived in Washington's Time
description: In a 36-square-foot open pit, just a few feet from the tourist restrooms at what was once George Washington's home, archeologists say they have unearthed a treasure trove of information about how the slaves of the nation's first President lived.

title: Business Scene;   Exporters Shrug At Dollar's Drop
description: THE dollar just might be on the verge of a big drop in value. It is already off 15 percent against the West German mark since mid-September, and Japan is taking steps to strengthen the yen and weaken the dollar. That should be wonderful news for the nation's exporters, the main beneficiaries of a cheaper dollar, but surprisingly, many greet the prospect with a shrug.

title: New Data Cited as Agent in Spy Case Asks Retrial
description: A principal witness against the only F.B.I. agent who has ever been convicted of espionage declared last summer that the bureau had improperly concealed information that might have helped the agent's defense.

title: More Sidewalks of New York Are Becoming Streets of Stars
description: Hardly a day passes that one does not come upon another photograph of another Hollywood star at home in New York. Stars are seen running in their sweat suits through Central Park, dining at restaurants bankrolled by other stars, sweeping into benefits for the South American rain forests, curled up on the couches of their newly decorated duplexes and talking about their projects. Maybe you've noticed.

title: Montana's Passing Leads 49ers in Super Bowl Rout
description: The San Francisco 49ers, capturing the National Football League title for the fourth time in a decade, enhanced their status as one of the great sports franchises with a record-breaking 55-10 trouncing of the Denver Broncos yesterday in Super Bowl XXIV.

title: Metro Matters;   Why a Sure Way To End Up in Jail Is Not So Sure
description: On April 1, 1989, Dowie Pringle was arrested after a neighbor in the Bushwick section of Brooklyn said Mr. Pringle threatened him with a loaded .25-caliber semiautomatic pistol.

title: Bench Helps Duke Beat Georgia Tech
description: A strong performance from the bench helped eighth-ranked Duke beat Georgia Tech by 88-86 today.

title: Elizabeth Marks Weds Paul Taylor
description: Elizabeth Leah Marks, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Stuart Marks of New York, and Paul Andrew Taylor, a son of Marjorie Taylor of Newton, Mass., and the late Manuel Taylor, were married yesterday. Rabbi Marc Angel officiated at Congregation Shearith Israel in New York.

title: Tie Keeps Islanders And Devils in First
description: After the 4-4 tie between the Islanders and the Devils at Nassau Coliseum today, the Islanders' Pat LaFontaine, following an appropriate dictum, stepped from the locker room to the corridor - and kissed his sister.

title: Don't Cut Israel and Others to Aid East Europe;   Big Soviet Bailout
description: To the Editor:

title: Frustration Again for Elway
description: Not long after the Denver Broncos had qualified for Super Bowl XXIV, John Elway decided that he would let his blond hair grow. He would not get a haircut, as he had done before his two previous - and unhappy - appearances in the championship game.

title: Rangers Beginning to See (a Dim) Light
description: ''A team can't just turn it on again like a light switch,'' James Patrick said.

title: Sports of The Times;   Parasols and Footballs
description: A TAXICAB here was suddenly halted at an intersection as a parade, with horns blaring, knees pumping and bright parasols undulating, made its Orphic way down St. Charles Street.

title: Du Pont Millions at Issue In an Heir's Sanity Case
description: A du Pont heir who once ran for Congress is back in court here trying to prove that he is sane and competent.

title:
SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS: TENNIS;

Just How Far Is Too Far?
description: LEAD: JOHN McENROE has always had the ability to stir debate. Was he a vile-mouthed brat or a volatile genius? Were his outbursts self-indulgent excesses or merely responses to provocation?

title: Dividend Meetings
description: Following is a partial list of dividend meetings for the week of Jan. 28, 1990:

title: VOTE IS MOVED UP BY EAST GERMANS; COALITION WIDENED
description: Meeting late into the night, the Government and all major political groups in East Germany agreed today to hold the country's first democratic elections on March 18 instead of in May, and to form a coalition government until then.

title: Review/Theater;   Struggle With Conscience In an Almost Forgotten War
description: In one of the early episodes of the television series M*A*S*H, Col. Henry Blake, the Army surgeon played by McLean Stevenson, bitterly observes that there are two rules of war. The first is that people die. The second is that there is nothing that doctors, chaplains or field officers can do about Rule No. 1. Rod Serling's teleplay ''The Strike,'' which is being given its first stage production by the Vietnam Veterans Ensemble Theater Company at the South Street Theater, examines the agony of conscience of one Army major who must make a battlefield decision that could end in the death of a score of men he himself has sent out on a reconnaissance patrol.

title: A Man Of Character
description: On the night of Friday, Sept. 10, 1971, a nervous group of civilian ''observers'' entered D-Yard at the Attica State Correction Facility in upstate New York, where more than a thousand rebelling inmates were holding 35 hostages.

title: Israel and East Germany to Talk About Ties
description: Israeli and East German officials are to begin preliminary talks on Monday aimed at establishing the first diplomatic ties between the two nations, the Foreign Ministry said today. But first the two sides must resolve longstanding disagreements over the Nazi genocide.

title: A Computer As Recruiter
description: MOST college coaches no doubt would revel in a system wherein, by simply asking a computer, they could find just the scholar-athlete they need.

title: Municipal Cars Are Cut Sharply In Dinkins Plan
description: More than 1,000 municipal workers and administrators will lose their city-owned cars this year as part of the continuing austerity program called for by Mayor David N. Dinkins.

title: Results Plus
description: N.B.A.

title: Don't Cut Israel and Others to Aid East Europe
description: To the Editor:

title: Christmas Spirit Is Still Alive Among Givers to the Neediest
description: Although the year-end holidays are long gone, letters sent to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund last week continued to relate ways in which people were moved by Christmas and the New Year to reach out to others.

title: Broncos Feel Effect of Elway's Off Day
description: John Elway's inability to get the Denver Broncos' passing offense going in the early part of the Super Bowl yesterday put an unrealistic burden on his defensive teammates. And Bobby Humphrey's fumble in the first quarter broke the game open for the 49ers.

title: East German Venture Decree
description: East Germany's coalition Government has approved a decree that allows foreign companies with fewer than 500 employees to have a majority stake in a joint venture with an East German company.

title: More Malpractice Than Lawsuits, New York Medical Study Suggests
description: A long-awaited study of malpractice in New York hospitals, perhaps the most comprehensive ever conducted in the United States, concludes that thousands of hospital deaths and tens of thousands of injuries are tied to negligence each year but that relatively few victims seek recourse in the courts.

title: Dawn Quixote Takes the Palm Beach
description: Dawn Quixote may or may not have the stamina to contest the Triple Crown races this spring, but the 3-year-old colt proved today that he has plenty of speed and is especially dangerous when the footing is sloppy.

title: Life in Girls' Gang: Colors and Bloody Noses
description: It was Shadow's coming out party, her initiation into the Tiny Diablas girls' gang in the Watts district, and she was dressed in the height of gang fashion: narrow corduroy pants, a sweatshirt in the gang color purple, extravagantly teased hair and exaggerated black-red makeup.

title: Savings Unit Seeks 2d Chance
description: The Imperial Corporation of America, one of California's largest savings and loans companies, made a series of spectacular mistakes in the last few years, including betting heavily on speculative high-yield ''junk bonds,'' buying a portfolio of consumer loans that went sour and financing the importer of the ill-fated Yugo automobile.

title: Sports of The Times;   Are 49ers the Best Ever? No
description: WITH their 55-10 rout of the Denver Broncos in Super Bowl XXIV, Joe Montana and the San Francisco 49ers answered all the questions except the two that can never be answered with certainty: is Montana the best quarterback in pro football history and are these 49ers the best team?

title: A Sympathetic Pope Visits Some of Africa's Poorest
description: From a compound for lepers to the outer fringes of the encroaching desert, Pope John Paul II journeyed today among West Africa's poor and afflicted, urging them not to yield to ''despair, pessimism or passivity.''

title: Holmgren Awaits Word From Jets
description: Mike Holmgren, the San Francisco 49ers' offensive coordinator, said tonight that he had not yet been contacted by Dick Steinberg, the Jets' new general manager, regarding the Jets' coaching vacancy.

title: Episcopal Priest Leaves As Head of Gay Mission
description: A gay Episcopal priest ordained just last Dec. 16 has been forced to resign as director of a Hoboken ministry to homosexuals because of comments he made questioning celibacy and monogamy.

title: Review/Television;   A 'Nightline'-Style Program on New York
description: ''Jack Cafferty's Newsline New York'' is on the right track. Each edition of this new nightly half-hour program, at 11:30 on Channel 5, moves in on one New York story, and Mr. Cafferty makes a hard-driving engineer.

title: Stake Is Cut In Chock Full
description: Randon A. Samelson, the chairman of Orange-Co. Inc., said Friday that his company had lowered its stake in the Chock Full o'Nuts Corporation to 5.9 percent from 12.7 percent.

title: In Fast-Changing East Germany, The Economy Is Stuck in Neutral
description: When Gert Schmidt, an economist in Dusseldorf, met recently with a group of executives from West German companies, they all eagerly sought his advice on doing business in East Germany.

title: In Stands, A Study In Bronco Blue
description: Two young men in Bronco colors - orange-and-blue caps, orange-and-blue sweaters and orange-and-blue-painted faces - sat behind an end zone in the Superdome today, took some photographs and watched the game. And cheered early. Very early.

title: Enough Equipment To Fill Golf Course
description: WHEN a group of 10 young Russian golfers was brought to Florida this month as guests of the PGA of America, the best player among them, Dennis Zherebko, 14 years old, had no problem playing to his 18 handicap on the Lake Nona course in Orlando.

title: Market Place;   Some Promise In Gaming Stocks
description: SEVERAL small companies serving the $9 billion casino-gaming business might be the strongest performers in the industry, several analysts say.

title: At 21, He's Off And Winning
description: NOT every 21-year-old college student can say he owns a string of harness horses. But then, not every college student has a mother who operates a chain of Chinese restaurants.

title: Accord Is Reached On U-Groove Irons
description: Karsten Manufacturing Corporation, makers of the controversial Ping Eye 2-irons, has dropped a $100 million lawsuit that threatened the future authority of the United States Golf Association.

title: Some Scientists Doubt the Value Of 'Genetic Fingerprint' Evidence
description: Leading molecular biologists say a technique promoted by the nation's top law-enforcement agency for identifying suspects in criminal trials through the analysis of genetic material is too unreliable to be used in court.

title: Elizabeth Meyers, Administrator, 83
description: Elizabeth Meyers, director of college activities at Barnard before she retired in 1972, died of cancer on Wednesday at Sentara Leigh Memorial Hospital in Norfolk, Va., while visiting a son in Virginia Beach. She was 83 years old and lived in Short Hills, N.J.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Buckley/DeCerchio
description: Buckley/DeCerchio just keeps on growing. On Friday, the agency was awarded the $1.1 million account for the National Lampoon humor magazine. The agency is also moving out of Tom DeCerchio's apartment to an office at 536 Broadway in Manhattan.

title: Ethnic Albanian Protesters Battle With Yugoslav Police
description: Thousands of ethnic Albanians fought with the police today in the Yugoslav province of Kosovo in demonstrations demanding that the Communist authorities lift a state of emergency and allow free elections. A man was reported killed and four injured.

title: One Problem Then Another Forces Cancellation of Flight
description: Passengers on a Delta Air Lines Boeing 727 slid down evacuation chutes onto an airport taxiway today after smoke was spotted in the cabin as the flight was about to take off, officials said.

title: Reviews/Music;   Preludes for Strings Nod at Jazz and Hymns
description: The New York debut recital of the New England String Quartet in Weill Recital Hall on Tuesday evening may have been a bit premature. Both the collective and the individual work of the young players - Ellen Jewett and Heidi Yenney, violinists; Holly Barnes, violist, and Kris Yenney, cellist - seemed far from ripe, and it was therefore hard to gauge the potential of the group, formed in 1985.

title: Slow Pace For Reform In East Bloc
description: The rush toward political reform has swept through the nations of Eastern Europe with startling speed. But their attempt to move from the central planning of Communism toward free markets promises to be a much slower, more difficult and socially divisive transition.

title: Review/Ballet;   The Wit and Whimsy of Roland Petit and Troupe
description: Since the 1940's, Roland Petit has amused and amazed audiences by combining the refinement of classical ballet with the extravagance of the Parisian music hall. Some of this French choreographer's productions have been lofty. Others have been saucy. Most have been unpredictable.

title: Diana Giasullo Wed to Bryan Adams
description: Diana Marie Giasullo, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Anthony Giasullo of Maplewood, N.J., was married yesterday to Bryan Henry Adams, a son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry B. Adams of Wayne, N.J. The Rev. Richard J. Mieliwocki performed the ceremony at Our Lady of Sorrows Roman Catholic Church in South Orange, N.J.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   2 Colleagues Back at Blau
description: Jan Leth thought Barry Blau & Partners was too small. So in 1987 the art director left the direct-response ad agency, based in Fairfield, Conn., for Rapp Collins Marcoa, owned by the Omnicom Group. David Klang thought Blau was too big. So last February the creative supervisor left for the Saugatuck Group, a Westport, Conn., consulting group that was just starting a direct-marketing division.

title: Northeastern Skies Light Up, And So Do the Switchboards
description: Thousands of people in the Northeast reported seeing a strange blue-green light in the sky Saturday night.

title: INSIDE
description: Blunders on the Caspian

title: Immunogen Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago periods' revenue included a $300,000 milestone payment by E. Merck.

title: Upheaval in the East: Soviet Union;   KREMLIN BYPASSED IN MEDIATION OFFER
description: A new sort of political initiative has emerged beyond the Kremlin's orbit with the resourceful Baltic separatist movements persuading their counterparts in the feuding southern republics of Armenia and Azerbaijan to hold peace talks in the Latvian republic.

title: Altex Industries reports earnings for Year to Sept 30
description: Year-ago figures included a writedown of $1,894,000.

title: 25 Named Trustees of Museum of the Indian

Experts attributed the drop to bad weather in some states and a general seasonal decline. title: Reviews/Music;   5-Part Series on the Songs Of Cole Porter Opens at Y
description: In a letter to Cole Porter early in 1933, Irving Berlin congratulated the songwriter on ''Night and Day,'' calling it his ''best spot.'' A slide showing the actual letter that Berlin sent to Porter was one of the fascinating visual tidbits in the opening program of the Lyrics and Lyricists series at the 92nd Street Y on Sunday as it began its 20th season. Another was a clip from ''Night and Day,'' the movie biography of Porter, in which the composer, played by Cary Grant, was shown leading a collegiate chorus in the Yale song ''Bulldog.'' As Jim Lowe, the evening's host, pointed out, Grant, who was 6 feet 3 inches tall and 42 years old when he made the film, was impersonating a man who was 18 years old and 5 feet 6.

The Governor and the Bishop
description: LEAD: Bishop Austin Vaughan's embarrassing attack on Gov. Mario Cuomo's position on abortion is -from the perspectives of Roman Catholic theology - wrong and unjust. In fact, the Governor's stance is just a little on the conservative side of mainstream Catholicism.

title: RJR Bonds Off Sharply For 2d Day
description: Some RJR Nabisco debt securities continued to plummet in price yesterday, as they had on Friday after Moody's Investors Service lowered its rating on about $7 billion of the company's debt.

title: David Campbell, 95, Publishing Executive

In this amiable anthology of nine brief sketches (at the Vineyard Theater), fathers and sons, friends and lovers come to terms with strained relationships - and couples try to remember what drew them together in the first place.

title: Japan in Pact On Mexican Oil
description: Mexico's state-run oil monopoly has signed an agreement to supply Japan with $4 billion worth of petroleum in the next five years, officials said.

title: McDonnell Order
description: The Federal Express Corporation exercised three options to acquire freighter versions of the McDonnell Douglas Corporation's MD-11 aircraft and added another eight options. Federal Express now holds a total of 8 firm orders and 11 options, McDonnell Douglas said. The new firm orders are scheduled for delivery in 1992. Industry analysts estimate the average price of an MD-11 jet at about $100 million.

title: Boeing Net Drops 55.7%; Strike Cited
description: The Boeing Company today reported a 55.7 percent decline in earnings for the fourth quarter, when its commercial aircraft operations were disrupted by a strike and its military business continued to show losses.

title: Haiti, as Expected, Calls End to State of Siege
description: The military Government of Haiti said tonight that it had lifted a state of siege and restored parts of the Constitution that it suspended nine days ago before launching a major crackdown on political opponents.

title: BRIEFS
description: Debt

title: Reviews/Music;   A Return to Swampy Blues
description: It's back to the swampy blues for the drummer Ronald Shannon Jackson and the latest edition of his group, the Decoding Society. Where earlier lineups of the Decoding Society drew on the odd meters and zigzag melodies of ethnic music, the current group usually stays with marches and stomps, bluesy vamps and ballads. But its experimental edge has shifted, not vanished. Mr. Jackson has adapted an idea from his old employer, Ornette Coleman; like Mr. Coleman's Prime Time, the current Decoding Society now includes two bassists and two guitarists, and they can fill every register with improvisation.

title: Europe Inflation Up
description: The inflation rate in the European Community reached 5.4 percent in December, up from 4.4 percent at the end of 1988, the bloc's statistics office, Eurostat, said today. For December, consumer prices in the 12-nation economic bloc were three-tenths of 1 percent higher than in November. All European Community members had higher inflation last year except Portugal, where the December rate of 11.6 percent was down from the 11.7 percent recorded a year earlier.

title: Quotation of the Day
description: ''What it represents is that there are some white people who understand that the events after Carol Stuart's death had a profound effect on race relations in this city. What makes it truly remarkable is that it was the family of the victim, not the Mayor or other white leaders, who did it. It shows that Boston has decent hard-working people who understand how other people, people in the minority community, can suffer, can be victimized.''

description: Many of the leading figures of the nation's operatic establishment converged on the capital during the weekend to attend the 20th annual Opera America conference, billed as a ''forum on the future of opera.'' In the time not spent grandly charting new courses, the conferees had an opportunity to contemplate the present as well, in the three productions of the Washington Opera's winter season at the Kennedy Center's 1,142-seat Eisenhower Theater: Nicolai's ''Merry Wives of Windsor,'' Massenet's ''Werther'' and Argento's ''Aspern Papers.''

Mr. Luytjes, 42 years old, is serving a 10-year sentence in Federal prison on drug charges.

description: FEW graduate schools of business can keep current with world economic and political trends just by analyzing their student rosters, but the Management Education Institute Inc. in Cambridge, Mass., can do just that. The reason: more than 95 percent of its students come from abroad to study for a master of science degree in management, which is earned over 11 months.

title: Bank of New England Sells Credit Card Unit
description: The Bank of New England Corporation yesterday announced the sale of its consumer credit card business to Citicorp for $828 million, producing a profit for the company of $176 million.

title: Bridge
description: A British partnership completed a remarkable double in London Saturday. At the end of a three-day battle at the Regents Park Hilton Hotel, Tony Forrester and Andrew Robson were victorious in a field of 14 world-class pairs. A week earlier they had won a similar event in the Netherlands.

title: Apple Promotes European Unit Chief in Big Realignment
description: Apple Computer Inc. confirmed today that it was bringing one of its stars back from Europe to take charge of most of its somewhat listless operations in the United States.

title: Connie Kay's Drums Purr and Tap, Not Thunder
description: When the Modern Jazz Quartet opened a set at the Cafe Carlyle the other night with George Gershwin's ''Summertime,'' Connie Kay, the group's drummer for the last 35 years, turned in a characteristically virtuoso performance by quietly moving sounds around.

title: Upheaval in the East;   Honecker, in Disgrace and in Poor Health, Is Arrested as He Leaves a Berlin Hospital
description: East Germany's relentless pursuit of its former hard-line leaders finally reached Erich Honecker today. The ousted Communist Party chief was released from the hospital and immediately arrested.

title: Upheaval in the East: Poland;   Successor Party Picks New Leaders
description: Two young leaders of Poland's newly defunct Communist Party were elected today to head a new left-of-center party that hopes to win back the public support lost by the Communists.

title: Mandela, 'Faceless Man With a Fax,' Negotiates His and His Nation's Future
description: For the last week, audiences packing a popular dinner theater in a grimy industrial quarter of Johannesburg have reserved one of their biggest laughs for a line offered by the country's best-known political satirist, Pieter-Dirk Uys. ''Who would have thought,'' Mr. Uys has said each night, strictly deadpan, ''that a faceless man with a fax machine could run the country from a prison?''

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day on Friday about the bankruptcy proceedings of Federated Stores Inc. misstated the effect on discounts for retired employees. The discounts were ended on Jan. 15 as the company filed its petition. But along with that filing, it petitioned the judge to approve a restoration of the discounts. On Thursday he did so. The article also misstated the size of the discounts; they vary among the company's nine retailing chains.

title: Review/Television;   How Noriega and the U.S. Kept on Using Each Other
description: ''The Noriega Connection'' ends with this judgment, attributed to ''one former C.I.A. official'': ''Over the course of seven Administrations that dealt with Noriega, the national interest was simply a matter of political convenience.'' In its use of an unidentified source to make so sweeping a criticism, tonight's ''Frontline'' documentary, at 10 on Channel 13 and at 9 on Channel 49, succumbs to the less attractive tendencies of a generally admirable series. Apparently, when it comes to Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, lately boss of Panama and now in jail in the United States on drug charges, anything goes.

Such bucolic images suggest the color palette that dominated last week's Paris couture collections. What was new was seeing these full-bodied pastels for day as well as for evening.

title: Small Quakes Jolt California

The epicenter was 25 miles north of El Centro, near the Salton Sea, according to the California Institute of Technology in Pasadena. The quake times and readings were: 6:01 A.M., 2.8; 6:02 A.M., 2.8; 6:04 A.M., 2.9; 6:16 A.M., 2.7, and 7:54 A.M., 2.5.

For most members of the company, the agreement calls for a salary increase of $50 a week in the first three years and in the fifth year, with a $25 increase in the fourth year. The contract also provides for a cost-of-living increase in the fourth year.

title: Trial Is Told of General's Suicide After He Defied Ceausescu's Order
description: An officer testified today that President Nicolae Ceausescu's Defense Minister shot himself in the heart because he could not bring himself to obey the dictator and order troops to fire on demonstrators during last month's uprising.

title: 49 Chilean Guerrillas Use Tunnel To Escape From Jail in Santiago

title: Children's Opera on Crack: Scenes From Real Life
description: Jose is only 10 years old, but already he feels the pangs of being an outsider. He tries crack and sings, ''I feel strong.'' As his addiction grows, however, he becomes morose and hostile. In the end, he dies from a drug-induced heart-attack.

title: A Panel Hears Tales of Fears and 'Wilding'
description: In a voice choked with emotion, a Brooklyn mother told a City Hall hearing yesterday that when she sends her children to school by public transportation each morning, she worries she will not see them alive again because of marauding groups of violent youths.
