title: Plea Accord Is Accepted by Figure in Barry Inquiry
description: A District of Columbia employee pleaded guilty to drug charges today as part of an agreement with Federal prosecutors to provide evidence in their investigation of drug use by the city's Mayor, Marion S. Barry Jr. Prosecutors said the city worker, James P. McWilliams, was in a downtown Ramada Inn room in December 1988 when Mr. Barry used cocaine with a friend, Charles Lewis. Mr. Lewis, who has pleaded guilty to unrelated drug charges, has said under oath that he used drugs with Mr. Barry at the hotel. Mr. Barry has denied in sworn testimony to a Federal grand jury that he ever used cocaine with Mr. Lewis. Mr. McWilliams's testimony could prove crucial in any attempt to determine whether Mr. Barry told the truth.

title: Economic Scene;   Does Japan Play Fair?
description: THE Japanese do not mean to offend, say the new breed of Japan-watchers, whose revisionist views on international trade and finance have become fashionable from Capitol Hill to the Commerce Department. But the Japanese hardly understand what is meant by free markets and are not about to be converted by the Heritage Foundation. Rather than rage across the cultural abyss, the revisionists say, it would be in everyone's interest for America to insist on a fair share of the international market and let the Japanese figure out the least unpleasant way to accommodate the demands.

title: Ban the Boom
description: Ever since there have been radios, adolescents have turned up the volume to annoy adults. Portable radios, and later ''boom boxes,'' some the size of large suitcases, made it possible to carry the annoyance out of the house. Now ''boom cars'' - automobiles fitted with high-powered sound systems - are driving annoyance across town. Communities are cracking down, with reason.

title: Pipe Bomb Explodes in Houston Church
description: A pipe bomb apparently mailed to one of Houston's largest churches exploded this morning, injuring the pastor's daughter, the police said.

title: Classroom Discipline and Lessons in Social Values
description: Laurel Cress, a third-grade teacher, has done away with all the usual ways of maintaining order. Students do not get points or candy for behaving well. The names of problem students are not posted on the blackboard or anywhere else in the classroom.

title: About Education
description: ''Rumanians Call for Freedom in Schools,'' read a recent headline in The New York Times. Student leaders were demanding a purge of Communist-dominated and academically threadbare schools and universities.

description: In an unusual advertising campaign, the Intel Corporation is bypassing its customers, the computer makers that use its microprocessors, to try to persuade computer users that they would be better off with its more powerful 386SX chip than its older 286 chip.

Crane Plans to Bid For Milton Roy
description: The Crane Company said its board of directors had authorized a $21-a-share offer for the Milton Roy Company. Stock in Milton Roy, a St. Petersburg, Fla., maker of measuring instruments, rose $1 today, to $17.625, on the New York Stock Exchange. Crane slipped 62.5 cents, to $22.25. Crane, which sells building products, said it was ready to make the offer but needed the cooperation of Milton Roy's board to insure its shareholder rights plan did not prevent the offer from proceeding. Crane, a pollution control company in New York City, holds an 8.4 percent stake in Milton Roy.

The business has been acquired by Baron Bridge Supplies in Louisville, Ky.

description: A woman was found guilty of murder today in the suffocation of one of two infant daughters she claimed were abducted three years apart by a masked man.

title: About New York;   Of Circus Bears, Super Bowls And Glasnost
description: How to begin? Perhaps last June when Brigham Kerr married Angela Surazhsky, whose family moved to New York from the Soviet Union a decade before. No, we'll start on the evening of Jan. 11, the opening of the Moscow Circus at Radio City Music Hall.

title: Momentum Grows for Military Spending Cuts in West Europe
description: The upheavals in the Communist countries in Eastern Europe and the Bush Administration's talk of closing bases and withdrawing troops from Greece, Britain, Italy, West Germany and Turkey have stepped up the political momentum toward greater military spending cuts in Western Europe.

title: Devils Hit Skids Against Kings
description: To the Devils, it all must have looked like an attractive stretch of the schedule a couple of months ago. There was this game in Los Angeles and then three off days before the next game in Vancouver.

title: Antley Hopes to Return
description: Chris Antley, a top jockey whose career was interrupted by drug use, could get his license back by March 15. The New York State Racing and Wagering Board announced yesterday that it would act on Antley's application for a license on or after that day.

title: One Yugoslavia or Six?
description: Yugoslavia has come to the brink of radical change later than its Eastern European neighbors. Now it faces fundamental questions, like the future of Communist rule and its survival as a single country. Yet unity is not automatically the top priority. Yugoslavia's most compelling need now is for effective reforms to halt its slide toward ethnic conflict and economic ruin. Washington still has an interest in trying to preserve Yugoslav unity, but not at any cost.

title: Rape Case in Mexico Fuels Outrage at the Police
description: The arrest of four federal policemen accused of having led a gang that raped, beat and robbed more than a dozen women here has stirred widespread public outrage and led to a renewal of calls for a sweeping overhaul of Mexico's police and public-security apparatus.

description: In hospital wards here, a bedraggled and stunned group of refugees from Liberia are struggling to sort out the reasons behind the outburst of violence that has led to hundreds of deaths there.

title: Coral Potter, 49, Dies; An Actor and Manager
description: Coral S. Potter, an actor with the Jean Cocteau Repertory Theater for 17 years, died of lung cancer on Thursday at St. Vincent's Hospital in Manhattan. He was 49 years old. Mr. Potter had been a member of the Cocteau's resident acting company since its second season in 1972. His many credits included ''The Golem,'' ''The Duchess of Malfi,'' ''Waiting for Godot,'' ''The Cenci,'' ''Hamlet,'' ''Ghosts,'' ''Twelfth Night,'' ''A Midsummer Night's Dream,'' ''Rhinoceros'' and ''Volpone.'' He was also the company's business manager for five years and performed with a number of summer-stock companies. In the 1960's, Mr. Potter acted Off Broadway under the stage name George Walden and was a Turkish interpreter for the Army.

title: Chronicle
description: He can't read music and has never played an instrument. But ROBERT FULGHUM, 52, will lead the Minneapolis Chamber Symphony in the fourth movement of Beethoven's monumental Ninth Symphony, his Walter Mitty dream-come-true.

title: Quayle Trip: Resentment Dramatized
description: Vice President Dan Quayle's trip to Latin America and the Caribbean was supposed to allay some of the region's resentment over the United States invasion of Panama, but instead it seems to have dramatized the depth of that resentment.

title: School Bus With 38 Children Skids Off Road
description: A school bus with 38 kindergarten and first-grade students skidded off an Orange County road and into a tree today, injuring most of the children, the authorities said. At least four of the children were seriously hurt.

title: But Is the Child Learning? Schools Trying New Tests
description: John Mangini, a biology teacher at Kennedy High School in Waterbury, Conn., recently gave his students some live brine shrimp instead of a test. Or, rather, the shrimp were the test.

title: USX Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

The company said that improvement in operating income in 1989 was primarily due to better results in the energy segment where operating income was $987 million, more than twice the 1988 level. Marathon Oil Co. had operating income of $862 million on sales of $11.2 billion in 1989 versus operating income of $506 million on sales of $9 billion. Fourth quarter operating income was $166 million versus $123 million.

description: To the Editor:

title: In Parliament Shift, Prague Communists Become a Minority
description: The Communist Party handed over more than 100 of its parliamentary seats to pro-democracy groups today to end its four-decade hold on Czechoslovakia's legislature.

title: RECESSION CHANCES HAVE DIMINISHED, GREENSPAN INSISTS
description: The chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, Alan Greenspan, told Congress today that the chance of an imminent recession has diminished markedly since spring and that the nation's current slow growth is likely to prove only a ''temporary hesitation.''

title: Chronicle
description: A libel case brought in High Court in London against PEREGRINE WORSTHORNE, the former editor of The Sunday Telegraph, and his paper ended yesterday. The winners were ANDREW NEIL, the editor of The Sunday Times, and his paper.

title: Review/Television;   Confessions About Women By an Earnest 18-Year-Old
description: Much of ''Women and Wallace'' can sound like the intensely earnest confession of an 18-year-old. Why not? It is. Jonathan Marc Sherman was just that age when he wrote the play, which went on to become a 1988 winner in the Young Playwrights Festival in New York. Tonight at 10 on Channel 13, the ''American Playhouse'' series is presenting ''Women and Wallace'' in an adaptation of a version originally done for Playwrights Horizons Off Broadway. Once again, the director is Don Scardino (''A Few Good Men''), and Josh Hamilton portrays, quite affectingly, the obviously autobiographical character of Wallace Kirkland.

title: Campbell Soup
description: The Campbell Soup Company said it plans to sell its Juice Bowl Products Inc. subsidiary and close a foreign plant. Campbell acquired Juice Bowl in 1982 to produce the company's tomato-based juices and expand the company's vegetable juice line. The Camden-based company said that Juice Bowl, based in Lakeland, Fla., was no longer needed. Campbell will close its frozen convenience food plant at Sittingbourne, Kent, England. The plant employs 262 people and produces frozen sausage rolls. Production will be moved to another Campbell plant in Salford, England.

title: For Bitter Newspaper Rivals, an Uneasy Alliance

The brawl left them with zealous readers who took sides as if the papers were football teams, but also with annual losses in the tens of millions of dollars.

description: The company attributed the earnings decline to the effects of a $40- a-day special dividend paid in May. The company said for the year, it incurred an interest expense of about $31,812,000 related primarily to debt from the special dividend. description: THE traditional French and American way to cook flatfish like sole and flounder is sauteing. Delicate species like these can be broiled, but they tend to dry out quickly if not watched carefully. A third method I have used successfully for years is high-temperature roasting.

title: Emanuel Lazzaro, Executive, 90
description: Emanuel Lazzaro, a retired trucking company executive, died on Saturday at his son's home in Brooklyn. He was 90 years old and lived in Brooklyn.

description: Erich Honecker, East Germany's former Communist leader, was released from detention today after a court ruled he was too ill to be held but he still faces a treason trial in March.

description: rrCommunicating by personal computer has long required a telephone. But yesterday the International Business Machines Corporation and Motorola Inc. announced a joint venture to make it possible for roving employees like sales and repair personnel to reach their computers at headquarters by radio waves.

title: Coghlan Says He'll Run In the Wanamaker Mile
description: Eamonn Coghlan surprised nobody yesterday when he announced that he would run in the Wanamaker Mile instead of the 3,000-meter run at the Panasonic Millrose Games at Madison Square Garden on Friday.

description: ED BEHR likes to bake. Out of his oven tumbles a profusion of breads, biscuits, brioches, pizzas, cookies, even, truth to tell, some of the more interesting types of cake, although texture is one of the aspects of baking that fascinates him and the texture of most cake, he says, is, well, boring.

Maloney said yesterday. But he added that there was no way to insure that a similar incident could not occur.

title: Review/Concert;   20th-Century American, and Nothing But
description: Twentieth-century composers can scarcely complain of neglect this past week in New York. Parnassus and the New Music Consort have offered substantial programs, the Juilliard School is in the midst of a Schoenberg celebration, and on Sunday afternoon at Carnegie Hall, the American Composers Orchestra under Hugh Wolff played music by Joan Tower, John Adams, Gerald Levinson and Walter Piston.

title: Bond Prices Up After Hectic Day
description: A rumor from Moscow overtook news reports from Washington in the credit markets yesterday and prices of Treasury securities closed higher after a volatile session.

title: Peruvian Police Ambush and Kill 18 Rebels
description: A police patrol ambushed and killed 18 Marxist guerrillas in Peru's Andean foothills, the Government said today. The clash added to a surge in rural political violence that has claimed at least 30 lives in the past four days.

title: A New Decoder to Foil Satellite-TV Pirates
description: After several years of losing hundreds of millions of dollars in revenue from people who watch without paying, the satellite television industry is counterattacking with some success on two fronts.

title: Impact Systems Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Maury Federal Savings Bank reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
FirstFederal Financial reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included extraordinary loss of $409,000.

title: Drug-Laced Air Called Risk to Babies
description: There is growing medical concern that the very young children of cocaine-addicted parents can be injured by breathing the drug-laced air in their homes.

title: Review/Music;   More From Schoenberg and Colleagues
description: Though the Juilliard School's series called Focus 1990, the World of Arnold Schoenberg, might appear to be another crash course in 20th-century musical history, its real goals may lie beyond the scope of a thumbnail survey. The necessarily disjointed programs assembled by Joel Sachs can serve a purpose if they stimulate listeners not only to examine this often murky subject through the lens of one composer's development but also to think afresh about the social and political climate in which 20th-century music grew.

title: New Chief Executive Named By Combustion
description: Combustion Engineering Inc., a maker of industrial equipment, has a new name and a new chief executive. The new name is Asea Brown Boveri Inc.; the new boss, with the titles of president and chief executive, is George S. Kimmel.

title: Eastern European Countries Seek Help From U.N. Human Rights School
description: As Eastern Europe moves toward more democratic government, the authorities in Czechoslovakia, East Germany, Hungary and Rumania have asked the United Nations to help them promote greater respect for their citizens' human rights.

title: Yale Honoring Keeper of Flame;   For 25 Years, Cozza Has Stoked a Glowing Football Tradition
description: If you think Ivy League colleges de-emphasize football, please don't mention that while the Joel E. Smilow '54 Coach of Football at Yale University is interviewing a hot prospect.

title: Once Again Now
description: This week we had the budget. The budget is a big story in Washington, which is probably why we have it. To understand the budget, remember: The budget is not a budget. The budget is a story.

title: A Chance to Expand Democracy
description: Why don't Americans vote? While other parts of the world edge closer to democracy, America's democracy is shrinking. Reflecting a steady decline in participation, barely half the voting-age population took part in the 1988 Presidential election - the worst turnout in 64 years. The uninspiring campaign surely didn't help. But the problem starts with simple arithmetic. Only 61 percent of all eligible voters are registered.

title: Aim of New Project Is to Foster Musicals
description: A plan to create, develop and provide a working home for new American musicals was announced yesterday by Martin J. Bell, producing director of New Musicals, the organization that is to present the works.

title: Real Estate;   An Addition To Newark's Downtown
description: DOWNTOWN Newark has a striking addition to its evolving skyline, the $74 million Newark Legal Center. The structure, which was completed last month and got its first tenant this month, was built to house law firms and keep them in the city.

title: Stephenson Is Mending
description: Jan Stephenson, who underwent surgery last week for a double fracture of her left ring finger, said yesterday that she had started rehabilitation and hoped to rejoin the Ladies Professional Golf Association tour soon.

title: Mentor Graphics reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Thinking Machines Seen in Japan Deal
description: The Thinking Machines Corporation, a maker of parallel supercomputers, will announce this week that it has sold its first machine in Japan. The Japanese organization, Auditory and Visual Perception Research Laboratories, is associated with the Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Company. The group said it was buying the supercomputer, known as a CM-2 Connection Machine, as part of its attempt to make breakthroughs in the fields of vision and speech recognition.

title: Walter F. Loeb Retires To Publish Newsletter
description: After 16 years as the senior retail analyst for Morgan Stanley & Company, Walter F. Loeb, an often-quoted commentator on Wall Street, is retiring to become a consultant and newsletter publisher.

title: First Federal Savings (Ga.) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After previously reported $300,000 reserve for general potential losses on loans and real estate. c-Net income Corrected from yesterday's editions.

title: Allied Security Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-After a loss from an accounting adjustment of $476,045.

title: WINE TALK
description: BEFORE Curly died three years ago, Rowdy was the boss. He's still on the right wheel, but somehow he doesn't have the old gumption. And, let's face it, his new partner, Chucky, is practically half his age.

title: Memorabilia Is Stolen
description: Jerseys belonging to Kareem Abdul-Jabbar and Walt Frazier were stolen on Sunday afternoon from the Basketball Hall of Fame, Joseph O'Brien, the executive director of the sports museum in Springfield, Mass., said.

title: Of Budgets And Truth
description: Shaken by the political appeal of Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan's plan to cut the Social Security tax, the Bush Administration has put a new gloss on an old proposal. In the budget submitted to Congress on Monday, the Administration called for creation of a new ''Social Security Integrity and Debt Reduction Fund.''

title: New York Assembly Chiefs Offer $62 Million Hospital Rescue Plan
description: Signaling that the rescue of the state's troubled hospitals will be a legislative priority, the Democratic leadership of the State Assembly today proposed spending $62 million to ease the crisis caused by crowding in emergency rooms, drug abuse, AIDS and increased labor costs.

title: Rival Seeking to Freeze Amgen Profits on Drug
description: Moving aggressively after a recent court decision over patent rights to a lucrative new anti-anemia drug, Genetics Institute Inc. of Cambridge, Mass., fired another volley in its battle with Amgen Inc. of Thousand Oaks, Calif.

title: Coca-Cola Net Sets Record, Rising to $1.7 Billion in 1989
description: The Coca-Cola Company said yesterday that its profits reached an all-time high last year of $1.7 billion, bolstered by a fourth quarter in which earnings more than tripled.

title: For Some Harlem Youngsters, New Ranger Is Familiar Face
description: Not many of the youngsters who participate in the Ice Hockey in Harlem program knew who all of the Rangers were when the team held a clinic yesterday afternoon at the Lasker Rink in Central Park. But they did recognize at least one player from last year's clinic, even though he was wearing a different jersey then.

title: Innovex Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
5 MORE ARE KILLED IN YUGOSLAV RIOTS
description: At least five people were reported killed Tuesday as riots swept the southern Yugoslav province of Kosovo, and Belgrade television said the situation was approaching civil war.

title: Tokyo Opposes Cuts in U.S. Forces in Asia
description: Reacting to the cutbacks announced in President Bush's proposed military budget, a senior Japanese Government official argued today against any reduction in the United States' military presence in Japan or the rest of Asia because of a continuing Soviet menace.

title: Angola Rebel Chief Halts Tour
description: Jonas Savimbi, the leader of Angola's rebels, interrupted a European tour to return to Angola today because of what he said was a concerted air attack by Government forces.

title: Cheney's Wary First Step
description: Defense Secretary Dick Cheney's budget represents a first step toward restructuring the military but stops short of the overhaul that some members of Congress and outside experts have advocated as a response to the diminishing Soviet threat and changes in Eastern Europe.

title: Horizon Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income

title: Mystery of the Bottom-Opened Cigarette Pack
description: To the Editor:

title: Battle Mountain Gold reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
KEY RATES
Fiserv Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
For Colombians in Queens, Time of Pain and Questions
description: In the boxcar restaurants and boisterous salsa-pumped bars of Queens, where the talk is all too often of bad things that happen to Colombians, conversations of the last few days have been more painful than usual, and sometimes more bitter.

title: Fund American Cos.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Net income c-After a loss of $11,659,000 from debt extinguishment cost. The company formerly Fireman's Fund Corp., changed its name on Dec. 8, 1989. Share earnings assumes issuance or conversion of all dilutive securities. The company said earnings include ''fresh start'' benefits of $7 million in the fourth quarter 1989 versus $11 million in the fourth quarter 1988. The full year 1989 included ''fresh start'' benefits of $32 million versus $46 million in 1988. The fiscal 1988 included an extraordinary loss of $11,659,000 for early extinguishment of debt.

title: Donald J. Newman, Criminologist And Ex-SUNY Dean, Dies at 65
description: Donald J. Newman, a criminologist and former dean of the School of Criminal Justice at the State University of New York at Albany, died of a stroke on Friday at the Albany Medical Center. He was 65 years old and lived in the Albany suburb of Slingerlands.

title: Bronx Couple Charged With Robbing Schoolgirls
description: A Bronx couple was arrested last night and charged with robbing three young girls in a University Heights school yard to raise money to buy drugs, the police said.

title: F.D.A. Panel Seeks Expanded Use of AIDS Drug
description: A Federal advisory committee recommended today that the AIDS drug AZT be approved for the treatment of people who are infected with the AIDS virus and have faltering immune systems but no symptoms of illness.

title: Savings Fugitive Indicted; U.S. Offers $200,000 Reward
description: Prosecutors call it the latest chapter in the Maryland savings and loan scandal, which shook financial markets in the summer of 1985, gave the country vivid pictures of depositors lined up in front of savings associations and became a grim harbinger of the nationwide scandal to come.

title: REAGAN IS ORDERED TO PROVIDE DIARIES IN POINDEXTER CASE
description: A Federal district judge today ordered former President Ronald Reagan to turn over excerpts of his private diaries to John M. Poindexter, the former national security adviser, who had argued that they would show Mr. Reagan had authorized his actions in the Iran-contra affair.

title: Wary Gorbachev Sees Momentum Toward Germans' Reunification
description: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, meeting with Prime Minister Hans Modrow of East Germany, acknowledged today that pressure is building for German reunification. But he again cautioned against undue haste in dealing with the complicated issue.

title: Corrections
description: An article in Business Day yesterday about daily trading in the stock markets referred incorrectly in some editions to the decline in the Dow Jones industrial average since the beginning of the year. Through the market's close on Monday, the drop in the Dow had been 199.82 points. The article also misstated the day's change in the stock price for Apple Computer Inc. It closed on Monday at $33.25, up 50 cents.

title: Metropolitan Financial Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Book Notes
description: Putting Back the Words

title: Coca-Cola Co.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included equity income from discontinued operations of $16,249,000, or 5 cents a share and $21,537,000, or 6 cents a share for the quarter and year, respectively, and a gain on sale of discontinued operations (net of income taxes of $421,021) of $509,449,000 for both the quarter and year. c-Included equity income from discontinued operations of $3,765,000, or 1 cent a share for the quarter and an equity loss $44,283,000 for the year. The company said 1988 results have been restated to reflect the investment in Columbia Pictures Entertainment as a discontinued operation. The restated had no effect on previously reported net income or net income per share.

title: Plastique Moderne reports earnings for Year to Aug 31
description: b-Included income from discontinued operations of $827,915, or 15 cents a share, and $162,202, or 3 cents a share, for the latest and prior year, respectively. Figures are in Canadian funds.

title: Woman, 93, Saved From Fire
description: A 93-year-old woman who was trapped by a fire in her apartment above the White Horse Tavern, a Greenwich Village landmark, was rescued yesterday by three police officers, officials said. The woman, Katherine Fitzgibbons, was removed from her smoke-filled apartment at 561 Hudson Street by the police at 8:30 A.M. She was taken to New York Hospital where she was in good condition. Four apartments in the wooden building were severely damaged but the tavern was spared. The 110-year-old White Horse Tavern was made famous by the poet Dylan Thomas. It remains a popular saloon for writers and actors.

title: Regional Federal Bancorp reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Ewing Everett, Lawyer, 92
description: Ewing Everett, a retired Federal tax lawyer, died on Sunday at Danbury (Conn.) Hospital after a brief illness. He was 92 years old and lived in Ridgefield, Conn.

title: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Tracy-Locke Account
description: Tracy-Locke, Dallas, has won the $15 million advertising account of Budget Rent-A-Car, which was formerly handled in-house. A spokeswoman for the car rental company said it had also awarded its public relations account to Ketchum Public Relations.

title: Gifts to the Neediest Are Often Prompted By a Second Motive
description: Katsumi Tashiro of Harrison, N.Y., had an unusual motive for sending a gift to The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, a desire to alter the perceptions that some New Yorkers have about Japanese people.

title: FirstFed America Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included pre-tax gain of $25,000 on sale of mortgage loans. c-Included pre-tax gain of $1,338,000 on sale of investment securities. FirstFed said the decrease in net income for the latest first quarter is primarily due to an after-tax gain of about $855,000, which was realized during the year-ago first quarter in connection with the sale of Federal Home Mortgage Corp. participating preferred stock. In addition, the expenses relating to the proposed merger with Bancorp Hawaii Inc., totaling about $198,000, also contributed to net income for the latest first quarter being less than in the year-ago period.

description: b-Included after-tax securities losses of $296,000 for the quarter and $356,000 for the year. c-Included after-tax gains of $9,000 for the quarter and $169,000 for the year.

description: Last year's Little League champions finally received their championship rings. Unfortunately, they bore the wrong inscription.

Bonn's Central Bank Head Hopeful on Links With East
description: Karl Otto Pohl, the president of West Germany's central bank, said last night that under the right conditions the West German and East German currencies could be gradually linked.

U.S. and Laos Are Getting Friendlier
description: The Communist leaders of Laos want better relations with the United States and American economic aid, and the United States appears ready to respond.

description: The International Lease Finance Corporation, an airplane leasing company based in Beverly Hills, Calif., said today that it had placed firm orders to buy 42 new jets worth $1.9 billion from three manufacturers: the Boeing Company, the McDonnell Douglas Corporation and Airbus Industries.

description: A ruling on the argument by Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega, the deposed Panamanian strongman, that he cannot be tried on drug charges because he is a prisoner of war has been delayed a week, court officials said today.

title: Talented Seventh Graders Face an S.A.T. Challenge
description: Some high school students taking the college boards over the weekend found themselves sitting next to people who looked more like kid brothers or sisters than prospective college students.

title: Nancy Gruver, Leader In Bridge, Is Dead at 58
description: Nancy Gruver, one of the nation's leading contract bridge players, died of a heart attack Sunday at Howard County General Hospital in Maryland. She was 58 years old and lived in Ellicott City, Md.

title: BUSINESS DIGEST
description: The Economy

title: Terex Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Casualties of the Drug War
description: LEAD: As a cancer survivor, I find it discouraging and disappointing that the Drug Enforcement Administration has rejected the recommendation of its own chief administrative law judge that marijuana be reclassified to allow doctors to prescribe it. The judge, Francis L. Young, described it as ''one of the safest therapeutically active substances known to man.

title: Newark Cathedral Worth Visit From Manhattan
description: To the Editor:

title: Key Events in Shearson's History
description: April 1981: American Express Company, founded in 1850, begins its push into the securities business by announcing plans to buy Shearson Loeb Rhoades, Wall Street's second-largest brokerage house, for about $915 million in stock. Sanford I. Weill, chairman of Shearson becomes chairman of Shearson/American Express Inc.; Peter A. Chohen, another Shearson executive, is vice chairman.

description: b-Net income

title: Mellon Bank Selling Unit
description: The Mellon Bank Corporation said today that it was seeking a buyer for Mellon Financial Services, its Illinois-based consumer finance company.

title: The Royal Shakespeare: Ready to Move On
description: The artistic director and chief executive of the Royal Shakespeare Company, the ''embattled Terry Hands,'' as he is so often described in the British press, sat dressed in black in his white-walled London office the other day and stated for what might have been the thousandth time that his 29-year-old theater company was embattled, yes, but not yet ready for embalming.

title: Fort Dearborn Income SecuriFties reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31

description: The company said total costs and expenses in the latest quarter increased by $6,372,000 from the year earlier. It said about 50 percent of increased costs were due to one-time costs associated with the acquisition of the Oncoscint and Oncotec product lines for marketing by its Eurocetus unit, and from costs associated with the Oct. 17 earthquake in California.

description: * Gearon Hoffman Conlon & Nye Advertising will handle advertising and public relations for the David M. Winfield Foundation.

Arbour's Return to the Helm Bails Out Islander Sinking Ship
description: There is nothing casual about Al Arbour's relationship with his resurgent New York Islanders, nor is there any end to it in sight.

title: Listless Islanders Are Beaten by Blues
description: Against St. Louis tonight, the Islanders rarely showed any of the signs that brought them a nine-game winning streak earlier this month and thrust them into first place in the Patrick Divisio. The result of New York's lackadaisical approach was a 2-1 loss to the Blues.

title: Hoyas Trounce Seton Hall By 70-48
description: Mark Tillmon scored 25 points tonight, including 16 in the decisive first half, as Georgetown gained a share of first place in the Big East with a 70-48 victory over Seton Hall.

title: Hugo Cohn, Engineer And Consultant, 102
description: Hugo Cohn, an electrical engineer who helped develop radio beacons for distinguishing between friendly and enemy aircraft, died on Monday at St. Luke's-Roosevelt Hospital Center in Manhattan. He was 102 years old and lived in Manhattan.

title: Lavalintech Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Nov 30
description: Results are in Canadian funds.

title: Stocks Sag Again; Dow Drops 10.14 Points
description: Pessimism about stocks involved in deals, primarily the UAL Corporation, depressed stock prices broadly yesterday as trading volume rose sharply.

description: b-Included non-cash after-tax charges of $1,383,000 for the quarter and $3,029,000 for the 9 months, from the amortization of an ESOP. c-Included after-tax gain of $3,871,000 from the sale of securities for the quarter and 9 months; the 9 months also included a second quarter gain of $2,212,000 from the restructuring of a retirement plan.

description: The MCI Communications Corporation, the long-distance telephone company, reported disappointing fourth-quarter earnings today.

description: Tomato Juice, Anyone?

title: Suns Defeat Nets, 120-85
description: Kevin Johnson scored 12 of his 30 points in a lopsided third period as the Phoenix Suns beat the Nets, 120-95, tonight for their ninth victory in a row at home.

title: LeMond in Trump Race
description: Greg LeMond, the two-time winner of the Tour de France, and Dag-Otto Lauritzen, last year's winner of the first Tour de Trump, will head an elite professional field for this year's second Tour de Trump.

title: Corrections
description: Because of a production error, several entries in a list of military bases being considered for closing or reductions were misplaced in some copies yesterday. A corrected list appears today on page A12.

title: Springs Industries reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 30
description: b-Included an after-tax restructuring charge of $11.2 million, or 63 cents a share.

title: Miniature Golf, the New City Game
description: Outside, a bitter wind is slicing off Lake Michigan, and the sidewalks are glazed with ice. But on the third floor of a refurbished warehouse on the North Side, where an open area has been rearranged as an 18-hole miniature golf course, the little fairways are as crowded as Pebble Beach on a Sunday morning.

title: 19 Feared Lost in Channel
description: A Greek-registered cargo ship disappeared during a storm in the English Channel and all 19 crew members were feared dead, the British Coast Guard said today. Two bodies, one identified as that of a Greek member of the crew, washed ashore on the south coast of England with a lifeboat bearing the ship's name, Flag Theofano.

title: Cenvest Inc.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The company said 1989 results were affected by a $3.6 million increase in general loan loss reserves taken in the quarter ended Sept. 30.

title: First of Michigan Capital Corp.  reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 29
Assix International Inc. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Accord Set on Tariff Cuts
description: After more than six months of bargaining, international trade officials reached agreement today on how to negotiate tariff cuts.

title: Court Won't Block Offer for Cipher
description: A Federal court declined to block the Archive Corporation's hostile bid of $7.50 a share for Cipher Data Products Inc. and dismissed Cipher's lawsuit against Archive. Cipher, in an attempt to elude the unsolicited offer, had filed a lawsuit in the United States District Court for the Southern District of California seeking to restrain the bid by the rival maker of tape drives.

title: Community Banks Inc.  reports earnings for Year to Dec 31
description: The year-ago per share earnings adjusted to reflect 5 percent stock dividend paid in December 1989.

title: Madrid and Catalonia Divide Dali Paintings
description: A year after the death of the Surrealist painter Salvador Dali, the Spanish Culture Ministry and the Catalan regional government have agreed on how to divide his artistic legacy.

title: GroveBank for Savings reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: The addition of $485,000 to the bank's loan loss reserve reduced latest quarter and year profits by 33 cents a share.

title: Big Three's Auto Production Is Likely to Rise in Quarter
description: Car and truck production in the United States and Canada, which was severely curtailed in January, will improve during the rest of the first quarter if the Big Three auto makers adhere to their production schedules.

title: Review/Film;   A Wizard Who's Hexed by Hollywood
description: Has any film maker ever worked harder to win his audience's affections than Mike Jittlov, the writer, director, co-producer and star of ''The Wizard of Speed and Time''? On the evidence of Mr. Jittlov's world-class home movie, it hardly seems possible that anyone has. Mr. Jittlov, for whom this is clearly a labor of love as well as a Herculean effort, attempts every conceivable trick in the special-effects book in order to wow his viewers, and at times the results are literally dizzying. Only occasionally, though, are they anything more.

title: Fidelity Federal Savings (Va.) reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: Year-ago per share earnings adjusted for a 6-for-5 stock split, paid in November 1989.

description: What I Saw at the Revolution

description: b-After extraordinary gains from tax-loss carryforwards of $17,000 for the quarter and $1,121,000, or 19 cents a share, for the 6 months. c-Net loss d-After an extraordinary gain from tax-loss carryforward of $125,000, or 2 cents a share, for the quarter and 6 months.

title: First Financial Caribbean reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
description: b-Included a gain of $1,780,000 from the sale of servicing rights. c-Net loss The company said latest quarter and year figures included spin-off related expenses of $512,000 and $2,049,000, respectively, compared with similar expenses in the year-ago quarter of $4,204,000 and $4,204,000 in the year.

title: Gentex Corp. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
If Congress Can't Cut This . . .
description: LEAD: As Congress takes up debate on the Pentagon budget, the members should think a moment about the confused people in Chelsea, Wis., Lovingston, Va., and dozens of other communities. These people are having trouble squaring the apparent end of the cold war with the Air Force's continuing preparations for a retaliatory nuclear strike.

title: Some G.O.P. Leaders Balk at Registration Bill
description: The Bush Adminstration and the House Republican leader objected today to a national voter registration bill that supporters, including other Republicans, say would add millions of unregistered Americans to the voter rolls.

title: Masaru Ogawa, Japanese Journalist, 74
description: Masaru Ogawa, former editor of The Japan Times, Japan's largest English-language newspaper and one of the country's most prominent journalists, died on Sunday of heart failure at his home in Tokyo. He was 74 years old and had been ill for several weeks.

title: Dinkins Reported Set to Ask A Half Billion in New Taxes
description: When he presents his preliminary budget for New York City tomorrow, Mayor David N. Dinkins will propose $550 million in new taxes, plus service cuts and other measures, to close a budget gap and allow for some modest new social programs that he holds dear, city officials said yesterday.

title: Marion Net Off; Lambert Up
description: Marion Merrell Dow Inc., the recently merged pharmaceutical company based in Kansas City, Mo.. said yesterday that its net income fell 59.3 percent in the fourth quarter of 1989. Meanwhile the Warner-Lambert Company said its net income for the quarter rose 19.1 percent.

title: Quotations of the Day
description: ''If the President is not serious about deficit reduction, why should Congress be serious?''

title: Stanley Works reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 30
description: b-Included a LIFO gain of $4.4 million, or 6 cents a share.

title: Warner-Lambert Co. reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Long Swiss Exile for a Wartime King of Rumania
description: King Michael of Rumania, who has been living in exile for 42 years, wants his throne back.

title: Cuomo Now Forecasts a Bigger Budget Gap
description: Just two weeks after he presented his new budget, Gov. Mario M. Cuomo said today that he had probably overestimated revenues and would have to propose additional taxes or spending cuts to bring the budget into balance.

title: COMPANY NEWS Stride Rite Rejects $32-a-Share Bid
description: The Stride Rite Corporation announced it had rejected a $900 million takeover bid from a group of investors, declaring the company would best be served by pursuing an independent strategy for growth. Stride Rite, the leading children's shoe maker in the country, received the $32-a-share offer in December from a group led by Walsh, Greenwood & Company, a Greenwich, Conn., investment concern.

title: Ford Loses Patent Suit On Wipers
description: A former engineering professor who says he invented the intermittent windshield wiper now used by most major car and truck manufacturers has won a bellwether patent-infringement case against the Ford Motor Company.

title: Christians Fight Muslims and Each Other in Beirut
description: Lebanese Army troops loyal to Gen. Michel Aoun exchanged fire with Christian militiamen in two quarters of Christian East Beirut today.

title: Washington Gas Light reports earnings for Qtr to Dec 31
Riders' Rights, Beggars' Rights
description: The subway is not the street, not Hyde Park or Union Square Park where ideas and commerce flourish with room to spare. It is an underground space sometimes shadowed with narrow nooks and scary stairways and sometimes peopled by wild-eyed vagrants who just might be loony enough to push someone in front of a train.

title: In Bordeaux, Wine's Still King But Food Is Gaining Attention
description: AT wineries in Bordeaux, the question of what food to serve with the wine is easily answered. Chances are it will be roast lamb, roast veal or roast filet of beef, regardless of whether the wine planned for dinner is a Leoville-Las-Cases 1970, a Ducru-Beaucaillou 1971 or a Gruaud-Larose 1980. ''In Bordeaux, we're not too serious about matching food and wine,'' Jean-Eugene Borie, owner of Chateau Ducru-Beaucaillou and several other properties in the Medoc, said at a recent dinner at the winery. ''We tend to prefer simple but tasty food that allows the wine to shine.''

title: Committee Criticizes Eastern Air
description: The committee representing the preferred stockholders at Eastern Air Lines said yesterday that it had lost faith in the airline's management and called for dramatic steps to salvage any value that was left in the airline.

title: Panel to Study Move by Campeau
description: Representative Jack Brooks said today that the House Judiciary Committee, which he heads, would review the bankruptcy of the American retailing operations of the Campeau Corporation and examine the need for legislation to restrict corporate takeovers.

title: Mitterrand Is Said to Agree to Free Hunger Striker
description: President Francois Mitterrand has promised to release a convicted pro-Iranian terrorist in exchange for his agreement to end a four-month hunger strike, published reports said today.

title: Vera Hahn, 67, Dies; Interior-Design Editor
description: Vera Hahn, an interior-design editor for several magazines, died of lymphoma on Tuesday at New York Hospital. She was 67 years old and lived on Roosevelt Island.
